headline: A-Rod: 0 for 2
text: In Alex Rodriguez’s second turn at the plate, with Bobby Abreu on first and nobody out in the bottom of the third, and with many of the fans in the capacity crowd on their feet, he hit a 1-0 pitch with a sharp crack of the bat to deep center field. The audience roared in anticipation, and bulbs flashed again. But center fielder Jerry Owens tracked it down at the front edge of the warning track near the 408-foot marker.

headline: From Iraq to the Campaign Trail
text: For months, Rudolph W. Giuliani mainly chose to speak about the Iraq war only in passing, or when asked to comment on a specific event or issue like President Bush’s troop buildup.

headline: A-Rod: 0 for 3 (but, Wow!)
text: Alex Rodriguez batted for the third time in the fourth inning with the Yankees holding a 9-3 lead and Charlie Haeger on the mound in relief of José Contreras. At that point, the Yankees already had four home runs. Bobby Abreu and Robinson Canó had three-run home runs, Melky Cabrera had a two-run homer and Matsui had a solo shot.

headline: A-Rod: 0 for 4, but Others Continue Bombardment
text: Alex Rodriguez batted for the fourth time in the bottom of the sixth inning, this time against Gavin Floyd, a right-hander. At this point, the Yankees led, 11-3, and all but two of them — Rodriguez and Andy Phillips — had at least one hit. Rodriguez was the only Yankee not to have reached base. (Phillips was safe on an error in the third.)

headline: A-Rod: 0 for 5, and a Souvenir for a Fan
text: By the time Alex Rodriguez batted for the fifth time in the game, in the seventh inning, the atmosphere had turned surreal. Just before Rodriguez batted, Shelley Duncan, replacing Bobby Abreu, hit the eighth home run of the game for the Yankees to give them a 16-3 lead. But Rodriguez flied out to center to make his box score line 0 for 5, all on fly balls. When Rodriguez returned to the dugout, he handed his bat to a young boy in the box seats. As the Yankees took the field for the eighth inning, Chris Basak was at third base in place of Rodriguez.

headline: Television in Afghanistan
text: Owning a TV was a crime under the Taliban. But in a study this year of Afghanistan's five most urban provinces, two-thirds of all people said they watched TV every day or almost every day.

headline: Access vs. Quality
text: Stanley Fish has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below. — The Editors

headline: This ‘Harry’ Stands Out From the Crowd
text: LAUREL HOLLOW, N.Y., July 28  Harvinder Anand, the new mayor of this Long Island village of multimillion-dollar homes, private beaches and yachtsmen, is, like many other residents, a successful business executive, a boater and a connoisseur of world travel. His Sikh turban and beard drew double takes when he moved to the community about 10 years ago, but it does not get many anymore. At least not among the locals.

headline: A Pedophile’s Blog (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Giants Want Strahan Back, but Not as a Distraction
text: ALBANY, July 31 — The Giants finally spoke to Michael Strahan, their wayward defensive end, though they did not learn if he intended to report to camp or retire. A simple yes or no would not end the focus on Strahan. The Giants have concerns, whether Strahan comes back or not.

headline: Murdoch’s Journal: Don’t Expect ‘Hedgeless Funds’ Headlines
text: You can bet serious money — billions even — that the article about the sale of The Wall Street Journal and the rest of Dow Jones & Company in today’s Journal will be fully and ferociously reported, with no quarter given to its new owner, Rupert Murdoch.

headline: Mets Float Some Offers, but Cannot Close a Deal
text: MILWAUKEE, July 31  The nonwaiver trade deadline came and went Tuesday afternoon with the Mets looking exactly as they had when they arrived here Monday night: with a new second baseman, Luis Castillo, but their pitching staff intact.

headline: New Deal Debate for a New Era
text: From the very beginning of the nation’s modern social welfare system — even before Michael Moore began to explore the issue — there was a tension in it: What should the government be expected to provide? What should be left to the individual? How much government is too much?

headline: Democrats Scrambling to Expand Eavesdropping
text: WASHINGTON, July 31 — Under pressure from President Bush, Democratic leaders in Congress are scrambling to pass legislation this week to expand the government’s electronic wiretapping powers.

headline: Overpass Collapses in Northern California; 2 Are Injured
text: SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 — A freeway overpass under construction collapsed on Tuesday, injuring a road worker, trapping a truck driver for hours and snarling commuter traffic in the fast-growing area of Butte County, about 152 miles northeast of here.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Correction: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Saturday about criticism of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales by some Justice Department lawyers misquoted an opinion article in The Denver Post that was written by one of those lawyers, John S. Koppel. He wrote that under the Bush administration the Justice Department had been “thoroughly politicized” — not thoroughly publicized — “in a manner that is inappropriate, unethical and indeed unlawful.” Also, a chart in some editions misidentified the forum for a May 23 hearing at which Monica M. Goodling, a former aide to Mr. Gonzales, testified. The hearing was in the House, not the Senate.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in some copies on Saturday about the complex relationship between Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York and Andrew M. Cuomo, the state attorney general, whose office released a report criticizing Mr. Spitzer’s aides for misusing the State Police to discredit a political rival, misidentified the division once headed by Mr. Spitzer in the Manhattan district attorney’s office, where Mr. Cuomo also once worked. It is the labor racketeering unit, not the rackets bureau. (The error appeared in an article in some copies on July 19, 2005, and in an article on May 22, 2002.)

headline: Seize the Cesium
text: London

headline: Manhattan Media Buys a Weekly
text: The New York Press, the city’s second-largest free weekly newspaper after The Village Voice, was expected to be sold today to Manhattan Media, a publisher of weekly newspapers.

headline: Chinese Market Awash in Fake Potter Books
text: SHANGHAI, July 31 — Chinese readers could not wait for the official release of “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,” the much anticipated seventh and concluding book in the series, a little more than a week ago. And they did not have to.

headline: Children’s Health Plan Focus of New Struggle
text: WASHINGTON, July 31 — The Children’s Health Insurance Program has suddenly become a vehicle for an ideological struggle between President Bush and Congress over the future of the health care system.

headline: Jets’ Ferguson Lives Every Man’s Dream: Food and Plenty of It
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., July 31  Only in the National Football Leagues does a man weighing 290 pounds appear to be supermodel slim.

headline: Hurricane Victims Rush to Apply for Grants as Deadline Looms
text: NEW ORLEANS, July 31  Hundreds of Louisianians whose homes were ruined by Hurricane Katrina rushed to meet a Tuesday deadline set by the state’s troubled housing aid program, even as a deficit of billions of dollars threatened to leave thousands without a grant.

headline: U.N. Approves Peacekeepers for Darfur
text: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously yesterday to authorize the deployment of up to 26,000 peacekeepers to try to stop the violence in Darfur, in western Sudan, where some 200,000 people have been killed in four years of conflict.

headline: Adu Makes Jump From M.L.S. to Portugal
text: Freddy Adu has gone to Portugal and life goes on in Major League Soccer.

headline: Plight of Muslim Immigrants in Post-Sept. 11 America
text: In their no-frills documentary, “Out of Status,” Pia Sawhney and Sanjna N. Singh examine the actions of the Immigration and Naturalization Service after 9/11 and the devastating repercussions for America’s Muslims.

headline: It Will Take More Than Charm
text: The New York Police Department has managed to hold down crime in impressive ways, but it has yet to earn the confidence of a large number of the people it protects, especially among minority communities. Hoping to ease tensions, the department has turned to cultivating charm, or at least basic people skills, with its officers. It’s a good start, but it’s not nearly enough.

headline: South Korea Urges U.S. to Change Stance on Negotiating With the Taliban
text: SEOUL, South Korea, July 31 — Shocked by the killing of a second South Korean hostage in Afghanistan and weary from the 13-day-old crisis, South Korea on Tuesday urged the American and Afghan governments to show “flexibility” over Taliban demands for the release of imprisoned militants.

headline: U.S. Death Toll in Iraq in July Expected to Be Lowest in ’07
text: BAGHDAD, July 31  The death of a marine in western Iraq brought the American military death toll to 74 so far in July, on course to be the lowest monthly figure this year.

headline: Sacrificing Food Safety (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Congress Not Expected to Vote on Iraq Policy Before Recess
text: WASHINGTON, July 31  Congressional Democrats pulled back Tuesday from a final series of votes on Iraq policy before the August recess, hoping a month spent at home with voters frustrated by the course of the war would persuade more Republicans to join Democrats in supporting a troop withdrawal.

headline: F.C.C. Hands Google a Partial Victory
text: SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 — The Federal Communications Commission moved cautiously Tuesday toward creating a more open national wireless broadband network, handing a partial victory to Google, which was pushing for more competition in cellphone services.

headline: Islamic Opposition Group Pulls Out of Elections in Jordan
text: AMMAN, Jordan, July 31 — After months of growing tension with the Jordanian government, the opposition Islamic Action Front abruptly withdrew from nationwide municipal council elections on Tuesday. The group cited voting irregularities in the elections, which were seen as a test for the more politically sensitive parliamentary elections this fall.

headline: Sex Slaves Returning Home Raise AIDS Risks, Study Says
text: Adding another bleak dimension to the sordid world of sex slavery, young girls who have been trafficked abroad into prostitution are emerging as an AIDS risk factor in their home countries, according to a study being released today.

headline: Bodies of 4 Afghan Judges Are Found
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 1 — The bodies of four Afghan judges kidnapped 10 days ago were found today in a mountainous area of Ghazni province, south of Kabul, the same province where 21 South Korean hostages are being held by suspected members of the Taliban, officials said.

headline: Jeremy Blake, 35, Artist Who Used Lush-Toned Video, Dies
text: Jeremy Blake, an up-and-coming artist who sought to bridge the worlds of painting and film in lush, color-saturated, hallucinatory digital video works, has died, the New York City Police said yesterday. He was 35 and lived in the East Village in Manhattan.

headline: Manhattan: Agreement on West Side Medical Tower
text: Two New York developers have signed an agreement to build a 1.2 million-square-foot office tower on the Far West Side that would serve as a hub for manufacturers of devices, diagnostics, computer systems and other equipment for the medical industry. The developers  Gary Barnett, the chief executive of the Extell Development Corporation, and Israel Green  said they planned to begin construction in early 2009. The tower would rise at 11th Avenue and 34th Street, on a site that is now home to the Copacabana nightclub. Mr. Green has spent five years developing the concept and pursuing a Manhattan location. He said it was an opportunity for New York City to become the principal center for the $260 billion global market for medical devices and diagnostics. The project may have to wait until the city completes part of an extension of the No. 7 subway line, which passes beneath the site.

headline: Queens: Councilman Fined for Ethics Violation
text: City Councilman James F. Gennaro, left, a Queens Democrat, has been fined $2,000 for asking a staff member to volunteer for his 2003 re-election campaign and for allowing city equipment to be used to write and print a campaign letter, both violations of the city ethics code, the Conflicts of Interest Board said yesterday. In a settlement with the board, Mr. Gennaro said he did not remember asking the staff member to volunteer for him and did not know that his city-supplied computer, printer and paper were used for a campaign letter, but he did not dispute either allegation. “Council member Gennaro accepts responsibility for any oversights that took place in his office in 2003,” his lawyer, Arnold N. Kriss, said in a statement. “Measures have been implemented to ensure that this will not happen again.”

headline: U.S. Pressing Arab Nations to Increase Support for Iraq
text: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, July 31  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Tuesday coupled their military assistance package for Arab allies with a public request for Arab leaders to do more to back the Shiite-led government in Iraq.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,644 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Adu Departs After Mixed Reviews
text: Freddy Adu has gone to Portugal, and life goes on in Major League Soccer.

headline: Keep Your Eyes on Adjustable-Rate Mortgages
text: Two years ago, when the housing market was roaring along, I called a mortgage broker on the West Coast and asked for some help. I told him that I wanted to interview some recent home buyers who had taken out an adjustable-rate mortgage — one of the big drivers of the boom — and he was nice enough to pass along a short list of names.

headline: A Teacher Grows Disillusioned After a ‘Fail’ Becomes a ‘Pass’
text: Several weeks into his first year of teaching math at the High School of Arts and Technology in Manhattan, Austin Lampros received a copy of the school’s grading policy. He took particular note of the stipulation that a student who attended class even once during a semester, who did absolutely nothing else, was to be given 45 points on the 100-point scale, just 20 short of a passing mark.

headline: E.E.O.C. Backs Boulud Workers
text: IN a lawsuit and a consent decree filed yesterday, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission backed accusations by workers that Daniel Boulud denied them promotions at his restaurant Daniel because of their race and ethnicity and retaliated against some who complained about it.

headline: The Theme Is Ancient, but the Subject Is Modern
text: The Israeli director Ami Dayan had planned to stage “Kiss of the Spider Woman” for the Denver Center for the Performing Arts last year. Then the radical Hamas party swept the Palestinian Authority elections, and Israel and the United States refused to negotiate with the new leadership. “I called the theater and I said, ‘Look, we’ve got to do a different play,’ ” Mr. Dayan recalled.

headline: Saving a Drug Company (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reader Responses
text: Here are excerpts from reader replies to David Leonhardt’s Aug.1 column on mortgages and the housing market:

headline: Giuliani Seeks to Transform U.S. Health Care Coverage
text: ROCHESTER, N.H., July 31 — Rudolph W. Giuliani on Tuesday called for transforming the way health care coverage is provided in the United States, advocating a voluntary move from the current employer-based system to one that would grant substantial tax benefits to people who buy their own insurance.

headline: A Diet Book Serves Up a Side Order of Attitude
text: Ever since Running Press, an imprint of Perseus Books, first published the raucous, profanity-laced diet book “Skinny Bitch” in December 2005, it has sold steadily. From an initial print run of fewer than 10,000 copies, there are now more than 245,000 in print.

headline: In Endorsements, No Athlete Is a Sure Thing
text: Michael Vick lost another endorsement yesterday because of the dogfighting charges against him. In its divorce petition, Rawlings said everything it needed to about how it weighed jurisprudence against its corporate image.

headline: Dow Jones Deal Gives Murdoch a Coveted Prize
text: Rupert Murdoch finally won his long-coveted prize yesterday, gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal and one of the world’s most respected news sources, for $5 billion.

headline: Legendary Voice Will Let Fans Do Call on Bonds
text: LOS ANGELES, July 31 — When Hank Aaron broke the career home run record 33 years ago, Vin Scully made a call that evoked race, history and the American experience.

headline: Man Regains Speech After Brain Stimulation
text: A 38-year-old man who spent more than five years in a mute, barely conscious state as a result of a severe head injury is now communicating regularly with family members and recovering his ability to move after having his brain stimulated with pulses of electric current, neuroscientists are reporting.

headline: H.I.V. Patients Anxious as Support Programs Cut
text: SAN RAFAEL, Calif. — In the golden hills of Marin County, it is hard to imagine that free food or emergency cab fares could matter much to anyone.

headline: Sports Briefing | Khannouchi Out of Half-Marathon
text: Khalid Khannouchi, the Moroccan-born American who has twice broken the world record for the marathon, withdrew from Sunday’s NYC Half-Marathon.“It’s not an injury,” said Sandra Khannouchi, his wife, coach and manager. “He has a mechanical problem. His foot lands flat, and he has a burning sensation.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about discounting in the book industry, misstated the location and history of the Barnes & Noble bookstore on Union Square. It is on 17th Street, not 18th Street, in the former Century Building, which was acquired by Barnes & Noble in the 1990s; it is not the original store. (The first Barnes & Noble was opened on Fifth Avenue at 18th Street during the Great Depression.)

headline: A Director Also Elusive on Home Video
text: Unlike Ingmar Bergman, Michelangelo Antonioni is poorly represented on DVD. He did not have the good luck to make most of his films for a single, state-subsidized production company, and as a result rights to his films are spread around the world and are often difficult to track down.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on July 12 about bombings of natural gas pipelines in Mexico, and a correction in this space on July 23, referred incorrectly to the cause of minor bombings in Mexico City last year. A coalition of guerrilla groups claimed responsibility for the bombings — not the splinter group whose correct name is the Revolutionary Army of the Insurgent People.

headline: Senate G.O.P. Hearings May Start by Next Week
text: ALBANY, July 31 — Senate Republicans said Tuesday that they would start hearings as early as next week that could become a public forum for investigating Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s administration. They did not rule out seeking to compel the governor’s testimony.

headline: Breast Cancer Strikesan ABC Host
text: Her voice muffled at times by tears, Robin Roberts, above, told viewers of “Good Morning America” yesterday that she had been given a diagnosis of breast cancer and would undergo surgery on Friday. As she clutched the hand of her co-host, Diane Sawyer, Ms. Roberts said she had found a lump in her breast during a self-examination she conducted on the night she completed a segment about the death of another colleague, Joel Siegel. Mr. Siegel, an ABC film critic, died on June 29 at 63 after a long battle with colon cancer. Ms. Roberts, 46, told viewers that she was grateful her cancer had been detected in “the early stages.” After her surgery, Ms. Roberts said, she would undergo further treatment, which she did not specify. Asked afterward how much time Ms. Roberts expected to take from “Good Morning America,” an ABC News spokeswoman said, “At this point, she’s not expected to be away for an extended period of time.”

headline: Recipe: Cornstarch Ice Cream
text: Time: 20 minutes, plus chilling

headline: Nigeria: New Leader Shakes Up Army
text: President Umaru Yar’Adua reshuffled top officers in Nigeria’s powerful army, retiring about a dozen generals and shifting the commanders of several divisions. The shake-up of the command, two months after Mr. Yar’Adua took office in the first turnover in power between democratically elected leaders, was described by senior government officials as a routine shift from one generation of officers to the next. He was elected in April in a vote heavily criticized by international observers, but has made overtures to include opposition parties in his government. Unlike many of his predecessors, Mr. Yar’Adua, a former governor and chemistry teacher, has never served in the military.

headline: Michelangelo Antonioni, Bold Director, Dies at 94
text: Michelangelo Antonioni, the Italian director whose chilly depictions of alienation were cornerstones of international filmmaking in the 1960s, inspiring intense measures of admiration, denunciation and confusion, died on Monday at his home in Rome. He was 94.

headline: Michel Serrault, 79, a Star of ‘Cage aux Folles,’ Is Dead
text: Michel Serrault, a French film star known internationally for his role as the temperamental drag queen Zaza in the original film version of “La Cage aux Folles,” died on Sunday at his home in Honfleur, France. He was 79.

headline: Queens Day Care Worker Gets 20 Years in Rape of 4-Year-Old
text: A State Supreme Court justice sentenced a Queens day care worker to 20 years in prison yesterday for raping a 4-year-old boy in her care. The justice said that some parents’ continued support for the worker made him question whether the community had “lost every grasp of our moral compass.”

headline: Yankees Have Pitching, So They Add Betemit
text: On July 8, the day before the All-Star Game break, the Yankees led the Angels by 10 runs when Scott Proctor was sent in to pitch the eighth inning. To the Yankees’ decision makers, this was an obvious sign that Manager Joe Torre would probably always favor Proctor over a pitcher just up from the minors, no matter how promising that pitcher seemed.

headline: Mayor Takes the Subway — by Way of S.U.V.
text: He is public transportation’s loudest cheerleader, boasting that he takes the subway “virtually every day.” He has told residents who complain about overcrowded trains to “get real” and he constantly encourages New Yorkers to follow his environmentally friendly example.

headline: Jittery Stock Market Drops as Mortgage Fallout Spreads
text: With little respite on the horizon, the mortgage market was hit with another wave of bad news yesterday, sending the stock market down sharply.

headline: Cease to Assist?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Ford and G.M. Expect a July Sales Drop
text: DETROIT, July 31  Over the last 18 months, General Motors and the Ford Motor Company have cut thousands of jobs and billions of dollars in costs and narrowed their North American losses. That helped each post unexpectedly strong second-quarter profits.

headline: Ice Cream That’s a Stretch
text: WHY do we always try to make ice creams smooth? When we add egg yolks (or cornstarch, as Mark Bittman does this week in The Minimalist) to an ice cream mix, and then stir it constantly while it freezes, we do it to block the growth of hard-edged ice crystals. But smooth ice cream doesn’t give the mouth much to do. Just for a change, how about ice cream that is coarse and crunchy? Or chewy?

headline: A Kitchen Crowd for Fox
text: With an all-rerun lineup of sitcoms followed by “CSI: Miami,” CBS earned the title of most-watched network on Monday. But Fox, with an assist from “Hell’s Kitchen,” posted the highest ratings among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the cooking competition delivered the night’s best numbers in that demographic market, leading the 9 p.m. hour over all with 8.6 million viewers. “CSI: Miami” remained dominant at 10 (8.8 million), ahead of both NBC’s “Dateline” (6.2 million) and the second half of ABC’s special “Six Degrees of Martina McBride,” which averaged a last-place 4.3 million viewers from 9 to 11. NBC ranked third for the night, as it did at 9 with a new installment of “Age of Love” (5.4 million). ABC was fourth.

headline: Red Sox Add Gagné for Bullpen Insurance
text: LOS ANGELES, July 31  The Boston Red Sox have the best record in Major League Baseball, but that does not mean they are content. Even the best team can improve, which is precisely what the Red Sox did yesterday before the nonwaiver trading deadline by obtaining reliever Eric Gagné from the Texas Rangers for pitcher Kason Gabbard and two minor leaguers.

headline: Lender Agrees to Contribution of $2 Million to a Student Fund
text: One of the nation’s largest student loan companies, Nelnet, agreed yesterday to pay $2 million into a fund to educate high school students about financing college, settling an inquiry into its business practices by the New York attorney general.

headline: Language Evolution’s Slippery Tropes
text: All branches of science search for origins. Biologists want to know how life on earth began. Astronomers want to know how the universe got started. Even in mathematics, questions about how different numerical systems came to be constitute a legitimate line of inquiry.

headline: Lazard Posts 2.2% Profit Decline
text: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said today that its second-quarter profit dropped 2.2 percent from the same period a year ago, as its asset management business continued to grow while its mergers and acquisitions advisory work dipped slightly.

headline: Obama Calls for U.S. to Shift Focus on Terrorism
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 — Senator Barack Obama said today that the United States should shift its focus from the war in Iraq to a fight against terrorism in Afghanistan and Pakistan. He said that if the Pakistani government fails to eradicate terror operations inside its borders, the United States should withhold aid and should strike Al Qaeda targets there itself.

headline: Peekskill Finds New Use for an Old Landfill
text: Peekskill, an economically struggling city 40 miles north of Manhattan on the Hudson River, has formed a partnership with a private developer to cap an 11-acre former municipal landfill and build the city’s first Class A office space in decades.

headline: To Be Title Contender Again, Celtics Are Looking to Garnett
text: With the addition of Kevin Garnett, the Boston Celtics believe they have been transformed from rebuilders to title contenders.

headline: Still Lagging, Paterson Schools Stay Under New Jersey Control
text: New Jersey education officials said yesterday that the Paterson public schools would remain under state control after a new state report found continuing problems with the district’s academic instruction and school board operations.

headline: Hub of Halfpipes Rises in Corner of California
text: CARLSBAD, Calif., July 31 — Ten years ago Bucky Lasek moved west with his wife, newborn daughter and commitment to a career in skateboarding, settling in this laid-back seaside community in northern San Diego County.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Breast Cancer Strikes

headline: Uncertainty Now in a Golden Youth’s Trajectory
text: WASHINGTON, July 31 — No matter what his doctors eventually tell John G. Roberts Jr., or the world, about the diagnosis and outlook for his seizure disorder, it is clear that something changed irrevocably following the 52-year-old chief justice’s momentary loss of consciousness on a vacation island dock on Monday afternoon.

headline: Recipe: Fish Stew With Rice (Thiebu Djen)
text: Adapted from Ken Alice N’doye

headline: Unwise Arms Deal With Saudi Arabia (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Earthly Hurts: Yes, You Can Take Them With You
text: Heaven is low on testosterone in the bleak but whimsical vision of Betty Shamieh, the author of “The Black Eyed,” a thoughtful but rambling new play that opened last night at New York Theater Workshop. Adrift in an afterlife seemingly devoid of men, four women from Palestine debate the ethics of terrorism, the long history of female oppression and the knotty problems of the contemporary Middle East.

headline: Amid War, Passion for TV Chefs, Soaps and Idols
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 25 — Seven years ago, during a very different time in a very different Afghanistan, a medical student named Daoud Sediqi was bicycling from campus when he was stopped by the Taliban’s whip-wielding religious police. The young man immediately felt an avalanche of regret, for he was in violation of at least two laws.

headline: Dining Briefs
text: NEW PLACES

headline: Joint Chiefs Nominee Questioned on Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, July 31 — The Navy admiral nominated to become chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said Tuesday that American military efforts in Iraq would fail unless Iraqi leaders did more to bridge sectarian divides. But he also warned that a rapid exit of American troops could turn Iraq into a “cauldron” for broader Middle East strife.

headline: Hostile Fans and Quiet Bat for Bonds
text: LOS ANGELES, July 31 — Barry Bonds had five friends at Dodger Stadium on Tuesday night. Actually, he had five protectors, the security officers who stood as rigid as marines in left field as Bonds warmed up between innings. They formed a loose wall near Bonds, just in case.

headline: Leave Your Name at the Border
text: Dinuba, Calif.

headline: Criminal Case After Adoptions Spurs Review
text: Child welfare workers in New York City said yesterday that they were poring over hundreds of records for possible cases of adoption fraud and abuse after a woman who adopted 11 foster children, and collected subsidies for them, was arrested in Florida and charged with abusing and neglecting the teenagers and young adults living under her care.

headline: Norma Gabler, Leader of Crusade on Textbooks, Dies at 84
text: Norma Gabler, a Texas homemaker who recoiled at material in her children’s textbooks and became the public face of a crusade with her husband to rid schoolbooks of content they considered antifamily, anti-American and anti-God, died on July 22 in Phoenix. She was 84.

headline: South Africa: Anglogold’s Chief to Retire
text: Robert M. Godsell, the chief executive of AngloGold Ashanti, plans to retire after running the company since its creation in 1998 and helping it become the world’s third-biggest gold producer with operations in 10 countries. Mr. Godsell, left, who will step down on September 30, will be succeeded by Mark Cutifani, the chief operating officer of Companhia Vale do Rio Doce’s nickel unit, AngloGold said. Mr. Godsell, 54, was the chief executive of Anglo American’s gold and uranium division from 1995 before taking over as head of AngloGold, a company formed by a merger of Anglo American’s separately traded gold companies and the gold assets of Minorco. Other acquisitions included Ashanti Goldfields of Ghana.

headline: Access vs. Quality
text: Whenever I’m asked, and sometimes even before I’m asked, I advise parents of college-age children to not send their sons and daughters to private schools, but to send them to public institutions, at least if there are any good ones in their state.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article last Wednesday about the death of a Staten Island teenager who was a passenger in a car that the police said was speeding before it crashed misspelled the name of a street where car racing was reported in April. It is Drumgoole Road, not Drumgould.

headline: A Chronicler of Alienated Europeans in a Flimsy New World
text: Decades before it was given a name, Michelangelo Antonioni recognized the malady we now call attention deficit disorder. In his great 1960s films, “L’Avventura,” “La Notte,” “Eclipse” and “Red Desert,” but especially in “L’Avventura,” his masterpiece, it wasn’t diagnosed as a chemical imbalance, but as a communicable social disease.

headline: Father and Son Restaurateurs in New York City Plead Guilty to Tax Evasion
text: Two members of the Cipriani family, renowned for its string of opulent restaurants in New York and Venice, pleaded guilty to tax evasion yesterday and agreed to pay $10 million in restitution and penalties to resolve a case brought by Robert M. Morgenthau, the district attorney of Manhattan.

headline: Russia Offers Support to Palestinian President
text: MOSCOW, July 31 — Russia gave some support to the American and European approach to the Palestinian question on Tuesday, offering military aid to President Mahmoud Abbas, leader of the secular Fatah faction, and saying it had downgraded relations with the rival Islamists of Hamas.

headline: Retired General Is Censured for Role in Tillman Case
text: WASHINGTON, July 31 — The Army moved on Tuesday to stanch the furor over the mishandling of the friendly fire death of Cpl. Pat Tillman in Afghanistan by censuring a retired three-star general for errors and deceptions and apologizing profusely to the Tillman family and the public for “mistakes, misjudgments and a failure of leadership.”

headline: Mark Twain’s ‘Dead’: An Unexaggerated Report
text: The dates have been set for Mark Twain’s new play (yes, explanation to come).

headline: Subscriber Gain Helps Sirius Narrow Loss
text: Sirius Satellite Radio, the pay-radio broadcaster planning to buy XM Satellite Radio Holdings, posted a narrower second-quarter loss after gaining more subscribers than analysts expected.

headline: Footnotes
text: Barbara Walters told viewers of “The View” yesterday that she would officially announce today who would replace Rosie O’Donnell as the show’s moderator. ... A back injury has forced the Dutch conductor Edo de Waart to cancel his engagements with the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood on Saturday and Sunday. He will be replaced by James Levine at the first concert and Ludovic Morlot at the second. Both programs remain unchanged. ... Janeane Garofalo, Denis Leary, Bill Maher, Sarah Silverman and Damon Wayans will be among the performers at the fourth annual New York Comedy Festival, Nov. 6-11 at sites like Carnegie Hall, Avery Fisher Hall, Town Hall, the Beacon Theater and Carolines on Broadway. ... World premieres by Camille A. Brown and Frederick Earl Mosley, as well as company premieres of Maurice Béjart’s “Firebird” and Robert Battle’s “Unfold,” will highlight the 2007 New York season of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, at New York City Center, from Nov. 28 through Dec. 31. ... Unexpected problems and expenses during renovations may prevent the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow from reopening early next year, Reuters reported. The theater’s director general, Anatoly Iksanov, said he hoped it would reopen in the fall. ... Next year, the Eagles plan to issue their first full-length studio album since “The Long Run” in 1979 and to tour, Billboard.com reported.

headline: Detroit Is Outsold by Imports in U.S.
I’ll Have the Fish Paste Sushi With the Green Tea Rice
text: CHICAGO, July 31 — If you believe the vendors at the annual Institute of Food Technologists convention, you may soon be able to eat and drink your way to better health.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on July 12 about bombings of natural gas pipelines in Mexico, and a correction in this space on July 23, referred incorrectly to the cause of minor bombings in Mexico City last year. A coalition of guerrilla groups claimed responsibility for the bombings — not the splinter group whose correct name is the Revolutionary Army of the Insurgent People. (Go to Article)

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about lawsuits filed over proceeds from the sale of handmade quilts from Gee’s Bend, Ala., omitted the surname of one plaintiff. She is Lucinda Pettway Franklin.

headline: Saudis Consider Embassy in Baghdad
text: JEDDA, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 1 — Saudi Arabia’s foreign minister today said his country was considering opening an embassy in Baghdad and said he was “astonished” by recent criticism of its Iraq policy by a Bush administration official.

headline: A Home Run Parade That Rodriguez Is Unable to Join
text: The Yankees have played 16,218 games since their first season in 1903. Never have they hit more home runs than they did last night at Yankee Stadium. Seven players slugged a total of eight homers in a 16-3 rout of the Chicago White Sox, tying a club record set in 1939.

headline: Before Them, Films Were Just Movies
text: BY an awful and uncanny coincidence — the kind of occurrence that, in a movie, would have to be taken as symbolic lest it seem altogether preposterous — Michelangelo Antonioni and Ingmar Bergman died on the same day. Since Mr. Bergman was 89 and Mr. Antonioni 94, neither man’s death came as much of a shock, but the simultaneity was startling. Not only because they were both great filmmakers, but more because, in their prime, Mr. Antonioni and Mr. Bergman were seen as the twin embodiments of the idea that a filmmaker could be, without qualification or compromise, a great artist.

headline: Britney Spears Sheds Another Husband
text: The second of Britney Spears’s two 2004 marriages has officially ended in divorce, according to her lawyer, The Associated Press reported. Exit Kevin Federline, above with Ms. Spears, a backup dancer, actor, rapper and successor to Jason Alexander, a childhood friend of Ms. Spears’s who departed via annulment after 55 hours. “Everything is finalized,” Ms. Spears’s lawyer, Laura Wasser, said Monday after a hearing in Superior Court in Los Angeles. The court commissioner, Scott Gordon, signed orders for dissolution of marriage, an alimony agreement and child custody. Ms. Wasser said the alimony agreement would not be made public unless enforcement becomes an issue, and, citing the interests of the children, she added that the child custody agreement had been sealed pending a hearing on Aug. 14. Since February, Ms. Spears, 25, and Mr. Federline, 29, have shared custody of their sons, Sean Preston, 22 months, and Jayden James, 10 months. Ms. Wasser said that Ms. Spears, who cited irreconcilable differences in seeking the divorce on Nov. 7, was “O.K.” with the terms of the settlement but “would like to be with her kids more.”

headline: Johnson & Johnson Plans to Cut 4,800 Jobs
text: With generic competition looming for two of its blockbuster drugs and use declining for its drug-coated stents, Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it would eliminate up to 4,800 jobs.

headline: A Plea for Respect for a Familiar Fish
text: I WISH I’d had Al Gore with me at Wild Salmon, where I stumbled across a new sign of climate change. It concerned dessert, and it might well have concerned him.

headline: What You Get for... $8.5 Million
text: Dorset, Vt.

headline: Republicans Shun Debate, and Right Cries Out
text: When the leading Republican presidential candidates started to squirm last week about attending a Sept. 17 YouTube debate, in which the public would ask questions via video, there was a surprising backlash from the world of Republican and conservative bloggers.

headline: A Simple Thirst, a Great Cab
text: SNOHOMISH, Wash.

headline: Finding Dakar in New York
text: RESTAURANTS

headline: Ethiopia: Interpreter Freed
text: Mohamed Abdi, an Ethiopian-American interpreter detained for more than two months without being charged, was released over the weekend, American officials said. He had been working as an interpreter for the American military in the volatile eastern Ogaden region when Ethiopian troops arrested him and two American soldiers in early May. The Americans were promptly released, but Mr. Abdi was sent to a military camp where he was kept until Sunday. An Ethiopian military spokesman said he had no information about the events.

headline: Zimbabwe: New $200,000 Bill
text: The central bank issued a new $200,000 Zimbabwe bill as a “convenience” to beleaguered citizens, already so battered by hyperinflation that the common method for carrying currency is not a billfold, but a grocery bag. The new note is worth either $13 or $800 in United States money, depending on which of the government’s official exchange rates one uses, but on the black market patronized by most Zimbabweans, it is worth a bit over one American dollar. On the street, the $200,000 bill will buy roughly a quart of gasoline or a two-pound bag of sugar. Previously, the $100,000 note was the highest bill in circulation. The government released the new note as the International Monetary Fund issued a report warning that annual inflation in Zimbabwe — officially 4,500 percent but more than 10,000 percent by conservative unofficial estimates — could reach 100,000 percent by year’s end.

headline: Campaign Puts Giuliani and Ailes in Uncharted Territory
text: Roger Ailes and Rudolph W. Giuliani have been pulling for each other for nearly two decades.

headline: Taking the Guesswork Out of Which Subway Escalators Are Broken
text: For many straphangers, encountering a broken elevator or escalator can be one of the more unpleasant surprises of travel in the subway system, requiring a long trek up a hot flight of stairs. For riders in wheelchairs, it can be far more than an inconvenience, requiring a lengthy detour to get out of the subway system.

headline: Rumsfeld Denies Cover-Up in Tillman Case
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 — Former Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today he felt terrible about the military’s flawed handling of the death of Cpl. Pat Tillman, the former football star who was killed in Afghanistan. But he and other former Pentagon leaders insisted that there had been no attempt to cover up the way it happened.

headline: Getting a University to Aim Higher
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — A thick loose-leaf book jammed with charts and graphs details Lee T. Todd Jr.’s ambitious plans for the University of Kentucky. But in a recent speech to a chamber of commerce, Dr. Todd, the university’s president, summed them up in three brisk words: “Research drives jobs.”

headline: New Interest in Bridgeport’s Neglected Neighborhoods
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — Not long after John M. Fabrizi was elected to a full term as mayor in 2003, he joined with business leaders in inviting the Urban Land Institute, a research organization sponsored by the real estate industry, to advise Connecticut’s poorest city on how to turn itself around.

headline: House, 411-8, Passes a Vast Ethics Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON, July 31  The House on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved sweeping ethics rules that would require lawmakers to disclose the names of lobbyists who gather more than $15,000 in political contributions for them within a six-month period. The measure would also impose new restrictions on accepting gifts, discounted airfare and other long-held perquisites of office.

headline: To Ethiopians in America, Bread Is a Taste of Home
text: IN neat head scarf and stained apron, Frehiwot Reta welcomed a customer into her tiny apartment in Harlem on a Sunday afternoon. Squeezing between stove, desk and dining table, she passed the woman a steamy bag of fresh injera, the tart, spongy flatbread that is, literally, the foundation of every Ethiopian meal.

headline: A Drowsy Family Vacation, Except for That Little Affair
text: “Summer ’04,” the second feature by the German director Stefan Krohmer, is being praised as a daring work, and the synopsis is enticing. It’s a dark drama in which upper-middle-class vacationers — liberal parents (Peter Davor and Martina Gedeck), their easygoing teenage son (Lucas Kotaranin) and the son’s 12-year-old girlfriend (Svea Lohde) — meet a depressive yet magnetic German-American expatriate (Robert Seeliger), who pals around with the girl, then has a secret affair with her boyfriend’s volcanically sensual mom.

headline: Voting Officials Face New Rules to Bar Conflicts
text: The state officials who run the nation’s elections — most with little oversight — are facing new efforts to limit what have been widely criticized as political and financial conflicts of interest.

headline: Following in Lafayette’s Footsteps, or Rather, His Wake
text: ROCHEFORT, France, July 29 — Piece by piece, a graceful structure of whimsy and magic is taking shape in this old river port, fulfilling the dream of a group of seafaring Frenchmen to honor a founding father of French-American friendship.

headline: Report Assails Oversight of College Lenders
text: The federal Department of Education, after months of criticism for its lax oversight of the student loan program, still has no system to detect and uncover misconduct by lenders and protect student borrowers, a new government report says.

headline: Glavine Delivers, but History Must Wait
text: MILWAUKEE, July 31 – Those in the 300-victory club choose new members very carefully. When a worthy candidate comes along, flashing his credentials, he is considered but given this warning: Hardly anyone comes in on his first try.

headline: Iwo Jima Sculpture, Model for Marine War Memorial, Is Losing Its Home on Floating Museum
text: A 62-year-old sculpture of the flag-raising on Iwo Jima is getting the heave-ho from the museum on the aircraft carrier Intrepid while the ship is docked in Staten Island for an overhaul, museum officials and the sculpture’s owner said yesterday.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on July 17 about the NorthEast Two-Spirit Society, an organization for gay American Indians based in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to one member, Kevin VanWanseele, a Kumeyaay Indian. Before he moved to New York, he had been living in a suburb of San Diego — not on the nearby Barona Indian Reservation, where he had grown up.

headline: Ethics Questions Plague Other Alaska Senator
text: WASHINGTON, July 31  Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, has been drawn into a swirl of ethics accusations that have already brought F.B.I. scrutiny to the two other members of the state’s Congressional delegation and resulted in a raid this week on the home of Senator Ted Stevens.

headline: Calendar
text: In and Around 34th Street

headline: 2 Killed and 7 Are Wounded as Shots Fly in Brooklyn
text: Two people were killed and seven wounded by gunfire during a bloody four hours overnight in Brooklyn, the police said yesterday. It did not appear that the four shootings were related, the police said, even though two of them occurred three blocks apart.

headline: Sometimes, Better to Leap Without Looking
text: One of the toughest challenges Charles Altmann faced in switching careers was learning to keep his mouth shut. But that is the sort of sacrifice you have to make if you heed the call of your inner entrepreneur.

headline: Manhattan: No More Baby Formula in Gift Bags
text: New York City’s 11 public hospitals will no longer offer free samples of baby formula in gift bags to new mothers, the city’s Health and Hospitals Corporation announced yesterday. The agency said the decision was meant to promote breast-feeding as part of the city’s campaign to improve infant health. The agency estimated that 24 percent of women who deliver at public hospitals breast-feed exclusively after they are discharged, up from fewer than 15 percent of such women a year ago. “Breast-feeding is a very important way to protect the health of babies and mothers,” said Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the commissioner of the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. Officials with the hospital agency said formula would be available for women who request it.

headline: Indian Movie Star Gets 6 Years in Gun Trial With Terrorist Link
text: NEW DELHI, July 31 — One of Bollywood’s best-loved film stars was sentenced Tuesday in a Mumbai courtroom to six years in prison for illegally possessing weapons, a judgment hailed by critics and supporters of India’s judiciary as a strong, if unusual, example of its willingness to stand up to the country’s rich and powerful.

headline: New Policy on Cuba (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the restaurateur Daniel Boulud’s settlement of a discrimination lawsuit misidentified the plaintiffs in a lawsuit filed against the Restaurant Opportunities Center of New York, an organization that had criticized Mr. Boulud. They are former employees of Windows on the World, the World Trade Center restaurant destroyed on 9/11 — not of Colors, a restaurant created after 9/11 by other former employees of Windows on the World.

headline: Khmer Rouge Figure Is First Charged in Atrocities
text: BANGKOK, July 31  A tribunal in Cambodia charged the commandant of the main Khmer Rouge torture house with crimes against humanity on Tuesday, bringing the first charge in a long-delayed trial in the deaths of 1.7 million people in the late 1970s.

headline: Coming Clean in the Capitol
text: It took a while, and the process certainly hasn’t been pretty, but the Democrats are close to winning passage of their long-promised ethics reform bill. We suspect it will take a lot more than one new law to break the binding and corrupting ties of lobbyist cash and politics. But the bill, which the House approved with overwhelming, bipartisan enthusiasm yesterday, is a good start.

headline: From Eggless Custard, Summer’s Iced Treat
text: LAST winter, I wrote about custards — puddings, really — that are thickened not with eggs but with cornstarch. When the weather warmed and I started making ice cream, I wanted to see how the puddings would perform as a stand-in for my traditional six-egg-yolk custard, the base for what I’ve always believed was the best ice cream.

headline: In Praise of Tap Water
text: On the streets of New York or Denver or San Mateo this summer, it seems the telltale cap of a water bottle is sticking out of every other satchel. Americans are increasingly thirsty for what is billed as the healthiest, and often most expensive, water on the grocery shelf. But this country has some of the best public water supplies in the world. Instead of consuming four billion gallons of water a year in individual-sized bottles, we need to start thinking about what all those bottles are doing to the planet’s health.

headline: Government Makes a Case, and Holds Dogs as Evidence
text: SURRY, Va., July 31  More than 60 dogs seized from Michael Vick’s property have been sheltered here and in kennels across several counties in southeastern Virginia since April.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Looking Ahead

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption with an article in Business Day on Friday about plans by Goldman Sachs to start a hedge fund, which will be managed by Raanan A. Agus, the head of its equity proprietary trading desk, misidentified the man shown. He is Daniel H. Stern, founder of Reservoir Capital — not Eric Mindich, who had previously been a part of that trading desk at Goldman.

headline: In Murdoch’s Past, Clues to The Journal’s Future
text: So now what?

headline: Senate Bill Revisits Medical Safeguards
text: For the fourth year in a row, Senator Byron Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, is seeking to pass legislation that would curb the shortcomings of boxing’s medical safeguards.

headline: Judge Orders Author to Pay Film Company $350,000 in Legal Fees
text: Laura Albert, the fiction writer better known as JT LeRoy, was ordered yesterday to pay $350,000 in legal fees to a film production company that sued her successfully for fraud.

headline: Cutting a Tumultuous Era’s Soul Soundtrack
text: One day in the early 1960s, a young man who worked as driver and baggage handler for a group called Johnny Jenkins and the Pinetoppers lugged its instruments into the studios of Stax Records in Memphis, where the band was scheduled for a recording session. As it happened, the young man sang too — in a husky tenor — and spent his idle hours that afternoon begging people to hand him a mike.

headline: A Rolling Stone Prepares to Gather His Memories
text: Let’s see how much he remembers: the guitarist Keith Richards, a founding member of the Rolling Stones, is writing an autobiography, to be published by Little, Brown & Company in the United States and Weidenfeld & Nicolson in Britain in the fall of 2010.

headline: Hempstead Village Divided on $2 Billion Comeback Plan
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., July 31  For centuries this village was the center of activity on Long Island, until modern suburbia exploded around it and decay set in.

headline: Stocks Close Higher After Late Rally
text: Stocks closed higher on Wall Street today after a rally late in the session, reversing course from a slump yesterday that led to a sell-off in Asia and carried over in Europe because of concerns about the mortgage industry.

headline: Going From Behind a Sales Counter to the Old Course
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 31 — There was a time, not that long ago, when the only thing that seemed more unlikely than a Women’s British Open being held here was a Women’s British Open being held here with Carri Wood in the field.

headline: Fine Diner to Riffraff: Tipsy Tales of 4-Star Benders
text: THE Bordeaux was flowing, the foie gras abundant and the well-heeled epicures at Daniel were having a refined old time when suddenly all eyes turned toward a table against one wall and all conversation ceased.

headline: When the Doctor Says ‘It’s Cancer’ (7 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Roberts Facing Medical Option on 2nd Seizure
text: Despite his quick recovery from the seizure he suffered on Monday, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. faces a complex diagnosis and a difficult decision.

headline: Oil Prices Continue to Rise, With a Close Above $78
text: The great oil rally, now in its fourth year, shows no sign of slowing down.

headline: Nutrition Labels Proposed for Alcohol
text: A PROPOSAL to require the alcohol content, servings per container and some nutrition information be printed on alcoholic beverage packaging was published yesterday by the Treasury Department. It comes several decades after the agency was first petitioned to require the information and four years after the most recent request.

headline: Mr. Abe on the Ropes
text: Japan’s deeply unpopular prime minister, Shinzo Abe, is insisting that he won’t step down, even after his Liberal Democratic Party won only 37 of the 121 contested seats in the upper house of Parliament in last Sunday’s election. Mr. Abe is not legally required to go so as long as he holds on to the lower house majority, but the political message is clear: If he is determined to stay, he must change course.

headline: Getty to Return 40 Artifacts to Italy
text: ROME, Aug. 1 — The J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles has agreed to hand over 40 objects from its antiquities collection that Italy contends were looted, putting an end to a “long and complex negotiation,” the museum’s governing trust and the Italian Culture Ministry said in a joint statement today.

headline: Gaining Admittance to the Club
text: As second home developers continue to build communities geared to popular pastimes like golf, tennis, horseback riding and fishing, property ownership often includes a club membership application.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: MIDNIGHT (IFC) INDIE SEX II: CENSORED The burlesque performer Dita Von Teese, at left with a friend, who knows that sometimes less obvious is more scintillating, is the host of this four-night festival, which explores how sexual fantasies have been played in independent films  and made it around production codes. First stop: “Indie Sex: Censored,” which moves from Eadweard Muybridge’s human-motion studies of naked men and women to the 1930s Hays Code to the Motion Picture Association of America’s institution of a formalized rating system in 1968 to its request at this year’s Sundance Film Festival that young filmmakers create more NC-17 movies. Peter Sarsgaard, Miranda July, Heather Matarazzo, John Cameron Mitchell, John Waters, Tatum O’Neal, Rosanna Arquette, Piper Perabo, Ally Sheedy, Guinevere Turner and Ms. Von Teese tell us what they think.

headline: A Cotswolds Country Home
text: Digging in the lush gardens of their Cotswolds country home often inspired Rebecca and Cyrus Harvey Jr. to create new soaps and scents for Crabtree & Evelyn, the botanical body and home products company that they founded in 1973.

headline: Restoring the Faith After Hitting the Bottom
text: What good is a nadir if it’s denied or ignored? What’s the value of reaching the lowest of the low if it can’t buy a cheap epiphany?

headline: Tapes Implicate Tijuana Police in Drug Trafficking and a Killing
text: TIJUANA, Mexico, July 31  Just days before a critical governor’s election in Baja California, federal authorities have released tapes to a newspaper suggesting that many members of the Tijuana police force have worked for drug traffickers and helped in the killing of a federal agent, the newspaper reported Tuesday.

headline: Bill Would Extend Lawsuit Window
text: The House passed a bill that would give workers more time to file wage discrimination lawsuits. The bill passed on a vote of 225 to 199, not enough to override a threatened veto from President Bush. In May, the Supreme Court ruled that under the terms of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 an employee had 180 days to bring suit after the first unfair paycheck was issued. The Senate is working on a similar measure.

headline: Violence Rages in Iraq as Sunni Bloc Leaves Cabinet
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 1 — Iraq’s largest Sunni political faction resigned from Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s cabinet on Wednesday, severely weakening the government’s credentials as a national unity coalition and setting back hopes of reconciliation.

headline: Dow Jones Deal Gives Murdoch a Coveted Prize
text: Rupert Murdoch finally won his long-coveted prize yesterday, gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal and one of the world’s most respected news sources, for $5 billion.

headline: A Requiem for Tenants of Carnegie
text: The process server played his knuckles on the door, fortissimo.

headline: Readers May Be Wary, but Ad Executives Are Not
text: Villain, savior or just an ambitious businessman? In Manhattan’s financial district yesterday, core Wall Street Journal readers who had been following the drawn-out Dow Jones takeover events had no shortage of opinions about Rupert Murdoch.

headline: Recipe: Peanut Stew With Lamb (Mafe)
text: Adapted from Ken Alice N’doye

headline: In Civil Unions, New Challenges Over Benefits
text: NEWARK, July 31  United Parcel Service now grants full health benefits to same-sex partners of its employees, provided they have registered for a civil union in New Jersey (as opposed to, say, in Vermont). But FedEx does not provide benefits to the partners of its New Jersey workers  unless they happen to work at Kinko’s, a FedEx subsidiary.

headline: Edwards’s Campaign Tries to Harness Internet
text: WASHINGTON, July 31 — Most presidential campaigns mark their progress by how they are doing in the polls and how much money they are raising.

headline: To Ford, a Disaster. To Edsel Owners, Love.
text: KINGSTON, N.Y., July 31 — Martin Lennox took out an ad in the local paper to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the day his car rolled off the assembly line. Then he gave a party.

headline: In Dense Stews From Senegal, Intriguing Secrets
text: WITH its spotless new white-tile floors and gleaming stainless-steel ovens, the basement kitchen of Patisserie des Ambassades, a French cafe in Harlem on Frederick Douglass Boulevard, has the fit and finish of a laboratory. On a recent weekday morning, its two resident scientists — bakers in starched white coats — glazed mixed-berry tartlets and spread crème Chantilly over thin sheets of millefeuille pastry on a long steel table.

headline: A Writer Finds the Rare Lives of Two Rare-Book Dealers Worth Singing About
text: LONG BRANCH, N.J. — The New Jersey Repertory Company here has always had a taste for the unusual, and the genesis of its current production, a world-premiere musical called “Bookends,” is suitably quirky. The piece came about when the woman who took Sidney Poitier home for dinner met the rare-book dealers who exposed Louisa May Alcott’s dark secret.

headline: As Easy as Pie, and It Sizzles
text: IF it weren’t for a certain 10-year-old friend of mine, I might never have contemplated a summer fling with deep-frying. But when I heard that Madeleine got an electric mini-deep-fryer for her birthday, I begged her mother to let her take it with us for the weekend.

headline: 43 Are Arrested in Gang Inquiry in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES, July 31  More than 400 police officers and federal agents took part in predawn raids on Tuesday, arresting 43 people suspected of being members of the Eastside Pain Bloods gang in a narcotics and gun trafficking investigation, federal and city officials said.

headline: Campaign for a Yogurt Enlists Stylish Partners
text: THE images are eye-catching, luscious and tactile: on the left-hand page of the magazine is an advertisement for a Tourneau watch, its elaborate silver face shown up-close and in striking detail.

headline: Call by U.S. House for Sex Slavery Apology Angers Japan’s Leader
text: TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 1 — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe expressed some irritation on Tuesday at the resolution approved by the House of Representatives in Washington that calls on Japan to acknowledge its wartime sex slavery. His reaction indicated strongly that the Japanese government would not offer surviving victims an official apology.

headline: Japan: Maker of Subaru Posts Loss
text: Fuji Heavy Industries, the maker of Subaru cars, posted a loss for the first time in eight quarters after sales declined in the United States and Japan. The net loss was 332 million yen ($2.8 million), or 0.46 yen a share, compared with a profit of 4.6 billion yen, or 6.42 yen, a year earlier, Fuji said. Sales fell 3.4 percent, to 318.2 billion yen from 329.5 billion yen. Separately, Suzuki Motor said first-quarter profit rose 20 percent, helped by increased sales of compact cars in Asia and Europe and a weaker yen. Net income climbed to 24.4 billion yen ($205.3 million), compared with 20.3 billion yen, a year earlier, the Tokyo-based company said. Sales rose 17 percent, to 894.5 billion yen. Mazda said first-quarter profit fell 63 percent as losses from currency hedging more than doubled. Net income fell to 2.48 billion yen ($21 million), from 6.61 billion yen, a year earlier. Sales rose 11 percent, to 814.3 billion yen. Mazda is based in Hiroshima.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article and headline on July 19 about Exxon Mobil’s cleanup of an underground oil spill in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, referred imprecisely to the source of the 17 million gallons of oil and oil products that the state estimates has contaminated Newtown Creek and its banks. Although an explosion in 1950 contributed to the contamination, the area has been used by various petroleum companies for more than 140 years, and the 17 million gallons accumulated gradually over that time — not all at once after the explosion. (The error also appeared on Nov. 1, 2005; June 23, 2006; and on Feb. 9, July 16 and July 18 of this year.)

headline: Nine Roles, One Able Soprano and Abundant Conniving
text: Of the myriad challenges a soprano can set before herself in a recital, none offer precisely the same sort of demands as Judith Weir’s “King Harald’s Saga,” from 1979. The work’s wide vocal range and elaborately curling melodies require a singer with exceptional flexibility and flawless intonation. Then there are the dramaturgical concerns: Ms. Weir’s quirky piece is a three-act opera that includes nine roles, all sung by unaccompanied soprano in the space of 12 minutes.

headline: Davies Finally Tees Off at the Old Course
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 31 — Laura Davies of England has been a professional golfer for more than 20 years and has won dozens of tournaments all over the world. But until Tuesday she had never played the Old Course.

headline: World Stock Markets Fall Sharply
text: SINGAPORE, Aug. 1 — Stock markets in Asia fell sharply today on concerns about widening mortgage woes in the United States and the threats they pose: that investors are being forced to sell Asian assets to cover losses in the United States, and that hard-pressed American homeowners will scale back their demand for Asian exports.

headline: Letters
text: Farm Animal Welfare

headline: U.S. Death Toll in Iraq in July Was the Lowest in ’07
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 1 — The deaths, announced today, of four American soldiers in Baghdad on Tuesday brought the total American military death toll in July to 78, the lowest monthly figure so far this year.

headline: O. J. Simpson Book Rights go to Goldman Family
text: A federal bankruptcy judge has awarded rights to the reviled O. J. Simpson book “If I Did It,” a hypothetical account of how he could have killed his former wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, to the family of Ronald Goldman, right, her friend who was murdered with her in a 1994 knife attack, The Associated Press reported. “After 13 years of trying to get some justice, today is probably the first time we had any sense of seeing light at the end of the tunnel,” said Mr. Goldman’s father, Fred. Mr. Simpson was acquitted of murder in 1995 but lost wrongful-death civil lawsuits to the Goldman and Brown families, who are seeking to satisfy their multimillion-dollar judgments against him. He has maintained his innocence. Under the settlement with a court-appointed trustee, which was approved by the judge, A. Jay Cristol, in Miami, the Brown family is to receive part of the first 10 percent of gross proceeds from the book and the Goldmans the rest. Publication of the book by HarperCollins was canceled amid public outcry. David Cook, the Goldmans’ lawyer, said that discussions with literary agents, publishing houses and movie studios were in progress.

headline: From Wyoming to Montana on Foot
text: TEN THOUSAND feet above sea level, just north of the Wyoming-Montana border, lies Albino Lake, a fish-shaped oblong of icy water bounded on its east by a reddish, rock-slide-scarred ridge and on its west by the high, bare peak of Lonesome Mountain. A few tiny, rocky islands poke up from the water, and on one stands a thatch of purple wildflowers that glow like neon in the golden light of late afternoon. When night falls, the surface of the lake turns silver, then black. The rough stillness in the air is a constant reminder that, although a thin trail runs along the shore, this is the very edge of civilization — the frontier.

headline: Hal Steinbrenner Steps Into the Spotlight
text: The last time I remember hearing Hal Steinbrenner speak was at a news conference introducing José Contreras in 2003. He was representing his father, George, and he stood up and said one sentence: “I’ll keep it brief, but we’re expecting great things.”

headline: Late September
text: The mail truck goes down the coast

headline: Poems by Charles Simic
text: A selection of poems by the new Poet Laureate.

headline: Currents
text: For the home (and the closet and liquor cabinet), all things Trump and more.

headline: Private Equity Goes Back to School
text: Among the many sources of private equity’s huge war chests has been cash from university endowments. Now buyout firms are pouring some of that money back into colleges — and the companies that service them and their students.

headline: More Red Ink After Alcatel-Lucent Merger
text: The telecommunications equipment maker Alcatel-Lucent posted its second consecutive loss in the second quarter on costs related to its recent merger and an unfavorable product and geographic mix, the company said Tuesday.

headline: Guessing Murdoch’s Strategy for The Journal
text: Since the News Corporation‘s offer for Dow Jones & Company was made public three months ago, Rupert Murdoch’s business career, character and motives have been dissected in an effort to predict what he might do as the owner of The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Former Merrill Broker Sentenced in Squawk-Box Case
text: A former Merrill Lynch broker was sentenced Tuesday in federal court in Brooklyn to a year and a day in prison for witness tampering and making false statements in connection with an alleged scheme to misuse information broadcast over brokerage “squawk boxes.”

headline: Manhattan Media Said to Buy The New York Press
text: The New York Press, the city’s second-largest free weekly newspaper after The Village Voice, was expected to be sold Wednesday to Manhattan Media, a publisher of weekly newspapers, according to The New York Times.

headline: Banks Must Wait for South Korea’s Big I.P.O.’s
text: South Korea is encouraging state firms to go public, but investors and big banks will have to wait until next year at least before crown jewels like Incheon International Airport hit the market.

headline: Alitalia Chairman Steps Down in Wake of Failed Auction
text: Berardino Libonati, chairman of Alitalia, the Italian state-controlled airline, resigned Tuesday following the failure of the government’s attempt to sell the carrier. Mr. Libonati, who had been appointed to guide the airline’s privatization, resigned after all prospective buyers pulled out of the sale last month following a seven-month auction.

headline: Aon May Sell Combined Insurance Unit
text: Aon said Tuesday that it is once again considering a sale or spinoff of its Combined Insurance Company of America unit, a move analysts applauded along with the parent’s stronger-than-expected financial results in the second quarter.

headline: Brookfield Plans Infrastructure Spin-Off
text: Canada’s Brookfield Asset Management plans to spin off a 60 percent stake in its infrastructure operations to its shareholders in a deal worth about $600 million, the company said Tuesday.

headline: EGL Shareholders Approve $2 Billion Buyout
text: EGL shareholders have approved the $2 billion buyout of the logistics provider by Ceva Group, the company said Tuesday. The buyout of Houston-based EGL by Ceva, which is owned by affiliates of Apollo Management, is expected to close Thursday.

headline: Third Bear Stearns Fund Skids on Mortgages
text: Another Bear Stearns hedge fund has been hit by turmoil in the mortgage market.

headline: The Wall Street Journal Under Murdoch
text: Since the News Corporation’s offer for Dow Jones & Company was made public three months ago, Rupert Murdoch’s business career, character and motives have been dissected in an effort to predict what he might do as the owner of The Wall Street Journal. Based on his history, Mr. Murdoch is expected to try to broaden The Journal’s influence beyond pure business readers.

headline: Technology Partners Raises $300 Million
text: Technology Partners, one of the first venture capital firms to get into clean technology, announced it has raised $300 million for its eighth fund. The firm will use the funds to invest in clean tech companies as well as life sciences and health/lifestyle companies.

headline: New Zealand's Dairy Farms
text: Since New Zealand's government drastically reduced subsidies to farmers in the 1980s, its agricultural community has never been the same.

headline: Sovereign Wealth Funds: The New Hedge Fund?
text: One of the enduring criticisms lobbed at hedge funds is their lack of transparency. Now, regulators and lawmakers may soon have a new target in their fight against opacity.

headline: Dow Chemical Said to Prepare Imperial Bid
text: Dow Chemical, the largest chemicals group in the United States, is considering making a rival offer for Imperial Chemical Industries, the British maker of Dulux paints, The Telegraph reported.

headline: 3i Said to Pull NCP Auction Amid Market Turmoil
text: The turmoil in the debt markets has claimed another casualty, with a British private equity firm, 3i, pulling its auction of NCP Services, a company that supplies traffic wardens to many of Britain’s local councils, according to The Telegraph.

headline: Enron Plaintiffs Call for White House Support
text: Former investors in Enron called on the White House on Tuesday to support efforts to hold third parties accountable when their actions help a company defraud investors.

headline: Jones Apparel Favors Japanese Bid for Barneys
text: The Jones Apparel Group said Wednesday it plans to accept a $900 million cash bid for Barneys New York from Fast Retailing of Japan.

headline: Amp’d Mobile Seeks to Sell Assets
text: After holding an emergency auction, the bankrupt wireless carrier Amp’d Mobile is seeking approval for “very discrete asset sales” in a Wednesday, Aug. 1, hearing, The Deal.com said, citing a court schedule.

headline: Discovery Said to Embrace Treehugger
text: Discovery Communications has scooped up a companion Web site to its upcoming Planet Green cable network, agreeing to buy Treehugger.com for about $10 million, The New York Post reported.

headline: Macquarie Warns on Debt Fund Losses
text: Australia’s Macquarie Bank warned on Wednesday that retail investors in two debt funds face losses of up to 25 percent as fallout from the global credit crunch widened, knocking 10 percent off its shares.

headline: Deutsche Bank Posts Rise in Profit
text: Deutsche Bank, Germany’s biggest bank, said profit rose 31 percent, beating analysts’ estimates, on record second-quarter trading revenue. Net income climbed to 1.78 billion euros ($2.43 billion), or 3.60 euros a share, from 1.35 billion euros, or 2.44 euros, a year earlier, the Frankfurt-based bank said on its Web site Wednesday.

headline: Lazard Earnings Fall 2.2% as Fewer Deals Are Done
text: Lazard said second-quarter earnings fell 2.2 percent, as the firm completed fewer merger and acquisition assignments, but the profit was higher than analysts had forecast. Profit declined to $61.5 million, or 53 cents a share, from $62.9 million, or 60 cents a share, a year earlier, the New York-based company said.

headline: Tanglewood Festival: Can Music Talk Politics?
text: Lenox, Mass. — One question being explored at this summer’s Festival of Contemporary Music is whether concert music can effectively express political concerns. But when it comes down to it, there seem few illusions about that. Works with texts can do it, of course. But then it’s the text that’s making the statement; the music, if it is effective at all, can amplify the text and give it emotional resonance and dimension.

headline: The Dow Jones Sale: Wall Street Speaks
text: Villain, savior or just an ambitious businessman? In Manhattan’s financial district Tuesday, core Wall Street Journal readers who had been following the drawn-out Dow Jones takeover events had no shortage of opinions about Rupert Murdoch.

headline: Murdoch and Dow Jones: How The Deal Got Done
text: While Rupert Murdoch finally won his long-coveted prize — gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal — closing the $5 billion deal was a marathon of conference calls and all-nighters for those involved in the deal-making process.

headline: Morning Buzz: The Mayor’s Unusual Commute, Tax Evasion Convictions, and More
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has often boasted of his subway-riding prowess, casting himself as a straphanger who uses the subway for his daily commute. But after five weeks of observing the mayor’s commuting habits, a team of New York Times reporters has concluded that the mayor’s routine is somewhat unusual, Michael M. Grynbaum reports. When he does take the subway to work — at least several times a week — he is picked up by two S.U.V.’s and driven from his town house on 79th Street to the subway station at 59th Street, where he catches the express train (the No. 4 or No. 5 subway line) to City Hall. “Where would you drive from in Manhattan to a subway station?” an M.T.A. spokesman, Jeremy Soffin, said when told about the routine. “That would be pretty crazy.”

headline: Shadowing the Mayor of New York
text: When I started as a reporting intern on The Times’s Metro desk, I didn’t expect I would find myself shadowing the mayor of New York. But when my editor asked me how I’d feel about waking up every morning at 6 o’clock to hop on a subway and stand around a street 70 blocks from my apartment, it seemed too good to pass up. The story was irresistible: Checking Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s assertion that he commuted regularly to work by subway. It was a perennial political question: Did image live up to reality?The last time I’d been conscious at that hour involved finishing up a term paper from the night before. But Mayor Bloomberg is a notorious early riser — in his 1997 autobiography, he recalls chastising a colleague for arriving to work at 8 a.m.

headline: Quick Bits: AOL Shrinks, Dell Gains Support
text: A lot of follow-ups on yesterday’s events:

headline: 2008: Obama on Terrorism
text: For the last few weeks, Republican candidate Mitt Romney has been accusing the Democrats of using “defeatist” language on terrorism and the war in Iraq. Rudolph W. Giuliani has arguably been even tougher, calling Democrats the “party of losers” who “refuse to admit the existence of Islamic terrorism.”

headline: DealBook Talks Dow Jones
text: On Tuesday night’s episode of “The Charlie Rose Show,” DealBook’s Andrew Ross Sorkin sat down with Charlie Rose and The New Yorker’s Ken Auletta to talk about the News Corporation‘s $5 billion deal for Dow Jones. You can watch the full video after the jump.

headline: Lightly Updated
text: Subtle revisions (a decorator calls them the 50-year fix-up) in a town resistant to change.

headline: Genstar Adds Adviser for Canadian Deals
text: Genstar Capital, a private equity firm based in San Francisco that focuses on midsize companies, added Kevin T. O’Leary to its strategic advisory board.

headline: WSJ: Opinions Not for Sale
text: The Wall Street Journal editorial page wants its readers to know that it won’t be changing its political perspective just because Rupert Murdoch bought Dow Jones, the company that owns The Journal:

headline: Race and Restaurants
text: On Monday Daniel Boulud settled a lawsuit filed by busboys and runners who said he didn’t promote them to be waiters because they weren’t white. Today, the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission weighed in, filing a lawsuit that backed the workers’ complaints.

headline: Quadrangle Hires Former Yahoo Executive
