text: Quadrangle Group, a media- and communications-focused investment firm based in New York, said Wednesday it had hired Daniel Rosensweig, the former chief operating officer of Yahoo, to open an office in Silicon Valley in September.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Absaroka- Beartooth Wil
text: Matt and his camping partner hike and skinny dip on the way to Hidden Lake, in the Absaroka-Beartooth Wilderness.

headline:
Living with Music:
A Playlist by Irvine Welsh
text: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for “Living With Music,” a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the “celebrity playlists” on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

headline: Wet and Wonderful and, Best of All, Free
text: It’s not often that I use a post on this site to link to the editorial page of the newspaper, but today I felt I simply had to. Please read “In Praise of Tap Water.”

headline: Gol! Gol! Gol!
text: [Correction appended]

headline: Bear’s Stock Hits New 52-Week Low
text: Does James Cayne still feel like hitting the greens?

headline: Murdoch’s Deal History Shows Fickle Streak
text: Don’t count on Rupert Murdoch holding on to Dow Jones and the Wall Street Journal for the long term, warns Slate’s Jack Shafer, the media critic who has written many scathing columns about Mr. Murdoch since the media baron’s News Corporation made its bid in May. He’ll keep it long enough to destroy it, then sell it off, Mr. Shafer predicts.

headline: Bull Says ‘Non’ to H.P. Takeover Rumors
text: Bull, a French computer services company, said on Wednesday that, contrary to a recent report, it was not in negotiations with Hewlett-Packard nor had it received an offer from the American computer giant. “There are no ongoing negotiations, and we have not received a formal offer,” Bull’s chief executive, Didier Lamouche, told a conference call when asked about Hewlett-Packard.”

headline: When Hedgies Drink Box Wine, That’s News
text: This just in: Hedge fund managers like to drink expensive booze, Dan Dorfman revealed Wednesday in the New York Sun. He reports that six hedgies showed up at Tse Yang, a Chinese restaurant in New York, and spent $4,800 on a single round of a rare cognac.

headline: Transcript: Houston Dynamo Coach Dominic Kinnear
text: It was a rare day off on Monday for Coach Dominic Kinnear and his defending M.L.S. champion Houston Dynamo.

headline: July Heat Wilts 2 More Hedge Funds
text: Two more hedge fund managers may need a swig of something to ease the pain of stinging losses for July.

headline: New Deal Debate for a New Era
text: In her web column today, Robin Toner tackles the newest incarnation of one of the nation’s oldest debates:

headline: The Web Site as Self-Defense
text: Some writers’ Web sites are expansive and welcoming. Others are grudging and spartan.

headline: Justice Roberts’s Full Disclosure
Democrats Welcome Representative Maloney’s Backing
text: Micah Z. Kellner was reminiscing this week about his successful race for an Assembly seat on the East Side of Manhattan last June. He spoke of the hours he spent campaigning and the consistent support he got from his chief political benefactor: United States Representative Carolyn B. Maloney.

headline: Ladies and Gentlemen, Plug In Your Engines
text: The first 30 teams have been announced in the Automotive X Prize, and that brings up one question:

headline: Something to Nosh On: Here’s the Skinny on Jewish Delis
text: Every aspect of the Jewish delicatessen — from the declining popularity of kishka to the rise of online sales to the gentrification of the Lower East Side — was touched upon at a panel discussion before a standing-room-only crowd Tuesday night at the Museum of the City of New York. References to pitcha (calf’s foot jelly, an old delicacy) and the long-gone Garden Cafeteria drew knowing and nostalgic sighs. The owners of three legendary Jewish eateries spoke.Matthew Goodman, the author of “Jewish Food: The World at Table,” moderated the panel, held in conjunction with the exhibition “The Jewish Daily Forward: Embracing an Immigrant Community,” on view through Nov. 25. Despite talk of a revival, the number of Jewish delis has fallen precipitously in the post-World War II era, a theme that dominated the discussion.

headline: Brazil, Guyana and Rainforest Emissions Credits
text: For years developing nations like Brazil argued that they should play no role in cutting greenhouse gas emissions. After all, they said, the rich world has been responsible for putting most of the CO2 already there up in the atmosphere, and poor countries need to industrialize at top speed to alleviate grinding poverty.

headline: Tanglewood Festival: Stacking the Deck With Jazz
text: Lenox, Mass. — Lots of big, not entirely supportable generalizations are being made about the “Generation of ’38” composers who are being celebrated at Tanglewood’s Festival of Contemporary Music this year. One is that drawing on popular music is a generational hallmark. Pop, for this generation, is jazz. And the jazz they grew up with — that of Mingus, Monk and Dave Brubeck, for example, and the later Ellington works — differs from contemporary classical music more in accent and (sometimes) instrumentation than in substance.

headline: Deep Brain Stimulation
text: An animation depicts the insertion of electrodes into the brain of a patient with severe brain injury. (Source: Cleveland Clinic) Eds note: No sound

headline: Dave's Cutting-Room Floor
text: David Pogue reviews trivial gadgets in his weekly video report.

headline: Liars Can’t Be Trusted
text: The news that Bear Stearns has halted withdrawals from a third hedge fund — one that sounds much less risky than the two that collapsed — is a reminder what happens when people suspect lies.

headline: Analysts on Blackstone: Buy, Buy, Buy
text: The Blackstone Group has been feeling a chill on many fronts lately — from Capitol Hill, labor unions and the stock market, just to name a few. But the private equity giant got a big batch of love letters Wednesday from the research departments at investment banks, which initiated coverage on Blackstone en masse with droves of “buy” ratings.

headline: Onischuk and Radjabov Take Over Lead at Biel as Carlsen Stumbles Again
text: The wheels continued to fall off for Magnus Carlsen of Norway as he lost a second consecutive game at the Biel International Chess Festival, this time to Loek Van Wely of the Netherlands. The tournament’s leaders are now Alexander Onischuk of the United States, who today beat Boris Avrukh of Israel, and Teimour Radjabov of Azerbaijan, who decided to take the day off by playing a 10-move draw against Alexander Motylev of Russia. (“Playing” does not seem like the right verb to describe such a game.) The games can be followed live or replayed at the tourament’s official Web site.

headline: You Asked, We Answer
text: With permit in hand, our builder, Johnny, is ready to begin, but he can’t start construction until Bank of America closes our loan. He thinks it’s stupid, but it is bank policy. And since the bank is waiting for a couple of documents from the county, we’ve got to wait, too — but it looks like we can actually break ground in about a week!

headline: Bloomberg: ‘The Story Is What It Is’
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg brushed off questions this afternoon about a report on his morning subway commute that revealed he is typically driven in an S.U.V. to a Midtown express subway stop 22 blocks from his Upper East Side home.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Hot Rod'
text: The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Hot Rod" a film about an unintelligent, untalented, aspiring stuntman.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'El Cantante'
text: A. O. Scott reviews "El Cantante," starring Marc Anthony and Jennifer Lopez.

headline: Garden State Riddle: How Will the Chicken Cross the Road?
text: Oh, all right, so maybe this isn’t about chickens, but in its plans to widen a part of the Garden State Parkway to three lanes from two, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority has set aside $9 million to build tunnels for certain animals to cross to the other side. It doesn’t include chickens because they’re not on federal or state threatened or endangered species lists, as far as we know. Those critters that are on that list — there are 14 and they include the Pine Barren tree frog, the eastern tiger salamander and timber rattlesnake — will be able to avail themselves of tunnels made of 36-inch reinforced concrete to get from one side of the parkway to another, according to an article  in today’s Star-Ledger.

headline: Disney to Buy Club Penguin Web Site
text: The House of Mouse is about to its doors to flocks of virtual penguins.

headline: A Push to Restrict Tinted Windows in Cars
text: The city’s public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum, and lawmakers in the State Legislature and the City Council are calling for law enforcement authorities to crack down on the use of illegally tinted windows.

headline: What We’re Reading on the Blogs
text: Odd couple: Rudolph W. Giuliani and Norman Siegel. [The Daily Politics]

headline: Parsing Obama’s Tougher Talk
text: Barack Obama’s declaration, during a foreign-policy address today, that he would be willing as president to use military force against Al Qaeda in Pakistan (“If we have actionable intelligence about high-value terrorist targets and President Musharraf won’t act, we will”) has provoked a blogburst. (Here’s The New York Times news story on Obama’s speech.)

headline: Dispute Festers Over Moving of 9/11 Ceremony
text: The decision to move the 9/11 memorial ceremony this year to Zuccotti Park from ground zero — where it was held every year from 2002 to 2006 — continued to spark debate today.With construction finally under way at ground zero, the authorities say the site cannot accommodate the ceremony. Instead, the ceremony is scheduled to be held at Zuccotti Park, at Broadway and Liberty Street, which was built in the late 1960s and originally known as Liberty Plaza Park. The park reopened in 2006, under a new name, after an $8 million renovation.

headline: Hey, We’re Walking Here
text: It sometimes seems as if there’s advertising around every street corner in mid-Manhattan. At Fifth Avenue and 39th Street, at least until today, there was advertising at the street corner: this makeshift mini-billboard for a nearby Subway sandwich shop. Then the Department of Transportation arrived.

headline: "I Am American Business"
text: CNBC Advertisement with Herb Kelleher, President and Chief Executive, Southwest Airlines.

headline: "I Am American Business"
text: CNBC Advertisement with Bob Johnson, Founder, The RLJ Companies.

headline: "I Am American Business"
text: CNBC Advertisement with Mel Karmazin, Chief Executive, Sirius Radio.

headline: "I Am American Business"
text: CNBC Advertisement with Julie Clark, Founder, The Baby Einstein Co.

headline: Smiles of a Web Video
text: Of the two great filmmakers who died this week, Ingmar Bergman lent images to the world of pop culture in a way that Michelangelo Antonioni did not — mainly by virtue of the chess game with Death in “The Seventh Seal.” (Of course, he was also referenced by Woody Allen, over and over and over.)

headline: Tanglewood Festival: Composers in Waiting, Well, Wait
text: Lenox, Mass. — Things are winding down here. The Festival of Contemporary Music offers only two more concerts, an orchestral performance tonight and the closing concert tomorrow, split between works of the jazz composer Julius Hemphill and electronic works by Musica Elettronica Viva (Alvin Curran, Richard Teitelbaum and Frederic Rzewski). As a coda, the Friday night Boston Symphony Orchestra concert, led by James Levine, includes the Concerto for Bass Viol and Orchestra by John Harbison, the festival’s director (on a program otherwise devoted to Beethoven, Mozart and Ravel).

headline: Can Zwinky Save Ask?
text: Barry Diller may be missing Jeeves, but at least he has Zwinky.

headline: Food Shortage in Zimbabwe
text: Zimbabweans try cope with the effect of 10,000-percent-a-year hyperinflation on their food supply.

headline: NASA Plans a Near-Miss
text: Enceladus is the coolest place in the solar system you’ve likely never heard of. And Enceladus, one of the moons of Saturn, is indeed cool — its surface temperature averages about minus-325 degrees Fahrenheit. It is also the shiniest object in the solar system, reflecting almost all of the light that hits it.

headline: Rumsfeld Testifies on Tillman Death
text: Former Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld testified about his knowledge of the death of Army Ranger Pat Tillman.

headline: Giuliani and Fox News
text: In case you glide by The Times’s home page on the Web tonight, we’d like to call your attention to an article by Russ Buettner on the long-longstanding relationship between former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani and Roger Ailes, of Fox News.

headline: Bonds in L.A.
text: A group of hecklers stood outside the visiting clubhouse at Dodger Stadium on Tuesday night, waiting for Barry Bonds.

headline: International Influence
text: Exchange-rate-rich Europeans are not the only foreign buyers gobbling up property in the United States, according to a first-of-its kind study by the National Association of Realtors.

headline: Your Comments on my Farm Column
text: My Thursday column is from Yamhill, Oregon, my hometown, and is about the disgraceful new farm bill that House Democratic leaders have backed. We all know that our ag subsidies harm Africa and are hugely costly, but one of my points is that they are also bad for the family farm and rural America itself. I’d welcome your comments here.

headline: Selig Watches Bonds, Grudgingly
text: Commissioner Bud Selig was at Dodger Stadium to watch Barry Bonds pursue Hank Aaron’s record again on Wednesday night, but Selig did not sound like someone who was thrilled to be in Los Angeles.

headline: You Can Survive Polyester
text: COMMON wisdom in fashion says that it is easier to take a luxury brand downscale than to make a mass brand more expensive. But that doesn’t explain why the most popular men’s shirts at Scoop this spring, or those that flew off the racks at Jeffrey New York, were made by Gant. Gant?

headline: Russia Set to Plant Flag on Arctic Seabed
text: The Russian research ship Akademik Fyodorov, escorted by a nuclear icebreaker, has reached the North Pole on a mission to send two small piloted submarines to plant a Russian flag on the seabed of the Arctic Ocean, directly under the pole, the Interfax news agency reported. The Mir submarines will dive 15,400 feet, possibly tomorrow, and a member of Parliament will accompany the crew to the bottom. The mission is intended to support Russia’s claim that the Artic Ocean, including the North Pole, lies within Moscow’s exclusive economic zone. Russia maintains that a geological feature called the Lomonosov Ridge, directly under the pole, forms part of the Siberian continental shelf and thus belong to Russia. At issue are scientific projections that the ice cap will recede because of global warming, opening the Artic Ocean to offshore oil drilling. Canada and Denmark also claim the Lomonosov Ridge.

headline: A New Kicker for the Giants Tries to Settle In
text: ALBANY, Aug. 1 — Training camp separates players from their families, purposely cutting away the distractions of home to focus on the team. None of the Giants know this feeling as acutely as Lawrence Tynes.

headline: Safety Violations Cited for Deaths in Subway Work
text: The deaths of two subway workers in April resulted primarily from flawed safety procedures and a lax “organizational culture” in which track workers and supervisors flouted basic safety rules and failed to alert operators of oncoming trains to the presence of workers on the tracks, according to reports released yesterday by New York City Transit.

headline: A Heckler Dresses Up as Bonds
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1  A group of hecklers stood outside the visiting clubhouse at Dodger Stadium on Tuesday night, waiting for Barry Bonds.

headline: On a Home Network, the Right Drive Means Storage for All
text: It does not take much effort these days to accumulate several hundred gigabytes of data. A few hundred songs, a couple of vacations’ worth of photos, a dozen movies and television programs — and suddenly the 80 gigabyte hard drive in the notebook computer is straining.

headline: Whoopi Goldberg Joins ‘The View’
text: Rosie O’Donnell’s name wasn’t mentioned on “The View” Wednesday morning. But a few moments after Barbara Walters introduced Whoopi Goldberg to a live television audience as the show’s new moderator, replacing Ms. O’Donnell, Ms. Goldberg left no doubt that a new era was dawning.

headline: Getting One for the Price of One
text: This week, Rudy Giuliani is focusing on health issues, attacking Democrats’ plans to get the government more involved in covering the cost of medical care. In a campaign tour of New Hampshire town meetings, he used the word “socialism” so often that it crowded out the old nonterror-related record-holder, “Ronald Reagan.” Other frequently repeated nouns were “choice” (good) and “France” (bad).

headline: Engineers See Dangers in Aging Infrastructure
text: A steam pipe explodes near Grand Central Terminal, a levee fails and floods New Orleans, a bridge collapses in Minneapolis.

headline: A ‘Queer Lion’ Comes to Venice
text: After four years of negotiations, the Venice Film Festival plans to award a Queer Lion. A spinoff from the event’s principal prize, the Golden Lion, the Queer Lion will be awarded to the best film in competition or in any festival sidebar that features a gay theme or character, Reuters reported. The Berlin Film Festival has been awarding a similar prize, the Teddy, a play on its Golden Bear, for the last 21 years.

headline: Belly Up, My Man. We Need to Talk.
text: Anyone who watched the British Open this month had to notice Sergio Garcia’s new “belly putter” — an extra-long putter that stays anchored in the belly during the stroke. It helps keep the hands from shaking. In other words, it’s a putter for total wusses. Just ask Garcia’s colleague Ernie Els, who once said: “Nerves and the skill of putting are part of the game. Take a tablet if you can’t handle it.”

headline: Queens: Trade School Owners Charged
text: The owners of a Jackson Heights trade school were charged yesterday with giving students the answers to tests for state asbestos-removal certificates and with allowing illegal immigrants to use false information to apply for the certificates, prosecutors said yesterday. The owners, Juan Herrera, 61, and Julia Herrera, 49, both of Clifton, N.J., were charged in Criminal Court on Tuesday night with falsifying business records and tampering with government records, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said detectives who went undercover as students at the Herreras’ school, Senagryph Training Facilities, were told to use fake Social Security numbers on certificate applications and given answers to questions on the certifying exam. Mr. Brown said the lapses allowed illegal immigrants to gain access to high-security work sites, including bridges, tunnels and airports.

headline: Gonzales Offers a Defense to Senate Panel
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales offered a narrowly drawn defense of his recent Congressional testimony on Wednesday, saying he had been truthful in denying that there had been serious disagreements within the Bush administration about the National Security Agency’s program of wiretapping without warrants.

headline: And the Band Stayed On
text: Fairfax, Va.

headline: Elle Has a Little Work Done
text: THE most glamorous thing about the offices of Elle magazine is that they have an excellent view of Condé Nast, eight blocks to the south, where Vogue and GQ and Vanity Fair exist in movie-set-worthy splendor and Town Cars idle in perpetuity. Roberta Myers, the editor of Elle, wears Prada, but she takes the subway to work.

headline: In a Spotlight, This Village Barely Noticed
text: PORT CLYDE, Me., Aug. 1 — The annual sale of fisherman dolls went on here Wednesday morning without a hitch at 10 o’clock, villagers popped into the general store for groceries and iced tea, and kayakers set out for the water.

headline: Police Announce Breakup of Extensive Car-Theft Ring
text: WEST TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 1  It was a far-flung, multimillion-dollar luxury auto theft and fencing ring, the police said, the largest New Jersey had ever seen. A gleaming new Mercedes-Benz or BMW, sitting in the Port of Newark and destined for a driveway in the suburbs, would be stolen, stuck in a container, shipped across the ocean and sold  at up to double the retail price  on the streets of faraway cities like Cairo.

headline: Arbitrator Awards Avery a Raise, Keeping Him a Ranger
text: Rangers forward Sean Avery finished last season believing he had found a home in New York, and thanks to an arbitrator’s ruling, he will live in it for another year.

headline: Jamaica Bay Loses Marshes at Faster Rate, Report Says
text: The saltwater marsh islands of Jamaica Bay — crucial habitat for dozens of species of fish and birds — are vanishing at a rate far faster than previously thought and could disappear within five years, according to a report scheduled to be released today.

headline: Updating Newport, Ever So Gently
text: Newport, R.I.

headline: After Torrid July, Matsui Is Also Nearing Milestone
text: Hideki Matsui wears ice packs on his knees after most games. Is there something seriously wrong? “No, no, it’s not that bad,” Matsui, speaking through an interpreter, said with a smile. “I’m just getting old.”

headline: Shaky at the Start, Pérez Settles in to Strike Out 11
text: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1 — The Mets needed six relievers to plow through Tuesday’s mess of a loss, and the last thing Manager Willie Randolph wanted to see up on the scoreboard in the second inning Wednesday night was a big 5 beside the word Brewers. The number was not too far from where Prince Fielder’s majestic home run landed an inning earlier, and Oliver Pérez was in danger of losing his grasp on the evening.

headline: And Now, Folks, Behold the 15-Minute Publisher
text: In the Middle Ages, a book was a big production. It might take a year for a monk to copy a manuscript, which is Latin for “written by hand,” onto a specially prepared calf, sheep or goat skin and then to decorate it with silver or gold.

headline: What’s My House Worth? And Now?
text: THE value of my house fluctuates more often — and for even more mysterious reasons — than my weight these days.

headline: In Mexico, Rebel Politician Courts the Law-and-Order Vote
text: TIJUANA, Mexico, Aug. 1 — As politicians go, Jorge Hank Rhon, the former mayor of this teeming border town, is more colorful than most. He built his fortune with a network of betting parlors, and he keeps a private zoo of thousands of animals, including leopards, lions and a parrot in his office whose screeches make it difficult to carry on a conversation.

headline: West Bank: Israel Starts Razing Wall Near Hebron
text: Israel began dismantling a low concrete barrier that ran for 25 miles along roads south of Hebron. Israel had claimed that the barrier, though just 32 inches high, was intended to provide additional security for Jewish settlers, but in February 2006 the High Court accepted the contention of the Association for Civil Rights in Israel that the wall violated the rights of Palestinian residents in 21 rural communities and prevented farmers from crossing the roads with their herds of livestock. The court gave Israel six months to remove the barrier. When it failed to do so, the civil rights group sought to have the state held in contempt of court. Last week, the court ordered the wall’s destruction within two weeks.

headline: Tip of the Week: Open-Source Computer Programs
text: TIP OF THE WEEK: Software like Adobe Photoshop and Microsoft’s Office suite are industry standards — and expensive. If you’re on a budget and not afraid of working without telephone support, consider open-source software. Developed by programmers all pitching in — and available to download free — open-source programs let you create files in standard formats at a price that is hard to beat. For image editing, there’s the GIMP at http://gimp.org/. The software suite at OpenOffice.org offers a word processor, a spreadsheet program and more. Both have versions available for Windows, Linux and Mac OS X.

headline: Lazard Posts 2.2% Profit Decline
text: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit dropped 2.2 percent from the period a year ago, as its asset management business continued to grow while its mergers and acquisitions advisory work dipped slightly.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: City Councilman Accused of Rape Tells a Grand Jury That He Is Innocent
text: Councilman Dennis P. Gallagher appeared before a Queens grand jury investigating rape allegations against him yesterday and asserted his innocence, telling the panel that a sexual encounter with his accuser was consensual, his lawyer said.

headline: Latest Cronenberg Film to Open London Festival
text: A David Cronenberg thriller set in London is scheduled to open the London Film Festival on Oct. 17. The film, “Eastern Promises,” reuniting Mr. Cronenberg with Viggo Mortensen, right, the star of his “History of Violence,” centers on a mysterious, ruthless man tied to a Russian organized-crime family who crosses paths with an innocent midwife (Naomi Watts) who is trying to right a wrong she has accidentally uncovered. The screenplay was written by Steven Knight (“Dirty Pretty Things”).

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 7 P.M. (Cinemax) TWO HANDS In 1964, at the age of 36 and at the height of his career, the pianist Leon Fleisher, above, inexplicably lost the use of two fingers on his right hand. He didn’t regain it for some 30 years. This documentary from Nathaniel Kahn (“My Architect”) tells the story of Mr. Fleisher’s struggle, and of his rebirth as a two-handed performer. “There was a lot of despair and misery and unhappiness, but there were commensurate ecstasies,” he says in the film, adding that you can’t really expect to have one without the other. “Two Hands” is the second film in Cinemax’s presentation of this year’s Oscar-nominated short documentaries.

headline: And Here’s to You Mr. Robinson, My Friend
text: Son. That’s what Bill Robinson called Darryl Strawberry. Not Darryl or Straw or any street variations. Son. On days when Darryl wasn’t quite ready to play, Bill would materialize in front of Darryl’s locker, using that deep, melodious voice.

headline: Senate May End an Era of Cloakroom Anonymity
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 — Nowhere in the ponderous rules of the United States Senate is there any reference to the Mae West hold, the chokehold or the rotating hold.

headline: Obama Calls for Military Shift in U.S. Focus on Terrorism
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 — Senator Barack Obama said Wednesday that the United States should shift its military focus away from the Iraq war to a broader fight against Islamic extremism, vowing to dispatch American forces to eradicate terrorist camps in Pakistan if that nation failed to take such action.

headline: Content Makers Are Accused of Exaggerating Copyright
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 — An association of computer and communication companies, including Google, Microsoft and Yahoo, on Wednesday accused several professional sports leagues, book publishers and other media companies of misleading and threatening consumers with overstated copyright warnings.

headline: Birds of a Feather, Obese Together (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: One Woman, 11 Adoptions and a Time of Urgency
text: Judith Leekin, who was charged by Florida prosecutors yesterday with abusing 11 children she had adopted from New York City, has been described by the authorities as a devious swindler adept at gaming the child welfare bureaucracy.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: August 1, 2007

headline: Brooklyn: Park Restoration Planned
text: City officials announced plans yesterday for a $40 million restoration of Dreier-Offerman Park in Bensonhurst. The 77-acre park, which overlooks Gravesend Bay, was acquired through a series of donations and purchases, starting with a gift of land from the Dreier-Offerman Home for Unwed Mothers in 1933. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the development project called for the construction of three baseball fields, six soccer fields, kayak launches, nature trails, a playground and a recreation center. The work, scheduled for completion in 2011, is part of an effort to ensure that every New Yorker lives within a 10-minute walk of a park or open space, the mayor said.

headline:
Over-
Equipped on the Links?
text: Jason Fagone argues in today’s newsletter that golfers who use the new, weird putters strip the game of one of its inherent challenges. Take it a step further: Has modern equipment altered the game for better, or worse, and why?

headline: Once Shunned, Freestylers to Meet Rivals
text: CARSON, Calif., Aug. 1 — As the X Games prepared to introduce freestyle motocross in 1999, the sport’s organizer, Paul Taublieb, received a call from a representative of a motorcycle manufacturer. He wanted to know if there was any way to stop the sport from being added.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,645 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

headline: Senate Approves Tighter Rules on Ethics and Lobbying
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 — The Senate gave final approval today to a sweeping package of new ethics and lobbying rules, with an overwhelming majority of Republicans and Democrats agreeing to better police the relationship between lawmakers and lobbyists.

headline: Dozens Missing as Minneapolis Search Efforts Are Halted
text: Rescue workers halted their efforts this afternoon to search the waters of the Mississippi River in Minneapolis for dozens of people still missing in the wreckage of a collapsed highway bridge after strong currents blocked their work.

headline: Manhattan: Tax Credits for Child Care
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer authorized a city program yesterday that will offer impoverished families tax credits to help offset child care costs. Under the program, part of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s broad effort to reduce the city’s high poverty rates, families earning $30,000 or less who use accredited child care services for children up to age 4 would be eligible for credits worth up to $1,700 per household, city officials said. The program is to cost the city $42 million a year and serve up to 49,000 families.

headline: Bridge Collapse in Minneapolis Kills at Least 7
text: An Interstate highway bridge in downtown Minneapolis loaded with rush-hour traffic dropped more than 60 feet into the Mississippi River last night, sending at least 50 vehicles and passengers into the water.

headline: Mets Decide to Shift Sosa to the Bullpen
text: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1  Jorge Sosa, who stabilized the back of the Mets’ rotation by winning six of his first seven starts, has been shifted to the bullpen as the team readies for the eventual return of Pedro Martínez.

headline: House Passes Children’s Health Plan 225-204
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 — Over angry Republican objections, the House on Wednesday passed a sweeping expansion of the Children’s Health Insurance Program, financed with increases in tobacco taxes and cuts in subsidies to private Medicare insurance plans for older Americans.

headline: Innovation and a Jolt Jump-Start a Festival
text: On Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, as the immensely gifted young cellist Alisa Weilerstein played the volatile solo part in the New York premiere of Osvaldo Golijov’s mesmerizing “Azul” for cello and orchestra, conducted by the dynamic Louis Langrée, it was hard not to pinch yourself and wonder whether this really was the opening concert of the 41st Mostly Mozart Festival.

headline: Judge Allows Class-Action Bias Suit Against Novartis
text: A federal judge has ruled that female drug sales workers for Novartis Pharmaceuticals may proceed with a class-action gender discrimination lawsuit against the company.

headline: I’m Ripping You Off
text: YAMHILL, Ore.

headline: Bosnia Plans to Expel Arabs Who Fought in Its War
text: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina — When Fadhil Hamdani first came to Bosnia from Iraq in 1979 he had no idea he would stay so long. But after prolonged studies, marriage to a Bosnian woman, the birth of five children and citizenship, the years turned into decades.

headline: Bring It On: Dodgers’ Beimel Challenges Bonds
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 — Joe Beimel was about 13 when he waited in the parking lot of Three Rivers Stadium in Pittsburgh to get one of his favorite players to autograph a baseball card. The player signed the rookie card and Beimel saved it in a binder. He still has it. The player was Barry Bonds.

headline: A Leg Up on Running Injuries
text: As the rush of fall road-running races nears, one challenge is to reach the starting line without first joining the large majority of runners -- as many as 80 percent -- who suffer a leg injury each year. A review of injury studies about lower-body injuries among runners, published in the current issue of The British Journal of Sports Medicine, provides some explanation for what causes so many injuries. It might not be everything you’d expect. Those most likely to be injured, the review found, include people who’ve been injured before; are too obsessive, running for a year or more without a break; or are men taller than 5-foot-6. (No study in the review looked at the issue of women's height.) Runners with a relatively high body mass appear to somehow avoid foot injury -- perhaps, the authors speculated, because Clydesdales, in general, run less. Surprisingly, some factors didn’t contribute to injury risk, including having legs of different length, using alcohol, or running after dark, when people may be more prone to misstep. The one element that was found to prevent running injuries most consistently was increasing mileage gradually, to a maximum of about 40 miles per week.

headline: A 13th Top 10 for Prince
text: The latest installment in the “Now That’s What I Call Music!” franchise held out against Prince and the “Hairspray” soundtrack to remain the No. 1 album in the country for the second week in a row. No. 25 in the “Now” franchise has songs by T-Pain, Avril Lavigne, Gwen Stefani, Mims and 16 others, and has sold 149,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, a 33 percent drop from last week. “Hairspray” (New Line) moved up two spots on the Billboard chart to No. 2 with 101,000 sales. The new CD from Prince, right, titled “Planet Earth” (NPG/Columbia), moved 96,000, opening at No. 3. “Planet Earth” is his 13th album to reach the Top 10; his first was “1999” 24 years ago. The Canadian pop-punk band Sum 41 opened at No. 7 with “Underclass Hero” (Island), and “Every Second Counts” (Hollywood) by Plain White T’s jumped 11 spots to No. 10 on the strength of that group’s No. 1 single, the ballad “Hey There Delilah.”

headline: Martha Stewart Extends Losses
text: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, producer of the “Martha” cooking and home crafts television show, reported a wider second-quarter loss as it redesigned its Web site and its sales at Kmart declined.

headline: In Fox News, Giuliani Finds a Friendly Stage
text: Roger Ailes and Rudolph W. Giuliani have been pulling for each other for nearly two decades.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page obituary on July 25 about Albert Ellis, a psychologist who pioneered a straightforward approach to psychotherapy, misstated the period during which he lived with a companion, Janet L. Wolfe, a former executive director of the Albert Ellis Institute in Manhattan. It was 1965 to 2002, not 1966 to 2003. A picture caption with the continuation of the obituary referred incorrectly to the St. John’s University students he was shown lecturing to in a nursing home last December. They were graduate students in school counseling, not psychology. (Go to Article)

headline: The Presence of Malice
text: South Hadley, Mass.

headline: No Defense These Days for Yankee Offense
text: The Yankees hit five more home runs last night in an 8-1 victory against the Chicago White Sox at Yankee Stadium, but none were by Alex Rodriguez, who leads the majors with 35 but remained stalled at 499 for his career.

headline: Luxembourg: Profit Up at Steel Maker
text: Arcelor Mittal, the world’s biggest steel maker, reported a 50 percent increase in second-quarter profit, more than analysts had estimated, after raising prices in Europe and the Americas and accelerating cost savings. Net income climbed to $2.72 billion, or $1.97 a share, the Luxembourg-based company said. That compares with $1.82 billion, or $1.31 a share, based on figures Arcelor Mittal calculated as if it had existed a year earlier. Sales gained 21 percent, to $27.2 billion. Arcelor Mittal said it was ahead of schedule in reaping the cost benefits of its $38.3 billion combination last year.

headline: Cigna Profit Slips on Enrollment Decline
text: Cigna said second-quarter profit fell 27 percent because of costs related to a discontinued insurance business. Enrollment in Cigna’s health plans fell, and the company’s shares declined.

headline: A Welcome Mat for the Myspace Generation
text: Trying to get your teenager into the gym? You may be in luck. As The Times reports today, some smaller, independent gyms have started wooing teenagers instead of shooing them. In the last year, these centers have fitted themselves with foosball tables and juice bars, and provide classes for teens, and -- of course -- Internet access. The goal: A places to work out and hang out.

headline: The China Connection: Globalization and the Narcotics Trade
text: For all its global reach, there is something antiquated about the drug trade. The story of a bag of cocaine peddled in an American suburb, for instance, often begins in the Andes, where Quechua and Aymara Indians have harvested coca for centuries.

headline: For Your Inner Math Lover, the Calculator Goes Retro
text: Hewlett-Packard introduced the first hand-held scientific calculator in 1972 and sent the engineer’s stalwart slide rule the way of the buggy whip. Named the HP-35 because it had 35 keys, the pocket-size device sold 10 times as well as expected in its first year, no small feat considering that it cost $400. The HP-35 was discontinued after three years, but the company has just released a “retro” version to mark its 35th anniversary.

headline: Louisiana: Hospital Executives Testify Before Congress
text: The five major New Orleans private hospitals are going to lose $135 million this year and more than $400 million by the end of 2009, hospital executives told a Congressional committee. Speaking at a hearing of a House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee. The executives attributed the losses to increased costs from the effects of Hurricane Katrina, including increasing insurance and utility rates, an increase in bad debt and in uninsured patients and paying higher salaries to attract and keep doctors and nurses.

headline: Sparks Stuck in Transition After Losing Key Players
text: Midway through a sentence about the sudden retirement of the star point guard Chamique Holdsclaw, Michael Cooper quickly excused himself and ran from reporters onto the floor of Madison Square Garden.

headline: You See Duct Tape, They See a Moneymaker
text: It’s sticky, and many Americans have a roll, just in case, but a number of resourceful entrepreneurs have made duct tape the focus of their businesses.

headline: 2 Laptop Bags That Also Hold the Kitchen Sink
text: When you think of Logitech you think of computer accessories — the electronic kind. But next month the company will add the Kinetik line of computer bags: a backpack, shown here, and a briefcase.

headline: Lead Paint Prompts Mattel to Recall 967,000 Toys
text: Mattel, the maker of Barbie dolls and Hot Wheels cars, is recalling nearly one million toys in the United States today because the products are covered in lead paint.

headline: Florida: Lawyers for Padilla Co-Defendant Rest Their Case
text: Lawyers for a co-defendant of Jose Padilla rested their case, a day after Mr. Padilla’s lawyers said they would not call defense witnesses. Lawyers for the co-defendant, Adham Amin Hassoun, 45, a Lebanese-born Palestinian, ended after more than a week of testimony. On Tuesday, Anthony Natale, a lawyer for Mr. Padilla, told Judge Marcia G. Cooke of Federal District Court in Miami that his team did not plan witnesses. The men are accused of participating in a “North American support cell” that prosecutors say provided money, goods and recruits to assist “global jihad.”

headline: Keyboard for Xbox Speeds Typing
text: Sending voice and Webcam picture messages to fellow Xbox 360 players over Microsoft’s Xbox Live service is a cinch, but tapping out old-fashioned text messages using the 360’s onscreen keyboard isn’t much fun. A new $30 miniature keyboard called the Chatpad speeds up text entry to let you best even the fastest BlackBerry touch-typists.

headline: Novartis Faces Class Action Over Sex Bias
text: A federal judge has ruled that female drug sales workers for Novartis Pharmaceuticals may proceed with a class-action gender discrimination lawsuit against the company.

headline: Japan: Land Values Rise
text: Japanese land prices rose 8.6 percent last year, more than nine times faster than in 2005, when a 16-year property slump ended as the country’s economy rebounded. The average land price jumped to 126,000 yen ($1,063) a square meter, the National Tax Agency said. In 2005, land prices rose 0.9 percent. Prices in Tokyo, home to a 10th of Japan’s population, increased for a third year, surging 17 percent to 570,000 yen a square meter in 2006. Land prices are recovering after dropping by more than half from their peak in 1991. Prices rose or were stable for the first time in 15 years in areas outside the three largest regions  Tokyo, Osaka and Nagoya. The most expensive land nationwide was again in the fifth block of Ginza, a central shopping district in Tokyo, where prices soared by a third, to 24.9 million yen a square meter. That is still about a third less than peak prices in 1991.

headline: For Close Relatives, Questions With No Answers
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 2 — The couple were having their typical after-work conversation on Wednesday. Sherry Engebretsen, a financial director, told her husband, Ron, that she had had a long day full of meetings. He said that they should talk about it later, when she got home. She said, “O.K., I’ll see you in a few minutes.”

headline: Russia Plants Underwater Flag at North Pole
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 2 — A pair of Russian submersibles descended more than two miles under the ice cap on Thursday and deposited a Russian flag on the seabed at the North Pole. The dive was a symbolic move to enhance the government’s disputed claim to nearly half of the floor of the Arctic Ocean and potential oil or other resources there.

headline: Sunni Faction Quits Iraqi Cabinet; Blasts Kill 76 in Capital
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 1 — Iraq’s largest Sunni political faction resigned from Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s cabinet on Wednesday, severely weakening the government’s credentials as a national unity coalition and setting back hopes of reconciliation.

headline: Youth Soccer Group Agrees to Withhold Taxes From Coaches
text: In a case widely watched by youth sports leagues across the country, the Internal Revenue Service has reached an agreement with the Fairfield United Soccer Association that clarifies the employment status of the group’s coaches, the association’s president said yesterday.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: Striking Out With Sweet Peas

headline: An Incomplete Energy Bill
text: The House will begin debating Friday on a generally useful energy bill that would increase energy efficiency, encourage more responsible oil and gas development on public lands and stimulate investment in cleaner fuels. Yet the bill is incomplete. If it truly hopes to address the problems of global warming and energy independence, three vital issues need to be addressed.

headline: Hungry Bears Are Lured by the Well-Stocked Home
text: TAHOE CITY, Calif. — In the 17 years the Hyde family has lived at the edge of a national forest, bears have broken into their garage three times, but nothing prepared them for what they found in July after returning from five days of wilderness camping.

headline: Gates Offers Blunt Assessment of Iraqi Progress
text: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said today that he was discouraged by the departure of the major Sunni Arab bloc from Iraq’s coalition government, and noted that the Bush administration may have misjudged the difficulty of achieving reconciliation among Iraq’s sectarian factions.

headline: Panel Approves China Bill
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  (Bloomberg News) — The Senate Banking Committee approved legislation Wednesday aimed at forcing the Treasury Department to take a tougher line against China and other countries lawmakers say are keeping their currencies weak to bolster exports.

headline: Titters, Snickers and Guffaws, With a British Accent
text: LONDON, Aug. 1  — Here are three ideas for sitcoms that even the greenest television producer would shrug off as too stale to fly. So how do they also happen to be the plots for three of the freshest shows in London this summer?

headline: Murdoch and Dow Jones Pick 5 to Safeguard Wall St. Journal
text: Five people just signed on for what may be the most thankless task in journalism: making sure that Rupert Murdoch plays fair with his new acquisition, The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Education Dept. Criticized for Loans Oversight
text: The federal Department of Education, after months of criticism for lax oversight of the student loan program, still has no system to detect and uncover misconduct by lenders and protect student borrowers, a new government report said yesterday.

headline: U.S. Halts Heating Oil Deliveries by Two Companies Accused of Swindling
text: After charges of theft and money-laundering against officials with two major New York City heating oil delivery companies, federal prosecutors announced yesterday that deliveries by their trucks would be halted.

headline: An Easy-to-Use HD Digital Recorder (and at a Lower Price)
text: Most cable companies offer high-definition digital TV recorders for a low monthly price, but many people find these devices lacking in features and difficult to program. The new TiVo HD recorder is aimed squarely at that market, offering 20 hours of HD storage (or 180 hours of standard TV), an easy-to-use interface and the ability to record two channels at once.

headline: Man Regains Speech After Brain Stimulation
text: A 38-year-old man who spent more than five years in a mute, barely conscious state as a result of a severe head injury is now communicating regularly with family members and recovering his ability to move after having his brain stimulated with pulses of electric current, neuroscientists are reporting.

headline: Nature Red in Tooth, Claw and Carapace
text: I HAVE been hand-watering my vegetable garden this summer because we have a drought here in central Maryland. It’s painful to see the fields of stunted corn, the skimpy potato plants, the undersized tomatoes with blossom-end rot.

headline: Artwork Pulled From Show
text: A video installation by the Singaporean artist Lynn Lu has been withdrawn from the Singapore Art Show after Ms. Lu conceded its close resemblance to the work of an American artist, Jason Mortara.  After the installation was mentioned in an article published in The International Herald Tribune on July 20 (and in The New York Times on July 25) Mr. Mortara wrote to the National Arts Council in Singapore to declare that Ms. Lu’s work, identified by the title “X,” above, was “a substantively direct copy of a copyrighted piece” that he created in 2002 and called “Memories Revisited.” In it he used ink to write memories from his life on pieces of toilet paper before burning them over a candle. In “X” Ms. Lu wrote the names of former friends, colleagues and lovers on toilet paper using apple juice so that the names would appear briefly when exposed to the heat of the candle. Mr. Mortara said a “coincidence” was “impossible,” because he and Ms. Lu knew each other and they had performed on the same night at a show in San Francisco in 2003. After questioning by Heman Chong, curator of the Singapore show, Ms. Lu said that she had been inspired by Mr. Mortara’s work and that she and he had agreed to retitle her installation “X (After ‘Memories Revisited’ by Jason Mortara)” and to share the small grant she had received for her work. She said: “It had not occurred to me before this that Mr. Mortara would consider ‘X’ a copyright infringement of his work, as artists often influence each other, but I saw it as a grave insensitivity and carelessness on my part. I apologized to Mr. Mortara for my poor judgment, and suggested crediting him” with the new title.

headline: Murcer Revisits Emotional Night About Munson
text: It was, to Bobby Murcer, his best and most emotional game.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article last Thursday about a government report that found many more cases of West Nile virus than at the same time a year ago misstated the extent of the virus’s spread since it first appeared in the United States in 1999. It has spread to every state but Alaska and Hawaii, not to every state.

headline: A Crooner Who Woos With Modesty, Humor and More Than a Little Swing
text: Michael Bublé wants the world to know that just because he is a swinging crooner from the old school, he is not a good little mama’s boy looking to please the grown-ups by singing their music. That’s why he called his third studio album “Call Me Irresponsible,” he joked from the stage of Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday evening.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: O. J. Simpson Blames His Ghost

headline: Downtown Diner Is Moving to Wyoming, Lock, Stock and Original Stools
text: La Barge, Wyo., is a small town. It is so small, it does not have its own grocery store. Nor does it have a restaurant — well, one that is open, anyway. That’s all about to change, though, and in big-city style.

headline: Foreign Automakers Pass Detroit in Monthly Sales
text: DETROIT, Aug. 1 — Detroit auto companies’ grip on the American automobile market ended in July, when dismal auto sales gave foreign nameplates the lead for the first time ever, sales reports showed Wednesday.

headline: Television Adjusts Coverage of Bonds
text: ESPN2, which added San Francisco Giants games Tuesday night and last night to follow Barry Bonds’s attempt to tie and break Hank Aaron’s career record of 755 home runs, will also carry tonight’s Giants-Dodgers game at 10 Eastern.

headline: Women Lagging in Birthplace of Golf
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 1 — Up the road from the 18th green at the Old Course, roughly 160 paces as a caddie counts, is a two-story stone building barely big enough to contain the history of women’s amateur golf in the British Isles.

headline: As Ex-Leader Awaits Sentencing, Hollinger Files for Bankruptcy
text: Hollinger Inc., the Canadian company that Conrad M. Black used to control his newspaper empire, filed for bankruptcy yesterday and said it would explore options for the Sun-Times Media Group while facing payments on debt and shareholder suits.

headline: Democrats Plan to Assess Voting State by State
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The Democratic Party will announce on Thursday a state-by-state effort to identify potential problems in how elections are administered before the 2008 presidential election.

headline: Initiations: Exciting, Mundane or Awful
text: “My First Time,” an exercise in Web-theater synergy at New World Stages, consists of short monologues about inaugural encounters with sex that together channel all the thrill of a photo album chronicling a trip you didn’t take. Where was this vacation? Certainly not on distant white beaches but perhaps somewhere on the outskirts of a midsize American city.

headline: Caps on Prices Only Deepen Zimbabweans’ Misery
text: BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe, July 28 — Robert G. Mugabe has ruled over this battered nation, his every wish endorsed by Parliament and enforced by the police and soldiers, for more than 27 years. It appears, however, that not even an unchallenged autocrat can repeal the laws of supply and demand.

headline: Design Steps Up in Disaster’s Wake
text: AFTER Hurricane Katrina destroyed Karen Parker’s house on Division Street two summers ago, her first instinct was to leave her storm-ravaged hometown of Biloxi, Miss., behind. But she couldn’t bring herself to abandon two generations of extended family there, any more than she could see living indefinitely with her six children in their 10-foot-wide FEMA trailer. So, a few weeks after the storm, Ms. Parker decided to rebuild on her street.

headline: 3 Die in Home Near Atlanta; 2 Boys Injured
text: ATLANTA, Aug. 1  Two boys were the only survivors of an attack at a home in a normally peaceful, middle-class suburb northwest of Atlanta that killed a mother and her two teenage daughters, investigators said Wednesday.

headline: A Familiar Set Helps to Create a New Cultural Market
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — One of the most popular talent shows to hit Arab television this year has some of the trappings of similar shows in Europe and America: swaggering contestants, big-budget sets, grizzled judges and the chance to become a real star.

headline: Judge Rules 3 Can Be Charged With Hate Crimes in Gay Man’s Death
text: Three men accused of beating a gay man to death during a robbery attempt can be charged with hate crimes without evidence that they were motivated by hatred for gay men, a judge ruled today.

headline: Manhattan: Theater to Close
text: The Actors’ Playhouse, a 62-year-old Off Broadway theater that has been home to such productions as “Funhouse,” “Torch Song Trilogy” and “Naked Boys Singing!” and actors including Robert De Niro and Lily Tomlin, is closing. The theater’s rent, which had doubled in the last six years, was getting too expensive, said Peter Breger, who has operated the playhouse since 1995. “Basically, we just couldn’t make it,” Mr. Breger said yesterday. The Playhouse is the latest in a string of Off Broadway theaters to close in the last few years; others include the Promenade, the Perry Street Theater and the Variety Arts theater. The owner of the property, Duell Management, did not respond to a message seeking comment; Mr. Breger said his understanding was that Duell was “in negotiations with people to turn it into something other than a theater.”

headline: Manhattan: Lawyer Admits Using a Runner
text: A Manhattan lawyer pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to obtaining clients in personal injury cases from a go-between and lying to the state Office of Court Administration to hide the arrangement, prosecutors said. The lawyer, David Sheeger, 50, was charged with offering a false instrument for filing by paying the go-between to bribe hospital workers to obtain information about patients who had been treated for accidents, typically car accidents, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. The go-between, who was paid $500 per case, would contact the patients on behalf of Mr. Sheeger’s law firm, Mr. Morgenthau said. It is illegal in New York for lawyers to accept referrals from nonlawyers. Mr. Morgenthau said that Mr. Sheeger had obtained 67 cases using a go-between from April to November 2002. After his plea, Mr. Sheeger was disbarred, placed on probation and ordered to forfeit $110,000 obtained through the scheme, prosecutors said.

headline: A Study Finds Some States Lagging on Graduation Rates
text: Dozens of states accept any improvement in high school graduation rates as adequate progress, and several set a goal of graduating fewer than 60 percent of their students, according to a study released yesterday by the Education Trust in Washington.

headline: Reliving a Week at Magic School, or a Decade of Rock
text: When someone says, “everyone is dead and you’re next,” there is only one thing to do: start the week over. That is exactly what young sorceress-in-training Lilet Blan does in Vanillaware’s strategy game GrimGrimoire.

headline: Sudan Agrees to U.N. Peacekeepers to Complement African Union Force
text: DAKAR, Senegal, Aug. 1 — Sudan’s foreign minister told reporters Wednesday that the government supported the deployment of a United Nations peacekeeping force for Darfur, as authorized by the Security Council, while a number of countries in Africa, Asia and Europe volunteered to send troops to join it.

headline: Schoolchildren Struggled to Escape
text: They all said the same thing: It was as if they were suddenly in a movie.

headline: Gaza: Israeli Troops Kill 2 in Raid
text: Israeli forces killed two armed Palestinians and wounded several others during an army incursion into northern Gaza. The dead men belonged to the military wings of Hamas and the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, according to statements from the groups. An army spokeswoman said a rocket-propelled grenade had been fired at soldiers but caused no casualties. Palestinian witnesses said that army bulldozers had razed large areas of farmland in the operation.

headline: With Rove Absent, Aide Is Grilled by Senate Panel
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 — The Senate Judiciary Committee grilled a young political aide from the White House today about the firings of nine United States attorneys and voiced disdain for a man who was not there: the aide’s boss, Karl Rove, President Bush’s chief political adviser.

headline: Alan M. Pottasch, 79, Dies; Creator of ‘Pepsi Generation’
text: Alan M. Pottasch, who became known as the “father of the Pepsi Generation” for leading the team that devised exuberant commercials in the 1960s and ’70s that linked Pepsi-Cola to the likes of skydivers and skateboarders, died Friday in Los Angeles. He was 79 and lived in New Fairfield, Conn.

headline: The Side Deal in the Deal for Dow Jones
text: On Sunday night, after months of debate within the Bancroft family about protecting the editorial independence of Dow Jones & Company, the discussion turned to a very different, 11th-hour, question: would Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation cover the Bancrofts’ legal and banker fees?

headline: Mom, I’m at the Gym Doing Homework (Really!)
text: IT is 5 p.m. on a Tuesday and Victor Cal and Suliman Sharif, both 14, have already taken Overtime Fitness in Mountain View, Calif., by storm. They hopped wildly on the flashing lighted squares of an In the Groove dance pad, rode stationary bikes, shared cellphone pictures, chatted with a personal trainer and played a rousing game of table tennis. The pair, friends since seventh grade, once spent five hours at this airy health club.

headline: Allies Urge Republicans to Join YouTube Debate
text: When the two leading Republican presidential candidates started to squirm last week about attending a Sept. 17 YouTube debate, in which the public would ask them questions via video, they faced a surprising backlash from their ideological allies in the blogosphere.

headline: Disney Acquires Web Site for Children
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1  Racing to solidify its dominant position in children’s entertainment on the Internet, the Walt Disney Company said Wednesday that it had acquired a subscription Web site aimed at preteenagers, Club Penguin, in a deal that could total $700 million.

headline: Glavine Doesn’t Dwell on the One That Got Away
text: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1  It was past midnight when Tom Glavine met up with his family after Tuesday night’s 4-2 loss to the Brewers, and he was the calmest one among them.

headline: CNBC Admirers Talk About Their Climb Up the Ladder
text: JUST in case Rupert Murdoch is wondering who watches CNBC — the business network that he plans to compete with this fall when he introduces a competitor, the Fox Business Network — a series of commercials starting today will tell him.

headline: Jets Rookie Is Back Playing First Love
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 1  Jesse Pellot-Rosa was a starting guard on the Virginia Commonwealth basketball team that upset Duke in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament in March.

headline: Wall Street Continues Its Rebound
text: Stocks staged their second consecutive late-afternoon rally today, recovering even more losses from the sharp sell-off last week.

headline: America’s Most Coddled
text: Senator Charles Schumer got partway off the fence this week on the issue of whether the most highly paid Americans  mainly partners at hedge funds and private equity firms  should continue to enjoy a super-low tax rate. Currently, at a typical hedge fund or private equity firm, partners pay a flat tax of 15 percent on most of their mega-earnings. Salaried employees and wage earners  the majority of the work force  face income tax rates as high as 35 percent.

headline: Excavating Data  From Ancient Disks
text: Q. I have a boxful of 5.25-inch floppy disks that I used during college in the 1980s, and I’d like to extract the information from them. Where can I find a drive that supports these disks?

headline: Trenton: Meadowlands Developer Fined
text: EnCap Golf Holdings, a developer that has faltered in its bid to transform garbage dumps in the Meadowlands into homes and an entertainment district, has been fined $1.054 million for allowing methane gas to escape from one of its construction sites, the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection said yesterday. According to agency documents, the gas was released from the Kingsland Landfill in Lyndhurst, where one of EnCap’s construction sites is located. The leaks were detected from October of last year through July 24. Methane gas is typically funneled through underground pipes underneath the landfill. EnCap, which is owned by Cherokee Investment Partners in North Carolina, was also fined for not obtaining permits to operate at the landfill. The company plans to appeal the fine, a spokesman said.

headline: South Korea: Exports Surge
text: South Korea’s exports grew at the fastest rate in six months in July, as global demand was strong enough to counter the effects of a stronger won. Exports rose 20 percent from a year ago after climbing 15.3 percent in June, the commerce ministry said. Exports climbed to $30.9 billion and imports gained 14.9 percent to $29.4 billion, resulting in a trade surplus of $1.6 billion in July, the ministry said. Mobile-phone exports gained 30.5 percent in the first 20 days of July from the same period last year, the ministry said. Shipments to China, South Korea’s largest trading partner, rose an estimated 30.4 percent in the first 20 days of July from a year ago. Exports to the United States gained 24.7 percent, the report showed.

headline: Prada’s Sassy Sister Knows How to Party
text: CHAMPAGNE was pouring in the afternoon last week for the grand reopening of the Miu Miu store on Prince Street in SoHo, after a brief but total renovation.

headline: Go Ahead, Fight With Mother Nature
text: DO you worry that your face sends the wrong message? These days, there are more ways than ever to adjust a look, according to aesthetic physicians, psychologists and makeup artists.

headline: A Fall in the Park
text: Daniel Sullivan, the director of the Public Theater’s Shakespeare in the Park production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” fell through a trapdoor on the set Monday during a tech rehearsal and was taken to the hospital, where he was treated for four fractured ribs and a collapsed lung, a spokeswoman for the Public said yesterday. He is expected to return to rehearsals in a couple of days, she said, although he is still being treated. It is unclear whether previews would begin on Tuesday as planned.

headline: Providers of Child Care May Now Vote on Unionizing
text: The state has given the go-ahead for New York City’s 28,000 home-based child care providers to hold an election on whether to unionize.

headline: O. J. Simpson Blames His Ghost
text: O. J. Simpson has distanced himself from the description of the 1994 slaying of his former wife Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald L. Goldman in his aborted book “If I Did It,” Reuters reported. In an interview streamed live on Tuesday by the Web site Market News First (www.MN1.com) Mr. Simpson, who was acquitted of criminal charges in the case but found liable for the deaths in a subsequent civil trial, said the book was composed by an unidentified ghostwriter and that he reluctantly assented to a chapter about the night of the crime as told by him only after the publishers agreed to label it hypothetical. Mr. Simpson said he allowed the author to ask him questions, but was otherwise passive in describing the killings. “I read what he wrote, and I saw all of these major holes, all of these impossible things,” Mr. Simpson said. “All of these other parts of the book I would correct, but I told myself, ‘If I correct this, there are going to be people out there that say, “Oh, look how accurate this is,” ’ Right?” Rights to the book, dropped by HarperCollins after a public outcry, have been awarded to the Goldman family in payment of the multimillion-dollar civil judgment against Mr. Simpson. He criticized them, The Associated Press reported, saying, “I find it sort of hypocritical that they talked everybody in America to boycott the book: it was ‘immoral,’ it was ‘blood money.’ But now we see it wasn’t ‘blood money’ if they got the money.” David Cook, a lawyer for the Goldman family, said: “Mr. Simpson himself has placed us in this horrific setting of seeking to liquidate this asset. His comments are beyond redemption.”

headline: For Buffalo Dreams
text: TEPEES may be available at only one store on Ibiza, but there are plenty of sources in the United States.

headline: Elvis Lives On as a Robotic Head, Descended From a Chimpanzee
text: If there is a rash of Elvis sightings later this month, it may be because of the arrival in stores of the WowWee Alive Elvis, an animatronic Elvis bust with infrared eyes and lips that sync to music.

headline: ‘In Cold Blood,’ Re-enacted in Our Time
text: CHESHIRE, Conn.

headline: NBC’s Formidable Talent
text: With a 90-minute “America’s Got Talent,” NBC once again proved unbeatable in the ratings on Tuesday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 10.7 million viewers tuned in from 8 to 9:30 p.m. to watch the NBC talent show featuring David Hasselhoff, below, as a judge. Following it at 9:30, the NBC show “Singing Bee” (9.8 million) held steady from its week-ago ratings to post the night’s highest numbers among adults 18 to 49. NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (7.3 million) also finished first at 10 while tying ABC’s “Primetime” (6 million) in the 18-to-49 set. ABC ranked second for the night in that demographic, but third in total viewers behind CBS, which got a boost from an “NCIS” rerun at 8 (7.8 million) and “Big Brother” at 9 (7.1 million). Fox was fourth overall. In the cable-news race for July, MSNBC and CNN fought for second place in the desirable demographic of adults 25 to 54 during prime time. While Fox News remained entrenched in first place (318,000), MSNBC improved 35 percent from its year-ago levels to draw 191,000 viewers, finishing just short of second-place CNN (213,000).

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. How can I enliven an empty stairwell?

headline: If There Must Be Change
text: JOHN PEIXINHO described Newport style as having a “certain well-worn comfort and a reverence for the past; also, mildew is an issue.” That might explain all the slipcovers. Here are some objects he coaxed into Newport’s old houses and clubs:

headline: Top Seeds Win Team Event at Nashville Championships
text: The 64-board final of the premier event, the Spingold Knockout Teams, at the American Contract Bridge League’s Summer North American Bridge Championships took place in Nashville on Sunday. The No. 1 seeds and defending champions, Nick Nickell of New York; Bob Hamman and Hemant Lall of Dallas; Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla.; Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach, Fla.; and Paul Soloway of Mill Creek, Wash., defeated Andrei Gromov and Aleksander Dubinin from Russia, and Cezary Balicki and Adam Zmudzinski from Poland, by 120 international match points to 55. At halftime Nickell led by only 3 imps, but the second half was a rout. Nickell conceded only one swing of greater than 5 imps on any board, and to hold world-class opponents to fewer than 1 imp per board is unusual and impressive.

headline: Prosecutor Will Weigh Full Inquiry of Governor
text: ALBANY, Aug. 1 District Attorney P. David Soares of Albany County is conducting a preliminary review to determine whether his office should investigate Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his staff, Mr. Soares said on Wednesday.

headline: Contractor Calls Shooting of Two Men Self-Defense
text: One man was killed and another wounded after being shot in Queens late Tuesday by a contractor who told investigators that the men had demanded $20,000 from him and threatened to harm his wife, law enforcement officials said.

headline: A Wide Range of Sounds, From Antillean to Zouk
text: It has been more than a decade between New York City shows for Kassav’, the band from Martinique and Guadeloupe that has brought French Antillean music to an international audience since the 1980s and regularly sells out large theaters in Europe. On Tuesday night, with a sold-out audience at S.O.B.’s, Kassav’ had obviously not been forgotten. Audience members shouted along on nearly every song, singing not only the words but also the zigzagging horn-section lines. And Kassav’ has had so many hits it had to pack them into medleys.

headline: When a Mayor Plays Just Another Straphanger
text: Fred Siegel keeps a vivid memory of encountering a certain mayor on the subway.

headline: Baseball Gets Into Resale of Tickets
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 — Major League Baseball once frowned on scalping, the resale of tickets among fans and sidewalk entrepreneurs. On Thursday, professional baseball will announce plans to get into the business.

headline: A Last-Minute Rally Saves the Day, if Not the Week
text: They bobbed and weaved. Then, seemingly out of nowhere, they surged.

headline: Iran Hangs 9 Convicts, 7 Publicly, in a Crackdown on ‘Thugs’
text: TEHRAN, Aug. 1  Iran held a public hanging on Wednesday in Mashad, in the northeast, of seven men convicted of rape, the ISNA student news agency reported. Two other men were hanged Wednesday in a prison in Zahedan, in the southeast, convicted of armed smuggling of narcotics, the news agency reported.

headline: A New Tribe of Tepee Dwellers
text: IBIZA, Spain

headline: Panel Queries Rumsfeld on Tillman Battle Death
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  With Donald H. Rumsfeld seated at the witness table, the chairman of a House committee investigating the bungled aftermath of the friendly fire death of Cpl. Pat Tillman told a packed Capitol Hill hearing room Wednesday that the time had come for some answers. What did Mr. Rumsfeld and other top Defense Department officials know about Corporal Tillman’s accidental killing by American forces, he asked, and when did they know it?

headline: Spitzer Vetoes Bill on Training Aid Recipients
text: ALBANY, Aug. 1 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer vetoed legislation late Wednesday night that would have required social service agencies to train welfare recipients for better-paying jobs and train women for work in construction, computer sciences and other jobs traditionally held by men.

headline: World Bank Agency Finds Its Africa Projects Are Lagging
text: At a time when the International Finance Corporation, the World Bank Group’s private-sector arm, is in the midst of a major expansion of its investments in sub-Saharan Africa, an internal evaluation released yesterday found that its projects there over the past decade had performed below average compared with those in other regions.

headline: I Am Not a Crab: When Wrinkles Lie
text: ARLENE MILLER of Newton, Mass., was aware that her face had changed as she aged. But she had no idea how striking her expression had become to others until a trip to the grocery store several years ago.

headline: California Struggles to End Budget Deadlock
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1  California lawmakers scrambled Wednesday to end a deadlock over the state’s overdue budget, as $1 billion in payments to hospitals, nursing homes, colleges and dozens of state suppliers ground to a halt.

headline: MasterCard Meets Most Estimates
text: Shares of MasterCard Inc., the second-biggest credit card company after Visa, dropped the most since last year’s initial public offering after the company reported earnings that fell short of the most optimistic analyst estimates.

headline: In Prison Call, Inmate Feared New Action in a Cold Case
text: Through a telephone at the Attica state prison, a feared figure of Russian organized crime learned last year about movement in a murder case 14 years cold.

headline: When Frank Lloyd Wright Scandalized Chicago
text: Unlike most writers of historical fiction Nancy Horan has not had to inflame the passions of real people in order to create a transporting drama. If anything, she has had to tamp down the truth behind “Loving Frank,” a novel about the most fearsome chapter in the wildly eventful life of Frank Lloyd Wright.

headline: Getty Agrees to Return 40 Antiquities to Italy
text: ROME, Aug. 1 — After long negotiations, the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles has agreed to hand over 40 objects from its antiquities collection that Italy contends were looted from its soil, the two sides said on Wednesday.

headline: Despite Deadlines Long Past, States’ Budget Battles Drag On
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 1  Five states missed their July 1 deadline to pass new budgets, and on Wednesday, three of them  California, Illinois and Wisconsin  entered the second month of the fiscal year without one.

headline: Sub-Saharan Africa: A Less Encouraging View (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Get Your Free Net Phone Calls Here
text: The price of home phone service has dropped 30 percent since 1999. Surely, say the analysts, that trend line will eventually plummet all the way to zero. Surely, thanks to the Internet’s ability to carry your voice, landline phone calls will soon be free.

headline: Saudi Arabia Says It May Meet Israel
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 1 — Saudi Arabia’s foreign minister said Wednesday that his country would consider attending President Bush’s planned Israeli-Palestinian peace conference in the fall, which would put Saudi officials publicly at the same table as their Israeli counterparts for the first time since 1991.

headline: House to Leave Fuel Efficiency Out of Debate on Energy Bill
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 — The House of Representatives will open debate on a complex package of energy legislation on Friday, but strict new auto mileage standards will not be part of the discussion, Congressional leaders said Wednesday evening.

headline: Marvin Zindler, 85, Crusader in ‘Whorehouse in Texas’ Case, Is Dead
text: HOUSTON, July 30 — Marvin Zindler, an antic and a populist television crusader here who became known nationally when he had “the best little whorehouse in Texas” closed on corruption grounds, died here on Sunday. He was 85.

headline: System Used to Monitor Foreigners Is Vulnerable, Report Says
text: The computer system used by the Homeland Security Department to monitor foreigners entering the United States is extremely vulnerable to manipulation by unauthorized users, compromising the government’s ability to intercept terrorists, a new report by Congressional investigators concluded. The report by the Government Accountability Office warns that someone could easily erase, modify, copy or simply gain access to records of millions of travelers. The computer system, which is set up at 285 air, sea and land ports nationwide, has cost the government $1.7 billion since 2002.

headline: Just What Is ‘Victory’ in Iraq? (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Japan: Polls Indicate Public Wants Abe to Go
text: More Japanese want Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to resign than support his decision not to quit after his governing Liberal Democratic Party’s drubbing in Sunday’s election in the upper house of Parliament, according to polls conducted Monday and Tuesday by three major news organizations. In polls in the nation’s two largest newspapers, Yomiuri and Asahi, 45 percent and 47 percent, respectively, said Mr. Abe should step down; 44 percent and 40 percent said he should remain. In a poll by Kyodo, the largest news service, 50 percent said Mr. Abe should resign, while 44 percent backed him. Yomiuri said its poll was a telephone survey of 1,725 eligible voters. Asahi’s, also a telephone survey, included 1,094 voters. Kyodo did not state its sample size.

headline: Back Up iTunes Your Way
text: Q. The iTunes program has an option to back up the library to CD or DVD. How can I back it up to a U.S.B. flash drive?

headline: Manhattan: Man Held in Hotel Robberies
text: A 22-year-old man was in custody in Massachusetts late yesterday in connection with robberies at two Manhattan hotels, the police said. Detective Kevin Czartoryski, a New York police spokesman, said the man, Ermal Qoshja of Revere, Mass., was being held by Massachusetts State Police, who had acted on information from detectives in New York. Mr. Qoshja had not been charged yesterday evening, he said. The police said Mr. Qoshja was located after he used a cellphone taken in one of the hotel robberies. In the first, on April 13, a couple and their 9-year-old daughter were held at gunpoint and robbed in their room at the Millenium Hilton downtown. In the second, on May 31, a woman was struck in the face with a pistol and robbed in her room at the Roosevelt, and another man was struck when he tried to prevent the assailant from fleeing.

headline: Russia Threatens Cut in Belarus Gas Supply
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 1 — In the latest of Russia’s many disputes over energy payments with neighboring countries, the natural gas monopoly Gazprom warned Wednesday that it would reduce supplies to Belarus by 10 a.m. local time on Friday unless the former Soviet state pays an outstanding gas bill of $456 million.

headline: Bodies of 4 Kidnapped Afghan Judges Are Found
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 1 — The bodies of four Afghan judges, who were kidnapped 10 days ago, were found Wednesday in a mountainous area of Ghazni Province, the province where 21 South Korean hostages are being held by people suspected of being Taliban members, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Patriarch Teoctist, 92, Romanian Who Held Out Hand to John Paul II, Dies
text: Patriarch Teoctist, who as head of the Romanian Orthodox Church helped begin healing the thousand-year schism between Christianity’s Eastern and Western churches when he invited Pope John Paul II to Romania in 1999, died in Bucharest on Monday. He was 92.
