headline: With Left-Hander on the Mound, Damon Finds Himself on the Bench
text: When Johnny Damon arrived at Yankee Stadium for last night’s game against the Chicago White Sox, he saw his name was not in the starting lineup and he was not happy.

headline: Illinois: City Not Responsible in Porch Collapse, Court Finds
text: The City of Chicago is not legally responsible for the 13 deaths and dozens of injuries in a porch collapse in 2003, the Illinois Appellate Court ruled. Victims and family members had sued the city in 38 suits. They said city inspectors had failed to act despite knowing that the porch, built without a permit and not complying with codes, was unsafe. The court said the city was not responsible for injuries on private property not in compliance with codes.

headline: Iraq Snapshots Give 2 Views
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 — July ended with a monthly death toll for American troops in Iraq that was the lowest this year. Then August dawned with car bombs in Baghdad that killed scores of Iraqis.

headline: British Police Criticized in Shooting After Terror Attack
text: LONDON, Aug. 2 — The London police misinformed the British public about the identity of an innocent man shot dead by the police at a subway station the day after an attempted terror attack in London in 2005, an investigation by a police watchdog group concluded today.

headline: Doctor Recounts Imprisonment in Libya
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 1  — In the yard of the Bulgarian presidential residence, on the foothills of Vitosha Mountain, Ashraf al-Hazouz on Tuesday recounted his years of imprisonment and torture in Libya and aired his grievances: the beatings, the electrical charges all over his body, the injection that he was told carried the virus that causes AIDS.

headline: Surviving Without Subsidies
text: OHINEWAI, New Zealand — Watching grass grow is supposed to be dull. But watching it grow with a dairy farmer like Malcolm Lumsden is anything but.

headline: Notes About Competition
text: If we were in any other business, a risky takeover of a powerful competitor might lead to celebration. Not in our business. Good journalism, which is an essential part of American democracy, thrives on competition.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page obituary on July 25 about Albert Ellis, a psychologist who pioneered a straightforward approach to psychotherapy, misstated the period during which he lived with a companion, Janet L. Wolfe, a former executive director of the Albert Ellis Institute in Manhattan. It was 1965 to 2002, not 1966 to 2003. A picture caption with the continuation of the obituary referred incorrectly to the St. John’s University students he was shown lecturing to in a nursing home last December. They were graduate students in school counseling, not psychology.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: A Japanese Garden

headline: Your Cheatin’ Listenin’ Ways
text: JANICE RASPEN, a librarian at an elementary school in Fredericksburg, Va., came clean with her book club a couple years ago. They were discussing “A Fine Balance,” a novel set in India in the 1970s by Rohinton Mistry and an Oprah’s Book Club pick, when she told the group — all fellow teachers — that rather than read the book, she had listened to an audio version.

headline: Charles Simic, Surrealist With Dark View, Is Named Poet Laureate
text: Charles Simic, a writer who juxtaposes dark imagery with ironic humor, is to be named the country’s 15th poet laureate by the Librarian of Congress today.

headline: Bridge Collapse: Day 1
text: The entire span of a bridge in Minneapolis collapsed Wednesday, sending at least 50 cars and passengers into the Mississippi River.

headline: Bridge Collapses in Minneapolis
text: An Interstate highway bridge in downtown Minneapolis loaded with rush-hour traffic dropped more than 60 feet into the Mississippi River Wednesday night, sending at least 50 vehicles and passengers into the water and killing at least seven people.

headline: Bridge Collapse
text: The entire span of a bridge in Minneapolis collapsed Wednesday, sending at least 50 cars and passengers into the Mississippi River.

headline: Tahoe Homeowners' Unwelcome Guests
text: The Lake Tahoe area is experiencing a rise in bear home invasions.

headline: The End of Tolerance in Amsterdam
text: For one Amsterdam mayor, the Netherlands' famous tolerance has gone too far. Morrocan-born Ahmed Marcouch is taking the tough cop approach in a rough Amsterdam neighborhood, pushing his fellow immigrants to integrate. But some consider him a traitor.

headline: Physical Culture | Gear Test, Locks
text: Brad Quartuccio, editor of Urban Velo, a magazine that focuses on city cycling, tests locks in his day-to-day travels through Pittsburgh.

headline: Funny in the Summertime
text: A look at some of the shows that are drawing audiences to London theaters.

headline: So you want a romantic French wedding?
text: We all gawk at photos of lavish celebrity weddings in France of high watt couples like Eva Longoria who marched down the aisle with a bouquet of orchid stems at the Church of Sain Germain l’Auxerrois to marry Antonio Spurs point guard Tony Parker.

headline: Hollinger Files for Bankruptcy
text: Hollinger, the Canadian company that Conrad M. Black used to control his newspaper empire, filed for bankruptcy Wednesday and said it would explore options for the Sun-Times Media Group while facing payments on debt and shareholder suits.

headline: As Dow Jones Is Sold, CNBC Launches New Ads
text: Just in case Rupert Murdoch is wondering who watches CNBC – the business network that he plans to compete with this fall when he introduces a competitor, the Fox Business Network – a series of commercials starting Thursday will tell him.

headline: Options Backdating Rears Its Head Again
text: The government’s investigation of improperly dated stock options, which seemed quiet lately, is back in the headlines. The first chief executive caught up in the inquiry was sentenced Wednesday to five years of probation.

headline: Terra Firma Clinches EMI Deal
text: The private equity firm Terra Firma Capital Partners, run by the British financier Guy Hands, said Wednesday it had succeeded in its 2.4 billion pound ($4.9 billion) takeover of the music company EMI Group, garnering the 90 percent of shares needed to let it force out minority shareholders.

headline: Banks Said to Have Turned a Deaf Ear to Subprime Risks
text: Investment banks that bundle and sell home mortgages often commissioned reports showing growing risks in subprime loans to less creditworthy borrowers but did not pass on much of the information to credit rating agencies or investors, according to some of those who prepared the reports.

headline: Canaan Partners Leads Two Funding Rounds
text: Canaan Partners said it led a $10 million financing for Associated Content, marking the second funding announcement for a community journalism Web site in one week. Canaan, a venture firm based in Menlo Park, Calif., also said it led a $15 million funding round for EzRez Software, which makes online travel-reservation software.

headline: Crescent Investors Approve Morgan Stanley Buyout
text: Crescent Real Estate Equities said Wednesday that its shareholders overwhelmingly approved the sale of the company to Morgan Stanley Real Estate. At a morning shareholders meeting, 74 percent of the total shares outstanding voted in favor of the sale for $22.80 a share, Crescent said.

headline: Canadian Investment Firm Snags Hotel REIT
text: British Columbia Investment Management has struck a deal worth 1.2 billion Canadian dollars ($1.1 billion) to acquire the Canadian Hotel Income Properties Real Estate Investment Trust, offering 19.10 Canadian dollars per unit.

headline: Nasdaq Supports L.S.E. Bid for Italian Rival
text: The Nasdaq Stock Market said late Wednesday that it supports the London Stock Exchange‘s plans to acquire an Italian rival, Borsa Italiana.

headline: Landry’s in Talks Over Debt Refinancing
text: Landry’s Restaurants says it is negotiating with its bankers to replace $400 million in bond debt with bank debt.

headline: Bear Hit by Legal Claim Over Failed Hedge Funds
text: A day after two ailing Bear Stearns hedge funds filed for bankruptcy, the bank was slapped with a legal claim for allegedly misleading investors about the funds’ exposure to subprime mortgages, a lawyer for an investor said Wednesday.

headline: Cadbury Considers a Spinoff Amid Sale Doubts
text: Cadbury Schweppes said Thursday morning it is prepared to spin off its North American soft drinks business if the proposed 7 billion pound ($14 billion) sale is scuppered by turmoil in credit markets. The group made the announcement as it unveiled a fall in first-half profits.

headline: Marathon Settles Trading Case
text: Houston-based Marathon Oil, which on Tuesday agreed to buy Western Oil Sands of Canada for about $5.56 billion, will pay a $1 million fine to settle allegations it tried to manipulate oil prices in 2003.

headline: Advanced Medical Walks Away from Bausch Bid
text: Advanced Medical Optics on Wednesday withdrew its $4.23 billion unsolicited takeover bid for its rival eye-care company Bausch & Lomb, saying Bausch had put up unrealistic hurdles to a potential deal.

headline: Martha Stewart Said to Join GTCR on 2 Deals
text: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia is joining forces with a private-equity partner GTCR Golder Rauner, to buy food-crafting company Wilton Industries and a paint-by-number specialist, Dimension Holdings, The New York Post reported.

headline: V.C. Funding Down, Report Says
text: A new report from Dow Jones VentureOne reveals that venture firms in the United States have raised less capital during the first half of 2007 than in any other six-month period in almost four years.

headline: Schering-Plough Plans $2.5 Billion Offering
text: The pharmaceuticals maker Schering-Plough said Thursday it plans to sell 50 million common shares and $2.5 billion in mandatory convertible preferred stock in a public offering.

headline: Credit Suisse’s Profits Rise 48 Percent
text: Credit Suisse said second-quarter net income was up 48 percent from a year ago to 3.189 billion Swiss francs ($2.66 billion), well ahead of expectations, lifted by record earnings from investment banking and wealth management.

headline: Some Hedge Funds Slam Doors on Investors
text: Some hedge funds that have suffered losses on investments are closing the gate on clients who want to pull money out, a move that could further undermine confidence in already shaky financial markets. Hedge fund managers argue that by temporarily barring withdrawals, they are essentially protecting investors from themselves, by preventing sales of securities at deeply depressed prices.

headline: Barclays Posts Rise in Profit
text: Barclays, the British bank competing to buy ABN Amro, posted a 14 percent increase in first-half net income and said subprime mortgage defaults in the United States will not slow the investment bank this year.

headline: NYSE Euronext 2nd Quarter Profits Rise
text: NYSE Euronext reported Thursday a second-quarter profit that more than doubled, getting a boost from record trading on its European stock and derivatives markets.

headline: London Theater Journal: British Fear West End Turning Into (Shudder) Broadway
text: LONDON, Aug. 2 – Alarm-bell essays have appeared in The Times of London and The Guardian in recent days, warning of the imminent death of the proper play at the hands of the mega-musical. The argument is that bloated facsimiles of song-and-dance movies (“Dirty Dancing”), jukebox shows (a stage version of “Desperately Seeking Susan,” with the songs of Blondie, is on the horizon) and flash-filled American imports (“Wicked”) are becoming so dominant that the day is at hand when the West End will be little more than – oh, the horror, the horror – a British version of Broadway.

headline: Why Buyout Firms Won’t Walk Away
text: Wall Street underwriters these days are probably wishing that buyout firms would abandon some of their announced leveraged buyouts, rather than force the banks to find financing in troubled markets. But according to The Financial Times’ Lex column, there are lots of reasons why that won’t happen.

headline: Baseball’s Deal With StubHub: The Benefits of Big
text: Mostly, it seems that when start-ups get acquired by big companies, they lose whatever pluck and speed that made them successful enough to be bought in the first place.

headline: The Leaking of the Private Equity Bubble
text: While market conditions have worsened, hedge funds may continue to feel prolonged pain, but private equity probably will not — at least, not for some time. So while firms like Bear Stearns, Sowood Capital and Tudor Investment may see sudden losses in their profits, buyout firms should feel the pain only later on, Breakingviews argues.

headline: Tanglewood Festival: I Hear a Symphony (at Last)
text: Lenox, Mass. — Whatever doubts one might harbor about devoting a new-music festival almost entirely to composers born during a three-year period in the 1930’s, the quality of the works performed at this year’s Festival of Contemporary Music has been consistently high. That isn’t always a given: most years, memorable peaks are offset by troughs — although given the partisanship of the new-music world, listeners may disagree about which is which.

headline: Morning Buzz: Track Worker Deaths; Giuliani and Fox; Florida Abuse Case; and More
text: The deaths of two subway track workers — Marvin Franklin, 55, and Daniel Boggs, 41 — in April resulted mainly from flawed safety procedures and a lax “organizational culture,” in which track workers and supervisors flouted basic safety rules and failed to alert operators of oncoming trains to the presence of workers on the tracks, according to reports released yesterday by New York City Transit. William Neuman describes the reports as a “broad indictment” of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s safety practices.The report on Mr. Franklin’s death was particularly scathing, asserting that “organizational culture was such that critical safety rules were not practiced in day-to-day operations.” The workers failed to cover up the electrified third rail or set up warning lights, and a supervisor who had promised to act as a flagman, watching for trains, left his post. Moments later, Mr. Franklin was dragged under a train and killed, and his co-worker was seriously injured after he was pinned between the train and a wall [].

headline: The Side Deal in the Deal for Dow Jones
text: Many say the outcome of Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion move on Dow Jones & Company was inevitable. But some unusual side transactions along the way to this week’s agreement are raising questions about how the Bancroft family, which controls the company through a special class of shares, was persuaded to support the deal.

headline: Fiserv to Buy CheckFree for $4.4 Billion
text: Fiserv, an information manager for financial and insurance companies, said Thursday that it would buy CheckFree for $4.4 billion in cash. Fiserv will pay shareholders of the online banking and electronic payments company $48 a share.

headline: Quick Bits: Google’s Wireless Plans and a Merger Abandoned
text: Hot news for a hot day:

headline: Politics and the Poet Laureate
text: Charles Simic is the new Poet Laureate of the United States – or PLOTUS, to borrow the jolly acronym his predecessor, Donald Hall, liked to employ.

headline: 2008: Democrats Chart a Course
text: When the Democratic Leadership Council, a group made up of party moderates, wrapped up its annual meeting in Nashville earlier in the week having heard from none of the Democratic presidential candidates, many called it a “snub” — especially since the entire field is jetting off to Chicago this weekend to address a convention of liberal bloggers.

headline: Should Yahoo Try Again for Facebook?
text: Yahoo clearly wants a seat on the social-networking train. But how much should it spend for a ticket?

headline: Q & A: Houston Dynamo Coach Dominic Kinnear
text: It was a rare day off on Monday for Coach Dominic Kinnear and his defending M.L.S. champion Houston Dynamo.

headline: Ben Harper Croons About Barry Bonds
text: I spotted Ben Harper, dynamite musician and devoted Dodgers’ fan, in the concourse behind the first base box seats at Dodger Stadium on Wednesday night. I shook his hand and introduced myself.

headline: Edsall’s Got a Crush on Obama
text: Barack Obama’s speech outlining a muscular antiterrorism policy wasn’this “Sister Souljah moment,” says Thomas B. Edsall, political editor ofThe Huffington Post. But that’s only because Obama has already had atleast two Sister Souljah moments, Edsall suggests.

headline: Over-Equipped on the Links?
text: Jason Fagone argues in today’s newsletter that golfers who use the new, weird putters strip the game of one of its inherent challenges. Take it a step further: Has modern equipment altered the game for better, or worse, and why?

headline: Elton John Is Still Standing, but He’s Not Surfing the Net
text: There has been a bit of discussion lately about the sort of journalism Rupert Murdoch spawns. Here is a contribution from his London tabloid, The Sun, run under the byline of Sir Elton John.

headline: Embracing the CableCard
text: Oh, hallelujah and praise be to the F.C.C. On July 1, a new F.C.C ruling went into effect. It says that, as this Times article puts it, "cable companies now have to supply set-top boxes that come with a removable CableCard."

text: Updated, 6:07 p.m.

headline: When the News is the News
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Nitrogen and the Rapidly Dwindling Jamaica Bay Marshes
text: Out at Jamaica Bay, just a chip shot away from the runways at Kennedy International Airport, a battle is brewing between environmental groups and the city’s Department of Environmental Protection over just what is causing the bay’s marsh islands — tidal flats covered with marsh grass that are the lifeblood of all kinds of fish and birds — to wash away so fast that they could all be gone in as little as five years.An advisory committee put together by the City Council and the office of the mayor is today releasing a report [pdf] about the alarming rate of marshland loss — twice what it was just a few years ago. The committee, led by Brad Sewell of the Natural Resources Defense Council, said that many factors contribute to the disappearance: changing currents, sea level rise and overdevelopment around the fringes of the bay. (This shows the areas of marsh loss.) But the principal culprit, the committee said, is an excess of nitrogen from four municipal sewage treatment plants that ring the bay.

headline: Scotland Takes a Hard Line Against ‘Simulation’
text: Yesterday, the new chief executive of the Scottish FA announced a pilot project to use video review of a match to punish “simulation.” That’s diving (and the requisite writhing on the ground) in an effort to win a favorable call from the referee in which so many professional players seem to engage. Remember Rivaldo’s shameless play acting during the 2002 World Cup?

headline: A Thursday afternoon in Budapest
text: Busy day in sunny Budapest it was. The sweltering heat of recent weeks has faded into a balmy 29 degree Celsius, blue skied afternoon. But it seems rain is predicted for at least part of the weekend. Today the center of Budapest was a mess of traffic as the police closed off portions of the city to allow Gerhard Berger to drive an old McLaren while Tonio Liuzzi drove a Toro Rosso on the chain bridge. Lewis Hamilton did an event for Hungarian go-karters. We don’t know quite what his teammate Fernando Alonso did, since he was given permission by the FIA to skip the press conference but we were not told why.

headline: A Long Stay in New York, on a Budget
text: I am going to be staying in New York for six weeks later this year. Do you have any suggestions on where to stay for that long a period without breaking my wallet?

headline: YES Said to Be For Sale; Are Yanks on Deck?
text: The television network home of the Yankees may be on the block, according to a report on Thursday. The article also kicked up speculation about another deal — one that would likely be the biggest sale in professional sports.

headline: Bridge Collapse
text: A bridge loaded with rush-hour traffic dropped more than 60 feet into the Mississippi River on Wednesday night.

headline: Embracing the CableCard
text: Oh, hallelujah and praise be to the F.C.C. On July 1, a new F.C.C ruling went into effect. It says that, as this Times article puts it, “cable companies now have to supply set-top boxes that come with a removable CableCard.”

headline: Warning Signs for Republicans
text: The Democratic Party continues to hold a sizable advantage over the Republican Party on many major issues of the day, new polling suggests. While the Republican Party is still maintaining an edge on a few signature issues, the gap is closing on their advantage, according to the latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll.

text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Bridge Collapse: Day 2
Freddy Adu, ‘Happy and Proud’
text: Without having kicked a ball or broken a sweat, Freddy Adu said that his transformation is complete.

headline: Message from Time Warner: AOL Is Staying Put
text: Anyone hoping for a sign — even a hint — that Time Warner is considering a big, transformative deal probably went away disappointed after Wednesday’s earnings conference call.

headline: Not-So-Subtle Signs Promote Housing Projects
text: As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg continues to scoff at rumors of a 2008 presidential bid, at least one city entity seems keen on calling attention to his accomplishments. The scaffolding outside 426-428 East 11th Street, a five-story building under renovation in the East Village, features a giant red and yellow sign that shouts “HOUSING!” and, in smaller print below: “Brought to you by Mayor Bloomberg and HDC.”

headline: Before the Credit Crunch, a Timely Warning
text: In a June 18 commentary, Steven Rattner predicted that the market for high-yield corporate debt, the lifeblood of the leveraged buyout industry, was headed for a correction.

headline: Obama on the Use of Nuclear Weapons
text: In an interview with the Associated Press today, Barack Obama said he would not use nuclear weapons “in any circumstance” to fight terrorism in Afghanistan and Pakistan.

headline: There’s No Place Like Shea
text: Since joining the Mets, Luis Castillo has two hits in seven at-bats entering today’s game. Maybe he’ll start heating up when they return to Shea Stadium next week. According to Friend of Bats Trent McCotter of the Society for American Baseball Research, Castillo had the longest hitting streak (32 games) at a visiting ballpark by any player in the last 50 years. It ended earlier this season when he went hitless while playing for the Twins.

headline: The Weird Psychology of Security
text: This morning, the renowned security author and entrepreneur Bruce Schneier gave a fascinating talk  here at the annual Black Hat security conference in Las Vegas. Bruce is the guy I think about every time I go through airport security and am forced to surrender a nail clipper or take off my shoes. For years he has railed against what he calls “security theater,” measures that have no apparent benefit but supposedly make us all feel safer.

headline: A Pedro Martinez Update
text: The Mets will get their first look today at Brian Lawrence, recalled from Class AAA New Orleans to replace the banished-to-the-bullpen Jorge Sosa. Lawrence figures to stick with the team for a little while but with three consecutive Mondays off, the Mets can manipulate their rotation so that a) he doesn’t have to pitch every turn and, more importantly, b) make plans for the impending return of Pedro Martinez.

headline: How to Examine Gonzales
text: The Washington Post editorial page says Alberto Gonzales should not be impeached, nor should a special prosecutor be appointed to determine whether he perjured himself before the Senate Judiciary Committee though the editorial does add the caveat, “at least not yet.”

headline: New Laws Include Car Emission Labels and Tougher Littering Penalties
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the Legislature can’t agree on much these days, but the governor did manage to sign more than a hundred bills into law today, while vetoing 27.

headline: Moves in the Giuliani Camp
text: Two of the Giuliani campaign’s key fundraisers are taking on new roles, one moving to a more policy-oriented role and the other taking a lead in the effort to try and draw female supporters to the cause.

headline: Watch Out, Hamptons: Here Come the Clintons
text: Are you Hamptons-bound this weekend? So are Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, who will be attending several fund-raisers for her presidential campaign. The already hectic traffic scene will certainly be exacerbated by the Clintons’ motorcade and those of at least three other politicos holding events there this weekend: Rudolph W. Giuliani, Al Franken and Howard Dean.

headline: A Family Reunion
text: Legendary pianist Bebo Valdes, a Cuban exile, and his son Chucho, who still lives in Havana, recording together in Madrid. (Video: Carlos Carcas)

headline: Noted Mob Chronicler Becomes Part of the Story
text: When you’re one of the more prominent journalists in the city, covering one (or five) of the most dangerous organizations in the city, writing on one of the most hotly read topics in the city, you can sometimes become a public figure in your own right. It happens. It happened to Jerry Capeci, 63, the chronicler of Mafia life and foibles in his column Gang Land News, published online and in The New York Sun. He was in court facing a judge today.

headline: Message From Time Warner: AOL Is Staying Put
text: Anyone hoping for a sign — even a hint — that Time Warner is considering a big, transformative deal probably went away disappointed after Wednesday’s earnings conference call.

headline: Transit Chief Calls for Change in Safety Attitudes
text: New York City Transit has released two damning reports on the accidental deaths in April of two subway track workers, Daniel Boggs, 41, and Marvin Franklin, 55. The reports reveal a safety system so flawed that it is easy to come away with the impression that serious accidents are almost inevitable. That impression is deepened by the description in the reports of a broken safety culture among workers and supervisors, who routinely ignore basic precautions.The Boggs and Franklin reports are available as PDF files.

text: Yahoo clearly wants a seat on the social-networking train. But how much should it spend for a ticket?

headline: Answers From the Waterfront Expert, Part 2
text: Following is the second set of responses from Carter Craft of the Metropolitan Waterfront Alliance, who is taking questions from City Room readers this week. Readers are invited to submit additional questions here.

headline: Democrats Hunting Fox, Again
text: As the Democratic candidates seek to ingratiate themselves upon the netroots at the YearlyKos convention in Chicago this weekend, Rupert Murdoch’s whole taking-over-the-second-most-circulated-newspaper-in-the-country-thing gives them a convenient news peg for their attacks against the media mogul and his oft-maligned medium, Fox News Channel.

headline: G.O.P. Continues Minneapolis Meeting
text: Updated: The Republican National Committee says it plans to go ahead with its summer meeting in Minneapolis over the next few days although with a revised schedule. Earlier today, Tracey Schmitt, a spokeswoman for the R.N.C., said the schedule was “in flux” after yesterday’s highway bridge collapse.

headline: Accredited Says It Might File for Bankruptcy
text: Accredited Home Lenders, a subprime mortgage lender that agreed in June to be acquired by a private equity firm, said its survival is in doubt and that bankruptcy is possible, sending its shares down as much as 52.5 percent.

headline: Blogtalk: MetroCard Slobs; Wild Dogs of Red Hook; Freedom Tower Lobby; Dorothy Parker Trial; and More
text: What we’re reading on the local blogs…

headline: Carlsen Wins Biel on Tie-Break Over Onischuk
text: Magnus Carlsen of Norway has won the Biel International Chess Festival tournament after beating Alexander Onischuk of the United States in the fifth tie-breaker game. Carlsen trailed Onischuk and Teimour Radjabov of Azerbaijan by half a point going into the ninth round, but he smashed Radjabov while Onischuk could only manage a draw against Alexander Motylev of Russia. The games can be replayed at the tournament’s official Web site.

headline: Taking Aim Again at Graffiti Tools
text: Six months after a federal appellate court struck down a New York City antigraffiti ordinance, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a new and more narrowly tailored version of the law today, hoping that it will pass constitutional muster.

headline: Russia’s North Pole Obsession
text: The Russian mini-sub foray to the sea floor more than 14,000 feet beneath the crust of floating, shifting sea ice at the North Pole — which left behind a titanium Russian flag, according to the official statements — is just the latest in a decades-long chain of efforts aimed at making Russia the dominant power in the Arctic.

headline: Following the Minneapolis Bridge Collapse
text: Searching for the best sources on the Bridge collapse around the Web. The full story from The Times is here.

headline: A Righteous E-Mail Battle
text: A little e-mail battle brewing over the past few days between Senator Sam Brownback of Kansas and Mike Huckabee, the former governorof Arkansas, is escalating into an endless Punch-and-Judy show. And like spellbound children, we’re captivated by every volley.

headline: To Catch a Falling Knife
text: Lone Star Funds, a private equity operation, prides itself on its ability to figure out when markets have overreacted and driven down prices to unreasonable levels. In June, it stepped in to buy Accredited Home Lenders, a troubled sub-prime mortgage lender. (Is that redundant?)

headline: Art Underground
text: Images of New York subway mosaics from the Squire Vickers era.

headline: Fatigue Cracking Suspected on Bridge
text: Repeated stress may have been a major cause of the bridge collapse in  Minnesota.  Investigators do not know if annual tests were done properly.

headline: New York Bridges in Focus
text: The bridge disaster in Minneapolis has prompted officials in New York City and elsewhere to look again at their infrastructure.

headline: Clinton and the Bloggers
text: CHICAGO – We’re at the second annual YearlyKos convention, where liberal bloggers have convened with excitement that almost all the Democratic presidential candidates are courting them in person on Saturday.

headline: Belize Dreams
text: Today’s article on Belize in the IHT spotlights Placencia, one of the fastest growing areas in the former British Honduras. A 45-minute flight from Belize City, Placencia is gateway to some of the country’s wildest attractions, including a jaguar reserve and Blue Hole, a famous dive spot.

headline: Aging Bonds Gets Help in Outfield From Davis
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2  Four coaches for the San Francisco Giants sipped beers and looked drained in the clubhouse after a numbing loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers on Wednesday night. Giants Manager Bruce Bochy drank a beer in his office, too. Barry Bonds, who is still chasing history, was one of the first players to leave the exasperating scene.

text: POP

headline: Being Old, Then and Now
text: Last week, while driving from a campaign event in Keene, N.H., I stumbled upon a used bookstore that I hadn’t seen since I was a teenager. I stopped in  even though I was rushing to catch a plane  and came upon a sad book published anonymously in 1911.

headline: French President Chooses U.S. for His Summer Vacation
text: BOSTON, Aug. 2 — President Nicolas Sarkozy of France will not be traipsing through the lavender fields of Provence or sunning himself on the Riviera on holiday this year.

headline: Subway Deaths Raise Questions on the Selection of Supervisors
text: After the deaths of two workers on the subway tracks, New York City Transit officials are grappling with a hard question: Are they putting the right people in charge of work crews underground?

headline: No Hate Required for Hate Crime in Gay Man’s Death, Judge Rules
text: Three men arrested in the death of a gay man who was beaten and then struck by a car during an October robbery attempt can be charged with hate crimes without evidence that they were motivated by hatred for gay men, a judge ruled yesterday.

headline: Hedge Funds Are Not Profiting From Market’s Current Volatility
text: WARREN E. BUFFETT once said when the tide goes out, you find out who is naked. There is suddenly a lot of skin showing on Wall Street.

headline: Time for Insight or Your Chakras
text: WHEN the unanswered e-mail messages are well into double digits, you can no longer tell the difference between the kids’ and the dog’s toys, and twice-weekly yoga classes barely make a dent, it may be time to escape to a wellness festival.

headline: Clinton-Obama Tensions Spill Into the Senate
text: They work in the same building. They slog through the same rigorous travel schedule. Along the way, they often cross paths several times a day.

headline: Toyota Builds on Streak of Record Earnings
text: TOKYO, Aug. 3 -- Toyota Motor reported a 32 percent rise in quarterly profits on Friday, continuing a streak of record earnings as the Japanese car company seeks to widen its lead over General Motors as the world’s largest automaker.

headline: Stunned Victim Turns Hero
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 2 — By the time they reached the Interstate 35W bridge, the children on the bus were waterlogged and serene, some still in their bathing suits, ready to go home. It was a rare moment of quiet, and as the bus crossed over the Mississippi River a few of the counselors, barely out of adolescence themselves, had dropped off to sleep in their seats.

headline: A Promising Day for Martínez
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Aug. 2 — Pedro Martínez took the mound in a simulated game Thursday morning at Tradition Field expecting to throw about 45 pitches in his bid to return to the Mets this season. He ended up throwing 67 and saying the process proved therapeutic.

headline: Theater Listings

headline: Ex-Wall St. Executives Go to Bat to Help Nonprofits
text: An organization founded by two former Goldman Sachs partners is using Wall Street methods to help charities raise money to finance expansion.

headline: Fall Down, Go Boom, Get Paid. Then Teach Others How.
text: High above the ground, one man crashed a beer bottle over the head of another man, sending him tumbling 35 feet. Nearby, a third man went crashing down a flight of stairs.

headline: Beyond the Turnstile
text: “Architects of the New York City Subway, Part II: Squire Vickers and the Subway’s Modern Age,” featuring artwork by Squire J. Vickers, will run through Oct. 28 at the New York Transit Museum, Gallery Annex and Store, adjacent to station master’s office, Grand Central Terminal, (212) 878-0106; mta.info\museum. Open Mondays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 8 p.m., and Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission is free.

headline: Suspended Spitzer Assistant Is Blameless, His Lawyer Says
text: ALBANY, Aug. 2  Darren Dopp, the top aide to Gov. Eliot Spitzer who was at the center of an effort to tarnish Mr. Spitzer’s chief political rival, emerged on Thursday as his lawyer lashed out at Republicans and accused Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of rushing to judgment.

headline: Tommy Makem, 74, Hero of Irish Folk Music, Dies
text: Tommy Makem, a songwriter, balladeer and folk singer who with the Clancy Brothers and as a soloist introduced a raucous, revolutionary take on time-honored Irish folk music, first in the United States and then in Ireland, died Wednesday in Dover, N.H. He was 74.

headline: Tender Hearts and Lip-Gloss Dreams
text: Arriving as inevitably as puberty, “Bratz” introduces the swollen-headed, fashion-addicted dolls of the title to a live-action movie and an even more prominent position in the tweener universe. In human form, however, their craniums appear normal, giving no indication of the acres of retail space within.

headline: Spaying Animals (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Italy Plans to Drop Civil Lawsuit Against Getty

headline: Cloak-and-Dagger in All Its Charm
text: There weren’t a lot of gun battles during the cold war, and the targets were judiciously selected. “Only the ones in uniform,” one C.I.A. agent says to another as they crouch on a Berlin rooftop in 1954 and fire shots at enemies a building away. The K.G.B. man among them is off limits. “They don’t shoot at us,” the agent says, “we don’t shoot at them.”

headline: A Little Girl in the Eye of Her Family’s Political Storms
text: Julie Gavras’s wonderful film, “Blame It on Fidel,” is a deeply political movie that sidesteps strident polemics by viewing the ideological conflicts within a French-Spanish family through the eyes of a smart, willful child. As the daily life of 9-year-old Anna (Nina Kervel) is drastically revised after her parents, Fernando and Marie de la Mesa, suddenly become radicals, she resists change with the ferocious determination of a youngster who is told that she must part with her favorite toys.

headline: Newspaper Editor Is Killed in Possible ‘Targeted’ Attack
text: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 2 — The editor of a prominent African-American newspaper here was killed on a downtown street Thursday morning in an attack the police described as “targeted.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on July 18 about a wake for Russel Timoshenko, a New York police officer fatally shot when he and his partner stopped a suspicious vehicle in Brooklyn, misstated his age at the time he immigrated with his family from Belarus. (The error first appeared in articles in some copies on July 13 and 15.) He was 9, not 7.

headline: White House Aide Won’t Answer Questions of a Senate Panel
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 — J. Scott Jennings, a 29-year-old White House aide, refused repeatedly on Thursday to answer questions before the Senate Judiciary Committee, saying he was under orders from President Bush not to respond.

headline: Our Wit-Lit Heroine Avoids Marrying a Juiceless Man
text: How do you explain the Jane Austen bandwagon, which rolls on full steam with “Becoming Jane,” an imitation screen adaptation of an Austen-like novel that imagines the author’s romantic life at 20? Austen’s refined language, which Sarah Williams and Kevin Hood’s screenplay does a reasonably good job of capturing, is part of the charm. In the age of “whatever,” who doesn’t relish receiving a scrupulously considered, grammatically correct answer to a question?

headline: Blind Man’s Dark Paradise, Laid to Waste by the Gift of Sight
text: The Iranian director Majid Majidi’s sad, soulful film “The Willow Tree” is his second movie to explore blindness and sight on multiple levels. Its heartbreaking 1999 forerunner, “The Color of Paradise,” focused on the desperately lonely but strangely happy existence of Mohammad, a blind 8-year-old whose widowed father reluctantly abandons him to the care of a rural carpenter, then vanishes. “The Willow Tree” examines the traumatic shocks experienced by a blind professor of literature whose eyesight is miraculously restored.

headline: A Clinic Conducted in Shadows
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 — Eleven-year-old Danny Casas sat on the outfield grass at Dodger Stadium on Thursday afternoon, listening to a team of experts tell him that steroids could make him violent, depressed, suicidal, ugly and bald.

headline: Morgan Settles a Bias Suit
text: Morgan Stanley has agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit that accused it of unfair treatment of black and Latino employees in the retail brokerage division since 2002.

headline: Brass: Roll It, Spin It or Stamp It, to Suit Your Fancy
text: One of the small, must-see shows this summer is “A Brass Menagerie” at the Bard Graduate Center. It will make you smile.

headline: Bottled Water or Tap? It Matters (8 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Easley Wins 90-Foot Dash on Inside-the-Park Homer
text: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 2 — Damion Easley considers himself a spry 37-year-old, but as he rounded third base in the sixth inning Thursday, less than 90 feet from legging out an inside-the-park home run, he had only one thought on his mind.

headline: Viacom Profit Down Despite Solid Revenue
text: The media company Viacom posted better-than-expected revenue for the second quarter yesterday as advertising income rose, but earnings fell slightly because of a tax gain in the period a year ago.

headline: At Saratoga, Top Racing, Stately Homes and Spa Waters
text: SARATOGA Race Course, second row of bench seats in front of its fairy tale of a grandstand: A boy and a girl, probably between 6 and 9 years old, were bookending their father. Dressed in khakis and a dark pink Tommy Hilfiger polo shirt, the fortyish man studied the day's race schedule in The Times Union in Albany.

headline: An Ocean of Air
text: As a metaphor for absence and nothingness, air has performed admirably for centuries. It has pulled off one of the great con jobs in human history, concealing endless complexities behind its bland, transparent facade. Layer by layer, from the ionosphere to the Earth’s surface, Gabrielle Walker exposes the Earth’s atmosphere for what it is, a restless, electrically charged, dynamic superhero, entrusted with the sacred mission of protecting our planet, nurturing life and even, when looked at from a certain angle, making love possible.

headline: Anger Is Tempering Sympathy for South Korean Hostages
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 2  As the South Korean hostage crisis entered its third week, sympathy here for the 21 people remaining in Taliban captivity in Afghanistan has been tempered by anger over their decision to travel to such a dangerous region.

headline: Gates Offers Blunt Review of Progress in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Thursday that he was discouraged by the resignation of the Sunnis from Iraq’s cabinet and that the Bush administration might have misjudged the difficulty of achieving reconciliation between Iraq’s sectarian factions.

headline: At Bridge Site, Search of River Moves Slowly
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 2 — A day after the deadly collapse of the most heavily traversed bridge in Minnesota, fierce currents and giant, unsteady shards of steel and concrete slowed divers Thursday in their search of the Mississippi River for people still missing and feared dead.

headline: Building Starts on Plant to Convert Plutonium
text: AIKEN, S.C., Aug. 1 — Construction began here this week on a factory to turn plutonium recycled from nuclear weapons into fuel for civilian power reactors, a swords-to-plowshares concept first seriously proposed more than a decade ago.

headline: Bush Sends Warning Meant for Syria: Don’t Meddle in Lebanon
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  President Bush said Thursday that the United States would freeze the property and assets of anyone trying to undermine Lebanon’s democratically elected government  a move intended as a sharp warning to Syria and its ally Hezbollah.

headline: Home Run Drudgery Is Soporific
text: Amazing what can happen at a baseball game when you are waiting — and as Ray Davies once sang, “So tired, tired of waiting” — for one specific player to hit a milestone home run.

headline: Who Knew Carrying Out a Civic Duty Could Be So Tricky?
text: The current presidential contest looks as if it’s going to be pretty lively, but it’ll have to go some to be more entertaining than “Election Day,” an outrageous comedy by Josh Tobiessen, featuring a couple of remember-the-name performances from a young cast.

headline: Without Cash, Instant Profits Were No Help
text: The problem faced by American Home Mortgage Investment in the weeks before it collapsed was aptly summarized 134 years ago by Walter Bagehot, the English journalist:

headline: Talking About Relaxing Works for Rodriguez
text: Flashbulbs popped on a humid afternoon each time a pitch approached Alex Rodriguez’s wheelhouse. In some ways, he had a decent day, breaking out of a career-worst 0-for-21 slump, hitting two singles, scoring once and knocking in a run. But Rodriguez failed for the seventh consecutive full game to hit his 500th career home run. He did not even come close.

headline: Driver in Glasgow Airport Attack Dies From His Burns
text: LONDON, Aug. 2  An Indian-born aerospace engineer who the British authorities say drove a burning Jeep Cherokee into a terminal at Glasgow Airport in a botched terrorism attack died Thursday night in a hospital in Scotland, the police said.

headline: Skateboarding’s Mega Ramp Is a Draw, but Also a Danger
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 — At 62 feet tall and 293 feet long, the Mega Ramp is so massive that its events may be among the few spectacles held in the Staples Center for which the best seats are those farthest from the floor, in the arena’s upper deck. From any closer it is almost impossible to take in the full scope of the setup.

headline: A Look at the Fund-Raising of a G.O.P. Noncandidate
text: When former Senator Fred D. Thompson began testing the waters this spring for a run for the Republican presidential nomination, he sparked heated speculation about just where his financial backing might come from.

headline: EUROPE | Italy: Insurer’s Income Tops Estimates
text: Assicurazioni Generali, Italy’s largest insurer, reported first-half profit that beat analysts’ estimates and agreed to sell its Nuova Tirrena unit for 1.25 billion euros ($1.71 billion). Net income advanced to 1.78 billion euros from 1.4 billion euros a year earlier, the company said. Generali’s first-half operating result from its Italian life insurance business rose 14 percent, to 979 million euros, as the company made a greater proportion of its premiums from its proprietary sales network. Gross domestic life insurance premiums fell 10 percent, to 8.35 billion euros, as bank sales dropped 34 percent. Generali, based in Trieste, Italy, is considering acquisitions abroad as the Italian life insurance market contracts, and it will use funds from the sale of Nuova Tirrena, a car insurer, to expand internationally.

headline: Son of Falsely Convicted Man Seeks More of Award
text: BOSTON, Aug. 3 — Lawyers are asking a judge to increase the amount of the award given to Edward Greco, the son of one of four men the government has been ordered to pay $101.8 million for falsely convicting them of a 1965 gangland murder.

headline: Man Killed by Gas Fumes After Electricity Is Cut Off
text: MASTIC BEACH, N.Y., Aug. 2  A 19-year-old Long Island man was killed Thursday and seven members of his family were sickened when a gasoline-powered generator they were using because their power had been shut off for nonpayment spewed carbon monoxide fumes into their home, the authorities said.

headline: Some Restaurant Chains Still Serve Too Much Trans Fat, Group Says
text: More than a month after the deadline for city restaurants to stop preparing food with artificial trans fat, some fast-food chains are still serving French fries with high amounts of it, a nutrition advocacy group said yesterday.

headline: Nugent Is Hoping to Build on Last Season’s Success
text: HEMPSTEAD, N. Y., Aug. 2 — The goal posts were 57 yards away, but they were within range for Mike Nugent. During a sultry Thursday morning at Jets practice, Nugent broke the monotony by kicking the ball between the uprights and ending a two-minute drill.

headline: Shining Light on Inner Lives to Explore Them on the Stage
text: The duo behind Diquis Tiquis, a company from Costa Rica, makes for an odd pair. At first, Alejandro Tosatti, lanky like a rag doll with gloomy features seemingly etched from an Edward Gorey drawing, appears worlds apart from Sandra Trejos, whose earthy fluidity and mane of dark curls embody voluptuous warmth. Oddly, they fit together like bookends.

headline: A Cultured Retreat in the Shadow of the Seven Sisters
text: IN 1933, a radical arts academy opened in a remote valley about 15 miles east of Asheville, N.C. Simply called Black Mountain College, after the town where it was built, the school was founded by John A. Rice, a maverick educator who sought to create a sort of paradise for painting, architecture, sculpture and the liberal arts in the heart of Depression-era Appalachia.

headline: At Hussein Grave, Legend Lives as Fury Simmers
text: AWJA, Iraq — The grave site has a forlorn, even jumbled air. There are filigreed inscriptions hailing him as a martyr, as a hero of the insurgency and as “the eagle of the Arabs,” his favorite sobriquet. But alongside these there is the mundane bric-a-brac of his life — a carved wooden eagle hung with his personal prayer beads, and a gallery of informal photographs, one showing him with a cigar.

headline: Creating a Myth With Canvas and Paint
text: Until his death from tuberculosis in 1857, at the age of 44, William Ranney was among the liveliest and most beloved suppliers of homespun imagery of the hazards and romance of the American West. But after the Civil War he fell out of sight as tastes changed and that kind of work was no longer fashionable.

headline: A First Step to Save Darfur
text: The United Nations Security Council has at last taken a meaningful step toward stopping the genocide in Sudan’s Darfur region, authorizing a joint United Nations-African Union peacekeeping force to begin operations this fall. With 26,000 soldiers and police officers, it will be the world’s largest peacekeeping effort.

headline: In Cultural Haven, Cubans Need Not Choose Sides
text: MADRID — This is surely not the only city in the world where a handful of Cubans can spend a day together and avoid talking politics. But it is certainly the preferred one for Cuban artists and intellectuals of all political stripes, who find the freedom here that they could never have in Havana and the opportunities that may elude them in Miami, both polarizing cities in the endless debate about Fidel Castro and the nature of exile.

headline: Lawyer Seeks Mental Testing of Suspect in J.F.K. Case
text: The lawyer for a former air cargo worker charged in a plot to detonate fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport asked a federal judge yesterday to allow a psychological examination of the man to determine his “intellectual limitations.”

headline: A Question Recurs: How Safe Is Las Vegas?
text: LAS VEGAS, Aug. 2 — The morning after a gunman opened fire inside the New York-New York Hotel-Casino a month ago, Sylvia Cunningham, a tourist from Dallas, received two text messages from her mother urging her to cut short her annual six-day trip to Las Vegas.

headline: Senate Passes Children’s Health Bill, 68-31
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 — The Senate defied President Bush on Thursday and passed a bipartisan bill that would provide health insurance for millions of children in low-income families.

headline: European Bank Signals September Rate Rise
text: FRANKFURT, Aug. 2 — The European Central Bank signaled Thursday that it would raise interest rates in September to curb inflation amid an expanding economy. Its president, Jean-Claude Trichet, also vowed to pay “great attention” to volatile developments in global financial markets.

headline: Russians Plant Flag on the Arctic Seabed
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 2 — A Russian expedition descended in a pair of submersible vessels more than two miles under the ice cap on Thursday and deposited a Russian flag on the seabed at the North Pole. The dive was a symbolic move to enhance the government’s disputed claim to nearly half of the floor of the Arctic Ocean and potential oil or other resources there.

headline: Put Out This Tobacco Bill
text: Washington

headline: Where a Literary Couple Catch Their Breath Down the Shore
text: GAY TALESE never learned to swim and only occasionally ventures onto the beach. The wind makes it impossible for him to read the newspaper and, he said, during a recent visit to his second home in Ocean City, N.J., “I’m not going to sit on the sand swatting flies.”

headline: A Family Torn Apart by Deception, Betrayal and War
text: Of all the wounds inflicted by modern guerrilla war, the one that leaves perhaps the deepest emotional scars is that of families torn apart by conflicting loyalties, replacing familial love and faith with suspicion and mistrust. In “Masked,” a powerful play by Ilan Hatsor at the DR2 Theater, three Palestinian brothers are locked in a life-and-death struggle over issues of deception and betrayal.

headline: Within Discredited Stem Cell Research, a True Scientific First
text: The world of stem cell research was set reeling two years ago when its most successful practitioner, the Korean scientist Hwang Woo Suk, was found to have fabricated much of his work. But according to a new post-mortem of his research, he did achieve a scientific first, though not the one he claimed.

headline: New Rules on Bridge Construction to Begin Soon
text: In October, the federal government will begin enforcing new rules for highway bridge design meant to make new structures more efficient, more reliable, safer and longer lived — and implicitly better than hundreds of thousands of existing spans across the nation.

headline: The Profane Before the Sacred
text: With “The Ten,” David Wain uses the Ten Commandments the way a suicide uses a bridge. Stringing together a series of stone-tablet-based short films — from the gross to the surreal to the certifiably nuts — Mr. Wain, the writer and director of “Wet Hot American Summer,” repeats his strategy of aiming low and trusting in the higher power of genitalia.

headline: House Votes to Ensure Leave for Forces in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 — The House voted on Thursday to limit how quickly American troops can be sent back to Iraq after serving a rotation there, in the Democrats’ latest challenge to Bush administration war policy.

headline: With Starrett City Deal Nearly Dead, Developer Tries Again
text: Only days before the expiration of his $1.3 billion contract to buy a sprawling Brooklyn housing complex, David Bistricer is throwing the real estate equivalent of a Hail Mary pass.

headline: Kandy-Colored Dot-Flake Streamline Maverick
text: Peter Young’s art is a blast from the past that singes the present. His almost-major career, which flourished during the fashionably mythic late 1960s and early ’70s, has been drifting just out of reach for decades, a tantalizing medley of dotted, stained, gridded and geometric paintings, rarely seen but not forgotten.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Tales by Baghdad Diarist Are True, Magazine Says
text: In a note online, The New Republic said it had confirmed that all the anecdotes reported by the Baghdad Diarist, an American soldier in Iraq writing under a pseudonym for the magazine, had been investigated and confirmed. Conservatives writing at The Weekly Standard online and elsewhere had questioned whether the cruel incidents recounted by the diarist, Pvt. Scott T. Beauchamp, had occurred. “We spoke with five other members of Beauchamp’s company, and all corroborated Beauchamp’s anecdotes,” as did other sources contacted, the statement said. The one inaccuracy, it said, was that a conversation mocking a disfigured woman turned out to have occurred at Camp Buehring in Kuwait, before the unit’s arrival in Iraq.

headline: American Home Mortgage Says It Will Close
text: American Home Mortgage Investment, the troubled mortgage lender based in Melville, N.Y., will close today, making it the latest company to fail this year as loans made to home buyers, some even with solid credit histories, go bad.

headline: Nortel Loses $37 Million as Sales Falter
text: The Nortel Networks Corporation, the biggest maker of telecommunications equipment in North America, posted a second-quarter loss of $37 million yesterday on declining sales to phone companies.

headline: Comforting Words for a Nerve-Wracked Nation: ‘McGarrett. Five-0.’
text: In 1968, one of those awful years for which the term “hell in a handbasket” was invented, a war-weary, riot-torn nation gave its heart to a cerebral man of action with a passion for law and its elusive partner, order.

headline: Congress Is Getting Ready to Debate Energy Bill
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 — This was to have been the year that that Congress finally took meaningful action to address the related problems of energy dependence and global warming. The new Democratic majority vowed to make these issues a top priority, President Bush spoke of ending America’s addiction to imported oil and industry groups promised to do their share to build a cleaner and more efficient future.

headline: Judge Backs C.I.A. in Suit on Memoir
text: Valerie Wilson may be the best known former intelligence operative in recent history, but a federal judge in New York ruled Wednesday that she was not allowed to say how long she worked for the Central Intelligence Agency in the memoir she plans to publish this fall.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on July 7 about the popularity of 100-calorie packages of snack foods misstated the annual sales figure for such products. It is $200 million a year, not $20 million. (Go to Article)

headline: Survivor Recounts Terrifying Plunge
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Thuy T. Vo, 26, was stopped in traffic midway across the Interstate 35W bridge here on Wednesday evening when it collapsed into the Mississippi River.

headline: Evacuees Return After Vast Fires in Canary Islands
text: MADRID, Aug. 2  Residents and officials in Spain’s Canary Islands on Thursday were surveying the charred aftermath of devastating forest fires that raged across the archipelago in recent days, burning homes and destroying thousands of acres of pine forest that are home to some of the islands’ unique wildlife.

headline: Job Growth in July Is the Slowest in Months
text: The job market lost some of its punch last month as employers added 92,000 jobs  the fewest in five months, the Labor Department said today. In a further sign that hiring has slackened somewhat, the government also reported that the unemployment rate edged up last month to 4.6 percent from 4.5 percent.

headline: Unilever to Cut 20,000 Jobs
text: LONDON, Aug. 2 — Unilever, the maker of Dove soap, Vaseline cream and Knorr soup, said on Thursday that it plans to cut 20,000 jobs over the next four years to speed up a recovery program aimed at narrowing the gap with Procter & Gamble.

headline: Estimate of Missing Is Lowered in Bridge Collapse
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 3 — An official estimate of the number of people still missing after the collapse of a highway bridge over the Mississippi River fell sharply today to as few as eight, as divers continued to search the water for more bodies.

headline: For Young Earners in Big City, a Gap in Women’s Favor
text: Young women in New York and several of the nation’s other largest cities who work full time have forged ahead of men in wages, according to an analysis of recent census data.

headline: ‘Dream’ Performance Is Canceled
text: The first preview of the Public Theater’s Shakespeare in the Park production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” scheduled for Tuesday night at the Delacorte Theater, has been canceled because of the director Daniel Sullivan’s injuries from an accident on the set this week. The previews will begin on Wednesday.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: People in the News
text: People

headline: The Utopia of Sharing in Oneida, N.Y.
text: THEY wanted to create a heaven on earth. For 33 years they believed they’d succeeded, at a utopian commune infamous for “free love.”

headline: In London, Pirates of the Coliseum, With an Imperial Majesty
text: LONDON, Aug. 2 — What’s the connection between “Pirates of the Caribbean” and 19th-century choreography? Answer: The old ballet called “Le Corsaire” (“corsair” = “pirate”).

headline: Stampeding Congress, Again
text: Since the 9/11 terrorist attacks, the Bush administration has repeatedly demonstrated that it does not feel bound by the law or the Constitution when it comes to the war on terror. It cannot even be trusted to properly use the enhanced powers it was legally granted after the attacks.

headline: Underground Renaissance Man: Watch the Aesthetic Walls, Please
text: IF you’re looking for ways to wax poetic about the New York City subway and the vast planning that went into building it, Ibsen and Shakespeare may not be the first authors who leap to mind, especially as August settles its annual swelter on the tourist-packed platforms. Kafka maybe? Beckett? Dante? De Sade?

headline: Never Pick a Fight With a Washing Machine
text: “Hot Rod” might be called the poor man’s “Eagle vs. Shark” if “Eagle vs. Shark” were not already the poor man’s “Napoleon Dynamite.” It certainly lacks the conceptual purity and aesthetic integrity of the “Jackass” movies. In any case poor certainly describes the quality of the filmmaking. Directed by Akiva Schaffer from an improvisation-enhanced script by Pam Brady, “Hot Rod” is unapologetically, almost proudly crummy looking, as though paying tribute with its sloppy framing and clumsy editing to the goofy, half-baked quality of its hero’s stunts.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Eye Infections From Solution Continuing to Harm Users
text: More than a fourth of the contact lens users who suffered serious eye infections linked to Advanced Medical Optics’ recalled Complete MoisturePlus lens cleaner have required corneal transplants, according to an update on the outbreak released yesterday by federal health care authorities.

headline: Still Searching, but With Darker Eyes
text: Jaw clenched, brow knotted, body tight as a secret, Matt Damon hurtles through “The Bourne Ultimatum” like a missile. He’s a man on a mission, our Matt, and so too is his character, Jason Bourne, the near-mystically enhanced superspy who, after losing his memory and all sense of self, has come to realize that he has also lost part of his soul. For Bourne, who rises and rises again in this fantastically kinetic, propulsive film, resurrection is the name of the game, just as it is for franchises. This is the passion of Jason Bourne, with a bullet.

headline: Sergei Antonov, 59, Bulgarian Accused in Plot to Kill a Pope, Is Dead
text: Sergei Antonov, a key figure in the so-called Bulgarian connection in the plot to assassinate Pope John Paul II in 1981, was found dead in his apartment in Sofia, Bulgaria, on Wednesday. He was 59.

headline: An Old Ski Town Faces the March of the Wine Bar
text: NOT long ago, Mammoth Lakes, Calif., was the kind of place where night life might involve hanging out in the condo-village game room and pumping quarters into the Elvira-Mistress of the Dark pinball machine. Its sleepy assemblage of shingled mini-malls, bait and tackle shops and Alpine-style motels was clustered in a small downtown, and a few cabins and vacation houses were on the outskirts. At 7,800 feet near the Sierra Nevada’s eastern edge, it drew visitors mostly for the skiing — Mammoth Mountain averages close to 400 inches of snow a year.

headline: For 2 Suspects in Killings, Records of Repeat Offenses
text: WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 2  One of two men accused of burglarizing the home of a Connecticut woman and killing her and her two daughters told the authorities that he used to steal money and electronics from upscale homes to feed his crystal methamphetamine habit, while the other violated his parole after failing a drug test and once escaped from detention, according to parole files released on Thursday.

headline: Sorenstam Gets Helpful Text From Woods
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 2  Fifteen minutes after Annika Sorenstam teed off in the first round of the Women’s British Open, Lorena Ochoa signed off on her six-under-par 67.

headline: Marine Is Guilty of Unpremeditated Murder of an Iraqi Man
text: A Marine Corps squad leader was found guilty yesterday of killing an Iraqi man whom he and several other service members abducted last year while searching for an insurgent leader who lived nearby.

headline: Is the Dance Over? Citigroup Is Upbeat
text: Charles O. Prince III cannot catch a break.

headline: Rice Backs Appointed Palestinian Premier and Mideast Democracy
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Aug. 2 — Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, embracing an appointed Palestinian prime minister here in the West Bank, said Thursday that the United States still supported democracy in the Middle East. But she defended the American refusal to recognize the earlier, elected, Hamas-led government.

headline: Stocks Fall Sharply Amid Credit Fears
text: Stocks tumbled today on fears that the worsening ills in the mortgage and debt markets could soon take a significant toll on consumers, businesses and the overall economy.

headline: What’s in a Name? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Test for Democrats
text: It’s been a good Democrats, bad Democrats kind of week. The bill expanding children’s health insurance that just passed in the House makes you want to stand up and cheer. Reports that Senator Charles Schumer opposes plans to close the hedge fund tax loophole make you want to sit down and cry.

headline: Ford Moving Closer to Sale of Car Units
text: The Ford Motor Company, which sold its Aston Martin sports car brand in March, would like to be rid of its Land Rover and Jaguar operations by the end of the summer, and Volvo by the time winter arrives.

headline: Martínez Stays Cool Under Hot Florida Sun
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Aug. 2  Pedro Martínez took the mound in a simulated game Thursday morning at Tradition Field expecting to throw about 45 pitches in his bid to return to the Mets this season. He ended up throwing 67 and said the process proved therapeutic.

headline: Court Rules Against F.B.I. in Raid on Lawmaker
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 — Representative William Jefferson, the Louisiana Democrat under indictment on corruption charges, won a partial victory in court today as an appellate tribunal ruled that federal agents went too far when they searched his office last year.

headline: Fighting Addiction, on a Variety of Fronts
text: ONCE one accepts the premise that addictions are as unique as snowflakes or thumbprints, the addiction confessed by Karen M. Carpenter-Palumbo, commissioner of the New York State Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Services, seems practically legitimate.

headline: Growing Pains for a Yearly Tribute to Classic American Cars
text: ROYAL OAK, Mich., Aug. 1 — It used to be that the string of suburbs north of Detroit turned the third Saturday of August — and just the third Saturday — into a gas-fired playground for classic car lovers.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10 P.M. (CMT) CMT AT SUMMERFEST 2007 In late June more than 890,000 revelers descended on Milwaukee for 11 days for this 40th annual music festival, which calls itself the world’s largest, and CMT was there. This three-night series presents concerts by a trilogy of chart-topping country music artists, starting with the sweet sounds of Sugarland. A performance by Sara Evans will be broadcast at 10 p.m. tomorrow, and one by Big & Rich, above, at 10 p.m. on Sunday.

headline: Porto Hussong and Chi
text: Porto Hussong

headline: A Queens City Councilman Is Indicted in a Rape Case
text: City Councilman Dennis P. Gallagher has been indicted by a Queens grand jury investigating rape allegations against him, the councilman and his lawyer confirmed yesterday.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Minneapolis Bridge Had Passed Inspections
text: The eight-lane bridge in Minneapolis that collapsed on Wednesday had been diligently inspected for years and had always passed, state officials said yesterday.

headline: Teacher Convicted of Abuse of Elementary School Girl
text: SYRACUSE, Aug. 2  In an emotionally charged case that has touched on differences in race, class and religion, a music teacher who regularly let elementary school girls sit on his lap while the class watched movies in a darkened classroom was convicted Thursday of sexually abusing one of them.

headline: ASIA | South Korea: U.S. Beef Is Blocked
text: South Korea halted imports of beef from the United States after a shipment from Cargill was found to contain a bone part banned as a precaution against mad cow disease. South Korea’s quarantine authority found a piece of the vertebral column of a cow in one of 1,176 boxes from a shipment imported on July 29 weighing 18.7 metric tons, the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry said. Cargill said it had packaged the beef. A Cargill spokesman, Mark Klein, said the company is investigating the incident and will work with United States and South Korean officials.

headline: Homelessness Could Mean Life in Prison for Offender
text: ATLANTA, Aug. 2 — A sex offender who was unable to register his address with state officials because he was homeless is facing life in prison for violating a new registry law that politicians in Georgia have hailed as the nation’s toughest.

headline: Israel to Revise Plan for Stipend for Holocaust Survivors
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 3 — Trying to forestall an embarrassing protest march by aged survivors of the Holocaust, Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert agreed on Friday to rethink a widely criticized plan to give them a monthly stipend of some $20.

headline: Gap Tries a Somewhat Old-Fashioned Campaign
text: GAP’S advertisements have nearly always been memorable — but, particularly in recent years, not necessarily for selling pants.

headline: Bragging With Brocade in Baroque-Era Tapestries
text: When the Metropolitan Museum of Art presented “Tapestry in the Renaissance: Art and Magnificence” five years ago, it was the sleeper of the season. Curators had feared it would be too scholarly, too esoteric to attract large audiences. But they were wrong. The show brought in some 215,000 visitors, more than twice the museum’s estimates.

headline: Big Money, Big Houses and Big, Nasty Demons
text: “If I Didn’t Care,” an undernourished little noir set in the Hamptons during the winter, stokes the tempting fantasy that this elite enclave on the southeastern shore of Long Island is the seat of all evil. Where big money settles, souls disappear, devoured by the demons of real estate envy and other cravings.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Thaddeus E. Owens, 88, Who Was Judge in Racially Tense Case, Dies
text: Thaddeus E. Owens, the judge best known for presiding over the series of trials stemming from the murder of Yusuf K. Hawkins on a street in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, in 1989  a killing that stoked racial tensions in New York City  died in Brooklyn on July 21. He was 88 and lived in Brooklyn.

headline: Mexico: New Allegations of Corrupt Police for Tijuana’s Ex-Mayor
text: Jorge Hank Rhon, the fabulously wealthy former mayor of Tijuana, faced new accusations of corruption in his city’s police force, just four days before voters are to decide whether he will be the new governor of Baja California. The newspaper Reforma reported that authorities had issued arrest warrants for two of Mr. Hank’s former police commanders, alleging the cover-up of a murder by police officers in 2005 and the killing of another police commander in 2006. Mr. Hank, 51, who operates a network of betting parlors, has been running on a promise to clean up crime in the drug-plagued state, while his political opponents have accused him of being involved in crimes ranging from money-laundering to murder. He denies any wrongdoing and has never been charged with a crime.

headline: Gay, World’s Fastest in ’07, Keeps on Going Unaided
text: LONDON, Aug. 2  Standing outside a news conference, Tyson Gay was bored. So without looking up, Gay, the fastest man in the world this year, began sprinting down an empty hallway Thursday as if in slow motion. For the next few minutes, he concentrated on the carefully honed movements of his arms, repeating them until they were exactly right.

headline: Yankees Tire After Matching an Eight-Run Inning
text: Dozens of reporters surrounded Alex Rodriguez long after a draining game at Yankee Stadium. He had two hits yesterday, although not his 500th home run, and the first question was whether he felt better about his at-bats.

headline: London Police Misled Public, Report Says
text: LONDON, Aug. 2  The London police misinformed the British public about an innocent man shot dead by the police at a subway station the day after an attempted terrorist attack in London in 2005, an investigation by a police watchdog group concluded Thursday.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: In Ways Large and Small, Many Bridges Meet Definition of ‘Deficient’
text: More than 2,000 bridges in New York State meet the federal government’s definition of “structurally deficient,” from the heavily traveled on-ramps of the Brooklyn Bridge to a 28-foot span across Trout Brook near the Canadian border.

headline: Ahead of Schedule, Adu Shifts Career to Europe
text: Without kicking a ball or breaking a sweat, Freddy Adu said yesterday that his transformation from domestic wunderkind to expatriate soccer player was complete.

headline: In Increments, Senate Revisits Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 — When a broad immigration bill failed in the Senate in June after a vitriolic national debate, many legislators said the issue was dead, perhaps until President Bush left office. But already some of the less contentious pieces of the bill are returning to life.

headline: Tough Delay for Big Game by Take-Two
text: Take-Two Interactive, the video game publisher, said yesterday that it was postponing the release of the latest game in its wildly popular Grand Theft Auto series. The delay is likely to have ripple effects on the broader video game industry during its crucial holiday selling season.

headline: Life, Assembled One Room at a Time
text: The Portuguese film “Colossal Youth” was one of the most fascinating competition entries at the 2006 Cannes Film Festival. To judge by the noisy walkouts during its press screening, it was also one of the most disliked — although the truer word might be misunderstood. Beautifully photographed, this elliptical, sometime confounding, often mysterious and wholly beguiling mixture of fiction and nonfiction looks and sounds as if it were made on another planet. And, in some respects, it was.

headline: When the Bay of Fundy Swells, a River Roller Coaster Begins
text: THE guide piloted our boat into the roiling rapids and we hit the first wave head-on. The force lifted us skyward and dropped us with a thud. We smacked into the next few waves in this set of rapids and got bucketsful of water in our faces as we shrieked and laughed. Then our guide circled around and we hit the rapids again.

headline: $32.5. Million for Undersea Cable to Link 21 Countries
text: The board of the International Finance Corporation, the private-sector arm of the World Bank Group, approved investing up to $32.5 million in an undersea fiber-optic cable project that is designed to connect 21 African countries. The East African Submarine Cable System is to link sub-Saharan Africa to Internet and telecommunications services, giving development a boost. It will run from the southern tip of the continent to the Horn of Africa, connecting South Africa, Mozambique, Madagascar, Tanzania, Kenya, Somalia, Djibouti and Sudan. Construction of the cable is expected to begin in weeks and to be finished by 2009, according to the I.F.C. Thirteen more adjoining countries are to be linked to the system, financed by public and private investors. Total construction costs are estimated to be $235 million.

headline: Art in Review
text: GENESIS, I’M SORRY

headline: Cerberus Completes Deal for Chrysler
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Aug. 3  For almost a decade, people here debated whether Chryslers should still be considered American cars, how to correctly pronounce “Daimler” and what to make of the man with the German accent and funny mustache running one of Detroit’s automakers.

headline: National Briefing | West | California: Virus Deaths Prompt State of Emergency Declaration
text: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger declared a state of emergency in three counties where people have died after being infected with the West Nile virus. There have been four deaths in the state attributed to the virus, he said. To try to stop the spread of the disease, which is mosquito-borne, the governor declared a state of emergency in Kern, Colusa and San Joaquin Counties, making financial assistance available to the local vector control districts and directing state agencies to take proactive measures to protect Californians from further spread of the virus. “I will continue to ensure our local agencies have whatever resources they need to fight the spread of this disease,” Mr. Schwarzenegger said in a statement.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: The Police: Sing Along With Sting, One More Time
text: During their exultant encore at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, the Police played songs from their first and last albums, released only five years apart. For the few people in the arena who weren’t singing along, it was a reminder of the actual brevity of this band’s reign. And when Sting altered the lyrics to one of the older songs, singing “Welcome to the Andy Summers show” in a verse of “So Lonely,” it was a reminder of why ages passed before this reunion tour.

headline: Old Course Plays Exactly as Ochoa Imagined It
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 2  The Old Course at St. Andrews is for the discerning artist, its holes blending together like colors in an Impressionist painting. It takes a creative mind to conquer a layout in which the fairways are not neatly framed by trees and the greens look more like amorphous puddles than elbow patches sewn into the ground.

headline: Feeling the Heat, Not Breathing Fire
text: HONG KONG, Aug. 2 — The first purchase by the Chinese government’s new overseas investment fund, a $3 billion stake in the Blackstone Group, has produced an unusual public reaction within China.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,647 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Iran: 2 More Public Hangings
text: Two men convicted of shooting a judge to death in his car two years ago were publicly hanged from cranes on two pickup trucks in Tehran. The hangings were in front of the courthouse where the judge, Hassan Moghaddass, was killed. The executions took place a day after nine hangings in other parts of Iran.

headline: Last Words of Missing Echo as Relatives Wait for News
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 2 — The couple were having their typical after-work conversation on Wednesday.
