Sherry Engebretsen, a financial director, told her husband, Ron, that she had had a long day of meetings. He said that they should talk about it later, when she got home. She said, “O.K., I’ll see you in a few minutes.”

headline: The 2010 Economic Doomsday
text: Just about everybody remembers Captain Louis Renault, in “Casablanca,” declaring, “I’m shocked, shocked to find that gambling is going on here.”

headline: Congress Backs Tighter Rules on Lobbying
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 — The Senate gave final approval Thursday to a far-reaching package of new ethics and lobbying rules, with an overwhelming majority of Republicans and Democrats agreeing to improve policing of the relationship between lawmakers and lobbyists.

headline: Yankees’ YES Network Stake Not for Sale
text: Goldman Sachs is evaluating whether possible new investors in the YES Network, the channel of the Yankees, would pay enough to place a value of at least $3 billion on it — about four times what it was worth nearly six years ago when it was formed.

headline: Leonard Lief, 83, an Educator and a Lehman College President, Dies
text: Leonard Lief, the first president of Herbert H. Lehman College of the City University of New York, died Monday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 83.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Zimbabwe’s Chaos: The Powerful Thrive
text: BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe, July 28  Earlier this month, shortly after Zimbabwe’s president, Robert G. Mugabe, proposed legislation mandating a gradual transfer of all businesses to what he called “indigenous” ownership, a Zimbabwean businessman said he received an unexpected telephone call. The caller, a stranger, said that he represented a group of indigenous investors.

headline: Belarus Says It Will Pay Russian Gas Debt
text: Belarus said it would pay $460 million it owes Russia for natural gas supplies within days, signaling a possible end to another conflict that has threatened gas deliveries to Europe. Belarus accepted gas rate increases that went into effect in January and it has paid 55 percent of the bill. A Russian threat to cut off gas for Belarus today raised fears that Belarus would siphon gas and that shortages in Europe would result. Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, the Belarussian president, ordered the government to pay, although it was not immediately clear where it would find the money. Gazprom, the Russian gas monopoly, said that there was time for a settlement, although one had not yet been reached yesterday.

headline: Strahan’s Holdout Makes Way for His Opposite
text: ALBANY, Aug. 2 — Justin Tuck was expected to ultimately replace Michael Strahan at left defensive end for the Giants. No one imagined that day could arrive so soon.

headline: Big Law Firm Embracing Bankruptcy Practice
text: For Richard Levin, the commute to his new law firm from the Upper West Side required only a slight adjustment: simply get off the subway one stop earlier.

headline: When the Salsa Throbs, a Singer’s Soul Is Revealed
text: On the evidence of “El Cantante,” in which he plays the salsa singer Héctor Lavoe, Marc Anthony is not much of a screen actor. When the character is not in front of an audience, Mr. Anthony seems to recede behind his high, delicate cheekbones and tinted glasses, as the director, Leon Ichaso, buries him in distracting formal gimmicks and camera stunts. For the viewer Mr. Lavoe remains out of reach, an artist whose inner life remains locked inside the actor’s diffidence.

headline: Nuclear Weapons Comment Puts Obama on the Defensive
text: Senator Barack Obama found himself on the defensive again yesterday about his views on foreign policy, this time over a comment he made about the use of nuclear weapons in Afghanistan or Pakistan.

headline: Easy Getaways
text: WHO Beverly Parnes, 54, a high school teacher from Ardsley, N.Y., shown with her husband, Jerry, 57, a structural engineer

headline: Correction; For the Record
text: A chart on Sunday with a front-page article about universities that charge different tuitions for different majors misstated the undergraduate division at Iowa State University that charges more than other programs. It is the College of Engineering, not the business school.

headline: A Landing Pad of the Well-Off, as Busy as Ever
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., July 27  Binoculars in hand, Jim Brundige, manager of the tiny airport here, surveyed the Friday night comings and goings. In one five-minute span, three helicopters landed, a corporate jet took off on Runway 10-28 and a propeller plane taxied to a halt about 30 yards from the terminal.

headline: Take-Two Delays Grand Theft Auto IV
text: Take-Two Interactive, the video game publisher, said yesterday that it was postponing the release of the latest game in its popular Grand Theft Auto series, a delay that has implications for the broader video game industry during its crucial holiday selling season.

headline: Bringing Serious Muscle to an Already Brawny Beethoven
text: “The Grosse Fuge will sound better after a glass of wine,” Geoff Nuttall, the St. Lawrence String Quartet’s gregarious violinist, joked before the ensemble performed Beethoven’s String Quartet in B-flat (Op. 130) in the Kaplan Penthouse on Wednesday, part of the Mostly Mozart Festival’s Little Night Music series.

headline: A Poet’s New Post
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Fully Prepared for Anything
For Young Earners in Big City, Gap Shifts in Women’s Favor
text: According to an article in today’s New York Times, young women who live in New York and several of the nation’s other largest cities who work full time have forged ahead of men in wages.

headline: Voyage of the Acorn
text: Images of Duke Riley's voyage to intercept the Queen Mary II with his replica of a Revolutionary Era-war submarine in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: Jay Leno's 1909 Baker Electric
In Hunt for Programmers, Desperation Sets In
text: See update at the bottom; LinkedIn says it made a mistake.

headline: Boston Scientific Reverses on Endosurgery Offering
text: The medical device maker Boston Scientific said Thursday that it had decided against selling a minority stake in its endosurgery group to the public, a move that it had explored to raise as much as $1 billion in cash and help pay off debt from a $27 billion acquisition.

headline: Morgan Stanley Settles a Bias Suit
text: Morgan Stanley has agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit that accused it of unfair treatment of black and Latino employees in the retail brokerage division since 2002.

headline: Ex-Wall St. Executives Go to Bat to Help Nonprofits
text: An organization founded by two former Goldman Sachs partners is using Wall Street methods to help charities raise money to finance expansion.

headline: Big Law Firm Embracing Bankruptcy Practice
text: While other Manhattan firms are building up their bankruptcy departments, Cravath, Swaine & Moore, is just getting into the practice. For the first time in its history (parts of the firm date back to 1819), Cravath is forming a restructuring practice. And it has broken tradition to do so, by hiring a partner from outside the firm.

headline: Nortel Is Ready to Make Deals
text: Nortel Networks is in takeover mode, chief executive Mike Zafirovski told Reuters on Thursday, confirming what Wall Street has been saying for a while about the maker of telecommunications equipment.

headline: American Home Mortgage Says It Will Close
text: American Home Mortgage Investment, the troubled mortgage lender based in Melville, N.Y., will close Friday, making it the latest company to fail this year as loans made to home buyers, some even with solid credit histories, go bad.

headline: Sowood’s Fall Hits State Pension Fund Hard
text: The Massachusetts state pension system lost $30 million with this week’s collapse of Sowood Capital Management, the first evidence that public money also went down the drain when the $3 billion Boston hedge fund lost more than half its value in July.

headline: MarketWatch Founder Takes Seat at V.C. Table
text: Larry Kramer, former president of CBS Digital Media and founder of the financial Web site MarketWatch, has joined a venture capital firm, Polaris Venture Partners, as a senior adviser.

headline: Tedeschi Realty Unloads Shopping Centers
text: Tedeschi Realty, based in Rockland, Mass., on Thursday sold 25 shopping centers, most in the greater Boston area, to Dividend Capital Total Realty Trust of Denver for $377 million.

headline: G.E. Spinoff Genpact Rises in Market Opening
text: Shares of a business service provider, Genpact, soared nearly 20 percent Thursday in their market debut, producing a 289 percent partially realized gain on investment for the company’s two private equity backers, General Atlantic, and Oak Hill Capital Partners.

headline: ABN Amro Chief Goes Back to Court
text: ABN Amro‘s chief executive was back in court Thursday as a group of shareholders who lost a bid to halt the $21 billion sale of the company’s United States division kept up their fight. This time, they are pushing for an investigation into alleged mismanagement.

headline: Shell Taps $2.4 Billion in 3 Refinery Deals
text: Royal Dutch Shell said Thursday it had agreed to sell three oil refineries in France and stakes in two Norwegian Sea fields worth $2.47 billion (1.8 billion euros).

headline: Judge Approves Delphi Investment Plan
text: Delphi took a big step on its road to recovery Thursday when a bankruptcy court agreed to let Appaloosa Management and other investors inject up to $2.55 billion into the struggling auto-parts maker.

headline: Will Disney’s Penguin Deal Put Rivals on the March?
text: Walt Disney‘s deal to buy Club Penguin for up to $700 million is causing tremors among the companies that have developed online digital communities, not least because of the price tag.

headline: Developer of HIV Drugs Raises $31 Million
text: Tobira Therapeutics, a new company developing a pair of HIV drugs, raised $31 million in a first round of funding led by Domain Associates. Other investors who threw in included Frazier Healthcare Ventures, Montreux Equity Partners, and Canaan Partners.

headline: Dell’s ASAP Deal May Be the First of Many
text: Dell‘s $340 million acquisition of ASAP Software could lead to similar, if smaller deals, by the struggling computer company, analysts told The Deal.com. The company is copying its rivals who are pushing deeper into the services business, which provides higher margins than computers and is in high demand from Dell’s corporate buyers.

headline: Madison Dearborn Chief Builds Team for Cubs Bid
text: As news that a stake in YES Network may be on the block sparked talk Thursday of a possible sale of the Yankees, another auction of a highly-prized baseball team has been heating up.

headline: Candover Said to Mull Revision of Stork Bid
text: Britain’s Candover is considering revising the terms of its 1.5 billion euro ($2.1 billion) offer for Stork, the Dutch industrial conglomerate, after it emerged that Marel, an Icelandic company that opposes the deal, had built a blocking stake, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Next Stop for Silicon Valley: Vietnam
text: For Silicon Valley investors, there’s new hot spot on Asian horizon: Vietnam. The San Jose Mercury News reports that a tech gathering in the Valley to discuss Asia’s new roaring tiger drew drew an array of participants, from Google representatives to Ho Chi Minh City start-up executives.

headline: Evergreen Executive Out Amid Tepid Performance
text: Evergreen Investments, Wachovia‘s asset management unit, said its chief investment officer was leaving after more than two decades with the firm. The executive, Christopher Conkey, will officially leave the firm, which has $281 billion under management, in a couple of weeks and will be temporarily succeeded by Evergreen’s chief executive Dennis Ferro.

headline: Anglo American Paves Way for Tarmac Sale
text: Anglo American put its Tarmac road-building business up for sale on Friday as it met forecasts with a 22 percent rise in first-half earnings and pledged to return a further $4 billion to shareholders. The chief executive, Cynthia Carroll, said the sale of Britain-based Tarmac, which analysts say could fetch at least $6 billion, was the mining group’s last major piece of restructuring as it moves to focus on its metals and minerals businesses.

headline: London Theater Journal: How One Really Good Show Can Turn Around a Dour Day
text: LONDON, Aug. 3 – I so needed the shot of adrenaline I received last night, and I’m grateful to the National Theater for the injection. It had been a gray, viscous day, with the look and feel of an oyster. I had breakfasted over whinging newspaper stories about British ineptitude (the rail service, the underground, the airways), complaints I heard echoed at a lunch party later that day.

headline: Yankees’ YES Network Stake Not for Sale
text: Investors who were licking their lips Thursday on the news that YES Network might be up for sale may be disappointed to learn that only a portion of the Yankees channel is being shopped. The New York Times reported that Goldman Sachs is evaluating whether possible new investors in the YES Network would pay enough to place a value of at least $3 billion on it – about four times what it was worth nearly six years ago when it was formed.

headline: Dow Jones Sale Heats Up Presidential Race
text: It was probably only a matter of time before one of the most written-up deals of the summer — Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion bid for Dow Jones & Company — entered into the rhetoric of presidential hopefuls.

headline: RBS Reports Strong Profits Amid ABN Battle
text: The Royal Bank of Scotland, one of the banks in a takeover battle for ABN Amro, beat analysts’ expectations with an 11 percent rise in profit and lifted its dividend by 25 percent.

headline: Is the Dance Over? Citigroup Is Upbeat
text: Charles O. Prince III cannot catch a break.

headline: Blackstone’s Falling Stock Sparks Anger in China
text: The first purchase by the Chinese government’s new overseas investment fund, a $3 billion stake in the Blackstone Group, has produced an unusual public reaction within China, The New York Times reports. Since Blackstone went public on June 22, the company’s shares have fallen steeply, pushing down the value of the Chinese government’s investment by more than $425 million in just six weeks.

headline: Subprime Rattles Germany’s Union Investment
text: Union Investment Asset Management, Germany’s third-largest mutual fund manager, halted redemptions from a fund holding subprime mortgages after clients withdrew 100 million euros ($137 million) in the last month, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Merrill Move Rocked Bear Stearns Funds
text: A late June move by Merrill Lynch to protect its clients from a struggling hedge fund run by Bear Stearns helped hasten the fund’s ultimate collapse, Reuters reported Friday.

headline: Hedge Funds Feel the Markets’ Chill
text: Warren E. Buffett once said when the tide goes out, you find out who is naked. There is suddenly a lot of skin showing on Wall Street, writes The New York Times’ Jenny Anderson.

headline: Morning Buzz: A New Look at the Region’s Bridges; Young Women’s Rising Earnings; a Councilman’s Indictment; and More
text: Government officials throughout the New York region responded to the Minnesota bridge disaster on Wednesday night by ordering safety inspections of the region’s aging infrastructure. In The Times, Russ Buettner reports that more than 2,100 bridges in New York State have been deemed structurally deficient by the federal government, even though the term has varying definitions. New York City officials said the city’s bridges are safe even though three of them — including the Brooklyn Bridge — were rated poor in the city’s annual bridge report card last year. Meanwhile, Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York and Gove. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey have ordered reviews of bridges in their states.Under the federal rating system, The Daily News reports, the Brooklyn Bridge scored “dramatically lower” than the bridge in Minneapolis that collapsed. (Perhaps that fact raises even more questions about the rating system than it does about the Brooklyn Bridge.)

headline:
Stray Questions for:
Eric Schlosser
text: What are you working on?

headline: Nortel Is Ready to Make Deals
text: Nortel Networks is in takeover mode, chief executive Mike Zafirovski told Reuters on Thursday, confirming what Wall Street has been saying for a while about the maker of telecommunications equipment.

headline: In Taipei, Wikipedians Talk Wiki Fatigue, Wikiwars and Wiki Bucks
text: Noam Cohen, the author of the Link by Link column, is at Wikimania 2007, the annual gathering of people involved with Wikipedia, in Taipei. This is the first of his dispatches.

headline: Queens Councilman Is Charged With Rape
text: Updated, 1:15 p.m.

headline: Praise From an Unlikely Source
text: The Wall Street Journal editorial page isn’t exactly a target constituency for a Democratic candidate in advance of the presidential primaries and caucuses, but a Journal editorial nearly swoons over Barack Obama’s statement [$] that, as president, he would target Al Qaeda in Pakistan if General Pervez Musharraf won’t: “Obama is taking heat from liberals and conservatives alike for his comment that he wouldn’t hesitate to send U.S. troops into Pakistan to capture or kill Al Qaeda leaders. Actually, it’s the best thing we’ve heard yet from the junior U.S. Senator from Illinois.” The editorial adds:

headline: The Alaia Chronicles
text: Alex A gets right to the point: How does Azzedine Alaia do it? I think there are several things to keep in mind about Alaia and his method of working.

headline: Of Open Wounds and Decent Intervals
text: In the Twin Cities today, a counselor at a day camp for small children may start to lead a circle of youngsters in “London Bridge is Falling Down” – and then stop short. A movie buff in the public library’s video room may reach for “The Bridge on the River Kwai” – and then put it back on the shelf. Card players may wonder whether their weekly bridge game really feels right. Conversation in a dental office may stumble over a mention of bridgework, in a surgical supply store over trusses, in a writing workshop over concrete examples, at a poker table over going down to the river.

headline: 2008: Republicans Set to Debate
text: On Sunday the Republican presidential candidates will gather for a live ABC News debate from Des Moines, Iowa. The war in Iraq will surely be one of the issues on the agenda, and a Bloomberg News story today notes subtle changes in the way some candidates are talking about the war.

headline: Playing the Buffett Buying Game Again
text: We know that Warren E. Buffett is on the prowl for a $40 billion to $60 billion deal. Now that the credit markets have sidelined potential private equity rivals, the Berkshire Hathaway chief may have an even easier go of it, Bloomberg News suggests.

headline: As Take-Two Swerves, Funds Take a Hit
text: If you play the activist-investor game, be prepared to get burned. That is the lesson for Oppenheimer Funds, a mutual-fund manager that took the unusual step earlier this year of leading a campaign to take control of Take-Two Interactive, the maker of the wildly popular “Grand Theft Auto” video game series.

headline: The Week in Comments: Slurs, Raps, Polls, Moms, Ads, Noshes and Tinted Windows
text: A look back at the week that was, in the words of our readers.

headline: Quick Bits: Cheap Computers in China; Google Gives and Takes Away
text: It may be a summer Friday, but the tech world is boiling:

headline: 25 Bloomberg Signatures = One Beer
text: An e-mail newsletter arrived in the City Room inbox overnight from the local group devoted to drafting Michael R. Bloomberg for president. Here are highlights:

headline: Hedge Funds Thank Heaven for Lockups
text: Starting a couple of years ago, many privacy-loving hedge funds started using “lockups” as a way to sidestep a new rule requiring them to register with regulators. Under lockup provisions, investors’ capital cannot be withdrawn for some period, often one to two years. Funds with lockups of two years or longer were exempt from the fund-registration rule.

headline: Watch Your Mouth
text: Since the Heysel Stadium riot that killed 39 Juventus fans in Brussels in 1985 and the Hillsborough disaster  that killed 93 soccer fans in 1989, authorities have been evangelical in their efforts to curb hooliganism and end dangerous behavior in stadiums around the world.

headline: Daimler Seals the Chrysler Deal
text: Whatever thumps the sale of Chrysler will take in the debt markets, one thing is clear: the deal is done.

headline: The Mayor on Bridge Safety, the 9/11 Ceremony and More
text: The Minnesota bridge collapse, the decision to move the 9/11 ceremony this year and a variety of other topics were on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s mind this morning as he sat down with John Gambling of WABC-AM for his weekly radio interview. [Listen in the city’s player or download the file at nyc.gov.]

headline: Dead on Arrival
text: Images of the Brooklyn Museum's project to subject one of its mummies to a CT scan.

headline: The Victims
‘Hero’ Worship
text: We can’t all be heroes: Los Angeles Times columnist Rosa Brooks is perturbed by the post-9/11 habit of referring to everyone in uniform as a “hero.” “The empty rhetoric of heroism is everywhere these days,” Brooks writes. She adds:

headline: More Feeble Than Lethal Now, Bonds May Need a Rest
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 — Barry Bonds was alone with a laptop computer on Thursday, searching for the reasons why his pursuit of home run history had stalled. Bonds ignored the San Francisco Giants teammates who were playing video games beside him in a back room and watched a stream of his at-bats.

headline: Clinton-Obama Tensions Spill Into the Senate
text: In his Web column today, Jeff Zeleny writes that for Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, the genteel decorum of the Senate has given way to the go-for-the-jugular instinct of the campaign trail:

headline: Blackstone Bill Has Another Partnership on Alert
text: Buyout firms are not the only ones paying close attention to a measure widely known as the Blackstone Bill.

headline: Bourdais watch
text: In my continuing effort to avoid writing about the Formula One spy scandal while attending this Hungarian Grand Prix – and avoiding the story is not an easy task, except that there is little real, decisive news to report on the scandal – I thought I would bring up that topic we have spoken about frequently on this blog: Sebastien Bourdais.

headline: The Next Wayne Rooney
text: Manchester United has signed Rhain Davis, a 9-year-old from Australia, to its youth academy based largely on the skills he displayed in this video sent to the club by Rhain’s grandfather. (It could be the second-biggest signing for ManU this month.)

headline: Your “Free Call” Indicator
text: You know, of course, that in general, cellphone calls to other people who have the same carrier as you (like Verizon or AT&T) are free, right?

headline: Clinton Will Do Q&A at Bloggers Event
text: CHICAGO — Reversal in the Clinton camp.

headline: Banks Said to Pull More Alliance Boots Loans
text: The market for high-yield debt appears to have closed tighter than ever. On Friday, three banks trying to sell 1 billion pounds ($2 billion) of junior loans to finance the buyout of Alliance Boots pulled the debt offering, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Bush Takes the Lead on Climate Change?
text: U.S. President George W. Bush vowed earlier this year to gather leading polluters together to discuss climate change and now he’s set the date: Sept. 27-28.

headline: A Glass of Wine and No Thou
text: So I thought I was going to have dinner with a winemaker but as it turned out crucial tasks back at the winery intruded on my needs. So I’m on my own in the town of Los Gatos, Calif., in the heart of Silicon Valley.

headline: What’s Fresh in the City Greenmarkets This Weekend
text: The bins at city greenmarkets will overflow this weekend with dozens of varieties of fresh local produce, including fragrant ripe peaches, sweet corn, heirloom tomatoes, apricots, potatoes and eggplants. The first pears of the season have arrived. Artichokes will make an appearance.

headline: Revised Rules Coming on Filmmaking and Photography, After Uproar
text: After an outcry from videographers, filmmakers and still photographers — including a satirical rap video and an online protest petition that has gathered more than 20,000 signatures — the Mayor’s Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting announced this afternoon that it would “redraft” proposed rules that would have restricted how images can be recorded in New York City, one of the most filmed and photographed places on the planet.

headline: Cubs Knock on Wood
text: The long, strange trip of Kerry Wood has, yet again, reached Wrigley Field. Before today’s game, the Cubs will activate Wood, who has not pitched in the major leagues since June 6, 2006, because of the same shoulder problems that have bothered him since the start of 2005. Wood has had 11 stays on the disabled list and two major surgeries.

headline: Animals Where They Don’t Belong
text: Serious news can sometimes be sparse on deep-summer Fridays, but there never seems to be a shortage of off-kilter animal stories, and The Lede notes a theme of unintended consequences threading through several.

headline: Investors May Start Showering Money on Water Firms
text: Will water become the next big “clean tech” investment?

headline: Central Park West Loses Decades-Old Market
text: It is not easy to find a grocery store on Central Park West. In fact, it is not easy to find a store of any kind. But for 42 years — until last weekend — Gristedes operated a 3,200-square-foot supermarket at the West 62nd Street corner of the Century apartment building.

headline: That Juggernaut Named Wii
text: Call the Wii The Little Console That Could.

headline: Feeling Lucky
text: As Paul and I get closer to our construction loan closing and to breaking ground, the reality of what we are about to do is starting to sink in — and it’s making me nervous! This is a huge financial and logistical commitment.

headline: UBS Names New Fixed-Income Chief
text: In another executive shuffle at UBS, the Swiss bank’s Latin America chief will become its new head of global fixed-income sales and trading. Andre Esteves will move to London from Brazil and report to Huw Jenkins, the head of investment banking, the firm said Friday.

headline: The Friendliest Confines
text: If anyone can tell me a better way to spend a Friday afternoon, please let me know. The closest clouds to Chicago are in Peoria. It’s 77 degrees with a slight breeze circulating through the press box, and from my seat in the second row I can catch a glimpse of Lake Michigan.

headline: At Nobu, a Lawsuit Over Workers’ Tips
text: Just who is entitled to share the tips at New York City’s fanciest restaurants?

headline: One Man’s Art (a Submarine?) Runs Into Trouble
text: Updated, 11:10 p.m.

headline: Murdoch, Dow Jones and the ‘Jerk Premium’
text: To clinch Dow Jones and its crown jewel, The Wall Street Journal, Rupert Murdoch had to reach deep: At $60 a share, his bid was 67 percent above the stock’s price before the offer became public in May.

headline: More From Bagehot, Gramley and Bear Stearns
text: My column today uses a quote from “Lombard Street” by Walter Bagehot: “Every banker knows that if he has to prove that he is worthy of credit, however good may be his arguments, in fact his credit is gone.”

headline: Surprise Leaders at the U.S. Open
text: Benjamin Finegold, the fourth seed, and Amon Simutowe, the ninth seed, lead the 108th U.S. Open with perfect scores after six rounds. The Open, which is being played in Cherry Hill, N.J., wraps up tomorrow evening. The games can be followed live or replayed at Monroi.com.

headline: Seen: Lonelygirl15 on a New Site
text: Lonelygirl15 doesn’t believe in exclusive relationships.

headline: All Work and No Play
text: It’s not unusual to hear people complain that work consumes so much of their energy and time — or their partner’s — that they are too exhausted for intimacy.

headline: Day 2: Following the Bridge Collapse
text: Searching for the best sources on the Bridge collapse around the Web. The full story from The Times is here.

headline: Poll: Iowa Democrats Like Their Choices
text: The voters in Iowa are finding things to like about the top three Democratic candidates, according to the latest ABC News/Washington Post Poll. Half the voters who said they were likely to participate in next year’s Democratic caucuses described Hillary Clinton as having the best experience. John Edwards and Barak Obama were each seen as the most likeable candidate by a third of the voters. All three are seen as understanding people’s problems.

headline: For Immigrant, a Spiritual Refuge
text: An interview with Zachariah Jok Char, who fled Sudan 21 years ago and is now a priest in Grand Rapids, Mich.

headline: Locking Up Loopholes
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his Aug. 3 column, “A Test for Democrats.”

headline: Ageing Through the Ages
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s Aug. 3 column, “Being Old, Then and Now.”

headline: Missouri Closes a Rickety Bridge
text: The collapse of the I-35W bridge in Minneapolis has prompted officials in Missouri to close a highway bridge near St. Louis that they were worried might soon fail.

headline: Thank You For Not Smoking
text: Melissa Dubbin and Aaron S. Davidson.

headline: The Invisible Hand
text: Jeffrey Miller

headline: My Secret Smile
text: Paul McGuirk

headline: Bob Floss
text: David Ellis's "Bob Floss." Digital animation (2007). On view at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum. Courtesy of David Ellis and Chris Doyle Studio.

headline: Kegel Exercise
text: Shannon Plumb

headline: Gioconda
text: Karina Aguilera Skvirsky

headline: CART RAID
text: Chris Wilcha

headline: Room 863
text: Amy Yoes

headline: Answers From the Waterfront Expert, Part 3
text: Following is the third and final set of responses from Carter Craft of the Metropolitan Waterfront Alliance, who took questions from City Room readers from July 30 to Aug. 3.

headline: Slide Show: The Week in Pictures, Aug. 3
text: Photographs taken in New York City by Times photographers in the past week.

headline: The Case for Melky Cabrera
text: Jason Giambi will play in a doubleheader tonight for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre, and Joe Torre expects him to be activated during next week’s series in Toronto. The big question is how Giambi will work his way into a lineup that has been functioning quite well without him.

headline: At YearlyKos, (Sigh) No Naked Bloggers
text: The New Yorker’s Hendrik Hertzberg is blogging from the liberal netroots gathering known as YearlyKos. Ezra Klein fears for his carefully crafted blogosphere niche. (“So should the rest of us retire? Compared to Hertzberg, we’re largely illiterates.”) Hertzberg’s initial reaction to the Kos Krowd: “I admit that I was expecting this crowd to look weirder. Not hippie weirder, though I did expect a bit of that, but nerdy weirder. So I was surprised at how extraordinarily normal everyone looked.”

headline: One More Yankees-Seinfeld Connection
text: The “Seinfeld” version of George Steinbrenner and George Costanza’s stint as the team’s assistant to the traveling secretary forever forged the link between the sitcom and the team. But Thursday’s White Sox-Yankees game further extended that bond.

headline: Amazon to Rent Its Cash Register
text: Amazon is wading further into the business of processing payments for other Web sites, going head to head with the eBay-owned PayPal and Google’s fledgling Checkout service. In a blog post today, Amazon’s Jeff Barr announced the Amazon Flexible Payment Service – a way for other companies and developers to use Amazon’s payment system on their own Web sites.

headline: The Working-Class Millionaire
text: Hal Steger has more than a million dollars in the bank, but it's not enough -- he has neighbors with far more. And he is not alone.

headline: It Was Sony in the Dining Room With a Candlestick
text: Ladies and gentlemen, start your conspiracy theories.

headline: Rising Farmland Prices
text: Prime farmland is selling for about $5,000 an acre in central Illinois, up from about $3,000 five years ago.

headline: Con Edison Reduces Voltage in Brooklyn
text: Updated, 11:30 p.m.

headline: Remember Ned Lamont?
text: CHICAGO — Well, he’s here at the YearlyKos convention, and just popped up on stage in the main ballroom of McCormick Place to thank bloggers and activists who helped him win last year’s Democratic primary (if not the general election against Senator Joe Lieberman and, who was the Republican candidate again?)

headline: More on Mother Teresa and Bloggers
text: CHICAGO –Just to address some confusion, we want to offer a belated but much-needed explanation about the booing of Mother Teresa that I should have provided earlier in the original post from the Kos conference: It was a passing reference to a light remark made by the emcee of a trivia quiz.

headline: Vows: Seungah and Elliot
text: Seungah Jeong and Elliot Taub finally got together when Seungah first called Elliot on a whim after he gave her his number at a party.

headline: Obama Takes Heat on Pakistan
text: During a major foreign policy speech on Wednesday Senator Barack Obama promised that as president he would consider military strikes against terrorists in Pakistan if the country refused to root them out. Those comments drew a sharp response from Pakistani officials as well as the Bush administration today.

headline: A Changing Tune or Does the Song Remain the Same?
text: There has been much reading of the tea-leaves lately on statements of the leading Republican presidential candidates on Iraq, with political observers looking for any sign that they are beginning to put distance between them and President Bush’s military surge in Iraq.

headline: General Petraeus’s Report
text: Before the Iraqi national squad arrived in Baghdad this evening, Stephen Farrell spoke with General David Petraeus, who was waiting to salute them.

headline: The Asian Cup Arrives in Baghdad
text: We’ll have Stephen Farrell’s full report soon over in World News, but here’s a clip from the Green Zone red carpet to whet your appetite.

headline: Brooklyn Artist in Troubled Water
text: Duke Riley was detained after his replica of a submarine from the Revolutionary War neared the Queen Mary 2.

headline: Giambi Set to Return, but Who’s Leaving?
text: The Yankees have played a version of “Who’s on First?” all season, using nine players at first base and working out Wilson Betemit there before last night’s game.

headline: A Championship Moment From the New League Leader
text: At the recently concluded Summer North American Bridge Championships in Nashville, the next president of the American Contract Bridge League was elected. That honor, richly deserved, went to Dan Morse of Houston.

headline: Courteous Police Officers (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pet Population Control (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Broader Spying Authority Advances in Congress
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 —A furious push by the White House to broaden its wiretapping authority appeared on the verge of victory on Friday night after the Senate approved a measure that would temporarily give the administration more latitude to eavesdrop without court warrants on foreign communications that it suspects may be tied to terrorism.

headline: Markets Fall as Lender Woes Keep Mounting
text: Stocks tumbled yesterday on fears that the worsening ills in the mortgage and debt markets could soon take a significant toll on consumers, businesses and the overall economy.

headline: Recreation in the City (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mets Start Out With Patience, Then Pile It on in the Ninth
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 3 — If the Mets were to plot the effects of Howard Johnson’s three weeks as hitting coach on a graph, they would draw a few surges, a couple of dips and one gigantic spike. That came Friday, when the patient hitting approach that Johnson, following team orders, has worked to instill resulted in a season-high 11 walks against the Chicago Cubs at Wrigley Field.

headline: So Many Investigations
text: It seems that everywhere they turn these days, New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his staff face another investigation. There have already been two inquiries into the pushing of State Police to release embarrassing information about the governor’s top political opponent, Senator Joseph Bruno. Now there could be three or even four more, ready to sidetrack everything else important going on in Albany.

headline: Obama’s Flexibility (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Nostalgia for Yesterday’s Future
text: “Masters of Science Fiction” is an odd summertime diversion. Into the season of “America’s Got Talent” and “So You Think You Can Dance,” ABC is dropping a series of four talky, philosophical dramas based on stories by well-known science-fiction writers (well, three well-known science-fiction writers and Howard Fast). It’s a pure throwback, a “Twilight Zone” homage with Stephen Hawking in the Rod Serling role.

headline: Airplane Crashes Create Anxiety Among Brazil’s Travelers
text: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 3  Alire Assis Brasil, in town to visit an aunt, waited patiently Thursday for her bus back to her home in Florianopolis  some 18 hours away.

headline: Keeping a Hitting Machine Humming
text: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 3 — What can you do for Barry Bonds? Joe Lefebvre, the batting coach for the San Francisco Giants, has heard the question, which is really more of a disguised criticism, so often that he has a prepared answer.

headline: Oil Refineries (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Press Baron Champions ‘Viewspaper’
text: Anthony O’Reilly is perhaps best known in the United States as the former chief executive of the H. J. Heinz Company and a champion of all things Irish. But his broad business interests include investments in hotels and natural resources and a major stake in Waterford Wedgwood. Lately, however, Mr. O’Reilly has been drawing attention as the founder, major shareholder and chief executive of Independent News and Media, the British-based publisher of London’s Independent, The Irish Independent and more than 100 newspapers in Australia, New Zealand, South Africa and, most recently, India.

headline: Bottled vs. Tap Water? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: On the Move, the Parisian Way (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Screenwriter as God, Examining His Creations
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 — A big, sand-colored house atop a grass slope in this city’s genteel Hancock Park district is one key to unlocking the meaning of “The Nines.”

headline: 7 Arrested in Death of Oakland Newspaper Editor
text: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 3 — A day after a prominent newspaper editor was shot to death downtown, the police here on Friday arrested seven men and seized several weapons that they suspected were used in his killing and those of two other men.

headline: Haunted by Seamus
text: Most high-profile politicians acquire weird little bits of biography that you just cannot shake out of your mind. A reporter once told me that he sat next to a member of Congress on a trip, while said lawmaker kept eating mayonnaise out of those little packets they give you at fast-food restaurants. Even if this guy someday single-handedly resurrects the Equal Rights Amendment and shepherds it through 37 State Legislatures, when I look at him, a corner of my brain will always think condiments.

headline: Toyota Says Quarterly Profit Jumped 32%
text: TOKYO, Aug. 3 — Toyota Motor reported a 32 percent rise in quarterly profit on Friday, continuing a streak of record earnings as the Japanese car company seeks to widen its lead over General Motors as the world’s largest automaker.

headline: Mystics Defeat Liberty
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) — Alana Beard scored 24 points and Nakia Sanford added 16 to help the Washington Mystics beat the Liberty, 80-68, on Friday night.

headline: Managers See Basics as a Buy in Risky Times
text: The stock market’s volatility is making portfolio managers nervous, but it is not making them sell, many say. Instead, their response to the cascade from record highs has been to ensure that they own shares of businesses less sensitive than most to changes in economic conditions or to the whims of investment fashion.

headline: Report Says S.E.C. Erred on Pequot
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission bungled a promising investigation two years ago into suspicious trading at Pequot Capital Management, a giant hedge fund, according to the final report released yesterday by Congressional investigators looking into the matter.

headline: Risks of Pregnancy (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Elite American Racer Finds Full-Time Commitment Pays
text: Last summer, at age 29, Peter Gilmore made a career decision. He decided to suspend his life as a part-time elite runner and part-time businessman and put all his energy into distance running.

headline: He’s Still No Seer, but Underdog Is Here
text: A motherless boy, a graceless dog and a witless script propel “Underdog,” a live-action resurrection of the 1960s television series about a canine superhero who speaks in rhyme while fighting crime. (Sorry, it’s catching.)

headline: Bollywood Goes on a Trip to the A.T.M.
text: “Cash on my mind/Making money all the time. ...“ Sounds like a rap hit, but no, it’s the theme to “Cash,” a Bollywood caper providing abundant proof that Hollywood pictures have no monopoly on ostentatious wealth, or, to use a spent expression, bling.

headline: National Briefing | California: Reporter Suspended Over Relationship
text: Mirthala Salinas, a broadcaster in Los Angeles who covered politics for Telemundo and became romantically involved with Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa, was suspended Thursday for two months without pay. Her suspension followed an investigation into whether the ethical standards of the station, KVEA-TV, had been violated because of her relationship with the mayor. The station’s news director was also suspended, its general manager reassigned and the station’s group president reprimanded.

headline: Court Partly Rebuffs F.B.I. on House Office Search
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 — An appeals court ruled on Friday that the F.B.I. violated the Constitution in the methods used to search evidence seized in the office of Representative William J. Jefferson, the Louisiana Democrat indicted on bribery charges involving $90,000 found in his home freezer.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: The Dog Runs Free

headline: Lawmaker Calls for Registry of Drug Firms Paying Doctors
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  An influential Republican senator says he will propose legislation requiring drug makers to disclose the payments they make to doctors for services like consulting, lectures and attendance at seminars.

headline: Book Tackles Old Debate: Role of Art in Schools
text: When two researchers published a study a few years ago concluding that arts classes do not improve students’ overall academic performance, the backlash was bitter.

headline: Complications Hindering Moynihan Station Plans
text: The proposed overhaul of Pennsylvania Station, Madison Square Garden and the surrounding neighborhood has long been described by the developers as a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. It is also a project that is getting more complicated with each passing month.

headline: Bush Visits Collapsed Bridge in Minneapolis
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 4 — President Bush surveyed the pancaked concrete, contorted steel and hulks of half-sunken cars this morning on a visit to the bridge that collapsed over the Mississippi River.

headline: William J. Tuttle, Master Movie Makeup Man, Dies at 95
text: William J. Tuttle, a Hollywood makeup artist whose work was so renowned that he won an Oscar years before there was an official Academy Award for makeup, died on July 27 at his home in Pacific Palisades, Calif. He was 95.

headline: To Get a Clearer Look at the Poor, an Artist Uses Distorted Images
text: A young woman travels to an impoverished district in a large, sprawling city where she distributes cameras among children and invites them to take photographs of themselves and their surroundings. The photographs are printed and make their way into galleries in other cities, on other continents.

headline: A Pakistani Envoy in Britain Defuses Cultural Land Mines
text: London

headline: Chávez Takes ‘Crazy Battalion’ of Supporters on the Road
text: LA FRIA, Venezuela, Aug. 3 — “Surely they will take photos of us by satellite,” said President Hugo Chávez, referring to intelligence agencies from the United States, as his Airbus touched down Friday in this Andean city with the actor Sean Penn, a clutch of cabinet ministers and visiting dignitaries from half a dozen countries in tow.

headline: Housing and the Poor (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Schumer and Tax Breaks (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Workers Say They Feel Blindsided by Lender’s Failure
text: MELVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 3  Among the 1,400 or so people who lost their jobs here Friday, there were undoubtedly some who understood the macro and micro factors that led American Home Mortgage Investment Corporation, one of the largest and fastest-growing mortgage companies in the country, to crash in a heap this week, even as it was hiring employees by the dozen.

headline: Night Raid in Iraq: Seeking Militants, but Also Learning the Lay of the Land
text: FORWARD OPERATING BASE KALSU, Iraq — Capt. Eric Nylander passed the word down the line of soldiers in the darkened Chinook helicopter: “Ice,” meaning the landing area was free of enemy fighters.

headline: Judge Orders Corzine Mail Turned Over to the Court
text: TRENTON, Aug. 3 — A state judge rejected on Friday an attempt by Gov. Jon S. Corzine to dismiss a lawsuit filed by Republicans seeking public disclosure of e-mail messages he exchanged with the state union official who is also a former companion.

headline: In the Alps, a Conquest Takes Two Generations
text: John Harlin III was 9 years old when a frayed rope sliced over a rough edge of limestone, sending his father plunging 4,000 feet to his death. It was the winter of 1966, and John Harlin II’s climbing team was nearing the end of a grueling siege against a new route on perhaps the biggest, most notorious mountain wall in Europe — the North Face of the Eiger, in the Swiss Alps.

headline: Charity Work, ‘American Idol’-Style
text: Seven years ago, during a gripe session in the teachers’ lounge, Charles Best and others counted up things they needed. Books. Pencils. An occasional field trip. And they talked about a fact of life: generous people would be glad to give money to buy supplies, but not necessarily to write a check that would vanish into the maw of the school system.

headline: Clinton Will Hold Chat Session With Bloggers After All
text: The Clinton campaign reversed itself yesterday and decided that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton would attend an individual meeting with liberal bloggers this weekend in addition to her appearance at a larger forum featuring most of the other Democratic presidential candidates.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on July 26 about the reopening of the north end of City Hall Park, which surrounds the Tweed Courthouse in Lower Manhattan, included outdated information from a park advocacy group about park hours and access. A path from Broadway to Centre Street is open to the public from 6 a.m. to 1 a.m. daily without interruption; it is not closed at certain times for exclusive use by a nearby charter school. Only one gate on Chambers Street  not two  is occasionally closed to the public, and those occasions are the times the school is in session, not just when students are arriving and being dismissed. The second gate, on the west side of the Tweed building, is open to the public without restriction during park hours.

headline: After Protests, City Agrees to Rewrite Proposed Rules on Photography Permits
text: Responding to an outcry that included a passionate Internet campaign and a satiric rap video, city officials yesterday backed off proposed new rules that could have forced tourists taking snapshots in Times Square and filmmakers capturing that only-in-New-York street scene to obtain permits and $1 million in liability insurance.

headline: Bergman, Antonioni and the Religiously Inclined
text: In this week’s obituaries for Ingmar Bergman, perhaps no character in the great filmmaker’s work was mentioned more frequently than God.

headline: Partisan Anger Stalls Congress in Final Push
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 — Congress stumbled toward its August recess on a discordant note Friday as angry partisanship and distrust slowed the House and Senate in the latest example of the ideological standoff that has made progress difficult all year.

headline: Robert E. Keeton, 87, Author of Influential Law Treatises, Is Dead
text: Robert E. Keeton, a former federal judge and Harvard law professor who wrote widely influential treatises on tort law, courtroom tactics and no-fault auto insurance, died July 1 in Cambridge, Mass. He was 87 and lived in Cambridge.

headline: Marine Sentenced in Killing of Iraqi
text: A military jury sentenced a Marine squad leader to 15 years in prison yesterday for killing an Iraqi man whom he and seven other squad members abducted near Hamdaniya last year.

headline: A Tide of Wine May Drive European Growers From a Way of Life
text: PERPIGNAN, France — A few months ago Isidore Santamaria went out into his picturesque vineyard in southwestern France and ripped row upon row of neatly cultivated vines out of the ground.

headline: States Across the Country Race to Inspect Bridges
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 3 — As recovery divers moved from car to car in the murky waters of the Mississippi River on Friday, state officials across the country raced to inspect bridges that are similar to the steel-deck truss bridge that collapsed here, killing at least five people.

headline: Giuliani’s Security (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on July 26 about the reopening of the north end of City Hall Park, which surrounds the Tweed Courthouse in Lower Manhattan, included outdated information from a park advocacy group about park hours and access. A path from Broadway to Centre Street is open to the public from 6 a.m. to 1 a.m. daily without interruption; it is not closed at certain times for exclusive use by a nearby charter school. Only one gate on Chambers Street — not two — is occasionally closed to the public, and those occasions are the times the school is in session, not just when students are arriving and being dismissed. The second gate, on the west side of the Tweed building, is open to the public without restriction during park hours. (Go to Article)

headline: Spitzer Aide, the Subject of an Investigation, Resigns
text: ALBANY, Aug. 3  An aide to Gov. Eliot Spitzer who is accused of threatening a Republican state official resigned abruptly on Friday, adding to the controversy here.

headline: Police Say Driver of Ice Cream Truck Sold Drugs Near School
text: The driver of a Mister Softee ice cream truck was arrested yesterday on charges of selling cocaine and marijuana from his truck while it was parked outside a middle school in Queens, the police said.

headline: Slowly, Clinton Shifts on War, Quieting Foes
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 — A little more than a year ago, before Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton entered the race for the White House, she drew a storm of boos from an audience of liberal Democrats here as she declared that it would be a mistake to set a “date certain” for withdrawing American troops from Iraq.

headline: The Arts in School (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A headline on Page 7 of the Travel section this weekend, with the Next Stop column, refers imprecisely to the relationship between the city of Nantes, France, and the region of Brittany. Although Nantes was long the capital of Brittany and remains strongly identified with it, France’s current administrative structure puts it in the Pays de la Loire region.

headline: Keeping a Hitting Machine Humming
text: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 3 — What can you do for Barry Bonds? Joe Lefebvre, the batting coach for the San Francisco Giants, has heard the question, which is really more of a disguised criticism, so often that he has a prepared answer.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Scenes From an Overrated Career
text: Chicago

headline: As the Vision Fades, the Indignities Grow
text: Robert Masello used to laugh at his parents when he went out to eat with them. If the restaurant had a menu with pictures, his father would point to any vaguely appealing image. For his farsighted mother, Mr. Masello, in his teens at the time, would hold the menu up from across the table.

headline: State Puts Restrictions on Self-Described Pedophile
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 — In a surprise to parent groups and their lawyers, a judge issued a statewide restraining order Friday prohibiting a self-described pedophile from coming closer than 10 yards to any minor in California.

headline: Suspect in Connecticut Killings Left Long Trail of Lawbreaking
text: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 3  Throughout more than two decades in and out of Connecticut prisons for everything from stealing pocketbooks to possessing weapons, Steven J. Hayes was given many chances to turn his life around, chances he often squandered.

headline: Florida Counties Try to Contain Phosphate Mines
text: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. — Arguing that the State Environmental Protection Department is far too lax in regulating open-pit phosphate mines, three Gulf Coast counties are spending millions of dollars in an effort to keep the mines from further expansion in a major watershed.

headline: With Sale, Chrysler’s Identity Is Simplified
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Aug. 3 — For almost a decade, people here debated whether Chryslers should still be considered American cars, how to correctly pronounce “Daimler” and what to make of the man with the German accent and funny mustache running one of Detroit’s automakers.

headline: A Surer Way to Feed the Hungry
text: Globally, about 800 million people are chronically hungry, and the number rises every year. The Bush administration is pushing what should be an obvious policy change to help those most acutely in need  victims of catastrophe or some other emergency. Instead of shipping American-grown food abroad, Washington would send American dollars to buy food from local farmers.

headline: ‘Stop and Frisks’ Decrease in 2nd Quarter, the Police Say
text: The New York Police Department released information last night showing that officers stopped 113,945 people on city streets for the second quarter of this year, a number that a spokesman said was 12.4 percent lower than that recorded in the same period in 2006.

headline: Wood Activated by the Cubs
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 3  The long, strange trip of Kerry Wood has again reached Wrigley Field. Before Friday’ 6-2 loss to the Mets, the Cubs activated Wood, who has not pitched in the major leagues since June 6, 2006, because of the shoulder problems that have bothered him since the start of 2005. Wood has had 11 stays on the disabled list and two major surgeries.

headline: Stock Market Cycles
text: SALES of high-end art, jewelry and wine are booming. Stocks, until recently, were hitting new highs, and consumer confidence and spending are solid.

headline: The Generation of ’38, Still Kicking
text: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 2 — The Tanglewood Music Center’s Festival of Contemporary Music, for which composers and new-music fans assemble here every summer, has evolved into a compact parade of competing modern styles. Often that competition has to do with one generation’s concerns giving way to those of the next. This year the composer John Harbison, who directed the festival, assembled a program in the competing aesthetic ideas of a single generation.

headline: Dramatic Fall Exposes the Risk in Extreme Sports
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 — When the telecast of the skateboard Big Air event at the X Games on ESPN cut to a commercial Thursday night, the scoreboard screens at the Staples Center kept the crowd entertained with footage of crashes from past X Games events.

headline: Passengers Scowl as Airlines Smile
text: THE nation’s airlines are beginning to right themselves, but for passengers, air travel is becoming much worse. The two things are not unrelated, according to Knowledge@Wharton, the online journal of the Wharton School of Business (knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu).

headline: An Artist and His Sub Surrender in Brooklyn
text: At slack tide off Red Hook, Brooklyn, there are usually lots of things floating in the water, most of which you would not want to touch without the help of a good hazmat suit. But just after sunrise yesterday, something truly strange was bobbing there in the shallows near Pier 41: a submarine fashioned almost completely from wood, and inside it a man with an obsession.

headline: WFAN Said to Be Replacing Imus With an Ex-Quarterback and a ‘Jersey Guy’
text: WFAN, the AM radio station in New York City that served as a flagship for Don Imus’s show before he was fired over his racial and sexual asides about a college women’s basketball team, has apparently settled on a permanent successor.

headline: What’s Good for a Business Can Be Hard on Friends
text: A month ago, Brandy McDowell sat down with her longtime friend, Kezia Chandler, and told her she had switched cellphone carriers. Their relationship has not been the same since.

headline: China: Pro-Tibet Protesters Arrested
text: The authorities detained as many as 200 ethnic Tibetans this week after a protest in the town of Lithang, in Sichuan Province, an area populated by Tibetans, Radio Free Asia reported. It said the group had apparently demanded the release of a Tibetan man who was arrested Wednesday after calling for the return of the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, during a celebration sponsored by the Chinese Government. The celebration was part of an annual festival in the town. The Dalai Lama fled Tibet in 1959, after a failed effort to gain independence from China. Many of his followers in Tibet continue to believe that the territory should be independent from China.

headline: Prosecutors Charge Five in the Death of a Student
text: Two Rider University officials — the dean of students and the director of campus Greek life — and three fraternity members were charged yesterday in connection with the death of a freshman in March after a night of binge drinking at a fraternity party on the main campus in central New Jersey.

headline: Deal for Dow Jones a Springboard for Murdoch’s Plans
text: DOW JONES & COMPANY has a new owner; meanwhile, more companies succumbed to the latest mortgage meltdown, and Mattel announced a huge toy recall.

headline: So Many Parking Rules, Even Marines Are in Trouble
text: WHITE PLAINS

headline: Mostly Someone Other Than Mozart
text: The Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center has, in its first week, been mostly Beethoven. And that mini-festival culminates today in a long two-part re-creation of one of Beethoven’s most famous concerts, in 1808, which presented the premieres of major works including his Fifth and Sixth Symphonies and Fourth Piano Concerto. Louis Langrée will conduct the festival orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: So Long to the Analog Era; Home Movies Reborn on DVD
text: OVER the years, we have videotaped many precious moments: the birthday parties, the out-of-tune recorder concerts, the school plays (“Is that him? No, look behind the moving cactus”), the baseball all-star game (lovely except for the voiceover of my shouting “Over here! Look over here!”).

headline: Hands-On Role for Wife in Thompson’s Campaign
text: One Friday afternoon last month, Jeri Kehn Thompson took attendance at the testing-the-waters presidential campaign headquarters of her husband, Fred D. Thompson. Mrs. Thompson checked to see which staff members were working at their desks, said a Republican close to the campaign, and went on to chide those who were A.W.O.L.

headline: The Distance-Running King Isn’t Resting on His Laurels
text: Haile Gebrselassie walked through Manhattan on a sweltering afternoon, a slight man in a simple khaki outfit, drawing attention only because two burly bodyguards cleared a path for him. Gebrselassie’s trademark smile, unwavering in yesterday’s heat and commotion, erupted in laughter when two passersby wondered aloud if perhaps he was the president of an African country.

headline: Olmert Will Rework Aid Plan for Survivors of the Holocaust
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 3 — Trying to forestall an embarrassing protest march by survivors of the Holocaust, Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel on Friday agreed to rethink a widely criticized plan to give them a monthly stipend of about $20.

headline: Preventing the Next Bridge Collapse (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fannie Hillsmith, Distinctly American Cubist, Dies at 96
text: Fannie Hillsmith, a late-blooming Cubist painter, died on July 27 at her home in Jaffrey, N.H. She was 96.

headline: In Tanning Circles, the Roof Is Becoming History
text: A lone cluster of clouds gathers demurely behind the Con Edison Building as Claire Kuhn and Jessica Watson spread their striped beach towels into a pristine pool of sun that has formed on the roof. Un-self-consciously, they splay their bikini-clad bodies toward the light.

headline: Centrist Democrats Still Have a Role (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Britain Responds to Disease Outbreak
text: LONDON, Aug. 4 — British authorities burned 60 head of cattle found infected with foot and mouth disease on a farm in southern England today as they moved quickly to try to contain any spread of the disease that devastated the British livestock industry in 2001.

headline: Understated Safety Slips Into a Starting Role
text: ALBANY, Aug. 3  It was just about a year ago when James Butler, a little-known Giants safety, was cleared to practice after surgery on his kidney. He reluctantly met with reporters, and short stories were written about the surgery he had to unclog a blockage, the extra padding he would wear under his uniform and the extra fluids doctors told him to consume.

headline: Our Man in Iraq, Embedded Unhappily
text: An appendix to Nicholas Kulish’s debut novel about a gossip columnist who finds himself embedded with the marines at the outset of the Iraq invasion notes that among the author’s favorite books are Evelyn’s Waugh’s “Scoop” and “Sword of Honour” trilogy, Graham Greene’s “Our Man in Havana” and Joseph Heller’s “Catch-22.” Normally, this might be leading with one’s chin. But Mr. Kulish, the Berlin bureau chief for The New York Times, was actually embedded with the marines in 2003 while working for The Wall Street Journal, and he has brought home a story worthy of his literary idols. This is a very good book: funny, harrowing and sympathetic.

headline: Game-Show Royalty Clash, With Jester on the Sidelines
text: On “Grand Slam,” a single-elimination tournament of game-show champions that will be broadcast on GSN starting tonight, the questions are often difficult. They encompass algebraic equations, geometric proofs and anagrams for Irish playwrights. But no question is tougher than the one viewers may ask: What is Dennis Miller doing here?

headline: Arraigned on Rape Charges, Councilman Is Out on Bail
text: City Councilman Dennis P. Gallagher, who prosecutors say raped a woman in his Queens campaign office on July 8 after meeting her at a neighborhood bar, surrendered at a Forest Hills police station early yesterday to face 10 counts of rape, criminal sexual acts and assault. He pleaded not guilty at an arraignment later in the day and was released on $200,000 bail.

headline: In the Hayloft
text: At the moment, I’m sitting in my office watching someone else mow the lawn. He’s just caught the mower blades on some weed-barrier cloth at the edge of the hostas. He’ll probably clip the nearly hidden rocks just down the hill from the paperbark maple. And I wouldn’t be surprised if he got stuck in one of the holes I dug for a tree that never got planted. I never think about these things when I mow the lawn. I miss them instinctively. They’ve somehow grown into my bones like everything else about this place  bedrock surfacing in the middle pasture, monarchs drifting over the milkweed, bumblebees drinking at the edge of the spot we keep wet for the pigs.

headline: Shy Scot Steps Into Spotlight at the Women’s British Open
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 3  Before the Women’s British Open, it was easy to overlook the best title prospect from Britain, Catriona Matthew.

headline: U.S. Airstrike on 2 Taliban Commanders in South Wounds at Least 18 Civilians, Afghans Say
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 3  The United States military said Friday that it had carried out an airstrike on two Taliban commanders during “a sizable meeting” of insurgents in a remote region of Helmand Province in southern Afghanistan, but that it could not be sure the men had been killed.

headline: Abbas and Olmert May Meet in Jericho
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 4 — Palestinian officials said today that President Mahmoud Abbas and the prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, will meet on Monday in the West Bank city of Jericho. This would be the first meeting of the two leaders in Palestinian territory.

headline: Younger Players Give Yanks a Spark
text: Chien-Ming Wang and Robinson Canó will always be linked by their entry into the major leagues early in 2005. Their instant production helped save that sagging season and caused an epiphany for the Yankees’ management.

headline: Belarus: Russia Suspends Threat of Gas Cuts
text: Gazprom, the Russian natural gas monopoly that is controlled by the Kremlin, said it would not cut natural gas shipments to Belarus, signaling an end to a payment stand-off that had threatened customers downstream in Europe. The announcement was made after Belarus agreed in negotiations to pay the nearly $460 million it owed in back payments, according to Gazprom. The first payment was made yesterday, and Gazprom said Belraus had agreed to pay the balance within a week. The pricing dispute underscored anew the shifting relations between the Kremlin and Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, the Belarussian president, who has relied in part on Russian support to maintain what Western officials have called the last dictatorship in Europe.

headline: Valerie Plame Wilson Loses C.I.A. Lawsuit
text: A federal judge has ruled in favor of the C.I.A. in its effort to prohibit the former agent Valerie Plame Wilson from disclosing the dates she worked for the agency in her coming book, Publishers Weekly reported yesterday. Ms. Wilson, along with her publisher, Simon & Schuster, filed a lawsuit in late May in New York seeking to stop the C.I.A. from interfering with publication of the book, “Fair Game,” right. In their suit they argued that since the dates of Ms. Wilson’s C.I.A. service have been made public, she should be able to use them in her memoir. But Judge Barbara Jones ruled that the dates were never declassified, and said that a letter from the C.I.A., which neither Ms. Wilson nor her publisher has seen, convinced her that there were national security reasons for keeping the dates out of the book. A spokesman for the publisher said that it was “disappointed in the court’s ruling, which we believe runs counter to the First Amendment, sets a dangerous precedent and creates an unreasonable standard by which the government can disappear public information and rewrite history.” He added that no decision had been made about whether to appeal the ruling, but that Simon & Schuster still expected to release the book this fall.

headline: Inching Along, Divers Battle Jagged Debris and Currents
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 3 — Along the banks of the Mississippi on Friday, people found bluffs and outcroppings and stood there in clusters, watching. Except for a lucky few, who glimpsed divers slipping in and out of the water, they were watching a drama that was invisible.

headline: European Company Close to Reaching Libyan Arms Deal
text: PARIS, Aug. 3  — European Aeronautic Defense and Space, Europe’s largest aerospace company, confirmed Friday that it was close to signing two weapons contracts with the government of Libya. It would be the first arms deal with the North African country since the European Union lifted military sanctions on it nearly three years ago.

headline: Limits Sought on Use of Surplus U.S. Ships
text: A Senate committee unanimously approved an amendment to the Coast Guard reauthorization bill that would more tightly restrict how private owners could use surplus Coast Guard vessels obtained from the government.

headline: Hundreds of Inspectors Check Nation’s Old Steel Bridges
text: On the old bridge that carries Missouri Route 5 over the Lake of the Ozarks, near a place called Hurricane Deck, men with hammers spent yesterday whacking the girders and plates on the underside and listening to the voice of the steel. A subtle whisper could indicate a crack that could cause a collapse like the one in Minneapolis on Wednesday.

headline: Tigers’ Pérez Is Suspended 80 Games After Failed Test
text: Detroit Tigers infielder Neifi Pérez’s season is over after it was announced that he tested positive for a banned stimulant for the third time.

headline: For Families of Missing, an Agonizing Limbo
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 3 — They are the missing, the unrecovered.

headline: Pampered Princess to Take On Colts in the Hambletonian
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 2 — Given the right circumstances and the right horse, a filly can defeat colts at the highest levels of racing. Rags to Riches proved that in the Belmont Stakes in June. It could happen again Saturday.

headline: Drug Gangs Use Violence to Sway Guatemala Vote
text: GUATEMALA CITY — It is election time in Guatemala and that means rallies and banners — and body bags.

headline: Federal Rules to Improve Design of Highway Bridges Will Go Into Effect in October
text: In October, the federal government will begin enforcing new rules for highway bridge design meant to make new structures more efficient, more reliable, safer and longer lived — and implicitly better than hundreds of thousands of existing spans across the nation.

headline: Broadway Melodies
text: The 2008 lineup of Lyrics & Lyricists, the series on the American Songbook at the 92nd Street Y, will include Ted Sperling singing the songs of Sammy Cahn (1913-1993) in January; Rob Fisher exploring Fred Ebb (1928-2004) in February; and Deborah Grace Winer on the songs of Carolyn Leigh (1926-1983) in March. The cabaret singer Jeff Harnar will make his first appearance as artistic director in May for a romp through the songs of 1959, a year that had a remarkable number of soon-to-be-classic musicals, including “Gypsy,” “The Sound of Music” and “West Side Story.” Andrea Marcovicci will conclude the season in June with a show devoted to a selection of songs written after 1965. The shows will take place on Saturday nights at 8, Sundays at 3 and 8 p.m., and Mondays at 2 and 8 p.m. Information: (212) 415-5500 or www.92Y.org/lyrics.

headline: Iraqi Soccer Heroes Return Out of Sight of Adoring Fans
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 3 — They won the Asian Cup on the most public of stages, but Iraq’s soccer heroes returned home on Friday to celebrate behind the blast walls and razor wire of Baghdad’s Green Zone, far from the gaze of their disappointed fans.

headline: Bulging Profits in U.S. Often Originate Overseas
text: AMERICAN companies have been very profitable in recent years — but not necessarily because of the American economy.

headline: The Columbine Syndrome
text: Have you followed the series of articles in The Times about Joshua Komisarjevsky, the Cheshire, Conn., 26-year-old who, on early parole for a long string of late-night home robberies, teamed up with an accomplice and broke into a nearby house, sexually assaulted a woman and at least one of her young daughters, beat the father with a baseball bat and left them all to die in a fire? (The father alone survived.)

headline: Board Calls Police Dept. Lax on Cases of Misconduct
text: The Police Department has increasingly failed to prosecute New York City police officers on charges of misconduct when those cases have been substantiated by the independent board that investigates allegations of police abuse, officials of the board say.

headline: Italian Priest Accused of Sexual Assault by Ex-Clients
text: ROME, Aug. 3 — A prominent Italian priest who is close to some of Italy’s most powerful politicians has been accused by men who were once clients of his drug rehabilitation charity of sexually abusing them, his spokesman confirmed Friday.

text: Greg Winter and Larry Rohter discuss Brazil’s global warming policies.

headline: Waiting for the Truth on Corporal Tillman
text: Now that the Army has completed its seventh inquiry into the death of Cpl. Pat Tillman and top military leaders have testified in Congress, we still don’t know who concocted a phony story about how Corporal Tillman died and whether the White House knew it was happening. Congress needs to clarify whether this messy affair reflects astonishing incompetence or a conspiracy to exploit a famous soldier’s death.

headline: Jekyll Has a New Name, but He’s the Same Old Guy
text: The inspiration for “Jekyll,” an odd and oddly addictive four-part mini-series that begins tonight on BBC America, is of course the Robert Louis Stevenson story, but somebody involved also seems to have been spending a lot of time watching “Un Chien Andalou.” Tight shots of eyeballs abound, and though nobody slashes one with a razor, as in that famous short film by Luis Buñuel and Salvador Dalí, the mere appearance of an iris and pupil, filling the screen, has a similar creep-out effect.

headline: The Van Gogh That Wasnt
text: Experts have determined that “Head of a Man,” a painting attributed to van Gogh for more than 70 years, is a fake, probably painted by one of van Gogh’s peers, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Gerard Vaughan, the director of the National Gallery of Victoria, in Australia, said that a team at the van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam had found that the painting differed stylistically from the artist’s other works and was mostly likely painted by one of his contemporaries. The painting was taken to Australia in 1939 by Keith Murdoch, father of the media mogul Rupert Murdoch. The museum bought it in 1940 for about $3,500. “It was purchased as a van Gogh work, and had been accepted as a van Gogh for more than a decade” before the purchase, Mr. Vaughan said in a statement. The painting’s authenticity was first called into question last August, when it was on display at the Dean Gallery in Edinburgh. Critics said the work, dated 1886, was of a different style than other van Gogh paintings of the same period and was not mentioned in any of the artist’s letters. When the Edinburgh show closed, the National Gallery of Victoria sent the painting to the van Gogh Museum for analysis. “It is very important to make the point that it’s not a forgery,” Mr. Vaughan told reporters. “There is no evidence to suggest that someone produced this picture ... to pass it off as a work by van Gogh.” When it was thought to be a van Gogh, the painting had been valued at about $21 million.

headline: Rodriguez Is Youngest to Reach 500 Home Runs
text: After waiting eight games to hit his 500th home run, Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez did not wait long today to finish the drama. He drilled the first pitch he saw from Kansas City pitcher Kyle Davies deep to left field for his milestone homer.

headline: Jobs Growth Slid in July, Echoing Drift
text: Job creation slackened last month, extending a trend of softening employment growth that mirrors the modestly downward path of the economy.

headline: A Family’s Benign Neglect at Dow Jones
text: “The primary reason I was in favor of the deal,” said Elisabeth Goth Chelberg on Wednesday, “is because I did not think that family ownership was ever going to be in the best interest of the company.” She paused for a second, and then offered a small, sad correction. “I mean this family ownership.”

headline: Californian Arrested on Terror Charges
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3  — Federal authorities said Friday that a California man has been arrested on terrorism-related charges and indicted along with his Malaysian brother, a fugitive and suspected leader of Jemaah Islamiyah, the group blamed for killing 202 people in the 2002 bombing of a nightclub in Bali, Indonesia.

headline: Over-40 Players Do Their Part at the Old Course
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 3  A one-under-par start at the Women’s British Open was not good enough for the defending champion, Sherri Steinhauer. Before her second round at the Old Course, she altered her putting stance.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10 P.M. (ABC) MASTERS OF SCIENCE FICTION The physicist Stephen Hawking narrates this new four-part anthology series, featuring adaptations of some of the genre’s most famous short stories, performed by actors including Malcolm McDowell, Terry Quinn, Elizabeth Rohm, Brian Dennehy, John Hurt, James Denton and Anne Heche. First: “A Clean Escape,” based on John Kessel’s short story, set in a post-apocalyptic future, about Dr. Deanna Evans (played by Judy Davis, above), a psychiatrist charged with interrogating a distinguished if befuddled man (Sam Waterston) who appears to be having a memory lapse. Mark Rydell (“On Golden Pond”) directed from a script by Sam Egan.
