headline: Gary Anderson speaks about the F1 spy scandal in the virtual paddock
text: Yesterday our reader, Toof, asked a question for the virtual paddock. I decided that the best person to answer the question was not a team member, who might have a slanted point of view, but Gary Anderson, a former technical director at Jordan, and then Stewart Grand Prix and then Jaguar. Anderson is now working as a commentator for the Setanta Sports television channel in Ireland. Gary kindly accepted to answer Toof’s question.

headline: A Crowd Chases Leaders at U.S. Open
text: Things got a little bit tighter at the top of the U.S. Open as the leaders after the sixth round, Benjamin Finegold and Amon Simutowe, drew quickly with each other in Round 7 and were caught by Tegshsuren Enkhbat, a master, who won his seventh round game. The U.S. Open is being played in Cherry Hill, N.J. The games can be followed live or replayed at Monroi.com.

headline: Influential Wives on the Trail
text: The role of candidates’ wives was analyzed in the press in two very different ways today. The Times’s Michael Cooper and Marc Santora bring you the Fred D. Thompson camp’s internal debate about whether his wife, Jeri Kehn Thompson, is helping or hurting by getting involved in day-to-day operations. But looking back, it appears that whatever liability Hillary Rodham Clinton’s assertive reputation posed for her husband’s campaign in 1992, the way she conducted herself then is reaping major benefits now.

headline: Comings and Goings
text: Airports are full of grumpy travelers who have either sat or are about to be seated in cramped spaces for a long time. So spas in airports seem logical. Xpresspa has taken the idea and run with it, having opened full-service spas in airports like John F. Kennedy, Dallas-Fort Worth and Raleigh-Durham. Now the company is going global. Last month, it opened not one but two new spas at Cancún International Airport, and is scheduled to open a center at Amsterdam Schiphol Airport on Nov. 1. Built with all-natural materials, all of the spas offer massages, waxing, facials and manicures/pedicures (www.xpresspa.com). ... Olivia.com, a company that caters to lesbians, is offering a Caribbean cruise to promote awareness and raise money for breast cancer research. “Cruise for Our Cause,” scheduled for March 30 to April 6 of next year, will include a walk led by a lesbian sports celebrity and an auction. Items will be donated by Melissa Etheridge and the music group Heart, featuring Nancy Wilson (above) and Ann Wilson, who are also scheduled to perform during the cruise. Tickets start at $1,499. ... In celebration of the 10th anniversary of Hong Kong’s becoming part of China, the Langham Hotel, Hong Kong, is offering the Decennial Celebration package. Good through Sept. 30 (subject to availability and blackout dates), the two-night package includes a suite, a helicopter tour of the city, a cruise, dinner for two at T’ang Court, daily breakfast, a laundry allowance and round-trip transportation between the airport and the hotel. Rates start at $1,997 (hongkong.langhamhotels.com). ...Through the end of the summer, discounted midweek packages are available at bed-and-breakfasts like the St. Francis Inn in St. Augustine, Fla. The deal includes an evening ghost walk, a bay cruise, museum admissions and two nights of accommodations for $179 per person a night, based on double occupancy. The Long Dell Inn in Centerville, Mass., is offering a two-night package that includes two round-trip ferry tickets to Martha’s Vineyard or Nantucket ($349 a night per person, based on double occupancy). See www.bnbfinder.com/midweek for more deals and details. ... Eurosocks (www.eurosock.com) has introduced a line of socks and underwear: TravelSox. The garments, designed for long days on your feet or for long flights with little wiggle room, cost $29.95; underwear starts at $18.

headline: Her Mother, Her Self
text: As a novelist known for chronicling the vanishing world of working-class Irish Catholics, you bring a tone of almost-religious adoration to your latest subject — your mother, whose death dominates your new memoirs, “Circling My Mother.” My mother really loved me. And one of the gifts that I have been given is that I have never thought for one second of my life that I was not greatly beloved.

headline: Little Girl Loved and Lost

headline: A Bridge Collapses
text: The nation’s physical foundations seem to be crumbling beneath us. Last week, a 40-year-old interstate highway bridge collapsed in Minneapolis, plunging rush-hour traffic into the Mississippi River 60 feet below. Two weeks earlier, an 83-year-old steam pipe under the streets of Manhattan exploded in a volcano-like blast, showering asbestos-laden debris. And two years before that, substandard levees gave way in New Orleans, opening the way for the floodwaters of Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Supplying Homers, but Not Necessarily in Demand
text: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 4 — Outside of San Francisco, there are not many places in Major League Baseball that Barry Bonds can find peace. Everywhere he goes, he is unwanted. Every time he takes the field, he is booed.

headline: It’s, Like, a Buddy Film by, Like, Buddies
text: SETH ROGEN really does look that way. In life the fuzzy-headed nebbish from “Knocked Up” is, well, a fuzzy-headed nebbish, though these days he appears a little trimmer — is somebody training for next year’s “Green Hornet”? — than when he hooked up with Katherine Heigl in the hit movie. (Mr. Rogen recently agreed to help write and possibly star in “Green Hornet,” Columbia’s planned movie about the comic-book hero.)

headline: Deal Redo
text: An older gentleman asked my father-in-law, Steve, a coin collector, to evaluate a gold coin. Steve gave an off-the-cuff evaluation of $80, then offered to buy it. The gentleman accepted. Some days later, Steve discovered that the coin could be worth five or six times his original estimate. Must he seek out the former owner and renegotiate? — James S. A. Brown Ill., Nashville

headline: Think Your Dog Is Smart? Its Collar May Be Even Smarter

headline: Storm Watch
text: Warm air rises and forms a cumulus cloud. It keeps rising, and the cloud churns into a thunderstorm. One thunderstorm in every 10,000 breeds a tornado. One tornado in a hundred gains enough speed to rank as an F4 on the Fujita scale of intensity. An F4 is categorically devastating. One tornado in a thousand is even worse than devastating. The winds of an F5 swirl us beyond belief. According to T. Theodore Fujita — a researcher seen here to resemble a ruthless whirlwind himself — in an F5, “incredible phenomena can occur.”

headline: Subprime Mortgages Linked to Rise in Foreclosures
text: MOUNT VERNON

headline: Festival Presents Storytelling as Theater
text: THE seventh annual Mohegan Colony Storytelling and Music Festival, to be held on Saturday in Crompond, is not just for children. While the program includes events for families and a separate venue for children’s performers, the focus is on stories for adults. A roster of storytellers will entertain grown-up audiences from the historic Martha Guinsberg Pavilion stage, where Paul Robeson, Isadora Duncan, Theodore Bikel and Pete Seeger once stood.

headline: Lost Pets
text: A literary omnivore, Nicholas Christopher is versed in classical lore and pulp fiction, and his novels, at their best, are a thrilling amalgam of the two: erudite, lyrical and breathlessly paced. In what may be a sly wink at “The Da Vinci Code,” his latest effort concerns a medieval manuscript with a whiff of heresy, suppressed and possibly destroyed by order of the pope. But the story that unfolds features neither murderous monks nor ritual orgies. Here we’re in the hands of a different kind of writer, and his language is primarily that of fable. The opening line sets the tone: “The first beast I laid eyes on was my father.”

headline: Drawing Fire, Judith Giuliani Gives Her Side
text: It has not been an easy few months for Judith Giuliani. Her rollout to the public received rocky reviews from the political class, Republicans included. A series of negative articles about her shopping habits, marital past and supposedly testy relations with campaign staff followed. Her appearances alongside her husband, Rudolph W. Giuliani, grew suddenly scarce — and some analysts suggested that she keep it that way.

headline: A Snack Bar on the Beach
text: In Sea Cliff Village on Long Island Sound, with its new boardwalk, it costs $20 for nonresidents ($10 for residents) to use the beach for the day.

headline: Maine Loses His Composure and the Mets Lose a Game in Chicago
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 4  There were still six innings of baseball to be played Saturday when the Mets lost. Their afternoon unraveled in the time it took for John Maine to pound his glove against his hip, a visceral reaction to what would have been an inning-ending call at first base that instead went against his team.

headline: Italian With a Nod to the Venetians
text: THE Tuscan chef who introduced me to Italian cooking used to joke that you don’t need a G.P.S. to travel in Italy; the regional differences are so evident in the cuisine that you can always tell where you are by the food you’re eating.

headline: 3 Relatives Are Hurt in Stabbing at Home
text: A 26-year-old New Jersey man stabbed his sister and her young daughter and slashed her infant son across the face during a dispute yesterday, the police said, adding that all three were expected to survive.

headline: ‘Doors Open’

headline: Inside the List
text: BURKE’S BLOWDOWN: The great crime writer James Lee Burke turned 70 in December. As a kind of belated birthday present, his new novel, “The Tin Roof Blowdown,” is receiving some of the best reviews of his career — the book enters the fiction list this week at No. 4. Burke has long written about Louisiana’s Gulf Coast, and in “The Tin Roof Blowdown” he pokes around in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrinia. In the book, his stalwart hero, Detective Dave Robicheaux, is among the relief workers looking for survivors in the flood. The message boards on Burke’s Web site are full of posts arguing that the book “should be required reading for the boys and girls in Washington, D.C.” Writing in The Washington Post, the thriller critic Patrick Anderson called Burke’s novel “the best fictional portrait of Katrina that we have so far.” But Anderson urged readers to keep Burke’s achievement in perspective: “There’s a bigger, better novel, perhaps by some as-yet-unknown Robert Penn Warren, waiting to be written about this American tragedy.”

headline: Great Wedding! But Was It Legal?
text: IN an era of six-figure weddings when couples obsess about the band playlist and hand towels for the restrooms, one question may get short shrift: Is the person performing the wedding legally able to do so?

headline: Jill Jacobs, Guy Austrian
text: Rabbi Jill Jacobs and Guy Izhak Austrian are to be married this afternoon at the Westside Loft, an events space in New York. Rabbi Shira Stutman is to officiate.

headline: On Big Screen, the Right Play Can Help Advance the Plot
text: In “The Seventh Seal,” the 1957 film directed by Ingmar Bergman, who died last week, a game of chess between a knight and death is one of the central plots and one of the most memorable images in film history.

text: Kate Crist and Ellen Sprovach are to be joined in a civil union ceremony this morning at the Grenville Hotel in Bay Head, N.J. The Rev. Jennifer Ansbach, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate.

headline: Man’s Killing by Officer Could Be Case for Grand Jury
text: Eleven weeks after a driver was shot dead by an off-duty police officer in the Bronx, lawyers in the case say they are expecting a decision soon on whether the case will go to a grand jury.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A New Luster in the Ancient Heart of Brittany
text: ON a recent summer afternoon, a tiny cafe called La Petit Epicerie, in the heart of Nantes, was packed with diners. Pascaline Lelard, a local real estate agent, très à la mode, sat down at a communal table with a flourish, spreading out her black flounced skirt and smoothing her wavy blond hair behind one ear. She chatted briefly with the owner, Christophe L'Hermiteau, who returned with a large salad, dressed with sesame seeds and herbs, anointed with a slice of toast topped with tzatzki and smoked salmon. Ms. Lelard then turned to me, sitting alone with a red notebook, jotting down details on the interior (antique tables, a banquet laden with home-made desserts).

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: DEVILS IN THE SUGAR SHOP. By Timothy Schaffert. (Unbridled, paper, $14.95.) Think “Sex and the City.” Now make the city ... Omaha. The circle of women in this sprightly and eager-to-please novel — an artist, a writer, a hostess of sex-toy parties and a pair of twins who own a bookstore — are wise and worldly, enjoying the gentrification campaign that has given them their own ersatz Manhattan. Ashley, a writer of sexy novels that don’t sell very well, conducts erotica-writing workshops and fights valiantly against the genre’s clichés, “forbidding any character’s mouth from forming into ‘a perfect O’ of pleasure or surprise or delight, or into an O of anything, for that matter.” With her best friends — Viv, the artist, and Deedee, who has found great success selling, Tupperware-style, what used to be called “marital aids” — Ashley has made her little slice of redeveloped downtown Omaha into a swanky scene that meets chick lit’s exacting locational criteria. But its setting aside, can a novel still be called chick lit if (a) it’s written by a guy, and (b) most of the chicks in question are in their late 30s to early 40s and not especially interested in shoes? When the characters spend as much time as these do searching for love, sipping cocktails and seeking comfort in one another’s company, the answer is yes, though Schaffert’s version of it is a good deal smarter and funnier than most of the disposable volumes cluttering up this genre’s walk-in closet.

headline: Fully Prepared for Anything
text: ASSUMING the worst, Lesley Horton was extra-prepared when she embarked on her apartment hunt last spring.

headline: Bear Stearns Ousts a Top Executive
text: The crisis in the credit markets finally reached the executive suite of Wall Street firms last week, and the victim was an unexpected one: Warren J. Spector, a co-president at Bear Stearns who some had thought could become the firm’s next chief executive.

headline: Getting Coffee Is Hard to Do
text: A coordination problem (a term of art in economics and management) occurs when you have a task to perform, the task has multiple and shifting components, the time for completion is limited, and your performance is affected by the order and sequence of the actions you take. The trick is to manage it so that the components don’t bump into each other in ways that produce confusion, frustration and inefficiency.

headline: A Bad Deal Gets Worse
text: President Bush is understandably desperate for some kind of foreign policy success. But that cannot justify sacrificing his principled stand against weapons proliferation to seal a nuclear cooperation deal with India. The agreement could end up benefiting New Delhi’s weapons program as much as its pursuit of nuclear power.

headline: Scottish Wind Scatters the Field and Leaves Ochoa All by Herself
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 4 — After 54 holes, a British Open is again led by a young, Spanish-speaking golfer who is considered the best player never to have won a major. Last month at Carnoustie, Sergio García had his chance to spit-polish his record with a wire-to-wire victory but came up short. Now it is Lorena Ochoa’s turn.

headline: Thy Neighbor’s Stash
text: Robert H. Frank, a professor of economics at Cornell University, is an anthropologist of the ultra-rich. His prior books “Luxury Fever” and “The Winner-Take-All Society” have explored how the earning and consuming patterns of the very wealthy affect society at large. (He’s no relation to fellow pluto-anthropologist Robert Frank of The Wall Street Journal, author of the recent book “Richistan.”)

headline: They’re All No. 1, but Are They Worth It?
text: ON Wall Street, bragging rights are the coin of the realm, and money is the measure. Just as Hollywood studio heads watch box-office receipts to judge who’s on top, investment bankers anxiously wait to see who is No. 1 on so-called league tables, which rank banks based on the size of the deals they handle each quarter.

headline: A Former Soviet Retreat Grows Up
text: THE Lithuanian resort town of Druskininkai, built amid natural springs, peat bogs and pine forests, was for many years a favorite retreat for well-to-do Soviets and a playground for their architects. As such, the city, which is about 80 miles southwest of Vilnius, developed an infrastructure of wacky Soviet-style hotels and spa facilities.

headline: Privately Financed Condos in Mott Haven
text: MOTT HAVEN, a hard-luck neighborhood in the South Bronx, is getting its first-ever condominium project to be built with private financing, according to Wilhelm Ronda, the director of planning and development for Adolfo Carrión Jr., the Bronx borough president.

headline: Home Economics
text: The housing market is shaky, the dollar keeps weakening against the euro, the price of oil continues to rise and stock prices are volatile. Do Americans have reason to be gloomy about the economic outlook? For the second year in a row, the Op-Ed page has asked four writers from around the country to provide quarterly snapshots of their local economies. Here are their second dispatches.

headline: Building Blocks
text: IN the 1980s, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority began fixing decaying subway stations and upgrading underpowered trains. This mighty undertaking would have been delayed by untold years had the authority not managed to win exemption from the state’s environmental review law, which adds time, cost and unpredictability to projects. And New York City’s version of the state rules is even more burdensome. Now, with Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s ambitious plan to improve infrastructure and housing throughout the city, it is time to take the unwieldy review process off the table for some projects — and make it meaningful for others.

headline: The Art Is Striking, and So Are the Cars
text: RAY AND ALYSSA ABEYTA have remained passionate about North Williamsburg, Brooklyn, even as it has gone through various transformations, from artists’ refuge to hipster haven to its current incarnation as a locus of high-priced condominiums “only one subway stop from Manhattan.”

headline: Gelati in Colors to Rival a Rainbow
text: Maarten Steenman, who has won hearts and waistlines with his cocoa-dusted pyramids and pastel-colored macaroons at La Tulipe Desserts, in Mount Kisco, has a new passion: gelato. One corner of his sparkling European-style shop is now a gelateria, where behind a gleaming curve of glass, trays of smooth, rich gelato and summery sorbets are aligned like a child’s set of watercolors. Flavors vary, but on a recent day there were pistachio, torrone, praline and stracciatella gelati and sorbets of white peach, blood orange and coconut, to name a few. (Fear not, Mr. Steenman always has vanilla and chocolate.)

A case in point is the opposition to a plan to build two four-story apartment buildings in downtown Larchmont.

headline: Fate of 5 in U.S. Prisons Weighs on Cubans’ Minds
text: HAVANA, July 29  In Cuba, they call them “the five.” Their faces are plastered on walls and billboards everywhere. Merely being a relative of the five grants celebrity status. Even children know them by their first names  Gerardo, René, Ramón, Fernando and Antonio.

headline: Is Santa Fe Ready for a Makeover?
text: A SUNDAY evening in late June. A crowd of well-dressed people is spilling out of the St. Francis Auditorium at the Museum of Fine Arts in downtown Santa Fe, a grand adobe building some 90 years old, with monolithic mud towers and tender curvaceous walls connecting them. The late sun doesn't just gleam on the old adobe edifice. It's deeper than that. The red and orange that lights up on the walls, over the heads of the exiting crowd, seems to come from deep within them. The low light tranforms the scene into a vision.

headline: The Search for Nuance From the Fed
text: FOR an organization renowned for telegraphing its intentions, the Federal Reserve has left a lot of investors scratching their heads. Some take recent remarks by its chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, as a sign that the next eventual move in interest rates will be up, while others are just as convinced that a cut is in store.

headline: Anna and the Fling
text: Jill Bialosky’s novel “The Life Room” isn’t chick lit, but Eleanor Cahn, its protagonist, is certainly a Lit Chick. A Columbia professor, she’s preoccupied with “Anna Karenina” and is approaching 40 in a state of erotic conflict. She loves her husband and children, but is vaguely unfulfilled. Her friends don’t get her, and she yearns to feel her own pulse again: “Something has been brewing inside me and I can’t look away from it any longer: I see myself as I truly am, rife with deep, complicated desires.” A second adolescence seems under way.

headline: www.FriesWithThat?.com
text: WHO has never been put on hold while trying to order pizza, hot wings or moo shu pork? Who has never opened a delivery bag and discovered a Coke instead of a Diet Coke, or that the brown rice is as white as the napkins the restaurant neglected to include?

headline: Town Approves Rules to Fight ‘Pay to Play’
text: IN an effort to end the influence-buying practice known as pay to play, the Greenburgh Town Council has approved new regulations governing campaign donations that its members, in a statement, said could be the toughest in the state.

headline: 36 Hours in the Cinque Terre, Italy
text: WITH its miles and miles of breathtaking trails, the Cinque Terre along northern Italy's Riviera has long been a magnet for hikers. And while trekking through the five villages is certainly a backpacker's dream — each town is a unique destination carved rather amazingly into the steep terraced-vineyard coastline — that shouldn't preclude lesser jocks from heading to this wildly charming region. In fact, the only way to truly experience the sensory overload that this small area has to offer is by getting off those well-trodden paths. It's almost unfair how much intense beauty, great cuisine and amazing aromas are jampacked into such a compact space.

headline: Greening Up by Cutting Down on Plastic Bags

text: BAGHDAD, Aug 5 — President Jalal Talabani shuttled between Shiite and Sunni leaders in Baghdad today, trying to find a way of bringing Sunni Arabs back into the fold after they walked out of the government last week.

headline: Cheshire Home Invasion Fuels Race for Protection

headline: One, Only Sometimes the Loneliest Number
text: FOR starters, it’s not empty. Riders pile on and squeeze in to avoid the pinch of the closing doors. Arms reach out like branches from the thicket of standees to cling to available pole space; one young woman, stranded, braces herself by pressing a hand against a low ceiling. Hip-hop spills from headphones, people inexplicably wear sunglasses, and there’s the occasional whiff of bad breath.

headline: Correction: The Week Ahead: July 22-28
text: A film entry in the Week Ahead report on July 22 about the Museum of Modern Art’s retrospective of films released through Rialto Pictures misidentified Rialto’s national sales director. He is Eric Di Bernardo — not Mike Thomas, who once held the job. The entry also misstated Adrienne Halpern’s position at Rialto. She is co-president, not co-director for marketing and acquisitions.

headline: A Time to Heal
text: I remember being scared of the iron lung and not so much of the disease itself. Cause and effect were not yet prerequisites of childhood when I was growing up in the early ’50s in a small do-nothing town in western Massachusetts. There were overheard dinner-table conversations about an epidemic, and forced March of Dimes collections with my mother, but polio was a pretty vague menace for a rambunctious kid with trouble to get into. Vague, that is, until my friend’s sister caught the virus, and it became anything but, and the whole town, stunned, pitched in to send her to Boston to be saved.

headline: Sofia Yakren, Boris Bershteyn
text: Sofia Yakren and Boris Bershteyn are to be married today at Hakone Gardens in Saratoga, Calif. Rabbi Miriam Senturia will officiate.

headline: Opening the On-Ramp for Women
text: TWENTY-SOMETHING women have surged past young men on the salary scale in New York and other large cities, according to recent news reports. But these fast starters may find themselves blindsided as they progress into their 30s and 40s. Indeed, even though 59 percent of recent undergraduate degrees are held by women, more than 90 percent of the top earners at Fortune 500 companies are men. Sylvia Ann Hewlett has made it her mission to change that.

headline: Safe From Persecution, Still Bearing Its Scars
text: ALBANY, July 29 — Midway through the Sunday service at Emmaus United Methodist Church, the rustle of hymnals ceased and the piano fell silent. The new African choir stepped from the pews, and with the fervor of people who have endured decades of persecution, sang from the heart.

headline: Deficient, but Not Necessarily Dangerous
text: The I-35W bridge that collapsed into the Mississippi River last week had been diagnosed by engineers as “structurally deficient” two years ago. Should we be surprised it suddenly broke apart?

headline: A Friendship Too Tight for Breathing Room
text: IT began like many other romances: an introduction at a party. She and I slid quickly into an easy banter, drifting from the food table to the bar to the couch, smiling and laughing, the sparks between us practically visible. Anyone could see we were falling for each other. There was just one thing: neither of us was a lesbian.

headline: The Owl and the Forest
text: The spotted owl, once famously referred to by the first President Bush as “that little furry-feathery guy,” was not exactly a popular little guy among angry timber workers in the Pacific Northwest. Listed as an endangered species in 1990, the owl triggered a series of court cases that halted logging in millions of acres of old-growth forests and led President Clinton to put those acres permanently off limits. For a bird that few people have ever actually seen, the spotted owl has done as much as any other creature to save the American landscape.

headline: Correction: Photo in the Review of the ‘Age of Betrayal’
text: A picture on July 22 with a review of “Age of Betrayal: The Triumph of Money in America, 1865-1900,” by Jack Beatty, was published in error. It showed George Jay Gould, not his father, the financier Jay Gould.

headline: District Says Free Ride Must End
text: FOR many graduate students at Rutgers with young children, home is a residential dorm on the university’s campus that extends into Piscataway Township. Now, the local school district is fighting to recoup money it spends to educate the children of those graduate students in the town’s public schools.

headline: Carolyn Janiak, Scott Earthy
text: Carolyn Marie Janiak and Scott Richard Earthy were married yesterday at the Stanford University Memorial Church in Stanford, Calif. The Rev. Joanne Sanders, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Lebanese Election Brings a Tense Showdown
text: BIKFAYA, Lebanon Aug. 5 — Thousands of Lebanese voters went to the polls today to fill parliamentary seats left vacant by the assassinations of two prominent members, in a tense and emotional election that was widely seen as a bellwether of this country’s political direction.

headline: Cargo Ships Leaving Red Hook? Maybe Not So Fast
text: The scene at the Red Hook piers in Brooklyn on Friday morning was a standoff between grit and glitz.

headline: Erin McDuffie, Patrick Morales-Doyle
text: Erin Marie McDuffie, the daughter of Mary S. McDuffie and Montez E. McDuffie of Sandusky, Ohio, was married yesterday to Patrick Morales-Doyle, a son of Loretta J. Morales and Michael C. Doyle of Urbana, Ill. Meagan Prahl, a minister of the Universal Life Church and a cousin of the bride, officiated at the Boston Public Garden.

headline: Living Modestly Despite a Nice Nest Egg
text: By Silicon Valley standards, Brian Wilson is not rich. But despite a nest egg of roughly $1.5 million  small in comparison to many of his engineering friends’  Mr. Wilson, 40, feels less anxious about his wealth than many of his peers.

headline: The City of Napa, No Longer Willing to Be Left Behind
text: NAPA, Calif.

headline: On an Ancient Sea, Europe Dreams and Schemes
text: ROME

headline: Over the Top? At Times, but Always Fun
text: MOST restaurants in Water Mill are situated prominently on Montauk Highway. Muse Restaurant and Aquatic Lounge, which opened in mid-May, is harder to find, tucked into a corner of the Water Mill Shopping Center. It’s worth the hunt.

headline: 2 British Veterinary Labs Searched
text: LONDON, Aug. 5 – British health inspectors combed two veterinary laboratories in southern England today after it was discovered that the strain of foot and mouth disease at a farm four miles away was the same as used in the production of vaccine at the facilities.

headline: Getting Iraq Wrong
text: The unfolding catastrophe in Iraq has condemned the political judgment of a president. But it has also condemned the judgment of many others, myself included, who as commentators supported the invasion. Many of us believed, as an Iraqi exile friend told me the night the war started, that it was the only chance the members of his generation would have to live in freedom in their own country. How distant a dream that now seems.

headline: What’s the Big Deal? The State of the Rebate in the Summer of ’07
text: THE auto industry’s rebate frenzy is over, but there are still some alluring cash-back offers for buyers who can bring themselves to take advantage of automakers in distress, which is just about all of them.

headline: Patti’s Turn, if Not Always Rose’s
text: THE police were called to City Center last weekend when violence flared in the lobby during intermission at the closing performance of “Gypsy,” shortly after Patti LuPone stormed down the aisle one last time as Momma Rose.

headline: Dungeons, Dragons and Dope Beats
text: AUSTIN, Tex.

headline: Wall of Sound
text: I got my first hearing aids when I was 4 years old. To that point, I was slow to pick up language, slow to show an interest in the world. I mostly sat under a table in my family’s apartment and stared at the corner. “That boy is slow,” my grandfather said.

headline: Deon Bray and John Silvetz
text: Wilda Deon Bray and John Paolo Romano Silvetz were married yesterday afternoon at St. Andrew’s Dune Church in Southampton, N.Y. The Rev. Peter M. Larsen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Hotel Rooms Set the Scene, and 45 Artists Star
text: Several years ago I asked Denise Markonish, the former curator of Artspace in New Haven, whether she had ever collaborated on a project with other contemporary art museums in Connecticut. It was a casual question that I had since forgotten — until I saw it repeated in the opening pages of the catalog for “50,000 Beds,” a joint exhibition by Artspace, Real Art Ways in Hartford and the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield. “The answer then was ‘No,’ ” the catalog said; “now, nearly five years later, the answer is ‘And how!’ ”

headline: With Pasture as His Canvas, an Artist Turns a Purple Heart Green
text: HAMPTONBURGH, N.Y.

headline: Correction: Evening Hours
text: The Evening Hours column on July 22 misspelled the surname of a guest at the Parrish Art Museum benefit on July 14. He is Eric Boman, not Bowman.

headline: Just a Taste of Home
text: OF the seven drinks currently on the specialty cocktails menu at Django, a Midtown brasserie and lounge, Mojnu Hoque created, well, seven of them. But he has never drunk one.

headline: Protecting the Public Came Last
text: Nearly two weeks after the sadistic killing of three members of the Petit family in Cheshire, Connecticut residents remain shaken. The details are infuriating. The police say that two parolees with lengthy arrest records, Joshua Komisarjevsky, 26, and Steven J. Hayes, 44, broke into the house at 3 a.m., beat and tied up Dr. William Petit, and proceeded to terrorize Jennifer Hawke-Petit and the couple’s two daughters, Hayley, 17, and Michaela, 11. By 10 a.m., Mrs. Petit and the two girls were dead.

headline: Patriots Who Love the Troops to Death
text: GERALD FORD spoke the truth when he called Watergate “our long national nightmare,” but even a nightmare can have its interludes of rib-splitting farce.

headline: Where the Jingling of Change Is the Sound of Unease
text: Her face was as creased and worn as old leather. A semicircle of blue ink was tattooed between her eyebrows, a sign of tribal belonging, and despite the sweltering heat, a thick scarf was wrapped tightly around her head. Sitting on the sidewalk on 37th Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens, she rattled a plastic yogurt container filled with coins at passers-by.

headline: Palestinians Say Olmert and Abbas Are Set to Meet
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 4 — Palestinian officials said Saturday that President Mahmoud Abbas and the prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, would meet Monday in the West Bank city of Jericho. It would be the first meeting of the two leaders in Palestinian territory.

headline: With a Hammer, Finding Ghosts in the Glass
text: BUENOS AIRES

text: Jennifer Lynn Marotta, a daughter of Antonia and Andrew J. Marotta of Fairport, N.Y., was married yesterday to Guthrie Chipman Collin, a son of Debbie and Richard C. Collin of Queensbury, N.Y. Arthur Eccleston, a Roman Catholic deacon, officiated at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in New York.

headline: Married to a Muscle Car
text: I’VE been around this car a long time,” Mike Tyrrell said as he leaned against the electric-blue ’65 Chevy Malibu SS and smiled.

headline: The Dispirit of ’67
text: Milford, Mich.

headline: Defending Champion Is Trying to Stop Going Backward
text: LONG POND, Pa., Aug. 4  An orange tongue of flame flicked at Jimmie Johnson as he sat in his crumpled stock car, but that was only a warning. A second tongue of flame shot over his blue helmet, and it singed his eyelashes.

headline: Shakespeare in Chaps and a 10-Gallon Hat
text: If Buffalo Bill Cody had wanted to give his audiences a bit of high culture along with his Wild West shows, he might have come up with something like the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival’s rip-snorting treatment of “As You Like It.”

headline: Series Raises the Curtain on the Muppets
text: WHEN Alan Hofmanis, 37, was a child, “The Muppet Show” bridged the generation gap between him and his father.

headline: Seungah Jeong and Elliot Taub
text: Seungah Jeong and Elliot Isaac Taub were married last evening. Mary Beaty, a chaplain of the Humanist Society, officiated at the Hotel on Rivington in New York.

headline: On the Riverfront, Warnings of an Aggressive Algae
text: A potentially devastating algae discovered in the Connecticut River in Vermont this summer could threaten trout streams throughout New England, prompting official warnings to fishermen and boaters to clean their boots and vessels to avoid carrying the algae from stream to stream.

headline: Parting Gift
text: I was worried that “To My Dearest Friends” would turn out to be a “You go, girl!” book. The elements were all in place. Two 60-ish New York women — Alice, aloof and self-contained, and Nanny, casual and effusive — meet when their recently deceased friend, Roberta, entrusts them with the key to a safe-deposit box and a note that says, “You’ll know what to do.” In the vault, the women discover a steamy letter to Roberta from an anonymous lover. Will they track down this shadowy figure? Will they become friends during the search, perhaps discovering a few truths about themselves along the way? What do you think?

headline: Extra Practice Pays as Bonds Ties Aaron’s Mark
text: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 4 — Barry Bonds was waiting, the San Francisco Giants were waiting and the baseball world was waiting. Eventually, Bonds was going to nudge into a tie with Hank Aaron on the career home run list. Even if it was not necessarily an untainted achievement, it was inevitable. That inevitability rumbled into reality on Saturday night.

headline: Baby’s First Diet Pill
text: Why do people get fat? We habitually divide the causes of obesity into two categories: genetic predisposition (having lots of overweight relatives) and lifestyle choices (eating too many chips or even, according to a recent study, having fat friends). A new field called developmental programming maintains a third possibility: that obesity, like many aspects of our physiology, can be traced to the months just before and after birth, when the brain and other organs are still fine-tuning themselves.

headline: The Republicans Candidate Debate
text: The following is a transcript of the Republican candidates debate hosted by ABC News and moderated by George Stephanopoulos, of ABC News, and David Yepsen, of the Des Moines Register.

headline: In a Maze of Indexes, Finding Prices to Live By
text: HOW fast is the cost of living rising?

headline: G.I. Gets 110 Years for Rape and Killing in Iraq
text: A 23-year-old Army private was sentenced last night to 110 years in prison, a day after a military jury convicted him of rape and four counts of murder for his role in the attack last year on an Iraqi family in Mahmudiya, a hostile Sunni Arab town south of Baghdad.

headline: Correction: The Week Ahead: July 15-21
text: A film entry in the Week Ahead report on July 15 about screenings of the digitally restored version of the 1927 film Fritz Lang film “Metropolis” included incorrect information from the film’s distributor about the amount of material that was restored. The restored version contains more than 1,200 rescued shots, not 1,200 rescued scenes.

headline: Young Athletes Try New Coach: The Psychologist
text: A competitive gymnast for most of her life, Heather Benjamin has traveled the country and won her share of awards. But last year she developed a fear of jumping from one bar to the other in the uneven bars event. So she did something familiar to professional sports stars — she talked to a sports psychologist.

headline: Correction: Wrapped in the Star-Spangled Toga
text: An article on July 1 about comparisons of America to ancient Rome referred imprecisely to a statue of George Washington once housed in the United States Capitol. The sculptor, Horatio Greenough, modeled his work after a Classical statue of the Greek god Zeus. Although Greenough’s unpopular statue had been nicknamed “George Jupiter Washington” — after Zeus’s Roman counterpart — it was not “Washington in the guise of a Roman god.”

headline: We’re All Geeks Here
text: San Diego

headline: Larry Mathews, a 24-Hour Hairdresser, Dies at 86
text: Larry Mathews, who earned a reputation as New York’s most wide-awake hairdresser by opening what seems to have been the city’s first 24-hour beauty parlor to serve insomniacs, talk-show guests, showgirls and other working women, died on Tuesday in Aventura, Fla. He was 86.

headline: Buzz Marketing
text: About a year ago, Philips Norelco began the push to sell a device called the Bodygroom as a product to help men shave areas of the body other than the face. At the time, according to Jim Olstrom, director of the home division of the retail-data collection firm NPD Group, the idea of a product specifically made for below-the-neck shaving barely existed. Today, the Bodygroom is one of at least four products in what’s seen as a distinct and fast-growing category; nearly 250,000 body-hair trimmers have been bought in the United States in the last year, according to NPD data (which does not count Wal-Mart). “Nobody was talking about this category,” Olstrom says. “Now it’s completely out in the open.”

headline: Condo Music
A French Actress’s Life on Screen. Kind Of.
text: PARIS

headline: When It Comes to Rebalancing, a Little Means a Lot
text: IT’S a question that has been on many investors’ minds since the stock market hit the skids two weeks ago: Should portfolios be rejiggered in light of rising market volatility?

headline: Don’t Let the Sun Catch You Tanning
text: THE villain in Danny Boyle’s new sci-fi thriller “Sunshine” is — spoiler alert! — a certain someone who wants our nearest star to go completely dim, even if all of humanity never gets to tan again.

headline: The Days and Nights of Maurice Cherry
text: AS his bus exited the Garden State Parkway, Maurice Cherry gazed out the window, waiting for the precise moment when the gleaming silhouette of Atlantic City would swim into view. Suddenly there it was, lit up like noon even at midnight.

headline: Laura Efros, Noam Kugelmass
text: Laura Lisa Efros, a daughter of Magdalena Efros of Haworth, N.J., and the late Norbert Efros, was married last evening to Noam Kugelmass, the son of Judy W. Kugelmass and Harold Kugelmass of Interlaken, N.Y. Rabbi Morton M. Rosenthal officiated at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia.

headline: Animals? In a Zoo? Heavens!
text: Animals? In a Zoo? Heavens!

headline: Doggy Bags
text: Novelty handbags often suggest different breeds of dog. There is the wrinkly shar-pei, right, whose folds of skin are reflected in an array of puckered leather bags. There also are dogs who call to mind the shaggy-look leather bags, above and left. The artisan dog handbags by Priscilla Snyder, bottom left, are intricately embroidered works of art. Some of Ms. Snyder’s newest bags are three-dimensional sculptures.

headline: Against the Current
text: They follow her along the banks of the Nile, entreating: “Halloo. Come here!” They hike up their djellabas and wade in after her. They want to row for her; they insist they are “bolice” officers. And in ways at once oddly innocent and salacious, they nudge the conversation toward sex. Of the Egyptian men she encountered in Aswan and Luxor, Rosemary Mahoney writes: “You never knew whether to give them a brisk slap for the impertinence or to welcome the irreproachable trust they seemed to offer. It was ... what made them interesting.”

headline: Grass Roots Rising
text: “Blessed Unrest” is about a movement that no one has noticed, not even the people involved. “The movement,” as Paul Hawken calls it, is made up of an unknowable number of citizens and mostly ragtag organizations that come and go. But when you do see it, you understand it to include NGOs, nonprofit agencies and a seemingly disparate range of people who might describe themselves as environmental activists, as well as people who might not describe themselves as anything at all but are protesting labor injustices, monitoring estuaries, supporting local farming or defending native people from being robbed of the last forests. There are a few billionaires, working hard to give their wealth away, and there are even some Christian evangelicals, who have decided the earth is not theirs to trash, but the movement is mostly about shared beliefs, even if those beliefs are unproclaimed. “Life is the most fundamental human right,” Hawken writes, “and all of the movements within the movement are dedicated to creating the conditions for life, conditions that include livelihood, food, security, peace, a stable environment and freedom from external tyranny.”

headline: Correction: 36 Hours in Edinburgh
text: The 36 Hours column last Sunday, about Edinburgh, Scotland, referred incompletely to air service between New York and Edinburgh. Although there are no direct flights between New York City’s two airports and Edinburgh, Continental does offer nonstop service from Newark.

headline: If the Shoe Fits, Write on It
text: EVERY edgy pastime eventually loses some of its outlaw luster, thanks to corporate America’s proficiency at borrowing lingo and imagery from the underground. Consider tagging, the act of covertly spray-painting nicknames and slangy messages on walls. Different from graffiti in that it refers primarily to script, not artwork, tagging is the sort of rebellious hobby that disaffected teenagers love and strait-laced adults abhor.

headline: Alexandra Pulver, John Bassett
text: Alexandra Bouchard Pulver, a daughter of Michele B. Pulver and Judge George J. Pulver Jr. of Catskill, N.Y., was married last evening to John Lancaster Bassett, a son of Jacqueline M. Bassett and William W. Bassett of Alamo, Calif. The Rev. Phillip Smith, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. Mary’s Church in Hudson, N.Y.

headline: Zelig of the Night
text: ONCE, a seemingly endless list of late-night radio talk-show hosts broadcast out of New York: Barry Gray, Long John Nebel, Tom Snyder, Big Joe Rosenfield and his “Happiness Exchange.”

headline: Our Town
text: When I first met with Judy Sigwalt and her fellow village trustee Paul Humpfer this past April, they were, understandably, feeling assured, if not emboldened. A few weeks earlier, with the endorsement of the two local newspapers, they were elected to their village board on the platform that their town, Carpentersville, Ill., should do everything in its power to discourage illegal immigrants from settling there. They vowed to pass a local ordinance that would penalize landlords that rented to illegal aliens and businesses that hired them. They also pledged to make English the official language of the village, which would mean discontinuing the practice of printing various notices — including building-code violations and the monthly newsletter — in both English and Spanish. The third candidate on their slate also won, giving them a majority on the board. Sigwalt and Humpfer considered their election a mandate. Indeed, many in this village consider them heroes. Their supporters wear buttons that read, “Illegal Means Illegal,” and: “I’m tired. Are you? Ask Me Why!” with a sickly looking bald eagle wrapped in the American flag.

headline: When a Co-op Building Commandeers a Terrace
text: Q Our terrace is the staging area for work on the co-op’s facade, rendering it virtually unusable. Are we entitled to a maintenance reduction?

headline: Lara Pellegrinelli, Steve Smith
text: Lara Veronica Pellegrinelli was married on Thursday to Steve Smith at Studio 450, a loft in New York that is used for events. Mary Beaty, a chaplain of the Humanist Society, officiated.

headline: Can a New Lease Halt Eviction?
text: Q If a landlord starts an eviction proceeding against a rent-stabilized tenant for nonpayment, but then during the proceeding the landlord sends the tenant a renewal lease and ultimately accepts the signed lease and an additional security deposit, what impact would that have on the eviction?

headline: The Loan Comes Due
text: SUDDENLY it’s not so easy to borrow.

headline: Six Novels of Clues to the Soul of Mother Russia
text: CONFRONTING the career-ending possibilities presented by a mass grave unearthed in central Moscow, a government supervisor in Martin Cruz Smith’s new novel, “Stalin’s Ghost,” frets aloud: “What if the grave runs under the entire court?”

headline: Erin Torneo and Sascha Paladino
text: AS a girl growing up in Connecticut, Erin Torneo was more likely to have her nose in a book than be dressing up as a bride. As a grown woman, she grew so weary of listening to friends dissect the intricacies of butter cream frosting and white dresses, she helped write a book about how society puts pressure on women to marry.

headline: Nicole Lipman, Michael Ellis
text: Nicole Shein Lipman, the daughter of Lydia Lipman and Dr. Derek Lipman of Lake Oswego, Ore., is to be married there this evening to Michael Sanford Ellis, a son of Suzanne Ellis of Orlando, Fla., and Raymond Ellis of McLean, Va. Rabbi Shlomo Levin, an uncle of the bride, officiated in a city park next to the home of the bride’s parents.

headline: Pedaling Through a City Reborn
text: A SOLITARY clarinetist tweaked out a mournful melody on a lawn in front of the Federal Chancellery, a sleek marble and concrete construction that looms over the Spree River. It was an overcast morning, and I was bicycling along the Spreepromenade, a gravel path that curves through the legislative heart of Berlin, the German capital. On either side of the river rose some of the striking new buildings that have confirmed the city's place at the forefront of modern architecture: the glass-domed Reichstag building and the Paul-Löbe-Haus, an annex to the German Parliament.

headline: Katherine Townshend and Robert Stockton
text: Katherine Elston Townshend, a daughter of Joan Elston Townshend of Berwyn, Pa., and the late John Frank Townshend, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert William Stockton, a son of Barbara B. Stockton and Richard Warren Stockton of Vero Beach, Fla. Barbara King Briggs, an Episcopal deacon and a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated at the Round Barn in Waitsfield, Vt.

headline: A Volatile Week Ends With a Thud
text: Volatility was the catchphrase for the stock market last week. Stocks veered up and down sharply, and a swoon in the last two hours of trading on Friday plunged the market into negative territory for the week.

headline: Energy Bill Adopted by House Requires Utilities to Use Renewable Power Sources
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 — The House passed a wide-ranging energy bill on Saturday that will require most utilities to produce 15 percent of their electricity from renewable sources like wind and solar power. President Bush has vowed to veto the bill because it does nothing to encourage increased domestic production of oil and gas.

headline: Kathleen Moran, James Fisher
text: Kathleen Mary Rose Moran, a daughter of Mary and James J. Moran of Garden City, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Marshall Fisher, the son of Suzanne and Marshall Fisher of Rockville, Md. The Rev. Timothy J. O’Connell, a minister of the Association for Contemporary Catholic Life, officiated at the Cosmos Club in Washington.

headline: Sexy Beast
Leslie-Anne Skolnik and Steve Brill
text: ON May 25, 2004, one of New York City’s foremost foragers, Steve Brill, and his wife, Leslie-Anne Brill, seemed to have been forsaken by nature’s generosity.

headline: Archive to Expand Access to Files on the Holocaust
text: BAD AROLSEN, Germany, Aug. 2  Like other Holocaust victims, Noemi Ban has gone back numerous times to survey the ghostly field of chimneys at Auschwitz-Birkenau, the Nazi concentration camp in Poland where she and her family arrived in July 1944, and she alone survived.

text: ISLIP

headline: After a Lull,  Signs of a Bump in Bankruptcies
text: Filing for bankruptcy was never a walk in the park, but until recently it was fairly easy to do. Why pay off your bills when you could liquidate and get a clean slate? That philosophy got out of hand, though, and lawmakers noticed.

headline: Kathleen Reeder, Matthew Paley
text: Kathleen Elizabeth Reeder and Matthew Gregory Paley were married yesterday afternoon at the Church of the Holy Comforter in Broomfield, Colo. Bishop Donald Hultstrand, who retired as the Episcopal bishop in the Springfield, Ill., diocese, performed the ceremony.

headline: 10 Ways to Keep Europe Within Reach
text: THE dollar recently plunged to a record low against the euro, pushing prices for gondola rides in Venice and beer in Brussels to new heights for American travelers. The sticker shock has been even worse in Britain, where the ratio of the pound’s value to the dollar’s has been more than 2 to 1. But you don’t have to eat at McDonald’s or stay at a fleabag hotel to afford a European vacation. Below are 10 ways to save money.

text: Preparing Ourselves for the Coming Storm

text: CAN the selection of a showerhead make or break a hotel brand? Some hotel executives seem to think so.

headline: Letting a Stair Lift Do the Climbing
text: IS going upstairs getting you down? You might be a candidate for a stair lift, a chair that runs up the staircase on a rail.

headline: Yellowstone’s Wolves Save Its Aspens
text: Aspens may be symbols of the West, but over the last half century, they’ve been disappearing from the Lamar Valley of Yellowstone National Park. The reason is not a mystery. The elk that winter there were eating the young aspen shoots before they had a chance to grow.

headline: Often on Point but Rarely in Charge
text: THE image of a woman rising on point, simultaneously authoritative and fragile, exalted and vulnerable, is central to ballet. As Balanchine wrote in a 1965 essay in Life, the ballet “is a woman.”

headline: Tasteful Shadings in Colors and Flavors
text: WHEN the tumbling translucent surf is only a block and a dune away, a restaurant cannot compete; it must complement. Blue succeeds effortlessly at both design and dinner.

text: Seven children were hospitalized yesterday after being overcome by carbon monoxide on a private boat near the Rockaways in Queens.

text: An Understudy on Broadway

headline: Zoe Billinkoff, Michael Furman
text: Zoe Ruth Lewin Billinkoff, the daughter of Dr. Sharon Lewin and Donald Billinkoff of New York, is to be married this evening to Michael Saul Furman, the son of Robyn Furman and Dr. Martin J. Furman of Providence, R.I. Rabbi Wayne M. Franklin will officiate at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York, with Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz taking part in the ceremony.

headline: Courting Fantasy Fans (and Everyone Else)
text: NEIL GAIMAN’S novel “Stardust,” the source for the new movie of the same name that opens Friday, is a bit of an anomaly among the works that have made him a legend in the comics world. To begin with, though it was originally published in four installments by DC Comics in 1997, “Stardust” was never a comic book series with panels and dialogue, like, say, Mr. Gaiman’s famous “Sandman.” It’s a prose novel with Arthur Rackham-like illustrations by Charles Vess, and came out in a comics format only because traditional book publishers didn’t want to spring for so much color printing. ”Stardust (Being a Romance Within the Realm of Faerie)” was subsequently reissued as a hardback and trade paperback, and in 1999 was published in a text-only version, without the Vess illustrations.

headline: Elizabeth Zeltser, Ronen Voloshin
text: Elizabeth Zeltser, a daughter of Natasha Zaitseff of New York and Mark Zeltser of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Ronen Voloshin, a son of Ilana Voloshin and Arkady Voloshin of Bethlehem, Pa. Judge Barrington D. Parker Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in the Southern District of New York officiated at the Boathouse Restaurant in Central Park.

headline: For Beer Tastes, on Beer Budgets
text: VISITING the big city can leave you parched, especially in summer. It's easy to develop a more-than-one-beer thirst as you gamely tramp from museum to museum, from landmark to landmark.

headline: Fire Guts Historic Building at a Tarrytown School
text: A fire, which may have been caused by a lightning strike, gutted a historic building that contained the library of the private Hackley School in Tarrytown, N.Y., early yesterday, school officials said.

headline: Amy Miller, Jeffrey Shaman
text: Amy Beth Miller, a daughter of Susan and Donald S. Miller of Bayonne, N.J., is to be married today to Jeffrey Abraham Shaman, a son of Carol Shaman and Col. Paul R. Shaman of Fairfax Station, Va. Rabbi Gordon Gladstone is to officiate at the Newark Museum.

headline: Don’t Be Afraid of Rupert Murdoch
text: London

headline: When Dangerous Mistakes Become a Pattern
text: WITH the July 17 airplane crash in São Paulo, in which 199 people died, aviation safety has once again become a matter of intense concern among travelers. But it is not just Brazil that is in the spotlight. In the last few weeks, planes landing and taking off have come within seconds of colliding at airports much closer to home — like La Guardia and Orlando International. How can consumers find out which airports, airplanes and airlines have a pattern of dangerous errors?

headline: Christmas Turkeys
text: In Washington, they call them earmarks. In New Jersey, they call them Christmas tree appropriations. They are pet grants quietly slipped into major legislation, usually at the last minute, that benefit someone or something in a legislator’s district. Whatever their name, they create the potential for big trouble.

headline: In Hollywood, a Sacred Cow Lands on the Contract Table
text: JASPER JOHNS isn’t paid based on the number of years his flag paintings remain popular attractions at museums. Rem Koolhaas doesn’t cash a check every time an architecture fan takes a trip to Seattle to see his space-age public library. So why should the writers, directors and actors responsible for box-office bombs like “Gigli” be able to pocket some cash every time somebody buys the DVD?

headline: Rats, Roaches and the Naked Man With the Gun
text: IN 1979 and 1980, my father, Esteban Torres, worked under an exterminator’s license setting traps in and fumigating businesses and homes throughout the Bronx and Manhattan. I won’t bore you with roach and rodent stories — those could run on forever. Instead, I’ll tell you about some of the people my father worked for, the ones he called crazy or knuckleheads.

headline: You, Your Friends, Your Friends of Friends
text: IN a way it all seems so obvious. Your friend found a lump in her breast, so you have that long-delayed mammogram. One by one your friends stop smoking, so you stop, too. Of course people are affected by their friends’ habits and their health.

headline: The Road to Rightville
text: As I grow older, I avail myself more and more of the ancient prerogatives of old men. I hitch my pants high, shake my head at the barbarous young and drive a stone-cold 55 on the highway. I’m risk-averse and dress as I please. (In my beginning is my end: I’ve evolved from slob to hipster slob to ironic slob back, finally, to slob.) I distrust change, labor unions and Al Sharpton and believe that at high enough rates income taxes become confiscatory. In short, I am white, privileged, middle-aged and boring. But one thing I am not, and never will be, is a conservative. The recent essay anthology “Why I Turned Right: Leading Baby Boom Conservatives Chronicle Their Political Journeys” (Threshold Editions, $23) has given us liberals a chance to think about why, even in our calcifying stodginess, American conservatism remains a nonstarter for us, a stack of loyalty oaths we’d never be tempted to sign.

headline: Vacation, All I Never Wanted
text: First the provocative statistic, then a discussion of how it has been interpreted and then my own reflections on the topic, The Decline of the American Summer Vacation, an already-much-scrutinized phenomenon that accounts, as it happens, for my need to write this article efficiently and swiftly. Like the roughly 50 percent of working Americans who won’t take warm-weather getaways this year (and the 46 percent of those who will take holidays but will stick by the pool instead of surfing the breakers so they can use their BlackBerrys and laptops), I’m scarily overtired and need to crash soon

headline: Up Front
text: Michael Beschloss, who not long ago was named the official “presidential historian” of NBC News, became interested in American presidents at the age of 8, when his parents took him to visit the Abraham Lincoln house in Springfield, Ill. “From that moment on,” he wrote in an e-mail message, “Lincoln was the man for me.” Soon after, “it dawned on me that one could write history books on presidents as a profession.” Beschloss has gone on to write about Franklin Roosevelt, Harry Truman, Dwight Eisenhower, John Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson. His latest book, “Presidential Courage,” recently spent nine weeks on the best-seller list. Asked how George W. Bush fits his idea of presidential courage, Beschloss observed: “Bush partisans will insist that the president was brave to go to war in Iraq because the outcome of his presidency would depend on whether or not America won. But presidential courage — as I define it in the book — is when a president risks his popularity for an important cause for which Americans of the future are grateful. At the moment, it’s sadly hard to imagine that future Americans will feel that way about the Iraq war.”

headline: The Independent
text: One of the fascinating side streets in American film is the history of “race pictures,” celluloid productions by black artists for black audiences during those decades when Jim Crow laws enforced segregation. The mainstay of race pictures was Oscar Micheaux (1884-1951), an intrepid filmmaker-novelist-entrepreneur whose career spanned four decades and who made more than 40 movies. Not surprisingly, given that he opened doors for future black filmmakers and collaborated with important figures like Paul Robeson and the novelist Charles Chesnutt, a whole scholarly industry has grown up around Micheaux. Now Patrick McGilligan, biographer of Alfred Hitchcock, Fritz Lang and George Cukor, has synthesized the advance work of these scholars and written “Oscar Micheaux,” a popular life of this colorful figure.

headline: Lost in Tehran
text: A memorable title will surely attract readers, but when a book becomes a classic, it’s hard to say whether the title has been part of its canonization or has merely become retroactively canonical. Would “Trimalchio in West Egg,” one of Fitzgerald’s initial choices, have in time accrued the same force as “The Great Gatsby”? “The Septembers of Shiraz,” poignant once you’ve read this first novel by Dalia Sofer, is, on its own, a title at once overly poetic and misleading. An American reader might be forgiven for thinking Sofer has written a romance set in the Napa Valley, “Sideways” with Vaseline on the lens. And that would be a great shame because “The Septembers of Shiraz” is a remarkable debut: the richly evocative, powerfully affecting depiction of a prosperous Jewish family in Tehran shortly after the revolution. In this fickle literary world, it’s impossible to predict whether Sofer’s novel will become a classic, but it certainly stands a chance.

headline: Not the President’s Men
text: Every American generation looks at history through the lens of its own preoccupations. If a book on those towering World War II generals Dwight Eisenhower, George Marshall and Douglas MacArthur had been published in the late 1960s or early ’70s, at the zenith of anti-Vietnam War sentiment, many readers would have found it (in a catchphrase of the time) “not relevant.”

headline: The Boy Next Door
text: What if it had been Mrs. Robinson who was the pursued, and Benjamin the pursuer? What if, when the young man came knocking, the grown woman hid, locked her bedroom door and “stayed motionless on her bed, not answering, hugging her knees tightly”? What if, when he refused to believe she couldn’t love him, she didn’t run to him, but from him?

headline: Family Resemblances
text: About three-quarters of the way through George Hagen’s galloping, brazenly eventful family saga, “Tom Bedlam,” the title character briefly pauses to catch his breath and ponder “the strange convergence of his past with the lives of his children.” As well he might — though “strange convergence” may actually understate the case. What seems to govern the fate of Tom and his kin over the 40-some years the story blithely spans might more accurately be described as pure, out-of-the-blue coincidence. One of his daughters calls it providence; another isn’t so sure. Readers could be similarly split: some delighting in the ingenuity of Hagen’s plotting, others finding its ease and godlike capriciousness a little (or more than a little) suspect. “Tom Bedlam” is the sort of novel that tends to be described, not always admiringly, as old-fashioned. But it’s odder, and better, than that: a strange convergence of the English novel’s estimable past and our own, rather less confident, present.

headline: The Days of Their Lives
text: There are certain faces in old portraits that feel familiar, oddly enough, by virtue of their very anonymity. If you’ve visited any of the stately homes of England, you’ll have seen them lurking high on the walls of the ancestral gallery, banished to the dim reaches far above the Canalettos the ninth earl brought back from his grand tour and Gainsborough’s notorious rendering of Countess Camilla en déshabillé. While the tour guide may linger eloquently over those, she’ll probably ignore the nondescript canvases of glum-faced Jacobean worthies, their lace and armor glinting dimly under darkened varnish.

headline: ‘Down the Nile’
text: ON THE DAY that I hoped to buy a rowboat in Luxor, Egypt, I was awakened, as I had been every morning in Luxor, by a Koranic antiphony drifting from the Islamic boys' school next door to my hotel. With all the zeal of a Baptist preacher's, a young boy's amplified voice shrieked repeatedly in Arabic, "There is no God but God, and Muhammad is his witness!" and a shrill chorus of his schoolmates howled the words back at him. I got out of bed and went to the window - at 7:00 a.m. the glass was already warm as an infant's forehead - and discovered that during the night many colorful cloth banners had been strung above the corniche, Luxor's Nilefront boulevard. In hand-fashioned Arabic characters, the banners read, "Welcome Mister President of the Government, Muhammad Hosni Mubarak, the Leader of Our Victorious and Progressive Destiny." Scores of teenage Egyptian soldiers in black uniforms, woolen berets, and white plastic spats lined the avenue in the ninety-eight-degree heat, more or less at attention, rifles at their sides, evidently awaiting the president's arrival. Profiting from a police barricade, the usually hectic street was, for once, mercifully quiet. Across the glittering ribbon of the Nile, the Temple of Hatshepsut and the Valley of the Kings lay blanketed in the pink morning light.

headline: ‘Tom Bedlam’
