headline: ‘15 Stars’
text: Not since the immense fame of Grant, Sherman, and Lee at the close of the Civil War have three generals become such household names as Douglas MacArthur, George C. Marshall, and Dwight D. Eisenhower by the climax of World War II. Colleagues, and on occasion competitors, they had leapfrogged each other, sometimes stonewalled each other, even supported and protected each other, throughout their celebrated careers.

headline: ‘Falling Behind: How Rising Inequality Harms the Middle Class’
text: Many years ago, I attended a lecture by a philosopher who began his talk with a thought experiment. For me as a listener, that approach worked so well that in the years since I have tried to employ it myself at every opportunity. A recent conversation with a neuroscientist friend shed some light on why this device is often so effective. Different parts of the brain, it seems, specialize in thinking about different things. When we are confronted with a question in a specific domain, blood flows to the relevant part of the brain, priming it to think more effectively about the related ideas to follow.

headline: ‘Oscar Micheaux’
text: Most people pronounced his last name "Mee-show," though some who knew him insist it was "Mi-shaw."

headline: ‘The Life Room’
text: She had been born with different colored eyes. One blue and the other green. When she looked at herself in the mirror, she felt as if she were split down the center, divided, as if one part of her were competing with the other. She had heard that if a person has dissimilar eyes at birth, it is quite possible that the two eyes were subjected to different pressures within the womb.

headline: ‘To My Dearest Friends’
text: Naked Charles pads from his shower to his semainier. He would not dream of turning on our light. Charles assumes I am asleep. After so many years, he senses his way in the dark.

headline: Puppets and Protest
text: A look at the work of the Bread and Puppet Theater, which is based on a farm in Glover, Vt.

headline: Coetzee’s Canon
text: A little knowledge may be a dangerous thing, but dangerous things are very often exciting, and only the truly saintly would deny that there is a pleasure in forming opinions of writers whom one has never read a word of. Without experience to cloud one’s judgment or information to slow one’s thinking, the passage from ignorance of a writer’s work to a vague acquaintance with its main elements — courtesy, say, of an essay or a review executed by someone better versed — can be a stimulating imaginative exercise. On the basis of brief descriptions and short quotations the reader is free to conjure up a figure who may not much resemble the artist in question but is rich in associations anyway and who will do — will have to do — for now (which sometimes, sadly, is all the time one has).

headline: Presidential Rebound
text: The president is a failure. His foreign policy is a mess, and he’s hounded by scandals at home. A hostile opposition has seized the Congress, and he’s fought to stay relevant in the face of humiliating approval ratings.

headline: Correction: For Tourists With Wet Noses
text: The Weekend in New York column on July 22, about bringing a pet along on a visit to New York, mischaracterized the W Hotels' policy on dogs. There are a $100 nonrefundable cleaning fee and a $25 charge above the daily room rate per night; dogs are not allowed at no extra charge.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE LAY OF THE LAND, by Richard Ford. (Vintage Contemporaries, $14.95.) The third installment, following “The Sportswriter” (1986) and “Independence Day” (1995), in the serial epic of Frank Bascombe — flawed husband, fuddled dad, writer turned real estate agent — was selected by the Book Review as one of last year’s 10 best books. It’s Thanksgiving 2000: the Florida recount grinds on, and Bascombe, now 55, battles prostate cancer, copes with a strange turn in his second marriage and logs long hours on the highways and back roads of New Jersey, taking expansive stock of middle-age defeats. “By now, we have gotten to know Frank Bascombe well enough to take his measure, and to appreciate that, like almost no one else in our recent literature, he’s life-size,” A. O. Scott wrote here.

headline: Editor’s Choice
text: THE U.S. ARMY/ MARINE CORPS COUNTERINSURGENCY FIELD MANUAL. Introduction by Sarah Sewall. (University of Chicago, paper, $15.) Crucial reading for understanding the huge demands of successful counterinsurgency.

headline: Hamilton/Alonso:  Echoes of Senna/Prost?
text: Until now the two leaders of the championship and their McLaren Mercedes team have done an excellent job of putting on a show of great friendship and teammate respect. Sure, Alonso complained about not having equal treatment, and Hamilton has been quick to tap the latter’s back in a big brotherly way…. But until now, and this qualifying scandal, there was never any indication that the Senna/Prost scenario might be able to play out again at McLaren.

headline: Overseas hunt for Vietnamese pho
text: My brother’s friend is as good a symbol of the new France as any. Born in Paris to Cambodian parents, she grew up in an immigrant area before moving onto university, then a job in finance, then a more conventionally French neighborhood. But when she wants to eat Asian, she returns to the 13th arrondissement of her childhood, where the streets are dotted with Chinese, Thai and Vietnamese restaurants.

headline: Sunday Morning Debate Blogging
text: After Party: This ABC debate was a subdued Sunday morning affair, especially compared with the raucous, freewheeling forum at the YearlyKos convention Saturday with the Democrats.

headline: Bree, We Knew and Knew Ye
text: Bree is dead, but you should never be cynical about “LonelyGirl15″.

headline: Revisiting the Past
text: Writer Steven Torres revisited his old neighborhood with his father, Esteban.

headline: It’s Wide Open at the U.S. Open
text: Five players are tied for the lead going into the last round of the U.S. Open in Cherry Hill, N.J. The games can be followed live or replayed at Monroi.com.

headline: A Conversion Tale From YearlyKos
text: CHICAGO — The YearlyKos convention was a huge affirmation of blogger culture, and there are many personal accounts of it posted all over the Web. But as the event winds down, we wanted to recount for you one small scene we witnessed here that served as a reminder, that even as the netroots celebrates its growth and success, sometimes people have to be escorted onto the Web one at a time.

headline: The Trial of Fake Steve Jobs
text: Ladies and gentlemen,

headline: New York Filmmakers Speak Out
text: A decision by the mayor's office to drop new rules for cameras on city streets was a victory for grassroots organizers.

headline: Giuliani Takes a Slap and Gets It Back
text: David Yepsen?

headline: Scenes From an Italian Restaurant
text: If Tom Glavine lasts deep into tonight’s game and wins his 300th game, maybe the smallest sliver of credit should go to Armando and his staff at La Scarola, an amazing Italian restaurant where Glavine and some of his traveling party ate last night. Nothing like a little carbo-loading before a big start.

headline: Down on the Farm
text: I’ve been at a conference and haven’t had much time to respond to posters, but let me do that here for just a bit.

headline: “Slaughter in the Jungle”
text: That’s the cover headline on the latest Newsweek, and it’s about the Congo.

headline: Sotheby’s Art of Growing
text: Sotheby’s International Realty is continuing its aggressive franchise expansion, adding a well-known brand to the competition in luxury home markets around the world.

headline: Moment of Indecision Clears Path for the Women’s Winner
text: With 200 meters left for the women’s leaders in yesterday’s NYC Half-Marathon, Catherine Ndereba blinked and Hilda Kibet did not. That was enough for Kibet, who has been overshadowed by Kenyan countrywomen like Ndereba, to win in a sprint finish.

headline: Old Issues of Playboy and Rolling Stone Will Be Available on DVDs
text: Starting next month, people who enjoy fine writing — oh, and nude photography — will be able to order a boxed collection of some of Hugh M. Hefner’s very favorite issues of Playboy, all to appreciate from the comfort of their own mansion.

headline: Public vs. Private
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

headline: A Celebrated Artist Dies, Then His Life Gets Difficult
text: Oscar Feldman, the fictitious painter at the heart of Kate Christensen’s mischievous new novel, was given a lot of latitude during his lifetime. He had a big reputation, two parallel families, and a career based on appreciating female nudes. Now he is gone, and this book, which begins with his obituary in 2001, is about the reassessments that take place after his death. It turns out that Oscar left behind a whole slew of women who would like to re-evaluate him.

headline: A Half-Win for Cellphone Users
text: The Federal Communications Commission opened the door to much needed competition in cellphone services last week when it set the rules for an auction of public airwaves early next year. It did a disservice to consumers by not requiring the winners to resell capacity to other carriers on a wholesale basis. This decision is likely to slow the arrival of new competitors and technologies. It could also delay creation of a higher-speed cellular pipe to the Internet to compete with D.S.L. and cable.

headline: Kurt Busch Snaps His Winless Streak
text: LONG POND, Pa., Aug. 5  Kurt Busch stormed to the front on the first lap and pulled away from the pack whenever he needed to Sunday, but thousands stayed in their seats at Pocono Raceway until the end of the race, rooting for at least a little drama.

headline: The Bidding Rises to Slam, So the Defense Has a Puzzle
text: You are on lead against a slam freely bid by your opponents. What does it mean if your partner doubles?

headline: Braves Feel Good About New Faces, and So Do Fans
text: ATLANTA, Aug. 5  Since the deadline-day deal that dropped the slugging first baseman Mark Teixeira into the Braves’ lineup, no amount of bad news could calm the euphoria here around the deal. In the 72 hours after the Braves acquired Teixeira from Texas, they went from three and a half games behind the Mets in the National League East to five and a half back, and there was a shrug, as if it were a temporary setback.

headline: Jean-Marie Lustiger, French Cardinal, Dies at 80
text: PARIS, Aug. 5 — Cardinal Jean-Marie Lustiger, who was born to Polish Jews, converted to Roman Catholicism as a boy, then rose to become leader of the French church and an adviser to Pope John Paul II, died Sunday, the Paris archbishop’s office said. Cardinal Lustiger, whose mother died in a Nazi concentration camp and who always insisted that he had remained a Jew after his conversion, was 80.

headline: Heavy Metal and Light: Always Serve Chilled
text: This is a big show for Banks Violette. It’s his first New York gallery exhibition in five years and is split between two locales. In both places he tries an alchemical fusion of the heroic, theatrical aspects of 1960s and ’70s art with the masculine bombast of heavy metal. The result, if successful, might be a canny contemporary Gesamtkunstwerk, a heavy-metal update of Wagner’s total artwork. Instead the visceral heat and rage of heavy metal have been tamed and reduced to nonthreatening levels. (An enthusiast might call it a “formalist” resolution.)

headline: Finding a Property Manager
text: Managing a second home from afar is almost impossible without local helpers to handle rentals or check up on the house in the event of bad weather.

headline: In Praise of Film Scores (Didn’t You Hear Them?)
text: Classical music for people who are afraid of classical music: that’s one way of looking at traditional film scores, which bring symphonically orchestrated music to more people than most serious composers are ever likely to attract to concert halls. As movie audiences are emotionally swept up in the synergy of photography, acting, settings and costumes, it is music more than any other element that effects what the director Francis Ford Coppola calls the “fusion” of these ingredients into “a critical mass.” It usually works best if it is only half-heard.

headline: In Debate, Republicans Make the Case for Staying in Iraq
text: The leading Republican presidential candidates said yesterday that the military escalation in Iraq appeared to be restoring stability, and they berated their Democratic counterparts for advocating an end to American involvement there.

headline: Any Given Saturday Outruns His Top Rivals to Win the Haskell
text: OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 5  Winning for the second consecutive time since he finished eighth in the Kentucky Derby after bruising his foot, Any Given Saturday dominated a solid group of rivals in Sunday’s $1 million Haskell Invitational at Monmouth Park to thrust himself into the race for the 3-year-old championship and set up a potential showdown with Street Sense, the winner of the Kentucky Derby, later this year.

headline: Shooting of 4 College Friends Baffles Newark
text: NEWARK, Aug. 5 — The authorities were struggling to explain one of Newark’s most chilling slaughters in recent memory after three young friends were lined up against a schoolyard wall and shot dead late Saturday. A fourth person survived a gunshot.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some copies on Wednesday about Congressional efforts to pass legislation to expand the government’s electronic wiretapping powers misspelled — yet again — the surname of the attorney general of the United States, in three of four references. He is Alberto R. Gonzales, not Gonzalez. (The Times has misspelled Mr. Gonzales’s name in at least 14 articles dating to 2001 when he became White House counsel. This year alone Mr. Gonzales’s name has been misspelled in February and March, and in two articles in April.) (Go to Article)

headline: Objection to Speakers Was Based on Mistake
text: Daily Kos, the left-leaning political blog, on July 23 published an entry by a regular contributor, Eve Gittelson, with the headline “NBC & PBS ‘journalists’ grace AHIP speakers network.” AHIP, whose name stands for America’s Health Insurance Plans, is the main lobbying group for the health insurance industry.

headline: 5 Ministers Threaten to Leave Iraq’s Cabinet
text: BAGHDAD, Aug 6 — Five ministers suspended their participation in meetings of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s cabinet on Monday, sending a warning signal that they may pull out of his increasingly isolated government if their demands are not met.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Politically Neutral, in a Blurry Sense
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — A half-hour into a packed news conference here raising a curtain on Wikimania 2007, the annual gathering of a few hundred rank-and-file editors and high-minded theorists devoted to Wikipedia, a Taiwanese reporter raised his hand and apologized for being late.

headline: Ex-Home Depot Chief Taking Reins at Chrysler
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Aug. 6 — Robert L. Nardelli, officially named as Chrysler’s new chief executive, said today that he wanted to move faster and more efficiently with the turnaround strategy meant to revive the struggling auto company.

headline: Paying More, but Reaching Fewer Ears
text: Radio ads have become roughly twice as expensive over the last decade, while radio ratings have dropped by 6.6 percent, or 1.3 million people, over the last eight years, according to a Federal Communications Commission study released July 31. The study reviewed industry trends since 1996, when the Telecommunications Act of 1996 loosened rules on station ownership.

headline: Ghostwriter Disputes Simpson’s Account
text: The ghostwriter of the aborted book “If I Did It” has contradicted O. J. Simpson’s accounts of its creation and content, including the hypothetical description of the slaying of his former wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ron Goldman, Reuters reported. The ghostwriter, Pablo Fenjves, disputed Mr. Simpson’s characterization of himself as a mostly passive participant in the composition of the chapter that depicts him holding a bloody knife at the scene of the crime. “The whole book, the whole idea for a book, originated with O. J. Simpson and a couple of his handlers,” Mr. Fenjves said. “O. J. read the book, his book, several times. I made every change he asked for, and he signed off on it.” In an Internet interview last week Mr. Simpson said he had been approached by publishers at HarperCollins about doing the book and had reluctantly consented to a chapter about the night of the crime as told by him only after they had agreed to label it hypothetical. Mr. Fenjves said: “I find it completely unnecessary to defend myself against this man. All I can say is that if there are errors in the book, it’s because O. J. didn’t correct them, or worse, he fed them to me.” Amid public outrage, publication of the book was canceled last year. Rights to it were awarded last week to Mr. Goldman’s relatives to satisfy a $33.5 million judgment they won against Mr. Simpson in a civil trial after he was acquitted of the slayings in a criminal case.
A credit for pictures last Monday with an article about a reunion of the comedy troupe the Kids in the Hall misspelled the given name of the photographer. He is Yannick Grandmont, not Jannick.

headline: Iraqi President Starts Talks to Try to Bring Sunnis Back
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 5 — President Jalal Talabani shuttled between Shiite and Sunni leaders in Baghdad on Sunday, trying to find a way to bring Sunnis back into the fold after they walked out of the government last week.

headline: Reconsidering the Role of the Warrior in Our Post-Enlightenment World
text: In one of the final events of the recent Lincoln Center Festival, a lone Mongolian bard named Burenbayar came onstage and chanted “The Secret History of the Mongols.” He had memorized the 13th-century text during long hours grazing animals on the steppes of Central Asia. And as is true of many ancient sagas, he sang of arms and the man — that is, of warfare and heroism.

headline: In Rome, a New Ritual on an Old Bridge
text: ROME, Aug. 5 — Love, in all its splendor and mess, found a fit expression on Rome’s oldest bridge last year. Inspired by a best-selling book, then the movie version, young couples wrote their names on a padlock. They chained their locks around lampposts on Ponte Milvio. Then they symbolically cut off escape by tossing the keys into the wine-dark Tiber below.

headline: Beckett in Britain
text: Five little-known works by Samuel Beckett will be brought to the London stage this season by the Young Vic under the direction of Peter Brook. To be known as “Fragments,” the show, a co-production with the Théâtre des Bouffes du Nord in Paris, opens on Sept. 15 for a run through Oct. 6 and includes “Rockaby,” “Rough for Theater Act I,” “Act Without Words II,” “Come and Go” and “Neither.”

headline: Putting the Government’s Words in the Doctor’s Mouth
text: Carol Kling had an abortion in 1982, when she was 22. Testifying before a state legislative committee in South Dakota a couple of years ago, she said she would not have made that choice had she understood what she was doing.

headline: Opposition Has Edge in Lebanon Vote
text: ROUMIEH, Lebanon, Aug. 5 — Lebanon’s fragile stability was jolted Sunday by a hotly contested parliamentary election in an important Christian district where a little-known opposition candidate claimed victory. If the claim is verified, it would be a major blow to Lebanon’s governing Western-backed coalition, which has been engaged in an intense power struggle with an alliance of opponents for months.

headline: Surge in Immigration Laws Around U.S.
text: State legislatures, grappling with the failure of the federal government to overhaul the immigration laws, considered 1,404 immigration measures this year and enacted 170 of them, an unprecedented surge in state-level lawmaking on the issue, according to a report by the National Conference of State Legislatures.

headline: Retooled Patriots Turn Their Back on Defeat
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Aug. 2 — The governor of Massachusetts was in town and an outdoor-sports megastore, rising in the shadow of Gillette Stadium, had just been unveiled in the sweltering sun. It was another day of business for the New England Patriots, when even the absence of Randy Moss from practice could not dampen the anticipation of a new football season.

headline: Treasury Bill Auctions for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Bronx: Man Shot to Death at Block Party
text: A Bronx man was fatally shot Saturday night at a block party in Sound View Park, the police said yesterday. The man, Larry Wynn, 20, of University Avenue, was shot in the back about 10 p.m. when someone fired into a crowd, the police said. He was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead, the police said. No arrests were made yesterday.

headline: Even on the Subway, the Mayor Is the Mayor (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Out for Milk, Brooklyn Father Is Fatally Stabbed
text: A 44-year-old married father of two who left his family’s Brooklyn apartment Saturday night to buy some milk died after being stabbed on his return home and collapsing in his father’s arms, the police said yesterday.

headline: Nothing to Watch on TV? Streaming Video Appeals to Niche Audiences
text: Buffering ... buffering ... buffering.

headline: Sal Mosca, 80, a Jazz Pianist and Teacher, Dies
text: Sal Mosca, a jazz pianist whose career began playing with giants like Charlie Parker, Miles Davis, Billie Holiday and Sarah Vaughan only to take himself out of the public eye in later life, died on July 28 in White Plains. He was 80.

headline: Link Is Seen Between British Labs and Livestock Virus
text: LONDON, Aug. 5  British health inspectors combed two veterinary laboratories in southern England on Sunday after it was discovered that the strain of foot-and-mouth disease at a farm four miles away was the same as the one used in the production of vaccine at the facilities.

headline: Romance as a Struggle That She Will Win
text: Beyoncé walked onstage at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, made a quick commanding gesture, and sparks rained down. Her band kicked into the funk beat of “Crazy in Love,” and she started to sing and dance, alternating stop-motion angular poses and serpentine shimmies, switching between robot and seductress. Her face was angry and exultant; she belted the song with bright swoops and vehement rasps. Like many of Beyoncé’s songs, “Crazy in Love” treats romance as a power struggle, and it’s hard to imagine her not winning in the end.

headline: New CDs
text: PLIES “The Real Testament”  (Slip-N-Slide/Atlantic)

headline: Tons of Repaving Material Was on Bridge at Collapse
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 5 — Trucks carrying tens of thousands of pounds of crushed stone were parked on the Interstate 35W bridge, and more stone was sitting on the deck when the bridge collapsed, investigators said Sunday, raising suspicions that the added weight of materials intended for repairs may have played a role in the bridge failure.

headline: The Executioner’s Hood
text: Many people assume that execution by lethal injection is simple and gentle. It’s neither. An inmate is given three drugs to do three things: (1) Knock him out. (2) Paralyze him so he doesn’t flop around or gasp in a way that upsets witnesses. (3) Kill him. If a step goes awry, an inmate can be paralyzed, inadequately sedated or unable to move or cry out as the poisons do their agonizing work.

headline: No Snow, but White Still Provides the Sizzle
text: CARSON, Calif., Aug. 5 — Wearing thick black sunglasses and a black and white bandanna that pulled back his tangled red mane, Shaun White looked every bit the sports superstar he has become since winning the 2006 Olympic gold medal in halfpipe snowboarding.

headline: Bid to Root Out Lead Trinkets Falters in U.S.
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 — Despite a two-year effort to eliminate the threat of poisonous lead in inexpensive children’s jewelry, hundreds of thousands of tainted items are still being sold across the United States, the federal government has found.

headline: Mummy’s Log: Visited Scan God in Land of the Dead
text: MANHASSET, N.Y. — There were no obvious signs of foul play.

headline: Lost Van Gogh Is Found
text: First a fraudulent van Gogh was ousted from the catalog of his works. Now comes word of the discovery of a new van Gogh. The painting was found below the paint surface of van Gogh’s “Ravine,” owned by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. The news, announced by that museum and the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam, came as the National Gallery of Victoria, in Australia, was reporting that a team at the Van Gogh Museum had determined that “Head of Man,” attributed to van Gogh for more than 70 years, was probably executed by one of his peers. The painting beneath “Ravine” was discovered during a technical examination by Meta Chavannes, a Museum of Fine Arts conservator. It was most likely painted in June 1889, when van Gogh was at the asylum of St.-Paul-de-Mausole and was reused as a support for “Ravine” a few months later. Louis van Tilborgh, the van Gogh research curator at the Van Gogh Museum, related it to “Wild Vegetation,” a drawing van Gogh sent his brother Theo in mid-1889. Scholars have suggested that the drawing was one of about a dozen copies of paintings that van Gogh sent to Theo at that time, but until now, no one was aware of a painting upon which this drawing could have been based.

headline: The Clinton-Kerry Alliance
text: At first blush they seemed like a surprising couple: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator John Kerry, teaming up last month to defend Mrs. Clinton from Pentagon criticism over the Iraq war – criticism that had a Swift-Boat-style ring to it, her campaign believed, of questioning her patriotism.

headline: Wine Company Takes a Harvest on Tour
text: In lieu of advertising in traditional media, Robert Mondavi Private Selection this summer is recreating the wine harvest experience for potential buyers on a cross-country tour.

headline: Bridge Disaster Revives a Quiet Web Site, Making It a Source for Original Reporting
text: The headquarters of Internet Broadcasting, a publisher of 70 local TV station Web sites, are located 10 miles from the site of Wednesday’s highway bridge collapse in Minneapolis. When word of the collapse came, the company sent reporters to the scene.

headline: It’s an Ad, Ad, Ad, Ad World
text: It is only a matter of time until nearly all advertisements around the world are digital.

headline: We Never Really Talk Anymore
text: Experts on language — the real ones, not those of us who merely use it — are having an intense debate about which species can talk. On one side are those who believe that only humans converse. On another side (this kind of debate can have many sides) are those who say, what about dolphins and whales and certainly the amazing Koko, the gorilla?

headline: Edwards Cites Safety Hazards in Arguing for Trade Restrictions
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Aug. 6 — Former Senator John Edwards seized on the recent imports of tainted pet food and unsafe toys from China to argue here today that the United States needs new trade policies to protect both its workers and its consumers.

headline: Kentucky Politics, Served With a Helping of Ribs at an Annual Barbecue
text: FANCY FARM, Ky., Aug. 4 — They came for the barbecue pork and the roasting of rivals.

headline: A Neighborhood Balks at a Chain Restaurant
text: There really is a John inside Johnny’s Pizza in Sunset Park, Brooklyn — John Miniaci Jr., whose father, John Sr., founded the neighborhood pizzeria in 1968.

headline: Fortis Vote Could Decide Fate of Bid for ABN Amro
text: LONDON, Aug. 5 — Shareholders of Fortis, which is part of a group bidding for ABN Amro, will vote on Monday on whether to support what would be the world’s largest banking takeover.

headline: Families and City Mourn as Hunt for the Missing Continues
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 5 — For the Sacorafas family, history of the most devastating kind seems to have repeated itself.

headline: I.B.M. Near Supercomputer Contract
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 — The National Science Foundation is planning to award I.B.M. a contract to build the world’s fastest supercomputer at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, according to documents that were accidentally placed on a federal government Web site for a short time last week.

headline: Third in ‘Bourne’ Series Tops Weekend Box Office
text: The thriller “The Bourne Ultimatum” outran the competition at United States theaters over the weekend, selling a strong $70.2 million in tickets and giving Universal Pictures one of the strongest openings in its history.

headline: Selective Prosecution
text: One part of the Justice Department mess that requires more scrutiny is the growing evidence that the department may have singled out people for criminal prosecution to help Republicans win elections. The House Judiciary Committee has begun investigating several cases that raise serious questions. The panel should determine what role politics played in all of them.

headline: Daniel Relishes the Moment That Kept Her Going
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 5  After they finished playing, Meg Mallon and Juli Inkster parked themselves behind the 18th green, joining Louise Suggs, the 1948 Ladies’ British Open Amateur champion and one of the founding members of the L.P.G.A., who presided over the final round of the Women’s British Open on Sunday like golf’s queen mother.

headline: Fearful of Restive Foreign Labor, Dubai Eyes Reforms
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — They still wake before dawn in desert dormitories that pack a dozen men or more to a room. They still pour concrete and tie steel rods in temperatures that top 110 degrees. They still spend years away from families in India and Pakistan to earn about $1 an hour. They remain bonded to employers under terms that critics liken to indentured servitude.

headline: Bonds Takes Day Off and Starts to Feel Like His Old Self
text: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 5 — Barry Bonds rested Sunday, meaning he and Hank Aaron will share the home run record until at least Monday. Bonds was relaxed and relieved after he finally hit his 755th homer Saturday night. It showed in his face, in his mannerisms and in his words.

headline: Bellwether Mexico Election Goes Smoothly
text: TIJUANA, Mexico, Aug. 5 — Voters went to the polls on Sunday in Baja California to decide between a conservative economist from the president’s party and a colorful tycoon who owns betting parlors and comes from a storied political family in the once dominant Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI.

headline: Editor Interviews Self on Murdoch
text: Paul E. Steiger, former managing editor of The Wall Street Journal and now editor at large of the paper, was a keynote speaker at the annual convention of the Asian American Journalists Association in Miami and had intended to discuss the future of journalism.

headline: Footnote
text: Sean T. Buffington, 38, most recently the associate provost for arts and culture and director of cultural programs at Harvard University, has been named the president and chief executive of the University of the Arts in Philadelphia, effective Aug. 15.

headline: Career Women in Japan Find a Blocked Path
text: TOKYO, Aug. 5 — Yukako Kurose joined the work force in 1986, a year after Japan passed its first equal opportunity law. Like other career-minded young women, she hoped the law would open doors. But her promising career at a department-store corporate office ended 15 years ago when she had a baby.

headline: ‘Jihad: The Musical’ Draws Protests
text: The shadow of Osama bin Laden fell across the start of the Edinburgh Fringe festival yesterday as a new show, “Jihad: The Musical,” publicized as “a madcap gallop through the wacky world of international terrorism,” prompted an online protest to Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain, Agence France-Presse reported. Condemned by the protesters as a “tasteless portrayal of terrorism and its victims,” the show — one of 2,050 offerings of drama, music and comedy by nearly 19,000 performers through Aug. 27 — was defended by its producer, James Lawler of the Silk Circle Production Company. “We have no intention of causing offense or insult with this show,” he said. “It is simply a musical comedy.” The show tells the story of Sayid, a young Afghan peasant who dreams of success as a flower farmer selling poppies to the West. But on the night a jihadi cell is to attack Western targets, including one known as the “Unidentified, Very Prestigious Landmark,” he must decide whose side he is on.

headline: Just Like Beethoven’s Big Night, but Longer
text: The concert must have been life-altering for Beethoven and perhaps for others. It was certainly historic. Yet few in the Theater an der Wien in Vienna on Dec. 22, 1808, could have been thinking in such grandiose terms. Most were probably just trying to get from one end of a long and arduous evening to the other.

headline: Opposition Has Edge in Lebanon Vote
text: ROUMIEH, Lebanon, Aug. 5 — Lebanon’s fragile stability was jolted Sunday by a hotly contested parliamentary election in an important Christian district where a little-known opposition candidate claimed victory. If the claim is verified, it would be a major blow to Lebanon’s governing Western-backed coalition, which has been engaged in an intense power struggle with an alliance of opponents for months.

headline: Weapons for Iraqis Are Missing, Study Says
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 — The Defense Department cannot account for 190,000 weapons, including more than 110,000 AK-47 rifles, issued to Iraqi security forces, a new report by government investigators says.

headline: Dear Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Mortgage Maze May Increase Foreclosures
text: In 2003, Dianne Brimmage refinanced the mortgage on her home in Alton, Ill., to consolidate her car and medical bills. Now, struggling with a much higher interest rate and in foreclosure, she wants to modify the terms of the loan.

headline: Murdoch Gives In, So to Speak
text: Some of the winners in the News Corporation’s purchase of The Wall Street Journal were less obvious than others.

headline: Nuclear Deal With India (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Highs and the Lows of Rankings on Amazon
text: It may seem obsessive, but every day — sometimes hourly — Aaron Shepard checks the Amazon.com sales rankings for his 12 self-published books. He even created a Web site, www.salesrankexpress.com, that lets authors check their Amazon rankings instantly.

headline: U.S. Marshals Let Fugitives Come to Them, in Church
text: NASHVILLE, Aug. 5 — Since March, David Moran has been looking over his shoulder. Not a day passes, he said, that he does not think about the arrest warrant issued after he missed a court hearing for driving without a license.

headline: Food That Travels Well
text: Austin, Tex.

headline: Abbas Is Host in Meeting With Olmert
text: JERICHO, West Bank, Aug. 6 — Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel met Monday with the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, in Palestinian territory for the first time in a gesture meant to strengthen the moderate Palestinian leadership and inject a feeling of momentum into long-dormant peace efforts.

headline: Housing Crackdown Hits Indian Immigrants
text: ISELIN, N.J., Aug. 3 — With the workweek behind him, Deepu Dass focused on a pesky bald spot in his front lawn here. As he sprayed the patch with water, urging the grass toward the perfection achieved by several neighbors, he said confidently: “I planted seeds.”

headline: Sea, Sand, Sky and an Invitation to Worship
text: ASBURY PARK, N.J.

headline: London Gathering Defends Vision of Radical Islam
text: LONDON, Aug. 4 — An international radical Islamic party that has been the focus of increasing concern in Britain launched a frontal attack on its critics at a carefully stage-managed conference in London this weekend that attracted several thousand relatively well-heeled Muslims.

headline: 2 G.O.P. Contenders Duel Over Religion
text: Over the last several months, the Republican presidential field has been consumed by the near-collapse of Senator John McCain’s campaign, the question of whether Fred Thompson would enter the race, and whether Rudolph W. Giuliani’s appeal would endure.

headline: Mets’ Glavine Reaches Milestone After a Week of Anxious Moments
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 5 — The likeness on Tom Glavine’s Hall of Fame plaque will reflect how history perceives him. He will wear the cap of the Braves, for Atlanta is where he won his two Cy Young awards, compiled his five 20-victory seasons, captured his World Series title.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Madonna’s Adoption of Malawian Boy Delayed

headline: Afghan President Bringing Bush a Gloomy Report on Security
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 — On the eve of his Camp David meeting with President Bush, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan painted a bleak picture of life in his country, saying that security had worsened and that the United States and its allies were no closer to catching Osama bin Laden than they were a few years ago.

headline: Strahan Says Absence Is Not About Money
text: Giants defensive end Michael Strahan said that he had hoped to make a decision about retirement “without much hoopla,” but it is far too late for that. Having informed the Giants, through his agent, on the eve of training camp that he was considering retiring after 14 N.F.L. seasons, Strahan stayed quiet for 10 days, listening to everyone else discuss what he might be thinking.

headline: Punk on Parade, With Flexible Marching Orders
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Aug. 4 — Who’s the headliner on this summer’s Vans Warped Tour? Who knows?

headline: Psychiatric Center for Teenagers Is Mired in Patient Accusations of Rape
text: A widely respected residential psychiatric treatment center for teenagers in Manhattan acknowledged yesterday that it was cooperating with law-enforcement authorities who have charged three former employees with sexually assaulting girls at the center in recent years.

headline: Yes, Being Old Is Another Dimension (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Billed as the Best, Gebrselassie Holds True to Form
text: Haile Gebrselassie stormed out of hilly Central Park and separated from his two competitors a few blocks down Seventh Avenue.

headline: Burned Once, but Starting Up Again
text: “How many people have you got on staff now?”

headline: Ochoa Caps Week of Firsts With Breakthrough
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 5 — It was love at first sight for Lorena Ochoa. From the moment she first saw the Old Course last week, under a full moon so luminous it seemed as if the scene had been choreographed by Hollywood, she felt as if she and St. Andrews had been brought together by destiny.

headline: Two Pitchers: Fall Guys for a Few Days, Then Forgotten
text: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 5 — Clay Hensley wore the worried expression of a man who was doomed to spend the rest of his life watching, hearing about and talking about one lousy pitch.

headline: Head Held High as the Journey Is Finished
text: Chicago

headline: Sailor Falls Overboard
text: The Coast Guard searched yesterday for a crewman who fell from a 600-foot tanker ship as it approached the Port of New York, the Coast Guard said. About 10 a.m. yesterday the tanker, Overseas Altamar, was about 20 miles off Long Branch, N.J., when the crewman fell overboard, the Coast Guard said. The sailor, who was not named by the Coast Guard, was wearing a life vest and crew members threw him a life preserver, the Coast Guard said. The Coast Guard and the New York police were searching for the man.

headline: The Substance Thing
text: Two presidential elections ago, the conventional wisdom said that George W. Bush was a likable, honest fellow. But those of us who actually analyzed what he was saying about policy came to a different conclusion — namely, that he was irresponsible and deeply dishonest. His numbers didn’t add up, and in his speeches he simply lied about the content of his own proposals.

headline: Stairs to Remain Intact in Ground Zero Plan
text: The Spitzer administration says it has taken steps to finally solve the quandary of the “survivors’ stairway” at ground zero.

headline: Mr. Bush, Here’s a Plan for Darfur
text: Frustrated by the genocide he is tolerating in Darfur, President Bush has suggested to aides on occasion that maybe the U.S. should just send troops there.

headline: In Volatile Day, Stocks Reverse Friday’s Losses
text: Wall Street rallied late this afternoon as investors bid up financial stocks, which have fallen significantly in recent weeks because of problems in the credit and mortgage markets.

headline: Holocaust Survivors Protest Size of Payments Planned by Israel
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 5  Several dozen Israeli survivors of the Holocaust, supported by hundreds of younger relatives and supporters, marched in protest on Sunday in front of Prime Minister Ehud Olmert’s office, saying that a planned government stipend was too small, insulting both the living and the dead.

headline: Queens: Driver Accused of Hitting Three
text: A Queens woman has been charged with driving drunk and running over two women and a child Saturday, prosecutors said yesterday. The woman, Susan E. Karnabe, 54, of Alderton Street, was scheduled to be arraigned in Criminal Court last night on charges of vehicular assault, reckless endangerment and driving under the influence of alcohol, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Ms. Karnabe struck Aviva Govshovitz, 57, her mother, Frida Shein, 86, and her granddaughter, Mia Tetelman, 3, about 2:45 p.m. as they crossed at Gerard Place and Yellowstone Boulevard in Forest Hills. Ms. Shein broke a rib and Mia suffered multiple injuries and was in critical condition at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens, Mr. Brown said. He said Ms. Karnabe drove off and was arrested at her home.

headline: Mussina and Offense Combine to Finish Sweep
text: When Mike Mussina climbed the mound and fired his first pitch yesterday, more than 54,000 fans at Yankee Stadium cheered. But in some ways, Mussina appeared much less relevant than usual.

headline: Ex-Home Depot Chief to Take Reins at Chrysler
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Aug. 5 — Robert L. Nardelli, who was ousted as chief executive of Home Depot amid shareholder discontent this year over his enormous pay package, will soon take on one of the most prominent jobs in corporate America: revitalizing the troubled automaker Chrysler LLC.

headline: Chilling Details, 62 Years Later, of the Ground Zero in Japan
text: Especially with another 9/11 anniversary not that far away, some of the survivor stories recounted tonight on HBO will sound to many New Yorkers like something they have been hearing a lot in the last six years.

headline: Iraqi Legislators, on Hiatus in Jordan
text: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 5 — Saleh al-Mutlak, a senior Sunni leader in Iraq’s Parliament, is spending his summer vacation here at a well-appointed apartment that his wife and son moved into last year. Lighting a cigarette on his patio, near a small garden of pink roses, he acknowledged breathing easier in a place where loud explosions are caused by fireworks, not bombs.

headline: Will Scarborough Shift Become Permanent?
text: MSNBC has not yet decided to hand its morning program, formerly led by Don Imus, to Joe Scarborough, though negotiations with him continue, an NBC News executive said yesterday.The Associated Press reported Saturday that it was likely that Mr. Scarborough would be appointed the permanent replacement for Mr. Imus, who was host of the morning program at MSNBC until he was fired in April over racially insensitive remarks. The NBC executive, who asked not to be identified because the talks are continuing, said that Mr. Scarborough’s appointment remained “likely, though there’s a chance it may not work out.” The executive said a final decision might not be made until September. Mr. Scarborough, a former congressman from Florida, has previously worked as a prime-time host for MSNBC. Under the title “Morning Joe,” Mr. Scarborough has been host of the morning MSNBC program regularly for the past several months. The NBC executive did confirm that with WFAN radio about to name Boomer Esiason and Craig Carton as the permanent radio replacements for Mr. Imus, MSNBC would not be interested in returning to the simulcast it participated in with WFAN during Mr. Imus’s tenure.

headline: Boil-Water Advisory Continues
text: United Water New Jersey customers in most of Bergen County and parts of Hudson County were advised to continue boiling water today, a spokeswoman for the utility said last night. The advisory had been put in place for 800,000 residents after lightning strikes briefly disrupted power to a water treatment plant in Haworth on Saturday. Restrictions for outdoor water use were lifted yesterday morning, but officials were waiting for water quality test results, expected this morning, before making further decisions.

headline: Madonnas Adoption of Malawian Boy Delayed
text: Conflict clouded the efforts of Madonna, right, to adopt a Malawian boy after news yesterday that the official appointed to monitor her suitability had been refused permission to travel to Britain, Reuters reported. According to the weekly Malawi News, Kate Kainja, Malawi’s minister of women and child development, accused the monitor, Penstone Kilembe, of obtaining an airline ticket and money from Madonna without government approval. Ms. Kainja told the newspaper, “We have already contacted Madonna that someone else and not Kilembe will come to assess her because we feel Mr. Kilembe personalized the whole issue when other people can go.” Mr. Kilembe dismissed suggestions that he had personally asked Madonna for airfare. The High Court appointed him to travel to Britain and was to rely on his testimony in deciding if Madonna and her husband, the filmmaker Guy Ritchie, should be allowed to adopt the child. Madonna took the motherless boy, David Banda, in October after his father, Yohane Banda, placed him in an orphanage. Mr. Kilembe said, “What this means is that the whole adoption process may crumble and David sent back to his village.”

headline: A Baby Girl’s Bath Becomes a Young Couple’s Nightmare
text: The 11-month-old girl stood in the tub, playing in shallow water with a 2-year-old girl, both looked after by a teenage mother home alone. The last moments of normal life in the third-floor apartment on Classon Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, ended that way, with one young mother, a pot of rice on the stove down the hall and two children in shallow water that would not be shallow enough.

headline: Strahan Says Concern Is Career, Not Contract
text: Giants defensive end Michael Strahan said he had hoped to make a decision about retirement “without much hoopla,” but it is far too late for that. Having informed the Giants, through his agent, on the eve of training camp that he was considering retiring after 14 N.F.L. seasons, Strahan stayed quiet for 10 days, listening to everyone else discuss what he might be thinking.

headline: Is Giuliani’s Daughter an Obama Supporter?
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani’s daughter, Caroline, has done her best to keep out of the spotlight as her father runs for president, choosing to keep complicated family matters private. And for his part, Mr. Giuliani has tried to shield both her and his son, Andrew, from attention.

headline: Bush and Afghan President Differ Over Iran’s Role
text: CAMP DAVID, Md., Aug. 6 — President Bush and President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, close allies in the fight against terrorism, found much to agree about today as they wrapped up a two-day summit meeting here, with one major exception: the role of Iran in Afghanistan.

headline: ‘Fake Steve’ Blogger Comes Clean
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 — For the last 14 months, high-tech insiders have been eating up the work of an anonymous blogger who assumed the persona of Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive and one of the world’s most famous businessmen.

headline: Fortis Shareholders Back ABN Amro Bid
text: LONDON, Aug. 6 — Shareholders of Fortis, which is part of a group bidding for ABN Amro, voted on Monday in the first of two meetings to support what would be the world’s largest banking takeover.

headline: Bush Signs Law to Widen Reach for Wiretapping
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 — President Bush signed into law on Sunday legislation that broadly expanded the government’s authority to eavesdrop on the international telephone calls and e-mail messages of American citizens without warrants.

headline: Professor Puts Swing’s Rhythm to Music
text: In Room 415 of the Becton Center, a gray and humorless building on the edge of the campus of Yale University, a physics professor named Robert Grober spent a recent morning hitting scuffed golf balls into a beat-up net.

headline: A Top Official at Bear Stearns Ousted
text: The crisis in the credit markets finally reached the executive suite of Wall Street firms last week, and the victim was an unexpected one: Warren J. Spector, a co-president at Bear Stearns who some had thought could become the firm’s next chief executive.

headline: The Bolshoi’s Whiz Kids on Display in London
text: LONDON, Aug. 4 — The Bolshoi Ballet’s latest whiz kid, Ivan Vasiliev, is a colorful, engaging, 18-year-old firecracker who looks good as a smiling, fully clad and mustachioed slave in a virtuoso divertissement pas de deux in Act 1 of “Le Corsaire” or as a stone-faced, near-naked, painted-gold-all-over dancing statue in Act 2 of “La Bayadère.”

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 7 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO Michelle Pfeiffer, left, waxes philosophic about her life, career and the films she made on her ascent to stardom, from her role as Elvira Hancock, the icy arm candy of Tony Montana (Al Pacino) in “Scarface,” to her current incarnation as the shellacked Velma Von Tussle in “Hairspray.” The famously beautiful Ms. Pfeiffer also offers this nugget about filming a love scene: “It’s awkward,” she says. “Sometimes people’s wives show up. It’s like, ‘Hey, how you doin’?’ ”

headline: Murdoch and the Journal
text: I think the hand-wringing about Murdoch buying Dow Jones is probably overdone. I read the Wall Street Journal every day and love it, and I would be horrified if he messed it up — but I’d bet that he won’t.

headline: Your Comments on my Darfur Column
text: My Monday column notes that President Bush discussed with aides the possibility of sending ground troops into Darfur but was persuaded not to by Condi Rice. My sourcing on that is very solid, and I think the episode reflects the fact that Bush is actually more interested in Darfur than most of the people around him. He seems to raise it with foreign leaders and with cabinet members more than they raise it with him.

headline: The Second Year of YearlyKos
text: At YearlyKos, now an annual gathering of liberal bloggers and progressive activists, the online and Washington worlds came together.

headline: Letter from Michael Strahan to Giants Fans
text: To the New York Giants’ Fans:

headline: Jimmy Wales: 2 Million Articles Down and More to Do
text: At the Wikimania conference in Taipei, this weekend there was a group of volunteers active in editing the online encyclopedia who started calling themselves “The Old-Codgers Coalition.” Like many at the conference, they were trying to cope with the impact of the site’s popularity.

headline: Mortgage Woes
text: Last week a large lender, American Home Mortgage, closed up shop, the latest among several such failures. Stocks tumbled over mortgage worries. Many home owners are feeling pressure from increased monthly payments as adjustable-rate mortgages climb with interest rates. Others are finding it more difficult than in the past to renegotiate the terms of their mortgages to avoid default. (Sunday’s Week in Review section published a guide to the problems.)

headline: Foreign Workers and the Building Boom
text: Construction workers, a million strong in Dubai and famously mistreated, have won some humble victories.

headline: Ex-Home Depot Chief to Lead Chrysler
text: Robert L. Nardelli, who was ousted as chief executive of Home Depot this year amid shareholder discontent over his enormous pay package, will soon take on one of the most prominent jobs in corporate America: revitalizing the troubled automaker Chrysler.

headline: Telus Hangs Up on BCE Bid
text: Telusabandoned its pursuit of its rival BCE, the parent company of Bell Canada, stymied in large part by its inability to get regulatory guidance on which assets it might have to sell to make the merger acceptable to Canadian regulators.

headline: Germany Looks Into Subprime Fallout at IKB
text: Prosecutors in Düsseldorf and government regulators in Berlin are looking into how a German bank became overexposed to the subprime mortgage lending crisis in the United States, but stopped short Friday of announcing a formal investigation.

headline: Canadian Bomb-Disposal Company Buys Rival
text: Canada’s Allen-Vanguard, which makes bomb disposal equipment, has struck a cash and stock deal worth 650 million Canadian dollars to acquire a privately held explosive-disposal company, Med-Eng Systems

headline: Burned Once, but Starting Up Again
text: In his 1998 book “Burn Rate,” the journalist Michael Wolff describes his misadventures in starting and abandoning a technology company in the 1990s. The book became a parable for an era and elevated the term in the title, which refers to the amount of money a company blows through each month above its revenue, into the popular lexicon.

headline: International Power Harvests Trinergy Wind Farms
text: A British-based electricity generator, International Power, said it had clinched a 1.84 billion euro ($2.52 billion) deal to buy German and Italian wind farms owned by their European operator Trinergy.

headline: Union Seeks to Restrain 2 Financial Firms
text: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to require that the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and the hedge fund Och-Ziff Capital Management Group, both planning public stock offerings, be regulated as investment companies.

headline: Brocade Jury Breaks for Weekend
text: The jury in the first criminal trial associated with stock-option backdating adjourned early Friday afternoon without returning a verdict.

headline: Sun Capital Ties Up Deal for Limited Stake
text: Sun Capital Partners said Friday that it had completed the acquisition of the Limited chain of stores and has named the retailer’s co-presidents to top management positions. The deal finalizes Limited Brands‘s exit from the Limited and Express apparel businesses to focus on lingerie and body care.

headline: London Theater Journal: M. Poirot and the Mysterious Case of the Sore Throats
text: LONDON, Aug. 6 – All cardinals look alike from a distance, particularly if the one with the recognizable face has gone missing. That, in any case, seemed to be the opinion of the white-haired gent who started chatting to me (or was it to himself?) in the men’s room of the Haymarket Theater on Saturday afternoon.

headline: Journal Editor Interviews Self on Murdoch
text: Paul E. Steiger, former managing editor of The Wall Street Journal and now editor at large of the paper, was a keynote speaker at the annual convention of the Asian American Journalists Association in Miami and had intended to discuss the future of journalism.

headline: Decision on Google Deal May Shape Web
text: The behind-the-scenes battle over federal approval of Google‘s proposed $3.1 billion acquisition of DoubleClick could shape the Internet’s future, The Los Angeles Times wrote. At stake is control of the growing online advertising market, estimated at $21.7 billion this year.

headline: Millionaires Who Don’t Feel Rich
text: The New York Times takes a look at a peculiar psychological phenomenon in Silicon Valley, where accomplished and ambitious members of the digital elite still do not think of themselves as particularly fortunate, in part because they are surrounded by people with more wealth — often a lot more.

headline: Report Faults S.E.C. on Pequot Investigation
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission bungled a promising investigation two years ago into suspicious trading at Pequot Capital Management, a giant hedge fund, according to the final report released by Congressional investigators looking into the matter.

headline: Fortis Shareholders Vote in Favor of ABN Bid
text: Fortis, the Belgian financial group, moved a step closer to buying part of ABN Amro Holding after Fortis shareholders backed its financing plan.

headline: Auburn Avenue
text:
Images from the King Center, the King National Historic Site and Preservation District and the
APEX Museum in Atlanta.

headline: After Postini, What’s Next for Google?
text: Google‘s recent purchase of Postini could be a prelude to more deals in the security business, according to the research firm 451 Group. It speculates that the Web search giant might try deals in the areas of URL filtering, anti-data leakage and identity and access management.

headline: Sowood Founder Offers Apology
text: A contrite Jeff Larson, founder of the Boston hedge fund Sowood Capital Management, spoke to his clients for the first time Friday and tried to explain how events of recent weeks wiped out more than half of their $3 billion investment.

headline: Measuring the High-Yield Debt Pile-Up
text: A string of debt offerings, many related to private equity buyouts, have recently crashed on the rocks of an imploding credit market. So how many of these deals have met with resistance from increasingly wary debt investors?

headline: Akzo Raises ICI Offer to $16 Billion
text: Britain’s Imperial Chemical Industries, the maker of Dulux paints, has tentatively agreed to a sweetened 8 billion pound, or $16.3 billion, takeover offer by a Dutch rival, Akzo Nobel and a German partner, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: The Real ‘Fake Steve’ Unveiled
text: The parlor game that has captivated high-tech insiders for the last 14 months has come to an end after The New York Times’ Brad Stone unmasked the man behind “The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs,” a blog that channels and lampoons Steven P. Jobs, Apple‘s chief executive and one of the world’s most famous businessmen.

headline: Bidder for Barneys Goes Higher
text: Fast Retailing of Japan has increased its offer to acquire Barneys New York, the luxury retailer, to $950 million after Istithmar, an investment group based in Dubai, matched Fast’s original $900 million offer, Barneys’ owner, Jones Apparel Group, said Sunday.

headline: Morning Buzz: A Newark Murder Mystery; a Brooklyn Pizza Battle; Coney Island’s Future; and More
text: Newark authorities are struggling to comprehend the grisly slayings of three friends who were lined up against a wall in a schoolyard and shot, execution-style. A 19-year-old woman, Natasha Ariel, 19, a student at Delaware State University, was also shot and survived.

headline: Is Merger Advice Worth the Price?
Top Official at Bear Stearns Is Ousted
text: The crisis in the credit markets finally reached the executive suite of Wall Street firms last week, and the victim was an unexpected one: Warren J. Spector, a co-president at Bear Stearns who some had thought could become the firm’s next chief executive.

headline: Why Plant a Flag at North Pole?
text: Russia’s planting of a flag at the North Pole was more than your latest piece of odd news. A historian writing in The Los Angeles Times says that “Russia is hardly alone” in audacious, and slightly weird, claims to territory over the years:

headline: So What?
text: While Hendrick Hertzberg finds the appeal of nostalgia at YearlyKos, other liberals simply find the deja vu repellent. “YearlyKos will add nothing to a much needed debate on the future direction of our country,” insists Nancy (The Hankster) Hanks. “The time for insurgence in the DP is over. Without a relationship to independent voters — left, center and right — YearlyKos will remain safely within the boundaries of the very partisan political culture that is responsible for the bad policy we are living with right now.”

headline: Clinton and the Lobbyists
text: O.K., it was a steamy weekend in early August, not a time when everyone is riveted to the presidential campaign trail. But a heady amount of politics took place this weekend. And from within that brew, a couple of moments are beginning to emerge as potentially significant.

headline: Boomer Chases His Own Home Run History
text: David “Boomer” Wells looked hyperactive. What else is new?

headline: 2008: From Debate to Debate
text: Fresh off back-to-back debate appearances over the weekend, the Republican and Democratic candidates will be looking to carry their momentum forward as they begin a busy week on the campaign trail. The Democrats face two more forums over the next few days – one in Chicago sponsored by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. on Tuesday and another in Los Angeles on Thursday organized by the Human Rights Campaign. It will focus on issues important to the gay and lesbian community.

headline: The Skim
text: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

headline: Edwards, McCain in Iowa
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa – Two of the presidential candidates — John Edwards and John McCain – are giving policy speeches here today.

headline: Foreclosures: A Call to Action
text: In today’s Times, Gretchen Morgenson has a frightening piece about the troubles facing many homeowners, headlined “Mortgage Maze May Increase Foreclosures.”

headline: Ask About Latino New York
text: Carolina González and Seth Kugel, freelance journalists who wrote “Nueva York: The Complete Guide to Latino Life in the Five Boroughs” (St. Martin’s/Griffin, 2006) and run Nueva York, a blog about Latino life in New York City, are taking questions from City Room readers this week. Readers are invited to submit their questions in the comment box below.

headline: Bloomberg Reports for Jury Duty
text: 3:40 p.m. | Mr. Bloomberg was dismissed as a potential juror in the asbestos case. He was sent back to the jury room, where he and other jurors released from the case could potentially be selected for another jury. Mr. Bloomberg and the other jurors in the room were sent home and told to come back at 9:30 a.m. tomorrow.

headline: Mia Farrow’s Darfur Gambit
text: A quick scroll down the front page of Mia Farrow’s Darfur blog suggests that she is not just another Hollywood do-gooder vapidly backing a fashionable cause. “LOOK at this!! If this is true he has done NOTHING” is a typical comment from her: focused on actions and results as opposed to words, of which there are many hopeful ones on the subject.

headline: To Our Readers
text: Beginning today, we present a bigger sampling of letters online, to make up for the reduced size of the print edition of The Times. The available space for letters in print has been reduced by about a third.

headline: The Clinton-Kerry Alliance
text: In his Web column today, Patrick Healy writes about the relationship between Senators John Kerry and Hillary Clinton:

headline: Guerrilla Marketing on the Upper West Side
text: Would you be happy if you had just spent millions of dollars to renovate one of the Upper West Side’s grandest landmarks and you were selling condominiums in that landmark for up to $6.7 million and you learned that guerrilla marketers had — without your permission — splashed an animated, illuminated Samsung logo on your freshly restored stonework?

headline: The Value of Deal Advice: A Closer Look
text: What is merger advice worth? One way of answering that question is to look at the post-deal performance of companies that made major acquisitions. Depending on which investment bank advised the buyer, the results are strikingly different.

headline: Cramer’s Own Bond-Driven Meltdown
text: While the debt markets continue their convulsions — or their return to sanity, depending on whom you ask — one high-profile stock picker is calling for action in the strongest terms. On Friday afternoon, the voluble Jim Cramer appeared on CNBC to talk with Erin Burnett about Bear Stearns‘ latest hedge-fund-related troubles.

headline: How Quickly and How Much do Menu Prices Change?
text: As I noted in a recent post on this blog about a return to the restaurant Falai, prices on the dinner menu had increased substantially over the two years of the restaurant’s existence. These increases seemed to reflect much more than normal inflation, much more than any rise in the costs of doing business.

headline: Familiar Face on the Field, New Face in the Bullpen
text: You never know who you’ll meet in Toronto. A few years ago, Sweeny Murti and I were standing on the field and met some producers for the movie “Fever Pitch.” They actually offered Sweeny a role, but he had to work and couldn’t make it.

headline: Beckham, Still in His ‘Civvies’
text: The David Beckham-less David Beckham Tour continued yesterday when the L.A. Galaxy visited Toronto. It had been billed as the superstar’s Major League Soccer regular season debut ( which should not to be confused with his L.A. Galaxy exhibition debut against Chelsea on July 21 or what would have been his SuperLiga debut on July 24 against Pachuca). But on Saturday, Beckham said he would again sit out due to his nagging ankle injury.

headline: 30 Years Since the Summer of Sam
text: Updated, 4:30 p.m.

headline: Goldman Hedge Fund Said to Extend Its Losses
text: Bear Stearns is getting the lion’s share of attention, but other investment banks are having hedge-fund problems of their own as the credit crisis deepens. Case in point: Global Alpha, the $10 billion flagship fund of Goldman Sachs, which Financial News says fell 8 percent in one week at the end of July and is down more than 12 percent on the year before fees.

headline: Sirius Chief Makes Appeal for Satellite Deal
text: Mel Karmazin, the chief executive of Sirius Satellite Radio, is turning up the volume in his effort to persuade regulators to approve his company’s merger with its main rival, XM Satellite Radio.

headline: Productivity, Baseball Style
text: Tomorrow the government will report on productivity figures for the United States. They have not been rising very rapidly of late, adding to economic concerns.

headline: Burying the Evidence: Carbon Dioxide Storage Stokes Ire
text: Will burying carbon dioxide continue to make burning fossil fuels viable?

headline: Market Jitters? Don’t Blame L.B.O.’s, Analyst Says
text: When pundits go looking to explain the stock market’s recent selloff, they often point to an expected slowdown, or worse, in leveraged buyouts. But Ryan Kloster, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, ran some numbers and concluded that a buyout freeze, if it happened, would barely register across the markets as a whole.

headline: Blogtalk: Debating the FISA Bill
text: Blogs on the right and left have been reacting to legislation President Bush signed over the weekend that expands the government’s authority to eavesdrop on Americans as part of its broader terrorism surveillance program. Congress passed the measure on Saturday by a vote of 227 to 183 “despite serious objections from many Democrats about the scope of the executive branch’s new eavesdropping power,” The Times’s Carl Hulse and Edmund L. Andrews reported.

headline: And They Have a Warrant This Time
text: While President Bush’s signing of the new wiretap law is the big news on the national security front, a lesser but related story is gaining a bit of attention on the Web.

headline: Urban Lesson: A Tale of 2 Bicycles
text: New York City is a great reality instructor, to borrow Saul Bellow’s unflinching phrase. The city teaches you to always exercise a certain amount of caution and skepticism and to seldom let your guard down.

headline: Having Issues
text: The new issues of The Believer and The Oxford American arrived in the mail last week, and they’re both stuffed with things I know I’m going to want to – have to – read.

headline: A Rivalry at McLaren Boils Over
text: “He doesn’t seem to have been speaking to me since yesterday. So I don’t know if he has a problem.”

headline: When a Kiss Isn’t Just a Kiss
text: News photographers are always urged to write detailed captions about their photos, and with good reason.

headline: Space Shuttle Commander Disputes Alcohol Reports
text: Scott Kelly, commander of the next space shuttle mission, sent a letter to a number of newspapers, taking issue with the reports that some astronauts had been drinking alcohol and perhaps were even intoxicated just before flight. The letter was released by NASA.

headline: Poll: The 2008 Issues
text: What issues do the voters expect to be most significant when they make their choice for president next year? It depends, at least in part, on their party identification.
