headline: Antitrust, Brooklyn Style
text: A staple of journalism is the noble local business arrayed against the evil national chain. In the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn, we learn that Johnny’s Pizza is facing competition from Papa John’s, a chain, and has responded with a petition drive against the chain.

headline: Seven Tie for First at U.S. Open
text: Instead of providing clarity, the last round of the U.S. Open in Cherry Hill, N.J., produced a seven-way tie for the championship. The five players in the lead going into the ninth and final round all drew their games, allowing two other players who trailed the leaders by half a point to catch them after they won their last round games. The games and the results can be viewed at Monroi.com.

headline: New York Press Gets Rid of Sex Ads
text: The new owners of New York Press, the free alternative weekly founded in 1988, announced a major change today, and it has nothing to do with the paper’s political coverage, underground sensibility or arts listings. The scrappy weekly is dropping its sexually themed ads.The banned ads include those “that advertise illegal massage parlors and blatant ads promoting prostitution,” the local chapter of the National Organization for Women announced today. (The New York Observer’s Media Mob blog reported the decision last week.)

headline: Brooklyn Artist in Troubled Water
text: Duke Riley was detained after his replica of a submarine from the Revolutionary War neared the Queen Mary 2.

headline: A Fiberglass Elephant in Chains
text: A sculpture depicting a tearful elephant in chains that was designed in New York and became the center of a federal lawsuit in Washington was put on display in Union Square Park today, with the blessing of New York City officials.

headline: Red, White or Bubbly?
text: What do you serve at a real estate closing?

headline: Airborne Linux Hackers Unite!
text: Virgin America calls its new in-flight entertainment system “Red,” but it is really a gigantic sociological experiment in airborne distributed computing.

headline: Blogtalk: Parking in the Parks; Women of Mystery; Tribes of New York; the Albany Scandal; and More
text: What we’re reading on the local blogs…

headline: Question of Leadership
text: Cerberus Capital Management announced today that Robert L. Nardelli is replacing Thomas W. LaSorda as Chrysler’s chief executive.

headline: A Union Splits Primary Endorsements
text: CHICAGO — As union leaders gathered here today for the Democratic presidential debate they are holding tomorrow at Soldier Field, the International Association of Machinists announced a novel political strategy: for the first time in its 119-year history, it plans to endorse both a Republican presidential candidate and a Democratic presidential candidate before the two parties hold their primaries.

headline: Bonds’s Record-Breaking Ball Is Upon Us
text: Barry Bonds is as close as he can be to breaking Hank Aaron’s home run record. Starting with tonight’s game against the Washington Nationals, he’ll have seven games at his home stadium to hit number 756.

headline: Win a Trip on MTV
text: After they returned from Africa, Leana, Will and Nick sat down with MTV to recount their journey to Rwanda, Congo and Burundi. The video was recently posted on mtvU.com.

headline: The Best Team in Baseball Since May 30
text: Before the finale of the Yankees’ last series in Toronto, on May 30, their record was 21-29. Since then, including a 5-4 victory here on Monday, the Yankees are 41-21, the best record in the majors in that span.

headline: Durbin Fallout From Bloggers Convention
text: Conservative bloggers accused Senator Dick Durbin, an Illinois Democrat, of violating Congressional ethics rules for using the official Senate seal in a video appeal to the liberal netroots at the YearlyKos convention this past week.

headline: Tancredo Takes a Tough Stance
text: Tough is a brand all the Republican candidates want to own as they run for president. Tough on terrorism, tough on crime, tough on Democrats.

headline: Poisonous Choices, Women at Risk
text: Judith Warner has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online on Tuesday. Post a comment about it below. — The Editors

headline: Newark in Turmoil Over Shootings
text: The shooting of four students has shocked a crime-ridden city and presented Mayor Cory A. Booker with one of the toughest challenges of his tenure.

headline: Taking the Mystery Out of a Date
text: So who was the mystery “boy from Dartmouth” with whom Hillary Rodham spent a Saturday night when she was an undergraduate at Wellesley?

headline: Sotheby’s Redux
text: A quick follow up to yesterday’s item about the rapid worldwide expansion of Sotheby’s International Realty, the real estate company bearing the name of the famous auction house. A Wall Street Journal story notes that Sotheby’s is losing some of its high end luxury luster as it expands in the United States.

headline: Warm Up Party at P.S. 1
text: The Times's Melena Ryzik attends P.S.1's Warm Up party in Long Island City.

headline: Digging Deep for Obama
text: Have some of Senator Barack Obama’s supporters figured out how to give more than the $2,300 legal maximum to back their candidate?

headline: Mays Feels Surge of Pride as Chase Nears the End
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 — Willie Mays is protective and proud when he speaks about Barry Bonds. Mays’s words come slowly, or they simply stop, if he dislikes a question. Mays’s words flow in bursts if he is discussing something compelling about Bonds.

headline: Research Identifies Brain Site for Fever
text: The area of the brain responsible for causing fever would just about fit on the head of a pin, researchers are reporting.

headline: Brower Takes His Spot in the Bullpen; Chamberlain Is Due Up Next
text: TORONTO, Aug. 6  Piece by piece, in small moves more than splashy ones, the Yankees have tightened their roster. They have a new backup catcher, a new backup infielder, and their bullpen remains under construction.

headline: What’s in a Name? Parsing the ‘God Particle,’ the Ultimate Metaphor
text: We need to talk about the “God particle.”

headline: When a Paper Called the Tide Rolls in, It’s the Publisher Delivering It
text: SEAVIEW, N.Y.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about the Minneapolis bridge collapse rendered incorrectly the hometown of one victim. It is Mounds View, Minn., not Moundsview.

headline: Baseball and Umpires Clash Over Background Checks
text: Major League Baseball and its umpires union are locked in disagreement about baseball’s right to conduct background checks on umpires, representatives from baseball and the World Umpires Association said yesterday.

headline: TV Show Suspended After a Drowning
text: Death by drowning has prompted suspension of a popular survivor television show in Nigeria, Reuters reported. The victim, Anthony Ogadje, was one of 10 contestants who had gone to Shere Hills Lake in the hilly Plateau State of Nigeria to prepare for the “Gulder Ultimate Search,” a program that poses an assortment of physical challenges for the participants. A statement yesterday from Nigerian Breweries, a unit of the Dutch brewer Heineken, which sponsors the show, said Mr. Ogadje had died suddenly and was believed to have drowned. “All attempts to revive him by the attendant medical team and the lifeguards, including his fellow contestants, failed,” Nigerian Breweries said. Broadcasts were to have begun on Thursday. The winner of the elimination contest receives $39,000 in cash, a four-wheel-drive jeep and $3,900 for clothes, as well as celebrity status in Nigeria, where most people live in extreme poverty and benefit little from the country’s oil weath.

headline: Setback for Novartis in India Over Drug Patent
text: NEW DELHI, Aug. 6 — Indian companies will be free to continue making less expensive generic drugs, much of which flow to the developing world, after a court rejected a challenge to the patent law on Monday.

headline: Booker Comes Under Siege After Bloodshed
text: NEWARK, Aug. 6 — As a weekend of bloodshed gave way to a day of mourning, the sleep deprivation and public battering were beginning to take a toll on Mayor Cory A. Booker, his face a curtain of sadness and fatigue. A group of protesters on the steps of City Hall were calling for his resignation, while a large huddle of reporters down the street waited with unanswerable questions about Saturday night’s fatal shooting of three college students in a West Ward schoolyard.

headline: Four Trips to Hell and Back at the Opera
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 5 — Orpheus, the awesomely gifted musician and poet of ancient myth, whose lyrics and songs could entrance wild animals and alter the course of churning rivers, is the hero of countless operas, including Monteverdi’s landmark “Orfeo” of 1607. With this historic work Monteverdi set the parameters and pointed the way for what was to come in the genre.

headline: Raul Hilberg, 81, Historian Who Wrote of the Holocaust as a Bureaucracy, Dies
text: Raul Hilberg, a Jewish émigré from Nazi-occupied Vienna who helped begin the field of Holocaust studies with his long and minutely detailed 1961 study of the massacre of European Jews, died Saturday in Williston, Vt. He was 81.

headline: NATIONAL BRIEFING | SOUTH | Florida: Deputy Is Shot After Traffic Stop
text: An undercover Broward County sheriff’s deputy was shot in the head by a motorcyclist he had pulled over, the authorities said. The deputy, Maury Hernandez, 28, stopped the suspect, identified as David Maldonado, 23, who the authorities said jumped off his bike and shot the deputy. Deputy Hernandez was reported to be in critical condition. He was on his way to an undercover operation when he made the stop, and was wearing plain clothes and driving an unmarked vehicle. Mr. Maldonado was arrested at a nearby condominium complex.

headline: Those Missing Guns in Iraq
text: American taxpayers are rightly prepared to pay for all the equipment our soldiers need to defend themselves in Iraq. What is harder to accept is that because of the Pentagon’s scandalous mismanagement, they may have been paying to arm Iraqi insurgents who are shooting at American soldiers.

headline: ‘Strong Probability’ Outbreak Originated in Labs
text: LONDON, Aug. 7 — There is a “strong probability” that the outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in Britain was caused by viruses that escaped somehow from a pair of veterinary laboratories where vaccines are made, a government report said today.

headline: To Punish Thai Police, a Hello Kitty Armband
text: BANGKOK, Aug. 7 — It is the pink armband of shame for wayward police officers, as cute as can be with a Hello Kitty face and a pair of linked hearts.

headline: Before Running Cars, Ethanol Fuels Land Boom
text: DeKALB, Ill. — While much of the nation worries about a slumping real estate market, people in Midwestern farm country are experiencing exactly the opposite. Take, for instance, the farm here — nearly 80 acres of corn and soybeans off a gravel road in a universe of corn and soybeans — that sold for $10,000 an acre at auction this spring, a price that astonished even the auctioneer.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of a production error, the Bridge column’s diagramed deal yesterday misplaced some cards. The ace, king, queen, seven and five of clubs were part of East’s hand, not West’s; and the two shown in East’s hand was one of the diamonds, along with the queen, jack, ten and nine.

headline: Six Trapped After Collapse in a Utah Coal Mine
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 6 — Scores of rescue workers toiled into the night Monday to try to find six coal miners who were trapped inside a shaft that collapsed with such force that seismologists at first thought an earthquake had occurred.

headline: 121-Year-Old Pier Seen as Portal to ‘Harbor District’
text: For the past 20 years, Pier A has been an overlooked remnant on the waterfront of Lower Manhattan.

headline: Baron Elie de Rothschild Is Dead at 90
text: Baron Elie de Rothschild, who oversaw the restoration and ascent of the renowned wine estate Château Lafite Rothschild after World War II, died Monday while on a hunting trip near the village of Scharnitz, in the Austrian Alps. He was 90.

headline: Mental Abilities: Good Readers Better Able to Retain Brain Skills
text: It is not surprising that when doctors examined people who had worked at a lead smelter for years, they found no lack of neurological problems associated with lead.

headline: Juggling Tasks at Site of Fallen Bridge
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 6 — Even as divers continued what they said would remain a slow, methodical search for at least eight missing motorists, giant cranes and barges began moving into place along the Mississippi River on Monday to begin removing the wreckage from last week’s deadly bridge collapse.

headline: Ancient Flying Reptiles Probably Swooped, Not Skimmed, for Food
text: It was a nice idea while it lasted.

headline: Climate Change Endangers India, U.N. Says
text: NEW DELHI, Aug. 7 — As exceptionally heavy rains continued to cut a wide swath of ruin across northern India, a top United Nations official warned today that climate change could destroy vast swaths of farmland in this country, ultimately affecting food production and adding to the woes of already desperate peasants who live off of the land.

headline: Correction
text: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Kentucky governor’s race misstated the timing of Gov. Ernie Fletcher’s pardon of current and former aides who have been, or could be, charged in an inquiry into a hiring scandal. Mr. Fletcher pardoned them before, not after, his own indictment in the case.

headline: Mets Look to Reverse Trend Against the Braves
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 6 — The National League East standings show that the Mets are on top with a four-and-a-half-game lead over Atlanta, which is all well and good, except that the first-place team has seemed to masquerade as a last-place one whenever it has played the Braves.

headline: Extradition Ordered for Three Accused in Airport Bomb Plot
text: A judge in Trinidad ordered yesterday that three men be extradited to the United States to face charges that they conspired with a former airport cargo worker to attack jet fuel storage tanks and fuel lines at Kennedy International Airport, officials said.

headline: Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: In a Former First Family, Cancer Has a Grim Legacy
text: Few families have been as devastated by pancreatic cancer as that of former President Jimmy Carter.

headline: Health Administrators to Reimburse State $7 Million in Duplicate Billing
text: Two companies that administered health care for New York State Medicaid recipients have agreed to return $7 million that they received through duplicate billings, the state attorney general’s office said yesterday.

headline: Still Here, by Being Stubborn, Not Mellow
text: What do rappers lose when they get older? In the case of Bun B and Pimp C, two rappers in their 30s from Port Arthur, Tex., who perform together as UGK, the answer is, not much.

headline: Bush Still Wields the Threat of Terrorism
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 — Until last weekend, President Bush had repeatedly fallen short in seven months of battles with a Democratic-led Congress that would not give him what he wanted on immigration or education, health care or energy policy.

headline: Literary Critic Leaves New Republic for New Yorker
text: James Wood, a senior editor at The New Republic, where he has been the literary critic for the past 12 years, is leaving to become a staff writer at The New Yorker.

headline: China Praises Its Progress Toward Olympics
text: BEIJING, Aug. 6 — With a year remaining before the 2008 Olympics open here, Beijing officials on Monday gave an upbeat progress report about their preparations, even as critics warn that China may fall short on Olympic commitments on the environment, human rights and press freedom.

headline: Learning: In Tiny Part of the Brain, a Key to Foreign Tongues
text: Just can’t manage to nail down the subjunctive tense in French or the difference between the Spanish verbs for “to be”? Blame your Heschl’s gyrus — or at least your left one, anyway.

headline: Financial Stocks Lead a Big Rally
text: Wall Street rallied late yesterday afternoon as investors bought financial stocks, which have fallen significantly in recent weeks because of problems in the credit and mortgage markets.

headline: Found at Yellowstone: Hot Spring Bacteria That Harvest Light
text: Ah, Yellowstone. Home to elk and bison, wolf and beaver, eagle and hawk — and a newly discovered light-harvesting bacterium.

text: Ingmar Bergman Archive in Peril

headline: A New Answer for Another Mystery in Saturn’s Rings
text: The rings of Saturn have become far less mysterious since Galileo first discovered them in 1610 (and thought they might be moons). The latest puzzle to be cleared up involves the origin of one of the outermost rings, a thin, faint one labeled G.

headline: Jerry Schneider, 87, Pioneer of Indoor Tennis, Dies
text: LONGBOAT KEY, Fla., Aug. 6 — Jerry Schneider, a developer and promoter of indoor tennis, died here July 18. He was 87.

headline: Exported Prisoners (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kai Siegbahn, Swedish Physicist, Dies at 89
text: Kai Siegbahn, a Swedish physicist whose work in developing a novel technique using electrons to test the composition and purity of materials won a Nobel Prize in 1981, died on July 20. He was 89 and had been visiting his summer home in Angelholm, in southern Sweden.

headline: Astronaut Profiles
text: The seven members of the crew of the current mission of the space shuttle Endeavour include a teacher-astronaut, an electrician-turned-chemist, combat pilots and a doctor. The mission, which is officially designated as STS-118, will bring new structural elements up to the International Space Station and carry on the process of building the station.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Friday about eye infections linked to the lens cleaner Complete MoisturePlus, produced by Advanced Medical Optics, misstated the manner in which the Centers for Disease Control learned that four contact lens users developed infections after the product was recalled on May 26, 2007. Those infections were reported individually to the C.D.C., not discovered as part of a survey that showed many contact lens users were unaware of the recall.

headline: An Aspiring Veterinarian, but First, a Prospective End With the Jets
text: It takes a keen mind and sharp instincts to play defensive line for the Jets, and Michael Haynes wastes no time displaying both.

headline: Darfur Rebels Agree on Approach to Peace Talks, U.N. Says
text: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 6 — Eight rebel groups from the chaotic Sudanese region of Darfur agreed Monday on a common platform for peace talks with the government, the United Nations announced.

headline: Russia: Ex-Yukos Official Sentenced to Life in Murders
text: A Moscow court sentenced Aleksei Pichugin, the former security chief of Yukos Oil, to life in prison as it upheld his conviction for involvement in at least three murders and four attempted murders. He had earlier been sentenced to 24 years in prison. His arrest in 2003 registered the start of the Kremlin-backed campaign against Yukos, once Russia’s largest oil company, and its founder, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky.

headline: Heat Waves Are Getting Longer
text: Researchers studying western European temperature records have found that the length of heat waves there has doubled since 1880, from 1.5 days to 3 days on average. They also say that the number of summer days that are far hotter than the average for a particular date has tripled. The team described its work in the current issue of the Journal of Geophysical Research-Atmospheres. The scientists, led by Paul M. Della-Marta of the University of Bern in Switzerland, said the findings supported the idea that global warming from human activities could be making Europe more prone to extreme conditions. They recommended that health agencies in the region work on ways to limit human health risks from summer heat.

headline: Injections to Kick-Start Tissue Repair
text: The human body is held together by a network of connective tissues that are highly vulnerable to injury — through exercise, accidents and even the normal lifting, pulling and pushing of daily life.

headline: Early Returns Indicate Gambling Tycoon Will Not Be Governor of Baja California
text: TIJUANA, Mexico, Aug. 6  The quest of Jorge Hank Rhon, a gambling tycoon and former Tijuana mayor, to become governor of the Mexican state of Baja California ended in failure Monday morning, as preliminary election returns showed he had lost to his rival from the president’s National Action Party.

headline: Beethoven’s Final Sonatas Blossom in Complex Simplicity
text: KATONAH, N.Y., Aug. 5 — Virtuosos are often praised with the statement that they make the music sound easy. The last 3 of Beethoven’s 32 piano sonatas did not sound easy when Mitsuko Uchida played them on Sunday afternoon at the final concert of this year’s Caramoor International Music Festival. The beginning of Opus 109 — Sonata No. 30 — sounded like a tangled wealth of notes that took all the work of 10 fingers to keep under control. This was, of course, an interpretive decision; if the music sounds difficult in the hands of Ms. Uchida, it is definitely because she wants it to.

headline: A Top Fidelity Executive Resigns
text: Ellyn A. McColgan, Fidelity Investments’ president for distribution and operations, has resigned, the company said today.

headline: Muslim Societies (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Doctors Warn Against Infrared Thermometers
text: Over the next month, thousands of high school and college football teams will get ready for fall by practicing in torrid conditions where heatstroke is a constant danger.

headline: Memo Pad
text: LAW ON STRANDED PASSENGERS Airlines operating in New York would be required to provide fresh air, toilet-waste removal, drinking water and snacks to passengers on an airplane that has left the gate and remains parked on an airport apron under a new state law signed by Gov. Eliot Spitzer last week. The legislation, originally drafted by a state assemblyman from Queens, Michael N. Gianaris, would take effect Jan. 1, although the airline industry has said it is considering a legal challenge. The Airline Passengers Bill of Rights came in response to instances of passengers being stranded for hours on parked planes, with inadequate ventilation and food and deteriorating hygienic conditions. On Feb. 14, for example, thousands of JetBlue passengers sat on parked planes during a snow and ice storm for as long as 10 hours at Kennedy International Airport.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the World Briefing column on Friday about arrest warrants issued in Mexico for police commanders who worked for Jorge Hank Rhon, who is running for governor of Baja California, misidentified the government entity that issued the warrants. It is the State of Baja California, not Mexico’s federal government.

headline: Britain Asks U.S. to Release 5 From Guantánamo
text: LONDON, Aug. 7 — In a major reversal of policy, the British government today asked the Bush administration to release five British residents being held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Europe | Germany: Infineon Fires Executive
text: Infineon Technologies, the European semiconductor maker, dismissed its chief financial officer, Rüdiger A. Günther, left, after three months on the job because of disagreements between him and the company. Mr. Günther, 49, will leave immediately and Peter Fischl, who was finance chief until retiring in May, will take the post temporarily, according to the company. Mr. Günther declined to comment on the conflict, as did Guenter Gaugler, a spokesman for Infineon.

headline: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK | Manhattan: Leadership Posts Lost
text: The City Council voted unanimously yesterday to strip Councilman Dennis P. Gallagher of his leadership and committee posts after he was indicted last week on charges of rape and assault. The Queens councilman, a Republican, had volunteered to give up his positions as minority whip and on several committees at the suggestion of Speaker Christine C. Quinn, she said. “We are deeply, deeply troubled by the allegations and the charges that are pending against council member Gallagher,” Ms. Quinn said at a City Hall news conference. “That’s why we believe removing him from his leadership position and committees is an appropriate action.” The Council declined to take further steps, citing a request from Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, to defer any investigation or proceedings until the criminal case is resolved.

headline: Rights Groups See No Improvement in China
text: BEIJING, Aug. 7 — Human rights groups today accused China of failing to improve its record on civil liberties and continuing to harass lawyers, dissidents and journalists despite official promises to make human rights a centerpiece of the 2008 Olympics in Beijing.

headline: SoHo Loft, ’70s Ambience, Near Ninth Circle of Hell
text: Irini Spanidou’s new novel, “Before,” is set in New York City in the 1970s, a time when SoHo was still a dangerous neighborhood, lofts were occupied by starving artists, protest marches were about Vietnam, and self-styled radicals subscribed to Ramparts magazine and listened to the Velvet Underground. Max’s Kansas City was the cool place to hang out, and Lou Reed and Gerard Malanga were considered celebrities.

headline: Mine Rescue Slows and May Take at Least 3 Days
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 7 — Efforts to reach six trapped coal miners were reduced to a crawl today as rescue teams pulled back for safety reasons, and drilling equipment began slowly chewing through thousands of feet of rock to where the men were working early Monday when parts of the mountain shook and fell.

headline: Ingmar Bergman Archive in Peril
text: The future of an Ingmar Bergman archive is in doubt, Variety.com reported yesterday, only days after the death of Mr. Bergman, the master filmmaker. Astrid Soderberg-Widing, one of five employees of the archive, in Stockholm, said that in addition to the $250,000 annual budget provided by the Swedish government, $600,000 was needed to digitize Mr. Bergman’s papers. She said his early notes were written on paper so thin that it is nearly impossible to leaf through them. Uncertainty also surrounds the continuation of government financing after the current allocation ends in February. The archive was established by the Swedish Film Institute in collaboration with the Royal Dramatic Theater, Swedish Television and Svensk, a producer and distributor. Support could come from the Bonnier family, whose media holdings in Sweden include television and newspapers. “We will see what we can do to save the archives,” a representative of the family said. “It is important not only to us; it is important for filmmakers, for scholars and for the Swedish culture that this heritage is not destroyed or wasted.”

headline: New DVDs
text: BRIGITTE BARDOT

headline: Table for Two
text: LET me make clear for the public record: I’m an abysmal athlete.

headline: Aging: Hip Protectors Don’t Help Prevent Fractures in Falls
text: A new study raises questions about the effectiveness of padded hip protectors worn by older people to help prevent fractures if they fall.

headline: Sun Microsystems Announces Faster Chip
text: Sun Microsystems yesterday announced a new version of the Niagara processor used in its most powerful server computers and said it would license the chip to other equipment makers as part of a plan to create a new line of business.

headline: Democrats Campaign on Mortgage and Trade Issues
text: Two Democratic presidential candidates, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and former Senator John Edwards, are moving to tap into the economic anxieties of working Americans by introducing proposals to deal with the home-loan crisis and the flood of imports from overseas.

headline: Searching for the Stars of the Future, Beginning at Age 9
text: LONDON, Aug. 6 — With the competition to sign the stars of the future cutthroat, soccer teams are staking their claims on talent early. And from Freddy Adu, who was billed as the next Pelé at age 14, to Wayne Rooney, a bullish striker who has been scoring goals in the English Premier League since he was 16, soccer loves a wunderkind.

Ernie Fletcher’s pardon of current and former aides who have been, or could be, charged in an inquiry into a hiring scandal. Mr. Fletcher pardoned them before, not after, his own indictment in the case. (Go to Article)

text: To the Editor:

headline: Fortis Shareholders Back ABN Amro Bid
text: LONDON, Aug. 6 — Shareholders of Fortis, which is part of a group bidding for the Dutch bank ABN Amro, voted on Monday to support what would be the world’s largest banking takeover.

headline: Lohan Is Said to Be Back in Rehab
text: Lindsay Lohan, below, has entered a rehabilitation center for the third time this year, the CBS television show “The Insider” reported yesterday. Citing sources within Cirque Lodge, a drug and alcohol treatment institution in Sundance, Utah, the “Insider” report said Ms. Lohan, 21, had checked in during the weekend for an intensive program expected to last at least 30 days at a reported minimum price of $30,000. Ms. Lohan, whose films include “Herbie Fully Loaded,” was treated at the Wonderland Center in Los Angeles in January and, after a Memorial Day weekend that led to her arrest on suspicion of driving under the influence, she was treated at the Promises rehabilitation facility in Malibu, Calif. Eleven days after her release on July 13, she was arrested on charges of drunken driving and cocaine possession. She faces a court hearing on Aug. 24.

headline: Fed Leaves Rate Steady; No Sign of Future Cut
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 — The Federal Reserve today largely sidestepped the growing anxiety over how tightening credit standards will affect the economy, deciding to leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 5.25 percent.

headline: Prosecution Wraps Up in ’92 Case
text: “This was the big fish?” the prosecutor asked, his tenor incredulous, his index finger aimed across the courtroom at Vitaly Ivanitsky.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, the “Most Popular” listing in the Most Wanted chart in Business Day yesterday, listing top sellers among re-released music CDs, misspelled the name of a singing duo. It is Simon and Garfunkel, not Simon and Garfunkle.

headline: Awareness: Counseling by Phone Benefits Drinkers
text: Experience has shown that even a few short discussions with a health professional can help a problem drinker. But sometimes people who could benefit from the talks are unable to come in or reluctant to do so.

headline: Finding (and Keeping) the Employees You Want
text: In a tight labor market like this one, hiring good employees is only half the battle. You also need to make sure they stay.

headline: Its Poor Reputation Aside, Our Fat Is Doing Us a Favor
text: In this country, the most popular cosmetic surgery procedure is liposuction: doctors vacuum out something like two million pounds of fat from the thighs, bellies, buttocks, jowls and man-breasts of 325,000 people a year. What happens to all that extracted adipose tissue? It’s bagged and disposed of as medical waste; or maybe, given the recent news about socially contagious fat, it’s sent by FedEx to the patients’ old college chums. But one thing the fat surely is not, and that is given due thanks for serving as scapegoat, and for a job well done.

headline: Lebanon Opposition Wins Key Seat
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 6 — The official results from the pivotal election on Sunday in the Christian-dominated Metin district of Lebanon confirmed a victory for Kamil Khoury, the opposition candidate, who narrowly defeated former President Amin Gemayel for a seat left vacant by the assassination of Mr. Gemayel’s son, Pierre, last November.

headline: Even Nonhousing Markets Feel Mortgage Fallout
text: The day-to-day financial dealings of Oneida Limited, the dinnerware and flatware maker, are typically about as far removed from the mortgage loan business as they can be.

headline: Letters
text: The Unconscious and Freud

headline: On First Day of Jury Duty, Bloomberg Is Not Selected
text: “Law & Order” it was not.

headline: U.S. Supports Patent Ruling in a Setback for Qualcomm
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6  In a decision watched closely by the mobile phone industry, the Bush administration on Monday let stand an earlier ruling that requires Qualcomm to pay licensing fees to its competitor Broadcom.

headline: Tougher Rules Change Game for Lobbyists
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 — H. Stewart Van Scoyoc, founder of one of the biggest lobbying firms in Washington, spent an anxious morning with his lawyer last week assessing the far-reaching ethics and lobbying rules Congress had passed the day before.

headline: Georgia Accuses Russia of Firing Missile
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 7 —Officials of the Republic of Georgia accused Russia today of violating the country’s air space and firing a guided missile, which did not detonate.

headline: In King’s Footsteps, Others Try to Dream
text: ATLANTA — If you stand in the middle of Auburn Avenue, outside the Queen Anne-style home in which the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was born in 1929, and look past the King Center, past the trees leading into the National Park Service Visitor Center and past Ebenezer Baptist Church, toward the office buildings and hotels of downtown Atlanta, you can get some sense of what the precocious Martin might have felt standing in the same spot, before his family moved off the street when he was 12.

headline: Six Remain Trapped in Coal Mine in Utah
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 6 — Six miners were trapped tonight inside a coal mine shaft that collapsed with such force that seismology experts at first believed it was an earthquake.

headline: Four Masterworks Stolen From a French Museum
text: PARIS, Aug. 6 — Five armed and masked thieves walked into a museum in Nice, France, while it was open on Sunday afternoon and stole two Impressionist paintings and two canvases by Jan Brueghel the Elder, the police said Monday.

headline: Deadly Inheritance, Desperate Trade-Off
text: BALTIMORE — The room lights were dimmed, and all eyes turned to the grainy pictures on a pair of overhead monitors in a small room at Johns Hopkins Hospital.

headline: Little Blue Lights
text: Q. Is it true that airport taxiways are lined with blue lights because blue light can be seen from the longest distance?

headline: 5 Ministers Threaten to Leave Iraq’s Cabinet
text: BAGHDAD, Aug 6  Five ministers suspended their participation in meetings of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s cabinet on Monday, sending a warning signal that they may pull out of his increasingly isolated government if their demands are not met.

headline: Newark Police, and Families, Are Searching for Answers
text: NEWARK, Aug. 6 — They had spent most of their young lives in perfect rhythm, a brother, a sister and their best friend: attending proms together, playing in the West Side High School marching band here, choosing the same college. A fourth young man, a more recent addition to their close-knit circle, had charisma enough to attract his own following.

headline: Once Tainted, Nardelli Now Has Chrysler’s Keys
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Aug. 6 — When Robert L. Nardelli was sent packing from Home Depot in January with a $210 million exit package and a reputation as an imperious chief executive who had made strategic blunders, he seemed tarnished forever.

headline: Owner of Canadiens Continues a Trend and Invests in a Nascar Team
text: Outside investors are increasingly finding a new home inside the Nascar Nextel Cup garage, and George N. Gillett Jr., the owner of the Montreal Canadiens, is the latest to buy in.

headline: Japan: Broad Survey Points to Growth
text: Japan’s broadest indicator of the outlook for growth signaled for the first time in eight months that the economy would expand. The leading index climbed to 80 percent in June, the Cabinet Office said, the first time it has been at or over 50 since October. A reading of 50 or more indicates the economy may expand in three to six months. The index is derived from as many as 12 monthly indicators. “The economy will probably accelerate in coming months as a pickup in U.S. exports brings a positive impact on the economy over all,” said Takeshi Minami, chief economist at the Norinchukin Research Institute in Tokyo. “As foreign demand remains robust, we can expect sustainable growth.”

headline: Olmert and Abbas Meet in West Bank for First Time
text: JERICHO, West Bank, Aug. 6  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel met Monday with the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, on Palestinian turf for the first time in another gesture meant to strengthen the moderate Palestinian leadership and inject a feeling of momentum into long-dormant peace efforts.

headline: News Reports Are Criticized by Astronaut
text: Cmdr. Scott J. Kelly, commander of the space shuttle mission scheduled to be launched tomorrow, has sent a letter to several newspapers saying recent reports of alcohol use by astronauts had been exaggerated in news accounts.

headline: Drywall Maker in Pain as Housing Suffers
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 4 — Plenty of companies — the mortgage lender Countrywide Financial, the hardware giant Home Depot and the insulation maker Owens Corning among them — are absorbing the ill effects of the yearlong slump in housing construction and sales.

headline: 19-Year-Old Confesses in Killing of Editor
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6  A 19-year-old handyman at a bakery has confessed to murdering a well-known newspaper editor in downtown Oakland last week, the police said Monday.

headline: Lee Hazlewood, ‘Boots’ Songwriter, Dies at 78
text: Lee Hazlewood, the reclusive songwriter and producer behind a slew of hits by Duane Eddy, Nancy Sinatra, Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin in the 1950s and 1960s, including Ms. Sinatra’s No. 1 smash “These Boots Are Made for Walkin’,” died on Saturday in Henderson, Nev. He was 78.

headline: Rich and Unhappy in Silicon Valley (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Giants Cornerback Eager to Go Back to Work After Concussion
text: ALBANY, Aug. 6  Last week, Kevin Dockery had headaches so painful that he was kept inside his dormitory room for days and he needed to wear sunglasses because he was sensitive to light. On Monday morning he was on the practice field in pads and a helmet, chasing after receivers and diving for balls with the same fervor as before.

headline: The Claim: With Sunscreens, High SPF Ratings Are Best
text: THE FACTS

headline: NATIONAL BRIEFING | WASHINGTON | Criticized, Senator Pulls Video
text: Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, has taken down a video from a YouTube Web site connected to his re-election committee, acknowledging through a spokesman that it should not have been posted because it was made in a Senate recording studio. Conservative bloggers had accused Mr. Durbin of violating Congressional ethics rules by using the official Senate seal in a video appeal to a convention of liberal bloggers. The spokesman, Michael Daly, said that Mr. Durbin’s team made what amounted to a “clerical error,” but that it did not intentionally violate ethics rules. Mr. Daly added that the campaign consultants who posted the video were not aware where it had been produced.

headline: When Horror Came to a Connecticut Family
text: CHESHIRE, Conn., Aug. 6 — Dr. William A. Petit Jr., his head bloodied and legs bound, stumbled out of a rear basement door of his two-story home here into a pouring rain, calling the name of a neighbor for help.

headline: Quick Bites of Theater Off a Menu of One Acts
text: Shorts are pants that don’t cover your legs, or theater pieces that don’t cover an evening. Both are meant to be light and fresh, and both can suffer from problems of scale if not properly tailored: revealing too much, or extending too far in a misguided attempt to be more durable, more fashionable, or more suited to evening wear.

headline: Work Begins to Remove Wreckage of Bridge
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 6 — Even as divers continued what they promised would remain a slow and methodical search for at least eight missing motorists, giant cranes and barges began moving into place along the Mississippi River today to remove the wreckage from last week’s deadly bridge collapse.

headline: White House Challenges Critics on Spying
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  The White House maintained Monday that the surveillance measure signed into law by President Bush over the weekend did not give the government any sweeping new powers to eavesdrop on Americans without court warrants.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about the coming release of boxed DVD sets of Playboy and Rolling Stone magazines, referred imprecisely to a Web site that will sell the DVDs. Although the site, covertocover.com, will take preorders, it will not do so until Sept. 1; it is not yet online.

headline: Credit Worries, Imported From U.S., Lead German Firm to Shut Fund
text: FRANKFURT, Aug. 6  Germany, which last week became the first European country to be infected by the woes in the American mortgage market, suffered another blow on Monday when an asset management firm in Frankfurt closed a fund to temporarily halt withdrawals by rattled investors.

headline: Posh Princes and Princesses of the Hills
text: “Baldwin Hills,” the popular BET series that begins the second half of its season tonight, would seem to have two main goals: to give a (primarily) black audience an alternative to teenage reality shows like MTV’s “Laguna Beach,” its obvious model; and to break down stereotypes by offering the rest of the world documentary proof that affluent African-American enclaves like Baldwin Hills actually exist.

headline: Competitors, Once Collegial, Now Seem Cool
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 — They work in the same building. They slog through the same rigorous travel schedule. Along the way, they often cross paths several times a day.

headline: Registered Traveler Program Remains a Work in Progress
text: LISTENING to testimony during a Congressional hearing last week, you would have been justified in concluding that the Transportation Security Administration had driven a spike through the heart of the lumbering Registered Traveler program.

headline: Zimbabwe: 7,660 Arrests in Price Campaign
text: Police officials said they had arrested 7,660 business owners and managers since June 26 on charges of violating government orders to slash the prices of goods in line with the government’s campaign to counter 10,000-percent-a-year hyperinflation. About 600 of those who were arrested were released after paying fines, the government said. President Robert G. Mugabe, speaking at a conference of poor nations in Malaysia, said the state would press its campaign.

headline: Free Market Comes With a Dark Side
text: Reading that a match last week involving the highly ranked Russian Nikolay Davydenko is under investigation by men’s professional tennis after betting irregularities, I was reminded of a few wild, high-risk rides I happened to take a few years ago.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A listing of American military deaths yesterday misidentified the country in which Sgt. Taurean T. Harris was killed. It was Afghanistan, not Iraq. An updated Names of the Dead appears today.

headline: Bush Differs With Karzai on Iran
text: CAMP DAVID, Md., Aug. 6 — President Bush and President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, close allies in fighting terrorism, found much to agree on as they completed a two-day meeting here on Monday, with one major exception: the role of Iran in Afghanistan.

headline: Japanese Find Romance and Rituals Far From Home
text: PARIS, Aug. 6 — The first time that Hirosha Watanabe and Naoko Shibuya entered a church was the giddy moment when they marched down the aisle, he in pearl gray tails and she in a frothy wedding dress, to the strains of the Wagner classic “Bridal Chorus.”

headline: The Protection Battered Spouses Don’t Need
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Farrow Offers to Take Sudan Prisoner’s Place
text: The actress Mia Farrow, above left, has told the president of Sudan that she is willing to take the place of Suleiman Jamous, above right, the ailing humanitarian coordinator for the rebel group Sudan Liberation Army who has been virtually imprisoned for more than 13 months, Reuters reported. Mr. Jamous, 62, has been confined to a United Nations hospital in Kordofan, east of Darfur, where he was moved by the United Nations without permission last year. He is in need of a stomach biopsy, which cannot be performed there. The government, based in Khartoum, has said he will be arrested if he leaves, but has declared itself open to discussing his release. In a letter to President Omar Hassan al-Bashir  of Sudan, posted yesterday on her blog at www.miafarrow.org, Ms. Farrow, who is also a Unicef goodwill ambassador, wrote: “At the Inter-Sudanese talks in Abuja in 2005, before his seizure, Mr. Jamous played a crucial role in bringing the S.L.A. to the negotiating table and in seeking reconciliation between its divided rival factions.” She said, “I am therefore offering to take Mr. Jamous’s place, to exchange my freedom for his in the knowledge of his importance to the civilians of Darfur and in the conviction that he will apply his energies toward creating the just and lasting peace that the Sudanese people deserve and hope for.” International experts have estimated that 200,000 people have died and that 2.5 million have been driven from their homes in more than four years of fighting in Sudan’s remote west.

headline: Giuliani’s Daughter Shows Support for Obama, for a Time
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani’s daughter, Caroline, has done her best to keep out of the spotlight as her father runs for president, choosing to keep complicated family matters private. And for his part, Mr. Giuliani has tried to shield both her and his son, Andrew, from attention.

headline: Japan and Sex Slavery (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bring Your Own Crossbones
text: Credit the artist Banks Violette with the recent surge in skull imagery, from consumer items to ludicrously luxe objets d’art. The artist’s obsession with all things goth and death metal, and his collaboration with the hardcore band Sunn 0 have made him an art-world celebrity, and one of the youngest people ever to have a solo show at the Whitney. His latest exhibit, split between the Team Gallery in SoHo and the Gladstone Gallery in Chelsea, is a bit cooler than his previous work, Martha Schwendener writes — the metal artifacts on view, like exploded drum kits and liquor bottles, are literally frozen. And he’s been moving toward performance art lately; catch this retrospective before he joins the line-up of Ozzfest.

headline: City Is Rebuffed on the Release of ’04 Records
text: A federal judge yesterday rejected New York City’s efforts to prevent the release of nearly 2,000 pages of raw intelligence reports and other documents detailing the Police Department’s covert surveillance of protest groups and individual activists before the Republican National Convention in 2004.

headline: The Contest Outside the Ropes at St. Andrews
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 6  The gorse bushes on the Old Course were as thorny as advertised, and the pot bunkers were about as much fun to get out of as quicksand. But neither hazard worried the players at the Women’s British Open as much as the one lurking outside the gallery ropes, in the realm of public opinion.

headline: Bridge Collapse Revives Issue of  Road Spending
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 6 — In the past two years, Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota twice vetoed legislation to raise the state’s gas tax to pay for transportation needs.

headline: Inmates Have Political Pull in Some New York Counties
text: More than 6 in 10 people who live in the western New York town of Groveland have probably never heard of their representative on the Livingston County Board of Supervisors, James C. Merrick. They certainly have never voted for him.

headline: A New Owner’s Unspoken Aggressiveness
text: The last time the Mets played the Atlanta Braves, the new ownership of the Braves was in place for only a week, certainly not time enough to make a difference. As the Mets prepare to play the Braves at Shea Stadium tonight, nearly three months later, the difference is palpable.

headline: U.N. Worker Is Accused of Falsifying Visa Letters
text: A Russian citizen working in New York for the United Nations was arrested yesterday on charges of using the organization’s letterhead to create fake documents that allowed several Uzbek citizens to illegally obtain visas to enter the United States.

headline: Timbuktu Hopes Ancient Texts Spark a Revival
text: TIMBUKTU, Mali — Ismaël Diadié Haïdara held a treasure in his slender fingers that has somehow endured through 11 generations — a square of battered leather enclosing a history of the two branches of his family, one side reaching back to the Visigoths in Spain and the other to the ancient origins of the Songhai emperors who ruled this city at its zenith.

headline: From Fresh Ideas and Better Steel, Safer Bridges
text: The collapse of the eight-lane steel-deck truss bridge last week in Minneapolis focused attention on deficiencies in many older spans around the nation. Despite these troubles, engineers say, new ideas and technologies are making bridges safer — not to mention longer and more beautiful — than they have ever been.

headline: Universities Install Footbaths to Benefit Muslims, and Not Everyone Is Pleased
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — When pools of water began accumulating on the floor in some restrooms at the University of Michigan-Dearborn, and the sinks pulling away from the walls, the problem was easy to pinpoint. On this campus, more than 10 percent of the students are Muslims, and as part of ritual ablutions required before their five-times-a-day prayers, some were washing their feet in the sinks.

headline: Guests, Running Late, Wake Up Hotels
text: Hotels have upgraded their beds, enhanced their technology, added more spa services and become more pet- and child-friendly in recent years. But their wake-up service? That is another story.

headline: Reggae Songs in Anglican Hymnal
text: Songs by the reggae greats Bob Marley, below, and Peter Tosh, who practiced Rastafarianism, will appear in new Anglican church hymnals in Jamaica, The Associated Press reported. Church leaders preparing a new collection of hymns said Marley’s “One Love” and Tosh’s “Psalm 27” would be the first reggae tunes to appear beside traditional worship music on the island where reggae was born. The Rev. Ernle Gordon, a church spokesman, said members of the Anglican Church of Jamaica were enthusiastic about including the songs in the hymnals, despite the sometimes vocal opposition of Marley (1945-1981) and Tosh (1944-1987) to Christianity. “They may have been anti-church, but they were not anti-God or anti-religion,” he said.

headline: Fail, Then Pass (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rescuing a Student From a Life in the Mines
text: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 4 — A sharp tongue does not preclude a good heart. Sterling proof of this truth is personified by Miss Moffat, the schoolmistress played with appealing zest by Kate Burton in the Williamstown Theater Festival’s spirited revival of Emlyn Williams’s 1938 comedy, “The Corn Is Green.”

headline: Asia | India: Wal-Mart Wholesale Deal Set
text: Wal-Mart Stores and the Bharti Group of India have agreed to set up wholesale stores and a supply chain in India, eight months after they signed an initial agreement. Their venture will open its first wholesale store by the end of 2008, according to Rajan Mittal, the joint managing director of Bharti Enterprises, who spoke at a news conference in New Delhi. Wal-Mart signed a tentative agreement to start a wholesaling business with the Bharti Group in November. The venture, a 50-50 partnership known as Bharti Wal-Mart Private, is planning to open 10 to 15 wholesale stores over the next seven years to sell to small retailers, hotels and restaurants. The proposed Bharti venture would supply the retail market with goods that come directly from producers like farmers, craftsmen and artisans, Mr. Mittal said.

headline: It Banishes Uterine Fibroids, but for How Long?
text: A little over a year ago, desperate for relief from uterine fibroids that made her menstrual periods last all month, Sharyn Sowell tried a new noninvasive procedure that uses focused high-intensity ultrasound beams to destroy the uterine growths.

headline: Lottery Numbers
In Wireless Competition, Mockery Is the Latest Style
text: WITH growth in the wireless market slowing, Alltel is turning to a sophisticated online campaign to maintain and expand its customer base.

headline: Judge Limits Navy Sonar, Citing a Threat to Wildlife
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6  A federal judge on Monday ordered the Navy to stop using medium-range sonar in training exercises off Southern California, saying that the Navy’s own assessments predicted that dozens of marine mammals, particularly deep-diving whales, could be harmed by the intense sound waves.

headline: In Dusty Archives, a Theory of Affluence
text: For thousands of years, most people on earth lived in abject poverty, first as hunters and gatherers, then as peasants or laborers. But with the Industrial Revolution, some societies traded this ancient poverty for amazing affluence.

headline: $1.5 Billion Verdict Against Microsoft Is Set Aside
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 — A federal district court judge delivered a major setback to Alcatel-Lucent on Monday by setting aside a jury’s $1.5 billion judgment against Microsoft in a patent infringement lawsuit over digital music technology.

headline: In a Hospital Stay, No Time to Rest
text: Grand Central Terminal may be synonymous with noise and haste. But as I recently discovered, it can be a lot quieter than a hospital bed.

headline: Jews in Argentina Wary of Nation’s Ties to Chávez
text: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 6 — President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela said Monday that his country would help the government of President Néstor Kirchner refinance more of Argentina’s debt and increase its energy supplies.

headline: Jack Cole, Creator of People Locator, Dead at 87
text: Jack Cole, a businessman who used early computer technology to sort the world — or at least millions of the people in it — by street address, creating a series of reverse directories that remain invaluable to detectives, debt collectors, telemarketers and anyone who needs to find someone, died on July 29 at his home in Spearfish Canyon, S.D. He was 87.

headline: Doping Is a Safety Issue (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Proper Care of Camel Hair, One Hump or Two
text: IN a hidden courtyard at the Bronx Zoo on a recent weekday, Ruth Iannuzzi soaped and scrubbed, then hugged, Alexander, 5, and Balkor, 3, a couple of two-humped camels from Asia who have had visitors doing double takes since they arrived at the zoo two years ago.

headline: Pensions and the Mortgage Mess
text: Even as the plunge continues in investments tied to dicey mortgages, government regulators remain skeptical of the need for new rules to cover these newfangled derivative products or the hedge funds that tend to buy them.

headline: It’s a Female Dog, or Worse. Or Endearing. And Illegal?
text: The New York City Council, which drew national headlines when it passed a symbolic citywide ban earlier this year on the use of the so-called n-word, has turned its linguistic (and legislative) lance toward a different slur: bitch.

headline: Poisonous Choices, Women at Risk
text: When the Supreme Court voted 5 to 4 to uphold the federal Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act this spring, the ambivalently pro-choice public was largely quiescent, believing, as Congress had previously ruled, that the procedure was “gruesome and inhuman,” medically unnecessary, highly controversial in the medical community and so rare as to be little missed.

headline: Woman, 20, Found Dead in Apartment Near N.Y.U.
text: Detectives are investigating the death of a 20-year-old woman whose badly decomposed body was found on Sunday wrapped in bedding in her mother’s apartment at a Greenwich Village building owned by New York University, officials said yesterday.

headline: Bonds Is Hailed, but Hits No Homers
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 — Before Barry Bonds took a swing Monday night, he received two standing ovations. There was anticipation, a tingly expectation, that Bonds would hit a homer into the cool, dark night and become the career home run leader. But it never happened.

headline: Bear Stearns Heir Apparent Tries to Restore Some Faith
text: Yesterday morning, the top 50 executives of Bear Stearns filed into the firm’s 12th-floor dining room. Nerves were taut — Bear’s president in charge of its bond business, Warren J. Spector, had just been forced out in the wake of the collapse last month of two of the firm’s hedge funds.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,657 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of these Americans over the past week:

headline: Milberg Trial to Proceed
text: Milberg Weiss, once the biggest United States investor class-action law firm, and a former partner, Steven Schulman, must go to trial to defend against charges that they illegally paid plaintiffs in securities lawsuits.

headline: The Paper’s New Look (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: 2 Charged in Connecticut Murder Appear in Court
text: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 7 — The two men accused of the brutal murders of a Connecticut family during a home invasion last month appeared in court today under unusually high security to hear the charges against them.

headline: Theater Briefs
text: Theater for a New Audience has announced its 2007-8 season, with three works exploring Europe and America’s relationship with Africa: “The Ohio State Murders,” by Adrienne Kennedy; “Oroonoko,” an adaptation by the Nigerian writer Biyi Bandele of Aphra Behn’s 1688 novella; and Shakespeare’s “Antony and Cleopatra,” starring Christine Baranski as Cleopatra.

headline: Bridge Hero Gets Offer: Paid Tuition
text: Among the dozens of wrenching accounts to come out of the collapse of the Interstate 35W bridge in Minneapolis, the actions of 20-year-old Jeremy Hernandez were a bright spot: Trapped in a tipping school bus with 50 children, he kicked open the back door and began helping them one by one to safety.

headline: Israel Removes Settlers in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 7 — Pelted by rocks and metal, hundreds of Israeli riot police today forcibly removed Jewish settlers from houses they had been occupying illegally for months in the West Bank city of Hebron.

headline: Yale Is the Front-Runner in a Balanced Ivy League
text: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 6  When Jack Siedlecki, the Yale football coach, learned that the Bulldogs were a clear favorite to win the Ivy League championship, he said he did not think it was the kiss of death. Instead, he said, it was logical.

headline: Family Guy Shows Its Muscle
text: With four Sunday reruns of “Family Guy,” which garnered the night’s top ratings among adults 18 to 49, Fox led in that demographic over all, while CBS once again earned the title of most-watched network for the night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the “Family Guy” episodes drew total viewer audiences ranging from 4.5 million viewers at 8 to 6.5 million at 9:30. Those numbers fell short of the competition on CBS, “Big Brother” at 8 (8 million), followed by a “Cold Case” repeat at 9 (7.2 million), which each led their respective time slots. At 7, CBS’s “60 Minutes” delivered 8.7 million viewers, the night’s largest audience over all. NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (6.4 million) finished No. 1 in the 10 o’clock hour, ahead of CBS’s “Shark” in second place (6 million). NBC ranked second for the night in total viewers, but fourth in the 18 to 49 set. ABC, whose lineup typically leads the night during the regular season, finished third with reruns.

headline: Cleaning Up Congress (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Akzo Raises Bid for British Chemical Company
text: Akzo Nobel, the world’s largest maker of paints and coatings, raised its bid for Imperial Chemical Industries to £8 billion ($16 billion) and won access to the British company’s books.

headline: Three Games to Remember, and Some Broadcasts to Forget
text: You can’t manufacture — and shouldn’t plan — a memorable call for a significant sports event. The best ones flow naturally. On Saturday, Barry Bonds’s 755th home run and Alex Rodriguez’s 500th did not yield poetry.

headline: Loss Widens at Trump Entertainment
text: The news only gets worse for Trump Entertainment Resorts.

headline: The Fear of Fear Itself
text: It was appalling to watch over the last few days as Congress — now led by Democrats — caved in to yet another unnecessary and dangerous expansion of President Bush’s powers, this time to spy on Americans in violation of basic constitutional rights. Many of the 16 Democrats in the Senate and 41 in the House who voted for the bill said that they had acted in the name of national security, but the only security at play was their job security.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10 P.M. (FX) DAMAGES Patty (Glenn Close) is faced with a threat to her litigation against one of the country’s wealthiest C.E.O.s (played by Ted Danson). Ellen (Rose Byrne, left), Patty’s protégée, learns what will be expected of her, and Tom (Tate Donovan) discovers some interesting information about Katie (Anastasia Griffith).

headline: Yankees’ Two Young Catalysts Cook Up Another Victory
text: TORONTO, Aug. 6  Robinson Canó had already doubled in the tying and go-ahead runs in the sixth inning Monday. As he crossed the plate on a single by Melky Cabrera, he clapped his hands in delight. Sure enough, at first base a moment later, Cabrera clapped, too.

headline: Pacers’ O’Neal Open to Deal
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 6 (AP)  Indiana Pacers forward Jermaine O’Neal is not demanding a trade to the Los Angeles Lakers, but he is open to the idea.

headline: Teacher-Astronaut to Fly Decades After Challenger
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  Barbara R. Morgan is now an astronaut by profession, heading into space this week for the first time on the space shuttle. But she said she would be approaching her mission “with the mind, eyes, ears and heart of a teacher.”

headline: Van Crash Kills Boy
text: A van from a summer camp in Sullivan County overturned on a highway in Maine yesterday, killing a 15-year-old boy and injuring 12 other people, authorities said. Two people were in critical condition. The van, from Camp Serene Springs in Bethel, N.Y., towing a trailer with canoes, was carrying 11 campers and two counselors for a trip to Maine so campers could canoe the Penobscot River and hike Mount Katahdin. The campers were all boys, 14 to 18. It overturned on Interstate 95 in Artgyle Township about 7 a.m., Stephen McCausland, a spokesman for the Maine Department of Public Safety, said. The victim was identidied by camp officials as Gedalya Rosenblatt. (AP)

headline: Recalling a City in Fear During the Year of ‘Son of Sam’
text: Thirty years ago New Yorkers were held in horrified thrall as a serial killer armed with a .44-caliber revolver and calling himself Son of Sam prowled the nighttime streets for just over a year. He killed six people and injured seven, mostly in Queens and the Bronx, before being captured.

headline: Security Crosses the Line: Confiscating Chocolate
text: Running a business that trains professionals who work in the oil, natural gas, power and green energy markets requires an energy reserve of one’s own. I founded this business back in 1991, and travel at least twice a month, mostly internationally.

headline: Spitzer Aides Linked to Effort to Tarnish Bruno Used Personal Accounts for Some E-Mail
text: ALBANY, Aug. 6  Top aides to Gov. Eliot Spitzer, including some at the center of an effort to tarnish the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, kept second BlackBerrys on which they sometimes communicated about political business, a spokeswoman for the governor said Monday.

headline: Goodbye, George and John
text: Names matter. People named Dennis and Denise are disproportionately likely to become dentists. People named Lawrence or Laurie are disproportionately likely to become lawyers. People named Louis are disproportionately likely to live in St. Louis, and people named Georgia are disproportionately likely to move to the state that served as home in “Gone With the Wind.”

headline: Bonds Still at 755 After 3 At-Bats
text: Barry Bonds returned to San Francisco on Monday to try to hit his 756th homer and break Hank Aaron’s career home run record. Bonds was ready, the San Francisco Giants were ready and the fans were ready. Even Willie Mays, Bonds’s godfather, was here for the potentially historic moment.

headline: America’s Sagging Automakers
text: Robert L. Nardelli, who was just named chief executive at Chrysler, faces enormous challenges. Chrysler is in the midst of its fourth turnaround effort in three decades and Japanese companies like Toyota and Honda are surging. In July, foreign auto companies surpassed their American counterparts in monthly sales for the first time.

headline: Sharing Paris
text: A look at a Parisian apartment with a shared ownership.

headline: Anonymous Nat Stings (Old) Killer Bee
text: The night was supposed to be about Barry Bonds, but John Lannan made sure there would be no celebration in San Francisco. John Who? Lannan, a 22-year-old left-hander who was making his third major league start for the Washington Nationals, silenced one of the best hitters of all time and made sure the home run record would be shared for at least another day.

headline: $100,000 Homes
text: Homes on the market in Pigeon Forge, Tenn., Seaside, Ore., and Boulder, Colo.

headline: A Fish Story
text: Images of Annie Sessler and her fish prints.

headline: McDonald’s Serves Up Boston Market
text: McDonald‘s said Monday that it had agreed to sell its meat-and-potatoes Boston Market restaurant chain to the private equity firm Sun Capital Partners for an undisclosed sum.

headline: Temple-Inland to Sell Land and Pass Proceeds to Investors
text: The forest products company Temple-Inland, which is under pressure from the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, said Monday that it would sell 1.55 million acres of timberland to the Campbell Group for $2.38 billion and then issue a $1.1 billion special dividend.

headline: Squabbling over the Sallie Mae Deal
text: There appear to be some mixed signals surrounding the proposed $25 billion buyout of student lender Sallie Mae.

headline: Milberg Weiss Trial to Proceed
text: Milberg Weiss, once the biggest United States investor class-action law firm, and a former partner, Steven Schulman, must go to trial to defend against charges that they illegally paid plaintiffs in securities lawsuits.

headline: Akzo Raises Bid for British Chemical Company
text: Akzo Nobel, the world’s largest maker of paints and coatings, raised its bid for Imperial Chemical Industries to 8 billion pounds ($16 billion) and won access to the British company’s books.

headline: Big Challenge Ahead for Bear’s New No. 2
text: At Bear Stearns, the torch, it seems, has been passed.

headline: American Home Mortgage Files for Bankruptcy
text: American Home Mortgage Investment filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Monday in Wilmington, Del., capping a tumultuous 10 days for what had been one of the nation’s biggest home lenders.

headline: Xstrata Plans to Mine Eland Platinum
text: Xstrata, which won a bidding war last year for Canadian nickel company Falconbridge, said Tuesday that it intends to offer 7.53 billion rand ($1.06 billion) for Eland Platinum Holdings of South Africa.

headline: Nardelli Now Has Chrysler’s Keys
text: When Robert L. Nardelli was sent packing from Home Depot in January with a $210 million exit package and a reputation as an imperious chief executive who had made strategic blunders, he seemed tarnished forever.

headline: NYSE and Nymex Talks Getting Serious, Report Says
text: Talks between the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Mercantile Exchange may be heating up.

headline: Upper Deck Can Proceed With Topps Bid
text: Topps said Monday that rival Upper Deck is free to begin a $425 million bid for Topps, setting up a potential showdown for the maker of baseball cards and Bazooka bubble gum.

headline: Homeland Security Firm to Go Public
text: ICx Technologies, which develops sensing technologies used in the homeland security market, is seeking to raise as much as $184 million in an initial public offering, according to a regulatory filing Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Canada Said to Mull Australian Media Rules
text: In the aftermath of three major takeovers in Canada’s broadcasting sector, the nation’s regulators appear poised to consider revamping the rules on media consolidation, using a system pioneered last year by the Australian government, The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: Allen to Sell DreamWorks Stake
text: The billionaire Paul Allen is selling the majority of his stake in DreamWorks Animation SKG and stepping down from the board of the animation company he helped bankroll in its infancy.

headline: Virgin Media Gives Bidders More Time
text: The British cable operator Virgin Media postponed its $23 billion (11.3 billion) sale of the company on Tuesday after it became apparent buyers would not have access to the debt needed to do a deal right away.

headline: Morgan to Bulk Up European Private Equity Unit
text: Morgan Stanley on Monday shrugged off the turmoil in leveraged debt markets by appointing Peter Bacon to a new position as chairman of European financial sponsors, signaling a desire to expand its undersized private equity business.

headline: Congressman Launches Private-Equity Blog
text: “Blogging about private equity is so easy, even a congressman can do it,” writes Dan Primack on PEHub. He is referring to New York Republican Tom Reynolds, whom he describes as an opponent of raising taxes on carried interest, which makes up the bulk of income of private equity managers.

headline: Weinsteins Raise $285 Million for Asian Films
text: The Weinstein Company/strong> has taken the wraps off a $285 million fund to fully finance the development, production, acquisition, marketing and distribution of a large slate of Asian-themed films over the next six years.

headline: Saint-Gobain Cements Deal for Maxit Mortars
text: Cie. de Saint-Gobain, Europe’s biggest supplier of building materials, agreed to buy the Maxit unit of HeidelbergCement for 2.13 billion euros ($2.94 billion) to double its production of industrial mortars.

headline: India’s Wipro to Buy U.S. Outsourcing Firm
text: Wipro is acquiring a United States outsourcing company, Infocrossing, in a deal valued at $600 million, the latest in a slew of overseas buys by Indian companies.

headline: 2nd-Quarter Proves Heady for V.C. Funding
text: Venture capital investment has reached its highest level since 2001, according to a report scheduled to be released Tuesday.

headline: Bear’s Cayman Move May Tempt Other Funds to Follow
text: Bear Stearns, in an effort to protect itself from shareholder lawsuits related to the collapse of two of its hedge funds, may establish a precedent for other failed hedge funds.

headline: London Theater Journal: A 21-Day Marathon Nears Its End With a Subdued Execution
text: LONDON, Aug. 7 – I attended a public hanging last night. It was, as you might imagine, a grim spectacle: the hooding of the head of the man to be executed; the sudden drop from the scaffold; the unbearable spastic twitching succeeded by the unbearable silence.

headline: Archstone Says Deal May Be Delayed
text: The giant apartment landlord Archstone-Smith said Monday that the closing date of its purchase by a group led by Tishman Speyer and Lehman Brothers could be pushed back to the fourth quarter.

headline: Amazon Invests in Music Download Site
text: Amazon.com has led a first-round venture investment in AmieStreet.com, an online music store with a social-networking twist. AmieStreet, which is less than a year old, sets the price for downloads according to a song’s popularity and allows users to rack up credits by recommending songs to their friends. The size of the funding round was not disclosed.

headline: Tyco Posts $3.55 Billion Loss
text: Aug. 7 (Bloomberg) -- Tyco International Ltd. (NYSE:TYC) , the world's biggest maker of fire and security systems, posted a third- quarter loss of $3.55 billion on costs to settle a shareholder lawsuit and split the company in three.

headline: Now, Even Nonhousing Credit Markets Run Dry
text: The day-to-day financial dealings of Oneida Limited, the dinnerware and flatware maker, are typically about as far removed from the mortgage loan business as they can be.

headline: Evercore Says Adjusted Earnings Doubled
text: Evercore Partners said Tuesday its adjusted pro forma net income nearly doubled from a year ago to $15.5 million in the second quarter. Advisory fees rose, as the investment bank picked up more revenue-generating clients and larger success fees, Evercore said.

headline: Morning Buzz: More Police Surveillance Files; Newark Reeling from Killings; an N.Y.U. Death; and More
text: A federal judge rejected New York City’s efforts to prevent the release of nearly 2,000 pages of raw intelligence reports and other documents detailing the Police Department’s covert surveillance of protest groups and individual activists before the Republican National Convention in 2004, Robert D. McFadden reports.The judge, Magistrate Judge James C. Francis IV, did agree to the deletion of sensitive information in the documents to protect the identities of undercover officers and confidential informants and to safeguard police investigative methods and the privacy of individuals caught up in investigations.

headline: Laws of Multiplication
text: According to NPR’s Weekend Edition, “the newest status symbol for the nation’s most affluent families is fast becoming a big brood of kids.”

headline: A Volatile Market Turns to Bernanke
text: Update, 4:13 PM Eastern The Fed statement that has been released is not going to please Jim Cramer. “The Fed sees the current situation less urgently than many on Wall Street do,” writes Jeremy Peters of The Times.

headline: 2008: An Early Labor Day
text: Chicago is getting a second dose of Democratic politics today as the presidential candidates return to the city to participate in an A.F.L.-C.I.O. debate at Solider Field just three days after they appeared at the YearlyKos convention. Tonight’s forum, which the Chicago Tribune previews, will be moderated by MSNBC’s Keith Olbermann and broadcast on the network starting at 7 p.m. Eastern.

headline: Murdoch’s Gem and Other Deal Aliases
text: Does Rupert Murdoch think of Dow Jones as a diamond in the rough?

headline: Is That a Mall Going Up on the Lower East Side?
text: With luxury apartment buildings rising on Orchard and Ludlow Streets, just below Houston Street, the prospect of a glittery, tacky shopping mall between them does not seem so remote. It is real enough that neighbors on the Lower East Side have been grumbling ever since a wall-sized poster for the Walbridge City Mall went up recently over an excavated lot on the block. Protest banners hang from nearby fire escapes. “Walbridge Go Home,” says one.

headline: Hebron Settlers Evicted
text: Pelted by rocks and metal, hundreds of Israeli riot police on Tuesday forcibly removed Jewish settlers from houses they had been occupying illegally for months in the West Bank city of Hebron.

headline: Keith Richards Flip-Flops on Key Issue
text: When Keith Richards’ memoir deal was announced, his publisher applauded “a man who has always stood up and spoken with candor about things that most people guard carefully.” A week later, the rock star reinforced the point with gusto.

headline: Hey, Jack Kerouac
text: We’ve officially entered what might as well be called Jack Kerouac Awareness Month.

headline: Tastes Great, Needs More Filling
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his Aug. 6 column, “The Substance Thing.”

headline: Buyout Loans: Who’s Holding the Bag?
text: Just a few weeks ago, selling the debt used to fund leveraged buyouts was a piece of cake. Now, it borders on the impossible. As a result, many of the investment banks that agreed to finance these deals are on the hook to make the loans themselves — at least until buyers and sellers can settle on a price and the debt can be resold.

headline: Confused About Carbon?
text: “Walking does more than driving to cause global warming, a leading environmentalist has calculated,” according to The Times of London. The article, reporting the claims of Chris Goodall, the author of “How to Live a Low-Carbon Life,” continues:

headline: Six Ideas for Taking Teenage Tourists Off the Beaten Track in New York City
text: Any suggestions for a Teenagers’ NYC? I’ll spend a week in the city with my daughter, 15, and son, 13 in August. We’ve were here five years ago and they want to see again some of the landmarks plus shopping, naturally.

headline: When Jack Met Steve
text: Here’s today’s second Jack Kerouac post … having found this clip on YouTube, it’s impossible to resist.

headline: Julius Baer Is Said to Consider Asset Management I.P.O.
text: Is the asset management arm of Switzerland’s Julius Baer headed to market? According to Crain’s New York Business, officials at the bank are considering an initial public offering of the New York-based unit, after having rebuffed several suitors. The publication said Julius Baer is being advised by Goldman Sachs.

headline: eBay’s Credit Line Stirs Speculation
text: Since eBay acquired the Internet phone service Skype in 2005 — a $2.6 billion deal widely believed to have been way too expensive, at least judging from the results thus far — it has refrained from making billion-dollar acquisitions.

headline: Two Beefcake Calendars, One Unhappy Fire Department
text: Who knew that there were two beefcake calendars featuring shirtless members of the city’s Fire Department showing off their abs and pecs?

headline: Szetela Trading Soccer for Calcio?
text: Last week, Jack Bell reported on the possible move of Columbus Crew midfielder Danny Szetela to Europe.

headline: Simply Ballroom
text: Here’s a slice of N.F.L. life you don’t see often: a team having a walk-through in an opulent hotel ballroom.

headline: Goldman Denies Liquidating Global Alpha Fund
