text: Many a hedge fund has been shaken up in the recent market turmoil, perhaps most famously two Bear Stearns funds. But despite rumors to the contrary, one of Wall Street’s biggest investment banks says its flagship hedge fund will remain open.

headline: To Avoid M.T.A. Fare Increase, Greater Subsidies Are Urged
text: How do you balance the budget of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority without a fare and toll hike?

headline: In ‘Testing the Waters,’ a Beach in Brooklyn Gets Low Marks
text: With its oceanfront vistas and proximity to the attractions of Coney Island, students at Kingsborough Community College might be forgiven if they sometimes want to hit the beach instead of the books. The two-year college occupies a 70-acre campus on Manhattan Beach, on the southern tip of Brooklyn.

headline: Quick Bits: Dell Tries Zing, Steve Case Sells Lime, Palm Hears Silence
text: Dell bought Zing, a consumer electronics software company. Dell’s other consumer electronics ventures, like the Dell DJ MP3 player, have been flops. [GigaOm, Release]

headline: Ex-Amaranth Trader Says New Firm Is ‘On the Brink’
text: Brian Hunter, whose ill-fated energy trades helped to bring down Amaranth Advisors, has offered a dire warning about his latest hedge-fund venture. Citing scrutiny from regulators, he said in court filings that the firm, called Solengo Capital Advisors, could flame out before it even gets up and running.

headline: Fred Thompson’s Site Gets an Upgrade
text: It’s one more sign that former Senator Fred Thompson is dipping in more than just his toe as he “tests the waters” for a presidential bid. By the look of the slickly revamped Web site his committee rolled out today, we’d say he’s in — at least knee-deep.

headline: Could You Call It a Comeback?
text: Micheline Maynard, The Times’s Detroit bureau chief, reported today on the comeback of Robert L. Nardelli, who “seemed tarnished forever” after leaving Home Depot but has emerged at the top of Chrysler.

headline: The Dalai Lama and Understanding Wikipedia
text: After three days at the Wikimania gathering of Wikipedia contributors in Taipai, with dozens of panels and presentations and even more chats in the hallways, it’s clear to me that the Wikipedia phenomenon can only be understood through contradictions. Here are some of the puzzles that may lead to enlightenment:

headline: Realtors Jump Into Carried-Interest Debate
text: In what at first seems like an unlikely alliance, the National Association of Realtors has weighed in on the side of the private-equity industry in its fight against raising taxes on carried interest.

headline: The Event at Apple Is About Events (in More Ways Than One)
text: Sometimes you feel like Steve Jobs could hold a press conference on the beach and declare this morning’s tides the greatest movement of water in history. As regularly as the tides, Apple, like all technology companies, upgrades its products to take advantage of new and cheaper parts. And, like all fashion companies, it changes the look of its line to make its customers lust after the latest thing.

headline: Principal Is Cited for Occult ‘Cleansing’ Ritual
text: A principal at a high school in Lower Manhattan had heard the jokes about using a “sage,” or spiritual guru, to perform a “cleansing” of the building to counteract misbehaving students. The principal took the jokes seriously –- performing a Santeria ceremony during the school’s midwinter break in 2006, according to a report released today by the special commissioner of investigation for the New York City public schools.One day last winter, the principal, Martiza Tamayo, told an assistant principal, Melody Crooks-Simpson, that she had a friend who could do just that. Ms. Tamayo promised that the friend “could burn sage and incense in the school and it would calm the students down,” according to the report. (Santeria is an Afro-Caribbean syncretic religion, some of whose adherents believe in trances, animal sacrifice and sacred drumming and dance.)

headline: From the Self-Referential Dept.
text: Brad Stone pulled the wraps off of Fake Steve Jobs before Dan Lyons, a.k.a. Fake Steve, and Forbes, his employer, could pull the wraps off Fake Steve Jobs on their own. That got a lot of people in a lather, as you can see from the comments to the blog post about the article.

headline: The Browns Finally Sign Someone! (But Not a Player)
text: Yesterday, something that I’ve been following professionally — the online secondary ticketing market — collided with one of my private interests, my hometown football team, the Cleveland Browns. The Browns announced that they would allow fans to resell their tickets through Viagogo.com, a European rival to StubHub that will now officially enter the American market.

headline: Making Booker
text: The longlist for the 2007 Man Booker prize has been announced.

headline: Words of Protest: Challenging Music’s Lyrical Standards
text: To the shouts of “Hey, hey, ho, ho, dirty lyrics has got to go,” dozens of protesters marched amid the bustling crowd this afternoon in front of the Virgin Megastore in Times Square.The crowd came out in support of the Decency Initiative, a campaign by the Rev. Al Sharpton’s National Action Network to address lyrical standards in the music and entertainment industry. Mr. Sharpton was in Detroit, one of 20 cities where the initiative scheduled rallies for today.

headline: The Art and Science of Naming
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s Aug. 7 column, “Goodbye, George and John.”

headline: Frugal Traveler: The End of the Road
text: The Frugal Traveler has ended his 12-week American road trip. Share your suggestions, comments and questions for Matt on the end of his journey.

headline: A Governor and a Philosopher — but Not a Lawyer
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer appeared in Jamestown, N.Y., today and gave an interesting and rather high-minded speech on the tension between power, humility and social justice. Quoting liberally from the famed cold war theologian Reinhold Niebuhr, Mr. Spitzer drew links between the Bush administration’s handling of the Iraq war and his own efforts to clean up Albany — even alluding to recent occasions where those efforts went a little awry (this quotation comes from the prepared text):

headline: Man and Monkey Detained at La Guardia
text: Updated, 10:40 p.m.

headline: Ignorance Is Not An Excuse
text: The closely watched criminal trial of Gregory Reyes, the former chief executive of Brocade Communications ended in a conviction today. He was accused of backdating option grants.

headline: Kristol’s Kind Words for Clinton
text: Hillary Clinton, Neocon? The blogosphere is atwitter today with the quote in the Washington Post from Bill Kristol, the editor of the Weekly Standard, that “Hillary Clinton is becoming the responsible Democrat who could become commander in chief in a post-9/11 world.”

headline: Mortgage Insurer Says It May Call Off Merger
text: The subprime mortgage market gave rise to trouble of a different sort on Tuesday, as MGIC Investment said that it believes it is not obligated to close its deal with the Radian Group. The nation’s largest mortgage insurer said in February that it would acquire its rival for $4.9 billion.

headline: Blogtalk: Jury Duty’s Over; a Yellow Porsche; Sushi on the Subway; and More
text: What we’re reading on the local blogs…

headline: Lawmakers Confront Con Edison Over Steam-Pipe Blast
text: “I’m Sicilian, and we have a saying: ‘When a fish rots, it rots from the head.’”

headline: X Prize on 100 M.P.G.
text: Regarding our recent blog post on the Automotive X Prize, Gary (#63) wrote: “Although I am interested in all of the technology that may come out of this, I think the mile per gallon equivalents should be raised to 150.”

headline: Why Blog?
text: Steve Levitt on the value of dropping an occasional bomb.

headline: Capital One to Buy NetSpend for $700 Million
text: Capital One Financial, a credit card issuer and banking company, said on Tuesday it agreed to buy NetSpend Holdings, a marketer of prepaid debit cards, for $700 million in cash. The transaction is not expected to have a material impact on Capital One’s earnings per share until 2009.

headline: The Putin Generation
text: A Kremlin-created youth group is engaging Russian teenagers with job opportunities and anti-American views.

headline: Ron Paul’s First Ad
text: With the Ames, Iowa straw poll just four days away, Representative Ron Paul is running his first television ad. The 30-second spot is running in the Cedar Rapids and Des Moines markets. Like Mr. Paul himself, the message is a mixture of traditional Republican pitches (the announcer says, “Ron Paul has never voted to increase taxes”) and those with a decidedly libertarian bent (text proclaims, “Stop the national I.D. card”).You can see the ad here.

headline: Labor Sets the Stage for a Democratic Forum
text: CHICAGO — Labor groups are ready to hand out 10,000 rain ponchos, but hope their members won’t have to use them tonight when the Democratic candidates and thousands of union members and leaders gather at Soldier Field.

headline: Jozy Altidore, Video Game Star
text: Jozy Altidore, the New York Red Bulls’ 17-year-old striker, has landed a coveted gig in the sports world: He will appear on the cover of EA Sports’ FIFA Soccer 08 sold in North America.

headline: U.S. Delays Decision on Grants for Congestion Pricing
text: Supporters of the mayor’s congestion pricing proposal will have to wait a few more days before getting a crucial federal go-ahead on the plan. The United States Department of Transportation, which had been slated to make an announcement on Wednesday about New York’s status in a federal competition for more than $500 million in funds, now says the decision will be delayed.“We won’t be making the announcement tomorrow,” said Brian Turmail, a spokesman for the department. “We don’t know when it’s going to happen.”

headline: The Writer’s Agony: Scented Candles
text: Weird. Jimmy Carter “teaches Sunday School” — hey, I thought that was called preaching — in a bolo tie:

headline: Intel’s Approach to Laptops for Poor Children
text: Intel insists that its project to make low-cost laptops for school children in poorer nations began nearly three years ago, before it heard of Nicholas Negroponte’s initiative, One Laptop Per Child.

headline: Are You Ready for Some (Political) Football?
text: CHICAGO — At this Democratic presidential debate, you might be able to see the candidates sweat.

headline: The Giants, Not Bonds, Celebrate
text: When Randy Winn smacked a run-scoring single to power the San Francisco Giants past the Washington Nationals, 3-2, in 11 innings on Monday night, almost every player and coach poured out of the Giants’ dugout to congratulate him.

headline: Mrs. Edwards: You Can’t Change John
text: When someone from the John Edwards presidential campaign says something that raises eyebrows, it’s usually the candidate’s wife, Elizabeth Edwards. Here’s her latest, via Edward Cone at CIO Insight:

headline: Live-Blogging the Democratic Forum
text: Wrap Up Even on a stage in the Chicago Bears stadium before an audience of union members, the Democratic candidates still vied for which one of them had the experience to be the world’s leader. We’ll try to keep the football metaphors to a minimum here, but whether one or the other was on offense or defense, we have to say that foreign policy issues – somewhat spurred by Senator Obama’s recent Pakistan speech – and of course, the war in Iraq and trade issues, produced a few of the hottest exchanges on the stage.

headline: The Putin Generation
text: A Kremlin-created youth group is engaging Russian teenagers with job opportunities and anti-American views.

headline: Definitely HIP
text: Love ’em or hate ’em-and it sure seems like most people hate ’em—Home Information Packs are now required in the U.K., at least for houses of four or more bedrooms. Eventually the unfortunately-named HIPs will be required for all homes under the new law, which mandates that sellers produce a packet of inspections and disclosures to hand prospective buyers.

headline: Burse Moves Ahead by Going to the Back
text: It is only fitting that Ray Burse Jr. was focused on education, taking a summer-school class on the history of Reconstruction and the Civil War, when he received a voice-mail message from F.C. Dallas Coach Steve Morrow telling him he should prepare for the first start of his professional soccer career.

headline: Remembering a Military Man
text: A year after the death of Brenton Gray, a private contractor in Iraq, friends and family gathered to remember him.

headline: Wait a Second…Is Bonds Starting on Tuesday Night?
text: When Ron Wotus, the bench coach for the San Francisco Giants, ripped the lineup card off a bulletin board on Tuesday night, a buzz circulated around the clubhouse. Was Barry Bonds being scratched from the lineup? To be honest, the buzz was mostly among the reporters who are in San Francisco to chronicle Bonds’s pursuit of history.

headline: Frugal Traveler: The Pacific Coast
text: The summer is ending and so is Matt's trip.  On his last and final week, he drives up the Pacific coast to Seattle, his final destination.

headline: Death Benefit Is Elusive for Emergency Workers’ Families
text: Michael D. Falkouski, a volunteer assistant fire chief in the Albany suburb of Rensselaer, was awakened at 2:30 a.m. on Jan. 23, 2005, in the middle of a blizzard. There had been an explosion and a bad fire; a man was severely burned.

headline: The Democrats and the Wiretap Law (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hey, Kids, Is Everybody Up for Some Guerrilla Warfare?
text: This slapdash sequel to “Daddy Day Care” finds its hero, Charlie Hinton (Cuba Gooding Jr., replacing the original film’s star, Eddie Murphy), taking over Camp Driftwood, the ramshackle day camp he attended as a boy. He hopes to expand his business; bond with his overprotected son, Ben (Spencir Bridges); and avenge an ancient humiliation by his childhood nemesis, Lance Warner (Lochlyn Munro), a rich swine who attended a rival day camp and now owns it.

headline: Manhattan: Principal Faces Dismissal After Religious Ritual
text: A principal at a Lower Manhattan high school who performed a Santeria religious ceremony at the school and coerced an assistant to help pay for it is likely to be fired, officials of the Department of Education said yesterday. The principal of Unity Center for Urban Technologies, Maritza Tamayo, paid a friend $1,800 to perform a ritual that involved sprinkling chicken blood on the floors to wipe out negative energy and as an antidote to students who misbehaved, according to a report released yesterday by the department’s special commissioner of investigation. During the school break in February 2006, Ms. Tamayo invited the friend to conduct the ceremony and urged an assistant principal to attend and pay $900, the report said.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Open Now

headline: Doll, You Oughta Be in Pictures
text: Morton Bartlett is already considered a great outsider artist by many. But his achievement gains new dimensions in a revealing show of his photographs, drawings and sculptures at the Julie Saul Gallery in Chelsea. Bartlett, who was born in 1909 and died in Boston in 1992, is known for making a group of about 15 ivory-skinned, anatomically complete plaster sculptures of young children and adolescents. Most are female, and he fashioned exquisite wardrobes for them. Then he took small, haunting black-and-white photographs of the figures, usually clothed but sometimes naked.

headline: Forget the States — Let the Regions Pick the Candidates
text: Miami

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article by The Associated Press on Thursday about flight recorder transcripts released after a fatal plane crash in São Paulo, Brazil, on July 17 reversed the identities of the pilot and the co-pilot, and their final comments. The pilot was Kleyber Lima, and he gave the first indication something was wrong when he said, “Only one reverser — spoiler nothing.” It was the co-pilot, Henrique Stephanini Di Sacco, who responded: “Look at that. Slow down. Slow down.” Then Mr. Lima responded: “I can’t. I can’t. Oh my God! Oh my God!” Then Mr. Di Sacco said: “Go! Go! Turn! Turn! Turn!”

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: LOTTERY NUMBERS

headline: German Fund Stops Payouts, Citing Mortgage Market Unease
text: WestLB Mellon Asset Management suspended redemptions of an asset-backed securities fund yesterday amid investor concern about the problems in the subprime mortgage market in the United States.

headline: Space Shuttle Set to Lift Off
text: The space shuttle Endeavour and its seven-astronaut crew are scheduled to lift off this evening and head to the International Space Station. The 10-minute launching window starts at 6:31 p.m. Forecasts give an 80 percent chance of favorable weather, with a small chance of showers the only concern. The Endeavour is carrying a truss segment to be added to the space station in the first of four spacewalks. The mission is scheduled to last 11 days, but will be extended to 14 days if a new system allowing the shuttle to draw electrical power from the station works as planned. NASA will broadcast the launching live at www.nasa.gov/multimedia/nasatv/.

headline: Signature Theater’s Hunt for New Home Continues
text: Having already lost a place it had been promised at ground zero, the Signature Theater Company now finds its downtown plans scuttled again: It will not relocate, as planned, to Fiterman Hall on West Broadway.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Saturday about “In the Shadow of Justice,” a documentary on “Dateline NBC” about the murder of a bouncer at a Manhattan nightclub, included incorrect information from the maker of the film, Dan Slepian, about its editing. While Mr. Slepian shot and assembled most of the film, it was edited by Rob Allen, not by Mr. Slepian.

headline: Notorious Absentee Shows Up, Grandly
text: Facing an overflow crowd of 15,000 at Wingate Park in Brooklyn on Monday night, Lauryn Hill said: “Let’s see how many people remember me. I know I haven’t been around for a while.”

headline: Goalie Puts Education First and Career Second
text: It is only fitting that Ray Burse Jr. was focused on education, taking a summer-school class on the history of Reconstruction and the Civil War, when he received a voice-mail message from F.C. Dallas Coach Steve Morrow telling him he should prepare for the first start of his professional soccer career.

headline: Aura of Tranquillity Engulfs Yankees’ New Reliever
text: TORONTO, Aug. 7 — Jeff Karstens spotted the fresh new face in the Yankees’ clubhouse on Tuesday and knew what it meant for him. “I don’t have to carry the candy bag anymore,” Karstens said, smiling.

headline: Rodriguez Is Hit, but Clemens Delivers Final Blow
text: TORONTO, Aug. 7  Retaliating for a teammate is part of the persona of Roger Clemens, the consummate gunslinger in double-knits. But he does not seem to relish the task, and he put it off on Tuesday until the seventh inning, with his 90th pitch.

headline: Riding Through the Veins of History on a Triumphal Wave of Sound
text: There are bands that shuffle humbly onto the stage of Madison Square Garden, happy to be there and nervous about filling the room with sound. (And with fans.) Then there is Muse.

headline: New Material at Wreck Site of Pirate Ship
text: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Aug. 7 — As pirate treasure goes, it does not look like much.

headline: Army Says Soldier’s Articles for Magazine Were False
text: An Army investigation into the Baghdad Diarist, a soldier in Iraq who wrote anonymous columns for The New Republic, has concluded that the sometimes shockingly cruel reports were false.

headline: A Softer Spanish Accent
text: SHOULD you need a fresh example of how oddly and cruelly fate can operate, consider Seamus Mullen’s past year.

headline: Deported in Error, Missing and Months Later Home
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7  An American missing in Mexico for nearly three months after being wrongfully deported has been found and reunited with his family here.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,668 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Dyspepsia of the Soul While Training for Utopia
text: The idea that human beings are perfectible is probably as old as the human race. But where are all those primitive feelings of anger, lust and revenge supposed to go? And do gods, gurus and self-control really work? In his satiric parable “Dysphoria,” part of the Ontological-Hysteric Incubator series for emerging artists, Alec Duffy paints a picture on the wall of humanity’s cave, and it isn’t pretty.

headline: All the Vulgar Charm, in a Smaller Box
text: TOLSTOY had it wrong about happy families, because there are none like the Shopsins.

headline: Manhattan: Mayor Completes Jury Duty
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg joined the city’s jury pool for a second day yesterday, but he was back to work at City Hall by early afternoon. The mayor was considered for a civil case involving a taxicab accident, but lawyers ultimately dismissed him. “I don’t take it personally,” Mr. Bloomberg said later. “I don’t take any pride in not being picked, or dissatisfaction either way.” Mr. Bloomberg, who spent his morning reading newspapers, postponed a jury duty call last summer because of the Queens blackout, a spokesman said.

headline: For Champagne, Hors D’oeuvres From the Sea
text: UPON arriving in Paris a couple of months ago, I headed for Rech, a 1930s fish restaurant that Alain Ducasse has taken over. I ordered Champagne. Then the waiter offered a plate bearing a small jar of gray stuff topped with glittering red beads of tobiko (flying fish roe) and slices of toasted baguette. I set to work on this somewhat loosely textured spread made of mackerel, and thought it was an excellent accompaniment for my flute of blanc de blancs.

headline: Marion Barry to Be in Wax Museum
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 — A decade and a half after a videotaped cocaine arrest that would have ended most political careers, former Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has won yet another election.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE KNIGHTS OF PROSPERITY An unlikely gang that steals from celebrities has a new target: Ray Romano’s house. The group also stages the kidnapping of Louis, one of its members, hoping his wealthy father will pay the ransom. At 9:30, in a special episode, the plot against Mr. Romano, above, continues, but the gang realizes that it has overlooked a crucial detail.

headline: Pérez Digs Early Hole, and Braves Pile It Up
text: When Oliver Pérez is pitching, it is easy to tell if the Mets are winning or losing without peeking at the scoreboard. Just look at the way he leaves the field after recording a third out. If the Mets are winning, Pérez will race toward the first-base line and vault over it with the aplomb of an Olympic decathlete. If they are losing, Pérez takes an entirely different approach.

headline: Steelers’ Tomlin Expects to Last and Win
text: When Mike Tomlin attended the College of William and Mary, he worked at a place near campus called Paul’s Deli Restaurant. The owner, Peter Tsipas, had no idea that Tomlin would eventually become an N.F.L. head coach, but he recognized early that Tomlin was hungry. Not just hungry to succeed, but hungry  period.

headline: U.S. Readies Tough Rules on Employers of Immigrants
text: In a new effort to crack down on illegal immigrants, federal authorities are expected to announce tough rules this week that would require employers to fire workers who use false Social Security numbers.

headline: Reader Responses
text: Here are excerpts from reader responses to David Leonhardt’s Aug. 8 column on preventive medicine:

headline: Selig Takes Leave of Bonds Watch
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 — Commissioner Bud Selig was not at AT&T Park on Tuesday night to witness Barry Bonds’s attempt to hit his record-breaking 756th home run. He was also not expected to be there for Wednesday night’s or Thursday afternoon’s games.

headline: Quarterly Loss Widens at Trump Entertainment, but Shares Surge 27%
text: In March, when shares in Trump Entertainment Resorts were trading around $20, the company disclosed that it was seeking potential suitors for a takeover. At that point, Donald J. Trump even envisioned pocketing $500 million from selling at a handsome premium his one-third stake in this company bearing his name.

headline: Summer Reading Programs Gain Momentum for Students About to Enter College
text: For students starting college, August is the time to quit the summer job, dump the high school sweetheart and, finally, open the book their college has asked them to finish before classes start.

headline: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Lets Individual Unions Decide Endorsements
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 8—The A.F.L.-C.I.O.’s executive council voted today against endorsing any presidential candidate, reflecting divisions over which Democrat to support and setting the stage for its 55 member unions to make individual endorsements.

headline: A Two-Character Play Starring Both Members of the Audience
text: EDINBURGH, Aug. 7 — Producers must have fantasized about it. Couldn’t we just eliminate the actors?

headline: 4 Parking Agents Accused of Writing Fake Tickets
text: Over a three-day period in June, four New York traffic agents gave the impression they were busy by issuing a multitude of tickets. But as it turns out, they issued dozens of those tickets from the comfort of their cars or while enjoying a meal, according to police officials.

headline: The Latin Mass (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Court Papers Said to Show Added Payments by Reporter
text: A former New York Times reporter who wrote an article in late 2005 about a teenager who operated a pornographic Web site may have sent more money to the young man than he had previously acknowledged, according to people familiar with sealed documents filed with a court in Tennessee.

headline: Georgia Accuses Russia of Missile Attack; Moscow Denies It
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 7  Officials of the Republic of Georgia accused Russia on Tuesday of violating the country’s airspace and firing a guided missile, which did not detonate, into Georgian territory.

headline: What You Get for ... $100,000
text: Boulder, Colo.

headline: Queens: Passenger Sneaks Monkey Aboard Plane
text: A man and his small spider monkey were detained yesterday after a flight crew alerted airport officials that they had a monkey aboard their aircraft en route to La Guardia Airport. The man boarded a Spirit Airlines flight on Monday night from Lima, Peru, to New York by way of South Florida, but did not report that he had a monkey with him, an airline spokeswoman said. It was only on the second leg of the flight, from Fort Lauderdale, that other passengers noticed the monkey. “It was clinging to his ponytail underneath his hat,” said Alison Russell, the airline’s spokeswoman. When the plane landed at 3:01 p.m. yesterday, the monkey was turned over to New York City Animal Care and Control, and the man, who was not named by airport officials, was turned over to federal officers for questioning, said Pasquale DiFulco, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which runs La Guardia Airport. “How the passenger got through security, I can’t begin to say,” Ms. Russell said.

headline: Tintin Prompts a Suit
text: A Congolese student has initiated legal action in Belgium to have the 1931 comic book “Tintin in the Congo” declared racist and removed from bookstores, Reuters reported. “It’s racist, and it is filled with colonial-era propaganda,” said the student, Mbutu Mondondo Bienvenu, who lives in Brussels. He is also seeking symbolic damages of one euro ($1.38) from Moulinsart, a company that owns the rights to Tintin but does not publish the comic. Belgian prosecutors said a judge’s decision on proceeding with Mr. Bienvenu’s motion could take six months. A spokesman for Moulinsart said: “The book dates back to 1931 and has to be seen in the context of the time. We are surprised to see this complaint after so many years.” Some stores in Britain and the United States have moved the book from their children’s shelves to the space for adult graphic novels. This year is the 100th anniversary of the birth of Georges Remi, the writer and artist who created the popular series under the name Hergé.

headline: Starbucks’s New Book
text: Starbucks has announced its latest book selection: “Listening Is an Act of Love: A Celebration of American Life From the StoryCorps Project.” Published by the Penguin Press and edited by the Peabody Award-winning radio documentary producer and StoryCorps founder Dave Isay, it comprises 50 stories reflecting everyday American lives that were drawn from more than 10,000 recordings from the StoryCorps oral history project. The book and a CD set will go on sale on Nov. 8.

headline: Lunch Recipe: Take One 7-Year-Old ...
text: THERE are plenty of ways to flatten a pan bagnat, the traditional tuna and vegetable sandwich from Nice. You could weight it with heavy books, or with a nice fat brick. You could squeeze it under a cast-iron skillet piled with cans, or press it beneath a stack of plates. Or you could find a child of about 7 and simply have her sit on it.

headline: Russia’s Castaway Intellectuals in Revolution’s Wake
text: In 1922, five years after the Bolshevik revolution, no one knew where Russia was headed. In an about-face, Lenin had initiated the quasi-capitalist New Economic Policy. For the moment, a nervous sort of freedom persisted, notably in the arts but, to a limited degree, in politics as well. Anyone looking for a portent, however, might have noticed a ship leaving Petrograd that September, carrying into permanent exile a carefully selected group of writers, intellectuals and scholars whose ideas the Bolshevik regime found objectionable. The Philosophy Steamer, as it came to be known, was followed six weeks later by a second ship. The machinery of totalitarianism was kicking into gear.

headline: A Moment of Stray Voltage, and a Life Upended
text: It was one of the muggiest days of the summer a decade ago. Philip Vanaria had gone for a walk in Greenwich Village, where he had lived most of his adult life. A friend wanted ideas for his birthday, which was coming up. At the corner of Hudson and Morton Streets, he called her from a pay phone.

headline: Bill Aims to Spur Housing for New York’s Poor
text: New York City officials and state legislators have reached an agreement to overhaul a popular tax break for apartment building developers. The aim of the revision is to encourage the construction of tens of thousands of apartments for New Yorkers of limited means.

headline: Injured Beltrán Hopes to Return This Week
text: Carlos Beltrán hit, ran and played catch yesterday for the first time since straining his left oblique muscle July 25. He said he was feeling better, but was not yet well enough to play in a game.

headline: Tale of Ruling Class Privilege Touches a Nerve in Italians
text: ROME, Aug. 7 — In the opening chapter of “The Caste: How Italian Politicians Became Untouchable,” readers learn that Italy has a unique sense of altitude.

headline: Salzburg Festival Loses a Soprano
text: The Russian-born soprano Anna Netrebko, below, has become the latest in an extended list of talent to withdraw from the Salzburg Festival. Ms. Netrebko, who was to have performed a stabat mater by Pergolesi this week at the event in Austria, said she was suffering from laryngitis, Agence France-Presse reported. Jürgen Flimm, artistic director of the festival, said, “We are very disappointed with Anna Netrebko, that she lets us down.” Among those who have pulled out of the festival for various reasons this summer are the soprano Patricia Petibon, the tenor Neil Shicoff and the tenor Rolando Villazón, PlaybillArts.com reported.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A music review on Monday about a Beethoven program at the Mostly Mozart Festival misidentified the key of the Mass in which movements were played. It was C major, not C minor.

headline: Moody’s to Reorganize Into 2 Units
text: Moody’s said yesterday that it would reorganize into two divisions, separating its credit ratings unit from sales, marketing and analytics to underscore the independence of its opinions on debt securities.

headline: Text of Statement by Fed Committee
text: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed’s monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to leave interest rates unchanged.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A brief article in Science Times yesterday about the possibility that a person’s reading level might protect against neurological damage from lead exposure misspelled the given name of an author of the study. She is Dr. Margit L. Bleecker, not Margrit.

headline: In Case of Apocalypse Later, a Plan to Ensure America’s Regreening
text: The botanists forged through a thicket and crossed a rocky ravine bed. Their quarry, Polygonatum pubescens, was proving elusive. But they would not rest. They had promised a shipment of its seed to their partners in a bunker across the ocean.

headline: Fed Leaves Rate Steady; No Sign of Future Cut
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7  The Federal Reserve kept its key interest rate unchanged on Tuesday and signaled that it still expected to avoid cutting short-term rates despite the recent tumult in credit markets and on Wall Street. The Fed suggested that it would change course only if economic conditions deteriorate badly in the weeks and months ahead.

headline: Iran: Another Reformist Paper Closed
text: The authorities shut down Shargh, a leading reformist newspaper, after it published an interview with an Iranian poet who lives in exile and writes about female sexuality, Saghi Ghahraman. It was the third time the paper has been ordered closed, and it was unclear when it might be allowed to resume publishing. The closing was another sign of the increasing pressures on press freedom. In May, the authorities shut down the reformist newspaper Hammihan, and last week, a journalist and blogger, Soheil Assefi, was arrested.

headline: A Less-Expensive Way to Own in Paris
text: Ever since she and her late husband spent their honeymoon in Paris more than 20 years ago, Dr. Iris Litt-Vaughan had dreamed of owning an apartment there.

headline: War on Terror Takes Focus at Democrats’ Debate
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 7 — The Democratic presidential candidates tangled over foreign policy Tuesday night, criticizing Senator Barack Obama for proposing an attack against Al Qaeda in Pakistan. He struck back at his rivals who had supported the Iraq war, saying they had “engineered the biggest foreign policy disaster of our time.”

headline: Potential Flaw Is Found in Design of Fallen Bridge
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 8 — Investigators have found what may be a design flaw in the bridge that collapsed here a week ago, in the steel parts that connect girders, raising safety concerns for other bridges around the country, federal officials said today.

headline: Some Words About Interpreting
text: Correction Appended

headline: For a Young Wallace, Success Is Slow to Come
text: Steve Wallace’s stock-car driving career was supposed to take off this year. Wallace, the 19-year-old son of the 1989 Winston Cup champion Rusty Wallace, had won in almost any kind of car he raced. He was a prodigy with a pedigree.

headline: Pete Doherty Warned
text: A disheveled Pete Doherty, below, was warned yesterday that he faces jail unless he proves his determination to quit drugs within a month, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Doherty, 28, the lead singer of Babyshambles, appeared in West London Magistrates’ Court, where Judge Davinder Lachlar said: “If he does not show his motivation, it’s prison, as simple as that. Depending on what information I have when you next come to court, the decision will be made.” Mr. Doherty has admitted possessing crack cocaine, heroin, marijuana and ketamine, as well as two driving offenses. Judges previously ordered him to take part in a detoxification program, but a review yesterday of his progress found he had since tested positive for drugs. A hearing was scheduled for Sept. 4.

headline: Chris Schwarz, 59, Dies; Photographer Who Honored Polish Jews
text: Chris Schwarz, a freelance photographer who roamed the ancient heartland of Polish Jewry to record remnants of a disappeared people, then opened a museum to celebrate their cultural heritage, died July 29 at his home in Krakow, Poland. He was 59.

headline: Corrections
text: A front-page article on July 29 about the uneven quality of medical care for cancer gave an incomplete list of cancers that can be prevented or cured with surgery alone. Skin, cervical and colorectal cancer can be prevented if precancerous lesions are detected and removed. Melanoma and other skin cancers, along with cancers of the prostate, breast, colon, rectum and cervix, can sometimes be cured with surgery if diagnosed early and removed. Colorectal and cervical cancers are not the only ones preventable or curable by surgery alone.

headline: Bonds Hits No. 756 to Break Aaron’s Record
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 — Barry Bonds swung and then immediately threw his arms in the air, realizing that he had become the most prolific home run hitter in major league history. Everyone in the ball park instantly realized the importance of what they had witnessed as well, watching Bonds’s latest and most important white streak soar into the night.

headline: 2 Lenders Voice Confidence as 2 Others Curb Operations
text: The Countrywide Financial Corporation and the CIT Group said they would be able to ride out the mortgage industry’s credit squeeze as two more rivals, the HomeBanc Corporation and Impac Mortgage Holdings, curtailed new loans.

headline: Blast Cause Won’t Be Known for 2 Months, Con Ed Says
text: Consolidated Edison said yesterday that it would be at least two more months before the company knew what caused a steam pipe to explode three weeks ago in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: The End of the Road
text: "NOTHING but sagebrush for 130 miles,” said the construction worker in the orange vest who was temporarily blocking U.S. Highway 20 in southeastern Oregon. As the Volvo idled in the midday heat, I looked past her at the landscape — at the dry, slowly rising hills matted with blue-green-purple tufts of hip-high scrub — then down at my map, and was impressed with her precision: For almost exactly 130 miles to the east, south and west, there was indeed nothing but sagebrush. This really was the desert. I shut off the engine and crossed my fingers, hoping the car and I would survive.

headline: U.S. Says Iran-Supplied Bomb Kills More Troops
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 7 — Attacks on American-led forces using a lethal type of roadside bomb said to be supplied by Iran reached a new high in July, according to the American military.

headline: Accusations of Impeding Murder Case
text: A woman was charged yesterday with interfering in the murder case against her brother and two other men, who have been accused in the shooting of two police officers during a traffic stop in Brooklyn last month.

headline: The Almighty Ruble
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 6 — The ruble got no respect.

headline: Free Lunch on Health? Think Again
text: The great hope of every health care reformer is that better care will mean cheaper care.

headline: Georgia Offers Evidence That Russia Fired Missile
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 8 — The Republic of Georgia presented what it called a mounting body of evidence today that a Russian warplane had entered deep into its airspace and fired an air-to-ground missile. It said it was seeking a special session of the United Nations Security Council to address the incident.

headline: Before the Big Night: Beethoven, Sweat, Tears
text: Sex, drugs and chamber music! Slapped on a bumper or emblazoned across a T-shirt, that phrase wouldn’t have the incendiary ring of the celebrated original, would it? Nevertheless, those are three key elements in “Opus,” an absorbing new play by Michael Hollinger that opened last night at the 59E59 Theaters as part of the Primary Stages season.

headline: Why Terrorists Aren’t Soldiers
text: THE line between soldier and civilian has long been central to the law of war. Today that line is being blurred in the struggle against transnational terrorists. Since 9/11 the Bush administration has sought to categorize members of Al Qaeda and other jihadists as “unlawful combatants” rather than treat them as criminals.

headline: Police Fight to Remove West Bank Settlers
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 7 — Pelted by rocks and chunks of metal, hundreds of Israeli riot police officers on Tuesday forcibly removed Jewish settlers from houses they had been occupying illegally for months in the West Bank city of Hebron.

headline: NBC to Air Games on Internet
text: NBC Universal Sports will stream 2,200 hours of live Summer Games coverage free from Beijing next year on its Web site, nbcolympics.com. It is the first time that NBC, or any network, has carried the Olympics on the Internet. . The broadband coverage will augment another 1,400 on NBC, USA, MSNBC, CNBC and Telemundo.

headline: Don’t Knock Bergman Off His Pedestal (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Spy Chief’s Political Education
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 — Last Thursday evening, during the frantic endgame of a White House push to broaden its eavesdropping authorities, Democratic leaders from the House and the Senate gathered in the Capitol office of Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, for a conference call with Mike McConnell, the nation’s top intelligence official.

headline: Cooking Up More Uses for the Leftovers of Biofuel Production
text: The baking tins and muffin cups lining the countertops in a corner of Ronald Holser’s cluttered laboratory were filled with curious substances resembling angel food cakes and loaves of bread.

headline: Judge Dismisses Law on Violent Video Games
text: A federal court has struck down as unconstitutional a California law to label violent video games and prohibit their sale to minors, Reuters reported. The decision, by Judge Ronald Whyte of the District Court for the Northern District of California, said, “At this point, there has been no showing that violent video games as defined in the Act, in the absence of other violent media, cause injury to children.” He continued, “In addition, the evidence does not establish that video games, because of their interactive nature or otherwise, are any more harmful than violent television, movies, Internet sites or other speech-related exposures.” The Video Software Dealers Association and the Entertainment Software Association had argued that their games were protected under the free-speech clause of the First Amendment. The law was passed in 2005 with strong backing from Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, after many legislators argued that violent video games could cause psychological harm and incite aggressive behavior in minors. The governor said he would appeal Judge Whyte’s decision.

headline: Announcers Offer Balance After 756th
text: The Barry Bonds ESPN Road Show finally ended last night. It was a peculiar and enervating march toward the finale, freighted not only with accusations of steroid use, but also the irregularity with which he was still hitting home runs. This was not the Mark McGwire-Sammy Sosa Dinger Derby of 1998, when Fox and ESPN stumbled over each other to carry the games they were playing so as not to miss a crucial homer.

headline: For an Iraq Contractor, Duty, and Then Death
text: SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., Aug. 5 — Brenton Thomas Gray was no longer a soldier when he died a soldier’s death last August on a northern Baghdad road. There were an armored car, a curbside bomb, a sizzling explosion. The sky went black with smoke and melting tar.

headline: Correction
text: A front-page article on July 29 about the uneven quality of medical care for cancer gave an incomplete list of cancers that can be prevented or cured with surgery alone. Skin, cervical and colorectal cancer can be prevented if precancerous lesions are detected and removed. Melanoma and other skin cancers, along with cancers of the prostate, breast, colon, rectum and cervix, can sometimes be cured with surgery if diagnosed early and removed. Colorectal and cervical cancers are not the only ones preventable or curable by surgery alone.

headline: Russia: Prison for Activist’s Killers
text: A St. Petersburg court sentenced four young men to prison terms of up to 12 years for their roles in a stabbing attack in the city in 2005 that killed Timur Kacharava, left, a 20-year-old student who belonged to an antifascist group that campaigned against hate crimes. Three young men received suspended sentences. The harsh sentences are a victory for prosecutors and rights groups who complain that Russian courts have underplayed the extent of neo-fascist violence in the country by handing down light punishments for hate crimes.

headline: In Bridge Collapse, Refugee Group Faces a New Ordeal
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 7  Among the hardest hit in the bridge collapse last week was a group that had survived war and strife in their homeland, Somalia, and a move across the world to settle here.

headline: Russia: Top Court Upholds Ban on Party
text: The Supreme Court upheld the Moscow City Court’s ban of the National Bolshevik Party as an extremist organization. The small fringe party has gained notoriety for its vocal and theatrical antigovernment demonstrations. The group’s leader, the writer Eduard Limonov, said in a telephone interview that he did not expect the latest ruling to affect its activities, including participation in the Other Russia coalition, a loose movement of anti-Kremlin forces that includes the former chess champion Garry Kasparov. “They will not shut us up,” Mr. Limonov said. “We have no fear.” He said the party would appeal the ruling to the European Court of Human Rights.

headline: Rhodes Is Lights, Camera, All Action
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 7  For Jets safety Kerry Rhodes, reporting to training camp means turning a page. It means leaving behind his off-season pursuits  parts in two movies, a magazine cover shoot, raising money for children’s scholarships in Alabama  and immersing himself in football again.

headline: 4 Americans Killed in Bombings in the Baghdad Area
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 7 — Roadside bombs killed four American soldiers in and around the capital, the United States military said Tuesday, and a proposal for an expanded United Nations role in Iraq moved closer to a vote.

headline: Two Little-Known Pitchers Have Kept Bonds in Check
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 — Two ballplayers stand atop the career list, one beefy and one slender, one active and one retired, one left-handed and one right.

headline: Progress Reported in Drilling for Miners
text: Rescue teams have drilled about one-third of the way down the 1,500-foot distance to where six coal miners have been trapped underground since early Monday, a mine official said today.

headline: Suspects Face Jeers and Victims’ Family in New Haven
text: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 7 — With roughly a dozen members of the Petit family sitting grimly in the front two rows, the two parolees accused of murdering three of their relatives during a brutal home invasion last month in Cheshire appeared in court on Tuesday under intense security.

headline: Leaders of 2 Koreas Will Meet in the North
text: TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 8 — The two Koreas announced Wednesday morning that they would hold a summit meeting later this month, the first since a groundbreaking meeting in 2000 began an ongoing reconciliation process on the Korean peninsula.

headline: Wells Still in the Rotation for Padres
text: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (AP)  The latest poor start for David Wells will not cost him a spot in the rotation with the San Diego Padres.

headline: Court Rejects the Right to Use Drugs Being Tested
text: A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that patients with terminal illnesses do not have a constitutional right to use medicines that have not yet won regulatory approval.

headline: Guidelines for Truckers (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Ice Cold War
text: Aboard Training Vessel Arctic Tern, off Newport, R.I.

headline: 32 Killed in U.S. Raid in Iraq Shiite Stronghold
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 8 — An American raid and airstrike killed 32 people in the Shiite stronghold of Sadr City today, in what American military officials described as the latest assault on a network linking Iraqi militants with money and deadly roadside bombs from Iran.

headline: Secrets of the Police
text: The city of New York is waging a losing and ill-conceived battle for overzealous secrecy surrounding nearly 2,000 arrests during the 2004 Republican National Convention. Yesterday, for the second time in three months, a federal judge ordered the release of hundreds of pages of documents that detail the Police Department’s covert surveillance leading to the convention. People who were detained, some for days and without explanation, may finally begin to get some answers.

headline: Burn Victim’s One Thought After Blast: ‘Make It Stop’
text: The seriousness of what had just happened did not register with Judith Bailey until she looked into a mirror. Layers of skin were peeling off her body. “My skin was gone,” she recalled yesterday in an interview from her hospital bed.

headline: When Cooks’ Dreams Outgrow Their Ovens
text: DEBBIE BONNER’S carrot cake, with its moist, macadamia-spiked layers, pineapple tang and aroma of candied ginger, could have come straight from her family’s kitchen in North Carolina.

headline: Jones Apparel Gets New Bid for Barneys
text: The fierce bidding war over Barneys New York, the luxury clothing retailer, escalated today when a private equity firm from Dubai raised its offer to $942 million — $117 million more than it had originally bid for the chain.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Cheering Section article in sports on July 29, about the excitement among N.B.A. newcomers over posing for rookie trading-card photographs, referred incorrectly to Brandan Wright of the Golden State Warriors. He was chosen No. 8 in the draft by the Charlotte Bobcats and then traded to the Warriors; he was not drafted by the Warriors.

headline: Founders of the Gap Now Plan a Museum
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 — Even in this city’s constellation of old-money heirs and dot-com multimillionaires, Donald and Doris Fisher hold a special place, having built a jeans and T-shirt shop into a global brand name known as the Gap.

headline: Executive Once Seen as Candidate to Be Next Chief Steps Down at Fidelity
text: Ellyn McColgan, a Fidelity executive who had been considered an heir apparent to the chairman and chief executive, Edward C. Johnson III, resigned unexpectedly yesterday.

headline: Investors Lining Up for Pieces of Seattle’s Comeback
text: The Seattle office market has made a spectacular recovery in the last few years. As a result many real estate investors want to park their money there. No one knows that better than Alfred Clise.

headline: City Has Short List for Cutoff of Water
text: After spending much of the last year trying to fix its outdated and unreliable water billing system, New York City is finally getting tough on delinquent ratepayers  but only on 11 of them.

headline: Manhattan: Airlines Seek Agents’ Testimony
text: A group of airlines and public transportation agencies sued the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. yesterday, seeking permission to interview five special agents and two intelligence officers who may have knowledge helpful in their defense of wrongful death lawsuits arising from the Sept. 11 terror attacks. The lawsuit was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan by American, United, Continental, US Airways and Delta Air Lines, and the public agencies that run the airports in Boston and Washington, after the bureau and the agency refused to grant access. Richard Kolko, an F.B.I. spokesman, declined to discuss the suit. The C.I.A. press office did not return phone calls seeking comment yesterday.

headline: A Kitchen Blitz, When 10 Minutes Seems Like an Eternity
text: This list was inspired by a recent Minimalist column on recipes that can be made in 10 minutes or less. But these recipes can be ready even faster, in 60 seconds or less. A skilled cook with imagination and a sense of adventure may feel free to improvise.

headline: Shaky Results in Core Areas Deflate High Hopes for Boston Scientific
text: FOR some time now, Wall Street optimists were saying things about Boston Scientific like “at these prices, there is not much downside risk.” Alas, in the last month, the continuing decline in Boston’s shares has made them look bad.

headline: Knicks’ Morris Is Charged With Driving Recklessly
text: Knicks forward Randolph Morris was arrested and charged with reckless driving early yesterday morning in Lexington, Ky.

headline: Giving Bottles a Second Life
text: Not long ago, we argued in this space that because America has some of the best tap water available, it is time to start thinking twice about drinking commercially bottled water. One big reason is that a lot of petroleum is required to manufacture and transport the plastic bottles, thus adding to global warming and other environmental problems. Of course, in certain circumstances bottled water is necessary. It is essential during emergencies  think Katrina  and it is certainly a better alternative when the only other drinks come loaded with calories.

headline: Ex-Brocade Chief Convicted in Backdating Case
text: Federal prosecutors scored a guilty verdict yesterday in the first options backdating case to go to trial, securing a conviction that is expected to embolden them to pursue similar cases.

headline: Mr. Gorbachev, Show Off This Bag
text: ABOUT a decade ago, Mikhail Gorbachev starred in a television ad for Pizza Hut, which praised America for delivering the benefits of capitalism to his country. Now he is trading in fast food for fine leather, appearing in an international print ad campaign for Louis Vuitton.

headline: First a Hook, Then Ink: An Artist’s Catch
text: MONTAUK, N.Y.

headline: All the Way to Timbuktu
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Some Quietly Intense Chills, Imported From Brazil
text: There is a deliriously inventive strain of popular music from the Brazilian state of Minas Gerais, best known from Milton Nascimento’s hot streak of records in the first half of the 1970s. They are ambitiously cooperative, full-throated singing albums; they are also guitar-heavy and harmony-rich. Some prominently included a guitarist in his early 20s named Toninho Horta.

headline: Nascar Driver Punished for Actions in Montreal
text: Nascar fined the driver Robby Gordon $35,000 yesterday for his vigilante-style antics at a Busch Series race Saturday in Montreal, and instead of suspending him, it placed him on probation for the rest of the year.

headline: Raise a Glass for the Taste, Not the Toast
text: LET’S begin with a couple of questions. Forgive me if I offer some answers as well.

headline: Newark: Corrections Officer Fatally Shoots Gunman
text: A New Jersey corrections officer fatally shot a man last night on a street after the man pulled a gun on him, the Newark police said. The corrections officer, whose name was not released, was shot in the foot during the confrontation and was in stable condition at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey Hospital. The officer was sitting on a porch on Grand Avenue about 9:30 p.m. when he was approached by the man, whom the police did not identify. The man then brandished a gun, the police said, and the officer fired. The state attorney general’s office is investigating, the police said.

headline: Cute Kitty Is Pink Badge of Shame in Bangkok
text: BANGKOK, Aug. 7 — It is the pink armband of shame for wayward police officers, as cute as it can be, with a Hello Kitty face and a pair of linked hearts.

headline: Britain Asks to Take Back 5 Guantánamo Detainees
text: LONDON, Aug. 7 — In a shift in policy, Britain on Tuesday asked the United States to release five detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who have resided in Britain but are not citizens.

headline: Music Found in Moscow May Be Hitler’s
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 7 — Hitler’s outward hatred for Jews and Russians may have belied a secret passion for some of their greatest musical works, if a recently discovered cache of records proves to be the remains of his private music collection.

headline: The Return of Foot-and-Mouth
text: You don’t have to be an English farmer to understand the fear raised by the recent discovery of foot-and-mouth disease on two farms in Surrey. The last time there was an outbreak, in 2001, the farming north seemed to become a funeral pyre, and life in rural areas ground to a halt.

headline: Bush Vows a Veto on Any Tax Increase
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 — With Wall Street skittish over the current state of financial markets, President Bush today described the economy as “thriving” and reiterated his belief that lower taxes are the best way to guarantee economic prosperity.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the What’s Online column in Business Day on Saturday, about an Inc.com feature on young entrepreneurs, misspelled the surname of the owner of bestparking.com, which tracks parking garage rates in several cities. He is Benjamin Sann, not Samm.

headline: Tornado Hits Brooklyn; Subway Back in Service
text: Most of the New York City subway system was back in service by this evening’s rush hour after a fierce morning storm disrupted transit service throughout much of the region and unleashed a rare and destructive tornado that whipped southwestern Brooklyn with winds of up to 135 miles an hour.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Sports of The Times column on Monday, about Tom Glavine’s milestone victory as the Mets beat the Cubs, referred incorrectly in some copies to the accomplishment. It was his 300th career victory, not his 500th.

headline: Veikko Karvonen, 81, Top Marathoner in the ’50s, Dies
text: Veikko Karvonen, a Finnish postal clerk who became one of the world’s best marathon runners in the 1950s, died Aug. 1 in Turku, Finland. He was 81.

headline: Viewers Tune In to ‘Singing Bee’
text: With a special hourlong Monday edition of “Singing Bee,” NBC surged into first place in the night in total viewers, while Fox remained the night’s leader among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the “Singing Bee” game show delivered 7.8 million viewers at 8, down from its recent average on Tuesdays at 9:30 but enough to make “Bee” No. 1 in the hour, just ahead of ABC’s “Wife Swap” (6.4 million). After it, NBC’s finale of “Age of Love” drew a series-best 7 million viewers in second place at 9. Fox came in first in the highly competitive time slot with “Hell’s Kitchen,” which drew 8.7 million viewers and the night’s top ratings in the 18-to-49 demographic. Also at 9, the debut of ABC’s “Fat March” attracted 4.4 million viewers in fourth place. ABC and CBS tied for third behind Fox and NBC in the 18 to 49 set. On Saturday 5.8 million viewers tuned in at 8 for Nickelodeon’s “Drake & Josh: Really Big Shrimp,” the largest audience for a made-for-television movie in the channel’s history.

headline: Newark Officials Say They May Soon Identify a Suspect in the Killing of 3 Friends
text: NEWARK, Aug. 7  Through a survivor’s account and ballistic evidence, investigators here were close to identifying at least one suspect involved in the Saturday night killings of three friends in Newark, law enforcement officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Abuses Belie China Pledge on Rights, Critics Say
text: BEIJING, Aug. 7  Human rights groups on Tuesday accused China of failing to improve its record on civil liberties, and of harassing lawyers, dissidents and journalists, despite official promises to make human rights a centerpiece of the 2008 Olympics in Beijing.

headline: Ethanol Is Feeding Hot Market for Farmland
text: DEKALB, Ill. — While much of the nation worries about a slumping real estate market, people in Midwestern farm country are experiencing exactly the opposite. Take, for instance, the farm here — nearly 80 acres of corn and soybeans off a gravel road in a universe of corn and soybeans — that sold for $10,000 an acre at auction this spring, a price that astonished even the auctioneer.

headline: Hollywood Starts Making Bollywood Films in India
text: MUMBAI, Aug. 7 — An Indian woman in a flowing beaded gown glides through a pond. A mosquito net brushes over her lover. And to insistent drumbeats of the Indian heartland, a dancing phalanx of tunic-clad women twirls.

headline: A Weak Dollar and the Fed
text: Despite the Federal Reserve’s stay-the-course message yesterday, investors are betting on at least one interest-rate cut by January, intended to quell turmoil in the markets and to juice the slow economy. But with the dollar also weak  recently hitting its lowest point in 15 years against an index of other major currencies  the Fed may be reluctant to oblige.

headline: Good Scores on National Economics Test
text: The nation’s high school seniors performed significantly better on the first nationwide economics test than they did on other recent national exams in history and science, and demonstrated a better understanding of basic market forces like supply and demand than officials expected.

headline: The Democratic Candidates Forum
text: The following is the transcript of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. candidates forum, as provided by Federal News Service.

headline: Mangosteens Arrive, but Be Prepared to Pay
text: DON’T be surprised if you see a round purple fruit in a locked jewel case at the grocery. Small shipments of fresh mangosteen, a Southeast Asian fruit legendary for its exquisite flavor but long unavailable legally on the United States mainland, started coming in last week from Puerto Rico.

headline: Nurse Practitioners (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Consumers Picked Up Pace of Borrowing in June
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (Bloomberg News) — Borrowing by American households rose more than forecast in June, as consumers turned to credit cards and nonmortgage loans to maintain spending.

headline: Should This Milk Be Legal?
text: THERE was the name of a Web site scrawled on cardboard and quickly torn to bits by an anonymous farmer in the Greenmarket at Union Square. Then came the paperwork, legal enough presumably, to protect the source of the illicit substance. Finally, Yaron Milgrom-Elcott received the monthly drop site: an address near Chelsea, open for two hours, show up or lose the white stuff.

headline: Canada: U.S. Seeks New Ruling in Lumber Dispute
text: The United States resumed its trade dispute over Canadian softwood lumber, just 13 months after signing an agreement intended to settle the decades-old issue. Susan C. Schwab, the United States trade representative, said in a statement that she would seek binding arbitration over allegations that Canada is not upholding its commitments under the accord. The United States contends that Canada should have begun reducing exports from British Columbia and Alberta in January and that it gives the lumber industry in Ontario and Quebec unfair assistance. David Emerson, Canada’s international trade minister, said in a statement that the dispute stems from “differing interpretations of the Softwood Lumber Agreement by Canada and the U.S.”

headline: Stricker Traces Upswing to Trailer
text: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 7 — Two years ago in Madison, Wis., on a course sheathed in snow, Steve Stricker set out to find the remnants of his swing inside a three-sided trailer.

headline: Serve Breakfast in Class, Advocates for Poor Urge
text: Advocates for poor children urged the city’s Department of Education yesterday to serve free breakfast in classrooms, saying that the practice of serving it in cafeterias failed to attract most of the children who need it.

headline: Checking Out Real Estate in New York to Make a Map, Not a Deal (Really)
text: The city that never sleeps is also the city that never stops rebuilding. Most New Yorkers — certainly any who have ever been awakened by jackhammers at dawn — realize that construction is simply a fact of city life.

headline: Bonds Leaves Lasting Mark With No. 756
text: It’s his record. Barry Bonds earned it with 756 disciplined swings. Let’s give him a pass the way a thousand pitchers did. For one day, let’s call a truce, the way the generals did in ancient Greece when athletes were headed to Olympia.

headline: U.S. Set for a Crackdown on Illegal Hiring
text: In a new effort to crack down on illegal immigrants, federal authorities are expected to announce tough rules this week that would require employers to fire workers who use false Social Security numbers.

headline: NBC Will Offer Olympics on the Internet
text: NBC Universal Sports will stream 2,200 hours of live Summer Games coverage free from Beijing next year on its Web site, nbcolympics.com.

headline: Judge Dismisses Law on Violent Video Games
text: Judge Dismisses Law on Violent Video Games

headline: 101 Quick Meals? Make It an Even 111
text: “SUMMER Express: 101 Simple Meals Ready in 10 Minutes or Less,” the Minimalist column on July 18, clearly struck a chord.

headline: Restaurateurs-to-Be Look Before Leaping
text: PASQUALE VIGGIANO and his wife, Geraldine, thought they knew the restaurant business. Ms. Viggiano had helped her mother run a cafe in Honduras and Mr. Viggiano had grown up hearing his parents’ fond tales of the luncheonette they opened when they came to Brooklyn from Italy.

headline: Safety Issues Slow Mine Rescue Efforts
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 7 — Efforts to reach six trapped coal miners came to a crawl on Tuesday as continued seismic activity forced out rescue teams, and drilling equipment began slowly chewing through thousands of feet of rock to where the men were working early Monday when parts of the mountain shook and fell.

headline: Ancient Nomads Offer Insights to Modern Crises
text: ALMATY, Kazakhstan — Every summer for the past eight years, Michael Frachetti has come to the desert steppe that rolls like endless yellow waves across this expansive Central Asian nation searching for evidence of a vast, connected nomadic society.

headline: Families of South Korean Hostages in Afghanistan Seek Solace, and a Solution
text: BUNDANG, South Korea, Aug. 6  Seo Jeong-bae was not too worried when his daughter and son, both Christians, told him last month that they were going to Afghanistan on an aid mission to help children in the Islamic country.

headline: Two Brothers, One Down and One Out
text: The French filmmaker Christophe Honoré was born in 1970, almost two years to the month after his country was seized by revolutionary fervor. By then, the New Wave had crested, and the no-longer-young Turks who had shaken up the art had moved on and apart.

headline: One Fan Follows a Slugger’s Chase From Behind Bars
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 — Forty miles from the fireworks, the streamers and the flashbulbs, Greg Anderson could only hope to commandeer the television.

headline: Boyfriend of Victim Slits Wrists, Police Say
text: A boyfriend of the 20-year-old woman whose decomposed body was found on Sunday wrapped in bedding in her mother’s apartment in Greenwich Village was taken into custody last night after he slit his wrists on a rooftop on the Upper West Side, the authorities said.

headline: Deputy Editor Is Out at Portfolio
text: Portfolio, a heavily promoted new business magazine that is about to publish its second issue, yesterday fired one of its top editors, James Impoco, according to several people at the magazine and the company.

headline: Giants Playing Without a Net at Fullback
text: ALBANY, Aug. 7  Robert Douglas could be the loneliest member of the Giants, particularly when players chat with teammates at the same position. Or he could be the luckiest member of the Giants, especially when it is time for preseason cuts.

headline: Some Wonder if Cash for Good Test Scores Is the Wrong Kind of Lesson
text: Should cash be used to spur children to do better on reading and math tests?

headline: Corzine Selects a Colleague to Serve as His Chief of Staff
text: TRENTON, Aug. 7 — Gov. Jon S. Corzine opted for loyalty and familiarity on Tuesday, naming Bradley I. Abelow, the state treasurer and a former colleague at Goldman Sachs, to be his chief of staff.

headline: Stolen Picassos are Recovered
text: Two Picasso paintings and a drawing valued at $66 million have been recovered, and three suspects were under arrest yesterday in Paris in connection with the theft of the art in February from the home of the artist’s granddaughter, Diana Widmaier-Picasso, Agence France-Presse reported. “The works are apparently in good condition,” said her lawyer Olivier Baratelli. Ms. Widmaier-Picasso was asleep in her house in the Seventh Arrondissement when thieves took the oils “Maya With Doll” (1938), top, and “Portrait of Jacqueline” (1961), above, as well as the drawing.

headline: More Generics Slow Rise in Drug Prices
text: A quiet coup is taking place in American medicine cabinets. Prescription bottles bearing catchy brand names like Zoloft and Flonase are being pushed aside by tongue-twisting generics like sertraline and fluticasone propionate.

headline: Warming Threatens Farms in India, U.N. Official Says
text: NEW DELHI, Aug. 7 — As exceptionally heavy rains continued to cut a wide swath of ruin across northern India, a top United Nations official warned Tuesday that the vagaries of climate change could destroy vast swaths of farmland in this country, ultimately affecting food production and adding to the woes of already desperate peasants who live off of the land.

headline: Shuttle Takes Off With Ex-Teacher on Board
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 8 — Culminating a smooth countdown, the space shuttle Endeavour lifted off into the hazy, humid skies this evening, carrying pieces of the International Space Station and a living reminder of the loss of the space shuttle Challenger two decades ago.

headline: Carnegie Tenants Gain a Reprieve
text: Thirty-three of the 45 tenants of the tower studios above Carnegie Hall have won a reprieve from plans by the Carnegie Hall Corporation to evict them to make way for renovations to expand the hall’s music education programs, which serve about 115,000 children, and improve its backstage space. The remaining 12 tenants are not part of the lawsuit. State Supreme Court Judge Eileen Rakower issued a temporary restraining order on Friday barring Carnegie Hall from further action until a hearing on the tenants’ case on Sept. 17.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption with an article yesterday about a debate at some colleges over the installation of footbaths that Muslim students can use in ritual ablutions before prayers referred incorrectly to footbaths at the University of Michigan-Dearborn. The university is planning to install them, but has not yet done so.

headline: British Outbreak May Be Linked to Human Action
text: LONDON, Aug. 7 — An investigation, ordered by Prime Minister Gordon Brown, on Tuesday concluded that the spread of foot-and-mouth disease among livestock at two farms in southern England was probably caused by human movement from nearby laboratory facilities that was either “accidental or deliberate.”

headline: Spitzer Acknowledges Need to Wield Power With Humility
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer spoke on the tension between power and humility during a visit to the Chautauqua Institution yesterday, criticizing the Bush administration for failing to recognize its mistakes in Iraq while acknowledging that his own administration had “allowed our passion to get the best of us” in recent weeks.

headline: Manhattan: Contract Settled With Police Lieutenants
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that the city had reached a tentative contract settlement with the Lieutenants Benevolent Association, the union representing police lieutenants. The agreement, for 26 months beginning on Sept. 1, calls for an 8.16 percent wage increase and applies to roughly 1,600 supervisors, the mayor said.

headline: The Joba Chamberlain Era Begins
text: It was an eventful night here at the Rogers Center, to say the least. Need a story line? Take your pick: Joba Chamberlain’s debut, Roger Clemens’s stingy pitching or the bench-clearing fracas after Alex Rodriguez took a fastball in the calf from Josh Towers?

headline: Home Run History
text: Barry Bonds hit a Major League Baseball record 756th home run last night. The achievement moves Bonds past Hank Aaron for career home runs. Several Sports of The Times columnists recalled other record-setting moments in baseball: Hank Aaron’s home run record, Maury Wills’s record for stolen bases in a season, Cal Ripken’s consecutive games, Barry Bonds’s earlier feat, the most home runs in a single season, and Pete Rose’s career hits.

headline: After the Storm: Reader Photos
text: Images of the aftermath of Wednesday's early-morning storm submitted by readers of The Times's City Room blog.

headline: Handy mobile Paris tour guide
text: Why bother paying for an old-fashioned tour guide when you can just call up one on your mobile telephone, which will steer you around major landmarks. Allovisit has versions in English and French for all major tourist destinations in France.

headline: Shakespeare in a Roman Park
text: Shakespeare in the park, in Rome, is an oddly Elizabethan experience, if only because the performances take place in a full-scale replica of Shakespeare’s 16th century Globe Theater in London.

headline: German Fund Stops Payouts, Citing Mortgage Market Unease
text: WestLB Mellon Asset Management suspended redemptions of an asset-backed securities fund Tuesday amid investor concern about the problems in the subprime mortgage market in the United States.

headline: Draper Fisher Takes Stake in Europe’s Esprit Capital
text: Draper Fisher Jurvetson, the venture capital firm, has acquired a strategic stake in Esprit Capital Partners of Europe.

headline: 2 Lenders Voice Confidence as 2 More Fold
text: Countrywide Financial and the CIT Group said they would be able to ride out the mortgage industry’s credit squeeze as two more rivals, the HomeBanc Corporation and Impac Mortgage Holdings, curtailed new loans.

headline: Fidelity’s Former Heir Apparent Resigns
text: Ellyn McColgan, a Fidelity executive who had been considered an heir apparent to the chairman and chief executive, Edward C. Johnson III, resigned unexpectedly Tuesday.

headline: Lenovo Soars on Word of a Packard Bell Deal
text: Shares in the Lenovo Group, now just starting to turn around a unit acquired from I.B.M., jumped more than 2 percent on Wednesday after the company revealed it hoped to buy a rival PC maker, Packard Bell, to strengthen its European operation.

headline: MercadoLibre I.P.O. Puts Focus on eBay
text: As MercadoLibre, the Latin American auction site, prepares for an initial public offering, analysts are speculating about what eBay, its largest shareholder, intends to do in the region.

headline: How Much Pain for Wall Street Banks?
text: Even as turmoil in the debt markets continues to spoil the fun for Wall Street, analysts have been loathe to speculate on when the good times — or at least more stable times — may return.

headline: For Jordan, an Uncoventional Buyout
text: Jordan Company, a New York private equity firm, is days away from closing a deal to buy the Production Resource Group, a supplier of lighting and audio systems used in theater productions, live concerts and trade shows, from Boston Ventures Management for $630 million, The Deal.com reported.

headline: ViVOtech Gets $22.5 Million Injection
text: A radio frequency payment technology developer, ViVOtech, raised $22.5 million in a third round from strategic investors to advance research and development.

headline: German Court Blocks Sonova Deal
text: Sonova Holding, a Swiss maker of hearing aids, said it would abandon its bid to acquire a Danish competitor after a German court ruled that it would not dismiss a regulator’s decision to block the 3.3 billion Swiss franc ($2.76 billion) deal.

headline: Passenger Takes $8.3 Million on Board
text: Passenger, which creates branded social networking platforms for companies that want to interact with and observe their customers, announced on Tuesday an $8.3 million Series B funding round.

headline: Tensions Rise in J Sainsbury Bid, Report Says
text: J Sainsbury, the grocery chain, is set to meet its suitor, Delta Two, Wednesday, amid signs of increasing tensions over a potential 10.4 billion pound ($21.1 billion) takeover, The Times of London said.

headline: Eon Makes Deal for Spanish Windfarm Operator
text: Eon of Germany agreed on its second acquisition in Spain on Tuesday, four months after being outmaneuvered in the 43 billion euro ($59 billion) bid battle for Endesa, the country’s biggest electricity group.

headline: Austria’s OMV Won’t Go Hostile on Mol Bid
text: OMV, Austria’s state-controlled oil company that wants to merge with rival Mol, will not make a formal bid against the wishes of the Hungarian company’s management.

headline: CompuDyne Agrees to Buyout Offer
text: CompuDyne, a security firm that provides blast-resistant windows and doors for federal buildings and embassies, agreed to be acquired by private equity investors led by Gores Group for about $59 million, the company said Tuesday.

headline: Lichtenstein’s Steel Partners Loses Battle for Bull-Dog
text: Steel Partners, the hedge fund run by Warren Lichtenstein, on Tuesday lost its final court appeal against a “poison pill” defense by Bull-Dog Sauce, the Japanese condiments maker it has been trying to take over since May.

headline: L.S.E. Wins Approval to Buy Italian Rival
text: The London Stock Exchange shareholders voted in favor of the exchange’s proposed 1.63 billion euro ($2.2 billion) acquisition of Borsa Italiana.

headline: Bank of America Names Head of Hedge Funds
text: Bank of America‘s alternatives arm has appointed a new director of hedge fund investments as it folds in its recent acquisition of U.S. Trust.

headline: Investor Sues Bear Stearns Over Fallen Funds
text: Bear Stearns was hit by a lawsuit from an angry investor over the collapse of two of the bank’s hedge funds.

headline: Investors Line Up for Pieces of Seattle’s Comeback
text: The Seattle office market has made a spectacular recovery in the last few years. As a result,Seattle is now on every real estate investor’s shopping list.

headline: Vodafone to Keep Stake in Verizon Wireless
text: Vodafone committed itself on Wednesday to holding on to its full 45 percent stake in Verizon Wireless, the mobile phone group in the United States, turning down the right to sell back up to $10 billion of shares to its partner in the venture, Verizon Communications.

headline: Faced With Racist Abuse, Beasley Strikes Back
