text: DaMarcus Beasley got a bit beat up during his Scottish Premier League debut last weekend for Rangers, his new club. But the muscling and hard tackles pale in comparison to the ugly abuse he and teammate Jean-Claude Darcheville reportedly suffered in Montenegro on Tuesday.

headline: Backdating Conviction Rattles Silicon Valley
text: Brocade Communications Systems‘ former chief executive, Gregory L. Reyes, was found guilty of conspiracy and fraud Tuesday in the first criminal options-backdating case to go to trial.

headline: Morning Buzz: Suspect Caught in N.Y.U. Killing; Deal on Tax Breaks for Housing; Anguish and Anger After a Blast; and More
text: A boyfriend of the 20-year-old woman whose decomposed body was found on Sunday wrapped in bedding in her mother’s apartment in Greenwich Village was taken into custody last night after he slit his wrists on a rooftop on the Upper West Side, Al Baker reports. The man, Michael A. Cordero, 23, later told doctors and nurses that he had killed his girlfriend, Boitumelo McCallum, a student at Mills College in Oakland, Calif., and the daughter of two New York University professors, the police said. While investigators had not named any suspects in the killing, they had said earlier yesterday that they were eager to speak with Mr. Cordero.The New York Post reports that a friend of Mr. Cordero’s entered the Sixth Precinct station house early Tuesday and told the authorities that Mr. Cordero had confessed to the crime. Citing the police, The Post reports that Ms. McCallum was probably killed on Thursday, the day after she held a raucous party at her apartment, at 4 Washington Square Village. According to The Post, a friend of Ms. McCallum’s in California told the police that Mr. Cordero regularly beat his girlfriend.

headline: Flooding Cripples Subway System
text: Updated, 4:10 p.m. | Gov. Eliot Spitzer ordered the Metropolitan Transportation Authority today to conduct a review of how torrential rains paralyzed New York City’s transit system this morning, disabling or delaying every one of the city’s subway lines. (Subway service was returning to a somewhat normal state this afternon, as the M.T.A. and hundreds of thousands of riders braced for the evening rush.)

headline: Backdating Conviction Rattles Silicon Valley
text: Brocade Communications Systems‘ former chief executive, Gregory L. Reyes, was found guilty of conspiracy and fraud Tuesday in the first criminal options-backdating case to go to trial.

headline: 2008: The Day Between Debates
text: Last night’s A.F.L.-C.I.O. presidential forum in Chicago offered the Democratic candidates a chance to make a pitch to union members and American workers, and while they addressed issues like health care and trade, some of the most heated exchanges were over foreign policy.

headline: TiVo's Ultimate DVR Redux
text: In September 2006, David fell head over heels for TiVo's high definition digital video recorder. Now, there's more to love for less.

headline: Earlier Warnings on Minnesota Bridge Are Unearthed
text: The gathering of warning signs began almost immediately after the bridge collapse in Minnesota, but the ones coming to light now are getting earlier, more urgent and harder for state officials to dismiss.

headline: Blackstone Raises ‘Largest-Ever’ Buyout Fund
text: The credit markets have all but slammed shut, and Blackstone Group‘s stock is trading below its offering price. But Blackstone still had something to crow about Wednesday.

headline:
Living with Music:
A Playlist by Daniel Handler
text: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for “Living With Music,” a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the “celebrity playlists” on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

headline: The ‘Least Bad’ Option in Iraq
text: The third wheel squeaks: Michael O’Hanlon and Kenneth Pollack of the Brookings Institution raised a lot of eyebrows last week with their Times Op-Ed article in which they wrote, “we were surprised by the gains we saw and the potential to produce not necessarily ‘victory’ but a sustainable stability that both we and the Iraqis could live with.”

headline: QuickBits: Sprint Slowdown; Bookmarks Get Bought
text: WiMax better be a SuccessMax for Sprint because its current phone business is struggling. The company barely broke even in the second quarter, with new customer growth stalled and heavy investments in its new WiMax network. [Reuters]

headline: Polo Profit Gains 10%
text: Aug. 8 (Bloomberg) -- Polo Ralph Lauren Corp. (NYSE:RL) , the designer of Chaps and Club Monaco clothing, said first-quarter earnings rose more than analysts estimated. The shares fell after the company cut its annual forecast for the second time this year.

headline: Answers About Latino New York, Part 1
text: Following is the first set of responses from Carolina González and Seth Kugel, freelance journalists who wrote “Nueva York: The Complete Guide to Latino Life in the Five Boroughs” and run a blog about Latino life in New York City. Mr. Kugel and Ms. González are taking questions from City Room readers this week. Readers are invited to submit additional questions here.

headline: Sotheby's Profit Rises 48%
text: Aug. 8 (Bloomberg) -- Sotheby's, the auction house whose shares have slipped on concerns that hedge funds may buy less art because of investment losses, said profit from continuing operations rose 48 percent, helped by strong London and New York sales including a Mark Rothko painting.

headline: And Bonds’s 756th Homer Goes to …
text: Update, August 9, 12:42 PM Eastern The Daily News interviewed Mr. Murphy, who vowed to give 49 percent of the winnings to his cohort at the game, Amir Kamal, “for watching my back”.

headline: Storms Snarl New York Commute
text: Powerful thunderstorms swept through the New York region on Wednesday morning, toppling trees and flooding the subways.

headline: Latest Status of Subway Lines [Aug. 8]

headline: Barneys Agrees to New Offer from Istithmar
text: The bidding war over Barneys New York escalated on Wednesday as Jones Apparel Group, which owns the high-fashion emporium, agreed to a new and higher offer from the investment arm of the Dubai government. Istithmar will pay $942.3 million for the chain, beating a rival unsolicited offer from Japan’s Fast Retailing.

headline: Food Stuff
text: Macaroons Everywhere, Except on the Sign

headline: After the Storm: Reader Photographs and Video
text: Updated, 8:50 p.m. | City Room invited readers to submit their photos and video clips of the disruptions or damage caused by the heavy rains this morning. Thank you to everyone who e-mailed us with contributions. We chose 20 of your images for a slide show.

headline: Music to my Ears (and Stomach)
text: I got choked-up and misty-eyed this morning. It was an emotional moment. Here I was, tap-tap-tapping on my laptop — the I-Mac is in the shop for repairs, a possible explanation for my delicate state — and catching up with the flurry of food articles in Wednesday’s papers when I saw, in the New York Post, a column by Steve Cuozzo reassuring me that I live smack in the middle of a restaurant Mecca.

headline: Blackstone’s Swelling Lobbying Bill
text: Currying favor in Washington is no cheap task, as the Blackstone Group is learning.

headline: Sallie Mae’s $25 Billion Question
text: In the standoff between Sallie Mae and its proposed acquirers, a few letters are getting a lot of attention: M.A.E., which stand for “material adverse effect,” the term used to describe an escape hatch that may or may not allow a group led by J.C. Flowers & Company to back out of its $25 billion agreement to take the company private.

headline: Analyzing Iraq Optimists
text: In her web column today, Janet Elder, The Times’s editor of news surveys and election analysis, examines the thinking and motivations of those who have maintained an upbeat view of Iraq:

headline: Strong Winds Cause Extensive Damage in Brooklyn; Officials Warn of Scorching Heat
text: Updated, 8 p.m. | Heavy winds toppled power lines, uprooted trees and damaged about 40 buildings in a wide swath of southwestern Brooklyn early this morning, particularly in the neighborhoods of Sunset Park and Bay Ridge.

headline: Drifting Wood
text: As Motoko Rich has reported, James Wood – he’s among the most influential literary critics alive – is leaving The New Republic to write for The New Yorker.

headline: Time for the Spin Cycle?
text: If the buyout chill continues, more companies might try demergers, otherwise known as spinoffs, to get rid of unwanted business units without the help of a buyer.

headline: Dean Kamen Lends a Hand, or Two
text: Eighteen months ago Segway entrepreneur and serial inventor Dean Kamen received a visit from Anthony Tether, the electrical engineer who runs the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, the military’s research and development agency.

headline: Will Warner Music Go Private (Again)?
text: Update:Warner Music‘s shares surged as high as 21 percent on Wednesday on a newspaper report saying that that its private equity backers may take the record label private, just two years after they took it public.

headline: Climate Protesters Claim a Victory at Heathrow
text: Protesters opposed to the expansion of London’s Heathrow will set up camp near the airport starting next week after an injunction sought by the airport’s operating company was narrowed by a judge.

headline: The Braves, on Average, Are Higher Than the Mets
text: Several players on the Mets, including Shawn Green and David Wright, marveled at the Braves’ lineup after last night’s 7-3 loss at Shea Stadium. The Braves, who got even better when they signed Mark Teixeira at the trade deadline, had four batters in their starting lineup last night who are averaging over .300: Matt Diaz (.344), Chipper Jones (.338), Yunel Escobar (.333) and Jeff Francoeur (.310). Escobar is filling in for the injured Edgar Renteria, who is out for a few weeks with a sprained ankle. Renteria’s average? It’s a cool .336. Teixeira, meanwhile, is on the doorstep of .300, averaging .292.

headline: Blogger to Pay $30,000 in S.E.C. Case
text: Prominent liberal blogger Jerome Armstrong has agreed to pay nearly $30,000 in fines in a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission over allegations that Armstrong touted the stock of a software company on Raging Bull, an Internet bulletin board, in 2000, without disclosing that he was being paid to do so.

headline: A Subtle Shift in Pentagon Technology
text: At the DARPAtech convention this week in Anaheim, Calif., many of the exhibitions dealt with the development of exotic technologies for tracking and killing enemies. So it was both inspiring and disturbing to see projects like robotic arms helping double amputees performing seemingly miraculous basic human functions.

headline: Storm Upends New York Commute
text: Commuters struggled to get to work as virtually every subway line and railroad was disrupted by flooding caused by overnight storms.

headline: How Apple Nurtured Fake Steve
text: This is our last word on the Fake Steve saga, I hope.

headline: City Assesses Storm Damage
text: Powerful thunderstorms swept through the New York metropolitan area Wednesday morning.

headline: Robotic Arm
text: A man demonstrates his robotic arm by eating M&Ms.

headline: A Time of Uncertainty for Republican Candidates in Queens
text: By now, many New Yorkers have heard of City Councilman Dennis P. Gallagher. For most of his time in the Council, Mr. Gallagher, a Republican from Queens, managed to avoid citywide renown. But he made headlines in the past month, culminating with his indictment last week on 10 counts of rape, criminal sexual acts and assault. Prosecutors say he raped a woman in his campaign office. Mr. Gallagher has denied any wrongdoing and pleaded not guilty.

headline: An Abandoned Wreck, Lingering
text: “What is this, Baghdad?” Bruce Toman asked Tuesday night. In fact, it was Second Avenue and 62nd Street.

headline: The Old Man and the Mound
text: Certain ballparks have distinct sounds. Trains rumble past Safeco Field in Seattle. Seagulls comb AT&T Park after games in San Francisco. Airplanes whoosh over Shea Stadium in Flushing. Horns were always bleating from the catacombs of Olympic Stadium in Montreal.

headline: F. Thompson Hires Top Staff
text: Just two weeks after Fred D Thompson shook up his political committee – the one that is “testing the waters” as he gears up to run for the Republican nomination for the presidency – he announced today that he has hired a senior-level campaign-manager-in-waiting, William B. Lacy, a former strategist to Bob Dole and aide to President Ronald Reagan.

headline: Why the Subways Flood
text: Heavy rains overwhelm the subway system, disrupting the morning commute for millions. Sound familiar?

headline: Brunswick Hires Lazard Ex-Communications Director
text: The Brunswick Group, a public relations firm, said on Monday that it has hired Lazard‘s former director of global communications as a partner. Richard Silverman will work on corporate and financial communications accounts, specializing in the financial services sector, Brunswick said in a statement.

headline: Riders Struggle to Get Home as M.T.A. Restores Service
text: Updated, 8:04 p.m. | The evening commute drew to a tiring and frustrating close, following the extensive disruptions that paralyzed the New York City subway system in the morning. As of 8 p.m. — more than 12 hours after the system was virtually shut down by torrential rains — most subway lines were running normally. The V and W lines were down, and parts of the F and G lines were not operating. Service on the E and R lines had been restored. The No. 7 line was making all local stops between Times Square and Main Street in Flushing, Queens.

headline: Early Primaries Now Even Earlier?
text: A likely move by the South Carolina Republican party to push up the date of the state’s G.O.P. primary may have a ripple effect in Iowa and New Hampshire, which have long had the nation’s earliest nominating contests.

headline: What’s Good for Romney …
text: Mitt Romney is quickly feeling the heat over this comment at an Iowa campaign event that, while none of his five sons volunteered for military duty, they are aiding the country by “helping me get elected.”

headline: Ricky Gervais: The Has-Been Who Still Is
text: Is Ricky Gervais finished? The question comes in for overly earnest debate here, with British writers giving pros and cons as if comedy were a matter for the House of Lords.

headline: Lining Up to Point Fingers at the M.T.A.
text: It is safe to assume that hearings will be held, studies will be conducted and recommendations will be made in the wake of the extensive transit disruptions in today’s morning commute. Politicians have already started to weigh in with their opinions.

headline: On Top of Everything Else: Conserve, Brooklyn
text: Amid all the other news this afternoon, Consolidated Edison issued an alert about the need for power conservation and a reduction of voltage in a large swath of Brooklyn:

headline: Mountain Men
text: For a long time I’ve been wanting to visit Smith-Madrone, way up in the Spring Mountain District, one of the most idiosyncratic producers in Napa Valley. All you need to know about Smith-Madrone is that it’s best known for its riesling. Nobody in Napa Valley is best known for its riesling, but there you have Smith-Madrone.

headline: Brooklyn Storm Is Declared a Tornado
text: The National Weather Service confirmed at 5:12 p.m. that a tornado touched down in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, this morning. The tornado was classified as a 2 on the Enhanced Fujita scale, which goes from 0 to 5. An EF2 tornado consists of winds of 111 to 135 miles per hour.

headline: Clinton Calls for More Spending on Infrastructure
text: In the wake of last week’s bridge collapse in Minneapolis bridge, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton called this afternoon for spending $10 billion in federal money over 10 years to redesign and rebuild roads, waterways, seaports, and some of the more than 60,000 bridges that have been identified as structurally deficient.

headline: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Sidesteps Endorsements — for Now
text: CHICAGO — The A.F.L.-C.I.O.’s executive council voted today against endorsing any presidential candidate, reflecting divisions over which Democrat to support and setting the stage for its 55 member unions to make individual endorsements.

headline: Clinton and the Bankruptcy Law
text: At the Democratic debate last night, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said that she “fought the banks” on bankruptcy overhaul. She made the statement as part of her defense for taking campaign contributions from lobbyists and special interests.

headline: Watch, Play, Obsess
text: This summer, we enjoyed the Concacaf Gold Cup, the Copa America and the FIFA U20 World Cup. M.L.S. has kept us involved, if not entirely satisfied. And we will have the Women’s World Cup soon enough. But now, soccer fans get to sink their teeth in the meatiest part of the year’s football smorgasbord as the top European and South American leagues begin their league, cup and international competitions.

headline: Did Bankers Put Nardelli Behind the Wheel?

headline: Presidential Debate Video ‘Liberated’
text: There are probably only a handful of causes (or maybe not even that many) that can unite liberal activists and conservative bloggers. Apparently “liberating” presidential debate video from the major broadcast and cable networks is one of them.

headline: The List Grows to 277: Our Readers Find 40 Certified New Reasons to Have Sex
text: Seek and ye shall find. Our quest for the 238th reason to have sex has been more successful than I dared hope. Hundreds of readers nominated additions to the list of 237 reasons published by Cindy Meston and David Buss of the University of Texas at Austin. The two psychologists have looked over the nominations and decided there are now 277 reasons to have sex.

headline: Questions About Romney’s Sons and Military Service
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — It is a question that Mitt Romney has gotten before on the campaign trail. Sometimes it is asked innocently; sometimes with a clear edge.

headline: Just a Small-Town Girl …
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton is probably the only person on the planet who could get away with calling Hillary Rodham Clinton a girl.

headline: Brooklyn Tornado
text: A tornado hit Brooklyn for the first time on record early  Wednesday morning.

headline: Your Suggestions for Bloggers
text: I’m going to be going on a book leave later this month, to work on a book with my wife about women in the developing world. We’re really excited about that.

headline: Your Comments on my Aid Column
text: My Thursday column is about the effectiveness of foreign aid. It’s a topic of considerable debate, and if you’re interested in the subject I strongly recommend Paul Collier’s wonderful new book, “The Bottom Billion.” In any case, please post your suggestions below.

headline: Bonds Goes to Cooperstown
text: Jeff Idelson scurried past the San Francisco Giants’ clubhouse, a black shopping bag in his hand and a vision for an exhibit in his head. Idelson, who is a vice president for the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum, has been trailing Barry Bonds to collect items from Bonds’s historic home run chase.

headline: Sore Calf, Quick Getaway for A-Rod
text: If anybody is worried about Alex Rodriguez’s sore left calf, please relax. The beat reporters stayed in the clubhouse until Rodriguez was gone after Wednesday’s 15-4 loss to Toronto. We were hoping for an update on his leg, but he was not in the mood to stop for a chat.

headline: With Homer Chase Over, It’s Back to Pennant Races
text: Now that we don’t have to fret about Barry Bonds at the moment — I mean, the next big story should be either retirement or indictment — can we please get back to the business of squirm-inducing pennant races?

headline: Voting Reform (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Digital S.L.R. With Some Top-of-the-Line Features but Not the Higher Price
text: It is a classic gadget-world situation: features that start off in a top-of-the-line model eventually migrate down the product line. Some features from the K10D single-lens reflex camera, for example, which Pentax prices at $899.95, show up in the $599 K100D Super, which shipped this week.

headline: Common at No. 1
text: The socially conscious Chicago rapper Common has scored his first No. 1 on the Billboard album chart with his new “Finding Forever” (Geffen). The album, the bulk of whose songs were produced by Kanye West, sold 155,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Korn’s untitled new album (Virgin) opens at No. 2, with 123,000 sales; it is the band’s seventh consecutive Top 10 album. Other new releases include the self-titled album by Sean Kingston, the 17-year-old Jamaican singer whose reggae-pop song “Beautiful Girls” is No. 1 on the singles chart. His album, released by Epic, opened at No. 6, with 75,000 copies sold. “Kidz Bop 12” (Razor & Tie), with toddler-friendly versions of pop hits by Avril Lavigne, Gwen Stefani, Gym Class Heroes and others, reached No. 7 in its first week out, with 71,000 sales. Last week’s No. 1, Vol. 25 in the “Now That’s What I Call Music!” series, fell to No. 3 with 123,000.

headline: Just Tell Me What’s Going On
text: New Yorkers are, by necessity, an adaptable species. Much like ants, we can reroute ourselves pretty quickly if there’s a log in the path or if our train breaks down during the morning commute. But there is something extraordinarily infuriating when that train stops running entirely, as many did yesterday, and nobody seems capable of telling us what’s happening.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: Exploring in Prospect Park

headline: N.Y.C. Transit Failings Similar to Those in 2004
text: After a heavy rainstorm crippled the subway system in September 2004, an investigation laid the blame on New York City Transit, saying that the agency had neglected basic maintenance of its drainage system, and that once the tunnels started to fill with water, the response was haphazard and ineffective.

headline: Thinking of Joining the Race?
text: REGISTER EARLY Popular relays fill up quickly, months before race day. Many race Web sites have bulletin boards for stray racers to find a team and vice versa.

headline: Stop, Look and (Even) Listen
text: THAT little voice you keep hearing isn’t always in your head. Just ask Stila’s makeup artist, Margaret Easley, whose voice is encapsulated in the Smoky Eye shadow kit ($38). Press a button on the flip top and for 49.5 seconds Ms. Easley talks you through the motions while advising you on which brushes to use.

headline: An Exhibitions Artis in the Bag
text: After weeks of rumors, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles confirmed yesterday that a retrospective of the work of Takashi Murakami, opening on Oct. 29, would include a fully functioning Louis Vuitton boutique, to sell handbags, above, and coin purses customized for the show by Mr. Murakami. The museum said that Louis Vuitton would pay for the construction and staff of the 1,000-square-foot boutique, and that no revenues from its sales would go to the museum, which receives some public financing. But at a time when several museums have been criticized for close relationships with commercial interests in the mounting of exhibitions, the museum’s officials took pains to justify their decision to include the store, saying that it “symbolizes the interweaving of high art, mass culture and commerce that has become essential to Murakami’s philosophy.” Mr. Murakami’s artwork has long included creating consumer and luxury goods. The museum’s chief curator, Paul Schimmel, who asked Louis Vuitton to participate, said the store would encourage viewers to “experience the commercial work of Murakami as profoundly as they will the most complex paintings, sculptures and exhibitions.”

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: An Exhibition’s Art

headline: As Off Broadway Changes, Some Venerable Theaters Vanish
text: The recent closing of the Actors’ Playhouse, a 62-year-old stalwart of Off Broadway in Greenwich Village, was hardly startling for people who keep up with theater news. The announcement that another Off Broadway theater is closing has become almost routine over the past few years.

headline: Conflict on Clinton’s View of Nuclear Weapons
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has criticized Senator Barack Obama for saying he would rule out using nuclear weapons to root out terrorists in Afghanistan or Pakistan, made a similar comment regarding Iran last year, before she became a presidential candidate.

headline: Potential Flaw Seen in Design of Fallen Bridge
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 8 — Investigators have found what may be a design flaw in the bridge that collapsed here a week ago, in the steel parts that connect girders, raising safety concerns for other bridges around the country, federal officials said on Wednesday.

headline: S. Carolina G.O.P. Moves Up Primary
text: CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 9 — The South Carolina Republican Party has moved up its primary to Jan. 19, leapfrogging ahead of the Florida primary and setting the stage for more states to move up their contests, potentially pushing the nominating calendar into December and moving up the date of the New Hampshire primary.

headline: Fossils in Kenya Challenge Linear Evolution
text: Two fossils found in Kenya have shaken the human family tree, possibly rearranging major branches thought to be in a straight ancestral line to Homo sapiens.

headline: Dialing 911 With VoIP
text: Q. Is it true there is no 911 emergency call function if you have VoIP service?

headline: NATIONAL REVIEWING | POLITICS | A Manager Without a Campaign
text: Just two weeks after Fred D. Thompson shook up his political committee — the one that is “testing the waters” as he gears up to run for the Republican presidential nomination — Mr. Thompson announced that he had hired a senior-level campaign-manager-in-waiting, William B. Lacy, a former strategist to Bob Dole and aide to President Ronald Reagan. Mr. Lacy, who is on leave from the Robert J. Dole Institute of Politics at the University of Kansas, also advised Mr. Thompson during his successful 1994 bid to represent Tennessee in the Senate. He helped revive a struggling campaign in which Mr. Thompson was trailing his Democratic opponent by a wide margin.

headline: SPORTS BRIEFING | GOLF | Aboff Wins Women’s Met Open
text: Susannah Aboff, a Princeton University junior, added a four-under-par 68 to her opening-round score of 72 to win the 20th Annual Lincoln Women’s Met Open Championship at Ridgewood Country Club yesterday. Aboff of Huntington Country Club became the fourth amateur to win the event. Her round included one bogey, on the par-5 17th hole, along with five birdies.

headline: The Blogs Are Alive With the Sound of Angry Democrats
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 — Progressive and liberal groups and left-leaning blogs are furious, tossing around fighting words like “spineless,” “craven” and “weak.”

headline: Bush Faults Easy Money for Volatility
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  President Bush, seeking to reassure Americans about the economy and combat Democratic criticism of his policies, said on Wednesday that recent financial market turbulence was not a cause for worry but a natural adjustment from the improvident lending of recent years.

headline: Utah Coal Area, a Region Apart, Knows Well the Perils of Mining
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 8 — Coal is probably not the first thing that comes to mind when people think about Utah, and there is good reason for that.

headline: Woman Was Strangled, Medical Examiner Says
text: A 20-year-old woman whose body was found in a Greenwich Village apartment on Sunday was strangled and smothered with a towel, the medical examiner’s office ruled yesterday. Her boyfriend was charged with second-degree murder in the killing.

headline: Theater Briefs
text: Chazz Palminteri’s  one-man show, “A Bronx Tale,” which played off Broadway in 1989 and was made into a 1993 film, will come to Broadway this fall, opening on Oct. 25 as a limited engagement at the Walter Kerr Theater. Jerry Zaks will direct the production, scheduled to run through Feb. 10.

headline: Endeavour Ready for Evening Launch
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Aug. 8 — The space shuttle Endeavour is fueled up and ready for liftoff at 6:36 p.m. today. Forecasts give an 80 percent chance of favorable weather, and launching preparations have proceeded without any glitches.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Sues Red Cross Over Symbol
text: The red cross symbol is an icon of relief from disaster. For months, it has also been the subject of a festering disagreement between major American institutions: the health care company Johnson & Johnson and the American Red Cross.

headline: Official at the Smithsonian Resigns After Meeting Transcript Is Destroyed
text: A high-ranking official has resigned from the Smithsonian Institution after acknowledging that he destroyed a transcript from an important Board of Regents meeting, the institution confirmed yesterday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article and picture caption on Tuesday about a surge of interest in the ancient books and texts stored in Timbuktu, Mali, misspelled the middle name of a Timbuktu resident whose family owns a 16th century Arabic text and whose ancestors ruled the city at its zenith. He is Ismaël Diadié Haïdara, not Diadé. (Go to Article)

headline: Miley Cyrusgoes Roaming
text: The singer, songwriter and actress Miley Cyrus, 14, will perform as herself and as her Disney Channel character, Hannah Montana, when she embarks in the fall on her 54-date “Best of Both Worlds” concert tour, beginning on Oct. 18 in St. Louis and ending on Jan. 9 in Albany. Ms. Cyrus, left, will perform at the Nassau Coliseum on Long Island on Dec. 27 and 28 and at the Prudential Center in Newark on Dec. 29 and 30. ... Paintings by Bob Dylan will hang among works by Picasso, Munch and Toulouse-Lautrec in an exhibition opening on Oct. 28 at the Chemnitz Art Collections in Germany, Agence France-Presse reported. The three-month show, “The Drawn Blank Series,” will feature more than 200 works in watercolor and gouache.... With seven nominations each, Justin Timberlake and Beyoncé led the field of nominees for the MTV Video Music Awards, The Associated Press reported. Beyoncé’s “Irreplaceable” was nominated for video of the year, as was Mr. Timberlake’s “What Goes Around,” co-starring Scarlett Johansson. Kanye West’s five nominations included video of the year (“Stronger”) and male artist of the year. The 24th annual Video Music Awards will be conferred during a live two-hour show on Sept. 9 at the Palms Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas.

headline: South Carolina Joins in Race for Early Primaries
text: States jockeying for influence are continuing to move their presidential nominating contests earlier and earlier in a kind of accelerating domino effect.

headline: Analyzing Iraq Optimists
text: About a third of Americans say the war in Iraq is going well. Maybe in the end, their steadfast support and optimism will be rewarded, but for now, they’re a decided minority, leaving those on the other side to ask, who are these people and why do they think that way?

headline: Cable TV Is Having Breakout Summer
text: Cable television has always feasted on the summer audiences abandoned by the largely vacationing broadcast networks, but this season has been a spectacularly good one.

headline: Bono, Foreign Aid and Skeptics
text: Almost nobody has campaigned so energetically for the poor in Africa as Bono, but when Bono spoke at a conference in Africa recently, he was heckled. Several Africans scolded him for demanding more foreign aid, saying that’s not what Africa needs.

headline: Jamaica Bay Marshlands (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fewer Mexican Immigrants Are Sending Money Back Home, Bank Says
text: This year a smaller percentage of Mexican immigrants in the United States sent money back to their homeland than in 2006, according to a report released yesterday by the Inter-American Development Bank. The bank said the reduction had left at least two million people in Mexico without the same financial help they had once received.

headline: An Easily Pocketed G.P.S. Tracker
text: Hansel and Gretel may have had bread crumbs, but this is the 21st century  there’s no reason to resort to baked goods to keep track of your path through the woods. The Trackstick II is a tiny G.P.S. tracker that can record your wanderings for weeks at a time.

headline: NATIONAL BRIEFING | WEST | California: Stem Cell Program Appointment
text: California’s $3 billion stem cell research program appointed an interim president, Richard A. Murphy, while it continued a longer-than-expected search for a permanent chief. Mr. Murphy recently retired as president of the Salk Institute for Biological Studies in San Diego. The previous stem cell program president, Zach Hall, announced his retirement in December and left at the end of April. The search for his successor has apparently been slowed by salary issues and doubts about how much authority a president would have, according to the California Stem Cell Report, a blog that monitors the program, the California Institute for Regenerative Medicine.

headline: Dinner Reservations? Speak to My Hair Stylist
text: LAST month, a gaggle of assistant stylists took a fashion-themed field trip along Fifth Avenue. They made several stops: Gucci, Bergdorf Goodman and the Peninsula and Four Seasons hotels.

headline: Businesses Near Blast Struggle to Return to Normal, or Even Just to Reopen
text: The front door to the Old Bridge Gourmet Deli, at 41st Street and Lexington Avenue, is about as close as any to the crater left by the steam pipe explosion outside Grand Central Terminal last month. Like several other businesses nearby, it remains closed.

headline: Correction: On a Northwest Island, a Whiff of England
text: An article on July 19 about gardeners in Washington State misstated the location of Heronswood, a plant nursery founded by the botanist and explorer Daniel Hinkley. It was on the Kitsap Peninsula, not the Skagit Peninsula.

headline: A Vote to Immortalize a Former ‘Mayor for Life’
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 — A decade and a half after a videotaped cocaine arrest that would have ended most political careers, former Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has won yet another election.

text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 — There are times in the life of George Herbert Walker Bush, the 41st president of the United States and father of the 43rd, that people, perfect strangers, come up to him and say the harshest things — words intended to comfort but words that wind up only causing pain.

headline: Near Brawl With Jays May Hurt Yanks Yet
text: TORONTO, Aug. 8  A day after the benches cleared twice at Rogers Center, the Yankees were still feeling the reverberations of their near brawl with the Toronto Blue Jays.
