headline: An Entire Bookshelf, in Your Hands
text: WHEN Paul Biba, a lawyer in Bernardsville, N.J., finds himself stuck waiting, he likes to pull out his Nokia E61i cellphone and read one of the 20 or so books he usually stores on it.

headline: Aaron Moves Over, Bonds Moves Up, but Questions Remain
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8 — On the night that Barry Bonds reached the peak of the most monumental home run hill, his wife, Liz, wore a black shirt with white letters. Written across it was “The King and I.” Surely, her statement Tuesday was about more than fashion.

headline: Game Show Buoys CBS
text: The new CBS game show “Power of 10,” with Drew Carey as host, delivered strong ratings in its preview on Tuesday, helping lift the network to second place for the night. NBC remained the leader over all with its combination of a 90-minute “America’s Got Talent” at 8, which attracted 10.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates, followed by a half-hour of “The Singing Bee” at 9:30 (9.2 million). Meanwhile, both “Power of 10” at 8 (9.2 million) and CBS’s “Big Brother” at 9 (7.2 million) earned second-place finishes in their respective time slots. ABC posted an improved night in the ratings, despite finishing third over all. The premiere of that network’s YouTube-inspired news program, “i-Caught,” which features amateur video submitted by viewers, drew 6.3 million viewers at 10. Among adults 18 to 49, the news program led the hour, ahead of repeats of CBS’s “NCIS” (6.8 million) and NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (6.4 million). Fox finished a distant fourth for the night.

headline: Is There an Iran Connection in Iraq? (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Amicably Split, and Still Sharing
text: FOR two people who might, in the society Mitchell Gold has been lobbying to create, be just another divorced couple, Mr. Gold and Bob Williams appear to get along exceptionally well. The men continue to run the furniture company that bears their names, and occasionally they even double-date, as they did last month at the Los Angeles wedding of Sarah Gore, the youngest daughter of Al and Tipper. They have even bought a pied-à-terre together in a newly built Manhattan tower (actually two apartments they combined) with a 180-degree view of the city from the 58th floor: the Hudson River to the west, the Statue of Liberty to the south, Times Square to the east. It is a view that dazzles, and Mr. Gold, an outgoing and down-to-earth man whose father was a grocer, appreciates it.

headline: 12th Graders Show Better Grasp of Market Forces Than Expected on U.S. Economics Test
text: The nation’s high school seniors performed significantly better on the first nationwide economics test than they did on other recent national exams in history and science, and demonstrated higher than expected understanding of basic market forces like supply and demand than officials expected.

headline: The Misery Strategy
text: The path the country has set on since the defeat of immigration reform in the Senate in June enshrines enforcement and punishment above all else. It is narrow, shortsighted, disruptive and self-defeating. On top of that, it won’t work.

headline: Vatican Plays Down Meeting With Priest Accused of Anti-Semitism
text: ROME, Aug. 9 — The Vatican worked to distance itself Thursday from a brief meeting between Pope Benedict XVI and a Polish priest accused of making anti-Semitic statements, in the latest of several tense episodes recently between Jews and Catholics.

headline: Swimming with the Fish
text: The Beijing Olympics open a year from this week, and Michael Phelps is not the only American swimmer poised to capture a chest full of gold. Natalie Coughlin has also mastered several strokes, and in 2004 left Athens with five medals, including two gold.

headline: Newark: Bank Robber Is Sentenced
text: A North Bergen man was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to nearly 17 years in prison for robbing 10 banks in New York and New Jersey, prosecutors said. The man, Eduardo Quevedo, 44, was arrested on June 19, 2006, a day after robbing a Bank of America branch in North Bergen, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney in New Jersey. When Mr. Quevedo was arrested, Mr. Christie said, federal agents seized an assault rifle, a handgun and ammunition. Mr. Quevedo admitted robbing 10 banks in 2005 and 2006 and was sentenced to 16 years and 8 months in prison. He was also ordered to repay more than $66,000, the amount taken in the robberies, prosecutors said.

headline: It's My World, They're Just Playing in It
text: The world of professional sports is a depressing one these days; dogfighting, game fixing, steroids, punters stabbing punters, Joe Morgan. Fortunately, I haven’t had to deal with any of it for about two weeks now: I’ve been busy playing PlayStation 3.

headline: Bankruptcy Trustee Sues Big Investor in Refco
text: The trustee for Refco, a commodities brokerage firm that collapsed in fraud a few months after it went public in 2005, has sued Thomas H. Lee, the private equity firm that controlled Refco, saying the firm should have known about the fraud before it sold stock.

headline: Queens: Driver Charged After Fatal Crash
text: A driver who suffered a seizure just before a fatal car crash last year has been charged with falsely stating on his driver’s license renewal form that he did not have a medical condition that could cause unconsciousness, prosecutors said yesterday. The driver, Alexander Juwah, 44, a St. Albans psychiatrist, was charged yesterday in Criminal Court with offering a false instrument for filing, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Dr. Juwah suffered a blackout on Springfield Boulevard on Nov. 4, 2006, causing a multicar accident that killed three people and injured seven. Mr. Brown said Dr. Juwah knew that he suffered from a seizure disorder at the time he renewed his driver’s license.

headline: Central Bank Raises a Key Interest Rate
text: Australia’s central bank raised its benchmark interest rate a quarter-point to the highest rate in almost 11 years. The bank raised the overnight cash rate to 6.5 percent, the first adjustment since November, to curb inflation running faster than the bank had forecast and to cool the biggest surge in lending since 1989. The increase might undermine Prime Minister John Howard’s campaign this year to win a fifth term. “This does not help the government in the lead-up to the campaign,” said John Edwards, the chief economist at HSBC Bank Australia in Sydney.

headline: No. 757 for Bonds Follows Long Night
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8 — Barry Bonds pulled a maple bat out of the rack for batting practice, began swinging it and said that he felt weak.

headline: A House That’s Just Unreal
text: FROM the roof deck of Sherman Ochs’s Mexican-style villa atop a breezy bluff, the entire island of Jalisco, population about 20, spreads out below. It is a picturesque place of palm trees, lush lawns and near-cloudless skies. And, of course, there are the perfect sands around the lagoon, where residents grind their perfect bodies together in an N.C.L., or Naked Conga Line. It is not exactly real, of course: Mr. Ochs is Don Ainsworth, a 57-year-old retired music teacher who lives in Ventura, Calif., and Jalisco is a sim (for simulator), a plot of land in Second Life, the virtual world introduced in 2003 by Linden Lab, a San Francisco company.

headline: Equity Firm Invests in NBC Universal-News Corp. Online Venture
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8 — The joint venture between NBC Universal and the News Corporation to bring their television shows and movies onto the Internet still lacks a Web site. It still has no name. It also has yet to announce a clear mission that persuades the large number of skeptical observers that real-world rivals can cooperate online.

headline: Sales Outpace Inventories at Wholesalers
text: Sales at United States wholesalers rose faster than inventories in June, increasing the chances that companies will order more from factories and help offset the housing recession.

headline: Walkie-Talkies for Chat and Emergency Alerts
text: Walkie-talkies have long been an alternative to cellphones for keeping in touch with family members and fellow adventurers on camping trips or Disney World jaunts  and without burning monthly minutes or suffering from lack of signal coverage. Motorola’s new Talkabout T9580RSAME two-way radios take communication even further by broadcasting emergency alerts through the handset as well.

headline: A Morning of Misery Amid Sweltering Company
text: At high noon yesterday, in the steamy subway station at Times Square, two sweating women were at dueling distance.

headline: Blockbuster Acquires Movielink
text: The video rental chain Blockbuster said yesterday that it had acquired the Internet movie provider Movielink to offer video downloading services to customers.

headline: Go Ahead, Expect Surprises
text: Artists make great exhibition curators. They have expert eyes, a personal stake in the game and contacts with all kinds of other artists, including those who ride under the establishment radar. Museum surveys of contemporary art rarely produce surprises. Artist-organized gallery shows almost always do.

headline: Internet Radio Made Easier
text: You’ve heard of air pollution and noise pollution? Don’t look now, but another depressing form of toxicity is taking the fun out of life: ad pollution. That’s the creeping commercial crud that has sapped the pleasure out of TV, faxes, e-mail and, of course, radio. These days, it seems as though AM radio has 52 minutes of ads an hour.

headline: Golf’s Wild Kingdom
text: Sometimes birdies and eagles aren’t enough. Occasionally, moose, bears, elk and wolves are necessary ingredients for a complete golf experience. They are all part of the Big Sky allure. Situated midway between Bozeman and Yellowstone National Park in southern Montana, Big Sky Resort is best known for its uncrowded downhill ski facilities, which were developed in part by Chet Huntley, the native Montanan and legendary newsman, in the early 1970s. Perhaps the region’s biggest boost came via the 1992 film, “A River Runs Through It,” which featured a section of the Gallatin River near Big Sky. Fifteen years after its “I have to go there” moment, Big Sky is busting out again, this time as a golf destination. Among the new real estate communities are Yellowstone Club and the more accessible Spanish Peaks, which opened its private Tom Weiskopf-designed golf course on Aug. 3. With its mountain vistas and 7,000-foot elevation, this is breathtaking golf, indeed. Public players tee it up at Big Sky Golf Course, a flattish, if scenic early Arnold Palmer layout. If you like your golf on the wild side, walk this way.

headline: A Korean Bridge Must Span Years of Bias and Sadness
text: SOROK ISLAND, South Korea — After the clod-covered offramp is smoothed over with asphalt, after the road signs are put up and the construction cranes taken down, a bridge, long anticipated, will open here in September. Spanning a third of a mile over seawater, it will connect this islet to the Korean mainland for the first time.

headline: Last of a Kind Has Some Words for Woods
text: Tulsa, Okla.

headline: Barry Bonds at 756*
text: The natural curve of a baseball slugger’s performance resembles the arc of a high, looping home run  up and up and up and then, inevitably, down and down. The ball can do nothing about gravity, and, ideally, the athlete can do nothing about growing older except to learn, if he hasn’t already, a certain patience and grace.

headline: When the Burden of Status Is Too Much to Shoulder
text: JEAN TOUITOU, the irrepressible designer of the influential French label A.P.C., makes no bones about his disdain for kitchen-sink-size status bags. They “belong to the trash bin of fashion history,” he stated, or rather spewed, via e-mail. “They’re so vulgar even a hooker shouldn’t wear them. That would be bad for her business.” O.K., so they’re not for everyone.

headline: Win for J. Lo, Loss for O. J.
text: Jennifer Lopez, below, whose net worth is estimated by Forbes magazine at $110 million, added about $545,000 after an award by a Los Angeles arbitrator in Ms. Lopez’s lawsuit to muzzle her first husband’s efforts to publish a tell-all book about their 11-month marriage, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. Lopez sued her former husband Ojani Noa for breach of contract, maintaining that the book violated an agreement not to divulge details of their relationship. Court papers on Wednesday showed that the arbitrator, Richard Chernick, had ordered Mr. Noa to give Ms. Lopez all copies of materials relating to the book and enjoined him from “criticizing, denigrating, casting in a negative light or otherwise disparaging” Ms. Lopez. ... O. J. Simpson has been ordered to pay the family of Ron Goldman any money he earns from a video game featuring his likeness, The Associated Press reported. A Los Angeles judge ordered that the money from the game, “All-Pro Football 2K,” be turned over to Mr. Goldman’s father, Fred Goldman, to satisfy a wrongful-death judgment now valued at $38 million in connection with the death of Ron Goldman, who was slain with Mr. Simpson’s former wife Nicole Brown Simpson in 1994.

headline: Using Technology and a Pint-Size Guitar for Big-Time Songs
text: There are no strings to break on Hasbro’s $70 Power Tour Electric Guitar, coming next month to stores and to hasbro.com/tiger. Instead, your fingers glide on a glassy, lighted fret board that picks up the electrical charge of your fingers  not unlike your computer touchpad  to sense the pitch.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 9 P.M. (Discovery) LOBSTERMEN: JEOPARDY AT SEA Now that the sharks have retreated, it’s time for other scary creatures of the deep  and the anglers who put their lives at risk so we can eat them. Tonight in this series premiere the territorial crews of five boats prepare to lay claim to their portions of the sea.

headline: Bush Says Iraqi Leader Shares His View on Iran
text: President Bush said today that he was confident that Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq shared the White House’s view that Iran is a destabilizing force in the region. Mr. Bush’s remarks came after Mr. Maliki visited to Tehran for talks with Iranian government officials on security in Iraq.

headline: Alou’s Homer Gives Mets an Edge in the Game and Perhaps Beyond
text: Moises Alou stepped to the plate in the eighth inning last night with the score tied and so much more hanging in the balance. The Atlanta Braves were trying to prove that they — not the first-place Mets — were the team to beat in the National League East. The Braves already had a good argument, having beaten the Mets in 7 of the 10 games they had faced each other this season.

headline: Japan: Mobile Phone Company’s Profit Surges
text: The Softbank Corporation, the Japanese mobile phone company, posted an eighteenfold increase in first-quarter profit after adding users at a pace twice that of the market leader, NTT DoCoMo. Net income rose to 25.1 billion yen ($211 million), or 22.36 yen a share, in the three months that ended June 30, from 1.42 billion yen, or 0.81 yen a share, a year earlier, Softbank said. Earnings were helped by one-time gains. Operating profit rose 45 percent, to 78.7 billion yen. Softbank cut prices to as little as 980 yen a month, the lowest in Japan, and said it would extend coverage by installing more base stations. Overall sales at Softbank, which controls 17 percent of the mobile market, increased 34 percent, to 663.1 billion yen.

headline: Gaza Could Face Economic Meltdown, U.N. Warns
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 9 — The United Nations issued a severe warning today that Gaza could face an economic meltdown with “disastrous consequences” unless the main border crossings into the territory are reopened.

headline: Britain Eases Livestock Restrictions
text: LONDON, Aug. 9 — British authorities relaxed their ban on the movement of livestock in the country today, a sign that the outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease, a highly contagious and potentially devastating virus, was coming under control.

headline: Cable Networks Boost News Corp. Earnings
text: The News Corporation reported strong quarterly earnings yesterday, but the announcement was upstaged by Rupert Murdoch’s comments on the company’s recent deal to buy the publisher of The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Louis Moyse, Founder of Music School, Dies at 94
text: Louis Moyse, a flutist, composer and founder of the Marlboro Music School and Festival, died on July 30 in Barre, Vt. He was 94 and lived in Montpelier, Vt.

headline: That Wind That Left Part of Brooklyn Upside Down? It Was a Tornado, All Right
text: It took experts until late in the afternoon yesterday to confirm what many in southwestern Brooklyn knew had descended on their neighborhoods as a new workday dawned. It was a tornado — the first to hit Brooklyn since modern record-keeping began — and it turned whole sections of Sunset Park and Bay Ridge upside down.

headline: Georgia Seeks U.N. Security Council Session About Missile
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 8  The Republic of Georgia presented what it called a mounting body of evidence on Wednesday that a Russian warplane had entered deep into its airspace and fired an air-to-ground missile. It said it was seeking a special session of the United Nations Security Council to address the matter.

headline: With One U.S.B. Hub, the Whole Network Can Access Peripherals
text: The modern PC is a constellation of devices orbiting a humming box. But now U.S.B. devices don’t have to be tied to one computer.

headline: Glue Maker for Big Dig Is Charged in ’06 Death
text: BOSTON, Aug. 8  The supplier of the epoxy that federal officials have blamed for the collapse of a Big Dig tunnel was indicted Wednesday in the death of a woman crushed by falling ceiling panels.

headline: Frank Rosenfelt, Studio Chief, Dies at 85
text: Frank E. Rosenfelt, who as a top executive at MGM helped steer the studio into new ways of making and showing movies, as well as acquiring and producing movies like “Doctor Zhivago” and “Network,” died Aug. 2 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 85.

headline: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Decides Not to Endorse for Now, Freeing Unions to Do So
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 8 — The A.F.L.-C.I.O.’s executive council voted on Wednesday against endorsing any presidential candidate, reflecting divisions over which Democrat to support and setting the stage for its 55 member unions to make individual endorsements.

headline: Little Building Defies Beijing’s Olympic Ambitions
text: BEIJING, Aug. 8 — Beijing observed the one-year countdown to the 2008 Olympics on Wednesday night with fireworks and pageantry at a celebration in Tiananmen Square. A few blocks away, Sun Ruoyu and her sister saw the streaks of color in the sky but did not dare leave their battered home.

headline: Tracking Fugitives, With French Nail Tips
text: How have female bounty hunters become a feature of the modern world? Three developments appear to have made it inevitable: Google, G.P.S. and Taser.

headline: Generals Don’t Need a Watchdog
text: BY now, most Americans know the story of Cpl. Pat Tillman. He bravely chose military service rather than the National Football League, and he was killed in Afghanistan in 2004 by fire from his comrades.

headline: A Patriarch Holds Court at His Own Party
text: “I got to tell you one more,” B. B. King said from the stage on Tuesday night, “and then I’m going to work.” And he spun another story about how he secretly loves the way beautiful young women pat old men on the head, and how he never saw an electric light bulb until he was 16, or how bringing a pile of paper money back home to your sweetheart isn’t as effective as it used to be.

headline: Fossils in Kenya Challenge Linear Evolution
text: Two fossils found in Kenya have shaken the human family tree, possibly rearranging major branches thought to be in a straight ancestral line to Homo sapiens.

headline: To Savor the Local Flavors, Head to the Airport
text: Airports have never been known for selling delectable food, but as the travel industry grows and airports strive to distinguish themselves, food and beverage courts are diversifying, too. For local brands, that can mean landing a tiny space in a big terminal and attracting lots of customers.

headline: Fans Risk Their Safety for Prized Homers
text: Matt Murphy, a Mets fan in a José Reyes jersey, emerged Tuesday night bloodied but potentially wealthier from his successful sortie to retrieve Barry Bonds’s 756th home run ball from dozens of San Franciscans at AT&T Park. Murphy, of Elmhurst, Queens, was led from the scrum to safety by two police officers.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about a study contending that French fries at some fast-food restaurants in New York still have high amounts of trans fat, despite the city’s restrictions on its use, misidentified the Manhattan restaurant shown at lunchtime. It was a Wendy’s, not a Burger King. (The study found that fries at both chains were high in trans fat.)

headline: Shuttle Endeavour Lifts Off Toward Space Station
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 8 — The space shuttle Endeavour lifted off into humid skies on Wednesday evening, carrying pieces of the International Space Station and a living reminder of the loss of the shuttle Challenger two decades ago.

headline: A Special Moment for a Pitcher Who Isn’t Special
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8 — The moment that provoked so much dread — among the commissioner, the public and pitchers everywhere — was saved by the man it hurt the most.

headline: When in Pain, PGA Tour Players Turn to Healer
text: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 8 — The most sought after guru at the 89th P.G.A. Championship once spent 730 days blindfolded.

headline: He Lived to Tell the Tale (and Write a Best Seller)
text: On June 7 Marcus Luttrell was discharged from the Navy, having served with the elite Seals, survived a fierce battle in Afghanistan and earned a Navy Cross for combat heroism. Less than a month later “Lone Survivor,” Mr. Luttrell’s memoir of the 2005 battle and his rescue, became a best seller.

headline: Automakers See a Weak Year for Sales
text: DETROIT, Aug. 8 — Major automakers are openly acknowledging what the rest of the country already knew: a soft housing market and high gasoline prices are damping sales of cars and light trucks.

headline: Calm Prevails as Iraqi Shiites Pilgrims Gather
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 9 — Tens of thousands of Shiite pilgrims converged on a shrine in western Baghdad on Thursday to honor an 8th century Imam, chanting and waving flags as they moved through the streets, but there were few instances of the violence that has blemished previous celebrations.

headline: Government May Raise Limits on Home-Loan Purchases
text: Alphonso R. Jackson, the secretary of housing and urban development, said yesterday that the government might raise the limit on purchases of home loans by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to increase liquidity in the mortgage market.

headline: Church Remembers Stalin’s Victims, While Kremlin Looks Away
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 8  A giant cross now commands the field where the first shots of Stalin’s Great Terror sounded 70 years ago. It was erected on Wednesday with religious pomp but little recognition from a government prone to whitewash one of Russia’s darkest eras.

headline: A (Very Poised) Dance on the Table
text: F. SCOTT FITZGERALD once described Daisy as “drowsing asleep at dawn with the beads and chiffon of an evening dress tangled among dying orchids.”

headline: From Two Broken Lives to One New Beginning
text: BALTIMORE, Aug. 2 — Donnie Andrews was a stickup man with a .44 Magnum who robbed drug dealers and was sentenced to life in prison for murdering one of them.

headline: Correction: Garden Q.&A.
text: An illustration of wax begonias accompanying the Garden Q. & A. column last Thursday was published in error. It should have shown sweet peas, as the caption said they were.

An obituary on Friday about the Irish musician Tommy Makem misidentified the source of an account he gave of his arrival in Boston in 1955, including his description of being told by a customs agent, “Have a great life,” and his declaration more than a half century later, “I took him at his word.” It was an interview last year with The Boston Globe, not The Associated Press.

headline: Senate Joins Knockoff Battle
text: THE movement by American designers to ban other companies from knocking off their work has gained some momentum since the idea was first introduced last year. At a news conference yesterday at the Fashion Institute of Technology, Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, talked about a bill proposing to extend copyright protection to fashion that had been introduced in the Senate last week, mirroring one that has been under consideration in the House since April 2006.

headline: Lawyers Still Like Edwards, but Spread the Wealth
text: When he ran for the 2004 Democratic presidential nomination, John Edwards, who had gained fame as one of the nation’s most successful trial lawyers, was the darling of many in the legal community, which opened its checkbooks and poured money into his campaign.

headline: Earthquake Rattles Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 — An earthquake rattled the Los Angeles area early today, shaking many people out of bed and causing officials to temporarily close a busy bridge after chunks of concrete came loose from the span.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: A Sudden Storm Brings New York City to Its Knees
text: A brief but fierce storm drenched the New York region just before the morning rush yesterday, paralyzing the transit system, flooding major thoroughfares, cutting off electricity to thousands of homes and causing confusion that lingered through a humid, sweaty day.

headline: Original Suitor Sweetens Its Barneys Offer to $942 Million
text: The fierce bidding war over Barneys New York, the luxury clothing retailer, escalated yesterday when a private equity firm from Dubai raised its offer to $942 million — $117 million more than it had originally bid for the chain.

headline: Ex-Astronaut Asks to End Use of Ankle Bracelet
text: Capt. Lisa Marie Nowak wants to get rid of her ankle bracelet.

headline: Harley’s Female Bikers (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bush Opposes Raising Gas Tax for Bridge Repairs
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9—President Bush spoke out today against an increase in the gasoline tax, an idea that is being discussed as a potential part of a new Congressional plan to shore up the nation’s bridges after last week’s deadly collapse in Minneapolis.

headline: Asians Make Broad Gains in New York Population
text: Asians were the only major racial or ethnic group to record population gains in every county in the New York metropolitan region since 2005, according to census figures released yesterday.

headline: Which Club Is More Exclusive?
text: Even as Barry Bonds was breaking the home-run record, people were predicting that Alex Rodriguez would someday overtake him. In the meantime, Tom Glavine gained his 300th victory, with seemingly fewer pitchers poised to ever reach that plateau. Which got us wondering: Is the 300-victory mark a more daunting, and impressive, achievement these days than reaching 755 home runs?

headline: Kazakhstan: Austria Rejects Extradition
text: Austria will not extradite Rakhat M. Aliyev, the former son-in-law of President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, to face kidnapping charges because there is no guarantee that he will get a fair trial in Kazakhstan, a spokesman for the Vienna public prosecutor said. He made the comments after a federal court ruled that Mr. Aliyev, until recently the Kazakh ambassador, could remain a free man in Austria. Austrian authorities are still investigating a charge of money laundering.

headline: Survivor of Newark Shootings Picks Out a Suspect
text: NEWARK, Aug. 8  The lone survivor of a schoolyard shooting that left three college students dead on Saturday night has identified a suspect in a photo array, investigators involved with the case said on Wednesday.

headline: Turning a Beer Run Into a Relay Event
text: WHEN Tara Ruotolo recruited far-flung pals and friends of friends to run the 197-mile Nike Hood to Coast relay race in northwest Oregon, she didn’t choose her partners in grime based on talent or tenacity alone.

headline: Be Yourselves, Girls, Order the Rib-Eye
text: MARTHA FLACH mentioned meat twice in her Match.com profile: “I love architecture, The New Yorker, dogs ... steak for two and the Sunday puzzle.”

headline: In the Upper Deck at Shea, Passing Time With America’s Pastime
text: A lifelong Yankees fan sat in the upper deck of Shea Stadium last night in a full Mets uniform, wearing a jersey, baseball pants and a cap, with a glove and ball in one hand. She was beaming with pride.

headline: Aid to Help Asia and Africa With Effects of Warming
text: The Rockefeller Foundation says it will invest $70 million over the next five years to help Asian cities and African farmers withstand floods, droughts and other global warming hazards.

headline: Terror Case Takes Winding Path in 2 Nations’ Courts
text: In the last two months, since federal authorities called a rare Saturday news conference to announce that four men had been charged in a plot to blow up fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport, the case has been moving forward on two tracks: one in Brooklyn, one in the Caribbean.

headline: Doctors’ Income (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Murdoch, Bound (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: When the Yankees Need His Best, Wang Delivers His Worst
text: TORONTO, Aug. 8 — To beat Roy Halladay on Wednesday, the Yankees’ Chien-Ming Wang needed to be exceptional. There may be no pitcher who is tougher on the Yankees than Halladay.

headline: Polish Minister Fired After Accusations That He Leaked Data
text: BERLIN, Aug. 8  Prime Minster Jaroslaw Kaczynski of Poland fired his interior minister on Wednesday over accusations that he had hindered a corruption investigation by leaking delicate information.

headline: Annual Exam Gives Bush Good Marks for Health
text: Though President Bush has had episodes of mild vertigo in recent weeks, they have not interfered with his work, and he is in excellent health, the White House said yesterday in releasing findings from his annual medical checkup.

headline: Today a Strong Wave, Tomorrow a Teardown
text: Amagansett, N.Y.

headline: Endless Puns With Your Inner Cat in Mind
text: IN contrast to the fog, which according to Carl Sandburg comes in on little cat feet, an unconventional campaign for a familiar pet food is arriving on every part of the cat — including the meow.

headline: Met Opera to Expand in Theaters Across Globe
text: The Metropolitan Opera plans to expand still further its live high-definition simulcasts into movie theaters around the world for the 2007-8 season, potentially tripling the audience for these broadcasts to an estimated one million viewers.

headline: Exploiting Africa’s Myths (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Emperor of Swat
text: SORRY, Barry Bonds. You’re still 112 home runs away from the home run record, the real record, that is. Hitting 756 dingers is certainly quite an achievement, more than anyone else has hit in Major League Baseball history. But it is far behind the world record, the 868 homers slugged by Sadaharu Oh when he played for the Tokyo Yomiuri Giants from 1959 to 1980.

headline: What Bright Effects You Have
text: FEELING blue? Don’t blame your serotonin or endorphins. Shades of blue may be hiding in your makeup.

headline: Bruno Case Inquiry Suspended
text: ALBANY, Aug. 8  The State Commission of Investigation said Wednesday that it would suspend its review of actions by aides to Gov. Eliot Spitzer involving the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, until the Albany County district attorney, P. David Soares, completed his own inquiry.

headline: Living and Painting by His Own Rules
text: Joe Andoe grew up in Tulsa, Okla., living a life straight out of Chuck Palahniuk’s twisted imagination. Mama was a gum-popping cutie. Little Joe was “a big slug of a baby.” His mother says she didn’t see much of him during his formative years. “My only explanation,” he writes, “is that I tried to stay the hell out of the way.”

headline: Floating Arctic Ice Shrinking at Record Rate
text: The area of floating ice in the Arctic has shrunk more than in any summer since satellite tracking began in 1979, and it has reached that record point a month before the annual ice pullback typically peaks, experts said.

headline: When High Price Is the Allure
text: WHEN readers leaf through the September issue of Vogue, which arrives on newsstands next week, they will encounter a Prada mohair twin set tagged at $2,925; a chunky Giles sweater, at $3,675; and a supersize Marc Jacobs bracelet, at $2,180. And as fall looks begin trickling into stores this month, shoppers will find basic designer sheath dresses selling for $1,200, coats for just under $4,000 and designer sunglasses for $500 or more.

headline: Former Take-Two Official Is Sentenced in Backdating Case
text: Take-Two Interactive Software’s former general counsel, Kenneth I. Selterman, was sentenced yesterday to three years of probation for falsifying a letter to regulators. He is the third former executive from the video game company, the maker of the Grand Theft Auto series, to be sentenced in a stock option backdating investigation.

headline: Queens: Gunman Sentenced to Life in Prison
text: A Jamaica man who fatally shot his father and his brother in 2002 was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to life in prison without parole, prosecutors said. The man, James Seecoomar, 38, was convicted of first-degree murder in February, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Seecoomar, a deli worker, shot his brother, Leonard, 35, in the back of the head with a revolver on March 27, 2002, as he watched television. When his father, James, 66, ran into the room, James Seecoomar shot him in the head and body, Mr. Brown said.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. How can I make a guest room more inviting?

headline: Two Are Arrested in Newark Shootings
text: NEWARK, Aug. 9  The police have arrested a 15-year-old and a 28-year-old man in connection with the schoolyard shootings on Saturday that left three college students dead and another seriously injured.

headline: Bronx: School Aide Charged in Assault
text: A 22-year-old school aide has been arrested on charges of raping and sexually abusing an eighth-grade student, the office of the special commissioner of investigation said yesterday. The aide, Anthony Casey Jr., is accused of raping the student, a 13-year-old girl attending Lola Rodriguez de Tio Junior High School in the Bronx, twice in May, the commissioner’s office said, and at least one other time in June. Some of the rapes occurred at Mr. Casey’s Bronx apartment, the office said. Mr. Casey, who was suspended without pay, worked at the school for two years.

headline: A Violinist Tones Down the Twang
text: The violinist Jenny Scheinman specializes in a slippery rusticity. Acoustic folk, Gypsy swing and country can all crop up in her music, in ways that elude classification. This is often the case in her weekly residency at Barbès in Park Slope, Brooklyn, where she interacts with a rotating cast of players. It was less obviously so on Monday night at Joe’s Pub, where she led what sounded a lot like a working band.

headline: It’s Summer: Isn’t Anyone at Work?
text: IT’S a wonder you are reading this article at all.

headline: The New Homer King (With an Explanation) (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
To Sleep the Big Sleep? Call It Murder, My Sweet
text: Among the many pleasures of classic noir films from the 1940s and ’50s is their chiseled dialogue. Goons, floozies and stoolies talk in aphorisms and one-liners, usually at machine-gun tempo. A hard-boiled dame playing coy won’t just say, “Go away,” when she can say, “That’s between me and the lamppost, and you ain’t no lamppost.” A gumshoe on the hunt always has a wisecrack in his back pocket, like, “It’s funny, but practically all the people I know were strangers when I met them.”

headline: In First Game Back, Martínez Is Hit Hard but Shrugs It Off
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Aug. 8  The last time Pedro Martínez pitched, the home plate umpire sidled up to him as he was leaving the simulated game and asked him to autograph a baseball.

headline: Hope Over Experience
text: The association of Chrysler and its new chief executive, Robert Nardelli, may go down in history as one of the most unusual matchups of corporate outcasts.

headline: Olympian Task: Measuring 26.2 Miles, to the Inch
text: Late Tuesday night and into yesterday morning, exactly one year before the start of the Beijing Olympics, two middle-aged men rode their bikes through Central Park, attending to a critical detail in the selection of America’s top male marathoners for the Games.

headline: For a Young Polish Player, One Trip Yields Two Gold Medals
text: At the 21st European Youth Team Championships in Jesolo, Italy, which ended July 21, there were three events: girls, won by Poland; junior, won by the Netherlands; and schools, won by Poland. The scheduling made it possible for someone to compete in both the girls and schools events, and Joanna Krawczyk made the most of the opportunity, picking up two gold medals.

headline: Hurdles Frustrate Effort to Shrink Guantánamo
text: The decision this week by the British government to request the return of five Guantánamo detainees with British ties was welcome news for Bush administration officials eager to cut the detention center’s population.

headline: Anger and Triumph, as Told From Front Line
text: There were minute-by-minute (and hour-by-hour) accounts of commutes thwarted — and accomplished, if in triple the usual time. There were comparisons of New York to third-world countries, of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to the Taliban.

headline: Beltrán Not Ready to Bat Right-Handed Yet
text: Carlos Beltrán is eligible to come off the disabled list today. But if his left oblique muscle is still causing him problems when he bats from the right side, he will not play in the series finale against the Atlanta Braves.

headline: Rescuers Close In on Utah Miners
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 9 — Rescuers said they were within six hours of possibly making contact with six coal miners trapped more than 1,500 feet underground by a cave-in since early Monday.

headline: Gaza: Israeli Troops Kill Hamas Gunmen
text: Three Hamas militants were killed by Israeli troops in northern Gaza. An army spokesman said two armed men were spotted approaching the perimeter fence in the morning and were killed in an exchange of fire. Hamas’s military wing said they were its members. The third, killed later in the day near the Erez crossing, was identified as a member of Hamas’s paramilitary police, known as the Executive Force.

headline: Islamic Finance and Its Critics
text: GENEVA — Before the attacks of Sept. 11, Prince Muhammad al-Faisal al-Saud felt welcome in America. A member of the Saudi royal family and a pioneer of Islamic finance, he was a pillar of a Saudi business establishment that has long relished its ties with the United States.

headline: British Criticize Air Attacks in Afghan Region
text: SANGIN, Afghanistan — A senior British commander in southern Afghanistan said in recent weeks that he had asked that American Special Forces leave his area of operations because the high level of civilian casualties they had caused was making it difficult to win over local people.

headline: Pakistanis Express Ire at Army and Musharraf
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 8 — “Before, our children would salute our soldiers when they passed. Now they spit on them.”

headline: U.S. Attack Kills 32 in Sadr City
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 8  An American raid and airstrike killed 32 people in the Shiite stronghold of Sadr City on Wednesday, in what American military officials described as an assault on a militant network bringing in money and bombs from Iran.

headline: New York Company Indicted in Collapse of Big Dig
text: BOSTON, Aug. 8 — The supplier of the epoxy that federal officials have blamed for the collapse of a Big Dig tunnel was indicted today in the death of a motorist crushed by falling ceiling panels.

headline: Dow Falls 387 Points on New Loan Fears
text: Stocks on Wall Street today suffered their biggest one-day decline since February after the turmoil in the home-loan market caused renewed concerns about tightening credit worldwide.

headline: Tip of the Week: Speed Your Online Mapping
text: TIP OF THE WEEK: If you spend a lot of time looking up locations around the United States on map sites, the Map+ add-on for the Firefox browser can save time. Once you install Map+ (available at https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/2394), you can highlight an address on a Web page and right-click on it to see a small Yahoo map of the location pop up in the Firefox window. J. D. BIERSDORFER

headline: Panel Takes Step Toward Denying Reappointment to Judge
text: A District of Columbia judicial panel has taken a first step toward denying reappointment to a local administrative law judge who sued a dry cleaner for $54 million over a pair of lost pants, said a government official who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the action concerned a personnel matter. The official said the panel voted unanimously Monday to send a formal letter to the judge, Roy L. Pearson Jr., expressing concerns about both his lawsuit against the business, Custom Cleaners, which he lost in June, and his record as a jurist. Mr. Pearson has 15 days to respond in writing and request a hearing before the panel, which could rule on his reappointment, to a 10-year term, as early as next month.

headline: David Shaw, Writer for Stage and Screen, Dies at 90
text: David Shaw, a Tony Award-winning writer for stage, screen and television, died on July 27 at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 90.

headline: Minorities Now Form Majority in One-Third of Most-Populous Counties
text: In a further sign of the United States’ growing diversity, nonwhites now make up a majority in almost one-third of the most-populous counties in the country and in nearly one in 10 of all 3,100 counties, according to an analysis of census results to be released today.

headline: In August’s Heat, Planning for Cooler Days
text: IT’S hard to think of planting anything new when temperatures are in the 90s, but now through early September is the time to plant fall greens and root crops. I need some fresh young arugula and basil to go with all those tomatoes now ripening on the vine. And beet and mustard greens are sweeter in the fall.

headline: Children and Exercise (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: From Two Broken Lives to One New Beginning
text: When Donnie Andrews and Fran Boyd got married, it was the culmination of a lengthy courtship that was as much about turning their lives around as it was about finding each other.

headline: Socializing Online
text: Today’s New York Times has an article about people who use the online community Second Life to live out their Architectural Digest-style fantasies. Second Life users “have built cities, created clothing lines and programmed their avatars — the characters that represent them in the three-dimensional space of Second Life — to ride horses, dance and have sex,” Seth Kugel writes. People use online communities to network for their real-life careers, to stay in touch with friends, and to publicize their political campaigns.

headline: On the Fringe: Dance
text: A look at some of the dance performances at the 2007 New York International Fringe Festival.

headline: Latest Transit Updates, Aug. 9: Mostly Back to Normal
text: Updated, 6 p.m. | The New York City transit system is mostly back to normal this morning, a day after a fierce storm paralyzed the subways, unleashed a tornado in Brooklyn and created misery for commuters. (For more news, see our Morning Buzz roundup.)

headline: Internet Tabletop Radios: A Comparison
Universal Music Invests in a Web Site
text: The Universal Music Group said on Wednesday that it had acquired a stake in the operator of the urban social networking Web site Loud.com.

headline: Former Take-Two Official Is Sentenced for Backdating
text: Take-Two Interactive Software‘s former general counsel, Kenneth I. Selterman, was sentenced Wednesday to three years of probation for falsifying a letter to regulators. He is the third former executive from the video game company, the maker of the Grand Theft Auto series, to be sentenced in a stock option backdating investigation.

headline: Blockbuster Acquires Movielink
text: The video rental chain Blockbuster said Wednesday that it had acquired the Internet movie provider Movielink to offer video downloading services to customers.

headline: Providence Backs NBC-News Corp. Site
text: The joint venture between NBC Universal and the News Corporation to bring their television shows and movies onto the Internet still lacks a Web site. It still has no name. It also has yet to announce a clear mission that convinces the large number of skeptical observers that real-world rivals can cooperate online.

headline: Murdoch’s Dow Comments Eclipse News Corp. Earnings
text: The News Corporation reported strong quarterly earnings Wednesday, but the announcement was upstaged by Rupert Murdoch’s comments on the company’s recent deal to buy the publisher of The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Banking on the Credit Meltdown
text: All the hand-wringing lately over how hard the investment banks and the hedge fund industry will be hit by the current market turmoil may be for naught, according to one report.

headline: Langone: Private Equity Is About a ‘Quick Buck’
text: Who benefits from private equity? That was one of the questions kicked around by participants in a panel talk during the Academy of Management’s annual conference this week. BusinessWeek framed the issue this way: “Do buyout firms like Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts add value to companies or just collect a heaping wad of cash?”

headline: At Fidelity, a Born-Again Star — or a Has-Been?
text: The resignation of Ellyn McColgan, a Fidelity executive who had been considered an heir apparent to the chairman and chief executive, Edward C. Johnson III, may have paved the way for Rodger Lawson, president of Fidelity to take the reins.

headline: Online Educator to Test Public Markets
text: American Public Education, a provider of online post-secondary education, filed Wednesday for an initial public offering of its common stock.

headline: Investors Pile on E-House Debut
text: Shares of E-House, a Chinese real-estate services company, rallied more than 40 percent Wednesday as Wall Street dove into a play on the hot real estate sector in China. The Shanghai-based company bills itself as China’s largest real estate agency and consulting services company.

headline: Sign Up Now: More Cash and Fewer Hangups for U.S. Goverment Work
text: There are a lot of reasons why a man would give up his undercover status after 30 years with the C.I.A. For Jose Rodriguez, whose identity was revealed Wednesday, it was to participate in minority recruitment events, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Dell’s Former Chief Set for $48.5 Million Payout
text: Dell said in a regulatory filing Wednesday that once it finally files an annual report, it intends to pay $48.5 million to Kevin Rollins, who resigned as its chief executive early this year. The money comes in the form of a payment in lieu of stock options, the company said.

headline: Successful Bond Sales Help Ease Fears
text: The deep freeze on corporate borrowing is showing signs of thawing, and that helped Wall Street post its third straight gain Wednesday. Although few analysts were willing to sound the all-clear for battered markets — for one, the bonds that sold well Wednesday were corporate grade — the mood has brightened significantly in the last few days.

headline: Arb Funds Feel Fallout from Credit Markets
text: Merger arbitrage hedge funds, which bet on the outcome of mergers and acquisitions, lost money in July over concern that turmoil in the credit market could derail some deals.

headline: Thomas H. Lee Partners Sued Over Refco Debacle
text: The trustee for Refco, a commodities brokerage firm that collapsed in fraud a few months after it went public in 2005, has sued Thomas H. Lee Partners, the private equity firm that controlled Refco, saying the firm should have known about the fraud before it sold stock.

headline: Fast Retailing Drops Out of Barneys Race
text: A Dubai-based investment fund appeared to have won the bidding war for Barneys New York, the luxury clothing retailer, after a rival bidder pulled out of the race Thursday.

headline: Fortis Profits Beat Expectations
text: The Belgian-Dutch financial services group Fortis, which is involved in a bidding war for the Dutch bank ABN Amro, reported a 16 percent year-on-year rise in second-quarter net profit on Thursday, beating analysts’ expectations thanks to strong banking results.

headline: Dolans’ Cablevision Offer May Be Looking Sweeter
text: The roiling credit markets and mediocre second-quarter results may be the push the Dolans, Cablevision System‘s founding family, need to persuade shareholders to green light their $36.26 a share offer to take the company private, The New York Post says.

headline: J.P. Morgan Sued by Ex-Bond Salesman in Greek Scandal
text: The former J.P. Morgan Chase salesman at the center of a Greek bond scandal is suing the bank, alleging he has been made a scapegoat.

headline: Coade Takes the V.C. Plunge
text: After resisting entreaties from would-be buyers and investors for years, an industrial design and engineering software maker, Coade, took the venture capital plunge, accepting $42 million in growth and liquidity funding from New York-based Insight Partners.

headline: Eurazeo Weaves $3.4 Billion Deal for Elis
text: Eurazeo, the French private equity firm, agreed Wednesday to buy a textile rental and cleaning service company, Elis GIE for 2.28 billion euros ($3.14 billion) from PAI Partners.

headline: Dubai’s OMX Move Threatens Nasdaq’s $3.7 Billion Deal
text: Dubai Borse on Thursday announced it is seeking to buy up to 25 percent of shares in OMX, the Nordic exchanges and technology group at 230 krona per share, threatening to derail an the Nasdaq Stock Market‘s agreed 25.1 billion-krona ($3.7 billion) bid for the Nordic exchanges and technology group.

headline: Rosneft Gobbles Up More Yukos Assets
text: Rosneft won another Yukos bankruptcy auction, buying key transport assets, including those used for exports to China, as it continued its drive to swallow up what was once Russia’s biggest oil producer.

headline: RBS to Delay British Hotel Sale, Report Says
text: The Royal Bank of Scotland has postponed the sale of a 1.1 billion-pound ($2.23 billion) British hotel portfolio because of spiraling costs in the wake of a global credit crunch, Reuters reported citing an unnamed source. It is not yet clear whether the deal has been permanently scrapped or simply delayed until the costs of borrowing and insuring debt have steadied, Reuters said.

headline: Wesfarmers Sweetens Coles Offer to Save Deal
text: Australia’s Wesfarmers, whose takeover of the Coles Group is in jeopardy because of a slide in its stock, said shareholders in the supermarket chain can opt for more cash as it seeks to make the offer more attractive.

headline: Tata May Gulp Down AriZona, Report Says
text: India’s Tata Tea is interested in acquiring AriZona Beverages and the Tata Group could make a $2 billion buyout offer, The Economic Times said on Thursday, citing unnamed sources.

headline: Ryerson Defends Its Buyout
text: The steel services company Ryerson on Wednesday defended its $1 billion deal to be bought by Platinum Equity, despite opposition from a hedge fund, Harbinger Capital Partners, and said it had extensive discussions with potential buyers.

headline: Campbell Soup Says It May Sell Godiva
text: Campbell Soup said it may sell its Godiva Chocolatier luxury chocolate brand to focus on soups, snacks and drinks. “We are exploring strategic alternatives, which also includes the divestiture of Godiva,” a Campbell spokesman, Anthony Sanzio, said to Bloomberg News.

headline: Morning Buzz: Chronicling a Day of Chaos
text: The punishing thunderstorm that paralyzed the subways and sent a tornado roaring over parts of Brooklyn and Staten Island thoroughly dominated the local coverage in New York City’s newspapers today.The transit system is mostly back to normal, with some delays. City Room has posted the latest updates.

headline: As Liquidity Exits Subprime, Enter Wilbur Ross
text: Wilbur Ross’s $50 million investment in American Home Mortgage Investment during the lender’s bankruptcy reorganization will apparently not be the last for the investor in distressed companies. In a Q&A with BusinessWeek, Mr. Ross said that he sees attractive targets in the subprime sector.

headline: Paribas Freezes Funds as Subprime Woes Keep Spreading
text: Anyone know how to say “subprime” in French?

headline: Home Depot Says Supply Unit May Be Sold for Less
text: The ongoing troubles in the debt markets may have rocked yet another major buyout. On Thursday, Home Depot said it is in talks with the three private equity firms that agreed to buy its supply unit — discussions that may lead to a lower price than the agreed-upon $10.325 billion. Home Depot also said it would cut the price it is offering in its share buyback.

headline: Pakistan’s Emergency-Rule Trial Balloon?
text: It all started on Wednesday night in Pakistan, according to Reuters. Television stations started reporting that Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the embattled president, was about to declare emergency rule, which would increase the military’s powers and postpone elections.

headline: In Search of a Stance on Iraq
text: The Associated Press is reporting that some of the biggest critics of the Iraq war seems to be softening their stances, or at least hedging their bets:

headline: The Spitzer Investigations: A Primer
text: Even a keen and avid follower of Albany politics might have trouble keeping straight all the different investigations and potential investigations currently swirling around the Spitzer administration, not to mention a whole lot of other people. So let’s play catch-up.

headline: 2008: Dueling Primaries
text: In a game of political one-upsmanship that is likely to shake up the 2008 election calendar, the South Carolina Republican party is expected to set a Jan. 19 date for its G.O.P. primary – moving its nominating contest ahead of Florida’s by more than a week.

headline: The Decline and Fall of the Typing Wife
text: In the unlikely event that someone decides to compile an online anthology called “Best American Blog Posts 2007” – please don’t, by the way – I know one that ought to make it into the book’s literary/academic section.

headline: Sudan to Free Mia Farrow’s Rebel
text: Suleiman Jamous, the confined Sudanese rebel leader who Mia Farrow offered to trade places with, will be freed when peace talks to end war and strife in Darfur begin, a top Sudanese official said today. The rebels would like the talks to start in two or three months.

headline: Dialing for Conundrums
text: A mind-tingling conundrum, posed by email today by reader George D:

headline: Five Fun Little Gadgets
text: I do a lot of stuff for The Times: a weekly print column, this weekly e-column, a daily blog, a weekly audio podcast and a weekly video. As a result, I can never blame people who get these various efforts confused ("I got your podcast in my e-mail today!"), or who have no idea that the videos, for example, even exist.

headline: Which Club Is More Exclusive?
text: Even as Barry Bonds closed in on the home-run record, people were already predicting that Alex Rodriguez would someday overtake him. In the meantime, Tom Glavine gained his 300th victory, with seemingly fewer pitchers poised to ever reach that plateau. Which got us wondering: Is the 300-victory mark a more daunting, and impressive, achievement these days than reaching 755 home runs?

headline: Next Week
text: The newsletter next week will look at some more of the stories covered in the new issue of the magazine, including the cover story, a profile of Serena Williams, the most exciting player in women's tennis, on the eve of the U.S. Open.

headline: Beltran a Model Citizen of Baseball
text: Carlos Beltran said this morning that he is still feeling discomfort from the right side the plate. He is ready to come off the 15-day disabled list today but still appears to be a few days away from playing in a game.

headline: Verón, M.L.S.’s Failure to Sign Him, and the Legacy of the N.A.S.L.
text: You may remember the stir a couple of weeks ago when it seemed the increasingly venerable Argentine star Juan Sebastian Verón might leave his hometown club, Estudiantes de La Plata, and sign with D.C. United. That has not come to pass — on Sunday Verón opened the season with Estudiantes in an atmosphere he’d never encounter in the M.L.S.: a packed stadium full of passionate fans, celebrating the club’s centennial, no less.

headline: Q & A: Fighting Racism in European Soccer
text: When U.S. international DaMarcus Beasley and his Rangers teammate Jean-Claude Darcheville were reportedly the victims of racist abuse during a Champions League qualifier against FK Zeta in Montenegro, UEFA said it would investigate. It would not the first time such ugly behavior at a soccer match has marred the game.

headline: Gannett: Reading Between the Lines
text: With Dow Jones & Company set to become part of Rupert Murdoch’s media empire, Gannett is sometimes touted as the next potential takeover target in the newspaper industry. But it is so huge — with a market capitalization of nearly $11 billion — that it is hard to imagine who the acquirer would be. Jon Morton, a newspaper analyst, told The New York Times in June that only a big, non-media buyer — he mentioned General Electric or a buyout firm — could possibly do such a deal, and even that’s unlikely.

headline: The Venice Biennale With a Guide
text: We are planning to go to the Venice Biennale in October and would like to get an in-depth view of the exhibitions with a knowledgeable guide. I would appreciate suggestions on how to book one. Alternatively, are there tours that concentrate on the biennale?

headline: Pay to Learn?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Primary Primacy
text: Election ‘07? South Carolina’s Republicans are going to move their presidential primaries to Jan. 16, 2008, which will likely set off a domino effect in New Hampshire, Iowa and elsewhere, “that could push the start of voting to New Year’s Day or even to before Christmas,” according to The Washington Post.

headline: Blogtalk: Red Cross Crossfire
text: Johnson & Johnson’s trademark-rights suit against the Red Cross, covered in The New York Times today, has triggered a torrent of blog headlines filled with disbelief and outrage. Here are some examples:

headline: Help NBC and News Corp. Pick a Brand Name
text: We reported today that NBC-Universal and the News Corporation raised a heady $100 million from Providence Equity Partners for its new online video venture.

headline: A Banker, a Bronfman and a Big Deal
text: Charles Murphy, until recently a top European banker at Credit Suisse, is apparently doing well in his new gig with Fairfield Greenwich Group, a hedge fund that, despite its Connecticut-sounding name, is based in New York, according to its Web site.

headline: The Abner Louima Case, 10 Years Later
text: Ten years ago today, a 30-year-old Haitian immigrant named Abner Louima was arrested and sodomized with a broomstick inside a restroom in the 70th Precinct station house in Brooklyn. The case became a national symbol of police brutality and fed perceptions that New York City police officers were harassing or abusing young black men as part a citywide crackdown on crime.The case also marked the beginning of the unraveling of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani’s relationship with the black community in New York. That relationship would deteriorate even further, after the police shot two unarmed black men, Amadou Diallo in February 1999 and Patrick Dorismond in 2000.

headline: South Carolina Pushes Up Primary
text: Fasten your seatbelts, as Bette Davis once advised, it’s going to be a bumpy ride.

headline: Wachovia Analyst Is Latest Buyout-Firm Convert
text: Another equity analyst has jumped into the buyout business. Joel Houck, formerly of Wachovia Capital Markets, has taken a job with American Capital Strategies, which said in a press release that he will oversee a new closed-end fund.

headline: The Fringe Festival
text: Melena Ryzik of The Times attends the opening night party of the 2007 New York International Fringe Festival.

headline: Clearing Out My Closet
text: I do a lot of stuff for The Times: a weekly print column, a weekly e-column, a daily blog, a weekly audio podcast and a weekly video. As a result, I can never blame people who get these various efforts confused (“I got your podcast in my e-mail today!”), or who have no idea that the videos, for example, even exist.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Roadside Stand? Also: Beach Advisories and Bad Summer Guests
text: Maybe you weren’t aware of it, but this is National Farmers Market Week, which brings to mind fresh corn, and roadside stands in general that we pass on our way to our weekend getaways.

headline: ‘Mi Aura’
text: Aura Estrada, 30, an essayist and the wife of the novelist Francisco Goldman, has died, apparently in a surfing accident while on vacation in Mexico in late July, according to Hunter College, where she was a second-year M.F.A. student. As part of the program, Estrada worked as a research assistant for Toni Morrison.

headline: Another Wall St. Chief Aligns With Clinton
text: Financial bigwigs continue to line up behind Hillary Clinton: The latest is Goldman Sachs chief executive Lloyd Blankfein. The endorsements are only adding fuel to a debate about whether Wall Street’s backing — and its money — are assets or liabilities for the Democratic presidential candidate.

headline: McLaren sets record straight
text: McLaren Mercedes today issued a statement that it says was done at the request of Lewis Hamilton, in order to set the record straight about how the two drivers are not enemies and how Hamilton did not swear at Ron Dennis after qualifying at the race in Budapest.

headline: Navy Divers Make Gains in Bridge Recovery Effort
text: Updated, 5:02 PM Eastern The official death toll in the Minneapolis bridge collapse ticked up to seven today with the discovery of two bodies in the wreckage in the Mississippi River, the Hennepin Sherriff’s Department announced.

headline: Rearming Japan
text: Will Japan eventually shed its pacifist constitution and develop a full-fledged military once again?

headline: Parking Lot in Dumbo Becomes a Public Plaza
text: The city’s Department of Transportation has transformed a once-forlorn triangular parking lot in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn into a public plaza with seats, tables, potted trees and an asphalt “floor,” painted green. The new public space marks the start of a citywide Public Plaza Initiative, an element of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s PlaNYC 2030 plan for environmental sustainability, which calls for adding 800 acres of new public space by 2030.

headline: Why Is Home Depot Back at the Table?
text: News that Home Depot may receive less than $10.3 billion for the sale of its professional supply unit helped drive the home-improvement retailer’s shares down more than 4.8 percent in afternoon trading Thursday. But despite the company’s terse explanation that financing conditions prompted the move, we’re still skeptical.

headline: M.T.A. Girds for Possible Flash Floods
text: Updated 5:31 p.m.

headline: Randolph Not Caught Up in Pedro’s Numbers
text: Manager Willie Randolph said today that he was not concerned about the negative statistics that Pedro Martinez posted Wednesday, his first minor league start since having rotator-cuff surgery last October.

headline: August Heat Burns More Hedge Funds
text: The recent wild swings of the stock market have wreaked havoc on yet more hedge funds. A publicly traded fund run by a unit of J.P. Morgan Chase has lost 5.3 percent of its value since the beginning of the month, while yet another fund run by Goldman Sachs suffered an 11 percent loss for July.

headline: Reality Bites
text: I woke up suddenly at 3 a.m. as if a phone was ringing or a child was calling. I listened for what had disturbed me, but everything was silent except for the sound of my heart pounding.

headline: Out and About: Aquagrill
text: I’m familiar with the longstanding rule: no oysters in months that don’t have an ‘r’ in them. And I continue to disobey it, for two reasons.

headline: ‘American Idol’ It’s Not
text: According to mediabistro.com’s TVNewser, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Democratic forum televised Tuesday night on MSNBC “was the lowest rated-yet of the eight primary debates/forums held this election season. Based on live + same day data, Nielsen found the debate had 960,000 total viewers and 340,000 viewers in the 25-54 demo.”

headline: SuperLiga Telecasts Doing O.K. in N.Y.
text: While the SuperLiga may not provide a particularly accurate measure of the strength of M.L.S. clubs vs. Mexican clubs (e.g., all the matches are played at the home grounds of the U.S. clubs), it is having some modest success on another front: generating interest in the United States — or at least in New York.

headline: Blogtalk: Hansen on Global Warming, the Tornado’s Path, an M.T.A. Spoof, and the High Cost of Cake in Fort Greene
text: What we’re reading on the local blogs…

headline: A Testy Exchange on Health Care
text: LAS VEGAS – Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton just had an awfully testy exchange over universal health care with an audience member here at the National Association of Black Journalists conference – a lively moment that ended with an artful diss from Mrs. Clinton that had the audience hooting.

headline: Movie Minutes: '2 Days in Paris'
text: Movie Critic Stephen Holden reviews "2 Days in Paris,"  starring Adam Goldberg and Julie Delpy, who also directed.

headline: Breaking Out of the Pack in Iowa
text: On the trail with the Republicans in the days before the Ames Straw Poll.

headline: Podcast: New York, Gateway to the Nation
text: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

text: What is the difference between a service advisory and a service alert?

headline: Renaissance Sculpture
text: Images from "Desiderio" at the National Gallery of Art.

headline: Frugal Traveler: American Road Trip
text: The summer is ending and so is Matt's trip.  On his last and final week, he drives up the Pacific coast to Seattle, his final destination.

headline: Back to Basics
text: This summer in Chelsea, the group shows have a more pronounced shift away from language and images and toward fairly raw materials.

headline: The Last-Minute C.E.O. Switch at Chrysler
text: From DealBook colleague Micheline Maynard, more on the surprise pick of Robert L. Nardelli as Chrysler‘s new chief executive:

headline: Clinton Discussed Use of Nuclear Weapons
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has criticized Senator Barack Obama for saying he would rule out using nuclear weapons to root out terrorists in Afghanistan or Pakistan, made a similar comment regarding Iran last year, before she became a presidential candidate.

headline: Dow Falls 387 Points on Loan Fears
text: Stocks on Wall Street suffered their biggest one-day decline  since February.

headline: Debate Proliferation
text: Debates seem to be taking on a new role in presidential politics. There is another one tonight, with most of the Democratic candidates scheduled to show up in Los Angeles to talk about gay issues.

headline: Veoh vs. Copyright Holders: Is a War Brewing?
text: Internet video service Veoh has gone to a southern California federal district court to seek protection from a possible lawsuit from Universal Music Group, according to Reuters.

headline: I Cough Up My Ill-Gotten Gains
text: Last week I wrote about farm subsidies and noted that every year I get paid $588 not to grow crops in an Oregon forest. It’s one more example of how ludicrous the agriculture subsidy system is. But when I complained about it, lots of you called me on it. You said, in effect, that if I objected to the system giving me the farm subsidy, I should reject it or at least give it to charity.

headline: Saving Babies
text: In today’s column I note that health interventions seem to be among the more effective kinds of foreign aid. An interesting working paper from the IMF confirms that. It finds:

headline: Iraqi Exiles in Jordan
text: Zeinab Majid describes fleeing her war-torn homeland and her new life in Amman.

headline: Iraqi Exiles in Jordan
text: Zeinab Majid describes fleeing her war-torn homeland and her new life in Amman.

headline: Golf Royalty
