headline: The Group Shows
text: Where and when to see the shows mentioned, all in Chelsea:

headline: Germany: Strike Affects Telecom
text: Deutsche Telekom, the largest phone company in Europe, reported a fifth consecutive decline in quarterly profit after a strike led to more fixed-line customer losses. Second-quarter net income fell to 608 million euros ($831 million) from, 1.02 billion euros a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 2.9 percent, to 15.6 billion euros. Revenue from abroad topped German sales for the first time after Deutsche Telekom lost 516,000 traditional phone lines in its home market while it added mobile phone customers in the United States. To help meet a 2 billion-euro cost-reduction goal this year, Deutsche Telekom moved 50,000 service employees into the new T- Service unit and cut their salaries, starting the biggest strike in more than a decade. The six-week strike ended in June after the Ver.di union agreed to a compromise reduction.

headline: Side by Side at a Crash Site, and Love Amid the Bodies
text: The three lives that intertwine in “Human Error,” a new play by Keith Reddin at the Atlantic Theater Company’s Stage 2, are not individually particularly interesting. Mr. Reddin, though, gets something out of them by simple juxtaposition, showing admirable subtlety in the process.

headline: Dancer Pleads Guilty
text: Nilas Martins, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet and the son of Peter Martins, the company’s master in chief, pleaded guilty yesterday in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., to a reduced charge of disorderly conduct stemming from his arrest there on July 3, when he was charged with felony possession of cocaine. City Court Judge Douglas Mills sentenced Mr. Martins, 40, to 40 hours of community service and ordered him to undergo a drug and alcohol test. Outside of court, his lawyer, E. Stewart Jones Jr., said Mr. Martins welcomed the test. “He does not use drugs,” Mr. Jones said. “He has not used drugs. He will never, ever use drugs.” He added that Mr. Martins took the plea to protect another, unidentified person who was with him in his car when he was arrested by a passing police officer in Saratoga Springs, where the company was in summer residence.

headline: On the Roof, a Weaning From Weeding
text: YOU should hurry up and see my roof garden. This year we still have our view of the Manhattan cityscape in its full gleaming glory, all the way from South Ferry to the Empire State. But thanks to the charmless chunk of schmancy condos now going up on Brooklyn’s Fourth Avenue (the Champs Élysées of auto parts stores), the rooftop sunsets we savored in summers past were, it turns out, our last.

headline: France: Bear, Farmers’ Foe, Killed by Car
text: Franska, one of five brown bears from Slovenia let loose in the French Pyrenees to increase the native bear population, was killed in a collision with a car, according to the police. The driver was unhurt, and the police said they would investigate. Opposition to the repopulation plan has been fierce, with local farmers accusing Franska of killing as many as 150 sheep. “If people had only listened to us, Franska would be living a happy and peaceful life in Slovenia,” Bernard Moules, a farmers’ union official, told Agence France-Presse.

headline: Comprenez-Vous Woody Allen Films? Here’s a Paris Version
text: The metabolism of Julie Delpy’s biting romantic comedy “2 Days in Paris” runs full tilt from the opening scene, of lovers asleep on a fast train from Venice. Once they awaken, the pace accelerates even further, and you strain not to miss a word of their smart, revealing and frequently crazy repartee.

headline: To See the World in Ballpoint Pen
text: The attraction for artists of the ballpoint pen has grown over the years, particularly in affectedly informal contemporary drawing.

headline: U.S. Backs Free Elections, Only to See Allies Lose
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates Aug. 9 — Lebanon’s political spin masters have been trying in recent days to explain the results of last Sunday’s pivotal by-election, which saw a relatively unknown candidate from the opposition narrowly beat a former president, Amin Gemayel.

headline: When Stars (Celestial) Fall, and Stars (Hollywood) Fly
text: In “Stardust,” a sprawling, effects-laden fairy tale with the thundering stamina of a marathon horse race, Michelle Pfeiffer is Lamia, as deliciously evil a witch as the movies have ever invented. Shooting deadly green lightning from rings on her tapering long-nailed fingers, she suggests a seriously lethal beauty contestant of a certain age who will stop at nothing to seize the crown.

headline: Democrats Voice Support of Gay Rights in TV Forum
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 — Six Democratic presidential candidates participated Thursday night in a televised forum devoted to gay issues. All voiced strong support for equal rights and government benefits for gay Americans, though the three leading candidates said they opposed same-sex marriage.

headline: Two Bushes in a Book Deal
text: Laura Bush and her daughter Jenna will write a children’s book for HarperCollins. The book, as yet untitled, to be published in English and Spanish in the spring, is set in a school where a mischievous little boy learns the fun of reading with the help of his teacher. An announcement yesterday from HarperCollins said the story, with illustrations by Denise Brunkus, is loosely based on the authors’ experiences as teachers. Their net proceeds and a portion of the publisher’s proceeds are to go to two national teacher programs.

headline: Industrial Echoes in Michigan’s Copper Country
text: FOUR hundred feet underground, in a musty, dripping passage into the Quincy Mine, Ed Yarbrough pointed to a dark opening in the wall. “Here’s an old explosives bin,” he said, tracing a flashlight beam along the rock, “hence the no-smoking sign.”

headline: Divers Find More Remains in Wreckage of Bridge
text: A week after divers in Minneapolis began searching the Mississippi River near the wreckage of a massive bridge collapse, they found the remains of at least two people yesterday, bringing the confirmed death toll in the collapse to at least seven, with others still missing.

headline: Relatives of Victims to Have Access to Ground Zero on 9/11 Anniversary
text: Relatives of those killed on Sept. 11, 2001, at the World Trade Center will be allowed to descend briefly into the ground zero site on the sixth anniversary of the attack, City Hall said yesterday. The decision was the result of a compromise reached by the families and the mayor’s office on this year’s commemoration of the day.

headline: Stem Cell Amendment Changes Little in Missouri
text: ST. LOUIS — When Missouri voters approved a constitutional amendment last November protecting human embryonic stem cell research, it was viewed as a key endorsement of the research even in states with deep religious roots and strong antiabortion forces like this one.

headline: A New Kind of Bank Run Tests Old Safeguards
text: A few generations ago, savers responded to financial panics with runs on banks, and even healthy institutions could fail if they could not raise enough cash quickly enough.

headline: Harry Potter and the Leopard-Walk- Up-to-Dragon
text: Harry becomes a fat, hairy dwarf after being caught in a “sour and sweet rain”; he loses all his magic and can get it back only by obtaining the magic ring. After he does, Harry becomes a dragon that fights evil. Voldemort has an even more powerful brother who makes trouble for Harry.

headline: Pavarotti Is Hospitalized
text: Luciano Pavarotti has been hospitalized in stable condition with a fever in Modena, Italy, his hometown, The Associated Press reported. The local daily, Il Resto del Carlino, reported that he was suffering from pneumonia. Officials and his manager said Mr. Pavarotti, 71, who underwent surgery for pancreatic cancer last year, was expected to be released in a few days.

headline: ’08 Landscape in Flux as States Seek to Change the Rules
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 — When state Democratic leaders from around the country meet this weekend in Vermont, the California chairman, Art Torres, expects to be peppered with the sort of questions that have been clogging his in-box for weeks.

headline: Deaths in Newark
text: Newark has seen hundreds of senseless killings over the years, but few have shaken its weary residents like last weekend’s brutal murders of three young people and the shooting of a fourth. One can only hope that the savagery of this latest crime will at last bring the city together in a new determination to end the bloodshed.

headline: Harry Potter and the Showdown
text: Harry makes his last visit to No. 4 Privet Drive, and his aunt and uncle are surprisingly kind to him. Snape shows up unexpectedly to ruin Bill’s wedding. Professor McGonagall reopens Hogwarts with Professor Slughorn as her deputy.

headline: NATIONAL BRIEFING | WEST | California: Fishing Banned Near Channel Islands
text: The federal government has banned fishing in eight sites in the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary, off Southern California, and has limited fishing in a ninth, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced. The action adds about 110 square nautical miles of protected areas to more than 100 square nautical miles already protected by the state and creates the nation’s second-largest network of marine protected areas, after reserves in the northwest Hawaiian Islands.

headline: Earlier Terrorist Screening to Begin for Flights Into U.S.
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9  By early next year, passengers on flights bound for the United States will have their names checked against terrorist watch lists before departure, instead of after takeoff, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff announced Thursday.
The Really? column in Science Times on Tuesday misstated one of the compounds that block UVA radiation and are frequently found in sunscreens. It is avobenzone, not avobenzene.

headline: Shiite Pilgrims Converging on Baghdad Shrine Are Protected by Improved Security
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 9  Tens of thousands of Shiite pilgrims converged on a shrine in western Baghdad on Thursday to honor an eighth-century imam, chanting and waving flags and in some cases riding in government vehicles. There were few instances of the violence that has blemished previous celebrations.

headline: Harry Potter and the Big Funnel
text: After six years at Hogwarts, Harry Potter becomes an intern sorcerer and is assigned to teach at the Honiton School. Harry has a painful time in his aunt’s house, as Dudley has met a belly-dancing girl. As Harry prepares to report to his job, Bat Bug warns him disaster awaits.

headline: A Boy Rendered Speechless by Life
text: Jeffrey Blitz’s tender but hardheaded “Rocket Science” plumbs the tormented consciousness of Hal Hefner (Reece Daniel Thompson), a fragile teenager with a paralyzing speech impediment that leaves him unable even to order lunch in his high school cafeteria. As he stands there desperately trying to articulate the words racing through his head (will it be pizza or fish?), you feel his excruciating humiliation.

headline: Queens: 40-Year Sentence for Rape
text: A homeless man was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 40 years in prison for raping one woman and trying to rape another last year, prosecutors said. The man, James Clark Brown, 45, was convicted of rape, attempted rape and robbery on July 23, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. He said that on the morning of June 13, 2006, Mr. Brown told a woman near the post office in Springfield Gardens that he had a gun and would kill her if she did not come with him. He ordered the woman to follow, but she escaped by pretending to tie her shoe before running away. About 15 minutes later, Mr. Brown forced another woman to accompany him to a nearby garage, where he raped and robbed her, the district attorney said.

headline: A Spaceman’s Latest Tour of Duty on the Planet Mongo
text: Whitey’s Lindy Hoppers have disbanded. The Works Progress Administration is defunct. The DeSoto Airflow has disappeared from auto showrooms. So why is Flash Gordon still with us?

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: F.D.A. Is Reviewing Heartburn Drugs After Studies Find Possible Heart Risk
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9  Two small studies of the popular heartburn drugs Prilosec and Nexium found that patients who took the medicines over many years had an increased risk of sometimes fatal heart attacks and heart failure.

headline: Manhattan: Cellphone Bill Vetoed
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday vetoed a bill intended to chip away at his administration’s ban on cellphones in public schools. The bill would allow students to transport cellphones to and from school, putting the onus on school officials to give students a place to store phones during school hours. The Department of Education is exploring the possibility of installing lockers from private vendors for cellphone storage. Mr. Bloomberg has said that cellphones disrupt learning. The City Council, which voted 46 to 2 in favor of the bill last month, is expected to override the mayor’s veto.

headline: Harry Potter and the Chinese Overseas Students at the Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry
text: Seeing the evil Black Monster approaching the magic world, Dumbledore turns to the Chinese sorcery school Nine Mysteries for help. The school sends six teenage wizards, who with their mysterious magical arts astonish Hogwarts and transform the lives of Harry and his friends.

headline: Markets in Asia and Europe Down Sharply
text: SINGAPORE, Aug. 10 — Stock markets in Europe and Asia fell sharply today, following a rout in the U.S. markets on Thursday over widening fears of losses in the American housing loan market.

headline: Army Tops Its July Recruiting Goal
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 — After falling short of its recruiting goals for two months in a row, the Army met its July quota for signing up new soldiers as it poured more manpower and other resources into the effort, the Army said today.

headline: Frank D. Rich Jr., 83, Real Estate Developer, Dies
text: Frank D. Rich Jr., the chairman and former president of the real estate development company that led the transformation of downtown Stamford, Conn., from a deteriorating factory and retail district to a sleek office and commercial center, died on Tuesday at his home in Darien. He was 83.

headline: Muslims Attack Feminist Writer
text: Incensed Muslims assaulted Taslima Nasreen, above left, the exiled Bangladeshi author and feminist, at a publication party at the press club in Hyderabad, India, yesterday, Reuters reported. Lawmakers and members of the All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen party, outraged by her criticisms of Islam and religion in general for oppression of women, threatened Ms. Nasreen with a chair and hurled a leather case, bunches of flowers and other objects at her while some shouted for her death. With her forehead bruised, she described the attack as barbaric before the police moved her to safety. In 1994 thousands of radical Muslims demanded Ms. Nasreen’s death for blasphemy, and she fled into exile after a court declared that she had “deliberately and maliciously” injured the religious feelings of Muslims with her Bengali-language novel “Lajja,” or “Shame,” about riots between Muslims and Hindus. The European Parliament awarded her the Sakharov Prize for freedom of thought in 1994.

headline: Is Fraud O.K., if You Help Just a Little?
text: It takes a team to pull off a good corporate fraud. Of course, the manager is responsible, but what about the people — and the companies — who just helped out a little? It may be that they are the only ones with enough cash to pay billion-dollar judgments.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: After the Storm: What Did We Learn? (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Deal to Simplify the Business of Implanted Identity Chips
text: The controversy over whether to implant radio identification tags in humans will not be abating anytime soon, but the complicated web of money-losing businesses behind the technology is about to become simpler.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Giving the Hometown Fans a Dose of Classic Hometown Hip-Hop
text: It’s not often that a rapper draws cheers of solidarity for his mode of transportation to a show. But when the Beastie Boys played Central Park SummerStage on Wednesday night, Mike D (a k a Michael Diamond) made a point of complaining, or bragging, about his slow ride uptown on an underventilated A train. On a day of citywide transit woes caused by a freak summer storm, the idea hit home: this is how we roll too.

headline: Federal Effort on Web Obscenity Shows Few Results
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 — Tom Rogers, a retired Indianapolis detective, toils away most days in his suburban home office reviewing sexual Web sites and other Internet traffic to see whether they qualify as obscene material whose purveyors should be prosecuted by the Justice Department.

headline: Daly Shows Field That Practice Is Not Necessary
text: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 9 — With a thickening waist and a wandering mind, John Daly travels from town to town and tee to green as an enigma, an underdog and a 41-year-old problem child.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Muslims Attack Feminist Writer

headline: Product Packages Now Shout to Get Your Attention
text: In the last 100 years, Pepsi had changed the look of its can, and before that its bottles, only 10 times. This year alone, the soft-drink maker will switch designs every few weeks.

headline: Transit Agency Will Consider Refunds for Subway Riders Stranded by Flooding
text: Subway riders may get a rebate on their MetroCards because of the extensive disruptions and delays caused by Wednesday’s flooding, the executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: 2-Year-Old Boy Killed by Fire in an Apartment Bedroom
text: A 2-year-old boy was killed and three members of his family were injured last night in a fire in their Queens apartment, the police said.

headline: Shark Hunter of ‘Jaws’ Fame Is Back as an Old Man of the Sea
text: ABOARD THE CRICKET II OFF MONTAUK, N.Y. — The sun was high and the ocean flat; only the flies were biting. The biggest thing the Monster Man had reeled in all morning was an egg sandwich from his cooler and a couple of landlubbers to listen to his shark-hunting stories.

headline: For Sarkozy: Duty, Bush, Jet Lag
text: PARIS, Aug. 9 — Never mind the carbon footprint. Nicolas Sarkozy, France’s super-active president, will be crossing the Atlantic twice in the space of a day, to attend a funeral in Paris on Friday and still keep his Saturday lunch date with President Bush in Maine.

headline: Big French Bank Suspends Funds
text: PARIS, Aug. 9 — The French bank BNP Paribas suspended operations of three of its funds and the European Central Bank injected cash into the financial system, both in the wake of turmoil in the United States mortgage market.

headline: A Date Goes Terribly Wrong. Now It’s Time to Return the Favor.
text: Rape is power.

headline: In These Shows, the Material Is the Message
text: Chelsea’s summer group shows are both test sites for new ideas and polling stations for aesthetic trends. They indicate what might be seen elsewhere in the near future — in the next Whitney Biennial, for example. A few summers ago there was an outbreak of ’60s psychedelia, rainbow colors and all-around craftsiness, lots of sewing and knitting and rather twee art. Then followed a summer or so of heavy-metal boys in black.

headline: Clinton, Too, Ruled Out A-Bomb Use
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has criticized Senator Barack Obama for saying he would rule out using nuclear weapons to root out terrorists in Afghanistan or Pakistan, made a similar comment regarding Iran last year, before she became a presidential candidate.

headline: Confronting a Crystal Meth Head Who Is Handy With a Chainsaw
text: Those of us who love A&E’s sick documentary series “Intervention” still become anxious before each new episode. Then, after a hiatus, the wariness tends to turn into something closer to blank terror.

headline: China Suspends Exports by 2 Firms Over Lead Paint
text: SHANGHAI, Aug. 9 — China said on Thursday that it had suspended the export licenses of two companies that it said used lead paint in toys made for American companies.

headline: Giuliani Moderates 9/11 Comments
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani today sought to clarify earlier comments in which he called himself “one of” the 9/11 cleanup workers and said he was “at ground zero as often, if not more, than most of the workers.” His statement has attracted sharp criticism from first responders and a rival campaign.

headline: Kazakhstan Says Austrians Erred in Extradition Ruling
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 9  The government of Kazakhstan accused an Austrian court on Thursday of ignoring irrefutable evidence in the court’s decision not to extradite Rakhat M. Aliyev, the former son-in-law of President Nursultan Nazarbayev, and said it would seek an appeal.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article yesterday about the relationship between President Bush and his father, George Herbert Walker Bush, misstated some dates in the history of the only other father and son elected to the presidency of the United States. John Quincy Adams was inaugurated on March 4, 1825, which was 24 years — not 28 — after his father, John Adams, left office. John Adams died in July 1826, which was 16 months — not 18 — after his son’s inauguration. (Go to Article)

headline: South Korea: Interest Rate Raised
text: The Bank of Korea unexpectedly raised its benchmark interest rate for a second time in two months to curb lending that may fuel asset-price bubbles. Governor Lee Seong Tae, left, and his board increased the overnight call rate by a quarter point, to 5 percent, the highest since July 2001, the central bank said. Mr. Lee wants to prevent households from building up excessive debt as they did four years ago, when one in 13 people was unable to pay back money owed and lenders, including LG Card, were driven to the brink of bankruptcy. Lending to households rose at the fastest pace in five months in July.

headline: Theater Listings
text: ‘RENT’ In the 11 years since “Rent” opened on Broadway, much has changed in the world that its writer, Jonathan Larson, described. For one thing, many more medications than AZT are available for people with AIDS, and while too many people still die from its complications, a lot live with the disease as well.

headline: Prickly Pear Lawns
text: WHO Alan Newman, 70, an insurance company chairman, and Jan Newman, 65, the company’s chief financial officer, from Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

headline: People in the News
text: People

headline: Ire Over Shanghai Rail Line May Signal Turning Point
text: SHANGHAI, Aug. 9 — “I have a dream,” Chen Liangyu, Shanghai’s disgraced Communist Party secretary, was fond of intoning before his aides, consciously echoing the words of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. And as the leader of China’s richest city, Mr. Chen had the power to make most of those dreams come true.

headline: Importer Recalls 255,000 Chinese Light-Truck Tires
text: Foreign Tire Sales, a New Jersey importer, said yesterday that it would recall about 255,000 light-truck tires made to order by a Chinese company.

headline: Getting the Rescue Right
text: Help has been way too slow in coming for the estimated 1.7 million people who will lose their homes to foreclosure this year and next. A modest bill to bolster funds for state, local and nonprofit agencies that help hard-pressed homeowners renegotiate their mortgages and restructure their debts has been slogging through the Senate since April, and it won’t be passed until October at the earliest — if ever. On the presidential campaign trail, Senator Hillary Clinton recently promised to introduce a similar relief measure — next month.

headline: Thoughts of Home for Jets’ New Back
text: Running back Thomas Jones is in a new place now, preparing for his first big test with the Jets. But his thoughts this week have turned to home.

headline: The Farmer’s Nightmare?
text: Only a few years ago, ethanol was just a line in a farm-state politician’s stump speech — something that went down well with the locals but didn’t mean much to anyone else. Now, of course, ethanol is widely touted — and, within reason, rightly so — as an important part of America’s search for energy independence and greener fuels. One day, we may be using cellulosic ethanol, the kind derived from grasses. For now, the ethanol boom is all about corn. And the real question is whether that will finally kill American farming as we know it.

headline: Harry Potter and the Waterproof Pearl
text: With the help of Gandalf and Peter, Harry Potter and the Little Warriors find the sea city in the desert. They go through a keyhole into a mysterious land, where they get gold armor and kill the head of the monsters. On their triumphant return, Hermione disappears. Dumbledore tells Harry that Hermione has been kidnapped by a monster. With help from his friends, Harry obtains the waterproof pearl. To rescue Hermione, Harry barges into the Dragon Palace alone to have a showdown with the Dragon King.

headline: Universal Music Will Sell Songs Without Copy Protection
text: Signaling another departure from the music industry’s longtime antipiracy strategy, the Universal Music Group will sell a significant portion of its catalog without the customary copy protection software for at least the next few months, the company announced yesterday.

headline: Stocks Are Volatile After Global Sell-Off
text: In a volatile day of trading that followed sharp declines in Asia and Europe, stocks fell sharply on Wall Street early today but closed essentially flat.

headline: Defendant Is Convicted for His Role in 2 Killings
text: A Ukrainian immigrant was convicted of murder yesterday for his role in two shootings dating to the heyday of Russian organized crime in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn.

headline: In San Francisco, Celebrations Make Way for Reality
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9  Ryan Klesko’s 1-year-old bulldog, Junior, waddled into the San Francisco Giants clubhouse Thursday morning, a not-so-subtle reminder that the dog days have finally arrived.

headline: As Credit Tightens, Investors Grow Wary of Bank’s Reliance on Debt
text: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 9 — Over the last few years, Macquarie Bank of Australia has become something of a role model for the investment industry, but in recent months, markets and investors have posed some difficult questions for the relative newcomer.

headline: The Farm You Want (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Lack of Runs Is Weighing on the Indians
text: For the Cleveland Indians, a team loaded with big bats, a strategy used Monday night seemed out character. In a scoreless game at the Metrodome, Manager Eric Wedge brought his infield in with a Minnesota runner at third base and one out, hoping to cut off a run at the plate.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Stocks Tumble as French Bank  Reacts to Home Loan Worries
text: Stocks dropped sharply as soon as trading opened today after a French bank, BNP Paribas, suspended operations of three of its funds in the wake of turmoil in the American market for home loans and the European Central Bank and the Federal Reserve injected cash into the financial system because of tightening credit markets.

headline: Russia: Bombers Resume Long-Haul Missions
text: Maj. Gen. Pavel Androsov, the commander of Russia’s long-range aviation forces, said its long-range strategic bombers, once part of the Soviet Union’s nuclear forces, had held new flight exercises that included passing by a United States naval base in Guam and trips to the North and South Poles. The bombers also fired eight training missiles at unspecified targets and hit them all, according to General Androsov, who spoke at a news conference. The path of the test flights and the performance of the missiles could not be independently verified but appeared to be another instance of Russia, flush with money from its oil and gas exports, trying to reassert itself as a military and global power.

headline: Size Doesn’t Keep Goldman Fund From Gyrating With Market
text: During the heady days of the market boom, Goldman Sachs, with its billions in hedge funds and private equity investments, came to define that era’s euphoria.

headline: U.N. Warns of Dire Results if Main Gaza Crossings Stay Shut
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 9 — The United Nations on Thursday issued a severe warning that Gaza could face an economic meltdown with “disastrous consequences” unless its main crossings were reopened.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: It’s a Vision Thing for Nash in Soccer and in Basketball
text: It was easy to tell who the sports fans were in Central Park on Tuesday afternoon. They were the ones doing double takes, pulling out their camera phones and snapping photographs of two top professional athletes who were nudging soccer balls around in the grass.

headline: It’s Tucker vs. Chan, Round 3
text: “Rush Hour 3,” the junky, clunky, grimly unfunny follow-up to the marginally better “Rush Hour 2” and the significantly finer “Rush Hour,” isn’t the worst movie of the summer. But it’s an enervating bummer nonetheless, largely because it shows so little respect for its two likable stars and its audience. Once again Jackie Chan and Chris Tucker, playing seriously unlikely detectives, bumble and slog through muddled setups, graceless action, crude jokes and even cruder stereotypes, sacrificing themselves on the altar of the director Brett Ratner’s vulgar success.

headline: Asian Markets Fall as Credit Fears Spread
text: SINGAPORE, Aug. 10 — Central banks around Asia joined efforts in the United States and Europe to stave off a credit crunch among banks today, as widening fears over losses in the U.S. housing loan market prompted investors to sell assets and commercial banks to reel in credit lines.

headline: A Van Halen Tour?
text: Van Halen, re-formed around its original frontman, David Lee Roth, will embark on a 50-date North American tour in October, The Associated Press reported, citing Billboard Magazine’s Web site, www.billboard.com. Neither the band nor the touring company Live Nation would confirm the report, but the band sent out a news release promising “an announcement of monumental proportions” at a news conference on Monday in Los Angeles, The A.P. said. Van Halen has not toured with Mr. Roth in more than 20 years.

headline: Not Making Money In His Sleep
text: In his heyday in the 1990s, the money manager Dana Giacchetto charmed clients like Leonardo DiCaprio and Tobey Maguire, the band Phish and Michael Ovitz — until he was caught defrauding them, for which he served about three years of a nearly five-year prison sentence. Last year Robert L. Geltzer, the court-appointed trustee for Mr. Giacchetto’s bankrupt company, Cassandra Group, unearthed a book deal in which Mr. Giacchetto was to split the proceeds with Emily White, his biographer. Mr. Geltzer sued, and in a settlement to be filed with bankruptcy court today, Mr. Giacchetto, 44, has turned over his stake in her book, “You Will Make Money in Your Sleep: The Story of Dana Giacchetto, Financial Adviser to the Stars,” and the rights to his life story in any film or television production to satisfy claims against Cassandra Group. Whether the settlement will raise much money is doubtful. The book has sold only 300 copies since its June publication by Scribner, according to Nielsen BookScan, which tracks about 70 percent of retail sales. tvjobs.com

headline: Harry Potter and the Chinese Porcelain Doll
text: Harry Potter learns that Mysterious Man (Voldemort) is going to China to persuade his rival Yandomort to attack Harry as well as the Western magic world. Harry decides to find Chinese Porcelain Doll, who could beat Yandomort in China. On a passenger steamer, Harry makes friends with Long Long and Xing Xing, who are part of a Chinese circus. It turns out that Naughty Bubble, the boy who usually bullied Xing Xing at the circus, was Yandomort. After Voldemort killed Naughty Bubble’s mother, Big Spinach, he took Naughty Bubble as his disciple, and taught him black magic to make him become Yandomort.

headline: Harry Potter and Platform Nine and Three-Quarters
text: Excerpt: This was a secret I had cherished in my heart for seven days. It scratched my heart and made it itch, and I decided not to tell anyone of it. But when I saw Hedwig, my owl, jumping outside my window, I knew it was the call from Hogwarts for me. Yes, it was I who had received the Hogwarts admission letter! I could not tell anyone of this, I would ride on my favorite flying broom, together with Hedwig and my magic wand, go-go-go, night clouds in the urban sky would cover my trails, and the meteor you saw in the sky was my traipsing manteau.

headline: Agency Lags in Protecting Children, Report Says
text: Many of the names are familiar, though perhaps faded from memory. There was Dahquay Gillians, 16 months, who drowned in a Brooklyn bathtub while his mother listened to CDs in the next room.

headline: Even Chrysler Officials Were Surprised at New Owner’s Leadership Choice
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Aug. 9 — Not only did Robert L. Nardelli’s appointment as the new head of Chrysler surprise people in the auto industry when it was announced on Monday, it shocked officials inside the auto company as well.

headline: Mortgage Losses Echo in Europe and on Wall Street
text: Turmoil in the home loan market ricocheted from the United States to Europe and back again yesterday as stocks on Wall Street suffered their biggest one-day decline since February, reflecting growing concerns about tightening credit worldwide.

headline: Man Charged in Newark Deaths Pleads Not Guilty
text: NEWARK, Aug. 10 — A third suspect, identified as a teenager, has been arrested in the execution-style slayings of three students here Saturday night, the authorities said.

headline: S. Africa Fires Official Praised for Anti-AIDS Work
text: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 9  The South African president, Thabo Mbeki, has fired his deputy health minister, who was widely credited with waging an aggressive assault on the nation’s devastating AIDS epidemic this year.

headline: Bush Plans Immigration Crackdown
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9  The Bush administration plans to announce numerous steps on Friday to secure the border with Mexico, speed the expulsion of illegal immigrants and step up enforcement of immigration laws, administration officials say.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Man and Youth Held in Killings of 3 in Newark
text: NEWARK, Aug. 9 — In a day of dramatic turns that included the surrender of one suspect to the mayor himself, the authorities announced on Thursday that a 15-year-old youth and a 28-year-old construction worker had been arrested in the murder of three young people and the wounding of a fourth in an episode that has unsettled this crime-hardened city.

headline: Singing the Blues All Over
text: EVERYONE loves the blues. Some people just don’t know it yet. Much like its followers, the blues has hitchhiked from one part of the country to another, evolving into new genres like R&B, soul and rock.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Hopes Dim for Miners After Air Test
text: The search for miners trapped underground in Utah suffered what appeared to be a major setback today, when a test of the atmosphere in a cavity where the miners were originally believed to be found oxygen levels incapable of sustaining life.

headline: With Civil Liberties Under Attack, Returning Fire
text: IN a law enforcement landscape that, with the finger of blame pointing straight toward the events of 9/11, has skewed increasingly uncivil toward civil liberties, Christopher Dunn, the associate legal director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, has too often been having a Sisyphean time of it.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,673 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: General’s Death Portends Election Troubles in Zimbabwe
text: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 9  With all the problems besetting Zimbabwe, the untimely death of Brig. Gen. Armstrong P. Gunda, flattened by a freight train in late June, may seem to deserve only passing mention. His family, however, begs to differ.

headline: Women Who Earn More (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Art in Review
text: JESPER JUST

headline: Just Don’t Call It Minimalism
text: BY and large musical Minimalists don’t carry cards. But they do know something about guilt by association.

headline: The Straw Poll Man
text: Early on, before the campaigning begins in earnest, presidential candidates lunch with journalists in order to get acquainted. During one of these lunches, Mitt Romney was talking about the global economy and was asked why he thought some nations grew rich and others didn’t.

headline: Vatican Plays Down Meeting That Angered Jewish Groups
text: ROME, Aug. 9  The Vatican worked Thursday to minimize the significance of a brief meeting between Pope Benedict XVI and a Polish priest accused of making anti-Semitic statements, in the latest of several tense episodes recently between Jews and Roman Catholics.

headline: Credit Card Legislation (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Feud Behind the Sale of Barneys New York
text: To the outside world, it looked like a well-orchestrated triumph: the clothing powerhouse Jones Apparel Group appeared poised yesterday to sell Barneys New York, the ultra-hip department store, for more than twice what the company paid for it, nearly $1 billion.

headline: Well-Off Fleeing Iraq Find Poverty and Pain in Jordan
text: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 9 — After her husband’s killing, Amira sold a generation of her family’s belongings, packed up her children and left behind their large house in Baghdad, with its gardener and maid.

headline: Buffett Is Invested in Rodriguez
text: Now that Barry Bonds has eclipsed Henry Aaron as No. 1 on the career home run list, baseball and its fans will watch with rapt interest in the next five or six seasons to see if Alex Rodriguez supplants Bonds. One of those fans is Warren E. Buffett, whose position in the financial world is similar to the one Rodriguez occupies in baseball.

headline: Newport Antiques (and Nantucket’s) in Summer Fair
text: A new antiques fair opens tonight in Newport, R.I., and it all began with one person who had a big idea.

headline: Indians Protest Wal-Mart’s Wholesale Entry
text: NEW DELHI, Aug. 9 — Wal-Mart, in a struggle to expand its global reach, is trying to enter India through the back door, but many consumers here have taken notice.

headline: Sometimes, Being Overlooked Is an Advantage
text: WHEN it comes to covering the waterfront in Narragansett, R.I., the patterns are well established.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Footnote
text: The New York Philharmonic will admit the public free to Avery Fisher Hall at 9:45 a.m. on Sept. 18 for the dress rehearsal of its gala opening night concert. Lorin Maazel, the music director, will rehearse the ensemble in an all-Dvorak program, including the Cello Concerto, featuring Yo-Yo Ma; the “Carnival Overture”; and Symphony No. 7. Tickets will be distributed on a first-come-first-served basis, beginning at 8 a.m. in front of the hall.

headline: Analysts See ‘Simply Incredible’ Shrinking of Floating Ice in the Arctic
text: The area of floating ice in the Arctic has shrunk more this summer than in any other summer since satellite tracking began in 1979, and it has reached that record point a month before the annual ice pullback typically peaks, experts said yesterday.

headline: The Chateau at Heavenly Village and the Residential Suites at the Ritz-Carlton, Kapalua
text: The Chateau at Heavenly Village

headline: Take Me Back to Egypt’s Land
text: “The Man in the White Sharkskin Suit” in this stunning memoir is the author’s father, Leon Lagnado, a prosperous businessman in Cairo during and after World War II, one of the city’s most elegant boulevardiers, who spent his nights in the restaurants, cafes, dance halls and casinos of what was then “the most cosmopolitan city in the world.” Impeccably dressed in suits made by Cairo’s finest tailors, he romanced the city’s most beautiful women, did business with French colonial merchants, gambled with wealthy Egyptians and socialized with British officers. Though there was severe rationing in the city during the war, “the nightlife flourished and cafe society preened and the hedonistic streak of the city went almost unchecked.”

headline: Bush Rejects Gas Tax as Way to Shore Up Bridges
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 — President Bush spoke out Thursday against increasing the gasoline tax, an idea being discussed as a potential part of a new Congressional plan to shore up the nation’s bridges after the deadly collapse in Minneapolis.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10 P.M. (ABC) PASTOR TO POWER: BILLY GRAHAM AND THE PRESIDENTS He has preached to more people than anyone in history and offered spiritual guidance to some of the world’s most powerful men. This “20/20” special explores the Rev. Billy Graham’s ties to 11 presidential administrations, both Republican and Democratic — from Harry S. Truman’s to George W. Bush’s — through interviews with former presidents and first ladies whom he served as a confidant, offering counsel on everything, from war to the existence of heaven. In a round-table discussion, from left above, Bill Clinton; Mr. Graham; Charles Gibson, the moderator; Jimmy Carter; and George H. W. Bush reflect on their friendships. Nancy Reagan, Barbara Bush and Hillary Rodham Clinton, who sought advice during the Monica Lewinsky scandal, also discuss their relationships with Mr. Graham, now 88. “I thought of them as just wonderful human beings who were wonderful personal friends as I knew them, each one,” he tells Mr. Gibson. “Pastor to Power” coincides with the publication of “The Preacher and the Presidents” by Nancy Gibbs and Michael Duffy of Time magazine.

headline: Regulating Tobacco (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sonnets in Marble
text: Reputation is the strangest thing. An artist is celebrated; he’s on top of the world. He dies, and his work is forgotten, or misremembered, or misunderstood as fashions change and canons form. Then suddenly he’s back in the spotlight, or what survives of him is, with scholars scrambling to make up for lost attention and time.

headline: García Is Feeling the Heat at Another Major
text: TULSA, Okla.

headline: Music for the Religious, From Two Who Weren’t
text: The development of new strands of Christianity over the centuries has been accompanied by varying ideas about the role of music in worship. The Council of Trent in the 1500s fretted that sensuous polyphony distracted congregants, and the Puritans banned music altogether. Later the prayers of some American churchgoers were accompanied by the unfettered emotion of gospel music.

headline: A Summer of Endless Winter in Lake Placid, N.Y.
text: SUVS loaded with bicycles and kayaks are making their way down Main Street, headed for dusty mountain trails and inviting waters. Vacationers sit sunning at outdoor cafes, and children frolic at the town beach. But close by, what appears to be a pile of snow is slowly melting, continually replenished by the frosty scrapings cleared from ice rinks by Zambonis. Farther down Main Street, a bobsled sits baking in the sun, and a few doors beyond that, a luge visibly radiates heat.

headline: British Farmers Hopeful Cattle Disease Is Under Control
text: LONDON, Aug. 9 — British farmers reacted with some relief Thursday to the government’s relaxation of the ban on the movement of livestock, a first sign that the spread of foot-and-mouth disease found in southern England was coming under control.

headline: Harassing Germany’s Media
text: Germany would seem to be one of the last places to find the government trying to intimidate its journalists these days. News of secret C.I.A. flights that whisked prisoners through the Continent to places where torture is allowed has horrified many Europeans in recent years. The German courts have been in the forefront of condemning “extraordinary rendition”  the practice of loading terrorism suspects onto planes and secretly flying them to Afghanistan or Syria or other particularly dangerous spots for anyone behind bars.

headline: Deported Canadian Was No Threat, Report Shows
text: OTTAWA, Aug. 9 — Canadian intelligence officials anticipated that the United States would ship Maher Arar, a Syrian-born Canadian who was detained in New York in 2002 on suspicion of terrorism, to a third country to be tortured, declassified information released on Thursday shows.

headline: Inside His Sketchbooks, Clues to Monet
text: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — It is difficult to imagine that anything remains unknown about Claude Monet, whose life and career have been picked over by scholars and bright-eyed doctoral candidates. But the revelatory exhibition “The Unknown Monet” at the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute here unfurls a new look at the role of drawing in the creative process of an artist whom we have always thought of as a painter, not a draftsman.

headline: Clemens Is Handed Five-Game Suspension
text: CLEVELAND, Aug. 9 — After hitting Toronto’s Alex Rios in the back with a fastball on Tuesday, the Yankees’ Roger Clemens did not try to claim innocence. It was clear that Clemens was retaliating for the Blue Jays’ actions toward Alex Rodriguez, and Major League Baseball agreed Thursday.

headline: Aide Says Cuomo Could Have Issued Subpoenas in Spitzer Case
text: ALBANY, Aug. 9  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo could have gained subpoena power in his investigation of Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s aides if the state inspector general had referred the matter to his office during the inquiry, an aide to Mr. Cuomo said on Thursday.

headline: Judge Spotlights Shortage of Interpreters for the Deaf
text: The prevailing custom in the New York courts is for sign language interpreters to work in tandem: one translates the rapid-fire arguments of courtroom life, while the other gets to rest weary hands.

headline: Red Cross Faces Criticism Over Aid Program for Hurricane Victims
text: A little-known American Red Cross aid program for victims of Hurricane Katrina has unleashed a wave of criticism from evacuees, who say that the program, which pays up to $20,000 for building materials, used cars, job training and other unmet needs, has been too secretive and strict, and its money too limited.

headline: Russell Johnson, Who Transformed the Sound in Concert Halls, Dies at 83
text: Russell Johnson, who combined architectural training, a love of music and acute intuition to revolutionize the quality of sound in hundreds of the world’s concert halls, each of which he regarded as a complex, unique instrument, died on Aug. 7 at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Giants’ Jennings: Souped-Up Cars for a Souped-Up Guy
text: ALBANY, Aug. 8 — The Mercedes (yawn) are sleek. The Escalades (ho-hum) are nice. Shaun O’Hara’s Hummer and Reuben Droughns’s Maserati stand out, sure.

headline: A Defector’s Second Life, Embracing North Korea
text: “Crossing the Line” tells of four American servicemen who defected to North Korea, with an emphasis on James Joseph Dresnok, a k a Comrade Joe, who became a privileged North Korean citizen and appeared in propaganda extolling Communism.

headline: Memo to the Dept. of Magical Copyright Enforcement
text: China has a world-leading knack for churning out copies and counterfeits, and the release of “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows” last month prompted a surge of peculiarly Chinese imitations as well as a quickie unauthorized translation. Below are excerpts from the publishers’ summaries and the texts of the various “Harry Potter” counterfeits that have been circulating in China in the last few years, translated by The Times from the Chinese. While the selections may not always make sense (even, or perhaps especially to, “Potter” aficionados), we can promise you this: no spoilers.

headline: In a Crisis, Subway Riders Get Little Guidance
text: Ten minutes after a suspicious package was found at a subway station in Washington on Wednesday, riders read about it on the electronic screens at all of the system’s 86 stations.

headline: Scores of Relatives Aid Romney
text: AMES, Iowa, Aug. 10 — They have driven here from California, Ohio, Canada or Texas, while others have flown from Michigan, Utah or Florida. There are aunts, uncles, cousins, second cousins, in-laws, nieces, nephews and grandchildren.

headline: Like Father, Like Son, Even When They Are Under Suspicion
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 — Ben Stevens is often said by Alaskans to be the spitting image of his father, Senator Ted Stevens. They have the same broad forehead, wide-set eyes and compact physique. They share the same rough-hewn personality, seemingly always spoiling for a fight.

headline: Romance in the Horsy Set, Starring the New York Mayor’s Daughter
text: The riders on the Irish horse show circuit have recently been paying attention to more than riding and jumping and, oh, mucking out stalls. They have been paying attention to one another, judging by The Irish Independent of Dublin.

headline: The Uses of Fear to Manipulate Americans (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wind-Damaged Brooklyn Begins to Straighten Up
text: It was the day after in southwestern Brooklyn yesterday: work crews pushed brooms, steered street sweepers, shoveled bricks, lifted tree trunks and started the rebuilding in the aftermath of the unlikely tornado that swept through the area early Wednesday morning.

headline: Another Body Is Found in Bridge Debris
text: Divers in Minneapolis searching the Mississippi River near the wreckage of a huge bridge collapse today found the body of someone killed in the disaster, bringing the death toll in the collapse to eight, with at least five others still missing.

headline: Life on a Big River in a House That Floats
text: HARD to believe that they’d simply hand over the keys to a 48-foot houseboat, but here I was at the helm, with little experience piloting a boat larger than a canoe. A maze of buoys and shore markers reminded me — as if I needed reminding — that the Mississippi is a working river where nature, recreation and commerce collide, and I jockeyed for space with whizzing Jet Skis and 6,500-horsepower towboats pushing rafts of barges the size of two football fields end to end.

headline: A River: Corruption and Oil Run Through It
text: Reporters based in Africa once coined a word for the rampant corruption that plagued the continent as it emerged from colonialism: Wawa, an acronym for “West Africa wins again.” In an engrossing one-man show called “Tings Dey Happen,” written and performed by Dan Hoyle, it becomes clear why Nigeria epitomized Wawa.

headline: Facing a Furor, Pakistan Rejects Emergency Rule
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 9 — Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, was on the brink of declaring a state of emergency in his increasingly volatile country but backed away after a gathering storm of media, political and diplomatic pressure, Pakistani officials acknowledged on Thursday.

headline: Another Body Is Found in Bridge Debris
text: Divers in Minneapolis searching the Mississippi River near the wreckage of a huge bridge collapse today found the remains of someone killed in the disaster, bringing the death toll in the collapse to as many as nine, with at least four others still missing.

headline: Quake Rattles the Los Angeles Area
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9  An earthquake with a magnitude of 4.6 rattled the Los Angeles area on Thursday, shaking many people out of bed and causing the temporary closing of a bridge after chunks of concrete came loose.

headline: Education Dept. Seeks Early Compliance on Loan Rules
text: Criticized for lax oversight of student loans, the federal Education Department is asking universities and lenders to abide voluntarily by its proposed rules banning certain marketing practices by loan companies, before the rules take effect next year.

headline: Romney Pushed on Conservative Credentials
text: URBANDALE, Iowa, Aug. 9  Mitt Romney is undergoing the stiffest test yet of his effort to win over conservatives wary of his ideological credentials.

headline: Bronx: Man and Woman Found Dead
text: A 26-year-old man and an 18-year-old woman, his former companion, were found dead in Tremont early yesterday in what is being investigated as a possible murder-suicide, the police said. Police officers responding to 911 calls at 12:30 a.m. found the body of the man, Lander Jones, lying on the sidewalk outside 325 East 176th Street, the police said. Later, inside Mr. Jones’s fifth-floor apartment in the building, the police found the body of the woman, Mabelyn Arriola, who lived on the second floor. Her throat was cut and she had been stabbed several times in the back, the police said. A knife was lying on top of her body. Investigators, relying in part on witness accounts, said they believed that Mr. Jones stabbed Ms. Arriola before slitting his wrists and jumping from his apartment window, the police said. He was pronounced dead at 1:10 a.m. at St. Barnabas Hospital. Ms. Arriola, who was pronounced dead at the scene, had obtained an order of protection against Mr. Jones but had visited him in his apartment before her death, the police said.

headline: Braves Snatch Another Series From Mets
text: Shea Stadium was nearly empty and a blue sky had turned gray when Bobby Cox walked out of the visitors’ clubhouse yesterday afternoon. Cox, the manager of the Atlanta Braves, was grinning. He looked as if he possessed a secret.

headline: For Storm, the Lead Is Icing on the Cake
text: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 9  When Graeme Storm was struggling to make money during the 2002 European Tour season, he took a job at a cake factory cleaning trays. He had made less than £12,000 (roughly $24,000) playing golf, so he supplemented his income with the factory job that paid £148 (about $299) a week.

headline: Harry Potter and the Half-Blooded Relative Prince
text: Harry realizes that his magic powers need improvement. He transfers to Qroutes School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, the biggest and most exclusive school of witchcraft and wizardry on the Royal Continent. But appallingly, Harry becomes a blood-lust monster. He is finally beaten by his classmates.

headline: Inside Art
text: The Inside Art column will resume next month.

headline: Former Astronaut Seeking to Be Free of Ankle Monitor
text: Capt. Lisa M. Nowak wants to get rid of her ankle bracelet.

headline: In the Grove
text: CLEARING a labyrinth of brush on their newly purchased property in 1999, Mish Tworkowski, a jewelry designer from Manhattan, and his partner, Joseph Singer, an architect, discovered something they hadn’t bargained for — an old, stooped apple tree. They hadn’t set out to grow fruit; when they bought this land in Millbrook, N.Y., with a crumbling creamery and a barn, they were aiming to create a second home. But an apple tree — even a derelict apple tree — seemed far too valuable to cast aside.

headline: Shaky Markets Prompt Rumors of Who’s in Trouble
text: The global stock and bond markets these days seem to be playing a giant game of hide and seek.

headline: Answer to Annual Question: No, Rivera Hasn’t Lost His Edge
text: CLEVELAND, Aug. 9 — He has taken the mound for the Yankees 242 more times than any other pitcher in the team’s history. He is 37 years old, a 13-year veteran who has pitched the equivalent of another season and a half in October.

headline: Democratic Commissioner to Leave S.E.C.
text: Roel C. Campos, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission who sparred with agency Republicans over how best to penalize companies for securities law violations, will depart in a month for the private sector, the commission said yesterday.

headline: Cambodia: Frenchman to Defend Khmer Rouge Jailer
text: A French lawyer who has defended people accused of genocide and terrorism was sworn in in Cambodia to defend the first member of the Khmer Rouge to be charged in connection with the deaths of 1.7 million people from 1975 to 1979. The lawyer, François Roux, will defend Kaing Guek Eav, the commandant of the Tuol Sleng torture chamber in Phnom Penh where at least 14,000 people were sent to their deaths. Mr. Roux was on the defense team of Zacarias Moussaoui, who was convicted in the United States of terrorism charges in connection with the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. He has also defended four people accused of genocide in Rwanda.

headline: Very Scary Things
text: In September 1998, the collapse of Long Term Capital Management, a giant hedge fund, led to a meltdown in the financial markets similar, in some ways, to what’s happening now. During the crisis in ’98, I attended a closed-door briefing given by a senior Federal Reserve official, who laid out the grim state of the markets. “What can we do about it?” asked one participant. “Pray,” replied the Fed official.

headline: Study Finds Genetic Key to a Kind of Glaucoma
text: Researchers have discovered the genetic flaws that underlie a major type of glaucoma, a leading cause of blindness. By pinpointing what goes wrong, their finding may provide a basis for devising new treatments.

headline: Gunman Dies and 10 People Hurt After Fight With Guards in Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 10 — A gunfight erupted in Jerusalem’s Old City today when a young Arab man took a pistol from a security guard and attempted to flee. The young man was killed and 10 people were wounded, including the guard, the police said.

headline: For Many Campaigns, the Little i’s Have It
text: MADISON AVENUE is giving a new spin to “I Spy,” the children’s game, by chanting, “I spy, with my little eye, a little ‘i.’ ”

headline: When It Comes to Viewers, Aaron Is Still No. 1
text: In a sports world without cable, ESPN, sports-talk radio stations or the 24-hour news cycle, Hank Aaron hit his 715th home run. The only stations that mattered were numbered 2 to 13, and on NBC stations on the night of April 8, 1974, Curt Gowdy said: “There’s a long drive. Ball’s hit deep. Deep. It is gone! He did it. He did it. Henry Aaron is the all-time home run leader.”

headline: To Curb Risk, Boston Scientific to Sell Device Maker It Bought in ’04
text: Boston Scientific’s tortured relationship with Advanced Bionics, the high-tech implant company it acquired in 2004, is about to end.

headline: New Zealand’s Jobless Rate Falls to Record Low
text: New Zealand’s jobless rate fell to a record low in the second quarter, adding to inflation pressure and increasing the prospect that the central bank would keep interest rates at a record high until at least June next year. The jobless rate dropped to 3.6 percent, from a revised 3.7 percent in the first quarter, Statistics New Zealand said. Companies added 14,000 workers. The central bank governor, Alan Bollard, raised the benchmark interest rate to a record 8.25 percent last month, saying four increases this year might contain inflation.

headline: After the Storm: What Did We Learn? (8 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Police Tell of Suspicious Activity Before Virginia Tech Shootings
text: Two days before the nation’s deadliest shooting rampage, when 32 people at Virginia Tech died at the hands of a fellow student, a young man was seen in a hooded sweat shirt in the same building where the massacre took place, and the doors were found chained shut, investigators said today.

headline: Nothing Suspicious About A-Rod, Boras Says
text: I took advantage of the off-day to visit the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio, this afternoon. As I studied the play-by-play of “The Drive” – folks here in Cleveland need no further explanation – my cellphone rang. It was Scott Boras, calling me back.

headline: Product Packages Now Shout to Get Your Attention
text: According to an article in today’s New York Times, consumer goods companies, which once saw packages largely as containers for shipping their products, are now using them more as 3-D ads to grab shoppers’ attention.

headline: First Time Owners
text: Nerissa Villamaria and Richard Villanova did not mind downsizing, as long as they still had sufficient space and could begin building equity.

headline: Bourdais at Toro Rosso in 2008
text: The Bourdais watch is finally over. No need to talk at length on this site about how the sport can continue to ignore one of the great racing talents of the day. Bourdais has finally signed with an F1 team. All right, it’s Toro Rosso – but that’s an even greater sign of just how important this driver is. With all the Red Bull drivers around who might fill both seats at the team, Toro Rosso chose Bourdais.

headline: Structurally Deficient Bridges in the New York Metropolitan Area
Democratic Commissioner to Leave S.E.C.
text: Roel C. Campos, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission who sparred with agency Republicans over how best to penalize companies for securities law violations, will depart in a month for the private sector, the commission said Thursday.

headline: Latest Transit Updates: M.T.A. Determined to Withstand New Rains
text: Updated, 10:34 a.m. | Determined to avoid a recurrence of the flooding that crippled the subway system on Wednesday, transit officials pumped drains, readied buses, summoned workers and postponed construction in anticipation of heavy rains this morning. The commute went smoothly for most riders, but there were sporadic delays in Queens and Manhattan.

headline: Boston Scientific to Unwind Advanced Bionics Deal
text: Boston Scientific‘s tortured relationship with Advanced Bionics, the high-tech implant company it acquired in 2004, is about to end.

headline: As Credit Tightens, Is the Macquarie Model Tenable?
text: Over the last few years, the Macquarie Bank of Australia has become something of a role model for the investment industry, but in recent months, markets and investors have posed some difficult questions for the relative newcomer.

headline: Topps and Upper Deck Trade Poison-Pen Letters
text: The war of words between Topps, the maker of baseball cards and Bazooka bubblegum, and Upper Deck, the rival that is trying to buy it, continued this week, as the two traded barbs over their deal negotiations.

headline: H&R Block May Delay Sale of Option One Mortgage Unit
text: H&R Block, eager to sell its money-losing Option One mortgage unit to Cerberus Capital Management, said Thursday that it might not complete the deal until the end of December.

headline: Nasdaq May Raise Bid for OMX
text: The Nasdaq Stock Market  pledged to press ahead with its 25.1 billion Swedish kronor ($3.7 billion) bid for OMX despite Borse Dubai of the United Arab Emirates encroaching on the offer with a bid for “at least” 25 percent of OMX, operator of the fifth largest exchange in Europe.

headline: Xtera Raises $52 Million from Pack of V.C.’s
text: Xtera Communications announced the closing of a $52 million second round that gives the optical networking company about $100 million in venture backing since its recapitalization in 2004.

headline: Bear Funds Get Temporary Shield from Investors Suits
text: Bear Stearns has managed, if only temporarily, to put some distance between itself and disgruntled investors in two of its now-bankrupt hedge funds.

headline: National Grid Close to Wrapping Up KeySpan Deal
text: National Grid‘s chief executive, Steve Holliday, said Thursday he is optimistic the utility conglomerate’s $7.3 billion takeover of KeySpan will finally close this month.

headline: S.E.C. Sues Former Nicor Executives
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a lawsuit Thursday against three top former executives of Nicor, a natural gas supplier, alleging financial fraud.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Said to Be Close to Chilean Deal
text: Bank of Nova Scotia is on the verge of making a takeover bid for Chile’s private Banco del Desarrollo in a transaction with an estimated value of $1 billion, Chilean media reported Thursday.

headline: Landry’s Arranges New Financing
text: Landry’s Restaurants said Thursday that it has arranged a bank loan to repay bondholders who have demanded early repayment on debt securities, but it will continue to fight a demand to immediately repay that debt.

headline: Ripplewood Hitches Former Ford Executive to Its Wagon
text: Former auto-industry executives continue to find new homes at private equity firms. The latest example is Sir Nicholas Scheele, a former president of Ford Motor, who has joined Ripplewood Holdings to help in its bid to buy Jaguar and Land Rover from his former employer, BusinessWeek writes.

headline: Genzyme Pays $65 Million to Settle Buyback Claims
text: Genzyme, the biotech company, will pay $64 million to settle claims that it schemed to buy back its Genzyme Biosurgery division from shareholders for less than it was worth.

headline: Onex Profit Triples, as Two U.S. Rivals Prepare to Report
text: Onex, Canada’s biggest buyout firm, said Thursday that its second quarter profit more than tripled and said it is optimistic about its ability to finance deals despite recent debt-market turbulence.

headline: Mortgage Losses Echo in Europe and on Wall Street
text: News on Thursday that BNP Paribas, the largest publicly traded bank in France, had suspended investors’ ability to remove money from three funds that had invested in American mortgage securities, began a sell off that ended with Wall Street stocks suffering their biggest one-day decline since February.

headline: Malaise Deepens at Goldman’s Flagship Fund
text: During the heady days of the market boom, Goldman Sachs, with its billions in hedge funds and private equity investments, came to define that era’s euphoria.

headline: Icahn Funds to Go Public Through Merger
text: Carl C. Icahn is going public, though not in the conventional way.

headline: S.E.C. Is Said to Check on Banks’ Subprime Assets
text: Securities regulators are checking the books at top Wall Street brokerage firms and banks to make sure they are not hiding losses in the subprime-mortgage meltdown, The Wall Street Journal reported Friday.

headline: ABN Amro Shares Fall on Bid Concerns
text: Stock in ABN Amro, the Dutch bank, fell the most in almost six years on concern turmoil roiling financial markets may hinder its takeover.

headline: Clinton on Iraq and Foreign Policy
text: At an event in Iowa, Hillary Clinton discussed Iraq and America's standing in the world.

headline: The Feud Behind the Sale of Barneys New York
text: To the outside world, it looked like a well-orchestrated triumph: the clothing powerhouse Jones Apparel Group appeared poised Thursday to sell Barneys New York, the ultra-hip department store, for more than twice what the company paid for it, nearly $1 billion.

headline: Obama on Iraq and Foreign Policy
text: At an event in Iowa, Barack Obama discussed Iraq and a new direction for American foreign policy.

headline: Who’s in Trouble Next?
text: Investors are scrambling to discover which banks, hedge funds or public companies are holding potentially hundreds of billions of dollars in bad loans and subprime-related mortgage securities that are imploding.

headline: Mystery Bidders Arise for Alitalia
text: A largely Italian consortium of financiers and entrepreneurs has expressed interest in buying ailing Italian airline Alitalia, which is struggling to find a buyer after a failed auction, the group’s lawyer said on Friday.

headline: Straws in the Wind for Wall Street
text: Before weather vanes and barometers and Doppler radar, farmers had the habit of tossing a handful of dry chaff in the air and watching which way and how far it fell, to inform their hunches about the weather to come — far from foolproof, of course, but at least it was something to go by.

headline: Branson Considers Buying Back Stake in Virgin Atlantic
text: Richard Branson’s Virgin Group is considering whether to buy out Singapore Airlines‘ 49 percent stake in Virgin Atlantic, Reuters reported Friday. And if it does so, Mr. Branson may take the airline public.

headline: Morning Buzz: Storm’s Aftermath, Newark Arrests, Child Welfare Failures and More
text: The aftermath of the storm that overwhelmed the subway system and the arrest of a man and a youth in the execution-style killings of three college students in Newark are the two major stories in the local news today.

headline: Exploring hidden Paris by canal boat
text: By David Rampe

headline: Fed Adds $19 Billion by Buying Mortgage-Backed Debt
text: Aug. 10 (Bloomberg) -- The Federal Reserve added $19 billion in temporary funds to the banking system through the purchase of mortgage-backed securities to help meet demand for cash amid a rout in bonds backed by home loans to riskier borrowers.

headline: ‘Hottest Year’ Data Meltdown
text: You just thought you were sweating? Among global warming Cassandras, the fact that 1998 was the “hottest year on record” has always been an article of faith. Stephen McIntyre, who runs the Climateaudit blog was always puzzled by some gaps he saw in the raw data provided by NASA that supported the claim (data compiled in part by James Hansen, the climate scientist who has long accused the Bush administration of trying to “silence” him). McIntyre says he has “reverse engineered” the data to find NASA’s algorithm, discovered that a Y2K bug played havoc with some of the numbers, and notified the space agency.

headline: Import Prices Rise on Higher Oil Costs
text: Aug. 10 (Bloomberg) -- Prices of goods imported into the U.S. rose more than forecast in July on higher oil costs, highlighting Federal Reserve concerns that inflation may not subside.

headline: States Ramp Up R&D Efforts as Federal Funding Fades
text: Whether you saw it as a tough ethical choice or pandering to conservative evangelicals, President Bush's decision in August 2001 to ban government funding of new stem cell research was an ominous turn. It marked the beginning of a steady erosion in federal spending on research and development.

headline: Federal Reserve Adds Cash to Soothe Nervous Markets
text: The Federal Reserve on Friday morning joined the European Central Bank and policy makers in Asia to add temporary cash to the banking system, aiming to stem a collapse in credit markets as lenders try to protect themselves against losses.

headline: 2008: Romney’s Real Test
text: For one or more of the Republican presidential candidates, Ames, Iowa, the location of tomorrow’s G.O.P. straw poll, may be where the campaign trail ends. Former Wisconsin Gov. Tommy Thompson has already said that without a first or second-place finish, he’s likely to drop out. Other campaigns are looking for a major lift from this weekend’s big political event — even though two leading Republicans, Rudolph W. Giuliani and John McCain, aren’t taking part.

headline: Quick Bits: AT&T Sorry About Censorship, Fraudsters Invade Second Life
text: AT&T decided it shouldn’t be in the censorship business. It apologized for cutting out parts of a Pearl Jam song it was Webcasting that criticized President Bush. [AP]

headline: Answers About Latino New York, Part 2
text: Following is the second and final set of responses from Carolina González and Seth Kugel, freelance journalists who wrote “Nueva York: The Complete Guide to Latino Life in the Five Boroughs” and run a blog about Latino life in New York City. Mr. Kugel and Ms. González tookquestions from City Room readers this week. The first set of responses was posted on Wednesday.

Judy Blume
text: Judy Blume’s books include “Forever” and “Are You There, God? It’s Me, Margaret.”

headline: Soldier From Washington Heights Is Killed in Iraq
text: Cpl. Juan M. Alcantara, 22, from the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, was one of four soldiers killed on Aug. 6 in Baquba, Iraq, after a bomb detonated while they were checking for explosives in abandoned houses.

headline: Q and A:  Tom Colicchio
text: It’s been a busy year for Tom Colicchio, a chef who was plenty busy already. “Top Chef” entered its third season, and Mr. Colicchio was still along for the ride, telling aspiring chefs where they went wrong and right, lending the show a kind of gravitas that keeps it from feeling too silly and melodramatic.

headline: Delgado’s Thoughts Remain a Mystery
text: The Mets’ locker room was not exactly a festive place after yesterday’s 7-6 loss to the Atlanta Braves, especially because the Mets staged a comeback that fell short by a few feet. Carlos Delgado was robbed of a solo homer by Willie Harris with one out in the ninth inning. It would have tied the game. Delgado looked disgusted as he retreated into the dugout.

headline: ‘Well, You’ve Got Me’
text: With those words, one of the longest and costliest manhunts in New York City came to an end.

headline: Mayor Calls Subway Disruptions a ‘Total Meltdown,’ Then Bickers With Radio Host
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg usually defends agencies and utilities in their response to emergencies — see his repeated defenses of the Consolidated Edison chairman and chief executive, Kevin M. Burke. Or at least he typically refrains from outright criticism. But in an apparent break from that pattern, the mayor this morning had sharp words for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s handling of a sudden rainstorm this week that shutdown of the subway system, calling it a “total meltdown.”

headline: The Buyout Loan Merry-Go-Round
text: If you aren’t confused by the recent credit crunch and its effects on the leveraged-buyout business, you will be soon.

headline: Beltrán Switches His Position
text: Carlos Beltrán was eligible to come off the disabled list yesterday but did not. Chances are he will not play tonight when the Mets begin a weekend series against the Florida Marlins. It appears as if he needs at least another day. Beltrán is still coping with pain from a strained left oblique muscle sustained on July 25. He can hit from the left side, field and throw without pain. But hitting from the right side is still problematic.

headline: Giuliani: I’m a 9/11 Worker
text: UpdatedIf you can’t beat ’em, join ’em. While campaigning in Ohio yesterday, Rudolph W. Giuliani adopted a variation of this approach when he was discussing the rescue and recovery efforts at ground zero following the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: New Bus Shelters Let You Plan Your Shopping and TV-Watching but Not Your Trip
text: In the department of missing transit information, the absence of route maps and trip tips at a few of the new bus-stop shelters being installed by Cemusa scarcely rises to the level of outrage.

headline: Canals, London-Style
text: A colleague of mine in Paris, David Rampe, has written about exploring the canals of Paris. Well, Paris is not the only European capital with an underappreciated set of picturesque old canals. London has some, too. Now that summer finally appears to have come to Britain, along with crowds of tourists at more famous sites, it’s a good time to explore these lesser known corners of London. Perhaps you’ll even want to stop for a pint.

headline: On Ceremony for Pitcher, Caller Tosses Bloomberg a Bit of a Curve
text: On Wednesday, after a thunderstorm shut down the subways and a rare tornado wreaked havoc in Brooklyn, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg paused to present pitcher Tom Glavine of the Mets the key to the city in honor of his 300th career victory, which he collected on Sunday night in Chicago.

headline: Falcons Embrace Change
text: The union of Coach Bobby Petrino and quarterback Michael Vick once seemed like a perfect match. Petrino, an offensive guru and former college quarterback, left Louisville earlier this year to become the Atlanta Falcons’ new head coach. He was hired to help finally turn Vick into a consistent winner.

headline: Bob Murray: Mine Owner and Lightning Rod
text: Outside the coal mining industry or Republican political circles, not many people would have had much reason to know who Bob Murray was before this week. Now, as the head of the company that co-owns and operates the Crandall Canyon Mine in Utah, where six miners have been trapped by a collapse since early Monday morning, Mr. Murray is the nationally known face of the drama — a face that a remarkable number of people seem to want to spit on.

headline: Moondancing All the Way to Wyoming
text: The journey of the Moondance Diner, reputedly the oldest surviving diner in New York City, to the small town of LaBarge, Wyo., about 2,125 miles away, is to begin in a matter of hours.Today, workers from a rigging company began breaking up the concrete foundation around the diner, at Grand Street and Avenue of the Americas near the Holland Tunnel. The move had been scheduled for Tuesday, but was delayed after city officials sought more information on how the diner would be lifted off its foundation. (Hydraulic jacks will be used.) There was a rush to get the necessary paperwork signed, but everything appears to be in order now.

The brand that made it famous is called Spanx, and it’s spandex, but no number of sporty x’s and cheerful rebranding can hide the truth: it’s a girdle.

headline: Making Sense of the Markets
text: Easy credit in the American home-loan market has turned from a sales pitch to a curse, as the troubles with subprime mortgages have developed into a credit squeeze that is shaking the world’s markets and has made loans much harder to get. Will the latest upheaval pose a threat to continued economic growth — and your own financial security? Floyd Norris, the chief financial correspondent of The Times, recently answered questions from readers about all the turmoil.

headline: Romney Confronts the War in Iowa
text: DES MOINES — It wasn’t exactly a day at the fair for Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, as he took his turn today giving the soapbox speech at the Iowa State Fair. It wasn’t the speech itself, that went fine. It was what happened afterward.

headline: Richardson Clarifies Gay Gaffe
text: After stumbling through a question at a forum Thursday night about whether people choose to be gay or are born that way, Democratic presidential candidate Bill Richardson spent part of the day trying to regain his footing by reaching out to prominent members of the gay and lesbian community.

headline: Remembering Long Island Dragway
text: One of the last bits that I cut out of my latest Auto Ego article on Mike Tyrrell were his laments on the closing of Long Island Dragway three years ago. Once there were several drag strips and oval tracks spread all over Long Island. Today there’s only Riverhead Raceway, which is a quarter-mile oval. There are no more drag strips. Long Island Dragway was the last.
