headline: Cashman’s Plan Takes Hold as Homegrown Yanks Take Over
text: Look at the Yankees’ roster right now. Of the 25 players, how many would you guess began their U.S. professional careers with the Yankees? Would you believe more than half?

headline: ‘Big Brother’ Wins
text: CBS was the most-watched network on Thursday night, thanks in part to the eviction installment of “Big Brother” at 8, which had 7.8 million viewers, according to Nielsen, the most that the show has had this summer. While CBS’s rerun of “CSI” at 9 delivered the night’s biggest audience over all (9.8 million), “Big Brother” was the night’s most popular show among adults 18 to 49. Fox’s coverage of the preseason football game between the Indianapolis Colts and the Dallas Cowboys had 7.5 million total viewers and was the second-highest-rated show in the 18-to-49 demographic. At 10, NBC’s “ER” repeat finished last (2.8 million) behind reruns of ABC’s “Men in Trees” (3.7 million) and CBS’s “Without a Trace” (9.2 million).

headline: Stones Film Is Delayed
text: The theatrical release of a concert documentary about the Rolling Stones by Martin Scorsese, right, has been postponed by seven months, to April, Reuters reported. The film, “Shine a Light,” had been scheduled to come out on Sept. 21, but a spokeswoman for the studio, Paramount Classics, said that more time was needed to set up a promotional campaign, and that the band was busy on a European tour through Aug. 26. Mr. Scorsese was in Rome last month to show the band a rough cut of the film, which was shot over two shows at the Beacon Theater in Manhattan last fall, featuring guest appearances by Jack White, Christina Aguilera and Buddy Guy.

headline: ‘You Go, Girl,’ as Translated Into Hindi
text: The making-of-a-team sports movie is a timeworn genre, and yet “Chak De! India” (“Go, India!”) finds new variations. Though the game here is field hockey, those fondly recalling the United States soccer team’s first-place finish in the 1991 Women’s World Cup will find a lot to like.

headline: A Horse Saves His Best for the Stretch Run of His Career
text: As one good racehorse after another ascends to stardom and then disappears in what seems like an instant, the exception will attempt to win today’s Arlington Million at Arlington Park outside Chicago. The Tin Man is a crafty old pro who possesses the rare combination of talent and durability and is still very much on top of his game at age 9. That is why he is considered one of horses to beat in one of racing’s premier grass events.

headline: Armstrong Team Falls With Cycling’s Image
text: The cycling team of Lance Armstrong and of this year’s Tour de France winner is disbanding for lack of a sponsor, the latest evidence that the sport is collapsing under the weight of persistent doping problems.

headline: U.S. Fines the City $30,000 a Day Over Delay in Water Filtration Project
text: One of the costliest construction projects in city history, a $2.1 billion water filtration plant in the Bronx that has been troubled by delays, community opposition and charges of mismanagement, is now being fined $30,000 a day by the federal government because there is no primary contractor to start the work.

headline: Judge Blocks Video of Anna Nicole Smith
text: A two-hour video of Anna Nicole Smith undergoing breast augmentation surgery has been blocked from distribution by a California judge, Reuters reported. The estate of Ms. Smith, the former stripper and reality-television star who died in February at 39, won a court order barring a plastic surgeon in Houston from selling or circulating videos of procedures that he performed on her in 1994. A lawsuit filed by her estate’s executor, Howard K. Stern, accused the physician, Dr. Gerald Wayne Johnson, of taping the surgery without Ms. Smith’s consent and sending copies to a Los Angeles-based memorabilia dealer, Thomas Riccio.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a report from The Associated Press and a subheading in the baseball roundup in some copies on Thursday about Wednesday’s game between Baltimore and Seattle reversed the outcome. The Mariners won, 8-4  not the Orioles.

headline: Market Swings Are First Crisis for Fed Chairman
text: Should the Federal Reserve help bail out billionaire hedge fund managers and millionaire traders — the very people who bought the risky mortgages that led to the current market panic?

headline: Fire Damages Film Sets at Studio in Rome
text: A fire has damaged part of the landmark Cinecittà film studio, right, in Rome, where thousands of films, from “Cleopatra” to “Gangs of New York,” have been made, The Associated Press reported. The blaze began late on Thursday on the set of “Rome,” an HBO series about the ancient empire, and burned through about 32,000 square feet before it was put out, firefighters said. No injuries were reported. Officials said the site where the fire broke out had a large amount of highly flammable synthetic material. The cause of the fire was unclear, but officials ruled out arson. A spokeswoman for HBO said that the main set of “Rome,” which includes a mock Forum, had not been destroyed, but that other parts of the set had been badly damaged. (The series, which ran for two seasons, has ended.) Opened by Mussolini in 1937, the sprawling complex covers about 100 acres on the outskirts of the city. The fire did not affect the historic parts of the studio, which houses the sets of “Ben-Hur” and other movies that were filmed there.

headline: NATIONAL BRIEFING | MIDWEST | Iowa: No December Caucuses
text: Gov. Chet Culver said the state’s 2008 caucuses, which traditionally begin the presidential nominating process, would be held in January. As South Carolina and other states consider moving up their contests, the prospect was raised that the Iowa caucuses could take place before the end of this year. “We’re not going in December; it just doesn’t make sense,” said Mr. Culver, left. New Hampshire’s secretary of state, William M. Gardner, has yet to announce a date for his state’s primary. Iowa law calls for the caucuses to come seven days before the New Hampshire primary, but Iowa officials said they would consider changing that law to keep the traditional one-two punch of Iowa and New Hampshire alive. “In this state, we’re going to still have Christmas,” Mr. Culver said.

headline: Google Is Closing Its Video Retailing Operation
text: After buying the video-sharing site YouTube nine months ago for $1.65 billion, Google plans to stop selling television shows on its homegrown video site.

headline: Central Banks Intervene to Calm Volatile Markets
text: Central banks around the world acted in unison yesterday to calm nervous financial markets by providing an infusion of cash to the system. But stocks still fell sharply in Asia and Europe, and in early trading in New York, before they recovered and closed essentially flat for the day on Wall Street.

headline: A Hamptons Barbecue, Aglow With Star Power
text: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. — Debbie Bancroft’s daughter Serena, a towheaded 11-year old with a tennis tan, had an important announcement one recent Sunday afternoon. “Mom, you know the Southside, that drink they have at National?” she asked. “Daddy put it in the chicken last night. Like, all of it.”

text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 10 — Dead blocks, they call them, the most visible legacy of the latest war in a city with a long history of wars.

headline: Wedded to Work, and in Dire Need of a Wife
text: Now that women have solidly earned their place in the work force, many find themselves still yearning for something men often have: wives.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 9 P.M. (Hallmark) CLAIRE  (2007) Valerie Bertinelli, above, returns to television after a four-year absence (but before her Jenny Craig weight loss) in this thriller about a widowed mother of two tormented by the death of her husband, which she saw through her psychic powers but couldn’t prevent. Now it’s up to her to face her fears and protect her community from a killer who seems to be striking randomly. This being Hallmark, she’s closer to the murders than she thinks.

headline: Making a Home, and a Haven for Books
text: Kurt Thometz got to the brownstone on 160th Street first, but a woman who designed lingerie came with more. “The underwear lady, she had $2 million in her purse, or so the broker told me,” he said. “Maybe what that actually meant is that she didn’t need a mortgage.”

headline: Los Angeles Hospital to Close After Failing Tests and Losing Financing
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 — Martin Luther King Jr.-Harbor Hospital, built in the aftermath of the Watts riots and one of the few hospitals serving the poorest residents of South Los Angeles, is headed for closing after federal regulators found Friday that it was unable to meet minimum standards for patient care.

headline: The Young and the Fearless, and Knowing When to Ruff
text: The premier event at the 21st European Youth Team Championships in Jesolo, Italy, last month was the junior teams, for players born in 1982 or later. The 22 countries played a complete round robin of 20-board matches. The winner was the team from the Netherlands, which finished just ahead of Italy, with Poland well behind in third.

headline: After Minneapolis Disaster, Concerns About the Pulaski Skyway
text: The Pulaski Skyway, a three-mile long steel silhouette rising and falling across the Meadowlands of New Jersey, has over the years attracted its share of praise, curiosity and, for those paying close attention to “The Sopranos,” a glancing kind of television fame.

headline: Bush 41 and 43, and the Rest of Us (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: At Weddings, Efficiency vs. Etiquette
text: A QUESTION appeared in the Dear Abby advice column recently that highlighted a new wrinkle in the financial side of wedding etiquette.

headline: Concern Rises About Reports of New Fighting in Darfur
text: MALAKAL, Sudan, Aug. 10 — The African Union is investigating reports of a new round of intense fighting between Sudanese government troops and rebels in Darfur in which more than 100 soldiers may have been killed, an African Union spokesman said Friday.

headline: Mel Shavelson, 90, Film Writer-Director, Is Dead
text: Mel Shavelson, a noted screenwriter, producer and director who worked with some of Hollywood’s biggest, brightest and most temperamental stars, died on Wednesday at his home in Studio City, Calif. He was 90.

headline: States Try to Alter How Presidents Are Elected
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 — When state Democratic leaders from around the country meet this weekend in Vermont, the California chairman, Art Torres, expects to be peppered with the sort of questions that have been clogging his in-box for weeks.

headline: Partial-Birth Abortion (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fannie Mae’s Offer to Help Ease Credit Squeeze Is Rejected, as Critics Complain of Opportunism
text: Fannie Mae, the nation’s biggest buyer of home loans, was blocked yesterday from expanding its mortgage holdings by 10 percent in what it called an effort to ease concerns about credit and shore up the struggling housing market.

headline: A Segregated Road in an Already Divided Land
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 10 — Israel is constructing a road through the West Bank, east of Jerusalem, that will allow both Israelis and Palestinians to travel along it — separately.

headline: Browns’ Quinn Shouldn’t Need to Apologize
text: Berea, Ohio

headline: Howard Judd, 71, Menopause Expert, Dies
text: Dr. Howard L. Judd, whose early studies of hot flashes led to refinements in the use of estrogen and other drugs to treat women who experience unpleasant symptoms during menopause, died on July 19 at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 71.

headline: A Prayerful Three-Pointer From the Orchestra Pit
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 10 — New religions do not arise every day, so serious note should be taken when a belief moves from cult status to bona fide faith. Recently a nascent creed has stolen the hearts and minds of thousands of young Americans. Its key tenets include the idea that everyone gets along really well in high school, and thus that being a teenager is super fun.

headline: Buyout Firm Says It Intends to Back Out of Deal for Lender
text: Lone Star Funds said yesterday it would not complete a takeover of Accredited Home Lenders Holding, citing “drastic deterioration in the financial and operational condition” of the mortgage company since the deal was announced. Accredited shares fell 44 percent in late trading.

headline: Scouting Central Park With Hope of Reaching Beijing
text: On any summer day, Central Park teems with recreational runners trying to log a few miles, burn some calories and escape cramped apartments and offices.

headline: Farmers Call Crackdown on Illegal Workers Unfair
text: Facing the prospect of major layoffs of farmworkers during harvest season, growers and lawmakers from agricultural states spoke in dire terms yesterday about new measures by the Bush administration to crack down on employers of illegal immigrants.

headline: Pressured School District Reverses, Allowing Play on Murder of Gay Student
text: OCEAN TOWNSHIP, N.J. Aug. 10  After a week of public outcry over the school district’s decision to block Ocean Township High School’s drama club from performing “The Laramie Project,” Superintendent Thomas M. Pagano decided Thursday to let the play go on this fall.

headline: Get the Lead Out (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Campaign Is a Family Project for the Romneys
text: AMES, Iowa, Aug. 10 — They have driven here from California, Ohio, Canada and Texas; flown from Michigan, Utah and Florida. There are aunts, uncles, cousins, second cousins, in-laws, nieces, nephews and grandchildren.

headline: Backup to Fore in Opener for Jets
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 10 — On the cold, damp night when Thomas Jones made his debut with the Jets, Leon Washington stole his thunder.

headline: Well-Traveled Photographer, Recording and Then Returning
text: ARLES, France — Susan Meiselas is looking a bit shaken. She has just heard that her trip to Guinea, scheduled to start the next day, has been canceled; her driver there has been assaulted and is fleeing the country. She is working with Human Rights Watch photographing child domestic workers, and clearly someone didn’t like it.

headline: Wicked Wickets of the East: Talking Tough on a Croquet Court
text: I COMMENCED my re-entry into competitive croquet on a sunny midsummer’s morning rife with misguided ambition and deceit. It was the opening day of the Meadow Club Invitational in Southampton, N.Y. In keeping with croquet custom, I wore white from cap to sneakers. My assigned first-round doubles partner was a silver-haired woman with an elastic band wrapped around her injured left wrist.

headline: Robotically Human After All: Daft Punk Melding Man and Machine
text: In 2005 the French dance-music duo known as Daft Punk seemed to be in a slump. After two brilliant and hugely influential CDs, the members, Thomas Bangalter and Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo, had disappointed fans with a third album, “Human After All,” that sounded relatively rote and uninspired.

headline: Head of City’s Arabic School Steps Down Under Pressure
text: The principal of New York City’s first public school dedicated to the study of Arabic language and culture resigned under pressure yesterday, days after she was quoted defending the use of the word “intifada” as a T-shirt slogan.

headline: Once Fired, Now Hired
text: Shawn Killinger, a former television reporter who was let go in Episode 3 of the 2005 television series “The Apprentice: Martha Stewart” after the host criticized her slogan “Fake it till you make it,” has been hired as a program host on the QVC shopping network. Ms. Killinger responded to a help-wanted ad that QVC had placed on tvjobs.com, and the network liked her chatty style. “Shawn has a natural ability to exude what we want, which is the over-the-fence philosophy in terms of talking to your neighbor,” said Kate Kirsch, a QVC spokeswoman. Ms. Killinger, a former CBS page and morning show host in Orlando, Fla., is undergoing a six-month apprenticeship at QVC and will begin as host on her own three- or four-hour overnight shifts in December.

headline: To Curb Illegal Migration, Spain Offers a Legal Route
text: TORRIJOS, Spain, Aug. 7 — Fatou Faye was not the first person to head for Spain from her run-down corner of Dakar, the Senegalese capital. Half a dozen friends and relatives left before her, squeezing into wooden fishing boats and wagering their lives on the high seas for the chance of a future in Europe.

headline: A Bloodbath in Newark, and Beyond
text: NEWARK

headline: Harrington Shines in an Offense Suddenly Short on Stars
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 10  For one unseasonably cool evening at a sparsely filled stadium in a New Jersey swamp, the Atlanta Falcons were a team without controversy, or star quality. Michael Vick was far away, his passing arm and his legal troubles hermetically sealed behind an N.F.L. ban.

headline: How Did Elvis Get Turned Into a Racist?
text: ONE of the songs Elvis Presley liked to perform in the ’70s was Joe South’s “Walk a Mile in My Shoes,” its message clearly spelled out in the title.

headline: The Need to Know
text: Like many in this country who were angered when Congress rushed to rubber-stamp a bill giving President Bush even more power to spy on Americans, we took some hope from the vow by Congressional Democrats to rewrite the new law after summer vacation. The chance of undoing the damage is slim, unless the White House stops stonewalling and gives lawmakers and the public the information they need to understand this vital issue.

headline: Food Aid Resources (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Japan: Nuclear Plant May Be Down for a Year
text: International nuclear inspectors said it would take up to a year for a nuclear power plant damaged during last month’s earthquake in Niigata Prefecture to restart operations, echoing an assessment by Japanese experts. The team from the International Atomic Energy Agency completed a four-day inspection of the plant, which is operated by Tokyo Electric Power, and is expected to release a report shortly on its safety.

headline: Record U.S. Corn Crop, Up 24%, Is Forecast
text: This year’s United States corn crop will be 24 percent bigger than last year’s, the government said yesterday, because farmers planted the most acres since 1944 after prices rose to a 10-year high in February.

headline: Italian Pride Is Revived in a Tiny Fiat
text: TURIN, Italy — When Luca De Meo, 40, became chief executive of the Italian carmaker Fiat Automobiles five years ago, one of his relatives — he forgets whether it was his aunt or his mother — told him, “Luca, you’ve got to bring back the 500,” or the Cinquecento, the chubby little car that symbolized Italy’s postwar economic miracle.

headline: Judge Says Unix Copyrights Rightfully Belong to Novell
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10  In a decision that may finally settle one of the most bitter legal battles surrounding software widely used in corporate data centers, a federal district court judge in Utah ruled Friday afternoon that Novell, not the SCO Group, is the rightful owner of the copyrights covering the Unix operating system.

headline: As Envoys Meet, No Budging on a Stalemate Over Kosovo
text: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia, Aug. 10 — A month after talks on the future of Kosovo foundered at the United Nations Security Council, envoys from the United States, the European Union and Russia began a three-day visit to the region on Friday in an attempt to kick-start a new round of negotiations.

headline: Air Test Results Worry Those Searching for Miners
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 10 — The search for six trapped coal miners suffered what appeared to be a major setback on Friday when a test found oxygen levels incapable of sustaining life inside a cavity where the miners were last known to be.

headline: Making Our Votes Count (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: When It Rains, Sewage Often Pours Into Harbor
text: Besides flooding subways, the wild downpour this week provided a disconcerting glimpse into one of New York’s dirtiest environmental secrets: heavy rain regularly overwhelms the city’s vast sewage system and pushes polluted water into places it is not supposed to go.

headline: A Mind-Set That’s Made for TV
text: BURBANK, Calif. — It was time, Amy Bloom said, to go to the other side of the room with the requisite couch, the box of tissues and the clock ticking down the 50-minute hour. You know, the side where the therapist sits, interpreting dreams and impassively imbibing neuroses. Or maybe not.

headline: Classics Out West
text: SINCE it began in 1950, the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance has perhaps become the signature event for classic car enthusiasts and collectors. The annual summer pilgrimage to California has grown into a weeklong celebration on the Monterey peninsula, with exhibitions, rallies and auctions.

headline: Europeans Are Wondering About Subprime Exposure
text: LONDON, Aug. 10  As subprime market tremors in the United States spread to Europe, they are raising questions whether regulation and accounting rules on the Continent are forcing companies to disclose enough information to investors about their exposure to such high-risk assets.

headline: Home Depot Wants In, but Some Arms Aren’t Open
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 — A proposal to open a Home Depot is deeply dividing the mostly rural area of Sunland in northern Los Angeles, but not for the usual reasons.

headline: Judge Sides With Broadcom in Qualcomm Patent Fight
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 (Bloomberg News) — The Broadcom Corporation was tentatively awarded $39.3 million in damages and legal fees on Friday in a patent dispute with a rival chip maker, Qualcomm, after a federal judge upheld a jury verdict that Qualcomm had infringed three patents.

headline: Corrections
text: An article and headline in Business Day on Thursday about a suit involving the collapse of the commodities firm Refco, and the High & Low Finance column on Friday about the same subject, referred incorrectly to both the defendants and the plaintiff in the suit. As the article described, the suit was filed by the trustee of the Refco Liquidation Trust, which represents creditors of Refco. He is not the Refco bankruptcy trustee, as the headline said, nor is he the trustee of the company, as the first paragraph said.

headline: Gunman Dies After Fight With Guards in Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 10 — A gunfight erupted in Jerusalem’s Old City on Friday when a young Arab man stole a pistol from a security guard and tried to flee. The young man was killed and 10 people were wounded, 3 moderately, including the guard, the police said.

headline: Vague Threat Prompts Steps by N.Y. Police
text: The Police Department set up checkpoints yesterday in Lower Manhattan and increased security after learning of a vague threat of a radiological attack here.

headline: Value of Arts Education (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Glavine Says a World Series Title Would Nudge Him Toward Retirement
text: If the Mets win the World Series this season, do not expect Tom Glavine to return next year. In a lengthy interview with reporters before the opener of a three-game series between the Mets and the Florida Marlins last night, Glavine said he would be more inclined to return for a 21st season if the Mets’ year ended without a championship.

headline: Ex-Comverse Chief Keeps Maneuvering to Avoid Return to U.S. in Options Case
text: WINDHOEK, Namibia, Aug. 10 — Jacob Alexander, the former chief executive of Comverse Technology, who faces charges of options fraud and is regarded as a fugitive, took his latest step on Friday to fight extradition from Namibia to New York.

headline: Wagner Lets Rare One Get Away, Spoiling Beltrán’s Return
text: When Billy Wagner runs from the bullpen to the mound during the ninth inning of games at Shea Stadium, fans always cheer as Metallica’s “Enter Sandman” blares over loudspeakers. And they almost always leave the ballpark to the tune of a victory.

headline: Security Council Approves a Broader U.N. Mandate in Iraq to Seek Reconciliation
text: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 10 — The Security Council approved a resolution on Friday that broadened the United Nations mandate in Iraq to include efforts to promote national reconciliation, help settle border disputes, encourage internal dialogue and lay the groundwork for a national census.

headline: NATIONAL BRIEFING | SOUTH | Florida: Sheriff’s Deputy Is Fatally Shot
text: A Broward County sheriff’s deputy was killed in the second shooting of a Broward deputy in the line of duty this week, the authorities said. The deputy, identified as Sgt. Chris Reyka, 51, was on routine patrol when he became suspicious of two cars in a parking lot behind a drugstore in Pompano Beach. As Sergeant Reyka got out of his car to investigate, someone jumped out of one of the cars and shot him several times before fleeing, according to a statement issued by the sheriff’s office. The shooting of Sergeant Reyka, an 18-year veteran of the force, comes four days after Maury Hernandez, an undercover Broward County sheriff’s deputy, was critically injured when he was shot in the head by a motorcyclist he had pulled over for running several red lights.

headline: Republicans in the Straw
text: Des MOINES

headline: In Hospital, Boyfriend Is Arraigned in Killing
text: Michael Cordero entered a cramped, antiseptic room inside Bellevue Hospital Center yesterday afternoon and sat down in a blue plastic chair.

headline: As Is: One Bridge, Needs Work
text: In its last state inspection, the Brooklyn Bridge rated 2.9 on a scale of 7, an unabashed poor rating, barely passing. It was not bad enough to close it or further limit traffic and city officials pronounce the bridge safe, but New Yorkers should be excused if they begin looking at the 124-year-old landmark in a different way.

headline: It Pays to Look for Trouble
text: YOU can always try to fix a problem after the fact, but doesn’t it make more sense to keep things from going terribly wrong initially?

headline: Bloodthirsty New Book Incites a Bidding War
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 — The item up for bidding was, at first blush, unremarkable. It was an unfinished manuscript, 397 pages long, less than half of the planned book, as well as an outline detailing story arcs and plot points to come. The writer? Someone named Jordan Ainsley, whom no one had ever heard of — not readers, not book editors, certainly not anyone in Hollywood. Yet the biggest movie studios were being asked to pony up seven figures for the privilege of committing the book, sight half-unseen, to film.

headline: Gouge Made by Debris Seen on Shuttle Wing
text: A piece of debris hit the underside of the space shuttle Endeavour during liftoff on Wednesday and gouged a small but potentially worrisome divot in a heat shield tile, NASA officials said yesterday.

headline: Swords Into Plowshares (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Fire Damages Film Sets At Studio in Rome

headline: Man Pleads Guilty in Attack on Portrait
text: A homeless man in London pleaded guilty yesterday to attacking a portrait of the 18th-century literary giant Samuel Johnson with a hammer, The Associated Press reported. Mark Paton, 44, was arrested on Wednesday after repeatedly hitting the $3.4 million portrait, by Joshua Reynolds, at the National Portrait Gallery. He admitted intent to cause criminal damage, though gave no explanation for the attack. “He has nothing against Sir Joshua Reynolds or Samuel Johnson,” said his defense lawyer, Euan MacMillan. Quentin Purdy, a district judge in the City of Westminster Magistrates’ Court, ordered Mr. Paton to undergo psychiatric tests before sentencing. The museum said it was confident that the painting could be repaired.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Giuliani Missteps in Imagery of Sept. 11
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani sought yesterday to clarify comments of a day earlier in which he called himself “one of” the Sept. 11 cleanup workers and said he had been “at ground zero as often, if not more, than most of the workers.” His statement has attracted sharp criticism from first responders and a rival campaign.

headline: Yanks of Future Offer Help in Present
text: CLEVELAND, Aug. 10 — Joba Chamberlain has a ritual before his first pitch of a game. He stands behind the mound, his back to the catcher, his glove on the grass, his hat in his hand and his head bowed. Then he points to the sky, climbs up the dirt slope and starts to terrorize opposing hitters.

headline: Hotter Than Hot, Woods Takes Lead
text: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 10 — The crickets fell silent when Tiger Woods, surrounded by a gallery of thousands, studied the sunbaked grass of the 18th green. He grabbed a white towel and wiped his forehead before finally settling beside his ball, turning his head to look at the hole and then returning his gaze downward.

headline: High-Maintenance Musharraf
text: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice helped head off what could have been a political cataclysm by calling Gen. Pervez Musharraf at 2 a.m. in Pakistan on Thursday and talking him out of seizing new powers to suspend Parliament, hamstring the courts, curb street demonstrations and guarantee himself a new presidential term. But the crisis may only have been postponed.

headline: Energy Surge
text: Buried in the rancor and confusion of the House’s prevacation windup last week was final passage of an energy bill aimed at moving the country toward a cleaner and more secure energy future. The bill will be negotiated with the Senate, which passed a companion measure in June. If they approve the best elements of both, the negotiators would produce the most useful energy bill in many years  and a modest, but important, down payment on the task of reducing oil dependency and global warming emissions.

headline: Canada Announces Plans for 2 New Bases in Its Far North
text: OTTAWA, Aug. 10 — In the latest of a series of claims over portions of the Arctic, Canada said Friday that it planned to build two new military bases in the far north to assert its sovereignty over the Northwest Passage.

headline: Pakistani Leader to Attend Afghan Tribal Gathering
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 10 — As hundreds of Pakistani and Afghan delegates entered a second day of discussions, the office of Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, announced Friday that he would attend the conclusion of the assembly, which was aimed at trying to end the terrorism and insurgency threatening both countries.

headline: The Miners
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 10 — Citing privacy concerns, Murray Energy has withheld the names of the six miners trapped in the Crandall Canyon Mine. But relatives and friends have confirmed their identities.

headline: South Africa: Fired Official Speaks Out
text: South Africa’s former deputy health minister, fired this week by President Thabo Mbeki, said her ouster was unjustified. “I was just doing my job,” Nozizwe Madlala-Routledge, said at a press conference. She said the health minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, once told her, “I’ll fix you,” and might have engineered her firing. While Dr. Tshabalala-Msimang has been fiercely criticized for ineffective AIDS policies, Ms. Madlala-Routledge won praise for trying to invigorate the government’s fight against the epidemic. The Health Ministry said in a statement that it remained committed to “pulling out all the stops” to expand AIDS prevention and treatment programs. The ministry denied that Dr. Tshabalala-Msimang had ever threatened to “fix” her deputy. “No such statement was ever made,” the ministry said.

headline: Footnotes
text: Richard Gaddes, 65, below, the second general director in the 51-year history of the Santa Fe Opera, has announced his intention to retire after his successor is chosen in a search estimated to last a year to 18 months. ... About a dozen of China’s well-known terra-cotta warrior figures will be among 120 works that will be seen at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta from Nov. 15, 2008, to April 26, 2009, in the exhibition “The First Emperor: China’s Terracotta Army.” The exhibition will be seen at the British Museum in London from Sept. 13, 2007, through April 6, 2008. ... ABC has ordered a comedy pilot starring Cedric the Entertainer as a proud family breadwinner who has difficulty adjusting after his wife’s hobby becomes a multimillion-dollar enterprise, Reuters reported.

headline: Comics’ Future May Loom on a Monitor, Not a TV
text: Midway through the recently concluded Just for Laughs comedy festival in Montreal, her first as vice president for programming, Maureen Taran was talking with a veteran stand-up comic who wondered, with evident envy, why so many young sketch groups were generating so much industry interest, and how he could get that kind of attention.

headline: Christies to Open Branch in Russia
text: Three months after Sotheby’s opened a Moscow office, Christie’s says it has plans to open a branch there as well, as wealthy Russians become an increasingly powerful force on the world’s art auction scene. A European executive for Christie’s International told Bloomberg News that the company would open a branch in Moscow by the end of the year, though it had not settled on a location. The office will cultivate clients and arrange for private sales, though auctions will not be held there. Christie’s said its sales of Russian art increased more than sevenfold from 2000 to 2006. The company sold $70.5 million worth of Russian art around the world last year and $69 million in the first half of 2007.

headline: Kiwanuka Readies for Debut at Linebacker
text: ALBANY, Aug. 9 — The off-season transition from defensive end to linebacker has been a private one for Mathias Kiwanuka, taking place in the classroom, on the practice field and in his own mind. Finally, in Saturday’s preseason game against the Carolina Panthers at Giants Stadium, Kiwanuka will be tested as the Giants’ starting strong-side linebacker.

headline: Explosive Barroom Fight Is Etched in Witness’s Mind
text: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 10  It was a balmy Sunday night last October, and Huguito’s, a tavern that caters to this community’s thriving population of Latin American immigrants, was jumping.

headline: Army, Shedding a Slump, Met July Recruiting Goal
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10  After falling short of its recruiting goals for two straight months, the Army said Friday that it had met its July quota, partly by pouring more personnel and other resources into the effort.

headline: Reported Drop in Surveillance Spurred a Law
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 — At a closed-door briefing in mid-July, senior intelligence officials startled lawmakers with some troubling news. American eavesdroppers were collecting just 25 percent of the foreign-based communications they had been receiving a few months earlier.

headline: A Werewolf War in Need of a Silver Bullet
text: Splitting hairs both morally and literally, “Skinwalkers,” the latest human-inhuman hybrid movie, pits good werewolves against bad — even if the distinction is fuzzier than their hides.

headline: Three Contemporaries, Each With a Different Way to View the Past
text: The three artists in “Midnight’s Daydream” were all artists in residence this past year at the Studio Museum in Harlem, but they take very different approaches to making art.

headline: Ogilvy Sets Sights on Second Major Title
text: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 10  In two calendar years on the PGA Tour, Geoff Ogilvy has risen from the mass of talented players from Australia to one of the best golfers in the game.

headline: Ignore the Last Few Weeks. It’s Been a Heck of a 25 Years.
text: IT has not been the best few weeks ever for stock market investors, but it has been the best 25 years.

headline: One More Reason to Smile for Verplank
text: Tulsa, Okla.

headline: German Chief Felled by Scandal Returns to Market on Smaller Scale
text: FRANKFURT, Aug. 10 — Heinz C. Schimmelbusch still keeps an apartment here, insisting he feels at home in a city where he was once the toast of the local elite and then, seemingly overnight, the villain in one of the most notorious corporate scandals of the 1990s in Germany.

headline: Appearing Now on a TV Near You? Surely a Presidential Debate
text: DES MOINES, Aug. 10 — There was a time when running for president of the United States meant visiting with voters in New Hampshire living rooms, eating your way across the Iowa State Fair, delivering speeches and raising money.

headline: Easy Money Isn’t That Easy
text: GUY KAWASAKI, venture capitalist and business pundit, posited that it’s “easy” to become an Internet millionaire, as long as you have a good idea. You don’t even have to work hard: a couple of hours a day in your underwear should be enough.

headline: Scratching Through the Glamorous Gloss for Diana, Real Human Being
text: Praising a docudrama about Diana, Princess of Wales, may seem ridiculous, like giving a sculpture award to a wax museum. But even those who despise the postmortem dissection of celebrities will have to admit that the knife has rarely sliced more cleanly than it does in “Diana: Last Days of a Princess.” The program, which will be shown on TLC tomorrow night, is as convincing as it is cheesy.

headline: Fed Stands Still on Rates; Chrysler Takes a Big Step
text: THE Federal Reserve stood still, but executives were on the move at Chrysler and Fidelity. The bidding for Barneys escalated and prosecutors won a guilty verdict in a significant options backdating case.

headline: Minnesota: Federal Money Allotted for Bridge Efforts
text: Minnesota will immediately receive $50 million in federal money to help pay for recovery and cleanup efforts and for design work on a bridge to replace the Interstate 35W span that collapsed on Aug. 1, Secretary of Transportation Mary E. Peters said. State officials say they are racing to build a bridge that can be open by the end of next year; the loss of the old bridge  the most heavily traveled in the state  has created traffic tie-ups in downtown Minneapolis and for thousands of commuters near the city. The $50 million in immediate financing is part of $250 million that Congress approved last week to replace the bridge. Divers recovered another body in the wreckage, bringing the death toll to at least eight.

headline: 3rd Suspect, 15, Held in Newark Killings as Hunt Continues
text: NEWARK, Aug. 10 — A 15-year-old youth on Friday became the third person arrested in the fatal shootings of three young people on a Newark playground last week. An intense police manhunt continued for at least two other suspects, including another teenager.

headline: Design Spotlights Collision of Engineering and Politics
text: There are oddities of the Pulaski Skyway that speak to issues as serious as its structural soundness and its place in engineering history. But others have more to do with the bare-knuckled politics of 1930s New Jersey.

headline: Man Called the Planner of 2 Killings Is Convicted
text: A Ukrainian immigrant who spent his youth in the pool halls of Brighton Beach, carried his shotgun in a tennis racket bag full of weapons and married into a Russian organized-crime syndicate was convicted of murder yesterday for planning and carrying out two shootings in the summer of 1992.

headline: Igawa Could Be on Way Up or Way Out
text: CLEVELAND, Aug. 10 — When the Yankees gave $26 million to the Hanshin Tigers last winter to negotiate with Kei Igawa, the deal did not include a money-back guarantee. Once the money was paid, it was gone for good.

headline: Children’s Health Insurance Bill Provides a Case Study
text: Among the many odd moments on the House floor in the tumultuous week before the start of the August recess, this may have been the oddest: Republicans waving goodbye to Democrats after they pushed through an expansion of a popular federal health care program for children.

headline: Can the IHOP Corp. Do for Applebee’s What It Did for Itself?
text: On a recent visit to the new cafeteria of The New York Times, Julia A. Stewart, 52, complimented the gleaming hardwood floors and then suddenly stopped. “I’m sorry,” she said, as she stepped around a coffee spill to grab a few napkins and then proceeded to clean it up.

headline: A Neighborhood Fixture Faces an Uncertain Future
text: New York City liquor stores generally tend toward the glum or the precious, involving either hurried exchanges with bulletproof glass and brown bags or bright, sleek shops that look more like U.F.O.’s. LeNell’s, a liquor store in Red Hook, has always aimed for a laid-back feel, with its sign out front advertising “likker,” and a coming wine tasting called “Rosé Ain’t for Wimps” and a cat named Whiskey sleeping among bottles of its namesake.

headline: A Pastor Finds a Way to Serve Two Disparate Flocks
text: CAMPBELLSPORT, WIS. The brick church, more than a century old, stands at the junction of two county roads tracing the glacial hills of southeastern Wisconsin. In the field across the way, the summer corn stretches eight feet from root to tassel. This being a Sunday morning, the Rev. Daniel Schultz greets the faithful on the front steps as they arrive for 9 a.m. worship at the Salem United Church of Christ. Pastor Dan, as he prefers to be known, is the only man in the congregation wearing a coat and tie. Over the next hour, he leads the 70 worshipers in a round of "Happy Birthday" for Jim Maul, a longtime member. He invites a half-dozen children to the pulpit, where he crouches among them to teach them to recite "The Lord's Prayer." In the part of the service designated for "sharing joys and concerns," he listens as people rise in the pews to tell of a relative's surgery, a brother's recovery from a liver transplant. Here is ministry at its most venerable, ministry at its most tender and intimate and finely grained. And it comes from a minister with a strikingly unlikely double-life, one part as the small-town preacher in a socially conservative spot of the Midwest, the other as an abrasive and confrontational voice of the religious left in the blogosphere. Exactly one week after Mr. Schultz presided over Sunday worship at his home church here, he gave a sermon in the vast arena of the McCormick Convention Center in Chicago. Instead of the farmers, factory workers and tradesmen who typify his regular congregation, the audience for his denunciation of the Iraq war consisted of the self-proclaimed "netroots" attending Yearly Kos, the annual political and media convention organized by the Daily Kos Web site. For three years, Mr. Schultz has supplied the voice of religion for Daily Kos, an epicenter of left-liberal activity with an otherwise fiercely secular bent. In 2004, Mr. Schultz began fielding prayer requests every Sunday night as part of a Daily Kos feature called "Brothers and Sisters." A year later, Daily Kos's founder, Markos Moulitsas, let Mr. Schultz spin off a formally connected online community, Street Prophets. In 4.3 million page views since then, Mr. Schultz's readers have found comparatively little balm in Gilead. True to the take-no-prisoners style of blogosphere discourse, Street Prophets traffics more in calumny and condemnation, though with an extremely learned theological intelligence behind it. "If Conservative Christians are looking for salvation," Mr. Schultz wrote in one characteristic post, "they ought to start looking to save themselves from themselves. They have much to repent for, like the rest of us. But unlike the rest of us, they have a unique level of judgmentalism and separation to get out of their system." Besides decrying the religious right on issues like gay rights, abortion and intelligent design, Mr. Schultz has also disparaged even seeming allies like Jim Wallis, probably the most prominent liberal among the evangelical Christian clergy. Mr. Schultz has reviled Mr. Wallis's "patronizing lectures." Somehow this balancing act seems to work, meeting the needs of two wildly disparate flocks and reconciling Mr. Schultz to himself. As someone who suffers from, and is medicated for, bipolar disorder, Mr. Schultz has, of necessity, become an expert on reckoning with extremes. "There's a part of me that's been angry since I was a kid," Mr. Schultz, 39, said in an interview. "Part of that is my illness, and part of it is a deep sense that the world isn't the place it was meant to be. I had to find a productive place to put that anger or it would swallow me whole. And part of my spiritual journey has been to claim that anger as spiritual." In choosing the blogosphere as his pulpit, Mr. Schultz forms part of a trend in which liberal members of the clergy are using the Internet the way Christian conservatives used cable television and talk radio in earlier decades. Diane Winston, a professor of religion and media at the University of Southern California, points to such similar figures online as Mr. Wallis, Rabbi Michael Lerner at Tikkun, the Rev. Tim Simpson at PublicTheologian and Rachel Barenblat at Velveteen Rabbi. "The blogosphere offers a new way to organize religious people into political communities," Ms. Winston wrote in an e-mail message. "For better or worse, it plays to traditional strengths and weaknesses of progressives." She continued, "It's not a political movement like the religious right and there's no inkling it could be. On the other hand, the Web seems the ideal medium for the wide-ranging discussions, coalition-building and open-ended organizing that characterizes the left." In the more prosaic part of Mr. Schultz's life, Salem United Church of Christ sought him out last year for eminently practical reasons. The congregation had released its previous pastor. Struggling to survive with about 80 active members, the church was limping along with guest preachers on a weekly basis. Mr. Schultz embodied both familiarity and new vigor. He was a "P.K." - a preacher's kid - who had grown up in his father's church 80 miles away in Madison. After earning degrees in English and history at the University of Wisconsin, and in the process falling away from religious observance, Mr. Schultz returned to it as he earned a master's degree in divinity from Emory University in Atlanta. He had pastored a church in Georgia and substituted at several congregations in Pennsylvania before being called by Salem. Along the way, Mr. Schultz chose as his theological heroes Reinhold Neibuhr, Martin Buber and Jack Kerouac. What impresses many congregants here far more, though, is the way Mr. Schultz and his wife, Jennifer Milazzo-Schultz, have enacted their faith by taking in two foster children. He has also managed to express his politics without imposing them. "Over all, we're a fairly conservative congregation, but everybody loves him," said Denise Goetsch, a member of the church's governing board. "Whatever people's personal politics are, they're here because they believe in God. And Dan's been good at making friends with pretty much anybody." Mr. Schultz's sermon here the week before Yearly Kos offered a prime example of how. Drawing on a passage from I Corinthians, Mr. Schultz preached for social justice while speaking directly to his humble church and its obscure home. "I believe in the underdog," he told the congregation. "I believe in the lost and the lumpy and the people nobody has ever heard of and the towns that don't quite exist on anybody's maps. I believe that they are where God has chosen to become incarnate."

headline: Richmond Flowers Is Dead at 88; Challenged Segregation and Klan
text: Richmond M. Flowers, who as the Alabama attorney general in the early 1960s drew national attention when he challenged the segregationist policies of Gov. George C. Wallace and prosecuted Ku Klux Klansmen in the killings of civil rights workers, died Thursday at his home in Dothan, Ala. Mr. Flowers, who later served a prison term for bribery, was 88.

headline: A Guide to Impressing Your Friends and Neighbors
text: It has been a long off-season. The Giants have not played in 216 days. And you are about to watch the Giants open the preseason against the Carolina Panthers.

headline: Hong Kong mobile tour guide
text: Why bother with a human tour guide when you can call up a digital one instead, asks my colleague Doreen Carvajal, who describes mobile phone audio tours of Paris at this Globespotters post.

headline: Teenagers on the Job
text: Less than half of the nation’s teenagers aged 16 to 19 are working this summer. The percentage holding summer jobs, 42 percent, slid to its lowest level since World War II. Fifty-three percent of teenagers were working in 2000; a decade earlier, 60 percent were, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Experts see many explanations for this decline. For example, immigrants are taking many jobs, like mowing lawns, once held by teenagers. More Americans over age 60 are staying in the work force in part-time jobs. The nation has lost three million manufacturing jobs since 2000. Meanwhile, many students take summer courses. In light of these numbers and explanations, what is your take on teenagers and summer work? Go to Article

headline: In Case You’re Not in Iowa …
text: If a trip to Ames, Iowa was not in the cards this weekend, not to worry. You can still follow all developments at today’s Republican Straw Poll, where Iowans have arrived by the busload to support their favorite G.O.P. presidential contender.

headline: 2008: Ames or Bust
text: Today’s the day — at least for some of the Republican campaigns. While Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator John McCain aren’t competing in the Ames, Iowa straw poll today, those who are each have something to prove. (The Washington Post, by the way, has a the Power Point presentation prepared for Mr. Giuliani’s top advisers showing how difficult it would have been for him to compete there, and The Chicago Tribune outlines just how expensive participation is.)

headline: An Interactive Way to Watch the Game
text: It’s easy to turn the first preseason game into a parlor game. The hardest part might be finding someone who has a parlor, or who remembers what one is.

headline: Lawrence and Sosa Come Through Again
text: Jorge Sosa has allowed one run in nine and a third innings since being moved to the bullpen on July 31. And Brian Lawrence has held his own in his first two outings with the Mets since replacing Sosa as the fifth starter.

headline: The Scene in Ames
text: AMES, Iowa — An early report from the Iowa Straw Poll in Ames: At least from signs and T-shirts, it seems to be a smack-down between Mitt Romney, the Republican of Massachusetts, and Ron Paul, the Texas congressman who could end up proving one of the more interesting tales of the day.

headline: Ron Paul Rallies Supporters
text: AMES, Iowa – The Ron Paul signs, it seems, are practically everywhere you look here at the Iowa Straw Poll. There are bumper stickers and billboards and T-shirts in a wide variety of colors.

headline: Make Way for the Fred Heads
text: AMES, Iowa — The Fred Heads are here.

headline: Barry Bonds and 800 Homers
text: I have covered 17 San Francisco Giants games this year, but, truthfully, I’ve really covered 17 of Barry Bonds’s games. There would have been no reason to cover the last-place Giants so much if Bonds’s were not pursuing Hank Aaron’s record for career home runs.

headline: Where Have You Gone, Chief Wahoo?
text: In 1991, when I was 16, I visited the old Municipal Stadium here in Cleveland. It had the smallest clubhouses you could imagine, and the vast emptiness of the place was spooky. During batting practice in the late afternoon, when a park is supposed to be empty, its cavernous feeling was really cool. But at game time, when there were still 70,000 empty seats, it didn’t feel quite right.

headline: Rock ‘n Roll Huckabee
text: AMES, Iowa — Mike Huckabee played bass for much of the morning with his rock-and-roll band “Capitol Offense,” taking the stage at one point with an Elvis impersonator and Lynn Hunter, the wife of his rival forthe Republican nomination, Representative Duncan Hunter, to sing Johnny B. Goode.

headline: Democrats’ Third Rail: Free Trade
text: In her foreign policy politics column today, Helene Cooper writes that the gap between Democratic candidates’ rhetoric on trade and their actions in office is particularly wide:

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, Aug. 12
text: With several of the Republican contestants in the Ames, Iowa straw poll set to appear on the talk shows, you can expect that there will be a lot of Sunday morning quarterbacking of the event and its significance.

headline: Romney Praises Bush, Sort Of
text: AMES, Iowa — The Iowa Straw Poll was where President Bush took his first big step toward winning his party’s nomination. He poured money and resources here in 1999, drawing 31 percent of the vote, way ahead of Steve Forbes, the billionaire, who drew 20 percent of the vote.

headline: The Sound of Crickets in Ames
text: AMES, IOWA — A late-afternoon dispatch from inside the Hilton Coliseum, where Republicans are meeting. Former Gov. Tommy G. Thompson is speaking. And we have one word to describe the hall: Crickets. Many empty seats. No rap on Mr. Thompson; the crowd has been diminishing since Mitt Romney spoke a few hours ago. Part of it due to the diversions outside – bands, rides and lots of food – all arguably more interesting than a speech by someone who probably will not get to be president one day.

headline: ‘Hobos’ For Paul
text: AMES, Iowa – The National Hobo Convention, the annual summer festival being held this weekend in the town of Britt, will have to wait until next year. Today, Dan and Laura Doucette had a Republican straw poll to attend.

headline: Collecting Mementos at Ames
text: AMES, Iowa — On Doug and Ilene Carlson’s mantle at their home just a few blocks from the Hilton Coliseum, where today’s Republican straw poll took place, is a photo of Mr. Carlson alongside a grinning George W. Bush taken at the 2000 straw poll.

headline: Electricity From the East River
text: Powerful currents and competition upstream have delayed the installation of more underwater turbines in the East River.

headline: Music at the Iowa Straw Poll
text: At the Iowa Straw Poll in Ames, each candidate had a tent to entertain voters. A sampling of their musical offerings.

headline: A Not-So-Final Roster
text: As promised — or as threatened — we are providing a far-too-early prediction of the Giants’ final 53-man roster. As the Giants play the Panthers on Saturday night, the team’s roster is at 86, plus one wayward player named Michael Strahan.

headline: Music at the Iowa Straw Poll
text: At the Iowa Straw Poll in Ames, each candidate had a tent to entertain voters. A sampling of their musical offerings.

headline: Romney Fund-Raiser Resigns
text: AMES, Iowa–A top fund-raiser for Mitt Romney who was indicted this week in Maryland on a $32 million fraud scheme has resigned from his position with the campaign as a national finance committee co-chair, aspokesman for Mr. Romney said.

headline: Straw Poll Results Expected Shortly
text: AMES, Iowa – Sign-waving supporters of Republican presidential candidates crowded the floor of Hilton Coliseum here, awaiting the results of the Iowa Straw Poll. They were scheduled to be announced at 7 p.m., Iowa time.

headline: Voting Machine Malfunction Causes Delay
text: AMES, Iowa – The results of the Iowa Republican Straw poll have been delayed for more than an hour tonight as officials recount about 1,500 ballots from one voting machine.

headline: A Fictional Minority
text: Stanley Fish has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below. — The Editors

headline: Romney Wins Straw Poll
text: AMES, Iowa – The outcome of the Republican Straw Poll was announced here tonight, with Mitt Romney easily claiming the first prize of the presidential campaign. He was followed by Mike Huckabee and Sam Brownback.

headline: Huckabee Celebrates Second-Place Finish
text: AMES, Iowa – When the Republican Straw Poll results were announced tonight, Mitt Romney had this to say: “I’m pleased as punch that I won!”

headline: Even 16-Year-Old Prodigies Sometimes Have Off Days
text: A week ago, Magnus Carlsen, a 16-year-old from Norway, won the Biel International Chess Festival, one of the strongest tournaments of the year. It was the biggest triumph of his career.

headline: Correction: Sending Back the Doctor’s Bill
text: An article on July 29 about how doctors’ compensation affects health-care costs misstated the views of Dr. Alan Garber, an internist and the director of the Center for Health Policy at Stanford University. He said health care organizations like Kaiser Permanente, which have salaried doctors on staff, are a good model for the future, but he did not say that all doctors should eventually be salaried.

headline: Land Grab
text: The executive summary of Richard Kluger’s “Seizing Destiny” is a one-page chart at the end of the book, “Principal Acquisitions of Territory by the United States.” The Treaty of Paris (1783) defined a new nation of almost 900,000 square miles. The Louisiana Purchase 20 years later more than doubled its size. In the 1840s, Texas, Oregon and the northern half of Mexico accounted for 1.2 million additional square miles. Buying Alaska in 1867 added over half a million more. Other parcels brought the United States to its present size of 3,540,305 square miles. In the modern era only Russia and Canada occupy more of the earth’s surface.

headline: Machu Picchu, Without Roughing It
text: LIKE so many avid hikers, Mary Narrod had always put Machu Picchu, the ancient Inca citadel in Peru, high on her wish list of places to visit. She planned to someday take a hike to get there. But her husband, James, was not fond of the idea of camping along the way. “It’s not that I won’t do it,” said Mr. Narrod, an active traveler himself, whose recent vacations have included hiking and heli-skiing. “But I like a shower after a day or two.”

headline: Merv Griffin, Television Impresario, Dies at 82
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 — Merv Griffin, a big-band singer who became one of television’s longest running talk-show hosts and formidable innovators, creating some of the medium’s most popular game shows before becoming a major figure in the hotel and gambling businesses, died Sunday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center here. He was 82.

headline: Jazz Fanfare for a New New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS

headline: A Biennial That’s Multidirectional
text: The allure of the art biennial, longtime promoter of political installations and socially engaged conceptual art projects, has faded over the years as the art world has increasingly become brand-conscious and obsessed with art fairs and money.

headline: Don’t Find Me, I’ll Find You
text: BREEZING past East Village dive bars on a recent Friday night, a stylish young woman and her banker boyfriend ducked into Gemma, the Bowery Hotel’s bustling new Italian-style restaurant.

headline: Claim of Plot to Strike City Unfounded, Officials Say
text: The New York City police pulled back their additional security checkpoints and radiological sensors in Lower Manhattan yesterday after determining that a report of a planned dirty bomb attack was unsubstantiated.

headline: Correction: Twilight of the Sun King
text: An article on July 29 about Philippe de Montebello’s tenure at the Metropolitan Museum of Art misstated the title the museum’s board granted him in 1999. While retaining the title of director, he was named chief executive, not president.

headline: L.I.R.R. Safety Campaign Under Way
text: A YEAR after a woman was struck by a train and killed, prompting a review by the Long Island Rail Road of the gaps between its platforms and trains, the railroad has begun a safety awareness campaign.

headline: A Gehry Signature in the Napa Valley
text: SURROUNDED by acres of sun-ripening grapes, 300 dignitaries and guests convened in the Napa Valley of California last month to celebrate the long-delayed groundbreaking of the Hall Winery, designed by the architect Frank O. Gehry.

A Place for the Arts, Still Going Strong; Is It Really So Hard to Carry Reusable Bags?; Working on Roofs

headline: Lives: The 37-Year-Old Version
text: To my naïve 37-year-old eyes, my parents’ condominium was just a place to sleep while my wife and I, separated after 10 years of marriage, “figured things out.” I had my own room, which was cluttered with a museum’s worth of cheaply framed photos. Wherever I turned, I saw myself — at my bar mitzvah, my senior prom, my high-school graduation. It was hard to resist the feeling that on some level I belonged there.

headline: Correction: Group Reduces Number of Patients With Bedsores
text: A picture caption with an article last Sunday about an initiative to reduce the incidence of bedsores in 150 hospitals, nursing homes and health care agencies in New Jersey misidentified an employee of Chilton Memorial Hospital who was helping a patient. She is Nancy Jones, a registered nurse, not Linda Thoden, a registered nurse who is the director of critical care services.

headline: Giuliani, Substance Firm, Struggles to Secure Style
text: The lights were low, the music soft and soothing, a lute was being plucked in the background. The next song, presumably meant to liven up the crowd, was a selection from Yo-Yo Ma.

headline: New Ritz-Carlton Thinks Big in Dallas
text: “Live Large. Think Big.” That’s the slogan for Dallas, and it also describes the design philosophy behind the new Ritz-Carlton there. Set to open on Wednesday, the 21-story hotel has 218 rooms, an outdoor swimming pool, a ballroom, a 12,000 square-foot spa, 14,000 square feet of meeting space and seven dining and social spaces, including Fearing’s Restaurant, presided over by the celebrity chef Dean Fearing. The hotel, within walking distance of the American Airlines Center (home to the Mavericks of the National Basketball Association and the Stars of the National Hockey league), has its own trolley stop along McKinney Avenue. Nightly rates start at $329 (www.ritzcarlton.com).

headline: Buy Low, Divorce High
text: FOR years, Michele Kleier, a real estate broker on the Upper East Side, knew why one of her most persistent clients was calling even before picking up the phone.

headline: For Want of a Swearing In, an Arrest Is Lost in Indiana
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 11 (AP)  The authorities may have inadvertently given hundreds or even thousands of people accused of drunken driving, dealing drugs and other crimes a way to get off the hook: The arresting officers were never sworn in.

text: Amelia Sturges Epifano, a daughter of Helene R. Epifano and Stephen B. Epifano, both of Fairfield, Conn., was married last evening to Robert Sheldon Johnson III, the son of Virginia Johnson and R. Sheldon Johnson of Rowayton, Conn. The Rev. Nicholas T. Porter performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

headline: ‘Doors Open’
text: Dawn was breaking as Allan dropped Mike off outside his apartment building.

text: "THE epicenter of the search,” I instructed a bevy of real estate agents, “is Zabar’s.”

headline: Far From the Reservation, but Still Sacred?
text: Yuma, Ariz.

headline: The Road to Clarity
text: “So, what do you see?” Martin Pietrucha I asked, turning around in the driver’s seat of his mint green Ford Taurus. It was a cold day in January, and we were parked in the middle of a mock highway set on the campus of Pennsylvania State University in State College. Pietrucha is a jovial, 51-year-old professor of highway engineering. His tone was buoyant as he nodded toward the edge of the oval stretch of road where two green-and-white signs leaned against a concrete barrier.

headline: The Naturals
text: Maxine Swann’s new book, “Flower Children,” is a “novel in stories” that offers shimmering, episodic glimpses into the life of a hippie family in the 1970s — four children and two eccentric parents. The book’s eight narratives follow the children through their lives at one- to two-year intervals as they explore, observe and are spirited away on road trips by their impulsive and bawdy father (whose girlfriends they slyly torment) and their more quietly rebellious mother (whose boyfriends they barely tolerate).

headline: Blythe Durrett, Timothy Browne
text: Blythe Elizabeth Durrett, the daughter of Deborah and Robert Durrett of Nashville, was married last evening to Timothy Joseph Browne, a son of Karyn and Joe Browne of Sands Point, N.Y. The Rev. Suzanne Cloyd Hultman, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Fearington House Country Inn in Pittsboro, N.C.

headline: Mirellise Vazquez, Thomas Birmingham
text: Mirellise Migdalia Vazquez was married yesterday to Thomas James Birmingham at Independence Harbor, a private estate in Assonet, Mass. Richard Ruge, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Things Fall Apart, but Some Big Old Things Don’t
text: A 40-year-old bridge in Minnesota collapses, an 83-year-old steam pipe in Manhattan explodes and three inches of rain immobilizes a subway system that goes back more than a century.

headline: Cloaked in Memories
text: SPEAK, memory. No, actually, put a sock in it.

headline: Matador Wins. Bull Dies. The End? Not in Portugal.
text: LISBON — With the grace of a dancer and the wiry strength of a jockey, Pedrito de Portugal is his country’s most famous matador. He is also one of its most notorious outlaws: the celebrated bullfighter was fined 100,000 euros, or $137,000, for the unlikely crime of killing a bull.

headline: In Place of the Original Carvel, a Mall
text: Hartsdale

headline: Resolved: Public Corporations Shall Take Us Seriously
text: The ring tone on Sister Patricia Daly's cellphone is the "Hallelujah" chorus from Handel's "Messiah," which makes every call sound as if it's coming from God. On the particular May afternoon, however, David Henry, who handles investor relations for the ExxonMobil Corporation, was on the line. Henry wanted to know if Daly planned to attend the annual shareholder meeting later that month — a rhetorical question, really, since Daly had been at every one of them for the past 10 years. At each she posed roughly the same question: What is ExxonMobil, the world's largest publicly traded oil company, planning to do about global warming?

headline: Bridge Collapse Puts Focus on Aging Local Spans
text: EILEEN DAILEY can’t remember much about her rescue on June 28, 1983, from the collapse of the Mianus River Bridge on Interstate 95 in Greenwich that sent her Toyota and three other vehicles plunging 75 feet into the dark water at about 1:30 in the morning. But she still lives with the partial paralysis that has been the legacy of the disaster for her.

headline: Survivors’ Stairway (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Couple of Geniuses Sitting Around Talking
text: ALBERT EINSTEIN and Pablo Picasso walk into a bar. No, this isn’t the beginning of a joke; it’s the premise of “Picasso at the Lapin Agile,” the play by the actor and comedian Steve Martin, which is headlining this year’s Guild Hall season in East Hampton.

headline: Two Schoolmates Reunite Their Soccer Dads, and Take Up the Ball
text: IT had been years since Erhardt Kapp and David Norris had seen each other, even though their sons saw each other every day.

headline: Just Try to Beat These Records
text: Babe Ruth’s record of 714 career home runs was once considered unreachable. Then Hank Aaron hit No. 715 in 1974. So the unreachable had lasted 39 years. Now Aaron has been eclipsed.

headline: 20 Hurt as Fatah Members Protest Arrests at Wedding
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 11  Fatah demonstrators protested Saturday in northern Gaza after 15 of their colleagues were arrested by Hamas at a wedding party on Friday night, in another sign of continuing tensions between Palestinian factions.

headline: Cheesy Can Be a Lot of Fun
text: NEW York has two kinds of quality cheese: The kind that goes for $15.99 a pound at Murray's on Bleecker Street or becomes part of a savory dessert plate at a restaurant like Artisanal; and the kind that fills the photo albums of tourists who think the height of New York City culture is found in Times Square and Little Italy.

headline: First Time on the Ship? Take an Audio Tour
text: Let’s say you’ve come onboard for your very first cruise, and you want to know everything possible about the ship, from where the captain resides to the location of the shuffleboard tables. If that ship happens to be Royal Caribbean International’s Liberty of the Seas, you’re in luck. Upon boarding, passengers are offered MP-3 players — the same devices used in many museums and historical sites — and are invited to go on a new audio orientation tour, narrated by Samantha Brown, a Travel Channel host, who guides passengers through about 30 stops on the ship. Antenna Audio, the producer of the tour, also plans to introduce podcasts with cruise-related themes, like information on ports of call and environmentally friendly practices on the ship (www.royalcaribbean.com).

headline: The Myth, the Math, the Sex
text: EVERYONE knows men are promiscuous by nature. It’s part of the genetic strategy that evolved to help men spread their genes far and wide. The strategy is different for a woman, who has to go through so much just to have a baby and then nurture it. She is genetically programmed to want just one man who will stick with her and help raise their children.

headline: Company Names May Adorn Stations
text: TWO of the more popular concert halls in the state have been renamed after car brands (the New England Dodge Music Center in Hartford and the Chevrolet Theater in Wallingford). And the state’s only major-league professional sports team (the Sun) doubles as a billboard for the casino it calls home.

headline: An Attractive Amalgam of Asian Influences
text: TENGDA ASIAN BISTRO, at the far left end of Goodwives Shopping Center in Darien, is the latest in a trio of Tengda restaurants in Connecticut, each slightly different from the others (there is a fourth in Katonah, N.Y.). The first of the Connecticut group, in Westport, is predominantly Japanese with a sprinkling of Chinese and Thai dishes; the Greenwich Tengda marries Japanese and European dishes.

headline: A Fictional Minority
text: The buzz about the new ABC show “Cavemen” is not good. The negative vibes take two forms. Some who have seen the pilot episode find it slapdash, poorly written and unfunny. Others worry that the show will reinforce racial stereotypes by encouraging viewers to identify the maligned Cro-Magnons with African-Americans.

headline: A Southern Hand Delivers an Italian Feast
text: HI, this is Paula,” says the perky voice on the answering machine. It is distinctly Southern, and for an instant you may wonder whether you misdialed. Weren’t you calling an Italian restaurant?

headline: Inside a Young Pitcher Lurks the Heart of a Hitter
text: When Tim Lincecum made his debut for the San Francisco Giants in May, the focus was on his amazing right arm. Lincecum looks like a high school pitcher until he unleashes fastballs that can reach 99 miles an hour.

headline: Democrats’ Third Rail: Free Trade
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Select Hospitals Reap a Windfall Under Child Bill
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 — Despite promises by Congress to end the secrecy of earmarks and other pet projects, the House of Representatives has quietly funneled hundreds of millions of dollars to specific hospitals and health care providers under a bill passed this month to help low-income children.

headline: Elizabeth Faidley and Jonathan Solars
text: VIOLINISTS tend to compare their relationship with their instruments to a marriage. It’s intimate, often expensive and intended to be long lasting — but it can be difficult to make the right match.

headline: Who Are You?

headline: The Man Who Asked Hard Questions
text: I GOT the news in Oviedo, a lovely little town in the north of Spain where I am shooting a movie, that Bergman had died. A phone message from a mutual friend was relayed to me on the set. Bergman once told me he didn’t want to die on a sunny day, and not having been there, I can only hope he got the flat weather all directors thrive on.

headline: Renovating a Building, and Perhaps a Suburb’s Image
text: EAST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 11 — In the cold nomenclature of tax assessors and municipal records, it is known as Lot: 2, Block: 280, District: 5.

headline: Margaret Heller, Rory Greebel
text: Margaret Faith Heller, a daughter of Catherine and Lloyd J. Heller of New York, was married last evening to Rory Garrett Greebel, the son of Marilyn and James I. Greebel of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein performed the ceremony at Central Synagogue in New York, with Cantor Richard Botton taking part.

headline: Blue-Chip Draft Picks Need Time to Mature
text: Every off-season gives football teams a chance to wipe the slate clean. With that comes the optimism of training camp, where the pieces start to come together.

headline: Where the Name Says It All
text: WHEN the Majestic opened at Central Park West and 72nd Street in 1931, there was nothing more modern in New York than this 32-story apartment building that mixed skyscraper design with Art Deco. But Irwin S. Chanin’s soaring twin-tower project was brought low in less than a year by the Depression.

headline: Millions Flock to Vote in Sierra Leone

headline: A Personal War, as History and Metaphor
text: Passing Veterans Green on my way home from the Westport Country Playhouse last week, I was struck by the suddenly ambiguous statue of a World War I doughboy carrying his kit bag, helmet and rifle. Somehow, he looked burdened rather than glorious, more worn-out than brave. Surely the memorial hadn’t changed; it was me. I was coming from David Wiltse’s new play and my head was full of questions about America’s participation in that tragic, famously unnecessary conflict.

headline: A Beloved Woodstock Nation Site Goes on Sale, for $8 Million

headline: Check Out the Hotel Before You Check In
text: Unsure about that “charming” two-star hotel you booked for your next trip to Paris? Wouldn’t a sneak peek into its bathroom or concierge area put your mind at ease? The minds behind TVtrip.com, a new Web site that offers video tours of European hotels, think so. Created by former managers of Expedia Europe, the free service offers 200 video tours of hotels in European capitals like Rome and Madrid, and plans to offer 1,500 by year’s end. The 45-second overview videos focus on public areas, restaurants, fitness centers and room categories. Reservations can be made through the hotel’s Web site or through a number of TVtrip.com partners, including Expedia.com.

headline: The Boy Who Lived
text: In March 1940, in the “midnight of the century” that marked the depth of the Hitler-Stalin pact (or in other words, at a time when civilization was menaced by an alliance between two Voldemorts or “You-Know-Whos”), George Orwell took the time to examine the state of affairs in fantasy fiction for young people. And what he found (in an essay called “Boys’ Weeklies”) was an extraordinary level of addiction to the form of story that was set in English boarding schools. Every week, boys (and girls) from the poorer quarters of industrial towns and from the outer edges of the English-speaking Empire would invest some part of their pocket-money to keep up with the adventures of Billy Bunter, Harry Wharton, Bob Cherry, Jack Blake and the other blazer-wearing denizens of Greyfriars and St. Jim’s. As he wrote:

headline: Lexus-Level Dependability, Now Available at Lower Prices

headline: With Crews and Zoos, a B-Boy World
text: LAST weekend at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in Scotland, amid the countless performances that make the Fringe an avant-garde hotbed, a group of break dancers from South Korea presented “Spin Odyssey.” A 70-minute narrative piece loosely based on Homer’s epic, the work transports an Odysseus-like character through time to a hip-hop wonderland, where he learns about the meaning of heroism through break dancing. With its long choreographed phrases and daring acrobatic moves in unison, “Spin Odyssey” is the latest example of how a style many might consider an ’80s leftover, as forgettable as leg warmers, is being transformed into an international art form.

headline: So Many Names, So Many Corrections

headline: The Return of a Blast From the Past
text: ON June 3, 2005, change came to WCBS-FM, the legendary oldies station that had been home to such memorable disc jockeys as Cousin Brucie (a k a Bruce Morrow) and Dan Ingram. Without warning, the station’s management dumped all of its D.J.’s and switched to Jack, a brash new D.J.-less radio format often compared to “iPod on shuffle,” playing a wide selection of songs from the 1960s to the present.

But that is exactly what the Interstate 35W bridge collapse in Minneapolis provided. Both Trenton and the state’s taxpayers have no choice but to deal with their own deteriorating bridges, even if it means raising taxes. Gov. Jon Corzine indicated that it may cost $5 billion to $7 billion to do the job.

headline: Same Old Aliens, but New Neuroses
text: FEW narratives in American popular culture have proved as durably resonant — or as endlessly adaptable — as “Invasion of the Body Snatchers,” the tale of a planetary takeover by extraterrestrial seed pods that replicate and replace sleeping humans. Originally a 1955 novel by Jack Finney, this paranoid fable has now cloned itself several times over, spawning four movies in five decades. Tapping into themes of individualism and conformity, personal freedom and social control, the idea of soulless “pod people” has become an all-encompassing metaphor that finds a sociopolitical relevance whatever the period.

headline: God Bless Amerigo
text: It’s one of the stranger quirks of history and geography. The continent that was supposedly discovered by Christopher Columbus is named for a decidedly second-rate Johnny-come-lately of an explorer named Amerigo Vespucci. Like Columbus, Vespucci was an Italian who sailed on occasion under the flag of Spain. But unlike Columbus, Vespucci was more at home in a counting house than a sailing ship. (Even Ralph Waldo Emerson, normally a booster of all things American, dismissed him as a mere “pickle dealer.”) What Vespucci did have, according to Felipe Fernández-Armesto’s wonderfully idiosyncratic and intelligent new biography of the explorer, was a gift for chicanery and self-promotion, along with an aching need to be remembered. As it turns out, America — this nation of notorious hucksters, dreamers and spin doctors — was named for just the right guy.

headline: They’ll Always Have Paris. Or Tortola. Or Kenya.

Siblings on Strings
