Instead, as part of the Kende Trio, she was playing the violin at the invitation of the Vatican, as Pope John Paul II blessed thousands in St. Peter’s Square in Rome — a pretty memorable Sweet 16 after all.

headline: Children’s Books
text: Gary Paulsen’s novel “Lawn Boy” is a Horatio Alger story for the hedge fund era. Not nearly as earnest as the Alger books, and a lot more fun to read, it’s about a 12-year-old Minnesota boy who in the course of a summer earns half a million dollars without really doing a whole lot. Paulsen’s unnamed narrator has two non-Horatian advantages: a stockbroker and a piece of heavy equipment. Or sort of heavy; it’s an old riding mower given to him by his grandmother as a 12th-birthday present. Though not in the least mechanical-minded, he feels an instant bond with the machine, and almost as soon as he fires it up a neighbor comes by offering to pay 20 bucks for a mowing job. The local lawn care guy, it turns out, has just run off with the wife of a customer, and presumably because he poses less of a sexual threat, Lawn Boy, as we might as well call him, soon has more work than he can handle. So he expands, hiring some undocumented workers, and also invests his profits in the market, starting with some shares in a coffin company.

The house boasted three string orchestras, a perfume-spouting fountain, 18-karat-gold spittoons and 30 opulent, themed bedrooms decked out with extras like a full-size effigy of Cleopatra or a station for setting off firecrackers. The sister-madams, Ada and Minna Everleigh, insisted that here a man “would never feel rushed or cheated, disillusioned or alone.”

headline: Standard Deviations
text: In one of the short stories from his new collection, Jerry Stahl struggles with some niceties of literary etiquette. The story is about the narrator’s torrid sexual affair with a half-Armenian, half-Guatemalan circus performer named Puray. “I suppose I should tell you now,” he says, a few paragraphs in, “Puray was a little person. Pre-P.C., a midget. A stacked half-pint. Knee-high. But where do you put that in the story? March it out in the first sentence, then that’s what it’s about. ... Then you make the associations. Stereotypes. ... But march the news out in the middle — ‘And, by the way, the love of my life was genetically predisposed to never make 40 inches’ — and what is that — O Henry?”

headline: A Drug-Runners’ Stronghold Finds a New Life

headline: Correction: Every Penny Counts

Obi Onyejekwe paid $400,000 for his co-op in Gramercy Park, not $420,000. The down payment amount was $100,000, not $84,000. His assets reported to the board were roughly $100,000, not $84,000.

headline: What, Me Worry? When It Comes to Retiring, Yes
text: It has been a steady drumbeat: Americans are not saving nearly enough for retirement, and they will pay the price later, by having to totter into the office until they’re 98.

headline: Sickening Acts
text: In a corner of Brentwood, where the streets have names like Apple, Peach and Cocoanut, there is a wooded path known as a place of drug use and violence. Its reputation is well deserved. A pair of shocking crimes there in the last 11 months claimed two male victims. Both were savagely attacked and died of their injuries.

headline: 36 Hours in Budapest
text: LIKE the blue Danube River that separates Castle Hill in Buda from the flâneur-worthy boulevards of Pest, the Hungarian capital of Budapest has a sophisticated and hedonistic side. Old World grandeur, stunning architecture and a rich cultural heritage give Budapest its undeniably noble air. But the city also offers plenty of opportunities to cut loose, relax and overindulge on everything from opera and wine to nightlife and cool art. What's more, few of these luxuries are prohibitively expensive. There are ornate public bathhouses, trendy design shops with flea-market prices and beautiful museums that don't cost a cent. So whatever side you choose, let your curiosity be your guide.

headline: Sad End to a Long, Slow Slide
text: UNIONDALE

headline: A Museum to Get Lost In, and How Israel Is Fixing It
text: JERUSALEM

headline: Letters: No Comparison; Show-Stopping Required; An Overlooked Trailblazer; Suzanne Farrell’s Ideal Role
text: BERGMAN AND ANTONIONI

headline: Christmas in August
text: Proving that one person’s pork is another’s example of government at its finest, Democrats who control the Legislature are engaged in a mud fight with the governor’s office over how to pay for local projects. The Legislature is holding up its approval of more than $2.5 billion in bonding for the next two years unless Gov. M. Jodi Rell agrees, as part of the package, to $208 million worth of playgrounds , athletic fields, emergency centers, roof replacements and the like — stuff that’s known here, in Washington and in state capitols across the land, as Christmas tree projects, but pork to you and me.

headline: Smoldering Auteur With a Short Fuse
text: CAN a director be too independent for independent film? In an arena increasingly seen as an annex of the major studios and where one of Hollywood’s contributions has been the acceptance of compromise, the career of the writer and director Tom DiCillo would suggest it’s true.

headline: The Insiders Aren’t So Bearish, After All
text: THE sharp stock market decline that began in late July is more likely to be a minor downturn in a continuing bull market than the beginning of a major bear market. That, at least, is the conclusion of an extensive analysis of corporate insiders’ trading behavior.

headline: Chilled, for Dog Days
text: Burgundy produces little dry sparkling wine. Louis Bouillot’s Perle d’Aurore rosé Crémant de Bourgogne is among the best. Chilled well, it’s a terrific mid-August refresher.

headline: In a Credit Crisis, Large Mortgages Grow Costly
text: When an investment banker set out to buy a $1.5 million home on Long Island last month, his mortgage broker quoted an interest rate of 8 percent. Three days later, when the buyer said he would take the loan, the mortgage banker had bad news: the new rate was 13 percent.

headline: Woods Widens Lead and Beckons a New Challenger
text: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 11 — Beneath the beating rays of the summer sun, Tiger Woods continued the business of hitting and chasing his golf ball, bending shots around the doglegs of Southern Hills to reprise his chase of Jack Nicklaus.

headline: Bad News Begins With the Bullpen and Ends With Lo Duca’s Injury
text: The Florida Marlins came back to beat the Mets, 7-5, in dramatic fashion yesterday at Shea Stadium. For the Mets, that was not even the worst news of the night.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: AIRLINE SEATS

headline: Much More Than Clams
text: One shouldn’t look for modesty in a business that dubs itself a castle, especially when it’s housed in a low-slung single-story affair made of wood, not stone, without a crenelation in sight. Yet at the Clam Castle, a bit of boasting seems appropriate, given that it’s been besieged by summertime seafood lovers for more than 40 years.

headline: The Dismal Science, Dismally Taught
text: WHEN I began teaching economics in the 1970s, I noticed that people were generally disappointed when they learned what I did for a living. When I began asking why, many said something like this: “I took Econ 101 years ago, and there were all those horrible equations and graphs.”

headline: Cagliari: The Other Sardinia
text: MANY of us imagine Sardinia as a Versace ad come to life: European playboys lounging on megayachts and Champagne flowing endlessly at clubs named, without irony, Billionaire. And it’s so — at least during the fashionable months of July and August, if you limit your visit on the island to the tiny, northeast jet-set enclave known as Costa Smeralda, or the Emerald Coast.

headline: Paving Over Fun
text: WHERE we come from, fun is much more circumscribed,” friends from Frankfurt told me, wide-eyed, when I took them out to Coney Island a few years ago.

headline: Bridge Collapse Puts Focus on Aging Local Spans
text: EILEEN DAILEY can’t remember much about her rescue on June 28, 1983, from the collapse of the Mianus River Bridge on Interstate 95 in Greenwich, Conn., that sent her Toyota and three other vehicles plunging 75 feet into the dark water at about 1:30 in the morning. But she still lives with the partial paralysis that has been the legacy of the disaster for her.

headline: Poland to Hold Early Elections
text: WARSAW, Aug. 12 — Seeking to end months of political turmoil, Polish officials confirmed today that the government would hold elections by November, two years ahead of schedule.

headline: A Neighborhood in Waiting
text: ELVIA NUÑEZ first arrived in the Bronx at age 11, when her family moved to the Fordham neighborhood from Mexico. They settled on Lorillard Place, in the Belmont section just below Fordham Road. There, they found an ethnically diverse neighborhood with a growing Latin American population.

headline: Exotics on the Easy Payment Plan
text: WERE F. Scott Fitzgerald alive today, he might be surprised to learn that the very rich are not always so different from you and me, at least in how they pay for their cars.

headline: Imposing a Sublet Fee
text: Q Would a co-op have to amend its proprietary lease in order to impose a fee when shareholders rent out their apartments? My co-op has no restrictions on subletting, and the board says that because the proprietary lease does not require shareholders to obtain its consent to sublet, the lease would have to be amended before the board could impose a sublet fee. And that would require the vote of two-thirds of the shareholders.

headline: Chicken Little’s Brethren, on the Trading Floor
text: THE job of an economist, among many other duties, is to put things into perspective. So, because I am an economist, among other duties, here is a little perspective on the recent turmoil in the stock and bond markets.

headline: An Abundance of Cruelties
text: Anyone who reads the papers or watches TV news sooner or later confronts something appalling — journalism is, among other things, a catalog of human cruelties. Recent accounts of severe and shocking mistreatment of animals in the New York region have underscored this truth in a heartsickening way.

headline: When Conflict Washes Up on a Quiet Maine Island
text: Vinalhaven, Me.

headline: Educating With Bribes (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Clam-Shack Country, the Classics Reign
text: LOCAL bounty is increasingly the attraction in the world's best eating places. And although the waters off Cape Cod have seen a terrible decline in fish (if it were discovered today, it would be named Cape Clam Shack, or Cape Summer House) there are still enough commercial fishermen to supply local restaurants. So I wish the reigning philosophy would be more as it is in coastal communities elsewhere: “Here's what we've got, and we hope you like it.” Aren't well-traveled Americans, having eaten whelk in France, head-on sardines in Italy, and fresh sea cucumber in Spain, venturesome enough to sample local shark, monkfish, octopus, skate and more?

headline: Who Owns the Concept if No One Signs the Papers?
text: WHO owns a bright idea? If the technology associated with an idea is new and the opportunities it offers are valuable, it will have many authors — most of whom may argue over ownership.

headline: How India Built the Bomb (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shuffling Off to Crawford, 2007 Edition
text: THE cases of Pat Tillman and Jessica Lynch were ugly enough. So surely someone in the White House might have the good taste to draw the line at exploiting the murdered Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl. But nothing is out of bounds for a government that puts the darkest arts of politics and public relations above even the exigencies of war.

headline: Look Who’s Talking
text: Academia, unlike every other sector of our culture, has apparently been considered too dull and esoteric to merit a reality show, but now there’s a natural vehicle: evolutionary linguistics, an emerging field awash in colorful personalities, wacky experiments and enough conflict to carry several seasons. Don’t let the name throw you; the scientists who study the origins of language are a passionate, fractious bunch, and you don’t have to be an egghead to be tantalized by the questions that drive their research: how and when did we learn to speak, and to what extent is language a uniquely human attribute? Call the show “American Babble.”

headline: Jennifer Abt, Andrew Eimer
text: Jennifer Rachel Abt, a daughter of Marci Rush Abt and Richard J. Abt of Meadowbrook, Pa., was married last evening to Andrew David Eimer, the son of Nancy R. Eimer and Jeffrey H. Eimer of Dix Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Joel Alpert officiated at the Park Hyatt Philadelphia at the Bellevue, and Rabbi Richard Allen took part in the ceremony.

headline: Kathleen Agresta, Thomas Price
text: Kathleen Anne Agresta, a daughter of Joan Agresta and Richard Agresta of Darien, Conn., was married Friday evening to Thomas Haile Upton Price, the son of Sondra Price and Dr. Thomas Price of Hopkinsville, Ky. The Rev. Edward J. Mills III, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Wequassett Resort and Golf Club in Chatham, Mass.

headline: Now, Even Those Temporary Wheels Can Be Greener
text: ROO ROGERS, who lives in Lower Manhattan, is helping to reduce auto emissions by not owning a car. But he still likes to take the wheel for occasional multistop spins around town, for hundred-mile drives to a vacation home on Long Island and for business trips when he’s in California.

headline: Jessica Kaufman, Joshua Goodman
text: Jessica Yael Kaufman, a daughter of Susan B. Kaufman and Dr. Richard E. Kaufman of Woodbridge, Conn., was married last evening to Joshua Alan Goodman, a son of Lauren E. Goodman and Dr. Richard A. Goodman of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Jo David officiated at Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

headline: Correction: Letter on ‘Peeling the Onion’
text: A letter to the editor last Sunday responding to a review of Günter Grass’s “Peeling the Onion” misattributed an epithet applied to the critic Marcel Reich-Ranicki, who was once pictured on the cover of Der Spiegel ripping apart one of Grass’s novels. It was the reviewer who referred to him as a “senile tyrant,” not Grass.

headline: Romney Wins Iowa Straw Poll by a Sizable Margin
Superdude
text: There is much that is supergood about your performance in “Superbad,” which opens this week. But how do you feel about landing your first big role in a film that celebrates male immaturity and vulgarity? Any time I have a conversation with a female reporter, this kind of comes up. The way that Michael Cera and I talk in the movie is vulgar. But whether people realize it or not, this is how 17-year-old kids talk today. You might not want to believe it.

headline: Ariana Rosen, Ross Levine
text: Ariana Rosen, the daughter of Barbara and Barry M. Rosen of Manhattan, was married last evening to Ross Michael Levine, the son of Deborah and Ronald S. Levine of Merrick, N.Y. Rabbi Charles A. Klein officiated at Cipriani 23rd Street in Manhattan.

headline: Letters
text: Robin Marantz Henig’s article (July 29) conveys the excitement of how much the new robotic generation can do — or seem to do — such as “interact” with “civility.” But it falls short of solving the puzzle of why the gap between mechanical “understanding” on one hand and plain old human “consciousness” on the other is actually growing rather than shrinking as our machines get more advanced. Berkeley’s John Searle has said that figuring out what consciousness is, on its own undeniably subjective terms, is our No. 1 scientific challenge.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,674 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American last week:

headline: Old School
text: Many sports give a separate award to promising rookies, and I’m glad they do. It would be unfair to demand that a rosy new talent show the prime-time swagger, the champion savvy of an M.V.P.; almost no one grabs that Jeter-and-Jordan perfection his first time up.

headline: Russian Voters Feeling Lost Without Translation
text: WHEN Inna Stavitsky ran for City Council from Brighton Beach in 2001, she found herself operating an unpaid sideline in translation.

headline: Heather Rossi, Christopher Spadaccini
text: Heather Elizabeth Rossi, the daughter of Patricia S. Rossi and Edward J. Rossi of Pittstown, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher Henry Spadaccini, the son of Marie Spadaccini and Henry Spadaccini of Brooklyn. The Rev. Peter G. Suhaka, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J.

headline: Colonizing an Urban Frontier
text: THE NOPA district of San Francisco — the name stands for “north of the Panhandle,” that sliver of green jutting east from Golden Gate Park — was once known mostly for low-income housing and random shootings. But an influx of attention-getting restaurants and boutiques in the last decade has made it one of the city's cooler destinations, even as it struggles to maintain its gritty individuality.

headline: Beijing ’08: Let the Politics Begin
text: BEIJING

headline: Correction: Kim Bendheim and Peter Fleischer
text: An article last Sunday about the marriage of Kim Bendheim and Peter Benjamin Fleischer misstated the title of a book by Susan Butler, the bride’s mother. It is “East to the Dawn: The Life of Amelia Earhart,” not “East of the Dawn.”

headline: In Oakland, a Black Pillar Dissolves in Unrest
text: OAKLAND, Aug. 10 — A federal judge’s order to liquidate the assets of Your Black Muslim Bakery will shutter one of this city’s black nationalist institutions, a step called long overdue by many members of the clergy and community activists.

headline: Auckland, New Zealand: Harrowset Hall
text: Harrowset Hall sounds like a prim English girls dormitory, so it's a bit of a shock to step through the small door on a quiet stretch of Ponsonby, a shopping district in Auckland, and discover a romantic den of feminine clutter that is more boudoir than boarding school.

headline: Sorting Through the Buyout Freezeout
text: WELL, so much for the “slow leak” theory.

headline: Volkswagen’s Wildest Bug
text: GREENWICH, Conn.

headline: Don’t Shut Off the Voters
text: Between 1997 and 2002, voters in Monroe rejected budgets approved by the Town Council 14 times, the most that any town in the state turned down its own budget during that period. This year, Monroe has outdone itself; it turned down a $70 million budget five times in the last several months before finally passing it.

headline: Tomato, Tomahto, et Al.
text: The tomatoes are in at Sang Lee Farms. Not just beefsteaks and cherry tomatoes; there are teardrop-shaped yellow tomatoes, small tart green zebra tomatoes, and more than 30 other varieties grown on the farm’s 23 acres (beefsteaks and zebra tomatoes, $4.99 a pound; cherry and teardrop tomatoes, $3.49 a pint).

headline: Bookshelf
text: PICTURES FROM OUR VACATION. Written and illustrated by Lynne Rae Perkins. Greenwillow/HarperCollins. $16.99. (Ages 5 to 8) Perkins captures the rainy days, empty-pool motel days and bent-racquet days that can make a vacation drag, until it suddenly develops its own glow. In a wonderful comic touch, Perkins (“Criss Cross”) has a brother and sister take pictures mostly of collapsing lawn chairs and the empty pool, while all the things “it’s hard to take a picture of” are what they will always remember.

headline: Inside the List
text: CRITICAL LIST: On The Times’s best-seller lists, the short descriptions that follow each title are written by editors here, who keep their opinions out of it. It wasn’t always thus. Observe the paperback best-seller list below, for example, which ran in these pages 35 years ago this week — on Aug. 13, 1972. Poor William Blatty, who made No. 1 only to have an anonymous voice describe his novel as a “crude occult exploitationer.” Then there’s Xaviera Hollander, whose “Happy Hooker” fares even worse. Here are the lists — at that time they were kept to five titles in each category:

headline: Revival of ‘Blondes’ Bounces Past Dead Spots
text: Anita Loos seemed to be hedging her bets when she wrote the short novel “Gentlemen Prefer Blondes” in 1925 and the sequel “But Gentlemen Marry Brunettes” in 1928. In fact, both her zany literary creations — the blond Lorelei Lee and her brunet buddy Dorothy Shaw — had a good chance of landing a man, whether they wound up at the altar or not.

headline: Cleavage Umbrage
text: Cleavage, a word once associated with a deep rift in Republican ranks, has now appeared within the Democratic Party.

headline: Taylor Swanson, Marc Holley
text: Taylor Lauren Swanson, the daughter of Teri and Stephen C. Swanson of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Marc Jacob Holley, a son of Charles L. Holley of Midlothian, Va., and the late Tina M. Holley. Judge Arlene H. Hahn of the Housing Part of Civil Court in the Bronx, officiated at the Harvard Club of New York.

headline: Tara Taff, Jake Levy
text: Tara Beth Taff, the daughter of Alissa S. Taff and Dr. Ross H. Taff of Huntington, N.Y., was married in New York last evening to Jake Matthew Levy, the son of Marjory Lehrer of Newton, Mass., and Dean J. Levy of Dover, Mass. Rabbi Susie Heneson Moskowitz officiated at the Ritz-Carlton, Battery Park.

headline: Cloak and Dagger Amid the Saris
text: THE three men who work at Bollywood Music on 74th Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, have never seen Rabinder Singh. Neither has Kanubhai Chauhan, president of the Jackson Heights Merchants’ Association. Nor has Shiv Dass, the owner of two Indian clothing stores and a jewelry shop on the same street.

headline: Dad’s in Iraq, and the Family’s on Edge
text: HASKELL

headline: Shira Abilevitz, Howard Forman
text: Shira Abilevitz, a daughter of Felice and Baruch Abilevitz of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Howard Leon Forman, a son of Susan Forman and Dr. Arthur J. Forman of Tampa, Fla. Rabbi Josh Blass is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Shaare Zion in Brooklyn.

headline: Restoring Trust in Mass Transit
text: Residents, commuters and visitors showed a tremendous amount of grace and forbearance last week when torrential rains closed much of the subway system. Despite uncomfortable heat and humidity, they piled into overburdened buses and found other ways to cope. Now that everyone has had a chance to cool off, officials need to work overtime to regain the public’s confidence in mass transit.

headline: Erin Fischer, Gregory Acton
text: Erin Nicole Fischer, a daughter of Judge Nora Barry Fischer and Dr. Donald R. Fischer of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Gregory Francis Acton, the son of Joyce V. Acton and David H. Acton of Media, Pa. The Rev. Thomas Burke, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul Cathedral in Pittsburgh.

headline: Bonds's Future Is on the Line, but His Past Is in the Way
text: Barry Bonds has worked for years to construct his reputation as the surly superstar, a man who cares so little about public opinion that he could barely face a television camera without sneering. Image and perception became a toxic mix once accusations of steroid use called into question his accelerating home run totals, completing Bonds’s public image as an arrogant jerk who probably cheated.

headline: Riding the Velvet Rails
text: AS the train rolled across the Tibetan countryside, I stared out into a harsh, bleak landscape. Tibetan nomads rode horses across seemingly endless grasslands dotted with small alpine lakes and ravines cut across snow-capped peaks. Tibetan traders hauling wheelbarrows piled with meat and barley walked a solitary road alongside the train route.

headline: Expect Slowdown on the Way to the Chase
text: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Aug. 11 — Clint Bowyer is chasing a championship in only his second season in the Nascar Nextel Cup series. But he had decided that it might not be such a good idea to push the pace Sunday.

headline: Like a Candy Store for Grown-Ups
text: Anyone who has stood, small coin in small hand, in an old-time candy store will get back that feeling of excitement when studying the seductive stock at Wm. Nicholas & Co. in Katonah. But instead of candy (although that’s available, too), glistening jars, bags, boxes and bowls of fine foods cram the shelves and display cases, tempting the adult customer.

headline: Visiting Justice
text: My wife's sister left her husband of 15 years. She has invited my wife and me to an overnight visit at her new boyfriend's house. I say that accepting the invitation would give the appearance of approval. I feel she should end one relationship or at least begin legal proceedings she has not before living with another man. My wife says it is not for us to judge. Should we visit her and her cohabiter du jour?

headline: China Enacting a High-Tech Plan to Track People
text: SHENZHEN, China, Aug. 9 — At least 20,000 police surveillance cameras are being installed along streets here in southern China and will soon be guided by sophisticated computer software from an American-financed company to recognize automatically the faces of police suspects and detect unusual activity.

headline: Sorrow and Anger as Newark Buries Slain Youths
text: NEWARK, Aug. 11 — From the early morning to the late afternoon, Newark was a city of mourning on Saturday, as people gathered at three separate funerals for three young friends executed in a schoolyard a week before.

headline: The Rainbow Runway
text: GOOSE-PIMPLY in a turquoise string bikini and silver heels, Stacy Wang stepped up to the microphone in a back room of East Manor, a dim sum restaurant in Flushing, Queens, and breathed deeply. “Hi, everyone,” she said brightly, introducing herself in Mandarin to the eight judges for the preliminary round of this year’s Miss New York Chinese beauty pageant. “I’m Stacy Wang, and I am 18 years old. I like to dance, play the piano, swim, play Go and read.”

headline: As Survivors, We Were Closer Than Lovers
text: LESS than a minute after I arrived alone, on Amtrak from Manhattan, I knew this wasn’t going to be easy. My ex-girlfriend, who was being as gracious as she could be after enduring a couple of years of cancer and four (partly successful) combinations of chemotherapy, was lighting a candle.

headline: Two Outlaws, Blasting Holes in the Screen
text: THE story of “Bonnie and Clyde” has been told so many times that it has acquired the patina of legend. It’s the kind of historical fable that circulates to explain how the world once was and how it came to be the way it is now: a morality tale in which the wild energies of youth defeat the stale certainties of age, and freedom triumphs over repression.

headline: Fatah Denies Hamas Claim on Talks
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 12 — A Hamas official in Gaza said today that his organization was holding unofficial talks with representatives from the rival Fatah movement, as tension between the factions continued to simmer on the ground. Fatah officials deny that any such dialogue is taking place.

headline: Masters of the Arcade Caught in a Replay
text: REDMOND, Wash.

headline: Jessica Kahan, Jeffrey Dvorett
text: Jessica Elise Kahan, a daughter of Betsy Kahan and Dr. Ronald Kahan of Wilton, Conn., was married last evening in Stamford, Conn., to Jeffrey Stuart Dvorett, a son of Barbara Dvorett and Barry Dvorett of East Meadow, N.Y. Cantor Shirah Sklar officiated at the Stamford Yacht Club.

headline: A Joy on Many Levels, Especially the Culinary
text: AS I stood in the roomy space with soft lighting and a gorgeous flower arrangement, watching Cab Calloway and the Nicholas Brothers perform their hearts out on a flat-screen TV, I thought to myself, I like this restaurant.

headline: Correction: Letter on ‘Edge of Evolution’
text: A letter to the editor on July 29 responding to a review of Michael J. Behe’s “Edge of Evolution: The Search for the Limits of Darwinism” misstated the year that an article about protein evolution by John Maynard Smith appeared in the journal Nature. It was 1970, not 1971.

headline: The Home-Run Apple: Headed for the Dugout?
text: When a player on the Mets hits a home run at Shea Stadium, a giant fiberglass apple, nine feet in diameter, rises from a 10-foot black top hat beyond the outfield wall. But this bit of theatrical kitsch, a fixture of Mets games since 1980, is unlikely to survive beyond the 2008 season.

headline: Ena Marwaha and David Lebel
text: Ena Marwaha and Ronald David Lebel were married yesterday at St. Francis of Assisi Church in Gates Mills, Ohio. The Rev. James L. Caddy, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Afterward, Shri Ashok Kumar Bhargava, a Hindu priest, performed a Hindu ceremony for the couple at the Cleveland Marriott East in Warrensville Heights, Ohio. The couple met at the University of Pennsylvania, from which they graduated.

headline: Technology Reveals New Worlds to Map
text: MORE than a decade ago, when Michelle Boivin told her father she had decided to major in geography, he was not impressed. “What are you going to do with a geography degree?” she recalled him saying. “All you can do with geography is teach.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The dance entry today in the Week Ahead report in Arts & Leisure misstates the date and time of a performance by Roxane Butterfly. She will perform at the Josie Robertson Plaza on Wednesday at 6 p.m., not Thursday at 8 p.m.

headline: It May Look Like Chaos, but It’s the Fringe
text: PLEASANT chaos powers the Midtown office of the New York International Fringe Festival. A gaggle of 20-somethings are usually in constant motion, squeezing past cluttered desks to answer phones, sort tickets or grab half-finished sodas from atop a tower of file boxes. Meanwhile their boss — Elena K. Holy, the festival’s producing artistic director — stays just as busy in a corner that she has closed off with a pastel-colored curtain.

headline: Old Questions Confront the Giants’ New Faces
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 11 — Among the smattering of fans sprinkled across the red and blue seats of Giants Stadium during the Giants’ first preseason game Saturday night, many wore replica jerseys of players who were not in a Giants uniform, and might never be again. Side by side, children wearing jerseys reading “Barber” and “Strahan” sat near adults wearing “Simms” and “Taylor.”

headline: Appealing to the Senses, and One in Particular
text: OPTIONS are the name of the game at Taste in Garden City. Diners can make a meal of Small Tastes (interesting tidbits) or choose the more traditional Tastes (appetizers) and Large Tastes (entrees).

headline: Sarah Luskin, Kenan Stern
text: Sarah Ruth Luskin, a daughter of Dr. Judith Luskin and Michael Luskin of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Dr. Kenan Walter Davis Stern, a son of Dr. Margaret Ewing Stern and Henry J. Stern of Manhattan, are to be married this afternoon. Cantor Chanin Becker is to officiate at Tappan Hill, an event space in Tarrytown, N.Y.

headline: Sounding the Alarm, or at Least Trying To
text: BUCHANAN, N.Y.

headline: How a ‘Good War’ in Afghanistan Went Bad
text: Two years after the Taliban fell to an American-led coalition, a group of NATO ambassadors landed in Kabul, Afghanistan, to survey what appeared to be a triumph — a fresh start for a country ripped apart by years of war with the Soviets and brutal repression by religious extremists.

headline: Kristen Bethke, Christopher Wendell
text: Kristen Ann Bethke, a daughter of Patricia and Philip Bethke of Midlothian, Va., was married yesterday to Christopher Scott Wendell, a son of Lynn and Peter Wendell of San Francisco. The Rev. Amy E. McCreath, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, and the Rev. Dr. Stephen L. White, also an Episcopal priest, participated in the chapel at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge. The couple met at Princeton, from which they graduated, she summa cum laude, he magna cum laude.

headline: The Thorns in Nature’s Bouquet
text: THE wildflowers are out in force: clouds of Queen Anne’s lace (also known as wild carrot); clusters of sharp two-toned black-eyed Susan; legions of spiky purple-hatted wild bergamot (or bee balm); and, if you are up early, the pretty petunia-like morning glory, a flower that more than lives up to its name.

headline: Correction: A Neighborhood Worth the Big-Ticket Investment
text: The “Living In” article last Sunday, about Central Harlem, misstated the plans for brownstones that are being renovated by Housing Works and the Abyssinian Development Corporation. They are to be used as housing for homeless single adults and families with members living with AIDS or infected with H.I.V., not to be sold at below-market rates through a lottery.

headline: Up Front
text: Christopher Hitchens once wrote a profile of Philip Pullman for Vanity Fair, but “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows” is the first children’s book he has reviewed. It’s been debated whether J. K. Rowling’s novels can really be considered children’s books, when so many adults read them, but Hitchens comes down firmly on the side that they are — “even though their author sometimes tries to pose adult dilemmas such as slavery and even bureaucracy,” he wrote in an e-mail message.

headline: Jay Leno and Conan O’Brien
text: JAY LENO

headline: A House to Grow Into
text: MOIM, a Korean-inspired restaurant that opened recently in Park Slope, is the kind of place that convinces Brooklynites that they’re living in the most cosmopolitan part of the city.

headline: Yes, a Lot of People Died, but ...
text: MOSCOW

headline: Shauna Burgess, Jonathan Friedman
text: Shauna Kathleen Burgess, the daughter of Diane and Thomas J. Burgess of Great Falls, Va., was married yesterday to Jonathan Hale Friedman, a son of Karen and Edward A. Friedman of Scarsdale, N.Y. Cantor Jan Morrison officiated at the Congressional Country Club in Bethesda, Md., with the Rev. Michael J. Kelley, a Roman Catholic priest participating.

headline: Nantucket’s Medical Mr. Fix-It for Whatever Happens to Ail You
text: NANTUCKET, Mass. — For an island flush with the financially fortunate, Dr. Timothy Lepore is a great leveler.

headline: Baseball Brotherhood: It's Not Just an Expression
text: Justin Upton and Delmon Young began their baseball careers in similar fashion. Two years apart, they were the first players selected in the June amateur draft, Young by the Tampa Bay Devil Rays in 2003 and Upton by the Arizona Diamondbacks in 2005.

headline: Not Being There
text: “Granola-eating street fighter” is the unimprovable description that BusinessWeek.com recently bestowed on John P. Mackey, the chief executive of Whole Foods Market. There certainly aren’t many people like Mackey, a vegan who has ruthlessly built Whole Foods into a $6 billion chain of organic groceries. But there are a lot of people who, one way or another, share his recent predicament.

headline: Dancing Away the Heartache, Tacos Included
text: AT Tacos 2004, a taqueria in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, whose bland red-brick exterior belies the rollicking scene inside, six waitresses two-stepped and twirled their customers across an impossibly small dance floor. The women wore identical white tops and black miniskirts with high slits that fanned out when they whirled.

headline: Weekley Is Not Like the Others
text: Tulsa, Okla.

headline: New Brunswick Still Loves the Lads From Liverpool
text: THERE seems to be a severe strain of latter-day Beatlemania circulating at the State Theater in New Brunswick.

headline: Suffering Differently
text: After the 2004 tsunami in Asia, many mental-health experts agreed that a “second tsunami” of mental illness in the form of post-traumatic stress disorder would strike the region. Like doctors rushing to the outbreak of an epidemic, American counselors and trauma researchers soon arrived on the scene hoping to pass on useful knowledge about PTSD. A few years on, however, their efforts have raised a troublesome question: Were they bringing the wrong treatment to the wrong people?

headline: Ohio Pushes Added Leave for Maternity
text: CINCINNATI, Aug. 11 — The Ohio Civil Rights Commission is pushing for a broad expansion of benefits for pregnant workers.

headline: Children’s Books
text: When my son was a baby, he had two ways of reviewing a new book. If he liked it, he would say “Den!” at the end, for “again.” If he didn’t like it, he would singsong “Dah-doy,” for “goodbye.” Sometimes, “dah-doy” came right in the middle of the book — a very negative review. A few months later, he added “too bore” to the review lineup.

headline: Darkness Falls
text: New Yorkers have switched from light summer clothes to their annual black August. A man, left, wears Chinese-style clothes, in the right fabric for the season. Echoing the sudden swarm of black are the imaginative fly-swatter sculptures by Terence Gower in the windows at Barneys, which include a fly, above; a dragonfly, below; a spider and a beetle.

headline: Laura Baur, Henryk Jaronowski
text: Laura Anne Baur, the daughter of Irene and William F. Baur of Glenwood, N.J., is to be married today to Henryk Jaronowski, the son of Lola and Efraim Jaronowski of Monroe, N.Y. Rabbi Garry A. Loeb is to officiate at the Meadowbrook, a reception hall in New Windsor, N.Y.

headline: Judging Ethics in Albany
text: As a general rule, the arbiters of ethics in New York State’s capitol are not a particularly energetic bunch. Despite numerous indictments of legislators in recent years, for example, the Legislative Ethics Committee has seemed asleep most of the time. And the State Ethics Commission, which has moved into the spotlight as the prime investigator of Gov. Eliot Spitzer, has in the past been a politically cautious group.

headline: Dark Water
text: If I’d been asked to bet on who’d write the definitive crime novel about Hurricane Katrina and the devastation of New Orleans, my money would have been on James Lee Burke. And that’s just what he delivers in THE TIN ROOF BLOWDOWN (Simon & Schuster, $26), a hard-boiled cops-and-robbers yarn that puts a human face on anonymous acts of good and evil in the chaos and horror of this natural disaster and its manmade aftermath.

headline: For Jets’ Clemens, the Wait Pays Off
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 11  Because quarterback Kellen Clemens appeared in only two games as a rookie last season and attempted only one pass, people assume his first season with the Jets was unproductive.

headline: Wartime Lies
text: Anne Frank attracts writers. Her best-known starring role in a literary improvisation is in Philip Roth’s 1979 novel, “The Ghost Writer,” in which Nathan Zuckerman spins a surreal tale about the hidden identity of a dark-haired, sexy, European-accented young woman he meets in the house of his mentor. The year is 1956; she would be the famous diarist’s age had Anne Frank survived the war. Zuckerman, reviled for daring to provoke Jewish sensibilities, fantasizes about introducing this Holocaust “saint” to his parents as his (already pregnant) bride and being welcomed back into the fold as a result.

headline: Amy Jones, Steven Freitas
text: Amy Kathleen Jones and Steven Freitas were married yesterday in Rome. Luca Badino, a city clerk, officiated at city hall.

headline: Police Hunt for a Fourth Suspect in Newark Schoolyard Killings
text: NEWARK, Aug. 11  The police appealed for the public’s help on Saturday in finding a 24-year-old man they said was part of a band of men and teenagers who shot and killed three young people and wounded another last weekend in a Newark schoolyard.

headline:
A Place for the Arts, Still Going Strong; Better Mass Transport, Not More Highways; Breeding Pit Bulls
and Endangering Them; Fewer Plastic Bags? Start on My Doorstep (4 Letters)

headline: Change Can Be Good
text: NERISSA VILLAMARIA saw little reason to uproot herself and buy a home.

headline: Coney Island of the Mind
text: FIRST came the sneer:

headline: Lauren Ordene, David Edelstein
text: Lauren Michelle Ordene and David Andrew Edelstein are to be married today at Temple Beth Ahm in Springfield, N.J. Rabbi Dov Hillel Klein is to perform the ceremony.

headline: Suddenly, the Hunt Is On for Cage-Free Eggs
text: The toy industry had its Tickle Me Elmo, the automakers the Prius and technology its iPhone. Now, the food world has its latest have-to-have-it product: the cage-free egg.

headline: Correction: 36 Hours in Edinburgh
text: The 36 Hours column on July 29 about Edinburgh misstated the name of the royal residence there; the error was repeated on the map. It is the Palace of Holyroodhouse, not Hollyrood House.

Neighborhoods in Need of Middle Schools; A Former Firehouse That’s Open to All; Congestion Pricing
and Working Artists; Random Assignments for Arbitrators; The Real Pioneers in Untraveled Places (5 Letters)

headline: May Tsui and Matías Verna
text: Dr. May Tsui and Dr. Matías Augusto Verna were married yesterday. The Rev. Dae Eun Jung performed the ceremony at the Scarborough Presbyterian Church in Scarborough, N.Y.

headline: Now Arriving: Reverse Commuters
text: MANY companies that have opted out of the tight Midtown Manhattan market in favor of Greenwich and Stamford office space are attracting growing numbers of young city dwellers who are turning the traditional commuting pattern on its head.

headline: In the Current Foreclosure Crisis, Echoes of the Past
text: IT is now widely believed that the aggressive mortgage lending during the recent real estate boom was unprecedented. In the final counting, that assessment may well be accurate.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The dance entry today in the Week Ahead report in Arts & Leisure misstates the date and time of a performance by Roxane Butterfly. She will perform at the Josie Robertson Plaza on Wednesday at 6 p.m., not Thursday at 8 p.m. (Go to Article)

headline: When Arbitrators Are Their Own Judges
text: WHEN Harley C. McDonald, a retired lawyer for a Nebraska construction company, lost 80 percent of his $60 million stock market nest egg, he lost faith in the brokerage industry.

headline: Earphone Identity
text: Emotibuds

headline: Elizabeth Page, Jason Bergman
text: Elizabeth Marie Page, the daughter of Patrice and Jonathan R. Page of Upper Saddle River, N.J., was married last evening to Jason Cole Bergman, the son of Linda and Bruce J. Bergman of Lawrence, N.Y. Rabbi Benjamin David officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

headline: A Slice of Nascar Country, Far, Far North of Talladega
text: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Aug. 11  A long line of cars and campers crept through the intersection of Fourth and Franklin Streets here during lunchtime on Friday, over pavement painted like a checkered flag. Unlike a typical stock car race in which ornery drivers swap fender paint, the procession was orderly.

headline: Between Win and Lose, the Casino Dealer
text: OVER the course of his career at the Jackson Rancheria Casino and Hotel in Jackson, Calif., Joe Hebel has been seen as a harbinger of fortune, a liaison to luck and the sweetest angel known to man.

headline: The Week Ahead: Aug. 12-Aug. 18
text: Theater

headline: Old Time Religion, and Hagiography
text: If Mahalia Jackson ever spoke a cross word or had an impure thought, you won’t find out about it at the Hartford Stage. Tom Stolz’s “Mahalia — A Gospel Musical” treats the woman generally acknowledged to have been the world’s greatest gospel singer as if she were Saint Mahalia — and the audience as if it were at Sunday school instead of the theater.

headline: Maureen Miesmer, Joshua Fay-Hurvitz
text: Maureen Elizabeth Miesmer, a daughter of Mary K. and Kenneth J. Miesmer of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Joshua Nathaniel Fay-Hurvitz, a son of Eileen D. Fay and Henry B. Hurvitz of West Hartford. Lois Procopion, a justice of the peace in Berlin, Conn., officiated in Riverside Park in Hartford.

text: Police Say Mother Let Minors Drink Alcohol

headline: Out of Egypt
text: In her new memoir, “The Man in the White Sharkskin Suit,” Lucette Lagnado relates how her father, Leon, first reacted upon escaping the dangerous anti-Semitic environment of Nasser’s Egypt in 1962: “Ragaouna Masr,” he cried, as their boat left the Alexandria harbor — “Take us back to Cairo.”

text: Utility Asks for Raise in Rate

text: COMEDY

headline: Thou Shalt Carry Fliers
text: WHEN David Wain, the comedian and filmmaker, released his feature-film directorial debut, “Wet Hot American Summer,” in 2001, he wound up with an unusual marketing technique that might be called the Air Force method: slip in under the radar, approach quietly and drop a giant bomb.

headline: Hallie Grainer, Mitchell Ulman
text: Hallie Beth Grainer, the daughter of Rochelle Grainer and Dr. Mark Grainer of Marlboro, N.J., was married last evening to Mitchell Adam Ulman, a son of Donna Ulman and Howard Ulman of Sharon, Mass. Rabbi Donald A. Weber officiated at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J., with Cantor Jacqueline Shuchat-Marx participating.

headline: Children’s Books / Young Adult
text: Ask any high school girl: boys can be a pain. Fall for one who seems appealing, and he turns out to be a monster. One moment he acts like you don’t exist, the next, he drives you crazy by playing it cool — while his brothers circle you with hungry eyes. If you take a break to cut the tension, and hang out “just friends”-style with a younger guy who’s puppy-dogging you, what happens? Wouldn’t you know, he turns out to be a nightmare too.

headline: India’s Whiskey-Drinking Elite Make Room for Wine
text: GUNDAMAKERE, India — They used to grow millet in the lap of these gentle hills, and mulberry trees to eke out silkworms. Today, the land is home to Kapil Grover’s shiraz vines.

headline: Hotshots Older and Younger; Offstage Opera
text: BACH: SONATAS AND PARTITAS FOR VIOLIN SOLO

headline: Cages Without Corners
text: GIVEN that their lives consist mainly of naps, meals and playtime, pampered dogs would seem to have little to complain about. But Peter Pracilio fears that even America’s most beloved dogs suffer from needless stress, caused by the boxy crates in which they often have to sleep or travel.

headline: A Pivotal Moment for Booker
text: NEWARK

headline: Rooms and Views
text: I GREW up in a rambling clapboard house in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn with five brothers and sisters, and two maiden aunts.

headline: Spawn Fishing
text: Out on the island-speckled delta of Alaska’s Yukon River, a Yupik Eskimo named Ray Waska and I were cutting the heads off a pile of salmon. After about 20 decapitations, I asked, “So, Ray, you guys ever get sick of eating this stuff?”

headline: Bridget Healy, Richard Sandler
text: Bridget M. Healy and Richard J. Sandler are to be married this evening at the Central Park Boathouse. The Rev. John O’Brien, a minister of the International Council of Community Churches and an uncle of the bride, is to officiate.

headline: A Chinese Tycoon, Inspired to Create Police Technology
text: SHENZHEN, China, Aug. 9  Behind Shenzhen’s aggressive introduction of new police technologies is an unusual computer software company that has won some of the initial government contracts, China Public Security Technology, and the wealthy tycoon who runs it, Lin Jiang Huai.

headline: It Takes Deep Pockets to Fight Global Warming
text: GLOBAL warming is by nature a big-enough problem to create the kind of necessity that could be mother, father and midwife to invention. And plenty of big ideas are out there to address it, some that may even lead to substantial enterprises much as our military needs have.

headline: On the Road (and in the Water) With Richter
text: One weekend during the 1994-95 N.H.L. lockout, Mike Richter  who helped the Rangers win the Stanley Cup the season before  put his goaltending gear on ice, slipped on his running shoes and participated in a half-marathon in Duluth, Minn.

headline: Recreating Colonial Charm, With Modern Touches
text: Southold

headline: Children’s Books
text: Thirteen-year-old boys are mysteries. By and large, they don’t keep diaries and no, they don’t want to talk about it, thank you very much. According to booksellers and parents I’ve met, they don’t read books either, but this may be just a nasty rumor.

headline: Road Bomb in Iraq Kills 5, Including a Governor
Jasmina H.Ahmetovic, Morgan Goulet
text: Jasmina H.Ahmetovic, a daughter of Marija and Zulfikar H.Ahmetovic of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Morgan Andrew Lombard Goulet, a son of Julie and Gerard Goulet of Warwick, R.I. Justice Joseph Covello of the Appellate Division in the State of New York, in Brooklyn, officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: Back to Nature, the Italian Way
text: WE were not 10 miles out of Cagliari, the cosmopolitan capital of Sardinia, when the late-afternoon traffic halted. The cause was soon apparent: a flood of long-haired sheep, blank eyes framed by wild white dreadlocks, spilling slowly across the highway.

headline: What's On Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (TLC) DIANA: LAST DAYS OF A PRINCESS Ten years after the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, this docudrama recreates the 12 weeks leading up to the car crash in a Paris tunnel that killed her and her companion, Dodi al-Fayed. Genevieve O’Reilly and Patrick Baladi, above, portray the couple in a work based on interviews with their close associates. The script also draws from the 832-page Paget Report issued by Britain’s Metropolitan Police Service, which examines the princess’s security arrangements, the scrutiny of Buckingham Palace and the news media, her relationship with the paparazzi, her thoughts on Mr. Fayed and her unrequited love for a British surgeon. Those weighing in include Mohamed al-Fayed, Dodi’s father, as well as his bodyguard Kez Wingfield. At 7, “Diana: Her Last 10 Days in Pictures” presents some of the final photographs taken of the princess.

headline: The Watch List
text: The Tigers and the Indians have allowed the Twins to creep back into the American League Central race. If Minnesota can make its annual run, Matt Garza, right, could be a contributing factor. In six starts since being called back up from the minors, Garza, the team’s top pitching prospect, is 1-3, but he has a 1.70 earned run average.

headline: Rocking the Boat, but Why?
text: WALL STREET responded to the Federal Reserve’s interest rate announcement last week with firm, if rapidly fluctuating, conviction. Stock prices and Treasury bond yields fell sharply, then rose, then continued to swing energetically through the week — and that was after the Fed left rates unchanged.

headline: A Fish Tale
text: A few months ago I took the most expensive nap of my life, and when it was over I decided it was all Hemingway’s fault. For $500, I booked a marlin charter out of Kailua-Kona, Hawaii. I had never gone for the really big fish, and I was juiced to finally get the chance. I imagined myself sitting, like Papa, on the deck of the Pilar, fighting the big fish in the big chair, muttering through gritted teeth the great man’s motto “Il faut (d’abord) durer” — first, one must endure.

headline: S.I. Woman Is Killed and Son, 26, Injured
text: A woman was fatally shot inside her Staten Island home last night and her 26-year-old son was wounded, the authorities said.

headline: False Alarm Triggers Turnpike Bus Hunt
text: SOUTH BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 11 (AP) — Officers from the State Police who responded Saturday to a call about armed men aboard a school bus on the New Jersey Turnpike found out the report was correct — sort of.

headline: What's Your Sign?
text: A look at how American highway signs have changed, and how we ended up with the Clearview font.

headline: Abreu Makes Case to Stay; Mussina Delivers Again
text: Walking into Joe Torre’s office on Saturday night, after an 11-2 victory over the Indians, the first question might as well have been, “So, who’s starting Game 1 of the World Series?”

headline: Your Comments on my Iraq Column
text: My Monday column is about Iraq, arguing that we need to pull out (perhaps with the exception of a force in Kurdistan). I also welcome the idea of partition to reduce the risk of genocide — but not if we have any fingerprints on the partition. I’d welcome your comments.

headline: Terrorism on the Rise
text: A timeline of terrorist attacks in Afghanistan from 2002 through 2005.

headline: ‘The Man in the White Sharkskin Suit’
text: On the first Thursday night of every month, Cairo grew completely still as every man, from the pashas in their palaces to the fellahin in their hovels, huddled by the radio and motioned to their wives and children not to disturb them. It was the night when Om Kalsoum, the Nightingale of the Nile, the greatest singer Egypt had ever known, broadcast live from a theater in the Ezbekeya section, her voice so transcendent and evocative that her fans could picture exactly how she looked as she came out onto the stage, enveloped in the lush white lace dress that softened and transformed her features.

headline: ‘Afterwards’
text: Winter afternoon, five hours patrolling, seventeen minutes on the vehicle checkpoint and counting. Rain. Two cars, two drivers: one man, one woman. She was in the white car, three children with her. One adult passenger, male, in the other car, the red one. One multiple: four men on the rise, four in the fields, and four on the road. Two of us by the first car, two by the second. One round fired.

headline: ‘The Headmaster Ritual’
text: "We were supposed to meet this morning?" asked Dyer, standing in the shaded portico of Headmaster Wolfe's residence, the humid Massachusetts air on him like a quilt.

headline: ‘Seizing Destiny: How America Grew From Sea to Shining Sea’
text: The great irony of James K. Polk's career as territorial expansionist extraordinaire, the one-term President under whom the United States acquired more land than any other, is that he was personally the least expansive of men.

headline: A Round Table on Harry Potter
text: There are 325 million copies of the seven Harry Potter books in print around the world, in 65 languages. The final book, "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows," sold 8.3 million copies the first day it was on sale, a publishing record. Almost more significantly, the series profoundly changed children's publishing, proving that there was potentially a huge crossover audience for popular titles. So what, finally, was it about Harry Potter that captured so many readers' imaginations? We asked a few writers, librarians, bloggers and kids what they thought the secret of Harry's success had been. Readers are invited to add their comments to the ones posted here.  - The Editors

headline: Editor’s Choice
text: THE MASTER BEDROOM, by Tessa Hadley. (Holt, $26.) In Hadley’s novel — a chess game of slow-burn erotic maneuvers — a London professor returning to her childhood home in Wales is attracted to the teenage son of an old friend.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE WORLD IS FLAT: A Brief History of the Twenty-First Century — Further Updated and Expanded, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Picador, $16. ) Building on his 1999 book, “The Lexus and the Olive Tree,” Friedman, a Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist for The New York Times, maps the next phase of globalization. What leveled the world’s economic playing field? Friedman cites 10 forces, including the dot-com bubble and bust, which turned China and India into high-tech epicenters of the outsourcing world. “The World Is Flat” considers the great opportunities and threats globalization represents to older industrialized nations, especially the United States. In the Book Review, Fareed Zakaria called Friedman’s metaphor of a flat world “ingenious”: “Its fundamental insight is true and deeply important.”

headline: Correction: Linz's Favorite Son, a Danish Quartet, a Soprano's Velvety Lasso
text: A CD review of Nicole Cabell’s “Soprano” last Sunday misstated the name of the composer of one selection, “A Child of Our Time.” He is Michael Tippett, not the composer Benjamin Britten.

headline: Correction: Singers Grounded by Sacred Roots
text: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about gospel singers who have crossed over to make pop music misidentified the performer shown at left, holding a bass guitar. He is Danyel Morgan, a member of Robert Randolph’s band, not Robert Randolph.

headline: New Grandmaster Shows He Is Already a Force
text: Last month, Fabiano Caruana, a 15-year-old with dual United States and Italian citizenship, completed the requirements for the grandmaster title. Yesterday, he tied for first in the 11th Hogeschool Zeeland tournament in the Netherlands. He won the tournament on tiebreak. The results and some of the games can be seen at the official Web site for the tournament.

headline: ‘Sin in the Second City’
text: In the winter of 1899, a train clattered toward Chicago, fat coils of smoke whipping the sky. Minna and Ada Everleigh sat together in a Pullman Palace car, sipping wine served by porters wearing white jackets and gloves. Velvet curtains framed the windows, and thick rugs absorbed the curved heels of their boots. The sisters checked their reflections in bevel-edged French mirrors,reclined on Marshall Field'smost luxurious bedsheets, ate in a dining car where woodcock and prairie chicken were presented on tables set with Belgian linen and expensive English china. The train, lit entirely by electricity, was fitted with a new contraption - "vestibules," accordion-shaped passageways that connected the cars, shutting out the fumes and wind. The air inside their car hung heavy and whisper quiet, but the sisters were restless, giddy with plans: They would build upon what they had learned as madams in Omaha, Nebraska, and create the finest brothel in history.

headline: Moiseenko Wins Arctic Chess Challenge; Carlsen Ties for Second
text: Alexander Moiseenko, a grandmaster from Ukraine, has won the Arctic Chess Challenge in Tromso, Norway, with 7.5 points out of 9. Finishing in a tie for second, a half-point back, were grandmasters Kjetil A. Lie of Norway, Vugar Gashimov of Azerbaijan and Magnus Carlsen of Norway. The games and the results are on the official Web site for the tournament.

headline: An Old Lion, but Still Dangerous
text: To describe Viktor Korchnoi as an ageless wonder is a cliche, but it is also apt. Korchnoi, who is 76, is leading the fifth Marx Gyorgy Memorial tournament in Paks, Hungary, after six rounds. His nearest competitor, chronologically, is Peter Acs of Hungary who is 26. The games and information about the competitors is here at the tournament’s official Web site.

headline: Lunacy and Chaos
text: A look at some of the shows in the 2007 New York International Fringe Festival.

headline: How the Iowa Straw Poll Works
text: How did Mike Huckabee, who had a relatively small operation, come in second in the Iowa Straw Poll? The unique process of the poll itself is a part of the answer.

headline: Well-Appointed Rentals
text: Developers are redefining the term "luxury rental" in Manhattan, for people who want the feel of a high-end condominium but don't want to buy.

headline: A Questionable Straw Poll
text: “Obviously this was an incredible day and victory for us,” said former Arkansas governor Mike Huckabee of Saturday’s Iowa Republican straw poll. “What happened for us today was stunning.” A curious statement, perhaps, given that Huckabee was soundly trounced by Mitt Romney — he finished with 18 percent of the vote to Romeney’s 32 percent — but then again, given the haphazard nature of the Ames event, perhaps close doesn’t only count in horseshoes.

headline: Lo Duca Needs Time Off, but How Much?
text: Catcher Paul Lo Duca, who was placed on the disabled list following last night’s 7-5 loss to the Florida Marlins, said today that he could probably play through his hamstring injury. But Manager Willie Randolph said the Mets simply did not want to take any chances.

headline: Reasons for Saying No
text: When I asked readers to give their reasons for not having sex, I predicted the list wouldn’t be as long as the reasons for saying yes. This didn’t seem an especially risky prediction, given certain biological imperatives (and the survival of our species for a couple hundred thousand years or so).

headline: Yankees Bear Down on Boston as Well-Armed Orioles Come to Town
text: The good news is everywhere for the Yankees, who are 29-10 since a brutal loss at home on July 1. They are just four games out of first place after their three-game sweep of the Indians and Eric Gagné’s weekend implosion in Baltimore for the Red Sox.

headline: Asia Booming
text: Residential housing prices are surging in parts of Asia, according to the latest report by the Global Property Guide. After years of moderate growth, prices jumped more than 10 percent in the Philippines, Singapore and South Korea, the study found.

headline: Electricity From the East River
text: Powerful currents and competition upstream have delayed the installation of more underwater turbines in the East River.

headline: Tommy Thompson Bows Out of Race
text: After a sixth-place finish in Saturday’s Iowa Straw Poll, Tommy Thompson, the four-term governor of Wisconsin and former secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, said he was ending his presidential bid.

headline: Your Perfect Work Environment
text: An article in today’s New York Times reports that as technology enables people to live and work wherever they want, increasingly they are clustering in resort playgrounds like Steamboat Springs (pop. 9,315) that have natural amenities, good weather — and, now, lots of people like themselves.

headline: Finding the Perfect Quarterback, and Plenty of Other Ones, Too
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Aug. 7 — His friends called, stunned, during the off-season. But for Tampa Bay quarterback Chris Simms, sitting at home in New Jersey, the transaction news this spring brought amusing, and sometimes unsettling, familiarity.

headline: Somalia and Ethiopia Are Accused of War Crimes
text: RUMBEK, Sudan, Aug. 13 — Human Rights Watch on Monday accused the transitional government in Somalia and the Ethiopian troops that helped bring it to power of committing war crimes in Somalia, saying Ethiopian troops had shelled hospitals, Somali officials had blocked aid convoys and both forces had shown wanton indifference toward civilians.

headline: West Islip: Man Accused of Hitting Woman While Driving Drunk
text: A Medford man was charged yesterday with driving while intoxicated after he apparently accidentally backed his car into his female companion’s mother, the Suffolk County police said. The man, Kenneth Gonzalez, 30, left a party at his companion’s house in West Islip after fighting with several of her family members, the police said. Several people had surrounded his Chevrolet Lumina, which was in the driveway, and when Mr. Gonzalez backed up, he struck the woman, Denise Stark, 49, the police said. Ms. Stark was taken to Stony Brook University Medical Center, where she was in critical condition yesterday with a broken neck and head injuries.

headline: And the Girls Fall Panting at Their Two Left Feet
text: The descriptions of romantic ruin given by the eight goofballs who show up for sexual makeovers tonight on VH1’s “Pick-Up Artist” feature more slapstick than misery. The dateless guys use metaphors involving pratfalls, bottles that break on their heads and even backward cartwheels to evoke how they feel when stunned into terrified silence by desirable women.

headline: F.D.A. and Tobacco (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Japanese Film Wins Top Prize in Locarno
text: The Japanese film “Ai No Yokan” (“The Rebirth”) won the Golden Leopard, the top prize, at the Locarno International Film Festival in Switzerland. Written and directed by Masahiro Kobayashi, above, the winning film is a love story about the mother of a murderer and the victim’s father, played by the filmmaker.

headline: To Stop Abuse, Hold the Abusers Accountable (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Public Service  Through Mug Shots
text: Animal Care & Control of New York City, a nonprofit organization that runs the city’s animal shelter system, is counting on mug shots to increase support.

headline: The No-Match Non-Solution
text: Who kept telling the country that immigration reform through enforcement alone was doomed to fail? President Bush, for one. “All elements of this problem must be addressed together,” he warned, “or none of them will be solved.” So what can be said about Mr. Bush’s latest stab at a policy, which fixates almost entirely on barricading the border, rooting out illegal workers and punishing their employers?

headline: Catch Me, I’m Falling
text: THE horrific collapse of the Interstate 35W bridge in Minneapolis was but one more in the history of infrastructure failures, and I’m afraid it will be old news soon.

headline: China, Filling a Void, Drills for Riches in Chad
text: KOUDJIWAI, Chad — The small plane flew in low over a scorched, peppercorn scrubland, following a broad, muddy river that was all elbows on its run to the southeast.

headline: Elderly Organize to Meet Problems of Aging
text: WASHINGTON — On a bluff overlooking the Potomac River, George and Anne Allen, both 82, struggle to remain in their beloved three-story house and neighborhood, despite the frailty, danger and isolation of old age.

headline: Elizabeth Murray, 66, Artist of Vivid Forms, Dies
text: Elizabeth Murray, a New York painter who reshaped Modernist abstraction into a high-spirited, cartoon-based, language of form whose subjects included domestic life, relationships and the nature of painting itself, died yesterday at her home in upstate New York.

headline: It Was Over Long Before It Was Over
text: Tulsa, Okla.

headline: Matthew Pulls Away
text: Catriona Matthew won the Scandinavian T.P.C. yesterday, shooting a four-under-par 68 and beating Laura Diaz and Sophie Gustafson by three shots in Loddekopinge, Sweden. Matthew finished with a nine-under 279 for her fifth victory. Annika Sorenstam, the defending champion and tournament host, closed with a 68 for her best round of the tournament and moved to 9th from 21st.

headline: A Shakespearean Deal With an Unlikely Assist
text: How does that quotation from “Twelfth Night” go? “Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon them.”

headline: Importing Chiefs, Detroit Reflects on Its ‘Car Guys’
text: DETROIT, Aug. 12 — Where have all the car guys gone?

headline: Republicans’ Debated YouTube Forum Is Back On
text: It looks as if the Republican presidential candidates, at least most of them, will be participating in a YouTube debate after all. The forum is now set for Nov. 28, the Wednesday after Thanksgiving.

Because of an editing error, an article Friday about newly released portions of an inquiry into the detention by the United States of a Syrian-born Canadian, Maher Arar, who was sent to a third country, where he was tortured, misstated in some copies the country where another Canadian, Ahmad Abou el-Maati, was tortured. It was Syria, not Kuwait. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the current value of a compensation package offered to Mr. Arar in January. The package was estimated to be 11.5 million Canadian dollars, including legal fees, although the exact amount of the fees was not disclosed. At current exchange rates, that would be about $10.9 million, not $9.75 million.

headline: Delaying the Inevitable
text: As we struggle to extricate ourselves from Iraq, it’s useful to look at how the Soviet Union handled a similar position in the 1980s. Then we should do the opposite.

headline: East River Fights Bid to Harness Its Currents for Electricity
text: From the eastern edge of Roosevelt Island, the past and perhaps the future of New York power are on display.

headline: New Formula Means More Money for Arts Groups in New York
text: The Mark Morris Dance Group got $80,000, up from $12,000 last year. The Flux Factory, an arts center in Long Island City, Queens, got $20,000, up from $3,000 last year. And the Mama Foundation for the Arts, which teaches gospel music, jazz and R&B in Harlem, got $12,500, up from $5,000.

headline: If We Treat Terrorists Like Criminals (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Week Ahead
text: THE CREDIT SQUEEZE The main focus will be on the credit crisis and its effect on the markets. Wednesday will be the 45th day before the end of the quarter, the deadline by which most hedge fund investors must notify the funds if they want to redeem investments.

Because of an editing error, an article on July 26 about the family background of Joshua Komisarjevsky, one of two suspects in the home invasion slayings of a woman and her two daughters in Cheshire, Conn., referred incorrectly to “In Cold Blood,” which recounted the similar murders of a Kansas family in 1959. Although the author, Truman Capote, referred to the work in an interview as a “nonfiction novel” before its publication in 1966, it is not in fact a novel.

headline: Stewart Keeps Surging as Gordon Spins Out
text: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Aug. 12  The race seemed over, but then the most treacherous turn on a slippery track claimed one more car. Clutching to the lead less than two laps from the finish on a chaotic afternoon, Jeff Gordon spun out.

headline: Too Darn Hot for Queen of Soul
text: Aretha Franklin canceled a hometown concert scheduled for last night at the DTE Energy Music Theater in suburban Detroit, because of the heat, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Franklin, the Queen of Soul, 65, said that with temperatures forecast to go above 90 degrees, the show could not go on, and that she hoped to reschedule it at a later date. “I am exhausted from the heat and cannot tolerate heat in these extremely high numbers and being in concert simultaneously,” she said in a statement.

headline: Formerly at Voice, Editor Takes a Job at the Competition
text: Anyone who has ever been fired abruptly from a high-profile job can perhaps relate to the revenge fantasy that David Blum seems to be living out — and the retaliation he may have in mind for his former employer.

headline: Woods Takes Every Shot and Wins 13th Major
text: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 12 — There was a different texture to this five-mile walk, an appearance of tension and conflict in Tiger Woods’s midst as he stepped into the furnace of Southern Hills Country Club on a broiling Sunday on the Plains.

headline: A Jets End Gets a Taste of What He Missed
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 12  A lot of time had passed between N.F.L. snaps when defensive end Andre Wadsworth took the field Friday night at Giants Stadium. That much was evident in the string of unfamiliar faces staring back across the line of scrimmage.

headline: For a Joke-Telling Candidate, a Second-Place Finish
text: DES MOINES, Aug. 12 — “I can’t buy you — I don’t have the money,” Mike Huckabee, the Arkansas Republican seeking the presidency, told Republicans at the Iowa Straw Poll this weekend. He offered a mock frown.

headline: Pack Mentality Among Hedge Funds Fuels Market Volatility
text: On Wall Street, there is a rage against the machine.

headline: A First Turn for Wheeldon and Company
text: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 11 — Could any new ballet company have begun with more good will and eager applause than Christopher Wheeldon’s Morphoses? At Friday’s inaugural performance at the Vail International Dance Festival in Colorado, almost all of the six dances by the new troupe were greeted by instant standing ovations from large parts of the audience.

headline: The Rove Legacy
text: Karl Rove leaves the White House in anything but victory. His legendary reputation was seriously diminished by the Republican defeat in the 2006 midterm elections, and has been eroded almost every day since then, as President Bush has struggled through his second term.

headline: Irene Morgan Kirkaldy, 90, Rights Pioneer, Dies
text: Irene Morgan Kirkaldy, whose defiance of white supremacy while traveling through the Upper South in the summer of 1944 led to a Supreme Court decision outlawing segregated seating on interstate bus lines, died Friday in Hayes, Va. She was 90.

headline: Aiming for a New Pittsburgh, and Falling Short
text: CIUDAD GUAYANA, Venezuela — When a group of urban planners from Harvard and M.I.T. arrived here in the early 1960s to design an industrial city almost entirely from scratch, they envisioned a “Pittsburgh of the tropics” that could anchor industrialization and population growth in southeastern Venezuela.

headline: It’s Lauren vs. Heidi in Battle of the Ex-BFFs
text: “The Hills,” which opens its third season on MTV tonight, is more convincing than “Friends” and just about any other comedy about female relationships because — as anyone who has ever been a young woman knows — undying friendships die.

headline: Fighting Continues Over James Brown Estate
text: David Cannon, a co-executor of the will of the soul singer James Brown, right, who has been accused of misappropriating $350,000 of Brown’s money, resigned on Friday after handing over a check for the full amount during a court hearing, The Augusta Chronicle reported. Almost two dozen lawyers were present at the four-hour hearing before Judge Jack Early, of the South Carolina Second Judicial Circuit, representing the numerous family members and others who are wrangling over the estate. (Brown’s former pastor, the Rev. Larry Fryer, has filed a motion on behalf of needy children who are meant to benefit from the singer’s “I Feel Good” Trust.) Friday’s hearing also revealed that there might not be much to fight for: Adele Pope and Robert Buchanan, the court-appointed lawyers assigned to help settle the estate, reported during the hearing that the estate and the trusts set up that were to be financed by Brown’s music royalties appear to have a zero balance. A follow-up hearing was scheduled for Sept. 24.

headline: Inflation Surges in China
text: HONG KONG, Aug. 13 — Steeply rising food prices pushed inflation in China to 5.6 percent last month, the fastest pace in a decade, government figures showed today, prompting renewed concern about whether inflation would spread more widely in China and abroad.

headline: Packing Their Trunks and Making Their Getaways
text: The dance component of the 11th annual New York International Fringe Festival opened appropriately with “All Aboard,” an hourlong, multimedia work presented on Saturday afternoon at the Linhart Theater in the East Village by the Armstrong/Bergeron Dance Company of Bryan, Tex. But the trip ran out of steam well before its destination.

headline: Bronx Man, 19, Is Killed in Shooting on the Subway
text: A 19-year-old man was killed and three of his friends were wounded after a man they were arguing with opened fire aboard a subway car in the Bronx yesterday morning, the police said.

headline: Most Asian Markets Spring Back From Last Week’s Plunge
text: SINGAPORE, Aug. 13 — If there is a crisis in global financial markets, it wasn’t apparent in Asia today.

headline: Head of Chinese Toy Company Said to Kill Himself
text: SHANGHAI, Aug. 13 — The head of a Chinese company that was behind the recall earlier this month of more than a million Mattel toys committed suicide over the weekend, China’s state-controlled media reported today.

headline: Lo Duca Lands on D.L. With Bruised Feelings
text: It is not clear how much time catcher Paul Lo Duca will miss with a strained right hamstring. Lo Duca said yesterday that he would be ready to return as soon as he was eligible to come off the disabled list in two weeks.

headline: New British Men’s Magazine, but No Nudity, Please
text: LONDON, Aug. 12 — Mike Soutar refuses to say who or what will be featured on the cover of Short List, a new men’s magazine he is introducing next month in Britain. But one thing seems certain: if it is a female model, she will wear at least a bit of clothing.

headline: Irresponsible Threats
text: The last thing China needs is to give American politicians new excuses to erect protectionist defenses against Chinese imports. So it is stupefying that some Chinese officials — with the blessing of the government press — have been talking of using China’s enormous cache of American Treasury bonds as an economic weapon.

headline: Ten Bucks a Dance
text: Twenty-eight dance companies from around the world will converge on New York City Center for the fourth annual Fall for Dance Festival, scheduled for Sept. 26 through Oct. 6. As part of the festival’s continuing effort to build new audiences for dance, tickets will once again cost only $10 for all performances in the 10-evening festival. Participants include the Kirov Ballet, the Lyon Opera Ballet and the French hip-hop troupe Compagnie Käfig. Several New York companies will join the lineup as well, including the City Center resident troupes American Ballet Theater, Paul Taylor Dance Company and Morphoses/the Wheeldon Company. Full details are available at nycitycenter.org, and tickets go on sale Sept. 9.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Addenda
text: Accounts

headline: Names in the News Get a Way to Respond
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12  The Internet offers immediate access to articles about every breaking news event anywhere in the world. But no one in the media business has quite figured out how to exploit that revolutionary fact.

headline: School Translators Can Help Parents Lost in the System
text: In an earlier life, Xin Meng chased stories as a reporter for a Chinese-language newspaper in New York. Now he spends his days figuring out how to translate mysterious phrases like “empowerment school” and “English language learner” into Chinese.

headline: Iraqi Premier to Hold Talks in Search for Compromise
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 12 — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said Sunday that he would meet as early as this week with leaders from all the major political parties of Iraq in the hopes of forging a grand compromise among the warring factions.

headline: A Filing by Gannett Has Set Off Alarms, and Reassurances
text: Has the newspaper business become like a nervous friend who jumps at every noise while you shrug it off? It’s easy to poke fun, but these days you can’t be so sure the friend is wrong.

headline: Popular Demand
text: “The Invasion,” one of many heirs to the 1956 science-fiction classic “Invasion of the Body Snatchers,” opens on Friday. Nicole Kidman (above) plays a psychiatrist trying to stay alive and find her son before the aliens get to her.

headline: Brooke Astor, 105, First Lady of Philanthropy, Dies
text: Brooke Astor, who by night reigned over New York society with a disdain for pretension and by day devoted her time and considerable resources to New York’s unfortunate, died this afternoon at her weekend estate, Holly Hill, in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. She was 105.

headline: Center Field and Center Stage Are Cabrera’s
text: Cleveland

headline: After Ups (4 Homers) and Downs, Mets Win
text: A lot of things went right during the Mets’ 10-4 victory over the Florida Marlins yesterday. Moises Alou hit two of the team’s four home runs, and the Mets piled on the runs, which helped end their homestand on a winning note.
