headline: A Matriarch After Your Attention, if Not Heart
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 10 — For all her grace and gentility, Eugene O’Neill’s Mary Tyrone was certainly a handful. Ditto Tennessee Williams’s Amanda Wingfield and Lillian Hellman’s Regina Giddens. Edward Albee’s Martha is a mother you wouldn’t even wish on an imaginary child.

headline: Flash of Speed From an Overlooked Part of the Giants Backfield
text: Missing from the discussions in the off-season about how to replace Tiki Barber at running back, beyond the buzz for Brandon Jacobs and the reports about Reuben Droughns, was Derrick Ward.

headline: Hawaiian-Style Lilt and Flow, With a Jab at Grass Skirts
text: Patrick Makuakane’s Na Lei Hulu I Ka Wekiu Hawaiian dance and music company knows how to put on a good show. Mr. Makuakane had the audience laughing and cheering on Saturday night at a performance at the Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival. And quite a few audience members rose to the occasion when he invited them to dance the hula in the aisles, as they did at the company’s last Out of Doors show, in 2004.

headline: Ad Seeking Portfolio Web Host Suggests, ‘Think Tina Fey’
text: What a difference an issue makes.

headline: Bullet Train Churning to Hard Bop
text: Louis Hayes’s syncopated ride-cymbal beat helped harden hard bop in the late 1950s and early ’60s. It was heard most widely on records by Horace Silver and Cannonball Adderley, and it survives as a classic mid-century American product, heavy and stylized and confident, a sound that can’t be easily whisked away.

headline: Xbox 360 Out of Order? For Loyalists, No Worries
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12— Imagine your blender breaking down twice. The vacuum cleaner giving up the ghost three times. The espresso maker repeatedly going kaput. Then imagine replacing the item with the same model over and over while keeping your brand loyalty and sanity.

headline: Troops Shelter an Unlikely Survivor in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 12 — Fatima Jbouri should be dead.

headline: A Coming of Age at Nickelodeon: Noggin and the N Will Get Their Own Channels
text: Nickelodeon is expected to announce today that Noggin, the daytime commercial-free preschool network, and the N, a nighttime advertising-supported network for adolescents and teenagers, will become 24-hour stand-alone networks and no longer share channel space.

headline: Manufacturers Find Ways to Navigate Web Retailing
text: FOR manufacturers, the Web can be a hazardous place. Consumers expect these companies to sell their products directly online, but retailers have other thoughts.

headline: East German Shoot-to-Kill Order Is Found
text: BERLIN, Aug. 12 — Seventeen years after German reunification, archivists have found the first written proof that East German border guards had been ordered to shoot to kill anyone trying to escape to West Germany, including women and children.

headline: If Thompson Runs for President, Don’t Look for Him in Reruns
text: Former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee segued neatly from Congress back to an acting career in 2002, when he joined the cast of NBC’s long-running crime series “Law & Order.”

headline: With Their Confidence Showing, the Yankees Complete a Sweep
text: CLEVELAND, Aug. 12  When Andy Pettitte walked off the mound at Yankee Stadium on July 1, in the midst of a seven-run second inning, the Yankees were on their way to a loss that pushed them four games below .500.

headline: This Land Is Your Land? This Land Is My Land!
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Taliban Release 2 Korean Hostages
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 13 — Two women who were among 23 South Koreans kidnapped by the Taliban in mid-July were freed today and were later in South Korean custody, in the first major breakthrough in the hostage case in nearly a month.

headline: Bay Shore: 2 Boys Injured in Boat Crash
text: Suffolk County police detectives yesterday were investigating a boating accident in which two boys were injured, one seriously, the police said. Two motorboats crashed about 10 p.m. on Saturday about a half mile south of the Bay Shore Marina. Three children, ages 11, 12 and 13, were thrown from a 22-foot boat driven by Brian Soltan, 45, of West Islip. The children, whose identities were not released, were rescued from the water and the boats were able to reach the marina, the police said. The 13-year-old boy suffered a head injury and was in serious condition yesterday at Stony Brook University Medical Center. The 11-year-old boy was in stable condition at Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center. Mr. Soltan was in stable condition at Southside Hospital, the police said.

headline: Small Investors Seen as Safer in Stock Slide
text: The wild swings in the stock market over the last few weeks have reawakened memories of the technology crash of 2000 in which many small investors lost their savings. But this time around, market experts say, ordinary investors seem less vulnerable than the professionals who have taken a beating.

headline: U.S. Market Seen for Iraqi-Made Clothes
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 12 — Iraqi and American officials think Iraq’s ailing economy could get a kick-start from American consumers interested in giving Iraqi-made clothes as Christmas presents.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Fighting Continues Over James Brown Estate

headline: Bronx: Woman Shot to Death
text: A 22-year-old woman was found shot in the head in the stairwell of her apartment building in Claremont yesterday, the police said. The woman, Glenda Pena, who lived on the sixth floor of 1348 Webster Avenue, was found between the second and third floors about 5 p.m., the police said. Ms. Pena was pronounced dead at Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center. There were no arrests in the case last night, the police said.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article Friday about newly released portions of an inquiry into the detention by the United States of a Syrian-born Canadian, Maher Arar, who was sent to a third country, where he was tortured, misstated in some copies the country where another Canadian, Ahmad Abou el-Maati, was tortured. It was Syria, not Kuwait. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the current value of a compensation package offered to Mr. Arar in January. The package was estimated to be 11.5 million Canadian dollars, including legal fees, although the exact amount of the fees was not disclosed. At current exchange rates, that would be about $10.9 million, not $9.75 million. (Go to Article)

headline: Man Charged in Church Shooting
text: A man accused of opening fire in a church in Missouri on Sunday, killing three people and wounding four, pleaded not guilty in court today to a range of charges including murder.

headline: Is Motherhood Noble Work? Not in the World of ‘Weeds’
text: Jenji Kohan, the creator of “Weeds,” which returns for a third season on Showtime tonight, spent part of her career as a television writer working on “Gilmore Girls,” an aspect of her résumé that seems singularly significant.

headline: In Study Abroad, Gifts and Money for Universities
text: As overseas study has become a prized credential of the undergraduate experience, a competitive, even cutthroat, industry has emerged, with an army of vendors vying for student money and universities moving to profit from the boom.

headline: Footnote
text: The One World Symphony from Brooklyn will present “One Summer Night” on Thursday at 8:30 p.m. at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights. The 85-minute concert will feature works by Ravel, Berlioz, Beethoven and Wagner.

headline: Poland to Have Elections 2 Years Early
text: WARSAW, Aug. 12 — Seeking to end months of political turmoil, Polish officials confirmed Sunday that the government would hold elections by November, two years ahead of schedule.

headline: To Stop Abuse, Hold the Abusers Accountable (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Remarks by Bush and Rove
text: Here are the remarks made by President  Bush and Karl Rove at the White House this morning concerning Mr. Rove’s resignation, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service.

headline: It’s All About Them
text: Ask not what your country can do for you — ask what you can do for your father’s political campaign.

headline: A Life of Hardship, and Now, Two Fugitive Sons
text: A few blocks from the Newark schoolyard where the killings had been carried out, Gloria Gomez sat on her porch in the fading afternoon light, hardship etched on her careworn face, and tears welled in her eyes as she spoke of her two fugitive sons and the terrible crimes for which they were being sought.

headline: For Austin, Loving the Attention, Hating the Mistakes
text: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 12 — With a hot sauce logo on his collar and an array of from-the-gut celebrations, Woody Austin jumped into the fray of the 89th P.G.A. Championship at Southern Hills and nearly made it his own.

headline: Anger in India Over Nuclear Accord
text: NEW DELHI, August 13 — Simmering distrust of the United States in the Indian parliament broke into full-throated protest today, as politicians from both the right and the left pounced on the government for its landmark nuclear accord with Washington. The prime minister, Manmohan Singh, defended the accord as good for India’s strategic and economic interests.

headline: A Stock Soars After a Spam Swarm
text: Last Thursday, inboxes around the world were flooded with crude PDF documents promoting the stock of the Prime Time Group, a tiny Florida company with cellphone and convenience-store interests, among others. “Insider Buying Alert!!!” the messages began, promising that the stock would “move like a comet.”

headline: Pension Fund Investments (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: From a Burmese Prison, a Chronicle of Pain in Paint
text: LONDON, Aug. 12 — A color photograph of the Burmese artist Htein Lin on the day of his release from prison shows him stooped and wan, looking easily 20 years older than his real age. His face is scrawny, and in one of his thin hands he holds a white plastic bag filled with the remnants of more than six years in a cell. He stands next to a uniformed military man who ran the jail.

headline: Self-Loathing in California. Self-Critique? No Way!
text: Back in 1975 “Shampoo” was a farce, a Hollywood sex comedy with Warren Beatty as its promiscuous, ingenuous hero. Showtime’s new series “Californication” is more of a dirge, a Hollywood sex tragedy with David Duchovny as its promiscuous, cynical hero. Roués who love women are hard to resist. There is nothing less appealing than a Lothario who dislikes women, except perhaps a misogynist Lothario who is a middle-aged, blocked writer prone to sleeping with younger women and even teenagers. “Californication” is supposed to be a dark comedy about love and sex in Los Angeles, but it is not nearly dark or funny enough — less “Shampoo” than “Rogaine.”

headline: New  CDs
text: LORI MCKENNA “Unglamorous”  (Warner Brothers Nashville)

headline: Calling Rappers (Plus Size Please)
text: Fox Searchlight Pictures is looking for the next big thing in rappers. “Notorious,” a film about the rapper Christopher Wallace, better known as Biggie Smalls and better still as the Notorious B.I.G., left, is in the works. But the role of the rapper, who was killed in 1997, is yet to be filled. The biopic’s producers have decided to open up the playing field and starting today are allowing actors to submit audition tapes via the Web site biggiecasting.com. The rapper’s mother, Voletta Wallace, offered some advice to would-be stars in an article on the Rolling Stone Web site: “I don’t want you to just imitate him,” she said. “I want to see his swagger, his style, his energy and smile come through.”

headline: Most Global Markets Spring Back From Plunge
text: If there is a crisis in global financial markets, it was not apparent in Asia and Europe today. And on Wall Street, the week got off to an unremarkable start.

headline: Merv Griffin, Television Innovator, Dies at 82
text: Merv Griffin, a big-band singer who became one of television’s longest-running talk-show hosts and formidable innovators, creating some of the medium’s most popular game shows before becoming a major figure in the hotel and gambling businesses, died yesterday in Los Angeles. He was 82.

headline: Afghan Rebels Find Aid in Pakistan, Musharraf Admits
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 12 — Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president of Pakistan, made a rare admission on Sunday before hundreds of Pakistani and Afghan delegates at a grand tribal assembly here, saying that support for militants emanating from Pakistan has caused problems for Afghanistan, and that his country should work to secure peace on its side of their mutual border.

headline: The 17 Percent Problem and the Perils of Domestication
text: In June, Science magazine published an article called “Domesticated Nature,” which noted that by 1995, “only 17% of the world’s land area had escaped direct influence by humans.” The article was accompanied by one map showing the enormous “human footprint” on Earth and another showing in a thicket of red lines the tangle of road networks and shipping lanes across the globe. That 17 percent figure is now certainly smaller, and that thicket of transport networks gets a little more tangled every day. The article takes as a working assumption what is obviously true: “There really is no such thing as nature untainted by people.”

headline: On Playing Fields, Grass Is an Endangered Species
text: Brandon Diaz ran across the springy grass infield, stood atop the pitcher’s mound and, with a short windup, let loose with a curveball to his father, John. The hardball zipped through the warm air, landing squarely in his father’s glove with a plop that could barely be heard above the raspy hiss and clang from a high-rise under construction across the street.

headline: At Tanglewood, Mozart and Sounds From Closer to Home
text: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 11 — Live, from the Berkshires, it was Saturday Night!

headline: Another Day at the Office
text: Bob Barker made it look so easy, but apparently working on the set of “The Price Is Right” can be dangerous at times. The show’s new host, Drew Carey, injured his arm during a rehearsal on Friday, the Web site TMZ.com reported. After getting his arm caught in a moving part of a grocery game, Mr. Carey was taken to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, but was released soon after and returned to the set.

headline: In Third Chapter, No Box Office Rush on ‘Rush Hour’
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 — The last big-budget movie of the summer, “Rush Hour 3,” opened in United States theaters with a middling $50.2 million in ticket sales, failing to match the performance of the franchise’s previous chapter.

headline: Dear Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Karl Rove, Top Strategist, Is Leaving the White House
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 — Karl Rove, the political adviser who masterminded President George W. Bush’s two winning presidential campaigns and secured his own place in history as a political strategist with extraordinary influence within the White House, announced on Monday that he would resign at the end of the month.

headline: Hamas and Fatah Disagree on Whether They’re Talking
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 12  A Hamas official in Gaza said Sunday that his organization was holding unofficial talks with representatives from the rival Fatah movement, as tension between the factions continued to simmer on the ground. Fatah officials denied that any such dialogue was taking place.

headline: From Housing Haven to Foreclosure Leader
text: STOCKTON, Calif., Aug. 11 — The north end of Clarks Fork Circle in Stockton tells you all you need to know about the depth of the mortgage worries here. On a curve in a handsome new residential development, four of five homes are for sale, at least two of which have already been repossessed by a lender.

headline: Hamas and Opposition Clash in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 13  Tensions rose today between the Hamas rulers in Gaza and the Fatah-led opposition there, with Hamas forcefully breaking up what opposition leaders insisted was a peaceful rally for freedom of expression.

headline: Off to Resorts, and Carrying Their Careers
text: STEAMBOAT SPRINGS, Colo. — Time was you could tell the urban refugees in places like this: corporate achievers who quit the rat race to open a bed and breakfast or a candle shoppe.

headline: Iranian Official Says Inquiry Into U.S. Scholars Has Ended
text: TEHRAN, Aug. 12  A senior judiciary official said Sunday that Iran had finished its investigation into two Iranian-American academics who were arrested in May on espionage charges, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported.

headline: A World Without Humans? It All Falls Apart
text: The abundant doomsday plotlines in “The World Without Us” make it a useful conversation piece, if a grim one. Traveling down many different avenues of scientific research, Alan Weisman postulates the complete disappearance of mankind from planet Earth. Then he extrapolates about what would happen without us. By his estimate most of our leavings would rot and crumble; much of our damage would take eons to undo. There’s one tiny bit of good news. Depleted sea species might recover if we would do them a favor and go away.

headline: Saluting the Wunderkinds (Mozart and Schubert)
text: Friday night’s Mostly Mozart program focused on teenage composers. Their names were Mozart and Schubert. Mozart, at 19, wrote his violin concertos (represented here by the fifth and last), and at 16 wrote his first draft of music to accompany the play “Thamos, King of Egypt” (though he kept revising it through the advanced age of 23). Schubert, at 19, wrote his fourth symphony.

headline: After 3 Deadly Crashes in Queens, 2 Drivers Face Charges
text: Two pedestrians and a driver were killed in three accidents in Queens during the weekend, the police said. Two of the drivers were charged with driving while intoxicated.

headline: Yes, the Fund-Raising Records Fell, Just Not as Far
text: For Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, it was a monumental achievement: Her campaign announced in April that she had raised $26 million in the first quarter of the year, more than any other presidential candidate.

headline: A Case So Shielded One Side Is in the Dark
text: San Francisco

headline: NBC Making a Clean Start in a House of Mixed Media
text: After it bought the Web site iVillage.com last year for $600 million, NBC Universal bragged that it had landed a digital darling. The women-focused Internet business was a perfect fit with the “Today” show, executives said, and would turbo-charge their online efforts.

headline: Ann Taylor Said to Plan Boomer Unit
text: Ann Taylor wants to grow up.

headline: With Spitzer Inquiry, Albany’s Eyes Are on Ethics Panel Just as It Is Changing
text: ALBANY, Aug. 10 — In 39 years as a litigator, Herbert Teitelbaum, who became executive director of the State Ethics Commission last month, sued Boston to let college students vote. He sued school officials in Philadelphia for not providing better English instruction for Hispanic children. And he took on the cities of White Plains, New Rochelle, Mount Vernon and Yonkers for discriminating against blacks applying for jobs as firefighters.

headline: Workers at Mine Plan a Third Rescue Hole
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 12 — Emergency workers searching for six coal miners who have been trapped for a week in a deep underground shaft announced Sunday that they would begin drilling a third hole through the mountainside and using a faster digging technique to speed up the horizontal push through the collapsed mine’s rubble.

headline: Wrong Way Out of Iraq
text: As Americans argue about how to bring the troops home from Iraq, British forces are already partway out the door. Four years ago, there were some 30,000 British ground troops in southern Iraq. By the end of this summer, there will be 5,000. None will be based in urban areas. Those who remain will instead be quartered at an airbase outside Basra. Rather than trying to calm Iraq’s civil war, their main mission will be training Iraqis to take over security responsibilities, while doing limited counterinsurgency operations.

headline: Goldman and Investors to Put $3 Billion Into Fund
text: Goldman Sachs and a group of investors are injecting $3 billion of capital into one of its flailing hedge funds that lost about 30 percent of its value last week.

headline: A Variation on the DVR, Without Ad Skipping
text: In a move that is certain to delight advertisers, Time Warner Cable is about to offer its customers a free recording feature for their televisions — one that will not allow them to zap through the commercials.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Brooklyn: Gunman Shot by Police
text: A man was wounded in a shootout with police officers in East New York on Saturday night, the police said. The shooting occurred about 11:50 p.m., as the officers responded to a report of an assault at 247 Vermont Street. After the officers arrived, they saw two men, one of them armed. The gunman fired at three people, the police said, and when the officers ordered him to drop his weapon, he fired at them. The officers returned fire, hitting the gunman, the police said. The man, whose name was not released, was in stable condition yesterday at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said. The officers were not injured. A loaded .22-caliber pistol was found at the scene, and charges were pending, the police said.

headline: Julie Halston, Host for Awards
text: Two years ago, at the inaugural New York Innovative Theater Awards, which honor achievement in Off Off Broadway theater, the host Charles Busch coerced one of the evening’s presenters — his friend the actress and comedian Julie Halston  — to stay onstage and serve as his co-host for the rest of the evening. She complied. This year Ms. Halston is taking over completely and will be the host of the third annual presentation, scheduled for Sept. 24 at the Haft Auditorium at the Fashion Institute of Technology. Among the presenters who have agreed to participate in this year’s event are  Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker; the lighting designer Natasha Katz (“Tarzan,” “The Little Mermaid”); and the director Leigh Silverman (“Well”). Receiving this year’s artistic achievement award, presented to “an individual who has made a significant artistic contribution to the Off Off Broadway community,” will be Doric Wilson, one of the first playwrights to present work off Off Broadway at the Caffe Cino. His comedy “And He Made a Her” opened there in 1961 with Jane Lowry and Paxton Whitehead playing the lead roles.

headline: Regulator in Europe Proposes a Superagency to Wield Power Over Its Phone Markets
text: BERLIN — After its success cutting mobile phone roaming fees, the European Commission is weighing a plan that could force some former phone monopolies in Europe to open their networks to greater competition.

headline: And We’ll Call It Graceland West
text: Thursday will mark the 30th anniversary of Elvis Presley’s death, and Elvis Week 2007 is all the rage in Memphis and elsewhere this week. Elvis paraphernalia — including the King’s Army shirt — is demanding huge prices on eBay, and the numerous gift shops at Graceland are selling all kinds of 30th-anniversary knickknacks, including Reese’s Peanut Butter & Banana Creme Cups (in honor of Presley’s favorite sandwich). Meanwhile a fan in California wants to give Graceland some competition, The Associated Press reported. Reno Fontana and his wife, Laura, recently purchased a Spanish-style white stucco home in Palm Springs with five bedrooms and seven bathrooms that Elvis and Priscilla Presley purchased in 1970. The Fontanas intend to decorate the home in Elvis style and eventually build a chapel (for weddings) and a recording studio. “We may have our names on the deed, but we are the caretakers,” Mr. Fontana said. “This house belongs to Elvis fans around the world.”

headline: Dutch Company Bets on Interactivity to Make G.P.S. Devices More Useful in the U.S.
text: MILAN, Aug. 12 — If you have ever been lost on the tiny, twisting, one-way back streets of Prague, Brussels or Milan, you have a pretty good idea why navigation devices that use the Global Positioning System are vastly more popular in Europe than in the United States.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10:30 P.M. (Showtime) CALIFORNICATION David Duchovny, left, stars as the novelist Hank Moody, a one-hit wonder who high-tails it from New York to Los Angeles when his acclaimed book is turned into a lousy romantic comedy starring TomKat. Natascha McElhone plays Karen, Hank’s longtime girlfriend, who dumps him when he proves to have raging hormones coupled with a maturity level somewhere below that of their 12-year-old daughter, Becca (Madeleine Martin). Madeline Zima is Mia, who’s out to sucker punch Hank in a way he never imagined. And Evan Handler is the sanctimonious if a tad envious Charlie, who wants his best friend to keep his pants on for once. Or else stop tempting Charlie with all that talk.

headline: Republicans’ Debated YouTube Forum Is Back On
text: It looks as if the Republican presidential candidates, at least most of them, will be participating in a YouTube debate after all. The forum is now set for Nov. 28, the Wednesday after Thanksgiving.

headline: Bargain tips for Paris shows and spectacles
text: Comedie Republique

headline: Q & A With Karl Rove and the White House Press Corps
text: Following is a transcript released by the White House of a question-and-answer session today between Karl Rove, the president's top political strategist, and members of the White House press corps. The question-and-answer session was conducted aboard Air Force One as President Bush flew to Waco, Tex., shortly after Mr. Rove announced that he would soon be leaving the White House.

headline: NBC May Take Oxygen, Reports Say
text: Oxygen, one of cable television’s last remaining independent channels, is shopping itself to NBC Universal, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The female-targeted channel has apparently been in talks to sell itself to General Electric‘s entertainment unit since June, the publication said.

headline: A New Call to Break Europe’s Phone Monopolies
text: After its success cutting mobile phone roaming fees, the European Commission is weighing a plan that could force some former phone monopolies in Europe to open their networks to greater competition.

headline: A Gannett Filing Sets Off Alarms and Rebuttals
text: Is Gannett in play?

headline: Hedge Funds Get Bitten by Pack Mentality
text: On Wall Street, there is a rage against the machine.

headline: Who Wants Dow Jones’s Other Titles?
text: Gannett, Lee Enterprises, and GateHouse Media may be the most likely buyers for the 22 local newspapers News Corporation‘s chairman Rupert Murdoch plans to sell after completing his purchase of Dow Jones this year, according to analysts.

headline: Consumer Groups Line Up Against Wild Oats Deal
text: Three consumer groups are siding with antitrust regulators in opposing Whole Foods Market‘s bid to buy a rival natural and organic food retailer, saying it would lead to higher food prices.

headline: Former Comverse C.E.O. Continues to Fight Extradition
text: Jacob Alexander, the former chief executive of Comverse Technology, who faces charges in the United States of options fraud and is regarded as a fugitive, has taken his latest step to fight extradition from Namibia to New York.

headline: Midwest to Consider Takeover Offer from TPG
text: Midwest Air Group said it would pursue a takeover offer, likely to exceed $400 million, from United States private equity firm TPG, which includes a passive investment from Northwest Airlines, the fifth-largest airline in the nation.

headline: German Prosecutors Investigate IKB Officials
text: German state prosecutors on Friday said they were investigating whether officials at the state-controlled bank IKB may have committed breach of trust or violated German securities law. A spokesman for the prosecutors’ office would not identify targets of the investigation, but said they included “former officials” at the bank, which reported major losses related to subprime mortgages in the United States.

headline: Making Sense of the Markets
text: Easy credit in the American home-loan market has turned from a sales pitch to a curse, as the troubles with subprime mortgages have developed into a credit squeeze that is shaking the world’s markets and has made loans much harder to get. Will the latest upheaval pose a threat to continued economic growth — and your own financial security? Today I will be answering questions from readers.To ask a question or to see my answers, click here.

headline: Tesla Puts New Chief at the Wheel
text: Tesla Motors, the Silicon Valley electric-car startup, named Michael Marks, the former chief executive of Flextronics who joined Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in early 2006, to succeed Martin Eberhard as chief executive.

headline: Revisiting the Idea of the Public Law Firm
text: When the Blackstone Group went public earlier this year, the move represented a break with the tradition of private equity firms being, well, private. Now, some are wondering if another industry which has long eschewed the public markets may be ready to throw off the private mantle.

headline: All Hyped Up, VMWare Preps for I.P.O.
text: EMC‘s VMware software business plans to raise as much as $1.1 billion Monday in what may be the largest technology offering since Google in 2004, a signal that demand remains robust for computer-related companies.

headline: Rove Resigns
text: Karl Rove, the political adviser who masterminded President George W. Bush’s two winning presidential campaigns, is resigning, the White House confirmed today. Jim Rutenberg has this story.

headline: Hollinger Blocks Opposition to Sun-Times Deal
text: Hollinger, the company Conrad Black used to run his newspaper empire, blocked bondholders from threatening its control of Sun-Times Media Group. Judge Peter J. Walsh of United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., extended an order stopping bondholders from seizing the Sun-Times shares Hollinger uses to control the company, owner of the Chicago Sun-Times and other papers.

headline: Vinson & Elkins Buys Bankruptcy Boutique
text: Vinson & Elkins has acquired a New York bankruptcy boutique founded by former partners of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
text: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: Despite Turbulence, BCE Buyout Remains on Track
text: The investor group taking Canada’s BCE private in a buyout worth 34.8 billion Canadian dollars ($33 billion) remains committed to the terms of the transaction and will not reprice the deal, a spokeswoman told The Globe and Mail Friday.

headline: U.S. Investigation of BP Widens
text: BP, the British petroleum company, disclosed that investigators in the United States have widened their investigation into its commodity trading activities.

headline: Brazilian Buyout Firm Strikes Deal for Pride Assets
text: GP Investments of Brazil, the largest Latin American private equity firm, agreed to buy Houston-based Pride International‘s drilling rigs in the region for $1 billion in a bet on rising oil and natural gas demand.

headline: DP World Said to Consider $2 Billion I.P.O.
text: DP World, the world’s third-largest container port operator, may sell $2 billion of shares this year in an initial public offering and list the stock in Dubai, the Middle East Economic Digest reported.

headline: When Arbitrators Are Their Own Judges
text: Securities arbitration panels are supposed to offer a way to resolve disputes fairly, faster and more cheaply than the overtaxed court system. A three-member panel hears the case; one person represents the brokerage industry, and the other two are public representatives.

headline: Drilling for Oil, No Strings Attached
text: China has launched a large scale program of oil exploration in Chad, one of Africa's poorest countries.

headline: Accredited Sues Lone Star to Complete Deal
text: Accredited Home Lenders, the money-losing subprime mortgage lender, said on Monday it had sued the private equity firm Lone Star Funds, seeking to force it to complete the $400 million takeover of Accredited.

headline: Signs of Weakness in a Sector Known for Strength
text: Financial stocks, particularly those of major investment banks, have outperformed the broader stock market in recent years. But in 2007, those stocks have fallen under a cloud. In June, they began a sharp decline that anticipated and exceeded the stock market’s subsequent midsummer swoon.

headline: As the Market Wobbles, VMware Is Bullish on Its Offering This Week
text: Last Thursday, when stock markets around the world fell in a panicky swoon, VMware calmly nudged up the price range on in its initial public offering.

headline: Akzo Clinches ICI Deal for $16 Billion
text: Akzo Nobel, the world’s largest maker of paints and coatings, agreed to buy Imperial Chemical Industries, a British rival, for 8 billion pounds ($16 billion).

headline: Blackstone’s Profit Triples, But Challenges Continue
text: The Blackstone Group, posting quarterly earnings for the first time since its highly anticipated initial public offering in June, said Monday that its net income more than tripled in the second quarter from a year ago, as its private-equity and real-estate businesses showed strong gains.

headline: Sorting Through the Buyout Freezeout
text: With the buyout frenzy all but over and the credit markets in disarray, there is plenty of blame to go around — and some praise too. Which private equity firms have run headfirst into the crash? Which deals earned brickbats at the time they were signed, only to look wise now? And which buyouts now stand to be repriced?

headline: Blackstone Takes Stake in Stiefel Laboratories
text: A privately held pharmaceutical company, Stiefel Laboratories, said Thursday evening that the Blackstone Group had made a $500 million equity investment in the dermatology specialist in exchange for a minority interest.

headline: Rove’s August Surprise
text: Following are various strands of Karl Rove’s resignation, from the meaning of the “Mark of Rove” and initial reactions across the Web to his emotional appearance with the president today and various assessments of his legacy. Later in the day, he talked to reporters in a long session that we covered here.

headline: Ailing Goldman Fund to Get $3 Billion Infusion
text: A third Goldman Sachs hedge fund is feeling the pain of current market turbulence.

headline: 2008: Plotting a Post-Straw Poll Strategy
text: After his first place finish in this weekend’s G.O.P. straw poll in Iowa, Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney declared that he was “pleased as punch” and his campaign said the strong showing would give him a lift.

headline: Morning Buzz: Stalled East River Turbines, a Stronger Ethics Panel, School Translators and More
text: Six underwater turbines that were installed in the East River near Roosevelt Island and are supposed to turn the river’s currents into electricity have been shut down for repairs and a basic redesign, Anthony DePalma reports. It has been a rough eight months for Verdant Power, the company that owns the equipment. Days after the first two turbines were lowered into the water, the East River’s powerful currents sheared off the tips of several blades. New blades — made of a cast aluminum that theoretically would hold up better — replaced the ones that were broken and were also installed on the four other turbines.Together, the turbines are capable of producing about 1,000 kilowatt hours a day of clean electricity.But the East River tides have proved too formidable even for the stronger blades, putting excessive strain on the bolts that hold them to the turbine hubs, so all six turbines have been shut for repairs. A and a video accompany Mr. DePalma’s article; an earlier video, in January, examined how the turbines work.

headline: Deutsche Bank Hires Greenspan as Adviser
text: Deutsche Bank said it had hired Alan Greenspan, the former chairman of the United States Federal Reserve, as a consultant to provide “advice and insight” to the company’s corporate and investment banking unit and its clients. In May, Mr. Greenspan signed a consulting deal with Pimco, the giant bond management firm, which became his first client since leaving the Fed in early 2006.

headline: Humor on the G.O.P. Campaign Trail
text: Mike Huckabee, it turns out, is one of the funniest presidential contenders.

headline: Rove on Rove
text: Karl Rove tells Paul Gigot, the editorial page editor of The Wall Street Journal, that he’s resigning from the White House “effective Aug. 31.”Rove seems to think — or at least his comments to Gigot logically suggest that — his departure will right everything that is wrong with George W. Bush’s second term. Gigot writes:

headline: An Even Funnier iPhone Spoof Video
text: Maybe I was just tired and slap-happy, but I couldn’t stop laughing at this brilliant spoof.

headline: TXU Plans Breakup if Buyout Fails
text: Amid concern that deals will be repriced or broken thanks to the worsening credit markets, at least one buyout target said it is preparing for the worst.

headline: The Rove Legacy and 2008
text: In his column today, Adam Nagourney takes a look at the legacy of Karl Rove:

headline: Dutch Regulator Is Said to Approve Barclays’ ABN Bid
text: Barclays will obtain Dutch regulatory approval to buy ABN Amro, Reuters reported Monday citing unnamed sources. Yet the Dutch bank’s share price showed few signs of recovery from Friday, when its shares plummeted amid concern that either or both takeover offers could fall through because of the recent market decline.

headline: Rome with a view (from a double-decker bus)
text: The most difficult thing about taking Rome’s 110 Open Bus, the city-run double-decker tourist line, is finding one of the stops where you can actually get on it. I spent a frazzled half-hour with a friend visiting from Canada trying to figure out where she could hop on the bus along the route, which starts at Rome’s Termini train station, and meanders through Rome, near to most of the city’s major sites like the Colosseum, the Trevi Fountain, Piazza Navona, and St. Peter’s.

headline: A Modest Step Toward a Better-Designed Sidewalk Maze
text: Many of the sidewalks of New York have been turned into human Habitrails, mazelike tunnels of sidewalk scaffolding through which pedestrians must scuttle nervously. A boom in construction and renovation, mandatory facade inspections and the rise of unconventional outdoor advertising is the cause.

headline: The Skim
text: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

headline: Pulling Cerberus’s Chief Into the Spotlight
text: Stephen Feinberg, the head of Cerberus Capital Management, loathes publicity. At an annual meeting of the private equity firm’s investors, he told the crowd, “If anyone at Cerberus has his picture in the paper and a picture of his apartment, we will do more than fire that person. We will kill him.”

headline: Clip from "Yo Gabba Gabba"
text: A clip from Nickelodeon's new show, "Yo Gabba Gabba."

headline: Goldman Sachs: ‘This Is Not a Rescue’
text: Goldman Sachs may be pumping billions of dollars in one of its troubled hedge funds, but don’t call it a bailout. Or a rescue.

headline: Quick Bits: Power Marriage Edition
text: Ad Networks are Hot. Facebook is hot. So Facebook Ad Networks are boiling hot. VideoEgg is starting one. After all, online video is so last year. [TechCrunch]

headline: ‘The Natchril Rithm o the Workin Class’
text: Books I need to own, part 317:

headline: Left Something in a Cab? Good Luck Getting It Back.
text: Updated, Aug. 14 | Ever left a wallet, cellphone or PDA in a New York City taxicab?

headline: Thinking of Houses Like Cars
text: The article in today’s Times on Stockton’s housing woes includes a picture of a home for sale, where the broker proclaims, “Priced Below New!”

headline: A Saturday Primary?
text: New Hampshire is still pondering when to hold its presidential primary, but it looks as if one of the options is a Saturday, either Jan. 5 or Jan. 12.

headline: Actually, Winning Isn’t Everything
text: Karl Rove’s reputation rests, in part, on the “Cult of the Consultant” among Washington journalists, notes Joshua Green, a senior editor at The Atlantic, in his well-timed September cover story on The Architect, headlined “The Rove Presidency.” (Though Green’s opening sentence is less well-timed than his subject: “With more than a year left in the fading Bush presidency, Karl Rove’s worst days in the White House may still lie ahead of him.”)

headline: Clinton’s First TV Ad
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign will begin broadcasting its first television ad in Iowa tomorrow. The one-minute spot titled “Invisible” features Mrs. Clinton walking through farmland, talking with voters as well as several image-softening shots of her cuddling with babies and gently putting her arm on the shoulder of an older woman.

headline: Why Did Crime Fall in New York City?
text: Did the “broken windows” strategy and CompStat drive down crime in New York City in the 1990s?

headline: Fantasy Baseball: Who Would Buy the Yankees?
text: The baseball world was in heavy speculation mode a few weeks ago after a report that the YES Network, the Yankees’ home on cable television, was up for sale. The story hinted that the Yankees could be next on the auction block, although a report the next day in The New York Times indicated that it was just Goldman Sachs‘s YES stake, and not the whole business, that was up for sale.

headline: Ils Aiment Ron Paul
text: Republicans have not been known recently for their warmth toward the French. But at least one contender for the G.O.P. nomination has developed a dedicated, if small, fan base in Paris: Representative Ron Paul of Texas, an anti-Iraq war libertarian.

headline: Report Finds Queens Library No. 1 in Circulation
text: The Queens Library is the No. 1 library system in the United States by circulation, having loaned 20.2 million items in the 2006 fiscal year, according to a new report by the Public Library Association.

headline: Sidewalk Collapses; 2 Workers Rescued
text: More crumbling infrastructure?

headline: KKR Sees Challenges If Downturn Continues
text: Henry Kravis is staying the course — at least for now.

headline: Another Democrat for Spitzer — but She’s Not in Albany
text: Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, the Manhattan Democrat, has just put out a statement in line with the Spitzer administration’s message these days. She is arguing that the State Ethics Commission is the best venue for any further investigation of “choppergate” and that everyone else should get back to work.

headline: Remembering Brooke Astor
text: Updated, Aug. 14 | Brooke Astor, the doyenne of philanthropy and high society, died at 1:50 p.m. today at Holly Hill, her estate in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., according to Kenneth E. Warner, a lawyer for Anthony D. Marshall, her son. The cause of death was pneumonia, he said. Mrs. Astor was 105.An obituary by Marilyn Berger offers a full account of Mrs. Astor’s life.

headline: Honoring Brooklyn’s Role in Ending Slavery
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg today announced the appointment of a six-member Commemoration Panel that is to come up with a plan to honor Brooklyn’s role in the 19th century abolitionist movement.The panel, which will work with the city and the Downtown Brooklyn Partnership, is to help find and select a cultural organization to manage the project, for which the city is planning to spend $2 million over the three years.

headline: I Wanna Talk About Me
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his Aug. 13 column, “It’s All About Them.”

headline: EBay’s Swarm Strategy to Take on Craigslist
text: If you can’t beat them, surround them.

headline: Blogtalk: Voting Machines, Deadly Cars, Politics and More
text: What we’re reading on the local blogs…

headline: Karl Rove Plans to Resign
text: Karl Rove is stepping down as President Bush's chief strategist, but his effect on the 2008 campaign is still felt, Adam Nagourney reports.

headline: Rubes and Racehorses
text: I went up to Saratoga Springs the other day, escaping any more office discussion about Fashion Week, which people keep saying is “just around the corner” with an eagerness that robs the best last days of summer. Here is some of the fashion I saw at the race track on Saturday: straw porkpie hats on old gentlemen, orchid-pink lipstick on old ladies, blue-striped shirts and Hermès horse ties, blue blazers, strings of pearls, floral sundresses, and stiffened tulle hats with petal brims that had a bridal cast. My favorite look was a generously cut seersucker suit worn with a bow tie and white Michael Jordan sneakers by a man who appeared to be 90.

headline: A Recipe for Hamptons Controversy: Piping Plovers, Piping Hot?
text: Like the horrendous traffic and the celebrity watching, the piping plover issue has become a perennial hot topic in the Hamptons.

headline: How Is Your Bridge Holding Up? Click Here.
text: Ford Fessenden of The Times has analyzed federal highway records on the bridges in the New York metropolitan region and created an interactive tool that allows readers to search the bridges of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut and examine the conditions of their deck, superstructure and substructure.

headline: Campaign Cash: An Early Caucus Dividend
text: What if there were a 2008 presidential nominating caucus held this year? In addition to possibly testing the patience of the electorate, such an event could open a loophole in the 1974 campaign finance laws, potentially allowing for a flood of new donations to the campaigns.

headline: The T-Shirt Groups
text: DES MOINES — They show up in red T-shirts, blue T-shirts and then, there is the “Cookie Mom” who is associated with the yellow T-shirt crowd. While most political rallies here in Iowa consist of politicians preaching to the crowds, a number of activist groups are turning that political model on its head. Folks in the red T-Shirts are from a group called Divided We Fail, which is part of the American Association of Retired Persons and they show up candidate gatherings to pose questions and influence the current crop of Presidential candiates.

headline: Blackstone’s $1.1 Billion Real Estate Problem
text: Observers parsing the Blackstone Group‘s first earnings announcement as a public company had a lot to chew on, including its acknowledgment that the buyout boom has gone on hold. But according to Breakingviews’ Lauren Silva, the private equity giant may have a bigger problem on its hands.

headline: Ask the New York Dog Experts
text: New York dogs have New York concerns: dog-run politics, interviewing with co-op boards and keeping up with the latest urban fashions. This week, two experts on urban dogs from the Animal Haven Shelter, Sanctuary and Adoption Center, with locations in SoHo, Flushing, Queens, and South Kortright, N.Y., are taking questions from readers.

headline: Measuring Shareholder Anger at Yahoo
text: The recent history of Yahoo’s troubles is well-known: the company lost the search race to Google; it missed out on key trends — social networking, for instance — and potential acquisitions — Facebook, most notably; its performance disappointed; some shareholders grew restless and focused their anger on a board that gave former CEO Terry Semel one of the richest pay packages in Corporate America.

headline: Straw Poll No-Shows Coming to Iowa
text: Fred D. Thompson has yet to formally announce his presidential candidacy. But his first campaign trip to Iowa this week should resolve questions — if any remain — about his intentions.

headline: For Rove, Last Disrespects
text: The good must have been interred with Karl Rove’s resignation letter, because there’s not a lot of love for him in blogland today, nor much respect for his reputation as a political mastermind.

headline: Dodd Stops at Iowa State Fair
text: DES MOINES -– When Senator Christopher J. Dodd finished speaking at the Iowa State Fair this afternoon, he did something that is quite ordinary for presidential candidates here. He signed autographs. He posed for a few pictures. Then, he took questions from an Australian broadcaster.

headline: Brooke Astor: A Long and Storied Life
text: Brooke Astor, New York's most famous doyenne of philanthropy and society, died at 105.

headline: Rove’s Interview Aboard Air Force One
text: During an Air Force One flight to Texas, Karl Rove engaged reporters in an altogether jolly good question and answer session, trading jokes, talking politics and only going off the record a handful of times, once to answer a question on his wife’s feelings on sticking it out until January 2009.

headline: Action on a Very Small Scale
text: It is not much of a leap from thinking about how the average person might begin to comprehend the potential of nanotechnology to thinking that turning it all into a computer game might help. After all, when you are talking about manipulating matter at its most fundamental atomic and molecular levels, there is no shortage of challenges to overcome — the basic element in any game.

headline: Sebastien Bourdais Sent to the Slaughterhouse
text: There seems to be a strong inverse relationship between the niceness of the Champ Car champion and his odds for success in Formula One. Those who’ve ranked high on the rootability meter – Cristiano da Matta and Alex Zanardi – fared poorly in Formula One. Those who’ve won – Juan Pablo Montoya and Jacques Villeneuve – were whiny little jerks.

headline: Children at Play
text: Do you agree with Howard P. Chudacoff, who suggests in his new book, “Children at Play: An American History,” that organized activities, overscheduling and excessive amounts of homework are crowding out free time and constricting children’s imaginations and social skills?

headline: Adams, Van Wely Lead Staunton Memorial
text: Michael Adams of England, the top seed, and Loek Van Wely of the Netherlands, the second seed, are tied for first place at the Fifth Howard Staunton Memorial Tournament. Each has 4.5 points after six rounds with five remaining. Games from the tournament can be replayed at its official Web site.

headline: Newark Unites After Killings
text: A week after violent killings in Newark, Mayor Cory Booker hopes to transform community outrage into action for peace.

headline: America Weighs In on Vick as Trial Date Nears
text: As N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell waits for the report on the internal investigation into whether Atlanta Falcons quarterback Michael Vick violated the league’s personal conduct policy, it’s worth wondering what Vick’s future might hold.

headline: Even if Life Is a Computer Simulation . . .
text: . . . we still have some real questions to consider. Nick Bostrom’s argument that we could be living in a simulation, the topic of my Findings column, is a clever new twist on the old life-is-but-a-dream notions of Western philosophers (like the idealist George Berkeley), Eastern religions and science-fiction writers everywhere (cf. “The Matrix,” “The Truman Show,” and the “holodeck” in “Star Trek: The Next Generation”). A few of the questions:

headline: Buying Into Sin City
text: Sky Las Vegas

headline: Low-Cost Canal Living
text: Amsterdam's canals are home to hundreds who have elected to live on houseboats.

headline: A First Lady’s No-Show Is Seen as a No-No
text: PARIS, Aug. 13 — Three weeks ago, Cécilia Sarkozy, the glamorous wife of the French president, drew criticism here for her high-profile role in the freeing of jailed medical workers from Libya, a job some thought was best left to diplomats. Now Mrs. Sarkozy, a 49-year-old former model, is under scrutiny again, this time for ducking out of public appearances where a presidential spouse would be expected.

headline: Rove Legacy Laden With Protégés
text: Whatever history makes of Karl Rove’s role in the White House, his legacy as a political strategist can be measured in a presidential campaign that has already begun without him. A look at the roster of every Republican presidential candidate finds people who have worked with him, and they have brought some of his methods to this race.

headline: Reputation Isn’t Fixed. Sometimes You Hear It Grow.
text: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 12 — Search for Edward Elgar on YouTube, and you can find a link to a short 1931 film clip of Elgar at 74, three years before his death, conducting the London Symphony Orchestra in the stately central theme of the “Pomp and Circumstance” March No. 1. Known in England as “Land of Hope and Glory,” the tune is familiar to any American who has ever walked down the aisle at a graduation ceremony.

headline: Goldman and Investors to Put $3 Billion Into Fund
text: Goldman Sachs announced yesterday that it along with a group of investors would inject $3 billion into the firm’s Global Equity Opportunities Fund, a flailing quantitative hedge fund that lost about 30 percent of its value in a week.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10:30 P.M. (Oxygen) I AM MANDY MOORE One of the few bubblegum-pop singers cum actresses of her generation not to fizzle, the normally private Ms. Moore, above, allowed cameras to follow her as she promoted her new album, “Wild Hope” (released in June after a four-year hiatus) and prepared for a televised concert. This hourlong special is “a raw look at a six-month promotional run,” Ms. Moore wrote in a letter on the Oxygen Web site (oxygen.com), “with no sweetening.” This from a woman with a hit titled “Candy.”

headline: Surge in Consumer Prices Stirs China’s Concern About Overheated Economy
text: HONG KONG, Aug. 13 — Steeply rising food prices pushed inflation in China to 5.6 percent last month, the fastest pace in a decade, government figures showed Monday, prompting renewed concern about whether inflation would spread more widely in China and abroad.

headline: Potter Translator Escapes Lawsuit
text: The French publisher of the Harry Potter books will not sue the teenager who was arrested for publishing his own complete French translation of the final Potter book, though he could still be charged by French officials, the BBC reported. The decision not to sue for damages was made in agreement with J. K. Rowling, the author of the books, said the book’s French publisher, Gallimard, which will publish the French translation of “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows” on Oct. 26. “The aim was never financial; it only aimed to protect authors’ rights,” said a spokeswoman for the company. The 16-year-old, from the southern city of Aix-en-Provence, was arrested last week after he posted his unauthorized translation, which appeared within a few days of the book’s release in English on July 21. Gallimard said France’s anti-piracy squad found the translation as part of an inquiry into organized networks that post pirated book translations online. Investigators were reportedly struck by the “near-professional” quality of the boy’s work.

headline: Ants Tend to Gravitate to What They Do Best, Researchers Show
text: The remarkable ability of ants and other social insects to divide the work in a colony is a result of many factors: genes, age, social interactions, even size or other physical attributes.

headline: U.S. Seeks W.T.O. Ruling on Product Piracy in China
text: The Bush administration asked the World Trade Organization to rule in a complaint against China over piracy of copyrighted movies, music, software and books, escalating a dispute that has strained commercial relations between the two trading giants. After consultations failed to resolve differences over what the United States argues are weak Chinese laws to safeguard patents and copyrights, the Trade Representative’s office took the formal step of asking the trade organization, which is based in Geneva, to decree that China’s laws fall short of international agreements.

headline: Right There on the Tarmac, the Inmates Revolt
text: ON July 29, Continental Flight 1669, a 737-700 with about 120 passengers aboard, was bound for Newark from Caracas, Venezuela, when bad weather caused the plane to be diverted to Baltimore. It sat there for about five hours with passengers on board as food and water ran low and toilets became filthy.

headline: Two Co-Defendants Likely to Plead Guilty in Vick Case
text: Two more people indicted with Michael Vick in connection with a suspected dogfighting ring are expected to plead guilty in the case later this week, according to the Web site of the United States District Court in Richmond, Va.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Saturday about the Federal Reserve’s decision to inject capital into the financial system mischaracterized the central bank’s action. The Fed lent $19 billion against mortgage-backed securities, it did not purchase the securities. In a second action, the Fed lent $19 billion through reverse repurchase agreements.

headline: Gouged Tile May Be Left Unrepaired, NASA Says
text: A small but deep gouge in the underside of the space shuttle Endeavour does not pose the potential of catastrophe, the NASA official overseeing the mission said yesterday.

headline: In Reversal, Japan’s Central Bank Pulls Back $5 Billion
text: TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 14 (Dow Jones) — The Bank of Japan drained 600 billion yen ($5 billion) from the money supply Tuesday morning, after pumping money into the system for two days to ease fears of a liquidity crisis.

headline: Ex-Surgeon General’s Maverick Side Was Bound to Appear, Friends Say
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 — In his speeches, Dr. Richard H. Carmona, the former surgeon general, often tells audiences about receiving the advice that if he wanted a friend in Washington, he should get a dog.

headline: Producer Prices Rise 0.6 Percent in July
text: A jump in energy prices caused prices paid at the producer level to rise more than expected last month despite falling food prices and small price increases for many other goods.

headline: These Moors, This Realm of Evil, This Tortured Isle
text: The “moors murders”  the serial sex killings of five children and the burial of four on the high border country between Yorkshire and Lancashire  stirred horrified revulsion throughout 1960s Britain. The killers, Ian Brady and his lover and follower, Myra Hindley, were soon caught, tried and condemned to multiple life sentences.

headline: In Gaza, Even a Hospital Is a Battlefield
text: Like a lot of documentaries, “Gaza E.R.,” tonight on PBS’s “Wide Angle” series, makes a grim subject a little more palatable by occasionally tossing in some humanism via a likable character who provides perspective and comic relief. It is a mark of how messed up things are in the Middle East that this character, the one who’s supposed to give us hope, ends up delivering the most dismaying comment in the film.

headline: Our Lives, Controlled From Some Guy’s Couch
text: Until I talked to Nick Bostrom, a philosopher at Oxford University, it never occurred to me that our universe might be somebody else’s hobby. I hadn’t imagined that the omniscient, omnipotent creator of the heavens and earth could be an advanced version of a guy who spends his weekends building model railroads or overseeing video-game worlds like the Sims.

headline: 46 Million Nokia Cell Batteries Defective
text: Nokia, the world’s biggest cellphone maker, warned consumers yesterday that 46 million of its handsets contained defective batteries made in China that could in rare cases overheat and even dislodge during recharging.

headline: U.S. May Provide Billions to Mexico to Fight Drug Cartels
text: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 13  Mexico and the United States are holding intensive talks to develop a plan for the United States to provide billions of dollars to Mexico to support its fight against drug cartels, but the negotiations are not likely to produce an agreement before next week’s trilateral meeting with Canada, officials from both countries said.

headline: Letters
text: The Evolution of Prosperity

headline: Russia: Bomb Derails Train; Dozens Hurt
text: An explosion derailed 12 cars of a passenger train on the country’s busiest line, injuring dozens and suspending rail service between Moscow and St. Petersburg, Russian news agencies reported. A railway official said Tuesday that the tracks were ruptured by an “improvised explosive device,” Reuters reported. There was no indication of who may have planted the bomb. The derailment occurred late on Monday in the Novgorod region north of Moscow.

headline: The Winds of Europe, in Sounds of the 1800s
text: Long before the advent of the home stereo and the iPod, all the most refined 18th-century European potentates maintained a harmonie — typically a wind octet, consisting of paired oboes, clarinets, bassoons and French horns — for private entertainment and courtly functions. By the time the craze swept through Vienna near the end of the century, harmonie arrangements of the latest operas and ballets had become all the rage and a lucrative source of income for industrious composers and skillful bandsmen.

headline: Rights Group Accuses Somali Interim Rulers of War Crimes
text: RUMBEK, Sudan, Aug. 13  Human Rights Watch on Monday accused the transitional government in Somalia and the Ethiopian troops that helped bring it to power of war crimes in Somalia, saying that Ethiopian troops had shelled hospitals, that Somali officials had blocked aid convoys and that both forces had shown wanton indifference toward civilians.

headline: Carrot Sticks or French Fries?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: New Yorks New Club
text: The Bowery Presents, an independent concert promoter, is expected to announce today that a new rock club is coming to New York, and it’s a big one: Terminal 5, with room for 3,000, at 610 West 56th Street in Clinton. The first concert, featuring the National, is to take place on Oct. 11. Others to appear in the following months include M.I.A., Justice, the Decemberists, Ween and the Shins. In the space once occupied by Exit, a cavernous dance hall, the three-floor, 40,000-square-foot club is the largest concert space to open this year in the city. Next month the Bowery Presents will open the Music Hall of Williamsburg, in Brooklyn. Tickets for the Oct. 11 show at Terminal 5 will go on sale Friday through terminal5nyc.com.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts yesterday about grants awarded to arts organizations by New York City under a new formula misstated part of the name of a dance company receiving a grant. It is the Mark Morris Dance Group, not Company.

headline: VMware Shares Surge With I.P.O.
text: Shares in the software company VMware surged 75 percent in their first day of trading, closing at $51, or $22 above the initial offering price of $29.

headline: In Beijing’s Games, a Vision of the Future
text: “China Is Near.” This Italian film came out in 1967, using China as a symbol of the mysterious, the powerful, the future looming over everybody. Lately, that title has been looping across the movie screen of my mind.

headline: Left It in a Taxi? Good Luck Getting It Back, a Report Says
text: Assaf Rutenberg, who has a tendency to misplace cellphones, has lost four in New York taxis, and each one has been returned. Once, he said, a cabby drove to Midtown from Queens on his day off to deliver a missing Treo.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Saturday about Richmond M. Flowers, the Alabama attorney general who opposed the segregationist polices of Gov. George C. Wallace in the early 1960s, rendered incorrectly at one point the given name of a surviving son. As noted elsewhere in the obituary, he is Richmond Flowers Jr., not Robert.

headline: After Killings, Sense of Unity Surprises Newark
text: NEWARK, Aug. 13 — An unexpected thing has happened to this crime-weary city since three young friends were shot to death in a school playground nine days ago.

headline: Phil Rizzuto, Yankees Shortstop, Dies at 89
text: Phil Rizzuto, the sure-handed Hall of Fame Yankees shortstop nicknamed The Scooter, who extended his Yankee life as a popular and even beloved broadcaster, punctuating his game-calling with birthday wishes to fans and exclamations of “Holy cow!”, died late Monday night. He was 89.

headline: At Australia’s Bunny Fence, Variable Cloudiness Prompts Climate Study
text: A fence built to prevent rabbits from entering the Australian outback has unintentionally allowed scientists to study the effects of land use on regional climates.

headline: Cash-Stuffed Suitcase Splits Venezuela and Argentina
text: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 13 — A scandal involving a Venezuelan businessman who tried to sneak nearly $800,000 into this country has opened a sudden rift between Venezuela and Argentina just a week after the governments signed debt and energy deals.

headline: Boats With Stories to Tell, Rescued From Obscurity
text: BUFFALO, Aug. 13 — Todd Parmington was finishing a restoration of a guide boat built about 1888 that ferried campers to church services in the Adirondack Mountains when he got an e-mail message in May from a teacher in Vancouver, Wash., researching her family’s genealogy.

headline: Footnotes
text: Tanz im August, Germany’s biggest dance festival, opens in Berlin on Friday. It will include 20 different productions at sites throughout the city, as well as concerts and exhibitions. The festival opens with the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker and her company, Rosas, who will present their “Steve Reich Evening” on Friday and Saturday. The festival closes on Sept. 1. For information: tanzimaugust.de . ... Lincoln Center Theater will present “Cymbeline,” one of Shakespeare’s late romances, in a production directed by Mark Lamos. The cast of 26 will include Jonathan Cake, Michael Cerveris, John Cullum, Martha Plimpton and Phylicia Rashad. Previews begin Nov. 1; regular performances begin on Dec. 2 in the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

headline: CBS and Imus Settle Differences Over His Firing
text: The voice of Don Imus could resurface somewhere on the radio dial as soon as this fall, after he and CBS announced yesterday that they had settled the remaining differences surrounding his firing in April over remarks deemed insensitive to women and blacks.

headline: Wal-Mart Cuts Annual Forecast
text: Wal-Mart sneezed today. Will the economy catch a cold?

headline: Truck Stop Confidential
text: Last Saturday evening, I found myself at the counter of a truck stop diner in Caroline County, Va. I was sitting next to a weathered trucker whose accent betrayed an East Texas upbringing and a lifetime devoted to tobacco products. We quickly established that we were both celebrating birthdays. He was 68.

headline: Turkish Presidential Pick Sets Up Clash, Again
text: ISTANBUL, Aug. 14 — Turkey’s governing party has chosen Abdullah Gul, an economist and a practicing Muslim, as its candidate for president, officials said Monday, a move that places the party and its pious followers on a collision course with Turkey’s secular elite.

headline: Imperial Chemical Agrees to Takeover Offer
text: LONDON, Aug. 13 — Akzo Nobel, the world’s largest maker of paints and coatings, said Monday that it had agreed to buy Imperial Chemical Industries for £8 billion, or $16 billion, after raising its offer twice in two months.

headline: Capital Punishment (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Little Night Art as Visual Counterpoint for Mozart Festival
text: The real action at the Mostly Mozart Festival takes place inside Lincoln Center’s halls, so “Breath,” a multimedia work by Marc Downie and Paul Kaiser of the OpenEnded Group, could be seen as an accompaniment, not the main attraction.

headline: Defending Nuclear Pact, India Premier Faces Criticism
text: NEW DELHI, Aug. 13  Simmering distrust of the United States broke into full-throated protest on Monday in the Indian Parliament, as politicians from the right and left pounced on the government for its landmark nuclear accord with Washington, heckling the prime minister before he could defend it.

headline: Brooklyn: Man Killed in Elevator Accident
text: A 34-year-old Brooklyn man working in an industrial warehouse was crushed by a freight elevator last evening, the police said. The man, Arturo Gil, was declared dead shortly after 5 p.m. at the site, the Whale Industrial Terminal Building at 14B 53rd Street in Sunset Park, the police said. The elevator had become stuck between the second and third floors and Mr. Gil was trying to move it, according to relatives, who said his body was caught as the elevator began to move. The Buildings Department said that the accident was under investigation but the police said that no criminal charges were expected. The building, which is owned by Whale Realty LLC, had received an “unsatisfactory” rating during elevator inspections on July 10, according to Buildings Department records. It is unclear if the rating included the elevator where Mr. Gil was killed. Mr. Gil, who came here from Mexico and lived in Sunset Park, had been working in the United States for about a decade, his cousin Rodolfo Veroles said. His wife was also in New York, and Mr. Gil sent money to Mexico to support his relatives, including his children.

headline: Blackstone’s Profit Triples, but Challenges Continue
text: The Blackstone Group, the private equity firm, said yesterday that second-quarter net income more than tripled over the period a year ago, as it made its first earnings announcement as a public company.

headline: U.S. Money for Traffic Is Short of Bloomberg’s Plan
text: The United States Department of Transportation announced today that it had allocated $354 million to reduce traffic in New York City, giving a boost to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan but providing significantly less money than the mayor had sought as part of his sweeping proposal.

headline: Joe O’Donnell, 85, Dies; Long a Leading Photographer
text: Joe O’Donnell, who took some of the first disturbing pictures after the nuclear bombing of Japan and also captured lastingly famous scenes as a longtime White House photographer, died last Thursday in Nashville, where he made his home. He was 85.

headline: Citing Learning Slumps, Mayor Presents Plan for Low-Performing Middle Schools
text: Calling middle school students the hardest to reach, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that he would direct an additional $5 million to about 50 of the city’s lowest-performing middle schools and appoint a high-level administrator to devise professional development programs for middle school teachers and principals.

headline: Romney Breaks Down His Millions in Income Last Year
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 — The Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney filed a financial disclosure form on Monday showing that his family received over $8 million in income last year from his former firm Bain Capital, including some earned through a tax break Congressional committees are trying to end.

headline: TV Meets the Web. All Is Safe.
text: Just to get this out of the way: “i-Caught,” which had its premiere last week on ABC, is not a sequel to “I Spy.” It is, according to the voice-over at the beginning of the program, “what happens when Internet video comes together with television.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Sunday about how security and rebuilding efforts in Afghanistan have faltered referred incorrectly in some copies to the timing of a trip to Afghanistan by NATO representatives. The trip occurred two years after the fall of the Taliban, not one year. A front-page chart with the article gave an incorrect total in some copies for the amount spent on aid and reconstruction in Afghanistan by the United States from 2003 to 2007. It is $19 billion, not $22 billion.

headline: Behavior: Hostility May Raise Risk for Disease
text: Researchers studying 313 healthy Vietnam veterans have found that anger and hostility may increase the risk for cardiovascular disease, diabetes and high blood pressure.

headline: Asia: China: Motorola Receives Mobile Phone Order
text: Motorola said it had received orders worth $394 million to supply network equipment to the China Mobile Communications Corporation next year in the first half. Motorola will supply equipment based on technology known as global system mobile communications, the companies said. China Mobile will use the equipment to expand its network, which spans 16 Chinese provinces and municipalities.

headline: Emphasis on Victories Adds Risk to the Chase
text: Stock-car racing has not been the same since Nascar asked Bob Latford to devise a new points system in 1974. Besides being arcane — why is a 43rd-place finish worth 34 points? — Latford’s system rewards consistency more than it does excellence.

headline: Louisiana: Payments to Churches Challenged
text: The American Civil Liberties Union and the A.C.L.U. of Louisiana filed a lawsuit in federal court against the governor and the state treasurer regarding payments the state made to two churches. Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco signed an appropriations bill last month that gave $100,000 to Stonewall Baptist Church in Bossier City and $20,000 to Shreveport Christian Church. In a statement, the A.C.L.U. said the money was disbursed without “any oversight or competitive bidding process, and the bill offers no purpose or justification for the challenged earmarks.” The payments were discovered after recent changes in the state’s earmarking system led to each earmarked appropriation’s being listed individually.

headline: After Glacial Retreat, Regrowth May Feed on an Ancient Snack
text: Glaciers aren’t necessarily forever, as the world is learning in this era of climate change. While many scientists analyze the causes of glacial retreat, others study the effects. One issue is succession: how is newly exposed ground repopulated by plant and animal life?

headline: For Top General in Iraq, Role Is a Mixed Blessing
text: BAGHDAD — Gen. David H. Petraeus looked out from a Black Hawk helicopter at the vistas of Baghdad rushing by 150 feet below on a recent summer evening, pointing at bustling markets, amusement parks and soccer fields scattered through neighborhoods where miles of concrete barriers stood like sentinels against the threat of suicide bombers.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The “Popular Demand” listing in the Most Wanted chart in Business Day yesterday about Nicole Kidman movies misidentified the actor who starred opposite her in “Batman Forever.” It was Val Kilmer, not Michael Keaton.

headline: Sweatology
text: Like the finish line of a long road race, the Times Square subway platform one recent hot afternoon was a study in wet humanity, from drenched (a large woman in shorts and a skimpy, sweat-splotched top, flushed and vigorously fanning herself), to barely bedewed (an elderly man in a suit and tie calmly reading his paper).

headline: Admire the Quagmire!
text: Check out this video from 1994, in which Dick Cheney says we shouldn’t invade Iraq because we can create a quagmire that way. “A quagmire” — that’s what he says.

headline: Google Goes After Microsoft Again
text: Google has taken yet another step toward challenging Microsoft’s domination in word processing, spreadsheets and other productivity software.

headline: The Death Toll in Darfur
text: On Sunday, the Times ran an op-ed piece suggesting that the Save Darfur Coalition was exaggerating the scale of genocide in Darfur and that the number of deaths was perhaps 200,000 rather than 400,000. I happened to be hiking with my kids around Mt. Hood then, but I came back to find my email account burning up with indignant emails about the essay (written, I hasten to add, by an outsider).

headline: Peru: 21 Suspects Captured in Guerrilla Drug Trafficking
text: Government officials said they had captured 21 guerrillas suspected of belonging to a faction of the Shining Path, the Maoist-inspired movement that continues to operate in jungle areas rife with cocaine trafficking. More than 200 special forces carried out the raids in the country’s northeast and in Lima. The guerrillas are suspected of allegiance to a Shining Path commander who uses the name Comrade Artemio, believed to be the last member of the inner circle of Abimael Guzmán, the philosophy lecturer and guerrilla leader whose capture in 1992 led to marginalization of the insurgency.

headline: Martínez Says He May Need 3 More Starts Before Return
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Aug. 14  After his second rehabilitation start against a minor league team Tuesday, Pedro Martínez said he was pushing for a return to the Mets after his next start. But before leaving Tradition Field, he said it might take three more starts for him to be ready.

headline: Open Wallet, Insert Mouth
text: The sophisticated Olympic athletes who ache to unleash their inner activists in the run-up to Beijing 2008 may find themselves overwhelmed by menu choices:

headline: In Newark Murder, a Mixed Band of Men and Boys
text: NEWARK, Aug. 13 — The computer, its screen blank, sat on a table in the living room of Gloria Gomez’s apartment. Two blocks away, four promising young people had been shot, three fatally, and now Ms. Gomez’s two sons were being hunted by the authorities. She did not want to believe that her boys could have played a role in the killings, but she consented to turn on the computer, which one of her sons had brought into the house recently, while she was away visiting her native Nicaragua.

headline: A Nonconforming Eggplant
text: IN high school I had a friend whose mother was famous for eggplant salad. I’d never had it before, and I found the notion perplexing.

headline: Off the Hoof
text: Here are some sources for buffalo meat:

headline: Reader Responses
text: Here are excerpts from reader responses to David Leonhardt’s Aug. 15 column on the stock market:

headline: Funeral A-List: New Version of Mrs. Astor’s 400
text: Meet Mrs. Astor’s 400, vintage 2007.

headline: Taking Educated Guesses to Try to Beat the Odds
text: If nothing else, “Power of 10,” the new sort-of quiz show on CBS, is an opportunity to ponder the question of why Drew Carey has become America’s go-to game-show host.

headline: Politics Is the New Star of India’s Classrooms
text: NEW DELHI, Aug. 14 — Quietly, a great upheaval is taking place inside Indian high schools.

headline: For Kosher Emergencies, Manna From a Machine
text: WHERE else but New York could two guys who grew up together find a way to blend kosher food, cutting-edge cooking technology and hip-hop?

headline: Donaghy Pleads Guilty in N.B.A. Betting Case
