text: Tim Donaghy, a former National Basketball Association referee who was investigated for his connection to a suspected gambling ring that involved wagering on league games, surrendered to federal authorities today and pleaded guilty to two felony counts related to gambling.

headline: Transfer of Iraqi Projects (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Start of the Engines, Roar of the Crowd
text: The first episode of the five-part series “Nascar in Primetime” offers nothing new about Nascar, which raises questions about ABC News’s motivation in producing a documentary about a sport that its Disney cousins, ESPN and ABC Sports, began carrying last month under a contract worth $560 million a year.

headline: ACT Scores Rise Slightly
text: The average score on the ACT college admissions test crept up slightly this year to 21.2 out of a possible score of 36, up from 21.1 last year, ACT, the testing organization based in Iowa, reported. Twenty-three percent of the record 1.3 million 2007 graduates who took the ACT earned scores showing they were prepared to grapple with introductory college courses in four areas, up from 21 percent a year ago. In some states, including New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, California and Oregon, the percentage increase in the number of students taking the exam was in double digits, said Richard L. Ferguson, ACT’s chief executive.

headline: Trenton: Tracking Sex Offenders
text: The operators of the social networking Internet site Facebook have agreed to cooperate with a request from New Jersey officials to help identify convicted sex offenders who might be participating in online chats. The Web site’s owners issued a statement yesterday saying that the company would work with New Jersey’s attorney general, Anne Milgram, above, to identify sex offenders online. Last week, Ms. Milgram sent a letter to Facebook and 11 other meeting sites asking for their help finding sex offenders online. Although it is not illegal for sex offenders to visit such Web sites, Ms. Milgram wants to determine whether such sites are being used to find potential victims.Compiled by John Sullivan

headline: With Rove’s Departure, a New Era
text: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 14 — President Bush took the White House in 2001 with Texas swagger, and promptly filled the West Wing with fellow Texans who shared his ideology and determination to fundamentally change the way the capital worked.

headline: Can a Girl From Queens Catch the Glamour Bug?
text: What might happen if the fashion, beauty and home design industries joined together and banned from employment anyone whose use of the term “like” extended too far beyond its conjunctive function? I think we would all, like, be going about our business in loincloths and yurts.

headline: Mets Counting on DiFelice Behind the Plate
text: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14  Judging by the ice pack and wrap encircling catcher Ramón Castro’s midsection, it was reasonable to surmise that the Mets were praying that Mike DiFelice would make it through Tuesday night’s game intact.

headline: Soft-Spoken Bédard Has Others Talking
text: Érik Bédard never set out to become the hottest pitcher in the major leagues. In fact, his high school did not even have a baseball team. Bédard’s journey from a tiny Canadian town to Yankee Stadium, where he will start this afternoon for the Baltimore Orioles, happened by chance.

headline: A Dot-Org Stresses That It’s No Dot-Com
text: A LARGE marketer of financial services is seeking to become the master of a domain name.

headline: How New Arabic School Aroused Old Rivalries
text: When aides to Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein were presented last fall with a proposal for an Arabic language and culture school, they thought the idea could be controversial. But they said they could not resist the appeal of a school that seemed right for the times and that would be a piece of the school system’s mosaic of dual-language programs.

headline: UBS Warns of Lower Profits if Market Turmoil Persists
text: LONDON, Aug. 14 — Europe’s largest bank, UBS, on Tuesday painted the grimmest picture to date for future earnings in light of recent market jitters, raising concerns about the sustainability of profit growth in the investment banking sector.

headline: F.D.A. Limits Children’s Cold and Cough Medicines
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 — In the first major reassessment of the safety of children’s cough and cold medicine in decades, federal drug officials said that the drugs should never be given to children under the age of 2 unless approved by a doctor.

headline: Tony Wilson, Impresario and a Founder of Postpunk Label, Dies at 57
text: Tony Wilson, a British television reporter who became one of the most influential figures in postpunk music with his Factory Records label, died on Friday in Manchester, England. He was 57.

headline: Italy: Refugee Bodies Seen Off Coast
text: The Coast Guard reported spotting as many as 14 bodies floating in the sea south of Sicily, the latest victims of the annual and deadly summer migration from northern Africa to Europe in search of asylum and economic opportunities. It said it had recovered two of the bodies. It also said it had spotted a second boat with 28 passengers.

headline: To Toss the Shells Is to Discard Flavor
text: SHRIMP shells pose a problem for good cooks. Leaving them on unquestionably enhances any shrimp dish, because their flavor is about as strong as that of the meat. Peeling shrimp at the table, however delicious, is a messy and sometimes finger-burning job. Removing the shells beforehand is easy enough, but for someone who cares about taste, discarding them seems akin to a sin.

headline: New York to Get U.S. Traffic Aid, but With Catch
text: The federal government said on Tuesday that it would provide $354 million for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s broad plan to reduce traffic, but left it to the city to come up with more than $200 million needed for the most controversial part of the plan: a system to charge people who drive into Manhattan.

headline: Vacation Homes as Art Projects
text: To Susan Mead, a Dallas attorney, old houses are canvases and she is the painter. Even the most dilapidated structures become striking compositions, three-dimensional landscapes for Ms. Mead’s blend of contemporary and antique furnishings, folk art and fine art — and always with an architectural twist.

headline: Prejudice and Politics: Sacco, Vanzetti and Fear
text: Precisely 80 years on, the Sacco-Vanzetti case still resonates like a mournful chord. Almost instantly elevated to the status of myth, the trial and execution of the anarchists Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti remains one of the blackest pages in the American national story, a cautionary tale of lethal passions fueled by political fear and ethnic prejudice.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Aug. 3 about Mike Nugent, the Jets’ place-kicker, incorrectly described an achievement. In 2006, he had the most accurate season in team history, not the most accurate season since Pat Leahy in 1990.

headline: With Jets' Jones Out, Houston Enters the Conversation
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 14 — When Jets tailback Thomas Jones crumpled to the turf with an injury to his right calf muscle during practice Sunday, some of his teammates said they thought of Cedric Houston, the running back who abruptly left the team on the eve of training camp.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,681 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: U.S. Set to Declare Iran Guards Terrorists
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 — The Bush administration is preparing to declare that Iran’s Revolutionary Guard Corps is a foreign terrorist organization, senior administration officials said Tuesday.

headline: Reading Lincoln’s Face
text: Recently, two researchers performed a 3-dimensional laser surface scan of two life masks of Abraham Lincoln, one made in 1860, the other in 1865. The study confirms what we have all noticed without noticing it. There was an extreme asymmetry in Lincoln’s face, characteristic of a condition called cranial facial microsomia. The right side of his face was much larger than the left, and the difference is most visible in the different sizes of his eye sockets. This may have been a developmental condition, or it may have been caused when, as a boy, he was kicked in the head by a horse.

headline: Seven Unions Ask Labor Board to Order Employers to Bargain
text: Seven labor unions asked the National Labor Relations Board yesterday to order employers to bargain with unions, even when the unions represent only a minority of employees.

headline: Hernández Goes Six Innings the Long Way
text: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14  In another lifetime, long before the elbow problems, shoulder surgery and occasional bouts of fatigue melded to create an image of his being a less-than-durable pitcher, Orlando Hernández routinely flouted baseball convention. Pitch counts? Who needs them. He was done when he said he was done.

headline: U.S.-Made Toys Benefit From China’s Troubles
text: Whittle Shortline Railroad, a company in Louisiana, Mo., that makes wooden trains and trucks, posted a banner on its Web site several weeks ago: “100 percent kid-safe,” it read, “with lead-free paints.” Mike Whitworth, the company’s owner, said the recent recalls of Chinese-made toys found to contain lead in their paint has been good for his business. Very good.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the What’s Online column in Business Day on Saturday about the venture capitalist Guy Kawasaki referred incorrectly to the first person at Apple Computer to be called “evangelist” — an executive whose job was to persuade software developers to write programs for the Macintosh. It was Mike Boich, not Mr. Kawasaki.

headline: U.S. Weighing Terrorist Label for Iran Guards
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 — The Bush administration is preparing to declare that Iran’s Revolutionary Guard Corps is a foreign terrorist organization, senior administration officials said Tuesday.

headline: Donaghy Set to Plead Guilty in Betting Case
text: Tim Donaghy, the former N.B.A. referee accused of betting on games he officiated, is expected to plead guilty in federal court in Brooklyn today, according to a person with direct knowledge of the case who spoke on condition of anonymity because the plea had not yet been entered.

headline: Tikhon Khrennikov, Prolific Soviet Composer, Dies at 94
text: Tikhon Khrennikov, a prolific Russian composer and pianist best known in the West as an official Soviet antagonist of Shostakovich and Prokofiev, died yesterday in Moscow. He was 94.

headline: As Smith Takes Flight, Giants Take Notice
text: ALBANY, Aug. 14 — A scene from Tuesday’s morning practice illustrated why the Giants are excited about Steve Smith.

headline: Full Speed Ahead, to the Beat of Schubert and Jobim
text: Smuin Ballet breezed into town on Monday night with a program, to be performed through Saturday at the Joyce Theater, that had a sad extra significance. Michael Smuin, who founded the troupe in 1994, died in April. But in “Schubert Scherzo,” his last piece and the Joyce program opener, Mr. Smuin left a clear statement of his legacy, at its best and worst.

headline: What You Get for... $650,000
text: Philadelphia

headline: Police Captain on Trial in ’06 Assault on Officer
text: In September 2006 a police captain in a jealous rage dragged an officer under his command by her hair into a car on a Greenwich Village street and beat her savagely, a prosecutor told a Manhattan jury yesterday.

headline: In Italy, Creating Worlds Takes Precision, Yes, and Politics
text: IMPRUNETA, Italy  It has been said that wars are a way of teaching geography. And maps are caught up in the strife.

headline: U.S. Keeper in England Shuts Out Pain
text: Marcus Hahnemann has had a relatively good summer for a player who had more than a dozen pins and two plates inserted into his right hand during an operation.

headline: Trading Is Halted in Shares of Mortgage Lender
text: Trading was halted yesterday in shares of the lender Thornburg Mortgage Asset after they plunged 47 percent, the most since their 1993 initial public offering. Earlier, five brokerage firms downgraded the stock and Moody’s Investors Service cut its debt rating amid turmoil in the home loan market.

headline: Blurring Time and Place in Venice
text: VENICE — You know you’ve wandered into an unusual exhibition when what first appears to be a standing lead sculpture by Anselm Kiefer — an angel’s wing, perhaps, or possibly a shield? — turns out to be something else entirely: an actual elephant’s ear.

headline: 4 Truck Bombs Kill 190 in Kurdish Area of Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 14  Four truck bombs killed at least 190 people on Tuesday in two villages in a Kurdish-speaking area near the Syrian border, destroying houses and sending hundreds of the wounded to at least six hospitals as far as 150 miles away, the Iraqi authorities said.

headline: New Thai Literary Puzzler Raises Questions, and Ire
text: BANGKOK, Aug. 14 — “Thaksin: Where Are You?”

headline: Mr. Bush’s Chance to Help Congress
text: It’s hard to imagine that President Bush would dare to veto the groundbreaking lobbying reform bill that Congress passed this month when bipartisan majorities finally faced up to voters’ plummeting opinion of Capitol Hill ethics. Yet, the White House is citing “serious concerns” and raising red-herring complaints about a measure that provides at least a start at reining in the disgraceful quid-pro-quo culture of lawmakers and lobbyists.

headline: Rizzuto Was the Yankees’ Chatty Talisman
text: The limousine was idling in a nearby parking lot. If Phil Rizzuto had known the location, he would have scrammed.

headline: Israel: Netanyahu Keeps Control of Party
text: Benjamin Netanyahu easily won re-election as the leader of the rightist Likud Party. His main challenger for the post was a religious ultranationalist, Moshe Feiglin. “The internal battle ended tonight, and tomorrow we will focus our efforts on bringing Israel a new leadership,” Mr. Netanyahu said in a victory speech. In opinion polls, Mr. Netanyahu, a former prime minister, has emerged as the front-runner to reclaim the office.

headline: Dow Off 167 Points in a Late Swoon
text: Stocks suffered another late swoon today on Wall Street as the turmoil in the American mortgage market continued to cast a pall.

headline: They’ve Just Got to Get a Message to You
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 — As a teenage rock fan, all Dennis Vorreyer really expected of the Lollapalooza music festival in Chicago two weekends ago was the chance to see his favorite bands perform live.

headline: Bomb Derailed Passenger Train in Russia, Officials Say
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 14 — A bomb set along railroad tracks exploded and derailed a passenger train Monday night between Moscow and St. Petersburg, wounding scores of passengers and shutting down service on one of Russia’s busiest rail lines.

headline: Corrections
text: Editors' Note

headline: Gaza: Israeli Strikes Kill 6
text: At least four Palestinian militants and two civilians were killed by Israeli air and ground forces in southern Gaza, according to Hamas, Islamic Jihad and Palestinian medical officials. An Israeli Army spokeswoman said the strikes were to “neutralize terrorist threats.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the revival of the Fiat 500 misstated the horsepower of the Citroën 2CV, a French economy car that was made from 1948 to 1990. Engines in the earliest models had nine horsepower, not two.

headline: China Announces Media Crackdown
text: HONG KONG, Aug. 15 — China today disclosed a crackdown on “false news reports, unauthorized publications and bogus journalists,” two months before the opening of the politically sensitive Communist Party congress, which is held once every five years.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Saturday Interview column in Business Day, with Julia A. Stewart, chairwoman and chief executive of the IHOP Corporation, referred imprecisely to the premium IHOP will pay to shareholders of Applebee’s International in its $1.9 billion acquisition for the company. The premium is 5.2 percent over Applebee’s share price in February at the time the company announced that it was considering selling itself — not 20 percent, which refers to the premium over Applebee’s share price late last year, before an activist investor started pressing the company to improve its stock performance.

headline: Canada: Defense Minister Loses Job
text: Defense Minister Gordon O’Connor, who has come under criticism over the country’s mission in Afghanistan and the treatment of Afghan detainees, was replaced in a cabinet reshuffle. Mr. O’Connor is now minister of revenue, a relatively minor position. Prime Minister Stephen Harper moved Peter MacKay, the foreign minister, to the defense post. He was in turn replaced by Maxime Bernier, the industry minister.

headline: Beyond the Numbers, the Horror That Is Darfur (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: 2 Guilty Pleas Expected in Insider Case
text: A former Morgan Stanley finance vice president and her husband, a former hedge fund analyst at ING Investment Management, are expected to plead guilty to insider-trading charges, according to a prosecutor.

headline: Gauging Beijing
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Back of the Envelope chart in Street Scene on Friday, about the value and number of mergers and acquisitions this year, referred incorrectly to the deals covered by the data. They were private-equity-related deals in the United States, not all merger and acquisitions.

headline: When Opportunity Knocks and Knocks
text: It was an extraordinary appeal for help.

headline: John Expires, Tony Returns
text: “John From Cincinnati,” the much-anticipated surfer drama and HBO’s would-be successor to the critical and commercial success of “The Sopranos,” was canceled yesterday, the day after its first-season finale, Reuters reported. The show, created by David Milch (“Deadwood”) and the author Kem Nunn, never clicked with critics or viewers despite extensive marketing and the participation of actors like Rebecca De Mornay, Bruce Greenwood and Austin Nichols, above. But hope for television executives is always only a hit away, and HBO also announced that James Gandolfini would follow up his role as Tony Soprano by playing the real-life corporate sports scout Sonny Vaccaro in an HBO film. The movie, called “ABCD Camp,” is a drama about the youth basketball camp established by Mr. Vaccaro, the man who got Michael Jordan to sign the first million-dollar shoe deal at Nike, The Associated Press reported. The film will not be Mr. Gandolfini’s first post-“Sopranos” appearance on HBO. As an executive producer of the documentary “Alive Day Memories: Home From Iraq,” which has its premiere on Sept. 9, he interviewed American armed forces veterans.

headline: A Bonus for Congestion Pricing
text: The federal government has attached some very smart conditions to the $350 million grant it awarded New York City yesterday as part of a broader $1.2 billion program to help cities relieve traffic congestion.

headline: The Times’s First Home Is Being Torn Down
text: After enduring a century and a half of change in Lower Manhattan, decrepit and anonymous, the birthplace of The New York Times is now being torn down, brick by brick.

headline: Letters
text: On Raw Milk and Choice

headline: Elevator Violations Draw Fine of $50,000
text: A New York City housing court fined a landlord $50,000 for serious elevator violations on Monday, one of the largest such civil penalties to date, a Department of Buildings spokeswoman said yesterday.

text: NEW PLACES

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
text: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading yesterday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: In Magazine Article, Giuliani Details His Policy on Iran
text: Laying out his views on foreign policy, Rudolph W. Giuliani, one of the leading candidates for the Republican presidential nomination, said he would be open to negotiations with Iran but would not rule out destroying its nuclear facilities as a last resort.

headline: UBS Paints Grim Picture for Future Earnings
text: LONDON, Aug. 14 — Europe’s largest bank, UBS, on Tuesday painted the grimmest picture to date for future earnings in light of recent market jitters, raising concerns about the sustainability of profit growth in the investment banking sector.

headline: In the Fruit Belt, Selling Summer Off the Truck
text: BENTON HARBOR, Mich.

headline: Jeter Remembers Rizzuto as a Positive Influence
text: Derek Jeter does not collect autographs and is not sentimental by nature. But he has always maintained that a certain signed photograph in his home office carries special significance. It is a picture of Jeter with Phil Rizzuto, his forefather as a champion Yankees shortstop and his unabashed fan.

headline: Deer Park: Accused of Sex Abuse
text: A Deer Park man was charged yesterday with robbing and sexually abusing a cabdriver at knifepoint, the Suffolk County police said. A driver for Comfort Taxi was at the Deer Park railroad station about 4 a.m. yesterday when a man got in the cab and held a knife to her throat, the police said. The man stole money from the driver and ordered her to drive away from the station, the police said. At Dunton Avenue and South Second Street, a second man ran up and entered the cab, and “subjected the victim to unlawful sexual contact,” the police said. The driver leapt out after the men ordered her to turn around in a parking lot, causing the cab to crash into a parked car, the police said. A Suffolk County police officer arrested one suspect, Robert King, 20, walking on Commack Road after the crash. He has been charged with first-degree robbery and sexual abuse, the police said.

headline: Padilla Jury to Start Deliberations
text: MIAMI, Aug. 14  Jurors in the terrorism trial of Jose Padilla will begin deliberations on Wednesday, after hearing Mr. Padilla’s chief public defender say the government failed to prove Mr. Padilla is a would-be terrorist.

headline: Rescuers Press New Efforts to Find Trapped Miners
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 14 — With engines groaning, the “continuous mining” machine chewed through the seemingly endless layers of coal and debris that separate rescue workers from six miners trapped nine days ago deep within the Crandall Canyon Mine.

headline: In a Finnish Archipelago, Memories as Sharp as a Pike’s Teeth
text: EKENAS, Finland — Jack Chivers spotted the lightning first. We stood on a pier on a bright summer Finnish night, looking down an archipelago extending into the Baltic Sea.

headline: China: Profit at Brokerage Firm Soars
text: The Citic Securities Company, the Asian brokerage firm, said first-half profit rose more than fivefold as a surging Chinese stock market fueled share trading and underwriting fees. Net income rose to 4.2 billion yuan ($554 million), from last year’s 775.8 million yuan, Citic said. Brokerage commissions at Citic, which is based in Beijing, rose sixfold, to 6.6 billion yuan, in the first half. Citic Securities made 473 million yuan, or 4.4 percent of its revenue, from arranging share sales in the first half. Its investment banking division is the leading underwriter this year, with 20.1 percent of the market. Citic and its units have 165 branches and more than 5,000 employees.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Question of Sons’ Choices Dogs Romney Campaign
text: Mitt Romney has been asked before on the campaign trail if his sons have served in the military, and he usually has dispatched the question easily enough.

headline: Gibbs Racing Strengthens Lineup by Adding Kyle Busch
text: HUNTERSVILLE, N.C., Aug. 14  Joe Gibbs Racing, with three championships this decade and two of the top drivers in Nascar under contract, is about to become even stronger.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Thursday about Frank E. Rosenfelt, a former top executive of MGM, rendered incorrectly a line from the MGM movie “Network,” which disappointed him when it failed to win the Academy Award for best picture in 1976. It is “I’m as mad as hell, and I’m not going to take this anymore,” not “I’m mad as hell, and I’m not going to take it anymore.”

headline: On Night Full of Memories, a Yankees Loss to Forget
text: If Phil Rizzuto would have been broadcasting last night’s game at Yankee Stadium, his scorecard would have been covered with notations of W.W., his shorthand for wasn’t watching.

text: Wal-Mart and Home Depot sneezed yesterday. Will the economy catch a cold?

text: ON fancy china and in hot dog rolls and burger buns, buffalo is finally coming of age as an alternative red meat. But it almost didn’t happen.

headline: Phil Rizzuto, Yankees Shortstop, Dies at 89
text: Phil Rizzuto, the sure-handed Hall of Fame Yankees shortstop nicknamed the Scooter who extended his Yankee life as a popular, even beloved, broadcaster, punctuating his game calls with birthday wishes to fans and exclamations of “Holy cow!” died Monday night. He was 89.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about the investment strategy of Macquarie Bank of Australia misstated its recent profit growth. The bank’s profit was up 60 percent in the fiscal year 2007, which ended in March, over the previous fiscal year — not in the first quarter of 2007.

headline: White Police Chief Could Upset a Balance in Newark
text: NEWARK, Aug. 14 — It was the kind of feel-good news conference that elected officials relish: Mayor Cory A. Booker told a room full of rapt reporters about the creation of new law enforcement posts, plans for dozens of surveillance cameras in the most crime-soaked neighborhoods and millions of dollars in private largess to help pay for what officials say will be the most high-tech gunshot detection system in the country.

headline: Killer of 3 Women in Buffalo Area Is Given a Life Term
text: BUFFALO, Aug. 14  A man who killed three women and told prosecutors that he had raped at least a dozen more over the past quarter-century was sentenced to life in prison on Tuesday.

PLAYER With his controversial transfer finally behind him, the Argentine striker Carlos Tévez is set to make his debut for Manchester United in today’s English Premier League match at Portsmouth. Tévez, 23, is likely to start in place of Wayne Rooney, 21, who broke his left foot in Sunday’s season opener against Reading.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A Sports of The Times column on Monday, about Tiger Woods’s ability to hold a lead in the final round of major golf tournaments, misstated his career victory total on the PGA Tour. It is 59, not 52.

headline: Bronx: Garbage Takes the Train
text: Garbage is now being shipped out of the Bronx entirely by rail instead of by trucks, part of a city plan to reduce the number of trucks traveling on the streets, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The Bronx is the second borough to use trains to ship the garbage; Staten Island began shipping household waste in May after the city reactivated the Staten Island Railroad. The Bronx ships about 2,100 tons of garbage each day for disposal outside the city, the mayor said.

headline: Jets Are Near Deal With First-Round Pick
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 14  The holdout of cornerback Darrelle Revis, the Jets’ first-round draft pick, reached 19 days Tuesday, and it is likely to end there.

headline: Those Empty Plastic Bottles (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Getty Research Institutehas New Leader
text: The Getty Trust in Los Angeles announced that Thomas W. Gaehtgens, below, one of Germany’s foremost experts on French and Dutch art and the founder of the German Center for the History of Art in Paris, has been named the new director of the Getty Research Institute. The institute — one of four wings of the Getty Trust, along with the museum, conservation institute and foundation — has been without active leadership since last fall, when Thomas Crow left to teach at New York University’s Institute of Fine Arts. Formed from the estate of the oil tycoon J. Paul Getty, the research institute houses one of the world’s largest art and architecture libraries, with 800,000 volumes and collections of photos, maps, manuscripts and letters. It awards fellowships and organizes one-year study projects that gather scholars from around the world. Reached by phone yesterday in Berlin, Dr. Gaehtgens (pronounced GATE-ghens), 67, said that “as someone who has done research for more than 40 years, the Getty institute is like heaven; it’s scholarly arcadia.”

headline: Greatest Threat to Vick May Be Links to Gambling
text: The assertion that Atlanta Falcons quarterback Michael Vick gambled on dogfighting appears to be a more serious threat to his professional football career and freedom than the federal felony charges that he helped organize and run a dogfighting ring.

headline: AirTran Tops Offer by Rivals in Bidding for Midwest Air
text: AirTran Holdings raised its offer for the Midwest Air Group, a regional carrier, to $445 million yesterday, topping a $424 million bid from the buyout firm TPG Capital and Northwest Airlines.

headline: When ‘Christmas Concert’ Are Fighting Words
text: NEW HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 13  The temperature in the room was over 90, and the crowd was angry. The topic at this regular August meeting of the school board: what else?

headline: Off the Menu
text: Chef on the March

headline: Shuttle Gouge May Be Left Unrepaired
text: Experiments conducted last night at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston indicated that temperatures inside a gouge on the underside of the space shuttle Endeavour were not likely to become dangerously hot during reentry.

headline: Some Baby Bibs Said to Contain Levels of Lead
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 — Certain vinyl baby bibs sold at Toys “R” Us stores appear to be contaminated with lead, laboratory tests have shown, making the inexpensive bibs another example of a made-in-China product that may be a health hazard to children.

headline: Footnote
text: Roberto Alagna is replacing the tenor Rolando Villazón in the first two performances of the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of Gounod’s “Roméo et Juliette” next month, The Associated Press reported. The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra announced last week that Mr. Villazón had canceled an appearance on Sept. 15.

headline: Study Cites Danger of Homegrown Terrorism
text: The potential for homegrown terror, particularly among disaffected immigrants, was the focus of a new study by the New York Police Department. It concluded that there is some danger from unassimilated Muslims, but less so than in some European countries.

headline: If You Cant Stand the Heat
text: The “Hell’s Kitchen” cookery is now closed, and Rock Harper, below, is Las Vegas bound. Mr. Harper, a 30-year-old executive chef from Spotsylvania, Va., became the latest Gordon Ramsay protégé selected on the Fox competition. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the show’s third-season finale on Monday drew 9.8 million viewers at 9 p.m. and its best ratings ever among adults 18 to 49. Fox easily led the night over all with its highest Monday result of the summer, getting a boost at 8 from a special edition of “So You Think You Can Dance” (7.8 million). CBS finished second with comedy repeats and “CSI: Miami” at 10 (8.3 million). ABC ranked third, as its new series “Fat March” garnered 4.9 million viewers in the 9 p.m. hour. NBC was fourth with “Dateline” at 10 (6 million) and reruns of “Thank God You’re Here” at 8 (4 million) and “Heroes” at 9 (3.1 million).

headline: Hopes for Revving Up Retail in South Norwalk
text: NORWALK, Conn. — Urban revitalization usually takes years, if not decades, and so far efforts in South Norwalk have taken the longer path.

headline: Europe’s Bank Says Financial Turmoil Largely Over
text: FRANKFURT, Aug. 14 — The European Central Bank declared on Tuesday that recent financial market turmoil was largely over, a sign that the bank would probably proceed with a plan to increase borrowing costs in early September to curb inflation caused by a rising economy.

headline: Imported From Britain: Ideas to Improve Schools
text: WASHINGTON — During a decade in power in Britain, the government of Prime Minister Tony Blair made efforts to improve English schools, with some apparent successes. Because American public education faces similar challenges, like what to do with failing schools and how to recruit better teachers, some educators believe there is much to learn from England’s experience.

headline: Pavarotti to Leave Hospital Soon
text: Luciano Pavarotti, who was admitted to the hospital last week with a high fever, is expected to be released “imminently” and is in high spirits and ready to resume recording a new album, The Associated Press reported. Doctors have given the tenor the go-ahead to leave the hospital in Modena, Italy, where he has been undergoing tests since last Wednesday, his London-based manager, Terri Robson, said in an e-mail message to The Associated Press. The 71-year-old singer, who underwent surgery for pancreatic cancer last year, “is looking forward to getting back to teaching his young singing pupils as soon as he is out of hospital,” Ms. Robson said. Next month, she added, he “plans to get back into his Modena recording studio to resume work on his new album of sacred songs.”

headline: Chávez to Propose Removing His Term Limits
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 14 — President Hugo Chávez will unveil a project to change the Constitution on Wednesday that is expected to allow him to be re-elected indefinitely, a move that would enhance his authority to accelerate a socialist-inspired transformation of Venezuelan society.

headline: Another Radio Station for New York and Web
text: WFUV says it has been awarded a $500,000 grant from the New York State Music Fund to support the development of a second full-time radio station for listeners in their 20s and 30s, which will emphasize independently and locally produced music. The fund, a grant program of Rockefeller Philanthropy Advisors, helps make contemporary music of all genres more available and accessible to diverse audiences in New York State. The station, which will cost $1.2 million to create and is scheduled to make its debut in the fall of 2008, will be available via the Internet at wfuv.org and mobile streaming audio and, in the New York area, as a high-definition radio channel at 90.7 FM. Programming will include established and emerging indie rock, electronica, world, dance and other musical hybrids. “Our city boasts one of the greatest, most multicultural local music scenes in the world,” said Chuck Singleton, WFUV’s program director. “Acts like Antibalas, Forro in the Dark and the Hold Steady,” he added,  “have no problem selling out venues all over town, yet they presently don’t have a home on the radio in New York City.” WFUV is a noncommercial, listener-supported public radio station licensed to Fordham University.

headline: Washington’s Small Businesses Tap Into Green Power
text: WASHINGTON — With its decidedly ’50s-era menu — chili, cheese fries, shakes and half-smoke sausages, a distinctive regional specialty — Ben’s Chili Bowl, a restaurant near the Howard University campus, might not seem a likely business to be at the vanguard of Washington’s “green power” movement.

headline: In-Demand Surprise From Disney
text: Rachel Courtien, 12, and two friends were settling in to watch an episode of “Hannah Montana” on Disney Channel’s on-demand cable service Friday night when they were startled to see an entry for “High School Musical 2” on the menu of available offerings.

headline: A Campaign Undeclared, Not Invisible
text: Since former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee has not yet declared his presidential candidacy, he cannot advertise on television, on radio or in newspapers to promote his political ambitions.

headline: Manhattan: New Police Official
text: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced yesterday that he had named Wilbur L. Chapman, who spent nearly three decades in the New York Police Department, to direct the way the department trains its officers for the multiple jobs of conventional crime-fighting, counterterrorism and community relations. Mr. Chapman, who retired in 1989 as the department’s chief of patrol, served in the interim as New York City’s transportation commissioner and then as the chief of police in Bridgeport, Conn. He succeeds Charles D. De Rienzo, who retired last month, as the deputy commissioner for training and will earn $170,310 annually.

headline: The Cuts Are the Same, but the Calories Aren’t
text: THE tenderest buffalo cuts for grilling or roasting are the same as for beef: rib-eye, New York strip and tenderloin. Less tender cuts should be braised or stewed very slowly. Buffalo can be substituted for beef in any recipe.

headline: Britain: Inflation Rate Slips Below Target
text: The inflation rate in Britain unexpectedly fell last month below the Bank of England’s 2 percent target for the first time since March 2006, weakening the case for another interest rate increase. Consumer prices rose 1.9 percent in July from a year earlier, down from 2.4 percent in June, the Office for National Statistics said. Economists had expected inflation, which accelerated to a decade high of 3.1 percent in March, to slow to 2.3 percent last month. So-called core inflation, which excludes energy, food, tobacco and alcohol, slowed to 1.7 percent in July, down from a decade high of 2 percent in June.

headline: A Second Life for Classical Music
text: As part of an effort to make classical music more accessible, a British orchestra will be the first to perform a professional concert in the virtual online world of Second Life, Agence France-Presse reported. The Liverpool Philharmonic said audience members from across the world would “sit” in a three-dimensional virtual version of Liverpool’s Philharmonic Hall and listen live as the real orchestra plays. The concert on Sept. 14, featuring works by Rachmaninoff, Ravel and contemporary Liverpool composers, will be led by the orchestra’s principal conductor, Vasily Petrenko. Audience members will be able to interact with one another (via instant messaging) and to take a bathroom break. Tickets will be offered free in a competition on the orchestra’s Web site: liverpoolphil.com.

headline: Recipe: Pasta With Shrimp Ragù
text: Time: 40 minutes

headline: Lottery Numbers
India’s Internal Partition
text: Bangalore, India

headline: Remembering a Classic Investing Theory
text: More than 70 years ago, two Columbia professors named Benjamin Graham and David L. Dodd came up with a simple investing idea that remains more influential than perhaps any other. In the wake of the stock market crash in 1929, they urged investors to focus on hard facts — like a company’s past earnings and the value of its assets — rather than trying to guess what the future would bring. A company with strong profits and a relatively low stock price was probably undervalued, they said.

headline: Hastert Will Not Seek New Congressional Term
text: Representative J. Dennis Hastert, the Illinois Republican who became House speaker at a moment of crisis for his party, has decided not to seek re-election in 2008, opening a second Republican-held House seat in his home state.

headline: Another Sunny Summer of Worries at MTV High
text: With all the talk of how baby names switch around in America, it’s as pleasing as the bygone scent of suntan oil to discover tonight, on the premiere episode of “Newport Harbor: The Real Orange County” on MTV, that some things never change: Southern California parents still name their daughters Chrissy.

headline: Queens: Two Charged in Fatal Crash
text: Two drivers were charged yesterday after a crash on the Cross Island Parkway killed one man and injured seven other people, the police said. The crash occurred shortly after midnight near the Whitestone Expressway when a Chevrolet Blazer driven by Bolivar Comacho, 18, of Queens and a Honda Civic driven by Milton Flores, 20, of Queens, collided, the police said. John Reyes, 19, a passenger in Mr. Comacho’s vehicle, was killed and five other occupants of the Blazer and two of the Civic were injured, the police said. Both drivers were among the injured. Mr. Comacho was charged with manslaughter and reckless driving, and Mr. Flores with driving while intoxicated, the police said.

headline: Self-Described Pedophile Is Arrested Twice
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14  A self-described pedophile who had bragged publicly that he had never been arrested was taken into custody twice this week on the campus of the University of California, Los Angeles, the authorities said Tuesday.

headline: Still Vital, ‘On the Road’ Turns 50
text: The best-selling novels of 1957 included “Peyton Place” by Grace Metalious and “On the Road” by Jack Kerouac.

headline: China: Higher Wages and Prices Lift Retail Sales
text: China’s retail sales grew at the fastest rate in more than three years, helped by a stock market rally and higher wages and prices. Spending climbed 16.4 percent, to 699.8 billion yuan ($92 billion) in July from a year earlier, after gaining 16 percent in June, the National Bureau of Statistics said. The figures are not adjusted for inflation. The biggest increase in consumer prices in a decade contributed to the acceleration. Stock market gains and a 14 percent jump in urban incomes underpinned demand. “Inflation played an important role in gains for food sales,” said Paul Tang, chief economist at Bank of East Asia in Hong Kong. “But in other categories, there’s genuine continued gains, and overall growth is steady.”

headline: Lessons on Homosexuality Move Into the Classroom
text: ROCKVILLE, Md.

headline: An Orchard in a Bottle, at 80 Proof
text: PORTLAND, Ore.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10 P.M. (ABC) NASCAR IN PRIMETIME With roots in Prohibition-era bootlegging, stock-car racing used to be a sport known primarily for its appeal to Southern white men. But these days, women make up more than 40 percent of Nascar’s 75 million fans, and drivers like Juan Pablo Montoya attract a growing Hispanic audience. So for the first time, Nascar has opened up its doors, and hoods and pits, to a news organization. For six months ABC News was granted uncensored access to drivers, fans and officials, both on and off the racetrack. Among the speed demons waxing poetic about life in the very, very fast lane: Jimmie Johnson, above, Tony Stewart, David Stremme, Stanton Barrett, Mark Martin, Johnny Sauter, Jeff Burton, Marc Davis and Mr. Montoya.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption yesterday about a guilty plea by Oliver M. Thomas Jr., a New Orleans official, in a federal bribery case misstated his status on the city council. He is a former president of the council, not its current president.

headline: CBS and Imus Settle Differences Over His Firing
text: The voice of Don Imus could resurface somewhere on the radio dial as soon as this fall, after Mr. Imus and CBS announced that they had settled the remaining differences about his firing in April over remarks deemed insensitive to women and blacks.

headline: Staten Island: Arraigned in Death
text: Edwin Garcia, 30, the Staten Island man law enforcement officials say smashed the head of his companion’s 21-month-old daughter, was arraigned yesterday in Staten Island Criminal Court and charged with second-degree murder. Marlene Medina, 24, the mother of the girl, Hailey Gonzalez, was charged with second-degree manslaughter. Mr. Garcia and Ms. Medina pleaded not guilty. Neither of their lawyers returned calls for comment. Prosecutors said that “in an attempt to discipline” Hailey on Aug. 7, Mr. Garcia “slammed her onto a playpen containing hard toys causing severe trauma” to her head. Despite obvious signs of distress, the couple waited five hours to get medical attention, prosecutors said. Hailey died on Monday after being taken off life support.

headline: Immigrants and Hatred (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Calendar
text: Guided Beer Tasting

headline: Asian Stocks Down Sharply; European Markets Also Dip
text: SINGAPORE, Aug. 15 — Asian stock markets fell sharply today, amid further signs that the turmoil in the American mortgage market was spreading overseas. European share markets followed Asia lower.

headline: Insuring Second Homes
text: When a 3,100-acre wildfire roared through the southern end of Lake Tahoe, Calif., last June, residents were instructed to evacuate the area. “My house was about a half mile from the fire,” said Fredy Buraye, the owner of a three-bedroom vacation home in the area. “It was pretty close.” Mr. Buraye said his anxiety about losing his home was slightly quelled because he knew he was adequately prepared for the situation. “I knew I had the right insurance coverage.” Mr. Buraye said he was lucky; the fire never made it to his home.

headline: Reading Fortunes in a Bowl of Pasta
text: THERE was no reason to dally. So on the first of my recent visits to Café Boulud, I dug right in and got pasta. I figured it would tell me a lot about what the restaurant had lost and how it was faring now. I braced myself.

headline: Death Toll in Iraq Bombings Rises to 250
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 15 — The toll in a horrific quadruple bombing in an area of mud and stone houses in the remote northern desert on Tuesday evening reached 250 dead and 350 wounded, several local officials said today, making it the single deadliest coordinated attack since the American-led invasion of Iraq in 2003.

headline: He’s Doing Whatever a Zebra Can
text: A downtrodden schoolteacher, a disabled boy and a government agent suffering from an embarrassing itch: these are the unlikely heroes of “Zebraman,” Takashi Miike’s bizarre detour from ultraviolence into family fare.

headline: China, Unregulated
text: “That’s the price of doing business,” is the too-often-heard excuse from American companies that choose to overlook China’s loose business ethics and tight, verging on strangling, political controls.

headline: Dow Off 167 Points in Late Swoon
text: The disquiet on Wall Street showed no signs of letting up today as the Dow Jones industrial average closed below 13,000 for the first time since April and the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index erased its gains for the year.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption with an article yesterday about falling water levels in the Great Lakes misspelled the photographer’s surname. It is John Flesher, not Fleisher.

headline: Subprime Problems Spread Into Commercial Loans
text: Turmoil in the subprime mortgage market spread again yesterday — this time to a type of short-term security held by money market mutual funds. These funds have become the investment of choice for many people seeking a safe haven.

headline: Tired of Energy Ills, Syrians Doubt the West Is to Blame
text: DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 14  Syria has had a summer of power failures and electricity shortages, and recent suggestions by Prime Minister Muhammad Naki al-Otari that American and French economic pressures are to blame are being greeted with skepticism by a weary public.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: An article in the House & Home section on July 26 about Janna Bullock, a renovator and developer of Upper East Side townhouses, reported that one of the owners of a house she had bought on East 67th Street tried to set it on fire on the day of the closing. (Although the owner was not named, the address of the house was given in a caption.)

headline: Along Both Sides of the Velvet Rope, Shallowness Reigns Supreme
text: Tom DiCillo’s angry comedy “Delirious” subjects modern celebrity culture to a microscopic examination that shows the toxic virus of fame squirming and multiplying under its lens. Here are the paparazzi posted like ravenous vermin in front of a velvet rope, ready to trample one another in a stampede at the next celebrity sighting.

headline: Mattel Recalls 19 Million Toys Sent From China
text: Mattel, the world’s largest toy company, yesterday announced the biggest recall in its history.

headline: After 60 Years, Will Pakistan Be Reborn?
text: London

headline: So Many Ventures Did Not Spoil the Chef
text: Beverly Hills, Calif.

headline: Will No Cage Hold Him? Monkey Again Escapes Zoo
text: ATLANTA, Aug. 14 — For the second time in two weeks, Oliver, a 9-year-old capuchin monkey at a Mississippi zoo, escaped his cage, and this time, his keepers said he proved to be an even more artful dodger.

headline: Producer Prices and Trade Data Give Fed Little Reason to Cut Rates
text: Two economic reports released yesterday suggested that the Federal Reserve was facing little urgency to lower interest rates soon.

headline: Virginia Tech Shooting Payments Are Announced
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 — Families of the Virginia Tech students and faculty members killed by a student in a shooting in April will receive more compensation and benefits than was originally planned, university officials announced today.

headline: Facing a Stark Reality, She Decides on a Raffle of Her Only Salable Asset
text: Iguatu, the desolate rural village in northeastern Brazil where Hermila (Hermila Guedes), a spirited 21-year-old single mother, arrives from São Paulo with her baby boy in “Love for Sale,” is the kind of oppressive backwater young people dreaming of a better life flee at the first opportunity. Hermila grew up there, and she returns filled with giddy fantasies of living happily ever after with her true love. Her boyfriend, Matheus, who fathered the baby, has promised to marry her and should arrive any day. Until he joins her, she and the baby stay with her aunt Maria (Maria Menezes) and grandmother Zezita (Zezita Matos).

headline: There’s Money in Oil, Oystermen Find
text: HOPEDALE, La. — The brave little oyster boats chug out daily from the dock here, but their richest harvest may actually be sitting in the office towers of downtown New Orleans, 60 miles west of this remote spot where marsh, sky and water converge.

headline: Samaritan’s Death Raises Questions About Her Choices
text: Geraldine Young was a former schoolteacher, 58 and single, who one day said God told her to take in homeless men and let them stay in the five bedrooms above her own. On this block of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the opinion has long been divided on whether that made her a saint or a fool.

headline: Beheading and Shooting by Russian Neo-Nazis on Video
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 14  The Russian authorities said Tuesday that they were investigating a video recording of what appeared to be the grisly execution of two bound and gagged young men, filmed in a forest beneath a large Nazi flag. At least one of the men was beheaded on camera as he lay in a shallow grave.

headline: James Stewart, Immortalized
text: James Stewart will be honored by a stamp bearing his image, The Associated Press reported. It will be released Friday by the United States Postal Service at ceremonies in at the Jimmy Stewart Museum in Indiana, Pa., the actor’s hometown, and at Universal Studios in Hollywood. The photograph on the stamp, left, is based on a portrait of Stewart, who died in 1997, as he appeared in a publicity photo for the 1949 movie “The Stratton Story.”

headline: Astronaut Teaches in Space, and Lesson Is Bittersweet
text: Barbara R. Morgan got back to teaching yesterday. The students were in Idaho; she was in space, orbiting aboard the International Space Station.

headline: ‘On the Road’ at 50
text: Published 50 years ago, “On the Road” still sells about 100,000 copies a year in various paperback editions, according to Viking. And while its era as a counterculture standard-bearer may have passed, it has far outlasted many other cult classics.

headline: Write a Title, Win a Book
text: I mentioned recently in this blog that I’ll be going on book leave soon to work with my wife, Sheryl WuDunn, on a book about women in the developing world. That provoked some interesting comments, and it reminded me that we still need a good title.

headline: Clear Creek Eaux de Vie
text: Anybody who reads my column in Wednesday’s newspaper, on the wonderful eaux de vie from Clear Creek Distillery, is likely to come away with this question: How do they get the pear into the bottle of pear eau de vie?

headline: The Bison Business
text: I’ve always felt sorry for food purveyors who want their products to shine at a conference but are at the mercy of the kitchen where the meeting is being held. Woe to the organization trying to promote any red meat under these circumstances, especially bison, which is a goner once it has been overcooked.

headline: Ex-Software Executive Begins Prison Term
text: Sanjay Kumar, the former chief executive of Computer Associates, now known as CA, began serving a 12-year prison term Tuesday for his role in a $2.2 billion accounting fraud at the software company.

headline: In a Reversal, Hedge Fund Will Support Sale of Ceridian
text: The hedge fund manager William A. Ackman dropped his opposition to the sale of Ceridian, the payroll processor, after tangling with the company for months.

headline: 2 Guilty Pleas Expected in Insider Case
text: A former finance vice president at Morgan Stanley and her husband, a former hedge fund analyst at ING Investment Management, are expected to plead guilty to insider-trading charges, according to a prosecutor.

headline: Documents Describe Whole Foods’ Strategy
text: Federal regulators filed court documents on Tuesday outlining concerns that stores in competitive markets will close and consumers will face higher prices if Whole Foods Market‘s $565 million purchase of Wild Oats Markets is completed.

headline: AirTran Tops New Offer for Midwest Air
text: AirTran Holdings reversed course Tuesday and raised its offer for the Midwest Air Group to $445 million, topping a $424 million bid from the buyout firm TPG Capital and Northwest Airlines.

headline: Fortress Battered by Wider Loss
text: The Fortress Investment Corporation posted a wider quarterly loss on Tuesday, sending its shares down 6.6 percent.

headline: Trading Is Halted in Shares of Mortgage Lender
text: Trading was halted Tuesday in shares of the lender Thornburg Mortgage Asset after they fell 47 percent, the most since their 1993 initial public offering. Earlier, five brokerage firms downgraded the stock and Moody’s Investors Service cut its debt rating amid turmoil in the home loan market.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
text: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Sentinel Management Freezes Fund
text: Sentinel Management Group on Tuesday froze a $1.5 billion fund, saying too many investors are trying to withdraw their money.

headline: Icahn Builds Stake in Kraft
text: Confirming recent rumors, the activist investor Carl C. Icahn disclosed Tuesday in a regulatory filing that his investment firm had acquired 3.92 million shares of Kraft Foods, a holding valued at about $138.2 million as of June 30.

headline: Buffett Takes Stakes in Dow Jones
text: Berkshire Hathaway, the investment firm run by Warren Buffett, bought stakes in Dow Jones and Bank of America and more than quadrupled its holdings of the health insurers UnitedHealth Group and WellPoint.

headline: Behringer REIT to Buy Canadian Rival
text: The Behringer Harvard Real Estate Investment Trust of Dallas is proposing to buy Canada’s IPC US Real Estate Investment Trust in an all-cash deal valued at about 1.4 billion Canadian dollars ($1.3 billion).

headline: V.C. Spending in Canada Falls 30%
text: Venture capital investment across Canada fell by nearly one-third in the second quarter of 2007 with Ontario taking the hardest hit, as investment levels in the province fell to less than half their totals from the previous quarter.

headline: Sainsbury Bidder Asks for Bank Guarantees
text: The banks arranging the 6 billion pounds ($11.9 billion) of debt finance for the Qatari-backed bid for Britain’s J Sainsbury’s supermarket chain have asked lenders for the money to be made available for longer as talks between the two sides drag on.

headline: Dodd Backs Banks in Enron Suit
text: Senator Christopher Dodd, who heads the Senate Banking Committee, joined a number of lawmakers and officials of both parties Tuesday in calling on the Bush administration not to side with defendant companies in a Supreme Court case that could determine the fate of a separate Enron lawsuit.

headline: Banks Agree to Give Basell $21 Billion in Loans
text: A Dutch company, Basell Holdings, has received a commitment for $21 billion in loans for its acquisition of Houston-based Lyondell Chemical in a signal that banks are still willing to finance some leveraged buyouts.

headline: Redemption Day: Will Hedge-Fund Investors Bolt?
text: For hedge fund bosses, today could be a nail-biter.

headline: Hedge Fund Managers Sue Akin Gump
text: In what The New York Law Journal regards as a cautionary tale, two former managers of a collapsed hedge fund, Veras Investment Partners, are suing Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld, claiming that the law firm advised them that the late trading that led to the fund’s collapse was legal.

headline: Tully’s Coffee Not So Hot to Go Public
text: Tully’s Coffee, once eager to jump into the stock market’s roiling waters, now waits nervously on the shore. The Seattle-based coffee retailer has indefinitely postponed its initial public offering, citing turmoil in the stock market.

headline: Janney Pays $2.5 Million to Settle Fees Case
text: Janney Montgomery Scott, the 175-year-old Philadelphia brokerage, will pay $2.5 million to settle allegations that it inflated borrowing costs and fees on stock loans.

headline: Doppleganger Takes $11 Million
text: Doppelganger, a music-focused virtual realm operator, announced Tuesday that it had received an $11 million infusion of venture capital.

headline: Warburg Takes Stake in Integra
text: As Integra Telecom works to close an acquisition that will greatly increase its heft, the Western operator said Tuesday that Warburg Pincus has paid $245 million for a stake in the company.

headline: Aegis Files for Bankruptcy
text: Aegis Mortgage, which is owned by an affiliate of Cerberus Capital Management , became the third mortgage lender to file for bankruptcy protection in a week as the weak housing market and rapidly deteriorating secondary one for mortgage loans continues to devastate the entire industry.

headline: Bear to Buy Ford’s Indian Finance Unit
text: Bear Stearns plans to enter India by acquiring the financial arm of Ford Motor, The Economic Times newspaper said in an unsourced story on Wednesday.

headline: Tribune Denies Zell Deal is in Danger
text: Tribune said its $8.2 billion sale to a group led by the billionaire Samuel Zell is still on, disputing an analyst who said the odds of the deal closing as scheduled are no better than 50-50.

headline: Troubled Dutch Investment Bank Is Sold
text: Kaupthing Bank, the biggest bank in Iceland, agreed to buy NIBC Holding for 3 billion euros ($4 billion), less than a week after the Dutch investment bank disclosed losses on United States subprime-mortgage bets.

headline: Subprime Problems Spread Into Commercial Loans
text: Turmoil in the subprime mortgage market spread again Tuesday – this time to a type of short-term security held by money market mutual funds. These funds have become the investment of choice for many people seeking a safe haven.

headline: Goldman to Waive Fees to Lure Investors to Fund
text: Goldman Sachs waived fees to draw investors to its Global Equity Opportunities hedge fund after stock-market losses wiped out $1.4 billion of assets this month.

headline: In It Together
text: A place built to nurture both young and elderly people.

headline: Mirant Auction Put on Hold, Report Says
text: The auction of Mirant is suffering from a brownout as the credit markets continue to take their toll on deal making. The Financial Times’ Deal Reporter site said Wednesday that buyers are waiting out the recent storm in the debt market and that the auction is merely on hold for now.

headline: 2008: F. Thompson’s ‘Phantom Campaign’
text: All summer, the rumors have flown about when former Senator Fred D. Thompson would officially announce his candidacy for president. Would he jump in on July 4 or perhaps later in the month? Now we’re hearing that it’s likely he’ll get into the race around Labor Day.

headline: Cadbury Said to Choose Spinoff Over Sale
text: Cadbury Schweppes, concluding that private equity firms will be unable to raise funds to buy its United States beverage business, is moving ahead with a demerger of the unit instead of a sale, The Times of London reported, citing undisclosed sources.

headline: Basis Says One Fund May Have Lost 80%
text: Australia’s Basis Capital Fund Management told investors losses at one of its hedge funds may exceed 80 percent as the United States subprime mortgage rout prompted creditors to force the Sydney-based company to sell assets, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Morning Buzz: A Mixed Picture for Congestion Pricing; the Six Newark Murder Suspects; the Astor Funeral Guest List; and More
text: A mixed picture has emerged on the announcement yesterday that the federal government is willing to provide $354 million to help reduce traffic in New York City and to put in effect Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion pricing plan. As William Neuman notes, the city had estimated that it would cost $223 million to install a computerized system to monitor traffic and impose a traffic fee on cars entering the busiest parts of Manhattan, and asked the federal government to cover $179 million of that.But the Department of Transportation said it would contribute only $10 million to that initiative. Instead, most of the federal money was reserved for bus depots and other mass transit improvements, like expanded ferry service. New York received far more than the other four cities that also received grants: Miami, Minneapolis, San Francisco and Seattle.

headline:
Living with Music:
A Playlist by Glenn Kurtz
text: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for “Living With Music,” a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the “celebrity playlists” on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

headline: How to Simulate the Universe
text: A lot of readers don’t want to believe they’re living in a computer simulation. The last post prompted a virtual avalanche of comments from people insisting it would be impossible for any computer to create a virtual world with virtual people with virtual nervous systems.

headline: Harikrishna, Acs Tie for First in Hungary; Korchnoi Fades
text: Pentala Harikrishna of India and Peter Acs of Hungary tied for first in the Fifth Marx Gyorgy Memorial Tournament in Paks, Hungary. (In an odd coincidence, the two share the same birthday: May 10, although Acs is five years older than Harikrishna.) The tournament, which was sponsored by a nuclear power plant in honor of Gyorgy, a nuclear physicist, ran from Aug. 4-15. The games and profiles of the players are on the tournament’s official Web site.

headline: Rice Whittles a Stick for Iran
text: Out on the campaign trail, candidates are carefully detailing their Iran policies, with Rudolph W. Giuliani being the latest. In two paragraphs of an essay in Foreign Affairs, he describes a broad strategy with the goal of proving to “the theocrats ruling Iran” that “we can wield the stick as well as the carrot.”

headline: Carville on Rove
text: Writing in The Financial Times, former Clinton strategist James Carville analyzes Karl Rove’s career: “There is no doubt that Mr Rove won elections. He has perhaps one of the most remarkable win-percentages in modern American politics.” At the same time, however, “He has lost an entire generation for the Republican party,” Carville writes. He continues:

headline: A Peek Behind the Automated Curtain
text: There is a school of thought that A.T.M.s are not technological marvels; that they are, in fact, mere facades. Behind the glowing screens and beeping buttons, this theory goes, stand rooms full of humans (or elves) who shuttle back and forth to the vault and simply slide money through the slots, performing the work of real tellers without any need for personal interaction with customers.

headline: A Plaintiffs’ Attorney Takes His Client List Upscale
text: For years, the name Jacob H. Zamansky provoked headaches on Wall Street. The plaintiff’s lawyer best known for suing Merrill Lynch over an infamous research report by Henry Blodget, Mr. Zamansky has long been known as a gadfly who represented small investors — and squeezed big settlements out of major firms in the process.

headline: Another Human-Computer Match and the Result Was Predictable
text: Ten years ago, Garry Kasparov lost a match to Deep Blue, a chess computer developed by I.B.M. Anyone who wants to relive the match can go to the Web site which is still up. Although the result was a bit of shock at the time, it was also inevitable. With improvements in computer speed and programming, everyone, even Kasparov, knew that eventually computers would surpass humans at playing chess. (In 1995, Kasparov had predicted that he would not lose until about 2005, but programming and computer hardware development were not exactly his area of expertise.)

headline: Buyout Blues Hit ‘American Idol’ Deal
text: Not even Elvis Presley is immune from the recent credit crunch.

headline: Harry Potter Behemoth Nears Russia
text: The Harry Potter craze has begun to fade in the United States, but the boy wizard has plenty of Russian fans eagerly anticipating the September 1 release of the official Russian translation.

headline: Halcyon Days
text: The Halcyon

headline: Romney and Richardson Unveil New Campaign Ads
text: Mitt Romney is up with yet another new ad in Iowa, this time an effort to extend his victory lap after the state’s Republican straw poll with a “Thanks, Iowa” commercial.

headline: Police Issue Report on ‘Homegrown’ Terror Threat
text: Updated, 5:54 p.m. | The city’s Police Department this morning released a report, “Radicalization in the West: The Homegrown Threat,” that examines, in 90 pages, how ordinary people in the West can become radicalized and followers of what the report calls a jihadist ideology. Although the findings in the new analysis are similar to those of other studies, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said the report — prepared by the department’s Intelligence Division — was an important addition to his department’s arsenal of counterterrorism tools.

headline: Hedge Funds Sail On, Despite the Storm
text: No liquidity problems here.

headline: Q & A: Reading’s Marcus Hahnemann
text: Marcus Hahnemann is now in his eighth year playing in England. Last season, the Reading keeper helped his team finish eighth in the Premiere League, their first season in the top flight. He recorded 22 shutouts in 38 league games.

headline: Off the Menu: Lidia Loves a Parade
text: This week in Florence Fabricant’s “Off the Menu” column, she reports that Lidia Bastianich will be the first chef to serve as grand marshal of the Columbus Day Parade. She joins an esteemed grand marshal lineage that includes Frank Sinatra, Sophia Loren  and Tommy Lasorda.

headline: ‘Each Issue Really Socks it to You’
text: I’ve never actually laid my hands on a copy of Ralph Ginzburg’s literary-cultural magazine Avant-Garde, which existed from 1968 through 1971.

headline: The Secret Language of Hedge Funds
text: When things turn bad, hedge fund managers can’t get away with telling investors that the dog ate their returns. But they have an array of other, far more technical-sounding explanations for losing billions of dollars of other people’s money. And those explanations have been getting quite a workout in the last few weeks, as some well-known funds are facing double-digit losses or shutting their funds down altogether.

headline: Congressional Race on Staten Island May Be a Rematch
text: For most of the 13 members of Congress from New York City, the November election is a sleepy event, with little in the way of competition. In fact, three congressmen from New York were uncontested in the general election in 2006 and eight members of Congress from the city won with 80 percent or more of the vote that year.

headline: Offerman Goes Off
text: José Offerman’s bat landed him in trouble Tuesday. Or rather, it’s what he did with his bat: Offerman was charged with two counts of second-degree assault after hitting the pitcher and catcher with his bat during an independent minor league game in Bridgeport, Conn.

headline: Vikings Land; Rubber Ducks Do Not
text: The nautical news goes farther and wider than world leaders are willing to roam this vacation season. From the North Sea to the South Atlantic, a trio of oddities on the high seas have carried on in their own odd way since we last wrote about them on July 3. Here’s a progress report.

headline: The Last Working-Class Bar in the Hamptons? Don’t Wear Your Penny Loafers
text: The Hamptons are known for many things, but blue-collar bars are not one of them.

headline: Counting Up Private Equity’s Lobbying Tab
text: In Washington, as in Wall Street, money talks. And during the first half of this year, it seems private equity firms were trying to say a lot.

headline: SLM Shareholders Approve Buyout
text: The SLM Corporation, commonly known as Sallie Mae, said on Wednesday its shareholders had approved the $25 billion acquisition of the student lender by a group of private equity firms and banks. The company in April accepted the cash leveraged buyout proposal, worth $60 per share, from J.C. Flowers, Friedman Fleischer & Lowe, Bank of America and J.P. Morgan Chase.

headline: A Call to Ban Smoking in Cars (With Children)
text: Under a City Council proposal, New York City would prohibit smoking in cars where children are riding, joining the ranks of Arkansas, Louisiana, Puerto Rico, Bangor, Me., and Rockland County, N.Y., where similar legislation has been passed.

headline: Turned Off by Giuliani’s Foreign Policy
text: Foreign Affairs has published Rudy Giuliani’s foreign policy manifesto, “Toward a Realistic Peace.” (The magazine has published similar essays by Barack Obama, Mitt Romney, and John Edwards, with more to come from “the top U.S. presidential candidates.”)

headline: The Edwards – Edwards Ticket
text: Breaking news from the Maple Inn Café in Osage, Iowa: Elizabeth Edwards is angling to be her husband’s vice president.

headline: Warning to Overseas Cell Travelers
text: From a reader:

headline: Blogtalk: Colombian Fried Chicken, Dylan Impersonators, Dark Humor of the Air Traffic Controllers, and More
text: What we’re reading on the local blogs…

headline: Making Money Off Bush
text: You can almost count the hours between the time that a White House official says something, a Democratic candidate responds, and then … a fund-raising appeal drops into everyone’s inbox. In the 2008 campaign season, it’s already a familiar routine.

headline: A quirky Berlin museum dedicated to The Ramones
text: By Andreas Tzortzis

headline: Never Let ‘Em See You Sweat
text: DES MOINES — Hillary Rodham Clinton may have been the coolest person at the Iowa State Fair today. According to The Des Moines Register, the heat index is 103, and everyone else here at the fairgrounds looked it. Makeup slid off women’s faces. Thousands of hands wiped brows and beat the still air with cardboard fans.

headline: Bomb Attacks in Northern Iraq
text: The coordinated attack on members of the Yazidi sect in two Iraqi towns near the Syrian border was the single deadliest bombing of the war.

headline: The Ups and Downs of Romney’s Portfolio
text: Mitt Romney has based much of his presidential run — both its image and its financing — on his experience with and investments in private equity and other alternative assets. It now seems that the former Massachusetts governor has gained even more from those investments — and lost, too.

headline: Brooke Astor’s Last Will and Testament
text: Following are copies of the disputed last will and testament of Brooke Astor, who died on Monday at age 105.

headline: Referee Pleads Guilty
text: Former referee Tim Donaghy admitted to gambling on N.B.A. games while working for the league.

headline: Tango in Central Park
text: For more than a decade, tango in Central Park has been the emblem of one of the city's most obsessed subcultures.

headline: Keane-O Vs. WAGS
text: What makes Roy Keane tick?

headline: Answers From the New York Dog Experts, Part 2
text: Following is the second set of responses from the dog experts Marcello Forte and Jennifer Bristol, who are the executive director and associate director, respectively, of Animal Haven. Mr. Forte and Ms. Bristol are taking questions from City Room readers this week. Readers are invited to submit additional questions here. A first set of answers was posted on Tuesday.

headline: U.S. U-17 Team Lands in South Korea
text: Want to feel old?

headline: 1,000 Points of Darkness
text: The Dow has managed to lose more than 1,000 points in the 19 trading sessions since it first closed over 14,000. It seems like every time stock buyers manage to get a rally together, as they did earlier today, there is another piece of bad news on the credit front. Today it is KKR Finance, which can’t sell enough mortgage loans, and Countrywide Financial, where a Merrill Lynch analyst named Kenneth Bruce is warning the company could go broke if it can’t sell assets for high enough prices.

headline: Giuliani Swings Through Iowa, Too
text: CARSON,Iowa — Rudolph W. Giuliani was nowhere to be seen in Iowa last weekend during the Iowa Straw Poll in Ames, the non-binding, pay-to-play poll for Iowa Republicans.

headline: Pedicab Owners Protest Pending Regulation
text: Nearly 50 pedicabs made their way down Broadway, from Columbus Circle through Times Square and all the way to City Hall, this afternoon in a last-ditch protest as the city prepares next month to begin regulating the human-powered vehicles for the first time. Pedicab operators will be licensed, and the number of vehicles will be capped at 325. No one is certain how many pedicabs are currently in use, but estimates have placed the number as high as 800 to 1,000.The pedicab industry started in the mid-1990s. The vehicles have become popular as an unconventional way to get around Midtown, but cabbies, bus drivers and police officers have often complained that the vehicles clog the streets. In February, the City Council approved a pedicab regulation bill over objections from some cab owners. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg seemed poised to sign the bill in March, but at the last minute, he changed his mind, swayed by arguments that the tiny industry should remain relatively unregulated. Later that month, the mayor vetoed the bill, but in April, the Council voted to override the veto.

headline: Dodd Woos Labor Crowd in Iowa
text: WATERLOO, Iowa – If Senator Chris Dodd of Connecticut were elected president, sleepovers might become more popular than state dinners at the White House.

headline: Lessons From the Master
text: Is Hillary Clinton Slytherin’s heir? Mark Kleiman, a U.C.L.A. public policy professor who writes at the academic group blog The Reality-Based Community, says Clinton’s campaign is “Rove’s disciple” for its attacks on Barack Obama.

headline: Rove vs. Clinton
text: Just two days after announcing he would be stepping down as a top adviser to President Bush, Karl Rove is ramping up his attacks on Democrats and, in particular, one of the party’s leading presidential contenders, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Will the Real Hooded Man Please Stand Up
text: Every human being has his own particular web of associations for identifying and interpreting reality, which, most often, instinctively and unthinkingly, he superimposes on every set of circumstances. Frequently, however, those external circumstances do not conform with, or fit, the structure of our webs, and then we can misread the unfamiliar reality, and interpret its elements incorrectly… — Ryszard Kapuscinski, “Travels with Herodotus” (2007)

headline: A Wonderful, Wide Community of All Ages
text: It’s been one year since an old man named Peter Oakley posted his first video on YouTube.

headline: The Quants Explain Disaster
text: A hedge fund manager sent me a copy of a report from Goldman Sachs entitled “The Quant Liquidity Crunch.” What follows are Goldman’s conclusion, and his dissection of that conclusion. (The manager prefers not to have his name used here. The people he mentions, if anyone needs to be told, are Warren Buffett and Charles Munger of Berkshire Hathaway.)

headline: I’m Outta Here
text: I’m headed for vacation, although my Friday and Saturday columns will appear this week. Comments will continue to be posted, but I probably won’t write new items until Aug. 27.

headline: Antiwar Challenge to Kucinich
text: By March, Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio will probably know the fate of his presidential bid. At that point, he might have to worry about his party’s nomination for his own Cleveland-based House seat. The race is already heating up, as his challenger for the Democratic nomination in the 10th Congressional District today accepted the endorsement of Paul Hackett, the Iraq vet and bitter war foe who himself sought a seat in Congress.

headline: The Interchangeable Left-Handers
text: I touched on this briefly in my game story in this morning’s paper, but I devoted a little more space to it in the notebook that will run in the early editions tomorrow: Was anyone else surprised to see Willie Randolph summon Scott Schoeneweis — and not the left-handed specialist Pedro Feliciano — with the tying run on third base and two outs in the eighth inning Tuesday?

headline: Sony v. Microsoft (With Helmets)
text: A video game review published this week in USA Today has set off the latest tit-for-tat among the loyalists of the Xbox 360 and its rival, the PlayStation 3.

headline: Reprieve for Bangkok’s Night Bazaar
text: Bangkok”s Suan Lum Night Bazaar, open for business

headline: Your Comments on my Climate Column
text: In Thursday’s column I focus on a wave of new research showing that climate change is already happening faster than scientists had anticipated. Most predictions about rising seas are based on computer models, but a series of new scientific studies have shown that actual measurements are worse than the models predicted.
