For example, the north polar ice cap is melting at three times the rate the models anticipated.

headline: Dow Drops 340 Points, Then Recovers Losses
text: Stocks staged a late rally today on Wall Street after a day of wild swings as investors continued to weigh the impact of the crunch in the American credit market.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: Purslane in Every Pot

headline: CIRCUITS| An Interactive Robotic Toy to Amuse Youngsters (and Scare Pets) as It Scuttles Across the Floor
text: What has four legs, walks like a crab and uses seven batteries? It’s Roboquad, a cat-size robotic toy from WowWee (www.wowwee.com) that manages to be both cute and creepy at the same time. The rotating legs give this $100 toy an insectlike motion that has the potential to send a pet under the couch. But the large darting infrared eyes give it a personable look.

headline: Newly Released
text: Let’s face it: August is not generally when publishing houses unveil their most precious gems, just after the arrival of the prime summer beach reads but before the autumn onslaught of prize bait. Often, as a result, the month offers a grab bag of titles that don’t quite fit in any other time. Still, pearls can be found.

headline: U.S. Is Prodding Pakistan Leader to Share Power
text: This article was reported by Mark Mazzetti, Helene Cooper and Carlotta Gall, and written by Mr. Mazzetti.

headline: Weapons of Mass Preservation
text: Washington

headline: Chinese Want to Cut Slice Going to U.S. Middlemen
text: GROWING numbers of Chinese companies are quietly setting up operations in the United States, even as trade with China has ignited loud debates in Congress.

headline: Where Is Everybody? The Gang at a Glance
text: MY daughter’s day camp ends at 5 p.m., and it takes only four minutes to drive there from my house if I get lucky at the stoplight on Miller Avenue, and there’s a good chance that the kids in the Blue Group will be dismissed a minute or two late.

headline: Amgen to Cut Jobs, a First for the Biotech Giant
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 — The biotechnology giant Amgen announced the first major layoffs in its heretofore charmed history today in reaction to sliding sales of the anemia drugs that account for nearly half its revenue.

headline: Aging at Home, and With Dignity (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Stand, Officer Tells of Affair That Grew Violent, Saying Captain Beat Her
text: The way prosecutors tell it, the trial of Alberto Sanchez revolves around a sad cliché: an office romance between a married woman and her boss that spiraled into domestic violence. The exception is that they are both police officers.

headline: A Credit Crunch Unlike Any Other
text: Twenty-first century financial markets react with lightning speed to events halfway around the world. Investors in China can immediately see what happened in New York and make trades in London based on the news.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,683 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

headline: Arias Alfresco, Siren Accompaniment
text: “You tend to forget how good opera is until you actually hear it,” Tony Zertuche, a 36-year-old playwright, said Tuesday afternoon. He was waiting in a long line in Bryant Park to buy $25 tickets to coming New York City Opera productions, which were being sold after the company’s Afternoon Arias lunchtime concert in the park.

headline: At Netflix, Victory for Voices Over Keystrokes
text: HILLSBORO, Ore. — Megan Funk had been on the phone for 30 minutes and had already untangled one billing knot, listened to a woman insist that she had returned a Pilates DVD when it was clear she had lost it and received one request to replace a cracked copy of “Hotel Rwanda” and another to replace a disappointing husband.

headline: Iran Arrests 2 Chinese on Charges of Spying
text: TEHRAN, Aug. 15  Iran has arrested two Chinese citizens on charges of spying for taking pictures of a military complex in the central city of Arak, where Iran is building a nuclear reactor, the judiciary spokesman said Wednesday.

headline: Study Abroad Is New Focus of Inquiry Into Perks
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 — New York’s attorney general is opening an inquiry into the relationships between universities and providers of study abroad, delivering subpoenas to five providers on Wednesday with more to come, a senior lawyer in the office said.

headline: Amateur Hour on Iran
text: The dangers posed by Iran are serious, and America needs to respond with serious policies, not more theatrics. Labeling Iran’s Revolutionary Guard Corps as a foreign terrorist organization  as the State Department now proposes  is another distraction when what the Bush administration needs to be doing is opening comprehensive negotiations with Tehran, backed by increasing international economic pressure.

headline: Searching for the Miners
text: It is beyond belief that in this Information Age, when new technologies can eavesdrop on any conversation and track people around the globe, rescue teams have no way to communicate with the six miners trapped underground in the Crandall Canyon Mine in Utah. Instead they are drilling holes in the ground to where they guess the miners might be.

headline: Neighbors of Home Invasion Victims Demand Stricter Repeat-Offender Laws
text: CHESHIRE, Conn., Aug. 15  Cheshire residents, angered by revelations that the men suspected of killing three members of a prominent family in a home invasion robbery last month had been paroled after convictions for burglary, rallied in a town park on Wednesday to demand stricter laws to keep repeat offenders behind bars.

headline: Textbook Case of Unblocking, but This One’s From Real Life
text: Inexperienced players sometimes complain that textbook plays they have been taught do not occur at the table, only in classes and publications. But they do arise occasionally, as evidenced by the diagramed deal, which occurred July 6 during a two-day knockout team event at the July 4th Regional in Deerfield Beach, Fla.

headline: Mood Swings as Rivera Negates Yankees’ Rally
text: The decibel level at Yankee Stadium soared like a firecracker during the top of the 10th inning yesterday. The 53,363 fans were ecstatic for two justifiable reasons. Shelley Duncan had tied the score against the Baltimore Orioles with a three-run homer in the ninth inning. And Mariano Rivera, a model of consistency this season, had just taken the mound.

headline: Nickelodeon to Limit Use of Characters on Junk Foods
text: Add Jimmy Neutron to the list of licensed characters that are going on a diet.

headline: After 20 Days, Revis and Jets Strike a Deal
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 15  The labor that delivered cornerback Darrelle Revis to the Jets was plodding, dragging on for 20 days beyond the due date. The last push started Tuesday night and continued well into Wednesday.

headline: Indonesia: High Economic Growth
text: Indonesia’s economy grew the fastest in more than two years in the second quarter as exports rose and lower interest rates fueled spending and investment. The economy expanded 6.3 percent in the three months ended June 30 after gaining 6 percent in the previous quarter, the Central Statistics Bureau said. Private consumption increased 4.7 percent in the second quarter from a year earlier, according to the report. Manufacturing expanded 5.5 percent, construction rose 7.8 percent and agriculture gained 2.4 percent. Government spending was up 3.8 percent. Exports rose 9.8 percent on rising overseas sales of commodities, including palm oil and coal, the report said, while imports increased 7.2 percent.

headline: West Bank: Talks on Japan-Sponsored Project
text: The foreign ministers of Japan, Israel and Jordan and senior Palestinian officials met in the West Bank town of Jericho to discuss the possibility of building a joint agricultural-industrial park in the Jordan Valley, underwritten by Japan. Earlier, the Japanese foreign minister, Taro Aso, announced the resumption of direct aid to the Palestinian Authority, suspended after Hamas came to power in elections in 2006.

headline: By His Former Lawyers
text: Michael Jackson’s former lawyers filed a lawsuit on Tuesday claiming that he owes them more than $113,000, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The Los Angeles law firm Lavely & Singer says that Mr. Jackson agreed in arbitration last year to pay $180,000 in three installments. He failed to make the final payment of $113,750 before the July 31, 2007, deadline stipulated in the settlement, the firm says in a complaint filed in Los Angeles Superior Court.

headline: Elvis and Integration (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: No Bailouts (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Venezuela to Purchase Thousands of Russian Rifles
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 15 — A proposed contract between Russia and Venezuela that could transfer thousands of sniper rifles to Venezuela has raised concerns in the United States about the potential use or regional distribution of the weapons by the socialist-inspired government of President Hugo Chavez.

headline: A Poet of the Diamond, Delivering His Lines on a Three-and-One Count
text: Williams Carlos Williams, a physician, was also an unconventional poet who died in 1963 shortly after winning the Pulitzer Prize for poetry.

headline: Establishment Threads in a Radical Fringe
text: EDINBURGH — If farce is tragedy speeded up, as has been said, Enda Walsh’s ferociously entertaining new play might be called a drama in three gears.

headline: Maker of Video Games Is Notified S.E.C. May Act in Options Case
text: The video game maker Take-Two Interactive said yesterday that it might face civil charges and fines from the Securities and Exchange Commission for backdating stock options.

headline: Madden on the Wii: Fun Even for Nonenthusiasts
text: When I was a boy I used to sit with my dad in front of the TV and watch football games. He would explain the rules and tell me about the teams and the important players while I tuned him out, distracted by what looked to me like a chaotic free-for-all. I never had the slightest idea what was going on in the game and usually wasn’t even sure where the ball was.

headline: Push by Chávez to Abandon Term Limits on Presidency
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 15 — President Hugo Chávez outlined a proposed overhaul to the Constitution on Wednesday night that would allow him to remain in power indefinitely through perpetual re-elections, an intensification of his efforts to assert greater state control over political and economic institutions.

headline: Talent Will Out
text: The finale of “America’s Got Talent” on NBC delivered the largest audience of Tuesday night, according to Nielsen’s estimate, with 10.8 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m. NBC’s “Singing Bee” at 9:30 (9.8 million) tied with CBS’s “Big Brother” among adults 18 to 49. “Big Brother” posted its highest numbers of the summer, attracting 7.7 million total viewers in the 9 p.m. hour. CBS ranked No. 2 for the night, just ahead of ABC’s back-to-back episodes of “Just for Laughs,” which averaged 6.8 million viewers and came in second among the 18-to-49 set in the 8 p.m. hour. Fox was fourth for the night.

headline: Remains Found in Bridge Disaster
text: Human remains were found in two of four vehicles pulled from the bottom of the Mississippi River, where they fell on Aug. 1 when the I-35W bridge in Minneapolis collapsed, the Hennepin County Sheriff’s office announced today.

headline: Mortgage Lender Moves to Shore Up Cash
text: Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, said today that it had tapped $11.5 billion in emergency loans from 40 of the world’s largest banks in an effort to shore up its cash position.

headline: The New Sophisticated-Smelling Me
text: YOU can go through life for only so long smelling like a dessert topping. For a few years now, I have been wearing a mix of a coconut-y moisturizer, Skin Trip, and a cake-batter-y perfume oil, Tunisian Amber, both acquired from the Integral Yoga store on West 13th Street. It was cool for a while, but I am nearing 40, and this sweet concoction doesn’t cut it anymore, unless my goal is to attract a doughnut.

headline: Underneath the Normal, the Nutty
text: If yours is a normal family, it probably isn’t very normal at all. We all know that family life is part facade, that a layer of weirdness or tension or both lurks beneath the Kodak moments. “Long Distance,” a program of three one-acts adapted from stories by Judy Budnitz, captures family life as it is but isn’t: skewed, unreal but somehow painfully accurate.

headline: Holocaust Tracing Service (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Aftershocks of War (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Edwards Opts to Redirect Nevada Staff
text: Former Senator John Edwards is moving a “handful” of paid staff members from Nevada to other early primary states, according to campaign officials, who characterized the shift as a routine event that occurs in any political campaign.

headline: R. Kelly’s Killer Serial: Video, Music, Cliffhangers, Midgets
text: The story began simply enough: the love triangle of Sylvester, Kathy and Rufus. But after 12 chapters the triangle was more like a lopsided octagon, with a dozen characters and as many cliffhangers. The dramas hinged on unlikely plot devices: leg cramps, pie allergies, the surprising things one finds hiding in cupboards.

headline: Brooklyn: Call for Blast Inquiry
text: A lawyer representing one of the most severely injured victims of last month’s steam pipe explosion in Manhattan said yesterday that an independent monitor should oversee the testing of evidence. In a hearing on a motion filed in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, the lawyer, Kenneth P. Thompson, said that Consolidated Edison, which runs the city’s steam network, could not be trusted to perform destructive testing on equipment found at the site of the July 18 explosion. Mr. Thompson represents Gregory McCullough, 21, who suffered third-degree burns. The lawyer obtained a temporary restraining order last week to stop the testing until a judge could review the motion. Henry G. Miller, a lawyer for Con Edison, said that an independent company, Evidence Security Inc., had been hired to secure evidence found at the scene. Arguments in Mr. Thompson’s motion are expected to resume this morning.

headline: Terrorist Label for Iran Guard Reflects U.S. Impatience With U.N.
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  In moving toward designating Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps as a foreign terrorist organization, the Bush administration is adopting a more confrontational approach with Tehran, reflecting frustration with a stalled sanctions package at the United Nations Security Council, officials said Wednesday.

headline: China Plans Greater Scrutiny of Food Exports
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 — Chinese government authorities are prepared to require that every shipment of food being exported to the United States and other countries be inspected for quality by the government, starting Sept. 1, a senior Chinese trade official said on Wednesday.

headline: Chávez’s Bid for Russian Arms Pains U.S.
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 15  A proposed contract between Russia and Venezuela that could transfer thousands of sniper rifles to Venezuela has raised concerns in the United States about the potential use or regional distribution of the weapons by the socialist-inspired government of President Hugo Chávez.

headline: In Sickness and in Health?
text: After an off-season of bad news about concussions in football, the N.F.L. this week approved guidelines to help monitor and manage concussions among active players. What should the league’s responsibility be for the health of former players?

headline: An Artist’s Artist (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pop Charts: Hot Rap
text: Two new rap albums take the top spots on the Billboard chart this week. The first in five years from the Port Arthur, Tex., duo UGK, “Underground Kingz” (Jive), reached No. 1 with 160,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Plies, a gruff rapper from Fort Myers, Fla., is at No. 2 with “The Real Testament” (Slip-N-Slide/Atlantic), which sold 96,000. The only other new album in the Top 40 is the self-titled second disc by the Jonas Brothers, a teenage trio from New Jersey whose music is on the extreme pop end of emo; it sold 69,000 copies and reached No. 5. Last week’s best seller, Common’s “Finding Forever” (Geffen), dropped to No. 7 with sales of 58,000, a decline of 63 percent.

headline: Business and Science to Join in Taking a River’s Pulse
text: BEACON, N.Y., Aug. 13 — Environmentalists and big corporations often end up in open conflict because they do not see eye to eye on whether a natural resource like a river should be protected or exploited.

headline: With a New Leader and Renewed Verve, Bolshoi Soars in Londoners’ Eyes
text: LONDON, Aug. 15 — The Bolshoi Ballet’s current season here, the third in four years, is such a success that it has inspired standing, shouting ovations from audiences and superlatives from sometimes finicky critics, including one who deemed a performance worthy of six stars out of five.

headline: Living in Her Moment, Again
text: WHEN she breezed into Manhattan last week, Zandra Rhodes had shed some elements of her operatic style. Her fuchsia hair, which she tends to wear upswept in a chopstick-anchored bun, was straight and fastidiously groomed. Her eyebrows, crazy semaphores that she sometimes pencils in like arrows, were conventionally shaped. And her eye shadow, which she applies in a rainbow-colored medley, was confined to two or three tints of blue. “The first thing I said to her,” recalled Ed Burstell, an executive at Bergdorf Goodman, where Ms. Rhodes had paid a sales call, “was, ‘Zandra, you’ve calmed it down.’ ”

headline: Thank God, This Will Only Get Worse
text: Stuart Stevens never imagined playing a sport without violence, and at one point swore to himself to “never take up any sports that fat people do well. Like golf.” Then, as he describes in "Thank God, This Will Only Get Worse," his essay for PLAY, a single shot of Nordic racing in his late-20s led him to obsessively pursue endurance sports. “But as you get older and life becomes more complicated, it’s easy to start questioning the value of spending huge chunks of your days going in what amounts to glorified circles,” he writes. “It’s an entirely rational epiphany and one that must, of course, be crushed immediately.”

headline: U.S. and Israel Sign Military Aid Deal
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 16 — Israel and the United States signed an agreement today that will give Israel $30 billion in military aid over the next decade. Officials called the aid a long-term investment in peace.

headline: Inquiry Threatens Ex-Leader of Securities Agency
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 — After operating for several decades at the highest levels of the intersection of Washington and the corporate world, Roderick M. Hills was someone whose advice was eagerly sought by companies under fire from federal authorities.

headline: Toy Makers Brace for a Chill in Sales
text: For toy makers, it is beginning to look as if it may be a rough Christmas.

headline: Schoeneweis Answers the Call for the Mets With a Lead in the Eighth
text: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15  Scott Schoeneweis encountered two surprises at PNC Park on Tuesday. The first came when he arrived at his locker to discover that his spikes did not make the trip from New York. That problem was remedied by his borrowing an extra pair from Oliver Pérez, whose size 11 Nikes were the exact model that Schoeneweis prefers.

headline: China: Production Pace Slows
text: China’s industrial production rose 18 percent in July, slowing for the first time in three months after reductions in export incentives. Output grew less than June’s 19.4 percent, the statistics bureau said. The slowdown is not likely to ease government concern that the economy may be overheating. “This is still a pretty robust number, highlighting the momentum of the Chinese economy supported by exports and retail demand,” said David Cohen, an economist at Action Economics in Singapore. It’s premature to speculate that the economy is slowing, Mr. Cohen said. Exports jumped 34.2 percent in July from a year earlier, the fastest pace in five months. Retail sales gained 16.4 percent, the biggest increase since May 2004 after adjusting for Lunar New Year distortions.

headline: More Jitters Over Credit; Markets Fall
text: Stocks fell sharply late yesterday afternoon, and one broad market index turned negative for the year as investors again questioned the economy’s ability to withstand financial shocks and higher borrowing costs.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. How can I make my new apartment feel older?

headline: Macy’s Beats Profit Estimates, but Lowers Earnings Forecast
text: Macy’s Inc., the department store chain, reported quarterly profit yesterday that exceeded analysts’ estimates but lowered its earnings forecast because of sluggish sales.

headline: Newcomer Chosen for Wi-Fi in 2 Counties
text: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y., Aug. 15  A $150 million plan to make wireless broadband available across Nassau and Suffolk Counties, covering 750 square miles and nearly three million residents, took a major step forward on Wednesday when Long Island officials chose a company for the project.

headline: New Home Construction at Lowest Level in  Decade
text: As more fallout from the mortgage market squeeze became apparent today, there was yet another sign that the worst of the trauma in the housing sector may not be over.

headline: This Summer, a Bumper Crop of Collars
text: A FASHION watcher might look back on the last decade and, in summation, tick off names like Hedi Slimane and Nicolas Ghesquiere and trends like the skinny suit. But even someone who claims not to follow fashion would have to have noticed how one look came to rule summertime men’s wear.

headline: Start Spearing the News
text: Perhaps you’ve seen Will Durst, the political humorist, doing sound-bite commentary on television, trying to riff on questions from some stiff anchor or talk-show host, and your reaction has been, “This guy’s kind of drab.” But that’s not the real Will Durst. The guy now cracking people up for 90 minutes at New World Stages in a sharp one-man show: that’s the real Will Durst.

headline: An American in the World Cup Is Dreaming Big
text: Whenever an American soccer team goes off to play in the World Cup, I receive eloquent letters from rugby aficionados, asking, “When are you going to write about us?”

headline: The Less-Than-Generous State
text: You would think that we were living in the lap of the Nanny State. One of the most puzzling facts of the political debate is how much traction Republicans still get from their calls to cut taxes and public spending, and how timorous Democrats are in arguing against them.

headline: The Router’s Fine Print
text: Q. Why does all the fine print on the newest, fastest network routers say “draft specification”? What does this mean if I want to buy a new router?

headline: Rove Steps Up His Attacks on Clinton’s Candidacy
text: Karl Rove intensified his attack on Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton Tuesday, saying she lacked the vision to be president while saying she was “so weak” on national security and support for the armed forces.

headline: My Dad, American Inventor
text: TOMMY HABEEB just wanted to be one of the new breed of involved dads: the hands-on guys who preside over bath time without creating a flood; the ones who return home from work early enough to crawl after their children toward the realm of make-believe. His ambitions did not include inventing the Water Bottle Nipple Adaptor.

headline: Forced to Pick a Major in High School
text: ENGLEWOOD, N.J. — Ninth graders often have trouble selecting what clothes to wear to school each morning or what to have for lunch. But starting this fall, freshmen at Dwight Morrow High School here in Bergen County must declare a major that will determine what electives they take for four years and be noted on their diplomas.

headline: An Adviser at the Edge of a Scandal Vows to Stay at Spitzer’s Right Hand
text: The top deputy to Gov. Eliot Spitzer said yesterday that he could remain effective in his job, even as some Democrats quietly question whether his continued role in the administration is hurting the governor.

headline: Economic Boom Fails to Generate Optimism in India
text: NEW DELHI, Aug. 15 — Prime Minister Manmohan Singh cautioned Indians against hubris in his annual Independence Day speech on Wednesday and promised a spate of antipoverty measures that hinted at the vulnerabilities facing his government and the nation.

headline: N.B.A. Referee Pleads Guilty to Gambling Charges
text: Tim Donaghy left the basketball court as a disgraced former N.B.A. referee in July and left a federal court room yesterday as an admitted criminal, a conspirator and a gambling addict.

headline: The Streets of Queens Where Rizzuto Played
text: When Phil Rizzuto was a boy in Glendale, Queens, it was rare to get your hands on an actual baseball. You played with Spaldeens wrapped in string, or flapping old cores patched with adhesive tape, and if the ball rolled into the sewer the boys went down after it.

headline: Jose Padilla Convicted on All Counts in Terror Trial
text: MIAMI, Aug. 16 — In a major victory for the Bush administration, a federal jury here found Jose Padilla guilty on terrorism conspiracy charges Thursday after little more than a day of deliberations.

headline: Near Misses on Ground Prompt New Use of Cockpit Simulators
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  In a step underscoring that much of the risk of air travel occurs on the ground, airlines have agreed to use their cockpit simulators to train pilots to taxi, the Federal Aviation Administration said Wednesday.

headline: Bluetooth and the End of Audio Wiring
text: Here at the Pogue Purely Hypothetical High-Tech Mutual Fund, we recognize that although you can’t predict the future of technology, a few calls are easy to make. Right now, for example, there are certain industries we avoid investing in — like analog recording tape, landline telephone service and wires.

headline: CIRCUITS: A Way to See DVDs in (Almost) High Definition, Without Choosing a Format
text: No one knows when the battle between the HD-DVD and Blu-ray video formats will end, but what’s an early adopter to do without ending up like the poor folks who bought Betamax? Until one format is the clear winner, you could try improving the video from your current DVDs instead.

headline: Long-Studied Giant Star Displays Huge Cometlike Tail
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 — Astronomers have discovered that a giant star that has been studied for centuries is streaking across the sky trailing an enormous, cometlike tail.

headline: Jenna Bush Is Engaged
text: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 16 — President Bush, who has been the sole male in his nuclear family with the exception, perhaps, of his dog Barney, will finally have a son-in-law.

headline: Newark: Shooting Victim Dies
text: A man who had been shot died about 8:30 last night after the car he was driving crashed into a fence at Clinton and Seymour Avenues in Newark, the Newark police said. His car also hit two pedestrians, whose conditions were not released. The man, whose identity was not released, was dead when the police arrived. His cause of death had yet to be determined.

headline: Bigger. Stronger. Better?
text: In America, the next generation of women soccer players move in virtual anonymity, not yet household names like Hamm and Foudy, members of the team that enthralled the country with their play in the 1999 World Cup. That doesn’t mean the younger players are slouches. In this issue’s “The Main Event,” Jeré Longman reports that the U.S. team heading to China for next month’s World Cup "is deeper, more of a threat to score from midfield and more sophisticated in a soccer sense than the ’99 team.” But until the team wins a World Cup, is it possible to call it the best U.S. squad ever?

headline: Agilent Shares Drop on Forecast
text: Shares of Agilent Technologies, the maker of scientific testing equipment, fell in trading yesterday in New York after slowing demand in Asia reduced the company’s sales and profit forecasts.

headline: Before Halloween, This Witch Is Closed for the Season
text: MONTAUK, N.Y.

headline: Finds a Home
text: Beaufort Books, a small publisher in New York, will publish “If I Did It,” the controversial account by O. J. Simpson, below, of the slaying of his ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ronald Goldman, The Associated Press reported. HarperCollins, the original publisher, had dropped the book because of public outrage. Sharlene Martin of Martin Literary Management in Los Angeles announced the deal, but Denise Brown, Nicole Brown Simpson’s sister, immediately called for a boycott of the work. The book will consist of Mr. Simpson’s original manuscript with commentary, said Michael Wright, a spokesman for Ms. Martin. The Goldmans, the publisher and Ms. Martin will contribute portions of the sales proceeds to the newly formed Ron Goldman Foundation for Justice to help victims of violent crime, Mr. Wright said. Last month a federal bankruptcy judge awarded rights to the book to Mr. Goldman’s family to help satisfy a $38 million wrongful-death judgment against Mr. Simpson.

headline: A Connecticut Hillside of Feisty Beauties
text: SOUTH KENT, Conn.

headline: Dramatic Warning to a Candidate
text: The blond helmet of hair is unmistakable. So, too, are the black pants, the peach-colored vest and the tiny cross dangling from her neck. And then there are the familiar flashes of sarcasm and self-righteousness, of practicality and compassion, and the rejoinders about Republicans like this bit of dialogue:

headline: Muslim Groups Oppose a List of ‘Co-Conspirators’
text: Two prominent Muslim American organizations took steps yesterday to reverse what they called a Justice Department effort to smear the entire Muslim community by naming some of its largest organizations as unindicted co-conspirators in a Texas terrorism trial.

headline: For Couples, a Matter of Give and Take
text: ADAM FORD, mild-mannered and trim at 170 pounds, doesn’t feel odd hitting his petite wife. How else will she learn to instinctively duck or perfect her combinations?

headline: Russia: Sale of Some Yukos Assets
text: The Russian court-appointed managers of Yukos, the oil company, sold its contested overseas assets at a bankruptcy auction for $306 million, taking another step toward the final dismantling of Yukos. As in previous sales, the property went to a little-known company for far less than its nominal value The buyer was a Russian real estate firm, Monte-Valle, which is owned by an American businessman, Stephen Lynch, who has worked in Russia for more than 10 years. Most of the oil fields, machinery and other Yukos assets inside Russia have already been sold. Outside of Russia, what remains of Yukos, once the country’s largest private company, is consolidated in a Netherlands-registered foundation that Yukos shareholders say controls roughly 2 billion euros ($2.7 billion) in cash and equities; the foundation is under the supervision of a Dutch bankruptcy court. The sale sets the stage for a complex and high-stakes legal struggle in the Netherlands between Mr. Lynch and former Yukos shareholders, who argue that the Russian bankruptcy process is illegitimate.

headline: CARE Turns Down Federal Funds for Food Aid
text: MALELA, Kenya — CARE, one of the world’s biggest charities, is walking away from some $45 million a year in federal financing, saying American food aid is not only plagued with inefficiencies, but also may hurt some of the very poor people it aims to help.

headline: Facing the Multiple Risks of Newer, Deeper Mines
text: As hope dims for the six miners trapped by a coal mine collapse in central Utah, engineers and seismologists are grappling with the broader implications of the Crandall Canyon Mine accident and the interplay of risks they say are mounting in the newer, deeper generation of coal mines, especially in the West.

headline: Floyd Landis, the Outcast
text: In her profile of Floyd Landis, "The Outcast," in the latest issue of PLAY, Sara Corbett paints a poignant picture of the cyclist, who lives in limbo while awaiting a ruling from the arbitration panel that is reviewing his doping case from last year’s Tour de France. Corbett answered a few of our questions about what she found in her reporting.

headline: Wiring the Frog, or Personal Tales From the Electronic Present
text: A year and a half ago, I began an editorial essay like this one with these words: “I do not own a BlackBerry or a pager. I don’t chat or instant-message or text-message. My cellphone could connect to the Web if I let it, but I don’t.” The essay went on to talk about the addiction of e-mail, as if that were somehow a racy new form of interhuman conversation. What an idiot.

headline: On Itunes
text: All of John Lennon’s solo albums are available on iTunes for the first time, after Yoko Ono, Lennon’s widow, approved a deal, BBC News reported yesterday. Many of the recordings had already been on sale through other digital stores, but “Lennon Legend” and “Acoustic” were not legally available online. The deal, which may pave the way for the entire Beatles catalog to appear online, follows a similar one with Paul McCartney in May.

headline: Astor’s Guardians Challenge Her Later Wills, Citing Incompetency
text: The court-appointed guardians of Brooke Astor have filed legal papers saying that the will she signed in 1997 should be the valid one. They argue that she was not mentally competent or was unduly influenced when she signed her last will in 2002 and several amendments to it over the following two years, according to people who have been briefed on the situation.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: Expanding a Collection

headline: Big Holder Considers Buyout of Charter
text: The billionaire Paul G. Allen may try to buy or recapitalize Charter Communications, the cable company he controls, according to a regulatory filing yesterday.

headline: Shuttle Crew Is Told to Study for Repairs, as NASA Wavers
text: In a change of plans, astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour will spend today studying plans for conducting a repair of the shuttle.
Manhattan

headline: Max Roach, a Founder of Modern Jazz, Dies at 83
text: Max Roach, a founder of modern jazz who rewrote the rules of drumming in the 1940’s and spent the rest of his career breaking musical barriers and defying listeners’ expectations, died early today in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Sheffield Stands Behind His Words
text: Gary Sheffield looked relaxed and in his environment. He wore a Detroit Tigers T-shirt, he crossed his arms and stood in front of his locker in Cleveland like a preacher by his pulpit. The words kept flowing, more opinions, more statements, more Sheffield.

headline: CIRCUITS: A Laptop That Lets Students Take Notes Two Ways
text: Parents and students seeking a back-to-school computer may want to consider a tablet PC. These convertible devices, which allow switching from keyboard to pen input, are ideal for note-taking.

headline: An Actor Really Sells His Material
text: NEW ORLEANS

headline: Albany: Questions on Aid Package
text: Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, left, a Westchester County Democrat, said yesterday that the terms of an aid package that federal officials offered this week for broad traffic reduction measures in New York City fall short of what is required under state law. Mr. Brodsky, who wrote an Assembly report critical of the plan, wrote a letter to Transportation Secretary Mary E. Peters yesterday asking for a clarification of the terms of the $354 million package. The aid is contingent on the state’s approval of a pilot program to carry out Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s most controversial proposal, which would charge drivers for entering the most congested parts of Manhattan on weekdays. Mr. Brodsky said a new state law that sets up a commission to study the mayor’s plan required a firm commitment of $200 million from federal officials by October. His comments and letter underscored continuing opposition in the Democrat-led Assembly. A spokesman for Speaker Sheldon Silver, who has expressed concerns about the plan, had no comment.

headline: Parents Warned Cough Medicines Imperil Infants
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 — Hoping to halt the growing number of injuries to infants and toddlers, the Food and Drug Administration issued an advisory Wednesday warning parents never to give cough and cold medicines to children under the age of 2 unless instructed to do so by a doctor.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: The Genius of ‘Baby Einstein’
text: Alexandria, Va.

headline: Bruce Wolmer, Editor and Art World Explainer, Dies at  59
text: Bruce Wolmer, the longtime editor and publisher of Art & Auction magazine and an expert on the heavily moneyed byways of the international art world, died in New York on Saturday. He was 59 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Bronx: E.M.S. to Replace Firehouse
text: A new emergency medical station will replace an old firehouse in Woodlawn that was closed last year because of structural problems, city officials said yesterday. Firefighters from Ladder Company 39 moved from their station at 243 East 233rd Street in June 2006 because of the building’s poor condition, city officials said. The ladder company is now based about a mile away, sharing quarters with Engine Company 63. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city would begin construction of a new station for emergency medical workers on the site in the fall of 2008. The new $12.4 million station will allow ambulances that are now based at three stations to operate out of one.

headline: Virus Spreading Alarm and Pig Disease in China
text: CHENGDU, China, Aug. 9 — A highly infectious swine virus is sweeping China’s pig population, driving up pork prices and creating fears of a global pandemic among domesticated pigs.

headline: China Cracks Down on News Media as Party Congress Nears
text: HONG KONG, Aug. 15 — China’s government said Wednesday that it was cracking down on “false news reports, unauthorized publications and bogus journalists.”

headline: Tibetans Turn Festival Into Mute Protest Against China
text: GYEGU, China — With the polish of veteran television M.C.’s, the slick, Chinese-speaking announcers used every trick in the book to try to get a largely Tibetan crowd of a few hundred people involved in the singing and dancing on stage.

headline: Offerman Charged With Assault After Bat-Wielding Incident in Minors
text: For 15 years, José Offerman played for seven major league teams, primarily as an infielder, earning as much as $6.75 million in 2001 and in 2002. Since May, he has been playing for the Long Island Ducks of the independent Atlantic League, earning less than $4,000 a month and hoping that at age 38 he could get back to the big leagues.

headline: Democratic Advisers Take Posts in Group Opposing Wal-Mart
text: WakeUpWalMart.com, a union-backed group that has waged an aggressive campaign against Wal-Mart, the nation’s largest retailer, will today name several Democratic political strategists as its new leaders and introduce a fresh round of ads.

headline: U.S. Defends Surveillance to 3 Skeptical Judges
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 — Three federal appeals court judges hearing challenges to the National Security Agency’s surveillance programs appeared skeptical of and sometimes hostile to the Bush administration’s central argument Wednesday: that national security concerns require that the lawsuits be dismissed.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Chinese in Africa (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Dock That Links an iPod to the Devices That Entertain You at Home
text: Hooking an iPod to a stereo is easy — unless you still want to use a remote and navigate using the iPod menus. For that you will need something like the Denon ASD-3W. This dock lets users attach an iPod to a sound system, operate the iPod with a remote and see its menus on a TV screen. For good measure, it will also let you connect your computer to the stereo wirelessly and listen to Internet radio.

headline: Coming This Weekend: The Latest Issue of PLAY
text: The September issue of PLAY comes out this Sunday, distributed inside The New York Times and online at nytimes.com/playmagazine. In this issue of the newsletter, a little peak at what you’ll find.

headline: The Legacy of the Raj: Adrift in Two Cultures
text: “As far as the world’s concerned, we’re not here, never were,” says Owen Monroe, the hero of Glen Duncan’s new novel “The Bloodstone Papers.” Owen is an Anglo-Indian of mixed Indian and European descent. He’s a disaffected legacy of colonialism, a “Half-caste,” as he puts it, a “Mongrel,” a “Pariah,” a “Cheechee,” a “Chutney Mary.” The son of immigrant parents, Owen lives in London where he’s a part-time college professor and pornographer writing under the delightful name of Millicent Nash.

headline: Backlash Over Book on Policy for Israel
text: “The Israel Lobby and U.S. Foreign Policy” is not even in bookstores, but already anxieties have surfaced about the backlash it is stirring, with several institutions backing away from holding events with the authors.

headline: Pools Conceived to Make a Splash
text: NICOLE SASSAMAN, a 36-year-old designer and property developer, devoted three years to building the swimming pool of her dreams at her home in the Hollywood Hills. A 25-foot expanse of glittering blue and green glass tile from Italy, the pool, completed last year, cantilevers out from a steep hillside and hugs the 5,500-square-foot house — once Greta Garbo’s — so closely that the house appears to float on a sliver of blue. In the evening, the twinkling cityscape of Los Angeles is reflected in the water, which seems to drop off into the hills below.

headline: A Cellphone for Those With a Modest Need to Send Messages
text: The Samsung Blast is part of a new breed of cellphones: messaging phones. Like the iPhone and the Helio Ocean, these phones aren’t aimed at the dedicated smartphone user or BlackBerry-loving business user. They are intended for people who need a little e-mail, a little instant messaging and not much else.

headline: Study Suggests That a Need for Physical Perfection May Reveal Emotional Flaws
text: IN the first season of the television drama “Nip/Tuck,” two plastic surgeons named Dr. Sean McNamara and Dr. Christian Troy hire a staff psychologist to determine whether their patients are psychologically equipped to handle cosmetic procedures. In one episode, the psychologist denies treatment to a severely depressed patient who later commits suicide.

headline: U.S. Stocks Open Lower After Major Asian Sell-Off
text: Stocks opened sharply lower on Wall Street today after a sell-off in Asia and heavy losses in Europe, the latest reverberations of the credit crunch stemming from the reversals in the American mortgage market.

headline: Astronomers Find Comet-Like Tail on Giant Star
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 — Astronomers have discovered that a giant star they have studied for centuries is streaking across the sky trailing an enormous, comet-like tail.

headline: 2 Ratings Services Downgrade Nestlé
text: Nestlé, one of the world’s largest food companies, was stripped of its AAA rating yesterday by Fitch Ratings and Moody’s Investors Service.

headline: Let’s Say You Are Not a Dreamgirl
text: SURELY the thousands of concertgoers who have seen Beyoncé on stage in a nude body-hugging gown that momentarily gives the impression that she is naked have wondered, “How can I get that look at home?”

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: New York Film Festival Lineup

headline: Creating a Village to Foster a Child
text: EASTHAMPTON, Mass.

headline: Must Be the Season of the Fred
text: August. Everybody but you is out of town. Congress is in recess. The Iraqi Parliament, of course, is long gone. You-know-who is in Texas. It’s 107 degrees in Crawford, but that brush wants cutting.

headline: New York Film Festival Lineup
text: “Persepolis,” an animated work based on Marjane Satrapi’s graphic novel about her childhood in Iran during the Islamic revolution (a scene from the film is above), will be the closing-night film at the 45th New York Film Festival. This year, the festival, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, runs from Sept. 28 to Oct. 14 and is to include 28 premieres. The previously announced opening-night and centerpiece selections are “The Darjeeling Limited,” by Wes Anderson, and “No Country for Old Men,” by Joel and Ethan Coen. New American films by Noah Baumbach, Gus Van Sant, Todd Haynes and Sidney Lumet will be shown, as will international productions by Julian Schnabel and Abel Ferrara. The directors Brian De Palma, John Landis and Ira Sachs will make their festival debuts. Among the foreign films are: “The Orphanage,” by Juan Antonio Bayona; “A Girl Cut in Two,” by Claude Chabrol; and “The Flight of the Red Balloon,” by Hou Hsiao-hsien. Five older films will be included, among them the long-awaited “definitive cut” of “Blade Runner” by Ridley Scott. Screenings will take place at the Frederick P. Rose Hall, home of Jazz at Lincoln Center, and other sites. For information: filmlinc.com.

headline: German Police Link 6 Dead Men to an Italian Mob Feud
text: FRANKFURT, Aug. 15 — A bitter feud between rival southern Italian crime families erupted on the streets of a northern German city early Wednesday morning, as the police in Duisburg found the bullet-riddled bodies of five Italian men in two vehicles.

headline: New York City Police Report Explores Homegrown Terrorism
text: Understanding how seemingly ordinary people become radicalized and hatch homegrown terror plots is essential for law enforcement officials in the United States and abroad to stay one step ahead, a study released yesterday by the New York Police Department concluded.

headline: Q: Who Is the Real Face of Plastic Surgery?
text: IT was the pale green and pink striped bikini that did it.

headline: Diehl Has No Place to Hide at Left Tackle
text: ALBANY, Aug. 15  A proficient offensive line has been compared to a clenched fist, its five pieces working together to deliver one fierce blow. But offensive lines are not always proficient, and if there is one position in the Giants’ mostly anonymous group that can stick out like a sore thumb, it is left tackle.

headline: Movements That Seduce, Right Down to a Walk Across a Stage
text: Trisha Brown has said she started dancing to music because she couldn’t handle hearing audiences coughing anymore. Had her troupe performed at the Damrosch Park Bandshell in silence on Tuesday, you have to wonder what she would have made of the muttering and sighing as people tried to see around those strolling through.

headline: The Big Melt
text: If we learned that Al Qaeda was secretly developing a new terrorist technique that could disrupt water supplies around the globe, force tens of millions from their homes and potentially endanger our entire planet, we would be aroused into a frenzy and deploy every possible asset to neutralize the threat.

headline: Iraq Toll at 250 in the Deadliest Attack of the War
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 15 — The toll in a horrific quadruple bombing in an area of mud and stone houses in the remote northern desert on Tuesday evening reached at least 250 dead and 350 wounded, several local officials said Wednesday, making it the deadliest coordinated attack since the American-led invasion of Iraq in 2003.

headline: A Mayor Stands by His Comments, and Gay Advocates Stand Against Him
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 15 — The uproar began last month, when Mayor Jim Naugle said that installing a single-occupancy restroom on a local beach could deter “homosexual activity.”

headline: Mexico: Northbound Migrants Stranded
text: At least 3,000 Central American migrants remained stranded along railroad lines in southern Mexico after an American train operator shut down its operations there, officials said. For decades, immigrants from Guatemala have crossed a river into southern Mexico and hopped freight trains going north, but the rail operator, Genessee and Wyoming Inc., based in Connecticut, decided last month to cease its operations. Now at least 2,500 people are camped out along the tracks in Tenosique, in Tabasco State, and hundreds more are stranded in Arriaga, in Chiapas. They have been waiting in vain for more than 18 days for a train that will no longer arrive. Guatemalan consular officials in Tabasco say hundreds of migrants have decided to continue their journey on foot and walk more than 200 miles to the next terminus, in Villahermosa. The same was true in Chiapas, with hundreds trying to walk to Oaxaca State, according to church officials who run shelters there.

headline: Above the Clouds, It’s Almost Heaven, Costa Rica
text: CERRO DE LA MUERTE, Costa Rica — It had been raining for two weeks in San José, Costa Rica, when I heard from Peter Gorinsky. We had planned to go fishing along the country’s Caribbean coast, but the forecast was hopeless.

headline: Port Authority Makes Deal to Put TVs in PATH Trains
text: If nothing else, the rainstorm last week that left millions of commuters in the dark about the whereabouts of their trains and buses reinforced the idea that riders can never have too much information.

headline: The Osmonds Rock On
text: The Osmond Brothers joined with their siblings Donny, Marie and Jimmy to tape a 50th-anniversary reunion show this week to be shown on PBS next year, The Associated Press reported yesterday. A gathering of seven Osmonds onstage has not occurred in more than 20 years. The PBS concert celebrates the anniversary of the founding of the original Osmond Brothers barbershop quartet — with Alan, Wayne, Merrill and Jay Osmond — in 1957. The Osmonds have recorded 142 albums and sold 100 million copies.

headline: Rizzuto’s Fans Post Tributes and Recount Funny Moments
text: To his fans, Phil Rizzuto was a warm-hearted personality who charmed them during chance encounters, kept them company in their living rooms and on their picnics, and elicited smiles with his idiosyncratic one-liners, loopy conversations, fear of lightning and love of cannolis.

headline: Russia: Student Held Over Execution Video
text: The police arrested a student they said had confessed to posting on the Internet a grisly video of two young men apparently being executed in front of a Nazi flag. The student, who the authorities said had turned himself in, was in custody in the southwestern city of Maikop and under investigation for inciting racial hatred. The police said that it did not appear that he was involved in making the video or the gruesome acts it showed. The video, which includes images of a man being beheaded, began circulating on Sunday and has called attention to racism and neo-fascism in Russia. An introduction to the video said one victim was from Tajikistan and the other from Dagestan.

headline: Bridge Failure Can’t Fend Off Usual Politics
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 15 — It took all of two weeks for the political unity brought on by a deadly bridge collapse here to fall apart.

headline: No. 1 With a Bullet (or, Rather, an Apocalyptic Blast)
text: The pop singer Dionne Warwick and the paranoid, drug-fueled science-fiction writer Philip K. Dick are not often mentioned in the same sentence or even the same chapter.

headline: Cracking Open a Spreadsheet
text: Q. My desktop computer runs Microsoft Windows XP Home Edition — which includes Microsoft Works Spreadsheet — but I cannot open Excel spreadsheets. How can I open them?

headline: At 18, Blogging His Way Into Elite Social Scene
text: In the movie version of his life, James Kurisunkal would already have a book deal and a clothing allowance by now. As it stands, the evening of July 11 will certainly suffice as the high point of his first summer in New York.

headline: Mixed Signals: Driving to Work as a Tax Break
text: They have made it a priority at the United States Department of Transportation: Get people out of their cars.

headline: Notes Detail Visit to Ashcroft’s Hospital Room
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 — John Ashcroft was “barely articulate,” “feeble” and “clearly stressed” as he sat in a hospital room chair in March 2004 when top White House aides unsuccessfully tried to persuade him, as the Attorney General, to sign an extension for warrantless domestic eavesdropping on Americans, according to notes made by Robert S. Mueller III, the director of the F.B.I.

headline: Russia: Bombed Rail Line Reopened
text: Russia restored full rail service on the line between Moscow and St. Petersburg, which had been suspended after a bomb derailed a passenger train on Monday. More than 60 people were injured. The authorities continued to investigate, saying they had made sketches of two suspects seen near the tracks before the bomb, described as a homemade device, exploded under the locomotive. Various theories were being explored, the authorities said, including that Chechen separatists or ultranationalists were involved.

headline: John Wallowitch, Singer and Songwriter, Dies at 81
text: John Wallowitch, a cabaret singer and prolific songwriter who was a colorful figure in the New York cabaret world for more than 40 years, died yesterday in the Bronx. He was 81.

headline: Mets Rally in the Ninth Inning, Then Narrowly Escape With a Victory
text: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15  One of the more popular phrases uttered within the Mets’ clubhouse this season is “if only.” As in, if only the Mets had played more consistently, they could be romping, not plodding, toward a division title. If only the Braves or Phillies had done the same, the Mets know they could be toiling behind either team.

headline: Bank to Pay $4.5 Million to Settle Suit Over Cards
text: A bank has agreed to pay $4.5 million to settle a claim by the New York State attorney general that it deceptively marketed credit cards to people with bad credit ratings.

headline: Consumer Prices Ease, Fed Views Inflation as Risk
text: The increase in consumer prices eased slightly last month, continuing a trend of gradual moderation, the government said yesterday. But long-term readings on inflation suggested that the Federal Reserve is unlikely to lower its guard.

headline: They’re a Little Bit Country, She’s a Little Bit Rock ’n’ Roll
text: Some pop alliances make sense well in advance. Others make no sense even after the fact. Then there is the current collaboration between Nickel Creek, the sweet-tempered alternative bluegrass group, and Fiona Apple, the powerfully saturnine singer-songwriter.

headline: Footnotes
text: The Off Broadway theater Playwrights Horizons will sell a limited number of $5 tickets by lottery to the first preview performances of all its productions, Playbill reported. “Live for Five,” as the program is called, will begin with the first show of the season, “100 Saints You Should Know,” by Kate Fodor. Ticket requests are being accepted on the theater’s Web site (playwrightshorizons.org). ... Manhattan Theater Club will revive William Inge’s “Come Back, Little Sheba,” to be directed by Michael Pressman and star S. Epatha Merkerson as Lola, the former beauty queen trapped in a lonely marriage. The production is to begin previews at the Biltmore Theater on Jan. 3 and open on Jan. 24. ... Regis Philbin will celebrate his morning show’s 20th anniversary in national syndication on Sept. 14, and Kathie Lee Gifford, his former co-host, will be on hand.

headline: A Hotel Is Back, Much Changed, but Still a Hotel
text: Is every building in Manhattan destined to be turned into a luxury condominium?

headline: A New Chrysler and a New Marketer
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Aug. 15 — From the executive suite to showroom lots, Chrysler L.L.C. is wasting no time in trying to persuade customers that it has come out from under the wing of its former German owners.

headline: Obama and Clinton Find Pluses in Poll
text: Senator Barack Obama has built his campaign around the idea that he is a transformational candidate and is more likely to bring change to the country than Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. And a new CBS News poll suggests that could be a fruitful line of argument for him.

headline: Trenton: Accord on Tracing Guns
text: Police departments in New Jersey will be able to trace gun ownership almost instantly through a federal-state agreement announced yesterday. The agreement provides the New Jersey State Police with round-the-clock access to e-Trace, a nationwide computer database of firearms purchases operated by the United States Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. The agreement, which is meant to help the police identify sources of illegal weapons, calls for each police department in the state to send gun-tracing information to the database. Just under a third of the state’s police departments had submitted tracing information to e-Trace, and it was not readily available to the authorities in other jurisdictions. Last year, nearly 5,000 people in New Jersey were arrested for possessing illegal firearms.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8:30 P.M. (WAPA America) PUERTO RICO NATIONAL BASKETBALL TOURNAMENT In this pre-Olympic tournament broadcast live over three nights from San Juan, the Puerto Rico national basketball team will face off against teams from Canada (tonight), Brazil (tomorrow) and Argentina (Saturday), including 12 N.B.A. players representing their home countries. (Above, Joel Jones of Puerto Rico.) The games will be broadcast on DirecTV (Channel 414). In 2004 Puerto Rico defeated the United States team in Athens in the most lopsided basketball loss in Olympic history. This year Puerto Rico advanced to the finals of the Pan American games before losing to Brazil.

headline: Yankees Reach Deal With Top Pick
text: The Yankees and their first-round pick in this year’s draft, the right-hander Andrew Brackman, reached agreement on a contract yesterday, hours before the Yankees would have lost his rights.

headline: Just Live, Baby!
text: "No owner inhabits a sports franchise as thoroughly" as Al Davis, reports Bryan Curtis in his profile of the enigmatic owner of the Oakland Raiders, "Just Live, Baby!" For four decades, with quick offensive strikes, colorful players and muscular catchphrases, Davis led the most successful team in football. The league has caught up with him in recent years, and the Raiders -- like his 78-year-old body -- are in grim condition. “Davis may be able to emerge every now and then to declare that reports of his death are greatly exaggerated,” Curtis writes. “But Davis’s personality-driven football is dead.”

headline: Earthquake in Peru Kills Hundreds
text: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 16 — A powerful earthquake shook Peru Wednesday night, killing at least 437 people, Civil Defense authorities said today. Another 1,350 were injured, according to Peru’s Health Ministry.

headline: A Young Big Man Shoots Like a Little Guy
text: Renardo Sidney may not be a household name, but he is well on his way to becoming one. The hype machine is already at work. Some think he could be the next high school player with a LeBron James-type impact on the National Basketball Association.

headline: New Owner to Combine Men’s Magazines
text: Stuff, one of the biggest of the “lad” magazines that took off in the 1990s, is being stuffed into its bigger sibling, Maxim, the publications’ new owners announced yesterday.

headline: Tip of the Week: How to Make Your Own CD Covers
text: TIP OF THE WEEK: If you make your own party-mix CDs with iTunes, you can use the program’s print options to create a stylish song list for the jewel case.

headline: Bolivia: Coca Leaves Predict Castro Recovery
text: A consultation of coca leaves by Aymara Indian shamans presages the recovery of Fidel Castro, according to Cuba’s ambassador to Bolivia. “The Comandante is enjoying a recovery,” Rafael Dausá, the ambassador, told Bolivia’s state news agency after attending the ceremony in El Alto, the heavily indigenous city near the capital, La Paz. Pointing to Cuba’s warming ties to Bolivia, as the leftist president, Evo Morales, settles into his second year in power, Mr. Dausá said, “Being in Bolivia today means being in the leading trench in the anti-imperialist struggle in Latin America.” Bolivia and Cuba, together with Venezuela, have forged a political and economic alliance called the Bolivarian Alternative of the Americas.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about financial disclosures filed with the Federal Election Commission by Mitt Romney, a Republican presidential candidate, misstated the year he ran successfully for governor of Massachusetts. It was 2002, not 1999. (Go to Article)

headline: 3 Germans and a Briton Die in Attacks in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 15  A roadside bomb killed three German police officers and wounded another on the outskirts of Kabul on Wednesday morning, German officials said. A Briton working for a private security firm was shot dead in Kabul in the afternoon.

headline: Virginia Tech Increases Aid to Victims
text: Families of the Virginia Tech students and faculty members shot to death by a student in April will receive more compensation than originally planned, university officials announced yesterday.

headline: After Sales Setback, Amgen Moves to Cut Jobs and Capital Expenses
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 — The biotechnology giant Amgen announced the first major layoffs in its heretofore charmed history Wednesday as it sought to cope with sliding sales of the anemia drug Aranesp, its biggest selling product.

headline: American Businessman Buys Contested Yukos Assets
text: The Russian court-appointed managers of Yukos sold its contested overseas assets at a bankruptcy auction for $306 million, taking another step toward the final dismantling of the oil company.

text: Stuff, one of the biggest of the “lad” magazines that took off in the 1990s, is being stuffed into its bigger sibling, Maxim, the publications’ new owners confirmed Wednesday.

headline: Allen Considers Charter Buyout
text: The billionaire Paul G. Allen may try to buy or recapitalize Charter Communications, the cable company he controls, according to a regulatory filing Wednesday.

headline: Alcoa Hires Former Siemens C.E.O.
text: The aluminum company Alcoa named Klaus Kleinfeld, the former chief executive of Siemens, president and chief operating officer Wednesday, and said he would most likely take over as chief executive when Alain J. P. Belda retired.

headline: Take-Two Recieves Wells Notice from S.E.C.
text: The video game maker Take-Two Interactive said Wednesday that it might face civil charges and fines from the Securities and Exchange Commission for backdating stock options.

headline: Bank to Pay $4.5 Million to Settle Credit Card Suit
text: First Premier Bank has agreed to pay $4.5 million to settle a claim by the New York State attorney general that it deceptively marketed credit cards to people with bad credit ratings.

text: From the executive suite to showroom lots, Chrysler is wasting no time in trying to convince customers that it has come out from under the wing of its former German owners.

headline: Midwest’s Board to Pick Between Bidders
text: Midwest Air Group‘s board of directors will meet Thursday to consider options for a sale, including a sweetened offer by AirTran Holdings, which revived its bid just as Midwest was about to finalize another deal.

headline: Countrywide’s Big Credit Draw Fuels Market Fears
text: Stocks fell sharply Wednesday in the United States, set off by worries that Countrywide Financial, the largest mortgage lender in the nation, could face bankruptcy if liquidity worsens after a Merrill Lynch analyst flagged that possibility. The mood grew even more grim Thursday morning, when the lender said it tapped its entire $11.5 billion credit line to boost cash on hand.

headline: Thomas & Betts to Buy Lamson & Sessions
text: Thomas & Betts, which makes electrical connectors and components, said late Wednesday it is buying a Cleveland-based supplier, Lamson & Sessions, for about $426.6 million.

A new CBS News poll indicates that the distinction they are trying to make is sticking in the minds of voters. The Times’s Katharine Q. Seelye takes a look at the results:

headline: Mitsubishi Looks Abroad for Expansion
text: The Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Japan’s largest bank, would consider buying a commercial bank in the United States or Europe to expand its international operations, a senior executive said on Thursday.

headline: Credit Suisse Chief Expects Credit Crunch to Ease
text: Credit Suisse‘s chief executive, Brady Dougan, weighed in on several issues in a video interview this week with The Financial Times, including the recent turmoil in the credit markets that has rattled stocks and hurt investment banks’ profits.

headline: Apple Takes a Step Back With iMovie ’08
text: Last week, Apple released a new version of its iLife suite—its $80 package containing iPhoto, iMovie, iWeb and GarageBand. The suite also comes preinstalled on every new Mac.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
text: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Kraft Said to Be Shopping Post Cereal Business
text: Kraft Foods is in the early stages of looking for a buyer for its Post cereals business, maker of the Grape Nuts and Shredded Wheat brands, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Schumer May Propose Partnership-Tax Bill
text: Charles Schumer, the Democratic senator from New York, is preparing legislation that would raise tax rates for partnerships in all industries, and not just in the private equity business. A spokesman said this approach would be “fairer” than current proposals being considered in Congress.

headline: Morning Buzz: A Tax Break for Parking, High School Majors, Astor Will Dispute, and More
text: The United States Department of Transportation doled out $848 million in grants this week to mitigate traffic and reduce congestion in five cities, including New York. But as William Neuman points out, the government still seems to be sending mixed signals about driving to work. Nearly 400,000 commuters nationwide — about half of them in the New York City area — take advantage of a federal tax provision that allows them to use up to $215 a month in pre-tax wages to pay for their parking at work.(More than two million people around the country take advantage of a similar program that allows them to use pre-tax income to pay for transit expenses, but that benefit is capped at $110 a month.)

headline: Notes on the News: Mayhem Moment
text: Mayhem is always in the mix in the morning news, but today it’s downright dominating. The lede story on many major news sites is the 7.9-magnitude earthquake centered near the capital of Peru. Initial reports from the region signal a death toll measured in the hundreds, such as this account from the mayor of Pisco reported by The Associated Press:

headline: Translation of the Document
text: The following is a translation of what appears to be a memo under the letterhead of the Committee for National Security, the Kazakh intelligence service, to President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev outlining steps agents took in the 2005 presidential elections to influence the judgments of international election observers and public opinion. The document was passed to European diplomats this summer from a source with connections to Kazakh intelligence. Its authenticity could not be determined, and a Kazakh diplomat in Washington called it a "fake." The document was translated by a diplomat in Europe.

headline: Deutsche Bank Demolition
text: What was the New York base of Deutsche Bank on Sept. 11, 2001, when it was badly damaged by debris from the World Trade Center, is now being painstakingly dismantled.

headline: Big Mama: The New Vogue
text: The September Vogue landed on my desk, or rather, on the floor. It came in a freight box. It’s very fat: 840 pages. Sienna Miller is on the cover of this super-duper issue, photographed by Mario Testino in Rome during the Valentino festivities. Though I can’t comprehend her appeal, apart from an American pixy-sportiness, she looks great in the clothes, mostly feathered things. My favorite fashion piece is Grace Coddington’s revisit with Kiki de Montparnasse and French café society in the ’20s and ’30s, photographed by Meisel. The clothes are right this season for a Jazz Age revue, especially Galliano’s and Chanel’s. (And perfect timing for “Making It New: The Art and Style of Sara and Gerald Murphy,” a great collection of essays and photographs of the period from University of California Press.)

headline: In Sickness and in Health?
text: After an off-season of bad news about concussions in football, the N.F.L. this week approved guidelines to help monitor and manage concussions among active players. What should the league’s responsibility be for the health of former players?

headline: New Jersey Releases Data on School Failures
text: The number of New Jersey schools that failed to meet the standards of the federal No Child Left Behind law fell in 2007, as many students managed to increase their scores on achievement tests, according to data the state is releasing today.

headline: Rankin v. McDermid
text: Two of Britain’s best-known (and most gifted) crime writers, Ian Rankin and Val McDermid, are battling, the Times of London reports, over this comment, which Rankin made in an interview last year: “The people writing the most graphic novels today are women. They are mostly lesbians as well, which I find interesting.”

headline: 10 Firms Bail Out Canada’s Commercial Paper Market
text: Amid fears of a spreading crisis in Canada’s debt market, 10 firms, including Quebec’s pension fund, said Thursday that they had agreed to bail out the 40 billion Canadian dollars ($37.4 billion) market for third-party asset-backed commercial paper. All told, the group, led by Caisse de Depot et Placement, will hold about two-thirds of the Canadian market for such commercial paper.

headline: Op n for Bus n  s
text: Like a ruby beacon piercing the night along upper Broadway, the neon sign atop the HOTEL EM I E on West 63rd Street seems to proclaim that it is once again open to guests, after being closed more than three years.

Beckham’s Comments Belie the Hype

Galaxy last night, he also wore the captain’s arm band and scored his first goal for the club, curling in a signature direct kick into the left side netting, cleanly beating D.C. United keeper Troy Perkins. Video highlights are available on MLSnet.com or the SupeLiga Web site.

headline: A Case of Digg or Die?

headline: Spitzer Says No to Segways on Roads, Among Other Actions on Legislation
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer acted on more than a hundred bills on Wednesday night. Among the notables, he vetoed a bill allowing for the use of Segways on roads and highways outside New York City, which would have essentially given them a status akin to a bicycle.

headline: Westchester District Attorney Switches Political Parties
text: This morning, the Westchester County district attorney, Janet DiFiore, dropped out of the Republican Party and registered as a Democrat. In a statement, Ms. DiFiore -– who was elected in 2005 to replace another Republican, Jeanine F. Pirro –- justified her decision by saying, “The principles of the Democratic Party are closely aligned with my views.” She also took the opportunity to announce her plans to run for re-election in 2009.

headline: Fifth Third to Acquire First Charter
text: The Midwest’s Fifth Third Bancorp said on Thursday it would buy First Charter for about $1.1 billion, adding nearly 60 bank branches in North Carolina and Georgia. Cincinnati-based Fifth Third said it would pay $31 in cash and stock per First Charter share, a healthy 53 percent premium over the target’s closing stock price Wednesday.

headline: Countrywide Filing Would Be Bankruptcy Bonanza
text: There are plenty of people hoping Countrywide Financial will not be forced to seek bankruptcy protection. Not least of these are Countrywide’s shareholders, including Barclays and Legg Mason, who would most likely lose their entire stakes. And then there are the 40 banks providing an $11.5 billion credit line to Countrywide, which the company said Thursday it had completely drawn down.

headline: Panel Rejects Columbia’s Expansion Plan
text: After a five-hour hearing on Wednesday — a meeting so contentious that at one point, former Mayor David N. Dinkins was heckled — the land-use committee of Community Board 9 in Manhattan voted resoundingly to oppose Columbia University’s expansion plan unless a number of conditions were first met, including the construction of low-income housing and certain environmental measures.

headline: Giuliani: Leave My Kids Alone
text: Republican presidential candidate Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has acknowledged having a strained relationship with his two children, got a novel question from a New Hampshire woman at a town hall meeting earlier today: Why should voters support him if his own children don’t?

headline: Call a Plumber? Not for This 19-Year Leak
text: Still smarting from the recent rise in water rates — at 11.5 percent, one of the largest increases ever — New Yorkers might be disturbed to learn about the rickety state of the city’s water supply system in a new report by the office of the New York State comptroller.

headline: The Decline of Local News on the Net?
text: A week after Google made headlines by opening up Google News to commentary, the Joan Shorenstein Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University is weighing in with an interesting study: Creative Destruction: An Exploratory Look at News on the Internet.

headline: Riding Scooters and Carrying BlackBerrys, the Inspectors Are Coming
text: The city’s newest team of inspectors will not issue tickets or fines. They won’t harass landlords over leaky pipes or ensure that builders are following city codes. No, the focus of the Street Conditions Observation Unit –- or Scout, for short -– will be the city itself.Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled the 15-member unit today. Its mission is to cruise the city streets looking for potholes, clogged catch basins, damaged bus shelters, even homeless people. The inspectors will ride along in small three-wheeled vehicles — powered by gasoline and resembling golf carts — that the city is calling “scooters.”

headline: Skype’s Bad Day
text: The massively popular Internet phone service Skype has been down all morning. Its Web site says that engineers have discovered a software problem which will be fixed in 12 to 24 hours. That is a disastrously long time for a service that eBay, owner of Skype, has been pitching as a core business communication tool to companies and stay-at-home professionals. In fact last year, eBay itself revealed it would begin weaning itself off landlines and instead use Skype as its primary phone service. Not surprisingly, I’ve been unable to raise anyone at eBay all morning.

headline: Mortgage Crisis Triggers Sell-Off
text: The collapse of the mortgage market has impacted the stock market and driven Countrywide Financial, the largest mortgage company, into survival mode.

headline: Elvis Is Everywhere
text: If scientists somehow proved that there was absolutely nothing more to say about Elvis Presley, it wouldn’t matter a bit. Just one look at the Elvis Sighting Bulletin Board proves that point: News is being generated beyond all reason. Of course, Elvis worship is not about reason; it’s about love. And in the year 2007, that love is being spread in the great snow globe that is the Web. And yes, it’s all shook up today, the 30th anniversary of his death.

headline: More on Rove vs. Clinton
text: When Karl Rove said yesterday that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s unfavorable rating was in the “high 40s,” maybe he hadn’t seen the most recent CBS News poll. And when he said no one had been elected with negatives as high as hers, he had apparently forgotten some recent history.

headline: Astor Funeral Details: Web Audio, Bloomberg Remarks, Names of Ushers
text: The funeral service for Brooke Astor, who died on Monday at the age of 105, will be broadcast live on the Web through audio streaming on the Web site of St. Thomas Church. The service is scheduled for 2:30 p.m. on Friday at the church, on Fifth Avenue at 53rd Street.A spokesman for the church, Gerald McKelvey, said today that Mrs. Astor’s son, Anthony D. Marshall, and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will speak at the service, which will follow the burial proceedings outlined in the 1928 edition of the Book of Common Prayer.

headline: A D.C. Scene Flips to Black
text: Movie scenes play out in Washington every day, but most of them are not nearly as important or widely known as the one starring several senior administration officials around the hospital bed of a gravely ill Attorney General John D. Ashcroft. According to one account, two White House aides asked him to approve a controversial domestic spying program, but he refused in dramatic fashion, lifting his head off his pillow and expressing himself in “very strong terms.”

headline: Dutch (and Van Wely) Lead English (and Adams) at Staunton Memorial
text: Michael Adams of England broke through with a nice sacrificial attack against Jan Werle of the Netherlands in Round 9 to tie Loek Van Wely of the Netherlands for the lead in the Fifth Staunton Memorial. Adams, the tournament’s top seed, and Van Wely, the No. 2 seed, have 7 points with 2 Rounds to play. Games from the tournament can be replayed at its official Web site.
