headline: Obama Takes Sharper Tone to the Trail
text: ATLANTIC, Iowa, Aug. 16 — Senator Barack Obama has moved in recent weeks to sharpen his tone noticeably as he fights for the Democratic presidential nomination, increasingly drawing sharp contrasts with his rivals and seeking to turn criticism of his foreign policy credentials into a fresh argument for change.

headline: Time of Their Lives
text: AT their best, new media are chaotic. The new technologies disrupt political pomp and glamour and engage people in an unpolished and unpredictable give-and-take. They also give citizens access to a surprising depth of raw information.

headline: Liam Rector, 57, a Poet and Educator, Dies
text: Liam Rector, a well-regarded poet and educator whose work appeared in many distinguished publications, shot himself on Wednesday morning at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 57.

headline: Theater Listings
text: ALPHABET CITY IV The Metropolitan Playhouse is quintessentially East Village. It occupies a small space on the second floor of a walk-up that it shares with another theater and a school on an artist-rich block just above the Lower East Side. The playhouse, under its artistic director, Alex Roe, explores America and American literature by producing old American plays, new ones based on old literary sources, and plays specifically about the city and the neighborhood.

headline: Parts Supplier Pleads Guilty to Fraud
text: An owner of a small South Carolina parts supplier pleaded guilty to fraud after collecting about $20.5 million over six years from the Pentagon for fraudulent costs, including $998,798 for sending two 19-cent washers to an Army base in Texas. Cynthia Stroot, a Pentagon investigator, said the supplier, C&D Distributors in Lexington, S.C., exploited a flaw in an automated Defense Department purchasing system: bills for shipping to combat areas or American bases that were labeled “priority” were usually paid automatically. A federal judge in Columbia, S.C., accepted the guilty plea of the owner, Charlene Corley, to one count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud and one count of conspiracy to launder money.

headline: A Day of Wild Market Swings and Global Anxiety
text: What looked as if it would be one of the worst days since Wall Street began its midsummer swoon ended yesterday with a whimper, not a bang.

headline: Lawyers Tell Vick to Accept Plea Deal
text: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 16  Michael Vick’s lawyers have advised him to accept a plea deal from federal prosecutors in his dogfighting case, according to a person with direct knowledge of the case.

headline: Australia: Qantas Reports a Jump in Profit
text: Qantas Airways, Australia’s biggest airline, said second-half profit almost tripled and announced plans to buy back 10 percent of its stock. Net income in the six months ended June 30 rose to 361.1 million Australian dollars ($299 million) from 127.4 million Australian dollars a year earlier, the company said. Qantas, based in Sydney, forecast pretax profit would rise 30 percent this fiscal year. The chief executive, Geoffrey J. Dixon, said the airline might sell or spin off its freight, holiday and air miles units, adopting strategies proposed by the Macquarie Bank-led buyout group that made a bid of 11.1 billion Australian dollars in May. The chairwoman, Margaret Jackson, above, who will leave in November after being criticized for her support of the buyout, said the company would spend about a billion Australian dollars buying back 10 percent of its stock.

headline: A Billion Dollars Later, New Orleans Still at Risk
text: NEW ORLEANS — Six inches.

headline: A Matchup the Yanks Can’t Seem to Win
text: The matchup was the same last Oct. 5, when the Detroit Tigers last played in New York. Mike Mussina faced Justin Verlander and the Yankees grabbed an early lead. Then the shadows took over and the lights went out.

headline: Israel to Get $30 Billion in Military Aid From U.S.
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 16 — Israel and the United States signed a deal on Thursday to give Israel $30 billion in military aid over the next decade in what officials called a long-term investment in peace.

headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Halts Sales of Vinyl Bibs
text: Toys “R” Us said today that it was halting sales of all vinyl bibs after laboratory tests showed evidence that some of the bibs were contaminated with lead.

headline: Rate of New Home Construction Plunges
text: As more fallout from the mortgage market squeeze becomes apparent, there was yet another sign yesterday that the worst of the trauma in the housing sector may not be over.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Warriors on Duty

headline: Events Prod U.S. to Make New Push for Mideast Deal
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 16 — Samuel Johnson once remarked that “when a man knows he is to be hanged in a fortnight, it concentrates his mind wonderfully.”

headline: Turf of Gangs and Gangsters
text: Weekend Explorer is a new feature that will appear occasionally in the Weekend section. It begins with a series of walking tours through areas of New York, in which a reporter, guided by a longtime resident of a neighborhood, seeks out still-visible traces of the city’s layers of history.

headline: Art Listings
text: ART

headline: Where Concept of a ‘Pet Rock’ Has Reached Its Apex
text: HYDERABAD, India — They rise unexpectedly between glass office towers or at the base of a 12th-century fort. Sometimes they are perched precariously, one on top of another, as though they were the left-behind playthings of a civilization of giants. More and more, they are broken into bits, first by dynamite, then painstakingly by hand, so that the earth can be flattened and new office towers can come up.

headline: Aide to Ex-Representative Is Given Probation
text: The former chief of staff to former Representative Bob Ney was ordered to serve two years’ probation for his role in the corruption scandal surrounding the lobbyist Jack Abramoff. The man, William Heaton, 29, left, who often served as Mr. Ney’s contact with Mr. Abramoff, must also perform 100 hours of community service and pay a $5,000 fine, Judge Ellen Segal Huvelle said in Federal District Court. Mr. Heaton pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy in February. Prosecutors did not seek a prison term for Mr. Heaton, who cooperated with them by taping conversations with his boss. Mr. Ney, an Ohio Republican, is serving a prison term of two and a half years.

headline: Palazzo del Lago and the Reefs Club
text: WHAT Lakefront resort and residential development.

headline: A Good Deed Is Rewarded, With a Catch
text: Brooke Astor, whose 105 years will be celebrated at her funeral today, donated a fair chunk of change to the New York Public Library. That gave her something in common with Ruth Cooper Jacobs, practically a kid by comparison at 98. Ms. Jacobs also sends money to the library, pretty much every year.

headline: Bogus Diabetes Test Strips Traced to Chinese Distributor
text: A global hunt started by Johnson & Johnson has tracked to China some counterfeit versions of the test strips used by 10 million Americans to measure their blood sugar levels.

headline: Michigan: Suit Over Rules About Ships’ Water Is Dismissed
text: A federal judge in Detroit dismissed a lawsuit brought by a coalition of shipping interests challenging a Michigan law intended to curb the introduction of invasive species into the Great Lakes. The law, enacted earlier this year, requires all oceangoing ships sailing into Michigan ports to obtain permits showing that the vessels will not discharge ballast water, which is held in the ballast tanks or cargo holds of ships to provide stability, into Michigan waters, or, if they do plan to discharge the water, that it will first be treated to remove any non-native species. On Wednesday, the judge, John Feikens of Federal District Court, rejected the shipping coalition’s claim that the law was unconstitutional. Judge Feikens wrote that invasive species posed a “serious threat” to the state’s environment.

headline: Former Spitzer Nominee Is Said to Be Investigated
text: ALBANY, Aug. 16 — The state inspector general is investigating Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s recent nominee for chairwoman of the Public Service Commission, according to a former aide to Mr. Spitzer who met with investigators.

headline: The Savvy Operator Who Aced That Newfangled Art Form, Opera
text: The 1950 book on Claudio Monteverdi by Leo Schrade, a penetrating study of a pivotal composer, is flawed only by its hyped-up title, “Monteverdi: Creator of Modern Music.” Monteverdi, the Italian master born in Cremona in 1567, loomed over the uneasy transition from the musical Renaissance to the Baroque. But the creator of modern music?

headline: Things That Go Burble in the Night
text: The eerie suggestiveness of the French-Romanian fright flick “Them” — an almost-real-time thriller, set in and around a besieged house in the woods — seems less old-fashioned than classical. The movie revels in atmosphere, using long unbroken takes and ambient sound (crickets, wind) to lull you into complacency before unleashing nerve-jangling shocks.

headline: At Asian Security Meeting, Russian and Iranian Criticize the U.S.
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan, Aug. 16  Iran used the meeting of a regional security organization here on Thursday to lash out at American plans for a missile defense shield, while President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia took an indirect swipe at what he calls Washington’s unilateral foreign policy.

headline: Top Talent Agent Joins William Morris
text: In a significant strengthening of its motion picture department, the William Morris Agency completed an expensive deal to hire Ed Limato, the longtime agent to A-list actors like Denzel Washington and Mel Gibson.

headline: Ethics Commission Tightens Rules on Officials’ Aircraft Use
text: The State Ethics Commission tightened rules yesterday on the use of state aircraft by public officials, the first concrete change to emerge after a scathing report issued by the attorney general’s office last month.

headline: Death ’n’ Yucks, Hallucinogens ’n’ Stiff Upper Lips
text: There’s no dearth of rude humor on screens right now, but “Death at a Funeral” stands apart because its characters — mostly reserved upper-middle-class British folk who have gathered to bury a patriarch — are determined to keep a stiff upper lip no matter what. That’s no small feat when one of the mourners has ingested a psychedelic drug and another is secretly holding a would-be blackmailer hostage in a room mere meters from where the body lies in state.

headline: Now, the Clicking Is to Watch the Ads, Not Skip Them
text: FOR generations, advertising interrupted the entertainment that Americans wanted to read, hear or watch. Now, in a turnabout, advertising is increasingly being presented as entertainment — and surprisingly, the idea of all ads, all the time, is gaining some favor.

headline: Send in the Crowd
text: ANYONE should be able to submit questions using online video, and the public could be invited to vote on which questions should be posed to the candidates.

headline: The People’s Court
text: SOME have argued that the “community” should be choosing which questions to ask the candidates, while others have said that the “community” should have a chance to weigh in after the debate. Both are novel, but I’m interested in how we get the “community” to participate during the debate.

headline: Good News on the Health of the Yankees’ Top Pick
text: Andrew Brackman is aware of the pedigree of the young pitchers he joined by signing with the Yankees on Wednesday. The Yankees took Ian Kennedy and Joba Chamberlain before the second round in 2006, and both have progressed rapidly through the farm system.

headline: The Padilla Conviction
text: It is hard to disagree with the jury’s guilty verdict against Jose Padilla, the accused, but never formally charged, dirty bomber. But it would be a mistake to see it as a vindication for the Bush administration’s serial abuse of the American legal system in the name of fighting terrorism.

headline: In Newark, Proposing a First Step in Regulating Guns
text: NEWARK, Aug. 16 — In the latest in a series of law-enforcement steps following the killing of three people here 12 days ago, Mayor Cory A. Booker unveiled what he called a “model ordinance” on Thursday that would make it easier for the police to track illegal firearms back to the places where they were purchased.

headline: Fed Cuts Lending Rate; Dow Closes Up 233 Points
text: Saying it now feels that the recent disorder in financial markets has raised the risk of an economic downturn, the Federal Reserve today approved a half-percentage point cut in its discount rate on loans to banks. The move sent markets surging on Wall Street and in Europe.

headline: Sip and Spin
text: IF this is truly the campaign of the new media, candidates should be required to answer questions only on their cellphone, BlackBerry or other personal digital assistant, so we can size up their personal text message codes, ring tones and thumb-typing skills.

headline: Life as High School, This Time on Vacation
text: There’s only so much cutesiness a sane adult can stand close-up, even given how bitter that adult inevitably sounds when bashing a successful commercial venture. Hating a phenomenon like “High School Musical” no longer makes you appear tasteful. It makes you seem stupid, as if you hated all of market capitalism, or all winners.

headline: Queens: Girl Is Struck and Killed
text: A truck driven by a man with a suspended license struck and killed a 13-year-old Queens girl riding a bicycle yesterday afternoon, the police said. The man, Carlos Noriega-Olivia, 36, was driving a 2006 Chevy truck on Junction Boulevard in Corona when he turned right onto 57th Avenue and hit the girl, Carolina Hernandez, who was crossing the intersection on her bike around 4:15 p.m., the police said. The girl was taken to Elmhurst Hospital Center, where she was pronounced dead. Mr. Noriega-Olivia was arrested and charged with driving with a suspended license.

headline: Lebanese Elections (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: With Markets Moving Wildly, Insight Suffers
text: Twenty-first-century financial markets react with lightning speed to events halfway around the world. Investors in China can immediately see what happened in New York and make trades in London based on the news.

headline: Keep ’Em Coming
text: ASK any kid with a cellphone: When the new media are always on and everything is connected, the truth becomes something you assemble with the help of friends. Imagine if presidential debates were not one-night-on-a-stage affairs, but always on.

headline: Albany: Doctor Rankings Questioned
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo sent letters yesterday to two insurance companies raising questions about the ranking systems they use for doctors, his office said. In letters to the companies, Aetna and Cigna HealthCare, Mr. Cuomo said the rankings were confusing for consumers, and he asked for information that would justify the ranking systems. Both companies said they would cooperate with the attorney general. Aetna said its system had a process for doctors to raise concerns and to correct errors in rankings. A spokesman for Cigna said it was reviewing the attorney general’s letter and could not directly comment on it, other than to say that Cigna would respond to the request for information.

headline: To Warren Buffett, Obama and Clinton Are Both Presidential
text: OMAHA — In the Warren Buffett primary, there is nothing but neutrality when it comes to divining who he believes would make the better Democratic presidential nominee: Hillary Rodham Clinton or Barack Obama.

headline: Five Years on, a Musical Revolution Marches in a Different Direction
text: WANTAGH, N.Y., Aug. 15 — In 2002 the rap-rock juggernaut Linkin Park set out on the first Projekt Revolution tour. The lineup was meant to bridge the rap-rock divide: it included the veteran hip-hop act Cypress Hill, the nu-metal band Adema, and DJ Z-Trip, known for his cross-genre mash-ups.

headline: An Ugly Loss the Mets Hope Is Soon Forgotten
text: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 — The Mets may go on to win the division, which would reduce Thursday night’s 10-7 loss to the Pirates to just Game No. 120 of 162. But if by chance they do not, and they finish in second place by the slightest of margins, they will remember what they saw and how they felt on an unbearably muggy evening in Western Pennsylvania and wish that it would never, ever happen again.

headline: Max Roach, Master of Modern Jazz, Dies at 83
text: Max Roach, a founder of modern jazz who rewrote the rules of drumming in the 1940s and spent the rest of his career breaking musical barriers and defying listeners’ expectations, died early yesterday in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Kong-Heads for Life
text: You could get calluses just watching “The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters,” Seth Gordon’s documentary about two men vying for the high score in Donkey Kong. But even if you didn’t lose years of your life to that deviously entertaining Reagan-era arcade game, Mr. Gordon’s movie still succeeds as a portrait of a subculture: Kong-heads who videotape each game to send to Twin Galaxies, a governing body in Hollywood, Fla., empowered to validate high scores.

headline: Panel Hints at Russian Involvement in Fallen Missile in Georgia
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 16  A panel of international military experts concluded in a report released Thursday that a missile found in a field in the Republic of Georgia last week fell from an airplane that flew from Russia into Georgia and then returned to Russia.

headline: Greece: Premier Seeks Snap Elections
text: Greece’s governing conservatives moved to hold parliamentary elections on Sept. 16, six months ahead of schedule, in the hope of winning a new mandate for their economic and social reforms. “We have made steady strides in improving our economy, but more needs to be done,” a spokesman for Prime Minister Kostas Karamanlis said after a flurry of meetings between Mr. Karamanlis, above, and senior officials of his cabinet. The spokesman said Mr. Karamanlis would meet today with President Karolos Papoulias, before moving to dissolve Parliament. Mr. Karamanlis’s New Democracy Party swept to power in national elections in 2004, ousting the Socialists, who had held power for a decade. A series of scandals has caused the party’s popularity to slip, with recent opinion polls showing it just slightly ahead of the Socialist Party.

headline: Areas of Athens Are Engulfed by Growing Fire
text: ATHENS, Aug. 16  Ferocious flames fanned by gales singed the northern outskirts of Athens on Thursday, destroying homes and causing power failures in the worst forest fire to close in on the Greek capital in a month.

headline: 2 Bodies Found at Site of Bridge Collapse
text: Two more victims of the highway bridge collapse in Minneapolis on Aug. 1 were identified today by the Hennepin County Medical Examiner’s office, leaving two more of the missing to be recovered. Those identified today were Vera Peck, 50, whose son died in the bridge collapse as well, and Christine Sacorafas-Mosher, 45.

headline: Stevens and Alaska, a Longtime Partnership
text: ANCHORAGE — Senator Ted Stevens, 83 years old, 39 years in office and all but eternal in the minds of many Alaskans, notwithstanding a couple of prickly months in the spotlight, is home again.

headline: Workouts, Not Bailouts
text: In April, Henry Paulson, the Treasury secretary, declared that all the signs he saw indicated that the housing market was “at or near the bottom.” Earlier this month he was still insisting that problems caused by the meltdown in the market for subprime mortgages were “largely contained.”

headline: Notes Detail Pressure on Ashcroft Over Spying
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 — Notes taken by Director Robert S. Mueller III of the F.B.I. say that Attorney General John Ashcroft was “barely articulate,” “feeble” and “clearly stressed” shortly after a hospital-room meeting in March 2004 in which two top White House aides tried to persuade him to sign an extension for eavesdropping on Americans without warrants.

headline: Art in Review
text: SUSANNE M. WINTERLING

headline: Advocates Hail Lutheran Act on Gay Clergy Members
text: The country’s largest Lutheran denomination officially bars openly gay people from the ministry. But in a move that advocates for gay men and lesbians are hailing as a step toward changing that policy, the denomination is urging its bishops to refrain from disciplining gay members of the clergy who are in committed same-sex relationships.

headline:
Where in the World Is That Exotic

Roof Ornament?
text: A new Web game developed by a museum group encourages children to single out an exotic artifact — a stone sculpture of a Chinese sea monster, a decorated shield from the Solomon Islands, an African mask or a Hopi kachina doll — and then search for its geographic origin, gaining information about the object along the way.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Helpful Hints for Saving the Planet
text: Yeah, yeah, yeah, the environment, blah, blah, blah, melting ice caps. To judge from all the gas-guzzlers still fouling the air and the plastic bottles clogging the dumps, it appears that the news that we are killing ourselves and the world with our greed and garbage hasn’t sunk in. That’s one reason “The 11th Hour,” an unnerving, surprisingly affecting documentary about our environmental calamity, is such essential viewing. It may not change your life, but it may inspire you to recycle that old slogan-button your folks pinned on their dashikis back in the day: If you’re not part of the solution, you’re part of the problem.

headline: Bushes’ Daughter Jenna Engaged
text: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 16 — When Jenna Bush started dating Henry Hager, her mother thought it wasn’t serious. Laura Bush even said so in a television interview in February 2005, then went on to describe Mr. Hager as “a very nice young man.”

headline: Cutting Off Terror’s Money Supply
text: News this week that the Bush administration is on the verge of adding the Revolutionary Guard Corps of Iran to its ever-expanding list of foreign terrorist organizations — the count stands at 42 undesirables, headlined by Al Qaeda, Hezbollah and Hamas — was not exactly music to the ears of Gary M. Osen, a lawyer on a personal and professional campaign to sue banks that he believes bankroll terrorist activities.

headline: The Ascent of a Common Man
text: Pocahontas, Iowa

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: For Giuliani, Ground Zero as Linchpin and Thorn
text: As Rudolph W. Giuliani campaigns around the country highlighting his stewardship of New York City after the Sept. 11 attacks, he is widely hailed for bringing order to a traumatized city. But he has also raised the hackles of rescue and recovery workers by likening his experience to theirs.

headline: Judge Sides With Whole Foods on Deal for Wild Oats
text: In the end, the online ramblings of Rahodeb didn’t scuttle the plans of Whole Foods Market to buy Wild Oats Markets.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8:30 P.M. (Animal Planet) MEERKAT MANOR Flower mounts a rescue mission to retrieve her pups, which she lost in a scuffle with the Zappas, those new neighbors from hell. Meanwhile Mitch tries to reunite the rest of the Whiskers family and along the way runs into Mozart, who has formed a group of her own with her former beau Carlos.

headline: A Crier Spreads the Word About Yesterday’s Town
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.

headline: Missile That Fell in Georgia Was Russian, Panel Says
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 16 — A panel of international military experts concluded in a report released today that a missile found unexploded in a field in the Republic of Georgia last week fell from an airplane that flew from Russia into Georgian airspace and then returned to Russia.

headline: NASA Rules Out Repair to Gouge in Shuttle
text: Convinced that a small gouge in the belly of the space shuttle Endeavour poses no danger, NASA managers decided last night not to send astronauts on a spacewalk to repair it.

headline: Unbuilding a Skyscraper Wounded on Sept. 11
text: It is, Avi Schick said, like watching a video of a building being built, but in reverse.

headline: Wakesurfing: Following the Boat Without a Rope
text: THE surf was up on Lake Charlotte, a 255-acre blue gem among the farm fields west of Minneapolis, and Todd Zaugg was yelling at his son to get into the water: “All right, señor, you’re on!”

headline: Giants Think Bigger After the Defensive Line Struggles
text: ALBANY, Aug. 16 — It is a training camp of Giants, so a couple of big bodies should not cause a stir. But when two new defensive linemen each weighing nearly 350 pounds, and perhaps more,jogged onto the practice field Thursday, more than the ground shook around the rest of the Giants.

headline: For Mario Batali, It’s Molto Michigan
text: WATCHING Mario Batali shovel a pizza topped with chopped tomatoes, wet chunks of fresh mozzarella and grilled artichokes into his crackling outdoor pizza oven, it is easy to imagine you are in a hill town outside Bologna, perhaps even in Borgo Capanne, where Mr. Batali apprenticed for three years at a trattoria. The surrounding spruce trees and the wind off the lake only add to the air of authenticity, as does the wood smoke that plumes out from the top of the brick oven and the smell of baking bread.

headline: Russia: Industrial Output Slows
text: Russian industrial production growth slowed in July after expanding at the fastest annual rate in two and a half years in June, the Federal Statistics Service said. Output grew at an annual rate of 7.8 percent in July, down from 10.9 percent in June, the Statistics Service said. For the month, output fell 2.7 percent after expanding by 4.5 percent in June. Manufacturing output expanded at an annual rate of 12.5 percent in July, compared with 15.6 percent in June, the statistics office said. Electricity, gas and water output expansion accelerated to an annual 3.3 percent from 2.9 percent in June. Mining and quarrying grew 1.2 percent in July, slower than the 2 percent pace of the previous month.

headline: Barbecue’s Main Events
text: SUMMER is winding down, but there’s still plenty of sizzle left in the grill. Right up to Labor Day and beyond, crowds will be clustering around monster cooking pits and savoring the smell of sweet, smoldering mesquite at some of the year’s biggest barbecue festivals.

An article yesterday about Karl Rove’s criticism of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton misstated when he made remarks to Reuters that were critical of Ms. Clinton. Those comments were on Tuesday, not Wednesday.

headline: Venerable Toronto Exchange Faces a Band of Rivals
text: OTTAWA, Aug. 16 — Canada does not look like an obvious place to start another stock exchange. Foreign takeovers, like last year’s acquisition of the giant nickel mining company Inco, and private equity moves on other companies, notably Bell Canada, have stripped the Toronto Stock Exchange of many large listings.

headline: 311 Expands With Scouts to Patrol the Streets
text: The city’s newest team of inspectors won’t write tickets or issue fines. They won’t harass landlords over leaky pipes or ensure that builders follow safety codes. The target of this team will be the city itself.

headline: Police at the Convention (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A New Springsteen Album
text: On Oct. 2 Bruce Springsteen will release “Magic,” an album on which he reunites with the E Street Band for the first time since the 2002 album “The Rising,” The Associated Press reported yesterday. The album, which is billed as Mr. Springsteen’s return to rock ’n’ roll, was recorded with the producer Brendan O’Brien in Atlanta and includes the guitarists Steve Van Zandt and Nils Lofgren, the bassist Garry Tallent, the drummer Max Weinberg, the keyboardists Danny Federici and Roy Bittan, the saxophonist Clarence Clemons, the violinist Soozie Tyrell and the vocalist Patti Scialfa.

headline: Boston Scientific Adds 2 Units to Those It Hopes to Sell
text: Boston Scientific said yesterday that it had added its cardiac and vascular surgery units to the list of businesses it wanted to sell to reduce debt and focus on its core businesses.

headline: Italian Police Seek to Avert Full Mob War After 6 Killings
text: ROME, Aug. 16  The police moved on Thursday to head off a full-scale mob war as investigators focused on the theory that one of six Italian men killed Wednesday in Germany had been responsible for the killing last Christmas of the wife of a leader in the ’Ndrangheta crime group.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

An article on Tuesday about the governing party of Turkey’s presidential nomination of Abdullah Gul, an economist and practicing Muslim, misstated the number of votes he would need to win confirmation in the 500-seat Parliament if he failed in the first two rounds of voting, when a two-thirds majority, or 367 votes, is required. In a third round, he would need 276 votes, not 267.

headline: Queens: Woman Accused of Killing Father
text: A 26-year-old Queens woman accused of killing and mutilating her father last month in her Arverne apartment was arrested last night and charged with murder, the Queens district attorney’s office said. For the past few weeks, the woman, Brigitte Harris, a security guard at Kennedy International Airport, has been in a Staten Island psychiatric hospital. She admitted herself there after the bound and gagged body of her father, Eric Goodridge, 55, of Staten Island, was discovered in her third-floor apartment on July 28. She was charged with second-degree murder and first-degree manslaughter. If convicted, she faces up to 25 years to life in prison.

headline: Case of Spy vs. Vote Monitor in Kazakhstan? Some Clues Surface
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 16 — What appear to be internal documents detailing an exchange between Kazakhstan’s intelligence service and President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev suggest that Kazakhstan conducted intelligence operations against international monitors during the presidential election in 2005, aimed at swaying the conclusions of the monitors’ reports.

headline: Free Elections? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Brooklyn: Woman Killed in Hit-and-Run
text: A 54-year-old Brooklyn woman was killed by a hit-and-run driver early yesterday in East New York, the police said. The woman, Eunice Washington of Brownsville, was with her adult son and daughter at Eldert Lane and Linden Boulevard when one of the three hailed a burgundy four-door sedan for a ride. What followed was unclear, but investigators said the family members got into a dispute with the driver. He then reversed over the curb, striking Ms. Washington, and fled, the police said. The police said the man may have been working as a livery car driver. The car also struck the son, who is 28, but he was not seriously injured, the police said.

headline: Ripken Brings Whiff of Majors to Youth Game
text: The youth baseball complex in Aberdeen, Md., that bears the Ripken family name is the ultimate playground for young players.

headline: Something Is Very Rotten in the City of São Paulo
text: “Manda Bala” (“Send a Bullet”), a flashy documentary about corruption, injustice and frog farming in Brazil, is a weird hybrid of political exposé and sensationalistic fluff. As it flip-flops between one mode and the other, it suggests a combination of “Darwin’s Nightmare,” the recent deadly serious French documentary about the despoiling of Lake Victoria, and “Mondo Cane,” the sensationalistic 1962 film that inaugurated a genre of globe-trotting documentary voyeurism.

headline: Former Yankee Tones Down Comments as Fans Weigh In
text: Gary Sheffield sat in the Detroit Tigers’ dugout while the Yankees were completing batting practice. Sheffield started to step onto the field but sat down again for an interview. That decision prevented Sheffield from being near several Yankees players and coaches, something that did not matter to him.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,692 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: A Lakeside Refuge That’s a Lot Closer Than It Feels
text: JUST about 65 miles north of New York City, the town of New Fairfield, Conn., attracts weekend residents drawn to the hush of Lake Candlewood, which was created by the Connecticut Light & Power Company in the 1920s. Today, the lake recharges the psychic batteries of the urban professionals who withdraw to the mid-20th-century cottages that sit on its wooded banks.

headline: The Flip-Flop Trail
text: WHO Matt Shepard, 50, a real estate agent from Arlington, Va.

headline: At Treasury, the Secretary Waits It Out
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 — What happened to the Hammer?

headline: People in the News
text: People

headline: Atle Selberg, 90, Lauded Mathematician, Dies
text: Atle Selberg, a mathematician whose theoretical work on the properties of numbers was recognized with the Fields Medal and other major prizes, died Aug. 6 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 90.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about the governing party of Turkey’s presidential nomination of Abdullah Gul, an economist and practicing Muslim, misstated the number of votes he would need to win confirmation in the 500-seat Parliament if he failed in the first two rounds of voting, when a two-thirds majority, or 367 votes, is required. In a third round, he would need 276 votes, not 267. (Go to Article)

An article on Monday about Htein Lin, a Burmese artist and former political prisoner whose paintings depicting incarceration in Myanmar, formerly Burma, are on display in London, misidentified Myanmar’s capital. It is Naypyidaw, not Yangon, formerly Rangoon. (The military government relocated the capital from Yangon to Naypyidaw, a remote jungle city about 200 miles north of Yangon, in 2006.)

headline: Ordinary People With Extraordinary Stories
text: Vividly impressionistic and delightfully curious, “Primo Levi’s Journey” retraces the writer’s arduous return from a newly liberated Auschwitz in January 1945 to his home in Italy more than eight months later.

headline: More Fears About China
text: Will Beijing’s leaders never learn? First, Mattel recalled millions of tainted, Chinese-made toys this week  just the latest scare over Chinese goods that is raising doubts worldwide about doing business with China. Now there are reports that the Chinese government is withholding information on a fast-spreading virus decimating its pig population, much as it tried to cover up the SARS epidemic in 2003.

headline: College Ratings Race Roars On Despite Concerns
text: Richard J. Cook, the president of Allegheny College in Pennsylvania, will not say precisely how he used to rate his college’s competitors when the annual U.S. News & World Report peer review questionnaire showed up in his mailbox. What he will say is, “I filled it out more honestly this year than I did in the past.”

headline: Russian Used List of Richest Americans to Find Targets for Theft, Officials Say
text: He was a young man with a big plan: taking aim at rich Americans, with the help of the Forbes 400 list, and robbing their financial accounts by trolling the Internet for information all the way from his base in Moscow, prosecutors in Manhattan said yesterday.

headline: A Peruvian City Is Left Devastated by Quake
text: PISCO, Peru, Aug. 17 — No area along the southern coast of Peru, which was ravaged by an earthquake that killed at least 510 people, was harder hit than this port city.

headline: For Better Health Care (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Castillo Pulls for Polanco to Continue His Streak
text: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 — Whenever the Tigers visited Minnesota, Luis Castillo would invite his friend Plácido Polanco to his home for lunch. Polanco would reciprocate when the Twins were in Detroit.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Error in Skype’s Software Shuts Down Phone Service
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 — The online telephone service Skype was not working for much of the day on Thursday, leaving its 220 million users, some of them small businesses that had given up their landlines, without a way to call colleagues, customers and friends.

headline: Yankees Sign Draft Picks, but Not Ambidextrous Pitcher
text: The Yankees managed to sign several of their top draft picks late Wednesday night, a little before the midnight deadline, for close to $7 million in signing bonuses. One pick they did not corral, however, could have been two players in one: Pat Venditte, the most talented ambidextrous pitcher in college baseball history.

headline: Destruction and Tsunami After Plates Collide Again
text: The earthquake that struck off Peru’s southern coast on Wednesday occurred in one of the world’s most active geological areas, where the South America plate collides with the Nazca plate, which underlies part of the Pacific Ocean.

headline: F.B.I. Studies Senator’s Role in Contract
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 — The F.B.I. is investigating whether Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska had a role in arranging a 1999 government contract worth as much as $70 million for a company that oversaw renovations of his house months later, officials said Thursday.

headline: Korea’s Extraordinary Send-Offs for Ordinary People
text: The volume of art made throughout history to mourn, commemorate and celebrate death trumps just about every other category. Even so, “Korean Funerary Figures: Companions for the Journey to the Other World” at the Korea Society is unusual because it presents objects created for ordinary people rather than for aristocrats or the wealthy.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Plunge as Asian Slump Persists
text: SINGAPORE, Aug. 17 — A deep plunge by stocks in Tokyo led a continued slump by Asian markets today, as the recent turmoil brought on by the housing-loan crisis in the United States sparked a rush to cut losses among investor who have been borrowing yen to invest globally.

headline: Singapore Airlines to Receive Superjumbo Plane on Oct. 15
text: PARIS, Aug. 16 — Singapore Airlines said Thursday that its first Airbus A380 would be delivered Oct. 15, entering service after a costly two-year delay for the plane, the world’s largest passenger jet.

headline: The Jets and the Giants Borrow $1.3 Billion for Their New Stadium
text: The Jets and the Giants yesterday completed a $1.3 billion financing agreement to build an 84,000-seat stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Allies Not Likely to Push Mugabe to Change
text: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 16 — Southern Africa’s political leaders gathered Thursday in Lusaka, Zambia, to discuss Zimbabwe’s political and economic collapse, but it appeared unlikely that they would press its president, Robert G. Mugabe, to change any of the policies that critics said had brought his nation to ruin.

headline: Blair to Write Book
text: Former Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, who stepped down in June, plans to write a book, The Associated Press reported yesterday, citing a Blair representative who would not speak on the record because no deal has been made. The representative said that the book, probably a memoir, hasn’t been started and is at least a few years from publication. There have been no negotiations with publishers, the representative said, but Mr. Blair has retained Robert Barnett, a Washington lawyer who has acted as book agent for Bill Clinton and Alan Greenspan,. A spokesman for Mr. Blair, Matthew Doyle, declined to comment.

headline: For Three Virgins, the Path to Sunrise Is Paved With Excess
text: Horny is as horny does in the sweetly absurd high school comedy “Superbad.” A tickly, funny tale of three teenage boys revved up by their surging, churning, flooding hormones, the movie joins the tumescent ranks of similarly themed works about male sexual desire — consider “Portnoy’s Complaint,” think “Porky’s” — and its somatic epiphanies, treacherous secretions, anguished lessons and apparently limitless storehouse of embarrassments. Behold the man (well, boy): fully sexed and wholly, touchingly virginal.

headline: Con Edison Wins Ruling in Pipe Explosion Case
text: Consolidated Edison won its legal fight yesterday to test a piece of equipment that may not have been working properly shortly before last month’s steam pipe explosion in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Morris Meets Amadeus: Odd, Elective Affinities
text: The most immediately remarkable feature of Mark Morris’s triple bill “Mozart Dances” is that whereas Mozart’s piano writing employs flourishes, trills, cascading passagework, Mr. Morris never once has his dancers do anything virtuoso. But this is just the first odd feature of many.

headline: Trial Starts for Owners of Nursing Home Hit by Storm
text: ST. FRANCISVILLE, La., Aug. 16 — Almost exactly two years after Hurricane Katrina, one of its worst horrors was revisited on Thursday in a courtroom in this sedate antebellum town, far from the coastal nursing home that became a watery tomb for 35 residents.

headline: Mortgage Ills Start to Strain Homebuying in Manhattan
text: The turmoil in the international mortgage market is starting to make it harder for New Yorkers to get the large loans that are typical in a city where the average apartment in Manhattan costs $1.3 million. In the past two weeks, banks have been increasing rates on so-called jumbo mortgages, sometimes at the very last minute, according to mortgage brokers and lawyers.

headline: Queens: Teenager Stabs Stepfather
text: A teenager fatally stabbed his stepfather, who was assaulting the boy’s mother, on Wednesday night, the police said yesterday. After consulting with the district attorney, the police said yesterday that no charges had been filed. The police said the stepfather, Arturo Moreno, 33, began arguing with his wife about 9:30 p.m. at their Ozone Park home. The dispute became physical, and the woman’s 14-year-old son, who was not identified, stepped in. During the altercation, the teenager stabbed Mr. Moreno in the chest, the police said. Mr. Moreno was pronounced dead at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, they said.

headline: Giambi’s Candor Earns Him a Pass From Selig
text: Jason Giambi will not be disciplined for tacitly admitting earlier this season that he had used steroids. Commissioner Bud Selig announced yesterday that Giambi’s willingness to cooperate with the investigation being conducted by the former Senator George J. Mitchell into steroid use in baseball swayed his decision.

headline: Europeans Plan to Investigate Ratings Agencies and Their Warnings
text: PARIS, Aug. 16 — The European Union announced on Thursday that it would investigate whether ratings agencies like Standard & Poor’s and Moody’s were adequately alerting investors to risks like securities backed by subprime mortgages in the United States.

headline: Pod People Propagating With a Fierce Indigestion
text: The latest and lamest version of Don Siegel’s 1956 pulp classic “Invasion of the Body Snatchers” (from the Jack Finney novel) might have been an accidental camp classic if its politics weren’t so abhorrent and the movie didn’t try to hide its ineptitude behind a veil of pomposity. A miscast Nicole Kidman stars as a Washington-area shrink who’s so deep in her own little world she doesn’t initially notice that everyone else appears to be mainlining antidepressants. Maybe they’re former patients. Or maybe all those tight skirts she wears have cut off her circulation. That certainly must explain why she barely notices Daniel Craig, wasted here as her best friend.

headline: Hits From a Drummer Who Reveled in Change
text: A selected discography of recordings featuring Max Roach, in chronological order:

headline: A Bratty American Star in Bollywood
text: In “Marigold,” a light romantic comedy billed as the first United States-India co-production, India provides one of its biggest stars (the bad boy Salman Khan), gorgeous scenery (Goa, Bombay, Rajasthan), a genre (the Bollywood musical) and even the daughter of a Nobel Prize winner (the actress Nandana Sen, whose father is the economist Amartya Sen).

headline: Lutherans Urge Restraint in Disciplining Gay Ministers
text: The country’s largest Lutheran denomination officially bars openly gay people from the ministry. But in a move that advocates for gays are hailing as a step toward changing that policy, the denomination is urging bishops to refrain from disciplining gay and lesbian clergy members who are in committed same-sex relationships.

headline: Referees Could Face Discipline From N.B.A.
text: The federal investigation into National Basketball Association gambling is generating information about other referees that could lead to disciplinary action short of criminal charges, authorities and lawyers involved with the case said yesterday.

headline: Can’t Tell a Book (Kapow!) by Its Cover
text: The biggest mystery about two new thrillers, “The Intruders” and “Power Play,” is why they look so generic. Their titles suggest nothing but vague, all-purpose peril. The raised letters on their covers scream so loudly that not even a blind person could miss the design style. Stacks and stacks of other books look just like these. Perhaps that’s the point. It might be risky in the world of blustery suspense books to indicate that these are anything special. Even though they are.

headline: Things Real and Unreal (What’s the Difference?)
text: The contemporary personal memoir — for instance, “A Boy Called It” — exerts a voyeuristic, train-wreck fascination: we want to hear, almost in spite of ourselves, about the travails of twisted childhoods.

headline: Too Young to Choose (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mr. Bernanke’s Moment
text: Despite the roiling stock market — and pleas from Wall Street for an interest-rate cut — Ben Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has enough evidence for now to justify holding rates steady. Inflation measures for July were mostly tame, but still did not show the sustained improvement that the Fed would like to see before lowering rates to juice the economy.

headline: 3 Killed and 6 Injured in Rescue Effort at Mine
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 16 — Three rescue workers were killed and six others were injured last night when a seismic jolt caused a mine accident during an effort to reach six men who have been trapped at the Crandall Canyon Mine since Aug. 6, mining officials said.

headline: A Little Abstract, a Little Eccentric, and More
text: The achievement of the American abstract painter Richard Pousette-Dart is like the Flying Dutchman. For decades it has roamed the vast seas of 20th-century American art, frequently sighting land but never making it to shore.

headline: While Kurds Count Bodies, Iraqi Leaders Try to Bridge Their Divide
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 16  Emergency workers continued Thursday to pull bodies from the rubble of a quadruple truck bombing in two villages near the Syrian border as Iraq’s prime minister, a Shiite, and its president, a Kurd, announced a new alliance of moderates in Parliament.

headline: Liberties Advocates Fear Abuse of Satellite Images
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 — For years, a handful of civilian agencies have used limited images from the nation’s constellation of spy satellites to track hurricane damage, monitor climate change and create topographical maps.

headline: Changing the Terms of Debate
text: The CNN/YouTube presidential debate, in which voters submitted online videos with questions for the Democratic candidates, was praised in some quarters as the most earthshaking change in communication technology for presidential politics since the Kennedy-Nixon debates in 1960.

headline: New Jersey Schools Show Small Gain in Standards
text: More than one-quarter of New Jersey’s 2,430 public schools were cited yesterday for failing to meet federal education standards after too few of their students passed state reading and math tests this spring, state education officials said yesterday.

headline: Sheffield Motivates Himself With Conflict and Criticism
text: Gary Sheffield prides himself on being an avowed truth-teller, a revealer of hypocrisy, a debunker of myth, but typically without ample explanation or factual support.

headline: The Recall of Toys Made in China (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Britain: Retail Sales Post Gain
text: Retail sales in Britain unexpectedly rose in July by the most in five months as price cuts by stores lured shoppers. Sales climbed 0.7 percent after gaining 0.4 percent in June, which was twice as much as previously reported, the Office for National Statistics said. Tesco, Britain’s biggest retailer, and Asda, owned by Wal-Mart Stores, cut prices on thousands of products to attract customers during the wettest summer on record. The gain in retail sales was led by electronics and furniture, the statistics office said. Household goods stores reported a 13.4 percent annual increase in sales, the biggest since October 2001. Retail sales rose 4.4 percent from a year earlier. Analysts said the strong figures would encourage the central bank to raise interest rates.

headline: Lake Trout: Big, Deep and Seductive
text: LAKE trout have some unflattering nicknames. “Mud chickens,” they’re sometimes called. Fats. Humpers. Half-breeds. Ken Schultz’s Fishing Encyclopedia, a reference book sacred to anglers, while gushing over the brook trout as “among the prettiest fish in the world,” derides the lake trout’s “distended belly.”

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Bronx: Police Officer Dragged by Car
text: A police officer was dragged by a car in Williamsbridge early yesterday after he tried to question the driver, whom he suspected of using drugs, the police said. The officer, who was not identified by the police, then shot the driver in the left leg, the police said. The officer had approached the car, at East 228th Street and White Plains Road, on foot about 1 a.m., believing two men in it were smoking marijuana. The car was driven off, and the officer was caught and briefly dragged, the police said. Investigators said the two men were seen throwing marijuana and cocaine from the moving vehicle, which police officers stopped after it had gone about two blocks. The officer was treated for minor injuries at St. Barnabas Hospital, and the driver was in stable condition at Jacobi Medical Center, the police said. Charges against the two men in the car, whose identities were not disclosed, were pending late yesterday, the police said.

headline: Big Changes and Big Loan for Lender
text: Shut out of the short-term debt market by an expanding credit crisis, Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, turned yesterday to 40 of the biggest banks, borrowing $11.5 billion as it tried to shore up its cash.

headline: Inquiry on Work on Senator’s House Is Confirmed
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 — The F.B.I. is investigating whether Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska had a role in arranging a 1999 government contract worth as much as $70 million for a company that oversaw renovations of his house months later, officials said Thursday.

headline: A Jets Coach Who Is Able to Bend but Not Break
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 15  His voice rises in fury when a special teams player misses a blocking assignment or makes the wrong cut on a return. Same old Mike Westhoff, the Jets players say with a laugh.

headline: Dell, Admitting Managers Inflated Sales Reports, Will Restate Income
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16  The senior management of Dell regularly falsified quarterly returns from 2003 through 2006 to create the appearance that the company had met sales targets, the computer maker disclosed Thursday.

headline: A Most Bookish Borough
text: It can hardly be a coincidence that the nation’s most ethnically diverse county, Queens, has just been awarded the top prize as the nation’s busiest library system. “No surprise at all,” says Lacey Chan, the library’s Hong Kong-born demographer, who tracks the ceaseless tide of neighborhood change so that the system’s 63 branches can meet readers’ polyglot curiosities and ambitions.

headline: Queens: Man Charged With Murder
text: A Queens man has been charged with killing one man and wounding another in a shooting last week in Laurelton, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Rhian Taylor, 21, of 229th Street in Laurelton, was charged with murder and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Taylor fired repeatedly into a car after an argument outside a party just before 2 a.m. last Friday. Darion Brown, 22, of 127th Avenue in Laurelton, was hit several times and died, prosecutors said. Another man was shot in the leg, they said.

headline: Stop Blaming Fat People (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Politics at Play on Martha’s Vineyard
text: Martha’s Vineyard

headline: A Maestro Who Kept It Simple (but Lush)
text: Here are some recordings of Monteverdi’s music worth seeking out:

headline: Lenders in Canada Act to Fix a Problem in Their Debt Market
text: OTTAWA, Aug. 16  Banks and money managers came together Thursday to end a credit crisis in an arcane branch of Canada’s debt market.

headline: Sam Pollock, 81, Hockey Executive, Dies
text: Sam Pollock, the Montreal Canadiens’ general manager who built nine Stanley Cup championship teams in the 1960s and ’70s, died Wednesday in Toronto. He was 81.

headline: Toll Climbs in Peru; Areas Lack Water and Power
text: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 16 — A day after a powerful earthquake devastated cities along Peru’s southern coast, government officials put the death toll at 437, with at least 17,000 people displaced and with wide areas without power, telephone service or road access on Thursday night.

headline: A United Nations of Hair: Straight, Curly, Flaxen, Waxen and 80 Feet Long
text: The library at Dartmouth College, the Ivy League stronghold in Hanover, N.H., is at the moment a showcase for human hair. Hanging in the grand entrance hall of Baker Library is a mammoth scrim made from more than 430 pounds of the stuff, the result of 42,350 free haircuts given to Dartmouth faculty and staff members and students in 2006, along with barbershop and salon patrons in the surrounding community. It’s possibly the greatest hair accumulation at an Ivy League college since the hirsute days of the 1960s.

headline: Asia Seen as Better Able to Deflect Waves From U.S.
text: HONG KONG, Aug. 16 — In the past, when economic growth has stalled in the rest of the world, the United States has usually been there to pick up the slack. Now that dynamic is reversed.

headline: Just Call Calgary a Big Playground
text: CALGARY, a city of skyscrapers amid the mountains and badlands of Alberta, is rich in big-ticket kid-pleasers. Cowboys? Check. Dinosaurs and zoo animals? Got ’em. Sports? How about trying the luge, biking down a mountain and riding a zip line off a ski jump, all in one place?

headline: A Musical Pioneer Who Never Stopped Searching
text: It happens all the time. Friends hear jazz that veers toward the traditional, or toward the refinement of a basic form, and they say something like this: “It’s good, but isn’t jazz supposed to be looking for something new?”

headline: China’s Rights Abuses (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Commercial College Ordered to Repay U.S. $2.5 Million
text: The parent company of Interboro Institute, a commercial college in New York City that a state investigation found had cheated in determining student eligibility for government financial aid, has been ordered to repay the federal government about $2.5 million, the company said yesterday.

headline: Brooke Astor’s Funeral Today, With Favorite Hymns
text: Fifteen years ago, at the age of 90, Brooke Astor issued a letter to her executors in which she laid out instructions for her funeral. Her second husband, Charles Marshall, had done the same thing before his own death in 1952, “and it was a great comfort to know that I was doing exactly what he wanted,” she wrote.

headline: As Lead Dimishes, the Nail-Biting Begins in Boston
text: BOSTON, Aug. 16 (AP) — Manny Ramírez had just struck out to end the game on Wednesday when the Fenway Park sound system began playing “Will You Still Love Me Tomorrow?”

headline: Even Musharraf’s Allies Question His Re-election Goal
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 16 — As President Pervez Musharraf begins his campaign this week for re-election to another five-year term, senior figures in the governing party have warned that the Supreme Court will almost certainly block his nomination for president and declare it unconstitutional.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Padilla Is Guilty on All Charges in Terror Trial
text: MIAMI, Aug. 16 — In a significant victory for the Bush administration, a federal jury found Jose Padilla guilty of terrorism conspiracy charges on Thursday after little more than a day of deliberation.

headline: Deeper Into the Neighborhood
text: Eating

headline: Rescue Halted at Mine After 3 Deaths and 6 Injuries
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 17 — Underground rescue operations were halted indefinitely today at the Crandall Canyon coal mine after a seismic jolt Thursday evening killed two rescue workers and an inspector from the federal Mine Safety and Health Administration.

headline: Two Plead Guilty in Dogfighting Case Tied to Vick
text: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 17 — Two of Michael Vick’s co-defendants pleaded guilty Friday to charges stemming from a dog fighting ring, leaving the Atlanta Falcons quarterback to face federal charges alone unless he to can strike a deal with prosecutors.

headline: POTUS! omg :)
text: MAYBE someday soon the candidates will have laptop computers at their lecterns, and we’ll hang a giant screen behind the stage. Then, as one candidate is talking, the others will use instant messaging to create a kind of scrolling commentary and critique, and all the comments will appear overhead.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: As Billboards, Public Phones Always Work
text: They stand on corners from Brighton Beach to the Bronx, all but mocking New Yorkers: Pay phones that may or may not work, which you can’t even check for a dial tone without worrying about germs.

headline: Life and Country in Upheaval
text: Like Douglas Sirk without the throw pillows, “Sunflower” is a shamelessly old-fashioned melodrama performed with such sincerity that resistance is futile. Following a troubled father-son relationship over more than 30 years in post-Cultural Revolution Beijing, the movie utilizes a simple dramatic structure to support a narrative filled with tumultuous social change.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Rough Night at Work, No Time for ‘PLAY’
text: I got a few advance copies of the upcoming issue of The New York Times’ PLAY Magazine on Thursday, and I brought in a copy for Mike Mussina. He gave me a lot of time for a feature called “The Art of Pitching,” and I’m happy with how it turned out. Look for it online Friday and in the Sunday edition of the Times.

headline: Market Troubles
text: Stock markets around the world are continuing their volatile week. According to an article in The Times from earlier this week, ordinary investors seem less vulnerable in this market than the professionals, who have taken a beating.

headline: Rolls-Royces on Auction
text: Rolls-Royces auctioned at the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance.

headline: Darden Restaurants to Acquire 2 Chains
text: Darden Restaurants, which operates the Olive Garden and Red Lobster chains, said Thursday that it had agreed to buy Rare Hospitality, owner of the LongHorn Steakhouse and Capital Grille chains, for about $1.19 billion.

headline: Boston Scientific Adds 2 Units to Those It Hopes to Sell
text: Boston Scientific said Thursday that it had added its cardiac and vascular surgery units to the list of businesses it wanted to sell to reduce debt and focus on its core businesses.

headline: E.U. Plans Investigation into Ratings Agencies
text: The European Union announced on Thursday that it would investigate whether ratings agencies like Standard & Poor’s and Moody’s were adequately alerting investors to risks like securities backed by subprime mortgages in the United States.

headline: Judge Sides With Whole Foods on Deal for Wild Oats
text: In the end, the online ramblings of Rahodeb didn’t scuttle the plans of Whole Foods Market to buy Wild Oats Markets. On Thursday, Judge Paul L. Friedman of Federal District Court in Washington refused the Federal Trade Commission’s request to block the merger of the grocery chains.

headline: Toronto Exchange Faces a Band of Rivals
text: Canada does not look like an obvious place to start another stock exchange. Foreign takeovers, like last year’s acquisition of the giant nickel mining company Inco, and private equity moves on other companies, notably Bell Canada, have stripped the Toronto Stock Exchange of many large listings.

headline: Once Goldman’s Hammer, Paulson Now Waits It Out
text: What happened to the Hammer?

headline: Hedge Funds Sue to Block Arcelor-Mittal Deal
text: Three hedge funds that hold stakes in steel maker Arcelor are seeking a Dutch court order to stop the company’s takeover by Mittal Steel, which offers them a share swap they are not happy with, Arcelor said Thursday.

headline: European Energy Firms Clash Over Deal Talks
text: The two largest Central European energy companies are headed for a clash after the chief executive of one, OMV of Austria, said Thursday that he was determined to merge with the other, MOL of Hungary, which was taking extraordinary moves to defend itself.

headline: 3Par Joins Parade of Storage I.P.O.’s
text: 3Par this week became the third data-storage systems specialist in less than two months to file for an initial public offering. The venture-backed company hopes to raise as much as $100 million to finance its campaign against the established industry giants, the analyst firm 451 Group wrote.

headline: Citadel’s Latest ‘Rescue’ Has Some Saying ‘Lawsuit’
text: These days, Citadel Investment Group seems to be riding to everyone’s rescue. But not everyone appears to be happy about it.

headline: Abu Dhabi Energy Firm to Buy Canadian Assets
text: Abu Dhabi National Energy, better known as Taqa, expects to spend as much as $3 billion over the next 12 months buying Canadian oil and gas producers, the company’s chief executive officer said Thursday.

headline: Proxy Firms Back Ryerson in Feud With Hedge Fund
text: Ryerson, a Chicago-based steel distributor, has gotten the support of several advisory firms in its proxy fight with activist shareholder  Harbinger Capital Partners.

headline: Deerfield’s Triarc Deal Up in the Air
text: Triarc, the holding company controlled by billionaire investor Nelson Peltz, said Thursday that Rosemont-based Deerfield Triarc Capital hasn’t yet secured financing for its planned acquisition of Triarc’s stake in money manager Deerfield.

headline: Cruise’s UA Accomplishes Financing Mission
text: For actor Tom Cruise and his partners, getting half a billion dollars to finance films amid the ongoing credit crunch might seem like “Mission: Impossible.”

headline: Macquerie Mulls Bid for Sourthern Water, Report Says
text: Australia’s Macquarie is plotting a consortium bid worth 3.5 billion pounds to 4 billion pounds ($6.9 billion to $7.9 billion) for Southern Water, the British utility that provides water to at least one million households in Kent, Sussex, Hampshire and the Isle of Wight, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Goldman’s ‘Global’ Confusion Over Romney Investment
text: The current upheaval in the market seems to have banks so bemused that they are having hard time keeping their funds straight.

headline: A Place Where Troops Can Start Withdrawing
text: The story starts with a very familiar ring to it: An international coalition sends troops to a pariah country in 2003 to help dispose of a corrupt, belligerent regime, tame the resulting chaos, and midwife a peaceful and reasonably democratic new government to take its place.

headline: MMI Drops Plans to Block Acxiom Deal
text: Acxiom‘s proposed $3 billion acquisition by private equity firm ValueAct Capital and technology buyout group Silver Lake got a boost Wednesday, after Acxiom shareholder MMI Investments said it would drop plans to fight the deal.

headline: Borse Dubai Tops Nasdaq’s Bid for Swedish Exchange
text: Borse Dubai, owner of the emirate’s two stock exchanges, offered 27.7 billion kronor ($3.96 billion) for Sweden’s OMX, topping a bid from Nasdaq Stock Market.

headline: Midwest Goes for Sweetened TPG Offer
text: After months of back-and-forth battling over AirTran‘s effort to acquire Midwest Air Group, Midwest has spurned AirTran one last time by formally deciding to sell to private investment firm TPG Capital for $450 million.

headline: Social Gaming Startup Gets $5 Million
text: Casual gaming startup Kongregate said on Thursday that it had received $5 million in its first round of funding. Venture firm Greylock Partners led the round.

headline: TripAdvisor Said to Buy Facebook Application
text: Update: Michael Delasandro, a partner on the Where I’ve Been team, writes in a statement below that there has been no sale.

headline: Weekend Explorer
text: Behind the veneer of an upscale Manhattan neighborhood, a dark past lurks in Hell's Kitchen. With John Strausbaugh.

headline: Lazard Chief Buys Up Firm’s Battered Stock
text: Lazard chairman Bruce Wasserstein opened his wallet this week to buy his firm’s beaten-down shares, which hit a 52-week low Thursday. Regulatory filings show he spent more than $5 million to purchase about 140,000 Lazard shares between Tuesday and Thursday. During the same three-day span, a trust for the Wasserstein family bought 329,500 Lazard shares for about $12.3 million.

headline: A Different Road to Buyout Financing?
text: The recent collapse of the debt markets has left many wondering what’s next for private equity. As banks have become more unwilling to commit to the financing of deals, after faced with the prospect of holding unsaleable debt on their books, some analysts have speculated that the buyout boom is over.

headline: Bear Stock Surges on Rumors of Stake Sale
text: Bear Stearns shares surged 13 percent Thursday amid speculation the securities firm may sell a minority stake, possibly to a Chinese bank.

headline: As Bear Cuts Jobs, Some Wonder Who’s Next
text: Here come the pink slips.

headline: Morning Buzz: Pay Phones as Ad Billboards, Giuliani’s Time at Ground Zero, Real Estate Jitters and More
text: Pay telephones generate far more money for the city through advertising than through the placement of calls. As Jo Craven McGinty explains in a front-page article, “The phone kiosks generate $62 million in advertising revenue annually — and last year the city got $13.7 million of the take.”That $13.7 million was triple what the city pulled in from calls. Although the number of pay phones in the city is shrinking — there are now about 22,700 — 80 percent of the decline has been from phones alongside buildings (where advertising is not permitted) rather than from phones at the curb (the only pay phones where ads are allowed).

headline: 2008: Pre-Debate Postures
text: As the Democratic presidential candidates prepare for a debate in Iowa this weekend, they have been staking out their positions over the last few days, setting the stage for Sunday’s showdown.

headline: Fed Offers Wall Street a Rate Reprieve
text: The Federal Reserve unexpectedly announced Friday that it has approved a half-percentage point cut in its discount rate on loans to banks, a move that many on Wall Street had been clamoring for. The decision came as stock markets have been whipsawed by speculation about which mortgage company or hedge fund could be the next to fall victim to the recent credit crunch.

headline: Apple Takes a Step Back With iMovie ’08
text: Last week, Apple released a new version of its iLife suite—its $80 package containing iPhoto, iMovie, iWeb and GarageBand. The suite also comes preinstalled on every new Mac.

headline: Rankin v. McDermid, cont.
text: In the Guardian this morning, Val McDermid throws buckets of cold water on her alleged feud with Ian Rankin (see post below), one that made shrill headlines in the U.K. (“Revenge of the Bloodthirsty Lesbians!”)

headline:
Stray Questions for:
Dagoberto Gilb
text: Dagoberto Gilb’s books include “Woodcuts of Women,” a book of stories, and “The Last Known Residence of Mickey Acuna,” a novel. His new novel, “The Flowers,” will be published by Grove Press in January.

headline: Ask the ‘Suburbanization of New York’ Editors
text: Jerilou Hammett and Kingsley Hammett, the editors of “The Suburbanization of New York: Is the World’s Greatest City Becoming Just Another Town?” (Princeton Architectural Press, 2007), will be taking questions from City Room readers next week. Readers are invited to submit questions in the comments box below.

headline: A Call for the Fed to ‘Stand Back’
text: An editorial in The Economist says the Federal Reserve and other central banks “must stand back” from intervening, through interest rate cuts, in the credit crisis that’s causing a panic in the world’s stock markets. The editorial concludes:

headline: Living Grandly
text: A trio from Milwaukee wanted to upgrade their quality of life by moving in together.

headline: No One Can Accuse Them of Acting Rashly
text: The title of the latest report from the Federal government’s nanotechnology policy coordinators on safety concerns borders on self-parody: “Prioritization of Environmental, Health and Safety Research Needs for Engineered Nanoscale Materials — An Interim Document for Public Comment.”

headline: High-Flying Days Are Over for One Fund Manager
text: The last time we checked on John Devaney, DealBook found out that he would be left high and dry. Now, it appears he may be grounded as well.

headline: When Should Rescuers Give Up?
text: The deaths of three rescue workers at the Crandall Canyon mine in Utah last night puts a tough question front and center: How do you decide when to give up?

headline: ‘An Appealing Commercial Cover’
text: In this Sunday’s Book Review, Luc Sante reviews Jack Kerouac’s “On the Road: The Original Scroll,” and Matt Weiland reviews John Leland’s book “Why Kerouac Matters: The Lessons of ‘On the Road’ (They’re Not What You Think).”

headline: Revisiting Joe Gould’s Secret
text: Fifty years ago tomorrow, a small, bearded, prematurely frail psychiatric patient named Joe Gould, age 68, died at Pilgrim State Hospital in Brentwood, on Long Island. For three decades, Gould, a Harvard graduate from a distinguished New England family, had spent his days and nights wandering the bars and taverns of Greenwich Village, staying in flophouses, living off the generosity of friends and strangers. He became unexpectedly famous as the subject of a celebrated profile by the writer by Joseph Mitchell.

headline: Social Networking, Here?
text: With all the troubles facing the newspaper business model, I’m a big believer that the best hope for reviving the model is to take newspaper websites and turn them into bases for social networks. You look at what happened to newspaper valuations over the last decade, and then what happened to the valuations of social networks like Facebook, Youtube, Myspace and so on, and you wish we could learn some of their techniques for creating communities and monetizing them. The upshot would be more eyeballs, longer time on the site, more free (reader-generated) content, and thus more advertising revenue.

headline: Aftermath of the Earthquake in Peru
text: An earthquake in Peru devastated the coast.

headline: China and Sudan
text: China plays a central role underwriting the Sudanese military and hence the genocide in Darfur. But it’s been difficult to get accurate information about China’s role, and in particular there has been dispute about Chinese transfers of military technology and help in setting up arms factories. The best analysis and reporting of this is in a new report by Small Arms Survey.

headline: A Measure of Guidance: Steakhouses Beyond the Beef
text: I frequently get questions from colleagues, appeals from friends and calls and e-mails from strangers asking for personalized restaurant guidance. In fact, I get too many to answer all or even most of them — it’s a sad fact of limited time — and that frustrates me, because I’d like to help. So this post is the first in what I hope is a partial, imperfect solution.

headline: Word Trip
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Hair as Medium
text: Images from Wenda Gu's exhibits at Dartmouth College.

headline: To Warren Buffett, Obama and Clinton Are Both Presidential
text: In his Web column today, Jeff Zeleny writes that in the Warren Buffett primary, “there is nothing but neutrality when it comes to divining who he believes would make the better Democratic presidential nominee: Hillary Rodham Clinton or Barack Obama.”

headline: For Google, a Very Happy Anniversary
text: On Friday, much of Wall Street was fixated on the Fed’s unexpected interest-rate move. But three years ago, on Aug. 19, 2004, something quite different had the markets all abuzz: the initial public offering of Google.

headline: A (Correctly) Sentimental Ground Breaking
text: Okay, I’ll admit it, it was extremely corny.

headline: In Search of real Ratatouille
text: It’s a rare moment when jaded French cinema patrons applaud a film’s closing credits. But that actually happened in my local theater for a showing of “Ratatouille” – the charmed journey of a rat gourmand. Similar praise is also being lavished by local French columnists who read profound significance in this post card to Paris. Does this ouvre reflect further warming in relations between Americans and the French? Your globespotter cannot answer these deep questions, but can offer a snap tour of real Ratatouille sites.

headline: City Experiments by Adding Color to Bus Lanes
text: With support from the Federal Highway Administration, New York City will be the first locality in the United States to test painted bus lanes, the city’s Department of Transportation announced today.As part of a trial period, existing bus lanes on East 57th Street, from Second to Fifth Avenues, and on Fordham Road, from University Avenue and Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard to the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, are being painted terra cotta, a deep red like the color of bricks. If the experiment works, officials hope that more motorists will stay out of the lanes, which are used during the morning and evening rush, on weekdays.

headline: Care for a Brain Chip?
text: Would you want a computer chip in your brain that could make you smarter?

headline: Young Readers Embrace Sanctuary of the Bronx Libraries
text: The old Fordham Library Center, an 84-year-old brick building on Bainbridge Avenue in the Bronx, has been empty since November 2005, when it closed to make way for the gleaming new Bronx Library Center, just up the hill on Kingsbridge Road.

headline: Analyst Weighs Two Fates for Countrywide
text: In what may be the most lukewarm upgrade of the week, an analyst at Banc of America Securities on Friday raised his rating on Countrywide Financial, the largest mortgage lender in the United States, from “sell” to “neutral.” The less-than-ringing endorsement came a few days after an analyst at Merrill Lynch slashed his Countrywide rating from “buy” to “sell” and flagged the possibility that the mortgage giant could end up in bankruptcy.

headline: Vows: Maggie & Gian-Murray
text: Maggie Thom and Gian-Murray Gianino became better acquainted when they sat together in a class titled "The Dramaturgical Approach to Psychology."

headline: Hastert Officially Announces Retirement
text: Former House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert officially announced today that he would not seek re-election to Congress, saying he still hoped to be an advocate for his home state of Illinois.

headline: New York Pays Its Final Respects to Brooke Astor
text: Updated, 4 p.m. | The funeral service for Brooke Astor, who died on Monday at age 105, began at St. Thomas Church at 2:34 p.m., after a prelude of organ music by Johann Sebastian Bach (and a reminder to mourners to turn off their cellphones). The service was broadcast on the church’s Web site through audio streaming. The guests were given an eight-page funeral program [pdf].

headline: Climate Protests
text: Plenty of people remarked on Al Gore’s comment, in my Thursday column, encouraging young people to engage in peaceful protests to block new carbon sources. Specifically, he said he was stunned that people weren’t blocking bulldozers constructing new coal-fired power plants.

headline: The Case of the Missing Shopping Carts
text: Greenport, the whaling village on Long Island’s North Fork, has emerged as a charming summertime destination whose art galleries and shops suggest a decaffeinated version of the Hamptons. (To all Greenporters, your death-threat calls and e-mail messages will not be answered until after Labor Day.)

headline: The Week in Comments: Taxis, Traffic, Water, Imus, Smokers, Dawgs, Segways and More
text: A look back at the week that was, in the words of our readers.

headline: Thompson at the Fair
text: DES MOINES — Like Mitt Romney, Rudolph W. Giuliani, Hillary Clinton and a host of other presidential candidates, the actor Fred Thompson punched his ticket at the Iowa State Fair today, acting very much the candidate despite legal restrictions on his political activity.

headline: Consequences for Lenders, Aid for Borrowers
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his Aug. 17 column, “Workouts, Not Bailouts.”

headline: Edwards Plays to the People
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s Aug. 17 column, “The Ascent of a Common Man.”

headline: Peering Back at the Window Gazers
text: In the newspaper world, there are articles that start with an urgent phone call from an editor and emerge magically from the sausage-making machine a few hours later. And there are articles that percolate for a lifetime. City Room asked me to explain how this article, part of the weekly Summer Rituals series, came to be.

headline: Fattest of the Hamptons Fat Cats?
text: The Southampton Hospital Thrift Shop, on Main Street in Southampton, is not your typical second-hand store. Designer clothing, heirloom jewelry and other precious castoffs from the rich and famous abound, although sometimes the prices make you wish you were paying retail.

headline: Here Come the Russian Bombers! Break Out the Duct Tape.
text: President Vladimir Putin of Russia announced today that his air force would resume the old Soviet practice, discontinued in 1992, of sending its strategic bombers on long-range patrols all over the world, including the edges of United States air space.

headline: What 207.297 M.P.H. Looks Like
text: On Wednesday, the Ford Fusion Hydrogen 999 broke 200 m.p.h. on the long course at the Bonneville Salt Flats:

headline: Lawsuit Challenges Google’s Keyword Ads
