text: Google and other search engines have been on the receiving end of a dozen or so lawsuits challenging a common practice in search advertising: the use of someone’s trademark, say Mercedes Benz, to show an ad for a competitor, say a BMW dealer. In that case, the BMW dealer would be buying ads tied to the search keyword “Mercedes Benz” from Google.

headline: In the Shadow of the U.S. Open
text: Located in the heart of Queens, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park has more to offer than just tennis.

headline: Blogtalk: Spitzer’s Ode, Carnage, Sitcoms, Tourists, and N.Y.U. Invades Brooklyn
text: What we’re reading on the local blogs…

headline: A Deadline for Red Hook Vendors
text: First, there were the “administrative issues” that caused a one-week delay in the return of the vendors to the Red Hook ball fields in Brooklyn. When the season did start in May, there was the small difference that they were set up inside the fence that rings the soccer field. No big hiccups there.

headline: Chablis
text: Had a little celebration the other day at Phoenix Garden, our favorite Cantonese restaurant, and the wine of the meal without a doubt was a 1996 premier cru Chablis “La Forest’’ from Vincent Dauvissat. This was classic Chablis at a peak, fresh and nervy and laden with tangy lime and crushed stone flavors. Its texture was captivating, and I thought it would be impossible to inhale these aromas and not love Chablis. I felt both inspired and greatly relieved.

headline: Rather Says Bloomberg Ruled Out White House Bid
text: Has Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unequivocally ruled out running for president? Dan Rather, the former CBS anchor who now hosts a news program at HDNet, thinks so.

headline: Remembrance of a Vital Institution
text: Martin Luther King Jr.-Harbor Hospital, which was erected in response to the Watts riots and is now closing, has played a vital role in the life of Watts.

headline: The Compact Disc Turns 25
text: Philips manufactured the first compact disc on this date in 1982, Slashdot and others note. If history is any guide, that makes the format late-middle-aged and nearing retirement, at least as a commercial music medium.

headline: For Clemens, It’s a Young 45
text: Looking at Phil Rizzuto’s career stats the other day, I noticed that he made his debut on April 14, 1941. That date was familiar for some reason — all those 1’s and 4’s – and it turns out that was the day Pete Rose was born.

headline: Beckham’s Afternoon Training Session
text: While Harper Collins was announcing his wife Victoria’s new book, David Beckham was uptown participating in a youth soccer clinic at Jacob Schiff Field in Harlem.

headline: Can You Hear Me Now?
text: As Jo Craven McGinty reported in The Times today, public phones are one of New York City’s more bizarre cash cows, generating $62 million annually — but in ad revenue instead of calls.

headline: P.M. Postscript: Family, Foreclosures and Fund-Raisers
text: The question has been coming up on the campaign trail this week and it did again today: Will Republican presidential candidate Rudolph W. Giuliani talk about his family?

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 17
text: Here is a slide show of 10 pictures taken in the New York region in the past week by photographers for The Times. Subjects include the funeral for a victim of the fatal schoolyard shooting in Newark, the Dominican Day Parade, Phil Rizzuto’s roots in Queens, and more.

headline: Why Wall Street Won’t Suffer
text: “The subprime-mortgage-market meltdown is a classic example of the way small fry get devoured, but the whales of Wall Street get rescued,” writes Fortune senior editor-at-large Allan Sloan. He adds:

text: For decades, the Iowa State Fair has been a must-attend event for political candidates. This week, the current crop of presidential contenders braved the crowds, the heat and the traditional pork-chop-on-a-stick, to keep the old tradition alive.  Go to Slide Show

headline: A Test for the Fed Chairman
text: After the Federal Reserve's move to cut the discount rate, the question is whether the chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, will cut rates further.

text: Fred Thompson appeared in Iowa Friday, acting very much the candidate despite legal restrictions on his political activity. (NBC video)

headline: The Stuff the Dream Cruise Is Made Of
text: The annual Dream Cruise up Woodward Avenue north of Detroit has morphed from a single-day charity event into a weeklong marketing extraganza, as Mary M. Chapman explained in The Times earlier this month.

headline: Taking Diabetes to Heart
text: Few diabetics do enough to protect themselves. Dave Smith thought he had been managing his symptoms when he suffered a heart attack.

headline: "Kid Nation"
text: A clip from the new CBS reality show.

headline: Chinese Businesses in Africa
text: A Chinese man who runs the biggest ice cream company in Malawi is emblematic of hundreds of thousands of Chinese who now do business in Africa.

headline: Fed Cuts Lending Rate in Surprise Move
text: The Federal Reserve today approved a half-percentage point cut in its discount rate on loans to banks, saying that it now feels that “tighter credit and increased uncertainty have the potential to restrain economic growth going forward.” Stocks immediately surged when markets opened on Wall Street, but shed much of the gains in morning trading.

headline: U.S. Proposes $2.78 Million Fine in Worker’s Death
text: Federal safety officials have called for a $2.78 million penalty against the Cintas Corporation, the nation’s largest supplier of uniforms, for violations at its Tulsa plant, where a worker died when he was pulled into a large dryer.

headline: Vacations Get Shorter, but Turn Up More Often
text: For years, Michele Clarke had trouble putting work aside and getting away with her husband and two young daughters for a rest. The last two-week vacation they took was in 2001, and Ms. Clarke, a corporate marketing consultant at Brainerd Communicators in Manhattan, worked through most of it on a laptop that her husband jokingly nicknamed “the beast.”

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,693 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

New Jersey Education Dept. Has Problems, Audit Finds
text: An audit of the New Jersey Education Department has found that inadequate staffing and resources, organizational problems and a lack of training and communications could hamper its ability to effectively oversee the state’s 615 school districts.

headline: Waking Up to the Real Estate Nightmare
text: It didn’t take a crystal ball to see that the collapse of the housing bubble was coming and that many home borrowers who took out risky loans were about to be squeezed. The warning signs, which have been visible for at least two years, were clear and repeated.

headline: Richard Bradshaw, Opera Director, Dies at 63
text: Richard Bradshaw, the conductor and general director of the Canadian Opera Company who pushed through the construction of a major new opera house in Toronto, died on Wednesday night. He was 63.

headline: Entrepreneurs From China Flourish in Africa
text: LILONGWE, Malawi — When Yang Jie left home at 18, he was doing what people from China’s hardscrabble Fujian Province have done for generations: emigrating in search of a better living overseas.

headline: Newest Tiger Is Still Rubbing His Eyes
text: Cameron Maybin was trying to sleep on a bus ride through Pennsylvania early yesterday morning, trying to doze through the three-and-a-half-hour trip from Erie to Altoona.

headline: No Applause, Please
text: CALL it the curse of the business press.

headline: It’s Time to Get Going, So Mets and Glavine Do
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 — The clock on the remainder of the Mets’ season started ticking at precisely 10:21 p.m. Thursday. That was one minute after their most embarrassing loss of 2007 came to a merciful end in Pittsburgh.

headline: Brooke Astor Is Eulogized, With Only a Hint of a Rift
text: The funeral yesterday afternoon for Brooke Astor, the grande dame of society and philanthropy who died on Monday at 105, was, much like the life of Mrs. Astor herself, marked by moments both warm and reserved, blue-blooded and democratic, earthly and spiritual, generous and, possibly, the slightest bit petty, rigidly executed and — at certain turns — playful.

headline: Election Equality (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Shy Festival Resolves to Seek Out Attention
text: LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 17 — The stillness of a glacier reigned. No trilling cellphones, hacking, fidgeting, whispering, text-messaging or any of the other distractions that can plague New York concert halls.

headline: Musical Mastery, Maybe
text: FOR a musician, there’s no better feeling than the one that comes from playing a piece of music perfectly after days or weeks of practice. Many beginning musicians give up because that feeling is elusive — few can just pick up a guitar for the first time and play even the simple opening riff to “Smoke on the Water.” Music is hard work.

headline: What a Difference a Simple Rate Cut Makes
text: As they have so often in the last few weeks, Wall Street traders came to work yesterday braced for the worst. Stock markets in Asia had taken a blow overnight. There was talk that the nation’s biggest home lender might be facing bankruptcy.

headline: Nokia Asks for Ban on Qualcomm Chip Imports
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 — Several developers of technology used in mobile phones are engaged in all-out hostilities over royalties and license fees on patents.

headline: Sosa, a So-So Starter, Thrives in Relief
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17  In three weeks, Jorge Sosa has gone from being the Mets’ least reliable starting pitcher to their most dependable reliever not named Billy Wagner.

A dance review on Monday about the inaugural performance of Morphoses, Christopher Wheeldon’s new ballet company, misidentified the company for which Hélène Bouchet, who is dancing with Morphoses, is a ballerina (and thus one of the companies from which the Morphoses cast is drawn). She is with the Hamburg Ballet, not the Munich Ballet; there are no Munich Ballet members in Morphoses.

headline: Flights of Experience: Movement as History
text: Live jazz. Athletic bodies, jumping and undulating. Rousing, infectiously enthusiastic performances by fine dancers. There’s much to enjoy about the Lula Washington Dance Theater, which offered a generous evening of crowd-pleasing music and dance on Thursday night at the Damrosch Park Bandshell as part of Lincoln Center Out of Doors.

headline: Two More Plea Deals Put Pressure on Vick
text: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 17 — Michael Vick’s future as a star in the National Football League became more tenuous Friday when two more of his co-defendants accepted plea agreements and implicated him in a dogfighting ring.

headline: When Students Go Abroad, Follow the Money (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Captain Admits to Affair, but Denies Beating Officer
text: A New York City police captain accused of assaulting a subordinate admitted in court yesterday that they had a forbidden sexual relationship, but he denied ever beating her.

headline: China: Cars Banned in Olympics Test
text: More than a million vehicles were ordered off the roads of Beijing as part of a test to gauge the city’s preparedness for next summer’s Olympic Games. With concern mounting that Beijing could be clogged with pollution and traffic during the Olympics, city officials began four days of driving restrictions to determine the impact on air quality and traffic flow. Results will be released later, but traffic was noticeably lighter, reducing some commuting times by half, and air quality seemed better, but a thin gauze of pollution still hung in the air.

headline: Wedding Etiquette (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: On the Spot
text: I’ve been thinking of a line in A. J. Liebling quoting the man he calls his literary adviser, Whitey Bimstein, who also trained prizefighters. “I once asked him how he liked the country,” Liebling writes. “He said, ‘It is a nice spot.’ ” I love this for the same reason Liebling does  the way it reduces the nonurban land surface of the planet to a single, homogeneous vanishing point. Mr. Bimstein was also perpetuating an ancient poetic habit, singling out an idealized setting from among the chiggers and ticks, the pokeweed and the poison ivy, in the actual countryside. I know some of Mr. Bimstein’s rural counterparts. They have lived in the country their whole lives and never once been to the city.

headline: Moves to Protect Children, and Bottom Lines
text: CHILDREN’S health was on business minds amid toy recalls and changes to nutritional advertising standards, while retail sales, hedge funds and a big stock issue by a high-tech company got Wall Street’s attention.

headline: Cabinet Official Addresses Safety of Imports
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17  Michael O. Leavitt, secretary of heath and human services, said Friday that it was impossible to check every import shipment that came into the United States but that the country should be prepared by the year 2015 to safeguard three times the imports it now inspects.

headline: In Praise of Scoops on Heaven, Hell and, Yes, God
text: The next time laments are heard and verdicts rendered about the media’s lack of attention to religion, will someone please remember Weekly World News?

headline: Like Old Times: Pettitte Rights Yanks
text: For most of the 54,290 fans in the stands at misty Yankee Stadium last night, this was the Andy Pettitte of their dreams. This was the Pettitte they remembered from the glory years, the one who took the ball in big games and delivered.

headline: House of Hartford’s Mayor Is Searched as Part of State Corruption Investigation
text: HARTFORD, Aug. 17 — Three candidates are challenging Mayor Eddie A. Perez in a Democratic primary next month, but Mr. Perez, this city’s first Hispanic leader, faced a graver test this week when state investigators searched his house in connection with an investigation into his hiring of a city contractor to renovate his kitchen and bathroom.

headline: Running Wrestling’s Empire
text: Professional wrestling has been making headlines recently, mostly from the case involving Chris Benoit, the wrestler who murdered his wife and 7-year-old son before killing himself in the family’s suburban Atlanta home in June.

headline: Thais to Vote on a Constitution That Would Restore Civilian Rule in Diluted Form
text: BANGKOK, Aug. 17  Thailand takes another step into its uncertain future on Sunday with a nationwide vote on a new constitution that analysts say is likely to weaken democratic processes and return power to traditional centers of authority.

headline: Stoking Metal’s Fire in the Heat of Summer
text: HOLMDEL, N.J., Aug. 16 — It seemed like a fairly ordinary day on Ozzy Osbourne’s annual Ozzfest tour, held this year at the PNC Bank Arts Center.

headline: Raising Sash for a View of the City’s Daily Ballet
text: Edna Ford starts early, at 6:30 a.m., sometimes 5. She showers, takes her medication, settles into the wheelchair by her window in the Bronx, then looks out at the courtyard.

headline: Boston College Expects to Score and Soar
text: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Aug. 16 — Boston College football will forever be defined by the seemingly impossible heave that beat Miami in 1984.

headline: Sometimes, It’s Not Easy Being in First Place
text: In a two- or three-day pair tournament, it is extremely rare for the duo leading going into the final day to win the event.

headline: Padilla Case Offers New Model of Terrorism Trial
text: There were two perfectly predictable schools of thought being expressed after the conviction of Jose Padilla on Thursday on terrorism-related charges. Supporters of the Bush administration said the conviction justified the more than three years Mr. Padilla spent in military detention before his criminal prosecution, while the administration’s opponents said the verdict proved that the criminal justice system should have handled the case in the first place.

headline: It’s Time to Get Professional About Getting Organized
text: Winnie Sandler knew she was running out of time. Her children, 9, 12 and 13, were away at summer camp, but soon school would start, and her family would be in a whirlwind for the next nine months if she didn’t get a system in place to organize the household.

headline: At German Base, Troops and Kin Gird for New Iraq Tour
text: WIESBADEN, Germany, Aug. 15 — With door prizes, a jazz band and thumping videos on a pair of large screens, the organizers of a rally at an American Army base here on Wednesday night did their best to create a festive atmosphere.

headline: Russia Resumes Patrols by Nuclear Bombers
text: MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 18 — President Vladimir V. Putin said Friday that the Russian Air Force would resume regular, long-range patrols by nuclear-capable bombers over the world’s oceans, renewing the practice after a 15-year hiatus in another sign of Russia’s growing assertiveness.

headline: Thompson Woos Iowa, a Presidential Hopeful in All but Formality
text: DES MOINES, Aug. 17 — Following in the path of Mitt Romney, Rudolph W. Giuliani, Hillary Rodham Clinton and a host of other presidential candidates, Fred D. Thompson punched his ticket at the Iowa State Fair on Friday, acting very much the candidate despite legal restrictions on his political activity.

headline: Markets Quake, and a ‘Neutral’ Strategy Slips
text: “We have to atone to our clients, but we have no right to whine for ourselves,” said Clifford Asness, the co-founder of AQR Capital Management, a money management firm that has been much in the news recently. “When we succeed, we make a boatload of money, we get imitators, and our risk increases. That’s how capitalism works.”

headline: Baseball’s Bad Bet
text: TIM DONAGHY, the National Basketball Association referee who pleaded guilty this week to federal charges stemming from his participation in an illegal gambling scheme, has sent a shudder through professional sports. Those who administer the games rightly fear for the integrity of their livelihoods, and those who watch the games fear for the purity of their pleasure.

headline: Journalist Signs to Write a Murdoch Biography
text: Michael Wolff, a columnist for Vanity Fair and the author of “Burn Rate,” a book about his experiences as an ill-fated dot-com entrepreneur, has signed with Doubleday to write a biography of Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation recently bought Dow Jones for $5 billion. The book was sold at auction, for a high six-figure advance, to Bill Thomas, editor in chief of the Doubleday Broadway Publishing Group. The deal was reported yesterday in The New York Post, which is owned by the News Corporation. Mr. Wolff, whose article about Mr. Murdoch appears in the September issue of Vanity Fair, expects to have the cooperation of Mr. Murdoch, members of his family and executives at News Corporation, though a spokesman for the publisher said the book was not an authorized biography. Doubleday expects to publish it in the fall of 2009.

headline: Judge Blocks Sentinel Plan to Sell Assets
text: The Sentinel Management Group cannot sell to the Citadel Investment Group assets that belong to two futures brokerage firms, a federal judge ruled yesterday in a $15.2 million lawsuit stemming from credit market volatility.

headline: At Camp, Coming Closer to the Earth, and Its Bounty
text: POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y., Aug. 13 — Eleven-year-old Cynthia Cabreja, nearly overwhelmed by an enormous red backpack, stared coolly over a mild-shock electric fence at several dozen frolicking baby piglets, many of them suckling furiously at the engorged udders of the three giant sows that had birthed them.

headline: A Better Way to Feed the Hungry
text: The traditional method of feeding the world’s hungry with American crops seems to be falling into disfavor. An article in The Times this week by Celia Dugger disclosed that CARE, the big global charity, had decided to stop selling subsidized American farm products in poor African countries because the program was inefficient and undercut local farmers.

headline: Germany: Ex-Red Army Member Freed
text: Eva Haule, a former member of the Red Army Faction who was convicted of participating in the murder of an American soldier in 1985 and later in the bombing of the Rhein-Main Air Base in Frankfurt when it was the main base for United States forces in Europe, is being released from prison after 21 years. She is the second former member of the extreme left-wing militant group, which was also known as the Baader-Meinhof gang, to be freed this year.

headline: One Bridge Doesn’t Fit All
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: Beckham’s Gift for Glamour and Goals
text: He was born with the gift. Even at 8 or 9, he could thump the ball harder and farther than his friends.

headline: Afghanistan: Official and Family Killed
text: A suicide bomber killed a district chief and three of his children in southern Kandahar Province, officials said. The chief, Khairuddin Kaka, was the top government official in Zhari, a rural district west of Kandahar City that has experienced a string of Taliban attacks. An unidentified man approached Mr. Kaka after he left a house in Kandahar City in the morning with his 2-year-old daughter and 6- and 12-year-old sons, according to a police official. They died when the unidentified man detonated explosives, killing himself as well.

headline: World View Podcast
text: GREG WINTER. Welcome to The New York Times World View podcast, a weekly conversation with Times foreign correspondents from across the globe. I’m Greg Winter, a foreign editor at The Times.

headline: 5 Former Officials Are Sentenced for Apartheid-Era Crime
text: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 17  Five security officials who confessed to the attempted murder of a black activist in the dying days of South Africa’s apartheid government received suspended sentences on Friday, ending a case that reopened a national debate about forgiveness for racial crimes.

headline: FedEx Cup Will Begin Without Woods
text: Tiger Woods stars in television commercials for the PGA Tour’s inaugural FedEx Cup playoffs, whistling the theme to “Rocky III,” and speaking to a portrait of Bobby Jones. But he will not appear in next week’s kickoff tournament at Westchester Country Club.

headline: Court Weighs Making Public Rulings on U.S. Wiretapping
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17  A secret court caught in the middle of a fierce political debate over the government’s wiretapping powers took a step toward greater transparency on Friday.

headline: Plan for Site of ’06 Blast on East Side Is Criticized
text: The Links Club usually whispers. This week, it growled.

headline: Ozzfest Pandemonium: 2 Die, 83 Are Arrested
text: Two men died and 83 people were arrested on Thursday at the Ozzfest concert in Holmdel, N.J., as the New Jersey State Police have stepped up security at the PNC Bank Arts Center to combat under-age drinking.

headline: S.I. Man Is Charged in Death and Abuse of Infant Son
text: A 21-year-old Staten Island man whose infant son died in May was arraigned on manslaughter charges yesterday, after the city medical examiner’s office found that the boy’s death had been caused by traumatic head injuries. The autopsy also showed signs of severe sexual abuse, the authorities said.

headline: Recalling Cold War, Russia Resumes Long-Range Sorties
text: MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 18 — President Vladimir V. Putin said Friday that the Russian Air Force would begin regular, long-range patrols by nuclear-capable bombers over the world’s oceans, resuming the practice after a 15-year hiatus in another sign of Russia’s growing assertiveness.

headline: Jittery Markets Deflate Trades Centered on Yen
text: SINGAPORE, Aug. 17 — The recent volatility in global stock markets has raised the prospect that a distinguishing feature of the financial world for years now, an investing strategy known as the yen carry trade, is losing some of its appeal.

headline: The Beat Goes On, Minus a Virtuoso
text: Sitting in a narrow dressing room behind a heavy red curtain at the Birdland jazz club in Midtown, the saxophonist James Moody, 82, rested his head in his hand and remembered gigs with Dizzy Gillespie, Thelonious Monk and someone else: Max Roach, his longtime friend, the legendary jazz drummer who died on Thursday at age 83.

headline: Extremes in Weather Kill Dozens Across U.S.
text: SAN ANTONIO, Aug. 17 (AP)  Rescuers searched Friday for people swept away in flash floods caused by the remnants of Tropical Storm Erin, as wary residents across the Gulf Coast watched as Hurricane Dean charged through the Caribbean.

headline: Having It All as a Wife (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Amgen Finds Growing Up Isn’t So Easy
text: AMGEN won over investors who viewed it as the first biotechnology company to graduate from adolescence to adulthood. It continued to grow fast, and its new maturity added something that other biotechs lacked: profits.

headline: China Seeks to Regain Confidence on Food Safety
text: SHANGHAI, Aug. 17 — After a series of high-profile recalls this year, the Chinese government announced Friday that it had formed a cabinet-level committee to improve the quality and safety of the nation’s food and other products, both for consumption at home and for export.

headline: U.S. Agency Is Swamped by Requests for Visas
text: Immigration authorities have received about 300,000 applications for high-skilled-employment visas since July 1, federal officials said yesterday, a deluge unleashed after the federal government first said it would not accept any applications for those visas during July and then reversed course.

headline: How the Vast Desert Teaches a Man Introspection
text: CAIRO

headline: U.S. May Add Eritrea to List of Nations Backing Terrorists
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 — The Bush administration is considering designating Eritrea as a state sponsor of terrorism, accusing it of running arms to Islamic insurgents in Somalia, the State Department’s top official for Africa said Friday.

headline: Happy Birthday, CD
text: The first compact disc ever produced rolled off the assembly line exactly 25 years ago yesterday, according to the BBC. The disc, a recording of “The Visitors” by Abba, was manufactured at a Philips factory near Hanover, Germany, on Aug. 17, 1982. The first CDs went on sale in November of that year, and since then more than 200 billion are estimated to have been sold worldwide. The creation of the CD, a joint effort of Philips and Sony, marked the beginning of the digital era in sound and image. The CD is still the dominant musical format despite the rapid growth in downloading music, legally or otherwise, from the Internet.

headline: Warrant Seeks Saddam Hussein’s Wife and Daughter
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 17 — An Interpol arrest order for Saddam Hussein’s eldest daughter and his first wife has been circulated, Iraqi officials said Friday.

headline: Edwards Says He Will Drop His Investments in Subprime Lenders
text: DES MOINES, Aug. 17 — The John Edwards presidential campaign said on Friday that Mr. Edwards would divest his portfolio at a New York hedge fund of investments in subprime mortgage companies that have foreclosed on victims of Hurricane Katrina. But the campaign said he would keep his $16 million investment in the hedge fund, the Fortress Investment Group.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: ‘Daily Show’ Goes to War

headline: Carolyn Goodman, Rights Champion, Dies at 91
text: Carolyn Goodman, a Manhattan clinical psychologist who became a nationally prominent civil rights advocate after her son Andrew and two other civil rights workers were murdered by the Ku Klux Klan in Mississippi in 1964, died yesterday at her home on the Upper West Side. She was 91.

headline: Theater’s Alternative Universe
text: As an experience in scruffy cultural consumption, the New York International Fringe Festival is without parallel in Manhattan, or possibly anywhere else.

headline: Ralph Alpher, 86, Expert in Work on the Big Bang, Dies
text: Ralph Alpher, a physicist whose early calculations and theoretical predictions supported the Big Bang concept for the origin of the universe, though his role was largely overlooked as later discoveries proved him right, died last Sunday in Austin, Tex. He was 86.

headline: A CBS Reality Show Draws a Claim of Possible Child Abuse
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 — The ads promoting “Kid Nation,” a new reality show coming to CBS next month, extol the incredible experience of a group of 40 children, ages 8 to 15, who built a sort of idealistic society in a New Mexico ghost town, free of adults. For 40 days the children cooked their own meals, cleaned their own outhouses, formed a government and ran their own businesses, all without adult intervention or participation.

headline: Of Mitt, Monks, and Mowers
text: Mitt Romney’s campaign has been trying to position him as the conservative alternative to Rudy Giuliani. They went searching desperately for examples of Rudy’s closet liberalism that do not involve things Mitt himself was doing until about five minutes ago. (Divorces will only take you so far.) They pounced on immigration, and, suddenly, New Yorkers discovered they are living in a “sanctuary city.”

headline: Latest Genealogy Tools Create a Need to Know
text: Katherine Holden’s family had long kept what she called “a deep dark secret.” When the family discussed its roots, there were hints, but no outright discussion, of a great-grandmother who had lived in South Dakota and was the equivalent of native royalty: the putative daughter of an American Indian chief.

headline: Daily Show Goes to War
text: “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” often places its mock reporters in mock locations  typically in front of digital backdrops of Congress or the White House. In a break with that tradition, the show announced yesterday that Rob Riggle, right, its “senior war correspondent,” had actually filed a week’s worth of reports from Iraq. “Yes, actual Iraq, not green-screen Iraq,” Comedy Central said in a statement. Mr. Riggle, who the channel said is a major in the Marine Corps Reserve and has served in Liberia, Kosovo and Afghanistan, was in Iraq this week as part of a U.S.O. comedy tour. He took along a writer and a producer from “The Daily Show” and shot segments with the troops whenever the tour schedule allowed. Mr. Riggle is to return from Iraq today, said Renata Luczak, a Comedy Central spokeswoman, who added that what he would bring back with him was a bit of a mystery. “Due to intense military security the show had very little contact with them to see what they got,” Ms. Luczak said. “ The show is getting the footage over the weekend.” Mr. Riggle’s reports, titled “Operation Silent Thunder: ‘The Daily Show’ in Iraq,” are to begin on Monday.

headline: Dancing Lessons
text: Sabra Johnson, below, a 20-year-old native of Utah, earned the title of “America’s Favorite Dancer,” along with a grand prize of $250,000, on Thursday night during the two-hour finale of Fox’s “So You Think You Can Dance.” The show powered Fox to its 13th consecutive Thursday-night ratings victory among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the finale averaged 9.4 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., and more than 11 million in its final half-hour. CBS ranked No. 2 over all, as both “Big Brother” at 8 (7.5 million) and a repeat of “CSI” at 9 (9.5 million) earned solid second-place finishes in their time slots. CBS’s “Without a Trace” (9 million) dominated the all-rerun 10 o’clock hour, ahead of ABC’s “Men in Trees” (3.6 million) and NBC’s “ER” (3.4 million). ABC and NBC finished about even in third for the night, although NBC fared better in the 18-to-49 demographic.

headline: The Jets’ Offense Sputters Without Jones
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 17 — There was a hole in the offensive backfield, a haze obscuring Chad Pennington’s vision and an altogether messy look to the Jets’ offense Friday night.

headline: Ethics Panel Subpoenas Reporter in Scandal
text: In an extremely rare move, the State Ethics Commission issued a subpoena this week to a reporter involved in the ethics scandal surrounding Gov. Eliot Spitzer, a signal that a full investigation into actions of the governor’s staff is under way.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page obituary yesterday about the jazz drummer Max Roach incorrectly rendered the name of his birthplace. It is Newland, not New Land, N.C. (Go to Article)

headline: The Fed’s Sudden Action Eases a Logjam in Corporate Borrowing
text: The Federal Reserve Board’s move yesterday to stabilize the credit markets helped to ease the pressure on a mundane but crucial part of the financial markets: short-term lending to corporations.

headline: Fire Breaks Out at Ground Zero
text: Flames tore through several floors of the vacant Deutsche Bank skyscraper opposite ground zero Saturday afternoon, sending potentially toxic plumes of smoke over Lower Manhattan in a scene eerily reminiscent of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline: Herndon, Va.’s Labors
text: Here’s what Roy Beck, the executive director of NumbersUSA, the hard-core anti-immigration organization, said in an e-mail after the Bush administration announced a border-and-workplace crackdown: “The illegal alien communities  and the outlaw businesses that hire them  are in a panic this weekend. It is most important that all of us contribute to that panic and ensure that it continues.”

headline: ‘Daily Show’ Alumnus Signs Deal With HBO
text: Ben Karlin, a creative force behind “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” for eight years who stepped down as its executive producer in December, is taking his act to HBO.

headline: Utah Mine Rescuers Halt Search After 3 Deaths
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 17 — A sense of doleful finality settled on Friday over the quivering mountain here that swallowed six coal miners 11 days ago.

headline: After Loss of Majority, Several Republicans Head for Exits
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 — A rash of retirements among House Republicans is adding to the party’s electoral challenges and raising questions about a rush for the exits.

headline: An Open-Minded Doctor (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lebanon Bans Tale of Fighters in Militias
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 17 — Over the next three months, the Lebanese artist Rabih Mroué will stage his new performance piece in Paris, Rome and the capitals of Tunisia, Morocco and Egypt. But he will not present it here, for the audience with whom it might resonate most.

headline: White House to Offer Iraq Plan of Gradual Cuts
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 — The White House plans to use a report next month assessing progress in Iraq to outline a plan for gradual troop reductions beginning next year that would fall far short of the drawdown demanded by Congressional opponents of the war, according to administration and military officials.

headline: Movement in High Gear, Intimacy Most Fleeting
text: BECKET, Mass., Aug. 16 — Henri Oguike has taken Britain by storm since forming his London-based modern-dance troupe in 1999. Trained at the London Contemporary Dance School and a former dancer with Richard Alston, Mr. Oguike has won numerous awards and driven many British reviewers into paroxysms of unqualified delight.

headline: Winehouse Cancels
text: Amy Winehouse, below, has canceled all her August concerts after being hospitalized last week for “severe exhaustion,” The Associated Press reported. Tracey Miller, a spokeswoman for Ms. Winehouse, the 23-year-old British soul singer, said she was putting her touring commitments aside “to address her health issues.” Ms. Miller added that “her family has requested that the media respect Amy’s privacy at this time. There will be no further comment.” British newspapers reported this week that Ms. Winehouse had checked into  and then out of  a rehab clinic near London. Her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, said on Thursday that the couple had just gone home to pick up a guitar. “Don’t worry,” he said, “she’s being looked after. We’re going back to this retreat. She’s determined to get well.” Ms. Winehouse is scheduled to begin a North American tour next month.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) PAN’S LABYRINTH  (2006) The Mexican-born Guillermo del Toro directed this political fable cum fairy tale, set in a dark forest in 1944 Spain, about a young girl whose fantasies are trampled by her stepfather’s fascist politics. The film, in Spanish with English subtitles, received Academy Awards for cinematography, art direction and makeup, but lost the Oscar for best foreign-language film to “The Lives of Others,” from Germany. Ivana Baquero plays the film’s heroine, Ofelia, who longs to believe in fairies, princesses and magic lands; Doug Jones, above, plays the woodland creature (a couple of them, actually) who charges her with three tasks. “Fairy tales (and scary movies) are designed to console as well as terrify,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “What distinguishes ‘Pan’s Labyrinth,’ what makes it art, is that it balances its own magical thinking with the knowledge that not everyone lives happily ever after.”

headline: Keeping Cool, Clear Tap Water
text: Americans have some of the best water in the world — a bragging point that seems to have gotten lost lately, even by those who take their daily exercise by waving the flag. Perhaps it is because the bottled water industry markets their product with waterfalls and soothing colors to make it seem like the clearest, cleanest, healthiest drink on earth. Unfortunately, that marketing can make tap water seem less clear, less clean and less healthy. When New York City did a survey on tap water recently, one youth was asked whether he drank from the public water fountains. “Yes,” he said, “but I’m going to die.”

headline: New Field for Earmarks in U.S. Goals on Energy
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 — Tucked away among the $3.2 billion in Congressional earmarks in the recently passed energy and water spending bill is a $4 million grant to a small company in suburban Chicago that is trying to solve the problem of capturing and storing carbon dioxide emissions.

headline: Grimmest Site in a Grim Peruvian City: The Cemetery
text: PISCO, Peru, Aug. 17 — No site in this ruined city rivals in misery the cemetery, where hundreds of people milled around freshly dug graves on Friday.

headline: Texas Trader Admits Guilt in Iraq Oil-for-Food Fraud
text: A Houston oil trader pleaded guilty yesterday in New York to federal fraud charges in connection with illegal profits and kickbacks involving the United Nations oil-for-food program in Iraq during Saddam Hussein’s rule.

headline: Fearing Slide in Economy, Fed Cuts Its Discount Rate
text: The Federal Reserve, saying for the first time that the recent disorder in the financial markets has raised the risk of an economic downturn, took the unusual step yesterday of encouraging the nation’s banks to borrow directly from the Fed, particularly to support home mortgage lending.

headline: In Automotive Trade Deficit, a Silver Lining for U.S.
text: IT helps to have a weak dollar and a declining auto market. At least it helps if you want to lower the American trade deficit.

headline: Playing Part-Time, Damon Is Weighing His Options
text: In the waning moments of Thursday’s loss to the Tigers, there was only one Yankee on the top step of the dugout. It was Johnny Damon, wearing a windbreaker and no cap, sitting and cheering. It was the most he could do after being removed for a pinch-hitter in the sixth inning.

headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Stops Selling Lead-Tainted Bibs
text: Toys “R” Us halted the sale of vinyl baby bibs at its stores nationwide yesterday and offered customers refunds on perhaps more than a million bibs after tests confirmed that at least some of the Chinese-made items are contaminated with lead.

headline: Being Right Is Bittersweet for a Critic of Lenders

headline: Coughlin Is Concerned by Burress’s Absence
text: ALBANY, Aug. 17  Giants wide receiver Plaxico Burress will not play in Sunday’s preseason game against the Baltimore Ravens because of an ankle sprain, and one of his backups, Sinorice Moss, could also miss the game with the same injury.

headline: A Homecoming for Hughes
text: Remember how you felt the first time you spent a really, really long time away from home? Remember the feeling just before you went back? That’s what Phil Hughes experienced tonight. He’s still only 21, remember.

headline: Fare of the Country
text: All over the tristate area, the concept of buying local food is growing at rates that have farmers, serious cooks and even the most casual farm stand shoppers in awe. What are your thoughts about the pursuit of farm fresh flavor? Go to Article

headline: Gay Couples and Adoption
text: For one gay couple, adopting a child brought a new focus into their lives, taking them from Manhattan to the suburbs to raise their new son. What are your thoughts on gay couples adopting children? Go to Article

headline: Premiere of ‘High School Musical 2’ Breaks Ratings Record
text: The Friday night premiere of the Disney Channel made-for-television movie "High School Musical 2" has set numerous ratings records and delivered the largest single audience in basic-cable television history, according to preliminary ratings reports provided by Disney.

headline: Aronian, Bologan Win Chess960 Events in Mainz
text: Vicktor Bologan, a grandmaster from Moldova, has won a Chess960 tournament at the Chess Classic in Mainz. The tournament used the rules of Chess960, also known as Fischer Random Chess, where all the pieces, except for the pawns, are shuffled before the first move. The idea is that players cannot use the openings that they have learned for regular chess and must instead rely on their wits from the beginning of the game. A good explanation of the rules and the history of Chess960 can be found here. The home page for the Mainz event, with all the results and some of the games, is here.

headline: Notes from Montana
text: So here I am, at a ranch in Montana miles from a grocery store. But there is Internet access, and I wanted to share a couple of things with you.

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, Aug. 19
text: Top White House adviser Karl Rove may be leaving his job at the end of the month, but his ability to be a thorn in the side of Democrats is clearly very much intact. While ABC’s “This Week” with George Stephanopoulos will feature a debate with the Democratic presidential candidates, Mr. Rove is set to appear on three other Sunday talk shows – a move that’s likely to steal some of the Democrats’ thunder.

Bloomberg confirmed at a news conference this evening. Mr. Bloomberg said there was “no danger” that the building would collapse and preliminary tests showed no environmental hazards.

text: Good evening from Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., on the banks of the brackish Hackensack River, within shouting distance of Manhattan.

headline: Correction

Mr. Spitzer has appointed two of five members of this commission (one in his former role as Attorney General). The Commission appointed the executive director.

headline: The Source With No Name

She brushes him off, declaring: “A journalist? Hell, what does that mean? Peeking through keyholes? ... A lot of daffy buttinskis running around without a nickel in their pockets and for what?”

headline: A Finding of Umpire Bias Is Small but Still Striking
text: Game officials have been quite the topic of discussion lately, what with the former N.B.A. referee Tim Donaghy pleading guilty Wednesday to two felony charges pertaining to gambling. But as salacious as explicit association with bettors has been, it was implicit association  the tendency for people in split-second interactions to favor members of their own race  that drew the attention of some prominent economists.

headline: A Day of Disney Magic Now Costs More
text: Walt Disney World (www.disneyworld.com) has raised its prices a third time in two years. An adult one-day, one-park pass has increased to $71 from $67; the same pass now costs $60 for children 3 to 9. Rick Sylvain, a spokesman, said that the cost of a full day at the park is still less than a full-priced ticket to a Broadway show, adding, “The longer you stay, the less you pay per day.” A seven-day pass ($219 for adults, $182 for children), for example, averages out to $31.29 a day for adults and $26 for children.

headline: Katrina Wuensch, Colin Loggins
text: The Rev. Katrina Ruth Wuensch and Colin Anthony Loggins were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church of Newfane, Vt. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Clough, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

headline: Oxygen Ran Out Quickly in 14-Story Climb to the Fire
text: The Fire Department’s emergency air packs are meant to provide firefighters with roughly 40 minutes of vital oxygen. But there is a catch: the harder a fighter has to breathe, the more quickly the oxygen runs out.

headline: A Beautiful Duet
text: NEKO CASE doesn’t play weddings, but tonight she was making an exception. On a recent Saturday the indie-rock superbabe took the stage at Union Hall in Brooklyn and warned a group of guests that the music they were about to hear was highly inappropriate for the occasion.

headline: Designated Villain
text: I come to bury George Steinbrenner, not to praise him. The all-conquering owner of the New York Yankees is not actually dead, of course, though he has withdrawn from public view; in a recent news account, a baseball executive described the Yankee owner as “inconsistently lucid.” But the era of the man who has in many ways personified baseballto the detriment of a game that many Americans, despite everything, still cherish — has ended. Historians will note that the terminal moment arrived July 31, when the Yankees, though trailing the first-place Boston Red Sox by eight games, allowed the league’s trading deadline to pass without dealing away any of their minor-league prospects in exchange for an established star who might help them win right now.

headline: That Yawn After Lunch Is Perfectly Normal
text: Q. Every day after lunch, you find yourself overcome by drowsiness, and you can’t get any work done because you just want to crawl under your desk and go to sleep. Why does this happen?

headline: Brooke Fitzsimmons, Todd Welsch
text: Brooke Diane Fitzsimmons, the daughter of Sandra and James J. Fitzsimmons of Rehoboth, Mass., was married last evening to Todd Christian Welsch, the son of Grace and James R. Welsch of New York. The Rev. George Witt performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

headline: Without a Net
text: In the early 1860s, Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr., then a brash Harvard undergraduate, wrote an essay criticizing Plato, whose classifications of ideas he found “loose and unscientific.” Holmes sent a copy of the essay to Emerson, whose books, he later said, had “set me on fire.” He soon received in return a nugget of stern wisdom. “I have read your piece,” Emerson replied. “When you strike at a king you must kill him.”

headline: A Troubled Parade, This One Without Shamrocks
text: The St. Patrick’s Day Parade has long struggled over the participation of gay groups. The National Puerto Rican Day Parade was scarred in 2000 by wide-ranging attacks on women. But a lower-profile march, the Pakistani Independence Day Parade, set for next Sunday, is competing with them both for fireworks.

headline: Yvette Lee, Scott Crowley

Crowley of Greece, N.Y. The Rev. Laurie B. Crowley, a sister of the bridegroom and a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Wainwright House in Rye, N.Y., with the Rev. Seung Ik Lee, a Presbyterian minister, taking part.

headline: Another Summer, Same Dark Stage
text: FOR the second consecutive summer, there is no Hamptons Shakespeare Festival in Montauk.

headline: French Foreign Minister Visits Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 19 — The French foreign minister, Bernard Kouchner, arrived in Baghdad today on the highest-level visit by a French official to Iraq since the 2003 invasion.

headline: Notes on Prison Camp
text: This short book prints 22 poems by detainees at the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, that have been cleared for release by the United States military. The poems — some by accomplished writers, others by first-time poets — suffer “some flaws,” as the book’s editor, Marc Falkoff, himself a lawyer for 17 detainees, puts it. It is hard to imagine a reader so hardhearted as to bring aesthetic judgment to bear on a book written by men in prison without legal recourse, several of them held in solitary confinement, some of them likely subjected to practices that many disinterested parties have called torture. You don’t read this book for pleasure; you read it for evidence. And if you are an American citizen you read it for evidence of the violence your government is doing to total strangers in a distant place, some of whom (perhaps all of whom, since without due process how are we to tell?) are as innocent of crimes against our nation as you are.

headline: Homey With a Dash of Dated
text: SOMETIMES you can go home again.

headline: The Politics of God

headline: Scoop!
text: In this sprawling memoir, the journalist Robert D. Novak feeds his keyboard more than five decades of newspaper clips, expense account filings and graying memory to chronicle his career as political reporter, syndicated columnist, television commentator and, finally, leading character in the outing of the C.I.A. officer Valerie Plame. As artless as it is fascinating, “The Prince of Darkness” dishes gossip and delivers payback to enemies for ancient slights; and on nearly every page it illustrates Novak’s noisome journalistic methods.

headline: Sometimes, Vegan Food Doesn’t Mean Tofurkey
text: Until recently, it’s been difficult to take vegan cuisine (made with no animal products) seriously. Vegan menus were full of things like vegan meatloaf and tofu cheese, imitations that only served to highlight what the food was missing. Without a cultural context, vegan has seemed more contrivance than a cuisine.

headline: A Generation Finds Its Mumble
text: RECENT rumblings — perhaps one should say mumblings — indicate an emerging movement in American independent film. Specimens of the genre share a low-key naturalism, low-fi production values and a stream of low-volume chatter often perceived as ineloquence. Hence the name: mumblecore.

headline: Some Kind of Sign
text: In the seventh century B.C., the Egyptian pharaoh Psammetichus conducted an unusual experiment: he plucked a couple of infants from their mothers and turned them over to a shepherd, to be raised in seclusion and in the absence of any spoken word. The idea was that whatever sounds the babies spontaneously emitted would reveal the oldest, the original human language.

headline: A Venerable Versailles Hotel to Shine Anew
text: The recently refurbished Hall of Mirrors in the Château de Versailles with its 30 restored Charles Le Brun paintings, 357 mirrors (48 of them new replacements) and 8,400 square feet of freshly buffed parquet flooring, must have helped to inspire the owners of the nearby Trianon Palace and Spa to renovate. The 200-room property, built in 1909 by René Sergent (designer of the Plaza Athénée in Paris), will unveil the first phase of its transformation on Sept. 1, including 101 newly designed rooms. But unlike the Baroque style of the palace, the hotel rooms will have a more modern feel. The other 99 rooms, spa and restaurants are to be finished by February. Rates start at 200 euros, about $280 at $1.41 to the euro (www.westin.com/trianon).

headline: From Salzburg, a Mozart-a-thon
text: WHEN the Salzburg Festival announced performances of all 22 Mozart operas to commemorate his 250th birthday last summer, some hardened music critics gave a deep sigh and wondered why. Must we, they asked, always schedule these compulsive marches through the complete Mozart on his big anniversaries, which now seem to arrive with positively eerie frequency?

headline: Seeking Equilibrium on Wall St.
text: WHO says there is uncertainty in the markets? It seems to have become a sure thing that before any trading session is over, some bank will have disclosed problems related to speculative debt.

headline: Vacant Rooms, Empty Feelings
text: THE front of the Fordham Library Center, a stately old brick building on a quiet block of Bainbridge Avenue just north of the teeming retail strip of Fordham Road, is covered in graffiti now, and one of its green-trimmed windows is broken. A sign in a display case next to the door reads: “The library is now closed. We will be opening January 17, 2006, in our new location.”

headline: Racing Becomes Afterthought as Focus Turns to Breeding and Big Bucks
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17  The winner of next Saturday’s Travers, Saratoga’s marquee race, will join a list that includes marquee names like Man o’ War and Whirlaway.

headline: Activist Message, Flown In From the Past
text: ROSCOE C. BROWN JR., 85, stood drill-baton straight addressing the audience after the first performance of “Fly,” a new play about the all-black Army Air Corps fighter squadron known as the Tuskegee Airmen. One of a few hundred remaining members of that World War II unit, he held up the Congressional Gold Medal that it had taken the government until last March to award to the squadron.

text: AND the winner is ... Sam Brownback.

headline: Winning Is the Only Thing for the U.S. Basketball Team
text: The Dream Team, in its various incarnations, has never lacked talent or star quality, only humility, cohesion and, occasionally, experience. So it seemed appropriate when Jason Kidd, in a July team meeting, referenced his 28-0 record in international play, turned to his youthful compatriots LeBron James and Carmelo Anthony and said, “I don’t want to see you guys messing with that record, either.”

headline: More Highways? Let’s Think Again; Today’s Solution, Tomorrow’s Problem; Teenage Employment on the Decline; Legislation Needed to Curb Plastic Bags (4 Letters)
text: More Highways? Let’s Think Again

headline: Bigger. Stronger. Better?
text: As the youngest of seven children, Abby Wambach grew up playing the role of family tackling dummy. By age 7, she was routinely lashed into hockey pads so her brothers could fire pucks at her in the neighborhood cul-de-sac. Even at meals, she was on defense: she learned to quickly bite each French fry in half so that her siblings wouldn't raid her plate. Twenty years later, Wambach offers this sage life lesson: “Always cut your underwear a little so that when your brothers hang you on the doorknob, it will tear away easier.”

headline: Margaret Strickler, Evan Powers
text: Margaret Evans Hennen Strickler, the daughter of Diana and Richard S. Strickler Jr. of Charlottesville, Va., was married there yesterday to Evan James Powers, a son of Elaine and John Powers of Wellesley, Mass. The Rev. Jeffrey P. Fishwick, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

headline: Too Much of a Good Thing Is Resulting in Tough Choices for Torre
text: The rules of baseball state that a team must field a pitcher and eight position players. This presents a daily problem for Manager Joe Torre, who has more than eight competent everyday players at his disposal, many of them high-salaried veterans.

headline: Toomer Thrives in Right Place at Right Time
text: ALBANY, Aug. 17  Eli Manning dropped back and looked for tight end Jeremy Shockey over the middle. But Shockey was lost in a maze of safeties and linebackers flooding the interior of the field.

headline: Lift Your Coffee Cup
text: Because Montclair sometimes seems more like a sixth borough of New York City than a town — it’s been called the Upper West Side West — newcomers to Toast might be forgiven for thinking they’ve entered New Jersey’s version of a hip breakfast spot in, say, Brooklyn.

headline: An Elegant Design to Complement a Bold Personality
text: LAST year, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg paid $45 million for a crisp, elegant town house at Madison Avenue and 78th Street to be the headquarters for the newly created Bloomberg Family Foundation.

headline: Beth Bitton, Michael Satlin
text: Beth Bitton and Dr. Michael Joseph Satlin were married last evening at the East Meadow Jewish Center in East Meadow, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald Androphy performed the ceremony.

headline: Have a Baby, Win a Prize
text: European countries have been experimenting with ways to halt a decades-long decline in fertility rates. The Irish Independent, in its Aug. 17 issue, took note of a Russian effort:

headline: Arpita Patel, Salil Pitroda
text: Dr. Arpita Hiralal Patel and Salil Satyan Pitroda were married yesterday in Hauppauge, N.Y. Pandit Ashok Vyas, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Hyatt Regency Long Island.

headline: Gifts of Gab
text: Take an electronic book or audiobook or DVD player down to the beach, and you risk getting the plot clogged up with sand. But take a book with paper pages, and you read it even through the stains of suntan oil (or as it is now apt to be, sunblock). At summer’s end, try a trio of Gutenberg-style volumes — the retronym is “print-page books” — about the use and abuse of words.

headline: Armchair Traveler
text: ‘MTV Travel Guides’

headline: He Never Stopped Walking
text: Matthew Stanley, 43

headline: Yippee Kay Oof!
text: A successful bull ride is eight seconds of waltz crossed with a wrestling match. The cowboy tries to situate his center of gravity over the bull's and somehow convince the judges that he, not the 1,500-pound bull, is dancing lead. In the 14-year history of the Professional Bull Riders tour, no one has done a better job of that than Adriano Moraes, who first rode a calf as a child in Brazil. Moraes, 37, is the oldest and most decorated member of the circuit, winner of an unprecedented three world championships, in 1994, 2001 and 2006. How has the old man — on perhaps his last lap around the circuit — managed to succeed, let alone survive, in this young man's sport?

headline: Keep College Gates Open
text: New Haven

headline: Trying to Be Green, With Very Little Water
text: ONE of the Mediterranean’s prized stretches of virgin coast lies on the eastern tip of the Greek island of Crete — more than 6,000 acres of land on a craggy peninsula dotted with scrubby bouquets of thyme and sage. If all goes as planned, a group of international investors will turn that land into Cavo Sidero, which is already being promoted as the largest eco-friendly luxury tourism development in southeastern Europe.

Benjamin Bryant, an uncle of the bride who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, officiated at a private estate in Wareham, Mass.

headline: Figures in a Landscape
text: Arthur Key, one of the characters at the center of Ron Carlson’s bluntly beautiful and unnerving novel, is a set builder for Hollywood films, a designer of three-sided barns, parts of fences and corners of houses, “sometimes just a frame with a tile roof.” He’s dependable and a stickler for safety, willing to lose a job to save a few lives. Which makes it that much worse when his brother dies on a film set after Arthur has failed to look out for him.

headline: Peru’s Troops Try to Restore Order in Areas Hit by Quake
text: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 18 — Faced with looting by armed gangs in the southern region devastated by Wednesday’s earthquake and under strain of electricity blackouts and short supplies of food and water, the authorities here said Saturday that they were sending 600 soldiers in an attempt to impose order.

headline: 15 Afghans Are Killed by Car Bomb
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 18 — A suicide car bomb attack killed 13 civilians and two Afghan security guards on the outskirts of Kandahar on Saturday morning, Afghan officials said, in one of the deadliest attacks in southern Afghanistan this year.

headline: Keyla Lozano, Tito Kon
text: Keyla Johanna Lozano was married yesterday to Tito Raul Kon. The Rev. Michael Marotta, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph Roman Catholic Church in Lodi, N.J.

headline: No Longer Lost, a Refugee Accepts Call to Leadership
text: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — About 7,000 miles separate Grace Episcopal Church here, where the Rev. Zachariah Jok Char preaches most Sundays, from the small town of Duk Padiet in Sudan, where he was born.

text: This year Wölffer Estate, in Sagaponack, has been on the covers of two trade journals, Vineyard & Winery Management and Wine East.

The Rev. Roddy O’Neil Cleary performed the ceremony at the First Unitarian Universalist Society of Burlington in Vermont.

headline: A Career Spent Giving Her Characters Life
text: I NEVER know what’s going to happen in my books,” the novelist Hilma Wolitzer was saying on a recent sultry afternoon, in her cool East Hampton living room. “I write them as a reader.”

headline: The War as We Saw It
text: Baghdad

headline: MaryBeth Slavin, John Reiss
text: Mary Elizabeth Slavin, the daughter of Brigitte Slavin and Dr. James D. Slavin Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to John Donohue Reiss, a son of Rosemary Reiss and Paul J. Reiss of Lake Placid, N.Y. The Rev. Edward Durkin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Church in Lake Placid.

headline: Next Step for Rerouting Planes May Be in Court
text: AFTER nearly nine years of study and more than a hundred public meetings, Federal Aviation Administration officials say they are weeks away from issuing a final decision on how to reroute airline flights over the region to ease bottlenecks in the sky. Communities that fear a sharp increase in the number of flights rumbling overhead are now turning to what they say is their only chance to stave off noise pollution: the courts.

headline: Lights, Camera, Hike!
text: As a guy who spent his teenage years in Texas, who wanted desperately to make the football team, who failed utterly and who as a grown man has followed the dramas of the state’s schoolboy squads, I can tell you this: High-school football in Texas isn’t really about football at all. Coaches will tell you that it’s a white-hot crucible in which young men, through blood rituals of violence and teamwork, learn painful lessons about who they are and what they’re capable of — that is, if they give 110 percent. It is also, if you believe the parents, a vehicle by which these boys’ families and community can share in moments of glory before returning to lives of quiet, dusty desperation. The players themselves might disagree, but they just play the game.

headline: The Pastime Nacional
text: THE food, by now, has been well chronicled: Vendors lining the edge of Red Hook Park in Brooklyn on summer weekends sling tacos and pupusas on folding tables under tarpaulin roofs. But for many of the people who flock to the park, they are just a warm-up for the main event, the Technicolor baseball games played all day long against a backdrop of post-industrial gray.

headline: John Buchanan, Steven Hitt
text: John Scott Buchanan and Steven Randall Hitt were married on Friday. Ann Moore, a civil marriage commissioner for British Columbia, officiated at Queen Elizabeth Park in Vancouver.

headline: The Walker and the Walk
text: OCCASIONALLY I think of leaving the city once and for all. Enough of the busyness and ambition, the hothouse summers. But almost as soon as I begin to imagine my pastoral life, I hit a wall. Where would I walk? The woods? Some wind-blasted shore? The sky, the light, yes — but so much of it?

headline: Kathleen Roosevelt, Jeffrey Walker
text: Kathleen Ann Roosevelt, a daughter of Ann Roosevelt and James Roosevelt Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Thomas Walker, the son of Gail S. Walker and Dr. Richard L. Walker of Somers Point, N.J. The Rev. Kim K. Crawford Harvie, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Arlington Street Church in Boston. The Very Rev. Kevin J. O’Leary, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

headline: Correction: A Museum to Get Lost In, and How Israel Is Fixing It
text: An article last Sunday about the Israel Museum omitted the name of one designer of the Shrine of the Book. Frederick J. Kiesler designed it with Armand P. Bartos.

headline: When Lost Bags Put You on a Carousel
text: FOR a vacation to Italy in June, Dominique Linchet had packed everything she thought her family of four would need when they arrived: toiletries, bathing suits, dental retainers. But when they stepped off their Alitalia flight in Rome, the suitcases they had checked were missing.

headline: How to Add Oomph to ‘Organic’
text: THE organic industry has gone wild in the last decade, but you wouldn’t know it at the Department of Agriculture.

headline: Clemens Returns as His Old Self
text: Roger Clemens, who turned 45 this month, must have been conscious of every wrinkle on his face during the top of the fifth inning yesterday at Yankee Stadium. Staring back at him from home plate was Cameron Maybin, the highly acclaimed 20-year-old who made his major league debut Friday for the Detroit Tigers.

headline: A River’s Pulse
text: “There isn’t room for permanent enemies anymore,” said John Cronin, a stalwart of environmental activism in the Hudson Valley and someone you might consider more likely to picket or sue a giant corporation than form a partnership with one. But there was Mr. Cronin on Wednesday, announcing that the Beacon Institute for Rivers and Estuaries, a nonprofit research organization that he runs, was collaborating with I.B.M. to open an ambitious center to study the river as it has never been studied before.

headline: Stephanie Shapiro, Jonathan Marden
text: Stephanie Eve Shapiro, a daughter of Bonnie and Michael Shapiro of Hewlett, N.Y., was married last evening to Jonathan Corey Marden, the son of Marsha and Arnold Marden of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Helene Ferris officiated at the Yale Club of New York City.

headline: A Chinese Century? Maybe It’s the Next One
text: CHINA claims that its economy is growing at 10 to 11 percent a year, and China’s official analysts say that their nation will catch up with the United States long before the 22nd century arrives. Don’t believe it.

text: Buika

headline: The New 30 Is Now 50
text: THE uncertainties on Wall Street may be sending shivers down the backs of hedge fund titans and their real estate brokers, but so far the upper reaches of the Manhattan property market have been so strong that a report concludes the truly rich now need to think about spending $50 million to acquire a one-of-a-kind property.

headline: An Itinerant Refugee in a Hip-Hop World
text: MAYA ARULPRAGASAM’S Brooklyn apartment was a neglected mess when she finally returned to it last month after six months abroad. But it took only a day to straighten it up and turn it into her version of a pied-à-terre, a makeshift multimedia headquarters. An audio mixing board, film canisters and shiny gold and black dancing outfits stood on one side of the apartment, and half of an uneaten papaya waited on a table in the back.

headline: Kathryn Swan, Ian Malin
text: Kathryn Foster Swan and Ian Ogden Malin were married yesterday at the First Parish Church, a Unitarian Universalist church in Portland, Me. The Rev. Peter Friedrichs, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony with the Rev. Thomas Shepherd, a retired Episcopal priest, assisting.
