text: Rosalind, the droll heroine of “As You Like It,” doesn’t thrill Kenneth Branagh. Mr. Branagh maintains that Rosalind — the character who Harold Bloom has argued is the first modern lover in all of literature — talks too much.

headline: Former Seoul Mayor Is Picked as Presidential Candidate
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 20  South Korea’s main opposition party chose a former mayor of Seoul, Lee Myung-bak, as its presidential candidate on Monday, making him the clear front-runner to succeed President Roh Moo-hyun in the election scheduled for Dec. 19.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: A Museum in Search of a Home

headline: New Jersey School Checks Are Defended After Audit
text: The New Jersey education commissioner, Lucille E. Davy, yesterday defended the state’s new monitoring system for school districts, disputing an audit last week that found the Education Department lacked the staff and resources to carry out its increased oversight responsibilities.

headline: Footnotes
text: Luciano Pavarotti will remain hospitalized in Modena, Italy, for several more days for further tests related to his pancreatic cancer, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Mr. Pavarotti, 71, was admitted to the hospital on Aug. 8 because of a high fever. ... Peter Gabriel is to be honored as an Icon by Broadcast Music Inc., Bloomberg News reported. Mr. Gabriel, 57, who founded the rock band Genesis in 1967, is to receive the BMI award on Oct. 16 in London. Previous honorees include Ray Davies, Van Morrison, Isaac Hayes, Dolly Parton, Paul Simon, the Bee Gees and James Brown. ... Lincoln Center Theater will present the New York premiere of “The Glorious Ones,” a new musical, based on a novel by Francine Prose, about a commedia dell’arte troupe in Italy during the Renaissance. Book and lyrics are by Lynn Ahrens, music by Stephen Flaherty and choreography and direction by Graciela Daniele. Performances begin on Oct. 11; the opening is Nov. 5 at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. ... Bob Yesselman, the director of Dance/NYC, is retiring on Sept. 30 from dance administration, after a 36-year career in which he helped manage the American Ballet Theater’s Ballet Repertory Company, the Paul Taylor Dance Company, the Joffrey Ballet, the Dallas Theater Center and the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival.

headline: Courts Block Laws on Video Game Violence
text: As video games have surged in popularity in recent years, politicians around the country have tried to outlaw the sale of some violent games to children. So far all such efforts have failed.

headline: Irish Underwriter Wins a Reprieve
text: The Structured Credit Company, an Irish underwriter of credit products for investment banks that was placed in provisional liquidation last week, has been given time by the High Court of Ireland to complete a reorganization plan.

headline: Nasdaq to Sell Stake in London Exchange
text: LONDON, Aug. 20 — Nasdaq put its stake in the London Stock Exchange up for sale Monday, ending a year-and-a-half-long attempt to buy the rival — one that has included a hostile bid, a dawn raid and a 48-page public defense circular.

headline: Radical Fundamentalism in Three Flavors
text: Christiane Amanpour, CNN’s chief international correspondent, is more tour guide and history teacher than reporter in “CNN Presents: God’s Warriors,” and that makes this ambitious look at three flavors of religious fundamentalism less than it could be.

headline: Sleights of Mind
text: The reason he had picked me from the audience, Apollo Robbins insisted, was that I’d seemed so engaged, nodding my head and making eye contact as he and the other magicians explained the tricks of the trade. I believed him when he told me afterward, over dinner at the Venetian, that he hadn’t noticed the name tag identifying me as a science writer. But then everyone believes Apollo — as he expertly removes your wallet and car keys and unbuckles your watch.

headline: British Civics Class Asks, What Would Muhammad Do?
text: BRADFORD, England — At the Jamia Mosque on Victor Street in this racially and religiously tense town, Idris Watts, a teacher and convert to Islam, tackled a seemingly mundane subject with a dozen teenage boys: why it is better to have a job than to be unemployed.

headline: Yankee With Bright Future Is Guided by His Past
text: Yes, Harlan Chamberlain insists, he did play baseball as a boy. Not in an organized league, but he played.

headline: Policeman Is Convicted of Beating Companion
text: A police captain who admitted having a forbidden affair with an officer under his command was convicted yesterday of brutally beating her on a Greenwich Village street.

headline: Sudden Impact, but the Wrong Kind
text: The Red Sox pursued Eric Gagné of the Rangers last month for two reasons: to bolster their already strong bullpen, the best in the American League, and to keep him away from the Yankees, whose bullpen desperately needed help. The Yankees didn’t get Gagné, but he has helped them more wearing a Red Sox uniform than he could have in their uniform.

headline: South Africa Official Is Accused, but Not Investigated
text: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 20 — South Africa’s minister of health has for years been the target of attacks for her defiant and unconventional stance on AIDS, and her boss, President Thabo Mbeki, has stood by her through thick and thin.

headline: Dr. Duncan W. Clark, Voice for Fluoridated Water, Dies at 96
text: Dr. Duncan W. Clark, a public-health expert who became a persuasive advocate for adding fluoride to New York City’s water supply in the early 1960s, when opponents claimed the health risks far outweighed the rewards, died on Aug. 5 at his home in Brooklyn. He was 96.

headline: Presidential Candidate Blames Killings on Newark Sanctuary Policy
text: NEWARK, Aug. 20 — Federal officials said on Monday that a second man among the suspects in the schoolyard slayings of three young friends was in the United States illegally, and a conservative presidential candidate flew into town to denounce the city’s leaders as complicit in the murders because they had declared Newark a “sanctuary” for immigrants.

headline: It’s Not Business Travel; It’s Show Business Travel
text: I have been lucky to experience ways to keep frequent flying interesting, even if there are no complimentary peanuts being handed out.

headline: Two Senators Call for New Leader in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 — The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, after completing a two-day tour of Iraq, said Monday that the government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki should be voted from office because it has proved incapable of reaching the political compromises required to end violence there.

headline: Tuscan Hills Are Alive With Amateur Archaeologists
text: CASENOVOLE, Italy, Aug. 16 — The Etruscan tomb was hidden in such a remote corner of Tuscany that Andrea Marcocci, the archaeology student who found and identified it about a decade ago, was not very worried that anyone else would stumble upon it.

headline: The Nose Knows
text: Kevin Kline will return to Broadway this fall to feed some of the greatest sweet talk to be found in the theater to Daniel Sunjata (“Take Me Out”), who will then use it to seduce Jennifer Garner, making her Broadway debut as Roxane in Edmond Rostand’s “Cyrano de Bergerac.” The 10-week engagement, to be be directed by David Leveaux (the 2004 “Fiddler on the Roof”), will begin previews on Oct 12 at the Richard Rodgers Theater, with opening night set for Nov. 1. ... Elsewhere on Broadway, since Adam Pascal and Anthony Rapp returned to the cast of “Rent” in roles they first played in 1996, ticket sales have nearly doubled. So the two have extended their comeback by a month, to Oct 7.

headline: Brother vs. Father
text: CBS’s “Big Brother” edged out Fox’s reruns of “Family Guy” on Sunday to draw the night’s highest ratings among adults 18 to 49. The CBS reality show garnered 7.6 million viewers to lead the 8 p.m. hour, according to Nielsen’s estimates, and the two “Family Guy” episodes, at 9 and 9:30, delivered 5.4 million and 5.8 million viewers respectively. For the night, CBS and Fox shared the lead with the 18-to-49 set, though Fox finished fourth in total viewers. CBS had a sizable advantage in total viewers, thanks in part to “60 Minutes” at 7, the most-watched program of the night with 9.6 million viewers. NBC ranked a close second over all among 18- to 49-year-olds, as its preseason football game between the New York Giants and the Baltimore Ravens averaged 6.9 million viewers from 8:30 to 11. ABC finished last among adults 18 to 49 and third in total viewers, ahead of Fox.

headline: Homecoming for Hughes, but No Satisfaction for Yankees
text: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 20 — According to local legend, the cliff swallows are supposed to return every March 19 to the old stone church at Mission San Juan Capistrano.

headline: Latin Sounds of Many Parts, Even Bagpipes
text: A few hours after the second performance of Osvaldo Golijov’s “Pasión Según San Marcos” ended on Sunday evening, some of the musicians from the Orquesta la Pasión ensemble reconvened at the Allen Room for what was billed as a jam session but was actually something more.

headline: Protesters Seek Leader’s Return to Arabic School
text: About 200 demonstrators gathered in front of the headquarters of the city’s Department of Education last evening, voicing their support for the beleaguered Khalil Gibran International Academy. Many of them called for the reinstatement of the school’s founding principal, who resigned under pressure this month after she defended the word “intifada” as a T-shirt slogan.

headline: Coming Soon: Web Video in High Definition
text: Video on the Web is going high-def.

headline: Cutting the Trans Fats
text: In the world of corn dogs and fried pickles, the nation’s classic summer fair has long been seen as one final safe haven from the health police.

headline: A Poem from Pogue’s Inbox
text: David: Your article in today’s Times (“A Two-Way Wireless Way To Do Audio”) called to mind a poem I recently wrote that you might find amusing.

headline: Home Sick
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: The Race to Be First
text: The Democratic National Committee is taking steps to rein in the free-for-all primary calendar in which states are moving up their contests to gain influence. The first target: Florida.

headline: Follow the Money(ed)
text: Goodbye, Des Moines. Hello, Nantucket!

headline: Food Stuff

headline: Irish Underwriter Wins a Reprieve
text: Structured Credit, an Irish underwriter of credit products for investment banks that was placed in provisional liquidation last week, has been given time by the High Court of Ireland to complete a reorganization plan.

headline: Luminent Mortgage to Sell Large Stake
text: The struggling mortgage investment firm Luminent Mortgage Capital took steps to bolster its liquidity Monday, but the company signaled its troubles were not completely over.

headline: Federal Court Delays Wild Oats Acquisition
text: The acquisition of Wild Oats Markets by Whole Foods Market was delayed Monday by a federal appeals court in Washington. The appellate court said that it needed more time to consider the Federal Trade Commission’s argument that the deal should be blocked pending the outcome of an appeal of a lower court ruling.

headline: Policy Will Let More Chinese Invest in Hong Kong Market
text: The Chinese government announced Monday that it would allow mainland Chinese citizens to invest in the Hong Kong stock market, the most significant move to date by Beijing officials to dismantle the barriers that prevent most Chinese from making international investments.

headline: Capital One to Close Residential Mortgage Unit
text: In yet another casualty of the fallout in the mortgage industry, Capital One Financial said Monday that it would stop making residential mortgages and close GreenPoint Mortgage, its wholesale mortgage banking unit.

headline: A Mithraic Temple in the Heart of Christian Rome
text: I hadn’t visited the Basilica of San Clemente in about ten years, so I had a bit of a surprise when I went with a friend this week. A decade ago, when you wanted to visit the area underneath the basilica – one of Rome’s most interesting underground ruins – you bought your tickets from wizened old nuns who kept the change in awooden box.

headline: Can Private Equity Firms Get Out of Buyouts?
text: The whispering persists. Can the private equity firms that committed to all those supersize leveraged buyouts get out of them?

headline: Sovereign Wealth Funds Spark Concerns
text: At a time of global financial instability, the Bush administration has started to worry that foreign governments are increasingly converting their dollar holdings into investment funds to acquire companies, real estate, banks and other assets in the United States and elsewhere.

headline: Sequoia Talks Jive into $15 Million Round
text: Jive Software said Monday that it had raised $15 million from Sequoia Capital in what marks the collaboration software product maker’s first round of outside capital to support expansion of its platform product.

headline: NeurAxon Relieves V.C.s of $32 Million
text: Pain relief drug developer NeurAxon of Waltham, Mass., has secured $32 million in a second round of venture funding, twice the size of its first round.

headline: Atticus Raises Stake in Freeport-McMoRan
text: Atticus Capital has raised its stake in Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold to 7.5 percent, as the hedge fund prepares to take on the mining company’s management.

headline: The College Second Home
text: Lena Datwani, a broker with Bellmarc Realty, says many of her clients are parents buying apartments for their college-age children, and she is not alone in noting the trend. The thinking is, parents invest in an apartment to provide housing for their children in college and also, eventually, to use as a pied-à-terre.

headline: VMware Wants to Take On Google in More Than One
text: VMware, with the proceeds from its $1.1 billion initial public offering burning a hole in its pocket, is putting some of that cash toward challenging Google for Silicon Valley’s most-coveted prize: computer-programming talent.

headline: Deals for Ford Units Seen Fairly Soon
text: Ford Motor may have chosen the new owner for Jaguar and Land Rover by the time it reports its third-quarter results in October.

headline: What You Get for… $25 Million

headline: SunTrust Banks to Cut 2,400 Jobs
text: SunTrust Banks, long considered a potential takeover target, said Monday that it expected to eliminate about 2,400 jobs by the end of next year as part of a plan to save $530 million annually by 2009. The job cuts equal about 7 percent of SunTrust’s year-end work force of 33,599 people. The bank, based in Atlanta, expects the cuts to reduce pretax earnings by $45 million this quarter.

headline: Juma Scores $5 Million
text: Juma Technology, a telecommunications services firm, announced Monday that it has raised $5 million in its first investment round.

headline: Lone Star Seeks to End Accredited Deal
text: Lone Star Funds said Monday it was seeking a court order to terminate its roughly $400 million purchase of Accredited Home Lenders Holding, saying the subprime mortgage lender had not met the conditions to close.

headline: Microsoft’s Ballmer Dodges Yahoo Deal Talk
text: Try as he might, not even veteran interviewer Charlie Rose could get Microsoft‘s chairman and chief executive, Steve Ballmer to disclose whether the company continues to mull an acquisition of Yahoo.

headline: Virgin Radio I.P.O. Still On Track
text: The new chairman of Britain’s Virgin Radio said the station’s initial public offering was on track despite financial market turbulence and persistent speculation that the business will go to a single bidder.

headline: Google Buys Stake in Chinese Web Site
text: Google revealed on Monday that it had acquired a stake in Chinese community Web site Tianya.cn, indicating a foray by the search giant into social networking in the world’s second-largest Internet market.

headline: I.S.S. Tells Topps Investors to Reject Eisner Deal
text: Powerful proxy advisory firm Institutional Shareholder Services on Monday urged shareholders in Topps to reject the trading card vendor’s $385 million buyout agreement with Michael Eisner’s Tornante and private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners.

headline: German Bank Said to Have $3 Billion in Subprime
text: Landesbank Sachsen Girozentrale, the German state-owned bank getting emergency funding, has about 3 billion euros ($4 billion) in investments linked to U.S. subprime mortgages, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: G.E. Said to Consider Sale of Japanese Unit
text: General Electric is seriously considering selling GE Consumer Finance, a Japanese unit that offers financial services, and may invite bids as early as September, according to the Nikkei business daily.

headline: Blackstone Tries Indian Garment Maker on for Size
text: Blackstone Group will spend around $165 million to buy as much 70.1 percent of Indian garment maker Gokaldas Exports, the first of a number of deals in the region the New York private equity firm has promised.

headline: S.E.C. Sues Sentinel for Fraud
text: It’s been a bad few days for the Sentinel Management Group.

headline: Should eBay Dial Up a Deal for Skype?
text: Two years ago, eBay paid $2.6 billion for Skype, saying the Internet-based phone service provider would provide a new way for the auction site’s customers to talk to merchants. But so far, that synergy has yet to materialize.

headline: Morning Buzz: Standpipe Flaws, More Years to Finish High School, an Inspector General’s Self-Defense, and More
text: In the latest twist in the investigation into the fire at the former Deutsche Bank building on Saturday, Al Baker and William K. Rashbaum report that a standpipe valve between the basement and the first floor of the building was shut, and that even if the valve had been open, water would never have reached it because the network of pipes that is supposed to deliver water from fire trucks on the street was also compromised, with several breaks in it.Investigators have narrowed the place where the fire began to a spot on the 17th floor where workers were known to take breaks after going through the decontamination process. Meanwhile, funeral arrangements were announced for the two firefighters who died in the blaze.

headline: Nasdaq Tries to Raise Cash Portion of OMX Bid

text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. – When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton addressed the Veterans of Foreign Wars national convention here yesterday, she told the story of how she met a “bright, young captain” in the 82nd Airborne Division named Patrick Murphy in 2003 during her first trip to Baghdad.

headline: Death to the SAT
text: The controversial social scholar Charles Murray, writing at The American magazine’s site, feels it’s time to abandon the SAT test. His complaints aren’t totally new: “The image of the SAT has done a 180-degree turn. No longer seen as a compensating resource for the unprivileged, it has become a corrosive symbol of privilege. ‘Back when kids just got a good night’s sleep and took the SAT, it was a leveler that helped you find the diamond in the rough,’ Lawrence University’s dean of admissions told The New York Times recently. ‘Now that most of the great scores are affluent kids with lots of preparation, it just increases the gap between the haves and the have-nots.’”

headline: Acon to Acquire Spencer Gifts
text: Gordon Brothers Group announced Tuesday it will sell a majority of Spencer Gifts Holdings in a management-led buyout backed by Acon Investments, a private equity firm in Washington. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

headline: A New Push to Get Staten Islanders to Kick the Habit
text: This afternoon, the city’s Health Department will kick off a five-week campaign handing out free nicotine-replacement patches, gum and oral medications at the Whitehall ferry terminal on Staten Island. The reason? The borough’s smoking rate has held steady since 2002, even as smoking rates in the Bronx, Manhattan and Queens have dropped by about 20 percent. About 27 percent of Staten Island adults smoke, compared with about 17.5 percent citywide.The nicotine-replacement items will be handed out to returning commuters at the ferry terminal, from 3 to 6 p.m., Tuesday through Thursday, through Sept. 20.

Senate Republicans have suggested that Kristine Hamann, the inspector general, ducked a full investigation into actions of the governor’s staff and chose to ignore an obvious conflict of interest. headline: Beers Worth Waiting For
text: The last night of the International Pinot Noir Celebration  features an outdoor salmon bake in which wild salmon, prepared in traditional Native American style on alder stakes over a fire pit, is the centerpiece of an extravagant buffet. As it had been some years since I had last attended the I.P.N.C., I had assumed that I would simply stroll in and find a seat in the grassy quadrangle at Linfield College when the time came. Wrong. More than 1,000 people attend the salmon bake, and they all line up well in advance so they can present their tickets to the diligent staff.

headline: Answers From the ‘Suburbanization of New York’ Editors, Part 2
text: Following is the second set of responses from Jerilou Hammett and Kingsley Hammett, the editors of “The Suburbanization of New York” (Princeton Architectural Press, 2007). The book is a collection of 14 essays about the economic and social changes that have swept the city over the past two decades and the Hammetts, who are husband and wife, run DESIGNER/builder magazine. They are taking questions from City Room readers this week. A first set of answers was posted yesterday. Readers are invited to submit additional questions here.

headline: Dodd on the Mortgage Lending Crisis
text: Senator Chris Dodd, the Democratic presidential candidate and chairman of the Banking Committee, said today that the recent volatility in the country’s mortgage market is “far too serious” an issue to get turned into a political football that gets pushed off until after the next presidential election.

headline: Park Officials Concerned Over Sick Dogs in Chelsea
text: Veterinarians have detected an unusual string of illnesses in dogs that use the dog run at Chelsea Waterside Park, part of the Hudson River Park. Officials are worried that the dogs may have swallowed “an illegal toxic substance” and have urged dog owners who use the run to be more attentive.

headline: Meet the Congestion Pricing Panel
text: In classic New York fashion, a 17-member hodgepodge of politicians, experts, advocates and others will decide the fate of congestion pricing in New York City by March 2008. The names of all 17 members of the New York City Traffic Mitigation Congestion Commission were announced this afternoon.

headline: The Classics of Pebble Beach
text: This 1935 Duesenberg SJ Special won Best of Show at the Pebble Beach concours.  More PhotosThousands of spectators turned out for the festivities surrounding the 57th Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance on the Monterey Peninsula of California, where some of the rarest vehicles in the world were on display and in competition. Judging at the event included 24 classes, from antiques (pre-1916) through post-World War II sports cars, with special categories for Aston Martins and models from the Auburn-Cord-Duesenberg group.   The Best of Show award went to a 1935 Duesenberg SJ Special owned by Harry Yeaggy of Cincinatti. Nicknamed The Mormon Meteor, the car was once raced by Ab Jenkins, who used it to set a 24-hour land speed record in 1935. Readers can see more images of the SJ, as well as some of the other vehicles on display, in this photo gallery. Full judging results can be viewed here.  Classic-car auctions attract much of the attention during Pebble Beach week. A sale run by Gooding & Company featured a set of first-series Rolls-Royce Silver Ghosts as well as a steam-powered vehicle from 1884, known as La Marquise, which is thought to be the world's oldest functioning automobile. La Marquise sold for $3,520,000 including the buyer's premium, well above the pre-auction estimate of just over $1.5 million. Full results from Gooding & Company are available here. La Marquise was featured in an article in Sunday's Times, as were the Rolls-Royces. RM Auctions also held a sale nearby, in Monterey. Results from that auction are available here.    Photos: Highlights From Pebble Beach

headline: The Classics of Pebble Beach, ’07 Edition
text: Thousands of spectators turned out for the festivities surrounding the 57th Pebble Beach Concours d’Elegance on the Monterey Peninsula of California, where some of the rarest vehicles in the world were on display and in competition. Judging at the event included 24 classes, from antiques (pre-1916) through post-World War II sports cars, with special categories for Aston Martins and models from the Auburn-Cord-Duesenberg group.

headline: State Releases List of ‘Persistently Dangerous’ Schools
text: The state education commissioner, Richard P. Mills, today released a list of 27 “persistently dangerous” schools. Under the federal No Child Left Behind Act, states must release such lists each year to give parents the chance to move their children to different schools.

headline: Thompson Targets Giuliani on Guns
text: Former Senator Fred D. Thompson is not only testing the waters for a run for president – he’s stirring the pot. He took a not-very-veiled swipe at the Republican frontrunner, Rudolph W. Giuliani, for supporting gun control.

headline: A Long-Needed Restoration for a Victorian Gothic Masterpiece
text: The former Jefferson Market Courthouse, a Victorian Gothic masterpiece in Greenwich Village, will undergo a $7 million renovation to fix its façade, windows, roof and tower and shore up its structural integrity, city officials announced today.

headline: Molto Mozzarella
text: Whenever I return to a familiar city, I eat to confirm I have arrived. In New York, I eat a sesame bagel with cream cheese. In Paris, a croissant. In Rome, many would race for a cappuccino at the nearest bar.

headline: The Highs and Lows of Being John Henry
text: The Boston Red Sox are still riding high atop the American League standings. But their principal owner is happy enough to keep barely afloat.

headline: C.I.A.'s 9/11 Report Faulted Tenet

headline: The Latest From C.J. Nitkowski in Japan
text: C.J. Nitkowski, the longtime major league veteran now playing with the Softbank Hawks in Japan, has answered our questions from time to time all year. Here are his latest responses from the e-mailbag….

headline: Q & A: FSC’s Christian Miles
text: Christian Miles has a job most soccer fans would envy. A television soccer commentator for nearly ten years, Miles does live game commentary for some of the world’s top leagues on Fox Soccer Channel. He serves as a sideline reporter for FSC’s Major League Soccer coverage and he co-hosts two studio shows on FSC — Fox Soccer Matchday and Soccer Sunday +. Miles is also the official play-by-play announcer for Chivas USA of M.L.S.

headline: Q and A: Michael Roberts
text: I knew Michael Roberts’ work as a writer, photographer, stylist and illustrator long before we were introduced in the late 1990s. Were we introduced? Or did we meet one day at a fashion show and just start talking? We quickly discovered that we had a link to the same unpublished Vivienne Westwood profile, for Vanity Fair, in the mid 90s. I had been asked to write a profile of Westwood, which I did, but publication of the piece was delayed and delayed until, eventually, the editorial window closed for her. Michael had photographed her—appropriately, under glass. He had found an enormous bell jar and Westwood had gamely consented to be photographed as if her head were a museum specimen. Or an offering at a pagan feast, brightly colored. She is a genius.

headline: How Should the 9/11 Anniversary Be Commemorated?
text: As Pearl Harbor Day and the anniversary of President Kennedy’s assassination were for past generations of Americans, Sept. 11 is the day we do not want to remember and the day we cannot forget. In New York, news reports about public emergencies and ground zero cause the memories to come rushing back.

headline: My Times Now Open to All

headline: Bush Takes a Step Away From Maliki

headline: Jon Lucien,  Smooth Singer of Mellow Jazz and Soul, Dies at 65

text: Nearly all the 65 dual-language programs in the New York City public schools are conducted in Spanish and Chinese, languages that are considered practical tools for future success.

headline: Thompson Brings Gun Control to the Fore
text: Former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee, who has not officially declared his presidential ambitions, took a not-very-veiled swipe yesterday at the leading Republican candidate, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, for supporting gun control.

headline: Keeping Pandora’s Box Closed
text: Your guides through the secret worlds of the N.B.A. and N.F.L. will be Tim Donaghy and Michael Vick, who, to score points before sentencing, could soon reveal the monsters beneath the beds of David Stern and Roger Goodell.

headline: Going Off to Summer Camp Behind the Fence of a Prison
text: BEDFORD, N.Y. — Like other youngsters attending camp this summer, 12-year-old Robert Van Every enjoyed a week of shooting hoops, playing musical instruments and competing in board games.

headline: Peru Family’s Struggle Reflects Hardships After Quake
text: PISCO, Peru, Aug. 21  The chilly dawn came as a relief for Marlen Mayhua. She and her seven family members roused themselves from a fitful slumber on mattresses  and one fruit cart  laid on the dusty sidewalk in front of the crumbled remains of their home.

headline: Bold Latin Flavors, With a Long Reach
text: ARE there no suitable rocks in all of New York State? What about New England? If I have my trivia correct, New Hampshire is called the Granite State. That sounds pretty flinty to me, and it’s a whole lot closer to Manhattan than South America is.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The About New York column on Aug. 11, about Kurt Thometz, who runs a bookshop specializing in rare and obscure books from his Harlem brownstone, misspelled the surname of his wife and misstated the location of the Harlem Book Fair. His wife is Camilla Huey, not Hoey, and the fair is on 135th Street, not 145th.

headline: Toll Rises Above 500 in Iraq Bombings
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 21 — One week after a series of truck bombs hit a poor rural area near the Syrian border, the known casualty toll has soared to more than 500 dead and 1,500 wounded, according to the Iraqi Red Crescent Society, making it the bloodiest coordinated attack since the American-led invasion in 2003.

headline: Dancing on the Steps of a Monument to Cultural Exchange, of a Sort
text: When the performance artist Rhetta Aleong immigrated to the United States from Trinidad in 1984, she says, she was irritated by people’s constant assumptions about her.

headline: Calendar
text: Barolo Tasting

headline: Report Cites Brutal Conditions in Chinese Factories
text: SHANGHAI, Aug. 21  A workers’ rights group in the United States released a report today detailing what it called brutal conditions and illegal practices in Chinese toy factories, many of which supply some of the world’s biggest brand-name toy makers, including Disney, Hasbro and Sega.

headline: With Ale, Tamales With a Chanterelle Twist
text: A BOWL of steamed mussels and a thatch of fries with mayonnaise are all you need with a bottle of Belgian blond or pale ale. You could replace the mussels with a lobster roll and do just as well, though with a less decidedly Belgian accent.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the F.B.I.’s investigation of Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, said that the senator’s spokesman did not respond to requests for an interview. The spokesman did reply and referred a reporter to a statement, part of which was quoted in the article, that had been provided to news organizations.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary yesterday about Leona Helmsley, the widow of the real estate magnate Harry Helmsley, misstated the title of a book about them by Richard Hammer. It is “The Helmsleys: The Rise and Fall of Harry and Leona,” not “Unreal Estate: the Rise and Fall of Harry & Leona Helmsley,” which was one of the prepublication titles.

headline: Correction
text: A recent Op-Ed article about the death toll in Darfur incorrectly characterized a ruling by the British Advertising Standards Authority on Save Darfur Coalition advertisements. The authority did not find that the ads, which put the number of dead at 400,000, “breached standards of truthfulness.” Rather, it told Save Darfur to present the figure as opinion, not fact.

headline: Prescribing Surfboards for Peace
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 21 — The noted American surfer, Dr. Dorian Paskowitz, has high hopes for Gaza, and like the waves, he will not let anything stop him trying to see them through.

headline: Big Night for Anderson, Long Night for Yankees
text: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 21 — Garret Anderson sat at a table in the Angels’ clubhouse Tuesday, studying all the baseball cards that fans around the country had sent him to sign.

headline: State Names 17 More ‘Persistently Dangerous’ Schools
text: New York State education officials yesterday added 17 schools to the list of those considered “persistently dangerous,” substantially expanding the list for the second year in a row. All but 2 of the 27 schools on the new list are in New York City, including a dozen schools designed for students with severe disabilities.

headline: Mr. Chávez’s Power Grab
text: Newspeak is alive and well in Venezuela. Last week, President Hugo Chávez portrayed planned constitutional amendments that would allow him to be re-elected indefinitely as a step toward “participatory democracy.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Weekend Explorer column on Friday about the Hell’s Kitchen neighborhood referred incorrectly to the status of St. Clement’s Episcopal Church, on West 46th Street. Though it houses a theater, the building continues to serve as a church; it is not a former church.

headline: Hurricane Weaker, but Still a Threat
text: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 22 — Weakened but still packing a punch, Hurricane Dean began battering Mexico’s Gulf coast with fierce winds and rain Wednesday afternoon as residents fled to shelters or hunkered down at home.

headline: Pakistan Released Qaeda Suspect as Case Was to Be Heard
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 21 — A Pakistani man suspected of aiding Al Qaeda and imprisoned for three years was released because the Supreme Court took up his case of detention without trial, his lawyer said Tuesday.

headline: Words Unspoken Are Rendered on War’s Faces
text: One of the more shocking photographs to emerge from the current Iraq war was taken last year in a rural farm town in the American Midwest. It’s a studio portrait by the New York photographer Nina Berman of a young Illinois couple on their wedding day.

headline: G.O.P. Consultant Accused of Threatening Spitzer’s Father
text: ALBANY, Aug. 21 — Lawyers representing Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s 83-year-old father, Bernard Spitzer, say a prominent political consultant who has been working for State Senate Republicans threatened the elder Mr. Spitzer this month in an anonymous, invective-laced phone message.

headline: Transcript of President Bush’s Speech at the Veterans of Foreign Wars Convention
text: Remarks by President George W. Bush at the Veterans of Foreign Wars national convention at the Kansas City Convention and Entertainment Center in Kansas City, Mo., on Aug. 22, 2007.

headline: Correction: In the Fruit Belt, Selling Summer Off the Truck
text: An article last Wednesday about the fruit market in Benton Harbor, Mich., misstated the origin of some produce sold at a farmers’ market in Madison, Wis. Only produce grown in Wisconsin can be sold there; farmers from out of state are not allowed.

headline: The Space Shuttle Hobbles Onward
text: What started two weeks ago as a routine space shuttle flight to service the international space station and let a teacher-astronaut inspire students from her perch in space turned into a bit of a nail-biter when the shuttle Endeavor suffered minor damage during liftoff. In the end, NASA handled the problem deftly, and the shuttle landed safely at the Kennedy Space Center yesterday. But it was a troubling reminder that the aging shuttles have some inherent defects that will always pose a risk as they limp toward retirement in 2010.

headline: Conine Is Welcomed by Familiar Faces
text: Jeff Conine’s first full day as a Met got off to a bumpy start. After the Cincinnati Reds traded him Monday, they mistakenly shipped his equipment to his home in Florida. So when Conine arrived yesterday at Shea Stadium, he had to borrow a glove, from Carlos Delgado, and a pair of cleats, from Marlon Anderson.

headline: Where Investing $154 Billion Is One Man’s Job
text: Warren E. Buffett may be a multibillionaire and a legend among investors, but he cannot do everything by himself. His holding company, Berkshire Hathaway, has 13 directors on its board besides Mr. Buffett, the chairman, to watch over its $269 billion in assets.

headline: Many Qualified for Child Health Plan Don’t Enroll
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — During the four years that her children were uninsured, Cassie O. Hall used the emergency room as their pediatrician. When Tayana had an asthma attack or Darren developed a stubborn rash, they would head to the hospital and settle in for a long wait.

headline: Sylvia Siegel, Activist on Utility Rates, Is Dead at 89
text: Sylvia Siegel, who brought a customer’s perspective to the regulation of California utilities and spent 16 years fighting against rates and rules that she maintained were unfair to consumers, died Saturday in Mill Valley, Calif. She was 89.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A correction in this space on Friday, to an article on Aug. 14 about the number of votes in Parliament the governing party in Turkey would need to win confirmation for its presidential nominee, Abdullah Gul, if he failed in the first two rounds of voting, misstated the total number of seats in the Parliament. If there were a third round, Mr. Gul would indeed need 276 votes, not 267 as originally reported, but the number of seats in Parliament is 550, not 500.

headline: A New Museum Is Frank in Its Exploration of the Slave-Trading Past
text: LIVERPOOL, England, Aug. 16 — The riverside docks here, now a gentrified quarter, were a critical pivot in the trans-Atlantic slave trade when this city rose from seedy port to rich entrepôt in the 17th century.

headline: A Marketing Campaign From One Heart to Another
text: Fifteen-year-old Jean strode into the Queens Center mall yesterday ready to make an impression. He had insisted on wearing a navy blue blazer, though it was so oversize it created a three-inch tent on each shoulder. When a camera pointed in his direction, he flashed a profusion of teeth.

headline: Extreme Measures?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Manning Tosses Barber’s Words Back at Him
text: ALBANY, Aug. 21 — For most of his closely scrutinized Giants career, quarterback Eli Manning has chosen to let the debate about his laid-back personality and his leadership skills swirl without adding much in his defense. He has stayed true to his low-key demeanor, hoping one day his on-field success will render the debate moot.

headline: In One Chains Stores
text: The nation’s three largest booksellers have made decisions about carrying “If I Did It,” O. J. Simpson’s book about the 1994 murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman, Publishers Weekly reported yesterday. Amazon and Barnes & Noble’s Web site (barnesandnoble.com) said they would carry the book. But Barnes & Noble stores will not carry it, a spokesman said, because the company’s buyers believe there is insufficient customer interest to justify stocking it. Barnes & Noble will special order the book for anyone who requests it, but the decision is a blow to the book’s publisher, Beaufort Books, which has minimal distribution in independent stores. Borders stores, on the other hand, will carry the title, but “will not promote or market the book in any way,” a spokeswoman said. “If I Did It” was to have been published last November by ReganBooks, an imprint of HarperCollins, with an announced printing of 400,000. But it was dropped in response to widespread outrage.

headline: Young American Cashes In on Gold Cup
text: After hitting a goal seen around the world, Benny Feilhaber has hit the big time.

headline: Judge Orders Foxy Brown to Jail
text: Looking uncharacteristically demure, in a high-collared blue dress with a large silver cross around her neck, the rapper Foxy Brown was jailed yesterday for violating her probation.

headline: Copter Crash Kills 14 U.S. Soldiers
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 22 — Fourteen American soldiers died when their helicopter crashed in northern Iraq today, the military said, as Iraq’s prime minister threatened to “find friends elsewhere” if the Americans withdrew support for his administration.

headline: China’s Diseased Pigs (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reversing Course, France Seeks an Active Role in Iraq
text: PARIS, Aug. 21 — After years of shunning involvement in a war it said was wrong, France now believes that it may hold the key to peace in Iraq, proposing itself as an “honest broker” between the Sunni, Shiite and Kurdish factions there.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Broadway Bound, Reluctantly

headline: Developer’s Big Manhattan Move Faces a Time and Credit Squeeze
text: Harry Macklowe, the New York developer, was flying high in February when he decided to buy a portfolio of prime Midtown Manhattan office towers for nearly $7 billion, using only $50 million of his own money.

headline: Three Relationships, Seen Through a D.I.Y. Lens
text: “I wanted to be the funny one,” laments the title character of “Hannah Takes the Stairs,” “and I’m never the funny one.”

headline: Russia: Activist Freed From Psychiatric Clinic
text: A woman held in a psychiatric hospital after publishing an exposé in an opposition newspaper detailing the harsh care of patients in the same hospital has been released, her supporters said. The woman, Larisa Arap, had been in custody near Murmansk since July 5. She claimed to have been beaten and drugged. Her case was taken up by rights organizations and advocates for a free press, who said her forced psychiatric treatment was a throwback to Soviet days, when dissidents were labeled as mentally ill and forced to undergo treatment, sometimes including electroshock therapy. Joel Simon, executive director of the New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists, called on the courts to investigate Ms. Arap’s treatment.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the Observatory column in Science Times on July 31 about a Swedish study of metal emissions from automotive tires and brake linings misstated the status of asbestos as an ingredient in brake linings. Although asbestos is banned as a brake-lining ingredient in some countries, including Sweden, it is still used in the United States.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (Fox) ANCHORWOMAN It’s that old, familiar story. A television station owner tries to boost ratings by putting a babe in the hot seat. The results are anyone’s guess. In this reality-cum-comedy series, Phil Hurley, the owner of KYTX, a middle-market station in Tyler, Tex., hires Lauren Jones, above, a Versace-clad swimsuit model, onetime Miss New York and former World Wrestling Entertainment diva with no journalism experience, to anchor the news. But his crew  Annalisa Petraglia, the reigning anchor; Dan Delgado, the news director; and Michelle Reese, a hard-nosed reporter with her eye on CNN  is having none of it.

headline: Members Named for Panel Studying Traffic-Cutting Plan
text: A commission heavy with advocates of congestion pricing was named yesterday to study Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s contentious traffic-cutting proposal and present a recommendation to state and city lawmakers.

headline:
Citing Vietnam, Bush Warns of 
Carnage if U.S. 
Leaves Iraq
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 22 — With a tough battle with Congress over the future of the war expected to come in September, President Bush offered a rousing defense of his Iraq policy today, declaring that he envisions an American victory there and asserting that a hasty withdrawal by the United States would unleash a bloodbath reminiscent of the Vietnam War era.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about a rush of applications for high-skilled employment visas paraphrased imprecisely the comments of Bill Wright, a spokesman for Citizenship and Immigration Services. He said that because of the high volume of applications, the agency could not acknowledge them immediately but was working to send out receipts and was updating weekly a public list of applications received. He did not say that the agency had not been able to notify applicants that their petitions had been received.

headline: Inheriting Some Frustrations at Medical Device Maker
text: When Arthur D. Collins Jr. steps down as chief executive of Medtronic at the company’s annual meeting tomorrow, his successor, William A. Hawkins, will have plenty of reasons to praise and thank him. But many Medtronic shareholders may be happy to see Mr. Collins go.

headline: More or Less Pale but All Belgian
text: SURPRISING as it may sound, hot weather is not always easy on the beer lover. Sure, you can chase a thirst with any number of meager brews. Simply refrigerate, pop top and chug, no problem. But what does that really get you beyond a starring role in the latest frat-boy beer commercial?

headline: Defending Those Who Call the Games
text: Lamell McMorris has studied at the feet of the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Martin Luther King III, who followed his father as a civil rights leader. McMorris is himself an ordained Baptist minister.

headline: Jailed Academic in Iran Is Released on Bail
text: TEHRAN, Aug. 21 — An Iranian-American academic jailed for more than 100 days on suspicion of promoting a “velvet revolution” in the Islamic Republic was released on hefty bail on Tuesday, looking tired and much thinner from her ordeal but pronouncing herself well.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Aug. 15 about the record producer Tony Wilson rendered incorrectly the name of a 1983 12-inch single by New Order that became a best seller but lost money for his company. It was “Blue Monday,” not “Blue Mondays.”

headline: A Noodle Shop Opens, to a Hubbub
text: THE moment a ramen shop opens in New York — as, say, when Ramen Setagaya appeared in the East Village this summer — the anxious online ranks of the restaurant-obsessed are immediately atwitter with high hopes that (and heated arguments over whether) this will be the one: authentic, singular, a temple to ramenical devotion.

headline: Ford Stays the Course, Wherever It May Lead
text: DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 21 — What has changed in the year since Alan R. Mulally left Boeing to be chief executive at Ford Motor?

headline: AIDS in South Africa (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: F.A.A. Chief to Lead Industry Group
text: Marion C. Blakey, the administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, will become the new head of the Aerospace Industries Association, a trade group representing civilian and military aerospace companies, in November, the association said. Ms. Blakey, who led the National Transportation Safety Board before joining the F.A.A., was appointed by President Bush to a five-year term. Her term expires Sept. 13. The term of a successor would fall mostly in the next presidential administration. The White House has not announced an intention to nominate a successor.

headline: Respects Paid to Fireman and Friend
text: The mourners divided themselves into two lines in the huge lobby of the Dyker Heights funeral home yesterday, one wearing black and one wearing blue.

headline: Survivor to China
text: A grave digger, a pro wrestler and a chicken farmer are among the 16 people who will compete on “Survivor: China,” The Associated Press reported yesterday. Other contestants on the show, which is to have its premiere on Sept. 20 on CBS, include a school lunch lady who throws axes and knives and collects Budweiser memorabilia; a Christian radio talk-show host; and a gay Mormon man who thinks the creation of the Spice Girls was “the most significant historical event of the past 100 years.”

headline: Lebanon: Militants’ Families Can Leave Camp; Truce Reported
text: The army said it had agreed to let the families of Islamic militants holed up in the Palestinian refugee camp Nahr al Bared, north of Tripoli, leave the battered camp. Lebanese and Palestinian officials estimate that up to 100 civilians, mostly the wives and children of the militants, are still inside the camp. Most other residents fled when the fighting started in May. The state-run news agency reported that the Palestinian Clerics Association had mediated the truce between the army and the militant group Fatah al Islam, but it was not clear when it might take place.

headline: Vintage Bradbury, Packaged Anew
text: LOS ANGELES — Though slowed by age, Ray Bradbury still speaks with exuberance. Hobbled by a stroke in 1999, he now dictates his work over the phone to his daughter in Arizona, who records and transcribes it before faxing edits back. Mr. Bradbury works in an overstuffed leather chair in a den lined by shelves of VHS tapes of classic movies and history texts. The room is crowded with models of dinosaurs, rocket ships and Jules Verne’s Nautilus submarine, his own dusty Emmy, a friend’s tarnished Oscar and a 52-inch flat-screen television not unlike the ones he presaged in “Fahrenheit 451.”

headline: U.S. Group Accuses Chinese Toy Factories of Labor Abuses
text: SHANGHAI, Aug. 21  A workers’ rights group in the United States released a report on Tuesday detailing what it called brutal conditions and illegal practices in Chinese toy factories, many of which supply some of the world’s biggest brand-name toy makers, including Walt Disney and Hasbro.

headline: Australian Court Rules for Indian
text: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 21 — A court in Australia ruled Tuesday that the country’s immigration minister had acted improperly when he revoked the visa of an Indian doctor because of his association with two distant cousins suspected of involvement in the botched bombings in London and Glasgow in June.

headline: Tribune Shareholders Back Zell’s Takeover
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 21 — The Tribune Company came one step closer to being taken private Tuesday after shareholders overwhelmingly approved an $8.2 billion buyout led by the real estate billionaire Samuel Zell.

headline: Critics Say Lessons From 9/11 Were Not Followed in Deutsche Bank Blaze
text: After the Sept. 11 attack at the World Trade Center, an independent consultant studied the Fire Department’s performance and identified a number of lapses amid all the undeniable valor of that day. It said that too many men rushed into the buildings before anyone realized the danger they were in, contributing to the staggering death toll.

headline: Cowher Relaxes Into Role as Analyst
text: Bill Cowher’s summers as an adult have all been in N.F.L. training camps: as a linebacker, an assistant coach or, for the last 15 seasons, as the coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers. He resigned in January, was hired by CBS Sports as a studio analyst for “The NFL Today,” and in a network conference room yesterday displayed a calmness at odds with his excitable sideline demeanor.

headline: Panel on Virginia Tech Shooting Issues Report
text: An internal report by the Virginia Polytechnic Institute about the April massacre on its campus calls for better communication about troubled students, more locks on classroom doors and improved communication to ensure that students are alerted to a campus-wide crisis.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about “Kid Nation” and other forthcoming reality television shows facing legal issues misspelled the surname of a chef who stars in one of the shows. He is Gordon Ramsay, not Ramsey. The name was also misspelled in the title of the show, “Ramsay’s Kitchen Nightmares.”

headline: ‘Chemical Ali’ and Others Begin Trial for 1991 Attack
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 21 — To a mostly empty gallery, the man known as Chemical Ali for his role in gassing villages in northern Iraq under Saddam Hussein stood up and identified himself as “the fighter, Ali Hassan al-Majid” on Tuesday, the first day of trial for his role in brutally suppressing the 1991 Shiite uprising in the south of the country.

headline: The Warrantless Debate Over Wiretapping
text: CONGRESS just passed, and President Bush hurriedly signed, a law that amends the legal framework for the electronic interception of various kinds of communication with foreign sources. Almost immediately, commentators concluded that the law was unnecessary, that it authorized a lawless and unprecedented expansion of presidential authority, and that Democrats in Congress cravenly accepted this White House initiative only for the basest political reasons. None of these widely broadcast conclusions are likely to be true.

headline: State to Fight U.S. Limits on Children’s Health Plan
text: ALBANY, Aug. 21  The Spitzer administration will aggressively lobby against new federal rules that threaten the governor’s plans to make health care coverage universal for children in New York, state officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Misgivings Spoil Plans of Start-Up
text: Three years ago, at a news conference at Tavern on the Green restaurant that featured a free-flowing bar, former President Bill Clinton helped introduce a new Internet search engine, Accoona, which was said to be powered by innovative artificial intelligence technology.

headline: Jets Endure the Storm Before the Calm
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 21 — It felt like a damp and drizzly November day at Jets training camp Tuesday, and that was fine for the man in charge. Coach Eric Mangini has not seen everything go his way this preseason, but he could not have asked for better (that is, worse) weather.

headline: German Woman Seeks Reunion With North Korean Husband
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 22  Koreans have long looked to Germany for similarities between the nations’ histories. Both countries have been scarred by war and separation.

headline: Harvard Endowment Reports 23% Gain for Fiscal Year
text: The Harvard Management Company, which oversees the endowment of Harvard University, reported yesterday that the endowment had posted a 23 percent gain for the fiscal year ended June 30.

headline: College Rankings (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Google Earth, a Service for Scanning the Heavens
text: After turning millions of Internet users into virtual explorers of the world with Google Earth, the Internet search giant is now hoping to turn many of them into virtual stargazers.

headline: Some Men Rule
text: Fox led the Monday night ratings, rebroadcasting a two-hour special, but CBS’s “Two and a Half Men” rerun earned the night’s highest ratings. Nielsen estimated that “Two and a Half Men” attracted 9.3 million viewers at 9 p.m., while “TV’s Funniest Moments,” on Fox, averaged 7.2 million from 8 to 10. CBS was No. 2 for the night, winning the 10 p.m. hour with a “CSI: Miami” repeat (7.6 million). ABC trailed close behind, as its “Wife Swap” rerun led the 8 p.m. hour (7 million), but “Fat March,” its new series, came in third at 9 (5.6 million). NBC, which broadcast a “Heroes” repeat at 9 (2.8 million), finished fourth.

headline: CBS Was Warned on ‘Kid Nation,’ Documents Show
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 — The producers of a CBS reality show featuring 40 children living on their own in the New Mexico desert were warned by the state attorney general's office while the show was being taped last spring that they might be violating the state's child-labor laws, according to interviews with state officials and documents obtained Tuesday under the state's open records act.

headline: Bid to Reopen Mine Divides Grieving Utah Town
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 21 — As relatives on Tuesday laid to rest one of three men killed here trying to rescue six trapped miners, this grieving mining town was torn over the future of the mine and the prospect of the lost miners’ being entombed permanently.

headline: Brooklyn: Road Closing in Prospect Park
text: Beginning on Monday, East Drive in Prospect Park will no longer be open to motor vehicles on weekday evenings, city officials said yesterday. Currently, drivers can use East Drive on weekdays from 7 to 9 a.m. and from 5 to 7 p.m.. The road is closed on weekends. City officials said the road was being closed as part of an effort to expand recreation in the park. Molly Gordy, a spokeswoman for the Transportation Department, said city traffic studies have indicated that the closing should not unduly affect neighborhoods in the area.

headline: California Ends Stalemate With $145 Billion Plan for Budget Deficit
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21  California lawmakers ended a partisan two-month budget stalemate on Tuesday, signing off on a $145 billion plan to do away with the state deficit through promised line-item vetoes by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about the average income of Americans from 2000 to 2005 misstated, in some copies, the nation’s total adjusted gross income in 2005. It was $7.43 trillion, not billion.

headline: Obama Sees a ‘Complete Failure’ in Iraq
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 21 — Senator Barack Obama said Tuesday that even if the military escalation in Iraq was showing limited signs of progress, efforts to stabilize the country had been a “complete failure” and American troops should not be entangled in the sectarian strife.

headline: Manhattan: Jefferson Market Renovation
text: City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn announced yesterday $4.9 million in new financing for restoration work of the historic Jefferson Market Library in Greenwich Village. The red-brick building, offset with limestone trim and a distinctive bell and clock tower, is considered the city’s premier example of High Victorian Gothic style. A report released this year found deterioration in the building’s facade and rusting of its iron structure, among other problems. The money will be used to renovate its exterior and to shore up its structural integrity.

headline: Kazakhstan Threatens to Halt Work on Big Offshore Oil Project
text: The government of Kazakhstan threatened yesterday to suspend work performed by a consortium of foreign oil companies at the Kashagan offshore field, one of the world’s largest oil projects, because of an assertion of environmental damage in the Caspian Sea.

headline: For Vacation, Pack a Toque
text: Here are several cooking schools in Paris. All can answer phone requests in English, and all offer classes for children.

headline: Broadway Bound, Reluctantly
text: The producers Jeffrey Richards, Jean Doumanian, Steve Traxler and Jerry Frankel wanted to bring “August: Osage County,” the raved-about play by Tracy Letts, to Broadway from Chicago.

headline: Tanja Liedtke, Dancer, 29, Is Killed by Truck in Australia
text: Tanja Liedtke, a dancer and choreographer who was named artistic director of the Sydney Dance Company in early May, died on Friday in Sydney, Australia, after being hit by a truck. She was 29.

headline: Despite Mine Law, Tracking Is Years Away
text: PRICE, Utah, Aug. 21  Perhaps the most wrenching aspect of the Crandall Canyon Mine collapse, for rescue workers and families alike, is that no one knows the exact location of the six trapped miners.

headline: FedEx Hopes for the Right Bounce From Golf
text: IF you are south of Greenwich Street in Manhattan between noon and 5 p.m. today, look for a weird miniparade: A guy carrying a “quiet” sign followed by a golfer, his caddy and an entourage of nattily dressed “fans.”

headline: Yes, Tap Water Is Plentiful, but Is It Fit to Drink? (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bush Takes a Step Away From Maliki
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 — When President Bush and Nuri Kamal al-Maliki stood side by side in Jordan last November, the president proclaimed the prime minister “the right guy for Iraq.”

headline: Go Green and Save Money
text: Have your eyes recently popped out of your head when you opened your electric bill? Do you, like me, live in one of those states where electricity has been deregulated and the state no longer oversees the generation price so your utility rates have skyrocketed since 2002?

headline: Learning to Cook, With Time Left to See Paris
text: SERIOUS cooks know they can go off to France and take immersion courses, but until recently, I hadn’t realized that it is possible to take quickie cooking classes: a few hours, a half day or a day.

headline: Fed Seeks Balance as Investors Clamor for Action
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 — Wall Street thinks the Federal Reserve is running short of time.

headline: MTV, RealNetworks to Mount Challenge Against iTunes
text: MTV Networks said yesterday that it would fold its floundering digital music service into a venture with RealNetworks, owner of the Rhapsody music subscription service, as part of a renewed challenge to Apple’s market-leading iTunes store.

headline: Many Eligible for Child Health Plan Have No Idea
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — During the four years that her children were uninsured, Cassie O. Hall used the emergency room as their pediatrician. When Tayana had an asthma attack or Darren developed a stubborn rash, they would head to the hospital and settle in for a long wait.

headline: Turkish Palace as Summer Home
text: As Murat and Nina Koprulu were deciding to invest in a summer home away from Manhattan, they figured that it made sense to embrace their family histories: Her mother is an archaeologist working at sites like Petra in Jordan; his ancestors were powerful grand viziers to the Ottoman sultans.

headline: Imitation or Flattery in Dueling Shows
text: The endless line of people who have a notion for a new jukebox musical or television talent show is proof of a legal point: nobody owns an idea. But that doesn’t mean the battles over exactly who owns what aren’t some of the hairiest in the theater business.

headline: Already, Apple Sells Refurbished iPhones
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21  Consumers looking for a deal on an iPhone may be able to knock $100 off the price of the smartphone by buying from an unexpected discount source: Apple Inc.

headline: Iraq War Brings Drop in Black Enlistees
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 — Joining the Reserve Officer Training Corps was once an attractive choice for people with few options growing up in impoverished, predominantly black East Baltimore. That has all changed, largely because of the war in Iraq.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The caption for a picture with the On Baseball column on Sunday, showing Phil Rizzuto and Pee Wee Reese together, referred incorrectly to the date the photograph was taken. It was Sept. 29, 1952, not before Game 1 of the World Series, which was played that Oct. 1.

headline: Monteverdi, From the Opera to the Church to Lincoln Center
text: A theme of this summer’s Mostly Mozart Festival is spirituality, explored by way of works from across the expanse of musical history. Having presented the most recent of its examples, Osvaldo Golijov’s “Pasión Según San Marcos” (2000), over the weekend, the festival offered the earliest, Monteverdi’s “Vespro Della Beata Vergine” (1610), at the Rose Theater on Monday evening.

headline: Counting on a Hotel to Make a Neighborhood Hot
text: To understand how the meatpacking district in downtown Manhattan was transformed from an obscure collection of a few bistros and boutiques scattered among beef-filled warehouses to a hot residential, commercial and entertainment destination, consider Michael Achenbaum’s explanation.

headline: A Moist Finale to a Summer of Movies in Bryant Park
text: At the drizzling dot of 5 on Monday evening, security guards dropped the barriers to the Bryant Park lawn. Hundreds of people began a slow-motion dash across the lawn for the park’s final night of free outdoor movies this summer. By the time “Psycho” started four hours later, about 2,000 people had grabbed a few square feet of grass and the unlimited romance of a city night outdoors.

headline: Virginia’s Gun Market
text: The “Iron Pipeline” of Interstate 95 remains alive and deadly, as a new federal study grimly confirms. Saddest of all is the evidence that some of the most far-reaching shady gun marts continue to operate in the state of Virginia, where the suicidal Virginia Tech student shot 32 people to death only four months ago. Virginia dealers have been a standout source for guns used in crimes up and down the seaboard, according to the federal study. They accounted for half of the 10,000 guns tracked by the study in the metropolitan Washington, D.C., area, and one in 11 in New York City.

headline: Plummer to Stratford
text: The Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Ontario, Canada, until recently the Stratford Festival, said yesterday that Christopher Plummer would play Julius Caesar next summer in Shaw’s “Caesar and Cleopatra.” Mr. Plummer last appeared at the festival in 2002 as King Lear. Anika Noni Rose will play Cleopatra. Des McAnuff, one of Stratford’s artistic directors, is to direct. The festival’s 2008 summer schedule so far includes Shakespeare’s “Hamlet,” “Romeo and Juliet,” “All’s Well That Ends Well,” “The Taming of the Shrew” and “Love’s Labour’s Lost.” “The Trojan Women” by Euripides, “Fuente Ovejuna” by Lope de Vega and Lessing’s “Emilia Galotti” will also be performed, along with two musicals, “The Music Man” and “Cabaret.” For more information: www.stratford-festival.on.ca.

headline: No Breakthroughs at Canada Talks
text: MONTEBELLO, Quebec, Aug. 21 — President Bush met with Prime Minster Stephen Harper of Canada and President Felipe Calderón of Mexico here on Tuesday at a gathering that focused primarily on strengthening ties and some thorny trade and border issues, but which produced no breakthroughs.

headline: After the Deluge, the Reality of Deprivation
text: MALINAGAR, India — Losing everything he owns has become a routine disaster for Shankar, a landless laborer in the northeastern state of Bihar who saw his home and belongings destroyed in some of the worst floods to hit the north of India in decades.

headline: Politics Seen in Nasty Call to Spitzer’s Father
text: ALBANY, Aug. 21 — Lawyers representing Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s father, Bernard Spitzer, say a prominent political consultant who has been working for State Senate Republicans threatened the elder Mr. Spitzer this month in an anonymous, invective-laced phone message.

headline: Atop Delta, a Veteran of Airlines
text: DETROIT, Aug. 21 — With Northwest Airlines’ former chief executive now in charge at Delta Air Lines, could closer ties between the companies be far behind?

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,700 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:

headline: China Raises Interest Rates to Cool Its Heated Economy
text: BEIJING, Aug. 21 — China announced Tuesday that it would raise interest rates for a fourth time this year in an effort to contain its racing economy and rein in soaring consumer prices.

headline: Shuttle Glides Safely Home in Spite of Damage
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla., Aug. 21 — The space shuttle Endeavour glided to a safe landing here Tuesday afternoon, apparently not much worse for wear.

headline: In Beijing, Orwell Goes to the Olympics
text: Beijing

headline: A New World for Sale, Ocean-to-Ocean View
text: When the 13 American colonies won their independence from Britain, they were a thin fringe of settlement clinging to the edge of a vast continent. Within 80 years, by acquisition and conquest, they would fill in what seemed to them millions of square miles of blank space on the map, from the Atlantic to the Pacific. “No other sovereign entity ever grew so large so fast to become so rich and so strong,” Richard Kluger writes in “Seizing Destiny,” his detailed history of how the United States put together the pieces of real estate that would eventually make it the wealthiest, most powerful nation on earth.

headline: Congestion Pricing (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rebels of Various Ages, All of Them With a Cause
text: “Snapshots,” at the Beckett Theater on Theater Row, has a gutsy, self-confident, liberal determination that smacks of bygone idealism. It reminds me of the way my mother, and my friends’ mothers, campaigned for George McGovern for president in 1972. Those mothers are approaching 70 now, and 70 is the approximate median age of the women in these three short plays, each of which tackles a different important subject: an aging great-grandmother, an unwanted child, a lifelong lesbian love affair.

headline: Like Ducks and Penguins, With Nervous Stomachs
text: The smell of Swinburne Island is the smell of the birds: layers of guano, decaying fish, salt water. It is a smell both tangy and rotten, and it intensifies as you fight your way through shoulder-high brush toward the bare branches where cormorants are nesting.

headline: Toll in Iraq Bombings Is Raised to More Than 500
text: One week after a series of truck bombs hit two poor villages near the Syrian border, the known casualty toll has soared to more than 500 dead and 1,500 wounded, according to the Iraqi Red Crescent Society, making them by far the worst coordinated attacks since the American-led invasion.

headline: Look for More Ways to Treat Diabetes (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Accusations Against Priest Convicted of Sexual Abuse
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 21  A Jesuit priest convicted last year of sexually abusing two teenage boys about 40 years ago is facing new accusations of abuse.

headline: Pushing Fed to Act Early if Not Often
text: Ben Bernanke got his first chance to use the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve to influence the housing market before he even officially had the job. It came in November 2005, toward the end of his all-day Senate confirmation hearing, when Senator Paul Sarbanes brought up the mortgage business.

headline: Mets Have Last Word in Seesaw Game
text: The Mets were bursting with confidence entering last night’s game at Shea Stadium, having won six of seven games. But those victories came against the Florida Marlins, the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Washington Nationals, teams that began yesterday in last place.

headline: For the Best Cuts, Here Are the Rubs
text: SOME people believe you can improve on a good grilled steak: the Italians use lemon and olive oil, the French compound butter or even béarnaise.

headline: Of Church and Steak: Farming for the Soul
text: Howard, S.D.
