text: To the Editor:

headline: Storm Misses Tourist Spots and Weakens
text: CHETUMAL, Mexico, Aug. 21 — Hurricane Dean hammered Mexico’s Yucatán Peninsula with blistering winds and heavy rain on Tuesday, missing the prime tourist spots of the Mayan Riviera but causing damage in Chetumal, the state capital, before being downgraded to Category 1 from Category 5.

headline: Greenspan and Bernanke: Evolving Views
text: Here are excerpts from some of the comments that Alan Greenspan and Ben S. Bernanke have made about the housing market over the last six years.

headline: Michigan Joins the Race for a ‘Me First’ Primary
text: The primary election calendar is a lot like the weather: Everyone gripes about Iowa and New Hampshire going first, but no one does anything about it.

headline: What They Left Undone on Summer Vacation
text: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 19 — Most of the people in “The Autumn Garden,” Lillian Hellman’s 1951 drama of midlife malaise, have reached the age when, as W. H. Auden wrote, “mirrors might be hateful for a while.” The joy and pain of the Williamstown Theater Festival’s absorbing revival, which runs through Sunday, come from watching a top-drawer cast embody a growing, reluctant awareness of receding hair and chin lines matched by receding hopes.

headline: A Successful Plan for Racial Balance Now Finds Its Future Uncertain
text: WHITE PLAINS

headline: Tiger Woods Takes a Break, but the FedEx Cup Won’t
text: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 21 — The biggest burden the rookie Brandt Snedeker carries is an oversized travel bag for 14 golf clubs.

headline: C.I.A. Lays Out Errors It Made Before Sept. 11
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 — A report released Tuesday by the Central Intelligence Agency includes new details of the agency’s missteps before the Sept. 11 attacks, outlining what the report says were failures to grasp the role being played by the terror mastermind Khalid Sheikh Mohammed and to assess fully the threats streaming into the C.I.A. in the summer of 2001.

headline: Stacking the Electoral Deck
text: The Electoral College should be abolished, but there is a right way to do it and a wrong way. A prominent Republican lawyer in California is doing it the wrong way, promoting a sneaky initiative that, in the name of Electoral College reform, would rig elections in a way that would make it difficult for a Democrat to be elected president, no matter how the popular vote comes out. If the initiative passes, it would do serious damage to American democracy.

headline: In Business With Your Children
text: IN THE HUNT

headline: Law for Music Acts
text: Music acts that impersonate real performers may be fined $5,000 to $15,000 under a new New York State law, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Called the Truth in Music Advertising Law, it prohibits copycat performances that attempt to cash in through false and misleading representations like names, billings and promotions similar to the original artists’. The measure was inspired by recording artists like the Platters, the Coasters and the Drifters, whose acts and routines have been copied without permission. It requires performing groups to have at least one member of the act they are claiming a connection to and a legal right to use that act’s name. Otherwise they must label their productions a “tribute” or “salute,” own the recording group’s service mark or have its authorization. Similar measures have passed or are pending in a dozen states.

headline: The Weather’s Fine, Hence the Invasion From Arizona
text: SAN DIEGO — Bulletin: Phoenix and Tucson have been evacuated because of summer heat and monsoonal moisture. The emergency shelter is here, or so it seems, for the displaced Arizonans.

headline: Group to Urge War Support
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 — A new group of prominent conservatives plans to begin a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign Wednesday to urge members of Congress who may be wavering in their support for the war in Iraq not to "cut and run."

headline: An Old Baseball Hand at the Tiller
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 21  The moment called for levity. And John McLaren  baseball lifer, longtime coach under Lou Piniella and, at age 55, a first-time major-league manager with the American League wild-card leading Seattle Mariners  was happy to provide it.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about the death of two New York City firefighters in a fire at the Deutsche Bank skyscraper at ground zero gave an outdated name in some copies for the hospital where they were taken. It is New York Downtown Hospital, not NYU Downtown Hospital.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A correction in this space on Friday, to an article on Aug. 14 about the number of votes in Parliament the governing party in Turkey would need to win confirmation for its presidential nominee, Abdullah Gul, if he failed in the first two rounds of voting, misstated the total number of seats in the Parliament. If there were a third round, Mr. Gul would indeed need 276 votes, not 267 as originally reported, but the number of seats in Parliament is 550, not 500. (Go to Article)

headline: After Prince Charming, a Blonde Tries to Recover
text: It is a relief to open the press kit for “Portrait of the Artist as a Dumb Blonde” and see pictures of its playwright and star, Sharon Fogarty, with her natural brunet hair. The one-act musical “comedy,” at Manhattan Theater Source, is a despairing portrait indeed.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Gwen Stefani, Covered
text: Gwen Stefani modestly rocked Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, yesterday, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Stefani, 37, performed in costumes that showed almost no skin after Islamic critics claimed that her customary revealing clothes could corrupt the youth of this Muslim-majority nation. “I am very inspired tonight,” Ms. Stefani told some 7,000 cheering fans at an indoor stadium, wearing a black leotard under a white short-sleeved shirt and black-and-white striped hot-pants suit, with black gloves up to her elbows. She changed costumes for every song, remaining fully covered as she belted out “Hollaback Girl” and other songs. Under government guidelines, a female artist must be covered from the shoulders to the knees and may not jump, shout, hug, kiss or throw things at the audience.

headline: Manhattan: Harlem River Esplanade Expansion
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the city parks commissioner, Adrian Benepe, broke ground yesterday on the second phase of the Harlem River Park Greenway and Esplanade. The $8.7 million project, financed through a combination of city, state and federal funds, will extend the waterfront park and bike path north from 139th Street to 142nd Street. Phase 1, completed in 2003, opened the esplanade from 135th to 139th Street. Phase 2 is expected to be completed by August 2008, the mayor said.

headline: So Many Tomatoes to Stuff in a Week
text: OF all the produce that tastes amazingly better in season —peaches and apricots, strawberries and peas — none inspires the same cultish devotion as summer tomatoes.

headline: New York G.O.P. Severs Ties With Consultant
text: ALBANY, Aug. 22 — A prominent political consultant who was accused this week of leaving a threatening, profanity-laced phone message for Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s 83-year-old father announced today that he would resign from his job and no longer work with State Senate Republicans.

headline: Newark: Man Sentenced for Threats to Train
text: A man was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to two and a half years in federal prison for making false bomb threats concerning the Hoboken PATH station, prosecutors said. The man, Miguel Reyes, 33, formerly of Newark, pleaded guilty in April to making the false bomb threats, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey. Mr. Reyes admitted that he made three calls to 911 in October and November last year saying there would be an explosion in the station. Compiled by John Sullivan

headline: London Calling
text: A look at some of the plays running in London this summer.

headline: The Accoona Files 1: A Search Company?
text: A few weeks ago I was happily blogging along, writing the Quick Bits news summary, when I came across coverage of the public offering of Accoona, a New Jersey search company. I was invited to its initial press conference, which was attended by Bill Clinton. I had thought at the time that it was unusual. I’ve been to hundreds of tech company events, and none was quite like that. So I spent a little time reading the company’s prospectus and reading about its founder (who the company calls Armand Rousso, but who seems to be named Marc Armand Rousso.)

headline: Captain America
text: Ralph Lauren turned Polo into a $13.5 billion fashion Disney.

headline: Water Everywhere
text: A look at the auditions for the show "Fuerzabruta," which has cast members perform in a pool.

headline: Candy Darling
text: Abbie Cornish, the Aussie Ingénue Of “Candy” and “Elizabeth: The Golden Age,” Talks With Lynn Hirschberg about satisfying her wanderlust.

headline: Off Kilter, on Target
text: The trick to eccentricity: Don't go crazy with it.

headline: A Look Back
text: Last summer, The New York Times covered the U.S. Open in a new way. One of the Sports section’s first blogs debuted, with The Times’ senior culture critic Michael Kimmelman leading a team of editors and bloggers who brought you the sites and scenes from Flushing Meadows.

headline: With Northwest’s Ex-C.E.O. Atop Delta, Will a Deal Take Off?
text: With Northwest Airlines‘ former chief executive now in charge at Delta Air Lines, could closer ties between the companies be far behind?

headline: Ford Stays the Course, Wherever It May Lead
text: As Ford Motor awaits offers for its Jaguar and Land Rover brands, The New York Times takes a look atwhat has changed in the year since Alan R. Mulally left Boeing to be chief executive at the car maker.

headline: Ackman’s Win-Win Bet on Target
text: Investors are often counseled, but often forget, that they should protect their downsides as they seek profits. According to Breakingviews, Pershing Square Capital‘s William Ackman has done just that as he pursues a shakeup of Target, which reported healthy earnings growth for tis second quarter.

headline: Upper Deck Drops Bid for Topps
text: A day after an influential proxy adviser threw its weight behind Upper Deck‘s $10.75-per-share bid for Topps, the firm said it had decided to withdraw its offer for the rival maker of trading cards.

headline: Trusts Seek $2 Billion From Advisers to Refco
text: Trusts representing creditors of the defunct futures and commodities broker Refco sued its legal, accounting and financial advisers yesterday for more than $2 billion over the company’s collapse.

headline: Transcontinental Signs Deal for Canadian Printer
text: Canadian media and printing company Transcontinental looks to expand its presence in Ontario after making a $130-million bid to take over PLM Group, Canada’s fourth-largest printer.

headline: Canada’s Biggest Banks Seek to Reassure Investors
text: Bank of Montreal, Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and Canada’s four other biggest banks agreed to work together to ensure that the C$120 billion ($113 billion) market for asset-backed commercial paper continues to “perform satisfactorily.”

headline: So Many Deals, So Much Debt
text: Harry Macklowe, the New York developer, was flying high in February when he decided to buy a portfolio of prime Midtown Manhattan office towers for nearly $7 billion, using only $50 million of his own money. His 2003 purchase of the General Motors Building on 59th Street and Fifth Avenue for $1.4 billion, though derided at the time as reckless, had been vindicated as the value of the building soared, enhancing Mr. Macklowe’s reputation as a visionary tycoon.

headline: Underwriter Pulls Out of Accoona I.P.O.
text: Three years ago, at a news conference at Tavern on the Green restaurant that featured a free-flowing bar, former President Bill Clinton helped introduce a new Internet search engine, Accoona, which was said to be powered by innovative artificial intelligence technology.

headline: Virgin Media Loses Chief
text: Troubled cable TV company Virgin Media, which two weeks ago postponed its auction due to turmoil in the credit markets, suffered a fresh blow Tuesday with the news that its chief executive, Steve Burch, was leaving immediately for “family and personal reasons”.

headline: Fugitive Fund Manager Arrested in Greece
text: A fugitive U.S. hedge fund manager who admitted defrauding investors out of millions of dollars was arrested in Greece on Monday, Greek police said on Tuesday.

headline: Will a Deal for Wyeth Cure Pfizer’s Ails?
text: Beset by cost-cutting, layoffs, and high-profile drug failures, what’s a big pharma to do? How about spend $90 billion to take out a competitor?

headline: Accredited Sells $1 Billion in Loans
text: Accredited Home Lenders Holding, the subprime mortgage lender that is suing Lone Star Funds to force the buyout shop to go through with a deal to acquire it, said Tuesday it would sell about $1 billion of loans to avoid margin calls.

headline: Was Bear Hit by the Green-Eyed Monster?
text: What has become of Bear Stearns? Fortune notes that, by all rights, this should be a Bear Stearns moment. Investors are skittish, and Wall Street players are unsure what to do next — precisely the conditions under which the scrappy independent has traditionally thrived.

headline: Metacafe Breaks Away With $30 Million
text: In a busy summer of online video investment, some start-ups are beginning to break away from the pack of YouTube wannabes, says the Red Herring.

headline: Nymex Confirms Takeover Talks
text: Nymex Holdings, parent company of the New York Mercantile Exchange, confirmed on Wednesday that it is holding talks with several suitors as it seeks to expand in Europe. It also said it may fire as many as 150 employees.

text: This is what people may be talking about today. It may even help you strike up a conversation with the cute girl in I.T., the one with the big G-Shock watch.

headline: Archstone Shareholders Approve Buyout
text: Apartment landlord Archstone-Smith said on Tuesday its shareholders approved a roughly $15.3 billion takeover offer from an entity controlled by Tishman Speyer and Lehman Brothers. The real estate investment trust said it expects the deal to close October 5.

headline: Dubai to Buy Stake in MGM Mirage for $5 Billion
text: Dubai World agreed to pay $5 billion for a 9.5 percent stake in MGM Mirage and half of the Las Vegas casino owner’s biggest development, bringing billionaire shareholder Kirk Kerkorian his biggest investment in the company.

headline: A Closer Look at the TD Ameritrade Report
text: Online brokers TD Ameritrade and E-Trade Financial have been holding merger talks, The Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday. However, it is not clear that the basis for the story is: the companies have said publicly they would explore a deal, and people close to both companies told DealBook that no deal is imminent.

headline: 2008: The Battles of Summer
text: So much for a lazy August. The waning days of summer have seen a series of bruising fights on and off the presidential campaign trail that have pitted state against state and candidate against candidate. The skirmishes are likely to spill over into the post-Labor Day campaign season.

headline: The Long Ride Home
text: Like a lot of the Book Review’s editors, I’m a long-distance commuter. I bomb in and out of the city every weekday from Garrison, N.Y., about an hour up the Hudson River from Grand Central Terminal. The Metro North trains I ride look exactly like the one pictured above.

headline: Morning Buzz: A Threatening Phone Message, Firefighting Lessons From 9/11, Vomiting Cormorants and More
text: A front-page article by Danny Hakim details explosive allegations that could add to the fractious political turmoil in Albany. Lawyers for Bernard Spitzer, Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s father, say that investigators traced an anonymous, invective-laced phone message left on the father’s answering machine to Roger J. Stone Jr., a political operative who has been working for the State Senate Republicans.

headline: Inside the U.S Open With The Times
text: The U.S. Open will begin Aug. 27 and run until Sept. 9 at the USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Flushing. The last of the season’s major tennis tournaments, the Open is a New York institution and one of the most exciting two weeks of the summer for tennis fans.

headline: Bush’s Iraq-Vietnam Parallel
text: Is Iraq like Vietnam? After mostly sidestepping the comparison, President Bush plans to embraced it in one respect in a speech today. As in Vietnam and Cambodia, he thinks the costs of pulling out are being underestimated by critics of the war in Congress and across the nation. Here is part of the prepared text for the speech, as released by the White House:

headline: Remembrance of Fries Past
text: August has traditionally been considered a slow news month (as a newspaper employee who long lacked the seniority for late-summer vacation, I’d beg to differ — remember Boris Yeltsin on that tank?), so the press tends to draw up a lot of coverage of anniversaries — get ready for Katrina redux. Laura Rozen at Mother Jones’s MoJoBlog brings up the fourth anniversary of something a great proportion of Americans have likely forgotten, or at least tried to erase from their memories: “It was only four years ago that Rep. Bob Ney (R-Ohio) and Walter Jones (R-NC) announced the official name change in Congressional cafeterias from French fries and French toast to Freedom Fries and Freedom Toast.”

headline: I.B.M.: The Net Trumps Television
text: Move over television. The Internet is our master now.

headline: The Politics Of Appearance

headline: Drama Divided by 32
text: Apparently, the United States Open will be blessed with good weather on Monday for its opening day. But it may be cursed with ho-hum matchups. Or so the conventional wisdom goes. We’ll know for sure later today when the Open draw is conducted at the Empire State Building.

headline: Accredited to Cut Jobs, Halt Loan Applications
text: Accredited Home Lenders may be suing to keep its buyout from collapsing, but it seems like it has more pressing matters on its hands. Namely, survival.

headline: Rio Tinto Eludes Debt Difficulties with Alcan Fundraising
text: Despite the difficulties companies have had recently in raising debt for buyouts, at least one acquiror has found little trouble in doing so. Britain’s Rio Tinto has raised $40 billion to fund its takeover of Alcan, the Canadian aluminum producer, The Financial Times reported Wednesday.

headline: A Call to Ban Foam Trays in Schools and Restaurants
text: Updated, 6:10 p.m. | New York City’s public school system goes through 850,000 Styrofoam cafeteria trays a day, 4 million in a week and more than 153 million in a school year. As this blog and an accompanying video reported in June, Parents Against Styrofoam in Schools, a grass-roots group arising out of Public School 154 in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, has called for limiting or ceasing the use of polystyrene, a petroleum-based material that can take centuries to decompose.Now, Councilman Bill de Blasio, Democrat of Brooklyn, wants to go even further. He is introducing a bill in the City Council today to would prohibit the use of polystyrene by City agencies and food establishments. Mr. de Blasio, like the Brooklyn parents, want the school system to switch to either reusable plastic trays or trays that are biodegradable.

headline: Stone Ends Work for Senate Republicans
text: Updated, 3:14 p.m. | Roger J. Stone Jr., the political consultant who has been accused of making a threatening phone call to Bernard Spitzer, the father of Gov. Eliot Spitzer, has stopped working for the State Senate Republicans.

headline: Istanbul bound – and a flying, virtual F1 paddock
text: There may be something to write somehow about the process of travelling to the races. Leaving by airplane in the evening after a race you encounter a virtual paddock – with everyone from teams dressed in their civilian clothes and you can’t recognize them.

headline: What’s Off the Record at N.H.T.S.A.? Almost Everything
text: If you want to know something as simple as who heads the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, don’t bother to ask the safety agency’s communications office. Without special permission, officials there are no longer allowed to provide information to reporters except on a background basis, which means it cannot be attributed to a spokesman.

headline: The Accoona Files 2: The Electronics Business
text: See Update below.One of the more curious aspects of Accoona, a Jersey City company that began life as a search engine, is that it wound up buying several Brooklyn-based electronics dealers with reputations for aggressive sales tactics and poor service.  An article on Accoona’s troubled attempt at a public offering ran in today’s Times.

headline: Lawyers Join the Comma Club of Billable Hours
text: Many lawyers may still moan about the burden of billable hours. But for a select few, the system has just become even more lucrative.

headline: Jozy Altidore, Ridin’ the Rails

headline: The DeLorean Dream Bubble
text: The Delorean is coming back, and excitement is rife in the blogosphere.

headline: Bird-Watching on Swinburne Island Has Its Ups, and Downs
text: In my 20 years working for The Times, I had photographed many things and been almost everywhere in the metropolitan region, but I had never been to Swinburne Island and somehow I had never photographed people picking up bird vomit. I was looking forward to this.

headline:
Living with Music:
A Playlist by Geoff Nicholson
text: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for “Living With Music,” a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the “celebrity playlists” on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

headline: Audio Card in a Cable
text: I’ve had a heck of a time perfecting the audio setup for recording my weekly Times podcasts (which is basically just me reading my column). It involves a microphone plugged into a USB audio interface box, but that approach has a number of problems:

headline: Does Sport Cause Crime?
text: A political scientist argues that sports breed criminals.

headline: Sound Familiar? Static Is Heard in Pinpointing a Recorded Voice
text: How can you tell for sure if a voice on a recording belongs to a particular person?

headline: Henin-S. Williams Again?
text: Top-seeded Justine Henin could again face Serena Williams in the quarterfinals of the United States Open, which begins on Monday, while Roger Federer might play Andy Roddick, whom he defeated in last year’s final, in that same round. Those were among the potential matchups randomly decided today at the Open draw ceremony in the Empire State Building.

headline: Top U.S. Banks Draw Upon Fed Discount Window
text: More banks have stepped forward and said they have availed themselves of the Federal Reserve’s discount-lending rate cut amid the credit market’s turmoil last week. The four biggest banks in the United States — Citigroup, J.P. Morgan Chase, Bank of America and Wachovia — said that they each borrowed $500 million through the so-called discount window by taking out loans directly from the Fed.

headline: Michigan Moves Toward Jan. 15 Primary
text: Gentlemen, start your engines!

headline: Billions and Billions of Decisions
text: It was like being interrogated.

headline: A Rough Ride, With Challenges, for a Brooklyn State Senator
text: When he was first elected to the State Senate in 2002, Kevin S. Parker was seen as a fresh young presence and one of Brooklyn’s upstart politicians. He had been an aide to the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, and a professor of political science at Brooklyn College.

headline: The Geek Movie of the Year: “King of Kong”
text: A few dozen techies gathered last night at the offices of the investment firm Clearstone Venture Partners for a screening of the undisputed geek movie of the year: “The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters.” The winsome documentary looks at the freakish world of competitive arcade video game playing and, in particular, two rivals who warily duel to claim the title of highest scorer on the 1981 Nintendo classic Donkey Kong.

headline: Spinning the Surge
text: It’s as close to an admission of fallibility as you’re likely to hear from a prominent political correspondent: “I predicted here that the August congressional recess would be a difficult time for Republicans, because they would be returning to their districts to face voters who were furious over the Iraq war,” writes Karen Tumulty at Time’s Swampland. “But if this morning’s Washington Post is right, the exact opposite has happened: It’s the Democrats who are being put on the defensive over the war.”

headline: A New Eco-Friendly Mobile Phone (Unless It’s Cloudy)
text: Working Assets is a wireless carrier that bills itself as focused on social responsibility. At present, for instance, the San Francisco company’s 50,000 subscribers can direct one percent of their monthly bills to progressive political causes.

headline: The Ashes From Being Tiki Torched
text: You may have heard the teaser about the Eli Manning-Tiki Barber clash that led off “SportsCenter” on Tuesday night. You may have heard (not literally, but almost) the blaring headlines from New York’s tabloids. The cover of the Daily News showed shouted “ELI TAKES DOWN TIKI,” followed by “Vicious feud boils over.” The back page read “ELI TORCHES TIKI.”

headline: City Council Takes Up a Bill to Ban Voyeurism
text: Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr.’s district office in Astoria, Queens, sits right outside the Ditmars Boulevard elevated subway station. “I started to get complaints from females who were upset that a rather large pervert was standing under the steps every morning, holding his cup of coffee, staring up at their skirts,” he told City Room in an interview. “The police told me there was no law against what he was doing. So I wrote one.”

headline: Lehman to Close Subprime Unit and Cut 1,200 Jobs
text: It appears the bloodbath is beginning. Lehman Brothers, a leader in packaging subprime mortgages into securities, is shutting down one of its home lending units and laying off 1,200 employees, or about 4.2 percent of its total workforce. The bank said it would take a $52 million hit to third-quarter earnings.

headline: A Political Operative’s Career: ‘The Stone Zone’
text: Roger J. Stone Jr., the political consultant who agreed to stop working for the State Senate Republicans after being accused of leaving a nasty message for Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s father, has a long history in bare-knuckle politics.

headline: ‘Fifth Fuel’ Keeps Utility Customers in the Green
text: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman’s Aug. 22 column, “Go Green and Save Money”.

headline: Baby, It’s Not Particularly Hot Outside
text: Updated, 5:24 p.m. | How cold and wet was it? So cold, that there’s never been a chillier high temperature in August. So wet, that if it doesn’t rain another drop or snow another flake for the rest of 2007, then it will still be a near-average year for precipitation.

headline: Live From the 71st Floor, It’s Tennis!
text: Of course, there were no jokes about the high drama of the United States Open draw even though the United States Tennis Association held it in a small conference room of the 71st floor of the Empire State Building. A view of the Statue of Liberty was framed by oversized photographs of Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe.

headline: Q AND A: IVY STARK
text: Ivy Stark’s résumé defines eclecticism. Toward the beginning of her career, she cooked at the Sign of the Dove; much more recently, she cooked at Rosa Mexicano. And as she toggled from one culinary tradition to another, she decided to gain the sort of formal education about wine that not many chefs have, earning a certificate from the American Sommelier Association.

headline: A Solution to the High-Tech Immigrant Challenge
text: No one really doubts the “immigrant dividend” to America’s high-tech economy. But

headline: Blogtalk: Bush, Iraq and Vietnam
text: Today President Bush used an appearance in front of a group of veterans to argue against the early removal of American forces from Iraq, drawing historical parallels to the end of the Vietnam war.

headline: Blogtalk: ‘What Hubris and Lying Brings You’
text: What we’re reading on the local blogs…

headline: The Accoona Files 3: Tales of the Crocodile
text: The most intriguing and most complex aspect of looking into Accoona is tracing the history of Marc Armand Rousso, its founder. It’s a tad difficult because he calls himself Armand Rousso these days. At other times he’s called himself Marc Armand, Marc Rousso, and Mark Benson. As I mentioned in parts 1 and 2 of this blog series, Accoona’s troubled attempt at a public offering  were recounted in today’s Times.

headline: Fla. Dems Stand Firm on Primary Date
text: The Florida Democratic Party has no plans, at least for now, of blinking in the showdown over the date of its presidential primary next year.

headline: Nike Ad
text: A new ad by Nike celebrates the female athlete.

headline: If You Can’t Run the White House
text: Oh, come on. This isn’t going too far. Michelle Obama’s supposed low blow, said to be aimed at Hillary Clinton, is absolutely fair — almost elementary campaign talk. It’s just a nice, sisterly insult, that “can’t run your own house.”

headline: Star Jones on Court TV
text: A clip from Star Jones' new talk show on Court TV.

headline: Answers From the ‘Suburbanization of New York’ Editors, Part 3
text: Following is the third set of responses from Jerilou Hammett and Kingsley Hammett, the editors of “The Suburbanization of New York” (Princeton Architectural Press, 2007). The book is a collection of 14 essays about the economic and social changes that have swept the city over the past two decades and the Hammetts, who are husband and wife, run DESIGNER/builder magazine. They are taking questions from City Room readers this week. A first set of answers was posted on Monday and a second set on Tuesday. Readers are invited to submit additional questions here.

headline: Bush Compares Iraq and Vietnam
text: President Bush said that the U.S. withdrawal from Vietnam was destructive and that leaving Iraq would be similarly dangerous.

headline: Behind the Michigan Primary Moves
text: Can we peek just for a moment under the rock that is Michigan politics?

headline: Whispers From Sony About a July Surprise
text: Bill Clinton had Super Tuesday, the Russians Stalingrad. Will Sony’s turning point be July 2007?

headline: “Kid Nation”
text: “Kid Nation,” a CBS reality show that is scheduled to have its premiere on Sept. 19, took 40 children, ages 8 to 15, and placed them in a New Mexico desert “ghost town” near Santa Fe for 40 days, during which they had little to no contact with their parents.

headline: Mussina on Shaky Ground?
text: After meeting with starting pitcher Mike Mussina on Wednesday, Yankees manager Joe Torre suggested that he needs better performances from Mussina to keep him in the starting rotation.

headline: Macro Software
text: David Pogue explores the time-saving qualities of macro software.

headline: In Brooklyn, Cheers for Obama
text: Senator Barack Obama came into the heart of Hillary country Wednesday night for a fundraiser organized by the group Brooklyn for Barack.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An “Arts, Briefly” report yesterday about the casting of Christopher Plummer in a 2008 production of Shaw’s “Caesar and Cleopatra” referred incorrectly to the Canadian theater festival where it will be presented. It is the Stratford Shakespeare Festival, which was until recently known as the Stratford Festival, not the other way around.

headline: Abbas Criticizes Israeli Strikes in Gaza
text: The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, condemned Israel for what he termed an escalation of violence against Palestinians, saying it “casts doubt about Israel’s real intentions towards the peace process.” On Monday, Israeli strikes in Gaza killed six militants from Hamas, and in separates strikes there on Tuesday, three from the Islamic Jihad group and two boys. Mr. Abbas, of Fatah, described the killings inside the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip as “a massacre which cannot be justified in any circumstances.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Monday about a promotion in 7-Eleven stores for “The Simpsons Movie” misidentified Gregg Brilliant, who commented on the campaign’s success. He is a spokesman for 20th Century Fox, not Fox Broadcasting.

headline: Her Journey, All True
text: SAN FRANCISCO — “I’m hopeless at this stuff,” Laura Albert had been saying as she stood in her apartment on a recent morning, placing objects into — then removing them from — a bag. Ms. Albert, the fiction writer better known as JT LeRoy, is blessed with gifts, though not a talent for logistics. She was running late for a road trip to Los Angeles, and her driving party — a Cuban-Dutch designer, a would-be film director and a reporter for The New York Times — had been waiting patiently since 10 a.m. It would be after 3 when they finally left.

headline: Armored Trucks’ Delivery Delayed
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 — The United States military said Wednesday that it would deliver less than half the number of blast-resistant trucks to Iraq by year’s end than planned.

headline: A Place to Go When a Child Really Refuses Food
text: Some years ago, a couple came to Ramasamy Manikam with a disturbing problem. Their 8-year-old daughter, who had suffered a brain injury, refused to eat despite countless hours of pleading and bribery. One thing worked: If they left the room, she would fling the food to the floor, get down from her chair, crawl into it and eat.

headline: Incorruptible Umpires (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Historians Question Bush’s Reading of Lessons of Vietnam War for Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 — The American withdrawal from Vietnam is widely remembered as an ignominious end to a misguided war — but one with few negative repercussions for the United States and its allies.

headline: The Ground Zero Fire (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Buildings With a Past (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: At a European Tournament, Adventures in Distribution
text: The inaugural European University Bridge Cup, which took place in Bruges, Belgium, Aug. 4 to 9, was won by Paris-Sud.

headline: Rule to Expand Mountaintop Coal Mining
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 — The Bush administration is set to issue a regulation on Friday that would enshrine the coal mining practice of mountaintop removal. The technique involves blasting off the tops of mountains and dumping the rubble into valleys and streams.

headline: Foot Locker Reports First Loss in 6 Years
text: Foot Locker, the largest athletic-shoe retailer by sales in the United States, reported its first loss in six years yesterday after it cut prices to clear out inventory.

headline: German Coalition Meeting Boasts Modest Agenda
text: BERLIN, Aug. 22 — In an end-of-summer rite, Chancellor Angela Merkel’s coalition government of conservatives and Social Democrats gather Thursday in a Baroque palace outside Berlin to seek unity and direction before the new parliamentary session.

headline: Brooklyn: Good Samaritan Killed
text: A man who stopped to help a driver in a disabled car on the Prospect Expressway early yesterday was killed when a drunken driver in a third car smashed into his car and the broken-down vehicle, the police said. The police said the victim, Rafael Rafailov, 50, stopped to assist a vehicle that was stopped in the middle southbound lane about 1:20 a.m. Mr. Rafailov and the driver of the disabled car were outside their vehicles when a car driven by Alexey Bushuyev, 22, of Brooklyn, struck their cars, the police said. Mr. Bushuyev and the driver of the disabled car, who was not identified, suffered minor injuries. Mr. Rafailov was declared dead at the scene, the police said. Mr. Bushuyev was charged with driving while intoxicated.

headline: Out for a Sunday Drive
text: Bill Murray, right, could face a drunken driving charge after cruising through downtown Stockholm in a golf cart and, citing United States law, refusing police requests that he take a breath test, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The police spotted Mr. Murray, 56, early Sunday in the slow-moving vehicle and noticed he smelled of alcohol when they pulled him over. “He refused to blow in the instrument, citing American legislation,” said Detective Inspector Christer Holmlund of the Stockholm police on Wednesday. “So we applied the old method: a blood test. It will take 14 days before the results are in.” Mr. Murray, who had been at a golf tournament in Sweden, signed a document admitting that he had been driving under the influence, and agreed to let a police officer plead guilty for him if the case goes to court. Detective Holmlund said it was not clear where Mr. Murray had picked up the vehicle or to whom it belonged. “It was a golf cart,” the detective said. “How it ended up in this predicament I don’t know.” Mr. Murray is not facing theft charges, he added.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about the efforts of a start-up search-engine company, Accoona, to go public misidentified the publication edited by Danny Sullivan, who commented on the performance of the search engine. He is editor in chief of the blog Search Engine Land, not editor of the online publication Search Engine Watch. (Mr. Sullivan founded Search Engine Watch, now owned by Incisive Media, but is no longer its editor.)

headline: Nikon and Canon Offer High-End Cameras in Fight for Pro Market
text: After decades as the undisputed leader of the market for professional 35-millimeter cameras, Nikon finds itself in an unfamiliar position in the digital age. Canon so dominates the professional market today, particularly when it comes to photojournalism, that it recently tweaked Nikon’s nose with an advertising campaign about its triumph.

headline: Trading Up From Red Paper Clip to White Picket Fence
text: Kipling, Saskatchewan

headline: Philip Masters, True Amateur of History, Dies at 70
text: Philip Masters, whose passion was history, which he literally dived into to help find the undersea wreck of the ship of Blackbeard the pirate, died on Aug. 18 in the Bronx. He was 70.

headline: The Great Clock Plot
text: This week, The Times reported that President Hugo Chávez is planning to move Venezuela’s clocks ahead by half an hour. The story created one of those wonderful moments of newspaper community, as readers around the nation suddenly shared an identical thought:

headline: Virginia Tech Issues Proposals for Security
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 — Officials at Virginia Tech University issued a set of mild recommendations for campus security Wednesday, suggesting the university provide more counseling for mentally troubled students, erect Internet-based message boards across campus to alert students of emergencies and install more surveillance cameras and better internal door locks.

headline: A Cellphone That Can Even Help You Find Your Friends (if Not Yourself)
text: Helio loves the sea. The company’s latest phone, the Fin, follows a pair of nautically themed cellphones  the Ocean and the Drift  and it is as thin and menacing as a shark’s dorsal appendage slicing through the water.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A review on Tuesday of the New Juilliard Ensemble’s concert at the Museum of Modern Art, which included a performance of “Umberhulk,” misspelled the surname of the composer of that work, as did the museum program. He is Andy Vores, not Vorhes.

headline: Keeping Appearances Up, and Costs Down
text: To give the house the look of “serious” architecture, Jennifer Luce covered the exterior walls in a stucco that resembles concrete: Santa Barbara Finish from Expo Industries, www.expoindustries.com. But the outside, as redesigned by Ms. Luce, is more window than wall. She ordered metal-framed windows from Fleetwood, a California company that she says is “very flexible as to size and configuration.” A window almost as big as a garage door — 7 by 8 feet — costs about $5,000. She added pivot hardware from Rixson, www.rixson.com, to create front and back doors that turn 90 degrees without side hinges.

headline: Legal Questions Remain for Freed Scholar in Iran
text: TEHRAN, Aug. 22 — Haleh Esfandiari, the Iranian-American scholar freed on bail after three months in prison, is waiting for Iranian judicial officials to inform her whether the travel ban against her will be lifted and a new passport issued to allow her to return to the United States, her husband and her lawyer said Wednesday.

headline: The C.I.A. Report
text: The C.I.A. inspector general’s report on the agency’s failures before Sept. 11 was devastating — but not because it showed that America’s spies missed the rise of Al Qaeda. George Tenet, then the director of central intelligence, rang the Qaeda alarm. He sent a memo to the entire intelligence community saying that he wanted no effort spared in the “war” with Osama bin Laden. He took on the president’s closest advisers to agitate for a strike on a Qaeda base in Afghanistan.

headline: A Competitive Race Between Mickelson and Singh
text: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 22 — Phil Mickelson and Vijay Singh arrived to professional golf through disparate channels, with Mickelson coming of age as an amateur in Southern California and Singh after a stint as a bouncer in Scotland.

headline: Lo Duca Says Timing Is Right for His Return This Time
text: The last time Paul Lo Duca made a prediction about his injured hamstring, he thought he would need to take a couple of days off. Two turned into six, which, after a somewhat hasty return, turned into a stint on the disabled list.

headline: California: Social Security Numbers Printed on Brochures
text: The California Public Employees’ Retirement System said it accidentally printed the Social Security numbers of almost a half-million retirees on brochures sent out last week. A mail-processing computer inadvertently added the partial or full Social Security number of each retiree on the mailing label attached to a brochure sent to 445,000 people announcing a board election, said a system spokesman, Brad Pacheco. The fund sent letters to its members apologizing and promising new procedures to prevent future mix-ups. The system manages retirement and health care benefits for 1.5 million current and retired public workers and their families.

headline: AT&T’s Overstuffed iPhone Bills Annoy Customers
text: When Justine Ezarik, a video blogger in Pittsburgh, saw that a box from AT&T had been delivered to her doorstep a couple of weeks ago, she thought that perhaps she had been sent a complimentary accessory for her new iPhone. Instead, she found a 300-page, double-sided, excruciatingly well itemized bill.

headline: East St. Louis Levees Fail Test
text: The five levees that protect the metropolitan area of East St. Louis, Ill., from the Mississippi River do not meet the Federal Emergency Management Agency’s standards for flood protection and will be removed from maps that the agency publishes to record flood vulnerability, government officials said yesterday.

headline: Against Yanks, Angels Add Power to Repertory
text: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 22 — On most days, Howie Kendrick is a singles-hitting second baseman for the Angels, stuck near the bottom of the batting order for a reason.

headline: Boots on the Ground Tell the Real Story in Iraq (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Grim Details Emerge in Trial of Hussein Aides
text: A former top aide to Saddam Hussein had two men tied to concrete blocks and thrown from a helicopter into deep water in 1991, according to testimony on the third day of the trial of Ali Hassan al-Majid, known as Chemical Ali, and 14 co-defendants on charges of crimes against humanity.

headline: Next Week
text: Will Leitch returns next week to once again look askance at the world of mainstream sports, and our At Play section takes a look at an increasingly popular treetop travel route: zip lines.

headline: Militias Seizing Control of Iraqi Electricity Grid
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 22 — Armed groups increasingly control the antiquated switching stations that channel electricity around Iraq, the electricity minister said Wednesday.

headline: ‘Free Iraq’ Is Within Reach, Bush Declares
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 22 — President Bush delivered a rousing defense of his Iraq policy on Wednesday, telling a group of veterans that “a free Iraq” is within reach and warning that if Americans succumb to “the allure of retreat,” they will witness death and suffering of the sort not seen since the Vietnam War.

headline: A Childhood Relived, but This Time as a Jet
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 22 — At the autograph session after the Jets’ practice Wednesday afternoon, one of the last members of the team to relinquish the felt-tip pen was also one of the most anonymous: the backup center Joe Villani.

headline: Multiplying the Middle Ground
text: Among other things, the bassist Dave Holland specializes in a sly manipulation of scale. Over the last few years he has led two successful ensembles: a quintet powerful enough to sound much larger, and a big band agile enough to feel much smaller. His new six-piece group appearing at the Blue Note this week occupies a flexible middle ground.

headline: At Saratoga, a Jockey’s Success Only Grows
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22 — Calvin Borel let an ear-to-ear smile say what a voice silenced by laryngitis would not: He was enjoying his first meet at New York’s fabled Saratoga Race Course immensely. Borel had just guided Syriana’s Song to victory in the second race here Wednesday and was being mobbed by fans as he made his way back to the jockeys’ room.

headline: Black Hawk Fails and Crashes, Killing 14 U.S. Soldiers
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 22 — Fourteen American soldiers died Wednesday when their helicopter crashed in northern Iraq, the military said.

headline: Queens: Men Charged in Holdups
text: Four Queens men who prosecutors said were suspected members of the Crips street gang were charged yesterday with robbing at least 16 bodegas in South Queens in the last five months, the authorities said. Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said that in one case, the men are charged with robbing one store and walking down the street to rob another just minutes later. The men, Gregory Burrowes, 27, Jeremy Edwards, 20, Keon Gill, 21, and Ryan Carter, 20, are charged with robbery and assault, Mr. Brown said. He said that not all of them participated in every robbery and that some suspects had not yet been arrested. In two of the robberies, he said, shots were fired and a worker was hit in both legs. The police have not yet arrested the suspected gunman, Mr. Brown said.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: I Lost My Laptop in Outer Space, and Other Tales of Office Theft
text: YEARS ago, back before children and bulk shopping, back when running out of something meant a separate errand, I stole a roll of toilet tissue from the office restroom. It was in the company’s interest that I stay longer rather than race out before the shops closed, I reasoned. It wasn’t stealing. It was a strategic investment of my time.

headline: Opponents Attack Giuliani’s New York Record
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani has showcased his record running the city of New York as he has campaigned for the presidency. But his performance as mayor is now being turned against him as two of his opponents have begun challenging him on two of the biggest issues in the Republican primary: gun control and immigration.

headline: College Board Quits the Loan Business
text: The College Board, the powerful testing organization known for its SAT and Advanced Placement exams, announced yesterday that it was getting out of the student loan business.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: Studio Art

headline: Foxy Brown Is Jailed for Violating Probation
text: Looking uncharacteristically demure, in a high-collared blue dress with a large silver cross around her neck, the rapper Foxy Brown was jailed yesterday for violating her probation.

headline: Large Gardens, Small Lessons
text: RUNNING an organic garden as elaborate as Highgrove is a complex and costly proposition — not a problem, of course, for Prince Charles — but many of the tips that he offers in the new book, “The Elements of Organic Gardening,” written with Stephanie Donaldson, are surprisingly simple.

headline: First on the Clarinet, Later With the Baton
text: The Mostly Mozart Festival’s namesake has had competition for the limelight this summer from an impressively eclectic lineup of composers, not least the exuberant Argentine-American Osvaldo Golijov, an enjoyably ubiquitous presence as the festival’s first composer in residence. But Mozart’s shadow loomed larger over Tuesday’s proceedings at Avery Fisher Hall than it has at many other festival events.

headline: Deluge Continues in Rain-Soaked Midwest
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 22  Already soaked from days of rain, a broad region from Minnesota to Ohio endured more flooding on Wednesday, as rainfall shattered records and weather forecasts called for more flood watches and additional rain.

headline: Being Read to at the Y
text: The 92nd Street Y Unterberg Poetry Center announced its 2007-8 lineup of readings yesterday. Among the writers scheduled to appear are Derek Walcott, the Nobel Prize-winning West Indian poet, on Sept. 17, and the Haitian-American writer Edwidge Danticat and the South African novelist Zakes Mda on Sept. 20. (Ms. Danticat will read from her new memoir, “Brother, I’m Dying.”) Mario Vargas Llosa is to appear on Oct. 15, reading from his new novel, and the Polish poet and essayist Adam Zagajewski on Dec. 6. On Jan. 7 the Nigerian novelist Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie will read, along with Dave Eggers. (After the reading, they will talk with the Sudanese civil war refugee Valentino Achak Deng, on whom Mr. Eggers based his latest fictionalized biography, “What Is the What.”) Roddy Doyle, from Ireland, and A. L. Kennedy, from Scotland, will read on Jan. 23; the Turkish novelist Elif Shafak reads from her latest novel, “The Bastard of Istanbul,” on Feb. 11. Andrew Motion, the poet laureate of Britain, will appear on April 7, and the Nobel Prize winner Imre Kertesz, from Hungary, will share the stage with the pianist Andras Schiff on April 17. The full schedule of readings is available at 92y.org.

headline: Yonkers: Fire Claims One Victim
text: A 78-year-old woman died after a fire broke out shortly before 6 p.m. yesterday in her apartment complex, the Yonkers police said. The woman, Louise Paciarello, who lived by herself in a first-floor one-bedroom apartment at Kristensen Houses at 45 Seymour Street, was brought out of the burning building to St. Joseph’s Medical Center, where she was pronounced dead. The fire was under control by 6:15 p.m.; all the other residents of the complex escaped. The cause of the fire is still under investigation.

headline: Italy’s American Baggage
text: Rome

headline: Scandal and Suicide in China: A Dark Side of Toys
text: They found the body hanging on the third floor of the Lee Der toy factory.

headline: Accident at Deutsche Bank Building Injures 2
text: A piece of construction equipment fell from the 23rd floor of the problem-plagued Deutsche Bank building this afternoon, crashing into a shed and injuring two firefighters, city officials said.

headline: Manhattan: Ferry Operation Transfer
text: After 54 years, the replacement of Circle Line as the operator of ferries to the Statue of Liberty is going to take a few months more. The National Park Service said yesterday that Hornblower Yachts, the California company it chose to succeed Circle Line, would begin carrying tourists to the statue and Ellis Island on Jan. 1, instead of Oct. 2. But fares will increase by 50 cents on Oct. 2 to $12 for adults and $5 for children. Hornblower is still negotiating to purchase Circle Line’s fleet of seven boats, said Terry MacRae, chief executive of Hornblower. Circle Line, which has operated the service since 1953, has agreed not to contest the park service’s decision to award the ferry contract to Hornblower.

headline: Winning It All
text: A ventriloquist, Terry Fator, took home the million-dollar prize on Tuesday on the finale of NBC’s “America’s Got Talent.” Nielsen estimated that the show attracted the largest audience of this summer on any network, drawing an average of 13.9 million total viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., with a 17 percent increase among those 18 to 49. An hourlong “Singing Bee” (9.1 million) kept NBC on top during the 10 p.m. hour, ahead of ABC’s “Primetime: Crime” (6.4 million) and CBS’s “NCIS” repeat (6.5 million). CBS and ABC finished roughly tied for second for the night. “Big Brother” on CBS delivered a solid 7.3 million viewers at 9, while “iCaught” on ABC trailed with 5 million during that hour. At 8, two episodes of ABC’s “Just for Laughs,” averaging 7.2 million viewers, outdrew CBS’s rerun of “Power of 10” (6.1 million) and the second part of Fox’s “On the Lot” finale (2.5 million). Fox ranked fourth over all.

headline: Appeals Court Grants Bail to Ex-Qwest Chief
text: Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International who was convicted of insider trading, may remain free on $2 million bail while he appeals, a federal court ruled yesterday.

headline: Peavy Dominates While Mota Fails Mets Again
text: In a sense, the Mets can cope with last night’s 7-5 loss to the Padres because it came against San Diego’s ace, Jake Peavy. He is one of the best pitchers in baseball. No one has pitched better on the road than he has. He struck out 11 in six innings. The Mets could not think of enough superlatives afterward to describe him.

headline: Worldwide Collaborators, Both Listening and Playing
text: Many people are often uncertain which verb to apply to their experience of attending a concert. “I saw a concert,” one says, then catches himself: “No, I heard it.”

headline: For 2008 Olympics Campaigns, the Starter’s Gun Went Off This Month
text: WITH less than a year to go until the 2008 Summer Games, the Olympic rings are everywhere in Beijing. How is an advertiser, even an official sponsor, supposed to stand out?

headline: Ticketmaster to End Live Nation Contract
text: Signaling a shake-up in the financial structure of the live entertainment business, Ticketmaster said yesterday that it did not expect to extend its long-term contract with Live Nation, the world’s biggest concert promoter.

headline: Scientists Induce Out-of-Body Sensation
text: Using virtual reality goggles, a camera and a stick, scientists have induced out-of-body experiences — the sensation of drifting outside of one’s own body — - in healthy people, according to experiments being published in the journal Science.

headline: Austrian Interns Run Into U.S. Visa Problems
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22  An unusual program that allows Austrians to volunteer in Holocaust institutions in the United States in lieu of serving in the Austrian military has been disrupted because of difficulties in obtaining visas from the American government.

headline: Asian Stocks Up in Early Trading, Buoyed by Rise on Wall Street
text: SINGAPORE, Thursday, Aug. 23 (Dow Jones) — Asian stocks pushed higher early Thursday, as a strong showing on United States markets inspired investors to unwind some of the recent damage.

headline: Does It Feel Like a Playoff?
text: The PGA Tour’s attempt to heighten interest in the latter part of its season begins today with the start of The Barclays, the first event in a new playoff tournament called the FedEx Cup. But Tiger Woods is absent, raising questions about how much meaning the playoff will have. Can golf, and other sports like Nascar and horse racing, really generate late-season interest with playoff formats, or do they appear more like gimmicks?

headline: Your Attention, Please!
text: IN her memoir, “DV,” Diana Vreeland recalled the time she saw Josephine Baker breeze into the back seat of her Rolls-Royce with Chiquita, her pet cheetah, in tow. According to description, Baker was beautifully dressed in a short black skirt and a barely there Vionnet shirt — “no sleeves, no back, no front, just crossed bars on the bias.” But the pièce de résistance was her animal accessory. “I had never seen anything like it,” Vreeland wrote. “It was speed at its best, and style.”

headline: Homemade Shortcuts for the PC
text: Are you ready for a shock? According to a study from the Sloan School of Management at M.I.T., computers actually make you less productive. By the time you’ve finished stumbling around your software and fiddling with your formatting, you’ve spent more time than you would have had you just typed the thing on a typewriter.

headline: A Memorial Service for Max Roach
text: A memorial service for Max Roach, the bebop pioneer who revolutionized jazz drumming, is scheduled for tomorrow at 11 a.m. at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122nd Street, in Morningside Heights. Friends of Mr. Roach, who died on Aug. 16, are expected to play and speak at the public memorial.

headline: Obscure Company Is Behind 9/11 Demolition Work
text: The John Galt Corporation of the Bronx, hired last year for the dangerous and complex job of demolishing the former Deutsche Bank building at 130 Liberty Street, where two firefighters died last Saturday, has apparently never done any work like it. Indeed, Galt does not seem to have done much of anything since it was incorporated in 1983.

headline: Deal Restarts Newfoundland Oil Project
text: OTTAWA, Aug. 22  A 15-month standoff between the Canadian province of Newfoundland and Labrador and several major oil companies over an offshore oil project ended Wednesday, putting the $5.6 billion development back in motion.

headline: Bronx: Man Stabbed to Death
text: A 20-year-old Bronx man was fatally stabbed in a building in Fordham about 8:15 p.m. yesterday, the police said. The victim, identified as Rafael Perdomo, was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. The attacker fled from the scene near the intersection of East 187th Street and Elm Place. There had been no arrests last night, the police said.

headline: Against Delusion: Robert Gober’s Nuts-and-Bolts Americana
text: BASEL, Switzerland — In this summer of international art exhibitions in Europe, unanimity among viewers and critics has been rare. But the grand retrospective for the American sculptor Robert Gober at the Schaulager museum here is drawing a chorus of superlatives.

headline: Despite New Church Rules, Sex Abuse in Catholic School Went Unreported
text: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 22 — For nearly two years, students at St. Dominic Savio Middle School here — particularly the girls — referred to Christian Butler, a part-time computer teacher, as “the Perv.”

headline: Finding Miners Alive Is ‘Totally Unlikely,’ Owner Says
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 22  The co-owner of a Utah coal mine where six workers have been buried since an Aug. 6 collapse said on Wednesday that finding life there was “virtually, totally unlikely” and that he would forever seal the mine and never pull coal from it again.

headline: Steep Rise in Fuel Costs Prompts Rare Public Protest in Myanmar
text: SINGAPORE, Aug. 22 — In a rare public demonstration in Myanmar, hundreds of people marched Wednesday in the country’s largest city to protest steep increases in fuel costs that have driven up the prices of transportation and commodities, according to witnesses and news reports.

headline: Few Initiatives Expected at Summit for Germany’s Ruling Coalition
text: BERLIN, Aug. 22 — In an end-of-summer rite, Chancellor Angela Merkel’s coalition government of conservatives and Social Democrats gather Thursday in a Baroque palace outside Berlin to seek unity and direction before the new parliamentary session.

headline: Report Raises Strong Doubt About Iraqi Government
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 — A stark assessment released today by the nation’s intelligence agencies depicts a paralyzed Iraqi government unable to take advantage of the security gains achieved by the thousands of extra American troops dispatched to the country this year.

headline: Under the Night Sky, a Vivid History Lesson
text: BECKET, Mass., Aug. 21 — It would be nice to feel unmitigatedly positive about Joanna Haigood’s “Invisible Wings,” an ambitious site-specific evocation of slave culture and history, linked to the history of the land that the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival now inhabits. On Tuesday — a day late, after rain forced the cancellation of the scheduled opening — a new version of this open-air work, first presented at the Pillow in 1998, opened on the festival grounds amid a sense of excitement heightened by the delay.

headline: Immigration Checks Ordered in New Jersey
text: TRENTON, Aug. 22 — The New Jersey attorney general, Anne Milgram, on Wednesday ordered local law enforcement agencies to inquire about the immigration status of criminal suspects and notify federal authorities whenever they believe someone arrested is in the country illegally.

headline: Departed Asset Deployer
text: In his victory lap of self-serving interviews, Karl Rove, the departed White House political guru, waxed humble. “I’m a myth,” he insisted. Wishful thinking.

headline: Uncertainty on Vote Dates Intensifies
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22  The uncertainty of the 2008 presidential calendar intensified Wednesday as the Michigan Senate voted to move the state’s primary to Jan. 15 and leaders of the Florida Democratic Party said they had no intention of delaying their nominating contest.

headline: Between Poses, a Barrage of Pickup Lines
text: THE words “Do you come here often?” are not sweet nothings when you are going into final relaxation during a yoga class. Nor do most yoga practitioners welcome someone who flirts shamelessly as mats are positioned during the lull before the teacher arrives.

headline: Fire Dept. Did Not Inspect Pipe in Doomed Building
text: The New York Fire Department failed to visually inspect standpipes in the former Deutsche Bank building every 15 days as required by city rules for buildings being demolished, and had not done any inspections at the building since November 2006, according to records released yesterday by City Hall.

headline: New York Athletic Club Picks Jones
text: Cedric Jones, a New England Patriots wide receiver for nine years and an administrator for the N.F.L. for the past 14, yesterday was named the athletic director of the New York Athletic Club. Jones succeeds 84-year-old Ray Lumpp, who is retiring after 47 years. Lumpp began in 1960, the year Jones was born.Jones played for the Patriots from 1982 to 1990. His last position for the N.F.L. was senior director of youth football. Lumpp was an Olympic gold-medal basketball player in 1948 and played five seasons (1948-53) with the Knicks and the Baltimore Bullets.

headline: Video Chats Aren’t Just for Tycoons
text: A few years ago, the phone was the only quick way to get in touch with distant relatives. Their voices were all you got, so it didn’t matter if Grandpa was still in his bathrobe and slippers.

headline: Political Consultant Resigns After Allegations of Threatening Spitzer’s Father
text: ALBANY, Aug. 22 — The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, forced one of his top political consultants to resign on Wednesday after allegations that he left a threatening telephone message at the office of Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s father.

headline: Footnotes
text: Bob Dylan and Elvis Costello will tour together this fall, Billboard.com reported. The 13-date tour, on which Amos Lee will also perform, begins on Sept. 22 in Duluth, Ga., and ends on Oct. 9 in Rochester, N.Y. Information and tickets: bobdylan.com/index.html. ... The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday that Joseph Kaiser will make his Met debut Oct. 3, taking over from the tenor Rolando Villazón opposite Anna Netrebko in Gounod’s “Roméo et Juliette.” Mr. Kaiser will also sing at the Met on Oct. 6 and Oct. 11. The Met announced last week that Roberto Alagna would sing on Sept. 25 and Sept. 29 in place of Mr. Villazón, who has canceled several months of performances. Mr. Kaiser had been scheduled to sing Steva in Janacek’s “Jenufa” at the Los Angeles Opera from Sept. 27 to Oct. 13; he has been replaced by Jorma Silvasti.

headline: Brooke Astor’s Guardians and Son Battle Over Estate
text: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 22 — Brooke Astor’s son, Anthony D. Marshall, asked a judge on Wednesday to reject a request by his late mother’s court-appointed guardians that they serve as administrators of her estate, saying that they would continue to be hostile and biased against him.

headline: City Tightens Rule Barring Private Trash in Public Bins
text: The city will have new powers to crack down on people who put trash in, of all places, public litter baskets, under a bill passed by the City Council yesterday.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Out for a Sunday Drive

headline: Along Come Joneses, in Two Takes on Reality
text: Fox’s new reality show “Anchorwoman” posits that even an untutored bikini model can be a newscaster. Court TV’s new offering “Star Jones” suggests that even a veteran television personality cannot handle a live talk show on her own.

headline: Brooklyn: Subway Worker Injured
text: A subway track worker was injured yesterday when he fell off a mechanical lift parked beneath the elevated tracks at the Broadway Junction station. A spokesman for Transport Workers Union Local 100 identified the worker as Martin Meyer and said he had worked for New York City Transit for more than 20 years. Mr. Meyer fell from the lift platform about 12:20 p.m. and landed on the cab or hood of the truck on which the lift was mounted, according to the union and the transit agency. The lift was being used to gain access to the underside of the elevated tracks. Mr. Meyer was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where a spokeswoman said he was in stable condition. Paul Fleuranges, a spokesman for the transit agency, said the cause of the accident was unclear. “All the safety equipment was in place,” he said.

headline: With This Software, Digital Home Videos Become Claymation Movies
text: If your home movies are just too dull to be endured, you have a new option: turn your family members into claymation characters.

headline: Apply a Mild Shock
text: HAD Dame Edith Sitwell, who chronicled the lives of eccentrics of the 1930s, been confronted with the contemporary spectacles of some of her countrymen, one has to wonder if she would revise her remark that “eccentricity is not, as dull people would have us believe, a form of madness.” For who, puzzling over how Amy Winehouse, in her state, gets her crazy eyeliner just right, or noting Pete Doherty’s newfound propensity for wearing two hats at once, would not consider the possibility that these people are out to lunch?

headline: Bidders Wanted. Preservationists Definitely Preferred.
text: FOX ISLAND, N.Y.

headline: A Bump in India-U.S. Rapport: Defining ‘Ally’
text: NEW DELHI, Aug. 22  Affection for things American can be felt regarding many things in this country, from sneakers to accents, to where the elite send their children for university education.

headline: How Can We Best Help Afghanistan? (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: JDS Loss Narrows, and Shares Move Higher
text: The JDS Uniphase Corporation, a telecommunications equipment maker, reported a narrower fourth-quarter loss as sales beat analysts’ estimates.

headline: Rose Bampton, Versatile Met Singer, Dies at 99
text: Rose Bampton, an American opera singer who switched from mezzo-soprano to soprano and sang leading roles in both ranges at the Metropolitan Opera, died on Tuesday in Bryn Mawr, Pa. She was 99.

headline: Intelligence Chief Reveals Eavesdropping Details
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 — The Bush administration has confirmed for the first time that American telecommunications companies played a key role in the National Security Agency’s domestic eavesdropping program after asserting for nearly two years that any role played by the companies was a “state secret.”

headline: Edward Avedisian, Artist Who Painted Bold and Bright, Dies at 71
text: Edward Avedisian, who helped establish the hotly colored but emotionally cool abstract painting that succeeded Abstract Expressionism in the early 1960s, died on Friday in Philmont, N.Y. He was 71 and lived in Hudson, N.Y.

headline: A Return to That Drop-Dead Year 1960
text: “I’M from Bay Ridge. We have manners,” Peggy, the pony-tailed secretary, scolds the colleague who has just propositioned her in “Mad Men,” the new drama on the cable channel AMC. Do Peggy’s colleagues at Sterling Cooper, the turbo-powered advertising agency where she works, fall a little short in that department?

headline: Correction: 	It’s Summer: Isn’t Anyone at Work?
text: The Life’s Work column on Aug. 9, about low productivity in summer, misstated the name of the research division of Kronos Inc., a productivity management company, which did a survey showing that 39 percent of the 1,077 full-time employees it questioned admitted to calling in sick to enjoy a day off in summer. It is the Workforce Institute, not the Workplace Institute.

headline: ‘Kid Nation’ Parents Gave Show Free Rein
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 — Children who participated in “Kid Nation,” a CBS reality show that has come under fire over questions of whether it violated child safety and labor laws, were required to do whatever they were told by the show’s producers, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, or risk expulsion from the show, according to a copy of the contract signed by the children and their parents.

headline: New Orleans Flood Plan Upgrade Urged
text: Federal officials outlined plans yesterday for a significant improvement to the New Orleans flood-protection system by 2011, but said the total cost would be more than double the $7.1 billion that Congress has already appropriated for repairs and upgrades.

headline: Hikers’ Guidebook Is Reinvented Online
text: BOSTON, Aug. 22  For people who hike the White Mountains of New Hampshire, the Appalachian Mountain Club’s guidebook for the area has been required reading for 100 years, as essential a part of a hiker’s gear as a backpack or sturdy boots.

headline: Memory Cards for Antiquity
text: Q. How long can I store pictures on a memory card?

headline: The Subject Was ... Something Else
text: Trying to talk tennis with Serena Williams, Susan Dominus discovered, is like trying to return one of her 120-m.p.h serves. You just keep swinging and missing. “Maybe it’s because she always gets the same questions about tennis,” Dominus says, “or maybe it’s because, for her, it’s like talking about work.”

headline: Après Rehab: A Lovely Sobriety
text: FASHION designers usually hate things that women can actually wear. Or, at any rate, they hate it when someone calls their clothing wearable. They feel profoundly reduced by the taint of utility. For that reason, a lot of fashion in the last few years has looked not merely extreme but also tangential to women’s lives.

headline: Pakistan Court Allows Return of Exiled Leader
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 23 — Pakistan’s Supreme Court ruled today that the former prime minister Nawaz Sharif, who was thrust into exile in 2000 after a military coup, could return to the country, in what could be a direct political challenge to Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.

headline: Grace Paley, Writer and Activist, Dies
text: Grace Paley, the celebrated writer and social activist whose short stories explored in precise, pungent and tragicomic style the struggles of ordinary women muddling through everyday lives, died on Wednesday at her home in Thetford Hill, Vt. She was 84 and also had an apartment in Manhattan.

headline: Firefighter Killed in Lower Manhattan Is Mourned
text: A fire engine rolled through the streets of Brooklyn this morning, a coffin draped in the red and white flag of the fire department sitting on its back. Bagpipes wailed, a caravan of black cars carrying grieving family members followed, and along the streets, rows and rows of men and women in blue suits stood in silence.

headline: Curiouser and Curiouser
text: New York State politics has become an arena best entered through the looking glass. First, Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s team tried to reveal the bad transportation habits of his chief Republican opponent by pushing state troopers to reveal all. Then came the investigations of his administration’s bad habits in using state troopers for political purposes. And now there is The Phone Call.

headline: Unsafe Mining
text: The announcement by the operators of the Crandall Canyon Mine that they will keep searching for the six miners trapped below the surface, and close the mine for good if they find no signs of life, is a welcome decision.

headline: Tight Leader Board at Met Open
text: Rick Hartmann of Atlantic Golf Club in Bridgehampton, N.Y., shot a four-under-par 67 to hold a one-stroke lead after the first round of the 92nd Met Open Championship at The Meadow Brook Club in Jericho, N.Y. A stroke behind Hartmann were Mark Schaare of Knob Hill (N.J.), Charlie Meola of Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn., and Anthony Casalino of Willow Ridge in Westchester County. Andrew Giuliani of Van Cortlandt, the 2006 M.G.A. Player of the Year, was at par 71.

headline: Cue the Film Awards Season and Strike a Somber Note
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 — Given the signals preceding next month’s bellwether Toronto International Film Festival, party planners might want pick to up some black crepe to go with those red carpets in the movie awards season to come.

headline: 4 Major Banks Tap Fed for Financing
text: The country’s four biggest banks announced yesterday that they had each borrowed $500 million from the Federal Reserve, taking an unusual step to ease the credit squeeze that has been rattling the financial system for weeks.

headline: Zimbabwe: Price Crackdown Eased
text: Faced with barren store shelves nationwide, the government has slightly eased its two-month rollback of prices, allowing retailers to mark up the prices of some basic commodities and farm goods by 20 percent. Most commodities vanished from stores when the government ordered all prices cut by at least 50 percent in late June; factories and retailers have been unwilling to restock, because the artificially low prices would have forced them to sell at a loss. The price rollback was an attempt to quell inflation, which was said by the government yesterday to average 7,600 percent a year but is regarded by experts to run at twice that rate. Those experts said the tiny price increases being allowed by the government were unlikely to spur production of new goods. The government has arrested, jailed or fined 12,000 business managers for violating price decrees under the rollback.

headline: Passion for Film Spurs New Festivals, but Grueling Work Keeps Them Going
text: Lunch hours were the first casualty of Tom O’Malley’s ambition. He sacrificed his afternoon breaks sometime last November as he pushed ahead with plans for the inaugural American Cinematic Experience Film Festival. His living room went next, overtaken by piles of paperwork and plastic tubs stuffed with DVD submissions for the event. Then his bank account took a hit.

headline: Sarkozy’s New Order
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Showtime in Austin
text: It’s not often that a writer turns out an article then finds his topic has become his neighbor. But that’s what happened to Michael Hall after he reported a story for the current issue of PLAY on the TV show “Friday Night Lights.” Hall, a senior editor at Texas Monthly, discovered that “Lights,” which is filmed in Austin, was making the rounds of the neighborhoods. “They shot a bar scene half block from my house last week,” Hall says. “They park cameras and trucks and catering services a block from our house in a church parking lot. People are used to seeing them. They’re all over Austin -- bars, record stores, book stores, and generally the hipster places.”

headline: 2 G.M. Brands, a Similar Car, but Very Different Results
text: DETROIT, Aug. 22 — When General Motors first showed off the Pontiac Solstice, the low-slung, head-turning roadster, it seemed the perfect antidote for the brand, whose flagship sedan had become known as the “Bland Am.”

headline: Bangladesh Imposes Curfew to Stifle Protests
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh, Aug. 22 — Shattering the calm of seven months of army-backed rule, violent clashes between students and the police led the government to impose an indefinite curfew on Wednesday night in six of the country’s largest cities, in a return of the political instability that prompted a caretaker government to take power in January.

headline: Connecticut Court Nominee Withdraws Over Immigrant Remark
text: HARTFORD, Aug. 22 (AP) — Judge John R. Downey of State Superior Court, Gov. M. Jodi Rell’s nominee for the State Appellate Court, withdrew his name from consideration on Wednesday after court transcripts showed that he had mistakenly claimed that only legal residents could use the court system.

headline: Hurricane Dean Fades, Leaving Behind Less Damage Than Expected
text: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 22 — Hurricane Dean, with its ferocious winds, monstrous Category 5 status and long trail of death and debris, was certainly no dud. But the weakened storm that swept ashore on Mexico’s gulf coast on Wednesday wreaked far less havoc than many anticipated it would.

headline: Play iPod D.J., With Those Essential Scratching Sounds and Smooth Transitions From Song to Song
text: As technology marches on, things are left behind. The clock radio supplants the rooster, the horseless carriage overtakes the coach-and-four, and the vinyl record player falls to the Numark iDJ2.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article and headline in Business Day yesterday on the investment returns posted by the endowment of Harvard University misstated the return for fiscal 2007, which ended June 30. The return was 23 percent, not 22.4 percent. (The figure published in The Times did not take into account net distributions to the university.) The article also misstated the value of the University of Virginia endowment. It is $4.3 billion, not $880 million.

headline: Manning Makes Strong Defense of Manning
text: Indianapolis Colts quarterback Peyton Manning, whose leadership ability was once questioned by a teammate, joined the fray between his younger brother Eli and the former Giants running back Tiki Barber, now a commentator for NBC. During a television broadcast Sunday night, Barber criticized Eli’s leadership skills. Eli fired back at Barber on Tuesday, and Peyton took a shot yesterday at former players who join the news media after their playing careers end and then criticize current players.

headline: Pettitte Helps Yankees Avoid Sweep in Anaheim
