text: ANAHEIM, Aug. 22 — The Yankees fled Angel Stadium on Wednesday night, grateful to have won a game, thrilled that they will not have to see this place for another year.

headline: Two Monitors, One PC
text: Q. Is there a way to connect two monitors to a Windows XP computer so I can keep my e-mail window up in one and do the rest of my work on the other?

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: Browning of the Clematis

headline: Assurances on Buybacks May Cost a Lender
text: Expanding rapidly as the nation’s largest home mortgage company, Countrywide Home Loans quietly promised investors who bought its loans that it would repurchase some if homeowners got into financial difficulties.

headline: Record Profit at Australian Mining Giant
text: BHP Billiton of Australia, the world’s largest mining company, reported an eighth consecutive record profit yesterday and said that weakness in the American housing market showed no sign of reducing demand for commodities in Asia and Europe.

headline: Correction
text: An article in Business Day on Monday about the pending deal to take Tribune Company private referred incorrectly to Tribune’s retirement benefit plans. The company has not halted contributions to retirement plans, nor would the proposed transaction to take the company private eliminate contributions to a retirement plan in exchange for stock ownership. The article also misstated the decline in Tribune’s print and online advertising revenue for the first half of 2007 compared with the same period in 2006. The decline was 8.7 percent, not 11.2 percent. (Go to Article)

headline: Older Players Lose the Swagger but Gain the Swag
text: With preteens forming corporate relationships and 20-somethings locked into wildly lucrative deals, tennis marketing often seems dominated entirely by the youth of the sport. But each year, hundreds of seniors across the country take the sport’s marketing to the opposite end of the age spectrum.

headline: Godfather of Soul; Father Many Times Over
text: ATLANTA, Aug. 22 — Callers to a certain Houston residence have lately been greeted by a cheerfully assertive message: “You have just reached the home of LaRhonda Petitt Brown.”

headline: Ranch House Made Over: From Modest to Modernist
text: SIX years ago, Greg Lemke, a scientist in La Jolla, Calif., took a close look at his modest 40-year-old house and realized, he said, “that the basic structure — plumbing, drains, wiring, roof, furnace — was starting to fall apart.” Mr. Lemke, an architecture buff, figured that while fixing all those things, he should try to turn the ordinary ranch house into something more distinguished.

headline: Organic Looks Easy, if You’ve Got a Royal Staff
text: Tetbury, England

headline: Estonia Accuses Ex-Official of Genocide
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 22 — The authorities in Estonia on Wednesday said that they had charged a cousin of a former president with genocide in connection with his role as a Communist bureaucrat involved in the deportation of civilians to Siberia in 1949.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on July 31 about efforts to stabilize the shrinking year-round population of Fishers Island, N.Y., an enclave for the wealthy in summer, referred incorrectly to public services on the island. Although most homes have septic tanks, there is in fact a sewer system that serves an estimated two dozen homes, according to an engineer who does inspections on the island.

headline: Japanese Trade Surplus Narrowed in July
text: Japan’s trade surplus narrowed more in July than economists had forecast as automobile exports cooled, heightening concern that growth in Japan, the world’s second-largest economy, might slow.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. How should I decorate a long, narrow living room?

headline: No, I Haven’t Been Mugged. Why Do You Ask?
text: YOU know fall is upon us when beauty companies start pushing femme fatale makeup.

headline: As Industries Wane, Entrepreneurs Reinvent
text: THE Wick family, owners of a century-old company that makes pipe organs, could have easily given up. Demand for the organs has plunged over the last few decades, as churchgoers took a liking to the modern sounds of electronic instruments. Soaring manufacturing costs have made new pipe organs prohibitively expensive, with some organs priced over $1 million.

headline: Lehman Closes Subprime Unit and Lays Off 1,200
text: Lehman Brothers, a leader in packaging subprime mortgages into securities, said yesterday that it would shut one of its home lending units and lay off 1,200 employees. The bank said it would take a $52 million charge to third-quarter earnings.

headline: South Africa: Study Challenges Garlic Claim
text: In an implicit rebuke to the Health Ministry, the Academy of Sciences of South Africa said its studies had found no scientific basis for the use of nutritional supplements as a first-line defense against H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. The country’s health minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, has been widely criticized for questioning the safety of anti-H.I.V. drugs and promoting nostrums like garlic, beetroot and lemon as effective agents against the disease. The academy’s report did not rule out the usefulness of good nutrition in countries like South Africa, where malnutrition is more widespread, and noted that a good diet was important in maintaining the body’s defenses against AIDS. But a healthy diet, it stated, plays a backup role to drugs like antiretrovirals in the body’s fight against AIDS.

headline: Tip of the Week: Setting Your Cellphone’s Alarm-Clock
text: TIP OF THE WEEK: Don’t rely on a confusing (or broken) hotel alarm clock when traveling. Most cellphones include an alarm-clock function. Check your phone’s Tools or Applications menu. And if your phone can receive text messages and you use Google’s or Yahoo’s calendar, you can set the software to send appointment reminders to your phone so you know where you have to be once you get up.

headline: Presidential Candidates, Beware Your Children
text: The Bureau for the Monitoring of Theatrical Plot Overuse issued a Level 2 warning this week on story lines featuring a female presidential candidate whose campaign is imperiled by a sex scandal involving her grown son.

headline: Council Committee Backs Rezoning Plan to Turn Jamaica Into an ‘Airport Village’
text: A plan to transform downtown Jamaica, Queens, into a vibrant “airport village” while preserving the quiet, low-scale character of neighboring side streets cleared an important City Council committee yesterday, all but ensuring final approval next month for the single largest rezoning of the Bloomberg administration.

headline: Mystery and Mirth on the Streets of Laos
text: Laos may seem an unlikely setting for a series of terrifically beguiling detective novels steeped in local color and history. But look at what ingenious use Alexander McCall Smith’s No. 1 Ladies’ Detective Agency books make of the equally exotic culture of Botswana.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An “Arts, Briefly” report on Aug. 11 about the hiring of Shawn Killinger as a host on the QVC shopping network referred incorrectly to the hours she is scheduled to appear beginning in December. She will be seen overnight, not during the day, and her appearances will last three to four hours, not a guaranteed four hours.

headline: HBO’s Rivals Say It Has Stumbled, Though Catching Up Is Tough
text: Has HBO, the pay-television channel stocked with so many outstanding shows that it declared itself in a category all its own — as in “It’s not TV, it’s HBO” — finally tumbled from its pedestal of prestige?

headline: Lehman Closes Subprime Unit and Lays Off 1,200
text: Lehman Brothers, a leader in packaging subprime mortgages into securities, is shutting down one of its home lending units and laying off 1,200 employees. The bank said it would take a $52 million hit to third-quarter earnings.

headline: Japan Pushes for Stronger Partnership With India
text: NEW DELHI, Aug. 22 — Japan pushed on Wednesday for stronger economic ties to India with one of the largest business delegations to visit here.

headline: Ah, the Tonic of Ginseng! Especially a $65,000 Sprig!
text: JINAN, South Korea — A roadside restaurant here was abuzz one recent morning with talk of a $65,000 ginseng plant.

headline: Many Found Sexually Active Into the 70s
text: Most Americans remain sexually active into their 60s, and nearly half continue to have sex regularly into their early 70s, researchers are reporting today as a result of the most comprehensive national survey to date of sexual behavior among older adults.

headline: Top Half of Women's Draw Features Drama
text: Maria Sharapova has not won a Grand Slam event since last year’s United States Open, where she jumped ecstatically on the court in her glamorous black dress, blowing kisses.

headline: Sometimes in Life, Three’s Not a Crowd
text: OSTERVILLE, Mass.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An art review on Aug. 10 of “A Vicious Undertow,” a film by Jesper Just at the Perry Rubenstein Gallery, referred incorrectly to another filmmaker whose camera work was similar. He is Max Ophuls, not his son, Marcel Ophuls, a documentary maker.

headline: What Do Unions Want? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Comeback Chance for Griffin Ends in Fiery Crash
text: The last time Keith Jones saw him, Eddie Griffin was smiling, upbeat and chatty. They met by chance last spring, at a Houston restaurant, and it seemed to Jones, a Rockets vice president, that Griffin  the troubled former Rockets forward  was optimistic.

headline: Gambling Dispute With a Tiny Country Puts U.S. in a Bind
text: With long blond hair reaching his shoulders and dozens of cloth bracelets peeking out from under his sleeves, Mark E. Mendel hardly conjures up the image of a typical lawyer.

headline: The Liberty Is Hoping Its Big Body Comes Up Big
text: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 22  When the Liberty opens its W.N.B.A. playoff series Friday night against the Detroit Shock at Madison Square Garden, Janel McCarville will play power forward or center. For a while, it did not seem she would be playing meaningful time anywhere, let alone become one of the most promising young players in women’s basketball.

headline: Reed Finds a Familiar Face in Comeback Try as a Giant
text: ALBANY, Aug. 22 — J. R. Reed trotted onto the practice field on his first day as a Giant about as anonymously as possible. His name had not yet been added to his No. 30 jersey Wednesday morning. In fact, he did not even have the number to himself. Another No. 30, DeCori Birmingham, worked out across the field at running back.

headline: Strike a Pose (There’s Nothing to It), and Dance, Priestesses, Dance
text: Like very high priestesses of separate and ancient religious cults, the dance soloists Pilar Rioja and Roxane D’Orléans Juste have come together to share a program, “2 Styles, 1 Passion,” at Repertorio Español. You could say that each in her own way is a dancer of the old school, at least in the sense that Randall Jarrell applies to a character in his novel “Pictures From an Institution” when he says, “And if her school had been any older it would have been dead.” It has been years since I have witnessed performances so wholly devoid of spontaneity and yet so anxious to indicate great artistry.

headline: Manhattan: Hotel Evacuated in Fire
text: A small fire in a restaurant at 511 Lexington Avenue yesterday afternoon led to an evacuation of the Radisson Lexington Hotel, fire and hotel officials said. The Fire Department said a fire was reported on the first floor of the building about 3:30 p.m. Fire officials said 78 firefighters responded, and the fire was contained in the ductwork. The fire was under control about 4:30 p.m., fire officials said. Two civilians and one firefighter were treated for minor injuries, the department said. Brian Dunne, a spokesman for the hotel, said the restaurant, Raffles Cafe, was a separate business from the hotel, which was not damaged.

headline: 14, and on a Career Path? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Drugstore Clinics Spread, and Scrutiny Grows
text: The concept has been called urgent care “lite”: Patients who are tired of waiting days to see a doctor for bronchitis, pinkeye or a sprained ankle can instead walk into a nearby drugstore and, at lower cost, with brief waits, see a doctor or a nurse and then fill a prescription on the spot.

headline: Toward Electoral Validity (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Tuesday, about the discovery of remains of a field of manioc grown by the Maya in Central America in the first millennium A.D., referred incorrectly to the nature of the discovery. The researchers said it was the earliest evidence for cultivation, not domestication, of the tuber in the Americas. Manioc was domesticated  that is, modified to become a more usable food resource  a few thousand years earlier, probably in Brazil.

headline: Like Mice on a Treadmill
text: If you’ve dusted off a pair of old running shoes since reading Gretchen Reynolds’s compelling article on the effect of exercise on the brain, you’re not alone. “Most of the experts I interviewed said they’ve started exercising more,” Reynolds says. “I’ve run every day since I wrote the story.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Two Weeks Later, Evidence and Memories of the Tornado Remain Vivid
text: For many New Yorkers, the tornado that struck southwestern Brooklyn two weeks ago may be little more than a memory of a novel visit by a typically Midwestern weather phenomenon. But on the blocks where the Category 2 tornado touched down, evidence of the destruction is still fresh.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: Just Looking Could Be Costly Under Proposed Voyeurism Law
text: When women in his Queens district started complaining of a strange man standing under the steps of the elevated subway at Ditmars Boulevard, looking up their skirts, City Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr. said he was as surprised as anyone to learn there was no law against it.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 9 P.M. (CNN) GOD’S CHRISTIAN WARRIORS In the late 1970s conservative Christians began to play a larger role in American politics, a response in part to Roe v. Wade, the United States Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion. By the 1980 national election the Moral Majority, founded by the Rev. Jerry Falwell, helped defeat 12 incumbent senators. “Whoever speaks up most gets to shape the culture,” Ron Luce, the evangelical activist, said more recently to a crowd of thousands in San Francisco at this year’s BattleCry rally, above, whose mission is to train young Christians to “battle” secular “virtue terrorists.” In this special, the final installment in a three-part series about religious fervor, Christiane Amanpour looks at the ways evangelicals influence American politics, and speaks with Mr. Falwell in what was to be his last interview, just one week before his death in May, about his battle against abortion and his thoughts on the 2008 presidential campaign.

headline: Head Turners
text: Make them stop and stare (for the right reasons).

headline: BofA Buys $2 Billion Stake in Countrywide
text: Bank of America said Wednesday that it has agreed to invest $2 billion in troubled lender Countrywide Financial, buying preferred shares that carry an interest rate of 7.25 percent and can be converted into common stock at $18 each.

headline: Top Banks Tap Federal Reserve for Financing
text: The country’s four biggest banks announced Wednesday that they had each borrowed $500 million from the Federal Reserve, taking an unusual step to ease the credit squeeze that has been rattling the financial system for weeks.

headline: Takeover Talks Buoy Nymex Stock
text: Wall Street registered its approval Wednesday of a potential takeover of the commodities exchange operator Nymex, sending the parent company’s stock higher. The share price jumped after the chairman of Nymex Holdings, Richard Schaeffer, said late Tuesday that the company had had preliminary discussions with a possible buyer. He said any deal must offer a meaningful premium to the current stock price.

headline: Appeals Court Grants Bail to Ex-Qwest Chief
text: Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International who was convicted of insider trading, may remain free on $2 million bail while he appeals, a federal court ruled Wednesday.

headline: Is the Bonus Bonanza Over?
text: Wall Street bonuses may be cut for the first time in five years as a result of the credit market freeze that is paralyzing leveraged buyouts, mergers and myriad computer-driven trading strategies, according to specialists.

headline: RCM Takes Computer Task Bid Public
text: RCM Technologies, which provides specialty professional staffing, made public Wednesday its $105 million offer for Computer Task Group after it was rebuffed twice by the board.

headline: Looking to Dump the Deal, MGIC Sues Radian for More Info
text: MGIC Investment, which agreed in February to buy rival mortgage insurer Radian Group but has since had second thoughts, has filed a federal lawsuit in Milwaukee to force the Philadelphia company to give it more information.

headline: PayPal Founder Sees Gold in Sparkly Slides
text: PayPal founder Max Levchin’s latest start-up Slide, which makes helps MySpace and Facebook users make sparkly slide shows, may seem frivolous. But Mr. Levchin expects the lighter side of the Web to generate serious money, even more than PayPal did, which he sold to eBay for $1.5 billion in 2002.

headline: Neuromed Swallows $53.3 from Investors
text: Neuromed Pharmaceuticals, a developer of pain medicines, announced Wednesday that it had raised $53.3 million in private financing to develop an opioid painkiller.

headline: TXU and Its Bidders Spent $17 Million on Lone Star Lobbying
text: TXU and the private equity firms trying to buy the company spent about $17 million on lobbyists and advertising during the most recent session of the Texas state Legislature, according to a report by a group that tracks political spending.

headline: 3i Plans to Build $1 Billion India Fund
text: Publicly listed British private equity house 3i Group plans to build on its already strong relationships in India with the establishment of its first dedicated India infrastructure fund, which has an initial target of $1 billion.

headline: Deal Chatter Lifts Stocks
text: Stocks rallied Wednesday, building on the recent recovery, as takeover talk and bets that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates next month cooled worries about the impact of the tightening credit market on equities and the economy.

headline: HSBC to Shut Mortgage Office and Lay Off 600
text: The U.S. mortgage unit of HSBC said Wednesday it will close an office in Indiana, a move that will affect about 600 workers, amid a severe downturn in U.S. credit and housing markets.

headline: Hedge Funds Seek to Block Arcelor Takeover
text: Three hedge fund investors in steel giant Arcelor asked a Dutch court Wednesday to block the company’s 30 billion euro ($40 billion) takeover by Mittal Steel, saying that a revised share swap deal has cost them 152 million euros ($205 million).

headline: Another Mortgage Lender Shuts Its Doors
text: Amstar Financial became the latest subprime casualty, announcing Wednesday that it is closing its mortgage banking subsidiary and transferring the operations to The Money Store.

headline: Paris Hedge Fund Hit By Sentinel Collapse
text: Further indications of the financial damage done by the collapse of Sentinel Management Group started to emerge on Wednesday when Capital Fund Management, a Paris hedge fund, said it stood to lose 27 percent of its assets as a result of the cash management firm’s troubles.

headline: Is VMware’s Stock Too Hot?
text: The initial public offering VMware, the year’s best so far, was a bright spot amid gloomy market conditions. But MarketWatch notes that some analysts think that the virtualization software maker’s stock, which has already soared more than 150 percent, may be burning too hot, too fast.

headline: “Welcome, YouTube. Seriously.”
text: When YouTube pitched its new ad format, it described to me the semi-transparent overlay ads as “something that has not been available before.” It probably should have added: “on YouTube.”

headline: Regulators Cry Foul on Dubai’s OMX Stake
text: Borse Dubai‘s planned $4 billion cash bid for OMX seemed in jeopardy on Thursday after Sweden’s Financial Supervisory Authority ruled it broke the law when it bought a large stake in the Nordic market operator on August 9. But the regulator will allow the sale to continue.

headline: Blow to HSBC Bid for Korea Exchange
text: HSBC has suffered an early setback in its attempt to secure a 2.5 billion pound ($5 billion) takeover of Korea’s sixth-largest banking group, Korea Exchange Bank.

headline: Britain’s Law Firms See $24 Billion Bonanza
text: The top 100 legal firms in Britain collected more than 12 billion pounds ($24 billion) in fees over the last year and the best-paid partners netted more than 2 million pounds each from their share of profits, according to a report in Legal Business magazine.

headline: Goldman Fund Is Said to Rebound
text: Goldman Sachs‘s Global Equity Opportunities hedge fund rose 12 percent last week after the securities firm shored up the money-losing pool with $3 billion of cash, investors told Bloomberg News.

headline: Banks Balk at Funding Home Depot Deal, Report Says
text: Home Depot‘s plans to sell its wholesale supply division to a group of private equity buyers is in doubt because the investment banks involved are reluctant to fund the deal, even at a lower price, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Perimeter Pulls In 2nd Round of Investments
text: Perimeter eSecurity, a provider of network security services, said on Thursday that it will have boosted its fundraising to more than $100 million this year after a second round of investments, this time from Goldman Sachs, Bessemer Venture Partners and the Stripes Group.

headline: Ex-Wal-Mart Executive’s Suit Dismissed from Michigan Court
text: The scandal-filled legal battle between Wal-Mart Stores and its former senior marketing executive, Julie Ann Roehm, has been tossed from a Michigan state court, Portfolio.com reported.

headline: Calculating a Private Equity Tax Hike
text: Efforts in Congress to more than double taxes on managers of private equity firms would generate little or no extra revenue to help pay for middle-class tax cuts that many lawmakers are seeking, a study finds. Buyout and venture capital firms would restructure their affairs to sidestep new tax laws, according to the study, by Michael Knoll, a law professor at the University of Pennsylvania.

headline: K.K.R. Denies Delaying I.P.O.
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts on Wednesday denied a report by the Times of London saying that the private equity firm has put its $1.25 billion initial public offering on hold.

headline: Flight for Safety
text:
The number of Iraqis fleeing their homes has soared since the American troop buildup began in
February, according to data from humanitarian groups.

headline: Ford C.E.O. Warns of Credit Impact on Jaguar Sale
text: Ford Motor Chief Executive Alan Mulally said on Wednesday that volatility in global credit markets was a concern in its disposal of British luxury brands Jaguar and Land Rover, but the conditions were not slowing down the sale.

headline: Morning Buzz: Behind Ground Zero Demolition Work, a Little-Known Company With Problems
text: In a front-page article, Charles V. Bagli, David W. Dunlap and William K. Rashbaum reveal that the John Galt Corporation, the subcontractor hired last year to demolish the former Deutsche Bank building at 130 Liberty Street, is “not much more than a corporate entity meant to accommodate the people and companies actually doing the demolition job.”In fact, the real companies behind Galt are the Regional Scaffolding and Hoisting Company, which is not in business to demolish skyscrapers, and former executives from Safeway Environmental Corporation, a company that had already been removed from one contract at 130 Liberty because of concerns about its integrity.

headline: 2008: Who Owns ‘Change’?
text: It’s a classic campaign theme that’s bound to come up in presidential races. And, during the 2008 election cycle in particular, when it comes to the idea of “change,” each of the leading Democratic presidential contenders is trying it on for size.

headline: Another in a series of F1 press conference reports
text: Felipe Massa was in quite a good mood at the beginning of the press conference, it seemed, as this race in Turkey is the place where he scored his first Formula One victory, last year.

headline: In Pakistan, a Court Opens Doors for Musharraf’s Foes
text: When Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry was reinstated as the chief justice of Pakistan’s Supreme Court in early July, the question immediately arose of how intensely he would challenge Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the man who tried to remove him.

headline: Waiting for Products to Arrive
text: The other day, I was looking at some absolutely amazing pictures of my kids, on a beach, at sunset, that my wife took with our trusty Canon SD800 digital camera. It was just amazing to see the quality that could come from a little tiny shirt-pocket cam like that. I smiled. “Yep,” I thought, “the pocket digital camera has finally arrived.”

headline: The Psychology of Numeracy
text: In this month’s Wired magazine, columnist Clive Thompson makes an outrageous and thought-provoking claim: that geeks like Bill Gates are better suited to comprehending the world’s problems than non-geeks.

headline: Goldman to Take Stake in Chinese Cement Maker, Report Says
text: Goldman Sachs is in advanced talks to take a quarter of a privately owned cement maker in east China for nearly $80 million, marking the latest foreign foray into the country’s fragmented cement sector, Reuters reported Thursday citing an unnamed source.

headline: Sporting Steroids: Ban the Ban?
MySpace, MTV Plan Candidate Chats
text: The popular social networking site MySpace is teaming up with MTV to hold a series of “candid, unfiltered discussions” this fall between young voters and the major Republican and Democratic presidential candidates.

headline: Reading the Right
text: An Associated Press-Ipsos poll released this week indicated that liberals read more than conservatives, and Pat Schroeder – the president of the American Association of Publishers, and the former Democratic House member from Colorado – made headlines when she tried to interpret the results.

headline: Glowing Tents to Light Up Roosevelt Island’s Southern Tip
text: Roosevelt Island has had many names: Manning’s Island, Blackwell’s Island, Welfare Island. It has also been the home of institutionalized populations: orphans, smallpox victims, patients with mental illness.

headline: Does It Feel Like  a Playoff?
text: The PGA Tour’s attempt to heighten interest in the latter part of its season begins today with the start of The Barclays, the first event in a new playoff tournament called the Fed Ex Cup. But Tiger Woods is absent, raising questions about how much meaning the playoff will have. Can golf, and other sports like Nascar and horse racing, really generate late-season interest with playoff formats, or do they appear more like gimmicks?

headline: A Pair of Crushing Defeats in Baseball
text: The only thing worse than losing is losing really, really badly. And the only thing worse than that is losing so badly that history is made. And that’s what happened last night in Baltimore, where the Rangers routed the Orioles 30-3, an offensive outburst unseen in 110 years.

headline: ‘You Can Learn to Enjoy It’
text: The last thing I’d want to buy, I’d guess, is a used sex manual.

headline: Remaining “On the Ground”
text: I’ll be on book leave for the next few months, slaving away on a book with my wife and so writing neither my column nor contributing to this blog. In my absence, I’ve recruited a first-rate team of diverse commentators to blog in this space – and hence make this space far more interesting than it ever was when it was just my sandbox.

headline: Waiting for Products to Arrive
text: The other day, I was looking at some absolutely amazing pictures of my kids, on a beach, at sunset, that my wife took with our trusty Canon SD800 digital camera. It was just amazing to see the quality that could come from a little tiny shirt-pocket cam like that. I smiled. “Yep,” I thought, “the pocket digital camera has finally arrived.”

headline: U-17 Update: Bad News
text: [UPDATED] The young Americans are out. Or, at least close to it. They could be playing for pride only in the final game of the first round of the U-17 World Cup in South Korea. They lost to Tunisia, 3-1, Thursday. The United States is bottom of the group with 0 points. Only a game on Aug. 26 against Belgium is keeping the Yanks around. Belgium beat Tajikistan 1-0.

headline: C’Mon, Tim!
text: Tim Henman, the great English hope with a classic game, is holding a news conference right now in Flushing Meadows to talk about his retirement, and British papers like the Times of London and The Guardian have already written appreciations (he spilled the beans to them earlier).

headline: Game On
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Out and About: Johnny Utah’s
text: We New Yorkers like to think we’re on the front edge of things, but there are trends — or at least curiosities — that pass us by. That happen elsewhere but not here, allowing others to enjoy what we are so cruelly denied. That force us to accept that we may not really be at the center of the universe. That leave us bereft.

headline: Firefighter Is Mourned in Brooklyn
text: Updated, 12:32 p.m. | Firefighters in their dress uniforms lined Fort Hamilton Avenue in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, this morning at the funeral for Firefighter Joseph Graffagnino, 33, who died in the fire that consumed the former Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan on Saturday.The funeral Mass at Saint Ephrem’s Church, at 929 Bay Ridge Parkway at Fort Hamilton Parkway, began shortly after 10 a.m. Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg were both scheduled to speak. The other firefighter who was killed on Saturday, Robert Beddia, 53, is to be buried on Friday after a funeral Mass at St. Patrick’s Cathedral.

headline: A Site Where Subway Riders Can Compare Notes (and Complain, Too)
text: If a new Facebook application makes it easier for thousands of subway riders to share information about delays and disruptions, they’ll have Mr. Bloomberg to thank.

headline: Near Miss
text: Chetumal

headline: A Literary Footnote to a Fire: John Galt
text: Who is John Galt?

headline: That Vietnam Analogy: Reactions
text: As he promised, President Bush’s speech before the Veterans of Foreign Wars yesterday contained a number of comparisons between Iraq and the Vietnam war: “Then as now, people argued the real problem was America’s presence and that if we would just withdraw, the killing would end … The world would learn just how costly these misimpressions would be.”

headline: Raising the Roof
text: My head today is full of stray and no-account thoughts, replies to Big Mama and other points of interest. I’m sorry if I seem a little untidy, but Mr. Roberts had the pole position, so I let his interview go on through before I turned back to Sept. Vogue. The topic still seems incendiary and very soon it won’t be as we slide toward another NY Fashion Week, more shows, more strange encounters with the so-called American Ideal.

headline: Soccer in Bridgehampton, Beach Closings, the War on Butts and More
text: Corey Kilgannon, who was reporting for the Beach Patrol last week, has filed one more dispatch from the Hamptons, this one about the people who make up the engine that drives the playground of eastern Long Island:

headline: Open Marks the End of a Marketing Road Trip
text: The start of the United States Open guarantees two developments: the promise of live televised tennis and the end of the “Greatest Road Trip in Sports,” also known as the U.S. Open Series.

headline: New Construction Accident at the Deutsche Bank Building
text: Updated, 3:20 p.m. | A piece of construction equipment fell from the scaffolding surrounding the troubled, partly demolished Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan at 1:54 p.m. today, injuring two firefighters, according to city officials.The officials said that the injuries to the two firefighters were not life-threatening, but that one firefighter suffered a head contusion. The injured firefighters were taken to St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village. It was not clear if anyone else was injured. Maria Newman of The Times has prepared a news article on the accident.

headline: A Rare Four-Letter Day in The Times
text: Some readers have noticed that The Times, in reporting about Roger J. Stone Jr. and accusations that he made a threatening phone call to Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s father, included an unexpurgated transcript of the call in print, as well as audio.

headline: Looking Beyond Rio For Christmas in Brazil
text: I am going to be in Brazil for Christmas and New Year’s with a friend. Can you suggest a nice area to spend four to seven days at Christmas before returning to Rio for New Year’s, or would you recommend staying in Rio?

headline: Qing Dynasty Treasures
text: Images from "Excellence and Elegance: Decorative Arts of the Eighteenth-Century Qing Court" at the Metropolitan Museum.

headline: A Note on Ceiling Height
text: Dear Readers:

headline: Edwards Keeps Trying Out Change Theme
text: Democratic candidate John Edwards jump-started his “One America’’ campaign with a bus-tour in New Hampshire today, a four-day rollout that began with a speech replete with the populist, anti-establishment themes he’s been pounding home elsewhere on the stump and at recent debates.

headline: The Boys From Brazil
text: Brazil will bring a potent, star-studded lineup that includes Ronaldinho and Kaká to the United States in September for its games against the United States in Chicago on Sunday, Sept. 9, and against Mexico in Foxborough, Mass., on Wednesday, Sept. 12. Both games fall on FIFA international “fixture” days.

headline: Quick Bits: The Late Edition
text: Jonathan Schwartz, chief executive of Sun Microsystems, says on his blog that he is changing the company’s ticker symbol from SUNW to JAVA, because, well, Java is everywhere. (By the way, he explains that SUNW stood for Stanford University Network Workstation.) The funny part is the reaction down in the comments section. For instance: “Jonathan, this is one more indication the board needs to look for someone with REAL ideas to lead a once great company. You’re all driving wonderful technology innovative and real engineers designed in the ground. You’re just a marketing weenie.” Laugh, but name another chief executive who would let that go up. (Jonathan Schwartz’s Weblog)

headline:
‘A Well-Turned Phrase in a Percy Novel
Could Take Out an Entire Subdivision’
text: It’s too early to know what to make of the new Southern magazine Garden & Gun.

headline: Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s Slide
text: Even for Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, who has experienced more than one last stand during his time atop Iraq’s shaky coalition government, the past few days must have been grueling. Several prominent senators and presidential candidates are calling for his ouster, President Bush and his lieutenants are voicing frustrations and a National Intelligence Estimate on Iraq’s progress, released today, expressed deep doubts that he can overcome sectarian differences.

headline: Learning to Stop Worrying and Love Surveillance
text: On Sept. 18, the United States will be waking up to life without the Pentagon’s Talon program, a database set up to track terrorism threats but later expanded to include nonviolent protests.

headline: Department of Corrections: YouTube Analysis Edition
text: One of the easiest, yet most mortifying, mistakes to make in finance is to misplace a decimal point. It seems Morgan Stanley‘s Mary Meeker did just that in writing about YouTube‘s new advertising model.

headline: Blogtalk: Closing Bookstores, Congestion Pricing, Sweet Smells, a Stolen Laptop and More
text: What we’re reading on other blogs…

headline: Movie Minutes: 'The Nanny Diaries'
text: Stephen Holden reviews "The Nanny Diaries," a film about being a nanny on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Champ'
text: Stephen Holden reviews "Resurrecting the Champ," starring Samuel L. Jackson and Josh Hartnett.

headline: Sacco and Vanzetti, 80 Years Later
text: Throughout the 1920s, huge workers’ rallies were held in Union Square to demand the release of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, the two Italian-American anarchists who had been arrested for murder in 1920. As night fell on Aug. 23, 1927 — 80 years ago today — a rally gathered in the square. Around midnight, a sign went up: “Sacco Murdered.” A short while later, another sign: “Vanzetti Murdered.”

headline: Looking at the ‘Extraordinary’ Steam-Blast Pipe
text: Con Edison officials said that they still cannot tell what caused a steam pipe to explode under Lexington Avenue last month, leaving one person dead and two seriously injured. But they showed pieces of the ruptured pipe to reporters at the company’s sprawling plant in Astoria, Queens, this afternoon.Sections of the pipe, including one peeled open like a tin can, were laid out in an aluminum shed. Outside, rust-colored pieces of various other pipes and valves found in the crater were arrayed on the ground.

headline: Videos for Brighter Days!
text: The efforts by ad agencies to whip up online-video trends are almost heartbreakingly dumb. But it’s wrong to weep for all of them.

headline: F.D.A. Takes Aim at Sunscreen Labels
text: The Food and Drug Administration today addressed a concern long thought to be on its agenda: sunscreen labeling.

headline: Nature's Freaks and Celebrities
text: Images from Times Square Ripley’s Believe It or Not! Odditorium.

headline: Los Angeles’s Other Soccer Team
text: Not everyone in Los Angeles is embracing David Beckham. The L.A. Galaxy midfielder has catapulted the Major League Soccer team to the top of the soccer world’s consciousness. But the team, which has two M.L.S. titles in 11 years, is not the only team in the city. Chivas USA, founded in 2004, attempts to draw on a much deeper history and, the team hoped, a more loyal and far-reaching fan base.

headline: Sony Defeats Truman
text: This just in from video-game reporting headquarters: Sony may be a consumer electronics giant, but its public relations folks aren’t so powerful when it comes to prognostication.

headline: Warner: Bring Some Troops Home
text: Senator John Warner, veteran of wars past and longtime Republican of Virginia, today called on President Bush to issue a strong signal to the Iraqi government by withdrawing a small contingent of American troops home around Christmastime.

headline: A Sign of Desperation
text: Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming

headline: ‘You Won’t Remember This’
text: “You Won’t Remember This” is a portrait of my son, Buster, from his first week until he was a few years old.

headline: Vows: Melanie and William
text: Being around William Lanzana's love for food and family helped to soften Melanie Miller's idea that marriage is an antiquated institution.

headline: Changes to Yahoo Video on the Way
text: Yahoo’s new chief executive, Jerry Yang, is hunkered down in the midst of a 100-day strategic review of the company (Kara Swisher of All Things Digital tells us we’re on Day 37) and isn’t talking to the press. In fact, most of Yahoo’s top brass isn’t talking either.

headline: Safe Haven
text: Baghdad Bureau Chief James Glanz discusses how the number of displaced Iraqis has skyrocketed in recent months.

headline: Safe Haven
text: Baghdad Bureau Chief James Glanz discusses how the number of displaced Iraqis has skyrocketed in recent months.

headline: Battle of the Ages. Will Youth Be Served Again?
text: The second NH Chess Tournament, which pits a group of “rising stars” against some “experienced” (a.k.a. grizzled) veterans, is under way in the Netherlands. After two rounds, the youngsters lead by one point. The games and profiles of the players can be found at the tournament’s Web site.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Lottery Numbers
In His Own Words
text: In an address yesterday in Hanover, N.H., John Edwards issued a thinly veiled criticism of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, an opponent for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2008, without mentioning her by name. Mr. Edwards has recently been challenging Mrs. Clinton to stop taking campaign donations from lobbyists, a challenge she has rebuffed, saying she will not be influenced by lobbyists or special interest groups. The following is an excerpt of Mr. Edwards’s remarks.

headline: As Phillies Get Hurt, Quest for Playoffs Takes Hit, Too
text: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23  Fabio Castro, the latest emergency pitcher for the Philadelphia Phillies, dropped a bunt in the third inning Thursday and sprinted to first base, as if running faster would save him a trip back to the Phillies’ top farm team in Ottawa.

headline: A Bit of Paradise on Island No. 999
text: CINDY LOZO walked through her new stone and cedar-shake house and onto a sun porch filled with white wicker, blue paisley cushions and floor-to-ceiling windows. “This is the view that made me agree to live on an island,” she said. Outside, antique mahogany Lyman boats cruised along the sparkling deep-blue expanse of the St. Lawrence River. Upstream, a stone structure resembling the biggest drip sand castle ever constructed stood against the horizon. And rising from the water in several directions were chunks of land sprouting beech, pine or poplar trees — a half-dozen of the famous Thousand Islands.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Marbury Clarifies Remarks on Vick
text: Knicks guard Stephon Marbury, who recently created a stir by appearing to defend dogfighting, issued a statement yesterday to clarify his position. Marbury said he did not condone the illegal sport, but was trying to make a larger point when he expressed support for Michael Vick, the Atlanta Falcons quarterback who has pleaded guilty to dogfighting charges.

headline: The Gritty City
text: More vérité than cinema, the documentary “Skid Row” is so raw that it’s virtually unwatchable. Unwisely choosing a recognizable hip-hop artist (Pras Michel of the Fugees) as their avatar, the directors, Niva Dorell, Marshall Tyler and Ross Clarke, have all but erased the line between social investigation and celebrity stunt.

headline: Charlie Parker, Uptown and Down
text: In “Bird Alone,” one of the terse and symbolically charged songs Abbey Lincoln chose to revisit on her recent album “Abbey Sings Abbey” (Verve), there are no specific references to Charlie Parker. But any jazz fan would recognize this alto saxophonist and bebop progenitor, whose sobriquet was Bird (or Yardbird), in Ms. Lincoln’s lyrics. The airborne creature of the title is untouchable and inscrutable, “Sending mournful soulful sounds/Soaring over troubled grounds.” After gliding high and swinging low, it vanishes, leaving only a song.

headline: Gunman Who Shot Wallace Is to Be Freed
text: Arthur Bremer, the gunman who tried to kill Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama as he campaigned for the Democratic presidential nomination in 1972, will be released from prison this year, a Maryland prison official said yesterday.

headline: Death Toll Climbs in Flood-Stricken Midwest
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 23 — The death toll from several days of storms climbed to 12 as heavy rain and flooding that have covered a large part of the Midwest continued Thursday.

headline: Beautifying the World With Amazon Ingredients
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  Brazilians’ longtime devotion to the body beautiful  whether it be spending fortunes on perfumes and cosmetics, slimming down to fit into minuscule swimsuits or revealing body waxing  is paying off.

headline: Immigration Officials Say Raids Will Not Halt for 2010 Census
text: In contrast to the months before and after the 2000 census was conducted, raids on illegal immigrants will not be suspended during the population count in 2010, federal officials say.

headline: Of Fliers, Fines and the Limits of Patience
text: The last straw for Simcha Felder came months ago. Actually, it was more like the last scrap of paper. His mother had been given a $100 sanitation summons for some advertisement fliers that lay messily on the sidewalk in front of her house in Borough Park, Brooklyn.

headline: Art Listings
text: ART

headline: Kendall Trade May Create Hole in Line
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 23 — The Jets took a hard line and refused to budge, trading their disgruntled offensive lineman Pete Kendall to the Washington Redskins on Thursday for a 2008 or 2009 draft pick rather than give him the $1 million raise he was seeking.

headline: A Sea of Sails
text: WHO Cindy Keesling, 60, shown with her husband, Phil Keesling, 62, who is a real estate developer in Paradise Valley, Ariz. WHERE Coronado, Calif. WHAT 5-bedroom house

headline: Ruling Paves Way for Noriega to Be Sent to France
text: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 24 — A federal judge in Miami paved the way Friday for Manuel Antonio Noriega, the former Panamanian leader ousted by the American military in 1989, to face money laundering charges in France once his prison term in the United States ends next month.

headline: Two Trainers of Home Aides Admit Fraud in Certification
text: ALBANY, Aug. 23  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced guilty pleas on Thursday from the former operators of two schools for home health aides who sold state certifications to hundreds of people who never received proper training.

headline: Hamas Breaks Up Fatah Protest in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 — Members of the Hamas Executive Force police militia broke up a protest of the rival Fatah faction in Gaza City today, firing into the air and briefly detaining several journalists who were trying to document the events, according to news media reports.

headline: Russia: Progress in Journalist’s Killing
text: Aleksandr I. Bastrykin, chief of the federal prosecution service’s investigations committee, says in an article being published today in Rossiyskaya Gazeta, an official Russian newspaper, that the killing of Anna Politkovskaya, the journalist who was fatally shot in Moscow last year, might soon be solved, according to a posting on the newspaper’s Web site. Ms. Politkovskaya, above, a correspondent for the independent Russian newspaper Novaya Gazeta, was a bitter critic of President Vladimir V. Putin and the wars in Chechnya. Her colleagues and the authorities have said she was murdered in a contract killing.

headline: United Air Might Sell Maintenance Unit
text: United Airlines said yesterday that it might sell all or part of its maintenance operations to outside investors to raise cash to modernize and expand the unit.

headline: With a 27-Run Cushion, a Save Is in the Books
text: ARLINGTON, Tex., Aug. 23 — A day later, Wes Littleton was still smiling over the good-natured barbs he heard after he was called to the mound to clean up the Texas Rangers’ record victory against the Baltimore Orioles on Wednesday night.

headline: The Passion Is Plentiful, and So Is the Angst
text: The turbulent reality of young love is something most of us would probably prefer not to remember too clearly. It’s easier to graze vicariously on movie fantasies of shapely young bodies swooning in rapturous lip-locks than to dwell on uncomfortable memories of needy, unformed adults in erotic collision.

headline: Report Offers Grim View of Iraqi Leaders
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 — A stark assessment released Thursday by the nation’s intelligence agencies depicts a paralyzed Iraqi government unable to take advantage of the security gains achieved by the thousands of extra American troops dispatched to the country this year.

headline: Fooled by Winds of Reform
text: ON many early mornings in Tehran, my uncle Ali would bang on our door to deliver large heaps of mammoth mushrooms from the mountain of Shemiran. Every summer and early autumn when I saw thunderstorms gathering in the sky, I knew we would have giant bunches of wild, tasty mushrooms the following day. My uncle believed that the storms pushed the mushrooms up from beneath the mountain’s numerous stones. Mushroom hunters like Ali would wake up early the next morning to go after those fresh, juicy mushrooms and cut off their heads.

headline: Appeals Court Backs Whole Foods Deal
text: A federal appeals court has rejected the attempt by regulators to block Whole Foods Market’s $565 million takeover of the rival Wild Oats Markets.

headline: The Art of Control in a Manchu Box
text: Life is a chancy deal. Wars happen; economies fail; a shadow turns up on the X-ray. No wonder we spend so much energy trying to control what’s around us.

headline: U.S. Forces Battle Iraqi Shiite Militia
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 24  American forces fought Shiite militia members in a poor area in northwest Baghdad early this morning, killing at least eight Iraqis, the American military said.

headline: Mine Safety Leader Loses Some Respect for Actions in Utah
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 23 — It was a telling moment one day last week in what had become a regular sideshow at the foot of a mountain here, where six coal miners were swallowed whole.

headline: Sabbatini Shoots a 63 for a One-Shot Lead
text: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 23  After two years of complex trials and elaborate mock-ups by the PGA Tour, the first real-life leader of a FedEx Cup playoff event lives for the sweet, simple feel of head-to-head competition.

headline: U.S. Bomb Kills 3 British Soldiers in Afghanistan
text: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan, Aug. 24 — Three British soldiers died in southern Afghanistan on Thursday in an apparent friendly fire incident involving a bomb dropped by an American plane, British officials announced today.

headline: Guardsman Placed on Leave Over Comments on Web Site
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23  The personal assistant of the top general in the California National Guard has been placed on leave after revelations that the aide’s personal Web site contained derogatory statements about women, jokes about black Jamaicans as “cannibals,” and violent references.

headline: Footnotes
text: Music at the Anthology (MATA), the new-music organization founded by the composers Philip Glass, Eleanor Sandresky and Lisa Bielawa, will hold a 10th-anniversary benefit concert on Sept. 25 at the Paula Cooper Gallery, 521 West 21st Street. For information: matafestival.org or (212) 563-5124. ...Vanessa Redgrave; her sister, Lynn Redgrave; and their brother, Corin Redgrave, will each receive a Lifetime Achievement Award at the 10th Annual Savannah Film Festival, which runs from Oct. 27 to Nov. 3 in Savannah, Ga. Information: scad.edu/filmfest/about.cfm.

headline: Foreclosure and Taxes
text: To forgive is divine, except when the thing being forgiven is debt. Then, it’s taxable.

headline: Cellphone Records Help to Clear a Murder Suspect
text: A man was cleared of murder charges yesterday after offering cellular telephone records as alibi evidence.

headline: Firefighters Bid One of Their Own Farewell
text: The firefighters in crisp blue uniforms stood in formation for the second successive day, for the second funeral of a fallen comrade, a day after two more of their colleagues were injured at the same site where these two had perished.

headline: In Primary, Tech’s Home Is a Magnet
text: SAN FRANCISCO — For presidential candidates campaigning in Iowa, the place to be is the state fair. Diners are popular in New Hampshire. But for those visiting Silicon Valley, it’s the Googleplex.

headline: For Army Coach, Winning Will Bring Trust
text: WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 21 — Football fans of a certain age may fondly remember a time when the Army football team was one of the best in the land. Younger fans may shudder at the thought that the modern Black Knights have gone through 10 consecutive losing seasons and five straight losses to Navy.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Aug. 15 about the names on the seating list for the funeral of Brooke Astor, the Park Avenue socialite and philanthropist, referred incorrectly to the hymns that Mrs. Astor wanted sung at the service. They came from the hymnal, not from the 1928 version of the Book of Common Prayer, of the Episcopal Church, to which Mrs. Astor belonged. The article also misstated at one point part of the name of a New York City arts group Mrs. Astor supported. It is the Municipal Art Society, not Arts.

headline: China: Bishop Arrested
text: Bishop Jia Zhiguo, the underground Roman Catholic bishop of the Zheng Ding Diocese in Hebei Province, was arrested, according to the Cardinal Kung Foundation, a group in Stamford, Conn., that promotes religious freedom for Catholics in China. It was the 11th time he has been arrested since the beginning of 2004; he previously served 20 years in prison. Underground and state-sanctioned Catholic churches operate separately in China, with underground churches as targets of repression that varies from province to province.

headline: Pipe Bears Graphic Scars From Steam Blast
text: One glance at the ruptured steam pipe that ran under Lexington Avenue leaves no doubt how it produced the geyser of steam and muddy water that shut down a section of Midtown for days and left one person dead and two seriously injured.

headline: F.D.A. Plans New Labeling for Sunscreen
text: The Food and Drug Administration proposed sweeping new rules for sunscreens yesterday to give consumers more detailed information about the level of protection they provide against sun damage.

headline: Manhattan: Tenants’ Lawsuit Dismissed
text: A State Supreme Court judge yesterday dismissed a lawsuit in which a group of tenants claimed that the owners of a housing complex, Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, violated rent stabilization laws by deregulating high-end apartments while continuing to collect tax benefits under the rent laws. Justice Richard B. Lowe III ruled that the owner had not violated the law and that the deregulation was allowed. Eric B. Levine, a lawyer for the tenants, said that his clients had not made a final decision but that he suspected they would appeal. Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village make up the city’s largest apartment complex, with 110 buildings and more than 20,000 residents.

headline: Portrait of President, Craving Power, Enthralls France
text: PARIS, Aug. 23 — The slim volume officially will be published only on Friday, but it is already the sensation of this fall’s literary season in Paris: the drama of Nicolas Sarkozy’s pursuit of the presidency through the eyes of Yasmina Reza, France’s most celebrated playwright.

headline: Inquiry Urges End to Charges Against Marine
text: A military investigator has recommended dismissing all charges against a Marine Corps infantryman accused of killing Iraqi civilians, including women and children, in a house-to-house raid in Haditha in late 2005.

headline: Abu Dhabi: Deal for a Canadian Oil Producer
text: Abu Dhabi National Energy, a state-controlled United Arab Emirates investor in oil and power assets, agreed to buy the Canadian unit of Pioneer Natural Resources for $540 million. Production at the Canadian unit of Pioneer, based in Irving, Tex., is more than 10,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day and will help Abu Dhabi National come closer to its goal of producing 100,000 barrels a day.

headline: In Queens, Books and More (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: A Winner at Edinburgh

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: A New Home With a Stepford Vibe
text: A surreal nightmare of gleaming surfaces and razor-sharp edges, “The Bothersome Man” unfolds in a sterile city where nothing is quite as it seems.

headline: Police Voice Concerns Over a Directive on Immigrants
text: NEWARK, Aug. 23 — One local police chief called it a publicity stunt. In a sheriff’s office, the directive was passed out at roll call, by officials anxious to quickly comply. And another chief — one of many who spoke on the condition he not be named for fear of ruffling the feathers of the state’s top law enforcement officer — said it seemed like a recipe for racial profiling.

headline: Trouble at Sea
text: “Deep Water,” a fascinating documentary about the first single-handed around-the-world sailing race, begins like a Boy’s Own adventure tale but ends up more akin to tragedy.

headline: Chile: Economy Grew 6.1% in Second Quarter
text: Chile’s economy expanded at the fastest pace in two years in the second quarter, bolstering expectations that the central bank will continue to raise interest rates to prevent accelerating growth and consumer demand from stoking inflation. The economy expanded 6.1 percent from a year earlier, the central bank reported on its Web site, the biggest expansion since 6.3 percent growth in the first quarter of 2005.

headline: For Those in a Month of Discontent, Weather Records Are Going the Wrong Way
text: Jersey Shore lifeguards left alone with the sea gulls and surfers. A tomato-tasting festival canceled by a hailstorm that pureed the crops. Cashmere sweaters selling fast, at $295 each, from an East Hampton boutique, to vacationers who had packed for sunshine.

headline: California: A Seismic Lull for Los Angeles
text: Los Angeles appears to be in a centuries-long seismic lull between periods of powerful earthquake activity, while communities inland, around the Mojave Desert, could be at higher risk of big quakes, according to a new study. Examining 12,000 years of geological records, the researchers, led by scientists at the University of Southern California, found several periods of prolonged strong earthquake activity in the area now covered by the city, with the most recent one lasting 4,000 years and ending around 1,000 years ago. The calmer intervals appear to last 1,500 to 2,000 years, they said. The authors said the seesawing pattern of risk between the city and the desert could be related to slowdowns of plate motion along the San Andreas Fault, which could increase activity in a fault network under the desert.

headline: The Devil Wears Down Her Nanny
text: “The Nanny Diaries,” a scattershot screen adaptation of Emma McLaughlin and Nicola Kraus’s 2002 satirical beach read, has one unassailable asset. As this exposé of the rich and miserable on the Upper East Side wobbles along uncertainly, it rests on the tense, squared shoulders of Laura Linney. Ms. Linney defies a screenplay that paints her character, Mrs. X, a Park Avenue socialite, as a monstrous control freak. She is a smart, flexible actress who invests her role, a composite of former employers of the novel’s authors, with enough humanity to arouse some pity.

headline: Pakistan Court Lets Exile Back to Run Again
text: This article is by Carlotta Gall, Salman Masood and Helene Cooper.

headline: Theater Listings
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: Mine Owner Has History of Run-Ins on Work Issues
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 23 — If Robert E. Murray accepts a Senate subcommittee’s invitation to testify next month about what went wrong at the Crandall Canyon Mine, he is likely to be questioned about, among other things, adopting a new and riskier mining plan when his company took over the operation last year.

headline: Correction
text: An editorial yesterday about the Central Intelligence Agency incorrectly cited the changing of the name of the C.I.A. headquarters building as a sign of shifting priorities by its former director, George Tenet, after President Bush assumed office in 2001. The building was renamed in 1999 by an act of Congress to honor George H.W. Bush, the current president’s father.

headline: Chasin’ the Bird: A Field Guide to Charlie Parker
text: Events

headline: Who Should Pay for Medical Mistakes? (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Butch van Breda Kolff, 84, Fiery Coach, Dies
text: Butch van Breda Kolff, a happy-go-lucky nonconformist who from 1951 through 1994 coached more than 1,300 college, professional and high school basketball games, died Wednesday in Spokane, Wash. He was 84 and had lived in Spokane for the last year.

headline: Paddling Down East From Inn to Inn
text: THE tides and wind were against us and the sun was in our eyes as we paddled into the harbor at Rockland, Me. My friend Kira and I emerged from the marina in our life jackets and spray skirts, lugging paddles, nautical charts and clothing across the street to the Old Granite Inn, our shoulders sore and heads aching from two hours of paddling in the heat.

headline: Analysts Cut Expectations for Economic Growth
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  The financial turmoil that began with the seemingly narrow meltdown in subprime mortgages is now forcing both policy makers and Wall Street analysts to scale back their expectations for growth in the overall economy.

headline: Don’t Get Rid of Earmarks
text: Washington

headline: A Trust Fund for Water (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: States Begin Action on Subprime Lending
text: Gov. Michael F. Easley of North Carolina signed legislation last week that would limit the ability of mortgage brokers to charge customers above-market rates and prepayment penalties and would protect subprime borrowers from highly risky adjustable-rate mortgages.

headline: Ex-Principal Files Appeal in Student Seduction Case
text: The former principal of a Montessori school in Manhattan has appealed her conviction for having sex with an under-age student, accusing prosecutors of concealing promises to a witness in exchange for his cooperation.

headline: The Bad News First
text: Boston

headline: A Real Plan for Iraq (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Outward Bound, Looking In
text: THE nine men who climbed to the summit of the Colorado mountain were combat veterans who had fought in Iraq, Afghanistan and Vietnam.

headline: Hebrew Charter School Spurs Dispute in Florida
text: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Aug. 23 — The new public school at 2620 Hollywood Boulevard stands out despite its plain gray facade. Called the Ben Gamla Charter School, it is run by an Orthodox rabbi, serves kosher lunches and concentrates on teaching Hebrew.

headline: Remembering an Acclaimed Soprano
text: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, the Metropolitan Opera and New York City Opera will present a tribute to Beverly Sills on Sept. 16 at 5 p.m. at the Metropolitan Opera. The public event, dedicated to Ms. Sills, left, who died on July 2 at 78, will include scheduled performances by Natalie Dessay, Anna Netrebko and Nathan Gunn, winner of the first annual Beverly Sills Award. The Met’s music director, James Levine, will play the piano. Among those expected to speak are Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Barbara Walters, Plácido Domingo, Henry Kissinger, Julius Rudel and Stanley Sills, Ms. Sills’s brother. Tickets will be free (limited to two tper person) and available at the Metropolitan Opera box office, first come first served, starting Sept. 16. The program will be broadcast live on Metropolitan Opera Radio on Sirius, the 24-hour satellite radio channel, and streamed live via RealNetworks at metopera.org.

headline: Pratfalls in Every Language
text: With “Mr. Bean’s Holiday,” the British comedian Rowan Atkinson continues a tradition that in the right hands — Buster Keaton, Jacques Tati, even Jerry Lewis in “The Bellboy” — never gets stale: comic pantomime. Or, in this case, near-pantomime, since Mr. Atkinson, in a sequel 10 years after “Bean,” speaks, but only rarely. He doesn’t have to. His googly eyes, gangly physique and elastic countenance are just fine for delivering the goods.

headline: A Sinking Anchor
text: “Anchorwoman,” Fox’s new reality series following a ratings-strapped small-town television affiliate after it hires a former swimsuit model with no journalism experience to read the news, drew just 2.7 million viewers Wednesday in its one-hour debut at 8 p.m., Nielsen estimated. Fox finished fourth for the night, just behind ABC. CBS led over all in total viewers, as its 8 p.m. game show, “Power of 10,” delivered the night’s largest audience (8.7 million). NBC, which ranked second in total viewers, earned top ratings among adults 18 to 49, getting a boost at 9 from “Last Comic Standing,” which earned its best numbers in that demographic for the summer and a total audience of 7.3 million. CBS’s “Criminal Minds” rerun finished first at 9 (8.2 million), as did a repeat of its “CSI: NY” at 10 (8 million). On Sunday, “Ice Road Truckers” had the best ratings on cable television for the night. Its season finale set a record for the History Channel, as an audience of 4.8 million viewers tuned in at 10.

headline: Mormons Who Massacre
text: The maudlin, grotesque western “September Dawn,” about the massacre on Sept. 11, 1857, of about 120 settlers by Mormons (and their Paiute Indian mercenaries), apes “Schindler’s List” in hopes of creating a Christian Holocaust picture.

headline: Commercial Paper Market Shrinks the Most in Seven Years
text: The size of the commercial paper market, a crucial source of short-term financing for businesses, decreased 4.2 percent last week, the biggest drop in at least seven years, as investors fled asset-backed debt and opted for the safety of Treasuries.

headline: Virginia: Court to Hear Case of Man Held as Enemy Combatant
text: The full federal appeals court in Richmond will hear the case of Ali al-Marri, the only person on the American mainland known to be held by the military as an enemy combatant. In June, a divided three-judge panel of the court, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, ruled that the detention of Mr. Marri, a citizen of Qatar, violated the Constitution. The full court’s order, issued Wednesday, said the court would hear arguments in October.

headline: A Rude Mechanical’s Dream
text: A jaunty assortment of parlor magician’s tricks ornament the fast and funny “Midsummer Night’s Dream” that opened last night at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. There are traditional acts of legerdemain with bright scarves, floating balls and luminous flowers. But the real magic happens when the bad actors take over.

headline: Exit Rove (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Grace Paley, Writer and Activist, Dies at 84
text: Grace Paley, the celebrated writer and social activist whose short stories explored in precise, pungent and tragicomic style the struggles of ordinary women muddling through everyday lives, died on Wednesday at her home in Thetford Hill, Vt. She was 84 and also had an apartment in Manhattan.

headline: Odd Jobs Help College Teams Stay Afloat
text: One Sunday morning every fall, members of the Penn State fencing team spend hours scraping nacho cheese, chewing tobacco, peanut shells and cigarette butts off the floor of the university’s 107,000-seat football stadium.

headline: 4 Words Remind Him How to Play the Game
text: Before Curtis Granderson slips on his Detroit Tigers cap, he reads the words written in black ink under the brim. He wrote “Don’t Think. Have Fun” on his cap last year, as a reminder to play baseball loosely and not scrutinize every situation. He wrote it there again this year.

headline: Camp Ends for Giants, but Questions About Strahan Don’t
text: ALBANY, Aug. 23  It felt like the start of fall, with cool air and the steady arrival of students to the State University at Albany campus. As the Giants began their final practice of training camp, with most of their cars packed and ready to roll south, a song blared near the cafeteria where they have eaten meals for most of the last month: “I’m going home,” the band Daughtry sang. “Back to the place where I belong.”

headline: Mobo Nomination for Winehouse
text: The British singer Amy Winehouse, top, received four nominations for the 12th annual Music of Black Origin (Mobo) Awards, BBC News reported yesterday. Ms. Winehouse, 23, who just canceled a string of concerts because of illness, is up for best British female, best R&B act, best video and best song. The rapper Dizzee Rascal, above, has also been nominated for four awards: best United Kingdom male, best hip-hop act, best song and best video (for “Sirens”). Mobo winners are chosen by voting on the awards show’s Web site (mobo.com).The presentation will be at the O2 arena in London on Sept. 19; it will also be broadcast live on the digital channel BBC Three.

headline: Martin Van Buren Slept Here
text: IN the waning days of summer, the drive through the verdant rolling hills of Columbia County is reason enough for a trip to Kinderhook, one of the oldest Dutch settlements in New York. Through a textured terrain of slate and granite outcroppings, open meadows, trees and wetland, the Taconic Parkway morphs from expressway to country road as it heads north. Take the Spencertown exit and follow Route 203 past cornfields, orchards, grazing cows and a golf course and through the villages of Chatham and Valatie, and Kinderhook awaits — some 130 miles from Manhattan.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A listing of American military deaths on July 13 misidentified the country in which Master Sgt. Randy J. Gillespie was killed. It was Afghanistan, not Iraq. An updated Names of the Dead appears today on Page A12.

headline: Civil Rights Division Head Resigning at Justice Dept.
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  The head of the Justice Department’s civil rights division announced Thursday that he was resigning, the latest in a long string of departures from the department in the midst of a furor over the leadership of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales.

headline: Where the Buzz Isn’t Hype
text: THE sight of a hummingbird zooming into a backyard, magically hovering midair, dipping into a flower for a sip of nectar and zipping away — all within 10 or 15 seconds — usually draws the same incredulous reaction: “Did you see that?”

headline: More Iraqis Said to Flee Since Troop Increase
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 23 — The number of Iraqis fleeing their homes has soared since the American troop increase began in February, according to data from two humanitarian groups, accelerating the partition of the country into sectarian enclaves.

headline: 3 Jazzmen, Obstinate and Wily
text: The bassist Gary Peacock, the pianist Paul Bley and the drummer Paul Motian opened their week at Birdland on Wednesday and quickly slipped into a funny ritual of cussedness.

headline: They’ll Take the Stairs and Defy Some Gravity
text: The great impresario Florenz Ziegfeld was famous for his use of stairs. As in the films of Busby Berkeley (a onetime colleague of Ziegfeld), legions of girls, girls, girls would line the many staircases in his spectacular productions. Yet even Ziegfeld can never have had stairs as impressive as those that front the United States Custom House in Lower Manhattan: stone, 37 of them, widening as they descend.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) BEDTIME FOR BONZO (1951) It’s all Ronald Reagan all day long on Turner Classic Movies, including this dandy about a professor (Reagan, above) with a deadbeat dad who tries to disprove his future father-in-law’s theory about inherited genetic traits by teaching a chimpanzee the difference between right and wrong. Lucille Barkley plays Valerie, the professor’s fiancée and the university dean’s daughter. Diana Lynn plays Jane, the other woman seen a little too frequently in the professor’s house. The marathon begins at 6 a.m. with “Love Is on the Air” (1937) and ends at 4:30 a.m. tomorrow with “Prisoner of War” (1954).

headline: Correction: Man Flees Police Station via Window
text: A man being questioned in a homicide escaped from police custody yesterday afternoon by jumping from a third-floor window at a Queens police station onto the roof of a lower building, the police said.

headline: Foreclosures Force Britons to Ponder Shift to Fixed Rates
text: LONDON, Aug. 22  Susan Whittaker was desperate. Four years ago, she purchased her first apartment in the town of Rochester, less than two hours east of London. But then interest rates started to rise, and the income from the small shop she ran with her partner no longer covered their adjustable-rate mortgage.

headline: Yes, Build Elegant Bridges, but Make Them Safe (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: New Home Sales Up 2.8 Percent in July
text: A rise in sales of new homes last month provided an unexpected respite from the steady stream of dismal housing market statistics lately, but economists cautioned that it was unlikely to last.

headline: Heroes and Has-Beens in Redemption City
text: “Resurrecting the Champ” is a cautionary fable that every journalistic go-getter dreaming of front-page bylines would do well to heed. Though the story is distantly based on fact, its protagonist, Erik Kernan (Josh Hartnett), is fictional. His sudden reversal of career fortune, following a brief, heady triumph, lends the movie moral traction.

headline: Prosecutors Push to Resume War Crimes Trials
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 — In an effort to revive the war crimes trials at Guantánamo, military prosecutors argued in a special appeals court on Friday that defects in their cases identified by two military judges in June can be repaired and that the prosecutions can proceed.

headline: 3 Attacks in Tense Caucasus Kill 2 Policemen and Soldier
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 23 — Gunmen in the volatile Caucasus region ambushed a police convoy on Thursday in the mountains of Dagestan, killing two officers. There were two other attacks in Ingushetia that left a Russian soldier dead. A total of at least 16 police officers and soldiers were wounded, the authorities said.

headline: Correction
text: An article and headline on July 23 about a new Israeli third-grade textbook referred imprecisely to the way it described the 1948-49 war with Arab countries that followed Israel’s declaration of independence. The textbook said that Arabs view the war as a catastrophe; it did not say that the war was a catastrophe for the Arab population or that the establishment of Israel was a catastrophe for the Palestinians. The Times, which did not have a copy of the textbook when the article was published, attributed the descriptions of what the book said to the Israeli Education Ministry. The text, translated from the Hebrew, says in a passage about the war: “Arabs call this war the Nakba” (which means catastrophe) “whereas the Jewish people call it the War of Independence.” This correction was delayed to get a copy of the book. (Go to Article)

headline: Sorrowful Tale at Trial of Hussein Aides Linked to 1991 Crackdown
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 23  One of Saddam Hussein’s most senior henchmen ordered two brothers to be thrown to their deaths from a helicopter after concrete blocks were tied to their feet, the men’s mother told a court in Baghdad on Thursday.

headline: Queens: Man Guilty of Stealing $6 Million
text: A Long Island man who posed as a lawyer was convicted yesterday in State Supreme Court of stealing $6 million and practicing law without a license, prosecutors said. The man, Mohammed Rafikian, 51, of Westbury, was convicted of first-degree grand larceny, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Rafikian, chairman and chief executive of First Investors Capital Corporation in Astoria, ran up millions in losses by day-trading stocks, and in order to cover the losses, posed as a lawyer and a registered investment adviser. Mr. Brown said that between 2000 and 2005, Mr. Rafikian stole $6 million from eight people after promising to invest their money. Mr. Rafikian, who defended himself, faces up to 130 years in prison when he is sentenced next month.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Monday about the impact of the “High School Musical” movies on the fortunes of the Disney Channel referred imprecisely to the channel’s current viewership among children 6 to 11 and 9 to 14. It is the highest-rated basic-cable channel for those age groups in prime time, not overall.

headline: Lohan Is Charged With Misdemeanors
text: Prosecutors in Los Angeles filed seven misdemeanor counts stemming from two drunken-driving arrests against Lindsay Lohan, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The district attorney charged Ms. Lohan, 21, with two counts each of driving under the influence, driving with a blood-alcohol level above .08 percent and being under the influence of cocaine, and one count of reckless driving. The police found cocaine on Ms. Lohan during the arrests on May 26 in Beverly Hills and on July 24 in Santa Monica. In each incident, the amounts tested were below the .05 grams required for felony charges, according to the district attorney’s office.

headline: Chinese Bank Has $9 Billion in Subprime-Backed Securities
text: The Bank of China, the nation’s second-largest commercial bank, said yesterday that it held almost $9.7 billion of securities backed by American subprime loans, the most of any Asian company.

headline: Smithfield Foods Net Soars, but Hormel Profit Tumbles
text: Smithfield Foods, the world’s biggest hog and turkey producer, reported yesterday that quarterly net income doubled on rising beef and pork sales. Hormel Foods said its profit fell on higher costs to make Spam meat products and bacon bits.

headline: Rise in Insider-Trading Cases Shows the Perils of Pillow Talk
text: As federal regulators have pursued insider trading cases this year, one of the oddities they have spotted is an increase in cases involving husbands and wives.

headline: The Padres Prevail After the Closers Leave Openings
text: Between them, Billy Wagner and Trevor Hoffman have 867 saves. Either could have added to his total last night, but neither did. Each blew a one-run lead in the ninth inning, escalating the drama in an already gripping game, before Adrian Gonzalez propelled the Padres to a 9-8 victory by hitting a bases-empty home run against Aaron Heilman in the 10th inning.

headline: White House Shell Game
text: The Bush administration’s obsession with secrecy took another absurd turn this week. The administration is claiming that the White House Office of Administration is not covered by the Freedom of Information Act, even though there are some compelling reasons to think it is. Like the fact that the office has its own FOIA officer. And it responded to 65 FOIA requests last year. And the White House’s own Web site, as of yesterday, insisted the office is covered by FOIA.

headline: Mets Extending Martínez’s Stay in Florida, for Now
