text: Pedro Martínez has spent most of the last eight months in Port St. Lucie, Fla., and he is itching to leave. That day will now come a little later. The Mets announced yesterday that Martínez would make his next rehabilitation start Monday for Class A St. Lucie in Jupiter, Fla.

headline: Italian Director Is Mugged in Rome
text: Giuseppe Tornatore, the director of “Cinema Paradiso” and other films, was mugged while taking a walk Tuesday evening in central Rome, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Mr. Tornatore was taken to a hospital after two young men attacked him, the newspaper Corriere della Sera quoted the director as saying, and suffered head trauma as well as several minor injuries. He was strolling after leaving his office when the two men asked him for directions, the newspaper said; while one thanked the filmmaker for the help, the other hit him on the head from behind. The two men made off with Mr. Tornatore’s wallet, mobile phone and watch, the paper reported.

headline: Adventures in Real Estate
text: For their directorial debut, Armen Kaprelian and Kent Llewellyn, former producers of HGTV’s reality show “House Hunters,” employ a Christopher Guest-style pseudo-documentary approach. As in Mr. Guest’s films, much of the dialogue is improvised (here with wildly mixed results), and no matter how ridiculous the characters come off, they’re more than just punch lines. In fact, despite their quirks, the three real estate agents and their clients — three couples in search of a dream home — featured in “Closing Escrow” are improbably endearing.

headline: Home Depot Said to Cut Price to Try to Save Sale of Unit
text: Home Depot was scrambling last night to save the sale of its wholesale unit to a consortium of private equity firms, lowering its asking price by about $1.2 billion from the original $10.3 billion it agreed upon, people involved in the talks said.

headline: Murder Spun From a Famous Accident
text: The 10th anniversary of the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, is not the sort of occasion that American television networks let go to waste. TLC’s “Diana: Last Days of a Princess” and CNN’s “Growing Up Diana” have already graced our screens this month. Still to come are BBC America’s “Diana: In the Name of Love” and Starz’s presentation of “Diana: The Witnesses in the Tunnel,” minus the shots of the princess inside her wrecked car that got Channel 4 in trouble when it broadcast the documentary in Britain in June.

headline: Tea Is Served, With Extra Rococo and a Hint of Revolution
text: The tea table sat unused for decades in a dining room, just one of a number of pieces of traditional furniture in an old family house near Philadelphia. How it came to be featured in a forthcoming Americana sale at Christie’s, estimated to sell for $2 million to $3 million, is a tale in itself.

headline: Of Fliers, Fines and the Limits of Patience
text: The last straw for Simcha Felder came months ago. Actually, it was more like the last scrap of paper. His mother had been given a $100 sanitation summons for some advertisement fliers that lay messily on the sidewalk in front of her house in Borough Park, Brooklyn.

headline: Butch van Breda Kolff, Basketball Coach, Is Dead
text: Butch van Breda Kolff, a happy-go-lucky nonconformist who from 1951 through 1994 coached more than 1,300 college, professional and high school basketball games, died Wednesday in Spokane. He was 84.

headline: Rival Drivers’ Groups Disagree on Likelihood of Taxi Strike
text: In competing Manhattan press conferences yesterday afternoon, rival advocacy groups said that (1) there could be a citywide taxi strike in September, and (2) there would not be a strike.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Aid Groups Urge U.S. to Revise Plan to Screen Their Workers
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  A Bush administration proposal to screen foreign aid workers and recipients for possible ties to terrorists has drawn criticism from private and religious aid groups, but there were indications that it might be revised before being adopted, aid organizations and administration officials said Thursday.

headline: Firm Hired to Monitor Gambling on Open
text: After a sports summer rocked by a gambling scandal involving the former N.B.A. referee Tim Donaghy and a betting investigation involving a match played by the fourth-ranked men’s tennis player Nikolay Davydenko, the United States Tennis Association has hired a consulting firm to detect and monitor potential gambling activity at the United States Open.

headline: O, Believers, Prepare to Be Amazed!
text: Before you leave even the first gallery in the Times Square Ripley’s Believe It or Not! Odditorium, which opened on West 42nd Street in June, you have already seen a six-legged cow, a legless acrobat, a car made of wood, the world’s ugliest woman and an albino giraffe. Look up: A bulbous replica of a 1,400-pound man hangs above the main floor, held aloft presumably just as the man himself was when a forklift heaved his body out of his home after he died in 1991.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,701 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Senate Panel Sets Hearing on Coal Mine
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 — A Senate subcommittee that oversees labor questions said Thursday that it would hold a hearing on the Crandall Canyon Mine collapse in Utah.

headline: Romney to Pitch a State-by-State Health Insurance Plan
text: Mitt Romney, an architect of Massachusetts’ universal health coverage plan, is unveiling his proposal for overhauling the nation’s health care system, calling for a state-by-state approach that he says will help millions of uninsured in this country gain access to affordable medical coverage.

headline: A ‘Mini-Boston’ on a Small Slice of Coast
text: NEW Hampshire’s sliver of coastline is often overlooked when it comes to seaside New England. It doesn’t have the cachet of Cape Cod or the craggy mystique of Maine’s rocky roar. And in a state known for its mountains (and residents as taciturn as those mountains), the thought of frolicking along its 18 miles of coast doesn’t quite square with popular perceptions.

headline: Gap’s Belt-Tightening Shows Results as Earnings Climb
text: The clothing retailer Gap Inc. said yesterday that profit rose for the first time in eight quarters after the company eliminated jobs and reduced inventory.

headline: Losing Gun Contol
text: Luridly earnest and laughably immoral, “Illegal Tender” is an old genre movie with a new look. Call it Hispanixploitation.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Switzerland: Cement Maker Beats Estimates
text: The cement maker Holcim increased profit more than analysts estimated on expansion in China and India and may acquire a controlling stake in Ambuja Cements of India. Second-quarter net income more than tripled, to 2.07 billion Swiss francs ($1.72 billion), bolstered by a gain of 1.1 billion francs from the sale of a stake in its South African unit, Holcim, based in Jona, Switzerland, said. Sales rose 16 percent, to 7.27 billion francs. Holcim will offer up to $1.34 billion to gain a majority of Ambuja, based in Mumbai.

headline: Amid Tears at a Funeral, Anger at a Needless Loss
text: The stories of Joseph Graffagnino’s life that were recounted at his funeral yesterday evoked an expected variety of emotions.

headline: N.F.L. Suspends Vick After He Files Plea
text: Michael Vick, the Atlanta Falcons star quarterback, was suspended indefinitely by the N.F.L. just hours after he admitted in court papers that he funded gambling associated with a dog fighting ring and was complicit in killing dogs that underperformed

headline: A White-Collar Lawyer Who Idolizes Darrow
text: If John Lauro is not known as “The Attorney for the Damned,” as Clarence Darrow was described, it is not for want of trying.

headline: Israel: Party Seeks to Ban Cremation
text: Leaders of Shas, the ultra-Orthodox party, proposed legislation to outlaw cremation, a day after the country’s only crematory was heavily damaged in a suspected arson fire. Cremation is forbidden in Jewish religious law and is not a common practice in Israel because of associations with Holocaust ovens. The crematory had been operating quietly for two years in a village north of Tel Aviv. Shortly before the blaze, its location was published in a regional ultra-Orthodox newspaper. Yitzhak Cohen, a government minister from Shas who handles religious affairs, said the proposed bill would “put an end to those who are implementing the ‘final solution’ once again.” Yossi Beilin, the chairman of the secular Meretz Party, accused Shas of “pushing Israel toward dark days” and said he had left instructions to be cremated after his death.

headline: Russia: Bombers Grounded After Crash
text: The air force grounded its fleet of hundreds of Su-24 attack planes after one of the jets crashed during a training flight in Russia’s Far East. The pilots ejected safely and the cause of the crash was not clear, according to comments by Col. Aleksandr Drobyshevksy reported by Interfax. The Su-24 is a Soviet-era twin-engine jet that was first manufactured in the 1970s and saw action in the wars in Afghanistan and Chechnya. The crash occurred during a week in which President Vladimir V. Putin spoke of the need to modernize Russia’s civilian and military aviation sectors.

headline: A Place for Rebirth
text: This documentary by the Brooklyn filmmakers Ashley Sabin and David Redmon is set in the Upper Ninth Ward of post-Katrina New Orleans. For several months after the disaster David Cross, the owner of a home-repair business, and his wife, an American Indian known as Ms. Pearl, opened their backyard to displaced people on the condition that they find jobs and not cause trouble. Those promises were more easily made than kept.

headline: Impromptu Summit of Kings in New York
text: Yung Joc had an announcement to make: “Y’all know I got T-Pain backstage. Y’all know I got Ciara backstage. Y’all know I got my big homey — both of ’em, T. I. and T. I. P.” The occasion was the New York stop on this year’s Screamfest Tour. The place was Madison Square Garden. And no doubt Yung Joc figured that if he couldn’t be the headliner, he might as well act like the host. (What does he mean, “I”?)

headline: Campaigning Not for Your Vote but for Your Dollar
text: FIFTEEN years ago, a presidential candidate named Bill Clinton spoke often about believing in “a place called Hope.” Today, there is a presidential candidate named Ray Hopewood — but believe in him at your peril.

headline: Frank Lloyd Wright, From the Inside and Out
text: PORTLAND, Me. — Until Frank Lloyd Wright appeared on the scene at the turn of the 20th century, most American architects might design you a house but didn’t particularly care how it lived with you. Not Wright. Turning away from traditional European models of homes and their furnishings, this bold yet practical visionary developed a truly American style of architecture, creating a harmony of house and nature by attuning a dwelling to its surrounding landscape.

headline: Giants Await a Leader, but Also Need Followers
text: How playful the Eli Manning-Tiki Barber quarrel seems, relative to more vexing issues dogging the N.F.L. Compared with the Michael Vick case, it’s a food fight in the school cafeteria or one of those intramural training camp scuffles that real men like Coach Tom Coughlin believe will make their players’ pores ooze with orneriness.

headline: Majors Considering Helmets for Coaches
text: A little more than a month after a minor league first-base coach was killed by a foul ball, Major League Baseball is considering a rule change that would require all coaches to wear helmets on the field.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: LIPA Chairman Advises a ‘No’ on Offshore Windmills
text: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Aug. 23 — Soaring costs have apparently doomed an ambitious project to build what might have been the nation’s first offshore windmills, clustered in 40 huge towers near Jones Beach.

headline: Nike Puts Women Back on the Pedestal
text: Nike has never shied away from shouting into a figurative megaphone to sell its shoes and apparel or to tell us to Just Do It. Nike’s amplified voice has shouted for Michael Jordan but has fallen silent in the service of Michael Vick, who has agreed to plead guilty to dogfighting charges.

headline: Officials Won’t Delay Raids on Immigrants for Census
text: In contrast to the months before and after the 2000 census was conducted, federal officials say they will not suspend raids on illegal immigrants during the population count in 2010.

headline: New Mexico Looks Again at Show’s Use of Children
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 — The New Mexico attorney general has reopened an investigation into whether the CBS reality show “Kid Nation” violated the state’s child-labor laws and other state regulations governing the welfare of children, a spokesman for the attorney general said on Thursday.

headline: Tractor Therapy Keeps Jets’ Matriarch in Harmony
text: Betty Johnson was carrying on a conversation about Brooke Astor, tractor therapy and football in the days of leather helmets. Without so much as dropping a preposition, Johnson managed to catch each of quarterback Chad Pennington’s first-quarter interceptions in the Jets’ preseason game last week against the Minnesota Vikings, her hands reflexively flying from her lap to her cheeks after each one in a demure depiction of Edvard Munch’s “Scream.”

headline: Art in Review
text: MARCEL BROODTHAERS

headline: McCain Tries to Tackle Age Issue by Calling It a Plus
text: Senator John McCain was fielding questions at a town hall meeting earlier this month in Ankeny, Iowa, when a woman raised her hand and asked him, “from one white head to another white head,” why he wants to be president in such troubled times.

headline: Uh, Lead My Rips: No More Bloopers
text: To the long list of everyday afflictions that includes dry, itchy skin and restless leg syndrome, add another: speech disfluency. Everyone suffers from it. As Michael Erard reckons it in “Um ... ,” his informal study of verbal stumbles and pratfalls, the average person will commit somewhere between 7 and 22 slips of the tongue each day and from two to four times a day will struggle, for an embarrassing length of time, to find the right word or name. It only gets worse. As the years go by, speech reverts to childhood levels of disfluency, with more pauses, more errors, more repeated words, but even the peak years are not great: up to 8 percent of the average person’s word output consists of meaningless fillers and placeholders like um, uh and er.

headline: Role of Telecom Firms in Wiretaps Is Confirmed
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 — The Bush administration has confirmed for the first time that American telecommunications companies played a crucial role in the National Security Agency’s domestic eavesdropping program after asserting for more than a year that any role played by them was a “state secret.”

headline: Now a Lobbyist, an Ex-Senator Uses Campaign Money
text: When he was last running for the United States Senate from New Jersey in 2002, Robert G. Torricelli collected donations from thousands of people who apparently wanted to see him re-elected. They might be surprised to see how he spent a portion of their money.

headline: A Winner at Edinburgh
text: “Between the Devil and the Deep Blue Sea,” a surreal performance piece that combines acting, animation, film and live music, has won the annual Carol Tambor Best of Edinburgh Award at the Edinburgh Fringe festival. The show, created by 1927, a new British theater company, will receive its New York premiere during the Under the Radar Festival at Performance Space 122 in January. More than 2,000 shows were presented at this year’s festival; “Between the Devil and the Deep Blue Sea” won every major award, including the Fringe First Award (from The Scotsman), the Harold Angel Award and the Total Theater Award for Best Emerging Company.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday, about the release of the Iranian-American academic Haleh Esfandiari from an Iranian prison on bail, misstated how Lee H. Hamilton, the head of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, got the answer to his plea to Iran’s supreme leader for her freedom. It was from the Iranian mission to the United Nations in New York, not the Iranian Embassy. (Iran and the United States have not had diplomatic relations since April 1980).

headline: Clashes Break Out in the Caucasus
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 24 — Two police officers were killed today in the Chechen capital of Grozny as they pursued a rebel, who was also killed, the Chechen Interior Ministry said.

headline: Terror and Duct Tape
text: Anyone who was in New York on 9/11 will certainly be creeped out by some of the shots in “Right at Your Door,” a doomsday-style film by Chris Gorak with a twist worth waiting for. Explosions, presumably engineered by terrorists, leave Los Angeles in a toxic haze, and the long shots of the downtown area shrouded in smoke will bring back all sorts of memories.

headline: Harry Potter Propels Bookseller’s Results
text: Barnes & Noble, the world’s largest bookseller, said yesterday that second-quarter profit rose 8.9 percent as demand for the latest Harry Potter book produced the fastest revenue growth in almost three years.

headline: The Problem Isn’t Mr. Maliki
text: Blaming the prime minister of Iraq, rather than the president of the United States, for the spectacular failure of American policy, is cynical politics, pure and simple. It is neither fair nor helpful in figuring out how to end America’s biggest foreign policy fiasco since Vietnam.

headline: Seeking Willie Horton
text: So now Mitt Romney is trying to Willie Hortonize Rudy Giuliani. And thereby hangs a tale — the tale, in fact, of American politics past and future, and the ultimate reason Karl Rove’s vision of a permanent Republican majority was a foolish fantasy.

headline: In a World of Heartbreak, He’s a Catch (Quirks a Plus)
text: That weird exhalation you hear at the multiplex these days is the sound of female characters settling for less than they deserve. Following on the wildly successful antifeminist heels of “Knocked Up,” Hollywood is falling over itself to introduce beautiful, smart young women to useless, possibly brain-damaged young men. Regular bathers need not apply.

headline: Subprime Fallout Could Help Venture Capitalists
text: THE sky is falling. The sky is falling. The ground is rising.

headline: Far-Reaching Policy for Aborigines Draws Their Fury
text: PAPUNYA, Australia, Aug. 18 — Since he walked out of the vast Gibson Desert in Australia in 1934 at the age of 12, Long Jack Phillipus has spent a lifetime helping his Aboriginal people slowly win rights from the white leadership. Then, this month, he saw the conservative government of Prime Minister John Howard abruptly throw the process into reverse. And he is angry.

headline: Those Rumors of Painting’s Death? Exaggerated
text: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. — Some battles in art are never fully resolved. Take the one over painting.

headline: America the Beautiful and the Altered, From on High
text: ROCKLAND, Me. — What have we done to the American landscape? Farmed and gardened it, but also plastered it with strip mines. Created parks, but also ugly industrial sites. Crisscrossed it with pleasant rural roads, but also railroad tracks and six-lane highways. Built great cities, which generate enormous waste dumps.

headline: New Search Begins for Contractor for a Difficult Job
text: Demolition of the former Deutsche Bank building, across Liberty Street from the World Trade Center site, has been delayed by insurance battles, environmental concerns, forensic archaeology, political turf wars, contractual wrangling, construction accidents and, last week, a blaze that killed two firefighters.

headline: Studies Report Inducing Out-of-Body Experience
text: Using virtual-reality goggles, a camera and a stick, scientists have induced out-of-body experiences — the sensation of drifting outside of one’s own body — in ordinary, healthy people, according to studies being published today in the journal Science.

headline: At a Family Gathering, an Internet Cafe Breaks Out
text: I’VE always enjoyed filling our home with family guests, but when a special event brought together our extended clan recently, a new wrinkle emerged.

headline: Bronx: Man Is Fatally Struck by Train
text: A 71-year-old man was killed after he was struck by a train while leaning over on a station platform, the police said. The man, identified by the police as Tran Thang, was standing on a platform at the Fordham Road station on the No. 4 subway line with his head leaning over when he was struck shortly before 4 p.m., the police said. After being hit, Mr. Thang fell into a 19-year-old man, injuring his nose, the police said. Mr. Thang was declared dead at the scene, and the 19-year-old was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital in stable condition. No charges are expected to be filed, the police said.

headline: Trenton: Immigrant Forced to Work
text: A West Windsor woman pleaded guilty yesterday in State Superior Court to criminal restraint for forcing a Filipino immigrant to care for her sick husband and do housekeeping, state prosecutors said. The woman, Angelita Reyes, 68, admitted that she had exploited the immigrant, Arlene Gado, 23, by paying her a fraction of what she was promised and forbidding her to leave the Reyes house unless accompanied by her employers. Prosecutors said Ms. Gado agreed to come to the United States to care for the children of Ms. Reyes’s son-in-law Anthony Mandap, who is the Philippines’ vice consul in San Francisco. But instead of working for Mr. Mandap, Ms. Gado was forced to care for Ms. Reyes’s ailing husband, Norberto, prosecutors said. Ms. Gado’s passport and visa were taken away and she was told she could not leave the house alone because she would be arrested, prosecutors said. If the judge accepts Ms. Reyes’s plea, she will be sentenced to probation, said Peter Aseltine, a spokesman for the attorney general’s office.

headline: Mexico: Weakened Storm Kills 8
text: Hurricane Dean, weakened to a tropical depression, is no more, but its remnants continued to hit Mexico. Eight deaths were reported yesterday, among the victims a family of four caught in a landslide in central Mexico and a mother and teenage son in a mountain village crushed when their roof fell in on them after a downpour. Over all, the storm is blamed for 25 deaths in Mexico and the Caribbean region.

headline: Detention Was Wrong, and U.S. Apologizes
text: The government has issued a rare written apology in a case involving an Iraqi refugee who was improperly imprisoned and pushed toward deportation by federal agents in Montana, the American Civil Liberties Union branch in Seattle announced yesterday.

headline: Yankees Are Clenching Fists for a Tighter Grip
text: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 22 — Sitting behind his office desk Wednesday night, with one torture test behind him and another just ahead, Joe Torre compared the 2007 Yankees with the 1998 Yankees.

headline: Bank of China Shares Plunge
text: BEIJING, Aug. 24 — After appearing immune to the turmoil engulfing the mortgage market in the United States, China suffered its first serious setback today from exposure to subprime loans.

headline: Afghanistan: German Hostage in TV Plea
text: A private Afghan television station broadcast a video of a German aid worker who was kidnapped by the Taliban last month in which he warns that his health is deteriorating. It was not clear when the video was recorded. In the south, roadside bombings in Helmand Province killed three civilians yesterday and two Canadian soldiers on Wednesday.

headline: Two Firefighters Are Hurt at Ground Zero Site
text: Two firefighters were injured yesterday when a worker lost control of a small forklift on the 23rd floor of the troubled Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan, sending it tumbling 200 feet to the ground, the authorities said.

headline: Number of Iraqis Held by U.S. Is Swelling
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 — The number of detainees held by the American-led military coalition in Iraq has swelled by 50 percent under the troop increase ordered by President Bush, with the inmate population growing from 16,000 in February to 24,500 today, according to American military officers in Iraq.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article Aug. 4, about a Congressional report that criticized the Securities and Exchange Commission’s handling of an insider trading investigation of the Pequot hedge fund, misstated one aspect of the report’s findings. The article stated that the report said there was no evidence that John J. Mack, a Wall Street executive, had provided inside information to Pequot. In fact, the report drew no conclusion about whether insider trading had occurred or whether Mr. Mack had provided inside information, although it did say there was “more than a sufficient basis” to question Mr. Mack as part of the investigation and that the S.E.C. had erred in resisting an investigator’s request to do so.

headline: Celebrating a Playwright
text: Edward Albee celebrates his 80th birthday on March 12, an event that will be marked by a number of productions in the New York area, collectively titled “The Albee Season.” The work spans 50 years, from Mr. Albee’s first play, “The Zoo Story,” written in 1958 (now part of “Peter and Jerry”), to the new works “Me, Myself and I” and “Occupant,” which will have their premieres next year. “Peter and Jerry” will run from Oct. 19 to Dec. 9 at the Second Stage Theater; “Me, Myself and I,” Jan. 11 to Feb. 17 at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J.; “The American Dream” and “The Sandbox,” March 4 to April 12 at the Cherry Lane Theater (where the plays had their debuts in 1961 and 1962); and “Occupant,” a portrait of the sculptor Louise Nevelson, May 6 to June 29 at the Signature Theater Company.

headline: Cultural Curriculums
text: A charter school in Florida has come under fire for tying its Hebrew-language based curriculum to religion. Opponents of the Ben Gamla Charter School say that it is impossible to teach Hebrew — and aspects of Jewish culture — outside of a religious context.

headline: User-friendly: Meet the Designer Inga Sempe
text: These are good times for design — and for designers. They can go the functional route, turning out plastic stacking chairs and sectional sofas that sell by the truckload, or they can go the design-art route, creating limitededition pieces that are sometimes sublime and sometimes ridiculous. Or they can do both, and no one will accuse them of selling out. And between the limitless possibilities of design art and technological innovations, functional doesn't preclude fanciful. There has probably never been so much good stuff out there to buy.

headline: Backstepping From Kyoto
text: The Canadian government released a report today that was supposed to outline how Canada would meet its Kyoto goals _ to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 6 percent from 1990 levels by 2012. Instead that report mostly explains why the goal can’t be met.

headline: The Jury’s Still Out
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Turning a Cement Factory Into a Park
text: Images from the artist Bob Cassilly's project to transform a St. Louis cement factory.

headline: An Excerpt from “Meet Julie”
text: An excerpt from the new American Girl book by Megan McDonald

headline: Excerpts From ‘Dawn Evening or Night’
text: Following are excerpts, translated by The New York Times and printed with permission of the publisher, from “Dawn Evening or Night,” a book by the playwright Yasmina Reza about President Nicolas Sarkozy of France:

headline: Sketches of Optimism
text: An exhibition of sketches by automobile designers offers a rare glimpse inside Detroit’s design studios in the muscle-car era.

headline: Bank of China Reports Heavy Exposure to Subprime Crisis
text: Aug. 24 — Bank of China Ltd. had its biggest drop since going public last year after the nation's second- biggest bank said it holds almost $9.7 billion of securities backed by U.S. subprime loans, the most of any Asian company.

headline: Cue the Lights
text: Each August, two married directors invite actors, musicians and designers to their house on the shore of Lake Lucille to spend a week working on a play.

headline: No Longer Boxed In
text: After leaving a one-bedroom rental in Gramercy Park, a family found a home in a Crown Heights row house.

headline: Home Depot Scrambles to Save Sale of Unit
text: Home Depot was scrambling Thursday night to save the sale of its wholesale unit to a consortium of private equity firms, lowering its asking price by about $1.2 billion from the original $10.3 billion it agreed upon, according to The New York Times.

headline: Abu Dhabi Fires Up Deal for a Canadian Oil Producer
text: Abu Dhabi National Energy, a state-controlled United Arab Emirates investor in oil and power assets, agreed to buy the Canadian unit of Pioneer Natural Resources for $540 million.

headline: The Golden Arches Go Upscale
text: To attract new clientele and more business, McDonald's is going modern in Europe.

headline: United Air Might Sell Maintenance Unit
text: United Airlines said Thursday that it might sell all or part of its maintenance operations to outside investors to raise cash to modernize and expand the unit.

headline: Bank of China’s $9 Billion Subprime Problem
text: The Bank of China, the nation’s second-largest commercial bank, said Thursday that it held almost $9.7 billion of securities backed by American subprime loans, the most of any Asian company.

headline: BNP Paribas Is Reopening 3 Funds
text: BNP Paribas, the French bank, said on Thursday that it would reopen three funds next week that it had frozen in a step that accelerated a slide in financial stocks.

headline: Appeals Court Backs Whole Foods Deal
text: A federal appeals court has rejected the attempt by regulators to block Whole Foods Market‘s $565 million takeover of the rival Wild Oats Markets.

headline: Insider Trading and the Perils of Pillow Talk
text: As federal regulators have pursued insider trading cases this year, one of the oddities they have spotted is an increase in cases involving husbands and wives.

headline: Commercial Paper Market Shrinks the Most in Seven Years
text: The size of the commercial paper market, a crucial source of short-term financing for businesses, decreased 4.2 percent last week, the biggest drop in at least seven years, as investors fled asset-backed debt and opted for the safety of Treasuries.

headline: In Presidential Race, Tech’s Home Is a Magnet
text: For presidential candidates campaigning in Iowa, the place to be is the state fair. Diners are popular in New Hampshire. But for those visiting Silicon Valley, it’s the Googleplex.

headline: N.Y. Regulators Green Light Keyspan Deal
text: New York’s Public Service Commission voted unanimously Thursday to authorize National Grid‘s $7.3 billion stock acquisition of KeySpan.

headline: The Tech I.P.O. Makes a Comeback
text: Could the subprime skunk that is fouling the public market actually be a bit of a blessing for Silicon Valley’s high-technology investors?

headline: Sun Hopes New Ticker Will Boost Shares
text: Silicon Valley investors will be soon waking up to JAVA – and Sun Microsystems hopes the new ticker symbol will help perk up its stock.

headline: Wasserstein On M&A, L.B.O.’s and Melting Markets
text: Bruce Wasserstein is no stranger to the gyrations of Wall Street. In a Q&A with BusinessWeek, the Lazard chieftain, who has helped broker more than $250 billion in deals in his career, gives his take on the latest market meltdown.

headline: Houston’s Bank of America Center Sold
text: Bank of America Center, an architectural icon on downtown Houston’s skyline, has been sold to Dallas-based Novati Group and an affiliate of the General Electric Pension Trust.

headline: Ryerson Shareholders Reject Harbinger Slate
text: Shareholders in steel services company Ryerson elected 11 directors nominated by the company at its annual stockholders meeting Thursday morning, according to an early tally, thwarting efforts by activist investor Harbinger Capital to install its own slate.

headline: Toronto-Dominion’s Profit Rises 39%
text: Toronto-Dominion Bank posted a 39 percent increase in fiscal third-quarter net income on higher profit throughout the company and sought to explain why it may hold onto its online brokerage unit.

headline: High Stakes at the Open
text: All In…

headline: Catching Up With Mark Cuban
text: Mark Cuban, who made his $2.3 billion fortune as an internet entrepreneur, has some news for you: The Internet is “dead and boring”, Mr. Cuban told Portfolio.com in a Q&A.

headline: Merrill Lynch Invests in Indonesian Coal Project
text: Merrill Lynch has put its own money to work alongside a couple of hedge funds in yet another highly structured equity deal, which will provide financing for an Indonesian coal mine at a time when global demand for this commodity continues to increase, FinanceAsia reported.

headline: Winnipeg Exchange Investors Approve ICE Deal
text: Shareholders of WCE Holdings, which owns the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange, on Thursday approved a takeover offer worth C$50 million ($47.6 million) by IntercontinentalExchange.

headline: Accredited C.F.O. Resigns
text: Accredited Home Lenders said on Thursday that Chief Financial Officer John Buchanan is resigning effective Aug. 31. The company disclosed the resignation in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Bankers Worry the Sun Has Set on L.B.O.’s
text: A worsening credit crunch and its broad impact on financial markets has some dealmakers predicting that leveraged buyouts are on hold for the rest of the year and perhaps well into 2008, Reuters reported.

headline: Pros Back Start-Up for the Armchair Set
text: Armchair quarterbacks will be able to put their play-calling skills to the test this football season thanks to a new online fantasy game from startup YOUbeQB.

headline: Despite Deal, Countrywide C.F.O. Waxes Gloomy
text: By discrediting virtually every step taken thus far to help the housing market and the mortgage industry, Countrywide Financial Chief Executive Angelo Mozilo killed Wall Street’s buzz about the credit crunch being over.

headline: Sentinel to Be Overseen by a Trustee
text: The fate of hedge funds and investors with funds tied up in collapsed U.S. investment management firm Sentinel was placed Thursday night in the hands of an independent bankruptcy trustee, amid continuing unease over the way certain creditors of the firm were treated.

headline: V.C.’s Turn Back the Clock for Aging Rock Stars
text: Past-their-prime rock bands have a new groupie: venture capital.

headline: Blackstone Says Tax Hike Would Cost It $525 Million
text: The Blackstone Group has gotten out its calculator and tallied up the cost of a Congressional proposal to more than double the tax rates buyout firms.

headline: Riverstone Hires BP’s Browne
text: Riverstone, an energy-focused private equity firm, said on Friday that it has hired John Browne, the former chief executive of BP, as a managing director and the managing partner of its European operations. The firm will open an office in London, where Mr. Browne lives.

headline: Subprime Troubles Sack HRJ
text: HRJ Capital, the investment firm whose partners include retired football players Joe Montana and Ronnie Lott, said one of its funds lost 12.3 percent in the first two weeks of August, erasing most of its 2007 gain, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Buyout Firm Is Said to Take Stake in Betsey Johnson
text: After being on the block for more than a year, eccentric fashion designer Betsey Johnson has finally found a buyer, The New York Post reported. Private-equity firm Castanea Partners has agreed to take a controlling stake in the company, known for its club girl chic and quirky fashions, sources told the paper.

headline: Precision Aims for $80.5 Million I.P.O.
text: Precision Therapeutics, a life-sciences company, filed on Friday to raise up to $80.5 million in an initial public offering of common stock.

headline: Waiting for Blackstone’s Next Step
text: For all the lumps the Blackstone Group has taken in the past two months, Stephen A. Schwarzman deserves credit for being the first of the buyout titans to take his firm public. So says Breakingviews, but there’s a caveat: while Mr. Schwarzman has done well for himself, he will have to start making money for his new public investors as well.

headline: Caucus Chatter
text: To our readers:

headline:
Stray Questions for:
Daniel Clowes
text: Daniel Clowes’s books include “Ghost World” and “David Boring.”

headline: Morning Buzz: Deutsche Bank Accident, Torricelli’s Spending, Taxi Threats, and Hot Weather on the Way
text: All the papers focus this morning on the accident at the Deutsche Bank building at 130 Liberty Street on Thursday afternoon that injured two firefighters.

headline: 2008: The Romney Prescription
text: Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney, who has said that his positions on some issues have “evolved” or changed in recent years, is set to discuss the details of a his health care plan in Florida today, which also seems to be something of an evolution from proposals he has supported in the past.

headline: Short Sellers Lose Badly on Opsware Bet
text: Silicon Valley denizens have been claiming that the credit crunch afflicting much of the deal landscape won’t affect them. In one case, their having been proven right has burned naysayers.

headline: Firefighter’s Funeral at St. Patrick’s
text: Updated, 1:30 p.m.

headline: Antigua and Goliath
text: Gary Rivlin of The Times reported on Thursday about a curious trade dispute between the United States and Antigua and Barbuda over Internet gambling sites. The tiny Caribbean nation instigated a trade complaint “against the United States, claiming its ban against Americans gambling over the Internet violated Antigua and Barbuda’s rights as a member of the W.T.O.” Antigua won the case in three different forums, and now is asking “the trade organization to grant a rare form of compensation if the American government refuses to accept the ruling: permission for Antiguans to violate intellectual property laws by allowing them to distribute copies of American music, movie and software products, among others.”

headline: Secure Advantage Loan TV Ad
text: As homeowners fall behind on mortgages, regulators are paying closer attention to advertising. Quicken Loans no longer offers the Secure Advantage Loan.

headline: Why Can’t We Compute in the Cloud?
text: What’s holding back computing-in-the-cloud?

headline: Why Can’t We Compute in the Cloud? Part 2
text: The possibilities (see the posting below) of in-the-cloud computing struck home not long ago when I flew from San Francisco to Vancouver, British Columbia, to begin a week long reporting trip including several days at the annual meeting of the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence and a stop at Microsoft’s financial analyst meeting.

headline: What Makes an Ideal Parent?
text: Steven Levitt on teaching his kids creativity.

headline: That’s Doctor Rock Star to You, Friend
text: The Imperial College in London awarded a doctorate in astrophysics  — a real one, earned the old-fashioned way with an abstruse, math-heavy 48,000-word thesis — on Thursday to, of all people, Brian May, who sings and plays guitar in the rock band Queen and wrote or cowrote “We Will Rock You” and many of the band’s other hits.

headline: Answers From the ‘Suburbanization of New York’ Editors, Part 4
text: Following is the fourth and final set of responses from Jerilou Hammett and Kingsley Hammett, the editors of “The Suburbanization of New York” (Princeton Architectural Press, 2007). The book is a collection of 14 essays about the economic and social changes that have swept the city over the past two decades and the Hammetts, who are husband and wife, run DESIGNER/builder magazine. They took questions from City Room readers this week.Cole: I saw neighborhoods in Manhattan destroyed in an attempt to turn the city into a theme park for the hyper wealthy. Sadly, so much history has been erased. There are no gritty areas left anymore; the meatpacking district is now a leper colony for trendies. NYC resembles the Las Vegas version of NYC; Broadway musicals, now Vegas floor shows. Ground zero, rebuilt, will be a mall for T-shirts and pizza slices. My question: What happens to a socioeconomic pyramid when you remove the middle and lower sections?

headline: Mash Up the Corporation
text: Jeremy Burton is betting that Facebook-style, bottom-up software development is destined to come to the corporate world.

headline: Get Ready for Kickoff
text: Coming soon from The New York Times: a new blog on the fierce competition and engrossing culture of college football. From the Bowl Championship Series and Heisman Trophy watch, to news and features about one’s alma mater or local collegiate team, The New York Times will take readers inside America’s great fall weekend ritual with interviews, insights and analysis from the tailgates to the sidelines.

headline: Like a Mute Button for Hate
text: The sidewalk ranter of southern Park Slope has an iPod now. It’s the best thing that’s happened to the neighborhood in months.

headline: To Sim or Not to Sim: Simulated Happiness versus Real Misery
text: The Lab judging panel will be busy this weekend picking a winner in the speak-to-the-Prime-Designer contest. (You can still enter today.) As they toil tirelessly, let us ponder this designer’s ethics, and whether it’s better to live in simulated joy or be really miserable.

headline: ‘Tank Yew Vedy Much’
text: This Sunday’s issue of the Book Review – the cover is at right – features, among other things, Darcey Steinke’s review of Mary Gordon’s new memoir, David Brooks on Drew Westen’s book “The Political Brain” and Gerald Howard’s essay on Norman Mailer’s 1970 movie “Maidstone.”

headline: Even More on the Upstairs Ceilings
text: Thanks for your comments and suggestions about ceiling height. I spoke to John Agnelli twice this morning and, as usual, he has his own point of view on the ceiling issue.

text: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

headline: Live Wines
text: I’m about to go on vacation, so this will be my last post until after Labor Day. As I’m about to leave I’m thinking about some wines that I’ve enjoyed in the last week or so and how inadequate our usual descriptive language is to characterize their appeal.

headline: Bad for the Country, and for My Numbers
text: In the Democratic presidential race, it’s been a week of ambiguously controversial remarks. Michelle Obama got things going with “if you can’t run your own house …”, and now The New York Post reports that Hillary Clinton, in a New Hampshire appearance, had this to say about a potential devastating terrorist attack on the United States: “It’s a horrible prospect to ask yourself, ‘What if? What if?’ But if certain things happen between now and the election, particularly with respect to terrorism, that will automatically give the Republicans an advantage again, no matter how badly they have mishandled it, no matter how much more dangerous they have made the world.”

headline: What We Think We’ve Learned About the Giants
text: With apologies to one of Esquire’s best monthly features, “What I’ve Learned,” and even Peter King’s “Five Things I Think I Think,” here are “A Bunch of Things We Think We’ve Learned” about the Giants during training camp:

headline: Honda Unwraps a New Accord
text: Honda recently released the vitals on its 2008 Accord, which hits showrooms Sept. 12. We’ll have some early driving impressions in the blog next week, followed by a full review in the Automobiles section of The Times. Until then, here are some early returns.

headline: Care to Dance? It Takes Two to, Well, You Know
text: So often in journalism, the matchup between story and reporter is crucial. City Room asked me what it was like to report this article, part of the weekly Summer Rituals series, and I can say that it was one of the coolest assignments I’ve ever had.

headline: Clinton: Best to Deal With Terror Attacks
text: Sounding positively Rudy-esque, Senator Hillary Clinton raised the specter yesterday of a terrorist attack before next year’s election. She said that such a thing could help the Republicans keep the White House — unless she were the Democratic nominee.

headline: Oh, and by the Way, Can We Have $10,000?
text: Alison and I should have known better.
