headline: Stop-Time
text: Paper Cuts is on hiatus.

headline: Children on the Campaign Trail
text: Traveling with the Edwards family in Iowa, it became clear that running for president and raising children do not always fit together neatly.

headline: The Bloomberg Angle to Colbert’s ‘Wristgate’
text: Stephen Colbert, who broke his left wrist in a Beyoncé-fueled on-set dancing mishap, finally had his cast removed on his Comedy Central show last night.

headline: Cemetery Celebrity Sightings
text: by David Rampe

headline: A Delay in the Home Depot Battle Royale
text: Negotiations over the fate of Home Depot‘s professional supply unit are likely to drag on through the weekend as financing of the $10.3 billion deal remains up in the air, people briefed on the matter told DealBook. Bankers and lawyers are expected to keep battling over whether the banks in the deal can withdraw their financing commitments, in what one person told The New York Times was “the most expensive game of chicken you’ve ever played.”

headline: Can Google Untangle the New York Transit Web?
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s Web site tends to crash in a crisis (although the agency claims to have fixed the problems). Some just think the site is hard to use. (And, of course, the subways and commuter lines are just part of the New York region transportation network.)

headline: In Court Today: The Astronaut Soap Opera
text: Update 3:45 p.m. EasternJohn Schwartz called The Lede from the courthouse with an update: After the lunch break, the proceedings were taken up mainly by the defense’s efforts to persuade the judge that the police acted without Captain Nowak’s consent in searching her car and in taking her statement without her lawyer present — familiar battlegrounds in many criminal cases (not to mention television shows).

headline: Your Comments: Prius Convertibles, Ford’s Fuel Cell Fusion, Silence at the N.H.T.S.A.
text: Today, we’re taking a page from City Room and pulling out some readers’ responses to our recent posts.

headline: Blogtalk: A Ferry Legend, a Freegan, Subway Stuffers, Martha Stewart and More
text: What we’re reading — and watching — on the blogs…

headline: An After-Hours Spot Above All the Rest
text: As anybody with a weakness for weepy film romanticism knows, closing time at the Empire State Building’s observation deck was always the stroke of midnight — right? Cary Grant waited up there for Deborah Kerr until the clock struck 12 in “An Affair to Remember” (1957), and Meg Ryan had to talk her way past a security guard to meet Tom Hanks there at night in “Sleepless in Seattle” (1993).

headline: The New Higher
text: A video trailer from mtvU's new poet laureate initiative.

headline: Soonest Mended
text: An excerpt of "Soonest Mended" by John Ashbery.

headline: Brzezinski Offers Support for Obama
text: Right on the heels of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s assertion that she could handle the political ramifications of a terrorist attack better than her Democratic rivals, a major foreign policy figure associated with Democrats endorsed her archrival, Senator Barack Obama.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 24
text: Here is a slide show of 13 pictures by photographers for The Times that tell the story of the past week in the New York region. Subjects include the fire at ground zero that killed two firefighters, a curious exhibit in the Times Square Ripley’s Believe It or Not! Odditorium, a summer camp where children can reunite with their incarcerated mothers and more.

headline: A Stage Actor's Wages
text: So many stage actors persevere with no or little pay, waiting for a break that pays.  Damian Baldet finally got his.

headline: Historic Drop in U.S. Home Prices
text: For the first time in more than 50 years, the median home price is expected to decline in 2007.

headline: Icahn Is Cleared for Biogen Move
text: Biogen Idec shares moved higher Friday on news that the Federal Trade Commission has approved activist investor Carl C. Icahn to purchase more of the company’s shares, MarketWatch reported. Stock in the biotech company rose 5 percent to $62.89, a 52-week high.

headline: P.M. Postscript: Democratic Infighting
text: The Democratic National Committee meets tomorrow in Washington to discuss whether to impose sanctions on Florida for moving its primary up from Feb. 5 to Jan. 29. (The party had stipulated that only a handful of states, including Iowa and New Hampshire, were allowed to hold nominating contests before February). The Florida Democratic Party demurred, and now the D.N.C. appears to be considering stripping the state of its delegates and telling the presidential candidates not to campaign there.

headline: How to Make Lemonade Through Interstate Car Sales
text: In this week’s Automobiles section, Christopher Jensen reports on the situation of car buyers who get stuck with lemons. All 50 states have laws regarding such vehicles, but he finds that in many cases the cars have been shipped to a state where they can be resold as if they had clean records. He writes:

headline: Tkachiev, Vachier-Lagrave Win French Championship. Who? Glad You Asked.
text: Vladislav Tkachiev and Maxime Vachier-Lagrave have tied for first in the French Championship. Andrei Sokolov finished third. The results can be found on the French Chess Federation’s Web site.

headline: Ditech TV Ad
text: A Ditech TV Ad for Fixed-Rate MortgagesSource: Competitrack

headline: Sheffield Sits and Mussina Stirs in Detroit
text: I’m back with the team after missing the series in Anaheim. Thanks to Lee Jenkins for his usual terrific work filling in.

headline: Rules to Draft By
text: Welcome back to 5th Down fantasy football central. I’m Mark St. Amant — author, freelance writer and a certified fantasy football junkie who’s shocked his wife hasn’t divorced him yet.

headline: The Korean Film Festival
text: Melena Ryzik of The Times attends the opening party for the New York Korean Film Festival.

headline: Delgado Dropped to Sixth
text: Ladies and gentlemen: Please forgive my brief absence from the blog; computer issues were not working in my favor. But since we last spoke, your Mets have made it a habit of playing, umm, interesting games. When you get a second, please thank Guillermo Mota, Billy Wagner, Trevor Hoffman and Carlos Beltran. Oh, we nearly forgot Carlos Delgado, who was dropped to sixth from fifth in the lineup today.

headline: The Korean Film Festival
text: Melena Ryzik of The Times attends the opening party for the New York Korean Film Festival.

headline: On the Job at Home
text: Working at home has its perks, but it also comes with potential interruptions like broken washing machines and last-minute changes in children’s schedules. Do you work at home? How do you balance working at home with family life? We invite you to share your thoughts. Go to Article

headline: ‘Kid Nation’ Lesson: Be Careful What You Pitch
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 — “Forty kids. One town. No adults.”

headline: Cards Train Teenagers to Use Plastic
text: HERE we are, a nation deeply in debt. All told, America’s adults are on the hook for well over $2 trillion, and more than a third of that is credit card debt. Given the circumstances, what is the best way to prevent our young people from skidding into debt?

headline: A Line of Dolls Enters the ’70s
text: Nine-year-old Julie Albright likes to wear her long blond hair loose, with a single thin braid in the front. With her parents divorcing, and with her move from a big house in San Francisco to a smaller apartment across town, she is trying to adapt to a bewildering web of changes, just like a lot of other children growing up in the 1970s.

headline: Green and Fashionable
text: Nearly every industry is promoting its “green-ness” these days, so it was probably inevitable that the fashion industry would jump on the bandwagon.

headline: Offbeat Runners Club Sets Off Terror Scare in New Haven
text: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 24 (AP)  Daniel Salchow and his sister, Dorothee, planned to spend a pleasant afternoon marking a trail for fellow members of their offbeat running and drinking club.

headline: A Note Is Linked to a Woman’s Killer
text: YONKERS, Aug. 24 — The police here believe that a 78-year-old woman found dead after a fire on Wednesday in her apartment in a complex for the elderly was strangled, leaving other residents and neighbors wondering what could have motivated her killing.

headline: Schubert With Tense Brio, Not Predictable or Pretty
text: Frans Brüggen should consider changing the name of his Orchestra of the 18th Century. The orchestra has, to be fair, done well by Bach, Rameau and Haydn since Mr. Brüggen founded it in 1981. But by the mid-1990s, when it completed what many record collectors still regard as the finest period-instrument Beethoven cycle on disc, it was doing its best work with music composed not in the 18th century but in the 19th.

headline: Sports Briefing: Golf: Met Open Has New Champion
text: Frank Bensel birdied the final two holes to finish with his third consecutive 67 and win the 92nd Met Open Championship at the Meadow Brook Club in Jericho, N.Y. Bensel finished one stroke ahead of the former Met Open winners Andrew Svoboda and Rick Hartmann; Jim Herman; and Bob Rittberger.

headline: Liberty Surprises Shock in Its Playoff Opener
text: On paper, the Liberty does not match up well with the Detroit Shock. But by halftime of Game 1 of the Eastern Conference semifinals last night, the Liberty found itself right where it has been all season — in step with the W.N.B.A.’s defending champion.

headline: Man Given Death for Raping Girl and Burying Her Alive
text: INVERNESS, Fla., Aug. 24 (AP)  A previously convicted sex offender was sentenced to death Friday for kidnapping 9-year-old Jessica Lunsford, raping her and burying her alive in his yard.

headline: Two New Deaths, Same Old Questions
text: In a partnership with the State of New York, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s government owns a ruined, contaminated skyscraper at 130 Liberty Street, across from the World Trade Center site. The building appears to have been a howling firetrap, the kind for which private owners would be indicted in days. Last week it killed two men, Firefighters Robert Beddia, 53, and Joseph Graffagnino, 33.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
text: A front-page article on Thursday about the John Galt Corporation, the demolition subcontractor working on the Deutsche Bank building at ground zero, gave an erroneous attribution for statements about the safeguards under which Galt was hired and about Galt’s failed bid for another city job in the Bronx. The statements — both in paraphrase and in direct quotation — were by John Gallagher, a spokesman for Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff, not by Mr. Doctoroff himself. (Mr. Gallagher was speaking in his own right, not for Mr. Doctoroff.) (Go to Article)

headline: Martial Arts With a Gun Instead of a Kick
text: Remember when a martial-arts movie was a martial-arts movie, and stars like Bruce Lee and the young Jackie Chan didn’t need wires, digital effects or firearms to convey their prowess? Today, it seems, anyone seeking a pleasant summer afternoon of dramatic Asian-style fisticuffs must settle for the kind of urban-action/martial-arts hybrid that is “War.”

headline: On Vacation, All by Myself
text: NOT knowing what I’d eat — or if I’d be eating at all — I decided to play it safe and dumped two dozen red multivitamins in a sandwich baggie. I stuffed the baggie into the pocket of my corduroys.

headline: Tangoing Cheek to Cheek for 3 Minutes in the Park
text: It was a sultry 6 p.m. in Central Park, and over by the 1872 Shakespeare statue at Literary Walk, melancholy rhythms spilled from two speakers propped up on park benches.

headline: The Lowly Pot Lid Takes a Star Turn
text: Human speech, Flaubert said, is “like a cracked kettle on which we hammer out tunes to make bears dance when we long to touch the stars to tears.”

headline: Click if You Read This Column
text: FOR many advertisers, the promise of the Internet lies in its ability to track and measure users’ responses, something that is generally impossible with television and print. But a new study concludes that advertisements can be effective even when they do not persuade users to click on them (technologyreview.com).

headline: Madeleine B. Stern, Bookseller and Sleuth, Dies at 95
text: Madeleine B. Stern, a prominent rare-book dealer, biographer and literary sleuth who helped bring to print Louisa May Alcott’s long-lost Gothic tales of murder, sexual subjugation, opium dens and other things simply too dreadful to mention, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 95.

headline: Job Security Isn’t Concern to the Yankees’ Mussina
text: DETROIT, Aug. 24 — Mike Mussina flew home to Pennsylvania on Thursday’s day off, and he took his son fishing. He was as successful with a rod as he was with a ball on Tuesday, when he started the Yankees’ 18-9 loss to the Angels.

headline: The C.I.A. Report: Is Anyone Accountable? (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Never Mind the Details: The Mayor Is Rich
text: If you want a taste of how large Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is living, consider this: Last year, he bought a new property, his ninth, in Florida where his younger daughter, Georgina, can ride her horses; he paid his household help at least $500,000; and he still owns a prestigious Park Avenue condominium where a former companion, Mary Jane Salk, lives.

headline: A Star on the Court Who Mingles Off It
text: Roger Federer is not lonely at No. 1. He has plenty of company off the court.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: The End

headline: Ex-University Head in Texas on Trial for Money Misuse
text: HOUSTON, Aug. 24 — With Texas Southern University struggling to survive as one of the nation’s largest historically black colleges, the former president once hailed as its savior faced a state jury here Friday, charged with misspending hundreds of thousands of dollars on personal luxuries.

headline: Protest Broken Up by Armed Hamas Force
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 24  Members of the Hamas Executive Force broke up a demonstration by Fatah, Hamas’s rival, in Gaza City on Friday, firing into the air and briefly detaining journalists who were trying to document the events, according to news media reports.

headline: When Seemingly Unimportant Cards Can Send a Vital Signal
text: At the first European Universities Bridge Cup, held in Bruges, Belgium, Aug. 4 to 9, the award for the best-played deal went to Jérémie Tignel, who was on the Paris Polytechnic team.

headline: With Software and Soldering, a Non-AT&T iPhone
text: AT&T is paying millions to be the exclusive United States provider of Apple’s much-hyped and glowingly reviewed gadget, the iPhone.

headline: Using All of Her Body to Cook, Latin Style
text: Ingrid Hoffmann, the latest arrival on the Food Network — her show “Simply Delicioso” is shown on Saturday mornings — seems to be quickly staking her claim as the country’s pre-eminent cleavage cook.

headline: American Instincts in a French Executive
text: Denis Hennequin is a rock ’n’ roll chief executive.

headline: A Dream Restored
text: SOWETO, South Africa — Unnoticed by the outside world, part of Arthur Ashe’s legacy — a tennis center for black South Africans — descended into decay and ruin long before his death in 1993.

headline: Companies Agree to Pay to Settle SAT Error Suit
text: Two big testing organizations, the College Board and NCS Pearson Inc., said yesterday that they had agreed to pay $2.85 million to settle a class-action lawsuit involving more than 4,000 students whose SAT exams were incorrectly scored in 2005.

headline: In Air Attack, U.S. Soldiers Kill 18 Gunmen
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 24  American soldiers battled Shiite militiamen in a poor neighborhood in northern Baghdad early on Friday, firing from helicopters and killing 18 gunmen, the American military said.

headline: Dispensing Friendship With Clients’ Stationery
text: A flier taped outside the Yorkville Copy Service on the Upper East Side boldly asks passers-by, in thick block lettering, if they happen to be “F.O.B.”

headline: Squelching the Citizenry’s Back Talk
text: The White House certainly has been guilty of mismanagement and lack of preparation on the big things, like the Iraq war and Hurricane Katrina. But it turns out that President Bush’s encounters with ordinary Americans have been micromanaged and laboriously controlled for the past five years to weed out the merest whiff of protest. Citizen volunteers are enlisted to vet cranky-looking sorts outside the event, and “rally squads” of zealots are prompted to pounce on anyone who manages to slip through with an outspoken thought or an unscripted word.

headline: After Plea, Vick Is Given Suspension by the N.F.L.
text: The National Football League suspended Michael Vick indefinitely without pay yesterday after he admitted in court papers that he paid for dogfighting bets and helped kill underperforming dogs.

headline: Getting Their Groove Back, With Help From the Magic of Dance
text: David Leventhal, a member of the Mark Morris Dance Group, is teaching a combination from Mr. Morris’s “Three Russian Preludes” to a crammed class of dance students. “Mark made this for Baryshnikov,” he tells them. “Then I danced it. Now you’re the third people to learn it.”

headline: Lebanon: Militants’ Families Leave Camp
text: Families of Fatah al Islam militants holed up in the battered Palestinian refugee camp Nahr al Bared, north of Tripoli, were permitted to leave under a temporary truce with the army. Their evacuation clears the way for a possible final military assault to end more than three months of fighting between the militant group and the Lebanese Army. A spokesman for the Palestinian Clerics Association, which mediated the operation, said 22 women and 41 children left the camp in buses accompanied by army vehicles, bound for interrogation. Two children were taken to a hospital. “The battle days were not easy, and exhaustion features were apparent,” said Sheik Mohammad al-Hajj, the association’s spokesman. “But the army has promised to release them very quickly.” A senior military official said the army, which had been calling on the remaining civilians to leave the camp for weeks, might now open a final assault. “The army does not have to worry about injuring children or women anymore,” he said. Most of the camp’s 30,000 residents fled in May, early in the fighting. The army estimates that 70 militants remain inside. They have rejected calls to surrender.

headline: When It Comes to Foreign Policy, What Counts as Experience?
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 — During Sunday’s Democratic debate, the candidates spent an awful lot of time discussing whether Senator Barack Obama has enough foreign policy experience to be president — so much so, in fact, that Mr. Obama quipped that “to prepare for this debate I rode the bumper cars at the state fair.”

headline: Crucial Relief for Diabetics (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: To Woo Europeans, McDonald’s Goes Upscale
text: LONDON — Taking a respite from an afternoon of shopping, Ita Clift sips a cappuccino at a McDonald’s. Though she rarely sets foot in the fast-food restaurant, Ms. Clift says she dropped in to this one in the Edgware Road section of Northwest London for a quick boost of energy and because the restaurant “looked so nice and sophisticated.”

headline: Wachovia Sues Mortgage Specialist Firm in Dispute Over Collateral
text: The Wachovia Corporation, the bank based in Charlotte, N.C., has sued the jumbo-mortgage specialist Thornburg Mortgage for failing to return collateral used in a derivatives transaction.

headline: Pakistan Prepares for Former Prime Ministers’ Return
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 24 — Officials from the party of former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif announced Friday that he would be returning to Pakistan within weeks, but the government sent mixed signals on how it would respond to a Supreme Court ruling that threw open the coming parliamentary campaign to all political players.

headline: Fighting Al Qaeda (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Window Gazing (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Luxury Miami Condo Conversion Is Facing Financial Trouble
text: In a sign that the real estate slowdown has hit even the most desirable locations, the developer converting the Savoy Hotel in the South Beach section of Miami into multimillion dollar Fendi-designed condominiums and condo hotels may be facing foreclosure.

headline: Chávez Is Ready to Return to Mets After Long Layoff
text: More than 11 weeks since going on the disabled list with a strained left hamstring, Endy Chávez returned to Shea Stadium and pronounced himself fit to rejoin the Mets. General Manager Omar Minaya said Chávez, who was awaiting clearance from the team’s training staff and doctors, should be added to the roster by the end of this weekend.

headline: After Two Years, a Tangled Mix of Good and Bad
text: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 24 — It is hurricane anniversary season in New Orleans, and the beleaguered city is threatened with a new inundation: a tidal wave of reports, assessments, stock-takings, prognostications and tongue-lashings.

headline: A Treaty Whose Time Has Come
text: A solemn international treaty known as the Law of the Sea Convention will celebrate its 25th anniversary this December, and for 25 years the mere mention of its name has been enough to induce deep slumber. Yet for all kinds of reasons — not least growing fears about the availability of energy resources — people are finally paying attention. That includes the Senate, where right-wing scare tactics and official inertia have long blocked the treaty’s ratification, leaving America as the only major power standing on the sidelines.

headline: Spirited Reminders of a Time Long Gone
text: The Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival has always had a populist tinge, particularly under the directorship of Jenneth Webster. With free admission and a wide range of dance and music events, the festival sprawls into just about every nook and cranny of Lincoln Center Plaza every summer, encouraging ambling passers-by to stop, look and perhaps even stay a while to watch the goings-on.

headline: Yankee Caps Pulled After Protesters See Gang Links in Symbols and Colors
text: Major League Baseball’s official cap manufacturer said yesterday that it would remove headwear bearing the colors and symbols of three gangs  the Bloods, the Crips and the Latin Kings  one day after activists protested the sale of the caps at retail stores in East Harlem.

headline: Running an Empire? No Sweat
text: Richard D. Parsons sat down at a quiet table by a window at Porter House New York, the fine year-old steakhouse on the fourth floor of the Time Warner Building, and looked at his watch. It was 7 p.m. “I’m going to have to leave at 8:30,” he said. “I’ve got another meeting.” He shot me a small, pained shrug. “It’s the middle of August, and I’m still busting my chops.”

headline: Leslie Lukash, Medical Examiner, 86, Dies
text: Dr. Leslie Lukash, who, as a self-described “diagnostician of death” helped identify the corpse of Josef Mengele, the Nazi doctor, and who oversaw the autopsies of as many as 50,000 bodies in more than four decades as the medical examiner of Nassau County, died on Aug. 16 in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 86.

headline: One Part Cement, Two Parts Whimsy, One Odd Park
text: ST. LOUIS — In an industrial area here known for truckyards, not art, a sculptor and entrepreneur named Bob Cassilly stands on a 100-foot-tall hill, created from some of the 182,000 truckloads of dirt that have been unloaded and applied to the skeleton of a former cement factory.

headline: Access to the Courts (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Minister Guilty in Gay Marriage Case
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 (AP)  A Presbyterian minister was found guilty of violating church law for officiating the weddings of two lesbian couples, the minister’s defense team said Friday.

headline: Chinese Seek to Buy a U.S. Maker of Disk Drives
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 — A Chinese technology company has expressed interest in buying a maker of computer disk drives in the United States, raising concerns among American government officials about the risks to national security in transferring high technology to China.

headline: New-Home Sales Climb, Giving Markets a Break
text: A rise in sales of new homes last month provided an unexpected respite from the steady stream of dismal housing market statistics lately, but economists cautioned that it was unlikely to last.

headline: Giuliani Boasts of Surplus; Reality Is More Complex
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani has been broadcasting radio advertisements in Iowa and other states far from the city he once led stating that as mayor of New York, he “turned a $2.3 billion deficit into a multibillion dollar surplus.”

headline: Who Will Pay for the Next Hurricane?
text: Philadelphia

headline: Jammin’ With Gabriel
text: They were rambunctious geniuses — Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie, Bud Powell and Max Roach — the nucleus of a group of immensely talented musicians who engineered a revolution in jazz as wondrous and profound as the birth of Cubism in painting.

headline: A Second Day, a Second Massing of Grief for a Lost Firefighter
text: Amid the somber majesty of St. Patrick’s Cathedral, thousands of firefighters, friends and relatives paid tribute yesterday to Robert Beddia, a 23-year veteran of the New York Fire Department, evoking his professionalism and the simple pleasures in his life, from poker and paddle ball to the many nieces and nephews he doted on.

headline: To Pick a Kicker, Giants First Need to See Them Kick
text: ALBANY, Aug. 23 — As much as the Giants would like to see their offense move the ball crisply against the Jets in Saturday’s preseason game, they really could use a few stalled drives. Field goals may be more important than touchdowns.

headline: 2 Palestinians Killed After Attacking Israeli Army Post
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 25 — Two Palestinian gunmen entered Israel from the Gaza Strip early today, attacking an Israeli Army post near the Erez crossing and moving nearly half a mile into Israel before soldiers killed them, Israeli and Palestinian officials said.

headline: Head-On Collision in Connecticut Kills 4 Teenagers and Injures 3 Adults
text: BRISTOL, Conn., Aug. 24 — Four teenagers from nearby towns who had met on MySpace never made it home from an evening swim at another friend’s pool on Thursday night. They were killed when the driver of their speeding Subaru sports car lost control and veered into an oncoming car in the opposite lane, according to the police and interviews with young people who knew them.

headline: A Consumption Tax (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Guilty Plea Is Arranged in Tax Plot
text: The owner of the nation’s largest maker of machine tools agreed yesterday to plead guilty to conspiracy in cheating the government out of $34.3 million in taxes through what the I.R.S. called “deceptive and elaborate tax evasion schemes.”

headline: Russia: Swiss Reject Request for Yukos Records
text: A high court in Switzerland has sharply criticized Russia’s case against Yukos, the former Russian oil giant that was essentially put out of business by Russian prosecutors after its founder, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, clashed with President Vladimir V. Putin. In a decision released this week, the Swiss court denied the prosecutors’ efforts to obtain documents about Swiss operations of Yukos and suggested that the prosecutors had repeatedly abused their power. Mr. Khodorkovsky is serving an eight-year prison sentence in Siberia for tax evasion and fraud, charges that his supporters call trumped up.

headline: An Economist’s Task: Building a Model for His People
text: Ramallah, West Bank

headline: Difficult Cleanup Lies Ahead for Soaked Midwest
text: OTTAWA, Ohio, Aug. 24 — Hundreds of families were kept out of their homes here on Friday as Main Street remained at the bottom of a milelong lake created by flooding from the Blanchard River.

headline: Max Roach Is Remembered for Music and More
text: Max Roach was remembered at his funeral not just as a brilliant drummer who helped bring about radical changes in American music, but also as a committed activist who worked hard to bring about radical changes in American society.

headline: Southeast Queens Is Split Over Makeover Proposal
text: When Gloria Black looks into Jamaica’s future, she sees a grand restoration: Department stores will move into spaces where discount jewelers sell removable gold teeth; vacant storefronts, their windows taped up with yellowing newspaper, will fill one by one. The prosperous downtown of the 1960s — the one that drew families from Harlem and Brooklyn and South Carolina — will return to southeast Queens.

headline: Wall Street, Still a Little Wobbly, Steadies Itself
text: THE stock market steadied this week after more than a month of volatility, partly in reaction to the Federal Reserve’s decision on Aug. 17 to encourage banks to borrow directly from the Fed at a lower rate and help ease the credit squeeze that has been rattling the financial system.

headline: As Woes Grow, Mortgage Ads Keep Up Pitch
text: Wall Street may have soured on the mortgage business. But on television, radio and the Internet, the industry is as ebullient as ever.

headline: Military Says It Can Repair Guantánamo Trial Defects
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  In an effort to revive the war crimes trials at Guantánamo, military prosecutors argued on Friday in a special appeals court that defects in their cases identified by two military judges in June could be repaired and that the prosecutions could proceed.

headline: New Laws for Housing Tax Break
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed into law yesterday three bills to revamp a popular tax break for developers and encourage the construction of thousands of apartments for low-income New York City residents.

headline: A Detective Is Suspended Over Station House Escape
text: A police detective in Queens was suspended yesterday, a day after he let a nimble murder suspect escape from a third-floor window of a precinct station house during questioning, the police said.

headline: A Trainer Takes It Slow and Saddles Fast Horses
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24  Shug McGaughey is a patient man, and a prudent horse trainer. He does not feel compelled to enter horses in every big race; he shows up in them only when he believes he can win. He is here with Sightseeing for the Grade I, $1 million Travers Stakes on Saturday.

headline: Bank of China Shares Plunge
text: BEIJING, Aug. 24  After appearing immune to the turmoil engulfing the mortgage market in the United States, China suffered its first serious setback Friday from exposure to subprime loans.

headline: Ex-Klansman Is Sentenced to Life for Killings in 1964
text: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 24 — Calling the crime “unspeakable because only monsters could inflict this,” a federal judge on Friday sentenced a former member of the Ku Klux Klan to three life terms in prison for his role in the 1964 kidnapping and murder of two black teenagers in Mississippi.

headline: The Ones to Watch in Osaka
text: With an Olympics looming in Beijing next year, the world track and field championships that begin today in Osaka, Japan, are a nine-day prologue to the main event, complete with the requisite heat and humidity.

headline: Dollars for Sale
text: During the worst of the markets’ recent volatility, many investors moved their money into supersafe Treasury securities, temporarily boosting the dollar against the euro and the British pound. But of late, the dollar has resumed its downward trend of the past several years. And policy makers and currency traders are once again hypervigilant for signs that Asian central banks might redeploy part of their dollar-based debt holdings into non-American investments.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) THE DEPARTED (2006) Matt Damon plays Colin Sullivan, the boyish but sinister protége of an Irish- American mobster (Jack Nicholson, far left with Mr. Damon) who goes undercover as a state police officer; Leonard DiCaprio is Billy Costigan, a state cop who infiltrates the underworld and slowly loses his grip. Now each organization has discovered that it has a mole in its midst. Martin Scorsese won his long-awaited Academy Award for best director with this crime thriller, based on the Hong Kong film “Infernal Affairs,” which also snared Oscars for best picture, best editing (the wondrous Thelma Schoonmaker) and best adapted screenplay (William Monahan). Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis gave a nod to Alec Baldwin and Mark Wahlberg in their roles as detectives: “As do the rest of the actors, they prove that what really counts here, in the end, isn’t the film, but all its swaggering men.”

headline: Choi Has Firm Grip on Greens and the Leader Board
text: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 24 — In the midst of a wicked putting slump two years ago, K. J. Choi resorted to the well-worn path of the 30-handicapper: He watched an infomercial that all but promised to change his life.

headline: Women in NASA Triangle Face Each Other in Court
text: ORLANDO, Fla., Aug. 24 — The first time Capt. Lisa M. Nowak met Capt. Colleen Shipman was seven months ago in a parking lot at Orlando International Airport. They were together again on Friday, in a tense courtroom.

headline: A Vietnam Quagmire of One’s Own (7 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: With Troop Rise, Iraqi Detainees Soar in Number
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 — The number of detainees held by the American-led military forces in Iraq has swelled by 50 percent under the troop increase ordered by President Bush, with the inmate population growing to 24,500 today from 16,000 in February, according to American military officers in Iraq.

headline: It’s Still Fat (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Generals Differ on the Timing of Troop Cuts
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 — As the Bush administration mulls options for withdrawing forces in Iraq, fault lines are beginning to emerge in a debate between commanders in the field who favor slow reductions and senior generals at the Pentagon who favor cutting the number of combat troops more deeply.

headline: After Warning, Contractor Got Bank Tower Job
text: The City Department of Investigation strongly cautioned Lower Manhattan development officials against using contractors with ties to a troubled demolition company to tear down the contaminated Deutsche Bank building, a person with knowledge of the events said yesterday. But development officials went ahead and approved such a company anyway.

headline: NASA Believes It Has Found Reason Foam Fell on Shuttle
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 — NASA engineers think they have found the cause of and a remedy for foam falling from brackets on the space shuttle fuel tank like that which recently damaged the Endeavour heat shield tiles, agency officials said Friday.

headline: If There’s a High-Definition TV in Your Future, Wait Till After the Holidays
text: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 — Consumers walking into an electronics store looking for a big-screen high-definition TV may find that the place looks and feels different from how it was last Christmas.

headline: New York’s Toxic Tower
text: With each day’s news about the dismantling of the old Deutsche Bank building at the World Trade Center site, blame for the deaths and injuries of New York firefighters spreads. Contractors, workers, inspectors, city and state officials — the list of the accused is growing extremely long. Enough. It is a time to find out what went wrong, fix it and devise a workable way to deconstruct this dangerous structure safely and soon.

headline: A Gift Offer for Artists in China: Museums
text: SHANGHAI, Aug. 24 — For years their work could not be exhibited in China, but now the country’s leading contemporary artists are being courted by major art collectors abroad and their paintings set records at international auction sales. A local government in Sichuan Province — the area in western China known for its natural beauty, spicy food and talented painters — is taking notice.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,716 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:

headline: Stopping Penny, Mets Help Pérez Win
text: The first seven innings went down like iced tea on an August afternoon. But no game, at least none that the Mets play, can end without the requisite nail-biting, Pepto-Bismol-swilling and head-shaking that have come to define the first three games of their homestand. So it was that last night, in the ninth inning, with the Mets clinging to a four-run lead, the Los Angeles Dodgers loaded the bases against Billy Wagner with one out to recall all those not-so-fond recent memories.

headline: Georgia Says It Fired on a Military Craft Violating Airspace
text: MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 25  Georgian police forces fired machine guns at an unidentified military aircraft that violated a remote area of Georgian airspace on Wednesday, a senior Georgian official said early on Saturday.

headline: A Summer Island Rallies Around Its Aging Chapel
text: COUSINS ISLAND, Me. — Gray-shingled with an inviting porch, this little island’s tiny chapel looks like a summer home, its stained-glass windows the only sign that it is something more.

headline: Jet That Helped Defeat an Alaska Governor Is Sold
text: It grounded one governor and did not exactly fly off the shelf on eBay, but the jet that came to symbolize the troubles of the former Alaska governor Frank H. Murkowski has landed with a new owner.

headline: Iraqi Factions’ Self-Interest Blocks Political Progress
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 24 — The National Intelligence Estimate released Thursday illustrated convincingly that, despite the troop buildup, Iraq has failed to forge the political reconciliation that could lead to long-term security and economic growth.

headline: U.S. Bomb Dropped; 3 British Soldiers Die
text: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan, Aug. 24 — Three British soldiers died in southern Afghanistan on Thursday in an apparent friendly-fire episode involving a bomb dropped by an American plane, British officials said Friday.

headline: Greece: Fires Claim 15 Lives
text: At least 15 people died as at least 140 forest fires raged out of control in the southern Peloponnesian peninsula. Fueled by winds and a three-day heat wave with temperatures up to 104 degrees that left forests and scrubland parched, the blazes, some of the worst in a decade, destroyed scores of homes and thousands of acres. The high winds prevented firefighting planes from taking off, news accounts said, leaving just ground forces to fight the fires. The emergency brought an appeal by the government for “urgent help” from other European Union countries. News reports said some of the victims had been trapped by flames near their homes and in their cars as they tried to flee. Tourists were also reported to be among the dead. With national elections in less than a month and public outrage already high over the government’s handling of a rash of earlier fires, the governing conservatives called for a 24-hour suspension of campaigning as act of mourning for those killed in yesterday’s infernos.

headline: In Court Ruling, Noriega Is Cleared for Extradition to France
text: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 24 — A federal judge in Miami paved the way Friday for Manuel Noriega, the former Panamanian general ousted by the American military in 1989, to face money laundering charges in France once his prison term in the United States ends next month.

headline: At 70, McCain Takes On Talk of His Age
text: Senator John McCain was fielding questions at a town-hall-style meeting earlier this month in Ankeny, Iowa, when a woman raised her hand and asked him, “from one white head to another white head,” why he wanted to be president in such troubled times.

headline: Quake Orphan Reflects Peru’s Loss, and Anger
text: PISCO, Peru, Aug. 23 — Through the choking smoke and with little light to guide him, Luis Palomino dug furiously through the rubble of the San Clemente church here two hours after last week’s earthquake buried parishioners under a pile of adobe stones.

headline: Germany to Ease Limits on Some Foreign Workers
text: BERLIN, Aug. 24 — In a major shift in policy, the German government announced Friday that it would ease labor restrictions for skilled workers from East European members of the European Union in an effort to overcome serious shortages in key economic sectors.

headline: Suspect Is Charged in Sexual Attacks in Miami and New York
text: A man the authorities said sexually assaulted three women in Miami and a homeless woman in Manhattan was tracked down after a two-year manhunt and arrested this week in Queens, the New York police said last night.

headline: Two Big Law Firms in Merger Talks
text: Two major American law firms are in advanced talks about a merger that would create one of the nation’s biggest legal advisers, a person briefed on the matter said yesterday.

headline: Praising Private Equity
text: THE conventional wisdom is that private equity firms are focused strictly on the short term.

headline: Experts May Have Found Remains of Czar’s Children
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 24 — Scientists in a Russian provincial capital say they may have unearthed the remains of two of Czar Nicholas II’s children, and are hoping to solve one of the enduring mysteries surrounding the start of the Bolshevik revolution.

headline: A Top Sprinter Learns to Push Himself
text: OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 24 — Tyson Gay’s secret to becoming the fastest man in the world this year is tucked away in a tattered three-ring binder.

headline: A Guiding Hand on Icy Terrain
text: TUCSON, Aug. 21  The sun was a blistering spotlight on the desert landscape. Inside a resort hotel, John W. Schutt, mountaineer and guide to uninhabitable terrain, spoke of crevasses and ice fields, snowmobile convoys and the frozen, wind-swept places where he has spent most of his life.

headline: Altria Board to Consider a Spinoff Overseas
text: The maker of the world’s most popular cigarette, Marlboro, may decide next week that American consumers are too much trouble.

headline: Turkey: Presidency Remains Deadlocked
text: Abdullah Gul, the foreign minister and candidate of the governing party, again failed to win a two-thirds majority of votes in Parliament to become president. He is widely expected to cinch the post in a third round of voting next week, when only a simple majority will be needed.

headline: Subway Supervisor Is Demoted for His Role in Fatal Acccident
text: The superintendent who investigators said was partly responsible for the death of a subway track worker has been demoted and will be assigned to a job as a cleaner, a person with knowledge of the disciplinary action said yesterday.

headline: Little Room for Shorter Players on the Beach
text: Finding attractive players has never been a problem in professional beach volleyball, as is evident at the A.V.P. Brooklyn Open tournament on Coney Island, where world and Olympic champions will compete through Sunday. But it takes more than ripped abs and skimpy swimsuits to help fans appreciate the game.

headline: In the Corner With the Gladiators: Trying Out the Life of the Cut Man
text: I GRABBED the mixed martial arts fighter Delson Heleno by the back of the neck and stared into his fiery brown eyes. Delson is a Brazilian-born welterweight, 29 years old, 5 foot 11 and 170 pounds, with a coffee-colored complexion and cauliflower ears. His shaved head was glistening with sweat and his chest heaved in anticipation of his bout in the International Fight League World Championship Semifinal.

headline: Soggy, Endless Night in Motown
text: After a four-hour rain delay, it might be past Joba Chamberlain’s bed time.

headline: A Threatened Future for Solidarity’s Birthplace
text: The Gdansk shipyard in Poland may be forced in to bankruptcy as it faces European regulators and a modernizing economy that has left it behind.

headline: F1 travel advice diary
text: Yesterday I put up no blog post, due to reasons of F1 logistical difficulties. I want to share those difficulties with you in order to A) Help readers with their own F1 travel plans, B) Give another angle to behind the scenes information, and C) Complain.

headline: It’s China vs. Russia, and China Leads
text: Halfway through a team match between China and Russia in the Russian city of Nizhniy Novgorod, China leads 27.5-22.5. The match started Aug. 20 and ends Aug. 30. Today is a rest day for the team match, which resumes tomorrow. The Russian Chess Federation’s Web site is covering the match, but it is all in Cyrillic. Chessbase.com and The Week in Chess are also following the match and they have the virtue for English speakers of not being in Cyrillic.

headline: Poli-Book Best Sellers for August
text: With this month coming to a close, a few new titles have quickly moved onto the political best seller list of The Caucus, including books by two senators in the 2008 presidential race.

headline: 2008: Judgment Day for Florida Democrats
text: Florida Democrats are once again crying disenfranchisement — this time pointing the finger at the Democratic National Committee. Party officials are set to vote today on whether to punish the Sunshine State for moving its primary up too far, to Jan. 29. The D.N.C. could eliminate all of the state party’s delegates to the national nominating convention in 2008 and bar candidates from campaigning there before the primary.

headline: Going Down to Yasgur’s Farm…
text: Yasgur’s farm in upstate New York

A news analysis article on Thursday about President Bush's speech comparing the mission in Iraq to other wars described imprecisely the timing of the American withdrawal from Vietnam. While President Johnson in 1968 refused requests from commanders to increase the military commitment in Vietnam by hundreds of thousands of troops, the reduction in forces began in 1969, not 1968.

A listing of American military deaths on Monday included erroneous information provided by the Department of Defense on the surname of a soldier killed in Iraq. His legal name was Willard M. Powell, not Willard M. Kerchief III.

A front-page article on Wednesday about a report by the Central Intelligence Agency's inspector general twice misspelled the name of one of the Sept. 11 hijackers. The correct spelling is Nawaf al-Hazmi, not Nawaf al-Hamzi.

headline: The Wonder Room
text: Selfridges in London has gone from high street to high end with the Wonder Room (right), its new luxury jewelry and gift emporium set to open Sept. 1. Shoppers who enter the 19,000-square-foot space from bustling Oxford Street will be able to stroll through an arcade of miniboutiques hawking such big-ticket items as Tiffany diamonds and Chanel fine jewelry, pause for a glass of wine in the Wonder Bar, then duck into a Dover Street Market-like concept store featuring an ever-changing bazaar of obscure perfumes, first-edition books, rare teas and other curiosities. "We didn't want the space to have a precious, museumlike quality," explains Anne Pitcher, the buying and merchandising director for Selfridges. "It's entirely accessible. It's Hermès to Chrome Hearts, with a wall of sunglasses in between, and that's the fun of it."

headline: When It Comes to Foreign Policy, What Counts as Experience?
text: In her web column today, Helene Cooper writes that a president’s job history only tells half the story about foreign policy:

headline: Belated Thoughts on Friday Night
text: There were a couple things from last night’s game that I didn’t have room to get in the paper. So here goes:

headline: Environmental Cost of China's Growth
text: When the Chinese government tried to calculate a national "Green G.D.P.," the formula showed the soaring economy in a more sober light.

headline: D.N.C. Sanctions Sunshine State
text: The Democratic National Committee took steps today to punish Florida Democrats for deciding to hold the state’s party primary on Jan. 29, 2008 — a week before the first date allowable under D.N.C. rules.

headline: Join the Conversation
text: Welcome to our roundtable discussion of China’s environment, part of our ongoing series, “Choking on Growth.” Throughout the week, a panel of scholars and environmentalists will take turns answering your questions on the political, social, scientific and economic challenges posed by the country’s rapid industrialization and equally sudden pollution crisis.

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, Aug. 26
text: Well, even in the last days of August, some of the presidential candidates will still be appearing on the Sunday news-talk shows. Very few, if any, are taking vacations right now.

headline: Players to Watch
text: Darren McFadden, tailback, Arkansas Finished second in the Heisman voting last season after showing he could run, throw and carry a team. His next trick: overcoming the instability in Fayetteville.

headline: Some Faces New and Old
text: Nick Saban, Alabama Coach Saban’s hefty contract gives four million reasons he will be the most-talked-about coach in the Southeastern Conference, if not the country, this season. Assignment No. 1: rehab a ragtag defense.

headline: Conference Outlook, Part 2
text: By Fred Bierman

headline: Conference Outlook, Part 1
text: By Fred Bierman

headline: Can Brennan Make the Leap From Hawaii to the N.F.L.?
text: HONOLULU – Hawaii Coach June Jones has been evaluating N.F.L. quarterbacks for 20 years as a player in the league, an assistant coach and a head coach.

headline: Welcome to The Quad
text: It’s been nearly eight months since the final, hoarse chants of, “Its Great/To Be/A Florida Gator” echoed through a steamy Arizona night after college football’s national title game. They were the final strains of a riveting football season that was packed with epic games, high drama and a surprise ending.

headline: Dirty China
text: The New York Times today starts a series on China’s pollution woes, a problem whose magnitude is enormous and will be difficult to solve. Some of the statistics are bound to shock: Of China’s 560 million urban dwellers only 1 per cent breathe air that meets European Union air quality safety standards.

headline: Jets and Giants: Can You Feel the Excitement?
text: People are elbowing their way into Giants Stadium, getting ready to watch the annual preseason game between the Jets and Giants. A half-hour from game time, there must be, oh, 1,247 people in the stands. If they would quit going to the beer line, we could get an accurate count.

headline: Torre Puts His Trust in Tampa. No, Really, He Does.
text: In past years, Joe Torre might have gotten a suggestion on pitching coming from Tampa, Fla., and ignored it. Billy Connors, a confidant of George Steinbrenner’s and a nemesis of the former pitching coach Mel Stottlemyre, was the organization’s pitching guru.

headline: Like the Virgins
text: Your window to brag that you knew the Virgins when is about to close. Until last year, they had no label, no shows and no record, so knowledge about this cool New York band was strictly by hipster word of mouth. Donald Cumming and Wade Oates met while modeling on a Ryan McGinley shoot in Mexico and decided to start a band to play the songs that Cumming had been recording in his East Village bedroom. They had barely recruited Nick Zarin-Ackerman and Erik Ratensperger and sent out demos before they were opening for Patti Smith and Sonic Youth and touring with Jet. It didn’t hurt that the model Jessica Stam was seen wearing their T-shirt backstage at the Lanvin show. As for the actual music (expect a major-label album in the new year), think the Strokes you can dance to.

headline: Drop Foreseen in Median Price of U.S. Homes
text: The median price of American homes is expected to fall this year for the first time since federal housing agencies began keeping statistics in 1950.

headline: Just How Contagious Is That Hedge Fund?
Once Again, City Police Say Suspect Has Escaped
text: In an embarrassing turn for the police department, a 17-year-old suspected of attempted robbery sneaked out of a Brooklyn precinct house early Friday. He was the second suspect to escape a city station house in less than 24 hours, and like the first man, appeared to have made his getaway by leaping from a window.

headline: Covering the Bases
text: Milestone Tracker

headline: Christine Green, Paul Jarrett
text: Christine Lorraine Green, the daughter of Kathleen B. Green and David R. Green of East Greenwich, R.I., was married yesterday to Paul McGarty Jarrett, a son of Maureen O. McGarty and Dr. David B. Jarrett, both of Athens, Ga. The Rev. Charles F. Flagg, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Governor Henry Lippitt House Museum in Providence.

headline: Diet by the Sword
text: I am trying not to think what Freud would say about this roomful of mostly women brandishing big sticks. At Equinox on Broadway and 19th Street, we stand in rows facing a mirror, eyes trained on our wooden swords as well as on our leader, Ilaria Montagnani. Moving to the beat of music that sounds like rhythmic jackhammering, we squat, lunge, slice and slash. The class is called Forza. The footwork is simple, and there are only 13 sword moves. The difficulty comes in making each cut precise, putting the whole body behind the swing and controlling the stick.

headline: Virginia Tech’s Grief (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Maria Ostrovsky, Andrew Fagenholz
text: Maria Ostrovsky, the daughter of Olga Ostrovsky and Zinovy Ostrovsky of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Andrew David Fagenholz, a son of Dr. Linda S. Fagenholz and Dr. S. Allen Fagenholz of Erie, Pa. Rabbi Stephen A. Klein officiated at Tarrytown House, a hotel in Tarrytown, N.Y.

headline: Spirits in the Material World
text: If recent history has revealed an appalling tolerance for prognosticators who are invariably, fatally wrong, it has also been unjust to the farsighted augurs who somehow always manage to get it right. When an author has correctly anticipated the extent to which people’s identities would someday be defined by their presence on the Internet, foreseen how the medium would generate its own pantheon of heroes and villains with nicknames like Essjay and lonelygirl15, and even name-checked the Japanese Harajuku scene before it could be hijacked by Gwen Stefani, he tends to have certain labels attached to him, like an old beater priced to sell at a used car lot: prophet, visionary, futurist. But what if he just wants to be a writer?

headline: Correction: The Road to Clarity
text: An article on Aug. 12 about typographical changes in American road signs refers erroneously to one adaptation of the Clearview typeface for standard design applications. A Greek version is planned; it does not yet exist.

headline: Editorial Notebook: A Big Thinker From a Small Town Exits Politics
text: Keith Robbins, a 38-year-old Republican, has been the first selectman in the small town of Bozrah for eight years. But there is nothing small about the way he thinks. He is president of the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities and has, for two years in a row, led the Southeastern Connecticut Council of Governments.

headline: In Nature’s Casino
text: It was Aug. 24, 2005, and New Orleans was still charming. Tropical Depression 12 was spinning from the Bahamas toward Florida, but the chances of an American city’s being destroyed by nature were remote, even for one below sea level. An entire industry of weather bookies — scientists who calculate the likelihood of various natural disasters — had in effect set the odds: a storm that destroys $70 billion of insured property should strike the United States only once every 100 years. New Orleanians had made an art form of ignoring threats far more likely than this; indeed, their carelessness was a big reason they were supposedly more charming than other Americans. And it was true: New Orleanians found pleasure even in oblivion. But in their blindness to certain threats, they could not have been more typically American. From Miami to San Francisco, the nation’s priciest real estate now faced beaches and straddled fault lines; its most vibrant cities occupied its most hazardous land. If, after World War II, you had set out to redistribute wealth to maximize the sums that might be lost to nature, you couldn’t have done much better than Americans had done. And virtually no one — not even the weather bookies — fully understood the true odds.

headline: Capturing Bob: A Family Affair
text: The only person in fashion more wonderfully deranged than the outlaw photographer Terry Richardson was, not surprisingly, his father. Throughout the 1960s and ’70s, Bob Richardson’s highly charged blackand-white images brought somber emotion to the glossy but sometimes sterile world of fashion. Much of Richardson’s oeuvre was destroyed during his erratic career, which was marked by mental illness and homelessness. The first comprehensive overview of his work is being published this fall, including his unfinished autobiography. Edited by his son, “Bob Richardson” (Grafiche Damiani) features a wide range of his best work, like his daring assignments for Harper’s Bazaar — one infamous piece featured the model Donna Mitchel in tears — and early portraits of Anjelica Huston, then his girlfriend. “I am not ashamed of anything,” he said in 2002, three years before his death at the age of 77. “I have no secrets. I am free.”

headline: At a Home Office, Life’s Little Interruptions
text: MORNINGS my wife drives off to work, while I go down to my office in the back of the house and start reporting and writing.

headline: The Golden Gate, Brought to You by ...
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 — There are no naming rights on the table and there will not be any logo-bearing neon signs, tower-to-tower banners or screaming billboards put up, either. That might ruin the view.

headline: Have Clipboard, Will Canvass
text: KATIE GOLIEB assumed her ready position in the middle of a Park Slope sidewalk: wide stance, hips swaying, clipboard cradled in her right arm. An approaching woman in heels and a skirt, seeing that she had been marked, quickened her step, but not before Ms. Golieb called out to her.

headline: Court Won’t Hear Battle Over Embryos
text: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 25 (AP)  The Texas Supreme Court has refused to consider the case of a woman who wanted custody of three frozen embryos after her divorce.

headline: Family Blessings
text: Not long ago while leaving a restaurant in Brooklyn, I walked into a strange and holy ritual. A red-haired priest in black suit and white clerical collar was out on the sidewalk blessing an iguana. Scales iridescent in the sun, the reptile looked like a small dragon. People gathered around and the sacrament had the undeniable air of divinity. After the priest made the sign of the cross over the lizard, he moved into the restaurant surrounded by true believers urging him to bless their son, their baby, their little yappy dog.

headline: Revved-Up Reflections
text: I’M a firm believer that loud tailpipes save lives,” said Justin Theroux, as he pointed his matte black Ducati motorcycle down West Fourth Street on a recent Sunday and jerked the throttle, sending out a jet-level whine that ripped a gash in the evening calm surrounding Washington Square Park.

headline: The New Halston?
text: When Harvey Weinstein announced this spring that he was going into the dress business, a couple of magazines made a fuss, but for the most part the fashion people treated him exactly as they would any newcomer. They regarded him with surprise and suspicion. It makes no difference that Weinstein is a successful producer of movies (he and his brother, Bob, started Miramax Films) and that those movies defied all kinds of conventions to win a total of 45 Oscars. Nor is there anything about his person that would send a fashion editor up the wall. He is polite, gregarious, at times charming. None of the bad faults for which he is legendary in Hollywood — the screaming, the harassing — are on display in fashion circles. And maybe it is for that reason that something about the sight of this bearish hetero sitting among the thin, knowing fashionistas compels sympathy as much as bemusement. Instead of getting in someone’s face, Weinstein, in this environment, has the companionable air of a man holding out his mitts so his wife can unwind her knitting yarn.

headline: Adena Halpern, Jonathan Goldstein
text: Adena Halpern, an author, is to be married this evening to Jonathan M. Goldstein, a television writer and producer. Rabbi Jeffrey A. Marx is to officiate at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles.
