Don’t Replace It, Rehabilitate It; Free H.I.V. Tests
at Planned Parenthood; Farmers’ Market in New Rochelle; Old Neighborhoods, New Highways (4 Letters)
text: Don’t Replace It, Rehabilitate It

headline: Grace Paley, a Loud Voice
text: Grace Paley, writer and social activist, died last week at 84. Her tragicomic short stories, rich with everyday dialogue, often chronicled the lives of women — generally Jewish New Yorkers. The following is an excerpt from “The Loudest Voice” in the collection “The Little Disturbances of Man”:

headline: Driver Charged After One Is Killed and Three Are Hurt in Crash in the Village
text: A delivery worker was killed and three others were injured early yesterday when a drunken driver crashed a sport utility vehicle into their parked van at an intersection in Greenwich Village, the police said.

headline: Spain’s Quiet Corner
text: FOR over 50 years all this was in ruins,” said José Luis Cuerda, hands spread, nodding toward a mountainside covered with terraced rows of young winding vines and the massive stone home behind us, his adopted Galician sliver of Spain. Stretched out before him now, spilling from lush terraces, were fledgling plants: albariño, treixadura, godello, torrontés, loureira. These are grape varietals native to the Ribeiro, a region of broad valleys near Ourense, the capital of the province of the same name.

headline: A Farmhand With an Arm for Fastballs
text: MONTAUK

headline: In a Long Parade, Local Winners
text: Osprey’s Dominion and Pindar, both in Peconic, fared best among Long Island’s wineries in the 22nd annual New York Wine and Food Classic this month.

headline: Unease in the Air and Revenge on the Screen
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: The Art of Collaboration: One Vision, Many Hands
text: FOR most of her career, Marcy B. Freedman, a video and performance artist in Peekskill, worked alone. Then she met Gene Panczenko, another video artist there, and things changed. The two joined forces, marrying his technical expertise and her ideas. “Gene was my first collaborator,” Ms. Freedman, 57, said. “Our first project went so well that I was inspired to do more.”

headline: Sexual Preference
text: I swooned at the sight of Cécilia Sarkozy at her husband’s inauguration in May. In her champagne silk Prada dress, the bodice stroking her torso, tiny pleats opening up at her waist and the skirt falling gracefully over the knees, she looked fresh, modern and sensual. And I wasn’t the only fashion editor to salute this injection of glamour into a world usually dominated by pantsuits and momsy coat-and-dress combos. The French fashion press was even comparing her to Jacqueline Kennedy during the White House years.

headline: Companionship, and a Good Deal
text: Two photographs with the continuation of the Hunt article last Sunday, about three people from suburban Milwaukee who ultimately found an apartment together in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, were reversed. The picture on the far left showed the building on Fourth Avenue described in the adjacent caption, and the second picture from the left showed the building on Court Street described in the leftmost caption.

headline: A Brighter Future for the Edison Tower
text: MENLO PARK

headline: It’s No Hydrant, but This Hardware Plays a Critical Role in Fires
text: The fatal fire at the Deutsche Bank building last weekend has called attention to some inconspicuous but ubiquitous New York street hardware: the two-headed pipes in front of every mid-rise and high-rise building.

headline: Marriage on TV; Workspace; ‘Bonnie and Clyde’; Mumblecore
text: MARRIAGE ON TV

headline: Wassup? Docs
text: At the fall shows, the catwalks reverberatedwith the sound of stomping boots as Dr. Martens — those Humvees of footwear and artifacts of a million misspent youths — enjoyed a fashion moment. Yohji Yamamoto spearheaded the return, collaborating with the brand to create a limited-edition line; chunky lace-up boots also lent a subversive edge to feminine frocks at Chloé.

headline: Eye Spy
text: Perched on the edge of her seat in a passenger lounge at La Guardia Airport, Clarissa Dalrymple rears back from her carry-on, aghast. “Damn it!” she says in a booming stage whisper. “I forgot my pearls.”

headline: Never Mind the Monologue: Audition by Endurance
text: SIX feet off the ground, on a treadmill in a darkened theater, J. D. Smith was running, really pounding it, his forehead blistered with sweat, his white shirt billowing. Suddenly he stumbled, his legs moving but not connecting, like a colt’s. He doubled over. But just as quickly he righted himself, and the pounding began again. Then he heaved forward, falling face first toward the ground.

headline: Getting Honest About Gambling
text: This year, after 10 years of avoiding the issue, the Connecticut General Assembly authorized a study to examine the effect of gambling on the state as a whole. This is a good step forward. After all, Connecticut is home to two casinos, Mohegan Sun and Foxwoods, that are among the world’s largest. The state’s lottery offers numerous games of chance, sold by about 3,000 vendors. And while gambling is harmless fun for many adults, it is a serious problem for some. It is therefore important for the state to get a balanced picture.

headline: History Boy
text: Chris Benz may be originally from Seattle, but don’t expect his customers to rock out in lumberjack flannels or defaced denim. “I like the ease and recklessness of grunge, but I’m not into holes,” says the 24-year-old Parsons graduate (top), who was awarded a Council of Fashion Designers of America scholarship before interning for Marc Jacobs and working for J. Crew. His debut collection (go to www.chris-benz.com) was inspired by old-school glamour: the jazz-era shirtdresses, mohair jackets, mink jockey caps and twill jodhpurs had a flapper-meets-slacker vibe that never seemed stagey. “I’ll do slouchy pants with low belt loops and a wallet chain for a tomboy look,” he says. “But I’m just as likely to put a chiffon flower on a blouse that Jordan Baker might have worn in ‘The Great Gatsby.’ ” He says his historical eclectism comes from a childhood spent rummaging through his grandmother’s attic. Cedar chips and old clothes? Just don’t call it grunge.

headline: Chandra Ahamed, Juan Grisanty
text: Chandra Sarene Ahamed, a daughter of Ann Ahamed and Dr. Sultan Ahamed of Mystic, Conn., was married yesterday to Juan C. Grisanty, a son of Celeste Reyes and Carlos Grisanty, both of Santo Domingo, the Dominican Republic. The Rev. Grzegorz P. Brozonowicz, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mary Mother of the Redeemer Church in Groton, Conn.

headline: Kelli O’Hara and Greg Naughton
text: AS performers, Kelli O’Hara and Greg Naughton know that show business relationships are more notable for their drama than for their longevity. Yet, this couple is betting that theirs will be a long run.

headline: Inside the Countrywide Lending Spree
text: ON its way to becoming the nation’s largest mortgage lender, the Countrywide Financial Corporation encouraged its sales force to court customers over the telephone with a seductive pitch that seldom varied. “I want to be sure you are getting the best loan possible,” the sales representatives would say.

headline: David Greenspan
text: AGE: 51 YEARS WORKING: 29 HIGHEST INCOME IN THE LAST 10 YEARS: $50,000 in 2002, which included an award from the California Institute of the Arts LEAST IN THE LAST 10 YEARS: $25,000 LAST SEEN IN: “The Argument,” which he also wrote, for the Target Margin Theater

headline: The Saxophone Man, and the Music of the Spheres
text: THE Starbucks at Fifth Avenue and 33rd Street, near the foot of the Empire State Building, is a surprisingly busy place on a Friday night, with groups of teenagers drifting from table to table and eyeing one another over cups of coffee.

headline: Tales From Tehran
text: Your first novel, “The Septembers of Shiraz,” has become a surprise hit, in part because it so vividly captures the veiled world of post-revolutionary Iran and the unjust fate of one Isaac Amin, a Jewish rare-gem dealer who winds up in jail. Is the novel at all autobiographical? It’s loosely based on my family’s experiences. When I was 8, my father was arrested for being a Zionist spy. We didn’t know where he was. My mom would go out looking for him. And then he just reappeared one day, about a month later.

headline: Too Rich
text: To the Editor:

headline: Universal Faith
text: Another school year, another round of controversy about religion in public education. This fall, two new yet already divisive publicly financed schools are set to open: the Khalil Gibran International Academy in Brooklyn and the Ben Gamla Charter School in Hollywood, Fla. Both describe themselves as nonsectarian institutions that emphasize a particular language — Arabic and Hebrew, respectively — and both have been criticized on the assumption that they will be organized around the distinctive cultures (and thus religions) associated with those languages. Meanwhile, at the University of Michigan at Dearborn, a small firestorm has erupted over plans to install foot baths in school washrooms to help Muslim students perform the ablutions required for daily prayer.

headline: Yonkers Keeps Going for the Green
text: YONKERS, the jewel of the Hudson? That’s the plan. Adding more green space to balance new high-density housing, Mayor Philip A. Amicone last week announced the dedication of seven acres of parkland downtown, most of it on the riverfront.

headline: John W. Gofman, 88, Scientist and Advocate for Nuclear Safety, Dies
text: Dr. John W. Gofman, a nuclear chemist and doctor who in the 1960s heightened public concerns about exposure to low-level radiation and became a leading voice against commercial nuclear power, died on Aug. 15 at his home in San Francisco. He was 88.

headline: The Politics of Appearance
text: So shoot me: at the end of the day (and the beginning, if it comes to that), in the high-definition show business of politics — as in everything else — looks matter. Appearance, whether we like it or not, has become the coin of the realm, the locus of our conversation: in our image-saturated, relentlessly scrutinizing Visual Age, we trade in it, subliminally or overtly, whether we are talking of Victoria Beckham or Hillary Clinton. “All meaningful discourse seeks to end appearances,” the sociologist Jean Baudrillard observes in his landmark 1979 book, “Seduction,” but then goes on to note that “it is also an impossible undertaking.”

headline: Op-Chart: A New, Improved Congress?
text: JUST before Congress adjourned for its August recess, Democrats engaged in a flurry of legislative activity, while Republicans complained about a “do-nothing” Congress’s meager policy accomplishments. Deep partisan differences, narrow majorities and a Republican in the White House have frustrated Democratic ambitions and fueled a toxic atmosphere in both chambers of Congress. The public’s low approval ratings reflect broad discontent with the direction of the country but also displeasure with Congress for failing to reverse course on Iraq and for continuing the bitter partisan warfare.

headline: Manhattan House Fight Escalates
text: THE huge $1.1 billion redevelopment of the Manhattan House on East 66th Street was to be the biggest condo conversion deal ever for Prudential Douglas Elliman and its best-selling broker, Dolly Lenz.

headline: Christine Terlep, Dylan Murphy
text: Christine Marie Terlep, the daughter of Kathleen M. Terlep of Kensington, Md., and the late Vincent B. Terlep Jr., was married yesterday to Dylan John Murphy, the son of Monica D. Murphy and John J. Murphy Jr. of Manhattan. Cardinal Avery Dulles, a Jesuit theologian at Fordham, performed the ceremony at Fordham University Church in the Bronx.

headline: Play It Again (and Send My Lawyer a Check)
text: WESTPORT

headline: Endless Summer Job
text: In 1982, after my sophomore year of college, an agency arranged a summer job for me: a couple needed someone to assist the cook at their estate in the Hamptons. My friends couldn’t believe I would sink so low — why not stay in the city, they asked, and attend rallies protesting apartheid? But the truth was that I was poor and really needed money for the school year.

headline: Politicizing a Triple Murder
text: Common sense tells us that the one thing Newark does not need after its triple murder this month is a bunch of presidential hopefuls trying to exploit the situation. Unfortunately, that is exactly what the city is getting — first from Rudolph Giuliani, then from a much longer shot for the Republican presidential nomination, Tom Tancredo. Both have been trying to make political hay out of an unfortunate police error instead of addressing larger problems.

headline: Sequels: Stay Fresh or Die Hard
text: I BLAME “Aliens.” Even though, 12 years earlier, in 1974, “The Godfather: Part II” had proven that a sequel could be both financially and critically successful, it was James Cameron’s exhilarating monsters-meet-the-military take on Ridley Scott’s elegant space nightmare “Alien” that really stirred things up. Changing directors and adding writers, “Aliens” showed that you could significantly alter the mood, visual grammar and overall sensibility of the original, please critics and still recoup almost five times your production costs. More than any sequel before it, “Aliens” demonstrated that a good idea — and a female action hero in minimal underwear — had legs.

headline: Sexual Politics
text: I am a lawyer. During a first date with another lawyer, we had sex, and I wore a condom. Days later, when I came down with a bad fever and couldn’t determine the cause, she revealed that she had genital herpes. A judgeship will soon open up in her county, and she’s a near lock for it. But if I report her lapse of sexual ethics, I doubt that the selection committee will pick her. Should I? — NAME WITHHELD

headline: Calendar of Events
text: FILM

headline: Terror Bombings Kill Dozens in South India
text: NEW DELHI, Aug. 25  A pair of synchronized explosions tore through two popular spots in the southern Indian city of Hyderabad on Saturday evening, killing at least 30 people and wounding 60 others in what state officials called a terrorist attack.

headline: A Lively Taste of the Pacific
text: Pacific breezes cool the vines and keep grapes fresh in the Casablanca Valley, a young wine region west of Santiago, Chile, that is best known for whites.

headline: 87, Square and Ever So There
text: MALIBU, Calif.

headline: 36 Hours in Ottawa
text: OTTAWA has always had image problems. Back in 1857, when it beat out its rivals Toronto and Montreal in a bid to become Canada's national capital, the Governor General bemoaned Parliament's move to what seemed a frontier outpost on the Ottawa River as an “exile to wilderness.” Since then, this city of 1.2 million has been written off as a staid hub of government. But beneath Ottawa's buttoned-up, civil-servant demeanor lies a surprisingly vibrant community, with enough green space, trails and water within city limits to satisfy the most hyperactive of travelers. (Go ahead, call it the San Francisco of eastern Canada — it's worthy.) This summer, as the unlikely capital celebrates its 150th anniversary, Ottawa is embracing its wilder side.

headline: Let the Dames Begin
text: Hugh Johnson, a serious if eccentric wine writer, did a delightful pop-up book years ago about hosting a fantasy dinner. Since it was his fantasy, he had dibs on the guests and the wines, and so entertained Napoleon, Sir Winston Churchill and other high-ranking poobahs. The Samurai Sipper has often fantasized similarly, only I’d pass on Thomas Jefferson an d have Edie Falco over for a post-Carmela henfest instead. I’d toy with serving a pinot grigio from Lorraine Bracco’s vineyards in Italy, but would decide that’s overkill. A 2003 Rosso del Soprano from Astor Wines and Spirits, 399 Lafayette Street, is hardly subtle. Still, Edie might be struck by the wine’s wild grapes, grown since antiquity in Messina, and by my $150,000 Steinway & Sons Model D music system, which didn’t fall off a truck.

headline: Minding the Meeting, or Your Computer?
text: BACK in 1994, when portable PCs started their descent from 15-pound luggables to today’s 5-pound laptops, I started taking mine to meetings at Microsoft, and so did my colleagues. So novel. So useful.

headline: Wang Gives Weary Yankees Exactly What They Need
text: DETROIT, Aug. 25  Before he shut off his cellphone on Saturday morning, Joe Torre took one last call as he wearily returned to the Yankees’ suburban hotel around 4:30 a.m. It was Brian Cashman, the general manager, asking Torre if he needed a fresh pitcher for Saturday.

headline: The Sound and the Fury, and Possibly the Danger
text: BRISTOL, Tenn., Aug. 25 — The roar of nearly 50 revving engines reverberated through the mostly empty stands Friday at Bristol Motor Speedway as Nascar’s elite Nextel Cup teams took to the half-mile oval racetrack for practice.

headline: Is There (Middle Class) Life After Maytag?
text: NEWTON, Iowa

headline: Calendar of Events
text: For Children

headline: Loves Sports, and Crayons Are Her Game
text: Mystic

headline: A Grand Gathering, but One With a Solemn Note
text: DENVER

headline: No Longer Boxed In
text: ONCE little Sophia Rückriegel began to crawl, all that her parents could think about was gaining more space. She bumped into furniture. Her toys consumed the living room.

headline: Jessica Roth, Ethan Lasser
text: Jessica Eileen Roth, the daughter of Marcia and Bruce J. Roth of Louisville, Ky., was married last evening to Ethan Weldon Lasser, the son of Lindsay G. Fisch and Lawrence J. Lasser, both of Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Chester Diamond officiated at the historic Henry Clay building in Louisville.

headline: We Who Are on Vacation in Rome Salute You
text: “I will endure to be burned, to be bound, to be beaten and to be killed by the sword” is not the typical oath uttered by tourists visiting Rome these days. But the Rome Cavalieri Hilton (www.cavalieri-hilton.it) aims to change all that with its gladiator training program.

headline: Blog Is the New Black
text: Are designers the new journalists? God help us, but it may be true, judging from the number of young talents who have taken to the keyboard. Sue Stemp, known for her thigh-baring cocktail frocks, has a Web site to chronicle the adventures of herself and her daughter, Kitty Babe. Hanuk Kim keeps a visual diary, which he e-mails to a select group; Chris Benz regularly reports on the goings-on in his West Village brownstone; and Hollywould’s Holly Dunlap says her site attracts an average of 80,000 hits a day. Hedi Slimane posts his austere photography on MySpace (above), which is also where the London avant-garde darling Gareth Pugh announces casting calls and requests for assistants. Even Donna Karan has given blogging a try, as a guest on HuffingtonPost.com. Her reason for doing so is clearly resonating with her colleagues: “I’ve simply gotten to a point in my life,” she wrote, “where I want to ‘address’ people, not simply ‘dress’ them.”

headline: A Field Trip for the Congestion Panel
text: The roster of panelists named to the 17-member commission to find ways to relieve traffic congestion in New York City is a mostly thoughtful and impressive one. Given that it includes both outspoken proponents and opponents of Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s proposal for congestion pricing, its meetings should be lively. They should also be open to the public, which will have to feel invested in any plan that has a hope of working. In addition, it’s vital that commission members be well-informed on the massive problem before them.

headline: Sixth Hole Finds Area Too Small for Miners
text: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 25 (AP) — The latest hole drilled into a collapsed mine where six men are trapped broke through into an area too small for the men to have survived in it, a lawyer for several of the men’s families said Saturday.

headline: The Blue Burbs
text: Anybody who insists on clinging to old stereotypes of the suburbs as rich, white and Republican will be pleasantly disappointed, in this region anyway. Long Island, a bastion of Republicanism since suburbia was invented there, is now pretty much blue, with Democrats controlling both county executive’s offices and legislatures, and big towns like Brookhaven, Babylon and Huntington.

headline: Nets Dancers Kick Up and Dig in Their Heels
text: The Nets Dancers tried a new routine last weekend: boot camp.

headline: Top Shelf
text: Don’t be surprised if the saleswoman at Saks asks for ID before she hands over Dior’s new L’Or de Vie La Crème. Laced with Chateau d’Yquem, it’s the latest in cosmetic hooch, at an intoxicating $320 a jar. Capitalizing on the fact that grape seeds are packed with antioxidants (the scourge of free radicals, those molecular demons behind wrinkles), the cosmetics industry has been hitting the bottle since 1995, when the French company Caudalie introduced a skin cream spiked with Bordeaux. Now even a scion of vintners is getting into the act. Davi, the new skin-care line by Carlo Mondavi, is a blend of grape leaf, fermented grape extract, green tea and other vitamin-loaded ingredients. But wine isn’t the only booze young Hollywood is packing for rehab these days. Thierry Mugler’s upcoming Angel La Part des Anges is a Cognac-inspired scent that is aged in cherry wood to produce a richer, plummier nose. Japan’s SK-II contains a byproduct of sake, and Jo Malone’s Blue Agava & Cacao has enough tequila notes that all you need is salt and a squeeze of lime. You can also fade your freckles with Caudalie’s latest: Vinoperfect Day Perfecting Cream SPF 15, a pigment-lightening compound that, sadly, does nothing for a hangover.

headline: Mind Over Matter, With a Machine’s Help
text: WOULD that thinking made it so, people sometimes wistfully say. But Christopher deCharms, the chief executive of Omneuron, a start-up in Menlo Park, Calif., believes the adage.

headline: Lauren Floyd, Raymond Pilliner
text: Lauren Jennifer Floyd, the daughter of Dr. Virginia Davis Floyd and Dr. Joseph Bernard Floyd of Stone Mountain, Ga., was married last evening to Raymond Lynott Kirk Pilliner, the son of Eileen Pilliner and Raymond Pilliner of Silver Springs, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Lloyd Green performed the ceremony at Morningside Presbyterian Church in Atlanta.

headline: The Brightest Bulb
text: Are you ready, boys and girls? Let’s play Why Is It Fashionable? All you have to do is pick an object. Not just any object, of course, but one that’s hot, something like a coat or a chair that, when you pick it apart, tells you everything you need to know about the zeitgeist.

headline: Brooklyn Dentist Faces Charges of Lewdness
text: A dentist accused of exposing himself to a patient and then refusing to let her leave his Brooklyn office was arraigned in Brooklyn Criminal Court yesterday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Now Modeling | The Celio Shoppenboys
text: The French men’s-wear store Celio, founded by two brothers as a Gallic riff on the likes of Abercrombie & Fitch, now has a homegrown answer to A. & F.’s in-store hotties. Meet the Shoppenboys.

headline: Louder Than Words
text: In July 1944, a member of the German resistance slipped a briefcase of explosives under Hitler’s table as part of a conspiracy to take down the Third Reich. The bomb went off, but someone had unwittingly edged the briefcase aside and Hitler of course survived. The conspirators were arrested, their failure confirming Hitler’s belief that he had been chosen to make history. Among those rounded up was the German lawyer and aristocrat Adam von Trott, who as a Rhodes Scholar in prewar Oxford had been a friend of the British philosopher Isaiah Berlin.

headline: No Ordinary Joe
text: Flick through any fashion publication from the mid-1990s, and it’s likely to feel about as relevant as an episode of “Sex and the City.” But anyone lucky enough to get their hands on an issue of Joe’s magazine will have a hard time figuring out when it was published. At first glance, its oversize pages look undoubtedly contemporary — there is a long interview with Miuccia Prada, and photo shoots by David Sims, Mario Sorrenti, Craig McDean and Steven Klein. Only after careful inspection is it apparent that the Bruce Weber images of a nude, nubile Kate Moss are pre-rehab; on another page, Naomi Campbell is gently holding a baby rather than clutching a Swarovski-encrusted BlackBerry.

headline: Nonfiction Chronicle
text: THE HALF-LIFE OF AN AMERICAN ESSAYIST. By Arthur Krystal. (David R. Godine, $24.95.) Arthur Krystal is not really a go-getter. A self-described “aimless, melancholic, bumptious freelance writer,” he shirks fashionable topics, even if they might bring in a buck. In the engaging title piece of this slim, occasionally stuffy volume, Krystal makes a vigorous case for the virtues of old-fashioned literary criticism, twitting the navel gazers of “creative nonfiction,” which he dismisses as just a fancy word for memoir: “Writing interestingly about Jane Austen requires more imagination than confessing to having slept with someone named Jane Austen from Beaumont, Texas.” Krystal ranges widely, taking on subjects ranging from the typewriter to boxing, and he’s not afraid of weighty topics: he slogs through the notebooks of Paul Valéry, ponders different theories of beauty and offers a defense of the seven deadly sins. (“On the whole,” he writes, “it helps to have sin around; it’s like having a set of instructions for building a life that God approves of.”) In “My Holocaust Problem,” Krystal (whose grandparents died in the camps) complains that the profusion of Holocaust books, films and memorials — “the pomp and circumstance of remembrance” — has trivialized the event. If the argument isn’t terribly original, he subtly ponders the obligations of remembrance. In his charming concluding essay, “Who Speaks for the Lazy?,” Krystal returns to justifying his underachieving ways: “Let’s face it, some boys and girls become writers because the only workplace they’re willing to visit is the one inside their heads.”

headline: Sara Austin, Kyle Smith
text: Sara Austin, a magazine editor, and Kyle Smith, a novelist and film critic, were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Sag Harbor, N.Y. The Rev. Elizabeth Carl performed the ceremony.

headline: Now Injecting | Silicone-Plumped Skins
text: The luxury handbag market is getting a face-lift thanks to the designer Mauro Orietti Carella, whose company, Zagliani, recently started a line of silicone-treated croc and alligator bags. When considering what to design for the 50-year-old Milanese house, Carella, who trained in dermatology, turned to a plastic-surgeon friend. “I asked him what he thought men and women really wanted in life,” he says. “He immediately responded, ‘Silicone!’ ”

headline: Correction: The Week on Long Island
text: A report in The Week column last Sunday about the Suffolk Community College budget referred incorrectly to 10 positions that County Executive Steve Levy said he planned to veto. Nine are faculty positions and one is administrative, according to the college; Mr. Levy had said all 10 were administrative positions.

headline:

Put Mahan in Contention
text: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 25 — In his younger and more excitable days, Hunter Mahan sometimes approached golf with a clenched fist and a slammed club.

text: The word warrior is winning its battle against fighter, soldier, servicemember, troops, even the most belligerent combatants.

headline: Their Titles Laundered, the Cars Are Still Lemons

text: LOS ANGELES — Marc Tyler was the best high school running back in California last year, a member of seven all-American teams, a winner of 46 consecutive games. He was the kind of centerpiece recruit that college football programs are built around.

text: Not so many years ago, it was axiomatic that an American who wanted to become a grandmaster or international master had to go to Europe to satisfy the title requirements.

headline: Red Bulls Lose on Own Goal
text: An own goal off the foot of Red Bulls defender Carlos Mendes in the 80th minute helped the host New England Revolution to a 2-1 victory last night in Major League Soccer. Mendes sent the ball back 40 yards toward Red Bulls goalkeeper Jon Conway, intending for a goal kick.The Red Bulls (10-9-3) took a 1-0 lead in the 30th minute on a goal by Jozy Altidore. Taylor Twellman tied the score in the first minute of the second half for the Revolution (12-5-6), the Eastern Conference leader.

headline: The City of Light, as Seen From a Glittering Perch
text: LIKE many of the best things in life, this one came along by chance — though it had been hiding in plain sight.

headline: Stop Making Sense
text: Between 2000 and 2006, a specter haunted the community of fundamentalist Democrats. Members of this community looked around and observed their moral and intellectual superiority. They observed that their policies were better for the middle classes. And yet the middle classes did not support Democrats. They tended to vote, in large numbers, for the morally and intellectually inferior party, the one, moreover, that catered to the interests of the rich.

headline: After Brush With Law, Hawaii’s Brennan Seeks Redemption
text: HONOLULU  After every home game, Colt Brennan waves to his probation officer as he leaves Aloha Stadium.

headline: A Psychology Lesson From the Markets
text: IT is no surprise that the Federal Reserve’s discount rate cut has not entirely reassured investors. The Fed can stop a run on the banks, but it cannot control the speculative cycle — a cycle built on psychology and misperceptions that has been sweeping much of the world for the last 10 or 12 years.

headline: Stiff-Arming Children’s Health
text: The Bush administration has imposed new requirements on a valuable children’s health insurance program that look so draconian as to be unattainable. Late on a recent Friday while Congress was in recess, a time fit for hiding dark deeds, the administration sent a letter to state health officials spelling out new hurdles they would have to clear before they could insure children from middle-income families unable to find affordable health coverage. Some 19 states may be forced to pull back programs they have started or proposed.

In general that is true, but owners of older cars are finding it is not always the case.

headline: Condos, Brand-New Yet Not So Perfect
text: WHEN dozens of buyers put down payments on apartments in the glassy new condominium tower called the Link at 310 West 52nd Street, they were looking forward to living with features like floor-to-ceiling windows and a meditation garden. But six months after they started moving in, they are still living in a construction site with an unfinished lobby, uncarpeted hallways and no access to the garden that was supposed to help them escape from the city’s stresses.

headline: No iPod for Him; He’s an Album Guy
text: BEN HARPER wants you to know he’s with the band. That is, the Innocent Criminals, with whom he has been performing for more than a decade. Mr. Harper’s eighth studio album, “Lifeline” (Virgin), due out this week, was a collaborative effort. The band created the music during sound checks before tour performances; then Mr. Harper would retire to his hotel and add lyrics. After wrapping up the last show, they ended up recording in a 16-track studio in Paris. Mr. Harper, 37, described the record as “not rock, not folk, not gospel, but with all those elements included.” While on vacation in Sardinia, he spoke with Winter Miller about what he likes listening to.

headline: Wakefield, Ageless Knuckleballer, Flutters Toward 20 Wins
text: He is 41 years old and his best pitch travels to the plate about 68 miles an hour. How could a pitch that flutters so softly be overpowering? Even the fans behind the plate think they could hit it. But let them try.

headline: ‘We All Live in a Red Submarine ...’
text: THEY were a handful of Russians in their 50s, these children of the old intelligentsia who gathered from around Europe this summer in a birch forest 100 miles south of Moscow for something somewhat surprising: a joyous journey back into their Soviet past.

headline: Lying and One-Night Stands
text: Badness — the good kind — is in the eye of the beholder. In the opening anecdote of the introduction to her essay anthology, “Bad Girls: 26 Writers Misbehave,” Ellen Sussman describes the rather grand entrance she made at the East Hampton mansion of her corporate attorney husband’s “hotshot clients.” The couples walked out to look at the ocean, and she writes, “I took one look, threw off my clothes, and ran naked into the waves.”

With Detroit in the playoff race, the best-case situation would be for Maybin, above, to contribute the way Miguel Cabrera did for the Marlins as they won the World Series in 2003, but it is more likely that he will develop his power in the coming years.

That is what it was like for Roethlisberger last season: People were always curious about his recovery. Of course, it seemed he was always recovering from something.

text: Q I understand that New Jersey law requires landlords to return security deposits within 30 days after tenants move out. In my case, my landlord took more than three months to return my deposit, and only after several e-mail messages, phone calls and threats to sue.

text: ISTANBUL, Aug. 25 — The Formula One season resumes with Sunday’s Turkish Grand Prix, and teams are hoping the three-week summer break will have pacified emotions, after incidents at the past two races showed why great racing requires cool nerves, psychology and self-discipline.

headline: Plastic Surge
text: My carbon footprint is as tiny and delicate as Cinderella’s. I don’t drive a car (who needs one in Manhattan?), I barely know what a dishwasher is (who eats at home?), and believe it or not, I don’t even have an air conditioner (it would ruin my Art Deco apartment).

headline: By Your Leave?
text: Q I own a co-op in Manhattan. I am a part-time resident and have my primary residence in Florida. On several occasions, maintenance people have entered my apartment to fix the intercom. I never gave them permission; apparently, the building had keys from the previous owner.

headline: Death Angel
text: “Bad Monkeys” is something of a science-fiction “Catcher in the Rye.” The protagonist, Jane Charlotte, tells her life story to a psychiatrist. She cracks wise and doesn’t quite fit into society, and the heart of her story is, seemingly, about a tragic younger brother. She’s a female Holden Caulfield, except she kills criminals with the equivalent of a ray gun.

headline: Democrats Take a Tough Line on Florida Primary
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 — The Democratic National Committee, threatening to take the toughest line possible, voted Saturday to refuse to seat any Florida Democrat at the Democratic presidential convention in 2008 if the state party did not delay the date of its 2008 primary to conform to the party’s nominating calendar.

headline: This War Is Not Like the Others — or Is It?
text: AS the nations of Europe leapt to arms in 1914, President Woodrow Wilson’s mind turned to President James Madison and the war with England in 1812.

headline: A Truck Tire That Goes the Extra 100,000 Miles
text: STRIKING a balance between conflicting needs is the everyday quest of an automotive engineer. A new engine might be designed for peak horsepower or maximum fuel economy, but not both at the same time; a suspension system can be calibrated for precise cornering or absolute comfort, but sacrifices must be expected in one trait to improve the other.

headline: Moving Clocks Ahead, Reaching Back in Time
text: CARACAS, Venezuela

headline: Challenging the Generals
text: On Aug. 1, Gen. Richard Cody, the United States Army’s vice chief of staff, flew to the sprawling base at Fort Knox, Ky., to talk with the officers enrolled in the Captains Career Course. These are the Army’s elite junior officers. Of the 127 captains taking the five-week course, 119 had served one or two tours of duty in Iraq or Afghanistan, mainly as lieutenants. Nearly all would soon be going back as company commanders. A captain named Matt Wignall, who recently spent 16 months in Iraq with a Stryker brigade combat team, asked Cody, the Army’s second-highest-ranking general, what he thought of a recent article by Lt. Col. Paul Yingling titled “A Failure in Generalship.” The article, a scathing indictment that circulated far and wide, including in Iraq, accused the Army’s generals of lacking “professional character,” “creative intelligence” and “moral courage.”

headline: Wild Calabria
text: Donna Leon has staked out Venice, Magdalen Nabb knows every narrow street in Florence, and Andrea Camilleri holds Sicily in the palm of his hand. But only Michael Dibdin, in the clever and exuberantly witty police procedurals he created for a dyspeptic cop named Aurelio Zen, tried to wrap his arms around the whole of Italy. Braving his way province by province — from the mountains of Alto Adige (in “Medusa”) to the caves of Sardinia (in “Vendetta”) — the British-born author produced crime stories that capture the idiosyncratic essence of each region while contributing to a dynamic study of the Italian national character in all its unruly glory.

headline: Brooke Grossman, Andrew Russakoff
text: Brooke Ashley Grossman, a daughter of Rita and Stuart Grossman of Glen Cove, N.Y., is to be married this morning to Andrew Marc Russakoff, a son of Gail and Norman Russakoff, also of Glen Cove. Rabbi David Freelund is to officiate at Carlyle on the Green, a caterer in Farmingdale, N.Y.

headline: Euro Pinchers Chime In With Some Tips
text: BEATING the euro is a hot topic among travelers these days. Responding to the Aug. 5 Practical Traveler column, “10 Ways to Keep Europe Within Reach,” more than 70 readers offered tips for saving money on a European vacation. Many of the comments, which were posted at nytimes.com/travel, made general recommendations for strategies like renting villas or apartments rather than staying in hotels; others were based on specific experiences. Here are 10 new suggestions, gleaned from the reader responses, to add to the 10 in the original column.

headline: Alexsandra Lloyd, Tom Sanford
text: Alexsandra Gullette Lloyd and Tom Sanford were married on Friday at St. Paul’s Chapel at Columbia University in New York. Msgr. Wallace A. Harris, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: The Devil Sells Prada
text: “Luxury,” Socrates once declared, “is artificial poverty.” I’m not poor, but there’s nothing like an afternoon spent shopping for luxury goods to make me feel that way. On a recent jaunt through some of Midtown Manhattan’s snazzier stores, I began to wonder why this should be the case. When, I asked myself, did it become commonplace to charge several thousand dollars for a mass-produced handbag? How could the flimsy designer sundress I bought on sale — a “steal,” the saleswoman assured me — still wind up costing a whole month’s salary? Why is my favorite brand of lipstick more expensive than a nice bottle of Italian wine? When did these products’ values grow so distorted, and what is the would-be customer to make of it all?

headline: The Spy Chief Speaks
text: After more than a year and a half of administration stonewalling on President Bush’s illegal domestic wiretapping, it was nice to see Mike McConnell, the director of national intelligence, finally unburden himself in a newspaper interview. It would have been nicer if Mr. McConnell had really wanted to enlighten the public.

text: IN October of 1852, a French clergyman saddles up a fine cream-colored mule and rides south out of Santa Fe. As the new Catholic bishop of the territory of New Mexico, he is embarking on his first visit to Indian pueblos.

text: In this year’s preseason rankings of teams on the level below the bowl contenders, the top 25 often includes New Hampshire, Massachusetts, James Madison, Delaware and Towson.

text: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 25 (AP) — Pedestrians at the nation’s busiest border crossing are losing conveniences in what the authorities describe as measures to improve security and critics say is an unnecessary crackdown.

headline: IVY LEAGUE

headline: Renee Rosnes, Bill Charlap
text: Renee Rosnes and Bill Charlap, jazz pianists, were married yesterday at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola, part of the Jazz at Lincoln Center complex, where both have performed. The Rev. Julie Laudicina, a nondenominational minister, officiated.

headline: What a Test Can Say About Your Style
text: REMEMBER your first self-assessment test? I took mine — it may have been the Myers-Briggs — in high school, sitting at a too-small desk in a drab, dingy classroom. As an unsmiling teacher paced back and forth, we grudgingly revealed details about our inner selves in the questionnaire’s little spaces.

headline: From Young Storytellers, a Playful Tone
text: What joy there is in this year’s “Aljira Emerge” show in Newark, the eighth installment of the gallery’s annual professional development program for young and emerging artists, mainly from the metropolitan region. It is not the strongest exhibition in recent years, but it is the most delightful visually.

headline: Luxe Populi
text: Luxury for the masses’ — the crusade that got under way in the late ’80s — implied that schoolteachers and cab drivers, having been denied Birkin bags and 911 Turbo convertibles for all of recorded history, were finally coming into their natural birthright. “Affordable luxury” would bring life’s finer things within reach and spread them around. Luxury brands began a precarious balancing act, continuing to bask in their exclusivity while opening the gates to a whole new breed of customer by introducing “entry-level” products at “accessible” prices. Poor Holly Golightly, stuck in the ’60s, munching her breakfast in front of Tiffany’s windows, hankering after the diamonds on display. If she were around today, she could go in and buy herself a piece of the brand: say, a $125 sterling-silver key ring.

headline: The Larder System
text: All right — I’ve had it up to here with getting older. And so I have decided I’m going to put an end to it. I have tried this before. In fact, if I had a minute less for every self-help book I’ve bought, fish-oil capsule I’ve swallowed and lotion I’ve slathered on my face in the hopes of looking younger, I’d be back playing with blocks. But this time it’s going to be different. This time I have the guarantee of Dr. Jeannette Graf, a dermatologist and the author (with Alisa Bowman) of “Stop Aging, Start Living.” Dr. Jeannette writes, “Not only does this program help you look more youthful on the outside, it also slows the aging of every cell in your body on the inside.” And let’s face it, nobody wants to have 17-year-old skin and a 51-year-old spleen.

headline: Hot Ticket
text: The New York Racing Association offers video replays of individual races at Saratoga, Belmont and Aqueduct through RaceReplays.com after a 5- to 10-minute delay. They remain available for the length of each race meeting.

headline: Countering Bridges’ Dark Allure

headline: New Direction for a Folk Festival With an Eye on Conservation
text: IF Judy Collins isn’t enough to bring out the crowds for this year’s Connecticut Folk Festival, maybe a more diverse group of performers and an expanded Green Expo, with representatives from up to 70 organizations, businesses and state agencies, will do the trick.

headline: Melanie Miller, William Lanzana
text: The Rev. Melanie Dawn Miller and William Michael Lanzana were married yesterday at the historic James House in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. The Rev. Michael W. Caine, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated.

headline: Yes, We’re in Newark
text: ON a sultry August afternoon in the Forest Hill district of Newark, Julie Hodge trimmed the lower branches of a pine tree growing across the property line of her brick colonial house, hoping to convince her neighbors that the whole tree didn’t need to come down. Nearby, there were residents painting shutters, replacing porch floor boards and planning for an evening at the open-air jazz concert in Branch Brook Park, just down the hill.

headline: Why the Roller Coaster Seems Wilder
text: STOCKS regained some composure last week, and not a moment too soon for investors worn out by the market’s turbulence. Credit markets remain easily spooked, however, and justifiably so. There is still so much that investors do not know about what lurks in portfolios around the world and exactly when it might jump out and say “boo!”

headline: Lousy Is the Best They Can Ever Be
text: LONDON

headline: West 142nd Street: Almost $2.9 Million
text: SOME people buy town houses in Harlem for their rich historical detail, the intricately carved moldings, the oak paneling, the Victorian grace. Others look for buildings that can be reshaped into starkly modern spaces.

headline: Jilian Gersten, Brian Shuman
text: Jilian Cahan Gersten, a daughter of Cora Cahan and Bernard Gersten of Katonah, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Brian Scott Shuman, a son of Joyce Shuman and Robert Shuman of Greensboro, N.C. Rabbi Andy Bachman is to officiate at the home of the bride’s parents.

headline: Out of Alaska: Zoo Seeks a Move South for Elephant
text: ANCHORAGE, Aug. 25 (AP) — A proposal is on the table to move Alaska’s only elephant out of the state, a plan that has found favor with both the Alaska Zoo and animal rights groups.

headline: What? And Leave Show Business?
text: I consider myself a worker,” said David Greenspan, who has been an actor, writer and director in New York for nearly 30 years. “I’m facing the same things that workers are facing throughout the country.”

headline: It’s Bird Eat Bird in a Cluttered Sky
text: THE summer travel season is building toward its Labor Day peak, and fliers are growing ever angrier about delays. Now, the beleaguered airline industry is trying to shift the blame onto an unlikely villain: corporate jets, which the airlines claim are literally crowding passenger planes out of the sky.

headline: Will the Credit Crisis End the Activists’ Run?
text: RATTLING the saber won’t be good enough,” Carl C. Icahn, the colorful investor who has made billions of dollars aiming at corporate America with vitriolic shake-up and breakup campaigns, lamented to me last week. “It’s going to be somewhat more difficult.”

headline: Katherine Wallach, Jason Ginsburg
text: Katherine Jean Wallach and Jason Andrew Ginsburg are to be married today at the Four Seasons Hotel in Hampshire, England. Laura Redwood, superintendent registrar for North East Hampshire, is to officiate.

headline: Heilman (Not Wagner) Keeps Mets on Track
text: There are still 34 games remaining in the Mets’ season, which, for the most pessimistic of fans, means there are 34 excruciating ways to lose, 34 different things that can go awry.

headline: How Congestion Pricing Could Play Out
text: COMMUTING to Manhattan by car has long meant enduring mind-numbing traffic and paying more and more for tolls, parking and gas. So in April, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed charging cars $8 to enter Manhattan below 86th Street on weekdays, suburban drivers had reason to groan yet again.

headline: Final Score
text: Several times while reading “Bearing the Body,” I found myself recalling Virginia Woolf’s remark that “Middlemarch” was one of the few English novels written for grown-ups. I’d always assumed I knew what Woolf meant, but “Bearing the Body,” Ehud Havazelet’s extraordinary first novel, made me consider what might be involved in writing for adults at our own cultural moment — adults who may have noticed that life in general, and people in particular, can be difficult, complicated and strange.

headline: No Free Lunch
text: In the 1930s, the Schechter brothers ran a chicken business in Brooklyn. The name Schechter is derived from the Yiddish word for “butcher,” and this is what the brothers did: they slaughtered chickens and sold them to shops. The brothers seemed to be typical immigrants, at once struggling and succeeding.

headline: Classics Elevate London’s Summer
text: LONDON

headline: 180 Degrees
text: To the Editor:

headline: Edwards Wins a Race Devoid of Bristol Drama
text: BRISTOL, Tenn., Aug 25 — The other 41 drivers served as little more than a colorful backdrop to a two-car race Saturday night between Carl Edwards and Kasey Kahne at Bristol Motor Speedway.

headline: Correction: Workers’ Paradise, and With a Nice View
text: A column last Sunday on the leftist summer colonies of northern Westchester misstated the title of Dan Thaler. He is one of two vice presidents of the Shrub Oak homeowners’ association, not its president.

headline: Grounding Air Albany
text: The abuse of New York State’s taxpayer-financed official aircraft has been one of many problems obscured by all the fuss over Gov. Eliot Spitzer administration’s “trooper blooper,” as one of his friends calls it. There are more than enough investigations now into whether Mr. Spitzer’s administration overreached by persuading state troopers to release politically damaging information about his Republican foe, State Senator Joseph Bruno. Now it is time for the Legislature to protect taxpayers from paying for trips to political fund-raisers like the ones that Mr. Bruno was enjoying before all this mess become topic No. 1 in Albany.

headline: Unshelved
text: Masha Hamilton has good story sense. She started out as a journalist for The Los Angeles Times, The Associated Press and other news organizations, reporting from Russia, Africa and the Middle East. It’s not surprising, then, that when she began a new career as a novelist she demonstrated a knack for setting her fiction in volatile, real-life situations. Her first novel, “Staircase of a Thousand Steps,” was a coming-of-age story set in a Middle Eastern village in 1966. Her second, “The Distance Between Us,” followed a war correspondent who found herself in the midst of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: Mailer Gets Hammered
text: In this era of instant cultural gratification, it is rare to have to wait 36 years to watch a film. But that’s how long it took for me to see “Maidstone,” Norman Mailer’s legendary exercise in improvisatory semifictional cinéma vérité. It finally arrived at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center this past July like a video transmission from the faraway Planet ’60s — a civilization in the throes of a crackup. I had been itching to see it ever since reading Mailer’s extraordinary essay on its creation, “A Course in Film-Making,” in New American Review in 1971, by which point the film had come and gone. For reasons its creator could hardly have anticipated, this lurid, ludicrous, lunatic spectacle was worth the wait.

headline: Beijing Air Raises Questions for Olympics
text: OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 25  With temperatures rising into the low 90s and with the humidity closing in on 90 percent Saturday, some marathoners could not bear it at the track and field world championships.

headline: Washington to Pittsburgh, by Bike
text: Here’s a way to kiss summer goodbye or take in the fall foliage without having to deal with traffic: bicycle from Washington to Pittsburgh using more than 300 miles of off-road trails through retired railway corridors.

headline: Teach the Toddlers
text: IN 1997, Albany passed legislation that was supposed to make publicly financed prekindergarten classes available to every 4-year-old in the state. A decade later, New York City has fallen far short of that goal. This school year, at least 17,000 city children will not get slots in the high-demand program.

headline: Love Us or Hate Us, Ya Can’t Ignore Us
text: DO Europeans hate America or love it? Lately the answer might seem a no-brainer. But “The Anti-Americans,” a one-hour documentary that has its premiere on PBS on Monday night, suggests that the correct response is: “Both.” We have, the show declares, “a hate-love relationship.”

headline: A Drugstore-Clinic Caveat (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Afiya McLaughlin-White and Devin Johnson
text: Afiya McLaughlin-White and Devin Antoine Johnson are to be married this evening at Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Calvin O. Butts III, the pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, will perform the ceremony.

headline: Love as an Illusion: Beautiful to See, Impossible to Hold
text: IN “Brokeback Mountain,” the 2005 critical hit and cultural flashpoint that won Ang Lee an Academy Award for best director, love is a haunting, elusive ideal briefly attained but forever out of reach. Mr. Lee’s new movie, “Lust, Caution,” which will have its premiere at the Venice International Film Festival this week, is also a tragic melodrama, one in which the lovers are up against forces beyond their control, but it takes a harsher view of romance. This time love is a performance, a trap or, cruelest of all, an illusion.

headline: The Heist, the Getaway and the Sawed-Off Leg
text: BERNARD McMAHON, a k a Bennie the Bum, a former bootlegger and onetime crony of the dapper gangster Legs Diamond, bent down to untangle a rope from a sawed-off shotgun. His speedboat, laden with stolen loot, was racing across Gravesend Bay. Suddenly, a blast punctuated the motor’s hum. The shotgun had accidentally gone off, leaving McMahon’s left knee a bloody mess.

headline: Erin Dittus, Russell Lang
text: Erin Leigh Dittus, a daughter of Rebecca L. Dittus and Dr. Robert S. Dittus of Brentwood, Tenn., was married yesterday to Russell William Lang, a son of Karen K. Lang and Roger P. Lang of Pompton Plains, N.J. The Rev. J. Mark Forrester, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Wightman Chapel in Nashville.

headline: 400 Candles, and a Yearlong Blowout
text: WHEN the makers of the 2002 movie “Catch Me If You Can” were looking for a stand-in for France for a pivotal scene, they looked to Quebec City. With its fortified stone walls, narrow streets, venerable churches, beckoning cafes, and French-speaking populace, Quebec oozes Old World Gallic charm.

headline: Christina Krettecos, Kevin White
text: Christina Dora Krettecos, a daughter of Elizabeth and Theodore Krettecos of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to Kevin Andrew White, a son of Lene White of Maple Glen, Pa., and the late Leland White. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos, the dean of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York, performed the ceremony there.

headline: Mother’s Day
text: When Sean Wilsey’s memoir, “Oh the Glory of It All,” was published in 2005, I went through it in great mouthfuls, laughing so hard I choked on my own spit, gasping with such noisy abruptness on the subway that I was forced to explain to my fellow passengers the contents of the passage I had just read, and why they had to immediately run out and buy this book. When I got to the end, rather than face the searing disappointment that there was no more book left to be read, I immediately turned back to Page 1 and started all over again.

headline: Pawleys Island, S.C.: The Original Hammock Shop
text: At the Original Hammock Shop on Pawleys Island, a historic seaside resort in South Carolina, you can see rope hammocks made the same way they've been made for more than 100 years, and then take one home.

headline: Creatures of Habit
text: Whether on the local news or the latest episode of “CSI,” meth is the drug of the moment. Last summer’s big-budget “Miami Vice” visited a meth-addled trailer park as well as the high seas of the sexier cocaine trade, and November brought the country’s first National Methamphetamine Awareness Day.

headline: Beyond the Selectric
text: GROWING up, I was surrounded by family members who were entrepreneurs. My father had his own public relations firm and did very well. But he fell ill when I was in high school, and my family suffered a reversal. It was a formative experience.

headline: Make Wine, Not War
text: Bergerac, France

headline: The Rubble of My Marriage, Hidden by Katrina’s
text: HURRICANE KATRINA came along at a strangely appropriate time for me. Its shattered lives and lost homes fell right in line with how my life was going at the moment.

headline: Louisa Livingston Kennedy, Voice of Iran Hostages’ Families, Dies at 73
text: Louisa Livingston Kennedy, the wife of a senior American official held captive during the Iranian hostage crisis who became a highly visible spokeswoman for the hostages’ families, died on Aug. 19 on Mount Desert Island, Maine. She was 73 and made her home on the island.

headline: Jack Kirby, a Comic Book Genius, Is Finally Remembered
text: The fear of being forgotten after death is endemic in the creative arts. In the case of the iconic comic book artist Jack Kirby, it happened while he was still alive. By the 1960s, Mr. Kirby had already revolutionized the comic book business more than once. Working as principal artist and in-house genius for Marvel, he created a voice and an aesthetic unmatched by any other company.

headline: Charmaine Smith, Sean Wright
text: Dr. Charmaine Angelina Smith and Dr. Sean Anthony Wright were married last evening in Philadelphia. The Rev. Charles Zlock, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Agatha-St. James Church.

headline: A Meteor Returns for a Victory Lap
text: IN much the way George Steinbrenner opens his wallet wide each year trying to field a winning Yankees team, similarly competitive collectors search for significant vintage cars and dig deep, hoping to bring home a Best of Show award, or at least a class win, from the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance.

headline: Chill Seekers
text: On a cool day in July, Kaz Adachi, a sculptor wearing a long, stiff apron and Wellington boots, was bent over two large blocks of ice fused end to end as he created a sushi bar for a wedding at the Manhattan restaurant Country. A Chopin mazurka was occasionally muffled by the roar of the chain saw Adachi used to gouge and groove the blocks.

headline: The Artwork Runs Hot, With Infusions of Cool
Captain America
text: If Bush America appears to be tanking — as the Iraqi war grinds into its fifth year and the universal sympathy vote that was ours after 9/11 has soured into a sort of universal distaste — Polo America is having a banner year. This began to become clear to me not long ago, as I walked across Red Square in Moscow. Spotting a young student wearing board shorts emblazoned with the Stars and Stripes, I stopped him to inquire what this sanctified emblem of Jeffersonian democracy signified in his mind. “Ralph Lauren brand,” he said flatly and moved on.

headline: Dead of Night: Yankees Lose at 3:30 A.M.
text: DETROIT, Saturday, Aug. 25 — By the third inning, the out-of-town scoreboard at Comerica Park was scrolling through Saturday’s games. That made sense, in a way, because it already was Saturday.

headline: Tales of Spotting Snarls From Above
text: CONSIDER the morning I coined the phrase “Tour de Merritt.”

headline: Sixteen Candles, but Few Blazing a Trail to the Ballot Box
text: IT is a nippy November Tuesday and your 16-year-old has her day all planned out. After school, she’ll have a rehearsal of her high school musical, “High School Musical.” She’ll instant-message her friends about that ridiculous question on the trig test, and she’ll drive to the mall for a burger with her boyfriend.

headline: Seaweed, Not Culinary Art, but Pressed and Mounted
text: Southampton

text: NEW CITY, N.Y.

headline: Elizabeth Holland, David Franklin
text: Elizabeth Ida Holland, the daughter of Louise Abbell Holland of Winnetka, Ill., and the late J. William Holland, was married yesterday to David Leigh Franklin, a son of Barbara and Herbert M. Franklin of Washington. Stephen F. Williams, a senior judge of the Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, officiated at the Lake Shore Country Club in Glencoe, Ill.

headline: Traditional Japanese With a Pan-Asian Bent
text: NOT too many years ago, some people we know would not eat raw fish. We suspect that maki sushi (rolled sushi) and all its fancy spinoffs with whimsical names are responsible for their change of heart. Like many converts, they have gone on to enjoy the delicate nuances of sashimi, what good Japanese sushi restaurants are all about.

headline: The Microbe Hunters and the Suspicious Fountain
text: When the city’s Health Department warned last month of a surge in cases of Legionnaires’ disease in Parkchester, a complex of 171 apartment buildings southeast of Bronx Park, one possible culprit was thought to be Parkchester’s central fountain.

headline: Someone’s in the Closet With Sylvester
text: ON Tuesday the R&B singer R. Kelly released “Trapped in the Closet: Chapters 13-22,” a DVD of the newest episodes of his video hip-hopera. Featuring 26 characters, byzantine twists of plot and cliffhanger endings, it has a story that can perplex even the most devoted fans.

headline: Martha Noel, Peter Kellner
text: Martha Walker Noel, the daughter of Patricia Noel and Hayes Noel of Aptos, Calif., was married yesterday to Peter Bicknell Kellner, the son of Martha B. Kellner and George A. Kellner of New York. The Rev. Frank C. Strasburger, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Tehàma Golf Club in Carmel, Calif.

headline: The Architect Who Shaped Upper Fifth Avenue
text: THERE are two names synonymous with the design of luxury apartment houses in the 1920s: Rosario Candela and ... uh ... what’s-his-name.

headline: A Troubled Neighborhood, and a Minister Who Refuses to Give Up
text: Nothing surprises the Rev. Gene McGhee anymore.

text: DAVID LETTERMAN

headline: Back in Print
text: In 1964, a 3-year-old girl named Laudomia was unhappily confined to her sickbed. It was, as these things go, not a bad place to be confined; her bedroom was on the third floor of the Palazzo Pucci, a massive 14th-century villa in Florence, just behind the Duomo’s pearl-gray immensity. But she was bored and restless, and so, to cheer her up, her father, an Italian aristocrat, brought her some perfume.

headline: Entry-Level
text: Just as BMW offers its more accessible 3 Series to younger buyers, many perfume houses offer beginning fragrances for their younger consumers. Each house follows its own logic.

headline: When Bad News Follows You
text: A BUSINESS strategy of The New York Times to get its articles to pop up first in Internet searches is creating a perplexing problem: long-buried information about people that is wrong, outdated or incomplete is getting unwelcome new life.

headline: A Composer Who Forged a Different, More Defiant Path
text: RUED LANGGAARD: SYMPHONIES 2 AND 3; SYMPHONIES 12 TO 14

headline: In This Civil War, It’s East vs. West
text: THE land around Unison, Va. — a clutch of homes 50 miles west of Washington, with no stoplight or commercial enterprise —looks much as it did around 145 years ago when Union and Confederate soldiers clashed in the fields.

headline: For Skate Parks, It’s a Material World
text: IT was the kind of day that cried out for heel flips off the halfpipe, but you would not have guessed it by the looks of the Sydney E. Frank skate park in New Rochelle, N.Y. Sun rolled off the year-old ramps on a warm Wednesday afternoon, but the park sat empty.

headline: The Nureyev Nobody Knows, Young and Wild
text: A POINT comes in the afterlife of an artist when, for the time being, biography has pretty much done its work. The essential history is known; the ambience is broadly understood; the relationship between the life and the work has yielded its chief mysteries. Barring bombshells any future surprises are apt to be minor: not revelations, just minutiae.

headline: A Turnaround: Stocks Up, Volatility Down
text: The stock market bounced back last week, with the three major indexes all posting weekly gains of more than 2 percent.

headline: The Market Is Bumpy, but Liquor Is Quicker
text: Just as a storm of change has been rattling the New York Stock Exchange of late, so has there been a change in the weather at the New York Wine Exchange, a well-stocked shop on Broadway near Battery Place, just a few blocks from its namesake. On a chilly evening last week, a marketing analyst named Effie Philippakos seemed to embody these fluctuations after she hurried into the store and headed straight for the spirits.

headline: Inès de la Fressange | Style Emissary
text: Even muses have trouble getting dressed. “I’m the type of person who wakes up and has nothing to wear,” says Inès de la Fressange, a roving ambassador for Roger Vivier accessories. Though she was once a model, a muse to Karl Lagerfeld at Chanel, the official face of the Marianne (“It’s like the French version of Uncle Sam except with big breasts”) and the designer of her own clothing line, she refuses to take fashion too seriously. Her style is a simple mix of T-shirts, tailored trousers and cropped jackets, worn with piles of accessories and a sense of humor. “I’ve always been the bouffon du roi,” or court jester, she says. “One time, before I walked onto a runway, I burned the top of a cork from a wine bottle and smeared a moustache above my lip.”

headline: Lily Mayer, Robert Roscoe
text: Laura Elizabeth Mayer, the daughter of Margery and Theodore V. H. Mayer of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Russell Fawcus Roscoe, a son of Jennifer Kenny of Hartfield, England, and the late John Roscoe, who lived in Clifton-upon-Dunsmore, England. The Rev. Thomas E. Nicoll performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. John’s Church in Larchmont.

headline: Michelle Volpe, Christopher Solgan
text: Michelle Lyn Volpe and Christopher John Solgan were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard D. Baker officiated at St. Malachy’s Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

headline: 30 Seconds With Andy Roddick
text: Andy Roddick, who says his kitchen skills are lackluster, cooked with celebrity chefs as the guests at the Dacor Taste of Tennis charity event Thursday in Manhattan.

headline: Jae Gruenke, Eric Barnhill
text: Jae Gruenke and Eric Charles Barnhill were married yesterday in New York. Tony Hileman, the senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, officiated.

headline: Street Sense Wins Travers, but Works Harder Than Expected
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25 — Calvin Borel knew the horseplayers were wrong. The colt he was riding, the Kentucky Derby winner Street Sense, was not a lock to capture the 138th Travers Stakes, and the six other horses in the Midsummer Derby were better than they looked.

headline: Competition So Fierce That the Yarmulkes Fly Off
text: MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 25 — Who is the most formidable Jewish ballplayer who ever lived?

headline: Caroline Pelham, Eric Burton
text: Caroline Nancy Pelham and Eric Michael Burton were married yesterday in Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass. The Rev. Aaron Fulp-Eickstaedt, a Presbyterian minister and a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated at the couple’s home there.

headline: Arsenal and Chelsea Win
text: Arsenal handed Manchester City its first loss of the season yesterday in the English Premier League, 1-0, and Chelsea beat Portsmouth, 1-0, to move into first place.Cesc Fabregas scored in the 80th minute to give Arsenal the victory and Frank Lampard scored in the first half for Chelsea, which has 10 points from four games. Manchester City is second with 9 points, 2 more than Wigan, Liverpool and Arsenal.In other matches, Liverpool beat Sunderland, 2-0; Birminghan won at Derby County, 2-1; Aston Villa defeated Fulham, 2-1; Bolton beat Reading, 3-0; and Wigan drew, 1-1, at West Ham.

headline: With Market Plans Afoot, Resistance Rises to More Fancy Foods
text: WHEN Fiorello La Guardia opened the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side in 1940, his goal was to clear the neighborhood’s streets of the shoddy pushcarts that he found so unsightly.

headline: Correction: Where Sheep Once Grazed, Now Poems Take Root
text: A caption in the Workspace photo essay last Sunday misidentified the actor depicted in a portrait in the home of the poet Donald Hall. It is Charles Laughton, not Charles Lawson.

headline: Dead Co-op Issue Gets a Second Life
text: A RECENT Manhattan court decision added a twist to a question that co-op lawyers thought had been answered by the state’s highest court in a 2005 ruling on designating a “holder of unsold shares” in a co-op.

headline: What Genius Cast This Play?
text: Gertrude Garnet: the very name suggests a woman of mystery and allure. With her flaming red hair in a seductive upsweep, gams encased in seamed stockings, and ensembles trimmed extravagantly in fur and leather, Gertrude is an out-and-out stunner. Add a come-hither manner and a sexy, gravelly voice, and you’ll understand why men find her totally irresistible.

headline: Maria Shim and Nicholas Fox
text: Maria So-Hee Shim and Nicholas Charles Fox were married yesterday afternoon at Beltane Ranch, an inn in Glen Ellen, Calif. The Rev. Timothy Boeve, a minister of the Reformed Church in America, officiated.

headline: Go Suck on a Topaz
text: Indian women have always gone the distance for beauty. They’ve had to. Even now, when globalization has plunked down card shops and appliance outlets in every town with more than five sacred cows, makeup-buying options are limited outside the big cities. In most places, you’re talking waxy lipstick in three cadaverous shades, sold at the general store. But there’s a reason, beyond a fortunate gene pool, that India regularly cleans up at the international Miss Strut pageants. Women there have a history of being resourceful, as Sharada Dwivedi and Shalini Devi Holkar explain in “Almond Eyes, Lotus Feet” (Collins), a fascinating compendium of traditional beauty and healing remedies spun as the fictional memoir of a princess.

headline: EASTERN LEAGUES
text: Colonial (F.C.S.)

headline: The Eye of the Beheld
text: ASK the federal agency charged with policing products that can be labeled “organic”: it is one of today’s most abused terms, right up there with “guaranteed” electronics and “luxury” apartments.

headline: Who Will Keep an Eye on the Spies? (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: José Saramago, the Unexpected Fantasist
text: One evening in June, the Portuguese novelist José Saramago was addressing a small gathering at a book party in Lisbon. The occasion was the reissue of a volume of his poems originally published in 1975. Saramago, who is 84, is an austere man, extremely tall and so lean that he is practically concave. The night was hot, but he was wearing, as usual, a dark suit and tie. An outspoken atheist, Saramago maintains that religion is to blame for most of the world’s violence. Yet in his old age he resembles nothing so much as a steely churchman from a Renaissance altarpiece, a St. Jerome in the desert.

headline: After Brush With Law, Hawaii’s Brennan Seeks Redemption
text: HONOLULU — After every home game, Colt Brennan waves to his probation officer as he leaves Aloha Stadium.

headline: Drafted and Thrown Into Duty
text: Andrew Miller made his 12th start of the season for Detroit on Friday in the opener of the Tigers’ four-game series with the Yankees. Joba Chamberlain, the biggest thing to hit New York since the Beatles, pitched his ninth scoreless inning in relief and was certain to relieve for the Yankees in another of the games, which are critical to the playoff races.

headline: Liberian Ex-Leader’s War Crimes Trial Is Stalled
text: PARIS, Aug. 25 — When Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, was arrested 17 months ago on war crimes charges and ordered to face international judges, it was heralded as a milestone for justice in Africa.

headline: Lara Ballard and Gigi Sohn
text: Lara Ann Ballard and Gigi Beth Sohn were joined in a civil union ceremony yesterday. Greg Trulson, a justice of the peace, officiated at the Moose Meadow Lodge in Waterbury, Vt.

headline: Letters
text: How Long Will It Take for China to Catch Up?

headline: With the Band Playing on, a Musician Gets Back to His Roots
text: Beacon

headline: Dropping the Chicken
text: Everything from the television-immortalized kitchen in Julia Child’s Cambridge house has been disassembled and reverently reinstalled at the Smithsonian Institution. Everything, that is, except the original iconic pegboard wall Paul Child designed to hang her prized copper pots, with hand-drawn outlines showing where each one goes. That wall and those pots are now enshrined 3,000 miles away in the Napa Valley, at Copia, the American Center for Wine, Food and the Arts. All Julia Child’s papers — manuscripts, lectures, fan mail — are back East, in the Schlesinger Library at Radcliffe. Except, of course, for those memories lodged in the minds and files of still very living Julia-ists, like her legendary editor, Judith Jones.

headline: Quake Victims Included in Aid Drive for Peru
text: HARRISON

headline: The Odd Woman Out, but Still Very Much at Home
text: I AM a person who likes a certain amount of peace and quiet. My three sons, on the other hand (now 12, 10 and 6), can induce chaos just by their presence. They bang and throw themselves about. They careen into table corners and door jambs. They howl in pain.

headline: Trump on the Beach
text: Say what you will about Robert Moses, master builder, despoiler of neighborhoods, symbol of all that is great and terrible in urban planning. At least he kept his name off things. And most of what he built, including his greatest achievement, Jones Beach State Park, was for the enjoyment and enrichment of the middle class. As high and mighty as Moses became, he never completely jettisoned the “public” from “public servant.”

headline: Tyson Gay Wins 100-Meter Title
text: OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 26 — Tyson Gay already had been part of a victory celebration at a world championships. He already had done a lap around the track with an American flag wrapped around his shoulders and his compatriots in a festive mood.

headline: The Letter That Changed the Future
text: ON July 12, someone slipped a letter under Ann Shannon’s front door and under the front door of every other apartment in Knickerbocker Plaza, a hulking government-subsidized complex on Second Avenue at East 91st Street.

headline: In 2008 Race, Little Ones Go on the Trail With Daddy
text: DES MOINES — Emma Claire and Jack Edwards, 9 and 7, were on their umpteenth campaign trip earlier this month, this time through small towns where their father was decrying rural poverty and the power of lobbyists.

headline: These Boots Are Made for Herding
text: IN the corporate lingo of Justin Boots, a footwear maker based in Fort Worth, professional cattle herders aren’t called cowboys. According to Louis Russo, one of the company’s brand managers, they are instead known as “Western lifestyle consumers,” and they go through expensive boots the way they go through toothbrushes.

headline: Homegrown Restaurant With Big-City Pedigree
text: AN APPETIZER called Angry Lobster. Fries with black truffles. Cheesecake ornaments hung on a tree. Not your father’s Millburn, that’s for sure. And in the case of Marc Cooperman, principal owner of a six-month-old gathering place called restaurant.mc, that is literally true.

headline: All in the Family
text: Late in “A Suitable Boy,” Vikram Seth’s fictional panorama of early 1950s India, the difficult but decent politician Mahesh Kapoor receives advice from an underling: “We should think above divisions, splits, cliques! ... This is India ... the country where faction was invented before the zero. If even the heart is divided into four parts can you expect us Indians to divide ourselves into less than 400?”

headline: Pennsylvania Political War Over Planned Tolls on I-80
text: BROOKVILLE, Pa., Aug. 23 — Anthony Foote spends a lot of time driving his Kenworth T-600 truck on Interstate 80 in Pennsylvania. He prefers it to the state’s other east-west highway, the Interstate 76 turnpike, which can cost him $140 in tolls.

headline: Correction
text: A review last Sunday about “Talking Hands: What Sign Language Reveals About the Mind,” by Margalit Fox, referred incorrectly to the remote Bedouin village whose indigenous sign language is described in the book. It is indeed called Al-Sayyid; researchers who led Fox there did not insist that she disguise its name to protect the inhabitants’ privacy.

headline: Terms of Enhancement
text: A new TV dramedy, “Lipstick Jungle,” will begin later this season on NBC, but those of us who use cosmetics every day already know that jungle well: it’s anywhere makeup and skin-care products are sold. High-end department stores or drugstores with more quotidian picks carry vast arrays of beauty products designed to baffle and confuse you, or so it seems. Some products offer vague instructions on how to use them; others are shrouded in self-serving dermababble that’s best deconstructed by molecular biologists and chemists. Some products are self-explanatory, but provide no clues as to where they fit into your daily routine. When exactly do you use a primer? Should your sunblock be applied before the moisturizer, or does it double as a moisturizer? Does makeup remover clean your face, and why do some cleansers exfoliate?

headline: Dress Rehearsal Shows No One Is Ready to Open

headline: The  Prêt Set
text: If names like Walter Albini, Ted Lapidus, Krizia and Guy Laroche don’t send you sprinting to your favorite vintage dealer, it’s time to bone up on your fashion history. By referencing the labels that epitomized European elegance 30 years ago, designers are reliving the golden age of prêt-à-porter — that heady era when dressing down meant settling for tights and Charles Jourdan sandals rather than fishnets and Maud Frizon pumps.

headline: A Revived Program and an Altered State at Rutgers
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  Mike Teel cannot quite pick the most preposterous moment of the past few months, but he has several to choose from. There was the man in Cancún, Mexico, gushing congratulations when he realized Teel was Rutgers’s quarterback. Or the time his face flashed on the video scoreboard while he was attending a Nets game, drawing the biggest cheer of the night. Or perhaps it was contemplating a billboard on the side of the New Jersey Turnpike inviting fans to join Rutgers’s season ticket waiting list.

headline: The Fed’s Subprime Solution
text: THE subprime mortgage crisis of 2007 is, in fact, a credit crisis — a worldwide disruption in lending and borrowing. It is only the latest in a long succession of such disturbances. Who’s to blame? The human race, first and foremost. Well-intended public policy, second. And Wall Street, third — if only for taking what generations of policy makers have so unwisely handed it.

headline: Getting Too Big for His Own Taxes?
text: Leona Helmsley may be dead but her oft-quoted sentiment that “only the little people pay taxes” lives on at CBS. In an amendment to his contract as C.E.O. of CBS, Leslie Moonves obtained the company’s promise to pay any state or local taxes he might incur in New York. The amendment states that Mr. Moonves, who lives in Southern California, cannot claim that having to work now and then in Manhattan is a “good reason” for quitting his job. But, it says, if New York authorities try to tax him for earning income in their territory, CBS will pick up the bill.
