Today we are living at the dawn of the ultra-mega-uber-monster book party, celebrations so huge and elaborate that you might think you were at a wedding, or at the bar mitzvah of a child who will, by his 16 and 1/365th birthday, own a car you will never be able to afford.

headline: My Car-Free Life

I knew that I would never own a car again as long as I lived in the city, and I planned to live in the city forever.

headline: Inside the List
text: WHY IS EVERYONE NAKED, MOTHER? Pat Montandon’s new memoir, “Oh the Hell of It All,” is a response of sorts to her son Sean Wilsey’s memoir, “Oh the Glory of It All,” which made the hardcover list for three weeks in 2005. Montandon’s book definitely isn’t her first. In 1968 she published a chic and sunny primer called “How to Be a Party Girl.” Poking around in that earlier book does give you a sense of what it must have been like to be Sean Wilsey. Chapter Five is titled “Why Is Everyone Naked, Mother?” The answer: “Shh, darling, this is a Garden of Eden Party. You’ll understand when you’re a little older. Run along, now.” Montandon’s book also includes this helpful advice: “Suppose you read in the newspaper one morning that a rarely seen comet is approaching Earth, and will be visible on a certain evening a few weeks off. Do you yawn and go on to the stock market reports and the obituaries? Not if you’re a Party Girl. You telephone the City Fathers ... and you ask them if they would like to lend you the Planetarium, for a Comet-Viewing Party.” When Playboy asked Montandon to pose for a centerfold, she declined: “Experts in the entertainment field tell me there’s such a thing as overexposure, and I certainly wouldn’t want to be a bore.” Alex Kuczynski reviews the new book this week.

headline: Dress Mode
text: I don’t like pants. Or I should say, I don’t like wearing pants. The entire jeans revolution of the past decade — the special rinses; the cuts that amplify the derrière or lengthen the leg; the low rise and the boot cut — does not intrigue me. The only time I wear pants is to walk my dog, and I wear them then only when the weather is freezing. Mostly, I use pants as a kind of fatness monitor: a particular pair of very narrow A.P.C. jeans functions like a scale. Twice a week, every week, I try them on. If they’re tight, I cut out chocolate; if they’re loose, I rejoice. Either way, the jeans stay on my body for about 15 minutes, long enough to truly gauge the fit, and then I change into a dress or a skirt. Like I said, I don’t like pants.

headline: Dirty Harry
text: I once found a great Perfecto jacket at a secondhand store in California; it was really small, probably a child’s size. I loved it because most people were still wearing hippie dresses to the floor back then, and we were much tougher with our straight-legged pants and narrow lapels — I guess you would have called our look Euro-mod. I used to hang around the New York Dolls, and they were definitely into those jackets. I remember having one that was black on the outside with red pleats in the back. Eventually, I started noticing lots of women in the music scene doing a “West Side Story” kind of tough-girl look with motorcycle jackets in different colors. My friend Stephen Sprouse did a cartoonlike version of the Perfecto, which I loved because it was almost to the knees. It’s cool that these jackets keep coming back — biker style is an American classic.

headline: Up Front
text: The novelist Darcey Steinke has two central themes. “I’ve always liked to write about sex and violence,” she said by phone the other day. And she’s always been drawn to “religion and divinity, and how a physical life would fit into that.” Both strands appear in Steinke’s novels — which include “Suicide Blonde,” “Jesus Saves” and “Milk” — and are the heart of her most recent book, “Easter Everywhere,” a memoir about growing up as the daughter of a Lutheran minister, which appeared this spring. Why a memoir? “I had a lot of theological ideas about myself and about religion and God, and I felt they were getting in the way of my fiction writing,” Steinke said. “Everybody was in the pulpit. Fiction is so much about paradox and ambiguity — so is religion — but I had all these new exciting ideas getting in the way.” A devotee of Augustine’s “Confessions,” she thinks memoirs should transcend the pulp-paperback form — “I was a sinner and now I’ve been saved” — yet still engage with “ideas of spiritual transformation.” “I’m all for 12-step, but I want there to be some sense of people wrestling with God,” she said.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE GREAT DELUGE: Hurricane Katrina, New Orleans, and the Mississippi Gulf Coast, by Douglas Brinkley. (Harper Perennial, $17.95. ) Interviewing hundreds of Katrina survivors, disaster responders and public officials, Brinkley, a professor of history at Tulane University in New Orleans, weaves their stories into a narrative of the hurricane’s first week. “The Great Deluge” harshly criticizes the inept response of the White House; FEMA; the mayor of New Orleans, Ray Nagin; and the city’s police department, while crediting those who filled the breach. Our reviewer, David Oshinsky, said Brinkley provides “a groundlevel view of human behavior far richer than the breathless news reports that stunned and shamed the nation in the summer of 2005.”

headline: Editor’s Choice

headline: Clinton Fund-Raiser on the Vineyard
text: OAK BLUFFS, Mass. – Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said Saturday evening that if she is elected president in 2008, she would quickly ask “distinguished Americans of both parties” to travel the world before her inauguration to proclaim a new era of “bipartisan foreign policy” in the United States.

headline: ‘Bad Monkeys’
text: It's a room an uninspired playwright might conjure while staring at a blank page: White walls. White ceiling. White floor. Not featureless, but close enough to raise suspicion that its few contents are all crucial to the upcoming drama.

headline: ‘Oh the Hell of It All: A Memoir’
text: Almost everything was considered a sin while I was growing up as a preacher's daughter in Texas and Oklahoma in the '30s: makeup, dying one's hair, funny papers on Sunday, movies, short-sleeved dresses, and jewelry. Tent revival meetings with sermonizers exhorting sinners to confess dotted the landscape, which stretched mile after mile across the flat plains of the Lone Star State and throughout the rolling hills of Oklahoma.

headline: ‘The Forgotten Man: A New History of the Great Depression’
text: Floods change the course of history, and the Flood of 1927 was no exception. When the waters of the Mississippi broke through banks and levees that spring, the disaster was enormous. A wall of water pushed down the river, covering the area where nearly a million lived. Commerce Secretary Herbert Hoover raced to Memphis and took command. Hoover talked railroads into transporting the displaced for free and carrying freight at a discount. He commandeered private outboard motors and built motorboats of plywood. He urged the people who were not yet flooded out, such as the population around the Bayou des Glaises levee, to evacuate early, then rescued with the trains those tens of thousands who had ignored his warning. He helped the Red Cross launch a fund drive; within a month the charity had already collected promises of more than $8 million, an enormous figure for the time.

headline: ‘Bearing the Body’
text: It was a spring evening and he had come in too soon. Beyond the dining room window the catalpa tossed heavily, leaves grown huge this week, trailing seedpods comically like tassels. The light over the houses was a charged blue, not as in winter when it drained abruptly into night, but softer, a presence, almost liquid, an invitation, a tease. In the street, a car circled a second time, its radio up, and he leaned in to hear but caught only the thin edge of a melody before it turned the corner and faded.

headline: ‘Backstage With Julia: My Years With Julia Child’
text: "It's an honor to have you on board, Mrs. Childs," announced the handsome flight attendant neatly clad in midnight-blue slacks, white shirt, and logoed tie. Bending over our seats, he whispered conspiratorially with a Texas drawl as broad as the state itself, "I'm such a huge fan. I have all your cookbooks."

headline: ‘The Camel Bookmobile’
text: Fiona Sweeney shoved a pair of rolled-up jeans into the corner of her purple duffel bag. Outside her bedroom window, a siren's wail sliced through the white noise of a wet snowfall. Those eerie man-made moans were part of New York City's wallpaper, a signal of trouble commonplace enough to pass unnoticed. But Fi registered this one, maybe because she knew she wouldn't be hearing sirens for a while.

headline: ‘India After Gandhi’
text: Freedom came to India on 15 August 1947, but patriotic Indians had celebrated their first "Independence Day" seventeen years before. In the first week of January 1930, the Indian National Congress passed a resolution fixing the last Sunday of the month for countrywide demonstrations in support of purna swaraj, or complete independence. This, it was felt, would both stoke nationalist aspirations and force the British to seriously consider giving up power. In an essay in his journal Young India, Mahatma Gandhi set out how the day should be observed: "It would be good if the declaration [of independence] is made by whole villages, whole cities even.... It would be well if all the meetings were held at the identical minute in all the places."

headline: ‘The Bloodstone Papers’
text: (Bolton and London, 2004)

headline: ‘Circling My Mother: A Memoir’
text: In the year 1908, Pierre Bonnard painted The Bathroom and my mother was born. The posture of the young woman in the painting is that of someone enraptured by the miracle of light. The light is filtered through the lace curtains, and its patterning is reflected in the water that fills the tub into which she is about to step. Even the floral spread on the divan from which she has just risen is an emblem of prosperity and joy. Bonnard is famous for painting bathing women; in all her life my mother has never taken a bath. At three, she was stricken with polio, and she never had the agility to get in or out of a bathtub. She told me that once, after I was born, my father tried to lift her into a bath, but it made them both too nervous.

headline: Blowin’ in the Wind
text: When the issue of energy came up in the debate among the Democratic presidential contenders on Aug. 7, the candidates began talking about “renewable” energy and one of them (Chris Dodd) mentioned wind power. Seems logical. Why spend all the effort and money to build huge electricity plants when the wind is always blowing? Who could argue against a technology that promises to derive energy from a renewable, and free, resource?

headline: Julius Wess, 72, Theoretical Physicist, Is Dead
text: Julius Wess, a theoretical physicist who plumbed the universe for unseen symmetries, including those in a theory that led to a prediction of a new class of fundamental particles, died Aug. 8 in Hamburg, Germany. He was 72.

headline: Passion, Through a Choir’s Revelation
text: New Yorkers have gotten to know the Schola Cantorum de Venezuela, a noteworthy Caracas chorus, for its participation in the Argentine composer Osvaldo Golijov’s “Pasión Según San Marcos.” The group performed it at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 2002, at Lincoln Center in 2006 and in this year’s Mostly Mozart Festival. Based on that, one could assume that the chorus was formed to sing Mr. Golijov’s piece.

headline: From Either Side of the Bar, Firefighters Embrace a Tradition

headline: Russia Arrests 10 in Journalist Death
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 27 — Russia’s prosecutor general said Monday that 10 people had been arrested for roles in the contract killing of Anna Politkovskaya, the prominent journalist and Kremlin critic. The arrested included a Chechen crime boss and career officers from the country’s police and intelligence services, he said.

headline: Past 50, and Still Running Into the Flames
text: There was a two-digit footnote to tragedy tucked behind the name of a fallen firefighter, Robert Beddia, who died Aug. 18 in the blaze at the Deutsche Bank skyscraper at ground zero. It was his age.

headline: Sax, Meet Oud: Jazz With an Arabic Accent
text: In past encounters Kristjan Jarvi’s Absolute Ensemble has generally been a classical chamber orchestra with an endearingly eclectic programming style in which standard repertory, new works and arrangements of rock songs rubbed shoulders, sometimes in seamless suites. But at Damrosch Park on Saturday evening it seemed clear that the ensemble is whatever Mr. Jarvi wants it to be, its makeup governed by the project he has assembled.

headline: Not Only Yankees Fans Cheering for Week 22
text: As the baseball executive in charge of the schedule, Katy Feeney is often the target of criticism from clubs and fans who don’t like some aspect of the schedule. It is only fair, then, to salute Feeney for her efforts for week No. 22 of the 26-week season. This, without any question, is her week.

headline: As Counsel, Thompson Walked Capital’s Fine Line
text: The Reagan administration was only a few months old when it faced a major test: Senators were calling for the head of the president’s new director of central intelligence, and no one knew if he would survive their investigation into his tangled past business dealings and questionable agency management.

headline: Ravaging Appalachia
text: Give the Bush administration credit for persistence. It just won’t let a bad idea die. On Friday, the Interior Department’s Office of Surface Mining proposed new regulations that it hopes will permanently legalize mountaintop mining  a cheap, ruthlessly efficient, environmentally destructive means of mining coal from the mountains of Appalachia.

headline: As Playoffs Near, Edwards Is Gaining Momentum
text: BRISTOL, Tenn., Aug. 26  The race to the playoffs is almost over in Nascar’s Nextel Cup series, and the drama that usually makes the final few weeks of the regular season a miniclimax is oddly missing this time. With two weeks to go before the Chase for the Nextel Cup begins, there is little doubt who will make the 12-car field, from the points leader Jeff Gordon to the 12th-place driver Kurt Busch.

headline: The College Credit Scam
text: The credit card industry has made a profitable art of corralling consumers into ruinous interest rates and hidden penalties that keep even people who pay their bills permanently mired in debt. The companies are especially eager to target freshly minted college students, who are naïve in money matters and especially vulnerable to credit card offers that are too good to be true.

headline: In Online World, Pocket Change Is Not Easily Spent
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 — The idea of micropayments — charging Web users tiny amounts of money for single pieces of online content — was essentially put to sleep toward the end of the dot-com boom. In December 2000, Clay Shirky, an adjunct professor in New York University’s interactive telecommunications program, wrote a manifesto that people still cite whenever someone suggests resurrecting the idea. Micropayments will never work, he wrote, mainly because “users hate them.”

headline: Giants’ Tuck Excels as Strahan’s Replacement
text: Before Saturday night’s game against the Jets, talk of Michael Strahan swirled through the Giants’ locker room. Players heard that Strahan was on his way back, ending his thoughts of retirement. Several later said they expected Strahan to rejoin the team as early as yesterday or today.

headline: Japanese Premier Reshuffles Cabinet
text: TOKYO, Aug. 27 — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe sought to overturn sinking approval ratings and calls for his resignation today by forming a new cabinet made up of political veterans.

headline: A Test of Skill in Beijing, but Not the Olympics
text: In this column 16 days ago I mentioned that the 2008 World Youth Team Championship might not take place because no country had undertaken to be host. I have since learned that my information was inaccurate. The World Bridge Federation is making it part of the inaugural World Mind Sports Games, which will take place Oct. 3 to 18, 2008, in Beijing.

text: Air travel has come a long way from a half-century ago, when passengers were in privileged company, themselves and their bags handled with respect. Flights were guided by a radar air traffic control system that was state of the art.

headline: Cellphone-Only Homes Hit a Milestone
text: From September 2006 to April 2007, the percentage of Americans in cellphone-only households for the first time overtook the percentage in landline-only households, according to Mediamark Research, a firm that has been tracking such data since the mid-1980s.

headline: Second-Chance Showings
text: For the second year the New York International Fringe Festival, which ended yesterday after 16 days and 200 productions, will be followed by the FringeNYC Encore Series, offering quick revivals of selected shows. Starting on Thursday 12 of the festival’s productions will be presented in rotating repertory at SoHo Playhouse and the Bleecker Street Theater through Sept. 16. Among those chosen for remounting are “Hillary Agonistes,” by Nick Salamone and starring Priscilla Barnes, above, of the sitcom “Three’s Company,” as Hillary Clinton, and “Bombs in Your Mouth,” a comedy about dysfunctional half-siblings who reunite after their father’s death. The full lineup and schedule for the series will be posted at fringenyc-encoreseries.com.

headline: With a Laugh, Shakespearean Stoppard Meets Stoppardian Shakespeare
text: LENOX, Mass. — Natasha, the foreign prima donna scheduled to play the leading lady in “The Cruise of the Dodo,” doesn’t have much respect for that unfinished musical’s creators: two playwrights who seem to be making up the story as they go along, jumbling together an emerald earring worn by the Empress Josephine, a suave international jewel thief, a stowaway, a kidnapping, a case of mistaken identity and just about every other cliché once found on the popular stage. Even the play’s title invokes an extinct, waddling bird instead of a mythic Carthaginian queen because no one thought it worth correcting a typo that turned Dido into Dodo.

headline: Footnotes
text: The Off Broadway “Frankenstein” coming this fall — not to be confused with the Mel Brooks monster musical “Young Frankenstein” — has some new cast members. Joining the previously announced Hunter Foster (“Urinetown”) as Dr. Victor Frankenstein, the mad scientist, are Steve Blanchard (“Beauty and the Beast”) as the monster and Christiane Noll (“Jekyll & Hyde”) as Frankenstein’s wife, Elizabeth. The new musical, inspired by Mary Shelley’s 1818 novel, will begin performances at 37 Arts on Oct. 10. ... The collective 13 Playwrights Inc., better known as 13P, will next present “Have You Seen Steve Steven?,” by Ann Marie Healy, beginning Sept. 15 at the East 14th Street Theater in the East Village. Ms. Healy’s comic drama, to be directed by Anne Kauffman (“The Thugs”), is about a Midwestern teenager whose life and sense of reality are knocked out of whack by what starts as a seemingly normal visit from a neighbor.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a sports article Thursday referred incorrectly to Roger Federer’s streak of United States Open titles. He is attempting to become the first man in the open era, which began in 1968, to win the United States Open four consecutive years. He would not be the first man ever to do it. Three men have won at least four in a row; the last was Bill Tilden, who won six consecutive Opens from 1920 to 1925.

headline: Inside a Jumble of Poverty, Texans Build a Future

headline: Norman Cohn, Historian, Dies at 92
text: Norman Cohn, a historian who influenced a generation of historians and social scientists with his insight that totalitarian ideologies of the 20th century, chiefly Communism and Nazism, were propelled by mythologies associated with medieval apocalyptic movements, died on July 31 in Cambridge, England. He was 92.

text: Home Depot was forced to drop the sale price of its commercial supply business by nearly $2 billion yesterday, according to people involved in the negotiations, one of the first big buyouts to be renegotiated as a result of the recent tightening of credit and problems in the housing market.

headline: On 10th Anniversary, ‘Dianabilia’ Takes Over
text: A DECADE ago, Diana, Princess of Wales, became a powerful princess of sales as her death created a cottage industry of marketers cashing in with books, magazines, television shows and merchandise like figurines and coins.

headline: Liberian Ex-Leader’s War Crimes Trial Is Stalled
text: PARIS, Aug. 25 — When Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, was arrested 17 months ago on war crimes charges and ordered to face international judges, it was heralded as a milestone for justice in Africa.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Sarah M. Boyd joined Vincent Partners, New York, as a new partner in the public relations division. She had been a vice president at Rubenstein Public Relations, New York.

headline: Late to Web Retailing? There’s Still Money There
text: DURING the tech bust, GSI Commerce Inc. was the company that salvaged many operations. Beginning in 2000, as start-ups failed, GSI increased its business by buying distressed online retailers like Fogdog.com and Ashford.com, and running the entire operations more efficiently than the retailers could themselves.

headline: ‘To Catch a Predator’ Is Falling Prey to Advertisers’ Sensibilities
text: In the last 18 months, NBC’s investigative segment “To Catch a Predator” has received wide attention, rejuvenating ratings for the network’s “Dateline NBC” newsmagazine and making a celebrity of Chris Hansen, the show’s host, who confronts men trolling online chat rooms hoping to meet teenagers for sex.

headline: Wells Makes a Good First Impression
text: David Wells had every reason to feel a little awkward during the series finale between the Mets and the Los Angeles Dodgers last night at Shea Stadium. But instead he looked right at home, delivering an outing that must have impressed his new teammates.

headline: Greek Fires Kill 12 More and Threaten Antiquities
text: ZAHARO, Greece, Aug. 26 — At least 12 more people were reported dead on Sunday in fierce forest fires in Greece, as walls of flame, though slowed in somewhat calmer winds, continued to consume homes and threatened the ruins where the Olympic Games were first played.

headline: Mortgage Crisis Forces Sale of German Bank
text: PARIS, Aug. 26 — The eastern German state of Saxony was forced to sell a troubled state-run bank Sunday as the global liquidity crisis set off by the United States subprime mortgage problems claimed its first major European victim.

headline: Another Prize
Humane Society Has Its Sights on Amazon.com
text: Michael Vick, the Atlanta Falcons quarterback, is expected to plead guilty today to federal dog-fighting charges and face up to five years in prison, but the Humane Society of the United States has a bigger target: Amazon.com.

headline: Federer and Nadal Help Bring Back the Rivalry to Tennis
text: Attempt to put Roger Federer’s deepening rivalry with Rafael Nadal into historical perspective, and it is striking how few great rivalries tennis has had to choose from of late.

headline: Superbad Scores Again
text: The raunchy teenage sex romp “Superbad,” starring Michael Cera, Jonah Hill (far right) and Christopher Mintz-Plasse (near right) as high school friends on a quest for alcohol and girls, held the top spot at the box office for the second consecutive weekend, grossing $18 million and upping the film’s cumulative gross to $68.6 million in 10 days, according to estimates released yesterday by the box office tracking company Media by Numbers. The summer has been superhot for Hollywood, as the overall box office reached a record $4 billion, beating the 2004 record of $3.95 billion with one more weekend to go before summer is over. This weekend alone the top 12 movies took in $90.2 million, an increase of 7 percent over the same weekend in 2006. The thriller “The Bourne Ultimatum” (Universal) moved up from last weekend, rising to second place from third with an estimated haul of $12.4 million in its fourth week of release, and a cumulative take of $185 million in four weeks. Swapping places with “Bourne,” the comedy “Rush Hour 3” (New Line), starring Jackie Chan and Chris Tucker, dropped to third place with $12.3 million for the weekend and $109 million overall in three weeks. Rounding out the top five were two new releases, “Mr. Bean’s Holiday” (Universal), the Rowan Atkinson comedy, which made $10.1 million, and the action film “War” (Lionsgate), with Jet Li and Jason Statham, which took in $10 million.

headline: Close Aides to Musharraf Meet With His Opposition
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 26 — Close aides to Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, and the chief of the country’s intelligence agency are in London to hold talks with Benazir Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif, the president’s two main political opponents, two generally reliable Pakistani newspapers reported Sunday.

headline: Andy Rooney Regrets a Racist Comment in a Recent Column
text: The humorist and commentator Andy Rooney has made a career out of being a grumpy old man, most frequently at the end of “60 Minutes” on CBS. But his latest rant, in the syndicated column he writes for Tribune Media Services, drew fire last week for crossing the line from crotchety to racist.

headline: Beat Federer? a) Be Serious. b) You Cannot Be Serious.
text: We know Roger Federer is friends with Tiger Woods. We know that his girlfriend of seven years, Mirka Vavrinec, is a former professional tennis player. We know he has been ranked No. 1 in the world since Feb. 2, 2004, a record streak.

headline: Aching Knee Keeps Jeter Out of the Lineup
text: DETROIT, Aug. 26  Derek Jeter never volunteers much about injuries. For Manager Joe Torre to determine the severity of a problem, he gauges Jeter’s reaction when he offers him a day off.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A map of Greece with an article yesterday about fires there included an erroneous mileage scale, showing a span that should have been labeled 100 miles instead of 10.

headline: Iraqi Prime Minister Assails Democratic Critics
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 26 — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki on Sunday extended his tongue-lashing of foreign politicians who have questioned his government, saying that two Democratic senators, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Carl Levin, needed to “start making sense again” after they called for his ouster.

headline: Suspended Spitzer Aide Is Expected Back at Work
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s communications director, who was a central figure in an attempt to use the State Police to embarrass the governor’s main rival, is expected to return to state government as early as this week, people briefed on the matter said yesterday.

headline: The C.I.A.’s Open Secrets
text: WHEN a federal judge dismissed Valerie Plame’s lawsuit against the Central Intelligence Agency earlier this month, she ruled that the agency was entitled to stop Ms. Plame from publishing the dates of her agency service, even though these dates had been supplied to Congress in an unclassified letter from the C.I.A. and had been published in The Congressional Record. Ms. Plame is just one in a long line of ex-C.I.A. employees to lose similar suits, in which the agency successfully defended the position that information in the public domain was classified.

headline: Bring in the Reggae, Hold the Hate
text: The more-or-less annual concert known as Reggae Carifest always seems to be controversial. Sometimes the lineup doesn’t match the flier. Or the stars spend their time onstage attacking one another. Or the audience can’t pick a favorite.

headline: Afghan Elders and U.S. Differ on Who Killed 12 Civilians
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 26 — Afghan elders said Sunday that airstrikes had killed 12 civilians in the southern province of Helmand on Saturday night, but an American military spokesman blamed Taliban militants for the civilian deaths.

headline: Helping Darfur Refugees ( Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Tame, the Trashy and the Rocker Quality
text: VH1’s “Rock of Love With Bret Michaels” is carnival sludge: a nauseating paste of fried dough, cigarette ash, salt and grain alcohol. The rococo pageantry and high spirits of “Flavor of Love,” the channel’s seminal reality dating competition, starring the hype man Flavor Flav, have gone missing from this, the rock version.

headline: Djokovic Looking for a Piece of the Pie
text: In a way, Novak Djokovic’s tennis career began at the Red Bull, the pizza-and-pancakes place his parents opened about 15 years ago in the Serbian ski resort town of Kopaonik.

headline: Taste of Victory: Online Outcry Revives a Chocolate Bar
text: LONDON, Aug. 26 — Two weeks ago, a Facebook member in Manchester, England, added her name to an online campaign to bring back a chocolate bar called Wispa, discontinued by its maker, Cadbury, four years ago.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 7 P.M. (USA) UNITED STATES OPEN  Venus and Serena Williams will play back-to-back matches following the opening-night festivities, which will celebrate the 50th anniversary of Althea Gibson’s historic victory at what was then called the National Championships. During the ceremony, titled “Breaking Barriers,” African-American female pioneers in the fields of sports, entertainment, politics and the arts will converge on the court to celebrate Gibson’s life and career. Serena Williams, above, was the first black woman since Gibson to win the United States Open; Venus Williams was the first black woman since Gibson to win Wimbledon. Tonight Serena is scheduled to play Angelique Kerber of Germany and Venus will play a qualifier. For Venus this year’s tournament is about more than tennis; this budding designer will be decked out in an outfit and shoes from her new EleVen label, which is produced in partnership with the retailer Steve & Barry’s. The morning rounds begin at 11.

headline: Orchestra Exchange Program
text: The Osnabrück Symphony Orchestra of Germany, led by the conductor Hermann Baeumer, will perform a program of Beethoven and Brahms in Tehran on Wednesday and Thursday, the Associated Press reported. The visit is part of an exchange program between the two nations, and follows a concert by the Tehran Symphony Orchestra last year in Osnabrück. “It’s a very small step in improving relations between the people in the two countries,” said Michael Dreyer, the head of Osnabrück’s Morgenland Festival, which played host to last year’s visitors from Iran. The female German musicians will observe Iranian law and wear headscarves.

headline: More Primary Care Doctors (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Testing a Format, in a Test of Firsts
text: When YouTube pitched its new advertising format to me, it described the semitransparent ads it is overlaying on videos as “something that has not been available before.” It probably should have added: “on YouTube.”

headline: Unauthorized Enjoyment of Song Irks Law Firm
text: It sounds like the setup for a joke: a law firm picks a fight with a legal blogger over the leak of an internal song celebrating — well, itself.

headline: Raymond Barre, 83, Former French Premier, Dies
text: PARIS, Aug. 26 — Raymond Barre, a prominent economist who was prime minister of France from 1976 to 1981, died in Paris on Saturday. He was 83.

headline: An 80-Year-Old Poet for the MTV Generation
text: MtvU, the subsidiary of MTV Networks that is broadcast only on college campuses, will announce today that it has selected its first poet laureate. No, he doesn’t rap. And it’s not Bob Dylan, or even Justin Timberlake.

headline: Forty Years of Growth, Except Where It Was Expected
text: Sometime in the 1950s, Amelia Delgado planted a sapling outside her Lower East Side tenement at 145 Clinton Street, where she and her husband, Ramon, were raising five children. The children are grown, have done well and now have children of their own. Her husband died 14 years ago.

headline: Popular Demand
text: Companies advertising on the cable and network television broadcasts of last year’s United States Open Tennis spent a total of $91.3 million. Roger Federer, above, and Maria Sharapova will defend their singles championships in the 14-day tournament, which starts today.

headline: After the Big 2
text: The Next Big One?

headline: In Full Summer, Pattern Emerges for Venus Williams
text: Venus Ebony Starr Williams stepped into her design company offices dressed in a tropical peasant skirt that flowed like a waterfall to her sandals. Winston, her 3-year-old springer spaniel, trailed with happy indifference.

headline: Boston’s Other Japanese Pitcher
text: CHICAGO, Aug. 26 — He came to the Red Sox as the other Japanese pitcher, a 31-year-old rookie reliever still mistaken for his more celebrated teammate by autograph seekers and in the occasional newspaper photo caption. Earlier this season, a Boston cabbie kept raving about this new guy, Hideki Okajima, unaware that his favorite left-hander was riding in the back seat.

headline: Bank Profits May Well Suffer, but Credit Crisis Hardly Leaves Them Defenseless
text: Banks these days are like football players running the gantlet drill: the turmoil in the credit markets is bound to hit them on one side or the other, even if they make it through.

headline: A Solution Seen to ‘Brain Drain’
text: A new academic study details the benefits and the threat of a “reverse brain drain” — skilled foreign workers going back to their home countries because they cannot get visas in the United States. One of the study’s authors has a solution that is not in step with the high-tech lobby. He advocates getting rid of the H-1B visa, the temporary work permit for skilled workers.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Pie Show
text: Joe Carlucci, the owner of Famous Joe’s, a Danbury, Conn., pizzeria, is also a “pizza acrobat” and will demonstrate his singular way with a hunk of dough on Saturday on the corner of Mulberry and Broome Streets in Little Italy. In a 40-minute performance set to Italian folk music, Mr. Carlucci, who won a gold medal at the “Squadra Acrobatica” Pizza Olympics in Salsomaggiore, Italy, in both 2006 and 2007, will perform gymnastics while balancing and tossing several pies.

headline: The Kibbutz Sheds Socialism and Gains Popularity
text: KIBBUTZ YASUR, Israel — For much of Israel’s existence, the kibbutz embodied its highest ideals: collective labor, love of the land and a no-frills egalitarianism.

headline: W.H.O. Urges Effort to Fight Fast-Spreading New Diseases
text: ROME, Aug. 25 — New infectious diseases are emerging at an “unprecedented rate,” and far greater human mobility — by planes, trains and ships — means that diseases have the potential to spread rapidly across the globe, a World Health Organization report warned this week.

headline: Twin Cities Editor Planning Online Daily
text: Joel Kramer, the former editor and publisher of The Star Tribune of Minneapolis, is expected today to announce plans for an online, nonprofit daily newspaper for the Minneapolis-St. Paul area, the country’s 14th largest media market.

headline: His Next Line to Cross
text: RAFAEL NADAL could continue banging from behind the baseline, flexing his muscular left arm and sending weary opponents flailing across courts of clay.

headline: A Political Crisis Brews in Greece as Fires Rage
text: MAKISTOS, Greece, Aug. 27 — When the water ran out, with pinecones popping and the flames still high around his house, George Dimopoulos switched to wine. He made it himself two years ago, and, nearly alone in his village as it all but burnt down on Friday night, he poured liter after liter, 200 in all, into his little copper hand-pumped crop sprayer — and sprayed and sprayed.

headline: So Bad They’re Good
text: Tom O’Horgan, who directed the original production of “Hair,” almost 40 years ago, will be honored at the opening night of the second annual Bad Plays Festival, which runs Sept. 10 to 30 at the Players Theater on Macdougal Street in Greenwich Village. The three-week festival, presented by NY Artists Unlimited (nyartists.org), comprises plays intended to be so bad — meaning irreverent, satirical and bawdy — that they are, it’s hoped, quite good.

headline: The Muse Who Made the Guitars Gently Weep
text: Pattie Boyd calls herself a muse, and she has the ravishing love songs (George Harrison’s “Something,” Eric Clapton’s “Layla” and “Bell Bottom Blues”) to prove it. But in Ms. Boyd’s case, being a muse also means never having paid a light bill until she was 45, jobless and suddenly unplugged from the world of rock ’n’ roll royalty.

headline: A Socialist Plot
text: Suppose, for a moment, that the Heritage Foundation were to put out a press release attacking the liberal view that even children whose parents could afford to send them to private school should be entitled to free government-run education.

headline: BET Says Cartoon Was Just a Satire
text: Black Entertainment Television’s new animation division seems to have stepped right into a pitfall of self-parody: a short cartoon video it introduced on July 20, “Read a Book,” seems to flaunt every negative stereotype in the African-American community.

headline: Using Muscle to Improve Health Care for Prisoners
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Last year, shortly after receiving extraordinary powers to overhaul the medical system in California’s prisons, Robert Sillen, armed with a stack of court papers, issued a blunt warning to cabinet officials at the governor’s office in Sacramento.

headline: Tourist in Russia Stumbles Into a Legal Predicament
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 25  Two months ago, Roxana Contreras was exploring a provincial Russian town when a street vendor persuaded her to buy some Red Army medals and old ruble notes the day before she was to return to her home in St. Louis, she said.

headline: A Director Sounds Off, but Is Soon Reassured
text: It used to be much easier for Hollywood to keep its employees under lockdown, so to speak. Faced with a volatile director who has trouble staying away from a microphone? Attach an attack-dog publicist to his hip and — presto! — problem solved.

headline: Vick Pleads Guilty in Dog-Fighting Case
text: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 27 — Michael Vick formally accepted a plea agreement from the federal government today at the United States District Court here, pleading guilty to a felony charge stemming from a dog fighting ring run from a property he owned.

headline: Sarajevo Film Festival Awards
text: A Turkish film about the fear of God overwhelming a true believer caught up in a powerful religious group was chosen as the best movie at the 13th Sarajevo Film Festival, Reuters reported. “Takva: A Man’s Fear of God,” directed by Ozer Kiziltan, won the Heart of Sarajevo award, which comes with a prize of 25,000 euros ($34,100). A jury led by the British actor Jeremy Irons made the decision, and the award was presented at the festival’s closing night ceremony Saturday. In the film a pious Istanbul man leads a solitary life until a religious group recruits him to work as a rent collector. His new job, which thrusts him into the modern world, tests his religious devotion. The seven-day festival included screenings of more than 170 feature films, shorts and documentaries.

headline: Pavarotti Goes Home
text: Luciano Pavarotti, below, was released from a hospital in his hometown, Modena, Italy, on Saturday after more than two weeks of treatment and testing since he was admitted with a high fever on Aug. 8, the BBC reported. Mr. Pavarotti, 71, underwent surgery for pancreatic cancer last July, and has not been seen in public since. At the time, he was in the midst of a farewell tour and had hoped to continue the tour this year, but so far his health has not allowed him back onstage.

headline: The MacArthur Lunch
text: United Nations

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A map of Greece with an article yesterday about fires there included an erroneous mileage scale, showing a span that should have been labeled 100 miles instead of 10. (Go to Article)

headline: No Votes, Just Hugs, Smiles and Pop
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Aug. 24 — If you’re starting to feel that this summer has been one long, hot slog, just be glad you’re not Jordin Sparks. Or Sanjaya Malakar. Or Melinda Doolittle. Or what’s-his-name, the bald one.

headline: New York City Fire Dept. Disciplines 3 Officers After Blaze
text: The New York City Fire Department relieved three officers of their commands today as it continued its investigation into the fire at the former Deutsche Bank building that killed two firefighters earlier this month.

headline: Mexico’s Plutocracy Thrives on Robber-Baron Concessions
text: Growing up in Mexico City, I always knew Mexico was an unjust country — a place where small coteries of the privileged control all power and wealth while half the population lives in poverty. But it never occurred to me that Mexico would have billionaires.

headline: For Stricker and Caddie, Overdue Tears of Joy
text: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 26  In the half-light of a hazy summer evening, when all of his work was done, Steve Stricker closed his eyes and let the tears fall.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption with a Page One article on Thursday about the electricity shortages in Baghdad and elsewhere caused by armed groups’ seizing control of switching stations in the power grid misstated in some copies the reason numerous electrical wires span the streets of the city. The wires are fed by private generators that are used as backups for districts without power from the central grid. The owners of the generators are not the ones withholding power from the grid.

headline: Way Before Lindsay and Britney, Chaos Swirled Around Iphigenia
text: If you think Lindsay Lohan has family problems, meet the new party girl on the scene, a blond ditz who should make the editors of Us Weekly drool.

headline: Remember Squirtle and Jigglypuff? They’re Back
text: Playground fads come and go, as those who have found themselves with neglected collections of Beanie Babies can attest.

headline: Jets’ Young Linemen Have Lessons to Learn
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 26  The Jets’ inexperienced left guards were not the only linemen exposed Saturday night.

headline: For the Road
text: Cormac McCarthy has been awarded the James Tait Black Memorial Prize for fiction for his novel “The Road,” the BBC reported. The prize was announced at the Edinburgh International Book Festival on Saturday, and Mr. McCarthy was not in attendance. Mr. McCarthy’s 10th novel, the story of a father and son in a postapocalyptic world, also won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction. In Edinburgh, Byron Rogers won in the biography category for his book “The Man Who Went Into the West: The Life of R. S. Thomas,” about the Welsh poet. In announcing the awards Judge Professor Colin Nicholson of the University of Edinburgh said both books were “destined to become classics in their respective genres.” The University of Edinburgh began awarding the two prizes in 1919, and past winners include D. H. Lawrence and E. M. Forster.

headline: Graduating From the Electoral College (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: With Turnover High, Schools Fight for Teachers
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — The retirement of thousands of baby boomer teachers coupled with the departure of younger teachers frustrated by the stress of working in low-performing schools is fueling a crisis in teacher turnover that is costing school districts substantial amounts of money as they scramble to fill their ranks for the fall term.

headline: Bush’s Statement on Gonzales
text: Following is the text of a statement delivered by President Bush on Monday, Aug. 27, on the resignation of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, as provided by the White House:

headline: Gonzales’s Statement
text: The following is the text of a statement delivered by Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales on Monday, Aug. 27, on his resignation, as provided by the Justice Department:

headline: Designing New Orleans
text: Images from two new design proposals for the city.

headline: Turkish Delight F1 style
text: It was not a great weekend for my photo harvest – too hot and too many other problems. Just imagine what it’s like for the men and women whose job it is only to take photos all day at every race – 36 degree Celsius temperatures, and elsewhere, rain, snow….

headline: Mortgage Crisis Forces Sale of German Bank
text: The eastern German state of Saxony was forced to sell a troubled state-run bank Sunday as the global liquidity crisis set off by the United States subprime mortgage problems claimed its first major European victim.

headline: Boston Hedge Fund Star Loses $400 Million
text: James Pallotta, Boston’s highest-paid hedge fund manager and a part owner of the Boston Celtics, told investors in his $8.5 billion Raptor fund Friday that some of the investments in the fund were “simply crushed” by the market turmoil of the past month, losing $400 million in a matter of weeks and leaving his investors with an 8 percent loss so far this year.

headline: Red Sox Owner Henry Scores Mansion
text: Call it inside baseball. John W. Henry, commodity trader and principal owner of the Boston Red Sox, has ponied up $16 million for the 18,000-square-foot Brookline, Mass., home of Los Angeles Dodgers owner Frank H. McCourt Jr.

headline: Price for Home Depot Unit Plunges in a Tight Market
text: To save its struggling deal, Home Depot was forced to drop the sale price of its commercial supply business by nearly $2 billion yesterday, according to The New York Times, becoming one of the first big buyouts to be renegotiated as a result of the recent tightening of credit and problems in the housing market.

headline: Tata Confirms Interest in Ford Brands
text: Ratan Tata, the chairman of Tata Group, has confirmed that the Indian conglomerate is interested in acquiring Ford Motor‘s Land Rover and Jaguar luxury brands.

headline: Arrow Shareholder Reverses Position on Teleflex Deal
text: In an about-face, a major shareholder in Arrow International said Friday that it would support the proposed $2 billion acquisition by Teleflex, according to a regulatory filing.

headline: Tishman Closes $1.7 Billion Chicago Deal
text: The Chicago real estate community heaved a sigh of relief Friday as Tishman Speyer closed on one of the city’s all-time largest property sales.

headline: Rio Tinto Extends Alcan Bid
text: Rio Tinto plans to extend its $38.1 billion takeover offer for Canadian aluminum giant Alcan, giving it more time to obtain regulatory approvals.

headline: Unauthorized Enjoyment of Song Irks Law Firm
text: It sounds like the setup for a joke: a law firm picks a fight with a legal blogger over the leak of an internal song celebrating – well, itself.

headline: Nasdaq May Sell L.S.E. Stake to Deutsche Borse, Report Says
text: The Nasdaq Stock Market is seeking to sell up to half of its 31 percent stake in the London Stock Exchange to Deutsche Borse for more than 400 millon pounds ($806 million), according to The Guardian.

headline: Hearst Launches Offer for TV Business
text: The Hearst Corporation announced late Friday that it plans a $23.50 per share tender offer for the 27 percent of Hearst-Argyle Television that it does not already own.

headline: Banks Can Weather Credit Crisis, but At a Cost
text: Banks these days are like football players running the gantlet drill: the turmoil in the credit markets is bound to hit them on one side or the other, even if they make it through.

headline: Inotek Pharmaceuticals Swallows $19.3 Million
text: Inotek Pharmaceuticals, a drug developer, said it secured a $19.3 million funding round to support preclinical and clinical studies.

headline: What Happened to Rooting for the Underdog?
text: Tennis is one of the toughest sports for non-elite professional athletes. Not only do you have to play qualifying tournaments just to get into major events like the U.S. Open (unless your country is hosting the Grand Slam, in which case you may get a wild-card entry), but once there, you often face a seeded opponent in the first round and with that the prospect of an early exit. And few fans know your name. They might cheer you on from time to time to extend the match, but when push comes to shove, most fans cheer for players they know — their favorite top seeds.

headline: Hard Times for Buyout-Backed I.P.O.’s
text: Private equity firms, until recently the high flyers of finance, have had a tough summer.

headline: Rivals Try to Pick Off Bear’s Hedge Fund Clients, Report Says
text: Bear Stearns‘ rivals are reportedly trying to poach the investment bank’s prime brokerage customers, telling them it’s too risky to stay while the firm deals with fallout from the subprime mortgage crisis.

headline: Backers of BCE Buyout Insist Deal Is on Track
text: It’s the biggest question in Canadian finance right now: Will BCE close the country’s largest buyout ever?

headline: Pluggd Taps V.C.’s for $6 Million
text: The lure of inside-the-video search was enough to hook Intel Capital, Draper Fischer Jurvetson Frontier, and Labrador Ventures into offering $6 million in a first round of funding to  Pluggd of Seattle.

headline: Despite Market Woes, Sellers Target Real-Estate Record
text: It may seem like a long-shot given the recent news from Wall Street, but a group of homeowners is holding firm on an ambitious goal — to break the record for the most expensive home sale in American history.

headline: In Defense of Private Equity
text: The conventional wisdom is that private equity firms are focused strictly on the short term.

headline: Inside the Countrywide Lending Spree
text: On its way to becoming the nation’s largest mortgage lender, Countrywide Financial often led potential borrowers to high-cost and sometimes unfavorable loans that resulted in richer commissions for Countrywide’s smooth-talking sales force, outsize fees to company affiliates providing services on the loans, and a roaring stock price that made Countrywide executives among the highest paid in America, according to The New York Times.

headline: Guilty Plea Is Arranged in Tax Plot
text: The owner of the nation’s largest maker of machine tools agreed Friday to plead guilty to conspiracy in cheating the government out of $34.3 million in taxes through what the I.R.S. called “deceptive and elaborate tax evasion schemes.”

headline: Wachovia Sues Specialist Firm Over Collateral
text: Wachovia has sued the jumbo-mortgage specialist Thornburg Mortgage for failing to return collateral used in a derivatives transaction.

headline: Altria Board to Consider a Spinoff Overseas
text: The maker of the world’s most popular cigarette, Marlboro, may decide this week that American consumers are too much trouble.

headline: Dewey, LeBoeuf Agree to Merger
text: Two major American law firms agreed on Monday to a merger that, if approved by their partners, will create one of the nation’s biggest legal advisers.

headline: Embattled Attorney General Resigns
text: WACO, Tex., Aug. 27 — Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, whose tenure has been marred by controversy and accusations of perjury before Congress, announced his resignation in Washington today, declaring that he had “lived the American dream” by being able to lead the Justice Department.

headline: Just How Contagious Is That Hedge Fund?
text: Hedge funds may well stay vulnerable to the kind of rapidly spreading losses that have been precipitated this summer by problems in the subprime mortgage market, Mark Hulbert argues in The New York Times.

headline: Will Credit Crisis End the Activists’ Run?
text: The recent credit crunch may strip activist shareholders like Carl C. Icahn of an important tool of their trade. The reason: Their strategies often depend on access to cheap capital.

headline: U.S. Steel Buys Canada’s Stelco
text: United States Steel has reached a deal to take over Stelco, making the company the final domino to fall in the Canadian steel industry.

headline: Morning Kickoff
text: Who doesn’t like to begin the day reading about football? We certainly do. And when we read something that interests us, we like to pass it on. So here’s our first installment of the daily morning kickoff, a collection of newsworthy and/or eyebrow-raising stories and links from around the country. Enjoy.

headline: Hotel Check-in Kiosks: Long Overdue
text: Each year, my wife and I each take each of our two older kids on individual special weekends away—that is, four trips total (the baby’s not old enough to appreciate it). It’s a treat for both participants; one-parent/one-child has a very different dynamic, and more bonding moments, than the constant uproar of whole-family trips.

headline: Acer Strikes $710 Million Deal for Gateway
text: Acer agreed to acquire Gateway for $710 million to overtake Lenovo Group as the world’s third-biggest maker of personal computers.

headline: Gonzales Resigns as Attorney General
text: A senior administration official said that Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, whose tenure has been marred by controversy and accusations of perjury before Congress, will announce his resignation this morning in Washington.

headline: Topps Postpones Shareholder Vote
text: Topps said on Monday that it would postpone a shareholder vote on a proposed $385 million takeover by two private equity companies, less than a week after rival Upper Deck withdrew its higher bid for the baseball card maker.

headline: Morning Buzz: Older Firefighters, and More Fallout from the Deutsche Bank Blaze
text: Robert Beddia, the 53-year-old firefighter who was killed on Aug. 18 in the fire at the former Deutsche Bank building, was among the 502 firefighters, out of a department of 9,090 uniformed firefighters, who are 50 or older. Michael Wilson, after interviewing many older firefighters, reports that they spoke of new challenges since they were probies, or first-year firefighters, from generation gaps around the kitchen table to sore knees and weary backs.

headline: 2008: Candidates on Katrina
text: This week marks the second anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, and several of the presidential candidates are traveling to New Orleans and the Gulf Coast, the site of the hurricane’s devastation, to focus on the unfinished business of recovery and restoration.

headline: Gonzales, a Surprisingly Unanticipated Resignation
text: The resignation of Attorney General Alberto Gonzales, first reported this morning by The New York Times, appears to have achieved the distinction of being both highly expected and, somehow, not expected all. Following are updates from the best sources around the Web.

headline: Gonzales Is Resigning
text: Attorney General Alberto Gonzales is resigning today, the Times’s Steven Lee Myers reports, with a 10:30 a.m. announcement planned. The nation’s chief prosecutor has been under fire throughout much of this year, with calls for his resignation emanating from Democrats and some leading Republicans.

headline: Fredo Gets Whacked
text: Conservative blogger “Captain Ed” Morrissey celebrates Alberto Gonzales’s resignation as attorney general. Morrissey writes at his blog, Captain’s Quarters:

headline: Exploiting Race Hinders Republicans
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his Aug. 24 column, “Seeking Willie Horton.”

headline: Home Depot Shares Rise as Deal Is Repriced
text: Shares in Home Depot rose 1.9 percent to $35.33 in afternoon trading Monday on news that the sale of the company’s wholesale supply unit, HD Supply, is still on track. The retailing giant agreed to trim the price to $8.5 billion as it prepares to sell the unit to Bain Capital, the Carlyle Group and Clayton Dubilier & Rice.

headline: What Will You Do With Your Life?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Where Are They Hiding?
text: Every major has at least one player who comes out of nowhere to inexplicably make the later rounds. Marion Bartoli did it at Wimbledon. Inspired by Pierce Brosnan, she made the finals.

headline: Going Long on Divorce?
text: Amid the recent market turmoil, securities firms and hedge funds have been scrambling to escape from money-losing trades. But could another kind of Wall Street transaction — the one between husbands and wives — start unwinding as well?

headline: Ask the Co-op Board Expert
text: Arthur Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer and vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, took questions from City Room readers this week. He is no longer taking questions. Read his answers here: Part 1, Part 2, Part 3, Part 4, and the final set, Part 5.)

headline: Gonzales: It’s Official
text: UpdatedIn an extremely brief statement, Attorney General Alberto Gonzales announced his resignation, saying that he would complete his work by Sept. 17.

headline: We Decided Not to Cover Bob Saget
text: The news can’t be predicted, but traditionally the week before Labor Day has been a slow period in the news. Many politicians and government officials are on vacation. Parents, teachers and students are savoring a final respite before the start of the school year. Office workers are distracted by thoughts of the holiday weekend ahead.

headline: On the Ground: Anne-Marie Slaughter in Shanghai
Even Latecomers to Web Retailing Are Turning Profits
text: During the tech bust, GSI Commerce increased its business by buying distressed online retailers like Fogdog.com and Ashford.com, and running the entire operations more efficiently than the retailers could themselves.

headline: Study Finds Elevated Asthma Rates Among 9/11 Workers
text: A study published today by the city’s Health Department shows that 3.6 percent of the 25,000 rescue and recovery workers enrolled in the World Trade Center Health Registry reported developing asthma after working at ground zero, a rate 12 times what would be normally expected for the adult population over the time period covered in the survey.

headline: Video: The Next Frontier of Outsourcing
text: From The Onion:

headline: Joke of the Day
text: The Defense Secretary briefed the President this morning. He told Bush that three Brazilian soliders were killed in Iraq. To everyone’s amazement, the color ran from Bush’s face, then he collapsed onto his desk, head in hands, visibly shaken, almost whimpering. Finally, he composed himself and asked the Defense Secretary, “Just exactly how many is a brazillion?” — www.office-humour.co.uk

headline: Is an M.T.A. Fare Increase Justified?
text: A new report by the state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, urges the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to hold off on raising fares and tolls. The authority’s board is scheduled to vote in December on a fare and toll proposal increase that would increase revenue from riders and motorists by 6.5 percent and raise about $300 million a year; it is not clear whether the $2 base fare for a subway or bus ride would increase as well.The new report [pdf] suggests that the authority’s fiscal outlook is unclear. The authority has recorded record surpluses in the last few years, largely driven by the real estate and mortgage taxes generated by the hot property market. However, the authority is projecting steep deficits starting next year and anticipates that the shortfall could be as high as $2.1 billion by 2011.

headline: You Can’t Make This Up: Potato Launchers
text: The web site spudetch.com says it all:

headline: One Hour In …
text: The United States Open is barely an hour old, and many spectators who can’t get enough tennis are already having meta-moments. American Express is offering fans a hand-held television that shows the six biggest courts, with the USA Network coverage.

headline: Fire Department Disciplines 3 Officers; Smoking Is Cited as Fire’s Cause
text: Updated, 3:27 p.m. | Three Fire Department officers were relieved of their commands this morning as the investigation continued into the fatal Aug. 18 fire in the former Deutsche Bank building. At an afternoon news conference, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced that smoking was the probable the cause of the fire and acknowledged that “failures in oversight, judgment and responsibility” had occurred.

headline: Snap, Hold, Swing: No Longer Taken for Granted

headline: Unlocking the iPhone Without the Soldering Iron?
text: George Hotz, a New Jersey teenager, got most of the attention last week for hacking the iPhone, but at least one other group claims to have come up with a way of liberating Apple’s popular gadget from AT&T’s wireless network. A group calling itself iPhoneSimFree, which first demonstrated its technique to Engadget’s editor, Ryan Block, said it could unlock the iPhone without any changes to the iPhone hardware itself. If it works, the solution could potentially be more broadly accessible to people who want to use their iPhones on GSM networks other than AT&T’s.

headline: If Kimi Thinks Formula One Is Boring…
text: Kimi Raikkonen isn’t typically in the business of providing good quote material, but after running one to two seconds behind his Ferrari teammate, Felipe Massa, all afternoon at the Grand Prix of Turkey, he summed up the current state of Formula One with a couple of zingers:

headline: Under Brooklyn Asphalt, 1776: You Say You Want a Revolution?
text: On this day 231 years ago, the British started the Battle of Brooklyn, also known as the Battle of Long Island, against Gen. George Washington’s army. British forces prevailed, subsequently occupying the city for the rest of the Revolutionary War. It was the war’s largest and one of its bloodiest conflicts with more than 30,000 men taking part and several hundred American casualties. Nearly a quarter of New York City’s buildings were burned to the ground.

text: The big names dominate the show courts here. But players with big games can be found on any of the outer courts, too.

headline: Storm Damage in Queens, Overlooked
text: On Aug. 8, a powerful thunderstorm shut down the New York City subway system and a rare tornado touched down in Brooklyn. Amid all the pronouncements that day — including a demand for answers from Gov. Eliot Spitzer and a news conference by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in the wind-ravaged Brooklyn neighborhoods — Queens was hardly mentioned at all.

headline: The Rich Getting Richer
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — Since Florida is opening its national title defense against Western Kentucky on Saturday, nobody expected any bombshells at Urban Meyer’s morning news conference.

headline: Have You Seen Me Lately (on the sideline)?

That’s because Adam Duritz, the lead singer of the Counting Crows, would not stop talking about his beloved Cal Bears. (And his hatred of Stanford, U.S.C, Oregon State, Notre Dame, the song “Rocky Top” … You get the point.)
