text: Sarkozy's blunt statement on Iran, Gonzales's resignation and more in this week's report by Alison Smale of the International Herald Tribune.

headline: The Carter Touch
text: First there was all the deja-vuish talk about “energy efficiency” on the campaign trail. Now its seems endorsements from people connected to the 39th president of the United States, Jimmy Carter, are suddenly in vogue.

headline: Senator Accused of Lewd Conduct
text: Roll Call is reporting that Senator Larry Craig, Republican of Idaho, pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge earlier this month after he was arrested in an airport restroom by a plainsclothes police officer investigating complaints of lewd conduct. It said Mr. Craig paid a $500 fine and is on one-year probation for the disorderly conduct charge.

headline: Candidates Look for Breakthrough Moments
text: As the candidates head toward a heavy burst of campaigning for Labor Day weekend, some of the White House hopefuls who haven’t been garnering much attention are seeking to break into the leading packs as the campaign intensifies.

headline: After Alberto Gonzales
text: The White House is a lonelier place for President Bush than it used to be, says Times correspondent Philip Shenon.

headline: Yahoo to Court: Dismiss Torture Case
text: Earlier this year, a Chinese political prisoner and his wife sued Yahoo in federal court in San Francisco, accusing the company of abetting in the commission of torture by helping the Chinese government to identify political dissidents who were later beaten and tortured. Another political prisoner has since joined the case.

headline: Distractions and Little Indignities
text: Distractions and Little Indignities

headline: Distractions and Little Indignities
text: The Open set a record for opening-day attendance, with 35,058 spectators of all ages and behavior patterns. There was at least one mini-temper tantrum on court, from someone old enough to know better, but even that incident turned out in her favor. More on that later.

headline: Revenge of the Book Eaters
text: The Times's Melena Ryzik attends Revenge of the Book Eaters, an annual fund-raiser for 826NYC, a nonprofit tutoring center for children.

headline: What We Want, Baby, She’s Got It
text: Aretha Franklin was an ideal choice to perform Monday night at the Althea Gibson tribute, and not just because of her pipes. Miss Franklin, as she was introduced at a news conference Monday night after her performance, is a knowledgeable tennis fan. She talked about following Rosie Casals, Ilie Nastase, Evonne Goolagong and Chris Evert — “I love the little outfits that Chrissie used to wear with the little frilly panties.” She called the outfits of Venus and Serena Williams very daring. “But they’re young. Young people start new trends, yeah. I wish I was in the shape that Serena is. You know, the little suit, all of that.

headline: Wild Card: The Words Joe Torre Still Hates to Say
text: When the Yankees won the wild card in 1997, Joe Torre was subdued.

headline: The Language of the Hands
text: Bill Clinton may have evolved with the friendlier smile, but in these photos he’s using the same kind of body language as the chimpanzee: the palm-up gesture, the subject of my Findings column.

headline: Industry News
text: Interesting stories from the world of real estate:

headline: Tuesday’s Expert: Yang Fuqiang
text: Welcome to the second day our roundtable discussion of China’s environment, part of our ongoing series, “Choking on Growth.” Throughout the week, a panel of scholars and environmentalists will take turns answering your questions on the political, social, scientific and economic challenges posed by the country’s rapid industrialization and equally sudden pollution crisis.

headline: Old Dogs Still Have Some Bite
text: At the half way point of the NH Chess Tournament in the Netherlands, the youngsters are leading the experienced team, but only by the narrowest of margins. The score stands 13-12. The tournament is a match of up-and-coming players against established veterans. The games and profiles of the players can be found at the tournament’s Web site.

headline: Where’s Nadal?
text: The day session matches were winding down around 10 p.m. on Monday, making the first-round tickets the biggest bargain in terms of time.

headline: First Day at the Open
text: Beautiful weather and record crowds graced the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center for the first day of competition.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Friday about actions being taken by state governments on subprime lending misidentified the type of bonds that Ohio plans to sell in a mortgage-refinancing program. The bonds are taxable mortgage revenue bonds, not taxable municipal bonds. Also, the article misstated the amount of bonds to be issued. The Ohio Housing Finance Agency says the sale will be based on market demand; the program has not been reduced to $25 million from $100 million.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Aug. 20 about the Church of San Clemente in Pisco, Peru, which was the deadliest spot in the recent powerful earthquake there, misidentified the denomination of the church. It is Roman Catholic, not Eastern Orthodox. The article also misidentified the patron saint of the parish. He was San Clemente Romano, or St. Clement, not St. Vincent de Paul. (The Vincentian Fathers administer the parish.) (Go to Article)

headline: Ex-Astronaut Will Plead Insanity
text: Captain Lisa M. Nowak, the former astronaut and naval officer who confronted a romantic rival at the Orlando airport in February, will plead insanity at her trial on assault and kidnapping charges, according to a notice filed on Tuesday in state circuit court in Orlando.

headline: Taiwan’s Acer to Acquire Gateway
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 — Acer, the Taiwan-based maker of personal computers, said Monday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Gateway for $710 million, a move that reorders the competitive landscape both here and abroad.

headline: A Daddy Longlegs Tells the Story of the Continents’ Big Shifts
text: Few people have heard of the mite harvestman, and fewer still would recognize it at close range. The animal is a relative of the far more familiar daddy longlegs. But its legs are stubby rather than long, and its body is only as big as a sesame seed.

headline: Man Sought in 6 Deaths Is Arrested in New York
text: HOUSTON, Aug. 27 — A 43-year-old man sought in six killings since last week in the Texas Hill Country and in Pennsylvania was arrested Monday in Shirley, N.Y., after a brief standoff, the federal Marshals Service said Monday.

headline: 50 Killed at Religious Festival in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 28 — A power struggle between rival Shiite groups erupted during a religious festival in Karbala today, as gunmen with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades fought street battles amid crowds of pilgrims, killing 50 people and wounding 200, Iraqi officials said.

headline: The House Lawyer Departs
text: Attorney General Alberto Gonzales has finally done something important to advance the cause of justice. He has resigned. But his departure alone cannot remove the dark cloud that hangs over the Justice Department. President Bush needs to choose a new attorney general of unquestioned integrity who would work to make the department worthy of its name again — and provide the mandate to do it. Congress needs to continue to investigate the many scandals Mr. Gonzales leaves behind.

headline: Democrats Face Online Diagnoses, but No Cure Yet
text: Although last year’s midterm elections ended in a historic Democratic take-back of Congress, party leaders and grass-roots supporters alike have acknowledged that the gains owed more to public unhappiness with the Iraq war and the presidency of George W. Bush than with any bold new policies advanced by the Democrats. In fact, the current race for the White House finds the Democratic Party facing both a deep-seated identity crisis and a Republican Party that, while weakened, still boasts a redoubtable infrastructure buttressed by a daunting message machine.

headline: A Veteran of Comedy Rediscovers His Dark Side
text: In the second episode of FX’s legal thriller “Damages,” a billionaire C.E.O. named Arthur Frobisher, who is being sued by his former employees for bilking them of their life savings, reinforces his Enron-era scoundrel credentials by cheating on his wife, snorting cocaine and putting out a contract on the life of a young woman whose only crime was having accidentally glimpsed him getting into a car with his broker.

headline: In India, Debting Farmers Who Reach Despair’s Depths
text: If your brain is in a free-association mood, and you tune in “The Dying Fields,” a “Wide Angle” installment tonight on PBS about farmers in India caught in a debt nightmare, you may find yourself thinking at first of America’s mortgage mess.

headline: Patterns: Examining Dementia and Weight Loss
text: Weight loss may be associated with the onset of dementia in women, but not in men, a new study suggests.

headline: Through Analysis, Gut Reaction Gains Credibility
text: Two years ago, when Malcolm Gladwell published his best-selling “Blink: The Power of Thinking Without Thinking,” readers throughout the world were introduced to the ideas of Gerd Gigerenzer, a German social psychologist.

headline: Home Depot Sells Supply Business
text: Home Depot agreed today to sell its commercial supply business to a consortium of private equity firms for $8.5 billion, nearly $2 billion less than the original agreement. It is one of the first big buyouts to be renegotiated as a result of the recent tightening of credit and problems in the housing market.

headline: Useful Mutants, Bred With Radiation
text: VIENNA — Pierre Lagoda pulled a small container from his pocket and spilled the contents onto his desk. Four tiny dice rolled to a stop.

headline: Is That Quick Dip a Cool Idea, or Not So Hot?
text: THE thought has surely floated across many minds. Here you stand, sweltering through a summer’s day. There sits a fountain. It is cool. You are not. A solution presents itself.

headline: Idaho Senator Says He Did Nothing Wrong
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 — Senator Larry Craig said today that he regretted his guilty plea in connection with an airport bathroom incident, and he accused an Idaho newspaper of hounding him mercilessly in recent months.

headline: Summer Play (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: G.O.P. Zeroes In on a Democrat It Sees as a Fluke Winner
text: ZANESVILLE, Ohio — Rushing between campaign events at the Muskingum County Fair, Zack Space trotted to a secluded picnic table, sat down, and shoveled forkfuls of grilled chicken into his mouth.

headline: Barely in Office, Ohio Congressman Can’t Quit Running
text: ZANESVILLE, Ohio — Rushing between campaign events at the Muskingum County Fair, Zack Space trotted to a secluded picnic table, sat down, and shoveled forkfuls of grilled chicken into his mouth.

headline: The Wealthy Get an Extra Shield for Wildfires
text: KETCHUM, Idaho, Aug. 26 — The wind shifted, and suddenly the wildfire that has been raging just west of these exclusive high desert hills appeared closer than ever to Al LaPeter’s 7,000 square feet of the sweet life.

headline: New DVDs
text: 3:10 TO YUMA

headline: Op-Chart: An Update on the State of New Orleans
text: TWO years after Hurricane Katrina toppled New Orleans’s levee system, leaving more than half the city under water, there are signs of revival. The city’s population has climbed to 68 percent of its pre-hurricane level, the work force is 78 percent of what it was before the flood, and sales tax revenues have rebounded to 84 percent.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A film review on Friday about “The Nanny Diaries” referred incorrectly to the character who narrates the book on which the movie is based. Although the nanny narrates both the book and the film, she is referred to only as “Nan” in the book — not as Annie Braddock, which is the name she was given for the film.

headline: Doctor, 64, Is Charged in Sex Abuse of 10 Women
text: NEWARK, Aug. 27 — A 64-year-old physician has been charged with sexually abusing 10 of his patients, women who had come to his office for ailments varying from lower back pain to sinusitis, the authorities said.

headline: The Voice of New Jersey, but Not the Boss
text: The voice of New Jersey?

headline: Kosovo Talks to Start Anew, but Parties Express Doubt
text: BLED, Slovenia, Aug. 27  The political deadlock over Kosovo’s future is unlikely to be resolved anytime soon despite the start of new negotiations on the province this week, according to two leading politicians involved in the talks.

headline: A Religious Candidate Is Ascendant in Turkey
text: After being shut out of the presidency last spring, Abdullah Gul, a religious man in the assiduously secular realm of Turkish politics, allowed himself a little soul-searching.

headline: U.N. Leader to Travel to Sudan Area
text: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 28 — Secretary General Ban Ki-moon announced today that he would travel to Sudan, Chad and Libya next week to press for an end to fresh violence in Darfur and for speedy deployment there of the joint African Union-United Nations peacekeeping force.

headline: 2 in Brooklyn Plead Guilty to Fraud in Home Care
text: Two men who ran a Brooklyn firm that placed home health care aides pleaded guilty to grand larceny yesterday in a scheme that defrauded Medicaid out of more than $12 million, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced.

headline: Cabinet Minister in Pakistan Resigns in Protest of Musharraf’s Re-election Efforts
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 27 — A cabinet minister resigned from the Pakistani government on Monday to protest President Pervez Musharraf’s plans to run for re-election while remaining head of the army.

headline: A FedEx Cup Prize Well Worth the Wait
text: With more than $117 million in career PGA Tour earnings between them, Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson know a lot about cashing big winner’s checks.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Rolling Stones

headline: Louisa Livingston Kennedy Dies at 73
text: Louisa Livingston Kennedy, the wife of a senior American official held captive during the Iranian hostage crisis, who became a highly visible spokeswoman for the hostages’ families, died on Aug. 19 on Mount Desert Island, Maine. She was 73 and made her home on the island.

headline: Egypt: Order Goes to Airbus
text: Airbus won a contract from EgyptAir for five 330-200s, a deal valued at $881 million at list prices. The order from the expanding Egyptian carrier includes options for an additional three planes, Airbus said. EgyptAir, the state-owned airline based in Cairo, said in a preliminary announcement Aug. 15 that two A330-200F planes to be used for training were part of the order, which will bring to 12 the number of A330-200s in EgyptAir’s fleet. Airbus is based in Toulouse, France.

headline: Rights for Farm Workers (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A “What’s on Tonight” television listing on Friday misspelled the surname of a journalist who appeared on “Bill Moyers Journal.” He is Rick Karr, not Carr.

headline: French Leader Raises Possibility of Force in Iran
text: PARIS, Aug. 27 — In his first major foreign policy speech as president, Nicolas Sarkozy of France said Monday that Iran could be attacked militarily if it did not live up to its international obligations to curb its nuclear program.

headline: Inquiry Focuses on Former Aide to Menendez
text: A federal investigation of Senator Robert Menendez over potential conflicts of interests with recipients of government financing has shifted focus to the lobbying work of his former chief of staff and confidante, according to lawyers and others familiar with the case.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 11 P.M. (9) PRINCESS DIANA: THE LEGEND AND LEGACY OF A PRINCESS Joan Collins is host of this 90-minute special, which traces Diana Spencer’s trajectory from Shy Di to the People’s Princess, above, even after she left the royal family. In “The Spirit of Princess Diana,” immediately following, psychics take a look at some of the questions surrounding her life and death.

headline: Russia Arrests 10 in Killing of Putin Critic
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 27 — Russia’s prosecutor general said Monday that 10 people had been arrested in the contract killing of Anna Politkovskaya, the prominent journalist and Kremlin critic. Those arrested included a Chechen crime boss and career officers from Russia’s police and intelligence services, he said.

headline: Senator, Arrested at Airport, Pleads Guilty
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 — Senator Larry E. Craig, Republican of Idaho, was arrested in June by an undercover police officer in a men’s bathroom at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, and pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct in the case three weeks ago.

headline: A Young Teacher Attends a School of Hard Knocks
text: When we meet the first-time teacher Monica Groves, she is hanging inspiring words on the walls of her classroom and anticipating her sixth-grade pupils.

headline: Not a Game: Simulation to Lessen War Trauma
text: The sun shines on an empty Iraqi street. A Blackhawk helicopter circles overhead. The aromas of spices from a market fill the air.

headline: Iraq to Allow Ex-Baathists to Regain Jobs
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 27 — Hours after Iraq’s political leaders declared a deal to return former Baathists to government jobs, Iraq’s most senior Sunni Arab leader said Monday that it was too small an olive branch for Sunnis to rejoin the government.

headline: Two Mets Return to the Lineup, Feeling Mended and Rested
text: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 — As much as Paul Lo Duca enjoyed the novelty of watching fireworks explode during the middle of one of his at-bats for Class A Brooklyn on Friday, he prefers to play in a pennant race, for a team that has missed him the past two weeks.

headline: Ancient Diamonds Add Layer to Debate About Ancient Earth
text: It sounds like something you might see for sale on a home shopping channel: diamonds encased in zircon. But these crystals are much more valuable to scientists who study the early history of the Earth.

headline: How Do You Move a Career Into High Gear? By Breaking the Rules
text: If you want to be a concert pianist when you grow up, there are certain rules. You do start playing as a young child. You don’t drop out of Juilliard. You do win competitions and get the attention of managers at a young age. You don’t end up at 30 with no management and no bookings, raising the money yourself for your first recording. And you definitely don’t make your New York recital debut with Bach’s demanding “Goldberg” Variations, which are supposed to reflect the wisdom of long experience, and Baroque style.

headline: Facing Trial, Government Agrees to Improve Conditions at Immigrant Center
text: HOUSTON, Aug. 27  The federal government and lawyers for immigrant children have announced an agreement to improve living conditions at the nation’s main family detention center for illegal immigrant suspects.

headline: A Connecticut Town Debates the Need for a Kind of Belt-Tightening
text: STRATFORD, Conn., Aug. 27 — The elderly residents of Stratford were calling Alvin O’Neal, a town councilman, with a persistent complaint. When they went to the supermarket, the library or anywhere else about town, all they saw were teenagers with saggy pants, their underwear more than peeking out.

headline: For Dance Troupe, Travel Is a Test of Poise
text: For dancers in the Mark Morris Dance Group, air travel is a bitter enemy. Moving dynamically through space is our job and our passion. On a long flight, we feel like caged tigers. We are used to moving, but instead we’re angry, sad, bored and hungry.

headline: 3 Disciplined Over Fatal Fire at Bank Tower
text: More than a week after two New York City firefighters died in a smoky fire at the former Deutsche Bank building, city officials relieved three senior fire officers of their posts yesterday, asserting they had failed to inspect the building or to draw up a specific plan on how to fight a fire inside the contaminated tower.

headline: Peace Dam Still Waits for the Flood That Never Came
text: HWACHEON, South Korea — In 1986, as South Korea was busy preparing for its largest ever international event, the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, North Korean soldiers broke ground on a gigantic dam just above the Demilitarized Zone.

headline: When Doctors Have to Deliver Grim News (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hughes Is Back; Velocity Is Lacking
text: DETROIT, Aug. 27  As he watched Phil Hughes pitch Sunday from his home in Connecticut, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman noticed that Hughes was not throwing as hard as usual. His fastballs were averaging 88 to 91 miles an hour, Cashman said, when they should have been 91 to 93.

headline: Unstable Crane Causes Evacuation in Stamford
text: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug, 28 — An unstable 180-foot crane hung precariously over downtown Stamford today as police kept drivers, office workers and residents away and engineers worked on plans to shore the crane up, repair it and then remove it from a construction site on Richmond Hill Avenue.

headline: The Solvable Problem of Organ Shortages
text: When the wife and younger daughter of Rear Adm. Kenneth P. Moritsugu of the Navy were fatally injured in separate automobile accidents, he authorized the donation of organs and tissues from both of them.

headline: Mr. Bean Bumbles on Voyage Across Pond
text: When he has performed in the guise of the google-eyed, maladroit Mr. Bean, the British comedian Rowan Atkinson has proven adept at blundering his way through all manner of challenges, whether navigating bustling street traffic, making cross-country European journeys or mastering the international box office.

headline: Second Record Level for Afghan Opium Crop
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 27 — Opium cultivation in Afghanistan grew by 17 percent in 2007, reaching record levels for the second straight year, according to a United Nations report released Monday.

headline: After Trailblazer Is Honored, Williamses Carry On Her Legacy
text: On her way to the court on opening night at the United States Open, Venus Williams seemed momentarily flummoxed. In the hallway from the locker room at Arthur Ashe Stadium, she was greeted yesterday by an array of stars, an eye-popping lineup of African-American women who came to honor the tennis icon Althea Gibson. Williams paused to kiss Jackie Joyner-Kersee, to say hello to Roberta Flack, seeming as if she wanted to hug each of them.

headline: Utley Rejoins Phillies and Shows Them What They Were Missing
text: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27  When Chase Utley entered the lineup Monday night for the first time in a month, Phillies fans stood and cheered in hopes that this fractured season, like Utley’s once broken hand, would finally heal itself.

headline: Survey Shows a High Rate of Asthma at Ground Zero
text: Rescue and recovery workers at ground zero have developed asthma at a rate that is 12 times what would be expected for adults, according to findings released yesterday by the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.

headline: Poverty Rate Falls, but More Are Uninsured
text: The nation’s poverty rate fell in 2006 for the first time this decade, the Census Bureau reported today, even as the percentage of Americans without health insurance coverage hit a record high.

headline: Dow Falls 280 Points on Economic Concerns
text: As Wall Street tried to sort through some problematic readings on the economy and new concerns surfaced about the safety of owning financial stocks, investors pushed the market down sharply today.

headline: Buddha Gets a Biopic
text: Born into a princely family in the sixth century B.C. in Kapilavastu on the border between present-day India and Nepal, Gautama Buddha abandoned luxury for spiritual enlightenment. Now the life of this man, who founded Buddhism, will be the subject of a film, Agence France-Press reported. Based on research by the Sri Lankan scholar Nimal D’Silva and others, the film will be shot in India and Sri Lanka by Shyam Benegal, an Indian director, for release in 2009. It is a venture of the Light of Asia Foundation, based in Colombo, Sri Lanka, and Beyond Dream Entertainment, based in India. “The message of the movie gives answers to global crises of conflict and environmental problems,” said Navin Gooneratne, chairman of the foundation.

headline: Poland and Germany Argue Over Art
text: Poland and Germany were embroiled yesterday in a dispute about art removed from each country during World War II, Agence France-Presse reported. Poland’s foreign minister, Anna Fotyga, said she had asked the culture ministry to compile a list of Polish works in German museums. Germany, meanwhile, was seeking the return of artifacts transported to Poland to avoid destruction during the war. Tono Eitel, the German negotiator, expressed frustration over Poland’s refusal to return pieces — including original scores by Mozart, texts by Goethe and a manuscript of the German national anthem — transported from Berlin to Krakow to protect them from Allied bombing. Poland considers everything found in its territory at the end of World War II to be its property.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Aug. 20 about the Church of San Clemente in Pisco, Peru, which was the deadliest spot in the recent powerful earthquake there, misidentified the denomination of the church. It is Roman Catholic, not Eastern Orthodox. The article also misidentified the patron saint of the parish. He was San Clemente Romano, or St. Clement, not St. Vincent de Paul. (The Vincentian Fathers administer the parish.)

headline: For a Low-Dose Hormone, Take Your Pick
text: Patches, pumps, pills, low-dose pills and super-low-dose creams and gels: Ever since the landmark Women’s Health Initiative study found that hormone therapy could be harmful, a dizzying array of new low-dose treatment options have been offered to counter the symptoms of menopause.

headline: Inspections Criticized Again, 20 Years After 7 Deaths
text: After a morning fire ripped through the Schomburg Plaza high-rise apartment building in Harlem, killing seven people on March 22, 1987, an outraged Manhattan grand jury criticized the Fire Department’s flawed performance, including poor inspections.

headline: A Defender of Bush’s Power, Gonzales Resigns
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 — Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales announced his resignation on Monday, ending a stormy tenure at the Justice Department that was marked by repeated battles with Congress over whether he had allowed his intense personal loyalty to President Bush to overwhelm his responsibilities to the law.

headline: In Volatility, Redemption for Manager
text: The debacle in mortgage lending that spurred wild daily swings in the markets has tripped up many hedge funds.

headline: Code Blue: A Medical Morality Play in 3 Acts
text: Code Blue, Code Blue, blasting over the hospital loudspeaker. Of course, it’s hardly a code. Everyone knows what it means: a patient is dying.

headline: Iraq Weapons Are a Focus of Criminal Investigations
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 27 — Several federal agencies are investigating a widening network of criminal cases involving the purchase and delivery of billions of dollars of weapons, supplies and other matériel to Iraqi and American forces, according to American officials. The officials said it amounted to the largest ring of fraud and kickbacks uncovered in the conflict here.

headline: Thornburg Pays Collateral Owed to Wachovia
text: Thornburg Mortgage Inc., the jumbo mortgage specialist sued by the Wachovia Corporation last week, said yesterday that it repaid the $5.1 million in collateral that was the basis of the bank’s litigation.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Baby Talk Crosses Cultural Line
text: It may be that when adults talk to babies, they use a language that is universally understood.

headline: Seeking Allies’ Support, Japan’s Leader Reshuffles Cabinet
text: TOKYO, Aug. 27 — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe sought Monday to raise sinking approval ratings and ward off calls for his resignation by forming a new cabinet made up of political veterans to replace a scandal-prone group.

headline: In Washington, Aid to Homeowners Debated
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 — Faced with a possible tidal wave of home foreclosures beginning this fall, Democrats and Republicans are battling over a philosophical question with huge practical implications: should the government ride to the rescue?

headline: Existing-Home Sales Fall to 5-Year Low
text: Sales of previously owned homes fell to a five-year low in July and the glut of unsold properties climbed to the highest since 1991 as the housing slump dragged on.

headline: Ugly Outing by Mussina Casts Cloud on Future
text: DETROIT, Aug. 27 — In a different time, when the Yankees were touched by magic, even their horror stories had happy endings. David Cone went from pillar to punching bag in 2000, but his season ended with a clutch relief appearance that helped win the World Series.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption with an obituary on Aug. 10 about the acoustic designer Russell Johnson incompletely identified a hall whose acoustics he designed. It is the Frederick P. Rose Hall of Jazz at Lincoln Center, not just “Jazz at Lincoln Center.”

headline: Taliban Agree to Release South Korean Hostages
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 28 — The Taliban agreed today to release 19 South Korean church volunteers held captive in Afghanistan since mid-July, the South Korean government announced, signaling an end to a wrenching hostage crisis that has gripped the country for 41 days.

headline: Asbestos, Hidden in Plain Sight
text: “Libby, Montana” sets a high bar for itself. An opening voice-over, covering idyllic home-movie scenes of life in the West, proclaims: “Either this is the most horrific story I’ve ever heard in my life, or those people are completely crazy. It couldn’t have happened.”

headline: After Photo Finish, Campbell Emerges With Gold
text: OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 27 — A race that lasted barely more than 11 seconds required quite a bit longer to unravel on Monday night.

headline: Venturing Into the Mines of Uganda, in Search of the Marburg Virus
text: Researchers reported for the first time last week that they have found the Marburg virus in a nonprimate species — bats.

headline: Math and Reading SAT Scores Drop
text: Average scores on the reading and math sections of the SAT test declined slightly this year, as the number of high school students taking the standardized exam grew larger and more diverse than ever before, according to a report released this morning by the College Board on the performance of the high school class of 2007.

headline: Insights: Racial Disparity Affirmed in Tobacco Advertising
text: The density of billboards advertising tobacco products is more than twice as high in black neighborhoods as in white, researchers have found in a review of studies.

headline: ‘Core Issues’ Raised in Mideast Talks
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 28  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel and the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, discussed the core issues of contention between their peoples at a meeting here today, but it was unclear how detailed their talks had been.

headline: Grandeur of the North, Yours by the Bushel, From Sibelius
text: In 1997 Colin Davis conducted an unforgettable Sibelius program with the London Symphony Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall. I could not have been the only person in the audience that night hearing one engrossing work — “Lemminkainen’s Return,” a short and craggy tone poem — for the first time.

headline: Digital ‘South Park’
text: Never underestimate the explanatory power of “South Park,” the animated Comedy Central show created by Matt Stone and Trey Parker. Again and again over the past 11 seasons, “South Park” has offered a satiric primer on adult behavior, including notably trenchant, compact analyses of the Mormon faith and whatever you choose to call Scientology. It would be interesting, now, to see a “South Park” episode devoted entirely to the groundbreaking new contract Mr. Stone and Mr. Parker have just signed with Viacom, the parent company of Comedy Central. The contract creates a new digital hub for all things “South Park” and also brings Mr. Stone and Mr. Parker half of the ad revenue their show generates. Historically, that kind of revenue sharing goes entirely against the principles of Hollywood.

headline: Teenager Takes Turn on Scout Team
text: Jesse Levine keeps his short brown hair hidden under a cap and his arms covered by sleeves. His shorts are a conventional length.

headline: Famous Friends on Tour for a Halberstam Book
text: The command post is a set of Manhattan publishing offices, and the foot soldiers include Joan Didion, Seymour Hersh, Bob Woodward, Anna Quindlen, Alex Kotlowitz, Paul Hendrickson, Samantha Power and Bill Walton. They are going on David Halberstam’s book tour for him.

headline: The Wise Men, Redux
text: In 1948, a Republican lawyer named Herb Brownell managed Thomas Dewey’s presidential campaign. When Dwight Eisenhower was beginning his run in 1952, Brownell flew to Paris to tell Ike how to campaign — how to do scheduling, how to organize a campaign team, which positions to take on Social Security and the budget.

headline: Prosecutors Seek Reporters’ Testimony in Murder Case Against Couple
text: After a year and a half of legal maneuvers and pretrial motions, murder charges against the parents of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown now hang on their own words, a judge said yesterday.

headline: Gonzales, Loyal to Bush, Was Firm on War Policies
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 — Days after President Bush’s secret eavesdropping program was publicly revealed in December 2005, a battle-weary Alberto R. Gonzales stood before a room of reporters at the White House and asserted that “the president has the inherent authority under the Constitution, as commander in chief, to engage in this kind of activity.”

headline: Nonprofit Payday Loans? Yes, to Mixed Reviews
text: APPLETON, Wis. — This city of 70,000 has five McDonald’s franchises, three Pizza Huts, four Starbucks shops — and 19 payday loan stores, brightly lighted storefronts with names like EZ Money and Check Into Cash that offer two-week loans without credit checks.

headline: For the Pilgrim on a Budget, the Vatican Has Air Charters
text: PARIS, Aug. 27 — It already has its own postal service, its own bank and even its own Internet domain. On Monday, the Vatican inaugurated its latest venture: a low-cost charter airline to ferry thousands of Catholic pilgrims from Italy to popular religious sites around the world.

headline: The Life of a Scullery Maid or Factory Slave? No Thanks
text: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 24 — Anyone game for a venture into the mountain air will find great pleasure in the Berkshire Theater Festival’s production of “Mrs. Warren’s Profession,” Shaw’s lively indictment of prudishness and patriarchal prejudice, in a two-week run here.

headline: Israeli Says Hamas Is Training Hundreds Abroad
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 27 — Hamas has sent hundreds of its fighters abroad for military training, most of them to Iran, the Israeli Army’s deputy chief of staff says, and Israel has the names of more than 100 of them.

headline: Two Years Later, a Street Still Waits for Its Promised Gentrification
text: Two years ago Freddy Saint-Aignan and his wife, Angelika, found the perfect location for their fledgling bar/restaurant, the Sugar Lounge: Columbia Street in Brooklyn.

headline: Two Infusions of Vision to Bolster New Orleans
text: In the two years since Hurricane Katrina, what has the rebuilding effort produced? No grand designs. No inspired vision for the future of New Orleans. There have been only a handful of earnest, grass-roots proposals to preserve what’s left of the historic fabric.

headline: Hazard: High-Fat Diet Raises Risk of Colon Cancer Return
text: Colon cancer survivors with diets high in meat and refined grains triple their risk of recurrence or death compared with those who eat fruits, vegetables and fish, a new study reports.

headline: Assigning Blame for the Mess in Iraq (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Taste of Victory for Isner and Young, 2 Promising Americans
text: When John Isner stepped to the United States Open baseline for the first time in his career, casting a slim 6-foot-9 shadow on the Armstrong Stadium court, the fans fell silent in anticipation of a serve that was an event unto itself.

headline: A World of Eloquence in an Upturned Palm
text: ATLANTA — The chimpanzees, after spotting the humans at the corner of their compound, came over to us with their arms outstretched and their palms turned upward. This was the chimps’ way of asking for a banana — and a lot more, as researchers here at the Yerkes National Primate Research Center have discovered.

headline: Martínez Is Pleased With Test
text: JUPITER, Fla., Aug. 27 — Pedro Martínez’s normally pinpoint control was not present Monday night. He threw far more balls against the Class A Palm Beach Cardinals than he had in any of his other rehabilitation efforts. Yet Martínez said that was a good thing.

headline: Holding Kids Hostage
text: The governors of New York and New Jersey were upset and not trying to hide it.

headline: What Looks and Sounds Like a Bailout?
text: A recurring question in the recent turmoil in the financial markets has been whether the Federal Reserve would bail out the banks, nonbank lenders and investors who are complicit in the excesses that sparked the credit crisis. Events have overtaken the debate. The bailout is well under way.

headline: Did Chernobyl Leave an Eden for Wildlife?
text: In recent years, there have been reports that the area around the Chernobyl nuclear plant had become something of a wildlife playground. The reports suggested that animals like wild boar, wolves and moose had flourished in the 40-mile-diameter “exclusion zone,” which was contaminated by low-level radiation from the disaster in Ukraine 21 years ago.

headline: Headliner Can’t Make It? Here’s a First-Class Fill-In
text: Abbey Lincoln, singing at two free outdoor concerts in New York in two consecutive days, on the same weekend as the memorial service for her ex-husband, Max Roach, and not too long after open-heart surgery: all this seemed a bit much to hope for. And it didn’t happen. Ms. Lincoln was scheduled to play both days of the 15th annual Charlie Parker Jazz Festival over the weekend — in Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem on Saturday and in Tompkins Square Park in the East Village on Sunday — but had canceled by Saturday afternoon.

headline: Bigger Than Las Vegas? That’s Macao’s Bet
text: MACAO, Aug. 22 — Las Vegas’s days as the capital of excess may be numbered.

headline: New Shop Promises Results Clients Can Gauge
text: STAN RAPP, a longtime direct marketer, is embarking on his third (at least) career, joining forces with a private equity fund to start an agency that intends to use the new media to help forge closer, and more measurable, connections with consumers.

headline: Deterrent to School Safety (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gatlin’s Drug Case Puts Concerns on the (Massage) Table
text: OSAKA, Japan, Tuesday, Aug. 28  At the hotel for the United States track and field team, inside a room usually used for late-night karaoke, a team of massage therapists awaited its next clients Monday, with creams, sprays and lotions at the ready.

headline: Letters
text: Debating a Hypothesis

headline: Best Choices to Be Stranded: Syracuse, Albany, Pepperoni
text: IT’S been an awful year for air travel, with delays and cancellations at record levels, with passengers stuck for hours on packed planes waiting to take off.

headline: Suspect Seaweed
text: Q. I have seen some warnings about hijiki seaweed as a possible source of high levels of arsenic. How alarmed should I be?

headline: 3 Colleges in Accord on College Board Inquiry
text: Fairfield University, Trinity College and Sacred Heart University, all in Connecticut, will pay tens of thousands of dollars each to various scholarship funds under agreements reached with the state’s attorney general, Richard Blumenthal. The accords end an investigation into relationships the institutions had with the College Board, the owner of the SAT and Advanced Placement examinations and a provider of student loans. The inquiry found that the College Board gave discounts on financial aid software to the colleges in return for being listed on their “preferred lender” lists given to students. The College Board announced last week that it was leaving the loan business.

headline: Spitzer Talks of Suing to Expand Health Plan
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer said Monday that New York would consider suing federal health officials if the state was not granted a waiver to expand its federally subsidized health insurance program for children.

headline: As Brazil Defends Its Bounty, Rules Ensnare Scientists
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Marc van Roosmalen is a world-renowned primatologist whose research in the Amazon has led to the discovery of five species of monkeys and a new primate genus. But precisely because of that work, Dr. van Roosmalen was recently sentenced to nearly 16 years in prison and jailed in Manaus, Brazil.

headline: Kazakhs Suspend Permits for Oil Field
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 27 — The government of Kazakhstan suspended environmental permits on Monday for a consortium of foreign energy companies developing a potentially huge oil field in the Caspian Sea, threatening to slow development of the largest oil find in the world since the discovery of Prudhoe Bay off Alaska three decades ago.

headline: Prosecutor Asks to Drop Hazing Charge Against 2 Rider Officials
text: TRENTON, Aug. 27, (AP) — The Mercer County prosecutor has asked a judge to drop charges of aggravated hazing against two Rider University officials in a case involving the drinking death of a fraternity pledge.

headline: Phillies Give Mets a Reminder the Race Is Only Beginning
text: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 — The push toward the playoffs, it is said, does not traditionally begin until the calendar page flips to September. But tell that to Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel, who, fighting for every last edge, was ejected for arguing a close play at first base in the bottom of the first inning.

headline: Homeless Man Held in Burglary of Dodd’s Office
text: HARTFORD, Aug. 27 (AP)  Police officers arrested a suspect on Monday in connection with a weekend burglary at the downtown office of Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democratic presidential candidate.

headline: Collaborators in a Quest for Human Perfection
text: Within a building secluded behind iron gates, in a laboratory painted black, two men in black masks and long hooded black robes stand over an operating table. One is tall and one is short, and of course they are trying to create life — any fan of horror movies knows that. But this is no movie: it is quite true, a little-known piece of early-20th-century medical history that segues seamlessly into the living horror of World War II.

headline: Sudan: Aid Agency Chief Expelled
text: Paul Barker, CARE’s country director for Sudan, said the government had abruptly expelled him from the country. Mr. Barker, who said he had been told Saturday that he had 72 hours to leave Sudan, said the government did not provide a specific reason but said it had “something to do with security.” Sudanese government officials could not be reached for comment. Last week, the European Commission’s envoy and a Canadian diplomat were expelled. Jan Pronk, the chief United Nations envoy, was expelled last October. CARE is one of the largest aid agencies in Sudan, spending around $20 million there each year on health, education and economic development projects. More than half of that money goes to the western war-torn region of Darfur.

headline: Candidates Call Anew for Rebuilding of New Orleans
text: The presidential candidates returned to New Orleans yesterday to press for the rebuilding of the city, using the coming second anniversary of Hurricane Katrina to attack the Bush administration while highlighting their own initiatives to aid the people there.

headline: The C.I.A.’s Problem (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A review yesterday about the chorus Schola Cantorum de Venezuela referred incorrectly to a performance in which it participated last year, the “Pasión Según San Marcos.” The work was performed at Lincoln Center as part of the Great Performers series, not as part of the Lincoln Center Festival.

headline: Justice Served?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: The Claim: Swallowed Gum Takes a Long Time to Digest
text: THE FACTS

headline: Departures Offer Chance for a Fresh Start as Term Ebbs
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 — The back-to-back resignations of Karl Rove and Alberto R. Gonzales, two longtime aides to President Bush who have become lightning rods on Capitol Hill, amount to a political housecleaning for the White House, providing Mr. Bush a fresh chance to make what he can of his remaining months in office.

headline: Bush Warns U.S. Withdrawal From Iraq Would Destabilize Mideast
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 — A hasty American withdrawal from Iraq would leave the Middle East disastrously exposed to further violence and instability, President  Bush warned today, as he sought to set the terms for a major debate in Washington next month over the future American presence in Iraq.

headline: 2 Big Law Firms Announce Merger
text: Two major New York law firms announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge, creating what will be one of the nation’s largest law firms, with broad international reach.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday about Richard D. Parsons, chief executive of Time Warner, misspelled the name of the employer of Richard Greenfield, a media analyst who commented on Time Warner’s stock price. It is Pali Research, a division of Pali Capital — not Peri Research.

headline: Noriega Can Be Extradited to France
text: MIAMI, Aug. 28 — A federal judge in Miami ruled today that Manuel Antonio Noriega, the former Panamanian general ousted by the American military in 1989, can be extradited to France, where he faces charges of money laundering and up to a decade in prison.

headline: Tyree’s Broken Wrist Adds to Giants’ Injury Troubles
text: The Giants cannot stem the onslaught of injuries. David Tyree, a receiver and special-teams star, broke his left wrist in Saturday’s preseason game against the Jets, Coach Tom Coughlin said. He is expected to be out for up to six weeks.

headline: For Davydenko, a New Kind of Grind
text: The last thing Nikolay Davydenko appears to be is the kind of tennis player likely to do something splashy, much less crazy. He is fair-haired but prematurely balding, athletic but unimposing, efficient but unspectacular.

headline: In a Rare View, Rings on Uranus Show Their Changes
text: It’s that time of year on Uranus — time for the semiannual ring-plane crossing, when the planet’s ring system appears edge-on to observers on Earth. (Unlike the other planets, Uranus spins on its side, making for extreme changes in viewing angles.) The crossing allows telescopes to take pictures of the rings from the unlighted side, free from the glare that can obscure faint parts of them.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An art review on Thursday about “Robert Gober: Work 1976-2007” in Basel, Switzerland, misstated the name of the Los Angeles museum where a Madonna by the artist was first shown. It was the Museum of Contemporary Art, not the Los Angeles County Museum of Contemporary Art.

headline: China in Africa (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Magdalen Nabb, Mystery Writer in Italy, Dies at 60
text: Magdalen Nabb, an expatriate English author whose sensitively wrought crime novels, set in her adopted city, Florence, won her the admiration and friendship of Georges Simenon, the writer whose sensibility most matched her own, died in Florence on Aug. 18. She was 60 and had lived and worked there since 1975.

headline: Perking Up Convention Halls
text: For years, industry slang for a convention center was “a box with docks.” It was blunt but apt shorthand. In recent years, though, convention center managers have been learning the lesson that hotel companies have already discovered: it is not enough to offer just a place to stay or meet.

headline: Awaiting Sentence, Vick Speaks of Mistakes
text: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 27 — Standing before microphones, reporters and cameras is nothing new for quarterback Michael Vick. But at a news conference Monday morning, the subject matter had nothing to do with touchdown passes or long, improvised runs downfield.

headline: Greek Leaders Criticized Over Fires
text: ATHENS, Greece, Aug. 28 — The fires that tore omnivorously through scores of villages and olive groves here may now also be changing Greece’s political landscape. The government of Prime Minister Kostas Karamanlis, facing national elections next month, came under increasing criticism today, not only over its handling of the fires but also over whether it stoked Greeks’ fears about who might be to blame.

headline: Peggy Samuels, Biographer and Art Historian, Dies at 84
text: Peggy Samuels, an amateur art historian who with her husband, Howard, wrote or edited 10 books on art and United States history, including a revealing biography of Frederic Remington, the renowned painter of the American West, died Thursday at her home in East Falmouth, Mass. She was 84.

headline: At Risk: Gestational Diabetes May Be Tied to Type of Cancer
text: Gestational diabetes may be associated with a substantially increased risk for pancreatic cancer, a new study has found.

headline: Beijing Seeks New Scrutiny of Investments by Outsiders
text: HONG KONG, Aug. 27  After a quarter-century of welcoming and even courting foreign investors, Beijing officials are starting to show considerably more caution. Chinese lawmakers are set to pass legislation this week that would limit foreign acquisitions in China on national security grounds.

headline: Memo Pad
text: CANCELLATIONS SOAR The number of domestic flights that were canceled by airlines nearly doubled from June 1 through Aug. 15 of this year, to 30,471, from 16,049 in that period in 2006, according to FlightStats.com. There were more total flights in that period — 1,437,600 flights compared with 1,406,780 flights last year.

headline: Sarkozy Lists Foreign Priorities, With Iran First
text: PARIS, Aug. 27 — In his first major foreign policy speech as president of France, Nicolas Sarkozy called the Iranian nuclear crisis “the most serious weighing on the international order today” and said that Iran could be attacked militarily if it did not live up to its international obligations to curb its nuclear program.

headline: Topps Delays Vote on Buyout Offer
text: The Topps Company has postponed a shareholder vote on a proposed $384.5 million buyout from a group led by Michael D. Eisner, the former Walt Disney Company chief executive, giving investors more time to consider the offer.

headline: Redone Home Depot Deal Not Thought Contagious
text: As the deal for Home Depot’s wholesale supply unit was renegotiated over the weekend, a question lingered about whether the push to lower the price was a harbinger for other buyouts.

headline: Former Islamist Is Voted in as President of Turkey
text: A former Islamist was elected president of Turkey today, breaking an 84-year grip on the office by the country’s secular establishment and ushering a new Islamic middle class from Turkey’s heartland into the center of political life in the staunchly secular state.

headline: In Greece, Wine Saves Life; a Mother’s Arms Do Not
text: MAKISTOS, Greece, Aug. 27 — When the water ran out, with pine cones popping and the flames still high around his house, George Dimopoulos switched to wine. He made it himself two years ago, and, nearly alone in his village as it all but burned down on Friday night, he poured liter after liter, 200 in all, into his little copper hand-pumped crop sprayer, and sprayed and sprayed.

headline: Race Takes 11.01 Seconds. Results Take 5 Minutes.
text: OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 27  A race that lasted barely more than 11 seconds required quite a bit longer to unravel Monday night.

headline: He’s in Iraq. U.S. Reward: Deport Wife?
text: While Alexander Gomez was in Iraq at the United States government’s bidding, that same government was trying to kick his wife out of this country. For the Colombian-born Mr. Gomez, more accurately Specialist Gomez of the New York Army National Guard, something was definitely out of kilter.

headline: Correction
text: Because of an editing error, an editorial on Sunday misstated a new rule governing the expansion of the State Children’s Health Insurance Program. States must show that they have enrolled 95 percent of the children in families with incomes below 200 percent of the poverty level before they can extend the limit above 250 percent, not to 250 percent.

headline: Fatal Fires in Greece
text: The government of Greece is facing a crisis over whether it was up to the task of handling the country's worst fires in more than a century.

headline: Monday’s Wild-Card Update
text: Wow. Three of the four wild cards I mentioned this morning won their first-round matches on Monday.

headline: Game Over for Vick?
text: Michael Vick formally pleaded guilty to a felony charge of conspiracy stemming from a dogfighting kennel being run from a property he owned in Surry, Va. A plea agreement with the government was filed Friday at the courthouse.

headline: Architects Add Zip on the North Folk
text: Images of the work of Long Island architects.

headline: $400,000 Homes
text: Homes on the market in California, Florida and New Mexico.

headline: Day 2 at the Open
text: It was a day without surprises as Maria Sharapova, Andy Roddick, Martina Hingis and Lleyton Hewitt all advanced easily to the next round.

headline: Courts Rule Against Hedge Funds in Mittal-Arcelor Deal
text: Courts in the Netherlands and France refused to grant injunctions seeking to block Mittal Steel‘s proposed $41 billion acquisition of a rival steel maker, Arcelor.

headline: Switzerland’s ABB to Sell Plant
text: ABB, the Swiss engineering company, will sell an oil and gas production plant, Lummus Global, to the Chicago Bridge and Iron Company for $950 million, ABB said.

headline: Thornburg Pays Collateral Owed to Wachovia
text: Thornburg Mortgage, the jumbo mortgage specialist sued by Wachovia last week, said Monday that it had repaid the $5.1 million in collateral that was the basis of the bank’s litigation.

headline: Refco Trusts Sue on Behalf of Currency Clients
text: Trusts representing creditors of the defunct commodities broker Refco said Monday that they had sued its legal and accounting advisers for more than $500 million on behalf of 75 foreign exchange customers.

headline: French Firm Snaps Up Fotolog
text: Fotolog, a photo-sharing social network founded by Meetup‘s co-founder and chief executive. Scott Heiferman, has been acquired. After several days of rumors that the company was up for sale, the French company Hi-Media Group announced on Monday that it had acquired Fotolog for $90 million in cash and stock.

headline: Former XenSource Chief Now Heads Rival Start-Up
text: As virtualization software continues to garner attention following VMware’s successful $1.1 billion initial public offering and Citrix’s rich $500 million purchase of XenSource, a co-founder of XenSource resurfaced Monday as the head of a rival start-up.

headline: Canada’s Regulators Scrutinize Radio Deal
text: Astral Media faced tough questions Monday from Canadian broadcast regulators who suggested the broadcaster is low-balling the C$1.08 billion ($1.02 billion) purchase price of Standard Broadcasting, a deal that will create the largest commercial radio company Canada has ever seen.

headline: Buffett’s Berkshire Raises Railroad Stake
text: Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway bought more than 10 million shares of the railroad company Burlington Northern Santa Fe since Thursday, increasing its stake to 14.8 percent, according to regulatory filings.

headline: Are Associate Lawyers in the Firing Line?
text: The current turmoil in the credit market has some law firm leaders predicting future layoffs of associates, according to The Legal Intelligencer.

headline: Bank of America’s Lewis: a Modern-Day Morgan?
text: Sentiment is growing that Bank of America‘s Kenneth Lewis may have won a place in the pantheon of great Wall Street titans by using his financial clout to help the country avoid economic ruin, writes MarketWatch’s David Weidner.

headline: Ohio Files Antitrust Suit Against Insurers
text: The state of Ohio has filed an antitrust lawsuit accusing Marsh & McLennan, the American International Group and three other insurers and their subsidiaries of price fixing and other anti-competitive behavior, the attorney general, Marc Dann, said Monday.

headline: After Gateway Deal, Eyes Turn to Lenovo
text: As executives at Gateway and Acer carried on about the many benefits of their $710 million merger announced Monday, TheStreet.com speculated that Acer’s nemesis, Lenovo, might make a counteroffer for Gateway.

headline: Whole Foods Closes Wild Oats Deal
text: Whole Foods Market said on Monday it had bought smaller rival Wild Oats Markets, following months of delays as U.S. antitrust authorities sought to block the $565 million deal. The acquisition extends Whole Foods’ dominance in the expanding natural and organic grocery market and eliminates one of the chain’s chief retailing rivals.

headline: Doubles, Anyone? Anyone?
text: When was the last time you heard someone say his or her favorite tennis players were the Bryan brothers or the Martin Damm/Leander Paes team?

headline: Deutsche Bank Loses Hedge Fund Executive
text: Hedge fund rainmaker John Dyment has left Deutsche Bank in New York to join Shumway Capital Partners, a hedge fund based in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Dyment was global head of the German bank’s hedge fund capital group.

headline: China Eastern Airlines Close to Stake Sale, Report Says
text: China Eastern Airlines will sign an agreement Sunday to sell a stake of itself to Singapore Airlines and Singapore’s state-owned investment company, Temasek Holdings, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing undisclosed sources.

headline: Waiting for the Social Networking I.P.O.’s
text: Social networking Web sites have fired up the media industry’s deal headlines the past couple of years, and now it looks as if social networking could heat up the market for initial public offerings, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

headline: Investors Tell Tales of V.C. Hardball
text: Some top venture-capital firms eager to expand into new markets are twisting their investors’ arms to get them to go along, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Medco Health Coughs Up $1.5 Billion for PolyMedica
text: The pharmacy benefits management company Medco Health Solutions said Tuesday it would pay $1.5 billion in cash for a diabetes treatment supplier, PolyMedica.

headline: Merrill Analyst Downgrades Three Rivals
text: Merrill Lynch is apparently not so hot on some of its rivals’ prospects right now.

headline: Judge Delays Ruling on Bear Funds’ Offshore Liquidation
text: Two bankrupt Bear Stearns hedge funds will have to wait another week or so before finding out if a New York judge will allow the bulk of their reorganization to take place in the Caribbean.

headline: NBC Universal Eyes Sparrowhawk Media, Report Says
text: NBC Universal is holding discussions to buy Sparrowhawk Media, which owns the international operations of the Hallmark Channel, for about $350 million, according to Reuters. Sparrowhawk, a private equity group backed by Providence Equity Partners and 3i purchased the international arm of the Hallmark Channel in 2005 for about $242 million.

headline: L.S.E. Rises on Renewed Takeover Buzz

headline: American Water Works Plans $1.5 Billion I.P.O.
text: American Water Works, a subsidiary of the European utility RWE, filed with United States regulators to sell as much as $1.5 billion in stock in an initial public offering. All the shares to be sold are held by a unit of RWE, which bought American Water Works in 2003 for $4.6 billion.

headline: Conrad Black Asks Judge to Overturn Guilty Verdict
text: Conrad Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International, who was convicted of fraud and obstruction of justice for stealing millions from the company, asked a federal judge to order his acquittal or give him a new trial. In papers filed today with Judge Amy St. Eve of United States District Court in Chicago, Mr. Black’s attorneys argued that evidence prosecutors presented to the jury during his 15-week trial doesn’t support last month’s guilty verdict.

headline: Carlyle Affiliate’s 2nd Bailout Pummels Shares
text: Shares of an $18 billion Dutch investment fund affiliated with the Carlyle Group dropped Tuesday, retreating after it received its second bailout from its private equity parent in a week, MarketWatch reported.

headline: Simons’ Renaissance Said to Pursue Private Offering
text: Renaissance Technologies, the $30 billion hedge fund run by James H. Simons, is said to be considering a share sale, apparently shrugging off concerns about volatile global markets.

headline: Buyout Chiefs See Lower Returns Ahead
text: Private equity funds are likely to book significantly lower returns in the next few years, as tighter credit markets limit the resale value of their portfolio companies, buyout professionals and analysts told Bloomberg News.

headline: Morning Buzz: Fallout From Fire, Man Suspected in Multiple Killings, Ground Zero Asthma and More
text: The city’s decision yesterday to discipline three Fire Department officers in the wake of the Deutsche Bank fire dominates local news coverage today. With the continuing revelations about malfunctioning equipment, inadequate fire plans and careless actions by contractors, the public pressure for answers continues to mount.In an overview, Al Baker notes that fire union officials criticized the decision to remove the officers from their command; some critics have started to call for the resignation of the fire commissioner, Nicholas Scoppetta. Meanwhile, the district attorney’s investigation into the case continues. An accompanying article by John Sullivan notes that the inspection system was revamped after seven people died in a Harlem apartment fire in 1987. But the scale of the work involved, with New York’s dense network of buildings, is daunting. Firefighters conduct general inspections while civilians perform reviews of critical systems like sprinklers. The number of inspections by fire companies fell sharply between the 2005 and 2006 fiscal years, for reasons that are not clear.

headline: Home Depot Confirms New Price for Supply Unit
text: Home Depot said on Tuesday that it was lowering the price of its wholesale supply unit business by nearly $2 billion, confirming media reports. As previously reported, the retailer will sell HD Supply to a consortium of private equity firms for $8.5 billion, while holding onto a 12.5 percent stake in the unit and backing $1 billion in financing.

headline: 2008: Thompson Talk
text: Could the announcement be just a week away? Former Senator Fred D. Thompson has been hedging all summer on officially joining the Republican presidential field, but if the latest chatter in political circles is right, he may jump in as early as next Tuesday.

headline: Wheels: Inside a Citroën Museum of Sorts
text: The Citroën Conservatoire includes an example of nearly every car ever produced by the automaker. More Photos  Tucked to one side of Citroën’s sprawling auto factory in Aulnay-sous-Bois, about 20 minutes outside of Paris, is a gray and mirrored-glass building surrounded by a fringe of green grass. One double-chevron logo adorns the awning of the entrance, but otherwise the structure is nondescript and incredibly reserved, like a warehouse from the future.   This is the Citroën Conservatoire, the company's private museum, which houses an extraordinary collection of cars and an example of nearly every car the company has ever produced.  Stepping inside it’s immediately clear that this is no parts depot. Rally cars, dune buggies, show concepts and elegant DS sedans from the 1950s all sit in orderly rows under high ceilings. A two-passenger helicopter powered by a Wankel rotary engine – developed by Citroën and the defunct German manufacturer, NSU – guards the end of a long line of former show cars dating back to the 1970s.   Photos: Inside the Citroën Conservatoire  Also included among the hundreds of classic cars are incredibly detailed and carefully organized archives: hand-written sales logs from the 1920s, original design sketches and even blueprints for the first Citroën dealerships.  The Conservatoire isn't usually open to the public, though this doesn’t mean that the cars in the collection are camera shy. Nearly all of the vehicles are kept in excellent running condition. Many are used on a regular basis, for a wide range of classic car events and publicity campaigns. On rare occasions, the Conservatoire is open to groups, including journalists and Citroën clubs from around the world.  I walked down row after row and found a gold-colored mystery machine hidden among the rest of the cars. Built sometime around 2000 -- Citroën isn’t clear about the exact date -- it was only a foam mock-up, and lacked an engine and interior. Based on the humdrum Citroën Xantia sedan, its mini pickup lines were awkward. To be honest, it’s unremarkable in every way except one: it was a little-known styling exercise for a proposed return to the United States market.   Denis Huile, director of the Conservatoire, pointed out one small clue to the concept’s American aspirations. Rather than sitting on Citroën’s standard Michelin tires, this car wore chunky all-terrain Goodyears. Yet the car never appeared at an auto show and, to the best of Mr. Huile’s ample knowledge, was never given an official name. In the end, nothing came of the proposed return to the United States, and the idea faded into obscurity.   But in an automobile museum that really isn’t a museum, is it any wonder that the most intriguing car is the one that doesn’t even have a name?   Photos: Inside the Citroën Conservatoire

headline: Answers from Yang Fuqiang
text: Today we have answers to reader questions from Yang Fuqiang in Beijing. Mr. Yang is the chief representative of the Beijing office of the Energy Foundation, a San Francisco-based non-governmental organization that promotes energy efficiency. Mr. Yang began his career working in Chinese energy research and has spent three decades working on energy and environmental issues. His present work is focused on finding ways to help China use energy more efficiently, which, in turn, can help reduce pollution.

headline: Questions for Orville Schell

Earlier this month, Mr. Schell traveled to China and met with Chinese experts and officials to discuss global warming.

headline: Census: New York Region Has Widest Income Gap
text: The rich grew richer in New York and the poor over all remained poor, according to census figures released today, resulting in the widest income gap of any major metropolitan area in the country.The top fifth of earners in 2005 made nearly 20 times what the bottom fifth earned in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut metropolitan region. In Manhattan, the disparity was a chasm, with the wealthiest making nearly 40 times more than the poorest — $351,333 compared to $8,855, or a bigger gap than in any county in the county.

headline: The Potential of Petrova
text: It’s the most vexing description for a talented athlete in any sport: the best player never to win a major, never to get a ring, never to earn the gold. They can’t all be Tiger Woods, who won his first major shortly after he removed his training wheels. Phil Mickelson wore the label until his emotional victory at the 2004 Masters. In tennis, Amelie Mauresmo was the reigning queen of disappointment until she won two majors last year, seven years after she reached the Australian Open final. Roger Federer was supposedly wasting his talent until he won his first Wimbledon and never looked back.

headline: Detection Comes Earlier, and So Do Tough Questions
text: Without fanfare, treatment of prostate cancer has reached a watershed moment. In 2007, for the first time, deaths from the disease will account for less than 10 percent of all cancer deaths in men, continuing a downward trend that began in the 1980s. This success stems largely from earlier detection of these tumors, which many experts credit to wider — and much debated — use of the controversial prostate-specific antigen blood test.

headline: Critics Ignored Record of a Muslim Principal
text: Last Feb. 12, you may recall, New York education officials announced plans to open a minischool in September that would teach half its classes in Arabic and include study of Arab culture. The principal was to be a veteran teacher who was also a Muslim immigrant from Yemen, Debbie Almontaser.

headline: Illinois: Lesbian Is a Finalist for Bishop
text: An openly lesbian priest is one of five candidates nominated by a search committee to be the next Episcopal bishop of Chicago. The nomination of the priest, the Very Rev. Tracey Lind, dean of Trinity Cathedral in Cleveland, came as a surprise because the Episcopal Church passed a resolution at its last general convention calling on dioceses to “exercise restraint” by not consecrating any more openly gay bishops. The Episcopal Church has been under pressure from fellow churches in the Anglican Communion to declare a moratorium on gay bishops, a response to the election in 2003 of an openly gay bishop by the Diocese of New Hampshire. The election in the Diocese of Chicago is Nov. 10.

headline: Precious Hours, Then Lives, Lost in Stroke's Wake
text: To hear researchers talk, the treatment of stroke verges on a breakthrough. Disability and death can be prevented, studies show; indeed, most strokes need never occur in the first place. Yet there is an enormous gap between hope and practice, between the medical system as it should be and as it is, between what patients should know and do and what actually happens in the real world.

headline: Correction: Off the Menu
text: Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Off the Menu column last Wednesday about the opening of Toloache, a Mexican restaurant, misstated its address. It is 251 West 50th Street.

headline: Belonging and Belief, Found in Scrap Lumber

People tend to return Mr. Nelson’s calls. They show up for meetings with him.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. Their films are at the heart of this episode of “CNN: Special Investigations Unit,” in which the young people, four of whom are shown above with Ms. O’Brien, center, describe their journeys.

headline: In Search of Good Teachers
text: With 50 million children set to return to school, districts all over the country are still scrambling to fill teaching positions and are having an especially difficult time finding qualified applicants to fill shortages in vital areas like math and science. These shortages will persist and the education reform effort will continue to lag until states, localities and the federal government start paying much more attention to how teachers are trained, hired and assigned.

headline: New York’s Gap Between Rich and Poor Is Nation’s Widest, Census Says

headline: Mets Demote Lawrence and Consider Options

headline: Bush's Chances of Uniting the Divide Seem Slim

Now, supposedly, the political temperature can finally cool in Washington; the two parties can settle into a more productive relationship and President Bush can manage a few more accomplishments in his final 16 months in office.

headline: People Being Themselves, and Other Sorry Tales
text: The forces of dignity and political correctness declared a small victory last month when BET announced that it was changing the title of this summer’s new show “Hot Ghetto Mess: We Got to Do Better” to simply “We Got to Do Better.” For their peace of mind, let’s hope those protesters haven’t actually been watching the show, which the host, the comedian Charlie Murphy, opens by declaring, “Welcome to ‘Hot Ghetto Mess.’ ”

headline: Selected Studies: Alzheimer's Disease

Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research.
