text: Dr. Nancy A. Collop is an associate professor of medicine at Johns Hopkins University and a former president of the American Board of Sleep Medicine.

headline: Carlyle Makes Loan to Support Affiliate
text: The Carlyle Group propped up its credit-investment affiliate in the British island of Guernsey by buying some of its assets and extending a second $100 million loan in case the market volatility of the last five weeks persists.

headline: Love Lost and Fame Gained for a Young Nureyev
text: Ballet made the front pages of newspapers around the world when Rudolf Nureyev defected from the Soviet Union on June 16, 1961. The dramatic circumstances are chronicled tonight in “Nureyev: The Russian Years,” part of the “Great Performances” series on PBS. But the fascination of this documentary is the light it throws on Nureyev’s life and career before his escape, through candid observations by close friends as well as colleagues in Nureyev’s youthful Leningrad years.

headline: Finance Chief of Google Plans His Retirement at 53
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28  Google said Tuesday that George Reyes, the company’s longtime chief financial officer, plans to retire. He will be one of only a few of the Internet search giant’s top executives to have left since its founding in 1998.

headline: Trying to Connect the Dinner Plate to Climate Change
text: EVER since “An Inconvenient Truth,” Al Gore has been the darling of environmentalists, but that movie hardly endeared him to the animal rights folks. According to them, the most inconvenient truth of all is that raising animals for meat contributes more to global warming than all the sport utility vehicles combined.

headline: Priced Out of Rome
text: Who wouldn’t want to live in Rome, one of the most beautiful cities in world?

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Aug. 16 about a joint project between I.B.M. and the Beacon Institute for Rivers and Estuaries, a scientific research organization, to create a center for river research that will monitor conditions in the Hudson referred incorrectly to John Cronin, the director of the institute. (The error was repeated in an editorial in the Westchester section on Aug. 19.) Mr. Cronin is the second Hudson riverkeeper, a private pollution watchdog — not the first, a distinction held by Thomas Whyatt, who served from 1973 to 1976.

headline: The Sound of Reading
text: Colin Powell, Garrison Keillor, Sandra Day O’Connor and Robert Duvall will be among the voices in a new series of book readings and discussions on XM Satellite Radio, the company announced. The show, “The Big Read,” created by XM along with the National Endowment for the Arts and the online audio bookstore Audible, will feature complete readings of classic books and discussions with authors in 30-minute weekday installments, beginning on Sept. 10 with Ray Bradbury’s “Fahrenheit 451.” Other titles to be broadcast on XM’s Channel 164 include Fitzgerald’s “Great Gatsby” and Amy Tan’s “Joy Luck Club.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Recipe: T’afia’s Ratafia
text: Adapted from Monica Pope

headline: Yankees, New and Old, Slow the Red Sox
text: If it all works out the way the Yankees hope, Joba Chamberlain will face the Boston Red Sox for years with a game on the line. The first confrontation came last night, and Chamberlain immediately sinned: he walked the leadoff man in the eighth inning, Kevin Youkilis.

headline: Wildflowers Find Favor With Highway Gardeners
text: NEWARK, Del. — For Americans on the move, a rest stop on the East Coast’s main thoroughfare, Interstate 95, seems an unlikely setting for a revolution. But to a growing number of horticulturalists, the vegetation stretching beyond the gas pumps toward the highway median might as well be marching behind a fife and drum.

headline: Paramus: Superintendent Resigns
text: The superintendent of the Paramus schools resigned Monday night, following criticism of her actions after the discovery of contaminated soil at the West Brook Middle School last year that eventually forced the school to close in May. The superintendent, Janice Dime, who had worked in the district for 22 years, will resign and receive $212,000 in salary for the coming year, plus $20,000 in medical benefits, said Mario V. Sicari, the school board president.

headline: Notes from the Center of an Epidemic
text: Dr. Terry Mason is a urologist, commissioner of the Chicago Department of Public Health, and a leading advocate for African-American men with prostate cancer.

headline: Orders for Simpson Book Soar
text: Beaufort Books, the publisher of “If I Did It,” the recently revived book in which O. J. Simpson hypothesizes about how he might have murdered Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman in 1994, announced yesterday that it would print 125,000 copies and would likely go back to press before the book is released around Sept 13. Eric Kampmann, owner and president of Beaufort, said the company already had orders for 116,000 copies from chain bookstores, independents and online retailers. Although Barnes & Noble announced that it would not sell the book in its stores, advance orders online at bn.com propelled it to No. 1 on its best-seller list on Monday, and it hovered between No. 2 and 5 yesterday. Last fall, after a public outcry, HarperCollins scuttled plans for a 400,000-copy print run by its Regan Books imprint. Since then, the Goldman family won the rights in bankruptcy court to publish the book. Separately, Denise Brown, sister of Ms. Brown Simpson, said yesterday in a statement that she was withdrawing from a planned Sept. 13 appearance on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” alongside members of the Goldman family. “At the time of accepting this proposition from Oprah, a publisher was not yet established, and publication was still pending,” Ms. Brown said, adding: “Since then, the Goldmans have retained a publisher who is rushing the book to market as we speak. And thus, has made the show a moot point for me.”

headline: Shorter Waits for Botox Than Examinations of Moles
text: Patients seeking an appointment with a dermatologist to ask about a potentially cancerous mole have to wait substantially longer than those seeking Botox for wrinkles, says a study published online today by The Journal of the American Academy of Dermatology.

headline: Strahan Has Decided When He’ll Decide
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 28 — Michael Strahan told the Giants he would announce his retire-or-return decision on Wednesday or Thursday, the team said.

headline: Selected Studies: Stroke
text: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: John Gardner, Who Continued the James Bond Series, Dies at 80
text: John Gardner, a prolific British thriller writer who wrote more novels about Bond — James Bond — than Ian Fleming did, died on Aug. 3 after collapsing near his home in Basingstoke, England. He was 80.

headline: Questions on City’s Role in Demolition Near 9/11 Site
text: The former headquarters of Deutsche Bank, at the edge of ground zero, has been in state hands for more than three years, ever since the Pataki administration fashioned a deal to buy and demolish it. The wounded tower had stood as both an ugly reminder of Sept. 11 and the slow progress in rebuilding downtown Manhattan.

headline: Ex-Astronaut to Enter a Plea of Insanity on Assault Charges
text: Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, the Navy officer and former astronaut who confronted a romantic rival at the Orlando, Fla., airport in February, will plead insanity at her trial on assault and kidnapping charges, according to a notice filed yesterday in State Circuit Court in Orlando.

headline: What to Ask About Alzheimer's Disease
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: Stocks Fall Across Asia After U.S. Losses
text: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 29 — The volatility triggered by the mortgage meltdown in the United States further plagued stock markets today, prompting a drop of all major indices in Asia a day after a battering on Wall Street.

headline: Selected Studies: Headaches
text: Government agencies, universities, and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Lucerne to Getan Opera House
text: The Lucerne Festival in Switzerland said yesterday it planned to build a 1,000-seat opera house, adding an important element to its classical music offerings. The festival put construction costs at $85 million, though it must still find a site and hold a competition for an architect. The hall will be flexible enough to present chamber music, music theater and experimental works, said Michael Haefliger, the event’s executive and artistic director. Taking place in summer and at Easter time, the festival operates in the Culture and Convention Center on Lake Lucerne, a much-praised modern building designed by Jean Nouvel. It has been trying to compete with its better-known rivals in Salzburg, Austria and Bayreuth, Germany, both opera destinations. “This project represents a quantum leap for the Lucerne Festival,” said Jürg Reinshagen, the festival’s board president, “and will position Lucerne even more prominently at the forefront of the international music scene.”

headline: U.S. Releases Group of Iranians Held in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, Wednesday Aug. 29 — Members of an Iranian Energy Ministry delegation visiting Baghdad at the invitation of the Iraqi government were released Wednesday, a day after being arrested at their hotel by American troops and led away in handcuffs and blindfolds.

headline: Dress Like Your Child, and the Terrorists Win
text: Fathers in America used to have sons. Now they have mini-me’s. Pop and his offspring head out to the mall dressed in the same outfits: baggy shorts, sneakers, athletic socks and T-shirt, topped by a baseball cap. At home they watch Cartoon Network, play video games and eat lots of breakfast cereal. One is older and bigger, the other smaller and younger, but their tastes overlap to a remarkable degree. Today’s child truly is father to the man.

headline: Tracing the Path from DNA to Dementia
text: Dr. Marcelle Morrison-Bogorad is director of the neuroscience and neuropsychology of aging program at the National Institute on Aging. In collaboration with the Alzheimer's Association, the institute runs the Alzheimer's Disease Genetics Initiative, which is collecting and banking genetic and cellular material from families in which multiple relatives have late-onset Alzheimer's, the most common form of the disease.

headline: Cautious Optimism for Sufferers of Joint Pain
text: For decades patients with osteoarthritis resigned themselves to what seemed to be the body’s inevitable breakdown. People grow old, doctors told them. Hips and knees wear out. What can you do?

headline: The Attorney General We Need (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Spring Awakening’ Perks Up
text: For a while there the musical “Spring Awakening” was barely making enough in a good week to meet its running costs. But after winning a raft of Tony Awards, unveiling a new advertising campaign and posting strong summer grosses, the show has recouped its original $4.2 million investment, said Ira Pittleman, one of its lead producers.

headline: Close Political Ally of Brazilian President to Face Corruption Trial
text: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 28 — A corruption scandal that has hovered like a black cloud over President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva for two years intensified this week after Brazil’s Supreme Court voted to put his former chief of staff on trial on corruption charges.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about a program in South Texas that helps families gradually rebuild shacks into homes misstated the surname of the Starr County ombudswoman who oversees the state’s Colonia Initiatives Program. She is Blanca Juarez, not Suarez. Also, the article carried an incorrect dateline, and a picture caption repeated the error. The article and photograph were from Rio Grande City; there is no town named Rio Grande.

headline: Idaho Senator Says He Regrets Guilty Plea in Restroom Incident
text: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 28 — Senator Larry E. Craig said Tuesday that he regretted his guilty plea in connection with an airport restroom incident, and he accused an Idaho newspaper of hounding him in recent months.

headline: Horticulturalists Seek to Go Native on Interstates
text: NEWARK, Del. — For Americans on the move, a rest stop on the East Coast’s main drag, Interstate 95, seems an unlikely setting for a revolution. But to a growing number of horticulturalists the vegetation stretching beyond the gas pumps toward the highway median might as well be marching behind a fife and drum.

headline: A Surgeon's Own Back Story
text: Dr. James N. Weinstein is editor of the medical journal Spine and chairman of the department of orthopedic surgery at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, N.H.

headline: What to Ask About Back Pain
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: The Necessity, and Elusiveness, of Sleep
text: Why do we sleep?

headline: Isinbayeva’s Boasting Exceeds Her Heights
text: OSAKA, Japan, Wednesday, Aug. 29  While her competitors struggled, one dropping out with a leg injury, another puffy-eyed and crying after a dispute with the judges, Yelena Isinbayeva remained in her bubble.

headline: A Sobering Census Report: Americans’ Meager Income Gains
text: The economic party is winding down and most working Americans never even got near the punch bowl.

headline: Beyond the Fringe
text: Record sales of 1.7 million tickets were announced yesterday, a day after the end of the 60th Edinburgh Festival Fringe, by organizers, the BBC reported. Sales increased 10 percent from last year’s total at the arts festival, which began on Aug. 5. ... The 75th Venice Film Festival opens today, with all 22 films in competition for the Golden Lion to be seen in their world premieres, Agence France-Presse reported. That has occurred only once before, last year.

headline: SAT Scores Dip Slightly in a More Diverse Field
text: Average reading and math scores on the SAT test declined slightly this year, as the number of high school students taking the standardized exam grew larger and more diverse than ever, according to a report released yesterday by the College Board on the high school class of 2007.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about “Have You Seen Steve Steven?,” a forthcoming production at the East 14th Street Theater, misstated the name of the presenter. It is the collective 13 Playwrights Inc., not 12 Playwrights Inc.

headline: Keep the Electoral College (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: One Mortgage Lender, at Least, Is Hiring
text: One mortgage lender announced that it was hiring yesterday as it tried to take advantage of the turmoil in the market, while another said it was cutting jobs.

headline: Report Cites Other Arrests at Airport
text: The arrest report accusing Senator Larry E. Craig of disorderly conduct in a bathroom stall at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport said Mr. Craig’s actions followed “numerous arrests regarding sexual activity in the public restroom.”

headline: Selected Studies: Childhood Asthma
text: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Amid All the Cheers, a Few Signs of Change
text: Take a 19-year-old Disney-groomed actress, beloved by tweens and former tweens. Put her onstage at Radio City Music Hall. Give her a microphone. No, a working microphone. Sounds like a recipe for disaster, right?

headline: After Blaze, New Focus on Smoking at Work Sites
text: Alan Theibotot was doing what a smoker does yesterday. He was smoking. More precisely, he was smoking during lunch.

headline: U.N. Secretary General to Meet Sudanese Leader
text: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 28 — Secretary General Ban Ki-moon announced Tuesday that he would travel to Sudan, Chad and Libya next week to press for an end to fresh violence in Darfur and for speedy deployment there of a joint African Union-United Nations peacekeeping force.

headline: S.& P. Cuts British Firm’s Debt Rating
text: A London money management firm, Cheyne Capital Management, may be forced to liquidate the assets backing its $10 billion commercial paper program in the latest casualty of the jittery credit market.

headline: What to Ask About Prostate Cancer
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: Tracking an Urban Plague
text: Dr. David L. Rosenstreich is director of the division of allergy and immunology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York. He is a former senior investigator with the Inner City Asthma Study, which identifies factors related to the development of asthma in children.

headline: A Breakthrough in Joint Pain
text: Revolutions are rare in the management of chronic disease, which tends to be a matter of incremental progress. But over the past decade, patients with rheumatoid arthritis have seen advances in treatment that most could barely have imagined. A new class of drugs called biologic response modifiers has transformed the lives of countless R.A. sufferers, so much so that many have been able to return to active, rich lives.

headline: Bush Cites Nuclear Risk of Leaving Iraq
text: RENO, Nev., Aug. 28 — President Bush told a receptive audience of veterans on Tuesday that an American withdrawal from Iraq would unsettle the entire Middle East, create a haven for Al Qaeda and embolden a belligerent Iran. He said Tehran’s nuclear programs threatened to put “a region already known for instability and violence under the shadow of a nuclear holocaust.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture on Friday with an article about the impending release from prison of Arthur Bremer, who shot Gov. George C. Wallace, appeared in mirror image. The photograph, taken by The Associated Press in 1972, showed Mr. Bremer facing left, surrounded by police officers and security agents. The A.P. incorrectly re-released the picture last week with him looking right.

text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

The photograph, taken by The Associated Press in 1972, showed Mr. Bremer facing left, surrounded by police officers and security agents. The A.P. re-released the picture last week with him looking right. (Go to Article)

headline: What You Get for... $400,000
text: Sarasota, Fla.

headline: Judge Upholds Right to Ban Metal Bats
text: In a case closely watched by baseball organizations and bat manufacturers across the country, a federal judge yesterday upheld a New York City law banning the use of metal bats in high school baseball games.

headline: Medco to Acquire Diabetes Supplier
text: Medco Health Solutions, the biggest American manager of drug benefits, has agreed to buy PolyMedica, the largest supplier of glucose-testing supplies for patients with diabetes, for $1.3 billion, the companies announced yesterday.

headline: The Shock Comes Back and Ousts the Liberty
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Aug. 28 — It has been a week of big comebacks in the W.N.B.A. playoffs, but the Liberty found itself on the wrong side of one Tuesday night, and it ended its season.

headline: China: Communist Party to Meet Oct. 15
text: A major congress expected to produce a new Communist Party leadership team will open on Oct. 15, the state news media reported. The dates of the gathering, held just twice a decade, had been kept secret for months by President Hu Jintao and other top leaders. Mr. Hu, who is also chief of the party, is expected to use the congress to place allies in major leadership positions to solidify his grip on power.

headline: Jersey City Landlords Prosper in New York’s Shadow
text: Although a few companies in other industries have begun moving in, office real estate in Jersey City is still very much an annex of Wall Street. Since modern towers started springing up along its waterfront in the 1990s, its fortunes have usually risen and fallen with the ebbs and flows in the financial markets.

text: Government agencies, universities, and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. headline: What to Ask About Depression
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: Astronauts Were Not Impaired for Missions, NASA Says
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 — A NASA investigation into astronauts’ use of alcohol before space missions has found no evidence of heavy drinking or drunkenness prior to launches, according to an agency report released today.

headline: Ocean Grove: Clash Over Civil Unions
text: New Jersey is seeking to dismiss a lawsuit claiming that it is pressuring the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association into allowing civil unions at its boardwalk pavilion. The state argues in its motion, filed on Monday in Federal District Court in Trenton, that the federal courts are not the proper jurisdiction for the lawsuit. The association, a Methodist group, said in its lawsuit that the state was violating its First Amendment rights by pressuring it to allow the ceremonies. The New Jersey Division on Civil Rights is investigating two discrimination complaints from gay couples whose requests to use the pavilion, which the association owns, for civil union ceremonies were denied. The association filed a separate request with the court asking that the discrimination investigation be stopped. Compiled by John Sullivan

headline: Selected Studies: Weight Loss and Obesity
text: Government agencies, universities, and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Doctor Accused of Sex Abuse May Face Additional Charges
text: BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 28 — A New Jersey doctor facing charges that he sexually abused 10 women in his care may have abused more patients, an official who had been briefed on the case said on Tuesday.

headline: Bush Sees Hope in New Orleans 2 Years After Storm
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 — President Bush toured New Orleans today, delivering a message of hope to a city devastated by wind and flood two years ago and still divided over the speed and effectiveness of federal help.

headline: Queens: Boy on Bicycle Killed in Crash
text: A 12-year-old boy was killed yesterday afternoon in Springfield Gardens when he was hit by a box truck while riding his bicycle, the police said. The boy, who was not named yesterday pending family notification, was riding alongside the truck just before 1 p.m. near 130th Avenue and Springfield Boulevard when he was hit by the vehicle, the police said. He was pronounced dead at the scene. No charges were issued against the driver yesterday, the police said.

headline: In Troubled District, School Starts With Enough Books but Not Enough Money
text: ROOSEVELT, N.Y., Aug. 22 — Students returning to school here can expect to find some things they have learned to do without in the five years their district has been under state control: enough textbooks for everyone, correct class assignments, even toilet paper in the bathrooms.

headline: Few Iraqis Reach Safe U.S. Havens Despite Program
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 28 — Despite a stepped-up commitment from the United States to take in Iraqis who are in danger because they worked for the American government and military, very few are signing up to go, resettlement officials say.

headline: How to Eat (and Read) Close to Home
text: NO one would ever mistake Edible Brooklyn for Edible Atlanta, though both are quarterly food magazines that share a corporate parent and a typeface. But the story titles in the latest issue of the Brooklyn version might flummox Atlantans. There is, for example, “Fresh Kills,” about a live poultry market in Williamsburg, and “Late Night Nosh,” which is self-explanatory, at least in New York City.

headline: Army Colonel Is Acquitted in Abu Ghraib Case
text: A military jury announced that an Army officer who was convicted of a lesser charge and acquitted of all others Tuesday in the Abu Ghraib prison scandal would receive a formal reprimand as his sentence.

headline: A New Role, but for Her, Familiar Turf
text: Marcia V. Lyles, New York City’s new deputy chancellor for teaching and learning, knows intimately just how students can get lost in the shuffle. In her sophomore year in high school in Harlem, Ms. Lyles was caught skipping class almost daily.

headline: Lawyer Quits Firm to Focus on Inquiry
text: William S. Lerach, a leading securities class-action lawyer who has been embroiled in a seven-year federal investigation into possible kickbacks to plaintiffs for their testimony, is retiring from his firm.

headline: New Orleans Pauses to Remember Victims of Katrina
text: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 29 — A day of mourning and remembrance for the victims of Hurricane Katrina began today with a solemn bell ringing at a cemetery at precisely 9:38 a.m., the moment when a key levee breached two years ago and devastated this Gulf Coast town.

headline: Census Shows a Modest Rise in U.S. Income
text: The nation’s median household income grew modestly in 2006, the Census Bureau reported yesterday, even as the percentage of people without health insurance hit a high.

headline: Taliban Will Release Hostages, South Korea Says
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 28 — The Taliban agreed Tuesday to release 19 South Korean church volunteers held captive in Afghanistan since mid-July, the South Korean government announced, signaling an end to a wrenching hostage crisis that had gripped the country for almost six weeks.

headline: The Limits of Willpower
text: Dr. Barry E. Levin, a neurologist at New Jersey Medical School, has been investigating the brain's role in obesity for more than 20 years. His recent findings suggest that exercise early in life may prevent obesity, even in people who have a genetic propensity to gain weight.

headline: Three Former Champions Advance at Open
text: Svetlana Kuznetsova, Martina Hingis and Lleyton Hewitt — three former United States Open champions — easily advanced to the second round of the Open today.

headline: Some Balk at Giuliani Role in 9/11 Ceremony
text: Each year since Sept. 11, 2001, Rudolph W. Giuliani has spoken at New York City’s commemorations of the attacks. At past ceremonies he has read off the names of some of the dead, given readings by Lincoln and Churchill, and recited poetry.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture on Friday with an article about an accident at the Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan in which two firefighters were injured by a falling forklift carried an erroneous credit. The photograph, showing the demolition scene, was by Suzanne DeChillo of The New York Times, not by Cary Conover for The New York Times.

headline: June Bingham Birge, Who Wrote Books and Plays, Dies at 88
text: June Bingham Birge, the author of books and plays, died on Aug. 21 at her home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. She was 88.

headline: Footnotes
text: A police log in Santa Monica, Calif., listed “attempt suicide” as the reason for officers’ response to a call from the home of the actor Owen Wilson, below, on Sunday, The Associated Press reported. The log did not indicate who made the call. Mr. Wilson’s press representative, Ina Treciokas, declined yesterday to answer questions seeking to determine if Mr. Wilson, who was hospitalized, tried to kill himself. ... Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band announced yesterday their first full-scale international tour since 2002-3. The 13-country journey begins in Hartford on Oct. 2, the release date for Mr. Springsteen’s album “Magic,” and ends in London on Dec. 19. Mr. Springsteen and the band are to perform at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., on Oct. 9 and 10 and at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 17 and 18.

headline: Panama: U.S. Backs Noriega Extradition
text: Manuel Antonio Noriega, the deposed Panamanian strongman who is ending a 15-year prison sentence in Miami, can be extradited to France, where he faces charges of money laundering and up to a decade in prison, a federal judge in Miami ruled. The decision by Magistrate Judge William C. Turnoff followed a decision last week by another federal judge that rejected an argument that Mr. Noriega, above, should be returned to Panama when his current term for drug trafficking and racketeering ends on Sept. 9. A lawyer for Mr. Noriega vowed to appeal. The final decision on whether Mr. Noriega, 73, can be extradited to France lies with Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice.

headline: Governor Refuses Blame in 35 Hurricane Deaths
text: ST. FRANCISVILLE, La., Aug. 28 — Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco was summoned to a courtroom on Tuesday to testify in a homicide case over Hurricane Katrina’s single biggest loss of life, and she refused to take blame for the deaths of 35 patients who drowned at a nursing home.

headline: A Hidden Cause of Headache Pain
text: Four percent of Americans suffer headaches daily, and scientists have suspected culprits as diverse as undiagnosed jaw disorders, genetic susceptibility and stress. But according to recent research, a sizeable and growing number of headaches are being caused by the very medications taken to alleviate them — and the problem is far more common than scientists had realized. Half of chronic migraines, and as many as 25 percent of all headaches, are actually “rebound” episodes triggered by the overuse of common pain medications. Both prescription and over-the-counter drugs may be to blame.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Aug. 20 about the greeting card market referred imprecisely to the number of paper cards sold relative to online cards, and misattributed the statistic. The statement that the paper card market is five times as large as the e-card market applied to cards sold by one company, American Greetings, not the industry at large, and it should have been attributed to American Greetings — not the Greeting Card Association, a trade group.

headline: Arrest Ordered for Russian Oil Entrepreneur, a Critic of the Kremlin
text: MOSCOW, Aug. 28  A Russian court issued an arrest warrant Tuesday for Mikhail S. Gutseriev, a former owner of Russneft, a large young oil company, on charges of tax evasion and fraud, a month after he published a letter critical of the government on a company Web site and in a Russian business newspaper.

headline: A Saint’s Dark Night
text: THE stunning revelations contained in a new book, which show that Mother Teresa doubted God’s existence, will delight her detractors and confuse her admirers. Or is it the other way around?

headline: Burning Man Is Torched
text: Flames early yesterday singed but did not consume the figure of the Burning Man looming atop a pavilion at the Burning Man counterculture arts festival in the Black Rock Desert of Nevada, The Reno Gazette-Journal reported. The fire, reported at 2:58 a.m., was extinguished in 23 minutes. Onlookers shouted “save the man” and cheered the firefighters. Paul Addis, 35, of San Francisco, was arrested on suspicion of arson and illegal possession of fireworks, according to the sheriff’s department, The Associated Press reported. The official man-burning ceremony is scheduled for late Saturday.

headline: G.O.P. Plans Early-Primary Penalties
text: The Republican National Committee plans to penalize at least five states holding early primaries, including New Hampshire and Florida, by refusing to seat at least half of their delegates at the national convention in 2008, a party official said yesterday.

headline: Bloomberg Proposes Expanding Tax Credit to Fight Poverty
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 — Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took his antipoverty message to a national stage on Tuesday, proposing an $8.5 billion expansion of the federal earned income tax credit to bring more poor people, especially men, into the work force.

headline: New Remedies for an Everyday Complaint
text: Dr. Robert Kunkel has been a headache specialist at the Cleveland Clinic for more than 35 years. He is past president of the American Headache Society and the National Headache Foundation.

headline: A Surplus of Treatment Options, Few of Them Good
text: Back pain is one of the most common medical complaints, so it’s no surprise that treatments for it have multiplied over the years. That ought to be good news; instead, many patients find that sudden back pain opens the door to a world of medical controversy. Virtually every pharmaceutical or surgical remedy has been challenged in recent years, and for all the money sufferers spend on doctor visits, hospital stays, procedures and drugs, studies clearly show that most people with back pain heal the old-fashioned way: on their own, slowly, without significant intervention.

headline: Iraqi Cleric Halts Militia Activities for 6 Months
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 29 — The radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr on Wednesday said that he was suspending for six months his Mahdi Army militia’s operations, including attacks on American troops, only hours after his fighters waged running street battles with Iraqi government forces for control of Karbala, one of Iraq’s holiest cities.

headline: Two Hits, One Short and One Far, Beat the Mets
text: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 — The momentum in this series smacked in front of the plate, kicked off a chunk of dirt and hugged the third-base foul line before coming to a halt beside the chalk. The Phillies, fooled by Tom Glavine through seven innings, tied the score in the eighth on Aaron Rowand’s swinging bunt that traveled about 30 feet.

headline: Republicans Plan to Penalize States on Primaries
text: The Republican National Committee plans to penalize at least four states holding early primaries, including New Hampshire and Florida, by refusing to seat at least half their delegates at the party’s national convention in 2008, a party official said Tuesday.

headline: Pension Inquiry Scrutinizes Fees to a Hevesi Consultant
text: ALBANY, Aug. 28  State investigators have been scrutinizing fees paid to the political consultant Hank Morris by investment firms seeking business with the New York State pension fund, including $12.3 million the Carlyle Group paid to a firm that employed Mr. Morris, according to companies that have been contacted as part of the inquiry.

headline: Damon Gets a Chance to Carry the Yankees
text: Johnny Damon tilted his head to the left as he trotted toward first base, a subtle gesture to try and help keep his fly ball down the right-field line in fair territory. It was not like Carlton Fisk waving his arms wildly to try and keep to keep his ball fair in the 1975 World Series. It was simply a head tilt.

headline: Greek Government Faces Political Fallout From Fires
text: ATHENS, Aug. 28 — The fires that tore omnivorously through scores of villages and olive groves here may now also be changing Greece’s political landscape: the government of Prime Minister Kostas Karamanlis, facing national elections next month, came under increasing criticism Tuesday, not only over its handling of the fires but also over whether it intensified Greeks’ fears about who might be to blame.

headline: Mussina to Lose His Spot in the Rotation, for Now
text: There are no games to waste in a race to the postseason, no time to let a proud veteran work through his problems with a playoff spot at stake. The Yankees delivered that point after last night’s game, announcing that the rookie Ian Kennedy would replace Mike Mussina in the rotation, at least for now.

headline: NBC Buys TV Group Overseas
text: NBC Universal announced yesterday the acquisition of a group of international cable television channels owned by Sparrowhawk Holdings of London, a deal that Jeff Zucker, the president and chief executive of NBC, said was the first sign of a strategic shift at the company.

headline: Newark: Shooting Suspect Extradited
text: One of the six suspects accused of killing three people and wounding a fourth in a schoolyard shooting in Newark on Aug. 4 was extradited from Virginia to New Jersey yesterday, the authorities said. The suspect, a 16-year-old, will be held at a juvenile detention center and will likely appear for a hearing in family court next week, according to Paul M. Loriquet, a spokesman for the Essex County prosecutor. He was captured in Woodbridge, Va., on Aug. 18, barely an hour after the authorities arrested his half brother, Rodolfo Godinez, 24, in Maryland. Mr. Godinez is fighting his extradition to New Jersey. Investigators said the two half brothers are part of a group of six men and teenagers charged with murder, robbery, and other crimes in the attack of four youths who were at the playground that night.

headline: Flood-Soaked Queens Blames Development, Lagging Sewers and Climate Change
text: For most of New York City, the flash flooding on the morning of Aug. 8 was brief, if breathtaking. But try telling that to Kathleen Conway of Woodside, Queens, whose son-in-law is busy ripping out the mold-grimed walls of her live-in basement before they crumble.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the Metro Briefing column in some copies on Thursday, about the death of a 78-year-old Yonkers woman whose apartment was set on fire, included an erroneous given name from the police for the victim. She was Louise Paciarello, not Madeline.

headline: Fears for Amy Winehouse
text: The father-in-law of the British singer Amy Winehouse urged her fans yesterday to boycott her music and said she should be ineligible for awards until she seeks treatment for drug addiction, the BBC reported. In an interview with BBC Radio 5 Live, Giles Fielder-Civil said that Ms. Winehouse, left, and her husband, Blake, Mr. Fielder-Civil’s son, would die without medical help. “Perhaps it is time to stop buying records,” he said. “It’s a possibility, to send that message.” But Ms. Winehouse’s father, Mitch, said, “It won’t send any message to Amy at all, unfortunately,” adding, “If I thought it would, it would be a great idea.” Mr. Fielder-Civil said he believed that Ms. Winehouse, a nominee for a Mercury Music Prize, an MTV Video Music Award and four Music of Black Origin (MOBO) Awards for her 2006 album “Back to Black,” had been using cocaine, crack cocaine and possibly heroin. His wife, Georgette, said she feared that her son and Ms. Winehouse would eventually die unless they received medical help. In a statement, officials of Island Records, Ms. Winehouse’s label, said, “We have been doing everything we can to help with Amy’s personal problems over the past few weeks.” Ms. Winehouse, who is to turn 24 on Sept. 14, was hospitalized this month for “severe exhaustion” and withdrew from concerts in the United States and Canada “to address her health.”

headline: What to Ask About Headaches
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: Calls Grow for Foreigners to Have a Say on U.S. Market Rules
text: Politicians, regulators and financial specialists outside the United States are seeking a role in the oversight of American markets, banks and rating agencies after recent problems related to subprime mortgages.

headline: Spitzer Vetoes Building Inspection Measure
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer vetoed a bill yesterday that would have required more regular inspections of New York City buildings that have been found to be hazardous. The move came days after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg wrote a letter to the governor urging a veto.

headline: Edible Films With Superpowers
text: New Brunswick, N.J.

headline: A Rookie Linebacker Bear Hugs a Challenge
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 28 — David Harris has always tackled challenges head-on, a trait that serves him well as an inside linebacker. In the fifth grade, Harris, a second-round draft pick of the Jets, was seven pounds over the 135-pound weight limit to play football with children his age. So he fashioned a track suit out of a trash bag and ran laps around the park near his home in Grand Rapids, Mich., until darkness caught up with him.

headline: Difference in A.L. East Traces to Off-Season
text: The Red Sox get no points for many of their acquisitions the past two years. J. D. Drew, Julio Lugo and Coco Crisp have not performed as expected. The pitching additions, on the other hand, are the primary reason the Red Sox are poised to win their first American League East title since 1995.

headline: Leon Shull, 93, Champion of Liberal Causes, Dies
text: Leon Shull, a leading advocate of liberal causes for two decades as national director of Americans for Democratic Action, died Saturday in Philadelphia, his hometown. He was 93.

headline: San Jose Likely to Become Bay Area’s Team
text: As the owner of the Oakland A’s, Lew Wolff is intimately familiar with the concept of three strikes and you’re out. That notion has not deterred Wolff, a wealthy, 71-year-old real estate developer, from picking up the banner of the San Jose Earthquakes, a team that has an 0-2 count.

headline: For the Overweight, Bad Advice by the Spoonful
text: Americans have been getting fatter for years, and with the increase in waistlines has come a surplus of conventional wisdom. If we could just return to traditional diets, if we just walk for 20 minutes a day, exercise gurus and government officials maintain, America’s excess pounds would slowly but surely melt away.

headline: Persistent Fear Drives Stocks Down
text: The stock market plunged late in the afternoon yesterday, registering its biggest drop in three weeks as investors were hit by fresh worries over declining consumer confidence, falling house prices, shrinking profits on Wall Street and uncertainty about the Federal Reserve.

text: Dr. Gary Firestein, the recipient of the Arthritis Foundation's 2006 Lee C. Howley Sr. Prize for Research in Arthritis, heads the division of rheumatology, allergy and immunology at the University of California, San Diego. His research into the causes of rheumatoid arthritis led to the development of so-called anti-TNF therapies that have revolutionized treatment.

text: Dr. Joan Bathon is director of the Johns Hopkins Arthritis Center and co-deputy director of the division of rheumatology at the Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center in Baltimore.

headline: Wages Up in China as Young Workers Grow Scarce
text: SHENZHEN, China, Aug. 28 — At the Dahon bicycle factory here, Zhang Jingming’s fingers move quickly and methodically — grabbing bicycle seats, wrapping them in cardboard and smoothly attaching them to frames.

headline: Women, Weight Gain and Antidepressants
text: Dr. Sanjay Gupta is the chairman of the psychiatry department at Olean General Hospital in Olean, N.Y., and clinical associate professor of psychiatry at the University of Buffalo. He researches the side effects of antidepressant use.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about the fire inspection system for buildings in New York City misstated the surname of a spokesman for the Fire Department, who said he could not provide more information on the reasons for a decrease in inspections from fiscal year 2005 to fiscal year 2006. He is Firefighter James F. Long, not Young.

headline: Gains Unclear as Israeli and Palestinian Leaders Meet
text: JERUSALEM, Aug. 28 — Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel and the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, discussed the core issues of contention between their peoples at a meeting here on Tuesday, but it was unclear how closely they moved toward a foundation for a final settlement.

headline: U.S. Troops Arrest Members of Iran Ministry in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, Wednesday, Aug. 29  An Iranian Energy Ministry delegation was arrested by American troops at a hotel in central Baghdad during an official visit to Iraq, the Iranian state news agency, IRNA, and hotel staff said Tuesday night.

headline: A Misanthrope and His Crumbling Castle
text: Jorgen Lauersen Vig, the solitary 80-something misanthrope who inhabits the dilapidated Hesbjerg Castle in the Danish countryside, resembles a gaunt, white-bearded magician from a dusty old storybook who has stepped out of a woodblock illustration into the 21st century.

headline: Idaho Senator Loses Committee Leadership Posts
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 — The political career of Senator Larry Craig of Idaho appeared to be collapsing today as fellow Republicans called for his resignation and party leaders ousted him from his committee leadership posts amid the fallout over his arrest and guilty plea in connection with an incident in an airport restroom.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Basics column in Science Times on Aug. 21, about the properties of lead, misstated the result of adding lead to gasoline. Lead additives were used to raise, not lower, an engine’s combustion point.

headline: Players Are Getting Bigger and Better
text: A new era of tall, big-serving players may be on the horizon at the top level of men’s tennis. Three players who are 6 feet 6 inches or taller entered the United States Open after impressive runs. But yesterday, two lost.

headline: Volatile Markets? Art World Takes Stock
text: The fall art auctions are almost three months away, galleries are still in their summer hiatus, and the Dow keeps fluctuating. But the art world is wondering how volatile financial markets might affect its own specialized market. What will happen at the major art auctions in November? Will collectors pull back on buying sprees until the mortgage lending industry stabilizes? Will sellers decline to consign their art, assuming that the run of record prices in recent years is due for a reversal? Or will they rush to sell now, fearing that by spring prices will be lower?

headline: Turk With Islamic Ties Is Elected President
text: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 28 — An observant Muslim with a background in Islamic politics was voted in on Tuesday as president, breaking an 84-year grip on power by the secular establishment and ushering a new religious middle class from Turkey’s heartland into the center of the staunchly secular state.

headline: In Day of Mass Arrests, Divergent Versions of Events
text: Along the terrace of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue, two teenage girls played guitar and sang. A yoga teacher hunted for a friend from New Orleans. A young woman who had spent the summer traveling around the country struck up a conversation with two men from Quebec. Hundreds of others sat or stood on the steps, holding flags and signs.

headline: In Naples, a Family Affair That’s Oh, So Delicious
text: LA TAVERNETTA in Naples is the kind of place that separates food lovers from dining aficionados. Clearly, food lovers win.

headline: A Scandal-Scarred G.O.P. Asks, ‘What Next?’
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 — Scott Reed, a Republican strategist, was at a dinner in Philadelphia on Monday night when his cellphone and Internet pager began beeping like crazy. Only later did he learn why. His party was buzzing with news of a sex scandal involving a Republican United States senator — again.

headline: Dogs From Vick’s Kennel Have to Pass a Behavior Test
text: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 28  The fates of the dogs seized from a property owned by Michael Vick hinge on the recommendations from certified animal behaviorists.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in the Itineraries pages of Business Day on July 31 about the changing nature of hotel bars misspelled the surname of a businessman who said he found the bars to be a good place to interact with colleagues or clients. He is Larry Cerri, not Cerci.

headline: In Europe, a Push by Phone Companies Into TV
text: BERLIN, Aug. 27 — Several European phone companies plan to announce significant expansions of Internet protocol television, or IPTV, this week, led by Deutsche Telekom, which is spending 3 billion euros and has linked about 4 in 10 German households to broadband TV.

headline: Colonel Is Acquitted in Abu Ghraib Abuse Case
text: A military jury acquitted an Army officer on Tuesday of charges that he failed to properly train and supervise enlisted soldiers involved in detainee interrogations in 2003 at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq, where prisoners were subjected to brutal treatment.

headline: Blake Has the Shots, Including Some for the Camera
text: James Blake wore a shirt the same color of blue as a pilot light, creating the feel that he was flickering as he darted from net to baseline in an illumination of his speed.

headline:
Botox Appointments Faster
Than for Moles, Study Finds
text: Patients seeking an appointment with a dermatologist to ask about a potentially cancerous mole have to wait substantially longer than those seeking Botox for wrinkles, a study published online yesterday by The Journal of the American Academy of Dermatology said.

text: Time: About an hour

headline: Chester Collier, 80, Dies; Led Westminster Show
text: Chester Collier, a broadcasting executive who helped develop “The Mike Douglas Show” and the Fox News Channel, and was a longtime presence in the dog-show world as an official of the Westminster Kennel Club, died Aug. 15 at his home in Wellington, Fla. He was 80.

text: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. headline: Bid Was Blind for a House Full of Needy Cats and Dogs
text: SADDLE RIVER, N.J., Aug. 28 — Soon after Michael Acciardi saw that the house next door to his was up for sale, he sidled over to its owner and asked, as diplomatically as he could, about any flaws.

headline: South Africa: Huge Gem Reported Found
text: An obscure South African mining company claimed to have found a greenish-tinged diamond weighing in at 7,000 carats, more than twice the size of the fabulous Cullinan, the pride of the British crown jewels and for a century the holder of the title world’s biggest diamond, but skeptics said the claim remained unproved. The company, which runs an unnamed mine in North West Province, circulated a photograph of the softball-size gem, which its spokesman, Brent Jolly, said was in a Johannesburg bank vault. But the find has not been certified, and naysayers said large diamonds, much less rare green ones, are rarely found in that part of the country. Government and diamond-industry agencies said they were unaware of the discovery.

headline: After Stumbling, Mattel Cracks Down in China
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif., Aug. 22 — The alarm bell went off for Mattel just as it was preparing to announce that it would recall 1.5 million Chinese-made toys tainted with lead paint.

headline: For Minority Kids, No Room to Breathe
text: Among Americans with asthma, minority children are in by far the worst situation. The numbers are striking: in the United States, 20 percent of Puerto Rican children, or one in five, have asthma. Among African-American youngsters, the rate is 13 percent, compared with the national childhood average of 8 percent. In addition, since 1999 asthma-related mortality rates have dropped for Americans as a whole, but not for minority children.

headline: Former Associate at Goldman Pleads Guilty
text: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of being the mastermind behind a complex insider-trading scheme, one that pocketed $6.7 million, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Between the Mumbles, Images of Sorrowful Poetry
text: Aaron Katz’s film “Quiet City” is punctuated with images of New York at twilight that cast a mood of reflective melancholy reminiscent of the loneliness at the heart of Edward Hopper paintings. Silhouettes of television aerials against a glowing orange and purple sky; yellow traffic lights on a nearly deserted avenue; a silvery subway train in the middle distance slipping through the dusky, blue-gray light; an industrial landscape at sunset: These and other beautiful images, photographed by Andrew Reed, resonate with the characters’ lives.

headline: In Thai Cultural Battle, Name-Calling Is Encouraged
text: BANGKOK, Aug. 23 — America has Tom, Dick and Harry. Thailand has Pig, Money and Fat.

headline: The Big Not So Easy
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Democrats Say They Will Press Gonzales Inquiries
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 — The resignation of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales does not mean an end to several investigations into his actions and truthfulness during his tenure at the Justice Department, with Congressional Democrats promising on Tuesday to press their inquiries.

headline: South Africa: Pretoria Name Blocked
text: Stepping into an increasingly bitter dispute, the Pretoria High Court temporarily barred the city government from posting road signs that identify Pretoria as Tshwane. The metropolitan area of the city, the nation’s capital, has been known as Tshwane for several years, but Pretoria — a name linked to Afrikaner colonizers — has remained the official name of the central governmental district even as a national debate over the issue has boiled on. The court sided with Afrikaner groups, ruling that the Tshwane Metro Council had tried to erect the new signs before their legitimacy could be argued in court. Council officials called the prohibition a mere speed bump in their plans to make Tshwane the region’s name in fact.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Aug. 21 about the conductor Claudio Abbado referred incorrectly to the last time he performed in the United States. It was in Ann Arbor, Mich. — not New York — shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: Brooklyn Navy Yard, a Roomy Haven for Industry, Once Again Is Booming
text: The Brooklyn Navy Yard, one of New York City’s major industrial real estate sites, is undergoing a renaissance.

headline: Sharapova Is Dazzling, Roddick Just Dominant
text: For a few minutes last night at the United States Open, it was possible to forget that the main event would be a tennis match. When Maria Sharapova made her entrance at Arthur Ashe Stadium wearing a sequined red dress and carrying a shiny black handbag, it looked as if she took a wrong turn on the way to a night of clubbing.

headline: Recipe: Broccoli Rabe (Friarielli)
text: Time: 20 minutes

headline: For MySpace Viewers, a Terra Incognita With No Cellphones or Internet
text: The end of the world is a grand subject for online auteurs. Web videos —like the shorts on YouTube — are at once futuristic and crude, full of the same uneasy sense of possibility and reversion to primitivism that science fiction has exploited in apocalyptic classics like “Riddley Walker” and “Blade Runner.”

headline: Hewitt and Hingis, Past Champions, Roll and Reminisce
text: Martina Hingis walked into the new players gym at the United States Open and did a double take when she saw herself on the wall, grinning and winning in 1997.

headline: As a Nation Heads Back to School, a Look at the Numbers
text: That tormenting “school bells ring” jingle for Robert Hall clothing stores is no longer around to remind children that their summer vacation is about to end. But nonetheless, school is beginning or already under way for fully one in four American youngsters and adults enrolled in the nation’s more than 95,000 public elementary and secondary schools, 3,200 charter schools and nearly 4,300 degree-granting colleges, as well as for the 1.1 million who are home-schooled.

headline: Songs That Are Keyed to Slipping, Sliding and Quivering
text: Jazz musicians often title their songs offhandedly, with a kind of disinterested shrug. The pianist Matthew Shipp puts more thought into the process, judging by a few of his recent compositions. “Slips Through the Fingers,” for example. Or “Sliding Through Space,” or “Quivering With Speed.” All three titles appear side by side on Mr. Shipp’s new studio album.

headline: Brooklyn: Charges in Cab Driver Death
text: A man was indicted on manslaughter charges in the death of a livery cab driver who was run down in the street, prosecutors said yesterday. The cab driver, Rafael Rafailov, 50, had stopped to assist another livery cab driver with a disabled vehicle on Ocean Parkway in Kensington last Wednesday when he was struck and killed by a third car. The driver of the third car, Alexey Bushuyev, 22, crashed to a halt nearby. His blood alcohol level tested at .11 percent, above the legal driving limit of .08 percent, prosecutors said. The manslaughter charges in the indictment carry a maximum penalty of 15 years in prison, prosecutors said. A lawyer for Mr. Bushuyev, Susan Kellman, said the charges were excessive. Noting that the disabled car was parked in the center lane, she said: “This seems like an accident. I don’t think you could have avoided it.”

headline: A Sobering Census Report: Bleak Findings on Health Insurance
text: The Census Bureau’s report on the state of American health insurance was as disturbing as its statistics on poverty and income. The bureau reported a large increase in the number of Americans who lack health insurance, data that ought to send an unmistakable message to Washington: vigorous action is needed to reverse this alarming and intractable trend.

headline: What to Ask About Stroke
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they are important.

headline: Katie Couric Will Make First Trip to Iraq
text: The CBS News anchor Katie Couric is to travel to Iraq and Syria to report on the war, the executive producer of the broadcast, Rick Kaplan, said yesterday.

headline: Police at Tennis Center Crack Down on Ticket Scalping
text: As they stepped off the No. 7 train onto the subway platform and took in the view of the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center, Sharon and Junior Levine had no idea they were about to break the law.

headline: A Pressing Need for Urgent Care
text: Dr. Larry B. Goldstein is director of the Duke Center for Cerebrovascular Disease and the Duke Stroke Center.

headline: Hard Lessons for New York
text: After two New York City firefighters died at the former Deutsche Bank tower, news of three internal memos with urgent warnings about the building began to surface. The memos argued for a specific firefighting plan for this building damaged on Sept. 11, 2001. Instead of heeding that advice, however, department officials decided to use the standard protocol for fighting fires in city skyscrapers. It was just one of many errors that may have cost firefighters Joseph Graffagnino and Robert Beddia their lives.

headline: 50 Die in Fight Between Shiite Groups in Karbala
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 28 — A power struggle between rival Shiite groups erupted Tuesday during a religious festival in Karbala, as men with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades fought street battles amid crowds of pilgrims, killing 50 people and wounding 200, Iraqi officials said.

headline: Occupational Hazard
text: Los Angeles

text: Ostrich Hors d’Oeuvres

headline: Boston’s Mr. Reliable May Be Mr. Available
text: When John Henry, the owner of the Boston Red Sox, was introduced at a charity event in Chicago last Saturday, the fans chanted, “Low-ell, Low-ell.” More than 300 Red Sox devotees used their voices to tell Henry that they would like to see Mike Lowell playing third base in 2008.

headline: Taliban Begin Release of Hostages
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, August 29 — Taliban militants released 12 of their remaining 19 Korean hostages in three stages today, Taliban and Afghan officials announced. Seven Koreans remain in Taliban custody.

headline: Lifting the Curtain on Depression
text: Depression is no monochromatic black veil, no shared melancholy, as is often claimed. Instead, the disorder is more like a virus that amplifies each sufferer’s particular vulnerabilities, whether anxiety, helplessness, self-doubt, anger or some combination of these. The subjective experience varies from person to person, yet treatment is far from personalized.

headline: Newark Victims Mourned at a Campus in Delaware
text: DOVER, Del., Aug. 28 — The deaths, more than three weeks ago and nearly three hours from here, echoed yesterday across the 400-acre campus, down the winding paths, past the historic buildings and converging at the student theater that is host to holiday concerts, dance recitals and the coronation of Mr. and Miss Delaware State University.

headline: In a ’64 T-Bird, Chasing a Date With a Clam
text: RECAPTURING a childhood memory is nearly impossible. Chasing after it in a black 1964 Thunderbird convertible with red interior certainly helps.

headline: The Journal Is to Rename Leisure Section for Weekends
text: The Wall Street Journal will rechristen Pursuits, its Saturday leisure section, as Weekend Journal, the same name as the Friday section, according to several people familiar with the paper’s decision.

headline: AT&T Prepares to Consolidate Some Ad Assignments
text: AT&T has placed in review its media planning and buying account as it seeks to consolidate media chores, now handled by five agencies, at one of them.

headline: Week’s Notables
text: PLAYER In Spain, Sevilla midfielder Antonio Puerta died yesterday, three days after he collapsed on the field during a game against Getafe. Doctors said Puerta, 22, died from the effects of prolonged cardiac arrest. Puerta walked off the field with assistance Saturday, but collapsed again in the training room and required resuscitation. Sevilla’s Champions League qualifying match against AEK Athens yesterday was postponed until Monday.

text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: Suspect May Have Shot at Others After Fleeing
text: HOUSTON, Aug. 28 — Federal marshals said Tuesday that they were investigating reports that a man charged in five killings in Texas and suspected in one in Pennsylvania might have shot at other people during his flight to New York.

headline: Furnishing From Afar
text: After buying a three-bedroom house on Baja Peninsula in Mexico near La Paz, Marjory Hawkins assumed that furnishing her vacation home would be a snap. She loaded up a trailer at her residence in Northern California with everything from pieces of living room furniture to dishes, hooked it up to her car and headed south to Mexico.

headline: Kennedy Replaces Mussina in the Rotation
text: The Yankees have made their decision on Mike Mussina: It will be Ian Kennedy on Saturday at Yankee Stadium. Mussina, who was 0-3 with a 17.69 E.R.A. in his last three starts, will continue his throwing program to stay ready if Kennedy falters.

headline: Day 3 at the Open
text: Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal,  Justine Henin and the Williams sisters were among the players in action on the third day of competition.

text: The digital camera's features include high-speed infrared to beam photos to another Fuji camera and an eBay mode.

headline: Have Mac Will Travel, but Not Connect
text: Oh the trials of traveling with my beloved Apple laptop!

headline: Chicago’s Pits for Pork Bellies to Close
text: The CME Group, created recently when Chicago’s big futures exchanges merged, said Tuesday that it was closing trading pits for pork bellies and other products as traders increase their focus on electronic platforms.

headline: One Mortgage Lender, at Least, Is Hiring
text: One mortgage lender announced Tuesday that it was hiring as it tried to take advantage of the turmoil in the market, while another said it was cutting jobs. IndyMac Bancorp said it had hired more than 600 former employees of the American Home Mortgage Investment Corporation and might hire 250 more.

headline: Finance Chief of Google Plans His Retirement at 53
text: Google said Tuesday that George Reyes, the company’s longtime chief financial officer, plans to retire. He will be one of only a few of the Internet search giant’s top executives to have left since its founding in 1998.

headline: Arrest Ordered for Russian Oil Entrepreneur
text: A Russian court issued an arrest warrant Tuesday for Mikhail S. Gutseriev, a former owner of Russneft, a young but larege oil company, on charges of tax evasion and fraud, a month after he published a letter critical of the government on a company Web site and in a Russian business newspaper.

headline: Lerach Quits Firm to Focus on Inquiry
text: William S. Lerach, a leading securities class-action lawyer who has been embroiled in a seven-year federal investigation into possible kickbacks to plaintiffs for their testimony, is retiring from his firm. Rumors that Mr. Lerach would leave had been swirling for months amid speculation that he would resign in exchange for the firm’s not being indicted.

headline: Standard & Poor’s Cuts British Firm’s Debt Rating
text: A London money management firm, Cheyne Capital Management, may be forced to liquidate the assets backing its $10 billion commercial paper program in the latest casualty of the jittery credit market.

headline: NBC Begins Strategic Shift With SparrowHawk Deal
text: NBC Universal announced on Tuesday the acquisition of a group of international cable television channels owned by Sparrowhawk Holdings of London, a deal that Jeff Zucker, the president and chief executive of NBC, said was the first sign of a strategic shift at the company.

headline: Judge Denies Motion to Acquit Former Brocade Boss
text: A federal judge declined to acquit the former chief executive of Brocade Communications, Gregory Reyes, on Monday, saying there was sufficient evidence to convict him in the first criminal trial related to stock-option backdating.

headline: Foreigners Call for Say in U.S. Market Regulation
text: Politicians, regulators and financial specialists outside the United States are seeking a role in the oversight of American markets, banks and rating agencies after recent problems related to subprime mortgages. Their argument is simple: The United States is exporting financial products, but losses to investors in other countries suggest that American regulators are not properly monitoring the products or alerting investors to the risks.

headline: Icahn’s Next Target: Biogen Idec?
text: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor who has battled executives at Motorola, Time Warner, and other iconic corporations, now appears to have Biogen Idec in his crosshairs.

headline: S.E.C. Charges Attorney with Backdating Fraud
text: In the latest aftershock of the options backdating investigations, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday charged the former general counsel of KLA-Tencor and Juniper Networks with civil fraud charges.

headline: Chief of Continental AG Hints at Going Private
text: Manfred Wennemer, chief executive of the German auto parts maker Continental, says he is not concerned about being the world’s biggest auto-parts supplier — even though the purchase last month of Siemens VDO moved his company closer to the leader, Robert Bosch.

headline: Tennis Funnyman Leaves the Open, and Its Fans, in Stitches
text: Journeyman-with-a-sense-of-humor Justin Gimelstob might not have put up much of a fight (after a surprisingly competitive first set) against fifth-seeded Andy Roddick on Tuesday night, but before he left Arthur Ashe Stadium, and professional tennis, he gave the crowd what has got to be one of the funniest moments thus far in the tournament.

headline: Terms Aside, Did Home Depot Give Away the Store?
text: The really important question about the sale of Home Depot‘s construction supply business apparently isn’t the price, which Home Depot lowered 18 percent on Tuesday, to $8.5 billion, after round-the-clock negotiations.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Reports Higher Profits
text: Strong results from domestic operations raised Bank of Nova Scotia‘s third quarter profit by 10 percent from the same period last year as the bank reported Tuesday that it had made 1.03 billion Canadian dollars ($970 million) in the most recent quarter.

headline: Mining Company Bids $1.4 Billion for Canadian Rival
text: Central African Mining & Exploration of London started an offer for Katanga Mining of Canada on Wednesday, which it said valued the company at 1.52 billion Canadian dollars ($1.44 billion).

headline: Magna Stake Sale Approved by Shareholders
text: Frank Stronach’s plan to bring in a Russian partner at Magna International has gone through.

headline: Barclays Shares Fall on Report of Credit Market Exposure
text: Shares in Barclays dropped sharply Tuesday after a report that the bank had been left with hundreds of millions of dollars worth of exposure to the troubled mortgage market in the United States through deals arranged by its investment banking arm.

headline: Advisory Firms Back TXU Buyout
text: The pending sale of TXU got a boost Tuesday as two proxy advisory firms backed the record-setting $45 billion buyout of the electric company and said a scarcity of available credit made a better offer unlikely.

headline: Behind Silicon Valley’s Love of Silly Names
text: Even if you could say Abazab or Eefoof without snickering, would you want to do business with them? Would you feel OK owning Wakoopa shares in your 401(k)? Telling potential in-laws you met on Frengo?

headline: Chrylser Said to Consider Asset Sales
text: Chrysler‘s new private equity owners might seek to divest assets in an effort to raise cash to fund a turnaround for the automaker, according to press reports.

headline: Skype Investors Now Turn to Jaxtr
text: Internet voice startup Jaxtr on Tuesday said it had raised $10 million in funding from a group of venture capitalists hoping to find the success that some had with Skype.

headline: Blackstone May Take Stake in Wind, Report Says
text: The Blackstone Group is in talks to buy a minority stake in Italy’s No. 2 fixed-line phone operator Wind, two years after it lost out in a bid battle for the company, according to Reuters. An Egyptian billionaire Naguib Sawiris bought Wind, the telecom unit of Italy’s Enel, in May 2005 for 12.1 billion euros ($16.45 billion) in one of Europe’s largest leveraged buyouts, topping a rival bid from Blackstone.

headline: Tensar Files for $201 Million I.P.O.
text: Tensar, an infrastructure service provider, filed with regulators on Tuesday to raise up to $201 million in an initial public offering of its common stock, Reuters reported.

headline: Hedge Fund Says No Plans for Stake Sale
text: Renaissance Technologies, the hedge fund group led by the mathematician James Simons, said there was “no truth” to a recent report that it may sell a minority stake.

headline: Are Insiders Hoarding Tech I.P.O. Spoils?
text: Tech-related initial public offerings may be back, enjoying a mild resurgence that has eluded them in recent years. But TheStreet.com warns that the comeback may have come with a price: those offerings are increasingly slanted in favor of insiders.

headline: Morning Buzz: More Deutsche Bank Fallout, Income Inequality, Leona Helmsley’s Will and More
text: The former Deutsche Bank building has been in state hands for three years, but the city has played a critical role alongside the state in evaluating how and by whom the 41-story skyscraper was to be demolished, Charles V. Bagli and William K. Rashbaum report. The John Galt Corporation, the subcontractor hired for the demolition, was made up of executives from one company without the requisite experience and two senior executives from a second company, Safeway Environmental, that was under scrutiny by city investigators. Safeway’s former owner was twice convicted of federal crimes, and has been accused of having ties to organized crime.Investigators have identified smoking as the likely cause of the fire that swept through the building on Aug. 18 and killed two firefighters. Alan Feuer examines the ubiquity of smoking on construction sites, where work rules almost always prohibit lighting up.

headline: On the Ground: Josh Ruxin in Rwanda
No Private Idaho
text: In its second editorial about Sen. Larry Craig, the Idaho Statesman editorial page remains unsatisfied with Craig’s explanation of what exactly happened in that men’s room: “Craig shed little new light Tuesday on his arrest and guilty plea; he did not provide Idahoans with the full account they deserve.”

headline: Leaping to Senator Craig’s Defense
text: As the political impact of Senator Larry Craig’s guilty plea tied to sexual misconduct deepens to what one ex-Republican called “devastating” levels, a legal question is uniting his backers among bloggers of various political stripes. As the conservative Captain’s Quarters puts it, “What Exactly Is The Crime?”

headline: 2008: Endorsements, Fund-Raising and Primaries
text: Many of the Democratic presidential candidates have been working hard to round up support from the country’s major labor unions, which have long been an important source of fund-raising dollars and campaign volunteers. The wooing was on display at the presidential debate in Chicago sponsored by the A.F.L.-C.I.O earlier this month.

headline: Food Stuff
text: When You're Having Only One: The 64-Ounce Beer

headline: Wednesday Morning Kickoff
text: Is there a better way to kick off the Wednesday links than the inaugural edition of The Dash? Each week, Pat Forde presents a hilarious look at the college football world, including the mockery of schedules, media guides and a few BBQ tips if you’re ever in Fayetteville.

headline: Video: Drivers Divided Over New Taxi Technology
text: The city’s Taxi and Limousine Commission is proceeding with one of the most significant changes in taxicab service in years. By January, all of the city’s 13,000 yellow cabs will be required to have a new set of technological features including credit card readers and passenger information monitors, which will allow riders to track their journey and also watch news and advertisements.

headline: Late Bloomer, or Overachiever?
text: Why is it that older women often beat their younger competitors in road races? That's what Gina Kolata sought to find out for her Personal Best column in The Times today, and some of the explanations she presents – including that the older women may just be trying harder – might surprise you.

headline: Basis Fund Files for Bankruptcy Protection
text: Basis Yield Alpha Fund, a hedge fund specializing in corporate and structured credit, filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday amid mounting losses from subprime mortgage assets, Reuters reported citing court papers.

headline: Remembering Hilly Kristal, 75, CBGB Founder
text: Updated, 10 p.m. | Hilly Kristal, who founded the punk-rock club CBGB and ran the legendary Bowery institution for nearly 33 years until it closed its doors last October, died on Tuesday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 75. The cause was complications of lung cancer, his son, Dana, said this morning, according to an obituary by Ben Sisario of The Times.

headline: Be Careful What You Joke About
text: In my most recent Times column, I reviewed macro software that automates common tasks on your Mac or PC. I opened the article with a reference to a 1986 M.I.T. study, which concluded that people are less productive with computers, not more.

headline: Answers From Orville Schell
text: Today we have answers to your questions from Orville Schell, the author of nine books about China – including “Virtual Tibet,” “Mandate of Heaven,” “Discos and Democracy” and “To Get Rich Is Glorious.” Earlier this month, Mr. Schell traveled to China and met with Chinese experts and officials to discuss global warming.

headline: Altria Tries Expansion Through Division
text: For the Altria Group, breaking up may be a prelude to bulking up.

headline: Answers From Zhang Jingjing
text: Today we are joined by Zhang Jingjing, who has answered questions from Beijing. Ms. Zhang, the director of litigation at the Center for Legal Assistance to Pollution Victims, was first called the “Erin Brockovich of China” after she won compensation for over 1,700 villagers in a class-action lawsuit against a heavily-polluting chemical plant.

headline: Hello, Goodbye on Day 3
text: It’s a beautiful day in Queens, the lines to enter the United States Open grounds are moving faster and today’s spectator freebie is a bar of soap. Lest one thinks the Open fans are cleaning up their act, the bar was already nicely crowded before the matches started at 11 a.m.
