text: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China said on Wednesday it would acquire Macau’s third largest lender, Seng Heng Bank. ICBC, China’s largest bank, will pay 4.55 billion Hong Kong dollars ($590 million) for a 79.93 percent stake in the Macau bank, which is majority-owned by Stanley Ho.

headline: Citigroup Leads $400 Million Deal for Cupmaker
text: Citigroup‘s venture capital arm led a $400 million deal for a controlling stake in Waddington North America, a maker of disposable cups, dinnerware and cutlery, according to Reuters.

headline: New Electric Car Start-Up Revs Its Engine
text: Another day, another electric car company.

headline: Carlyle Capital Sees Smoother Sailing Ahead
text: Carlyle Capital, a unit of the private equity firm the Carlyle Group, said on Wednesday it hopes the worst of the credit crunch has passed, allowing it to resume paying a dividend.

headline: Tenet Denies Possibility of Bankruptcy
text: Tenet Healthcare said Wednesday it has sufficient financial resources to stage a turnaround, rebutting an analyst’s report that sent its shares to a record low on Tuesday.

headline: New Study Criticizes Hedge Fund Salaries
text: After a month of disappointing returns and the high-profile collapse of several hedge funds, a new report has come out just in time to further raise the ire of those who feel that the rich fees collected by fund managers are undeserved.

headline: EndoGastric Solutions Takes $30 Million
text: A medical device maker, EndoGastric Solutions, has raised $30 million in venture capital, money that the company plans to use for sales and for marketing its StomaphyX device. The product was approved for sale in the United States in March.

headline: RBS Bankers Out Amid Debt Market Turmoil
text: The collapse of the subprime mortgage market has claimed the scalp of a senior Royal Bank of Scotland executive in the United States and six of his colleagues.

headline: Carrefour to Spin Off European Real Estate Arm
text: French supermarket giant Carrefour on Thursday responded to its fiercest critics — including some of its own shareholders — by announcing a plan to spin off its European real estate into a separately listed company.

headline: Rivals May Try Burberry On for Size, Analyst Says
text: Is the Burberry Group an acquisition target? A Merill Lynch analyst thinks so and has identified luxury goods makers PPR and Coach as possible buyers.

headline: Yahoo’s New President Oversees a Shake-Up
text: Susan L. Decker, Yahoo‘s new president, is putting her stamp on the company in a reorganization of its management ranks that creates a new division responsible for generating the bulk of the company’s revenue.

headline: Lehman Cuts Estimates on Rivals
text: Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch and Bear Stearns, four of the five largest securities firms, will earn less than expected through next year after a rout in subprime mortgages, according to a Lehman Brothers analyst.

headline: Goldman Said to Lose London Dealmaker
text: A top Goldman Sachs dealmaker in London who has worked on some of the investment bank’s most high-profile telecoms and media deals is leaving the the firm, The Telegraph reported. Alain Carrier, a Canadian, is leaving for a job in the Canadian government, according to the newspaper.

headline: Investors Buy $1 Billion Stake in Global Hyatt
text: Global Hyatt, the hotel company controlled by the Pritzker family of Chicago, said Wednesday that it would sell a minority stake to a group of investors, including Goldman Sachs Capital Partners, for $1 billion.

headline: Lehman, Goldman Are Said to Raise Funds for L.B.O. Debt
text: In an attempt to capitalize on a credit crunch that has depressed prices for leveraged loans in the secondary markets, Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers are actively raising funds to buy leveraged loans that trade at discounts in the secondary market, The Deal.com reports.

headline: American Home Mortgage to Auction Loans
text: The bankrupt home loan provider American Home Mortgage Investment, said on Wednesday a federal bankruptcy judge has authorized the auction by two affiliates of 5,700 mortgage loans with an unpaid principal balance of about $1.62 billion.

headline: Buyout Tax Debate Hits the Hamptons
text: It may be the late-summer doldrums, but the debate over taxes and private equity is hardly on vacation. It has just gone to the Hamptons — like much of the rest of Wall Street.

headline: H&R Block to Renegotiate Unit Sale to Cerberus
text: H&R Block, the tax preparation company, said on Thursday it is renegotiating the sale of its money-losing Option One Mortgage subprime lending unit to Cerberus Capital Management, casting doubt on it ability to complete the transaction.

headline: MovieBeam: An Encore Presentation
text: David Pogue reviews the MovieBeam, a box that connects directly to your TV set and holds 100 movies on its hard drive.

headline: Morning Buzz: More Deutsche Bank Questions, Leona Helmsley’s Dog, Moving 800,000 Cigars and More
text: In late 2005, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation had approved a tentative arrangement with three large contractors to do the complex work of dismantling the former Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan. But just as a draft contract was being completed, the deal fell apart — days after the president of one of the companies, North American Site Developers Inc. of Waltham, Mass., received an anonymous telephone call telling him to stay out of New York.William K. Rashbaum and Charles V. Bagli report that the F.B.I. investigated the threat, sending two agents to interview the company’s president, Chris Berardi. The collapse of the deal cleared the way for the hiring of the John Galt Corporation, the troubled subcontractor that is a focus of the criminal inquiry into the Aug. 18 fire at the building that left two firefighters dead.

headline: A More Pessimistic Report on Iraq
text: Add another assessment of the Iraq surge to the pile. A draft of a progress report requested by Congress from the Government Accountability Office is “strikingly negative” and questions a more optimistic report by the administration in July, according to The Washington Post, which obtained a copy.

headline: 2008: Return to Sender
text: After new details emerged about the criminal record of one of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s top donors — who has also given generously to many other Democrats over the years –– her campaign announced that it would give the $23,000 contribution from New York businessman Norman Hsu to charity. The question remains whether other donations that he bundled will be returned.

headline: Thursday Morning Kickoff
text: It’s game day! Warning: watching this video from our friends over at Sunday Morning Quarterback may make you want to get up and tackle the person in the cubicle next to you. We don’t condone that, no matter how satisfying it might be.

headline: Craig’s Next Move
text: In its third consecutive daily editorial about Senator Larry Craig, the Idaho Statesman editorial page asks Craig to resign.

headline: Man Shoots Three Former Co-Workers in the Bronx; 1 Is Killed
text: Updated, 12:16 p.m. | Police swarmed the Co-op City housing complex in the Bronx this morning after a vengeful former worker shot three former colleagues in succession, one fatally, starting at 7:50 a.m. An article on NYTimes.com has complete details and will be updated through the day.

headline: Exploring Governors Island
text: A free ferry trip takes passengers from the canyons of Lower Manhattan to the splendid sanctuary of Governors Island.

headline: Quattrone: ‘The Opera Is Over’
text: A federal judge formally approved a request by prosecutors to dismiss all remaining charges against Frank P. Quattrone, the former Credit Suisse banker.

headline: The Next Generation of Online Shorthand
text: By now, everybody, I hope, knows what LOL stands for. Most people probably recognize IMHO, BRB, and AFK. (If you don't know these, you can always Google* them.)

headline: Advice to Freshmen: Don’t Do It
text: This is the time of year when the streets of Morningside Heights, Greenwich Village and a few other neighborhoods are filled with new, unfamiliar faces: college freshmen. Various guides on paper and on the Internet tell these students what they should see and do in their new hometown.

headline: 2008 Honda Accord Is a Game-Changer
text: Last week we promised some first impressions of the 2008 Honda Accord. That task falls to me, since I just wrapped up four days with a jet-black V-6 sedan. Stop me before I gush.

headline: Do You Recall?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Dealbook: Buyout Tax Debate Hits the Hamptons
text: It may be the late-summer doldrums, but the debate over taxes and private equity is hardly on vacation. It has just gone to the Hamptons — like much of the rest of Wall Street.

headline: Day 4: Young Advances and Kuerten Returns
text: Richard Gasquet, the 13th-seeded Frenchman, withdrew from his match against the American Donald Young today because of an illness. Young, the junior champion who is having his breakout summer on the Tour, advances to the third round against Feliciano Lopez, the 60th-ranked Spaniard, who needed a fifth-set tiebreaker to defeat Igor Andreev.

headline: Thompson Hires Another Aide
text: Even though Fred Thompson, the actor and former senator, has yet to declare himself a candidate, he has already hired and fired two communications directors and now is bringing on a third. This time his choice is a veteran campaign media manager who has previously worked for California Gov. Arnold Schwarznegger and former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush.

headline: Baseball’s Stretch Run
text: This year’s chase for the eight playoff spots in baseball is the tightest in recent memory. The wild-card system, first used in 1995, has made September baseball exciting for more cities, but does the current system provide adequate compensation for the team that finishes with the best record in each league?

headline: The Next Generation of Online Shorthand
text: By now, everybody, I hope, knows what LOL stands for. Most people probably recognize IMHO, BRB, and AFK. (If you don’t know these, you can always Google* them.)

headline: Answers From the Co-op Board Expert, Part 2
text: Following is the second set of responses from Arthur Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer and vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, who is taking questions from City Room readers this week. A first set of answers was posted on Wednesday. (Update: Read part 3, part 4, and the final set, part 5; Mr. Weinstein is no longer taking questions.)

headline: QuickBits: Farecast, Sony, SanDisk
text: Really quick bits:

headline: Backpacking in Jordan, With Stops in and Around Amman
text: Do you have suggestions for someone who wants to do a little adventuring (by backpack) in Jordan this fall? I’ll be joining my parents for a tour of Madaba and Petra and figured I’d do a few days on my own, perhaps a day or two in Amman and a visit to the Dead Sea.

headline: McCain Introduces ‘No Retreat’ Bio-Video
text: Usually, the political bio-video falls into a few hoary subsets. There’s the up-from-humble-beginnings one, a tried-and-true route. The showed-courage-with-a-tough-political-stance genre. The devoted-family-man-you-can-trust-with-your-vote one.

headline: "Back to You"
text: Promotional spot for a new Fox sitcom, "Back to You."

headline: "Chuck Darling Is Back"
text: Promotional spot for a new Fox sitcom, "Back to You."

headline: Poll: Opposition to Congestion Pricing Is Growing
text: Bad news for Mayor Bloomberg. Opposition to congestion pricing, far from ebbing, may actually be on the rise, according to a new poll released this morning by Quinnipiac University.

headline: The Opening Bell
text: With major college football kicking off tonight, the stock watch for the 2008 N.F.L. Draft also begins.

headline: Univisión Postpones G.O.P. Debate
text: Univisión, the Spanish-language television network, is postponing its G.O.P. debate. Only Senator John McCain (coincidentally, the only Republican candidate who favored the comprehensive immigration legislation that failed this year) was able to commit to the original date, Sept. 16.

headline: Clinton Defends Campaign Donations
text: Commenting for the first time publicly about a disgraced donor, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton sent her best wishes to Norman Hsu, the wealthy Democratic fundraiser who turned out to be a fugitive. Just yesterday, her presidential campaign was forced to give away to charity $23,000 of his tainted donations.

headline: Ex-Astronaut Freed of Ankle Monitor
text: Capt. Lisa Nowak’s complaints about an ankle monitor, a condition of her release from jail for confronting a fellow officer and romantic rival for another astronaut, were legion.

headline: The Interpretation of Rule 6.05(m)
text: By now, I’m sure you’ve seen about a dozen replays, from all angles, of that nutty game-ending play last night.

headline: Chakvetadze Flies Under the Radar
text: While other more glamorous blond players live on the show courts, sixth-seeded Anna Chakvetadze of Russia was toiling on Court 13 against Nicole Pratt, the 68th-ranked Australian.

headline: Position Battles and Preseason All-Stars
text: Last year, a young quarterback named Tony Romo outplayed the Cowboys’ incumbent starter, Drew Bledsoe, in the preseason. Although Bledsoe retained his position to start the season, memories of Romo’s strong play lingered, and by Week 8 he was starting.

headline: After Microsoft, Hunting the Next Big Thing
text: Would-be inventors, take note: Nathan Myhrvold, a former chief technology officer at Microsoft, is behind a fund that has raised $355 million in what seems to be an effort to back new technologies in their infancy. Mr. Myhrvold knows a thing or two about getting in early: He was part of Microsoft’s original brain trust and once led its research arm.

headline: God Is Dog Spelled Backwards
text: Ever since Michael Vick professed to have found religion this week, alert commentators are evincing a wise, knowing air in pointing out something most whelps learn the minute they start reading — that “dog” is “God” spelled backwards:

text: A. O. Scott reviews "Balls of Fury," starring Christopher Walken.

text: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

headline: Answers From Lu Zhi
text: This afternoon, on the final day of this week’s forum, we have answers to your questions from Lu Zhi, a well-known scientist and environmentalist in China who heads the national office of Conservation International. Ms. Lu is a professor of conservation biology at Peking University in Beijing who is one of China’s most prominent experts on biodiversity.

headline: Ominous Bets, or Just a ‘Box’?
text: August has been a big month for dire market rumors, and here is the latest one: Blogs are abuzz about a spike in unusual options trades that appear, at least on the surface, to indicate that someone is betting on a huge market plunge next month.

headline: Engineers Fight Patent Reform, Not Patent Trolls
text: Is patent reform dead?

headline: Iraqi Chemical Agent Is Found at U.N.; No Public Danger, Authorities Say
text: Updated, 6:03 p.m. | Hazardous-materials specialists from the F.B.I. and the New York City Police Department went in to a United Nations building today to remove a chemical agent that had been recovered from an Iraqi munitions factory in 1996 and accidentally shipped to the United Nations, instead of the Army laboratory in Maryland where it was supposed to end up, officials announced today.The authorities said there was no threat to the public. The toxic substance, known as phosgene, remained for more than a decade in the East Side offices of the United Nations agency that was responsible for overseeing the removal of weapons of mass destruction from Iraq.

headline: Nadal Practices for His Night Match
text: Second-seeded Rafael Nadal practiced for slightly over an hour.

headline: Dramamine Not Included
text: The Orphalese

headline: U-17 World Cup: It’s Over for the U.S.
text: The hot and cold United States team at the FIFA U-17 World Cup went ice cold yesterday in Cheonan, South Korea, losing to Germany, 2-1, in the second round.

headline: Lazard Hires Lobbyist to Keep Tabs on Blackstone Bill
text: Proposed legislation in Congress to raise taxes on private equity has prompted yet another company to hire a lobbyist to look out for its interests on Capitol Hill. But it’s not a buyout firm — and for now it appears to be simply hedging its bets.

headline: Risk vs. Reward
text: An article by Pete Thamel in The New York Times today examines the lack of blockbuster non-conference games in college football this season. Saturday’s matchup between No. 15 Tennessee and No. 12 California in Berkeley is a notable exception.

headline: Novak: I Knew It Was You, Fredo
text: Now he tells us! Seven years after his first meeting with Alberto Gonzales, Robert Novak relays the news that “several Republican senators” believed in 2001 “that Gonzales was not qualified for a senior government position.” Novak writes in his Washington Post column:

headline: Seung-Hui Cho: Who Is This Man?
text: If Seung-Hui Cho’s heart of darkness would ever be pried open, Diane Strickland would seem a likely candidate.

text: Aired Wednesday night

headline: Senate Is Still Turning Up Heat on Governor
text: Republicans in the State Senate are showing no signs of letting up the pressure on the Spitzer administration.

headline: More Unions Announce Endorsements
text: Up until now, the country’s major labor unions have been dragging their feet on picking a candidate to support in the 2008 presidential primaries, but that’s beginning to change.

headline: Idaho Guv: The Bell Has Rung on Craig
text: The calls for Senator Larry Craig, Republican of Idaho and subject of a scandal involving a “lewd-conduct” arrest in a public men’s restroom, to resign are mounting. In fact, the chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, Senator John Ensign of Nevada, has now been quoted as suggesting that Mr. Craig’s decision to plead guilty to a less serious charge of disorderly conduct from the situation at the Minneapolis-St. Paul airport in June would be enough for Mr. Ensign to consider doing so.

headline: Progress Photos
text: John’s assistant, Pam Buttoclova, just e-mailed us photos to show us construction progress. I got so excited that I printed one out and carried it around my office, showing it to everyone and (I suspect) boring them thoroughly.

headline: Thompson Finally Sets a Date
text: Save the day: One week from today, Fred D. Thompson will really, seriously, once-and-for-all enter the 2008 presidential race.

headline: Spitzer and Cuomo Have Their Say, Separately
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo spoke — separately — at a luncheon held by the New York City Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association in Albany today. Both took questions afterward about the recent reinstatement of Darren Dopp, the governor’s former communications director, to the state payroll this week.Mr. Spitzer took square aim at suggestions floated by Senate Republicans this week that the reinstatement of Mr. Dopp was an effort to buy his silence. Mr. Dopp had been suspended for more than a month without pay after Mr. Cuomo’s investigation suggested that Mr. Dopp misused the State Police.

text: What we’re reading on other blogs…

headline: Roddick Wins, and How ‘Bout Them Yanks?
text: Andy Roddick, the fifth-seeded American, celebrated his 25th birthday today by advancing to the third round when Jose Acasuso retired from their match with the score at 4-6, 6-2, 6-1.

headline: Subway Riders Give a C-Minus to the No. 7 Line
text: A C-minus for service but an A for effort?

headline: ‘Right now, I’m Dating the Detroit Red Wings’
text: Aired Wednesday night

headline: An East Harlem Funeral Is Held on the Sidewalk to Protest a Church Closing
text: Carmen Gonzalez, of East Harlem, died at 72 on Monday. She had regularly attended Mass at Our Lady Queen of Angels, a Roman Catholic parish at 229 East 113th Street in East Harlem, for decades. When the church closed in February as part of a round of parish closings ordered by the Archdiocese of New York, Mrs. Gonzalez was devastated. She joined a small but fervent group of protesters who have urged the archdiocese to reconsider.So Mrs. Gonzalez’s family decided that the most fitting way to honor her memory was to hold a funeral ceremony outside the church, in lieu of the funeral Mass that would have been observed inside the parish had it stayed open. The ceremony was held outside the church at 9:30 a.m. today.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'The Nines'
text: Stephen Holden reviews "The Nines," starring Ryan Reynolds.

headline: Iranian Singer Mohsen Namjoo
text: A singer with a songbook of sly protest.

headline: Crowning the Corporate Governance Elite
text: Move over People’s “Most Beautiful” and Forbes “400 Richest People” – the world of magazine lists has grown by one.

headline: New I.A.E.A. Report on Iran
text: A new I.A.E.A. report raises questions about Iran's nuclear capabilities.

headline: Iowa + Gay Marriage = Candidate Statement
text: That didn’t take long. Mitt Romney just sent out a statement about an Iowa court’s decision striking down the state law banning gay marriage: “The ruling in Iowa today is another example of an activist court and unelected judges trying to redefine marriage and disregard the will of the people as expressed through Iowa’s Defense of Marriage Act. This once again highlights the need for a Federal Marriage Amendment to protect the traditional definition of marriage as between one man and one woman.”

headline: Managing Air Traffic Control
text: A unique solution to air traffic control headaches comes from an airline  that carries no complaining passengers: U.P.S.

headline: Michigan’s Primary: Now Even Earlier
text: The Michigan legislature voted today to move up the state’s presidential nominating contest to Jan. 15, 2008, making it the latest state to join the increasingly contentious tug-of-war between local and national officials in both parties over the primary election calendar.

headline: The Craig Tape
text: We can’t say, let’s go to the tape and ask you to watch video. But we can suggest that you may want to listen to the tape-recording, just post the restroom arrest, of Senator Larry Craig, Republican of Idaho, that has now been broadcast (repeatedly) in the last few hours on several cable television and news networks. That way you can hear him in his own voice in the immediate moments following his arrest.

headline: Hungarian Hopes to Start New Era
text: Top-ranked tennis players tend to come from countries in bunches: the Spanish men, the Russian women, the Serbs.

headline: Kennedy In ’07
text: When Ian Kennedy had a day off last season as a Staten Island Yankee, he visited Times Square, not Yankee Stadium. He had never been to the Stadium until Thursday, when he took the field in an empty ballpark after the Yankees wrapped up their sweep of the Red Sox.

headline: Wikipedia Editing Proves a Royal Embarrassment
text: The temptation to spin can be impossible to resist – even for royalty. This seems the lesson to be gleaned from the new WikiScanner, which revealed earlier this week that a Wikipedia article about a 2003 scandal in Holland was scrubbed clean by the subjects of the entry themselves, the Dutch royal family.

headline: Here We Go Again, James
text: James, James, James, James. Oh, man. You’re James Blake, with your own cheering section. You’re seeded. You’ve got a lethal forehand and a cool one-handed backhand. You’re handsome, (even with the shaved head), possess a heartfelt storyline and boast some brains (just getting into Harvard is good enough for us). You seem like a nice guy. You could have strangled Lleyton Hewitt all those years ago, and instead handled his obviously racist and inaccurate comment with class. But you lost that match in five. And eight others.

headline: Iraq's Search for Reconciliation
text: Shatha al-Musawi, a Shiite lawmaker, is struggling to move past her difficult history in order to help Iraq move forward.

headline: N.B.A. Backs Referees as Inquiry Continues
text: LAS VEGAS, Aug. 30 -- A federal investigation is ongoing, and an internal review has begun, but NBA Commissioner David Stern is not waiting for the results to defend the integrity of his league’s referees.

headline: Summer’s Almost Over
text: "EVERYTHING must go!” shouted the clerk manning a T-shirt rack outside Hoy’s Five & Ten, a purveyor of the kinds of trinkets and knickknacks that you would only entertain buying while on vacation.

headline: Scissors Author Settles Suit
text: A $2 million lawsuit against the author Augusten Burroughs, by the family that sued him for defamation for his best-selling book “Running With Scissors,” has been settled, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Financial terms were not disclosed, but Mr. Burroughs and the publisher, St. Martin’s Press, agreed to call the volume a “book” instead of “memoirs” in the author’s note, although the word memoir will still appear on the cover and elsewhere, and to change the acknowledgments in future editions to say that the Turcotte family’s memories of events he describes are “different from my own.” In addition future editions will express regret for “any unintentional harm” to them. But in a statement released yesterday by St. Martin’s, Mr. Burroughs declared his work “an entirely accurate memoir.” Howard Cooper, a lawyer for the family, said financial terms of the settlement were confidential. Mr. Burroughs lived with the Turcottes as a teenager, and though the book calls them “the Finches,” the lawsuit maintains that they are easily identified.

headline: Desperation Is Gone, and So Is the Drama
text: Exactly which playoff race are the Yankees in? Maybe the question should be how many they are in.

headline: The Last Stages of Summer
text: BERKSHIRE THEATER FESTIVAL The last three performances of “Mrs. Warren’s Profession” on the Main Stage are tonight at 8 and tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m. “Educating Rita,” after a hiatus, will run through Oct. 20 in the Unicorn Theater, with performances tonight and tomorrow night at 8. Tickets range from $38 to $62. Main Street, Stockbridge, Mass.; (413) 298-5576, berkshiretheatre.org.

headline: Corrections
text: An article published on NYTimes.com on Aug. 21 about Senator Barack Obama’s appearance before a Veterans of Foreign Wars convention paraphrased incorrectly from his comment about protests at military funerals. He said: “When men and women who died in service to this country are laid to rest, there must be no protests near the funerals. It’s wrong and it needs to stop.” He did not say that it was wrong for “anti-war activists” to protest at military funerals. (Go to Article)

headline: At I.B.M., a Vacation Anytime, or Maybe None
text: SOMERS, N.Y. — It’s every worker’s dream: take as much vacation time as you want, on short notice, and don’t worry about your boss calling you on it. Cut out early, make it a long weekend, string two weeks together — as you like. No need to call in sick on a Friday so you can disappear for a fishing trip. Just go; nobody’s keeping track.

headline: Gunslingers in Macau: A Far-Eastern Western
text: Johnnie To is a bloodthirsty showman, but he loves people.
