headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Christian-Muslim Mix in Art

headline: Lafayette’s 250th: Iraq Aside, We’re Still Grateful to France
text: Relations between the United States and France seem to have climbed out of the musty sub-basement where they had lingered since the start of the Iraq war.

headline: A City Defines Beautiful, but a Truck Owner and a Court Object
text: CORAL GABLES, Fla., Aug. 30 — Newcomers to this resolutely lush and lovely city would do well to peruse its “Citizen’s Guide to Code Enforcement” before settling in. They will find that pet snakes are forbidden, houses must be painted a city-approved hue and residents cannot so much as screen in their pools without permits.

headline: Disowning Senator Craig
text: The Republican Party is in quite a rush to keelhaul Senator Larry Craig for his run-in with the vice squad in an airport men’s room. Disclosure of the senator’s guilty plea to disorderly conduct set off a frenzy to demand an investigation by the Senate’s somnolent Ethics Committee and to strip Mr. Craig of his committee seniority. Some of the senator’s peers simply demanded that he resign.

headline: Edward Seidensticker, Translator, Is Dead at 86
text: Edward G. Seidensticker, an eminent translator from the Japanese who brought the work of ancient and modern writers to a wide English-speaking public, died on Sunday in Tokyo. He was 86 and made his home in Tokyo.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about plans by the Republican Party to penalize states for moving up the dates of their primaries misstated the precedent for national political conventions that opened without a clear-cut nominee. It last occurred in 1976, not 50 years ago. (President Gerald R. Ford and Ronald Reagan arrived at the Republican convention that year without the number of votes needed for the nomination. Mr. Ford swayed enough delegates to win narrowly on the first ballot.)

headline: Mother Teresa’s Struggle With Faith and Doubt (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fire Department Defends Transfers of Three Officers
text: Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said yesterday that the fire officers reassigned on Monday for failing to inspect the former Deutsche Bank building were not scapegoats, as union leaders and a brother of one of the officers have charged. The commissioner said that if the investigation into the fatal fire at the building exposed lapses among department chiefs at headquarters, he would support disciplinary action against them.

headline: After Months of Flirting, Thompson Is Almost In
text: The campaign of Fred D. Thompson, who has been running for president for months, formally announced yesterday that he would formally announce his bid for the Republican nomination for president next Thursday.

headline: NBC Will Not Renew ITunes Contract
text: NBC Universal, unable to come to an agreement with Apple on pricing, has decided not to renew its contract to sell digital downloads of television shows on iTunes.

headline: Bogs Afloat With Berries
text: THE cranberry is a unique fruit. For starters, it’s one of the few commercially grown fruits that are native to American soil. And then there’s the way cranberries grow, in a beautifully tangled mass called a bog. Most fascinating, though, is the way they are harvested — by flooding the bogs with up to a foot of water so that the berries, which float, are easy to gather when knocked off their vines.

headline: The Villages of Loreto Bay and Montaluce Winery and Estates
text: The Villages of Loreto Bay

headline: China: Antimonopoly Law Approved
text: After 13 years of reviewing drafts, the National People’s Congress approved a law that bans price-fixing, collusion, excessive market concentration and other monopolistic practices by private and state-owned businesses alike. The law marks another step toward a market economy and away from a centrally planned economy in which a series of giant state-owned enterprises held vast and unchallenged monopolies. The law’s most controversial provision, added this summer, calls for the government to conduct more formal reviews of foreign purchases of Chinese companies based on their potential to harm national security, including economic security. The law will take effect on Aug. 1, 2008.

headline: Borrowing the Tricks of TV News to Set a Show Apart
text: FIRST, television presented real news. Then came fake news on parody programs like “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart.” This weekend, Fox Broadcasting will send fake news vans onto the streets of four cities to promote a real show.

headline: Water Parks Gone Wild in Vermont
text: ON top of Danby Slide, a slick, 60-foot-long chute of the Mill River in Danby, Vt., Samantha Gill eased down to sit in a rush of water. Her hands were splayed back. Elbows locked. A roar of current tugged at her toes.

headline: In a Marathon Match, Blake Prevails
text: James Blake's match against Fabrice Santoro Wednesday night at the United States Open looked like a clash of eras, a match between two players with little more in common than the ball they slugged between them for three-and-a-half hours.

headline: Family Challenges Verizon Wireless Deal to Sell Bob Marley Ring Tones
text: It looked like a public relations coup when, on Tuesday, Verizon Wireless announced that it had signed an exclusive deal with the Universal Music Group to sell its customers ring tones from the catalog of Bob Marley, the famed reggae singer who died in 1981.

headline: Mysterious Reflections of Hollywood Paranoia
text: In the three loosely related stories that make up “The Nines,” a philosophical mind teaser with satirical fangs that marks the directing debut of the screenwriter John August, the stressed-out psyches of jockeying Hollywood muckety-mucks are disturbed by strange metaphysical intimations. Think of it as a kind of “Twilight Zone 2007” in which the paranoia endemic to an industry that runs on illusion, hype and extravagant grandiosity comes home to roost.

headline: Washington: Call for Answers on Missing E-Mail
text: Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, has renewed his demand that the Bush administration explain how millions of White House e-mail messages may have been lost, disclosing for the first time that there was a daily audit of the message system. Mr. Waxman, chairman of the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, said White House officials had failed to provide answers for three months, including naming the contractor that had audited the e-mail system. Mr. Waxman demanded in a letter that the White House respond by Sept. 10 and provide an internal report that analyzed the scope of the missing messages. Scott M. Stanzel, a White House spokesman, said officials would “respond expeditiously.”

headline: Dell’s Earnings Rise, but Delays Hinder Recovery
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 — Make no mistake, Dell is in the black. But production delays, particularly problems in getting the vivid paint colors of its new line of notebook computers right, are preventing the struggling company from growing as quickly as investors have hoped.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,726 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: P. B. MacCready, 81, Inventor, Dies
text: Paul B. MacCready, an awesomely accomplished inventor who studied circling hawks and vultures to figure out how to realize the loftiest dream of Leonardo da Vinci — inventing a human-powered flying machine — died Tuesday in Pasadena, Calif. He was 81.

headline: Why a U.S. Subprime Mortgage Crisis Is Felt Around the World
text: The evening entertainment for roughly 500 financial executives at the Deutsche Bank global derivatives conference last month in Barcelona did not come cheap — the Rolling Stones reportedly were paid more than $5 million.

headline: Decades After War Trials, Japan Still Honors a Dissenting Judge
text: TOKYO, Aug. 30 — An Indian judge, remembered by fewer and fewer of his own countrymen 40 years after his death, is still big in Japan.

headline: For Floating Concert Hall, a Gently Rocking Trio
text: Composers of program music use aural brush strokes to convey a scene or mood. Alexandra du Bois’s yearning “Soleil sur Mer” (“Sun on Sea”), inspired by the barcarolle, had a literal accompaniment from the waves gently rocking the floating concert hall, Bargemusic, in its world premiere on Wednesday night.

headline: Art in Review
text: INTRODUCTIONS

headline: France: Sarkozy Favors a Utility Merger
text: President Nicolas Sarkozy said he favored a merger of Gaz de France and the energy operations of Suez, implying Suez would have to shed its waste and water units to complete the long-pending deal. “I’ve proposed that Suez merge its energy business with Gaz de France to create a large gas and electricity group,” Mr. Sarkozy, left, said in a speech to a Paris business group. “This requires that Suez make a strategic choice to specialize in energy.” Suez’s chief executive, Gerard Mestrallet, has resisted considering a sale of the waste and water units, which account for about a third of operations. He declined to say whether he would be willing to hive them off for the deal to go through. The original plan to combine Suez and Gaz de France is now valued at about 56 billion euros ($76 billion). It has been mired in political and valuation concerns since it was first put forward in February 2006 to ward off a possible bid for Suez from Enel of Italy and to create Europe’s second-biggest utility.

headline: A Bruising Runner Is Changing His Style for His Own Good
text: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 30 (AP) — P. J. Hill, version 2.0, is a little leaner — but not necessarily meaner.

headline: Rights Group Accuses Hezbollah of Indiscriminate Attacks on Civilians in Israel War
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates Aug. 30  A report by Human Rights Watch accusing Hezbollah of indiscriminately attacking civilians during its war with Israel last summer has set off a furor in Lebanon.

headline: U.S. Cites ‘Secrets’ Privilege as It Tries to Stop Suit on Banking Records
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 — The Bush administration is signaling that it plans to turn again to a legal tool, the “state secrets” privilege, to try to stop a suit against a Belgian banking cooperative that secretly supplied millions of private financial records to the United States government, court documents show.

headline: Bush Offers Relief for Some on Home Loans
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 — President Bush, in his first response to families hit by the subprime mortgage crisis, announced several steps today to help Americans who have credit problems meet the rising cost of their housing loans.

headline: Report Showing Rise in Iran’s Nuclear Activity Exposes Split Between U.S. and U.N.
text: VIENNA, Aug. 30 — A report released Thursday showing a slow but steady expansion of Iran’s nuclear technology has exposed a new divide between United Nations arms inspectors and the United States and its allies over how to contain Tehran’s atomic program.

headline: Caribbean Visions of Tropical Paradise and Protest
text: In its apparent continuing effort to be as un-Manhattan as possible, the Brooklyn Museum has been cooking up shows that the fashion-obsessed art establishment is guaranteed to find uncool. Hip-hop, “Star Wars,” feminism. What could be next? “Infinite Island: Contemporary Caribbean Art” is next.

headline: Democrats Turn From Big Donor Who’s Fugitive
text: From $62,000 for Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York, to $10,000 for the Tennessee Democratic Party, the full extent of fund-raising by Norman Hsu came into focus yesterday, as campaigns across the country began returning his money in light of revelations that he is a fugitive in a fraud case.

headline: Pop
text: POP

headline: Apple Bars New NBC Shows From iTunes
text: The dispute between Apple and NBC Universal over the pricing of video on iTunes grew more heated today as Apple announced it would not add any new NBC television shows to the online store’s inventory.

headline: In New Brunswick, Where Surf Becomes Turf
text: AS hordes of New Yorkers and New Englanders clog I-95 on their way to Maine’s vacationland attractions each summer, a few wise souls stop only long enough to tighten the ropes holding the kayak on the roof, then keep moving north.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: A Lower Peninsula Spot Draws a Wider Crowd
text: EVERY year, it seems, the vacationers and second-home owners arrive earlier in Leland, Mich., attracted by the spirit-altering sunsets over the shipwreck-salted Manitou Islands and a modest life of sand, trees and deep blue water.

headline: Bronx: Man Kills Companion and Himself
text: A 32-year-old Bronx man fatally shot his 27-year-old longtime companion and then killed himself yesterday as the couple’s 9-month-old baby was nearby, the police said. The bodies of the couple, Arlington Marshall and Tricia Spooner, both shot in the head in what investigators called a murder-suicide, were discovered around 8:30 p.m. in Mr. Marshall’s basement apartment at 730 East 227th Street in Williamsbridge. A .38-caliber gun was recovered at the scene.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The byline for a front-page article yesterday about the legal troubles of a prominent Democratic fund-raiser and contributor to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign misidentified one of the writers. The article was by Mike McIntire and Leslie Wayne  not by Leslie Eaton, another Times reporter.

headline: Spare Times
text: ON THE STREET

headline: Brooklyn: Sentence Imposed for Norman
text: Former State Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., left, was returned to State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday from the Oneida Correctional Facility in Rome, N.Y., for imposition of another sentence of one to three years in prison, prosecutors said. That sentence had been stayed while Mr. Norman appealed a lower court decision, but was imposed after the appeal was denied, prosecutors said. Mr. Norman, who is now sentenced to serve three to nine years, has been imprisoned on two other charges since June. He was convicted in February of extorting money from judicial candidates.

headline: Got Arachnophobia? Here’s Your Worst Nightmare
text: WILLS POINT, Tex., Aug. 29 — Most spiders are solitary creatures. So the discovery of a vast web crawling with millions of spiders that is spreading across several acres of a North Texas park is causing a stir among scientists, and park visitors.

headline: One Dead and Two Wounded in Bronx Shooting
text: A former janitor enraged at losing his job opened fire with a pistol early yesterday at the Bronx housing complex where he lived and had once worked, killing his former supervisor and injuring two others, one critically, the police said.

headline: Trouble in Paradise? Call a Shaman, Hold the PlayStation
text: It would be nice to say that characters in kids’ animated television shows have only recently become pitchmen, but it’s a long tradition. Back in the mid-’60s you had Linus the Lionhearted, a mascot for the breakfast cereal Crispy Critters, with his own show on CBS (later on ABC), which also featured Sugar Bear, star of Sugar Crisp cereal. (Both characters were created by the Ed Graham ad agency.) In 1969 the Federal Trade Commission banned TV shows based on selling a sponsor’s product, and that was that.

headline: Portable Theater (Just Go With the Flow)
text: UNDER a full moon on Tuesday night, in a little-known corner of Staten Island, the Mabou Mines theater company was afloat, rehearsing its latest work. Jutting from Pier 7 1/2, a 90-foot barge, built up with several stories of scaffolding and filled with actors, musicians, costumes and props, bobbed gently in New York Harbor.

headline: Shiite’s Tale: How Gulf With Sunnis Widened
text: BAGHDAD, Aug. 30 — Shatha al-Musawi, a Shiite member of Parliament, first encountered the Sunni-Shiite divide on the day the Americans captured Saddam Hussein. Hearing the news with a close Sunni friend named Sahira, Ms. Musawi erupted like a child.

headline: Yankees Sweep Red Sox Behind Wang
text: The sweep last August was more emphatic. The Yankees won five games, not three, and they did it in Fenway Park, rampaging past a Boston Red Sox team that would not qualify for the postseason.

headline: Mortgage Firm Sells $500 Million in Stock
text: Thornburg Mortgage, a jumbo-mortgage specialist that was forced to stop making new loans, has sold $500 million of convertible preferred stock to raise cash.

headline: Yankee’s Pitches Get Red Sox’ Attention
text: Kevin Youkilis thought Joba Chamberlain’s first 98 mile-an-hour fastball over his head might have been accidental. But when Chamberlain followed that with an identical fastball again near his skull, it took Youkilis only a few tenths of a second to decide that Chamberlain was trying to drill him.

headline: Lessons in Apologies (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mussina Is Finally Dealing With Being Removed From the Rotation
text: Mike Mussina met with reporters yesterday and apologized for taking three days to discuss his removal from the Yankees’ rotation. In a way, though, his silence said enough.

headline: Protests Persist in Myanmar, Despite Arrests by Junta
text: BANGKOK, Aug. 30 — Linking arms for mutual support, grim in the face of plainclothes paramilitary gangs, small groups of protesters in Myanmar have staged street demonstrations for nearly two weeks in the most sustained defiance of the country’s ruling junta in a decade.

headline: Drug for Growth Disorder Approved
text: The Food and Drug Administration gave approval to a drug used to treat a rare condition that causes the body to produce too much growth hormone. The treatment, Somatuline Depot, will offer a new option for patients with acromegaly, which causes excess growth of the hands, feet and head. Ipsen SA, the Paris-based company that owns the drug in Europe, licensed American rights to the company Tercica, which is based in Brisbane, Calif., in November.

headline: In the Decade Since
text: Has it been 10 years already since Diana died? So it seems, and the best evidence isn’t the calendar. It’s the photographs of Diana, Princess of Wales, staring out at us from the newsstands and the Web and the television. They remind us how distant the near-past can seem, how sensitive we are to the nuances of the present.

headline: More Realism, Less Spin
text: A new report from Congress’s investigative arm provides a powerful fresh dose of nonpartisan realism about Iraq as President Bush tries to spin people into thinking that significant — or at least sufficient — progress is being made. With a crucial debate on Iraq set for next month, the report should be read by members of Congress who may be wavering in the fight with the White House over withdrawing American troops.

headline: Movies
text: MOVIES

headline: Musharraf’s Aides Deny a Deal With Bhutto
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 30 — Pakistani government officials denied Thursday that the country’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, had agreed to resign as army chief before presidential elections, contradicting statements a day earlier by Benazir Bhutto, an exiled former prime minister.

headline: 2 More U.S. Priests Align With African Anglicans
text: Deepening the disarray in the Anglican Communion over homosexuality, the archbishop of Kenya, Benjamin Nzimbi, consecrated two American priests as bishops of the Anglican Church of Kenya to serve disaffected Episcopalians in the United States. The new bishops, William Murdoch of Massachusetts, at right in photo, and Bill Atwood of Texas, left, will minister to Americans who have grown alienated from the Episcopal Church, the American branch of Anglicanism, which takes a liberal stance on homosexuality. The consecration at All Saints Cathedral in Nairobi followed similar consecrations of Americans by the archbishops of Nigeria and Rwanda. But those consecrations across regional boundaries have not been officially recognized by the archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, spiritual leader of the worldwide communion of 77 million members.

headline: Marketing Sprint Begins When the Race for the Gold Ends
text: OSAKA, Japan, Friday, Aug. 31 — When Tyson Gay hits full speed on the track, his face tells the story.

headline: A Festival Rooted in Female Ingenuity
text: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass. — In 1927 a wealthy New Englander who went by the sturdy name of Mabel Choate set out to preserve a building that housed a neglected 39-year-old social club in the central Berkshires, the Stockbridge Casino. Designed by Stanford White, the building had been described by The Pittsfield Sun in 1888 as the area’s first “symptom of dissipation and gaiety.”

headline: So Far, Few Surprises at the Open
text: Andy Roddick, a former United States Open champion, and Donald Young, an 18-year-old junior whose game is catching up to the hype that has surrounded him, each caught a break Thursday at the United States Open when their opponents could not finish their second-round matches.

headline: For McEnroe, Mellowing From Superbratty to Cuddly
text: John McEnroe will always be trailed by his youthful image as the spoiled superbrat in need of long-term therapy. But that’s O.K., it really is, he said, because he is capitalizing on tantrums of yore in films (“Mr. Deeds” and “Anger Management”), on TV (“CSI: NY” and “30 Rock”) and in a new American Express commercial in which he apologizes to a fictional chair umpire, hugs him and says, “You’re not evil!”

headline: John Who? Isner Stands Out in a Crowd in More Ways Than One
text: Dan Magill’s telephone rang Wednesday morning. When he answered it the voice on the other end of the line said, “Hey, Coach, it’s John.”

headline: Virginia Tech President Stands by Actions
text: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 30 — A day after a scathing state report criticized Virginia Tech’s handling of the shooting massacre in April, Charles W. Steger, the university president, defended his administration’s actions Thursday and said he had no plans to resign.

headline: Governor Commutes Sentence in Texas
text: HOUSTON, Aug. 30 — Hours before his scheduled execution as a disputed accomplice in a 1996 murder, Kenneth Foster won a rare commutation to life in prison on Thursday after Gov. Rick Perry followed the recommendation of the Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles and granted a death row reprieve.

headline: Taliban Free Remaining 7 Koreans Held Captive
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 30  The Taliban freed the seven remaining South Korean hostages in central Afghanistan on Thursday, Afghan officials announced, ending a six-week hostage crisis that had placed enormous political pressure on the South Korean government.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10 P.M. (CMT) CROSS COUNTRY His first gigs were in the hardscrabble honky-tonks and dance halls of Texas. But these days his singles consistently reach the Top 10 of the country-music charts, including last summer’s No. 1 hit “Wherever You Are.” She arrived on the scene as a finalist in the 2003 edition of “Nashville Star.” Now she’s a two-time Country Music Association Horizon Award nominee. In this special those two, Jack Ingram and Miranda Lambert, above, share songs, stories and their love for all things country. They also pay tribute to their Texas roots with a cover of Waylon Jennings’s “Are You Sure Hank Done It This Way.”

headline: Environmental Agency Calls for Sealing of Damaged Tower
text: The federal Environmental Protection Agency has told the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation that it wants the fire-damaged former Deutsche Bank building at 130 Liberty Street to be sealed up soon “to protect public health and the environment.”

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Letter to the Editor
text: To the Editor: I know this is vacation season, and I hate to be a killjoy, but I feel compelled to respond to your article “Wakesurfing: Following the Boat Without a Rope” (Aug. 17).

headline: Go West, Old Man
text: Every year we go to the beach, and every year it becomes more obvious that beach vacations are a metaphor for the human predicament. For while in his soul the contemporary man seeks to realize the loftiness of his essential nature, in actual life he finds himself whacking a ball against the windmill arm in an eternal game of mini-golf.

headline: From the Netherlands, With Attitude
text: NORTH ADAMS., Mass. — The Dutch painter and video artist Erik van Lieshout may not be the world’s biggest kvetch, but he could be a runner-up. In three up-close-and-personal videos at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, “Part 1,” “Part 2” and “Up!” (as well as a short fourth, “Lariam,” that is much more focused), Mr. van Lieshout whines, cries and wallows in hypochondria, parading his boorish self-obsession before his mother, his shrink and his editor friend Core, whom he taunts and bullies.

headline: Abandoned at the Border
text: FOR more than a year, men and women in our armed forces have been urging the United States to bring to safety the Iraqi translators and others who have worked beside them and are now the victims of retaliation. A Marine captain, Zachary Iscol, said he owed his life and the lives of his men to his Iraqi translator. “Just coming to work was an act of heroism and courage on his part,” Captain Iscol said.

headline: Barclays Helps Rescue Debt Fund
text: LONDON, Aug. 31  Barclays, the British bank forced earlier this week to deny reports of exposure to troubled debt products, said on Friday that it helped rescue a $1.6 billion debt fund at a London-based asset management firm.

headline: History Repeats as Yankees Sweep Red Sox
text: The sweep was more emphatic last August, when the Yankees rampaged into Fenway Park and won five games to bury the Boston Red Sox. The best the Yankees could do this time was to win three at Yankee Stadium and chisel a chunk from Boston’s sizable lead in the American League East.

headline: I.B.M. Researchers Advancing Computer Processing Ability
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 — Researchers at I.B.M. laboratories say they have made progress toward storing information and computing at the level of individual atoms.

headline: The Face That Greeted Residents as They Greeted Their Day
text: At Co-op City, the massive apartment complex in the Bronx, Audley Bent was the smiling face that greeted people every morning as they left their homes for work. As a supervising porter, he was the dapper man who knew their grandsons’ names, the guy in the tie who complimented them on their lipstick or their shirts.

headline: Mexico: Police Find Small Bomb at Skyscraper
text: About 10,800 people were evacuated from the 55-story Torre Mayor in Mexico City, after an anonymous caller warned the skyscraper’s management of a bomb. The police said they had found a small explosive device in a car on one of the parking levels of the office tower. They said the device was too small to have caused significant damage. The city’s public security secretary, Joel Ortega, said it was not known who had planted the device.

headline: Use of Bundlers Raises New Risks for Campaigns
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 — In amassing $52 million in campaign contributions in the first half of this year, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton relied on a platinum pyramid of 233 “Hillraisers,” including the movie director Steven Spielberg, the party powerbroker Vernon E. Jordan Jr., and the real estate mogul William C. Rudin.

headline: Manhattan: Body Found in Times Square Hotel
text: The body of a woman was found under a bed in the Carter Hotel in Times Square yesterday, with her head and legs covered in plastic, the police said. The victim, who was described by the police as in her 20s but whose name was not released pending family notification, was discovered shortly before 2:30 p.m. in a sixth-floor room of the hotel on West 43rd Street. The medical examiner will determine the exact cause of death, the police said.

headline: A Designer Handbag Amid the Briefcases on the Tax Beat
text: Lee Sheppard, who was wearing her standard black and sporting punky streaked blonde hair, strolled into a recent tax conference at Columbia University in Manhattan and waded through a sea of tailored suits.

headline: Burning Questions After a Blaze
text: THE tragedy of the fire at the Deutsche Bank building in lower Manhattan will not be alleviated by an arbitrary transfer and public humiliation of three good fire officers who were not even at the scene. If Deputy Chief Richard Fuerch, Battalion Chief John McDonald and Capt. Peter Bosco did something wrong, they should be tried in a court of law and given the same rights as all other people in our country. A sudden and unexpected transfer is a burdensome and embarrassing upheaval for a family. It is a department discipline tool that has no recourse and no court of appeals.

headline: From a Single Plant, a World-Class Garden Grows
text: BARBARA PACKER is no dabbler. Exhibit A: The Climbery, her seven-acre clematis garden at the weekend retreat she shares with her husband, Ira Weinstein, near Livingston, N.Y., in Columbia County. With 600 varieties and 6,000 vines, it’s the largest private clematis collection in the world, according to the International Clematis Society. Ms. Packer takes her garden’s ranking in stride. Formerly a lawyer specializing in cases involving exposure to toxic substances, she is used to focusing her considerable energies and achieving results.

headline: Theater Listings
text: THEATER

headline: Tennis Fans Find Excuses to Flee the Office for Flushing Meadows
text: It takes a special kind of tennis fan to appreciate Fabrice Santoro, and a more special fan still to play hooky from work in order to see him play. Mr. Santoro, a 34-year-old journeyman on the pro tour, is currently the 44th-best player in the world, according to the Association of Tennis Professionals computer ranking. He has an inelegant, open-toed style of play, with two-handed slicing ground strokes off both sides.

headline: Syria Says It Will Require Visas for Some Iraqi Refugees
text: BAGHDAD, Friday, Aug. 31  Syria informed the Iraqi government on Thursday that it would start requiring visas for some Iraqis next month, Iraq’s Foreign Ministry said, a step that would reduce access to the last remaining haven for fleeing Iraqis.

headline: Gross-Out Fanfares for the Common Man
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It’s a crystal clear afternoon here, and for once — just once — Mike Rowe is clean.

headline: Bank in Germany Posts Loss Because of Bad Stock Trades
text: PARIS, Aug. 30  WestLB, the troubled German state-run bank, said Thursday that it had lost more than $820 million on speculative trades in global stock markets in the first half of 2007  pushing it into a net loss for the period and renewing pressure for it to find a merger partner.

headline: Confronting Syphilis, Quite Candidly
text: IT’S like this.

headline: President of Standard & Poor’s Steps Down
text: Kathleen Corbet, president of the credit rating company Standard & Poor’s, resigned after lawmakers and investors criticized the company for failing to judge the risks of securities backed by subprime mortgages.

headline: Benjamin Aaron, an Expert in Labor Law, Dies at 91
text: Benjamin Aaron, a scholar of labor law and a member of presidential commissions who throughout his career promoted increased democracy in the workplace and protection for workers not represented by unions, died Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 91 and lived in Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Candor With Patients (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Martha’s Vineyard B&B&D (Dinner)
text: MARTHA'S VINEYARD is one of the few American destinations without a regional bed-and-breakfast inn association, which tells you something right off: This is an island of independent-minded New Englanders.

headline: Roddick Receives a Gift on His 25th Birthday
text: Andy Roddick’s racket flashed three times in the sun as he lunged for each volley José Acasuso drilled at him with increasing ferocity until Acasuso could only capitulate.

headline: Judge Won’t Order Tightening of Limits on Campaign Donors
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) — The Federal Election Commission can continue to regulate independent political groups case by case and does not need to adopt new rules to govern them, a federal judge said Thursday.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Inquiry Into Police Opens Old Wounds in Yonkers
text: YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 30  When Mayor Philip A. Amicone joined community leaders here in April to announce a settlement to decades-long litigation over housing segregation, it seemed as if this city might finally begin to shed the reputation for racial discord that had helped define it for generations.

headline: 2 Boston Firefighters Die in Restaurant Blaze
text: BOSTON, Aug. 30 — Two Boston firefighters were killed and 11 others were injured battling a blaze that appeared to start in a grease-caked ventilation shaft at a Chinese restaurant on Wednesday night, officials said Thursday. They were the first Boston firefighters to die in the line of duty since 1994.

headline: The Jets Win in a Rough Final Audition
text: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30  Those who like offensive football had to wait until the fourth quarter to enjoy the Jets’ 13-11 preseason victory over the Philadelphia Eagles on Thursday night.

headline: New Worries for Small Banks
text: For America’s small banks, the changing financial landscape of the last decade meant that many opportunities were no longer available. The big national banks went after consumer lending and came to dominate the market for credit cards. Lending to big companies had long since migrated away from local banks.

headline: Tony Snow to Step Down in September
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 — Tony Snow, whose face became familiar to millions of television viewers as well as the Washington press corps in his two years as chief White House spokesman, plans to leave his post on Sept. 14.

headline: Sarkozy Urges French to Play ‘the Game of Globalization’
text: PARIS, Aug. 30  In a country that has long resisted globalization, President Nicolas Sarkozy bluntly told France on Thursday to stop kidding itself and face up to it  but in a French way.

headline: Suit Filed Over Security Steps at NASA Facility
text: Twenty-eight scientists, engineers and other workers at one of NASA’s top research centers filed suit in federal court yesterday challenging new security measures, including questions about loyalty and sexual orientation, that they say violate their constitutional rights.

headline: N.Y.U. Plans a Branch in Abu Dhabi, Officials Say
text: New York University is planning to announce next month that it will open a full-fledged branch campus in Abu Dhabi, to be paid for by the Abu Dhabi government, according to officials close to negotiations that have stretched over more than a year.

headline: Shape of Pivotal Senate Race Hinges on Warner Decision
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 — Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, one of the Republican Party’s most influential figures on military issues and an increasingly critical voice on the course of the war in Iraq, will announce Friday whether he will run for re-election next year or, as many expect, retire.

headline: Carrefour, French Retail Giant, to Sell 20% of Its Property Unit
text: LONDON, Aug. 30  Carrefour, the French supermarket chain and the world’s second-biggest retailer, said Thursday that it planned to sell part of its real estate portfolio in an initial public offering, bowing to pressure from investors including the French billionaire Bernard Arnault.

headline: In Need of Relief, the Mets Find None
text: Philadelphia

headline: A Museum Shows How It Played Catch-Up
text: The fabled conservatism of the National Academy, longtime home of the retrograde and anachronistic in art, has faded over the years as this venerable institution has increasingly sought to attract new, younger members and audiences.

headline: Art Listings
text: ART

headline: Microsoft Settles a Dispute Over a Feature in Its Browser
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (Bloomberg News) — Microsoft said Thursday that it had settled an eight-year patent dispute that resulted in a $521 million jury verdict against it. Terms of the accord were not disclosed.

headline: Building a Modern Arsenal in India
text: NEW DELHI, Aug. 30 — India is developing a military appetite to match its growing economic power.

headline: Gay Secures Sprint Double With a Record Run
text: OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 30 — For anyone who watched Tyson Gay win the 100 meters in spectacular fashion at these track and field world championships, it seemed quite clear by the end of the curve what was going to happen in the 200.

headline: In Response to a Rider Survey, More Trains on the 7 Line
text: Is it worth getting up 20 minutes earlier if it means your train to work will be less crowded?

headline: Near the Big Game
text: WHO Rita Bass, 57, a former state employee, and her husband, Ray, 70, a retired assistant school superintendent, from Clarkesville, Ga. WHAT 1-bedroom condominium WHERE Athens, Ga.

headline: Aura of the Big Time and the Result to Go Along With It
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Aug. 30 — The black strips under Tiquan Underwood’s eyes said in neat silver writing exactly what he was feeling after Thursday night’s game: “I’m Back.”

headline: Democratic Donor Turns Himself In
text: After defying an arrest warrant since 1992, a valued and reliable rainmaker for the Democratic Party surrendered today at a California court to face a grand theft charge, according to wire reports.

headline: Luring, and Keeping, Good Teachers (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mirza Focusing on Success, Not Appearance
text: When Sania Mirza became the first woman from India to advance as far as the fourth round of a Grand Slam tournament  at the 2005 United States Open  she felt the glory and the sting of her instant success.

headline: Republicans Say Senator Will Resign Over Sex Sting
text: Senator Larry E. Craig, Republican of Idaho, plans to resign his seat on Saturday after Republican leaders put intense pressure on him to leave in the aftermath of an undercover sex sting, Republican Party officials said Friday.

headline: 20/20 Hindsight Through What Were Once Rose-Colored Glasses
text: GOLDMAN SACHS has an exercise that it periodically does with its employees. It asks them what the bank, and the industry, is doing that, in hindsight, will look stupid (they probably don’t phrase it as such, but that is what they mean).

headline: Cancer Society Focuses Its Ads on the Uninsured
text: ATLANTA, Aug. 30 — In a stark departure from past practice, the American Cancer Society plans to devote its entire $15 million advertising budget this year not to smoking cessation or colorectal screening but to the consequences of inadequate health coverage.

headline: Thompson to Announce Bid for G.O.P. Nomination
text: Fred D. Thompson will formally announce his bid for the Republican nomination for president next Thursday, starting with a Webcast and followed by a five-day swing through the early voting states, his campaign said today.

headline: Bernanke Says Fed Is Prepared to Act
text: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Aug. 31 — Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, declared on Friday that the central bank “stands ready to take additional actions as needed” to prevent the chaos in mortgage markets from derailing the broader economy.

headline: In Vietnam: Stars and Stripes, and Innocence Undone
text: Denis Johnson’s wildly ambitious new novel, “Tree of Smoke,” reads like a whacked-out, hallucinogenic variation on such whacked-out, hallucinogenic Vietnam classics as Francis Ford Coppola’s “Apocalypse Now,” Michael Herr’s “Dispatches,” Robert Stone’s “Dog Soldiers” and Stephen Wright’s “Meditations in Green.” It features a central character who comes to see himself as a combination of the Quiet American and the Ugly American, and another who comes across as a latter-day version of Kurtz in Conrad’s “Heart of Darkness.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Wednesday about a wildfire near Ketchum, Idaho, misstated the date the fire started. It was set by a lightning strike on Aug. 16, not last Friday.

headline: Thai Censors Lift YouTube Ban
text: BANGKOK, Aug. 31 — Thai censors lifted their ban of YouTube today after five months of blocking the online video site because it had carried material seen as insulting to the country’s highly venerated king.

headline: Katrina All the Time
text: Two years ago today, Americans watched in horror as a great city drowned, and wondered what had happened to their country. Where was FEMA? Where was the National Guard? Why wasn’t the government of the world’s richest, most powerful nation coming to the aid of its own citizens?

headline: Fears of Mob Feud Lead to Arrest of 32 in Italy
text: ROME, Aug. 30  The Italian police carried out a major raid on Thursday, arresting 32 people, in part to stop a deadly feud between warring crime families. The arrests were linked to the fatal shooting of six men outside a pizzeria in Germany this month.

headline: U.S. Says Company Bribed Officers for Work in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 — An American-owned company operating from Kuwait paid hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes to American contracting officers in efforts to win more than $11 million in contracts, the government says in court documents.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: A Latino Biennial That Bucks a Global Trend
text: This age of international art biennials has produced a class of continent-hopping artists identified less by nationality and ethnicity than by an allegiance to issues raised by globalization — or, as the art world likes to call it, “globalism.” (An exception is the Venice Biennale, founded about the same time as the modern Olympics and following a similar protocol, with nations selecting those they consider their strongest artists to represent them.)

headline: Chemical From Iraq Discovered at U.N.
text: No unconventional weapons were found in Iraq after the United States-led invasion in 2003. But a potentially deadly chemical agent produced by Saddam Hussein’s regime has turned up, improbably, in an office at the United Nations in New York, and it had the F.B.I. and the city police scrambling yesterday.

headline: Chamberlain Draws Boston’s Attention
text: Kevin Youkilis thought Joba Chamberlain’s first 98 mile-an-hour fastball over his head might have been accidental. But when Chamberlain followed that with an identical fastball again near his skull, it took Youkilis only a few tenths of a second to decide that Chamberlain was trying to drill him.

headline: For the Record
text: Tuesday’s editorial about “South Park” should have said the television show is in its 11th season, not its 12th.

headline: Outdoor Funeral for a Protester of a Church Closing
text: Carmen Gonzalez, of East Harlem, died at 72 on Monday. She had regularly attended Mass at Our Lady Queen of Angels, a Roman Catholic parish on 113th Street in East Harlem, for years. When the church closed in February as part of a round of parish closings ordered by the Archdiocese of New York, Mrs. Gonzalez was devastated. She joined a small but fervent group of protesters who urged the archdiocese to reconsider.

headline: Mets Ask Wagner to Get Six Outs, but He Records Only Four
text: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 — Billy Wagner was sitting on a beige couch with an ice pack resting on his left shoulder and a towel on his right. His eyes blinked every few seconds but his head, propped up by a hand, did not move. In the stunned silence produced by a bad inning, a tough game and a forgettable series, Wagner just stared directly ahead, alone with his thoughts after experiencing all three.

headline: Assessing the Wounds of an Ancient Assyrian Ruler
text: Archaeologists are all abuzz about some enormous, newly reinstalled ninth-century B.C. Assyrian sculptures at the Bowdoin College Museum of Art in Brunswick, Me. They say they can’t wait until it reopens on Oct. 14, after a two-year, $20 million renovation and expansion, to see what curators discovered when they remounted five ancient bas reliefs from a royal compound at Nimrud in northern Iraq.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a subheading yesterday with a report by The Associated Press in some copies of the baseball roundup reversed the score of the game between Detroit and Kansas City. The Royals  not the Tigers  won 5-0.

headline: Senator Warner Will Not Seek Re-election
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 — Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, one of the Republican Party’s most influential figures on military issues and an increasingly critical voice on the course of the war in Iraq, announced today that he will not run for re-election next year.

headline: Before the Summer Buzz Fades Away
text: Film: Humor for the Culture Wars

headline: Panel Will Urge Broad Overhaul of Iraqi Police
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 — An independent commission established by Congress to assess Iraq’s security forces will recommend remaking the 26,000-member national police force to purge it of corrupt officers and Shiite militants suspected of complicity in sectarian killings, administration and military officials said Thursday.

headline: Malta: Another Tragedy at Sea
text: Twenty-five migrants were feared dead in the waters south of Malta after their boat capsized as a Greek tug neared to rescue them. Maltese officials said just three people were plucked from the water after the migrants all moved to one side of their boat waiting for the tug. There was no word on where they had come from. While the number of often-deadly crossings from Africa to Europe is down this summer, the pace of boats arriving in Malta and Italy has picked up in recent weeks.

headline: Somber and Soulful World Fusion Meets Dance Club
text: Smoke machine, strobe lights and ... sitar? That was the combination at the Highline Ballroom on Wednesday night. Anoushka Shankar, Ravi Shankar’s daughter and musical disciple, and Karsh Kale, a tabla drummer who is also an electronica producer and programmer, have collaborated on an album, “Breathing Underwater” (Manhattan), and their band headlined a triple bill of world-music fusions to commemorate the 15th anniversary of Global Rhythm magazine. The transcontinental bill also included the South African trumpeter Hugh Masekela and the Guadeloupean New York saxophonist Jacques Schwarz-Bart.

headline: Only the Prices of Tickets Are in Regular-Season Form
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Aug. 30 — The empty seats at Gillette Stadium nearly outnumbered the occupied ones for the preseason game between the New England Patriots and the Giants on Thursday night. The $5 game program featured Patriots quarterback Tom Brady on the cover, yet he and every other first-string teammate did not play for fear that they could get hurt. The Giants trotted out their usual starters, then reeled most to the sideline before the end of the first quarter.

headline: Tape Shows a Senator Protesting After Arrest
text: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 30 — In the moments after Senator Larry E. Craig was arrested in an airport men’s room, he accused an undercover police sergeant of entrapping him, emphasized that he did not want to go to court or to jail and frequently said, “I don’t recall,” when asked about his reported sexual advances to the officer.

headline: Can-Do for New Orleans (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: China Replaces Key Ministers
text: BEIJING, Aug. 30 — The Chinese government replaced its finance minister on Thursday and appointed four other ministers in a reshuffling that foreshadows bigger personnel changes on the horizon as the Communist Party prepares for a pivotal political gathering in October.

headline: Bush Plans Steps to Help Troubled Borrowers
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 — President Bush, in his first response to low-income families hit by the subprime mortgage crisis, plans to announce several steps Friday aimed at helping Americans with credit difficulties to meet the rising cost of their housing loans, administration officials said Thursday.

headline: Justice Dept. Inquiry Focuses on Gonzales’s Claims
text: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 — The Justice Department’s internal watchdog disclosed Thursday that he was investigating whether sworn statements to Congress by Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales were “intentionally false, misleading or inappropriate.”

headline: The Tide Is Still Going Out
text: A chestnut from the investor Warren Buffett — “you only find out who is swimming naked when the tide goes out” — has been quoted a lot lately as investors learn more about excessive risk-taking by lenders, bankers, hedge funds and other investors.

headline: Iraq's Search for Reconciliation
text: Shatha al-Musawi, a Shiite lawmaker, is struggling to move past her difficult history in order to help Iraq move forward.

headline: Vacation Time
text: An article in today’s New York Times says that I.B.M. has stopped keeping track of its employees’ vacation time. Instead, for the past few years, employees at all levels have made informal arrangements with their direct supervisors, guided mainly by their ability to get their work done on time.

headline: Blake Finally Wins in Five
text: The business trip you still need to expense. The online profile you regret having written. Untreated acne on your back. Your somewhat scattered beauty-pageant explanation for American deficiencies in geography. We all wish we could sweep certain issues behind us and move on. For James Blake, it’s five-set matches.

headline: Hong Kong Art, Part 2: The Mall
text: There was a showdown in 2004, when both the Paris-based Centre Pompidou and the U.S.-based Guggenheim were vying for favor here and brought out top works for exhibition – their eyes firmly on a bid to open a branch in Hong Kong’s planned West Kowloon cultural district. (Neither succeeded, but that’s for another blog.)

headline: Ultimate Fighting Championship
text: Images from the event in Las Vegas.

headline: The Perfect Getaway
text: Images from Doug Lloyd's house on Long Island's East End.

headline: Vehicles by International Harvester
text: An S.U.V. pioneer that left before the party began.

headline: Where to Mingle with Stars (and Eat) in Berlin
text: by Andreas Tzortzis

headline: Sarkozy Favors a Utility Merger
text: President Nicolas Sarkozy said he favored a merger of Gaz de France and the energy operations of Suez, implying Suez would have to shed its waste and water units to complete the long-pending deal.

headline: Chinese Antimonopoly Law Approved
text: After 13 years of reviewing drafts, the National People’s Congress approved a law that bans price-fixing, collusion, excessive market concentration and other monopolistic practices by private and state-owned businesses alike.

headline: Judge Rejects Bankruptcy for 2 Bear Stearns Hedge Funds
text: Bear Stearns hit a wall in its efforts to shield two hedge funds seeking bankruptcy protection from investor claims by arguing that they are based in the Cayman Islands.

headline: As Losses Mount, WestLB Under Pressure to Merge
text: WestLB, the troubled German state-run bank, said Thursday that it had lost more than $820 million on speculative trades in global stock markets in the first half of 2007 – pushing it into a net loss for the period and renewing pressure for it to find a merger partner.

headline: Thornburg Mortgage Sells $500 Million in Stock
text: Thornburg Mortgage, a jumbo-mortgage specialist that was forced to stop making new loans, has sold $500 million of convertible preferred stock to raise cash.

headline: President of S&P Steps Down Amid Criticism
text: Kathleen Corbet, president of the credit rating company Standard & Poor’s, resigned after lawmakers and investors criticized the company for failing to judge the risks of securities backed by subprime mortgages.

headline: Sentinel Gets Court’s Okay to Pay Some Bills
text: Sentinel Management Group, a cash-management firm that recently filed for bankruptcy protection, won court permission to pay payroll, rent, utilities and insurance expenses in an amount up to $97,500.

headline: Another chess vs. F1 analogy, this time for Ferrari vs. McLaren
text: Regular readers of this blog will know that I like chess as well as F1, and often like to make comparisons between the two. (I’m a garbage chess player, with little knowledge of any openings – but these days computer software allows uneducated players to find a game at any time, and to watch as spectators as the world’s best players confront one another, and software estimates for the viewer who is leading.)

headline: Reassessing Banks’ Hedge-Fund Love Affair
text: For The New York Times’ Jenny Anderson, the most “boneheaded thinking” to come out of the hedge fund and private equity mania was the one by a handful of investment banks to pay astronomical sums for stakes in hedge funds, volatile businesses that banks should understand quite well (it’s the same as their own, she notes).

headline: Reklaim Drives Off With $7 Million from Goldman Sachs
text: Reklaim Technologies, which hopes to create a profitable business around selling the byproducts of recycled tires, has secured $7 million in venture financing from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Reverses Position on TXU Buyout
text: Franklin Resources, the large TXU, the electric utility, shareholder that had opposed selling the power company, said Thursday it has changed its mind.

headline: They Know Her Name Now: Ahsha Rolle
text: If Ahsha Rolle wants to continue competing at this year’s Open, she’ll have to keep winning in singles. Rolle and her doubles partner, Angela Haynes, were crushed on Thursday by Vania King (an 18-year-old Californian who lost in the first round of singles but is still alive in doubles and mixed doubles) and Emilie Loit, 4-6, 1-6.

headline: Investors Said to Push Canadian Exchange Merger
text: Major shareholders in the TSX Group, the parent of the Toronto Stock Exchange, and its rival, the Montreal Exchange have mobilized to push for a merger between the companies, a deal the two exchanges have discussed but so far failed to reach.

headline: WCI Shareholders Elect Icahn to Board
text: Shareholders of WCI Communities, a struggling homebuilder, elected the billionaire Carl C. Icahn to the board on Thursday, more than four months after management rejected his $22-per-share takeover bid.

headline: Court Deals Blow to J&J Suit Over Guidant Sale
text: A federal court judge dealt a blow to Johnson & Johnson in its $5.5 billion lawsuit over the sale of Guidant to Boston Scientific, dismissing some claims and only allowing part of the case to proceed. The ruling, which was made public on Thursday, throws out the case against Abbott Laboratories but allows J&J to go ahead with its claim against Guidant for breach of contract.

headline: Deutsche Banks Closes London Trading Desk
text: Deutsche Bank has shut down its proprietary credit trading desk in London and up to seven employees have left the bank – including department head Gerry Jackson – as the credit crunch claimed yet more scalps Thursday. The remaining members of the team, believed to be about 15 strong, have been given other jobs in the bank, according to The Telegraph.

headline: A History of Dance
text: Images from the Joyce Theater.

headline: Russian Steel Magnate Buys Arsenal Stake
text: A Russian mining magnate, Alisher Usmanov, has acquired a stake in Arsenal, the British soccer club, from David Dein, the club’s former vice-chairman and a close ally of manager Arsene Wenger.

headline: Where Will Business Objects Strike Next?
text: Business Objects has long been bandied about as a potential takeover target. But the reality is that the company, which makes business-intelligence software, has been the one doing the buying in recent years.

headline: Convio Files for I.P.O.
text: Convio, which provides fundraising and advocacy software and services for nonprofit organizations, plans an initial public offering, according to a regulatory filing Thursday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Lone Star Halves Offer for Accredited
text: Lone Star Funds cut its takeover bid for Accredited Home Lenders, the subprime mortgage company, by 44 percent, to $214 million, after the company laid off 60 percent of its workers and stopped making new loans.

headline: WPP Invests in Backer of MySpace China
text: WPP has invested in a Chinese venture capital firm that is leading the introduction of MySpace in China, according to The Telegraph. The advertising giant has ploughed an undisclosed sum into China Broadband Capital Partners, a Beijing-based investor in the technology and media sectors.

headline: Barclays Borrows from Bank of England Again
text: Barclays, blaming a “technical breakdown” in Britain’s bank-clearing system, borrowed heavily from the Bank of England’s lending facility for the second time in two weeks. Separately, Barclays also said it would take part in a rescue of a $1.6 billion debt fund it helped create.

headline: Private Equity Cites Progress in Tax Fight
text: The head of the Private Equity Council, a private-equity lobbying group whose founding members include the Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, says the industry has made progress in its battle against proposed tax increases being considered in Congress.

headline: K.K.R. Battles Banks Over First Data Terms
text: As Labor Day looms, one of the biggest tests of whether anxious debt investors will get back into the market is hitting some road blocks. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is in talks with major Wall Street banks over the $24 billion in debt it needs to complete a deal for First Data, according to media reports.

headline: Morning Buzz: Bronx Shootings, Iraqi Chemical Agent, Scoppetta’s Defense and More
text: A workplace shooting in the Bronx is the talk of the New York newspapers this morning. Paulino Valenzuela, 44, a janitor who had been fired from his job at Co-op City and then lost a lawsuit to get his job back, returned to the building where he had worked, killing a former supervisor, Audley Bent, 59, and shooting and injuring a supervisor, Phillip Zudrima, and a janitor, Sander Palaj. Mr. Palaj was in critical condition. The Times’s coverage includes an overview by Cara Buckley and a profile of Mr. Bent, the slain victim, by Alan Feuer and Trymaine Lee.The New York Post calls the shooting a “Bronx rampage,” while The Daily News notes that Mr. Valenzuela seemed calm when he turned himself in at a Bronx criminal courthouse, saying, “I just killed somebody.”

headline: YouTube and the Censors: An Update
text: It’s hard to think of a good analogy for exactly what YouTube is becoming in modern society. It has attracted a critical mass of public attention in a way that predigital analogues like public-access cable television or the sign-encrusted kiosks of Paris or the proverbial Hyde Park Corner soap box never could — to the point that it now matters pretty strongly to people and businesses and governments what is said and shown there, and they are doing things about it.

headline: Financial Stocks Surge Ahead of Bush Speech
text: Goldman Sachs, Blackstone Group and Countrywide Financial were among the financial firms whose shares moved sharply higher Friday before the opening bell as investors eagerly awaited an announcement from President Bush about what steps the government would take to help Americans with their mortgages.

headline: Where Everybody Knows Your Team
text: So, here we are, the start of another college football season, and maybe, like myself and a few others here at The Quad, you’ve come to a few realizations.

headline: 2008: The Perils of Big Money Politics
text: For much of the week, we’ve been keeping track of the fallout from the news that a top contributor to Democratic candidates across the country, including Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, has a criminal record and is considered a fugitive in California.

headline: It’s Electric: the CityEl Trike
text: Looking like a prop from a campy science fiction movie – where everyone wears pastel-colored jumpsuits, and every computer looks like an 8-track player mated to a Lite Brite – the CityEl city car somehow can’t help but make you smile. At the very least, it will cause most people to grab their camera and start snapping photos. It certainly had that effect on me when I happened upon one on the streets of Copenhagen, Denmark.

headline: Friday Morning Kickoff
text: Louisiana State opened the season with a 45-0 rout of Mississippi State, but the Tigers did not impress Scott Rabalais of the Baton Rouge Advocate. Talk about a tough crowd.

headline: Heaven Is a Tailgate Spread
text: We have a guest blogger today at The Quad. Wright Thompson, a senior writer for ESPN.com and ESPN The Magazine, tells us that it’s not just the football that makes college football Saturdays in the South transcendent. It’s the pre- and postgame tailgate spreads.

headline: Poll: Most New Yorkers Bleed Yankee Blue
text: Normally, the Quinnipiac University polls focus on politics and public policy. Perhaps to mark the end of summer, the university’s latest poll — of 1,461 New York City residents, surveyed from Aug. 21 to 27 — included a smaller sample of 729 baseball fans who were asked about America’s pastime.

headline: Fed Chief Gives No Hint of Imminent Rate Cut
text: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the central bank "stands ready to take additional actions as needed" to limit the effect of the recent financial market disorder on the economy as a whole, but he gave no hint that an interest rate cut was on the horizon.

headline: The ‘He Never Proposed’ Defense
text: Conservatives have begun making a few limited defenses of Sen. Larry Craig of Idaho. Writing at The Corner, National Review’s staff blog, Jonah Goldberg says “Craig’s (alleged) behavior is terrible” but not hypocritical, despite the senator’s voting record on gay marriage and other issues. Goldberg writes:

headline: Burning Man Suspect Merrily Faces Felony Charge
text: First we heard the news about the guy arrested for burning the Man way before the appointed time at the Burning Man festival. Then we saw his mug shot. And now Paul Addis has emerged in his full glory, delivering a superbly cuckoo performance during an interview with Wired magazine.

headline: Fitting Sept. 11 Into History
text: With the passage of time, it is natural that once indelible dates lose their power.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Road Trip Wrap-Up
text: Now that Matt has returned from his twelve-week excursion across the country, we’d like to know what’s been your favorite road trip?

headline: Clinton’s Top 10 Campaign Promises
text: Senator Hillary Rodham appeared on “The Late Show” with David Letterman last night and read a funny Top 10 list of campaign promises. “This is newsmaking,” Mrs. Clinton joked. “I haven’t done this anywhere else.”

headline: Learning the Downside of Derivatives, the Hard Way
text: Here is a question for Wall Street to ponder over the long weekend: Has the spreading out of market risk — a defining feature of the new age of financial engineering — actually increased it as well?

headline: It’s Crash, Bang, Smash ’Em Up at the County Fair
text: The Columbia County Fair in Chatham, N.Y., is pretty typical fare for a summer county fair. There are farm animal competitions, amusement park rides and vendors. There are also pig races and pig high-diving, and the highlight event comes Saturday night at the grandstand when Kevin Bacon and his brother are performing with their band.

headline: Remembering Diana
text: The service marking the 10th anniversary of the death of Diana, the Princess of Wales, was simple and poignant.

headline: A Grown-up City (Paris)…for Kids
text: By Nicola Clark

headline: Wakiya:  An Aloofness that’s Honest
text: At first I was put off by what would happen — by what I would be told — every time I called the new restaurant Wakiya for a reservation.

headline: In China, a Bull Market for Bankers
text: If you know what “Ni hao” and “Ebitda” mean, you may be well on your way to landing an investment banking job.

headline: QuickBits: End of Summer Edition
text: A few conversation starters for while you are traveling, or, if your social skills are like mine, socializing over the long weekend:

headline: Tony Snow Resigns
text: This just in. As Tony Snow, the White House press secretary had indicated earlier, he has decided to resign his post with the Bush administration, effective Sept. 14.

headline: For Rutgers, Rice Makes Everything Easier
text: After Rutgers’s 38-3 win over Buffalo last night, the Scarlet Knights still had three juniors on pace for Heisman Trophy-winning statistics. But don’t be fooled.

headline: The Down Low Talk Show
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: She Kissed Us Last Thing At Night
text: Rupert Murdoch’s johnny-on-the-spot Sky News has a succinct and handy video site that provides British tabloid and other news.

headline: Slide Show: Summer Is Nearing an End on Governors Island
text: Going to Governors Island (where you’d soak in the history and admire the houses of Colonels’ Row, above)? You’d better hurry …

headline: A Pre-Holiday Present for the Credit Markets
text: As Wall Street prepares to head out for Labor Day weekend, some good news for the credit markets may send bankers out with more spring in their step.

headline: Analyst Sees More Leeway for Bookstore Merger
text: What does organic broccoli have to do with Harry Potter?

headline: Marquee Matchups
text: Here are some games to keep your eye on during college football’s opening weekend. A special thank you to Awful Announcing for keeping track of all the announcing teams in college football. Amazing work by them.

headline: Wake Up America! Alien Cow Abduction!
text: Has anybody heard from Elsie lately? We rest our case:

headline: Safina Defeats Rolle for a Shot at Henin
text: Ahsha Rolle only had the Grandstand crowd going for her today. When Rolle, an American wild card, served to even the first set at 5-5 against 15th-seeded Dinara Safina, an insanely loud, rhythmic pounding started from who knows where, maybe the Mets’ stadium construction. Every close line call went against her, including a serve that looked wide but was called good and gave Safina match point.

headline: Thrift Shops Join a New Social Movement
text: Liberty House, a boutique on the Upper West Side that sells crafts and imported clothing and jewelry, began its existence in the late 1960s as a chain of stores with locations around the city based on a simple concept: Volunteers would sell merchandise, like quilts produced by craft cooperatives in the South, and all the profits from those sales would be returned to the producers, benefiting causes like the civil rights movement.Most of the store’s branches closed in the 1970s, and those that remained converted to for-profit businesses — though they retained the social consciousness of the West Side home neighborhood where they put down roots.

headline: Having it Both Ways
text: Quotes from President Bush’s speech today:

headline: Trying to Read Between Bernanke’s Lines
text: Somebody cue up “Fugue for Tinhorns” on The Lede’s iPod. The air seems filled with confident, closely reasoned advice for bettors — um, make that investors — on what the Fed will be doing with its benchmark interest rates over the next few weeks and months ( “I’ve got the horse right here … ” ), and they don’t exactly agree with one another.

headline: China Beats Russia; England’s Got Next
text: The 10-player (per team), 10-round match between Russia and China ended in victory for China, 52.5 to 47.5. The match, which started Aug. 20 and ended yesterday, was played in Nizhniy Novgorod, Russia. The teams were composed of five men and five women from each country, with the men and women playing each of their counterparts twice.

headline: Senator Warner Announces Retirement
text: Senator John Warner, 80, just announced that he would retire from his seat in Virginia at the end of his term. The news throws into play what would have probably been a safe Senate seat for the Republicans had he decided to seek re-election.

headline: A Man. A Machine. A Cure?
text: Pier Francesco Parra walks around the United States Open grounds with a coach’s credential, but he is quick to say it is fake.

headline: Degeneres/Clinton’08?
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton: former first lady, United States senator, presidential candidate, prop comic.

headline: 30-Something
text: It’s not easy to find 30-somethings in the Open singles draws. At the beginning of play today, the men’s field was still dotted with six — Tim Henman, Andrei Pavel, Carlos Moya, Agustin Calleri, Thomas Johansson and Hyung-Taik Lee.

headline: Answers From the Co-op Board Expert, Part 3
text: Following is the third set of responses from Arthur Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer and vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, who took questions from City Room readers this week. The first and second sets of answers were posted earlier. (Update: A fourth set was posted on Sept. 4, and the final set of answers was posted on Sept. 6. Mr. Weinstein is no longer taking questions.)

headline: ‘That’s How Hot It Was’
text: Aired Thursday night

headline: Apple Bites Back
text: As The Times reported this morning, NBC decided not to sell its videos on Apple’s iTunes when their contract expires this December.

headline: ‘A Park Avenue Fundraiser Hosted by Leona Helmley’s Dog’
text: Aired Thursday nightBeautiful day, wasn’t it? Unbelievable – one of those perfect – crisp, a lot of sunshine. Here’s how lovely it was in New York City today: Senator Craig came out of the men’s room squinting.

headline: Closing the Book (by Opening Books) on Summer Rituals
text: When I see people immersed in a book in public, I always wonder what they’re reading. Sometimes, on the subway, I even move closer to sneak a peek at the title. Since I grew up reading in New York, I know, too, that the city itself can infuse the experience of a book. So when my editors asked for volunteers with ideas for our Summer Rituals series, I leaped at the chance to roam the city with my curiosity unleashed, hunting for readers to interview. My article, which ends the series, was put up on the Web today and will appear in Saturday’s paper.Jury duty did crimp my plans a bit. I had hoped to return to a garden at the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park, where I used to go sometimes as a teenager to find just the right reading atmosphere. (Mainly what I recall reading there is “The Lady’s Not for Burning,” a delightful play in verse by Christopher Fry that is set in 1400; it was a gloomy autumn day, though, and Gregorian chant was playing in the background.)

headline: ‘Hey, I Wasn’t Trying to Marry the Cop’
text: Aired Thursday night

headline: San Francisco’s Wi-Fi Fog
text: It’s been more than two years since San Francisco Mayor Gavin Newsom championed the idea of blanketing the city with wireless Internet access, available to all for free. After fits and starts and protracted negotiations, the plan appears to have fizzled, for now, derailed by a mix of city politics and business challenges.

headline: Looking the Baiji Sighting News in the Mouth
text: After spending years on nearly everyone’s list of noteworthy critically endangered species, the baiji, or Yangtze river dolphin, seemed finally to have slipped away last year when a thorough six-week search of the Yangtze river basin in China, the creature’s sole habitat, failed to turn up a single one in the wild. (Andy Revkin wrote about the development in The New York Times – TimesSelect subscription required.)

headline: Bomar’s Long Wait Ends in Victory
text: HUNTSVILLE, Texas, Aug. 30 — The only sign that the Sam Houston State junior quarterback Rhett Bomar hadn’t played a game in 20 months was that he needed an I.V. before and during Thursday night’s 17-13 victory over Angelo State.

headline: A Sister Wins, and Her Brother Goes Home
text: What Dinara Safina could do – win her second-round match at the Open on Friday – her older brother Marat Safin could not. Safina, seeded 15th, ousted Ahsha Rolle, the wild card from Miami Shore, Fla., 6-4, 6-3, using a break a set to end the best tournament result in Rolle’s young career.

headline: Wall Street’s Summer That Wasn’t
text: In the financial world, Labor Day often marks a return to the usual hectic pace of business after a spell of relative calm.

Blogtalk: The Pope Is No. 1, Clinton’s Top 10 List List, Trouble Speaks, and More

headline: An Infamous Turning Point
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his Aug. 31 column, “Katrina All the Time.”

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em
text: Who doesn’t love displaying their college football knowledge by predicting who’s going to win what each week (strictly for recreational purposes, obviously)? Well, we at The Quad are no different.

headline: I Go to the Beach, Therefore I Am
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s Aug. 31 column, “Go West, Old Man.”

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: Harry Hurt III satisfies his greed for speed on the auto racetrack.

headline: “My Attorney, Bernie” (or Why We Don’t Micromanage)
text: Lily, a frequent commenter on this blog, is not alone when she asks why we are staying “so far outside the loop” when it comes to the day-to-day construction of our dream home.

headline: Nobody Loses, But Djokovic Advances
text: Between acrobatic shots and trainer visits, Novak Djokovic of Serbia and Radek Stepanek of the Czech Republic played a classic match today on Armstrong Court, with the artistry of the third-seeded Djokovic being challenged by the guile of Stepanek for almost five hours.

headline: The Week in Comments: Zombies, Grunting, Metal Bats, Lottery Dreams, CBGB, and More
text: A look back at the week that was, in the words of our readers.

headline: When Nanotech Was Popping
text: Here at Bits we make an effort to keep you abreast of the latest significant developments in nanotechnology. But the Bits archives would be woefully incomplete without an occasional look back, especially when the subject is probably the single funniest commentary ever written about nanotech.

headline: Frugal Traveler: American Road Trip
text: Matt Gross returns home and looks back on his summer spent discovering America.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 31
text: Here is a slide show of 14 pictures by photographers for The Times that tell the story of the past week in the New York region. Subjects include the new Nat Sherman tobacco store on East 42nd Street, a psychedelic exhibit at the Whitney, teenage girls who rock and more.

headline: Jozy Altidore, School Days
text: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore will contribute items for The New York Times Goal blog dealing with his life, soccer and his dreams for the future. This is his third post.

headline: I’m On Fire
text: By Adam Himmelsbach

headline: Stops on the Road to 2008
text: Adam Nagourney looks at the upcoming milestones in the 2008 presidential election.

headline: How Conservatives and Gays Can Get Along
text: Writing at the blog of the Independent Gay Forum, Jonathan Rauch (the author of “Gay Marriage: Why It Is Good for Gays, Good for Straights, and Good for America”) links to an op-ed by Steve Lonegan, the Republican mayor of Bogota, N.J., that was published August 19 in The Record.

headline: Breaking News: Pedro Martinez Will Start…
text: After watching Pedro Martinez throw “the best we’ve seen him” in a bullpen session at Turner Field, General Manager Omar Minaya announced that Martinez would either start Monday in Cincinnati or for Class A Brooklyn. Reading between the lines, unless Martinez wakes up tomorrow morning with his arm rotting, he will return to where it all began for him in a Mets uniform, the Great American Ballpark, on April 4, 2005.

headline: Doubles Team Avoids Culture Clash
text: They are the new Odd Couple of tennis.

headline: The Story of a 'Previvor'
text: Upon learning her high risk for developing cancer, a healthy 33-year old Deborah Lindner considered preventive mastectomy.

headline: The Story of a 'Previvor'
text: Two weeks after her surgery, Deb kept a diary of her recovery.

headline: The Story of a 'Previvor'
text: The day after the surgery, Joan and Deb discuss their different thoughts about Deb's decision.

headline: The Story of a 'Previvor'
text: Dr. D.J. Winchester discusses Deb's challenging surgery.

headline: Dispatches from the War on the Drugs
text: I recommend a couple of articles chronicling the unintended consequences of the war on drugs. One, by Ethan Nadelmann, is a global look at the damage done by prohibitionist policies. The other, by Radley Balko, is a look at a doctor convicted for prescribing opioids — and this case is in some ways more troubling than the Hurwitz case that I’ve been writing about.

headline: Coughlin’s Comments
text: By Frank Litsky

headline: Fantasy Football Intervention
text: I’m hooked on the A&E show “Intervention.” If you haven’t seen it (and if not, you should start TiVO’ing it post haste) this is the premise: they follow an addict — usually coke/crack, heroin, crustal meth or alcohol — and chronicle the typical day-to-day life of addiction. The lying, the stealing, the manipulating of friends and loved ones. It can be depressing at times, but it’s as riveting as HBO’s “Flight of the Conchords” is hysterical (unlike “The Two Coreys,” which I had high hopes for, but is clearly scripted, totally unfunny, and Haim looks like he’s been riding life’s Tilt-a-Whirl for wayyyy too long.)
